column2: LONDON, Friday, June 26 -- British bombers struck "in force" at targets in Germany during the night, it was stated authoritatively today.

HONOLULU, June 25 -- The Battle of the Pacific has just begun. Two weeks after Midway, six months after the Japanese attack on Pearl Harbor, it is possible today to see only a long, bitter road lying ahead. The optimism that prevailed, I am told, even in official circles in Honolulu the first few days after June 4, 5 and 6 has largely evaporated.
BERLIN, June 25 (From German Broadcasts recorded by The Associated Press) -- The German High Command issued the following communique today:

WASHINGTON, June 25 (AP) -- The assignment of Major Gen. George E. Stratemeyer to be Chief of Staff of the Army Air Forces was announced today, along with several other transfers of Army general officers.

The Navy announced yesterday the sinking of two small anti-submarine patrol vessels off the Atlantic coast earlier this month with a loss of twenty lives. It also revealed the torpedoing of a medium-sized Norwegian vessel several hundred miles off the southeast coast. All thirty-one members of the crew of this ship escaped unharmed.

WASHINGTON, June 25 -- Despite pleas from officials of fair associations and criticism from some members of Congress, the Office of Defense Transportation stood firm today on its request for general postponement of State and county fairs until after the war.

PRINCETON, N.J., June 25 -- With nation-wide gasoline rationing a virtual certainty, Washington administrators have the problem of seeing to it that American workers get to their factories and business firms without difficulty.

SOUTH BEND, Ind., June 25 -- Harold Gjolme, a University of Washington junior, today burned up the Chain o'Lakes course with a 66 to hurdle into the semi-finals of the national intercollegiate golf tournament.

WASHINGTON, June 25 -- Lawyers and business men were warned by Attorney General Biddle today that they must register under the amended Foreign Agents Act, the administration of which will be transferred from the State Department to the Department of Justice at midnight on Monday.

There is little time for applying powder and lipstick these days at the Pan-American Airways marine base at La Guardia Field. A visit among the feminine members of the ground crew yesterday made this fact stand out in bold relief.

WASHINGTON, June 25 -- Secretary Morgenthau said at a press conference today that he had suggested to Representative Doughton that the 1942 income tax might be paid next year monthly. The chairman of the Ways and Means Committee had seemed to like the suggestion and said it could begin either Feb. 1 or March 15.

Reports reach us that city butchers are doing away with "week-end specials." The announcement conies by way of an informed representative of the Consumers' Service Bureau of the New York Department of Markets. Ceiling prices, this informant says, are maintaining pork, beef and veal at steady levels.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: I read in yesterday's edition of your paper the letters of President Williams of Lehigh University and of Professor Newhall of Williams College and I cannot refrain from answering them, as it seems to me they show a complete misunderstanding of the suggestion that United States history be made compulsory in the colleges of this nation.
Upper Fifth Avenue department stores and specialty shops last night joined the large group of retail concerns in the midtown area now remaining open Thursdays until 9 P.M.

Acting upon Mayor La Guardia's assurance that the Public Health Research Institute of the City of New York, Inc., was a non-profit enterprise under city control, the Board of Estimate voted 11 to 5 yesterday to enter into a contract under which the city would pay the institute $100,000 a year for ten years for its researches on public health.

ATLANTIC CITY, June 25 (AP) -- The head of the Maryland Bar Association charged today that the Supreme Court of the United States had "freed itself not only from, precedents but also from, the words of the statute" in order "to serve the purpose of the New Deal."
Mrs. Donald M. Nelson isn't on the War Production Board, but she has plenty of other things to keep her busy -- giving talks, keeping up with her cooking and her sculpturing.

BERNE, Switzerland, June 25 -- Implementing their announced intention of suppressing any vestiges of even spiritual revolt in Czechoslovakia, the leaders of the German Gestapo yesterday called in the Elite Guard and armed forces for the second time to mete out "righteous retribution" to an entire village.

Luck of Three Kings Peter II of Yugoslavia is one of several boy kings who constituted a pleasant feature of the foreign news in happier days a few years ago. As children and as monarchs they were perfect material for the human interest story.

BERNE, Switzerland, June 25 -- Implementing their announced intention of suppressing any vestiges of even spiritual revolt in Czechoslovakia, the leaders of the German Gestapo yesterday called in the Elite Guard and armed forces for the second time to mete out "righteous retribution" to an entire village.

Borough President James J. Burke of Queens lashed out yesterday at critics of his activity for the Navy Relief Fund after an afternoon newspaper had published a report that employes in his office received a day off in return for their purchase of tickets to Steeplechase Park in Coney Island.

Nothing could be more serious to the United States and the cause of the United Nations than the present course of the Battle of the Atlantic. The whole outcome of the war depends upon our ability to make our might felt in England, Europe, China and the Near East.

WASHINGTON, June 25 -- Motorists residing in areas where gasoline rationing is in force were urged today in an open letter signed by six leaders of the government to form Car-Sharing Clubs to assure themselves adequate transportation without putting such a strain on public transportation systems that the latter might become exposed to a serious breakdown.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: On June 20 you published a letter in which complaint was expressed over the difficulty encountered in making an appointment at the Manhattan Blood Donor center of the American Red Cross. In this letter it was assumed that delay is due to lack of personnel and facilities.

The full impact of the war will hit the distribution trades when present inventories are worked off, Victor Pelz of the General Foods Sales Corporation declared yesterday at a luncheon meeting of the American Marketing Association at the Hotel Commodore.

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., June 25 -- In their final business session the United Confederate Veterans elected as Commander in Chief General John W. Harris, 94 years old, of Oklahoma City, and tentatively selected Macon, Ga., as their next meeting place.

CHICAGO, June 26 -- Liquidation in fairly liberal volume and commission house pressure today carried wheat prices on the Board of Trade down about 2 cents a bushel. Support was lacking and prices rallied only slightly late in the session on short covering.

WASHINGTON, June 26 -- Twenty-one chemical companies, including leaders in the field, and sixty-five of their officers were indicted at South Bend, Ind., today accused of violating the anti-trust laws in connection with production of acids vital to the conduct of the war.

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., June 26 -- The pageantry of prancing cavalry and rumbling horse-drawn artillery fire was missing today in the parade which was a climax of the Confederate reunion, but there remained the captains, though in dwindled numbers, and the tumult and the shouting.

A supply of official armbands that will permit the clergy to have freedom of movement during air raids "in the line of duty" have been received for distribution by the Rev. Dr. Robert Wyckoff Searle as general secretary of the Greater New York Federation of Churches.

A Republican victory in the State election this Fall was predicted yesterday by State Chairman Edwin F. Jaeckle, who declared that party unity and enthusiasm were greater than at any other time within his recollection.

The volume of new bonds offered here this week was somewhat larger than in the preceding period but continued well below the average, amounting to $5,145,000, compared with $1,792,000 last week. For the corresponding period last year $91,980,000 in new bonds was placed on the market.

WASHINGTON, June 26 -- The paper work involved in selecting the first two groups of 375 officer candidates for the Women's Army Auxiliary Corps will get under way here early tomorrow, when a committee of eighteen women will start a four-day meeting to select successful applicants from among those recommended by the Army Corps Areas.
BERLIN, June 26 (From German broadcasts recorded by The Associated Press) -- A Finnish communique broadcast by the German radio today follows:
Sound formulation of peace terms would help bring the war to an "earlier and victorious end," Hugh Gibson, former Ambassador to Belgium and Brazil, declared yesterday.

In spite of the huge task with which the railways are confronted in moving war traffic, safety and the conservation of manpower and materials are still in the forefront of their efforts. This was made clear by the twenty-second annual award of the E.H. Harriman Memorial Medals.
Opening of a safety campaign to save "war casualties" on the city's home front through prevention of all types of accidents was announced yesterday by the Greater New York Safety Council.

Selection of Frederick Graham, aviation editor of THE NEW YORK TIMES, as $250 first prize winner in the leading division of a four-part aviation writing and photography contest conducted by Trans-continental and Western Air, Inc., was announced yesterday.

DENVER, June 26 (U.P.) -- The American Newspaper Guild declared today at its final session that its two principal aims during the coming year would be extension of the "Guild shop for union security" and "adjustment of wages."

A limited number of letters signed by Mayor La Guardia warning 3-A men (deferred from the draft because of dependents) that their failure to enroll in the City Patrol Corps would result in "their defense status with the protective forces of the city" being reported to their local draft boards, went out in the mails yesterday in franked Selective Service envelopes, in compliance with a request from the Mayor's office.

PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., June 26 -- Mrs. Thomas Rudel of Cedar Creek today sprang a surprise when she won the women's Long Island golf championship by beating Mrs. Ruth Torgerson of Lakeville, 3 and 2, in the thirty-six-hole final.

Minority stockholders of Paramount Pictures, Inc., lost yesterday their Supreme Court suit to compel directors of the company to return to its treasury $100,000 paid out of company funds to Willie Bioff and George E. Browne, former labor leaders convicted of extortion.

WASHINGTON, June 26 (AP) -- The War Department today consolidated its various air transport facilities into a single world-wide system to carry personnel, supplies and mail to any part of the globe where the Army may be operating.

Insurance agents and brokers in this area were unable yesterday, for the second consecutive day, to obtain application forms for Federal war property damage insurance, although a steady flow of insurance men and their clerks streamed through the special quarters provided by the New York Fire Insurance Exchange to obtain the necessary documents.

WASHINGTON, June 26 -- Sixteen gallons of gasoline a month, or a total of 192 gallons to cover a full year's driving, will be allowed motorists holding basic "A" cards under the permanent rationing plan announced today by the Office of Price Administration.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: I have read with considerable interest the letter of Virgil Markham published June 21 entitled "Markham's Biography." In justice to your correspondent and your readers I feel that I should throw still further light on a subject which need not be allowed to become complex or equivocal.

MILWAUKEE, June 26 -- Asserting that scholars and men of letters had failed to oppose the rising Fascist revolution in the last decade, Archibald MacLeish, Librarian of Congress, told the final general session of the conference of the American Library Association here tonight that it was "a shame to Western scholarship and a reproach our generation will not soon forget."

The Globe Playhouse in London is the subject of a detailed study just released by Harvard University Press. John C. Adams, author of the book, devotes a fourth of his pages to establishing various hitherto misunderstood details relating to the design of the Elizabethan theatre and the rest to the design and the equipment of the multiple stage.

To Sports Editor of The New York Times: May I timidly suggest one possible contributing cause of the disappointing turn-out for the National A.A.U. track and field championships last Saturday; i.e., the races were run at metric distances?

The charge that "dangerous overcrowding" exists in the public schools, as alleged by the Joint Committee of Teachers Organizations in a newspaper advertisement on Thursday, was branded yesterday by Ellsworth B. Buck, president of the Board of Education, as "deliberate misrepresentation for selfish ends."

Members of the National Association of Merchandise Brokers, Inc., will not be allowed to sue a manufacturer or seller over any differences until the matter has been referred to arbitration, it was disclosed yesterday by Julius Perlmutter, managing director of the association, who stated that forty-one trade associations in the women's and men's apparel field have been notified of the ruling.

"Tower of Terror," a Britishmade production released here through Monogram, will open today at the Central. Wilfrid Lawson and Movita head the cast of the film, which deals with a British agent's adventures in Germany.
NEW YORK J. Howard McGrath, Governor of Rhode Island, and Mrs. McGrath are at the Waldorf-Astoria.
LONDON, June 26 -- Popular resentment at the government resulting from the Libyan defeat found reflection today in the unexpected defeat of the official candidate in the Maldon, Essex, by-election.

OTTAWA, June 26 -- Back in his seat in the House of Commons today after his conversations with President Roosevelt and Prime Minister Churchill and his participation in a meeting of the Pacific War Council, Prime Minister W.L. Mackenzie King had this grave report to make:

WASHINGTON, June 26 -- Latin America, whose financiers and economists will meet in Washington next Tuesday to implement the Rio de Janeiro resolutions of January 28, has been forced by the war to trade with itself to an absolutely unprecedented degree.

RIVERHEAD, L.I., June 26 -- District Attorney Fred J. Munder rested his case against Mrs. Edith Home Reichert late this afternoon in Suffolk County Court after five hours of testimony from five witnesses concerning the events that led up to and followed the fatal shooting of the 29-year-old Brooklyn housewife's brother, George Horne, 26, last Dec. 3.

WASHINGTON, June 26 -- Following is the vote by which the Senate voted a $76,529,000 appropriation today to continue operation of the Civilian Conservation Corps, Vice President Wallace breaking a tie vote:

FORT LEE, N.J., June 26 -- Police Chief John McDermott announced today that the case of Mrs. Helena Klee, 37 years old, of 30 Slocum Way here, who is accused by the police of hoarding 450 pounds of sugar, would be referred to Federal rationing authorities by mail.

Gross revenues of the Pennsylvania Railroad for the period June 1 to June 15 were estimated yesterday by M.W. Clement, president, at $34,419,000, an increase of 28.1 per cent over the similar period last year. He said that freight revenues approximated $25,458,000, up 21.1 per cent, and passenger revenues $6,679,000, an increase of 78.5 per cent.

For the first time in its history, the United States Steel Corporation will run a national newspaper campaign, dealing specifically with its contributions to the war effort. The campaign scheduled to break on Tuesday will appear in 268 papers in cities in which the corporation has any operation and in cities with a population of 75,000 and over.

WASHINGTON, June 26 -- War production factories in the United States produced in May nearly 4,000 airplanes, more than 1,500 tanks, nearly 2,000 artillery and anti-tank guns, and "well over" 100,000 machine guns and sub-machine guns, President Roosevelt said today.

PHILADELPHIA, June 26 -- A committee of three experts appointed by the Federal District Court reported today to the court that the liability of the Pennsylvania Railroad to the Pennroad Corporation, between which existed an interlocking directorate, for losses from investments totaled $23,844,931.

New State and municipal financing scheduled for next week by sixteen municipalities aggregates only $5,084,455, compared with $11,229,444 for this week. The weekly average of new offerings for the year to date now stands at $24,600,113.

BUENOS AIRES, June 26 -- At noon today -- the day when Germany's announced blockade of the Western Atlantic was scheduled to begin -- the Argentine Charged Affaires in Berlin, Luis S. Luti, delivered to the Wilhelmstrasse a note demanding reparations for the sinking of the Argentine steamship Rio Tercero.

To Sports Editor of The New fork Times: It was a pity that the sponsors of the recent Hale America Open, which was the national open golf championship in everything but name, did not select a course more worthy than Ridgemoor to be the site of a championship event.
WASHINGTON, June 26 (AP) -- Five wounded aviation heroes of the Pacific campaign, three of them participants in the Doolittle raid on Tokyo, had a shy Royal visitor today, King Peter of Yugoslavia.

CAIRO, Egypt, June 26 -- Opposed thus far only by British mobile forces and planes, two columns of German tanks, supported by mixed arms, yesterday approached Matruh, which is 130 miles east of the Egyptian frontier and 180 miles west of Alexandria.

Mackay Co., one of the oldest firms on the New York Stock Exchange, will dissolve on June 30. Malcom S. Mackay will become a special partner of Laidlaw Co., which will take over the accounts. Alfred B. Mackay, senior partner, will keep his seat on the New York Stock Exchange and make his office with Dominick Dominick.

CHICAGO, June 26 (AP) -- Prices of hogs rose today to the highest levels in sixteen years as packers bid for slaughter material to meet government demands for pork and lard. Gaining 10 to 15 cents a hundred-weight, choice hogs hit $14.70, peak since September, 1926, and 5 cents above the 1942 high established in mid-April.

Our Unkempt Garden Robert Moses, if he doesn't look out, is in serious danger of becoming another H.G. Wells in his uncontrollable passion for neatness. Pleading for the preservation of the old Aquarium building in Battery Park, it was contended by George McAneny and others that the old Castle Garden, as the "gateway of the nation," had historical meaning second only to Independence Hall.

Insurance and Savings Rejection by the House Ways and Means Committee of a proposal to permit individual tax-payers to deduct a portion of their life insurance premiums in computing income taxes was viewed yesterday with some alarm in insurance circles.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., June 26 -- Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer today purchased screen rights to Alice Duer Miller's narrative poem, "The White Cliffs of Dover," from Clarence Brown and signed Brown to direct the picture, which will be made from the poem.

NEW DELHI, India, June 26 (AP) -- A lanky, daredevil fighter pilot from Macon, Ga., Colonel Robert L. Scott, was assigned today to command the American Army's first pursuit planes in China, the Twenty-third Pursuit Group of the United States Army Air Corps.

VICHY, France, June 26 -- Six death sentences, one in absentia, and six to life at hard labor were pronounced today by the State Tribunal at Paris for alleged participation in a food store riot there on May 31.
CAIRO, Egypt, June 26 (AP) -- An R.A.F. communique said today:

After nearly four months of hearings, conferences and decisions the House Ways and Means Committee has completed its work on the new tax bill. The result, which is now in the hands of the drafting experts, is not perfect; but in the face of the difficulties involved, both technical and political, the committee has done a good job.

Requests from the War Department that companies acting as contractors to the Army air forces refrain from, making public quarterly financial reports promise to affect more than half the concerns with securities listed on the New York Stock Exchange, it was learned yesterday.
Seven Dodgers and four Giants have "made the team."

WASHINGTON, June 26 -- The question of how far the war economy of the United States shall be under civilian and how far under Army and Navy control will be decided within a few days by President Roosevelt. The controversy which has developed over the reorganization of the War Production Board has been referred to the White House.
Earle Newton Cutler has sold his thirty-two-acre country estate on Van Beuren Road, New Vernon, near Morristown, N.J., to H. Clifford Brown of Summit. Eugene V. Welsh was the broker.

AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, Australia, Saturday, June 27 (AP) -- The Allied bombers that attacked Lae and Salamaua, Japanese bases on New Guinea Island, Thursday night, blasted a Japanese ship that was, entering Lae harbor.

WASHINGTON, June 26 -- The delayed announcement by the Moscow radio yesterday that a Soviet vessel sunk off the Japanese coast on May 1 was the victim of a Japanese submarine is viewed in diplomatic circles here as a sure sign that Japanese-Soviet relations are worse.

Men fight for their liberty with songs on their tongues as well as with guns, tanks and planes. That was the contention of a lively program presented at the Town Hall last night under the auspices of the Negro Publication Society of America.

LONDON, Saturday, June 27 -- For the third time the British on Thursday night sent their massed bombers against Germany and "more than 1,000" of the big planes concentrated on Bremen, the Air Ministry said. Royal Air Force reconnaissance planes fly-...

As General Field Marshal Rommel drives deeper into Egypt, toward the main defenses of the British armies, American B-24 heavy bombers have gone into action. A formation of these huge "Liberator" planes, in which American pilots have already ranged far over the Black Sea and the Mediterranean, have twice joined the British in attacks on Bengazi, Rommel's Libyan base.

A big hit and a little one added up to an important run at Ebbets Field yesterday as the Dodgers squeezed past the Reds in the tenth inning to win, 5 -- 4. The word "squeezed" is used advisedly because it was a pretty squeeze bunt by Peewee Reese that chased in Billy Herman, who had tripled.

Trade Showing Spotty in Week Retail trade here was spotty this week, with some improvement shown during the last few days following the resumption of delivery service. Department stores were estimated as showing a decline of around 6 per cent or more in dollar volume, as compared with a year ago.

Fluctuations in the cotton futures market yesterday closely paralleled those of the preceding day, with slight initial gains supplanted early by moderate losses that were maintained until the end of trading on the New York Cotton Exchange.

WASHINGTON, June 26 (AP) -- The House and Senate were apparently hopelessly deadlocked tonight upon a major phase of the Agriculture Department's war food production program -- the sale of Government-owned grains for live-stock feed at below-parity prices.

A disaster unit van, newest type of civilian war aid motor vehicle, was presented yesterday to the New York Chapter of the American Red Cross toy employes of the Burndy Engineering Company in ceremonies outside the company's plant at 107 - "oulevard, the Bronx.

DETROIT, June 26 (AP) -- Al Benton of the Tigers, who lost five games in the first five weeks of the American League season, finally reached the 500 mark today by setting down the Athletics, 3 to 1, on six hits for his fourth straight victory.

GARDEN CITY, L.I., June 26 -- In trying to break a tie for the qualifying medal in the Long Island junior golf championship at the Cherry Valley Club today Robert L. Andrews, a University of Pennsylvania sophomore, bit off more than he could chew.

WASHINGTON, June 26 -- A moderate increase in the allotment of sugar to individuals under the rationing program was an early possibility, the Office of Price Administration said today in announcing that it had undertaken further studies of the sugar situation and of the outlook for future supplies.
BOSTON, June 26 (AP) -- Jimmy Foxx's first National League homer, which came with two out in the ninth inning and a mate on base, today gave the Cubs a 6-4 victory over the Braves.
MOSCOW, June 26 (AP) -- The Soviet Information Bureau issued this communique today:

WASHINGTON, June 26 -- Dissatisfaction over the way the Office of Price Administration is handling the price ceiling on foodstuffs threatened an open break by the food industries with the OPA here tonight after a three-hour session between OPA executives and an industry advisory committee appointed by the OPA.

The distance between stops on all franchised bus lines operating in the city limits will be doubled, starting at 12:01 A.M. on Monday, Police Commissioner Valentine announced yesterday. Commissioner Valentine's order, which was issued in compliance with the gasoline and rubber conservation program laid down by the Office of Defense Transportation in Washington, will also apply to city-owned buses operated by the Board of Transportation.
LONDON, June 26 -- The markets finished the week on a firm note, the oils providing the chief feature, with Anglo-Egyptian regaining 3s 1 1/2d and Iranian and Shell rising 1 1/4s each.

WASHINGTON, June 26 -- The National Labor Relations Board certified today that a union of plant-protection employes in the Fisher Body Lansing division had been selected by a majority in the unit as their collective-bargaining representatives while similar employes polled in the Fisher Body Pontiac division had split evenly in an election.

Captain Louis Goldberg, principal witness against Lieutenant Charles O. Dannhauser, who has been accused of attempting to influence the former to accept and collect bribes for the protection of a gambling ring, was described yesterday in testimony offered by John J. Reddan, former police inspector, as "vindictive," a "mediocre policeman" and as one who "would do anything to the men."

Another aerial blitz on German industrial centers, described as the greatest in air warfare, had only a salutary effect yesterday on the stock market. The news from other war sectors was still too depressing to permit traders to emerge from cover, and most of the day's trading was in low-priced issues.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: In a recent issue of THE NEW YORK TIMES there was a dispatch from Ottawa by P.J. Philip entitled "Curbs at Border Opposed in Canada," somewhat in criticism of the Canadian and American Governments for measures that are the results of war.

SOMEWHERE IN NORTHERN IRELAND, June 26 -- In the first review of its kind since the United States entered the war American troops here have just given King George VI and Queen Elizabeth an impressive demonstration of the grim efficiency and growing might of uncle Sam's fighting power.

Body and Mind Foundation, Inc., at 139 East Sixty-ninth Street, of which Dr. Edward S. Cowles, the psychiatrist, is the head, was fined $750 yesterday in Special Sessions and one of Dr. Cowles's assistants, Rudolph Rebold, got off with a suspended sentence on their recent conviction of violating the State Education Law by practicing medicine in the place without a license.
CHUNGKING, China, June 26 (AP) -- The Chinese communique said today:

Disputing the theory that "a post-war depression" and "fundamental changes in the social order" are inevitable, the National Association of Manufacturers released here yesterday a nine-point post-war program to speed reconstruction.
WASHINGTON, June 26 -- For the first time since 1924, the Senate discussed legislation in secret today.

WASHINGTON, June 26 -- The United States Coast Guard is giving serious consideration to the inclusion in its regulations governing standard equipment aboard all American merchant vessels of a paragraph making mandatory the employment of detachable vertical fenders or "skates" on all lifeboats.

The battle for Egypt is one of the decisive battles of the war. In scale it is a skirmish compared to the struggle of giant armies in Russia. The highest toll the desert campaign can take of German man and machine power is only a fraction of the cost paid for every advance and every retreat in Soviet territory.

CHICAGO, June 26 -- Capacity of the world's longest petroleum pipeline, carrying gasoline and fuel oil over a 1,261-mile system from Baton Rouge to Greensboro, N.C., soon will be increased 50 per cent, according to a statement made today at the session of the American Institute of Electrical Engineers.
The big four of the national professional tennis championship were inducted, not without difficulty, into the semi-final brackets yesterday at the West Side Tennis Club, Forest Hills.

ALBANY, June 26 -- The State War Council approved at a meeting today a reciprocal suspension of all local traffic laws and ordinances against cars and trucks registered in other States and operating in New York State.

Charles (Pickles) Greenspan, 28 years old, the last of a woman-led gang that five years ago obtained $1,000,000 in money and gems in a series of early-morning hold-ups of men and women returning to their homes from hotel receptions and night clubs, was sentenced to Sing Sing yesterday by Judge James G. Wallace in General Sessions for seven to twelve years.

ANKARA, Turkey, June 26 (AP) -- An eyewitness to the United States air attack on Tokyo last April 18, who was in a Tokyo street when the raid occurred, said today that the Japanese were thrown into panic and depressed by the feeble defense.

CHICAGO, June 26 -- In full view of their biggest home crowd of the year, the White Sox started running the bases like clowns under the Ringling big top at Comiskey Park tonight, but they suddenly veered back to a fair track, and behind the six-hit pitching of Hard Luck Edgar Smith submerged the Yankees. The score was 4 to 2.

GIRARD, Ohio, June 26 (AP) -- Joe Kirkwood, the Australian trickshot artist now playing from Abington, Pa., and Sam Byrd, former New York Yankee outfielder, today tied Horton Smith with 4-below-par 64s for leadership of the $5,000 Mahoning Valley open golf tournament.
Not only will the season open in most of New York on Wednesday for black bass, but it will also mark the initial day for the voracious muskellunge.
A woman we know has a knack for lending enchantment to everything she does. And all on the most slimmest of budgets.

WASHINGTON, June 26 -- Provision for re-rating war orders and for applying a new series of high-preference ratings is made in Priorities Regulation No. 12 and amendments to Regulations 1 and 3, issued today by the Director of Industry Operations of the War Production Board.

CAMP TAMIMENT, Pa., June 26 -- Predicting that the United Nations would win the war if the Axis did not become invincible by the end of this year, Edgar Ansell Mowrer, deputy director of the Office of War Information, told the Tamiment Labor Institute today that he expected "our lowest ebb" between September and December.
Nine, including Whirlaway, have been named for today's running of the $30,000 added Brooklyn Handicap, Army-Navy Day feature on the concluding program of the Aqueduct Summer meeting.

CHICAGO, June 26 -- Emphasizing the importance of home gardening as a vital factor in a successful war effort, the Men's Garden Clubs of America today urged the National Advisory Garden Committee to take steps looking to increased recognition by government, press and public of the Victory garden program and the food-for-freedom campaign.

THE war is doing strange things to the English novelists and intellectuals who wantonly misrepresented their country for two decades. An Evelyn Waugh, who used to snicker at all the values which have created the British Common-wealth of Nations, is now busy trying to refashion his wastrel characters into sterling patriots. A Beverly Nichols, once a pacifist, renounces his unreal philosophy.

PONTIAC, Mich., June 26 (AP) -- Officials of the Yellow Truck and Coach Company said today they had agreed to pay night shift workers for twenty minutes of time lost during a practice blackout, and that 11,000 strikers would return to their war production jobs tomorrow.

Last night's Stadium concert, at which Alexander Smallens made his initial appearance of the season as conductor In the series, only lasted until the intermission, when it became necessary to call the rest of the program off because of the rain.

The sinking of a small United States vessel in the Gulf of Mexico, with a loss of five lives, and the torpedoing off the South American coast of a medium-sized British ship, with two crew members not accounted for, was announced by the Navy yesterday.

NOW the fans are howling because some of their favorites were not put on the rosters for the All-Star game. They denounce the pickers and choosers as jugheads or prejudiced parties. They insist there is no justice and would like to know whither we are drifting.

The Town of Hempstead, L.I., bought yesterday 1,020 feet of ocean front beach between Trenton and Malone Avenues at East Atlantic Beach to give residents of this area a private beach park nearly 300 feet deep for their exclusive use.

STATE COLLEGE, Pa., June 26 -- The large amounts which are being spent by the Office of Scientific Research and Development in Washington to aid in the production of means to help win the war were revealed last night at the sessions of the American Association of Physics Teachers meeting at the Pennsylvania State College.

WASHINGTON, June 26 -- Lieutenant Draper L. Kauffman of the Naval Reserve, already a decorated veteran of the French Army and the British Navy in this war, received the Navy Cross from Secretary Knox today for unloading and examining a dud 500-pound Japanese bomb which fell on Fort Scofield, in Hawaii, Dec. 7.

Arthur W. Wallander, chief of staff of the city's defense forces, substituted for Mayor La Guardia yesterday afternoon in presenting awards to winners in the city-wide high school essay and poster competitions on the subject of "Salvage in Total War."

To Sports Editor of The New York Times: I was very interested in reading John Kieran's column concerning outdoor track and field in THE TIMES this morning. Surely there is something wrong with outdoor track and field in the metropolitan New York and Boston areas.

WASHINGTON, June 26 -- Vice President Wallace cast his first votes in the Senate today to break ties and thus succeeded in putting the Senate on record as in favor of continuance of the Civilian Conservation Corps for another year with a $76,529,800 appropriation.

CHUNGKING, China, June 26 (U.P.) -- Chinese troops have killed 2,000 more Japanese in the Honan-Shansi frontier mountains, raising to at least 4,500 the casualties inflicted there in ten days on one of the enemy columns operating against Chungking regulars and guerrilla troops in North China, it was announced tonight.

ST. LOUIS, June 26 (AP) -- Louis (Buck) Newsom fanned ten batters in six innings but the Browns nicked him for seven runs and then went on to defeat the Senators, 8 to 5, tonight to break a four-game losing streak. It was Elden Auker's ninth victory against six defeats.
BERLIN, June 26 (From German broadcasts recorded by The Associated Press) -- The German High Command issued this communique today:

Governor Lehman was asked yesterday to remove Mayor La Guardia from office on fourteen charges that he had broken the law and ten other charges that he was inefficient, which were contained in a communication sent to the Governor by ten civic workers.

TOKYO, June 26 (From Japanese broadcasts recorded by The Associated Press) -- Japan's Navy chiefs have sent congratulations to the supreme commander of ground forces in the Eastern Pacific -- whose name was not disclosed -- and Admiral Isoroku Yamamoto, commander in chief of the combined fleet, Domei, official Japanese news agency, said in a broadcast today.

Pre-Independence Day sermons will be preached tomorrow by the clergymen of New York, next Saturday being July 4. The discourses will deal with the present war for freedom, some of the topics being "A Second Front," "Mercy's Call," "A Declaration of Independence" and "Civilians in a World War."

NEWARK, N.J., June 26 -- In protest against the refusal of the Essex County Board of Freeholders to grant demanded wage increases, attendance and maintenance employes at the County Hospital at Cedar Grove and the Essex Mountain Sanitarium at Verona will take a five-day "holiday" starting Wednesday, Harry Schram, president of Local 180, Building Service International Union, A.F. of L., announced here today.

WASHINGTON, June 26 -- Maxim Litvinoff, Soviet Ambassador, joined in the conferences between President Roosevelt and Prime Minister Churchill on the offensive strategy of the war, the White House announced today.

A new world emergency fund of $600,000, authorized by the Northern Baptist Convention at Its annual meeting last month in Cleveland, was put in its budget by the world emergency fund committee of the conveniton at a meeting ended yesterday at 152 Madison Avenue.

The Federal Government, through the medium of the Export-Import Bank, obtained yesterday a directorship on the board of the International Telephone Telegraph Corporation. At a meeting of I.T. T.'s board here, Warren Lee Pierson, president of the Export-Import Bank, was made a director of the communications concern.

The effort of a Mount Vernon physician to prevent his local draft board from calling him for Army service failed in Federal court yesterday when Judge Simon H. Rifkind dismissed Dr. Frank J. Pirone's application for an injunction.

WASHINGTON, June 26 (AP) -- The Senate Agriculture Committee asserted today that dollar-a-year men in the War Production Board's chemicals branch were holding up production of synthetic rubber from grain alcohol because they were fearful of postwar competition with companies with which many of them had been associated.

Nicholas J. De Stefano, who is awaiting trial on charges that he used his position as secretary-treasurer of Local 202 of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, A.F. of L., to extort money from the union treasury, demanded in Supreme Court yesterday that he tie reinstated in his job, with back pay totaling $9,000.

MOSCOW, June 26 -- Kupyansk, a railway junction some sixty miles southeast of Kharkov, was yielded only after very heavy fighting, according to Russian reports here today. Only when the Germans had established overwhelming numerical superiority of tanks, planes and infantry by reinforcing troops that had failed to break the town's defenses in previous attacks did the scene of battle shift to the streets, where the bitter struggle continued for some time.

Placement facilities for delinquent children in New York City are virtually closed to the Children's Court, it was disclosed yesterdy by John Warren Hill, presiding justice of the Domestic Relations Court, in a report to Mayor La Guardia.

The Greater New York War Bond Pledge Campaign entered its final week-end phase last night in Times Square. Former Mayor James J. Walker touched it off with a plea for pledges that sent the crowd into high emotional pitch.

BERNE, Switzerland, Saturday, June 27 -- After four days of more or less sensational gains on the Kharkov front, German forces striking at the Russian lines between Kupyansk and Izyum were reported this morning to have been fought to a virtual standstill at many points.

New York City Controller Joseph D. McGoldrick sold yesterday by allotment to twenty-three local banks and trust companies $32,000,000 of New York City revenue bills at 0.75 per cent. The issue is dated June 25, 1942, and will mature in installments as follows: $2,500,000 on Aug. 3, $3,000,000 on Oct. 1, $3,500,000 on Dec. 1, 1942; $2,000,000 on Feb. 1, $2,000,000 on April 30 and $19,000,000 on June 25, 1943.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 26 -- An attack on the American citizenship of Japanese born in this country, aimed at disenfranchising perhaps 70,000 persons evacuated from the West Coast's military area No. 1 and having far broader implications, was begun in the Federal District Court here today.
CLEVELAND, June 26 (AP) -- The second-place Red Sox turned back the Indians' bid to gain on them tonight with a 3-to-2 victory. Dick Newsome allowed the Tribe only six hits for his seventh triumph.

The Experimental Theatre, organized to aid actors and playwrights in testing plays at a low cost, will present matinee performances of "Death, Mr. President" on July 7 and 9, it was said yesterday by Antoinette Perry, chairman of the group.

Amid the shrieks of a ladies' day crowd of 7,585 and the groans that emanated from their grizzled skipper, Frank Francis Frisch, the Pirates played the great American game of baseball at the Polo Grounds yesterday with buttered fingers.
CLEVELAND, June 26 (AP) -- The second-place Red Sox turned back the Indians' bid to gain on them tonight with a 3-to-2 victory. Dick Newsome allowed the Tribe only six hits for his seventh triumph.

The Experimental Theatre, organized to aid actors and playwrights in testing plays at a low cost, will present matinee performances of "Death, Mr. President" on July 7 and 9, it was said yesterday by Antoinette Perry, chairman of the group.

Amid the shrieks of a ladies' day crowd of 7,585 and the groans that emanated from their grizzled skipper, Frank Francis Frisch, the Pirates played the great American game of baseball at the Polo Grounds yesterday with buttered fingers.

WASHINGTON, June 26 -- Price adjustments, by Congressional or Administrative action, or both, to facilitate the movements of oil from the Midwest into the East Coast area in time to avert a serious Winter shortage, were demanded here today by Mayor La Guardia, who headed a conference of Eastern Mayors.

There is a party in progress this afternoon about which no one would hear as a rule. The patients and staff of the House of the Holy Comforter, 196th Street and Grand Concourse, the Bronx, are giving an affair in their victory garden.

NEWARK, N.J., June 26 (AP) -- Steve Roser of the Bears, serving his first season in Double-A competition after two years on smaller Yankee farm clubs, limited Syracuse to five hits in a twilight-arc-light encounter tonight and won, 3 to 0.

FORT DBS MOINES, Iowa, June 26 -- Learning to become a WAAC officer theoretically will be a thirty-nine-hour-a-week job, the first official Women's Army Auxiliary Corps training school curriculum showed today.
MOSCOW, Saturday, June 27 (AP) -- The midnight Soviet communique said:

NEWARK, N.J., June 26 (AP) -- The noise of bursting bombs and the destruction of buildings echoed out of Schools Stadium tonight at an air raid protection demonstration staged by the United States Army before 8,000 persons.

BERLIN, June 26 (From German broadcasts recorded by The Associated Press) -- The capture of the important rail town of Izyum, seventy miles southeast of Kharkov, after bitter street fighting, was claimed tonight by the Benin radio as General Field Marshal Fedor von Bock increased the pressure of his Ukraine offensive.
LONDON, June 26 (AP) -- An Air Ministry communique said today:

WASHINGTON, June 26 -- The National War Labor Board's first unanimous decision ordering inclusion of a maintenance-of-membership clause in union contracts was handed down today in the case of the Arizona operations of the Phelps-Dodge Corporation, a copper mining concern.

Handy Harman, local bullion dealers, announced yesterday that they would not be able to allocate any foreign-produced silver to industrial and art users for delivery in July. Because of the supply situation and the increased demand for the metal the concern has had to allocate supplies to purchasers for several months.

VENTNOR CITY, N.J., June 26 -- With the issue depending upon the results of tomorrow's final round, Abe Yanofsky of Winnipeg, chess champion of Canada, led the field of ten in the masters' invitation tournament by half a point tonight.

Another king in exile is a guest at the White House. On Thursday he put the case of his nation before Congress. Peter II of Yugoslavia is of a house and a country on which the repeated strokes of fate have fallen as on Thebes or Pelops's line. His father and his kingdom have been assassinated.

GREAT LAKES, Ill., June 27 -- The arrival of six former major leaguers today gave a measure of encouragement to Lieutenant Mickey Cochrane, who had begun to wonder when he would be able to assemble his all-star servicemen's baseball squad.

Fifteen million tons of shipping were constructed, repaired or converted in the eleven plants of the Todd Shipyards Corporation during the year ending yesterday, according to a report made by John D. Reilly, president of the company, at the annual meeting of the stockholders at 1 Broadway.

Discovery of the tomb of Tut-ankhAmen in Egypt gave newspaper readers an inkling of the work that the archaeologists have been doing since the opening of the century. Then came excavations along the Euphrates and in Asia Minor. Strange names of ancient cities and kingdoms appeared in the news -- Mari, Nuzi, Alakah, Hattusa, Urartu, Samaria, Megiddo, Pylos, DuraEuropos -- which have not yet found their way into school histories.
While home construction in the majority of Long Island residential centers for houses costing more than $6,000 has practically ceased, defense housing projects are showing more activity.

MILWAUKEE, Wis., June 27 Complete absence of social affairs and extra-curricular activities during the first of two 1942 Summer terms at Marquette university is a direct result of the terrific pressure to which students are being put in the streamlined wartime schedule.

BECAUSE the radio is, so to speak, a game of hide-and-seek -- programs forever seeking the listener hidden from the broadcaster's view -- its sundry performers must spend no small part of their time wondering about their effect upon people who hear them but have never seen them.

IN these days of uncertainty and tempestuous activity and anxiety a book about "an adventure in serenity" is like manna from Heaven. We have almost forgotten what the word means, but its sound is as sweet music from a far land.

NORTHAMPTON, Mass., June 27 -- War minors are now being planned at Smith College to meet the urgent demands being made upon the women's colleges by the civil service, war industries, and the intelligence services for graduates with certain types of specialized training.
When a nation becomes involved in war, short-sightedness and poor preparation for eventualities of a major nature stand out clearly. This is especially true of college education.

MILWAUKEE, Wis., June 27 -- The annual list of outstanding religious books of the year was announced yesterday at a meeting of the religious books section of the American Library Association, which held its annual conference here this week.

ANY reader who has begun to feel lately, as any reader excusably might, that we have had too many novels interpreting the American Revolution in terms of our own day and our own political thinking, will find pleasure and refreshment in "Tory Tavern."

Two talented young American soloists and the performance of two rarely heard works lent extra interest to the program conducted by Alexander Smallens last night at the Lewisohn Stadium. The soloists were Eleanor Fine, 15year-old pianist of this city, and Blair McClosky, baritone, while the works in question consisted of the early Mozart symphony in C major (K. 200) and Mahler's "Kindertotenlieder."

MACKLNLAY KANTOR'S new tale is a plain and pleasant Western with no pretense to anything more than neatly turned and well conducted entertainment for those who prefer literacy, good sense and credible characters even in an action-Western-detective mystery to the sort of thing fit only for adults.

Forty small "pilgrims" blazed a trail yesterday that, it is humanity's prayer, will remain the tranquil, happy road it started out to be. The trail led to a large country estate at Livingston Manor, Sullivan County, 120 miles from New York City.

THE Museum of Modern Art has been acquiring some more work by German moderns who have incurred the displeasure of the Nazi regime. A group of such items, presented under the collective title, Free German Art, was placed on public view last week and will continue to be shown through Aug. 16.

WASHINGTON, June 27 -- Coming operations by the military forces of the United Nations "will divert German strength from the attack on Russia," it was announced today by President Roosevelt and Prime Minister Churchill in a final communique on their week-long series of conferences in which the offensive strategy of the war was mapped.

The Government and people of the United States demonstrated a "remarkable wartime tolerance" in the six months following the Japanese assault on Pearl Harbor, the American Civil Liberties "Union declared in its annual report, made public yesterday.
BERLIN, June 27 (From German broadcasts recorded by The Associated Press) -- The German High Command issued the following communique today:

THERE is a very special magic in eating out of doors. Whether it's a hobo lunch in a green meadow, or a sophisticated dinner on some rooftop, the absence of restraining walls seems to increase the appetite.

WASHINGTON, June 27 -- The War Production Board's Production Requirements Plan, under which all manufacturing users of metals in excess of $5,000 worth a calendar quarter must file PRP applications with the board before the end of this month, will provide WPB with a continuous audit of a large segment of American industry after July 1, officials said here today.

HAINES FALLS -- An almost wistful sidelight on current motorists' troubles will be provided by an exhibition scheduled to open here on July 6. Andron's Mountain House, which occupies the site of the original Mountain House, the first hotel in these storied Catskills, is arranging an exhibition of vehicles used by visitors to this historic spot a hundred years ago.

WESTPORT, Conn., June 27 -- Wendell L. Willkie, speaking here this afternoon at a luncheon meeting sponsored by the Fairfield County Republican Women's Association, threw the full weight of his position as titular leader of the Republican party behind the candidacy of Raymond E. Baldwin as the party's nominee for Governor of Connecticut.

LONDON, June 27 (U.P.) -- The Times, commenting on the demands for a combined general staff and the introduction of modern hard-hitting tactics, said today that while deficiencies in British tactics were partly conditioned on the quality of British tanks, responsibility must be fixed since the entire series of campaigns since Norway had revealed similar deficiencies.

ASBURY PARK, N.J. -- To this New Jersey coastal resort area, wherein was acted out much history of the War for Independence, Americans of today are finding rest and relaxation for a more determined continuance of the current war effort.

IT'S pretty hard for a boy whose father is commander of a Coast Guard cutter to admit that he is afraid of the water. Ten-year-old Greg, happy on the safe, dry plains of Kansas, didn't want to go to Greenland on the Polarland, and he simply couldn't manage to tell his father that he hadn't learned to swim, as he had promised.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: With considerable discussion now taking place on the opening of a second front in Western Europe by the United Nations, the possibility for the opening of a third front must not be overlooked, for it offers some interesting possibilities from a strategic viewpoint.

WEST CHESTER, Pa., June 27 -- Miss Martha G. Thomas, the only woman ever elected to the State Legislature from Chester County, died last night in the Chester County Hospital here ten days after suffering a stroke. Her age was 73.

Two new fast cargo carriers for the Grace Line will be sent down the ways of an East Coast shipyard this morning in a double launching, the line announced yesterday. For security reasons the location of the launchings will not be made public until after the event, which will be witnessed by officials of the company and a few guests.

LONDON. IN the opinion of G.M. Young, one of our ablest literary critics, the praiseworthy endeavors of the Board of Education to promote the study of American history in English schools are unlikely to bear much fruit.

Willkie for Governor? It was June, 1940. The weather was scorching. Philadelphia was jammed. The Republicans had come to town to nominate their candidate for President. Thomas E. Dewey was way out in front but the name of Wendell L. Willkie, a dark horse who had never held political office, was on every one's lips.

Though many young braves are now on the warpath for Uncle Sam, more than 7,000 Indians are scheduled to dance in the annual Inter-Tribal Ceremonial to be held at Gallup, N.M., Aug. 12-15. For authenticity and brilliance this festival of the Indian country is unequaled, in the opinion of John Collier, Commissioner of Indian Affairs for the United States Government.

THE catfish builds a nest of pebbles to hatch its young and the pretty little mousefish carries its own fishing rod a-top its head. The mud minnow is a mean-dispositioned creature, but the archer fish is a friendly one which will greet an old acquaintance with a salute of a jet of water.

WHEN boys get to the age of 9, 10 or 11 they want to be up and doing, playing strenuous games, collecting things, making things. It is the age for building a tent or a snack in the woods or in the backyard, for interest in songs, yells, secret codes, puzzles and tricks.

PORTLAND, Ore., June 27 -- The enemy shells fired at Oregon's rugged seacoast this week brought to a climax a series of adverse military events which many Westerners, in the words of Senator Charles L. McNary, fear "may cancel the advantages gained by America from the Midway victory."

The recent government regulations banning use of rotenone on all ornamental plants emphasizes the use of substitute or alternate materials. In addition to ornamentals, such vegetables as eggplants, peppers, onions, sweet corn, squash, cucumbers and melons must be treated with materials other than rotenone.

Racing in the metropolitan area shifts to Empire City tomorrow where horsemen will have approximately $375,000 in purse and stake money to shoot at. The meeting will run for twenty-four days and then the thoroughbred sport in New York goes to Saratoga for the month of August.
BUFFALO, N.Y., June 27 (AP) -- Mort and Ann Mandell, husband and wife speedboat racing team from Cleveland, piloted their outboards to a double victory today in the Buffalo international aquagatta.

HAMILTON, N.Y., June 27 -- When World War I opened for the United States in April, 1917, Colgate University canceled its commencement program, graduated its 122 seniors by mail. There was little else to be done since 80 per cent of them had left the campus by early May to enter the armed forces or take part in work work.

It is now disclosed by authorities at the New York Postoffice that the last ship carrying mail for the Philippine Islands left San Francisco on Nov. 25, 1941. Mailcarrying vessels, including some which had left at an earlier date, learned at sea of the declaration of war on Dec. 7 and made for "unspecified ports" not then involved in the war.

The Federal Savings and Loan Insurance Corporation reports that on its eighth anniversary yesterday it has accumulated more than $33,000,000 in reserves and surplus. The agency was created by Congress eight years ago with a capital of $100,000,000.
BANNER ELK, N.C. -- Western North Carolina is being converted by hydroelectric power developments into a land of scenic lakes which are attracting numerous fishermen, tourists and other vacationists.

BEFORE the American Revolution, land travel in this country was restricted mostly to horseback and ox-cart over roads that were indifferently maintained by the towns through which they passed. Water routes were all right for commerce, but they limited the size of cargoes, and the expansion of industry demanded a medium better suited to the needs of the carrying trade.

As a result of the growing stringency in vital raw materials, the War Production Board in this area will intensify its campaign on the requisitioning of frozen and hidden inventories, Sydney Hogerton, deputy director for this region, announced yesterday.
Chicago THE twenty-first annual international exhibition of watercolors has opened at the Chicago Art Institute and will remain current through Aug. 23.

With nearly 6,000 nurses enrolled in field units, the organization of the city's trained nurses for duty in case of an air raid is now perfected. These volunteers, all active private duty or public health nurses pledged to community service in a city-wide campaign last Spring, are taking weekly refresher lessons at hospitals as members of the Citizens Defense Nurse Corps.

With the rival squads chosen, all decks have been cleared for the tenth annual All-Star game between the National and American Leagues which will be played July 6 at the Polo Grounds, starting at 6:30 P.M.

Clouds provide one of the most versatile and attractive "props" the outdoor photographer has to work with. They may be used to serve as backgrounds for interesting portraits, as valuable aids in composing a scene, as the revealing key to mood or atmosphere, as beautiful subjects by themselves.

To the Drama Editor: THE American theatrical season just ended has been a poor one. It is regarded as the poorest in the recent history of our theatre. Its poverty, however, should be a surprise only to those who are incapable of knowing when one era of time, and art, is finished and another started, or ready to start.
The national professional tennis championship suffered a heavy blow in the exchequer yesterday when rain washed out what was expected to be the most profitable day of the tournament.

After having traveled more than 50,000 miles by land and sea, nearly 300 oil paintings and watercolors comprising the exhibition of contemporary North American painting circulated in ten LatinAmerican countries by the Office of the Coordinator of Inter-American Affairs have been returned to this country and are now hanging in their accustomed places on museum walls and in private homes.

As the Greater New York War Bond Pledge Campaign neared its close John T. Madden, chairman, announced yesterday that 80 per cent of the city's 2,000,000 homes had been canvassed and 1,600,000 pledges had been signed. Around 2,000,000 or more pledges are expected to be signed by midnight tonight when the campaign formally ends -- although the mop-up will extend for several days.
Washington, D.C. AN exhibition of portrait busts of the Presidents of South American republics opened yesterday afternoon at the National Gallery of Art.

VENTNOR CITY, N.J., June 27 -- Defeating Walter B. Suesman of Providence in thirty-six moves in today's ninth and final round, Abe Yanofsky of Winnipeg, 18-year-old champion of Canada, captured first prize in the fourth annual invitation chess tournament on the Municipal Pier.

The Big Midget is Jay Otto, an entertainer in the night club which Jake Justus won on a bet, the story of which bet has been told in an earlier story about Jake Justus, Helene Brand and John J. Malone. Jake and Helene are married now, and Jake hopes to be able to support Helene in the style to which she has been accustomed by means of the profits of the club.

The soldiers and sailors of our country benefited to the extent of at least $100,000 yesterday at Aqueduct when the long-tailed chestnut, Whirlaway, smothered his opposition to take the historic Brooklyn Handicap, big feature on the Queens County Jockey Club's Army-Navy Day.

SAN FRANCISCO, Calif., June 27 -- If his thoughts are interpreted correctly, the Bay area resident is less worried about the possibility of a Japanese attack, that is to say, a bombing, on his part of the coast today then he was before the Battle of Midway, but he is concerned -- more for Alaska and the Pacific Northwest primarily than for himself -- over possible implications in the "occupation" of the Aleutians.

THE canvases of Miss Barne's books are always enlivened with odd and amusing personalities, unmistakably colored, no matter how minor their positions with reality. In this one it is dogs which fill the foreground: Sealyhams, spaniels, terriers, enough to satisfy any youngster who, like Thirza, thinks all dogs good and beautiful.

THE NEW YORK TIMES index of business activity has declined to its lowest level of the year and for the first time in 1942 is below the corresponding 1941 period. The figure for the week ended June 20 was 130.0, as against 131.4 in the previous week and 130.4 (revised) in the week ended June 21, 1941.

FORT BRAGG, N.C. THIS is the story of what happened to me and H.V. Kaltenborn, in that order. One day our lieutenant strode into the office and announced to all present: "H.V. Kaltenborn is coming to Fort Bragg.

Queens College's system of training speech instructors by using them, as "cadet-teachers" in the instiution's part-time free speech clinic for handicapped children and adults will be accelerated with the incorporation of a fulltime Queens Speech and Hearing Center on the campus, Professor James F. Bender, chairman of the speech department, announced yesterday.

WHEN Tom Stackhouse of the RAF was killed in a raid on Wilhelmshaven his 70-year-old grandmother, Lady Jane Stackhouse, read the telegram from the Air Ministry with dry eyes. She had lost her only son, the boy's father under similar circumstances during the First World War and had long steeled herself to meet this ultimate test of her courage.

RICHMOND, Va., June 27 -- Four new aluminum alloys of beryllium said to retain their high tensile strength even when subjected to the high temperatures encountered in the newest airplane engines have been developed by the Aluminum Company of America.

Editor The New York Times Book Review: THE BOOK REVIEW for May 31 carried a notice -- I would not call it a review -- of my book "The Coming Showdown." I take it that the function of the book section of a newspaper is, among other things, to give people some idea of what a book contains and what the author is driving at.

WASHINGTON, June 27 -- The President has awarded the Congressional Medal of Honor to one enlisted man of the Navy and the Secretary of the Navy has awarded the Navy Cross to another for heroism during an attack by Japanese planes on the Naval Air Station at Kaneohe Bay, Honolulu, on Dec. 7, the Navy Department announced today.

THE American war effort is probably the greatest and the best that any nation has ever made under anything like similar circumstances. Yet it still is certainly neither great nor good enough. Complacency would, accordingly, not only be out of order; it could be fataL And James B. Reston is therefore quite properly concerned, in his "Prelude to Victory," with what is wrong, not what is right, with the United States today.

Japan's Battle Line The Japanese carried their war to the American West Coast last week, held tight to their grasp on the westernmost of Alaska's Aleutian Islands and fought bloody battles in China. In actions spread 6,000 miles apart, they sought two objectives: to establish a land route to Singapore around the American submarines harassing them in the China Sea, and to capture bases from which air raids might be launched on their fragile cities.

WITH THE BRITISH EIGHTH ARMY, Matruh, Egypt, June 26 (Delayed) (U.P.) -- Strong enemy aerial bombardment and a stab by tanks to within five miles of Matruh indicated tonight that General Field Marshal Erwin Rommel was attempting to manoeuvre the British Eighth Army into an unfavorable position for the imminent Battle of Egypt.

COLUMBIA, Mo., June 27 -- A new division of instruction and research dealing with problems of the home and family living will be inaugurated at Stephens College with the opening of the autumn term in September, it was announced today by President James Madison Wood.

WELLINGTON, New Zealand, June 27 -- The Allies should get on with the task of winning the war and spend less time studying the post-war organization of a world in which conflict remains, Brig. Gen Patrick J. Hurley, United States Minister, said at a public reception in Christchurch today.

OTTAWA, June 27 -- While many future difficulties are foreseen, more than six months' successful administration of its all-over price ceiling by the Canadian Wartime Prices and Trade Board has yielded invaluable experience that will enable it to handle future problems with "increasing confidence and effectiveness," according to a review issued by the board.

WASHINGTON, June 27 -- The American B-25 bombers that carried out the daring surprise attack on Tokyo and other Japanese objectives last April 18 were equipped with improvised bombsights that cost about 20 cents each.

SANTIAGO, Chile, June 27 -- Unless Axis powers attack a ship belonging to a South American nation in the Pacific between the Panama Canal and Cape Horn, or attack the West Coast of South America, including the Panama Canal, or make attacks within the territory or national waters of Chile, the government will maintain its present position of "nonbelligerency" regardless of what happens in the Atlantic or outside specified zones in the Pacific.
GIRARD, Ohio, June 27 -- Determined to retain his Mahoning open golf title, Clayton Heafner of Durham, N.C., fired into a three-way tie at 131 today with Lloyd Mangrum and E.J. (Dutch) Harrison.

WITH the advent of Summer and the vacation season, trade volume has picked up from its recent recession but dollar sales continue to run below the percentage of gain which would be yielded by the increase in prices over the year.

Ten thousand WPA workers, or more than one-fifth of all those employed in this city, are scheduled for dismissal in the next two weeks, it was learned yesterday. The cut in the present work force of 47,468 is called for in plans made in anticipation of the passage by Congress of a bill providing $336,000,000 for Federal work relief in the fiscal year beginning Wednesday.

Drastic revision in the merchandising policies of the liquor industry would be inevitable under tax increases on alcoholic beverages contained in the new proposals just approved by the House Ways and Means Committee, it was declared in the trade yesterday.

From France comes word that a stamp has been released to mark the tenth anniversary of the death of Paul Marie Theodore Vincent d'lndy (1851-1932), composer, and that another item is being issued to commemorate the centenary of the birth of Jules Frederic Massenet (1842-1912), composer.

BERKELEY, Calif., June 27 -- The University of California, like most other institutions of higher education in the United States, has been endeavoring to gear its work as closely as possible with the war movement of the nation. It has been in the van of those who have placed men and facilities at the disposal of the government.

THE title of Anne Brooks's new novel, to be published in August by Morrow, is "Hang My Heart." Miss Brooks says that she took the title from a line in the old song, "There Is a Tavern in the Town." The line, as Miss Brooks heard it, reads, "I'll hang my heart on a weeping willow tree."

Pressure on the securities industry has not been relaxed in the first half of 1942. Brokerage operations have been almost uniformly unprofitable, for stock market volume has been the smallest since 1914, when the New York Stock Exchange was closed for almost five months.

WASHINGTON, June 27 -- American citizens held as prisoners of war by the Japanese will benefit from a $50,000 fund made available by the Catholic Bishops War Emergency and Relief Committee, it was announced today. Not alone Catholics but "Americans of whatever religious beliefs" will be included in the fund that will be distributed immediately through the Vatican.

"MR. GARDENIA JONES," a short subject produced by Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer, to assist the USO in its fund-raising campaign, may be withdrawn from further circulation unless the War Department modifies its objections to the film.

THE story of Arthur Lubin is the paradoxical pilgrimage of a chap who started out to entertain highbrows exclusively and wound up by being a popular success with brows of all elevations. Mr. Lubin, who has won laurel chaplets for his resurrection of the slapstick in five successive Abbott and Costello comedies, used to act and direct in the Little Theatres of California and New York.
Overpessimism about our war program as a consequence of the loss of Libya was deplored by rabbis in sermons here yesterday.

Despite the serious tonnage losses off the Atlantic Coast, in the Caribbean and the Gulf of Mexico, the shipping experts of the United Nations are keeping waraid materials moving overseas at a satisfactory rate, it was disclosed here last week.
Early in a Sunday evening in the Summer of 1950, perhaps sooner, Mr. Smith may turn to Mrs. Smith and say:

In a series issued to commemorate the sesquicentennial of the founding of the National Museum in Stockholm, Sweden introduces two eighteenth-century figures to philately's expanding gallery. They are Gustavus III (1746-92), sovereign, dramatist and patron of arts, on a 20-ore red, and Count Karl Gustaf Tessin (1695-1770), statesman, architect, writer, on a 408 olive.

BERLIN, June 27 (From Berlin broadcasts recorded by The Associated Press) -- German and Rumanian troops have captured more Soviet positions and pillboxes on the Sevastopol front, the German High Command said today.

WASHINGTON, June 27 -- A tremendous further expansion in aerial striking power of the Army appeared assured of Congressional approval today when the Senate Appropriations Committee, unanimously endorsed a $42,820,000,000 Military Supply Bill carrying funds for 23,550 new warplanes.

ADIRONDACK MOUNTAINS -- With the Office of Defense Transportation urging vacations near home, indications are that the Adirondack-Lake Champlain region, six to seven hours' traveling time from New York City by bus or train, with over 10,000 square miles of playlands, will be attracting a great many Easterners this Summer.

Charles Stolof, who was convicted of extortion while serving as secretary-treasurer of District Council 18 of the Brotherhood of Partners, Decorators and Paperhangers seven years ago, was returned to office last night in an election supervised by the Honest Ballot Association.

AFTER a great deal of manoeuvring and headaches on the part of those directly involved in the transactions, and considerable criticism, by no means undeserved, of features of Metropolitan Opera policy of many seasons, the admirable and definitive step has been taken to reduce the prices of seats to subscriber of next season from a 57 to a $5 top.

MOSCOW, June 27 -- Though yielding ground slowly in fierce rear-guard fighting, Marshal Semyon Timoshenko has prevented the Germans from taking immediate or spectacular advantage of the capture of Kupyansk.

TERRE HAUTE, Ind., June 27 -- A new set of basic plans for the operation of Indiana State Teachers College during the war and in the post-war period was outlined this week by President Ralph N. Tirey at a meeting of executives of leading teachers' colleges of the Middle West held at Clear Lake Camp, Dowling, Mich.

RELATIVELY few scribes have enjoyed a greater thrill than came to Mr. Flannery, who awoke to find himself catapulted suddenly out of a Middle Western radio station into a warring Europe he had never previously seen, and charged with the task of telling a vast radio audience as much of what was going on in Berlin as circumstances and censorship would permit.

The initial step has been taken to break up the log jam which recently has been holding up private building of defense housing so tightly as to bring it almost to a standstill, according to Herbert U. Nelson, executive vice president of the National Association of Real Estate Boards.

With wholesalers' stocks rapidly becoming depleted in many lines because of inability to do business under the March price ceilings, the food trades are anxiously watching the national food advisory committee formed last week to work with the Office of Price Administration in the solution of outstanding problems.

WASHINGTON, June 27 (AP) -- The State Department made puplic today the names of 420 more American citizens who will be returned to this country from Japanese-controlled territory in exchange for Japanese nationals en route to their homes from this country.

NEW Year's Eve, 1941: In a honkytonk somewhere in Louisiana a juke box is imploring a drunken crowd of soldiers to remember Pearl Harbor. Here, enjoying a last revel before San Francisco and embarkation, is "Private Peter Garth Lafavor of the new American Army.

LONDON, June 27 -- London's devastated East End, with its large areas of bomb-shattered houses, has become a battle school for the British Army. Amid surroundings exactly like those in an enemy town blasted by artillery fire and bombed from the air, soldiers demonstrated today what to do and what not to do when occupying a town still containing remnants of defending forces.

ALEXANDRIA, Egypt, June 27 (AP) -- With British submarines blasting away at Axis supply vessels, it was learned unofficially today that not a single enemy convoy had reached the important Libyan base of Bengazi in the past fortnight.

LONDON, June 27 -- Britain's price stabilization system has reached a critical stage. The new award of wages for coal miners is the first major example of the government refusing a subsidy. The entire cost of the increase in wages is to be passed on to the consumers, although the government is taking steps to prevent an increase in the costs of living.

DETROIT, June 27 -- Members of the National Association of Building Owners and Managers are returning to their homes in all parts of the country from their annual convention here taking with them a sobering picture of the outlook for their business despite the cheering news of a reduction in office building vacancies shown by their national Spring survey.

ATLANTA, June 27 -- This war's first major expeditionary force of United States marines has landed at a South Pacific port apparently equipped for offensive landing in that theatre of war. The far-off arrival of "transports swarming with marines" was revealed here today by Major Meigs O. Frost, Southern public relations chief for the Marine Corps.

DUE to the lack of proper education, there is a common misconception, prevalent not only among laymen but also among many in the profession, that excellent singing or speaking voices are golden gifts from heaven, and that the voices made of baser metals must of necessity be doomed to oblivion or, at best, mediocrity.

The shape of a new and liberated France, dominated neither by the men of Vichy nor by the men who lost the battle in 1940, appears in a declaration issued in London by General Charles de Gaulle. An exiled Frenchman, deprived of his former rank, stripped of his property, condemned to death by a Vichy-controlled court-martial, speaks well and bravely for France.

A partial list of contributions made to the Russian War Relief at last Monday's rally in Madison Square Garden was released for publication yesterday. More than $500,000 was received toward the nation-wide goal of $6,000,000.

CHUNGKING, China, June 27 -- Hundreds of thousands of Chinese civilians and soldiers have benefited either directly or indirectly through appropriations from the United China Relief Fund, which is financing a number of useful and urgently needed projects.

SHORTAGE of radiomen is a war-production problem that seems to grow ever more acute. The current pressing need, it seems, is not for more theorists and engineers, whose habitat is the laboratory, but for that peculiar variety of "expert" known as the practical radioman -- adept with the Morse code, who can splice a cable under fire in tank, airplane or submarine and do it quickly.

WASHINGTON, June 27 -- The writing of a tax bill such as the present huge measure, estimated to produce $5,924,000,000 in new revenue, involves a multitude of duties on the part of the Ways and Means Committeemen and touches the political and economic sides of many questions important to the Congressmen and their constituents.
Perhaps insufficient attention has been given to a program for the restoration of Atlantic salmon by the fishing, fraternity at large. It is no easy problem at best.

Annuals that cling close to the ground or grow in low mounds are often handy as a ground cover in sunny places, as an edging for a walk or along the lawn to save clipping. Portulaca is the simplest annual of this type, covering a large sunny area, even where soil is poor.

THE introduction written by that most Cornish of Cornishmen, Sir Arthur Quiller-Couch, for this collection of Charles Lee's delectable tales makes any discussion of the "Cornishness" of these little masterpieces wholly irrelevant.

LONDON, June 27 -- Ernest Bramah Smith, who under the name Ernest Bramah wrote the "Kai Lung" and "Max Carrados" books, died yesterday in Somerset at the age of 74. The life of the writer of detective fiction was somewhat of a mystery, as he lived in great seclusion, his widow even asking suppression of the place of death.

With every city in the United State seeking out the junkman and handing over to him its old hot-water bottles dilapidated doormats and threadbare tires, the importance of what technologists call "reclaimed rubber" is driver home. All this is no new story to the manufacturer of rubber articles.

THE new book by the author of "Men and Politics" begins with the narrative of a wartime journey to England and ends with an examination of the "shape of the peace to come." And this content and order are characteristic: Louis Fischer is first an alert reporter; beyond that he is a man of liberal-minded meditation upon the need and nature of the good life.
ST. LOUIS, June 27 (AP) -- Whatever they do the rest of the year, the Browns usually come through with a victory on stockholders' day.
To obtain some new rose plants from old ones that had grown on the place for a long time, the writer tried, with complete success, a method of propagating not frequently used.
