"ROTE IN MY HART": In an old unpainted cabin at the edge of a wood near Cedar Grove, Ala., lives Mrs. Sudie Dison, who, with the help of her ailing husband, runs a little farm. To her, as well as to many another farmer, went an appeal from the Farm Security Administration for more food production.

How the German Government recruited its spies from among German waiters, cooks and odd-job men, some of whom had been in the United States for ten and twenty years, and all of whom had been made Nazi sympathisers by German-American Bund activity, was disclosed in biographies of the eight members of the saboteur ring now in custody, which were released by J. Edgar Hoover, director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation.
CLEVELAND, June 27 -- Kendall Chase, pitching one-hit ball for seven innings and slamming a triple in his own behalf, today gave the Red Sox their second straight victory over the Indians, 6 to 3.

A record in community gardening, more vital today than when the project was started twenty-six years ago, has been set by the Jackson Heights Garden Club. Here war gardening in 1917, victory gardening in 1942, and just plain gardening in all the years between have all been taken in their stride by citified people determined to have gardens.

GRAND RAPIDS, Mich., June 27 (AP) -- New furniture creations will yield top interest to speculation about the future of their industry when dealers from all parts of the country gather here tomorrow for the opening of the Summer furniture market of the Grand Rapids Furniture Exposition Association.

RICHMOND, Va., June 27 (AP) -- Nineteen prominent Virginians sent to Governor Darden today a petition for clemency on behalf of Odell Waller, citing these five factors which they said should be taken into consideration:

THE Ballet Russe de Monte Carlo, which is now between two "festival series" engagements at the Lewisohn Stadium, is planning considerable repertory activity for next season. Seven new works are in the offing and four of them are definitely promised for the New York season in the Fall.

NOROTON, Conn., June 27 -- It was no ball game as far as the opening race in the Noroton Yacht Club's sixth annual Star Class race week was concerned today. After using up two and a half hours of the three-hour time limit trying to cover the opening windward leg, the race committee called the event off.

WASHINGTON, June 27 -- Reduction in the number of local and long-distance telephone calls, as a war necessity, has been urged by the Board of War Communications in letters to all telephone companies and to the heads of governmental agencies.

Ol' Dan'l Boone Davis, lean veteran sharpshooter of Leo Durocher's pitching corps, went into the ninth inning against the Reds at Ebbets Field yesterday with a two-hit shut-out in his grasp. A few minutes later the game had exploded in his face, the detonating power being supplied by Ray Lamanno's three-run homer which sent the Dodgers tumbling to defeat, 3 -- 1.
JUST for the fun of it, this baffled bystander took the latest set of big league baseball averages exposed to view and began to shift the columns around a bit.

Full plans for the American may not be completed for another Yacht Club's cruise, which has been set definitely for Aug. 10, two weeks. It has been decided to hold four short runs in Long Island Sound, but the stopping places will not be determined until the gas rationing system is settled, for one thing.

One hundred and fifty representatives of various organizations met yesterday afternoon at the Hotel Commodore to participate in the New York Conference for Mobilization of Foreign Born for Victory in 1942. The conference was sponsored by the American Committee for Protection of Foreign Born.

PHILADELPHIA, June 27 -- A registration statement covering the proposed issuance of 8,000 shares of $5.50 cumulative preferred stock, Series B, with warrants attached for the purchase of common stock, series of 1937, and of 97,200 shares of no-par common stock was filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission by the Mead Corporation.
Despite the drastic building restrictions due to war conditions several New Jersey developers in Bergen County communities are continuing home construction with a reasonable degree of activity.

For more than ten years the trophies given at championship contract bridge contests have been of sterling silver. According to a resolution adopted last Sunday by the executive committee of the American Contract Bridge League, the awarding of such trophies will soon be eliminated, or at least be sharply curtailed, "for the duration."

Two groups of saboteurs, highly trained by direction of the German High Command at a special school for sabotage near Berlin, carrying cases of powerful explosives and nearly $150,000 in cash, were landed on the Long Island and the Florida coasts from submarines in the last fortnight with orders to blow up certain key plants and to cause panics in large cities, it was disclosed last night.

PHILADELPHIA, June 27 -- John V. Loughney, retired banker and Supreme Master of the Fourth Degree, Knights of Columbus, died yesterday at his home in Drexel Hill after an illness of three weeks. His age was 79.

ASBURY PARK, N.J. -- The newly constructed $500,000 Monte Carlo Beach and Cabana Club on the beach front here, which had its official opening yesterday, will usher in a season of water shows and other aquatic events, beginning tomorrow.

THE average person who is not a student of history is likely to have only a confused impression of events of the past, even of the comparatively recent past. The picture in his mind is made up of fragments -- newspaper reports, word-of-mouth accounts of persons who took part in those events, and rumors whose source can seldom be traced.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, June 27 -- Agreement among students and faculty at Skidmore College that the old-fashioned town meeting type of discussion is the best method to clarify issues and cultivate intelligent public opinion about the war, resulted in a vote to inaugurate weekly group discussions as a part of the regular college program next year.

PHILADELPHIA, June 27 -- A registration statement providing for the issuance of voting trust certificates covering 566,551 shares of capital stock, $1 par value, of the Brewster Aeronautical Corporation was filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission by Arthur A. Ballantine, James G. Blaine and C.A. Van Dusen, trustees.

A program for wartime travel on the railroads has been mapped and is now being put into effect gradually. The running time of a number of fast trains will be lengthened and day coaches included in the "consist" of all trains where practicable.

THE WPA Music Project has undergone changes since it became the music division of the New York City WPA War Services two months ago. Its rolls have been pared to 516, all services not related to the war effort have been eliminated, and it has been reorganized so that it now consists of eighteen musical units which provide music for service men and war workers.

According to the monthly survey of open-market sales in Manhattan by the Real Estate Board of New York, dealing in the month of May showed a slight decline both in number of transactions and dollar volume than for the same month in 1939, 1940 and 1941.
NEW YORK Mr. and Mrs. Robert Emmet, who were at the Pierre for the Winter and Spring, have gone to Lake Champlain.

It is quite possible that Frank Francis Frisch, the first of all the Fordham Flashes, who now operates as the harried skipper of the careening Pirates, would have preferred to play the Giants along more scientific lines yesterday as they clashed in the second game of their current series at the Polo Grounds.

WHITE MOUNTAINS, N.H. -- Red Cross and war-relief work will be features at all leading resorts this season, with additional events, including social activities, in which the sale of war bonds and savings stamps will figure. Silver teas and other affairs for United China Relief and for the Army and Navy are in prospect.

The difficulties faced by local insurance agents and brokers in getting War Damage Corporation insurance for their property-owning clients on the books prior to midnight Tuesday were eliminated in part yesterday by telegrams sent out late Friday to insurance companies and departments throughout the country allowing the companies to provide the protection temporarily by declarations drawn up in the simplest form.

LONDON, June 27 -- With preparations of the British Royal Air Force about complete for continuing -- or rather, doubling in power -- its attacks against Germany, such as that on Thursday night, which left still-smoking ruins at Bremen, authoritative sources here directed attention today to the important part predicted for the United States Army Air Forces in the offensive over Europe.

WASHINGTON, June 27 -- The following foreign service changes since June 20 were announced today by the State Department: Wainwright Abbott of Pittsburgh, consul at Suva, Fiji Islands, assigned consul general there.

SARANAC INN, N.Y., June 27 -- Many persons prominent in society in New York and other cities and communities of Eastern States have opened their Summer homes here for the season, and more are expected next week for the Independence Day week-end.

On the list of flowers well loved for years by gardeners the violas have a high rating. Their ready adaptation to average garden conditions and the ease with which they may be grown make them choice subjects for any garden, large or small.

THE third part of Dr. Rene Kraus's new and voluminous work would serve as a very useful and timely volume in itself. Here in about 200 pages the author has gathered together all the information that a diligent journalist, knowing his field, could possibly find today about Europe.

DETROIT, June 27 -- The architects of America, facing trying times and uncertain employment because of the war, believe that peace will bring an era of readjustment in which their services and talents may be put to a handsome use in changing the pattern of the nation's economic and social life.

The steady influx of former residents of other cities into Manhattan apartments has received added impetus by the recent removal to New York of the national headquarters of the American Red Cross, according to the J.H. Taylor Management Corporation.

BOSTON, June 27 -- The Suffolk Downs track record for five furlongs was broken today by John L. Sullivan's Hygrohour, who won the $7,500 Myles Standish Stakes for juvenile colts and geldings in 58 2-5 seconds.

Retail trade here was rather spotty last week, although sales volume improved during the last few days. Resumption of delivery service aided department store trade, which had slipped off sharply during the early part of the week.

The cases undertaken by the detective firm of Cool Lam often turn out to foe something quite different from what the clients have represented them to be. That is because the senior member of the firm, who handles the preliminary negotiations, is in- terested only in the money to be made.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Your editorial "Tankermen" brings to mind an experience in World War I that furnishes an interesting detail to the picture you present. It concerns one Schneider, whom I first met at Fort Slocum.

THIS personal story of a young American who lived and worked for several years in Magnitogorsk, newest and biggest of the industrial towns that were born during the first Five-Year Plan, is intensely interesting for several reasons.

The best and most consistent support offered by the trade in several days yesterday sent active futures contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange into advances that matured into final net gains of 10 to 14 points, just a shade under the day's high marks.

NEWPORT, R.I., June 27 -- The first clambake of the season next Saturday at the Clambake Club, following the annual meeting, will be one of the principal fetes of a holiday week-end serving informally to launch the Summer season here.

Life in France grows steadily more difficult. Shortages increase. There is less coal, less food, less clothing, less of everything that one needs for even, a bare living. Most of the shops are still open but have little to sell. There is no candy, cakes or pastry.

The first and only public museum in America devoted exclusively to sound and hearing, and called Sonorama, has been opened at 570 Fifth Avenue. Included among its gadgets is the "magic trumpet," a ring of red plastic material handed out at the door. As the sightseer wanders through the museum, signals tell him when to put the trumpet to his ear.

HANOVER, Mass., June 27 -- Discovery of 3,000,000 pounds of scrap rubber, which transformed this normally quiet, rural community into a "boom town reminiscent of the gold rush days," was reported today by the Massachusetts Salvage Committee.

MANY of the Summer art colonies have already begun their seasonal activities; others will open soon. Among the current shows is one of paintings and sculpture, selected by a jury, at the Woodstock Artists Association, Woodstock, N.Y., to continue through July 22.

WASHINGTON, June 27 -- The shocking news from Tobruk and Sevastopol in recent days came at such a time as almost to obscure new developments which illustrate the gravity of war much nearer home, in waters that wash both the Eastern and the Western shores of the United States.

The Horticultural Society of New York announces that it will hold a mid-Summer flower show at 598 Madison Avenue on Aug. 12 and 13 in the interest of the Victory Garden Harvest Show movement and for the benefit of Army Emergency and Navy Relief organizations.

With collections of rubber scrap in the metropolitan area totaling 400 tons at noon yesterday, Eugene F. McCabe, local chairman of the petroleum industry's salvage committee, forecast that the day's intake, when completed, would be the largest for any day since the campaign started.

TOKYO, June 27 (From Japanese broadcasts recorded by The Associated Press) -- A Domei dispatch date-lined "Aboard a Japanese Warship on Lake Poyang" said today that Japanese riflemen and sailors landed yesterday at Jaochow, on the eastern lake shore, and occupied the city.

Undertaking a gigantic selling job for the nation, more than 1,000,000 retailers throughout the country will be ready on Wednesday to begin their unprecedented "Retailers for Victory" campaign for the sale of war bonds and stamps.

CHICAGO, June 27 -- The White Sox were among the casualties today as the Yankees resumed hostilities at Comiskey Park before a gathering of 6,068 customers. But the team itself was not the only casualty.

A twelfth century monastery, brought to this country from Spain at a cost of $500,000, is one of the works of art to be offered for sale tomorrow at Gimbel Brothers store, in the further disposal of the collection of William Randolph Hearst, which has been on display during the current season.

AN unusual setting, a grim and businesslike hero, an ingenious plot and a light touch with the love story make this thriller very satisfactory reading. It is told with cool detachment, even in the midst of hair-raising dangers and fiendish schemings, with excellent effect.

LONDON, June 27 (AP) -- German military leaders are urging Reichsfuehrer Hitler to occupy all France to meet the growing threat of an Allied attempt to establish a second front in Western Europe, an unusually well-informed foreign source declared today.

TO THE EDITOR: As a Briton in whose veins flows the blood of one who signed the Declaration of Independence, I would like to comment on Raymond Daniell's article ''Portrait of John Bull" which appeared in THE TIMES Magazine of June 14.

MONTICELLO -- Rationing of tires and gasoline has caused the cancellation of the public Fourth of July picnic that has been held uninterruptedly for forty-two years by members of the Narrowsburg Fire Department. However, the Independence Day celebration of the community of Roscoe, also an attraction for vacationists, will be conducted as usual.

DETROIT, June 27 (AP) -- The automobile manufacturers turned armorers for all the allied nations are once more raising their production sights. On the basis of present activities the year-end goal of a $14,000,000,000 annual production level will be reached weeks ahead of that date.

As New York City and the rest of the Atlantic seaboard felt over a second week-end the paralyzing effects of the gasoline drought, spokesmen for filling stations and garages complained yesterday that only the major suppliers would benefit from the 2 1/2-cent increase in gasoline prices allowed by Price Administrator Leon Henderson.

LOCUST VALLEY, L.I., June 27 -- All dirt roads and bridle paths as well as surfaced highways will lead to the Piping Rock show grounds on July 4, when members of society in horse-drawn vehicles of many styles, on saddles and by motor from distant points, will attend the Army-Navy benefit race meeting of the United Hunts Racing Association at the Piping Rock Club.

A Greek word meaning "flame" gave us the term "phlox'' -- the name of one of our choicest groups of cultivated plants. Nobody who has ever seen one of the boldly handsome tall border phloxes needs to be reminded of the aptness of the name.

THE first anniversary of the German, drive into Russia found the Soviet radio stronger by far than in June, 1941. In addition to recent powerful Moscow transmitters, a giant beam now appears early in the morning near 15.75 megacycles, a spot hitherto unused for short-wave broadcasting.

HOLLYWOOD. DR. CORYDON M. WASSELL, Naval Medical Corps hero of the Battle of Java, who has arrived in Hollywood to work with Cecil B. De Mille and James Hilton on Paramount's projected film about his exploits, was unperturbed this week after seven days' association with cinematic genius.

With the disclosure last week that 82 per cent of the colleges and universities of this country do not require the study of United States history for the undergraduate degree, many educators voiced the belief that more attention should be paid to this important subject.
An exclusive service club for merchant seamen, the first of its kind established on Staten Island, was opened yesterday in a store donated for the cause at 36 Victory Boulevard, in Tompkinsville.

With the volume of business the second smallest for a two-hour session in more than a year, the stock market closed yesterday about in balance after an easier opening had lost force and gave way to a moderately firm closing. Transfers on the Stock Exchange totaled 113,290 shares, against 127,060 shares for the previous Saturday.

Along the hundred-mile stretch of New Jersey's seafront the vanguard of an army of Summer pleasure hunters is moving, this week-end, across the threshold of another season of outdoor recreation and social activity. TOWARD the end of the engrossing factual record which bears the subtitle "The Story of American Tropical Medicine," Charles Morrow Wilson sums up the theme of his book and makes plain the meaning of its title.

CARTHAGE, Ill., June 27 -- Hancock and Adams are the two westernmost counties of Illinois, caught in the embrace of the Mississippi as it sweeps in a broad curve south of the Keokuk Dam down to the Mark Twain country about Hannibal, Mo.

PITTSFIELD, Mass. -- Pittsfield is to have an old-fashioned Independence Day parade next Saturday with eight bands and drum corps, and with military, naval and civilian organizations taking part. There will be a ragshag feature for children.

With the resumption of the tanker movement, the oil supply situation on the Eastern seaboard has shown some improvement in the last month. After declining steadily since Jan. 15, when submarines became active off the Atlantic Coast, oil stocks in the East Coast territory began to increase around May 15, which coincided with the decision of the Navy to convoy tankers up the Atlantic Coast.

DETROIT, June 27 (AP) -- Roger Cramer lashed a double off Rookie Dick Fowler with two out in the thirteenth inning today to score Billy Hitchcock from first base and give the Tigers a 6-5 victory over the Athletics. It was the fifth straight defeat for the seventh place Philadelphians.

A pair of strong soccer teams will collide at Starlight Park today in the feature game of a doubleheader. The groups are the New York All-Stars and the pick of the German-American League. Mayor La Guardia's letter warning 3-A men that failure to enroll in the City Patrol Corps would result in "their defense status with the city's protective forces" being reported to their local draft boards produced exceptional results yesterday when it was learned that 90 per cent of the 7,000 men to whom it was mailed had applied for enrollment in the corps.
WASHINGTON, June 27 -- Gasoline will cost Eastern motorists 2 1/2 cents a gallon more beginning Monday.

OF the 900-odd commercially licensed broadcasting stations in the United States, some 160 broadcast in foreign tongues to fourteen million foreign-born and first-generation Americans, an estimated three millon of whom neither speak nor understand English.

CHICAGO, June 27 (AP) -- Miss Betty Jameson, a grand champion, won the Women's Western open golf title today. The San Antonio girl triumphed over 17-year-old Miss Phyllis Otto of Atlantic, Iowa, 9 and 7, in the scheduled thirty-sixhole final at the Elmhurst Country Club.

LONDON, June 27 -- Sunburned and beaming over a half-smoked cigar, Prime Minister Winston Churchill was greeted this afternoon at Euston station by his family, members of his Cabinet and diplomats as a small crowd cheered.

PRESIDENT ROOSEVELT has banished the Hitler pincushion -- the rear end for pins -- from his office desk. It appeared there for only a day or two. He lets a caricature bust of Winston Churchill remain, however, along with so many other gadgets that hardly any room is left on the desk top for writing.

THE publishers class this as one in their series of Books for the Imagination. And fairly so. It is not contemporary fiction, nor historical novelizing, nor novelized reporting, but out-and-out fantasy. It picks up its war-weary hero from this crazy world and transports him to a world quite as crazy, topsy-turvy and bewildered, but frankly fey.

Three city departments and local trade unions are scouring the five boroughs for day-care centers for children. Dr. Leona Baumgartner of the Department of Health invites information from the public concerning day-care units in any neighborhood.

With shipments of steel for war purposes undisclosed because of the censorship, the annual report of the American Iron and Steel Institute on steel shipments to consuming industries shows that the construction industry was the largest consumer in 1941, taking 8,127,889 net tons of finished steel products for highways, railways, buildings and other construction.

WITH THE ATLANTIC FLEET, June 18 (AP) (Delayed) -- The blazing courage of the crew of the torpedoed little seaplane tender Gannet was described today by the skipper of the vessel, who, living up to ancient tradition, went down with his ship -- but lived to tell the tale.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: It is perfectly correct in speaking to an audience trained in patent law to speak of Alexander Graham Bell's telephone as a basic invention, but the word "basic" is likely to mislead most people. The so-called basic patent of Bell was his 1876 patent, which covered producing an undulating electric current by sounds and causing that current to reproduce the sounds.
CHICAGO, June 27 (AP) -- A son of the famed Blue Larkspur named Best Seller, owned by Robert Dienst and John Gailbraith of Columbus, Ohio, won the $7,500 added Equipoise mile at Arlington Park today.

Recent reports from Sweden telling of unrest and executions within Germany have a new note of significance for the opponents of the Nazi regime. They indicate that the measures of repression which have become routine in the occupied nations of Europe are now being applied, if as yet only in small measure, to citizens of the Reich itself.

WASHINGTON -- By next Wednesday about 30,000,000 American automobile owners are required to have on the windshields of their cars a $5 Federal stamp which will indicate that they have paid a "use" tax for their cars for the year ending June 30, 1943.
An outstanding field is announced for the thirteenth annual New York State women's golf championship which will be held at the Lake Placid Club, starting on July 6 and continuing through July 11.

MATRUH, Egypt, June 27 (U.P.) -- Two young British lieutenants revealed today that they had escaped after the fall of Tobruk by joining a German motor convoy in an Imperial Command Staff car and riding comfortably into Egypt.
Editor The New York Times Book Review: I hope you will give me some space in your letter columns for a brief comment on Elliot V. Bell's review of Carl Dreher's "Coming Showdown" on May 31.
BOSTON, June 27 (AP) -- Al Javery, with only forty-eight hours' rest, pitched his second shut-out in eight days today as the Braves beat the Cubs, 4 to 0.

CHAUTAUQUA -- Next Sunday the gates of historic Chautauqua institution in the hills of Western New York will swing open for the sixty-ninth annual assembly. The program of symphonies, sermons and Summer school will continue until the gates close, following a joint recital by Helen Jepson and John Gurney on Aug. 29.

Contending that price ceilings and inventory control can be only supplementary to a sound government fiscal and consumer goods policy that is now lacking, Saul Cohn, head of the City Stores Company and former president of the National Retail Dry Goods Association, said in an interview here last week that creation of a Civilian Production Board is vitally needed at this time to avert breakdown of the civilian economy.

Under the sponsorship of the Coordinator of Inter-American Affairs, Alan Fisher, camera club lecturer and writer on photography, on a six-month leave as PM staff photographer, starts the first week in July on a comprehensive picture-making tour of nine South American countries.

The extent to which the FHA program, now in its eighth year, has played a vital role in wartime as well as in peacetime in stimulating private home financing and home building along lines important to the national welfare is depicted by Federal Housing Commissioner Abner H. Ferguson.

NEWARK, N.J., June 27 -- A surprisingly strong Warinanco A. C. team of Elizabeth put on the steam today to tie the powerful Asbury Park A.C., defending team, in the New Jersey A.A.U. senior track and field championships.

Furniture is meeting its own wave of the future in a world no longer to any degree static. In the New York Midsummer Furniture Show, held at the Furniture Exchange Building, 206 Lexington Avenue, and open only to store buyers, a pre-view of styles in home-making for the coming year is offered.

A yardstick for measuring all building operations in the Northeastern States for the duration of the war has been presented to all public and private agencies and individuals contemplating construction programs by regional director John M. Gallagher of the Federal Works Agency.

NEW ORLEANS, June 27 (U.P.) -- Ted Schroeder, Stanford University student, and the nation's top-ranking amateur, won the singles championship of the fifty-eighth national intercollegiate tennis tournament today by defeating Larry Dee, a team-mate.

POCONO MOUNTAINS, Pa. -- Independence Day week-end will find the Pocono resort launched on what promises to be one of their most successful Summer seasons. Features of the holiday schedule are Fourth of July observances, golf and tennis tournaments and dances.

An Axis submarine was sent to the bottom off the coast of Cuba, with its crew and its load of torpedoes, by the five-man Navy gun crew of a United States sugar ship, it was revealed yesterday at a Florida port.

FORT JACKSON, S.C., June 24 (Delayed) (AP) -- Winston Churchill saw a spectacular display of America's expanding might today at the Army's largest infantry training post, where crack parachute troops plummeted from the sky by the hundred and live ammunition from big fields guns whistled directly over his head and burst near enough for him to feel the jar and concussion.

ONE of the most destructive attacks on our nation last year was not made by a foreign enemy. The attack came from within, and left in its wake 102,500 dead -- more than twice the 49,475 killed in the ranks of the A.E.F. during the First World War. Moreover, it left 350,000 persons permanently disabled and inflicted 9,000,000 other lesser casualties.

Declines in loans and discounts and substantial increases in holdings of United States Government securities will feature the mid-year statements of condition by banks which will appear in the latter part of this week. It is to be expected that some, but by no means all, of the Wall Street banks will show moderate gains over the first quarter of the year in deposits and in total resources.

The Rev. Dr. J. Henry Carpenter, who has been associated with cooperative movements in the United States, Newfoundland and Mexico, will leave soon for China to help that nation's 2,400 industrial cooperatives step up their output of products for carrying on the war and maintaining the national economy, it was announced yesterday by United China Relief, 1790 Broadway.

PHILADELPHIA, June 27 -- In addition to becoming the seat of the Securities and Exchange Commission, this city, through the Third Federal Circuit Court of Appeals, has become the battleground for three litigations of tremendous interest to the commission and to the utility holding companies of the nation.

GARDEN CITY, L.I., June 27 -- Proof that no golf match is won until the last putt is holed was again furnished today when Vincent Raskopf of the Garden City Country Club annexed the Long Island junior championship.

THE Summer concerts at Ravinia Park will open Tuesday night. Dimitri Mitropolous will make his initial Ravinia appearance on that evening in a program to be given with the assistance of the fifty sailors of the Great Lakes Naval Training Station Glee Club, Lieut. Comdr. Hjalmer Hanson director.

LONDON, June 27 -- Another British Army has met defeat. The story follows the familiar pattern of official optimism building up to a letdown. It began in Norway, was continued through Dunkerque and repeated at Hong Kong and Singapore and in Burma.

THE story of the murder of Amyas Crale is apparently quite simple. His wife, Caroline, was tried, convicted and sentenced to life imprisonment, and she died in prison soon after. But that was sixteen years ago.

Wider training of women in the specialized work of mass feeding is shortly to begin in local communities as the result of the completion of a course at the New York State College of Home Economics at Cornell University. Sixty key women from nineteen up-State counties who attended are now prepared to train other women in cooking and serving in quantities, should it become necessary to feed war evacuees.

BEDFORD HILLS, N.Y., June 27 -- Mr. and Mrs. Medley G. Whelpley gave a dinner dance last night at Medwel Farm, their Summer home here, for their daughter, Miss Harriet Whelpley, who was graduated recently from the Westover School.

LONDON, June 27 -- General Field Marshal Erwin Rommel's Axis war machine was reported tonight to be slowly rolling toward a standstill in front of the British line that extends from Matruh, Egypt, to a point some forty miles inland.

PHILADELPHIA, June 27 (AP) -- A team nine and one-half games off the pace should give any one the right to sing the blues, but not Billy Southworth, for, says the fidgety manager of the Cardinals, "show me any pitching staff in either league that equals ours."

FROM Monday through Friday this week Fritz Reiner will appear as guest conductor of the Stadium Concerts. On the opening night of his engagement he will have as his soloist Josef Hofmann, who will play the Beethoven "Emperor" concerto.

CHARLESTON, W.Va., June 27 (U.P.) -- About 60,000 miners in three large bituminous coal producing States began ten-day vacations today in protest over the refusal by the Southern Coal Producers Association to rebate fines assessed against miners for a sympathy strike last November.

Manhattan, Bronx and Richmond senior high schools didn't get a look-in as regards the capturing of city P.S.A.L. outdoor team championships this past season. Of the five outdoor champions crowned, two were Brooklyn schools.
WASHINGTON, June 27 (AP) -- Amateur athletes in the Army hereafter may compete with professionals in the service in Army-sponsored sports without endangering their amateur status.

BEDFORD HILLS, N.Y., June 27 -- Mr. and Mrs. Medley G. Whelpley gave a dinner dance last night at Medwel Farm, their Summer home here, for their daughter, Miss Harriet Whelpley, who was graduated recently from the Westover School.

LONDON, June 27 -- General Field Marshal Erwin Rommel's Axis war machine was reported tonight to be slowly rolling toward a standstill in front of the British line that extends from Matruh, Egypt, to a point some forty miles inland.

PHILADELPHIA, June 27 (AP) -- A team nine and one-half games off the pace should give any one the right to sing the blues, but not Billy Southworth, for, says the fidgety manager of the Cardinals, "show me any pitching staff in either league that equals ours."

FROM Monday through Friday this week Fritz Reiner will appear as guest conductor of the Stadium Concerts. On the opening night of his engagement he will have as his soloist Josef Hofmann, who will play the Beethoven "Emperor" concerto.

Sales of First National Stores, Inc., in the fiscal year ended on March 28 rose 22 per cent to $174,378,932 from $142,680,921 in the previous fiscal year, according to the annual report of Arthur O'Keeffe, president, mailed yesterday to stockholders.

PHILADELPHIA, June 27 -- Frank J. Willard, Receiver of Taxes and a power in Republican politics here for forty years, died of pneumonia last night at his home in South Philadelphia after a long illness. His age was 66. Complications resulting from his illness forced him to break a long rule of appearing at his desk at 8:45 A.M. each day, five days a week, while in public office.

THE Midsummer Chamber Music Festival to be held for the first time this Summer in Mount Kisco, N.Y., will be devoted this year entirely to contemporary chamber music. Three concerts will be presented on Sundays, July 19 and 26 and Aug. 2, at 4 P.M., in the Haussermann Chamber Music Hall, "Apple Trees," Millwood Road.

THE literature of our time -- using the term literature in in its widest sense -- will, in one respect at least, stand apart from that of all preceding periods. For will it not provide the commentator of the future with a richness and variety of source material which have been without parallel?

WASHINGTON, June 27 -- Full civilian control over Army and Navy purchasing was urged today by two members of the Senate Defense Investigating Committee. They said they were apprehensive that the War Production Board might lose this authority in a current reorganization move.

A leaflet intended to act as a guide for workers of social agencies when they come in contact with sub-standard housing conditions has been published by the Community Service Society and the Social Service Housing Committee, a federation, of housing specialists affiliated with public and private welfare agencies.

WHEREVER you live there are nature trails that you can follow. The pursuit of one hobby has led, for example, to the finding of more than a hundred and fifty different minerals in New York City; and there is a college teacher who has a real zoo in a Pennsylvania back yard.

WITH ballet in a new renaissance of popularity and appreciation this is a good time to bring out a life of one of its greatest artists. This step-by-step story of Pavlova's career will undoubtedly be popular with older girls not only for its initial theme but for the wider background it will give to the ballet.

When the scores are made out for war work done by women, a particularly bright record will be entered for those classed as handicapped but whose physical disability has spurred them on to a higher degree of deftness in skills the war industries need.

WASHINGTON. FOR the first time in American history the Army has a voice in the education of American youth. It is a voice yet still and small, and muffled under the title of the War Department's Orientation Course for Military Personnel. But some of the things it says may soon be heard, like a certain musket shot, around the world.

WASHINGTON, June 27 -- Donald M. Nelson, chairman of the War Production Board, appealed today to workers and management to observe the Fourth of July by making it a day of full production. He said that "we dare not have a July 4 holiday in war production."
Baccalaureate addresses fade into memory with the passing of June, but Manhattan steps briskly to the center of the stage. The "tight little isle" is being "promoted."

THE complete program for the six concerts to be given during the first three weeks in August at Tanglewood, near Lenox, Mass., by students of the Berkshire Music Center and assisting artists, under Serge Koussevitzky's direction, will be as follows:

WITH collections extensively rearranged for the duration of the war, and with part of the galleries closed off from the public from Monday to Friday, the Metropolitan Museum is, nevertheless, carrying on a fairly lively program of activities.

ASHEVILLE, N.C. -- The North Carolina Memorial Forest -- where 125,000 trees will stand as living memorials to the 125,000 soldiers North Carolina supplied to the Confederacy -- will be dedicated at exercises set for Sunday, July 12. Josephus Daniels, editor of The Raleigh News and Observer and former United States Ambassador to Mexico, will be the chief speaker.

WASHINGTON, June 27 (AP) -- Four Supreme Court justices denied today at separate times a stay of execution for Odell Waller, the Negro sharecropper of Virginia who is under sentence to die July 2 for murder.

ALBANY, N.Y., June 27 (AP) -- An independent movement to draft Wendell L. Willkie for the Republican nomination for Governor developed in Albany County today under leadership of Chester L. Hawley, county governor of the State Association of Young Republican Clubs.

SOAP TROUBLE -- An antioxidant is used in high-grade toilet and bath soaps to prevent their deterioration by sunlight and long standing. Without this protection soaps become yellow and rancid. The antioxidant heretofore used or this purpose has been an organic compound derived from toluene.

WASHINGTON, June 27 -- A plan proposed by the United Steel Workers of America five weeks ago for a union of labor groups of the United Nations to win the war is making some progress, but has run into two snags which are impeding action.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., June 27 -- Nineteen sterling silver plaques for outstanding journalistic achievements in the last twelve months were awarded by the National Headliners Club at its ninth annual banquet in the Hotel Claridge tonight.

CHUNGKING, June 27 -- It is generally admitted that current expectations of a probably imminent Japanese invasion of Siberia may arise in good measure from wishful thinking in the hope it would make available urgently needed air bases for the United Nations in Siberia.

DETROIT, June 27 -- Henry Ford's action in denying the Federal Housing Authority the right to construct a large war housing project on land he owns near the Willow Run bomber plant has turned into a controversy which may have a broad effect on the national policy with respect to the housing of war workers and their families.

Norman H. Davis, chairman of the American Red Cross, disclosed yesterday that negotiations were pending for the operation of a "mercy ship" in the Pacific Ocean, under supervision of the International Red Cross Committee, to carry food, clothing and other needed articles to United States prisoners of war and civilians interned in Japan and elsewhere in the Far East.
FOR one reason or another, several programs are shifting their broadcast time tomorrow, among them the following:

The continued rise in the volume of "money in circulation" to record levels points to persistent large-scale hoarding of currency in this country. The latest figures place the total amount of money outside the Treasury and the Federal Reserve Banks at more than $12,200,000,000, a rise of $2,741,000,000 in the past twelve months and an increase of about twice that amount in the past two years.

The New York-USO-Joint War Appeal has raised $2,950,000 toward its $4,450,000 goal, it was announced yesterday by Henry C. Brunie, campaign chairman, as United Service Organizations units in all parts of the country and in foreign bases prepared special programs for USO-Children's-Day today.

A statement from anti-Fascist leaders in Rome, just received, reveals that a monarchic-reactionary "compromise" putsch against Mussolini is being prepared, but is being opposed by true anti-Fascists, according to an announcement made yesterday by Count Carlo Sforza, former Italian Foreign Minister and head of the antiFascist Italians in this country.

WASHINGTON, June 27 (AP) -- In a move to put a great fleet of small boats into the war against submarines off the Atlantic and Gulf coasts, the Navy called today for all owners of seagoing craft to volunteer the services of themselves and their vessels.

WASHINGTON, June 27 -- Tire and tube quotas for July were announced today by the Office of Price Administration and, due to seasonal factors, showed an increased allotment in all tire classifications except that of recapped truck tires.

IF the wolf is snuffling at the keyhole -- well, it's possible to make a dish that will keep you going for several days, says M.F.K. Fisher, if you can succeed in borrowing 50 cents. Here, she continues, is exactly how to prepare it.

CHUNGKING, June 27 -- It is generally admitted that current expectations of a probably imminent Japanese invasion of Siberia may arise in good measure from wishful thinking in the hope it would make available urgently needed air bases for the United Nations in Siberia.

DETROIT, June 27 -- Henry Ford's action in denying the Federal Housing Authority the right to construct a large war housing project on land he owns near the Willow Run bomber plant has turned into a controversy which may have a broad effect on the national policy with respect to the housing of war workers and their families.

Norman H. Davis, chairman of the American Red Cross, disclosed yesterday that negotiations were pending for the operation of a "mercy ship" in the Pacific Ocean, under supervision of the International Red Cross Committee, to carry food, clothing and other needed articles to United States prisoners of war and civilians interned in Japan and elsewhere in the Far East.
FOR one reason or another, several programs are shifting their broadcast time tomorrow, among them the following:

Several additional arrests of "contacts and associates" of the eight submarine-borne saboteurs whose seizure was disclosed Saturday night were made known here yesterday by the Federal Bureau of Investigation.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Brazil, June 28 -- Foreign Minister Oswaldo Aranha disclosed today that all of Brazil's merchant marine, consisting of about 300,000 tons of ocean-going ships, would be placed under the jurisdiction of the Allied Shipping Control Board, which will operate here through the United States Embassy with the cooperation of the Brazilian Government.

The consumers' goods industries as a group reported net profits in the first quarter of 1942 that came within 2 1-3 per cent of the corresponding profits in the same period of 1941, despite the greater incidence of taxes and higher costs, charges and reserves this year.

If we are not to have a bitter and viciously retaliatory peace at the end of this war there must be created in the nation the spirit of genuine penitence and an attitude of forgiveness, declared the Rev. Dr. William Ward Ayer in his sermon yesterday at the Calvary Baptist Church, 123 West Fifty-seventh Street.

ST. LOUIS, Mo., June 28--Leaders of Federal Union, Inc., laid plans to bring their hope for a United States of the World down from the realm of mere theory and into actual being as their second annual convention closed here yesterday.

That book by Captain W.E. Fairbairn, specialist in hand-to-hand fighting that doesn't necessarily entail fair play, has come from the presses and will be published by Appleton-Century July 17. The author, a former member of the Shanghai Municipal Police and an instructor of the British Commandos, is now in this country teaching his methods to the United States armed forces.

Last week the Irving Fisher index of wholesale commodity prices rose slightly from 106.5 to 106.6. Increases in poultry, potatoes, livestock, eggs and lard outweighed decreases in oranges and grains enough to cause a rise of 0.3 per cent in the farm products index and 0.1 per cent in the raw materials index.

THERE has come to hand a copy of "Prop Wash," a modest single-sheet daily chronicle put out by the Aviation Cadet Regiment at Pensacola, Fla. The principal story of the day in the edition that arrived here introduces an old friend in a new suit. It's Potsy Clark, the former football leader of the Portsmouth Spartans, the Detroit Lions and the Brooklyn Dodgers.

DETROIT, June 28 (AP) -- Southpaw Hal Newhouser set down the Athletics on three hits for their sixth straight defeat, 3 to 2, in the first game of a double-header today, but the Mackmen struck back for a 3-to-0 triumph over the Tigers on the five-hit hurling of Luman Harris.

President Manuel Quezon of the Philippine Commonwealth with his wife and two daughters and two military aides attended low mass at 8 A.M. yesterday in St. Patrick's Cathedral, celebrated by Archbishop Francis J. Spellman.

Irregularity of movement prevailed last week in the cotton futures market. On the New York Cotton Exchange active contracts ended the week 5 points lower to 8 points higher, compared with net gains of 16 to 18 points in the previous week and with increases of 15 to 19 points in the week prior to that.

LONDON, June 28 -- Lord Glanely, who ran away and went to sea as a cabin boy at the age of 12 and who became one of Britain's great shipping men, was killed last night in a raid on a West of England coast town.
WASHINGTON, June 28 -- The votes of the delegations from New York, New Jersey and Connecticut on important roll-calls in Congress during the period June 20 to 26 were as follows:

GENEVA, N.Y., June 28 -- John Milton Potter, special assistant in the Office of Strategic Services in Washington, has been named president of Hobart and William Smith Colleges, according to an announcement by John K. Walker, chairman of the board of trustees of the colleges.

A maisonette apartment in the building at 960 Fifth Avenue has been leased by George A. Larsen through Douglas L. Elliman Co., who report leases to Alexander Salzman in 17 East Eighty-ninth Street; to Mrs. James S. Riggs in 25 East Eighty-sixth Street, and to Jacob David Kolker in 301 East Twenty-first Street.
BALTIMORE, June 28 (AP) -- Baltimore took the opener, 7 to 5, but Jersey City won the nightcap, 2 to 1, in today's double-header, marked by numerous arguments over umpire's decisions.

WASHINGTON, June 28 -- Admission today in an official communique from Berlin that Axis submarines in our waters were encountering "fierce American defenses" was greeted here tonight as an indication that our defense against the U-boats raiding in the Atlantic, the Caribbean and the Gulf of Mexico is reaching a point in its efficiency where their toll in shipping will be checked and then will diminish.
Seven new films are scheduled to arrive at Broadway theatres this week. The program follows:

CHICAGO, June 28 -- Operations in lard futures on the Board of Trade here were limited last week. Buying of July by a cash interest at one time caused a sharp upturn, but the market reacted quickly later on scattered liquidation, and the current delivery finished at $12.65 a 100 pounds, or up 2 1/2 cents from the close of the preceding week.

BERLIN, June 28 (From German broadcasts recorded by The Associated Press) -- The destruction of the Second Soviet Army and parts of the Fifty-second and Fifty-ninth Soviet Armies, and the capture of 32,759 prisoners and a large quantity of guns and materiel were announced today by the German High Command in a special communique.

A tenement property on the lower East Side figured in an all-cash transaction when the five-story building at 204 East Broadway, between Jefferson and Clinton Streets, was sold by Central Hanover Bank and Trust Company, as successor trustee of the Estate of Frederick H. Palmer, to a client of the P. Zaccaro Company.

There is enough rubber available to supply the military needs of the United States, but not nearly enough, to meet the war demands of the United Nations, W.L. Batt, Director of Materials, War Production Board, said yeaterday. Civilians will get no more rubber after they have used up their present supplies, he warned, and "the best possible use" must be made of privately owned tires.
NEW YORK Mrs. James Suydam Polhemus, Mr. and Mrs. Frederick S. Polhemus and Miss Elaine Polhemus are at Pocono Manor for the Summer.

MEXICO CITY, June 28 -- The tension and suspense at Tampico slackened today when the expected shelling of the oil district by the U-boat that sank the Mexican tankers Tuxpan and Chopas the night before last failed to materialize.

LONDON, June 28 (AP) -- While the main R.A.F. attack last night centered upon Bremen, several night-raiding British squadrons, mostly of American-made and R.A.F.-manned Bostons, blasted other places in Northwest Germany and airfields and war plants of inland and coastal France.

ST. LOUIS, June 28 -- The rapidly rising Missouri River poured its muddy waters over additional acreage of rich bottom land tonight, causing damage estimated in the millions of dollars. Three persons were drowned in flood waters.

"Sweet herbs from all antiquity" -- to borrow the words of a distinguished poet -- may be purchased this morning in a mid-town store for 15 cents a bunch. Transported to town early each day from a Long Island farm, they are whisked into the shop's refrigerator, from which they emerge so fresh that the dew still seems to sparkle on the leaves.

HARRY W. FLANNERY is the young American newspaper man and radio broadcaster who succeeded William L. Shirer as the Berlin correspondent of the Columbia Broadcasting System. He held his difficult post from December, 1940, until the Autumn of 1941. His book about his experiences in the Nazi capital, "Assignment to Berlin,"* is thus virtually a sequel to "Berlin Diary."

In our desire for liberty we have been emphasizing too much what belongs to us and too little what we belong to, the Rev. Ralph W. Sockman declared yesterday in his sermon in Christ Church, Methodist, at Park Avenue and Sixtieth Street.

Paul V. McNutt, chairman of the War Manpower Commission, and the Texas sharecropper mother of Dorie Miller, first Negro hero to win public acclaim in this war, told a Harlem audience of 6,000 persons last night that the American Negro, although unfairly discriminated against, must put all he has into the fight against Hitler or lose even his freedom.

The hopes Frank Bowden had of retiring the Brooklyn Challenge Bowl were shattered at the Knickerbocker Field Club yesterday when the veteran was beaten in an upset by Charles Masterson of Baldwin, L.I., in the Brooklyn title tennis tournament.
ST. LOUIS, June 28 (AP) -- Thirteen pitchers were bombarded with sixty hits today as the Senators swept both ends of a double-header with the Browns, 14 to 13 and 7 to 6.

Debt service was paid in full in 1941 on $3,190,165,289, or only 56.38 per cent of the total of $5,658,000,389 of publicly offered foreign dollar bonds outstanding on Dec. 31, 1941, according to a bulletin titled "Statistical Analysis of Publicly Offered Foreign Dollar Bonds," issued today by Dean John T. Madden, director of the Institute of International Finance of New York University.

PITTSBURGH, June 28 -- A decline in the available tonnages of scrap metal in some districts, combined with necessary repairs to furnaces, caused the steel ingot rate last week to remain unchanged at 99 per cent of rated capacity.
LONDON, June 28 -- Accustomed though the City has become to surprises in this war, it had yet another last week in the stolid resistance of the financial markets to the British defeat in Libya.

CHICAGO, June 28 -- The South-western States, which produce the lion's share of the surplus Winter wheat crop of the country, are experiencing unfavorable weather for harvest, and reports indicate that in some sections estimates of the yield will have to be reduced.

Three more United States merchant ships have been sunk and at least seventy-two more sailors have been drowned or burned to death by Axis submarines operating in waters on this side of the Atlantic, it was officially disclosed by the Navy yesterday.

SEIGNIORY'S CLUB, Que., June 28 (Canadian Press) -- Canadian women in uniform "have discovered that it pays to join up," Mrs. F.F. Rajell, Montreal businesswoman, last night told members of the Kappa Kappa Gamma sorority, at a "Victory" dinner closing a week-long convention.

The proposed closing of five of the city's evening high schools as an economy measure brought a protest yesterday from teachers in one of the schools, the Bushwick Evening High School in Brooklyn, and a petition to the Board of Education to reject the proposal.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The discussions of the tax bill before the Ways and Means Committee have come to a close. The committee and the Treasury deserve, great credit for completing an arduous task. Randolph Paul's great knowledge helped to ease hardship cases.

For several weeks there has been a deadlock between the Senate and the House over the question of permitting the Government to sell a limited amount of wheat for livestock feeding below parity prices. The Senate has approved such sales; the farm bloc in the House has voted against them.

As it did in 1939 and 1940, the General Motors Corporation topped all advertisers during 1941 in four major media, according to the third annual edition of "Expenditures of National Advertisers in Newspapers, Magazines, Farm Journals and Chain Radio," issued today by the bureau of advertising, American Newspaper Publishers Association.

CHICAGO, June 28 -- Mrs. Gerda Melend, 24-year-old brunette, who was to have been married next week to Herbert Hans Haupt, accused as a German spy and saboteur, told today of her reunion Tuesday with Haupt after a year's mystery absence and of her hunch that something was wrong.

The Greater New York war bond campaign, which had set its goal at 2,000,000 pledges, went over the top last night, John T. Madden, chairman, announced well in advance of midnight, when the campaign formally closed.

MOSCOW, June 28--The gradual eastward advance of General Field Marshal Fedor von Bock's Kharkov armies appears to have slowed down. It was never a swift advance, for the Russian defenses in depth between the Donets and Oskol Rivers are highly complex.

BOONTON, N.J., June 28 -- Taking the lead from Frank Walsh with a third-round 69, Johnny Kinder of Plainfield continued to play brilliant golf through the last round for a 71 to win the New Jersey State P.G.A. championship at the Knoll Country Club today with a total of 283.

DENVER, June 28 -- For the first time in the history of American education, plans for a nation-wide teacher placement service, intended to meet shortages of instructors in many parts of the country, were approved here today, as the annual convention of the National Education Association got under way.

With Lippy Leo Durocher managing the Dodgers by remote control, if at all, yesterday, they contrived nothing better than an even break with, the Reds, losing the opener, 6-3, and pulling out the nightcap, 2-1, before a throng of 31,165 at Ebbets Field.

NEWARK, N.J., June 28 (AP) -- Frank Kelleher's seventeenth home run with one on and one out in the seventh of today's nightcap gave Newark a 6-to-5 victory and an even break with Syracuse. Newark lost the opener, 5 -- 1.

VICHY, June 28 -- Another step in the general reduction of interest rates which the government has been effecting by stages has been announced with the beginning tomorrow of the conversion of the 4 1/2 per cent Public Works Treasury bonds of 1932 and the 5 per cent rentes of 1939.

Completion of a program of decentralized relief administration under which applicants for various forms of city relief can go to a single office in their own neighborhood instead of shuttling around town looking for the proper bureau, was disclosed yesterday by Welfare Commissioner William Hodson.
The text of the address by Paul V. McNutt, Federal Security Administrator, at a mass meeting sponsored by the Negro Labor Victory Committee and the National Conference of Christian Youths follows:

Reunions of the war It will be toward evening, and the sun will be dropping fast, and they will be sitting under the elms in the yard waiting. The car will swing up into the yard, as they do on farms, and he will get out.

The sudden change from confidence in the military outlook, a fortnight or more ago, to the misgiving which has followed the fall of Tobruk and the advance of General Rommel into Egypt, was reflected in last week's market. We had not only the agitation in Parliament, the nation-wide demand for information as to who was to blame, the immediate addition to our own war appropriations, but a reasonably steady decline in stocks.

If it were not so grim a reality the case of the eight confessed saboteurs landed on our coast from German submarines and promptly swept into the net of the F.B.I. would seem a fantastic plot borrowed from the movies. Actually these desperate invaders were bringing war into the very heart of this nation, war in its most ruthless form.

JACKSONVILLE, Fla., June 28 -- Florida East Coast residents were electrified today by the disclosure of the Nazi saboteurs' landing at Ponte Vedra Beach, but if there was any one who knew more about it than the F.B.I. chief told he was keeping mum.

LONDON, June 28 (U.P.) -- Newspapers today spurred agitation to force Prime Minister Churchill out of his secondary job as Defense Minister during this week's parliamentary war debate and pleaded for a rebirth of the post-Dunkerque spirit to carry Britain through the crisis in Egypt.

GIRARD, Ohio, June 28 -- His irons deadly and his drives true when he needed them, Clayton Heafner blazed home in a three-below-par 65 today successfully to defend his Mahoning Valley open title with a smashing 264 -- as low as any marksman ever scored in a recognized golf tournament.

LONDON, June 28 -- A large part of Prime Minister Churchill's week-end was devoted to discussing the revolt among some members of the House of Commons against his leadership with Clement R. Attlee, Dominions Secretary; Sir Stafford Cripps, Lord Privy Seal, and others in preparation for the coming debate, in which he faces for the first time in his Prime Ministership the challenge of a no-confidence motion.

Deploring racial and religious discrimination and hatreds in this country as "the back-wash of Hitlerism" and holding that the "vast majority" of Americans are vigorously opposed to such practices, Thomas E. Dewey declared last night that no just and lasting peace could be drawn by the Allies after the war unless the rights of minorities throughout the world were respected and fully protected.

The nation-wide total of contributions to the war fund of the United Service Organizations last week mounted to $11,868,232, a rise of $1,550,271. Prescott S. Bush, national campaign chairman, announced yesterday. He disclosed that this city had raised $2,950,000, or 64 per cent of its goal of $4,450,000.
With fields of five and eight, respectively, in the two $2,000 features, Empire City will open its twenty-four-day race meeting this afternoon with a 2:30 post time, latest in the metropolitan area.

Several hundred rabbis from various sections of the country will meet today at the Jewish Theological Seminary, Broadway at 122d Street, for the forty-second annual convention of the Rabbinical Assembly of America, at which wartime problems of the Jews, and the synagogues will be discussed.
LONDON, June 28 (AP) -- The Air Ministry issued this communique today:

CHICAGO, June 28 -- While Congress continues to debate major provisions in the Agricultural Appropriation Bill, harvesting of the new Winter wheat crop is progressing and the first flow of grain to market is under way with the promise that the current trickle will become a mighty flood that will engulf all available storage space in quick order.

Two Pan American Airways transatlantic Clippers arrived yesterday at La Guardia Field with a total of sixty-four passengers, thirty-two of whom came from Europe. Among them were Sir Frederick Leith-Ross, economic adviser to the British Government, and Sir Earle C. Page, former Australian Deputy Prime Minister and formerly of the British War Cabinet.

The battle for Egypt begins at a moment when American war production is reaching its full tide. Planes, guns, tanks and ammunition are coming from the factories at a pace which would have seemed impossible even a few years ago. But these fine weapons are not in themselves a guarantee of victory.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., June 28 -- "Assignment in Brittany," a current magazine serial by Helen MacInnes, has been purchased by Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer as a vehicle for Jean Pierre Aumont, French actor, whom the studio has signed to a term contract.

Unless the nations can soon realize their interdependence we are bound to see the last remnants of our civilization totter and sink beneath the sands of time, declared the Rev. Dr. Theodore Cuyler Speers in his sermon yesterday in the Central Presbyterian Church, Park Avenue and Sixty-fourth Street.
LONDON, June 28 -- The British and the United States Red Cross are taking all possible steps to coordinate completely plans for the entertainment of United States troops in the United Kingdom.

A considerable shake-up in the celebrated if slightly homicidal Brewster family of "Arsenic and Old Lace," which has been playing steadily at the Fulton since Jan. 10, 1941, takes place tonight. Indeed, there will be three new Brewsters in the cast. Brie von Stroheim will step into the murderous shoes of Boris Karloff, who is at last going to Hollywood to take up picture work already thrice deferred.

CAMP TAMIMENT, Pa., June 28 -- Walter Nash, New Zealand's Minister to the United States, and member of the Pacific War Council, today urged the creation of a world reconstruction and development council as well as a world military council to shape "the major policy and strategy of the war and reconstruction years."

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, June 28--In Berlin cafes these days one frequently hears people express belief in the existence of a secret gentlemen's agreement between Germany and Britain that the two countries henceforth abstain from bombing each other's capitals, says a neutral newspaper man who has just arrived in Stockholm from Berlin, where he served several years as a correspondent of a big daily paper.

LONDON, June 28 -- What is believed to be the decisive battle for the valley of the Nile began yesterday afternoon and has been raging throughout today over an area roughly 400 miles square that is identified by the name of Matruh.

Wholesale activity picked up last week, but the bulk of Fall business was not expected until after the Fourth of July, according to a summary of the week's activities prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by leading resident offices.

WASHINGTON, June 28 -- John O. Snyder, who has been a friend and adviser to scores of Representatives since the days of William McKinley, is going to retire as deputy sergeant at arms next week after forty-one years of continuous service in the House.

LONDON, June 28 -- Any one cherishing the illusion that the British are not wide awake should see that section of the populace engaged in the restaurant business in action here two weeks after the government's "dinner for a dollar" law became effective.

CLEVELAND, June 28 (AP) -- A pinch single by Chubby Dean in the eighth today scored Oris Hockett to give the Indians a 3-to-2 victory and an even break in a doubleheader with the Red Sox. Boston won the first game, 8 to 3.

The National Security Women's Corps has opened registration for three new units of the corps in the metropolitan area, it was announced yesterday. They are Hanover Unit at the Empire State Building, Friday at 6:15 P.M. Manhattan Day Unit at Rosoff's, 147 West Forty-third Street, Wednesday at 2 P.M., and the first Bronx Unit at the 5th Regiment Armory, 1122 Franklin Avenue, Wednesday at 8 P.M.

Milliners are already sending up style "skyrockets" -- and the Fourth still five days off. They are scintillating indications for the season, which will get under way by the middle of July. These skyrockets hint at the return to real millinery for Fall and Winter.

BERNE, Switzerland, June 28 -- The German press and official quarters are wholly occupied with the military situation in Egypt and Prime Minister Winston Churchill's return to London. Of the two events, the further military plans of the Axis powers are in the foreground of speculation.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y. June 28--After service this morning in St. John's Episcopal Church in Flushing, L.I., the Rev. H.C. Benjamin took a group of the younger members of his flock out to crew with him on his forty-one year old sloop Pecusa.
CAIRO, June 28 (AP) -- British headquarters issued this communique today:

NOROTON, Conn., June 28 -- After yesterday's postponement due to lack of breeze, the Noroton Yacht Club's first race for the John Taylor Arms Perpetual Trophy on the Sound was completed today. The breeze shifted from southwest shortly after the start and upset the program, which called for a beat to the Cows buoy on the first leg.
CHUNGKING, June 28 (AP) -- The Chinese Command issued this communique today:

LONDON, June 28 -- It may be an indication of British phlegm in the face of adversity or of the growing influence of women in this country that much time was spent in both houses of Parliament this week in a discussion of the very questions that have been bothering the distaff side of this nation for many months.

Radio's contribution to hemispheric good-will was praised yesterday by government and educational leaders of the Latin-American republics, the United States and Canada as the National Broadcasting Company presented a "preview" of its new Inter-American University of the Air.

The rise of 2 1/2 cents a gallon on gasoline and 2 cents on fuel oil prices approved by Price Administrator Leon Henderson last Saturday will "not increase the supply here," Mayor La Guardia declared in his regular Sunday broadcast yesterday.

Tom Finnerty of the New York A.C. captured the metropolitan A.A.U. senior 100-meter backstroke championship to highlight the swimming meet held yesterday at Broad Channel Bathing Park. Clocked in 1:17.2, Finnerty finished a yard ahead of Vie Gordon, Queens Central Y.M.C.A.

While vehicular traffic through tunnels and over bridges was about 40 per cent below normal yesterday, great crowds poured into and out of the city, mostly by train and bus. Terminals and hotels handled unusually large numbers, many of them men in uniform.

Long Acre Farm, an eighty-five-acre dairy property on the Lincroft-Everett Road, at Lincroft, in Monmouth County, N.J., has been, purchased by T.G. Egan of New York from Mrs. Walter S. Force. It contains a ten-room colonial house, the foundation and original part of which are said to be more than 200 years old.

J. Donald Budge and Robert L. Riggs, both former national amateur champions, reached the final round of the national professional tournament yesterday at the West Side Tennis Club in Forest Hills. They will meet Saturday for the title won last year by Fred Perry.

CAIRO, Egypt, June 28 (U.P.) -- Fifty engineers and technicians, directing 1,000 native laborers and mule drivers, have dug a new harbor into the Persian Gulf coast to land the mounting volume of war supplies for Russia, reliable sources revealed today.

PHILADELPHIA, June 28 (AP) -- Pitching one of the best games of his career, Tommy Hughes led the Phils to a 2-to-1 victory over the Cardinals in an exciting fifteen-inning struggle that gave the Phils a split in a double-header today. The Cards took the second game, 3 to 1, behind the five-hit pitching of Lon Warneke and Walker Cooper's hitting.

Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner Beane head a syndicate which today will make a public offering of 4 3/4 per cent cumulative preferred stock, $100 par value, of the G.C. Murphy Company at $105 a share. They operate a chain of variety stores.
WASHINGTON, June 28--One of the decisive battles in world history apparently was developing outside the ramparts of Matruh in the Egyptian desert today.
BERLIN, June 28 (From German broadcasts recorded by The Associated Press) -- The German High Command issued the following communique today:

With striped bass plentiful in Massachusetts waters during past weeks, the larger stripers are ahead of schedule around Cuttyhunk Island, according to the officials there, who have announced the opening of the second annual Cuttyhunk striped bass contest.

Something of the aura of an earlier and statelier era -- when great beauties enjoyed great fame and their simplest tricks for enhancing their charms were topics of intensive discussion -- invests the appearance on the American scene of a modern version of just such a set of formulas.

A campaign to raise $1,000,000 for war relief for America's Allies, chiefly Britain, Russia and China, and to stimulate Jewish participation in the American war program on the home front and on the battlefield, was launched yesterday by 1,000 delegates representing Jewish organizations in the city and the nation.

MOSCOW, Monday, June 29 -- The German Army has opened an offensive from the key stronghold of Kursk, 280 miles south of Moscow, the Russian High Command announced today. A communique said that "fighting commenced against the German troops, who had gone over to the offensive."

MINNEAPOLIS, June 28 (AP) -- Wollmar F. Bostrom, Swedish Minister to the United States, told the annual Swedish Day celebration here today that for the duration of the war Sweden was dedicated to rigid neutrality.

MEXICO CITY, Mexico, June 27 -- President Manuel Avila Camacho is studying proposals made by capital and labor separately regarding the formation of a Council of National Defense intended to direct the country's economic and social affairs for the duration of the war.

VENTNOR CITY, N.J., June 28 -- Jacob Levin of Philadelphia, today defeated Sidney Bernstein of Brooklyn in the game adjourned from last night to place second in the annual invitation chess masters tournament on Ventnor's Municipal Pier.

Life with, the Giants continues to be a series of ups and downs and yesterday, before 31,505 onlookers, they suffered two of the latter as Frankie Frisch's Pirates, spraying the Polo Grounds with a grand total of seven homers, bagged both ends of a double-header.

Appointment of a five-man administrative committee to direct the activities of the American Association for Social Security was announced yesterday in the first formal statement issued by the organization since the death of Abraham Epstein, its founder and executive secretary.

WASHINGTON, June 28 (AP) -- The Treasury, seeking a way to impose higher income taxes than those in the pending bill without penalizing too heavily persons who have fixed debt charges to meet, is studying a special income levy from which at least part of "saved" income would be exempt.

The ghost of the $155,000,000 New York World's Fair will walk today for the last time. As a final financial gasp before dissolution proceedings are begun, the corporation will pay to the holders of the outstanding 4 per cent debentures $940,198, or 3 1/2 per cent of the $26,862,800 original principal amount issued.

VICHY, France, June 28 -- Members of the Tri-Color Legion will receive the special advantages granted soldiers of the regular army, according to recent decisions of the government, it is understood here tonight.

NEW ORLEANS, June 28 -- The action of the Senate in voting approval to sell loan wheat below parity accounted for a late reaction in cotton futures last week after the market had stiffened early on weather and war reports and orderly liquidation of July contracts.

While automobile graveyards in the New York metropolitan area are yielding hundreds of tons of rubber scrap, barges tied up along the Manhattan waterfront with an estimated 1,000 old tires used for bumpers are showing increasing reluctance to part with their possessions.

WASHINGTON, June 28 -- Elliot E. Simpson, counsel for the House committee investigating the rubber situation, who has maintained that there are 10,000,000 tons of scrap rubber in the United States, today blamed non-cooperation of scrap dealers for the failure, of the scrap collection campaign to produce the quantities expected.
Sales of properties by banks featured realty trading in Brooklyn over the week-end.

CHUNGKING, China, June 28 -- A principal objective of the Japanese drive in Kiangsi Province, in addition to the enemy's attempt to clear a through rail line between Korea and Malaya, is probably to grab the rich tungsten fields of Southern Kiangsi, officials here observed today.

Expansion, and acceleration of the arms program have placed the question of Government finances in a new aspect, according to the Guaranty Survey, monthly review published by the Guaranty Trust Company of New York.

HONOLULU, June 28 -- Admiral Chester W. Nimitz, Commander in Chief of the Pacific Fleet, released today an official compilation of Japanese losses in the Battle of Midway showing that four Japanese aircraft carriers had definitely been sunk.

CAIRO, Egypt, June 28 (U.P.) -- The British Eighth Army, heavily reinforced since its defeat in Libya, clashed head-on with General Field Marshal Erwin Rommel's German and Italian forces on a twenty-two-mile front west and south of the Egyptian port of Matruh tonight.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 28 -- Several thousand German and Italian aliens who were required to move out of prohibited or restricted areas set up in California by Attorney General Biddle in late January and early February will be able to move back into or work in those districts under a new proclamation just issued by Lieut. Gen. John L. DeWitt, Western defense commander.

CHICAGO, June 28 -- Prices of corn on the Board of Trade here held last week within a narrow range, trading being mostly in the way of spreading between the various deliveries. Cash interests bought July and sold the deferred months, changing over hedges from July to September at a premium of 2 3/4 cents a bushel, for the latter, or about the cost of carrying the grain for two months.

Mr. Churchill went home to face the music much more cheerful than he was when he arrived in this country. The joint statement issued by the President and the Prime Minister does not furnish him with much ammunition for the explanations he has to make to a public more and more critical of the conduct of the war.

Alexander Smallens presented an all-French program at his fourth concert of the season last night with the New York Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra at the Lewisohn Stadium. All but one of the works were familiar, but the juxtaposition of the four works on the same program lent them addiditional interest.

BOSTON, June 28 (AP) -- The Cubs snapped out of a batting slump today in time to gain an even break with the Braves, winning the nightcap, 5 to 1, after bowing before Jim Tobin's three-hit pitching, 3 to 0.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The injustice of the dependency amendment to the Draft Act impels me to urge that it be modified and clarified before it is finally enacted into law. If it is too late for that, then it should be possible to amend its provisions to eliminate an obviously overlooked potential result which will bring about hardship and distress.

CHUNGKING, China, June 28--Chinese troops have recaptured Linhsien, a major Japanese base in Northern Honan, near the Shansi border area west of the Peiping-Hankow railway, and have killed 1,000 more Japanese in that sector, raising the total enemy casualties to 5,500 in thirteen days, war dispatches said tonight.

LONDON, June 28 (AP) -- The German air raid of June 1 on Canterbury, cradle of Anglican Christianity, damaged the famous cathedral, destroyed several historic buildings and laid waste much, of the residential section, it was disclosed today.
MOSCOW, June 29 (AP) -- The Soviet Information Bureau broadcast this communique today:
CHUNGKING, China, June 29 -- Some of the "Flying Tigers" whose one-year contracts have expired are leaving China for the "United States, it was learned today.
MOSCOW, Tuesday, June 30 (AP) -- The Soviet Information Bureau issued this communique today:

LONDON, June 29 -- The chief feature on the Stock Exchange today was a decline in Mexican Eagle Oil shares. Other markets were steady, with the turnover small. Mexican Eagle fell 1s to 9s on Lord Bearsted's statement that no settlement terms had been discussed and that no negotiations were progressing between the company and Mexico.

Tonight the Treasury will close its books on the second fiscal year of armament finance. The figures are already dwarfed by the outline of what is to come in the fiscal year opening tomorrow. Compared with what preceded, the budget totals show how much has been accomplished.

For conduct unbecoming a manager, Lippy Leo Durocher of the Dodgers, who will double in brass as pilot of the National League All-Stars, yesterday was notified he had been fined $50 and suspended for three days. The penalties came as a result of Durocher's part in Sunday's extracurricular activities at Ebbets Field.

DEAR E.B. White: Your "One Man's Meat," which gathers up your Harper and New Yorker essays into a single attractive and convenient volume, should be any man's meat. Like the lungs, lights, livers and good fat haunches of one of Vilhjalmur ("Friendly Arctic") Stefansson's caribou, it has all the vitamins, including those ordinarily obtained from spinach.

BERLIN, June 29 (From German broadcasts recorded by The Associated Press) -- The High Command announced today that German and Rumanian troops had forced a crossing of the Chernaya Valley and infiltrated to Mount Sapoun, south of Sevastopol.
ALBANY, June 29 -- The adjutant general released the following orders today:

CHICAGO, June 29 -- The traffic death toll in the country dropped 25 per cent in May as compared with April, or the greatest decrease for any month in the nation's history, the National Safety Council reported today.
