WASHINGTON, June 29 -- The United States and Great Britain will begin discussing post-war economic reconstruction problems tomorrow when Sir Frederick LeithRoss, chief economic adviser to the British Government and chairman of the Inter-Allied Postwar Requirements Committees meets with Secretary of State Cordell Hull at the State Department.
Nathalia Crane, poet and lecturer, will conduct a course in poetics at the Hunter College Summer session, which begins next Monday, it was announced yesterday by Professor Broderick Cohen, director.

In back of the small bakery is a large restaurant, and behind both is a warm busy kitchen. There, in a little corner that is exclusively hers, a white-uniformed woman makes crullers. With an experienced hand she cuts them out of the feathery-light dough, pops them into a great iron cauldron, then deftly deposits them on fresh clean paper.

WASHINGTON, June 29 -- Piece goods led all other departments with an increase of 20 per cent in sales during May, as compared with May of last year, according to the Federal Reserve Board's report of department store sales by departments made public today.

Willie Klein, professional at Wheatley Hills, played superb golf with P.R. Ryan for 31, 34 -- 65, and a tie with Walter Scheiber of Milburn and his amateur partner, Dr. E.J. Kempf of Timber Point, who posted 32, 33 -- 65, in the bestball pro-amateur tournament of the Long Island P.G.A. over the North Hills Golf Club course in Douglaston, Queens, yesterday.
WASHINGTON, June 29 -- The government tomorrow will register about 3,000,000 youths of the 18 to 20 year age group for possible military service under the selective service system.

New York Values There is one New York taxpayer who understands the overassessment situation quite well. It is the issue upon which some angry citizens want Governor Lehman to remove Mayor La Guardia, and the Mayor summed up the case perfectly when he said that if his removal from office will solve the assessment problem he will go a happy man.

MELBOURNE, Australia, June 29 -- Considerable surprise was aroused here today by articles in local papers to the effect that William S. Wasserman, head of the American lease-lend mission to Australia, had said that Australia would require very little more United States aid to enable her to take the offensive.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, June 29 -- A sermon directly opposing Nazi state and social theories was read yesterday at St. Hedwig's Church, Berlin, by the Catholic Bishop of the German capital, Count Konrad von Preysing.
Almost on the eve of tomorrow's opening of the bass season in New York and Connecticute, a copy of Ray Bergman's "Fresh Water Bass" arrived.

HONOLULU, June 29 -- At the end of what was probably the longest over-water bombing mission ever carried out by any air force, bombers of the Hawaiian Command early Saturday morning, Honolulu time, plastered the Japanese airdrome on Wake Island with several thousand pounds of highexplosive bombs and returned safely to their base, the Army Air Forces announced here today.

MOSCOW, Tuesday, June 30 -- The Red Army smashed wave after wave of German tanks attacking in the Kursk sector, north of Kharkov, yesterday, but was forced to yield some ground to reinforced German troops in the battle for besieged Sevastopol, the Russian High Command announced today.
BERLIN, June 29 (From German broadcasts recorded by The Associated Press) -- The German High Command issued this special communique today:

WASHINGTON, June 29 -- Acceding to the request of President Roosevelt, the Southern Coal Producers Association agreed today to refund by Aug. 1 the $200,000 in fines levied on members of the United Mine Workers who struck last Monday in sympathy with the captive mine walkout.
WASHINGTON; June 29 (AP) -- To curtsy or not to curtsy to royalty-and if so, how deep is it safe to dip ?

The Western Pacific Railroad Corporation, a holding agency which has full control of the Western Pacific Railroad, reported a net loss of $505,777 in 1941, compared with $508,642 in 1940. The Western Pacific Railroad and the Denver Rio Grande Western Railroad, of which it holds one-half the ownership, have paid no dividends since they went into bankruptcy in 1935.

The Rabbinical Assembly of America opened its forty-second annual convention yesterday at the Jewish Theological Seminary, Broadway and 122d Street, attended by 200 rabbis from all sections of the country. The three-day conference will deal with wartime problems of the Jews; religious and educational questions will be discussed.

For any one interested in going into the business of outdoor concerts, last night's program at the Lewisohn Stadium was a perfect sample of a successful recipe. Get Josef Hofmann as piano soloist, Fritz Reiner as conductor, the New York Philharmonic-Symphony as the orchestra and Beethoven as the composer.

Members of the Board of Estimate, at a hastily called five-minute session in City Hall late yesterday afternoon, took the first step toward dismissing seventy-five Welfare Department investigators as an alternative to paying them salary increments of $120 a year.

The first public move to get James A. Farley, principal sponsor of Attorney General John J. Bennett for the Democratic nomination for Governor, to accept the nomination himself was made last night, as the board of directors of the New York Young Democratic Club made public a resolution urging Mr. Farley to make himself available for the post.

Running to a new track record, Mrs. G.C. Winfrey's Aboyne yesterday flashed his best effort, 1:43-3-5 for a mile and a sixteenth, as Empire City opened its Summer meet with a crowd of 13,965. This was a sharp gain over last year's opening when 9,654 turned out to wager $570,033.

Following an organization meeting of the Mayor's Committee to Study City Finances, Council President Newbold Morris announced yesterday the personnel of eight sub-committees chosen to survey particular fields in the general financial survey.
PHILADELPHIA, June 29 -- Securities effectively registered during May amounted to $93,491,000, it was disclosed today in an analysis prepared by the Securities and Exchange Commission.
The bulk of the commercial leases reported by brokers and agents yesterday were for quarters in buildings in the suburbs.
John J. Seery, affectionately known throughout the police force as "Papa Seery," has resigned as First Deputy Commissioner after thirty-nine years of service in the department.

SOUTH SALEM, N.Y., June 29 -- Four persons were killed and eight were injured in an automobile accident involving three cars early today on Route 35 here just west of the Connecticut boundary. No arrests were made.

CHICAGO, June 29 (AP) -- Roughly treated at the start, Al Milnar, veteran Cleveland left-hander, steadied in the late innings today to take advantage of the Indians' seventeen-hit attack and beat the White Sox, 11 to 5. The victory enabled the Indians to remain in third place.
BALTIMORE, June 29 (AP) -- A homer by Hank Edwards, scoring Bob Lemon ahead of him in the ninth, clinched a 6-to-4 victory for the Baltimore Orioles tonight in their contest with Newark.
LONDON, June 29-A popular song heard up and down the British Isles contains the stanza:

With only one day before the deadline, more than half the city's automobile owners have not yet bought the $5 annual tax stamp that must be affixed to windshields of all cars beginning tomorrow, according to sales totaled yesterday.

LONDON, June 29 -- The correspondent of The Times, London, cables from Cairo, Egypt, today that the more deeply and more carefully the battle of Libya is considered the more apparent it becomes that the British reverse was due almost entirely to the poor tactical handling of the British armored forces.

The three-year basic training course for nurses will not be shortened in spite of the unprecedented demand for trained nurses by the armed forces, Miss Alta E. Dines, chairman of the National Committee on Red Cross Nursing Service, declared yesterday.

The Commonwealth of Massachusetts yesterday awarded to a banking group composed of the Bankers Trust Company of New York, and the Merchants National Bank, the Boston Safe Deposit Trust Company, the National Shawmut Bank and the Day Trust Company, all of Boston, an issue of $2,500,000 of notes at 0.465 per cent. The obligations, dated July 14, 1942, will mature on July 13, 1943.

MOSCOW, June 29 -- The Red Army propaganda service is now issuing for the German soldiers' use coupon books of "surrender visas" disguised as some of Dr. Joseph Goebbels's up-lift literature. Premier Joseph Stalin's May 1 order of the day is presented in the German language between dummy covers that may look like collections of film stars' pictures or German classics.

Although he refused yesterday on technical grounds to reinstate Nicholas J. De Stefano, now under indictment for extortion, as secretary-treasurer of Local 202 of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, A.F. of L., Supreme Court Justice Morris Eder criticized the local and its present officers severely for "utterly illegal" methods in outsing De Stefano and for attempting to "bedevil him because of his bad reputation an past record."

WASHINGTON, June 29 -- Harriet Elliott, new chief of the women's section of the Treasury's war savings staff, called on Ameri can women today to help win the war and hold down inflation by buying war savings stamps and bonds.

JERUSALEM, June 29 -- On the River Jordan near Jericho lies a vessel that has become another shrine in this already hallowed land, and it will, it is believed, be an object of veneration for generations to come.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., June 29 -- Top-ranking officers of the Army's Second Corps Area and the Navy's Third Naval District attended a meeting in the County Center here tonight to explain to 250 Westchester War Council officials why the dimout must he continued in inland communities.

MONTREAL, June 29 -- Air freighting of at least some of the war supplies being sent By the United States to many parts of the world is one means being studied by the War Production Board to ease the current shipping crisis, it was revealed here today by E.A. Locke Jr., assistant to Donald Nelson, chairman of the board.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., June 29 -- Ann Sheridan will play Nora Bayes, musical comedy star of the early 1900's, in "Shine On Harvest Moon," a screen biography of the singer, Warner Brothers announced today.

A Chinese dragon, twenty feet in length and manned by a half dozen Chinese youths, came to the Plaza Hotel last night. Flashing bright yellow and orange under the ballroom chandeliers, its papiermache body undulated across the floor in a ritualistic victory dance.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., June 29 -- Four objections to the probate of the will of Mrs. Anna H. Paton, all involving the technical form of the document and the wealthy dowager's mental capacity to make a will, were dismissed this afternoon by Surrogate Charles D. Millard on the conclusion of the contestants' case.

WASHINGTON, June 29 (AP) -- President Roosevelt has given the Commodity Credit Corporation limited authority to subsidize certain farm products in order to keep their cost to consumers down to the price ceiling fixed by Leon Henderson.

The fate of Egypt and perhaps of the Middle East, the vast region that is one of the keys to victory, was hanging in the balance last night as Axis armored forces pressed on past captured Matruh toward the rich Valley of the Nile.

Two armed guards walked into USO headquarters in the Empire State Building yesterday afternoon and for five minutes startled receptionists, typists and other workers. After explanations, the guards stood at attention -- but kept eyes glued on a large suitcase in their possession.
The Young Women's Hebrew Association moved out of its headquarters at 31 West 110th Street yesterday after twenty-eight years' residence in the nine-story building.
WASHINGTON, June 29 (AP) -- More than 500 American nationals will arrive in New York tomorrow aboard the Swedish liner Drottningholm from Lisbon, the State Department announced tonight.

WASHINGTON, June 29 -- Objections by Senator McNary, minority leader, to consideration of the $43,000,000,000 War Department Appropriations Bill -- the largest appropriation request in the nation's history -- without more time for Senators to study it forced postponement today of hoped-for disposal until tomorrow despite the fact that the new fiscal year for which the funds are to be provided begins on Wednesday.

WASHINGTON, June 29 -- How to prevent the Germans from getting into Latin America, for propaganda and espionage purposes, the millions of dollars of United States currency which they have seized in occupied Europe will be discussed at a meeting tomorrow of inter-American central bankers and economists known as the InterAmerican Financial and Economic Conference.

JERSEY CITY, June 29 (AP) -- Tommy Delacruz, a former Jersey City player, racked up his ninth victory of the season tonight in a twilight-night game when he stopped the Little Giants with four hits to give the Syracuse Chiefs a 2-to-1 victory in the opener of a three-game series.

WASHINGTON, June 29 -- The National War Labor Board's factfinding panel reported today that four "Little Steel" companies "are able to pay the requested wage increase of one dollar a day" demanded by the United Steel Workers of America, C.I.O.

ANN ARBOR, Mich., June 29 -- Joan Tesch, 19-year-old novice pilot who flew in circles above. Municipal Airport for an hour after she fainted at the controls, will be flying again in a few days because she intends to make aviation her life career, her mother asserted tonight.

"Somewhere in China," a dispatch printed in this newspaper said, there was "a solemn sacrificial ceremony to commemorate the 715th anniversary of the death of the great Mongol conqueror, Genghis Khan. Representatives of the Chinese Government attended." According to the books, Genghis Khan died Aug. 24, 1227.

NOROTON, Conn., June 29 -- Paul Smart, one of the Star Class international skippers, forged to the front today in the sixth annual series of the Noroton Yacht Club's racing for the John Taylor Arms Perpetual Trophy.

Government decree has clipped extraneous yardage off feminine lounging garments, In accordance with the national effort to conserve fabrics, and the resultant effect is surprisingly youthful and smart.

LONDON, June 29 -- There is no agreement betwen the British and the Germans to spare each other's capitals from bombing, the British would not make such an agreement, and furthermore there has not been any discussion of the matter, it was said here tonight.

A bronze plaque commemorating bricks and stones that once were part of Bristol, England, and now are part of New York's East River Drive, was dedicated yesterday at the drive near Twenty-fifth Street.

LONDON, June 29 -- Tonight it appeared that Prime Minister Winston Churchill proposed to let his critics present all their charges against the system that permits him to be Minister of Defense as well as Prime Minister before he attempts to answer them.

Buying by the trade and commission houses retrieved early losses in cotton futures yesterday and succeeded, with the aid of the prevalent shortage of contracts, in establishing final net gains of 10 to 12 points for active months on the New York Cotton Exchange.

Combining product advertising with promotion for War Bonds and Stamps, Shulton, Inc., is scheduling weekly and twice-weekly insurance in 183 newspapers throughout the country in July and August for its Victory Fan and talc combination.

CHICAGO, June 29 -- Former members of the German-American Bund are expected to be called tomorrow before the special Federal grand jury investigating seditious activities in the Chicago area. J. Albert Woll, United States attorney, said today that the decision to turn the spotlight on the bund was made prior to the arrest of eight Nazi saboteurs, two of them Chicagoans.

VICHY, France, June 29 (U.P.) -- German authorities have ordered the deportation of 8,000 persons from Lorraine and fifty French hostages from the industrial area of Northwestern France in an attempt to check a rising tide of anti-Nazi violence, it was announced tonight.

CHUNGKING, June 29 (U.P.) -- Chinese forces, after inflicting at least 10,000 casualties in two and a half weeks, have routed all remnants of the Japanese who sought to dislodge them from strongholds in the Taihang Mountain range, on the Honan-Shansi border, Chinese Army reports said today.

WASHINGTON, June 29 -- President Roosevelt, disappointed with a yield of only 218,998 tons in the first thirteen days of the nationwide scrap rubber campaign, directed today that the collection be continued ten days longer. His hope is that the drive will bring in enough scrap rubber to meet all military needs and provide some for civilian uses, thus averting the need for nation-wide gasoline rationing.

Joseph E. Davies, former Ambassador to Russia and author of "Mission to Moscow," has written an epilogue to his book to commemorate the first anniversary of the German attack on the Soviet Union. The epilogue, which includes a chronology of the first year of the war, may be obtained by writing the publishers, Simon Schuster.

Eighty-seven thousand dollars was realized yesterday at the first day of the special sale of art from the William Randolph Hearst collection at Gimbel Brothers, Eight thousand visitors attended the sale, buying works of art costing from thousands of dollars to small sums, according to Frederic A. Gimbel, managing director of Gimbel Brothers.

Physical instructors and athletes with college degrees can qualify for chief specialist ratings in the Navy under a new recruiting program announced in New York yesterday. This program is under the direction of Commander Gene Tunney.

The transfer of 1,000 students registered in Townsend Harris High School, which was closed by the Board of Higher Education after the Board of Estimate withheld funds for its reopening, to the other high schools in the city is proceeding with difficulty and may result in the loss of one or two terms in a majority of cases, it was learned yesterday from school officials in charge of the shift.

The suggestion was made in these columns on June 13 that some American town honor itself by taking the name of the Bohemian village which the Nazis announced on June 10 that they had "extinguished." They had, indeed, done all that Nazis can do. They had murdered all the men, placed all the women in internment camps, sent all the children to Nazi "schools," burned all the houses.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., June 29 -- The failure of some industries to convert quickly to production of war goods may cause post-war repercussions, Eugene Casey, an executive assistant to President Roosevelt, warned today. His statement was made at a press conference in connection with the meeting of the National Industrial Advertisers Association here today.

"Best Foot Forward," the musical comedy by John Cecil Holm, Hugh Martin and Ralph Blane, presently at the Barrymore, will close after the Saturday evening performance, which will be the 325th since it opened on Oct. 1, 1941.

HONOLULU, June 29 CUP) -- United States Army bombers early Saturday "blasted the hell" out of Japanese military installations on Wake Island and probably crippled the enemy air base, it was announced today. The raid, coming closely after the Midway sea victory, may presage other offensive missions against the Japanese.

WASHINGTON, June 29 -- Implications that at least six and possibly all of the eight German saboteurs would be turned over to the War Department for prosecution were seen in a statement issued tonight by Attorney General Francis J. Biddle.

LONDON, June 29 -- The Royal Air Force struck heavily at Germany's war centers in Northwestern France last night and today, pounding the railway junction at Hazebrouck during daylight after a night bombing attack on the U-boat station at St. Nazaire.

WASHINGTON, June 29 -- An attempt of Senator Smathers of New Jersey to bring up the hotly contested nomination of Thomas F. Meaney, alleged "pawn" of Mayor Frank Haggle of Jersey City, to be a Federal District judge in New Jersey was blocked in the Senate today.

Five public school children, cited for outstanding character and scholarship, received certificates and cash awards yesterday as winners of the Rebecca Elsberg and M. Samuel Stern Memorial Prizes. The awards were presented by Dr. John E. Wade, Superintendent of Schools, at the Board of Education.

LONDON, June 29 -- There was nothing encouraging in any of the news that came today from Egypt, where a terrific but unequal struggle has been raging back and forth, across the desert west of Matruh between the Axis armorea troops of General Field Marshal Erwin Rommel and the depleted forces of the British Eighth Army.

WITH BRITISH FORCES, near Matruh, Egypt, June 28 (Delayed) (U.P.) -- General Field Marshal Erwin Rommel sent his tanks and 88-mm. guns weaving across the desert today to by-pass Matruh. The British Eighth Army, fighting with screens of armored cars, sought to meet every Axis feint, but at best its operations appeared to be mainly of a delaying nature in a bid for time.

Pedro Hernandez, Puerto Rican featherweight, registered a surprise when he outpointed Charley (Lulu) Costantino in the feature eight-round bout at Dexter Park, which opened last night. Hernandez, the 4-to-1 underdog in the betting, thrilled a crowd of 4,000 fans by the ease with which he handled his rival.

The "confusing and complicated situation" which, has arisen with regard to the labels of wholesale distributors of peaches, pears, apricots and cherries, because of the restrictions on canners' supplies of sugar, affects the position of wholesale grocers "particularly and seriously," the National-American Wholesale Grocers Association declared yesterday in a special bulletin to its members.

RICHMOND, Va., June 29 (AP) -- Governor Colgate W. Darden Jr. promised tonight a decision tomorrow on the plea of counsel for Odell Waller, 25-year-old Negro, for commutation of his death sentence imposed in Pittsylvania County in September, 1940, for the slaying of Oscar Davis, a white tenant farmer.
When final tabulations of war bond pledges are made, New York City and all up-State cities combined will have signed for approximately 16.2 per cent of the national war bond quota of $12,000,000,000.

OSTERVILLE, Mass., June 29 (AP) -- After missing six putts from eight feet, Ben Loving of Longmeadow, the New England P.G.A. champion, today gained a twostroke lead on seventy-four rivals in the Massachusetts open golf championship by carding 71, 68 -- 139, five under par, for his first half of the seventy-two-hole competition at Oyster Harbors.

WASHINGTON, June 29 -- Special provisions to make it possible for contractors in the apparel industry to include higher labor costs in their charges were made by the Office of Price Administration today in a regulation effective tomorrow.

With the fall of Matruh the strongest defensive position between the Egyptian border and the Nile Valley has been lost. Its abandonment after so brief a fight must mean that the British are hoping to gain time to regroup and replenish their hard-pressed armies.
TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Every American institution of learning should require the study of United States history. It should be one of the "must" subjects for graduation.

LONDON, Tuesday, June 30 (U.P.) -- The German battleship Gneisenau, her gun turrets dismantled and her decks ripped by bomb hits scored by the Royal Air Force at Brest, in the English Channel, and at Kiel, lies at the Polish harbor of Gdynia, so badly crippled that she may be left there for the duration of the war, the Air Ministry announced today.

In spite of more adverse news from Egypt, the stock market was able yesterday to move irregularly higher on balance with a major spurt centering in the railroad issues. In relationship to the volume, the turnover in the carrier group was abnormal, and trading centered in this section most of the session.

WASHINGTON, June 29 -- American bombers struck successfully at Wake Island on Saturday for the second time since the small Pacific Ocean outpost fell to the Japanese on Dec. 23, the Navy Department announced in a communique issued here today.
CHUNGKING, June 29 (AP) -- The Chinese High Command communique said:

A severer shortage of gasoline in September, when railroad tank cars must be diverted to shipping fuel oil for heating and power, was forecast by the Petroleum Coordinator's office here yesterday. At the same time Lee S. Buckingham, State OPA Director, 535 Fifth Avenue, released copies of the blank application for supplemental gasoline ration books to be used after registration for permanent rationing on July 9, 10 and 11.

Four more United Nations vessels have been sunk in waters on this side of the Atlantic by enemy submarines or mines, it was disclosed yesterday by the Navy. Twenty-one sailors lost their lives in the sinkings, which brought the unofficial total of ships sunk in the Western Atlantic, Gulf of Mexico and Caribbean since Pearl Harbor to 324.

A strike of building and maintenance men employed at Parkchester, the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company's housing development in the East Tremont section of the Bronx, was called yesterday by Local 32-E of the Building Service Employes Union, A.F. of L., after negotiations between the management and the union ended in a deadlock.

The Society for the Promotion of Engineering Education ended its fiftieth annual meeting yesterday morning with sectional conferences at Columbia University, New York University, Cooper Union, Brooklyn Polytechnic, Newark College of Engineering, Stevens Institute and Pratt Institute.

WASHINGTON, June 29 -- In an effort to work its way out of a log-jam of supply bills before the end of the fiscal year tomorrow night, the House Held a night session to debate the $1,830,487,615 First Supplemental Defense Appropriation Bill.
NEW YORK Leslie, Lady Doverdale, of London is at the Savoy-Plaza.

Governor Darden of Virginia yesterday took up the painful task of determining whether or not he would commute the death sentence of Odell Waller, Negro sharecropper convicted of killing his landlord. This is no question between guilt and innocence, but of a degree of guilt.

CHICAGO, June 29 -- General liquidation in July grain contracts developed on the Board of Trade today and with some stop loss orders uncovered July wheat and oats declined to new low prices since mid-October. Oats led the break and finished 2 1/8 cents a bushel lower, while the deferred deliveries of that grain were 1 1/2 to 1 5/8 cents off.

WASHINGTON, June 29 -- Criticism, of the gasoline and sugar rationing programs flared again in the Senate today while its Commerce Committee heard conflicting testimony on the value of the proposed Florida barge canal and pipe line as means of meeting the East Coast shortage.

The ninth biweekly collection of tin cans by the Department of Sanitation for the reclaiming of vitally needed tin will be held tomorrow and Thursday, according to Clarence H. Low, chairman of the New York City Salvage Committee.

AFTER a whirl around the East, during which they broke even in ten games, the Pirates went westward. Onkel Franz Frisch, of course, went with them. Sadly. He hated to leave his flower garden in New Rochelle. He grows particularly fancy petunias. He claims that's how he got the job as staff assistant to Lippy Leo Durocher in handling the National League strategy in the All-Star game just ahead.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The loss of our sources of raw rubber in the East Indies and the inadequate response of the general public to the scrap-collecting campaign would make it seem urgent to recruit every available expert in the conservation of natural rubber and the production of substitutes.

Marking the sixth consecutive weekly decline, dollar sales volume of New York and Brooklyn department stores last week showed a decrease of 10 per cent under the corresponding period last year, according to the report issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.

PHILADELPHIA, June 29 -- In a raggedly played game that wound up in a ninth-inning runaway when the Brooks scored six times, the National League-leading Dodgers tonight walloped the Phils, 10 -- 3, to increase their lead over the idle Cardinals to nine and one-half games.

Men's Clothing Sales Spotty Although the general tone of the men's clothing market continues spotty, retail sales in sections of the Middle West were reported improved in manufacturing circles here yesterday. Local retail sales were slightly ragged in the East during the latter part of last week, but the pick-up in the West, where clothing sales have been quite poor, created a greater note of confidence in selling circles.

CLEVELAND, June 29 -- More than 300 members and guests of the Institute of Radio Engineers, opening a three-day convention, were assured today that while the radio industry is "doing a tremendous job in the war effort," there is danger of a "too-confined compartmentalization of knowledge," resulting in duplication of effort and consequent loss of contribution.

LONDON, June 29 (U.P.) -- The Germans have massacred more than 1,000,000 Jews since the war began in carrying out Adolf Hitler's proclaimed policy of exterminating the people, spokesmen for the World Jewish Congress charged today.

The disbarment of Dr. Maxwell Ross, Democratic leader of the Twenty-third Assembly District in Brooklyn, which comprises the Brownsville section of that borough, has been recommended to the Appellate Division in Brooklyn by one of Special Prosecutor John Harlan Amen's extraordinary grand juries, it was disclosed yesterday.

Ten cousins share equally the net estate of Mrs. Ida E. Wood, 93-year-old Herald Square Hotel recluse and widow of former Representative Benjamin Wood, who died on March 12, 1932. The beneficiaries, cousins once removed, receive $62,855 each, it was disclosed yesterday in a transfer tax appraisal.

CHICAGO, June 29 (AP) -- Arrivals of hogs today were only moderate and prices held relatively steady. Heavier "lard hogs" and sows, however, were weak to 10 cents a hundred pounds lower. Top price was again $14.70, the same as on Friday and at a peak since September, 1926. Eastern shippers supported the market, taking 2.500 head.

BERLIN, June 29 (From German broadcasts) -- Axis forces smashing eastward in Egypt stormed and captured today the fortress of Matruh, British bastion in the path of General Field Marshal Erwin Rommel's drive toward Alexandria, the German High Command has announced.

DENVER, June 29 -- Declaring that the country's school teachers had brought a defeatist attitude into the classroom in the last two decades, Governor Ralph L. Carr of Colorado told the delegates to the National Education Association's convention today that they should work to give students a more constructive viewpoint, and that this could be done in no better way than through a study of world and American history.

Contrary to opinion voiced in government circles, a retail inventory limitation order would be "overwhelmingly unpopular" with the great majority of smaller retailers it proposes to aid, according to advance returns from a questionnaire recently issued by the New York State Council of Retail Merchants, made public yesterday.

Another Treasury Call Commercial bank depositaries of the government were notified yesterday by the Treasury that it will withdraw $95,418,000 on Thursday from these depositaries in the Second Federal Reserve District, and a like amount on Friday.

"Mrs. Miniver," which will enter its fifth week at the Radio City Music Hall on Thursday, set a new attendance record by playing to 558,966 persons for the twenty-five-day period ending Sunday night, the management reported yesterday.

The three and one-half-year investigation of John Harlan Amen, Special Prosecutor, into official corruption in Brooklyn, believed to be the longest special law enforcement inquiry in the country, virtually came to an end yesterday with the announcement that Mr. Amen's two extraordinary grand juries would be discharged from duty today before Justice John MacCrate in Brooklyn Supreme Court.

WASHINGTON, June 29 -- Constant overburdening of telephone facilities may necessitate a priority system on calls in order to lighten the load, James L. Fly, chairman of the Federal Communications Commission, said today. A short time later the Senate confirmed the nomination of Mr. Fly for reappointment to the FCC.

WASHINGTON, June 29 -- President Roosevelt signed today a measure continuing for two years the 3 1/2 per cent interest rate on Federal Land Bank loans, but criticized the Congress for failing to take action on Administration recommendations which would eliminate the need for a Federal subsidy to continue low interest rates for the farmers.

WASHINGTON, June 29 -- Although June will fall below the $800,000,000 quota of war bond sales assigned for that month by the Treasury, State bond quotas totaling $1,000,000,000 -- the mark originally aimed at -- were set for July today Toy Secretary Morgenthau.
The business of two old. Wall Street firms whose histories go back a hundred years or more will be combined tomorrow when Mackay Co. joins Laidlaw Co.

WASHINGTON, June 29 -- Sales of all retail stores were estimated today by the Commerce Department at 54,437,000,000 in May, fractionally below sales in April. Retail trade in May continued the decline under way since February, with the department's seasonally adjusted index dropping to 136, compared with 137 in April of this year and 143 in May of 1941.

WASHINGTON, June 29 -- Administration of the rent ceilings imposed by the Office of Price Administration will be seriously handicapped if the OPA is compelled to operate on the $75,000,000 which the House Appropriations Committee has recommended, officials said tonight.

Richard Frederick Fruendt, 55 years old, of 11 East Seventy-fifth Street, Manhattan, pleaded guilty yesterday to the second count of an indictment handed up on Monday by the Federal grand jury in Brooklyn. The count charges that he conspired to supply defense information to Germany before the entrance of this country into the war
LONDON, June 30 -- The Air Ministry and the War Office are still debating the value of dive bombers, it was indicated in Parliament today.
The armored spearhead of Axis tanks had roared to within 100 miles of Alexandria last night and there were no signs that the impetus of the enemy drive had yet been checked.

RICHMOND, Va., June 30 -Quoting the opinion of the Virginia Supreme Court of Appeals that Odell Waller had received "a fair and impartial trial," Governor Darden declined tonight to interfere with the 25-year-old Negro's death sentence for the murder of a white tenant farmer.

BERLIN, June 30 (From German broadcast recorded by The United Press in New York) -- German troops storming Sevastopol from the north have crossed Syevernaya Bay, north of the city, and other forces attacking from the east have penetrated the inner ring of Russian fortifications, the High Command reported today.

CHUNGKING, China, June 30 (AP) -- Japanese forces in Kiangsi Province appeared tonight to have opened a new phase of their East China campaign with indications that the coastal province of Fukien might be their next objective.

With production of toys or games of metals or other critical materials ending yesterday in accordance with WPB limitation order L-81, trade estimates indicated that at least 70 per cent of retailer requirements of all types of playthings for the holiday season had been shipped or were en route to distributors.

Dillon, Read Co. and Glore, Forgan Co, are heading an underwriting group which today is offering an issue of $35,000,000 of Celanese Corporation of America 3 1/2 per cent debentures, due 1962, at 99 1/2 and accrued interest.

BOSTON, June 30 (AP) -- The Red Sox celebrated their return to Fenway Park today by banging out twenty-six hits for a total of forty-five bases, while sweeping a double-header from the Senators, 9 -- 8 and 5 -- 2.

MOSCOW, June 30 -- The German offensive in the Kursk sector is being developed on a big scale and many hundreds of tanks, followed by waves of German and Hungarian infantry, are pressing against lines held by Russian infantry. In several places these lines have been pierced, but Soviet riflemen and grenadiers are holding their positions, even after the tanks have gone on ahead, and are stemming the oncoming infantry and inflicting heavy losses.

A plan to use dogs to patrol the foggy beaches of Long Island on the watch for enemy landings was proposed yesterday by Lieut. Comdr. McClelland Barclay, U.S.N.R., the illustrator who has been creating posters to publicize the work of dogs for defense.

WASHINGTON, June 30 -- By two unanimous votes the Senate and House today completed legislative action on the $42,820,003,067 War Department Appropriation Bill for the fiscal year beginning tomorrow and thus sent the largest appropriation measure in the nation's history to the White House.

MONTCLAIR, N.J., June 30 -- Led by Robert Odman of the University of Washington, a field of forty players from twenty-three colleges started out in the Eastern intercollegiate tennis championship today on the clay courts of the Montclair A.C.

WASHINGTON, June 30 (AP) -- An Arkansas Negro who once successfully protested against his indictment by an all-white grand jury appealed to the Supreme Court today complaining that subsequently he was indicted by an all-Negro grand jury, which he contended was equally unfair.

A UNITED STATES EMBARKATION PORT (Undated, Delayed) -- Long lines of men in single file, laden with packs, rifles, helmets, gas masks and the field equipment of soldiers of 1942, file up the gangplanks of a row of gray-hued transports whose sides bear patches of rust accumulated in other voyages.

The Consolidated Gas, Electric Light and Power Company of Baltimore, in its report for the twelve months ended on May 31, issued yesterday, shows a net income, after taxes and charges, of $6,546,922. This was equal, after preferred dividend requirements, to $4.51 a share on the company's outstanding common stock,

The two-story building on an irregular plot 25 by 83.8 feet at 158 West Fifty-sixth Street was bought by Leo Salomon from the North River Savings Bank, through Brett, Wyckoff, Potter, Hamilton, Inc., brokers. The purchaser now controls a seventy-five-foot plot on West Fifty-sixth Street.

With the completion yesterday of the nation's fifth draft registration, in which the 18, 19 and 20-year-old sons of many Americans who fought in the first World War enrolled from coast to coast, the government's roster of its manpower now has approximately 43,000,000 men listed in Selective Service files or already in uniform.

After the longest record of service in the history of the New York Public Library, Dr. Frank Weitenkampf, dean of American print curators, retired yesterday. He had been continuously in the library's service for sixty-one years, since 1921 as chief of the prints division.

Formation of a State-wide "draft Willkie" committee, with the twofold purpose of getting Wendell L. Willkie to be the Republican candidate for Governor and then getting the Republican State leadership to switch to Mr. Willkie from Thomas E. Dewey, was announced yesterday.

DENVER, June 30 -- In the coming school year the United States faces a shortage of 50,000 teachers, which will result in the forced closing of a "considerable" number of schools, particularly in the rural areas, Dr. John W. Studebaker, United States Commissioner of Education, said today.

It seems now to be generally realized that the Administration has made a mess of sugar, costing the Treasury and private industry more than one billion dollars, needlessly paralyzing not only the sugar industry but numerous allied industries as well, throwing tens of thousands of people out of their jobs, climaxed this week by the closing of the Edgewater refinery, where more than 1,000 men were given their discharge.

Food as a weapon was the subject of a panel discussion yesterday after a "Food-Victory" luncheon at the New York Institute of Diatetics, 660 Madison Avenue. Nutrition experts took part in this discussion, under the leadership of Dr. Walter H. Eddy, Professor Emeritus of Psychological Chemistry at Columbia University.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., June 30 -- Mayor James J. Donovan of Bayonne, his deputy, Daniel J. Sweeney; Police Chief Cornelius J. O'Neill and two detectives were indicted today by the Hudson County grand jury on charges of misconduct in office.

The first of ten monster air raid sirens ordered by the city and described by their manufacturer as so powerful that they will carry for eight miles and "will break the eardrums of any one standing within 200 feet" when they are sounded, has arrived here and will probably be tested at noon Saturday, it became known yesterday.

The selection of former State Attorney General Carl Sherman to oppose Joseph Clark Baldwin for Congress in the Seventeenth Congressional District was announced yesterday at Tammany Hall, after a conference of the district leaders whose sections are included in that area.

LONDON, June 30 -- Bomber and fighter squadrons of the Royal Canadian Air Force now serving in Britain will be increased in strength by 50 per cent, Air Vice Marshal Harold Edwards announced here today. There will be no change in the operational set-up between the Canadians and the Royal Air Force, he added.

The Phils look no better to the Giants after dark than they do in the sunshine. The New Yorkers defeated the Philadelphians, 4 to 3, in a twilight-night game before a crowd of only 3,252 paid, the smallest at the Polo Grounds this season, last night.

When politics and strategy are translated into human terms, as they finally must be. Rommel's advance into Egypt narrows by so much the area within which any individual is protected by any law. The shadow of a blacker night than the so-called Dark Ages ever saw hangs over Alexandria, Cairo and the entire Near East.

CINCINNATI, June 30 (AP) -- The Reds overcame the Cubs by 4 to 1 tonight to cap a program which netted the Army-Navy relief funds more than $36,000 and rubber-armed Ray Starr his eleventh victory of the year.

Lady Decies gave a dinner last night in the Starlight Roof of the Waldorf-Astoria for her son, John Dahlgren, to celebrate his birthday. Among the guests were Mr. and Mrs. Griswold A. Thompson, Baroness de Villiers Terrage, Mr. and Mrs. Maurice Grill, Mrs. M. Duke Biddle, ]Vfrs. Leonora I-I. Warner, Mrs. Gustav Porges, Mrs. Reginald T. Townsend, Major George Howard McCully, Judge Jeremiah T. Mahoney, Huntington Hartford and Isaac Norton.

New Yorkers who have been initiated by degrees during the last two days into the new bus regulations whereby the distances between stops have been lengthened from two to four blocks are nearing the end of their period of grace.

MELBOURNE, Australia, June 30 -- The Netherlands Indies Government Information Service reports that a Japanese court martial has punished more Netherlanders in Java for listening to foreign radios. Two were sentenced to death, two to five years' and one to five months' imprisonment, according to the Japanese-controlled Batavia radio.

The collection of rubber scrap throughout the New York metropolitan area broke all records for a single day yesterday when 507 tons was checked in at the bulk plants, bringing the accumulated grand total for the drive to 3,494 tons.

WASHINGTON, June 30 -- Details of the intensified scrap campaign which will open on a nationwide scale July 13 were made public today by Donald M. Nelson, chairman of the War Production Board, and by Lessing J. Rosenwald, chief of WPB's Bureau of Industrial Conservation.

The four-story apartment building for twenty families at 1515 West First Street, Brooklyn, was sold by the 1502 Realty Company, Inc., to Max Silver, subject to three mortgages aggregating $52,930. This structure is on an irregular plot 111.3 by 145.7 feet.

The nation-wide crusade of public health education, sponsored by the Institute of Life Insurance as a new, major contribution to the war effort, will use signed statements by many of the leading medical and health authorities in a series of advertisements scheduled to appear in 281 newspapers with a combined circulation of 22,000,000.

An audience of 2,700 attended "Switzerland on Broadway," the Swiss musical festival which was presented last night by 150 SwissAmericans at the Cosmopolitan Opera House. The event was sponsored by the Swiss division of the USO as part of its campaign to raise $20,000 for the Greater New York United Service Organizations.

MINEOLA, L.I., June 30 -The Army has designated Nassau County as the first county in the United States to conduct a school for "civilian reconnaissance agents," it was announced here today by Colonel Edward C.O. Thomas, Nassau County director of civilian protection. He said the training and duties of the agents "will be highly secret and confidential."

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., June 30 -- All charges that Mrs. Anna H. Paton was fradulently influenced when she made her will disposing of a fortune that once amounted to $1,300,000 were dismissed by Surrogate Charles D. Millard today, two weeks after a trial of a contest over the will had begun before the surrogate and a jury.

Providence, R.I., June 30 (U.P.) -Nicholas Hansen, 27 years old, who was born and brought up in Newport, was arrested today on a charge of "advocating the destruction of the United States Government by force" after he allegedly confessed he would have been willing to blow up the Newport torpedo station for Hitler.

WASHINGTON, June 30 -- Any Senator who votes for the confirmation of Thomas F. Meaney as a Federal District judge for the District of New Jersey "will have to face that issue on the stump this Fall if he is up for re-election," Senator Norris warned the Senate today in opening debate on the nomination of this alleged "pawn" of Mayor Hague of Jersey City.

WASHINGTON, June 30 -- The general feeling among the war administrators seems to be that, if the War Labor Board orders the dollar-a-day wage increase for "Little Steel" workers which its panel has found their employers "able to pay," the head of the inflation camel will be well within the price-control tent.
FORT DIX, N.J., June 30 -- The ghost walked through company streets in $50 boots here today, but the echo of his footfalls was hollow and melancholy.
CAIRO, June 30 (AP) -- British headquarters communique said today:

WASHINGTON, June 30 -- Brig. Gen. James H. Doolittle, who recently won the Congressional Medal of Honor for leading the air raid on Tokyo, received today the Daniel Guggenheim Medal for notable achievement in the advancement of aeronautics.

Critics of Mayor La Guardia's proposal that men deferred in the Selective Service be used for patrol and other home-front duty were bitterly rebuked yesterday by the Mayor at the induction of 100 rookies at Fire Department Emergency Auxiliary Headquarters in Engine Company 31, at 87 Lafayette Street.

CANBERRA, Australia, June 30 -- To help overcome recent heavy losses of Allied shipping Australia will expedite her augmented merchant and naval shipbuilding program. This is a shift from the recent plan to concentrate on maintenance instead of construction.

An offer of 2,000 school buses throughout the State for use as emergency transportation to get essential war workers to and from their jobs if acute shortages of regular transportation should develop was made yesterday by Benjamin R. Miller, representative of the State Department of Education on the State War Transportation Committee.

WASHINGTON, June 30 -- Secretary Ickes, as generalissimo of the scrap rubber campaign, is not afraid of President Roosevelt, but he is scared of Congress. He admitted as much today in a letter to Vice President Wallace and Speaker Rayburn, appealing to Congress to give up the rubber mats under its cuspidors.

With no material change in the war news, the stock market held yesterday to a mixed course as interest continued to center in the railroad issues. Trading on the Stock Exchange was even smaller than on Monday, with sales 248,480 shares, against 262,293.

CAIRO, Egypt, June 30 (UP) -Premier Mustapha Nahas Pasha told Parliament today that he had received a message from British Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden reiterating that Britain not only was resolved to defend Egyptian territory, but had available ways and means of doing so.
WASHINGTON, June 30 -- President Roosevelt directed all Federal agencies to locate and turn in "every possible ounce" of scrap rubber.

WASHINGTON, June 30 (AP) -The War Department said today that the Army urgently needed cameras and lenses for 35 mm. motion picture cameras and called upon the public to sell any they have to the government.

WASHINGTON, June 30 (AP) -The Class I railroads had an estimated net income of $63,600,000 in May, compared with $43,137,083 in May, 1941. This brought the estimated net income, after interest and rentals, to $211,500,000 for the first five months of 1942, an increase of $92,000,000 over the corresponding period a year ago.
WASHINGTON, June 30 -- A sales loss of 5 per cent for May as compared with May, 1941, was reported by independent retailers, according to an announcement released today by the Bureau of the Census.

DETROIT, Mich., June 30 -- Nazi Air Oberleutnant Hans Peter Krug testified today concerning aid given to him by Max Stephan, Detroit tavern keeper, after he had escaped from an Ontario prison camp into this country.

New securities offered to the public here in June, while in somewhat larger volume than in the preceding month, were the smallest for any June in several years. Bond offerings were the lightest for any June since 1932, while stock emissions were the lowest for that month since 1940.

That old and seasoned warrior, Senator Norris of Nebraska, fought one of his best battles yesterday against the confirmation of Mr. Hague's candidate, Thomas F. Meaney, as Federal District Judge in New Jersey. Senator Norris addressed himself to the one pertinent issue, which was not the personal qualities of Mr. Meaney but Mr. Meaney's relationships with Mayor Hague.

Brisk buying by Wall Street and New Orleans interests, evidently emanating from the bullish sentiment engendered by renewed hopes of loans at 100 per cent of parity, was the principal factor in substantial gains established yesterday in cotton futures.

Our convictions concerning the tomato coincide with those held by a Dutch herbalist named Dodoens. Some years ago -- in 1583, to be exact -- this gentleman defined the vegetable as a food best eaten with pepper and salt and a bit of oil. In doing so, he seems to have summed up the subject in admirable fashion.
President Manuel Quezon of the Philippine Commonwealth left New York yesterday with his wife and three children for Lynchburg, Va., where he intends to spend the Summer resting under doctors' orders.

NOROTON, Conn., June 30 -- One point, or a single boat's position in a race, separates the two leaders of the Star Class sloops in the series for the John Taylor Arms Trophy, which will be concluded tomorrow.

Brushing aside suggestions designed to save the jobs of seventy-five Welfare Department social investigators, the Fusion majority in the Board of Estimate put through a resolution yesterday dropping them from the payroll because the Court of Appeals had decided that they were entitled to salary increments and back pay amounting to $85,000.

MOSCOW, Wednesday, July 1 -- The Red Army has launched a series of successful counter-attacks on the Kursk front, where Germany's great offensive, now in its fourth day, continues to smash in vain with waves of tanks and infantry at unyielding Russian lines.

WASHINGTON, June 30 -- This is a story that can now be told of how Secretary of State Cordell Hull, with consummate diplomacy, saved the situation when United States customs officials demanded that Canadian military forces, moving hurriedly into Alaska to strengthen defenses in connection with the Japanese landings in the Aleutians, pay duty to the United States on their spare uniforms and their fighting equipment.

With a message of thanks and encouragement from Secretary of the Treasury Henry Morgenthau Jr., 1,000 executives of department and retail stores launched last night their "Retailers for Victory" drive for the sale of war stamps and bonds this month.

The Bulova Watch Company, Inc., and its subsidiaries had a net income in the fiscal year ended on March 31 of $3,759,021 before Federal, State, social security and other taxes, and $2,000,145, or $6.15 a share, on 324,881 shares, after taxes, according to the annual report of Arde Bulova, chairman of the board.

WASHINGTON, June 30 -- The United States is rapidly becoming the world's workshop, is simultaneously ceasing to be a supplier of raw materials and is building up a record export balance for 1942, judging by one of $1,250,000,000 for the first four months of the year, the Commerce Department reported today.

WASHINGTON, June 30 -- The Garment Box Manufacturers Association of New York, made up of manufacturers supplying a substantial part of the national production of boxes used by the wholesale and retail garment trade, was charged today with a price-fixing combination and conspiracy in a complaint issued by the Federal Trade Commission.

Georgie (Sonny) Horne, undefeated middleweight from Niles, Ohio, outpointed Jerry Fiorello of Brooklyn in the star bout of six rounds at the Queensboro Arena lats night before 3,500 fans. Horne weighed 153 pounds as against 151 for Fiorello.

WEBBWOOD, Ont., June 30 (Canadian Press) -- Mme. Veronica Saint Michel of Webbwood, 64-year-old French-Canadian widow, told in an interview here today how butter and egg money she saved twenty-four years ago gave her the distinction of being proprietor of the Peasoup Mine, Ontario's newest and smallest producer of copper ore.

WASHINGTON, June 30 -- Control over imported commodities was extended by the War Production Board today to include goods in bond or afloat. In a ruling issued by J.S. Knowlson, Director of Industry Operations, effective Thursday, persons seeking to import materials on Lists I, II and III of Order M-63 covering general imports must file a special form with the WPB asking authorization for the importation, whether in bond or otherwise.

FORT BRAGG, N.C., June 30 -- When civilians hear the word "Geronimo" they think of the Indian by that name who terrorized the West years ago, but to Army men it is the yell of the parachutist as he dives from his big Army transport and starts floating to the ground.

Giving to this city a bronze plaque commemorating the site of broken bricks and stones brought here from the bombing of Bristol, the English-Speaking Union has given not only a reminder of British courage but of a historical sympathy and connection. Bristol, so long the second English city, is situated like New York at the junction of two rivers.

It is the plain duty of every loyal citizen of the United States to scotch all criticism of the British war effort, unjust criticism that invariably crops up whenever British arms suffer reverses, Wendell L. Willkie told a group of business and financial leaders at a luncheon meeting yesterday of the commerce and industry division of the British War Relief Society, Inc., at the Bankers Club.

WASHINGTON, June 30 -- The Treasury Department has suggested to the House Ways and Means Committee that some type of debt moratorium be improvised for taxpayers who may find it difficult to meet pre-war commitments and at the same time increased taxes.

LONDON, June 30 -- Bremen was pounded again early this morning by British night raiders returning to that German city for the third time in a week, the British Air Ministry announced. Nine planes out of a strong force failed to come home.

WASHINGTON, June 30 -- The formation of a Women's Auxiliary of the Air Youth Division of the National Aeronautical Association was disclosed today by Mrs. Clarence Norton Goodwin, chairman of the auxiliary.

WASHINGTON, June 30 (AP) -- A schedule of big-time football for soldiers was outlined at the War Department today after the appointment of Grantland Rice, sports columnist, as head of a civilian corporation set up to handle details of the program.

MELBOURNE, Australia, Wednesday, July 1 -- Allied land forces swooped down on Salamaua, Japan's largest invasion base in New Guinea, and "successfully engaged" the garrison in a hit-run raid, it was announced today. Striking swiftly and silently under cover of darkness, the raiders killed or wounded sixty Japanese troops and captured military equipment, then faded back into the jungle, a United Nations communique revealed.

Tokyo must be studying the 2,000-mile flight of our Army bombers from Hawaii to Wake Island with considerable concern. It is probably the longest over-water bombing raid ever made, and there is no indication that the round trip taxed the full range of these powerful fliers.

WASHINGTON, June 30 -- The National War Labor Board ruled today that its jurisdiction was broad and sweeping and that it had authority to consider, as a "major dispute," any controversy which not only directly concerned a large number of workers but which also affected the daily lives of a large number of people.
MAMARONECK, N.Y., June 30 -- Alex Watson of Hudson River was the winning pro for the second straight week in the Westchester pro-amateur best-ball competition at Quaker Ridge today.
MOSCOW, June 30 (AP) -- The Soviet Information Bureau broadcast this communique today:

LONDON, June 30 (AP) -- The German U-boat nest at Bremen was attacked heavily last night by the Royal Air Force and an informed source declared the cumulative destruction inflicted there has put the Nazis' second biggest port "in much the same state as Cologne, Emden, Luebeck and Rostock."

As buyers of $5 automobile use tax stamps for mandatory display today rushed internal revenue and postoffices, a survey yesterday showed that the annual Federal tax had been paid for only 180,000 of the 800,000 motor vehicles registered in the city.

LONDON, June 30 -- Despite the fact that the shortage of shipping is supposed to be the main obstacle to the United Nations opening of a front on the Continent or elsewhere. W. Averell Harriman, lease-lend coordinator, today said that so far the shortage of ships had not affected the transport of American supplies to any place in the war theatres.

THE eminent John T. (Terry) McGovern, who has been connected with intercollegiate, A.A.U. and Olympic athletics for many years, recently received a letter from Lieut. Col. Evan A. Hunter, secretary of the British Olympic Association, in which there was mention of some great British athletes of other years and what they are doing now.

Rugs designed by contemporary American artists have been placed on view at the Museum of Modern Art. Most of the designs are on the abstract side. A number of them are handsome and effective. While it may be doubted if members of the American Scene school would regard the outcome as rugged American art, the results, on the whole, certainly warrant the endeavor and provide striking adjuncts to modern decoration for the home.

A group of twelve triptychs designed for use in camps and on ships in religious services may be seen today, tomorrow and Friday at the headquarters of the Citizens Committee for the Army and Navy, Second Region Council, 36 East Thirty-sixth Street.

PHILADELPHIA, June 30 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission approved today a plan whereby North Western Illinois Utilities will sell all of its telephone properties to the Illinois North Western Telephone Company in exchange for $75,000 of common stock and $125,000 of 4 per cent promissory notes of the telephone concern.
CHUNGKING, June 30 (AP) -- The Chinese High Command communique said:

Directors of the American Can Company declared yesterday a dividend of 75 cents a share on the common stock, representing a reduction of 25 cents from the previous quarterly rate that has been maintained since 1930.

NYACK, N.Y., June 30 -- The versatile Office of Price Administration stretched its mighty arms into the folksy streets of Nyack today and, with the aid of thirty-five women citizens, staged one of the most successful and telling dramas of the home front.

The thirtieth anniversary of group insurance is observed today. In 1911 William J. Graham, vice president of the Equitable Life Assurance Society of the United States, negotiated the first major group insurance contract for Montgomery Ward Co., covering 2,900 employes for $5,900,000. The same contract today provides 46,650 employes with $50,000,000 of group life insurance protection. Group insurance now envelops 13,000,000 employes in 30,000 companies for approximately $20,000,000,000.

WASHINGTON, June 30 -- Acceleration of the program to form women's divisions in the various State war savings staffs will be her first responsibility, Miss Harriet Elliott, new chief of the women's section of the Treasury Department's war savings staff, said today.

Application of the scorched earth policy so wrecked the oil wells of Java that the Japanese invaders have been forced to plan the manufacture of a substitute fuel made from sugar and rubber instead of exploiting the mineral resources of the island, a former Netherlands Indies official said yesterday.

Paul Horgan's play, "Yours, A. Lincoln," will be presented at two performances at the Shubert by the Experimental Theatre the evening of Thursday, July 9, and the afternoon of Sunday, July 12. The first performance will be an invitation affair, attended by critics and people active in the theatre.

When the distance for the bus stop goes up from two blocks to four we have a good example of action and counteraction in determining human behavior. In a traveling public the size of New York's there must be thousands of people for whom the choice between bus and subway is decided by a narrow margin of pro and con.

The next three months will tell the story. For our side they will be the worst months of the war. Since early Spring all observers have agreed that this would be a Summer to try the souls and test the courage and endurance of all the nations fighting the Axis.

SCARSDALE, N.Y., June 30 -Gracie Fields and Jimmy Savo appeared with a company of thirty entertainers tonight in the variety revue "Fun for All" at the opening of a Summer season of plays and musical shows in the Scarsdale Theatre.

Because of the war and threats to public safety, Federal, State and city officials joined yesterday in warning against celebrating July 4 with firecrackers and explosives. The hazards of July Fourth fireworks were emphasized and attention was directed to a State law that prohibits the sale or discharge of fireworks except by licensed pyrotechnicians.

The Phillips Petroleum Company, acting in cooperation with the Missouri-Kansas Pipe Line Company, is negotiating with the Columbia Gas and Electric Corporation for the outright purchase of Columbia's majority common stock interest in the Panhandle Eastern Pipe Line Company, it was learned yesterday.

A bomb dropped from a United States naval seaplane patrolling off the Florida coast halted a Portuguese liner en route to New York with 215 refugees traveling under the auspices of the American Jewish Joint Distribution Committee, passengers on the ship reported when they landed yesterday.

CAIRO, Egypt, June 30 (AP) -- Superb generalship of a New Zealand brigadier enabled his troops to make an incredible dash to safety through the encircling Twenty-first German Armored Division after fighting a valuable delaying action twenty-five miles south of Matruh, dispatches from the front said today.

BERNE, Switzerland, June 30 -There is an incongruous note of cautious hesitation apparent in today's Italian press, which plays the story of the Axis armies' continued successes on the North African front under banner headlines, but in editorial comment warns the reader that "although the Egyptian battle is now entering its decisive phase with the initiative in our hands, there are still several questions to be answered."

Reflecting the general improvement in the financial condition of most of the country's railroad systems, rail securities with a par value of more than $2,400,000,000 have been added to the list of securities considered legally eligible for investment by savings banks in this State, it was announced yesterday by the New York State Banking Department.

With school "out" for the Summer vacation, thousands of children, fortunate enough to go to camp, began packing after dismissal from classrooms yesterday and many lost no time leaving for the open country. The peak of the exodus is expected today.

Bright as a banner against a Summer sky, a new red flashes on the scene. A true scarlet for the lips -- to flatter teeth into dazzling whiteness -- and a soft hue for the cheeks, in the form of a creamy rouge which smooths on and seems almost to lie beneath your tanned skin like a healthy fresh-air blush.

Eight hundred American and alien refugees from Nazi-dominated Europe were held last night on the Swedish refugee liner Drottningholm in the most intensive search ever conducted on a ship in New York Harbor.

Two new films will arrive at Broadway theatres this morning. At Loew's Criterion the newcomer will be Metro's "Jackass Mail." Wallace Beery and Marjorie Main head the cast of the Western, and Darryl Hickman, J. Carrol Naish, Joe Yule, Hobart Cavanaugh and William Haade appear in supporting roles. . . .

PUEBLO, Col., June 30 (U.P.) -After forty-two years of blindness, C.O. Clark, 69 years old, has regained his sight. When the bandages were removed yesterday after a delicate eye operation, he saw his wife for the first time.

One of the richest natural gas lines in the country, the Panhandle Eastern Pipe Line Company appears to be on the verge of a new phase of operation. Controlled by the Columbia Gas and Electric interests for many years, Panhandle Eastern has been the subject of much litigation as to ownership and operation by both the Department of Justice and the Missouri-Kansas Pipe Line Company.

Registrations of out-of-town buyers in the market for the week ended yesterday totaled 922, as against 1,070 in the preceding week and 1,056 in the like period of 1941, according to the listings of THE NEW YORK TIMES. Yesterday's arrivals numbered 247, as compared with 506 for last Tuesday.

James A. Farley, principal backer of Attorney General John J. Bennett for Governor on the Democratic ticket, yesterday rejected attempts to get him to take the nomination himself, and in so doing virtually defied any responsible party leaders to try to take the nomination away from Mr. Bennett.

The finance committee of the Detroit City Council yesterday approved the issuance of a total of $17,143,000 of refunding bonds, the flotation of which would complete the city's huge refunding program that has been in progress for some time.

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., June 30 -- Maurice Grosser, an artist of this city, was embarassed by a one-man exhibit today in police court. It was also a one-picture exhibition which followed the arrest of Mr. Grosser on the technical charges of "loitering" and "doing business without a license."

PHILADELPILA, June 30 -- A registration statement covering the issuance of $23,624,410 of general mortgage bonds, ten-year serial notes and common stock, the proceeds to be used to implement a proposed merger of the Cumberland County Power and Light Company,

WASHINGTON, June 30 -- Yielding to a sharply repeated demand by the House, the Senate voted early tonight for abolition of the Civilian Conservation Corps, and for its complete liquidation within twelve months.

The volume of stock trading on the New York Stock Exchange in June was the third smallest for any month in twenty-four years, or since 1918, and the dullest for a corresponding month in twenty-eight years, or since June, 1914, the month prior to the outbreak of the first World War.
A visit by Dr. Isaac Alcalay, former Chief Rabbi of Yugoslavia, marked the annual convention of the Rabbinical Council of America yesterday, in the Riverside Plaza Hotel.

Newspaper advertising played a major role in the success of the Greater New York War Bond Pledge Campaign, Samuel D. Fuson, vice president of Arthur Kudner, Inc., and head of the campaign's advertising committee, reported yesterday to John T. Madden, chairman of the campaign.

FROM the Rio Grande to the Strait of Magellan live some 120,000,000 of our Latin-American neighbors, of whom some 50,000,000 are sick. Pitiful poverty, a submarginal standard of living and general malnutrition make that sickness not an occasional affliction or a temporary pestilence but a chronic condition of life, the normal framework of society.

NEW ORLEANS, June 30 (AP) -The United States Circuit Court of Appeals held today that the National Labor Relations Board, in a case involving an employes' organization of the Southern Bell Telephone Company, had abused discretion confided in it and permitted itself to be enlisted as accuser by a labor union of national scope in its organizational campaign.

LONDON, June 30 (U.P.) -- All underground coal deposits in Britain will become the property of the government tomorrow in conformity with the 1938 Coal Act, which fixed that deadline for private coal owners to surrender their holdings.

MONTCLAIR, N.J., June 30 -- The Women's Metropolitan Golf Association closed its Spring schedule with a one-day tournament over the Montclair Golf Club course today, and a small field of thirty-five starters was led home by Miss Maureen Orcutt of White Beeches, whose score of 36, 29 -- 75 was seven strokes ahead of the nearest competitor.

LYNCHBURG, Va., June 30 (AP) -- The City Attorney of Lynchburg and its Representative in the Virginia House of Delegates were shot and killed in a downtown office building today. Soon after the double murder police pushed their way through the lunch-hour crowd in the corridors to arrest a middle-aged salesman in one of the victims' offices.

WASHINGTON, June 30 -- Announcement of the tribunal that will try the Nazi saboteurs seized in New York and Florida will be made tomorrow, within the forty-eight-hour period mentioned by Attorney General Francis Biddle yesterday, it was said at the Department of Justice today.

In a three-horse finish that sent the leading trio through the beams of the camera in space of a little more than a half length, Don Meade brought the consistent winner Argonne Woods home in front of Blueberry Pie and Bay View yesterday in the featured Questionnaire Handicap at Empire City.
BERLIN, June 30 (From German broadcasts recorded by The Associated Press) -- The German High Command communique said today:

CHICAGO, June 30 -- Liquidation by holders of July grain contracts apparently ran its course in the early trading today on the Board of Trade, and with an enlargement in buying power wheat advanced quickly and closed at the top with gains of 1 3/8 to 1 1/2 cents a bushel.

Events today: New York Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra, Fritz Reiner conducting, Lewisohn Stadium, 8:30 P.M.; Goldman Band, Edwin Franko Goldman conducting, the Mall, Central Park, 8:30; Rockefeller Center Choristers, John R. Jones conducting, patriotic concert, lower plaza of Rockefeller Center, 5:30.

Consolidation of Evans, Stillman Co. and Maynard, Oakley Lawrence under the name of Stillman, Maynard Co. becomes effective today. All the general partners of both firms will continue as partners of the new concern. Howard A. Plummer, however, who has been a limited partner of Evans, Stillman Co., is retiring, but will continue to have his office with the enlarged firm.

TRENTON, June 30 -- The New Jersey Supreme Court reversed today the conviction of Mr. and Mrs. Francesco LaTrecchia of 13-15 Third Street, Fair Lawn, as disorderly persons, following the expulsion of their children from school for refusing to salute the flag on religious grounds.

OSTERVILLE, Mass., June 30 (AP) -- Ben Loving, the little Longmeadow professional, had only one really poor hole in the seventy-two he played during the Massachusetts open golf championship, but it was enough to drop him into a first-place tie at 286 today with Lester Kennedy, steady Cambridge pro, at Oyster Harbors. They will play off for the title tomorrow over the 18-hole route.

BALTIMORE, June 30 (AP) -- Pitcher Tommy Byrne of Newark gave way to Phil Page in the eighth inning tonight, but chalked up his sixth straight victory when his mates batted out a 12-to-4 triumph over Baltimore.

HEADQUARTERS, Hawaiian Air Force, June 30 (AP) -- A new chapter in aerial warfare has been opened by the conflict in the Pacific and the showdown is yet to come in what "looks like a long, hard job" against an enemy that is "not a pushover," Major Gen. Willis H. Hale, commanding the United States Army Air Forces in the mid-Pacific, said tonight.

LONDON, June 30 -- There was a general falling away of business in the stock markets today and a consequent lowering of prices. National Bank of Egypt shares were marked down 1 1/2 and were quoted at 20 bid, offered at 27. Egyptian unified 4s fell 1/2 to 79 and Sudan Plantations fell 7 1/2 to 21s 10 1/2.

LONDON, June 30 -- The German tide in Egypt continued today to sweep eastward toward Alexandria. News reaching here from various sources indicated that the enemy had been slowed down but not halted. It was obvious that the fate of the great naval base and perhaps the Nile and Suez depended on the outcome of the race between General Field Marshal Erwin Rommel's advancing troops and the British reinforcements being rushed up from the east.

JERSEY CITY, June 30 (AP) -- Jersey City pounded a trio of Syracuse pitchers for thirteen hits last evening to score a 12-to-2 victory. Sid Gordon, who slammed his sixth home run of the season and a single to account for four runs batted in, paced the Little Giant attack.

PHILADELPHIA, June 30 -- A proposal by the West Texas Utilities Company to purchase all outstanding securities of the Pecos Valley Power and Light Company was filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission today.

ST. LOUIS, June 30 (AP) -- Mort Cooper missed his fourth consecutive shut-out tonight, but he did toss his ninth consecutive victory, as the Cardinals downed the Pirates, 4 to 2. Elbie Fletcher's first-inning homer snapped Cooper's scoreless innings at thirty-three.

TRENTON, N.J., June 30 -- Captain Torkild Rieber, who resigned as chairman of the Texas Company in 1940 after disclosure of his contact with Dr. Gerhard Westrick, Adolf Hitler's personal commercial envoy in this country, was named yesterday in a Chancery Court suit here to oust him as president and director of the Barber Asphalt Corporation of Perth Amboy.

Despite the Summer quiet along publishers' row, the month to come will offer tempting fare. Next Tuesday Macmillan will release "The Long Ships Passing," the story of the Great Lakes by Walter Havighurst, who learned to splice rope as a youngster aboard an ore boar.

BERNE, Switzerland, Wednesday, July 1 -- The military spokes man in Moscow this morning admitted that the Germans had succeeded in "seizing an important position" on the northern shore of the Bay of Seyvernaya, north of Sevastopol, from which their artillery is pouring an increasing stream of projectiles right into the Russians' last line of defense.

BERNE, Switzerland, June 30 -- A new development became apparent in occupied France today. For the time being, at any rate, hostages are no longer shot in reprisal but deported. The place of deportation is not indicated, but the presumption is that it is the Russian front for labor service near the firing line, which, in its way, may be equivalent to the death penalty.

Attorney General John J. Bennett Jr. began yesterday an inquiry into a sharp decline in the market price of 4 per cent first mortgage bonds of the Wisconsin Central Railroad Company Superior Duluth division and terminal, due in 1936. The bonds fell 13 1/4 points on the day.

Sixty-seven seamen lost their lives in the sinking of three ships announced yesterday by the Navy Department. A medium-sized United States ship was sunk off the Atlantic Coast June 1; a small United States ship was torpedoed in mid-June off the southeast coast, and a small Canadian merchant ship was sent to the bottom of the Caribbean late in May.

WASHINGTON, June 30 -- An inter-American conference of central bankers and government economists called to establish a common economic front against the Axis was told today by Under-Secretary of State Sumner Welles that "human termites" had been gnawing at the inter-American system and that military means, alone, could not defeat them.

Higher taxes, along with larger inventories and receivables resulting from increased war production, have already made it necessary for about 25 per cent of a representative list of corporations to seek additional ban' credit, while others probably will be obliged to borrow to meet the greater tax load in prospect for 1942, according to the results of a survey released yesterday by the National Industrial Conference Board.

Personnel and facilities of the fire insurance industry in this area were taxed to the utmost yesterday as the deadline for free Federal insurance on property against bombardment and other war risks approached.

WASHINGTON, June 30 -- President Roosevelt today directed all Federal agencies to intensify their efforts to locate and turn in "every possible ounce" of scrap rubber during the additional ten days of the nation-wide campaign. His instructions were conveyed in a memorandum from Harold D. Smith, Budget Director, which read as follows:

WASHINGTON, June 30 -- Protection against rising living costs will be extended by the Office of Price Administration tomorrow to cover the charges made for retail services, thus completing the OPA's third major step in the application of over-all price control.

The infant mortality rate in New York City last week dropped to an all-time low, Thomas J. Duffield, registrar of records in the city Health Department, reported yesterday. The rate was 21.1 per 1,000 live births.

WASHINGTON, June 30 -- Appropriations totaling nearly $45,000,000,000 were rushed to final passage today as the Senate and House, racing with calendar and clock, strove to clear away the jam of demands for the new fiscal year which begins tomorrow.

WASHINGTON, June 30 -- The government today closed its books for the fiscal year 1942 with total expenditures of nearly $32,000,000,000, receipts of less than $13,000,000,000, a deficit of over $19,000,000,000 and a daily rate of expenditure twice as great as during any period of the first World War.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., June 30 -Four of the short subjects Walt Disney has produced from material he gathered on a trip with his cartoon staff through South America last year will be released by RKO as a feature picture in LatinAmerican countries, Disney announced today.
