The quarterly tax period in June passed without material disturbance to the money market or to bank reserve positions, despite the lower general level of excess reserves prevailing, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York points out in the July 1 issue of its monthly review of credit and business conditions in this district.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 30 -Lieut. Gen. John L. DeWitt, Western defense commander, served a ten-day advance notice today that the Army would assume strict control, through the issuance of permits, over all civilian travel into and out of Alaska, and travel not absolutely essential would be stopped after July 10.

BUENOS AIRES, Argentina, June 30 -- The German note in reply to Argentina's protest against the sinking of the Argentine ship Rio Tercero arrived this morning and is at present being studied by President Ramon S. Castillo and Foreign Minister Enrique de Ruiz Guihazu.

LONDON, June 30 -- Amid deepening disquiet regarding the Middle Eastern outlook, Prime Minister Churchill announced in the House of Commons today that General Sir Claude J.E. Auchinleck had succeeded Lieut. Gen. Neil M. Ritchie on June 25 as commander of the Eighth Army now fighting to save Alexandria from the enemy.

AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, Australia, Wednesday, July 1 (AP) -- A high Army spokesman said today that the United Nations raid on Salamaua could be compared with the British Commando raids on the European Continent, but he did not disclose any illuminating details.

WASHINGTON, June 30 -- Individual opinion about the United States war effort, particularly opinion which presents what might be thought a "gloomy" picture or indicates that the program is not running perfectly, is considered censorable if destined for Latin-America, even in a personal letter.

LONDON, June 30 -- Britain's health after almost three years of war is better in many ways than it has been despite an increase in tuberculosis and spinal meningitis, Minister of Health Ernest Brown told the House of Commons today.

WASHINGTON, June 30 -- Sir Andrew Browne Cunningham, until recently fighting commander of Britain's Mediterranean Fleet and now a member of the Combined Chiefs of Staff, told a press conference here today that the fall of Alexandria would be "awkward" but that Port Said, Haifa and Beirut were capable of being used as bases for many of the British warships now in the embattled sea.

A National War Labor Board panel, after studying the subject for four and one-half months, has brought in a report favorable to an increase of $1 a day in the wages paid by the four "Little Steel" companies -- Bethlehem, Republic, Youngstown and Inland. The panel finds that the companies "are able to pay the requested wage increase."

The employes of Carl L. Norden, Inc., makers of this country's famous bombsight, yesterday presented to the Army, Navy and Marine Corps three of the instruments they had produced on their own time. and then contributed $5,327 to the Army and Navy relief funds.
The rabbit and kangaroo menace in Australia referred to in your issue of June 21 is of major importance -- especially the rabbits.

WASHINGTON, June 30 -- Major Gen. Eugene C. Reybold, Chief of Army Engineers, told the Senate Commerce Committee today that the government should proceed at once with the construction and improvement of inland waterways as a means of meeting the East Coast gasoline and oil fuel shortage, but he added that it would take three years to do the job in a way sufficient to bring substantial relief.

WASHINGTON, June 30 -- The House agreed today to the Appropriations Committee's recommendation for a cut to $75,000,000 for expenses of the Office of Price Administration and passed the first supplemental supply measure totaling $1,808,669,615, which would appropriate funds for this and several of other war agencies.

It may be a bit early to hail the return of the bluefish in local waters this year, but even the conservative-minded are hoping that recent signs mean that there will be more of these fish hereabouts than there have been in a long while.

PHILADELPHIA, June 30 -- The amazing tailspin of the Yankees appeared about to take two more convolutions in midair today when, through a last-minute recovery, the world champions managed to get back on an even keel by getting an even break in their double-header with the Athletics.

Miss Catherine Van Rensselaer, recently appointed director of physical education for the Women's Auxiliary Army Corps, outlined plans yesterday for the program that will take the place of the physical training that men get in the Army.

The Braves' had Manny Salvo and the law of averages on their side yesterday at Ebbets Field. The Dodgers could do nothing about the latter and less against the former so, for the first time this season, Brooklyn bowed to Boston, 4 -- 3, after the first eight meetings between the teams had gone to the Dodgers.

The number of cars that will have been loaded in the first nine months of 1942 will be close to the number loaded in all of 1941, estimates issued by the thirteen Shippers Advisory Boards indicated yesterday. This means that carloadings this year will approximate or exceed the record total set in the inflation year of 1929.

CLEVELAND, June 30 -- Radio engineers are vital in winning this war, but without a continued "courageous enterprise" on their part we might lose it, 300 radio experts and guests from all parts of the country heard here today at the Summer convention of the Institute of Radio Engineers.

WASHINGTON, June 30 -- The Hudson Manhattan Railroad today petitioned the Interstate Commerce Commission for permission to charge a ten-cent fare between Hudson Terminal in New York City and stations in Jersey City and Hoboken.

NEWARK, N.J., June 30 -- A nation-wide harvest of crumpled collapsible tubes, collected by drug stores and other retailers throughout the country, is arriving daily at a factory near here and, amid the aroma of shaving cream and toothpaste, is being rapidly converted into tin and other metals for war.

WASHINGTON, June 30 -- Sir Andrew Browne Cunningham, until recently fighting commander of Britain's Mediterranean Fleet and now a member of the Combined Chiefs of Staff, told a press conference here today that the fall of Alexandria would be "awkward" but that Port Said, Haifa and Beirut were capable of being used as bases for many of the British warships now in the embattled sea.

Continuation of good demand from Wall Street and commission houses advanced the cotton futures market as much as 24 points yesterday, but New Orleans selling and profit-taking on the rise minimized the gains near the end of trading on the New York Cotton Exchange.

CHICAGO, July 1 -- The grain markets continued on the upgrade today with an active demand for futures as well as the cash article. Wheat dipped slightly at the opening on light selling by houses with Southwestern connections which brokers attributed to hedging sales, but there was strong support with mills and commission houses on the buying side and prices moved steadily with the close on the Board of Trade at the top.

LONDON, July 1 -- Business on the Stock Exchange continued small today but industrials rallied sharply after an uncertain start. Courtaulds ended 1s 3d higher at 34s 3d. Others to show rises were Woolworth, Marks Spencer, the tobaccos, Dunlop and London Brick.

LONDON, July 1 -- The Polish Government in London has been urged in a report on the slaughter of 700,000 Jews in German-occupied territories to call on the Allied governments to adopt a policy of retaliation that will force the Germans to cease their killings.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: A New York newspaper reader who reads much of his paper and believes most of what seems sensible is apt to wonder at the time, thought and space given to peace plans at present, especially when the peace plan column appears on the same page with an announcement that the Germans have wiped out another Czech village, killing all the adults.

The New York, Ontario Western Railway and the New York, Susquehanna Western Railway announced yesterday that because of increased traffic it no longer would be necessary for the O. W. to continue treasury, accounting, traffic, purchasing and car service work for the Susquehanna.

A portrait of Dr. J. Bentley Squier, one of the world's leading surgeons in the field of urology, was unveiled yesterday at the J. Bentley Squier Urological Clinic of the Presbyterian Hospital, Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center, 620 West 168th Street.

RIVERHEAD, L.I., July 1 -- The "mercy slaying" trial of Mrs. Edith Reichert, 29-year-old Brooklyn housewife, came to an end this afternoon with a jury of nine men and three women deciding that she was insane temporarily and therefore not accountable when she killed her insane brother, George Horne, 26, at the Kings Park State Hospital on Dec. 3, 1941.

AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, Australia, Thursday, July 2 (AP) -- United Nations bombers in a long over-water flight yesterday attacked Japanese-held Kendari, in Netherland Celebes, General Douglas MacArthur's headquarters announced today.

WASHINGTON, July 1 -- Price ceilings on the 1942 pack of canned and dried fruits will be punctured to permit a price rise averaging 15 per cent, Leon Henderson, Federal Price Administrator, said tonight.
MOSCOW, July 1 (AP) -- The Soviet information bureau issued the following communique today:

CAIRO, Egypt, July 1 -- Extremely heavy fighting broke out this morning as Axis armored columns attacked the British Eighth Army around El Alamein, only seventy miles west of Alexandria. The new battle, which was described as "very big," began after a comparative lull yesterday during which the Germans apparently prepared for their supreme effort to break through the British defenses and reach the Nile Delta.

"Stars on Ice," the new ice show sponsored by Sonja Henie and Arthur M. Wirtz, opens tonight at the Center Theatre. Featured in the large cast of the extravaganza are Carol Lynn, Skippy Baxter, Dorothy Caley, Mary Jane Yeo, the Brandt Sisters, Fritz Dietl, the Thaells, Bob and Peggy Wright, Alex Hurd, Mayita Montez, Paul Castle, Hertha Grossman and Paul Duke.

Albert H. Bramson, 51-year-old securities dealer of Cleveland, was sentenced yesterday to three and one-half years in Federal prison and fined $5,000 for mail fraud and conspiracy of which he was recently convicted. Federal Judge Mortimer W. Byers at the same time sentenced three co-defendants to two years in prison and three others to six months.

DETROIT, July 1 -- As the climax to a tour of Detroit's armament factories and a series of talks with Edsel Ford and other industrialists, King Peter II of Yugoslavia tonight visited the giant Willow Run bomber plant of the Ford Company near Ypsilanti, Mich.

PHILADELPHIA, July 1 -- The Empire Gas and Fuel Company filed today wtih the Securities and Exchange Commission a registration statement covering $21,534,800 of 3 1/2 per cent sinking fund debentures due on Jan. 1, 1962. The proceeds will be used to effect the concern's proposed plan of capital reorganization.

WINNIPEG, July 1 (Canadian Press ) -- Ten to Ace, regarded as Canada's outstanding race horse, finished last in the six-horse field in the $5,000-added Canadian Derby today with Maginot Line, owned by Dr. L.H. Appleby of Vancouver, B.C., sweeping home first in the greatest upset in Canadian racing history.

WASHINGTON, July 1 -- A British purchasing commission with offices in London will handle the purchase of tea for both the United Kingdom and the United States, according to a tentative program worked out today by officials of both governments and representatives of the trade.
WASHINGTON, July 1 -- President Roosevelt reported to Congress on expenditures from the emergency fund; he had no engagements.

STANTON, Del., July 1 (AP) -Leading from start to finish over the grueling two and a half miles of the stake course, Kent Miller's Elkridge today won the $6,000 added Indian River Steeplechase Handicap at Delaware Park.

A fractional supply of July gasoline was delivered yesterday to filling stations -- and disappeared as quickly as a raindrop in the desert. The long lines of cars turned away with nearly empty tanks when the "No gasoline" signs went back up after a brief spell of feverish business at those stations that received delivery under the new month's quota.

The total volume of construction in the first six months of this year was $4,905,294,000, representing a 73 per cent increase over the same period last year, according to an announcement yesterday by The Engineering News-Record. This figure surpassed all previous annual volumes except that of 1941, when it required nine months for the volume to reach the current year's total for six months.

Soy beans are a very versatile vegetable. For as long as they can remember, Orientals have eaten these little legumes with beneficent results. In Switzerland they are said to have pinch-hit for coffee -- with unrecorded results. And here in America they have been used as forage for cattle, as material in making a motor car, as constituents in a loaf of bread and a bar of candy and a packet of cereal.
Thirty-five young patients at Bellevue Hospital donated yesterday their handiwork to the American Red Cross. The gifts included afghans, caps, table tennis bats, beanbags and artificial flowers.

The delay in liquidating the affairs of the local branch of the Yokohama Specie Bank is "a disgrace to the administration of the New York State Banking Department," it was asserted yesterday at a meeting of the foreign credit interchange bureau of the National Association of Credit Men, at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

CLEVELAND, July 1 -- As the climax to the three days' convention of the Institute of Radio Engineers, members visited the WarnerSwasey Observatory, home of the largest Schmidt telescope in the world, and looked through it at the stars during a local blackout.

JACKSONVILLE, Fla., July 1 (AP) -- Aviation Cadet Roland Kahn, 21, son of Mrs. Ray G. Kahn of 255 West Ninetieth Street, New York City, was killed last night when his training plane dived into the St. Johns River about three miles southeast of the Jacksonville Naval Air Station. The Navy said the accident occurred during flight manoeuvres.
BERLIN, July 1 (From German broadcasts recorded by The Associated Press) -- The German High Command issued the following communique today:

With sales in many stores exceeding in a single day quotas for the entire month, the "Retailers for Victory" drive in the sale of War Bonds and Stamps was opened here at noon yesterday. Shopping for merchandise was suspended for fifteen minutes when customers rushed to buy the "Biggest Bargain in the Store."
CHUNGKING, China, July 1 -Of the $1,608,979 American currency given China by United China Relief in 1491, nearly half was used for medical and public health programs.

WASHINGTON, July 1 -- Presidential intervention for Odell Waller, who is scheduled to be executed in Virginia tomorrow, was sought in a last-minute plea by a special committee today. The 25-year-old Negro sharecropper stands convicted of killing his white landlord.

Jesse L. Livermore, sock market operator, who shot and killed himself in the Sherry-Netherland Hotel on Nov. 28, 1940, left an estate of $3,795 and debts totaling $372,250, according to an accounting filed in Surrogate's Court yesterday by his widow, Mrs. Harriet M. Livermore of Los Angeles, Calif.

Guarantees that Townsend Harris students would be graduated within three years from the other high schools in the city to which they are transferring, provided they maintain sufficiently high scholastic averages, were made yesterday by Frederic Ernst, Associate Superintendent of Schools, and David H. Moskowitz, Assistant Superintendent.

The National City Bank reported yesterday, as of June 30, total deposits of $2,917,113,053, compared with $2,963,805,858 on March 31 last and with $2,934,824,738 on June 30, 1941. Total assets are now $3,128,263,792, compared with $3,170,716,166 three months ago and with $3,145,875,843 one year ago.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 1 -Orson Welles's Mercury Productions and RKO-Radio Pictures, which has financed and distributed Welles's films, broke off relations today in an open dispute which culminated weeks of bickering between Welles's Hollywood representatives and Charles Koerner, newly appointed head of the RKO studio.

A two-day auction sale that included property of Arline Judge, motion-picture actress and the former Mrs. Daniel R. Topping, was completed yesterday afternoon at the Crown Art Galleries, bringing a total of $24,000. It was estimated at the galleries that more than half this total represented property of Miss Judge, which had been removed from her apartment at 875 Fifth Avenue.

Fine Ship News One of the finest pictures ever printed is the air photograph of the Gneisenau with her turrets and deck structure ripped off, in her berth at Gdynia. We cannot have too many such pictures of Nazi warships. The merit, however, is entirely in the subject-matter.
David J. McLean, publisher of the Brooklyn Citizen, has leased an apartment of seven rooms and three baths in 485 Park Avenue through Douglas L. Elliman Co. and the M. Morgenthau-Seixas Company.

WASHINGTON, July 1 -- Controls over prices, rents and rationing have been placed in jeopardy by the House's approval of a budgetary appropriation of no more than $75,000,000 for the Office of Price Administration for the fiscal year, Leon Henderson, head of the agency, asserted here tonight.

With retail grocers deluging local headquarters of the Office of Price Administration with protests over their inability to recover the half-cent increase in the wholesale price of milk which became effective yesterday, the New York State Food Merchants Association has sent a special plea to Price Administrator Leon Henderson, it was learned yesterday.
CINCINNATI, July 1 (AP) -- The Cubs evened their two-game series with the Reds tonight by pecking out a 5-to-2 victory against the pitching of Johnny Vander Meer and Elmer Riddle.

WASHINGTON, July 1 -- Herbert Gaston, Assistant Secretary, denied on behalf of the Treasury today that any question of any attempt to collect duty from Canadian military forces at the Alaska border on their personal effects or arms or armaments had ever been raised in the Treasury.
The northern and southern squads for the International League's first All-Star game July 8 at Buffalo were announced yesterday by League President Frank J. Shaughnessy through The Associated Press.

CANBERRA, Australia, July 1 -The American Independence Day will be celebrated throughout Australia. Prime Minister John Curtin ordered government buildings to fly the Union Jack, Stars and Stripes and the Australian ensign and asked the public to cooperate as a mark of appreciation for the American forces here and as recognition of the bond between Australia and the United States.

Mayor La Guardia declared yesterday he would ask Congress to enact legislation providing that full publicity be given by draft boards on the reason for deferment of all registrants in Selective Service.

MELBOURNE, Australia, Jul 1 -- The raid carried out in Commando fashion by United Nations troops at Salamaua, New Guinea, was hailed here today, but it should be emphasized that this attack was harassing only, with no more important significance. Salamaua is still in the hands of the Japanese, who operate one of their principal air bases there.

WASHINGTON, July 1 -- President Roosevelt reported to Congress today on expenditures of $239,500,000 under "blank check" authority granted to him by Congress, showing that, of the sums disbursed or obligated, 87 per cent were spent for the Army, Navy, Maritime Commission and the Federal Loan Agency.

A dramatic plea by a detective in General Sessions yesterday as three robbers were about to be sent to prison not only reduced the term of the oldest to about one-third of what Judge Jonah J. Goldstein had intended to impose but actually gave the detective the opportunity to fix the term at two and one-half to five years in Sing Sing.

The first slaying of an important underworld figure involved in District Attorney William O'Dwyer's investigation into the operations of the notorious Brooklyn murder syndicate was recorded yesterday with the identification of a bullet-riddled body found in a patch of woods near Wilmington, Del., as that of Anthony Romeo, a former longshoremen's union delegate and close friend and alleged criminal associate of the boss of the Brooklyn waterfront rackets.
LONDON, July 1 -- Following are extracts from Oliver Lyttelton's defense of the government in the House of Commons today:

BERNE, Switzerland, July 1 -No reaction is obtainable tonight from private circles in France to the second notification broadcast from London to the populations along the coast that developments are impending. But certainly it has not come as a surprise.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., July 1 -- Herbert Mercready, sales manager of the Magnus Corporation, Garwood, N.J., was elected president of the National Industrial Advertisers Association at the close of its war conference here today.

Joseph B. Eastman, Director of Defense Transportation, sticks to his request that State and county fairs be given up until the end of the war. These fairs are an old and favored institution in every State. In Connecticut alone there are twenty-seven fairs, running between Aug. 20 and Oct. 11.

MOSCOW, July 1 -- A Soviet gesture to American and British merchant marine and navy men bringing war supplies to Russia was revealed today by Lieut. Comdr. Samuel B. Frankel of Stapleton, Staten Island, N.Y., who is assistant United States naval attache at Murmansk.

PHILADELPHIA, July 1 -- The United States Circuit Court of Appeals, in a 2-to-1 decision, today upheld the conviction of Enoch L. (Nucky) Johnson, former Republican leader of Atlantic City, on charges of income-tax evasion.

LONDON, July 1 -- Much of the parliamentary discussion today over the reasons for the recent British military reverses revolved around the question why the British do not have dive-bombers. It started in question time in the House of Commons and it continued throughout the debate on the notion of censure of the government.

BOSTON, July 1 (AP) -- Valdina Valet, racing in the colors of W.I. Lunt, charged down the stretch today to win the Suffolk Downs feature by a length and one-half from Miss Alice Cote's Bar Copper. The Back Bay Stable's favored Mersa Matruh was third, a length and a quarter farther back.

The proposal in Congress to prohibit further cost-plus-fixed-fee contracts in war production would lead inevitably to confusion and set back the war effort, the National City Bank asserts in its monthly review of business and financial conditions.
Two persons were killed late yesterday afternoon during a sudden electrical storm concentrated over Brooklyn and Queens.

ST. LOUIS, July 1 (AP) -- Ernie White, last year's freshman star of the Cardinals who has had difficulty getting started this season, blanked Frankie Frisch's Pirates, 4 to 0, on six hits today as St. Louis clipped a half-game from the lead of the idle Dodgers.

The second half of the year was inaugurated yesterday by the stock market under the handicap of the lightest volume in almost two years, and the continuing drag of the pessimistic news from Egypt. With the exception of a single flurry of strength in the early afternoon, which, however, was short lived, prices followed a course of least resistance throughout the session, and final quotations tended to the easier side.

WASHINGTON, July 1 -- Further repatriation of Americans from the European war areas in any mass movement received a crippling blow today in the refusal of the German Government to guarantee safe passage on future voyages for the chartered Swedish liner Drottningholm.

WASHINGTON, July 1 -- The House approved and sent to the Senate today a bill permitting nurses in the Navy to be promoted to the officer ranks up to lieutenant commander, in line with the practice now prevailing in the Army Nurse Service.
TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: May I rise to the defense of the East against attacks upon it for not doing its share in the present rubber scrap drive.

LONDON, July 1 -- Oliver Lyttelton, Supply Minister, defending the Churchill government in the opening of the debate on Prime Minister Churchill's conduct of the war in the House of Commons today, attributed the British reverses in Libya and Egypt to "tactical mistakes," the unsuitability of Crusader tanks for desert warfare and the fact that German tanks had heavier armor and had guns with a longer range.

Total deposits of the Guaranty Trust Company, as of June 30, amounted to $2,289,224,763, according to the quarterly statement of condition issued yesterday. This compared with $2,256,851,588 at the end of the first quarter of this year, and with $2,447,972,296 at the end of the second quarter last year.
WASHINGTON, July 1 -- A Navy communique based on reports received up to 8:30 A.M. said:

WASHINGTON, July 1 -- By a vote of 39 to 20, the Senate today confirmed the nomination of Thomas F. Meaney, sponsored by Mayor Hague of Jersey City, as a Federal district judge for New Jersey. The vote followed party lines closely, only one Republican voting in favor of the appointment and one Democrat against it.

The fifteen-story-and-penthouse apartment building at 1165 Fifth Avenue, at the south corner of Ninety-eighth Street, has been sold by the 1165 Fifth Avenue Corporation to the Emery Realty Corporation in a deal negotiated by the Wood, Dolson Company.

OSTERVILLE, Mass., July 1 (AP) -- An exceptionally smooth par-72 performance enabled Ben Loving, Longmeadow professional, to outscore an erratic Les Kennedy of Cambridge by six strokes today in their 18-hole play-off for the Massachusetts open golf title at Oyster Harbors.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., July 1 (AP) -- Accused by the Federal Bureau of Investigation of advocating the overthrow of the United States Government, by force, Nicholas Hansen, 27, a former Newport Naval Torpedo Station employe, was held in $10,000 bail today for hearing July 10.

ALTOONA, Pa., July 1 -- Two hundred and fifty enemy aliens were seized here tonight by agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation in connection with the Nazi sabotage plot to blow up the famous horseshoe curve of the Pennsylvania railroad near here.

Local WPA officials were authorized yesterday to scrap plans for an immediate cut of 10,000 in the New York City WPA rolls and to space over a three-month period the layoffs required to bring employment in this area down to the levels prescribed in the $283,000,000 appropriation bill passed by Congress Tuesday.

BERNE, Switzerland, Thursday, July 2 -- After four days' incessant bombing and shelling, German and Rumanian forces shortly before noon yesterday, in an action that for sheer bloody horror must have surpassed anything seen at Verdun in the last war, stormed the last line of Sevastopol's defenses and, according to a special announcement in Berlin late last evening, captured Russia's great Black Sea naval base.

BOSTON, July 1 -- Airtight pitching and timely hitting today enabled the Red Sox to sweep their second double-header in two days with the Senators, 3 -- 2 and 7 -- 1, before a paying crowd of 10,593 that included many Ted Williams hecklers.

MOSCOW, Thursday, July 2 (U.P.) -- Axis besiegers stormed deeper into the Sevastopol fortifications yesterday in violent hand-to-hand fighting, but Russian resistance stiffened and "our gallant defenders continue to repulse enemy attacks," the Red Army announced today.
ALBANY, July 1 -- Governor Lehman gave up tennis today for the duration and his playing shoes went on the scrap-rubber pile.

In Brooklyn Supreme Court two extraordinary grand juries have been discharged. Therewith is completed the main task of the inquiry, three years and a half long, conducted by Special Prosecutor John Harlan Amen into official corruption in Brooklyn. Mr. Amen's investigation has been remarkably searching and effective; so effective that the juries are needed no more.

Small industrial plants in the city, threatened with closing because they are not manufacturing war products and can no longer obtain materials for civilian manufactures, will be assisted by the War Department in converting their facilities to ordnance work, it was revealed here yesterday by Brig. Gen. Walter P. Boatwright, who took command of the New York, ordnance district headquarters at 80 Broadway.

CAIRO, July 1 (AP) -- The main British armored forces, bolstered by reserves, finally locked arms today with the onrushing Axis columns. Late tonight dispatches indicated that the battle area was just west of El Alamein.

As protest increased yesterday over the summary dismissal of seventy-one Welfare Department investigators by the Board of Estimate, Welfare Commissioner William Hodson and Budget Director Kenneth Dayton joined in the statement that they were trying to find some way to retain the employes.

Although the January grand jury two weeks ago closed its investigation of the death last Jan. 15 of Dr. Allyn King Foster in Bellevue Hospital of injuries suffered in some mysterious manner, the fact they had refused to hand up an indictment in the case did not become public until yesterday.

MOSCOW, July 1 (AP) -- Tass, official Soviet news agency, said today that the Vichy French Government had played and is playing an important part in supplying war materials and transporting troops via French Tunisia for Nazi Marshal Erwin Rommel in Egypt.

BERLIN, July 1 (From German broadcasts recorded by The United Press in New York) -- With the announcement of the fall of Sevastopol today, Reichsfuehrer Hitler promoted Col. Gen. Fritz Erich von Mannstein, commander of the Axis forces in the Crimea, to the rank of general field marshal "in recognition of his merits and the victorious conclusion of the Crimean campaign." He also created a special medal for all who fought in the battle.

UPPER MONTCLAIR, N.J., July 1 -- Mrs. Joseph E. Davis and her daughter, Mrs. J.B. Balding of Cedar Creek, playing alternate shots, won the annual mother and daughter championship conducted under the auspices of the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association with a score of 40, 43 -- 83 at the Upper Montclair Country Club today.

BUENOS AIRES, Argentina, July 1 -- The Chamber of Deputies, by a vote of 61 to 53, called on the government tonight to repeal the state of siege in force since the middle of last December. By so doing the Chamber rejected Senate action approving the state of siege but placing a time limit of sixty days on it.
When the second late opening of several Fifth Avenue stores occurs tonight the stores themselves will welcome it, in view of the results last week, it was said yesterday.

WASHINGTON, July 1 -- After great delay, punctuated by numerous assurances from its civilian chief, Secretary Knox, that the Axis submarines off the Atlantic coast were being conquered, the Navy has finally yielded to pleas in favor of much freer use of small boats and their crews in patrol and spotter service.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: In order to save money, it has been proposed that the staffs of a number of high schools be curtailed. If the children could be effectively taught with a decreased staff, the dismissals would be justified. It is a fact, however, that class sizes are already cumbersome.

TRENTON, N.J., July 1 -- Chancellor Luther A. Campbell took under advisement today an application by the Prudential Insurance Company of America for permission to convert itself from a stock to a mutual company.

After having survived two Axis attacks on the same ship, Robert F. Trost, 34 years old, of 97-15 Linden Boulevard, Ozone Park, Queens, one of seven torpedo attack survivors rescued June 16 in the Caribbean, is to return home this morning.

Companies which furnish less than one-third of their production to the Army Air Forces now may resume the publication of quarterly reports in a form which does not furnish information of possible value to our enemies, according to an announcement by Emil Schram, president of the New York Stock Exchange.
Sales of Treasury war savings bonds in the New York Federal Reserve District in June totaled $117,399,000, compared with $115,237,000 in May, it was announced yesterday at the Federal Reserve Bank.

WASHINGTON, July 1 -- A plan for control of the production and distribution of wheat during and after the war was made public by the State Department tonight in the form of an agreement for cooperation among five of the principal producing and importing countries of the world.

WASHINGTON, July 1 -- Appointments as officer candidates for the Women's Army Auxiliary Corps will not be announced until after the successful applicants have been sworn in, it was said today at WAAC headquarters. It had been planned originally to release the list of chosen candidates from Washington as soon as the special selecting committee had completed the job of naming the candidates.

Transport difficulties slowed up yesterday the collection of scrap rubber in the city and led to the charge that Mayor La Guardia's office had refused to cooperate in arranging the pick-up at service stations.

Japan will begin to draw some oil for her armed forces from the captured wells of the Far East within the next six to eight months, Arthur L. Elliott, European representative of the Standard Vacuum Oil Company, 26 Broadway, said yesterday when he arrived at La Guardia Field aboard a transatlantic clipper.

WELLINGTON, N.Z., July 1 -Prime Minister Peter Fraser announced his first National War Administration in the House of Representatives last night, naming seven government members and six oppositionists, who will be charged with the united direction of this country's part in the struggle.

Replacing nylon and silk styles that formerly retailed above $1 per pair, Gotham Hosiery Company, Inc., announced yesterday the addition of five new rayon constructions to its line, the first announced for the Fall and Winter season. Four of the new additions are priced at $9.75 per dozen, for the $1.35 retail range, the fifth being priced at $8.25 for the $1.15 bracket.

LONDON, July 1 (U.P.) -- Japanese land and air forces are "drifting toward the Manchukuo border," from where they can invade Russia "at their own chosen moment," the British military commentator said today.

WITH THE BRITISH FORCES, in Egypt, June 30 (Delayed) -Moonlight shimmered on naked bayonets in the early hours of Sunday morning as New Zealand battalions went into action southeast of Matruh and hacked their way through massed German forces barring the way to freedom.

WASHINGTON, July 1 -- For six hours today the National War Labor Board listened attentively to diametrically opposing and impassioned arguments by spokesmen for the United Steel Workers of America, C.I.O., and of the Inland and Bethlehem Steel Companies over the report of a fact-finding committee on the union demand for a wage increase of a dollar a day, union security and the check-off of union dues for 175,000 employes in the four companies affected.

This is not a time for loyal Americans to "incorporate for social purposes," Official Referee Jacob Marks declared yesterday in a report submitted to Supreme Court Justice Aaron J. Levy, sitting in the Bronx, in which he recommend ed denial of a certificate of incorporation to the Progressive Fraternal Organization, Inc., formed by persons largely of German extraction.

WASHINGTON, July 1 -- The War Department made public today the names of 111 United States sailors and Marines who are held as prisoners of war by the Japanese at Shanghai. Seventy-two were serving at Peiping and thirty-nine at Tientsin.

LONDONDERRY, Northern Ireland, July 1 -- A former mudflat here has been transformed in an incredibly short time into one of the most extensive American naval bases ever constructed outside continental United States. Complete with virtually every facility necessary for waging the Battle of the Atlantic, including repair shops and supply depots, this key base has been in commission since last Feb. 5 and now is functioning at "full speed ahead."

The Navy announced yesterday the sinking of two more ships by enemy submarines in the Western Atlantic. A medium-sized United States merchant ship was sunk June 15 off the north coast of South America, and a small vessel of Panaman registry was sunk off the Atlantic Coast June 24.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Why are the air raid wardens told not to help enforce the dimout? Both through the television lectures and at our meetings we are told to keep hands off -- that the police will do the enforcing.

THAT All-Star ball game at the Polo Grounds on Monday is going to be a colorful baseball spectacle, of course. It always is. But this time there is something beyond the stars to give it a lift. All the profit will go to provide baseball equipment for the leisure hours of the men in the armed forces, here and abroad.

Because of mounting taxes, says a memorandum presented by the Treasury to the House Ways and Means Committee, "many individuals are finding it difficult, if not impossible, to continue amortizing the mortgages on their homes" or to meet other commitments entered into before there was "reason to foresee the high tax rates of the war period."
Mr. and Mrs. Philip Rhinelander have come to the Carlyle from their country place in Oyster Bay.

At least 40,000 children have left the city by train and bus this week to spend their Summer vacations in camps in the country, leaving behind them more than 1,000,000 children of school age who will spend their Summer in the city.

The Chase National Bank, in its statement of condition made public yesterday, as of June 30, shows total deposits of $3,595,451,030, compared with $3,628,256,645 at the end of March, 1942, and with $3,615,427,528 at the end of June, 1941.

DETROIT, July 1 (AP) -- Elden Auker, veteran submarine ball specialist, became the first American League pitcher to win ten games when he blanked the Tigers on five hits in a twilight contest tonight while the Browns were rapping out fourteen for a 12-to-0 victory.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., July 1 -Nothing of a disturbing nature happened during the recent Birmingham hearings of the President's Committee on Fair Employment Practice and nothing disturbing to local morale has happened since.

General Boleslaw Wieniawa-D'Lugoszewski, Polish Ambassador to Italy at the outbreak of the war in 1939, fell to his death yesterday morning from the roof of 3 Riverside Drive, where he lived with his wife and daughter, apparently as a result of a dizzy spell, the Polish consulate general here announced yesterday.

March price ceilings affecting retail service establishments went into effect here yesterday quietly and without major difficulties. A number of complaints from the public of alleged violations of the ceilings were received at the local OPA offices, but few were reported valid.

DENVER, July 1 -- Pledging an "all-out effort" to win the war, the National Education Association in a resolution today asked the schools of the country to readjust their programs in whatever way may be necessary to meet the war needs.

PATERSON, N.J., July 1 -- America's answer to consumer complaints was found here today. Snatched from parlor, bedroom and bath for the production battle, household articles are starring in a wartime role.

William Ziegler Jr., member of the Jockey Club, who raced El Chico to championship heights a few seasons ago, scored a double at Empire City yesterday that brought a great deal of satisfaction because both winners were his own home-breds.

The young men who registered for possible military service this week were born during the Presidencies of Harding and Coolidge. The first World War was history to them, as the Civil War was to their fathers, and they did not pay much attention to the news until the Presidency of Franklin D. Roosevelt.
WASHINGTON, July 1 -- All rubber floor mats in the Capitol Building today were turned over to President Roosevelt's scrap rubber collection drive.

Some of the early reports on the opening of the bass season yesterday in near-by counties of the State found fishermen as enthusiastic as ever, although their ranks, by comparison with other years, were somewhat depleted.

CHICAGO, July 1 (AP) -- The first seven Cleveland batters that faced Orval Grove, White Sox freshman hurler, in the first inning today scored to give Al Smith more than the margin he needed for his seventh victory, 7 to 2. It was the Indians' third straight triumph in the series.

WASHINGTON, July 1 -- Congress, impatient to begin election-year recesses, found itself caught today in a Senate-House deadlock which not only left the Department of Agriculture (81,000 employes) without funds to start the new fiscal year but threatened either to force a curtailment of farm production or add an estimated $1,000,000,000 annually to the cost of living.

The large corner store in the two-story business building nearing completion at the southeast corner of Broadway and Fulton street has been leased by the Liggett Drug Company for a new unit in its chain of stores. Riker Co. acted as brokers in the deal in conjunction with the Herbert McLean Purdy Management Corporation, agents for the Fulway Corporation.

A straight line drawn due south from Sevastopol would end very near the mouth of the Nile. It would be a long line, crossing the Black Sea, Turkey and the eastern gulf of the Mediterranean, and could not be followed directly even by the open roads of the sky, which take no heed of mountains, deserts or the no-trespass signs of neutrals.

WASHINGTON, July 1 -- Reporting on the conversion of the automobile industry to war work, the War Production Board announced today that war shipments by the automotive industry in April were 46 per cent greater than in February.

The National Distillers Products Corporation yesterday announced the largest Summer advertising campaign in the history of the industry for bottled-in-bond whiskies. The regular use of small-space newspaper advertisements will be punctuated at intervals by 400 and 600 line copy in newspapers in the large markets.

The resistance of Sevastopol has at length been crushed after a siege that will live in history; the Nazis have commenced large-scale offensives in several sectors of the Russian front, and at El Alamein in Egypt the British last night were making a "backs-to-the-wall" stand.
NOROTON, Conn., July 1 -- Taking the final race of the series with his sloop Melody, Paul H. Smart today won the John Taylor Arms Perpetual Challenge Trophy at the Noroton Yacht Club.

Farrar Rinehart will publish on July 16 "North Atlantic Patrol: The Log of a Sea-Going Artist," the artist being Lieut. Comdr. Griffith Baily Coale, one of four commissioned by the Navy to record the war at sea. His book includes a graphic word-and-picture record of the sinking of the Reuben James, which he witnessed.

WASHINGTON, July 1 -- One-fourth of the 700,000 civilian employes of the War Department are women working in both technical and supervisory fields, the department's Office of Civilian Personnel and Training said today.

Nine hundred student officers of the United States Navy will move today into John Jay Hall, fifteenstory men's dormitory at Columbia University, the Navy Department announced yesterday. John Jay Hall, at Amsterdam Avenue and 114th Street, is the second Columbia dormitory to be leased to the Navy.
The Wayne Pump Company reported yesterday a net profit of $350,746 for the six months ended with May after $155,000 estimated Federal income taxes and other charges.

Signs of activity multiply on the Australian front. The latest is a commando raid on the Japanese base at Salamaua in New Guinea. This is the first land attack on the Japanese since they occupied Salamaua and Lae. There may be others to follow, for it is obvious that our air forces have been trying to soften up the enemy for some time.

MONTCLAIR, N.J., July 1 -- Edward Moylan of Spring Hill College of Alabama and Robert Odman of the University of Washington reached the quarter-final round of the Eastern intercollegiate tennis championship today before rain intervened at the Montclair A.C.

Detroit, Mich., will enter the market on July 9 with an issue of $344,000 of street railway revenue notes, for which bidders are requested to specify a rate of interest not exceeding 2 1/2 per cent. The notes, dated June 30, 1942, will mature semi-annually from Dec. 31, 1943, to June 30, 1946.

Men's clothing manufacturers estimated yesterday that close to 80 per cent of the business booked on Fall lines to date has been sold at increases of 7 per cent on suits and 14 per cent on topcoats and overcoats over levels of a year ago, pending release of the OPA regulations on these seasonal lines.

There will be a seat for every ticket sold for the All-Star game at the Polo Grounds on Monday at twilight. President Ford Frick of the National League made that clear at a luncheon at Toots Shor's restaurant yesterday while disclosing that some 30,000 general admission tickets are available at $2.20 each.

CHUNGKING, China, July 1 (AP) -- Japanese troops are overrunning the last few unconquered miles of the railway between Hangshow and Nanchang, against which they began driving from both the East and West six weeks ago, reports from the front said tonight.

More Class 1-B men -- those with minor physical defects but still fit for limited military service -- will be called in August for induction by draft boards in New York City, Colonel Arthur V. McDermott, local Selective Service director, announced yesterday.

BALTIMORE, July 1-(AP) -- Hank Edwards's home run smash in the eighth inning broke a 2-2 deadlock and gave Baltimore a 3-2 victory tonight over Newark. Bob Lemon hit a homer in the sixth to tie the count after the Bears had scored twice in the second inning.

ALBANY, July 1 (AP) -- The Appellate Division, Third Department, upheld today the Public Service Commission's order that the International Railway Company, Buffalo, cancel its Mitten Management contract as not in the public interest.
Saying that he had no intention of becoming a candidate for Governor, Wendell L. Willkie yesterday checked movements to draft him for the Republican nomination.

PHILADELPHIA, July 1 -- The Yankees, swaying perilously in the gales that have suddenly started swirling around the top of the American League, suffered another serious reverse tonight when they lost to the Athletics, 5 to 4.

MEXICO CITY, July 1 -- Two large properties of the Standard Oil Company of New Jersey will be returned to the company as a result of a Supreme Court decision today, which is based on the fact that they were not included in the expropriation decree, though they were taken over by the government in the latter part of 1938.

Stocks of gasoline in the United States at the close of last week were 88,611,000 barrels, a decrease of 1,236,000 from the 89,847,000 a week earlier, according to the American Petroleum Institute. A year ago supplies were 90,414,000 barrels.

ALBANY, July 1 -- New York State began its fiscal year today with an operating surplus of $47,098,163 and an accumulated surplus of $54,127,419, Governor Lehman announced at a press conference. It is the largest surplus the State has had since 1931 and was accomplished in spite of the repeal of the 1 per cent emergency tax and a 25 per cent reduction in the personal income tax, which alone had saved the taxpayers $45,000,000.

As part of its effort to promote harmonious relations between management and organized workers, the State Labor Relations Board is now disposing of cases in one-third the time it took when the board came into being five years ago.

WASHINGTON, July 1 -- Strong belief that President Roosevelt would make a personal decision concerning the form of tribunal to try the captured Nazi saboteurs and that this would be a military commission was expressed in Washington today.

Some "experts" in the Postal Section of the Office of Censorship in Washington have ruled that a private letter, sent by an American citizen to a Latin-American country, cannot be carried if it is "too gloomy." In the specific letter which was offered as a horrid example the statement had been made "that an unfortunately large number of North Americans haven't yet begun to know how big a war we are fighting."

WASHINGTON, July 1 -- The United States built sixty-six cargo ships and tankers totaling 731,900 deadweight tons last month, but despite this record-breaking total the Axis is still sinking ships faster than the United Nations are building them.

Restrictions in dress designs due to the L-85 order of the War Production Board will favor the increased use of costume jewelry as a decorative offset, it was stated here yesterday at the owing of Fall lines of this merchandise.

A lively topic in the cotton trade here is the amount of the staple in Egypt and also what will happen to it if the Germans are successful in their drive to the Suez Canal. The consensus seems to be that the cotton in Egypt is equivalent to about 2,350,000 United States bales.

PHILADELPHIA, July 1 (AP) -The United States Circuit Court of Appeals approved today the exchange of 400,000 shares of the Columbia Oil and Gasoline Company's preferred stock for five subsidiaries of the company, an arrangement set up by the Columbia Gas and Electric Corporation to meet the terms of an anti-trust suit of the government.

WASHINGTON, July 1 -- For what it costs to clothe one member of the Women's Army Auxiliary Corps, the United States could provide the uniform for an Army officer and have almost sufficient left over to purchase a sailor's outfit. Similarly, the country could finance the tailoring of a new Naval Reserve officer, and still have a little remaining before exceeding one WAAC's clothing bill.

WELCH, W. Va., July 1 -- State police reported tonight that the bodies of twenty-one men had been recovered from the wreckage of a southbound Army transport which crashed in flames after losing a wing at an altitude of 500 feet.
CHUNGKING, July 1 (AP) -- The Chinese High Command issued this communique today:

LONDON, July 1 -- The Axis advance into Egypt obviously poses for British naval authorities the most serious problems as to what to do with Alexandria and the warships there. Not the least of these problems concerns the French ships immobilized in Egyptian ports after the fall of France and the Oran incident.

WASHINGTON, July 1 -- The United States aircraft carrier Wasp repeatedly ran the gantlet of the Mediterranean in recent weeks to ferry British fighting planes to beleaguered Malta, the Navy announced today. The carrier, commissioned only in 1940, emerged unscathed from her exploits, the announcement added.

Property owner of high and low degree are estimated to have applied for as much as $25,000,000,000 of insurance on their property against enemy aggressions and our war measures, according to a survey among key concerns yesterday, the first day on which War Damage Corporation binders took effect.
MOSCOW, Thursday, July 2 (AP) -- The midnight Soviet communique follows:

There will be few "Mother Hubbards" finding cupboards bare in American homes for some time to come, a survey of New York's resident buyers has disclosed. Farsightedness plus ingenuity on the part both of manufacturers and retailers have resulted in ample stocks, for the present, to satisfy the average consumer.

TOKYO, July 1 (From Japanese broadcast recorded by The Associated Press) -- Japanese forces in China effected complete occupation of the Hangchow-Nanchang Railway today as vanguard units driving toward each other from the east and west met at Hengfeng, Domei reported.
A net profit of $495,271 for the fiscal year ended on April 30 last was reported yesterday by the Atlantic Coast Fisheries Company and its subsidiary.

CAIRO, Egypt, July 2 -- After a pause of a few hours following upon yesterday's heavy attacks, the Axis forces that are invading Egypt launched another fierce assault this afternoon on the British position at El Alamein, seventy miles west of Alexandria, swinging in simultaneously from both the south and the west.
BERLIN, July 2 (From German broadcasts recorded by The Associated Press) -- The German High Command communique said today:
CHICAGO, July 2 (AP) -- The Indians swept a four-game series from the White Sox with a 7-to-5 victory tonight before 29,062. The game netted $33,352 for the Army land Navy relief funds.

The exploits of those "mountain men" whose fur-trading expeditions a century ago opened up the country between St. Louis and the Pacific Northwest are the subject of "Plume Rouge," a novel by John Upton Terrell, which Viking will have in the bookshops July 24.

HAMILTON, Bermuda, July 2 -- Acting to meet supply problems, the Food Board, by government notice, today set a ceiling on the prices of all goods and ordered makeshift rationing by restricting consumers to one food dealer and making it an offense to sell or buy any food in excess of a normal quantity.

A situation to tantalize most holiday-minded motorists shaped up last night when it became known that plenty of gasoline to bring them back to the city was available at near-by vacation spots. The trouble was that thousands of automobile owners lacked the gasoline to get to these well-supplied places.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, July 2 -- The undersea warfare in the Baltic was heightened today when a submarine of unidentified nationality attacked the Swedish cargo ship Galeon and was in its turn attacked by a Swedish destroyer.

WASHINGTON, July 2 -- President Roosevelt today appointed a special Military Commission, composed of seven distinguished Army generals, to try the eight Nazi saboteurs who were arrested after they landed on the Atlantic coast from German submarines.

City police and internal revenue agents began yesterday a check of motor vehicles failing to display the $5 stamp representing the annual Federal tax on automobiles in use after July 1. Warnings were issued to drivers whose cars were found not to display the stamps.

CHICAGO, July 2 -- Increased hedging sales and profit-taking turned the wheat market downward today and while there was support at times from mills the buying was not aggressive and the close on the Board of Trade was at losses of 3/4 to 7/8 cent a bushel.

CHUNGKING, China, July 2 -- A review today of the activities of the American Volunteer Group, which will be inducted into the United States Army Air Forces July 4 under the present commander, Brig. Gen. Claire L. Chennault, disclosed that the famous Flying Tigers never numbered more than 250, but each man, pilot or ground personnel, was a specialist in his particular field.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., July 2 -- In sentencing a former Buchanan village official to serve one year in the Westchester County penitentiary and to pay a $250 fine for misappropriating public funds, County Judge Frank H. Coyne said today that recurrent embezzlements by public officials were due largely to the failure of communities to audit accounts frequently and to pay "living wages" to employes handling large sums of money.

Creditors of Japanese bank agencies "should be thankful" that the agencies have been administered in such a manner that they may expect payment of their claims in this country rather than being compelled to await the close of the war for payment from abroad, William R. White, State Superintendent of Banks, declared yesterday.

PHILADELPHIA, July 2 (AP) -- To W.S. Gifford, as president of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, $210,350 was paid in 1941, the annual report of the company filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission disclosed today.

An alien who has entered the country illegally has nevertheless the right to sue in the courts of the State to recover for services rendered or for breach of contract, Supreme Court Justice Morris Eder ruled yesterday. To deny this right, he said, would violate the Fourteenth Amendment, which forbids a State to deny equal protection of the laws to "any person within its jurisdiction."

PHILADELPHIA, July 2 -- A voluntary plan for compliance with the death sentence clause of the Holding Company Act was filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission by the Southern Colorado Power Company.

"This Is the Enemy!" a Russian importation, will have its premiere today at the Stanley Theatre. A fictional film, portraying the resistance of the civilian populations of Poland, Yugoslavia and occupied Russian territories to the Nazi invaders, it is reportedly the first Soviet picture on which two major studios, Lenfilm of Leningrad and Mosfilm of Moscow, have collaborated. "

United Youth for Victory seeks no quarrel with the New York City Salvage Committee, but we wish to clarify our position in reply to the letter of the vice chairman of the committee, printed in your columns on July 1. Here are the resolutions on salvage as adopted by delegates from thirty-six high schools and four colleges at our Town Hall Conference, which the New York City Salvage Committee disapproves:
AT A WEST AFRICAN PORT, July 2 -- It was important for us to know where Dakar was every moment as we flew the Atlantic from Brazil to Africa at night.

WASHINGTON, July 2 -- Canners of vegetables and manufacturers of a wide variety of grocery products will demand consideration similar to that given by the Office of Price Administration to packers of canned and dried fruits, it was learned here today.

CHICAGO, July 2 (AP) -- Representatives of livestock producing and marketing organizations, sent a telegram to Secretary of Agriculture Wickard urging that no ceilings be placed on prices of live hogs, cattle and sheep, the association said today.

OTTAWA, July 2 -- Two cadets from the Brockville officers training center were drowned and others were rescued with difficulty during a demonstration attack in the center of Ottawa this morning, involving swimming the Rideau Canal with full equipment.
The Board of Education, by the close vote of 4 to 3, at a special meeting yesterday dismissed forty high school teachers as an economy measure.

The report of the Electric Bond and Share Company for the first three months of this year discloses that the holding company failed to earn its preferred dividend requirements in the March quarter by $573,395. In the March quarter a year ago preferred dividend charges were covered by $601,530.

CAIRO, Egypt, July 2 -- The United States Army Air Forces have teamed with the Royal Air Force in the greatest raids ever staged in the Near East, blasting Axis bases from Western Libya to Crete for seven nights in a row and hammering home one attack at Bengazi on a scale comparable with the 1,000-plane British raid on Cologne, it was learned tonight.

SANTOS, Brazil, July 2 (UP) -- Two American survivors of a torpedoed United States merchantman said today that an Axis submarine which attacked their vessel picked them up and kept them aboard for three days while dodging repeated attacks by airplanes of the anti-submarine patrol.

LONDON, July 2 -- Still another batch of Americans who had come to Britain as members of the Canadian Expeditionary Force were transferred yesterday to the United States Army at a military depot in Southern England, where special facilities have been provided to expedite such transfers.

The simple sponge, to a lady at her dressing table, is an accessory to beauty. Indeed, in the past year, the natural sponge, or its synthetic counterpart, appears to have emerged from a long period of obscurity.
WASHINGTON, July 2 -- Leon Henderson was the target of real fireworks in the Senate today.

Welfare Commissioner William Hodson and Budget Director Kenneth Dayton issued a joint statement yesterday saying that the seventy-one Welfare Department investigators dismissed by the Board of Estimate on Tuesday might go back on the payroll for thirty days if they agreed not to press for salary increments and back pay awarded to them by the Court of Appeals.

WASHINGTON, July 2 -- Secretary Morgenthau disclosed today that the Federal Government's 1942 fiscal deficit was $19,598,000,000, of which 80 per cent was for war purposes, and renewed his plea to Congress for a tax bill which would yield far more than the pending measure as framed by the Ways and Means Committee.

BERLIN, July 2 (From German broadcasts recorded by The Associated Press) -- The German Army reported today that Axis forces were pursuing a British retreat toward the delta of the Nile, after having broken through the defenders' position at El Alamein, seventy miles West of Alexandria.

"Guest in the House," which introduced brothers Stephen f. and Paul S. Ames to the ranks of Broadway producers, will close after tomorrow night's perform'ance at the Plymouth. The Dale Eunson-Hagar Wilde coHaboraLion, staged by 'Reginald Denham, will have achieved a run of 152 per-' formances.

Early official returns from twenty-seven department stores revealed yesterday that the over-the-counter sales of War Bonds and Stamps on Wednesday, opening day of the Retailers for Victory campaign for July, totaled $699,185.

WASHINGTON, July 2 (AP) -- Differing with Chairman James L. Fly of the Communications Commission, Commissioner T.A.M. Craven told the House Interstate Commerce Committee today that the Federal Communications Act should be rewritten.

Park Commissioner Robert Moses may enjoy a good game of bridge from time to time, but he is not in sympathy with Culbertson or Blackwood addicts who attempt to use park property for card playing. Eight women appeared yesterday in Bronx Magistrates Court to attest this fact.

WASHINGTON, July 2 -- The bill creating a women's reserve in the Navy was passed by the Senate today with a voice vote after Senator Gillette, a member of the Naval Affairs Committee, explained that members of the reserve would take the places of regular naval personnel in noncombatant shore posts within the United States.

"IF you were to make little fishes talk, they would talk like whales," said Boswell to Dr. Johnson with considerable critical acumen. If the whales of modern American literature are the Hemingways and Steinbecks, perhaps one of the fishes is Robert Nathan, a delicate and radiant rainbow trout who weaves lovely patterns in fictional waters rather than makes big splashes.

BOSTON, July 2 -- Valdina Alpha, latest addition to the Pine Tree Stable of Framingham, Mass., turned in his third victory in four starts for his new owner by romping home four lengths ahead of Nimkoff and Stuart's Watch Over in today's $1,500 allowance six-furlong sprint on the sloppy Suffolk Downs track.

Special buses to the Empire City race track were canceled yesterday by President George Bull with the result that rain-swept racegoers got to the Yonkers course under more difficulties than have prevailed in years. Courtesy buses, at the expense of the race track, have been available for five years under the regime of the late James Butler, and latterly of Mr. Bull, as a convenience to patrons who come by railroad and subway.

BALBOA, Canal Zone, July 2 -- The round-up of twenty persons suspected of subversive activities, including supplying fuel and information to Nazi submarines in the Caribbean, was disclosed today by the Caribbean Defense Command.
DETROIT, July 2 -- Stolid and as devoid of expression as during three days of trial, Max Stephan, German-born Detroit restaurant owner, heard a jury convict him tonight of treason.

CHUNGKING, China, July 2 (U.P.) -- Today's war communique said the Chinese had "successfully checked" Japanese attacks to close the thirty-five-mile gap between their eastbound and westbound spearheads at Iyang and Shangjao, on the Kiangsi part of the Hangchow-Nanchang railway.
The battle for Egypt and all that Egypt means was approaching its crescendo yesterday at a desert crossroads that until two days ago was unknown to most of the western world.

DENVER, July 2 -- Stressing the importance of United States history, educational leaders representing several parts of the country, urged today that this subject be required of all students attending American schools and colleges.

Check transactions for the week ended on Wednesday were 3.3 per cent larger than for the comparable week of 1941, "partly because of the lesser proportion of first-of-the-month payments being included in the current week," Dun Bradstreet, Inc., announced yesterday in its report of twenty-three major cities of the country.

WASHINGTON, July 2 -- The National War Labor Board took under advisement today a fact-finding committee's report which presented a major test of the President's wage stabilization policy in the form of a virtual recommendation that wages in the four "Little Steel" companies be increased for 157,000 employes.

Colonel Henry Rogers Winthrop, now a limited partner in the New York Stock Exchange firm of Winthrop, Whitehouse Co., has arranged to purchase the Exchange membership of the late David V. Morris for $21,000. He was a nonmember partner on the board of governors of the Exchange from 1935 to 1938.

WASHINGTON, July 2 -- Leon Henderson, Director of Price Control, asked a subcommittee of the Senate Finance Committee in a stormy session today to restore House reductions in the funds to meet OPA expenses. He emerged smiling from the room where loud and angry voices and much gavel pounding by Senator McKellar, the chairman, were audible outside.
Henry C. Brunie, chairman of the Greater New York War Fund drive of the United Service Organizations, announced yesterday that 70 per cent of the $4,450,000 quota here had been raised.

Manufacturers of women's flannelette, brushed rayon and tucked-stitch nightgowns and sleeping pajamas are oversold for the remainder of this year, according to a report issued yesterday following a meeting of the National Women's Undergarment Manufacturers Association.

"Last warning" notices prior to the change in retail credit methods as a result of amendments to Regulation W of the Federal Reserve Board, calling for prompt payment on charge-account purchases made prior to June 1, were received yesterday by customers of local retail establishments. The change is effective next Friday.

BERNE, Switzerland, July 2 (AP) -- The International Agriculture Institute at Rome reported today the world's corn harvest in the past year set a record, the United States and Argentine leading while the European crop was cut by war and unfavorable weather.

WASHINGTON, July 2 -- Department store sales for the week ended June 27 were down 8 per cent, compared with the corresponding week last year, the Federal Reserve Board announced today. This came after a 9 per cent increase during the previous week.

LACKAWANNA, N.Y., July 2 (AP) -- The general manager of the Bethlehem Steel Company's Lackawanna plant said tonight that workers at one of its open-hearth furnace units had "left their jobs" and that the walkout would cut the mill's output a third.

Referring to the recent comment by William C. Herrington of the United States Fish and Wildlife Service apropos of the restoration of Atlantic salmon, Philip W. Porritt of Stamford, Conn., offers some of his own observations on this general subject.

War risk and bombardment insurance on a modest-sized apartment building of which I am trustee apparently is to cost $455, which is almost as much as the fire insurance cost for a year -- to be exact, 83 per cent as much.

OXFORD, Miss., July 2 -- "Men working" would be on the whole an accurate label to fling across the Deep South, where this begrimed bus rider has been operating for the past fortnight. Except for the evenings, when the jukeboxes which are the curse of America begin to scream out of the cafeterias, no one has time for a moment's idle conversation.

WASHINGTON, July 2 -- Syracuse will undertake in a few weeks a defense experiment in the use of block food wardens under the sponsorship of the Office of Civilian Defense, the Office of Defense Health and Welfare Services, the Agricultural Marketing Administration and the Office of Price Administration.

Supreme Court Justice Felix C. Benvenga approved yesterday a certificate dissolving the New York chapter of the America First Committee, Inc. The petition, listing as directors John T. Flynn, president, and Edwin S. Webster Jr., secretary, declared that all members had consented to the dissolution.

Despite the fact that the Treasury received last week a large part of the proceeds in cash, as well as in bank credit, for its new issue of $1,500,000,000 of certificates of indebtedness and already had made calls on depositary banks, effective yesterday and today, a new Treasury call was issued yesterday.

Mid-year condition statements reported yesterday by banks generally followed the trends indicated by institutions which reported previously. Most of the reports show increases in holdings of United States Government securities, declines in cash position, and small declines in total loans and discounts.

Sevastopol was defended as Winston Churchill said Britain would be, and as Britain surely would be: on the beaches, on the landing grounds, in the fields, in the streets, in the hills. The Russians have fought, here and on other fronts, with something in their souls that would not consent to defeat while life remained.

Arriving in the United States in groups from various parts of the far-flung battlefront in the Western and Southern Pacific, nearly 250 survivors of the war with Japan brought home yesterday their experiences of fighting the enemy in the sky, on land and on sea on Bataan and Corregidor, in the Coral Sea, off Australia and elsewhere.

President Roosevelt's nomination of Thomas F. Meaney to be judge of the Federal District Court of New Jersey was unmistakably made for political reasons. It is not the first of the President's political nominations to the Federal courts. The Senate vote which confirmed the nomination was no less political.
ST. LOUIS, July 2 (AP) -- The Cardinals won their fourth game in a row and their third straight over Pittsburgh, turning back the Pirates, 3 to 1, tonight on the five-hit pitching of John Beazley.

A twilight contest between the Giants and Braves will be the "ladies' night" baseball attraction at the Polo Grounds this evening, starting at 7 o'clock. The game was originally scheduled for last night, but was postponed.

WASHINGTON, July 2 -- The In-! terstate Commerce Commission set up rules today governing freight charges on large amounts of export freight now in storage on rail carriers' premises in the BlewI York-New Jersey port terminal area, which may be moved to interior points for storage under the authority of the Office of Defense Transportation.

Now, at this moment, when the fate of Egypt hangs in the balance, and Mr. Churchill tells the House of Commons that these are "times of mortal peril," let us reaffirm our faith in British courage, British endurance, British honor. Now, above all other times, let us give thanks for three years of steady courage and uncomplaining sacrifice on the part of the British people.

COLD SPRING HARBOR, L.I., July 2 -- A square dance will be given tomorrow night at the Cold Spring Harbor Beach Club for the benefit of the Navy Relief Society. The fete will be conducted in accordance with the dimout regulations of the Suffolk County Civilian Defense Committee, and by permission of the Coast Guard.

RICHMOND, Va., July 2 -- Only a few hours before his electrocution, Odell Waller scrawled a final testament, admitting "I haven't lived so upright" and saying "I have asked God to forgive me and I feel He has."

STANTON, Del, July 2 -- After nine unsuccessful attempts, Joseph E. Widener's 3-year-old gelding Crosstide was finally graduated from the maiden ranks at Delaware Park today when Eddie Wielander had him up in the last jump to beat the favored Trierarch a neck in the featured mile-and-seventy-yard Delaware City Purse.

If William Henry Jackson, climber of so many peaks, hadn't had the misfortune to fall in his room he would have gone out this month, as was his custom, to look upon a landscape which he has recorded so admirably. At 99 he might have been taken for 70. He was alert, eager, youthful of spirit and active of body.

This department has made sure of an adequate provision of good war news for the next fortnight by a device which is as simple as it promises to be effective. Inasmuch as the incoming 1942 crop of war dispatches in the morning paper is not likely to be very satisfactory for some days to come, this department proposes every morning to read the 1941 paper for the corresponding date.

Israel Lewis, 70 years old, president of the Narem Realty Corporation at 211 West Thirty-fourth Street, and his son, Herman, 43, entered not-guilty pleas yesterday in General Sessions on a first and second degree manslaughter indictment for not complying with the Multiple Dwelling Law in the rooming house at 239 West Sixteenth Street, in which five persons died in a blaze and six others were injured last March 7.

CHUNGKING, China, July 2 (AP) -- Large formations of Chinese bombers yesterday attacked Japanese military establishments in the Hankow area and Yoyang, in North Hunan at the mouth of Tungting Lake, both vital points on the Yangtze River, Central News reported today.

Many British and Canadian destroyers, corvettes and other anti-submarine craft have come to the assistance of the United States Navy in the battle against enemy submarines off our eastern seaboard, it was announced yesterday by the Navy Department in Washington, which also released during the day the news of three more sinkings of merchant vessels by Axis submarines.

WASHINGTON, July 2 -- The Congressional deadlock which is withholding from the Department of Agriculture its entire $680,000,000 operating fund for the new fiscal year reached an angry phase today when the Senate scotched a House attempt to write into law forthwith its demands that not a bushel of the large stores of government-held surplus farm commodities could be disposed of at prices below full parity levels.

WASHINGTON, July 2 -- The contest in the Senate over the nomination of Thomas F. Meaney to be a Federal judge in New Jersey was important because his designation by the President is an example of politics as usual in a time when the public is called on for the highest expressions of idealism and for acts of heavy sacrifice.
DETROIT, July 2 -- Big Al Benton survived a ninth-inning threat today to defeat the Browns, 5 to 4. It was his fifth successive victory and it enabled the Tigers to divide the two-game series.

WASHINGTON, July 2 -- President Roosevelt today accepted the resignation of W.W. Waymack, editor of the editorial pages of The Des Moines Register and Tribune, as an assistant member of the National War Labor Board. Mr. Waymack, in quitting the board, paid tribute to the labor policies of the President and the NWLB.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 2 -- "The Miracle," German religious spectacle play by Karl Volmoeller, which Warner Brothers acquired some years ago from Max Reinhardt, but which the company did not film, has been revived, and Samson Raphaelson has been engaged to write the scenario, the studio announced today.

The first convictions for treason in the United States were those after the "whisky rebellion" which centered in Pennsylvania in 1794 as an uprising against the attempted enforcement by the Federal Government of excise taxes enacted against domestic liquors by Congress in 1791.

PANAMA, July 2 -- The Guayaquil newspaper Universo reports that the Ecuadorean Foreign Office has announced the receipt through the Swiss Legation of a German offer to liberate or change the Nazi death sentence of Clemente Ballen de Guzman, an Ecuadorean in Marseille, France, provided reciprocal treatment is given by the Ecuadorean Government to Germans in Ecuador. Universo reports:

LONDON, July 3 -- A reorganization of the Government of India, giving the Indians a large majority on the Viceroy's council with an Indian as Minister of Defense on the council, and appointing two Indians to positions in the War Cabinet equal in all respects to the representation of the dominions was announced tonight.

MOSCOW, Friday, July 3 (U.P.) -- Fierce street fighting at close quarters is raging in Sevastopol after German shock troops crashed into the outskirts of the city, and 450 miles north the Germans have blasted open two new fronts above Kharkov in the Belgorod and Volchansk areas, the Red Amy announced today.
PHILADELPHIA, July 2 -- The concluding game of their series with the Athletics postponed today, the Yankees left for Boston for the important series with the Red Sox.

Announcement of the wool allocation order for the six-month period beginning Aug. 3 helped clear the situation in wool goods during the past week, according to the trade report of the Wool Associates of the New York Cotton Exchange, Inc.
CAIRO, Egypt, July 2 (AP) -- British Army Headquarters and the R.A.F. issued the following joint communique today:

NEWARK, N.J., July 2 -- Arrested in Asbury Park last night on a charge of impersonating an Army officer, Edward Byrnes, 30 years old, was brought here this afternoon to face an additional charge of embezzling $2,100 from the New Jersey Realty Title and Insurance Company, where he was employed in the auditing department until a month ago.

BERNE, Switzerland, July 2 -- German military quarters revealed today that heavily reinforced German units have been thrown into the fighting in the center and south of the Eastern Front. It is therefore presumed that the major activities that are to mark the beginning of the main offensive are under way and that the coming weeks will witness important actions in the further progress of the European War.

CAIRO, June 2 -- After a day of harassing operations by R.A.F. and United States fighters and bombers in cooperation with British ground units against the enemy in the El Alamein area, the Allied heavy bombers last night launched mass raids on Axis objectives along the Egyptian coast and at Tobruk.

A lingering belief that loans at full parity for major crops soon may receive Congressional approbation induced trade covering of short positions yesterday in the cotton market, forging final net gains of 21 to 25 points, or $1.05 to $1.25 a bale, for active contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange.

In the war against inflation we have now come to a decisive battle. Let us make no mistake, the demand for a wage increase of $1 a day in "Little Steel" which is now before the NWLB is a crucial test case. If that increase is granted the bars will be down. Similar wage demands, some of which are already pending, will then have to be granted too.

PHILADELPHIA, July 2 -- The American Gas and Electric Company petitioned the Securities and Exchange Commission today for approval of a plan whereby $3,500,000 lent by it to three subsidiary operating companies to assist them in financing programs would be converted into capital contributions.
