MEXICO CITY, July 2 -- Consolidating and augmenting her east coast defenses, Mexico set up today a Military Region, Gulf of Mexico, with all army, navy and air units in the area from the United States border to British Honduras under the command of General Abelardo Rodriguez.

Yesterday's statement of the twelve Reserve Banks showed reserve note circulation and holdings of United States Government securities to be at the highest of the year to date, the latter showing an increase of $145,705,000 for the week.

The theft of jewelry, variously valued at from $8,000 to $15,000, from the brownstone home of Mr. and Mrs. Hans J. Isbrandtsen at 87 Remsen Street in the Columbia Heights section of Brooklyn was disclosed yesterday, by the police.

Upward revision of early estimates for the nation of the amount of applications for war damage insurance, placed at $25,000,000,000 on Wednesday, became necessary yesterday when it was learned that nearly 90 per cent of the real estate in New York City, which has an assessed valuation in excess of $15,000,000,000, is to be insured under the Federal program for varying percentages of total value.

WASHINGTON, July 2 -- President Roosevelt appointed a special military court to try the Nazi saboteurs recently landed here from submarines and issued a proclamation denying the civil courts to certain persons in wartime. He had no engagements.
MOSCOW, Friday, July 3 (AP) -- The midnight Soviet communique said:

WASHINGTON, July 2 -- The authority of Elmer Davis, director of the new Office of War Information, to control the release or suppression of military information is being questioned by some high officials of the War and Navy Departments, who do not concede to him a right to direct their policies.

Following a trial without a jury, Judge Robert A. Inch in Federal Court, Brooklyn, yesterday found Peter Simsich of 176 Nostrand Avenue, that borough, an Italian subject, guilty of violation of the Selective Service Act. The court set July 16 for sentence and continued Simsich in bail of $500.

The Securities and Exchange Commission joined Attorney General John J. Bennett Jr. yesterday in the investigation of causes for a sharp break in the market value of 4 per cent first mortgage bonds of the Wisconsin Central Railroad Company, Superior Duluth division and terminal, on the New York Stock Exchange last Tuesday.

WASHINGTON, July 2 -- A substantial increase in the quota allotment of sugar for individuals is justified for the rest of this year by the supplies already on hand and those practically assured in the coming six months, according to figures furnished to the Office of Price administration by members of the industry and other government departments.

WASHINGTON, July 2 -- About 230,000 adult-size bicycles will be distributed to eligible buyers throughout the country under Federal rationing from July 9 to the end of August when another quota allotment will be announced.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 2 -- The California Supreme Court, in a majority opinion by Chief Justice Phil S.P. Gibson, held today that "untruthful picketing" was unlawful "picketing" and decided, contrary to a lower court decision, that false statements on signs and banners displayed by pickets were cause for an injunction.

SOMEWHERE IN AUSTRALIA, July 2 -- Australia almost certainly is safe from invasion for at least three months, but it now is evident that an Australian-based counteroffensive by the United Nations is unlikely in the next six months.
WASHINGTON, July 2 -- The War Production Board took complete control today over the entire supply of domestic cattle hides, calf and kip skins and buffalo hides.

Britain, after the war, will not be ruled by "a privileged class of landed aristocrats" nor will it go Communist, but rather it will be a country of full employment and social security for all, Harold Heresford Butler, new British Minister to the United States, asserted last night.
LONDON, July 2 (AP) -- The Bank of England weekly statement today showed note circulation at a new high of 801,605,000, an increase of 5,565,000.

MOSCOW, Friday, July 3 -- The Germans launched two more drives yesterday on the southwestern front between Kharkov and Kursk, in the neighborhood of Belgorod, some forty miles north of Kharkov, an old riverside town long in German hands, and Volchansk, about twenty miles southeast of Belgorod.

In view of the professed inability of wholesale grocers to comply with the pyramided regulations of the Federal Security Administration and the War Production Board with regard to syrups, except at considerable expense, an immediate adjustment should be made to permit relaxation of the regulations, the National-American Wholesale Grocers stated in a special memorandum filed yesterday with the WPB.

LONDON, July 2 -- Every available inch of space was taken in the House of Commons today for the wind-up of the debate on the central direction of the war. Khaki-clad Members of Parliament sat on the floor, the visitors' galleries were jammed, and the small, closely packed, inadequately ventilated chamber was like an oven.

WASHINGTON, July 2 -- The texts of President Roosevelt's order establishing a military commission to try the eight Nazi saboteurs, and of his proclamation suspending the right of court trial for enemy aliens who enter the United States to commit sabotage, espionage or warlike acts follows:
CLEVELAND, July 2 (U.P.) -- Uncle Sam comes out ahead no matter who wins next Tuesday night's game between a team of the boys in his service and the major league All-Stars, it was agreed tonight.
WASHINGTON, July 2 -- Some of the best-known general officers of the Army make up the military commission named today by President Roosevelt to try the eight Nazi saboteurs.

WASHINGTON, July 2 -- Legislation designed to alleviate the Eastern seaboard oil shortage through construction of two pipe lines and a barge canal and removal of spacing restrictions on drilling of new wells was approved today by a Senate Commerce subcommittee.

BATTLE CREEK, Mich., July 2 (AP) -- Major Samuel J. Davis, acting commanding officer of Kellogg Field, announced tonight that the following twenty-one officers and enlisted men were aboard the Army transport plane which crashed near Welch, W. Va., yesterday:

WASHINGTON, July 2 -- Hector Lazo, president of the Cooperative Food Producers of America, praised Leon Henderson today for putting maximum price regulations into effect. Without them inflationary increases in prices by the end of 1943 would have reached $50,000,000,000, he said.

WASHINGTON, July 2 -- John E. Hamm, deputy administrator of the Office of Price Administration, indicated today that the use of women volunteers to do the job of helping local shops to comply with price ceiling regulations would not immediately become national policy.

LONDON, July 2 -- The House of Commons gave Prime Minister Winston Churchill a fresh mandate today to continue the direction of the war both as Prime Minister and Minister of Defense. By a vote of 475 to 25, with about twenty-seven members abstaining, the first motion of censure that Mr. Churchill had had to face since he became head of the British Government in May, 1940, was defeated.
ALBANY, July 2 -- Governor Lehman's announcement of a $54,127,419 State surplus brought two proposals today far disposal of the largest Treasury reserve since 1931.

WASHINGTON, July 2 -- The House approved today and sent to the White House a Senate bill authorizing the Federal Reserve System to change the reserve requirements of member banks in central reserve cities within the limits of the present law, without necessarily making a change in such requirements of member banks in reserve cities.

MONTREAL, July 2 (Canadian Press) -- Formation of an international committee of "economic statesmen" to advise the International Labor Office in its current planning for the post-war reconstruction period was among the important decisions taken at the meeting of the I.L.O.'s emergency committee in London in April, it was announced today at I.L.O. headquarters here, in an article made public simultaneously in pamphlet form and in The International Labor Review, monthly I.L.O. publication.

WASHINGTON, July 2 (AP) -- An American flier, who has seen service in battles over Europe with the Royal Air Force, has described American aircraft as equaling or surpassing the best the Axis can offer.

OCEAN CITY, N.J., July 2 (AP) -- National A.A.U. track and field championships in eleven events will be decided Saturday when the nation's outstanding women athletes will vie for individual and team titles at Recreation Field.
Three matches will be on the final day's program for the national professional tennis championships tomorrow at the West Side Tennis Club, Forest Hills.
CHUNGKING, China, July 2 (AP) -The Ohinese High. Oow%and {8-I sued this conmuniqu today:
PHILADELPHIA, July 2 -- As aI means of simplifying its corporateI structure, the__Conso_____dated Elec-

The excellent work of the FBI in capturing Nazi saboteurs is extremely gratifying news. The publicity attending this capture has in this case a certain value in convincing "grousers" that the protective measures which the Army, Navy and Coast Guard have been taking to remove enemy aliens from certain coastal areas, license short-wave diathermy sets, etc., are completely justifiable and are not merely restrictions of civil rights.

LONDON, Friday, July 3 (U.P.) -- The German radio at Prague announced early today that General Kurt Daluege, Nazi protector of Bohemia and Moravia, had lifted the state of emergency in Czechoslovakia that he ordered in May following the assassination of his predecessor, Reinhard Heydrich.

The letter signed "G.H.K.," condemning the bathing suit measure, calls for comment. Laws are not made to preserve the morals of those who do not have them -- that would not be possible -- but to protect the orderly from the disorderly.

WASHINGTON, July 2 (AP) -- Four proposals relating to the control of Axis commercial and financial activities in the Western Hemisphere were submitted today to a committee of delegates of the Inter-American Economic and Financial Conference.

Advertising linage in eight New York newspapers last month registered a decline of 11.8 per cent, with all papers showing losses, according to a compilation yesterday based on Media Records figures. The fact that there were only four Sundays last month, as against five in June, 1941, contributed to the decline.

WASHINGTON, July 2 (AP) -- Seven officers of the Navy have received awards of the Distinguished Flying Cross and two naval enlisted n men have Been promoted for heroism in the sea and air attacks on Japanese bases on the Marshall and Gilbert Islands Jan. 31.

Earl Browder returned to his Communist comrades last night with the message that they, along with everyone else in this nation, must "unite for victory" to beat off the most deadly danger to this country in its 166 years of independence.
New York may receive this Summer the title of Mosquito City, unless steps are taken immediately to avoid an unnecessary by-product of our air raid precautions.

BOSTON, July 2 -- Joe Cronin today fined an apologetic Ted Williams $250 and the exasperated Red Sox manager warned the slugger that an indefinite benching would be the punishment for his next outburst of temper.

WASHINGTON, July 2 (AP) -- More than half the membership of the House, 219 Representatives, obtained "X" ration cards for unlimited purchases of gasoline, files of the District rationing administration showed today.

WASHINGTON, July 2 -- Establishment of a "buffer" zone about fifty miles wide and extending west from the present inland borders of the East Coast's present rationing area is being considered by the Office of Price Administration and the Office of Petroleum Coordinator.
LONDON, July 2 -- Business on the stock market was on a small scale again today. Egyptian issues were steadier with the unified 4s firm at 75 and Sudan Plantations up to 23s.

Despite Wendell L. Willkie's assertion that he was not a candidate, the Draft Willkie Committee decided yesterday to keep on with its attempt to bring about his nomination for Governor, presumably on the Republican ticket.

CHICAGO, July 2 -- President Will Harridge of the American League tonight announced the line-up of All-Stars who will take the field under Manager Joe McCarthy in the annual game with the National League All-Stars in New York's Polo Grounds on Monday.

RIVERHEAD, L.I., July 2 -- County Judge L. Barren Hill refused today to free Mrs. Edith Reichert, 29 years old, of Brooklyn, who was acquitted yesterday of first-degree murder in the "mercy slaying" of her insane brother, George Horne, 26, at the Kings Park State Hospital last Dec. 3.

The proposals of the committee on post-war problems of the National Association of Manufacturers come as a bitter disappointment. Next to winning the war the American people's greatest concern is the security of their post-war jobs. The N.A.M. is in position to contribute effectively toward that security.
WASHINGTON, July 2 -- President Roosevelt has accepted the resignation of Francis B. Sayre as High Commissioner to the Philippine Commonwealth.

Accidental or thoughless violations of the dimout regulations are far more numerous than deliberate ones, according to a survey made by civilian lighting experts who have been cooperating with the Army in studying the problem.

WASHINGTON, July 2 -- A red "fag bag" for the Presidential cigarettes and matches while President Roosevelt tours his Hyde Park estate was presented today by Betty FitzGerald of Washington, on behalf of the 700,000 Girl Scouts of America, Marwin H. McIntyre, secretary to the President, accepted the gift on behalf of the Chief Executive.

With 240 tons of scrap rubber and 208 tons of tin cans added yesterday to the local salvage hoppers, it was announced that the iron and steel industry had underwritten, with a $1,500,000 contribution, a nation-wide new drive to start July 13 for rubber, steel, tin, lead, zinc, copper and other critical war materials.

WASHINGTON, July 2 -- Axis-owned retail and wholesale stores, banks and industries that have been seized by Mexico under its war powers are being turned over to Mexican managers, who are directed to resume operations of the properties as a means of sustaining the nation's war economy, the Commerce Department reported today.

CAIRO, Egypt, July 2 (U.P.) -- British Empire troops, heavily reinforced from the Middle East, have encircled General Field Marshal Erwin Rommel's German Africa Corps on the Egyptian coast west of Alexandria and are hammering at it with all available weapons from front, flank and rear, it was learned tonight.

LONDON, July 2 -- Arthur Greenwood, deputy leader of the Labor party and until a few months ago a member of the War Cabinet, was attacked by a man armed with a knife in the early hours of this morning while returning home from the record sitting of Parliament.

Payments on the new issue of $1,500,000,000 of Treasury certificates of indebtedness, further withdrawals by the Treasury from its accounts in commercial banks, general shifts in funds throughout the country incident to the month-end, and further expansion in money in circulation caused wide changes last week in banking statistics.

WASHINGTON, July 2 -- Collections of surplus war material at the Capitol Building, including iron, steel, bronze, brass, copper, lead cable, cast aluminum, scrap metal and rubber total thus far about 636,230 pounds, David Lynn, architect of the Capitol, in charge of the survey, has reported today.

A Cape Cod kitchen -- a large square room with windows overlooking a blue bay -- used to be the scene of intense activity on the Fourth of July. A fat pink salmon, one that weighed all of sixteen pounds, was stuffed with a buttery bread crumb dressing early in the morning, then skillfully engineered into the hot oven of an old-fashioned coal stove.

CLEVELAND, July 2 (AP) -- A new cargo record for the Great Lakes is being established by the new giant freighter Leon Fraser, which is due to arrive at Conneaut, Ohio, tomorrow with 16,863 gross tons, bill of lading weight, of iron ore.

VICHY, France, July 2 -- After two years in the unoccupied zone, the Conseil d'Etat or State Council, the governmental consultative and judiciary body dealing with administrative cases and grievances against the State and which is headed by the Minister of Justice, now Joseph Barthelemy, has returned to Paris.

BUENOS AIRES, Argentina, July 2 -- At the end of a turbulent sitting at which insults and even missiles were tossed about, the Chamber of Deputies by a large majority rejected today the resignation from its Committee to Investigate Anti-Argentine Activities of Deputy Raul Damonte Taborda, who has been its chairman since its creation in June, 1941.

Holders of Series G war savings bonds, the series on which interest is payable every six months, failed to receive their dividend checks from the Treasury on July 1, a canvass in Wall Street banking circles revealed yesterday.

The necessity for unity, among both the American people and the United Nations, to defeat the Axis powers was stressed last night by Governor Lehman and Major Gen. Thomas A. Terry, commander of the Second Corps Area, in speeches at the celebration of the Society of Tammany or Columbian Order of the 166th anniversary of American independence in Tammany Hall.

BERLIN, July 2 (From German broadcasts recorded by The Associated Press) -- Germany's dead and missing in the first full year of the war on the Russian front were placed by the High Command today at 337,342, an increase of 141,704 over Adolf Hitler's figures of last Dec. 11.
Nearly 700 passengers, a majority of whom are believed to be United States citizens, were still being held by government authorities last night on the Swedish exchange liner Drottningholm.

More extended examinations at interim periods, adoption of the natural business year by corporations and extension of the time limit for submitting annual reports to the Securities and Exchange Commission were among recommendations made yesterday by the American Institute of Accountants and the New York State Society of Certified Public Accountants, which are seeking to relieve the pressure of wartime audit requirements on the accounting departments of corporations and certified public accountants.

WASHINGTON, July 2 (AP) -- Declaring that Alaska's economic stability and security were being threatened by price increases, Leon Henderson, Price Administrator, established a special price-fixing formula for the territory today.

A former refrigerator mechanc who enlisted in the Navy as a pharmacist's mate was arrested yesterday for posing as a Navy medical officer and for passing several worthless checks. Detectives who made the arrest said he had enlisted in the Navy seven months ago, deserted about a month ago and had been victimizing merchants in the midtown area.

After Grover A. Whalen had given Mayor La Guardia a medal at City Hall yesterday from the Committee of 160 which organized the recent "New York at War" parade, the Mayor suggested the headline for this story when he said:

WASHINGTON, July 2 -- Higher market prices for certain foods, principally wheat flour and dried and fresh fruits and vegetables, and for cotton and naval stores caused a rise of 0.3 per cent in the Bureau of Labor Statistics composite index of prices of 889 articles for the week ended on June 27.
LONDON, July 2 -- Following are the most important passages of Prime Minister Churchill's speech in the House of Commons today:

BAYONNE, N.J., July 2 -- Mayor James J. Donovan, in a statement today asking the residents of Bayonne to retain their confidence in him, described the indictments returned against him and four other persons by the Hudson County grand jury Tuesday as the "first overt act toward Hague's [Mayor Frank Hague of Jersey City] repeated threats to ruin me."

RICHMOND, Va., July 2 (AP) -- Odell Waller, 25-year-old Negro sharecropper, whose case ran through the State and Federal courts in an exhaustive, two-year legal fight, went to his death in the electric chair at the Virginia penitentiary today for the killing of Oscar Davis, his white employer.
Here is the gasoline situation the holiday motorist may expect throughout the Eastern States where rationing is in effect, as seen yesterday by auto club and gasoline dealer officials.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 2 -- A suit brought by the Grand Secretary of the Native Sons of the Golden West, aimed at disfranchising American-born Japanese, was dismissed today by Judge A.F. St. Sure of the Federal District Court.

The Italian people can be moved to revolt against the regime of Premier Benito Mussolini and to cooperation with the United Nations for a democratic victory provided a "more dynamic, more creative" policy is adopted toward Italy by the United States and its allies, Count Carlo Sforza, former Italian Foreign Minister, declared yesterday.

New State and municipal financing scheduled for next week by nineteen municipalities aggregates $6,268,892, compared with $5,584,455 this week. The weekly average of new offerings for the year to date now stands at $23,895,830.

JERUSALEM, July 3 -- Non-aggression, mutual aid and extradition clauses were included in the world's first recorded three-power pact, unearthed at Ras ul Ain on the Turkish-Syrian frontier in the form of clay tablets bearing cuneiform writing of 1500 to 1300 B.C.

ALBANY, July 3 (AP) -- Representative Hamilton Fish, Republican member of Congress from New York's Twenty-sixth district, declared today, "It will be just too bad" for Thomas E. Dewey if the latter attempts again to block his re-election.

BERNE, Switzerland, July 3 -The press of Germany is now giving increasing consideration to the effects of British air raids on the Rhineland, Ruhr and Northwestern German cities, a survey today shows, and the simulated freedom with which the activities of the Royal Air Force are now being discussed suggests a change in Nazi censorship and domestic propaganda policy, which formerly permitted only the High Command communiques to be printed.

Cotton futures were erratic yesterday, but the market was steadied in the late trading by strong trade support, believed to be covering by shorts. With this demand offsetting hedging and profit-taking, active contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange rallied from losses of 3 to 16 points to net gains of 10 to 14 points.

A "one-pupil" graduation was conducted yesterday on the lawn of Montefiore Hospital, Gun Hill Road and Bainbridge Avenue, the Bronx, when Andrew Staiano, 19 years old, a patient, received his diploma as a high school graduate.

Hubert Fauntleroy Julian, 44-year-old ex-colonel in the Ethiopian Air Force and self-styled Black Eagle of Harlem, was unable to enlist as a regular recruit in the United States Army because he was born in Trinidad, British West Indies, and never became a citizen of this country, but he managed to have himself inducted yesterday as a Selective Service volunteer.

Every motorist who wants better than an A ration card when the permanent gasoline control goes into effect on July 22 must join a car-sharing club with his neighbors or fellow-workers or be prepared to explain why it is impossible to do so in his case, George S. Van Schaick, director of the Second Civilian Defense Area, said yesterday.

There has been some discussion recently of a proposal to merge the appeal of the Red Cross with the appeals made by the Community Chests of different cities. Fortunately, President Roosevelt has taken a position against this plan. In a letter addressed to Norman H. Davis, he has expressed the opinion that the Red Cross "should make its war fund and membership appeals directly and separately and should not participate in joint fundraising efforts."

"Business as usual" is the prevailing holiday motto of the New York women's volunteer groups. The "glorious Fourth" is being celebrated on duty by the women canteen workers, hospital aides, motor corps and ambulance drivers.

It is reported in THE NEW YORK TIMES from London that the government is being urged to set up a scientific general staff as an aid to the British war effort. America should profit by the suggestion and take similar steps to open a free and untrammeled channel through which the scientific genius and inventive skill of this country can be utilized.

The long-awaited change of the OPA price ceiling period for raw, dressed and made-up furs is expected to be announced momentarily, according to the market survey issued yesterday by United Fur Brokers.

A unified campaign to save the positions of the forty teachers dismissed Thursday by the Board of Education in an economy move to offset budget cuts will be waged by the city's 35,000 teachers, it was announced yesterday by the Joint Committee of Teachers Organizations.

The educational program required for the officers and men of the Second Army, Lieut. Gen. Ben Lear, commanding, is the basis of a book to be issued by Appleton-Century early next month. Entitled "School of the Citizen Soldier," the book covers world geography and trade, United States history, the organization of our armed forces and those of Germany and Japan, and methods of propaganda warfare.

Girls in native costumes of the twenty-eight United Nations gave impetus to the sale of war bonds and stamps at a demonstration of Allied solidarity in Times Square yesterday under the auspices of the United States Treasury's New York War Savings Staff.

MOSCOW, Saturday, July 4 -Sevastopol, Russia's great Crimean naval base and fortress, has fallen as a mass of ruins, Soviet Russia officially announced today, but its magnificent defense was hailed as a major factor in holding up the German Spring offensive and it cost the Axis upward of 300,000 soldiers Killed or wounded.

Amateur press enthusiasts -- men and women, young old and middle-aged, from many sections of the country -- met yesterday in the Hotel Abbey, 149 West Fifty-first Street, to review interests and discuss differences at the sixty-seventh annual convention of the National Amateur Press Association.

Because of the appeal of Joseph B. Eastman, Director of the Office of Defense Transportation, for voluntary deferment "for the duration" of all meetings and conventions and kindred events not related to the war, the biennial convention of the United Lutheran Church in America, scheduled to be held in Louisville, Ky., Oct. 14 to 21, may be postponed.

George (Birdie) Tebbetts, Detroit catcher, will be New England's only native-born son in the major league All-Star game at the Polo Grounds next Monday. New England, which has produced such outstanding catchers as Mickey Cochrane, Gabby Hartnett, Bill Carrigan and Connie Mack, has two other representatives in the American League catching department in Jimmy Hegan and Red Desautels of Cleveland.

While Treasury officials in New York City relied more on patriotic cooperation than on legal enforcement, plans were announced yesterday in Northern New Jersey to summon evaders of the $5 annual automobile tax. The levy, due last Wednesday, is a war measure.

BERNE, Switzerland, July 3 -Non-military commentators in tonight's Italian press once again sounded a note of warning against undue optimism regarding the outcome of the battle for Alexandria. The first inkling of a slowdown in General Field Marshal Erwin Rommel's drive is given, and this is said to be "a natural outcome of increased difficulties inherent in a campaign with communications as long as his present ones."

BERNE, Switzerland, Saturday, July 4 -- After three days' fierce resistance on the Chersonese cape, west of Sevastopol, Russian forces there were reported by Moscow this morning to be making "their last stand" as they continued to exact a heavy toll from the enemy.

WASHINGTON, July 3 -- The national income, as judged from income payments to individuals, is still increasing sharply in the United States. The Department of Commerce reported today that such income payments totaled $8,656,000,000 in May, which was nearly 25 per cent greater than a year before and nearly 50 per cent greater than in May, 1939.

WASHINGTON, July 3 -- Another development in the interunion warfare between the Congress of Industrial Organizations and the United Mine Workers of America was a circular latter addressed by James B. Carey, secretary of the C.I.O., today to all State C.I.O.

The story of how one group of traders ran up the price of Wisconsin Central Railroad Company defaulted 4 per cent mortgage bonds from 12 1/2 to 35 in four months by purchases totaling $379,400 on the New York Stock Exchange preparatory to unloading most of the shares profitably in unlisted sales on the basis of "inside" tips, which never materialized, was revealed yesterday by Attorney General John J. Bennett.

MELBOURNE, Australia, July 3 -- With the example of Libya before them, many informed persons here are becoming concerned about certain views on the situation in this theatre of operations seemingly held at home.

WASHINGTON, July 3 -- American soldiers on leave in London will be able to celebrate the Fourth of July at the new George Washington Club, which will be opened tomorrow with ceremonies by the American Red Cross, officials of the Red Cross announced here today.

WASHINGTON, July 3 -- A wholesale and retail inventory policy committee within the War Production Board's Division of Civilian Supply has been set up to study the necessity for inventory control through the country, Joseph L. Weiner, deputy director, announced today.

Mrs. Louise Macy, a New York fashion authority and former Paris editor of Harper's Bazaar, will be married in about a month to Harry L. Hopkins, aide to President Roosevelt, it was disclosed yesterday.

Without interrupting their regular tasks, hundreds of thousands of war workers in factories, shipyards and mines from Maine to Florida listened yesterday by radio to a production rally held at the base of the Statue of Liberty.
BERLIN, July 3 (From German broadcasts recorded by The Associated Press) -- The German High Command communique said today:

BALTIMORE, July 3 -- The world's largest flying boat, a four-engine craft big enough to carry 150 fully equipped troops or to fly to Europe and back without landing, lifted off the waters of the Chesapeake Bay this afternoon for its first official flight. Before darkness the giant patrol bomber made three perfect rake-offs and landings.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., July 3 -Mrs. T. Markoe Robertson heads the executive committee for the war bond drive to be held in Agawam Park after the "gasless" parade here tomorrow morning under the auspices of the Malcolm R. White Post of the American Legion.

Gregor Piatigorsky, 'cellist, appeared as soloist at the concert of the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra, under Fritz Reiner, which attracted a moderate-sized audience to the Lewisohn Stadium last night. The program was the same originally announced for Thursday evening, which had been postponed.

"Atlantic Convoy," a Columbia action drama featuring John Beal, Virginia Field and Bruce Bennett, will arrive today at the Central Theatre. Supporting roles in the film, which was directed by Lew Landers, are played by Victor Kilian, Larry Parks, Forrest Tucker and Lloyd Bridges.

An official tally from Pearl Harbor makes it abundantly clear that the Battle of Midway was much more than a fortunate repulse of the enemy. It was a major Japanese disaster. Such a stiff blow seems bound to have a profound effect not only on the naval strategy of the Pacific but on the morale of a maritime nation which, previous to this war, never lost a sea battle.

WASHINGTON, July 3 -- Seven appropriation bills totaling $44,867,764,981, a sum well above the total expenses of the Federal Government for the first 129 years of existence, were signed by President Roosevelt today.

WASHINGTON, July 3 (AP) -- The Senators defeated the Athletics tonight, 4 -- 0, before a crowd of 5,000. Walter Masterson held the Athletics to five hits, allowing them not more than one to an inning, while his team-mates garnered seven safeties off Richard Fowler and Russ Christopher.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., July 3 (AP) -- Richard H. Simons, Connecticut FBI agent, said tonight his office had been informed "that an individual in custody in Mexico City has admitted to Mexican authorities that he is Gerhard Wilhelm Kunze, national leader of the German-American Bund."

LONDON, July 3 -- The outstanding feature of a cheerful stock market today was the recovery in the oil issues. Iranians rose 2s 6d to 43s 1 1/2d, Shell 2s 6d to 47s 6d, Mexican Eagle Is 6d to 10s 6d and Canadian Eagle 10 1/2d to 10s.

VICHY, France, July 3 (UP) -Marshal Henri Phillipe Petain, the Chief of State, told a group of returned war prisoners today that France was "crushed and whipped" although some of the population still did not realize it.

MELBOURNE, Australia, Saturday, July 4 -- Parades and fireworks were the only traditional features lacking from the Fourth of July celebration Americans enjoyed today as the Australians arranged a lavish program.

NEWARK, July 3 (AP) -- Jersey City rang up seven runs in the first inning of a twilight game tonight and coasted to a 9-to-2 victory over the league-leading Bears behind Rube Fischer's effective hurling.

WASHINGTON, July 3 -- Americans will get a two-pound "bonus" ration of sugar on their stamp No. 7 which will be expendable beginning July 10 and at any time up to Aug. 22, the Office of Price Administration said today.

WASHINGTON, July 3 (AP) -- The War Department disclosed today that the Army had surveyed about one-third of a proposed railway route to Alaska to supplement the inland highway already under construction.

BERNE, Switzerland, July 3 -"Coordination" of the French press in both zones is foreshadowed in private advices from Vichy tonight. A decree to that effect may be promulgated soon. On the face of it this is a success for the Chief of Government, Pierre Laval, but in reality there is not much change, merely more regimentation.

CAIRO, July 3 (AP) -- British forces tonight slashed at General Field Marshal Erwin Rommel's rebuffed forces on the northern end of the El Alamein line, seventy miles west of Alexandria. The rumble of heavy guns could be heard in Alexandria.

MANCHESTER, Vt., July 3 -Down-State and up-State New York vied for qualifying honors today in the fifteenth annual Robert Todd Lincoln Memorial Cup golf tourney at the picturesque Ekwanok Country Club, which snuggles between two ranges of the Green Mountains.

WASHINGTON, July 3 -- Despite the fact that the Detroit and Cleveland Navigation Company of Detroit has been operating at a loss since 1930 the War Labor Board unanimously decided today to bring the wages of its seamen up to the level of those prevailing for other seamen on the Great Lakes.

WASHINGTON, July 3 (AP) -- Relaxation of restrictions against civilian consumption of wool was urged today by spokesmen for the country's wool growers, testifying before a Senate committee studying a suggestion that the government buy the domestic clip for the duration of the war.

Lieutenant C. Leslie Glenn, chaplain of the Naval Reserve Midshipmen's School on the U.S.S. Prairie State, Hudson River and West 135th Street, is conducting a service for the students at 7:30 P.M. every Sunday through the Summer in the Riverside Church, West 122d Street and Riverside Drive.

Supreme Court Justice Ernest E.L. Hammer granted yesterday a certificate of reasonable doubt permitting freedom on bail, pending appeal from their conviction, to nine men convicted in General Sessions last month of extortion and conspiracy in connection with a $2,500,000 milk racket.

WASHINGTON, July 3 -- The State Department reiterated its charge today that the German Government had violated the agreement for exchange of nationals on the chartered Swedish liner Drottningholm by withdrawing its guarantee of safe conduct for the vessel between Lisbon and New York.

Leaders in the fresh food industry are making considerable progress in their efforts looking to an industry-wide campaign to promote consumption of fresh foods and thereby conserve man power and packaging materials.

People will read with interest the statement by H.H. Butler, the new British Minister in this country, that Great Britain after the war will not be ruled by "a privileged class of landed aristocrats." Not very many of us will note Mr. Butler's exact words. They are important:
CHUNGKING, July 3 (AP) -- The Chinese High Command issued the following communique tonight:
Doesn't Major Paul C. Raborg, in his "Mechanized Might," err in saying the British built the first tanks "to be used in Egypt for transporting large containers of water"?

To us old suffragists it seems at times that the hands of the clock have been turned back a quarter of a century. The American medical women are engaged in a campaign to be allowed to serve in the Medical Reserve Corps of the Army and Navy under equal rating with men physicians.

BALBOA, C.Z., July 3 -- Further details of the round-up of the spy ring, suspected of fueling and furnishing information to enemy submarines on the Gulf Coast, were revealed today by an officer of the Caribbean defense command.

The first offering of a silk leg construction in women's full-fashioned hosiery for Fall and Winter was made yesterday when the Van Raalte Company announced that it was including in its line a three-thread silk number, with rayon welt, silk heel and sole, and toe of rayon plated with silk, at $8.75 per dozen, to retail at $1.25 per pair.

WASHINGTON, July 3 -- Members of the Senate subcommittee who are considering the appropriation for the OPA said Mr. Henderson had left the impression that he is preparing "to go to bat" at once with the War Labor Board on the question of wage increases.
LONDON, July 3 -- The names of the British warships lost in the convoy operations in the Mediterranean between June 13 and 16 were announced tonight by the Admiralty.

Activity in the market for new issues of securities was restricted this week almost exclusively to the distribution of $35,000,000 of the Celanese Corporation's twenty-year 3 1/2 per cent debentures. The largest offering of industrial bonds since $100,000,000 of the American Tobacco Company's debentures appeared in April, the flotation attracted considerable attention in investment circles.

SOMEWHERE IN EGYPT, July 3 -- After what might be described as a comparative lull, the fighting in the El Alamein area was resumed today at dawn or shortly before with the same terrible intensity that has marked the conflict since the British took up positions in a supreme, determined effort to turn the tide of battle and hurl the invader back across the sandy stretches whence he came.

The approximate status of the municipal bond market is reflected in the following list of representative high-grade State, city and county bonds legal for savings banks in New York State, now offered by dealers:
WASHINGTON, July 3 -- President Roosevelt has approved a plan under which the people of Puerto Rico would elect their own Governors. At present the Governor is appointed by the President.

With hearts hopeful of victory over the foes of liberty, Americans everywhere will celebrate today our greatest national holiday, Independence Day. Many of the nations associated with us in the war also plan to celebrate. In New York City and its suburbs many patriotic observances will be staged.

WASHINGTON, July 3 -- A $62,000,000,000 saving on war costs, or just that much of a bulwark against the threat of uncontrolled inflation, can be effected within the next twenty months if prices are held at their present levels, Leon Henderson, the Price Administrator, said today.
ALBANY, N.Y., July 3 (AP) -- Cooperation of New York motorists with government efforts to curtail travel paid a 27.8 per cent dividend in lives in May, a new low record of fatalities for the month.
Two more sinkings of merchant vessels by submarines, with a combined death toll of fifty-four, were announced by naval authorities in this country yesterday.

The Manhattan Shirt Company, in a statement issued yesterday and covering the six months ended on May 30, estimates the net profit at $295,631 after Federal income taxes, equal to $1.42 a share on 208,107 shares of common stock, excluding 21,874 shares held in the treasury.

PHILADELPHIA, July 3 -- With three prominent citizens of the city as "neutral observers," Joseph Shallit, a reporter for The Record, was arrested today when he attempted to take a snapshot of the Liberty Bell in Independence Hall.

WASHINGTON, July 3 (AP) -- A proposal for integration of all the nation's transportation facilities into a limited number of systems was advocated today by a witness before the Board of Transportation and Research. The board, created by the 1940 Transportation Act, is studying the transportation problem with a view to recommending legislation.

BUENOS AIRES, Argentina, July 3 -- Captain Luis Pedro Scalese of the torpedoed freighter Rio Tercero arrived in Buenos Aires by air today to answer certain questions that the government wishes to ask him before replying to the German note delivered on June 30, in which it is understood the Wilhelmstrasse takes exception to the Argentine version of how the sinking occurred.

We must celebrate the glorious Fourth with too little gasoline and too little rubber; with priorities crowding in ahead of us when we go shopping; with our surplus cash, if any, earmarked for Government bonds or next year's taxes; with young men going off secretly on transports, when we had hoped they might be getting jobs and getting married.

WASHINGTON, July 3 -- Deferment of construction of five 60,000-ton superdreadnaughts was prompted by the lack of sufficient materials for the building of essential combatant craft and not by a decision that the battleship had outlived its usefulness, the Senate was told today by the Committee on Naval Affairs.
MINETTO, N.Y., July 3 (AP) -- An additional 100 workers joined today a walkout over wages at Columbia Mills, Inc., partly engaged in war work.

Whirlaway is among eight named for the $30,000 added Butler Memorial Handicap, to be run today at Empire City, where the management is conducting Army-Navy Day with the guarantee that the total will be at least $100,000.

BUFFALO, Saturday, July 4 (U.P.) -- Workers retired two open-hearth furnaces at the Bethlehem Steel Company's Lackawanna plant early today, ending a strike that had cut steel production to one-third of normal.

While advertising results for the first six months of this year, showing drops for all media, are not too encouraging, the increasing number of campaigns in support of government projects may partly balance the loss of product advertising in the second half, according to agency executives.

WASHINGTON, July 3 -- Stocks of domestic and foreign crude petroleum on June 27 were 253,364,000 barrels, according to the Bureau of Mines, United States Department of the Interior. This represented an increase of 616,000 barrels in the week, comprising an increase of 776,000 barrels in domestic stocks and a decline of 160,000 in foreign stocks.

ALBANY, July 3 -- Laidlaw Co., 26 Broadway, New York, have received authority from the State Banking Department to engage in the business of private bankers with a capital of $750,000. A previous certificate was revoked, owing to the addition of one partner.

CAIRO, July 3 -- Fighting west of El Alamein continued today, mainly in the northern area near the coast, and the British took a number of prisoners and knocked out several enemy guns, it was officially announced here.

Broadcasting a Fourth of July greeting last evening to the people of Australia and New Zealand, Mayor La Guardia said his greeting was the most pleasant assignment he had had in quite a while. He was introduced by Sir Angus Fletcher, consultant to WRUL on shortwave broadcasts to the British Empire.

WASHINGTON, July 3 -- As an Independence Day gesture to the American forces in the Far East, the National Symphony Orchestra tonight played the world premiere of Harl McDonald's new tone poem, "Bataan," at the Water Gate by the Lincoln Memorial.

Your paper and others carried the story that Mayor La Guardia sent a letter to 3-A draft registrants-informing them that failure to join the City Patrol Corps would be reported to local draft boards. The letter contained the unmistakable threat that the failure of a man to join this corps might result in his being placed in a different draft classification.

PHILADELPHIA, July 3 -- Unless President Ford Frick of the National League allows a protest by Manager Hans Lobert, today's meeting between the Dodgers and Phils will remain in the records as an 8-1 Brooklyn triumph, No. 8 for John Whitlow Wyatt, who almost hit a home run.

Undernourished children in Summer camps are receiving surplus food commodities through the Agricultural Marketing Administration, Department of Agriculture, 150 Broadway, it was announced yesterday. One hundred and sixty-five non-profit camps in New York, New Jersey, Connecticut and Pennsylvania are served from New York City and county warehouses.

I would like to correct an error which appeared recently in THE TIMES. In respect to the memory of Lou Gehrig, it is only fair that he receive all the honor that is due to him. If I remember correctly, your article stated that Mel Ott now is runner-up to Babe Ruth in the matter of runs batted in over a lifetime.

As part of a comprehensive code to guard against racial or religious discrimination in jobs filled through the United States Employment Service, Mrs. Anna M. Rosenberg, regional director of the Social Security Board, has instructed all public employment offices in this State not to make placements for any employer who "refuses to employ otherwise qualified applicants solely because of race, color, creed, national origin or descent," it was learned yesterday.

SAN JOSE, Costa Rica, July 3 -At least twenty-three men were reported tonight to have been lost in the torpedoing of a United States freighter by a German submarine that sneaked into the Puerto Limon harbor and fired three torpedoes at the vessel.

All banks and securities and commodity exchanges in the nation will be closed today, but Wall Street will not be deserted entirely. Several of the larger banks will operate key departments with skeleton staffs for inter-bank work that cannot wait, even for Independence Day.

LONDON, Saturday, July 4 -- Still suffering from the effects of the raid by 1,000 British bombers on the night of June 26 and two more strong blows by the Royal Air Force in the week since, Bremen was left devastated Thursday night when a "powerful force" of planes subjected that North German port and U-boat base to a fourth attack in the R.A.F.'s big offensive against Reich war centers, British officials said yesterday.

Accustomed to going all out for anything he undertakes, Leo Durocher yesterday named not one but two starting line-ups for the National League club he will pilot Monday night at the Polo Grounds in the All-Star battle with the American League's galaxy for the Army's Baseball Equipment Fund.

Yugoslavia's army will continue to fight until the war is ended or until it has been "wiped out," Peter II, King-in-exile of the Balkan country, declared in a press conference yesterday afternoon at the Waldorf-Astoria Towers. "That would be very difficult," he added, because "we have caught the Germans in a sort of war they know nothing about."

Fireworks touched off by exploding Giant bats beat in the Fourth of July by a few hours at the Polo Grounds last night as the New Yorkers routed the Braves, 10 to 6, in a twilight game. They stretched ten hits out to twentyone bases in spite of the rubber shortage, while pummelling four Boston pitchers.

MONTCLAIR, N.J., July 3 -Robert Odman of the University of Washington and Edward Moylan of Spring Hill College in Alabama filled the two lower varsity singles semi-final brackets in the Eastern intercollegiate tennis championships at the Montclair A.C. today.

NEWARK, N.J., July 3 -- After twenty-nine years' service, Frankland Briggs of this city has retired as vice president in charge of the legal department of the New Jersey Bell Telephone Company, it was announced today. He will remain on the board of directors, but the legal post has been assumed by Thomas Glynn Walker, who succeeded Mr. Briggs as general counsel on Jan. 1.
The ebb and flow of desert war surged around the sand dunes of El Alamein again yesterday as the crucial battle for Egypt continued with but brief and sporadic pause.

Although Mrs. Julia O. Flikke, superintendent of the Army Nurse Corps and highest ranking woman in the United States Army, has been commissioned as a colonel, it may take an act of Congress to keep the silver eagles on her uniform, it was disclosed yesterday.

CHICAGO, July 3 -- Wheat made a strong start and a tame finish today, advancing early on buying attributed to mills and reports that the Department of Agriculture was now favorable to the proposed legislation seeking to give farmers 100 per cent of parity loans.

Committees for underlying bonds, receiver's certificates and first and consolidated bonds of the Seaboard Air Line Railway filed yesterday a plan of reorganization for the company in the Federal court in Norfolk, Va. A committee for underlying bonds headed by Edwin G. Baetjer of Venable, Baetjer Howard of Baltimore, Md., also filed a plan.

New York City's public buildings, waterworks, museums and other property, and the great bridges and tunnels connecting Manhattan with the other boroughs and New Jersey thus far have not been insured with the Federal War Damage Corporation against bombardment risks, it was learned yesterday.

CLEVELAND, July 3 (AP) -- Hal Newhouser allowed only three hits tonight as the Tigers beat the Indians, 5 to 1, to pull within one game of the third-place Tribe. Detroit batted around in the first inning, routing Mel Harder with six hits and four runs.

Rainy weather took toll of retail trade here this week, although sales volume improved yesterday and Thursday. Estimates put department store volume at about 7 per cent under the corresponding period a year ago. Main-floor departments were fairly busy, but total store activity appeared to lack snap, except for the excellent customer response to the first week of the July drive for war bond and stamp purchases.

Acting with speed on a broad borough thoroughfare, two armed men held up a 30-year-old checker for the Morton Coal Company of 425 Carroll Street, Brooklyn, shortly after 10 A.M yesterday, and escaped with a $3,000 payroll. The checker, Joseph Minsky, 1536 Fifty-first Street, Brooklyn, was taking the payroll from the Lafayette National Bank at Fifth Avenue and Ninth Street, Brooklyn, to his office.
The Harlem River was revealed yesterday as a source of scrap rubber.

TIDBITS turn up where least expected, or "quo minime reris," as Prof. Moe Berg would intone it with the proper Virgilian swing. There has come to this desk a publication called "Benefactor," put out by the Humanity Publishing Company of Detroit. The issue at hand is a four-page affair and the front page "leader," written by Alfred Lawson, who apparently is the soul of the enterprise, is entitled: "Foresight Needed to Win This War."

On June 30 there were 1,242 stock issues aggregating 1,469,960,158 shares listed on the New York Stock Exchange with a total market value of $33,419,047,743, according to a compilation by the Exchange made public yesterday. On May 29 there were 1,242 stock issues, aggregating 1,469,388,445 shares, with a total market value of $32,913,725,225.

WASHINGTON, July 3 -- Vice Admiral Royal E. Ingersoll, Commander in Chief of the Atlantic Fleet, became a full admiral today by order of President Roosevelt. The promotion was thought to reflect the importance of activities in which the Atlantic Fleet is engaged.

In a 3-to-2 ruling, the Appellate Division decided yesterday that Sonja Henie, ice skater and film star, must pay $77,658 to Dennis R. Scanlan, promoter, of St. Paul, Minn., under an oral contract by which, he contended, she agreed to pay him 20 per cent of her motion-picture earnings if he would bring her to this country and obtain motion-picture roles for her.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 3 -RKO today signed Simone Simon for the leading role in "The Cat People," a modernized version of an ancient Balkan legend about peasant folk who turn into cats at night, after the manner of werewolves.

WASHINGTON, July 3 -- The Army relaxed its standards today for "limited" military service by selectees in the 1-B classification and it will now be possible for the Selective Service to induct men with one eye, others deaf in one ear and others with deformities including crooked spines.

Two former holders of the country's amateur singles crown, J. Donald Budge and Robert L. Riggs, will meet today for the national professional tennis singles championship at the West Side Tennis Club in Forest Hills, beginning at 2:30 o'clock.

ST. LOUIS, July 3 (AP) -- Although outhit, the Pirates beat down a desperate ninth-inning rally to trip the Cardinals, 5 to 4, today and drop them another full game behind Brooklyn. The Cards took the series, however, three games to one.

WASHINGTON, July 3 -- The Navy Department made public today a casualty list of 886 officers and men of the Navy, Marine Corps and Coast Guard as reported to their next of kin between June 7 and 17 inclusive. The list, the sixth to be issued by the Navy, brings its total casualties since the war started to about 11,000.

Imagine a child in the country asking for permission to step on the grass or being frightened by the song of a bird. Yet these are common experiences of the children who come from the slums of East Harlem to the beautiful country where our three Union Settlement camps are located at the Palisades Interstate Park.

BERNE, Switzerland, July 3 -Fighting in Yugoslavia between patriots and the occupying forces in cooperation with Croat troops has reached such a pitch that Ante Pavelitch, Croat leader, has gone to "the northern Bosnian front." From there he is issuing triumphant communiques, although the extent of the resistance is to be discerned in the admission that "Croat newspapers express the hope that soon it will be possible to cleanse Croatia of the 'Communist' revolt."
NEW DELHI, India, July 3 (UP) -- Military quarters here believe Japan will hurl against China -- not India -- the considerable army she is massing in North Burma during the monsoon fighting lull.
SAN ANTONIO, Texas, July 3 -- The prepared text of Associate Justice Robert H. Jackson's address at the annual banquet of the Texas State Bar Association was as follows:

The beginning of the month can sometimes be an unpleasant period. You sit at a desk and stare at the bills the mailman has just delivered. And somehow the sight of them in their neat envelopes leads to thoughts of income taxes and insurance premiums.

GOSHEN, N.Y., July 3 (AP) -Follow Me, owned by G.L. Hemp of Camp Hill, Pa., and driven by youthful Eddie Havens, won the Coaching Club Trotting Oaks for 3-year-old fillies today as the Grand Circuit program finally got under way.

LONDON, July 3 (U.P.) -- Americans in the British Isles, about 8,300 civilians and armed forces of undisclosed strength, will celebrate Independence Day quietly tomorrow, with their British hosts contributing to the ceremonies.

The protective committee for holders of Equitable Office Building Corporation thirty-five-year 5 per cent debentures has applied to the Federal Court for permission to pay the interest coupons due May 1 and Nov. 1, 1941, and the court has set a hearing for 10:30 A.M., July 10.

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., July 3 -- Young women in furbelowed, billowing hoop skirts curtsied to the Queen of the Cotton Ball, Dorothy Elizabeth Evans, and the King, Lieutenant Sam Read Smartt, in Memorial Auditorium here tonight while 5,000 spectators applauded.

WASHINGTON, July 3 -- The four charges under which the eight Nazi saboteurs will be tried by the Military Commission each started with an identical preamble reciting that "during the month of June, 1942, the prisoners, Ernest Peter Burger, George John Dasch, Herbert Haupt.

ON THE EGYPTIAN FRONT, July 2 (Delayed) -- A perfectly synchronized force of British tanks, infantry, mobile artillery and bombers struck the Axis invaders of Egypt at 6 P.M. today west and south of El Alamein.

MELBOURNE, Australia, Saturday, July 4 -- At a Fourth of July luncheon today Air Minister A.S. Drakeford declared that Pacific strategy now made Australia the most important base from which to deal with Japan, and Australia looked to the United States to furnish in very large measure the supplies necessary to hurl back the Japanese.

With good fields entered in the six events, the United Hunts Racing Association will hold its annual meet at the Piping Rock Club in Locust Valley this afternoon. The program is part of the general war effort, with all profits from the pari-mutuel betting going to the Army Emergency Relief and the Navy Relief Society.

The Appellate Division upheld unanimously yesterday the conviction for perjury of Morris U. Schappes, ousted City College instructor, whose indictment resulted from his testimony before the Rapp-Coudert committee investigating subversive activities in the public educational system.
MOSCOW, July 3 (AP) -- The Soviet Information Bureau issued this communique today:

A WEST COAST PORT, July 3 -- The destroyer Shaw, which pushed across 2,000 miles of water between Hawaii and the United States mainland with a false bow after suffering heavy damage at Pearl Harbor, is ready for battle again.

BOSTON, July 3 -- Fears that the Yankees are in immediate danger of evacuating their leadership in the American League flag race were rather forcefully dispelled along about dusk today as the world champions answered Boston's challenge by upsetting Joe Cronin's Red Sox, 5 to 3, in the opening clash of a three-game series.
The sale of three large apartment houses in the Bronx was reported yesterday, together with a number of other deals.

Current consumption of paper is generally reported as running substantially ahead of orders and by Fall the backlog in the hands of users is expected to be worked down to a point where new business will start to rise, executives in the industry reported yesterday.

Post-Independence Day sermons will be preached tomorrow in the pulpits of the city. Lessons will be drawn from the Declaration of Independence in the light of the world chaos. Some of the topics will be "Freedom Under God," "The Peril and Promise of Freedom," "The Purpose of Liberty," "Learning From the Nazis" and "The Crime of Waste."
CAIRO, Egypt, July 3 (AP) -- A joint British General Headquarters-R.A.F. communique said yesterday:

WASHINGTON, July 3 (AP) -- Expressing fear of wide-scale price wars and casualties among small independent dealers, a committee of Eastern gas station operators urged the Office of Price Administration today to modify the coupon gas rationing program which is to become effective July 22 in seventeen Eastern States.

The Amerex Holding Corporation declared yesterday a semi-annual dividend of 37 1/2 cents a share. This is 12 1/2 cents less than the amounts distributed in February, 1942, and in February and August last year.

The U.S. Atlantic tuna tournament apparently will be held this season, notwithstanding the obstacles that might be considered as militating against its success. The ways and means committee met the other evening and drafted plans for the holding of the event, that had become a fixture on the fishing calendar, as a "telegraphic competition" Aug. 17 and 19.

Hubert Pierlot, Prime Minister of Belgium, arrived at La Guardia Field last night aboard a Pan American transatlantic clipper and announced that he would discuss with United States officials the possibility of sending food to his occupied country.

When the noon whistle blows today at the Navy Yard in Brooklyn a brief ceremony occupying only a few minutes will mark the official transfer to the Navy of a field ambulance donated by the New York County unit of the American Legion Auxiliary.

PHILADELPHIA, July 3 -- Attorney General Biddle promised tonight in an address broadcast around the world that the post-war leadership of the United States would not be "sabotaged by isolationists" and assured friend and foe alike that this time America and her Allies would win not only the war but the peace.

Simplified housekeeping and one-dish meals may soon be no longer optional for the duration, as more and more "Matties" and "Susans," hypnotized by the lure of "war work," are dropping their pots and pans and leaving the kitchen for the assembly line.

WASHINGTON, July 3 -- Four German-controlled United States concerns and bomb and shell-mak-ink equipment which had been lying idle on a Brooklyn pier since 1939 were taken over today by Leo T. Crowley, Alien Property Custodian.

WASHINGTON, July 3 -- Four charges under which the Military Commission appointed by President Roosevelt will try the eight Nazi secret agents for sabotage and espionage and conspiracy to commit these acts were made public today by Attorney General Francis Biddle and Major Gen. Myron C. Cramer, Judge Advocate General of the Army, who will act as prosecutors.

Utilizing the experience of the Schenectady area as a guide, OPA officials are taking steps to register all housing units in nine other defense rental areas of Region II, in which rents have been formally "frozen." Region II embraces New York, and several up-State communities are included in the freezing order.

Thousands of mail orders for war bonds from New Yorkers on vacations or business trips throughout the country, who used pledge blanks printed in New York newspapers, have been pouring in since the drive formally ended last Sunday, headquarters of the Greater New York War Bond Pledge Campaign announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, July 3 -- President Roosevelt sharply criticized today "certain selfish and power-hungry groups" whom he accused of seeking to impair the government's freedom "to use its feed resources to produce food for the wartime effort."

Last year employes of the Public Library retiring after forty-five years of service received the praise due to honored veterans. Dr. Frank Weitenkampf, for twenty-one years curator of prints at the Public Library, has just retired after a service of sixty-one years. So he almost makes novices of the oldest hands there before him.

The Appellate Division, in a three-to-two decision, ruled yesterday, that a voting trust for stock of the Prudence Securities Corporation was not affected by the Streit law limiting voting trusts in real estate reorganizations to five years.

VICHY, France, July 3 (U.P.) -- A number of Soviet warships, chiefly gunboats, have fled from the Crimea to Turkish ports, the official French news agency said tonight, and German sources said Caucasian harbors were bombed all day to make them untenable for the rest of the Russian Black Sea Fleet, which has lost its Sevastopol base.

Service in two midtown hotels was interrupted yesterday by brief strikes of members of the Hotel Trades Council, an A.F.ofL. affiliate. Both strikes were called off after the managements had agreed to meet with the union to discuss contracts.
MOSCOW, Saturday, July 4 (AP) -- The Soviet midnight communique said:

A new super-siren, said to be 500 times as powerful as those now being used here, will be tested from its perch atop the RCA Building in Radio City shortly after noon today. It is the first of ten similar sirens that are to be installed in the city this month.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, July 3 -No figures are available here on Jewish massacres in Nazi-occupied areas except those furnished by refugees and occasional newspaper correspondence from Germany. They permit any conclusion one wants to make, from 100,000 to 1,500,000.

BERLIN, July 3 (From German broadcasts recorded by The Associated Press) -- German and other Axis troops have broken through the Russian front on a width of nearly 185 miles, the German High Command announced today.

CHICAGO, July 3 -- Chicago banks issued today statements of condition as of June 30, showing in most cases a moderate decline in loans for business use in the last three months. Deposits, which have been rising steadily over a long period, again established an all-time record.

Caught siphoning gasoline from one automobile to a car they had stolen to attempt a hold-up, according to the police, James R. Dickie, 23 years old, and Herman Santos, 20, both of whom said they had no home, were held without bail for the grand jury yesterday in Brooklyn Felony Court by Magistrate Francis Giaccone.
LONDON, July 3 (AP) -- The Admiralty issued this communique today:

With gains of a point or more plentiful, the stock market made yesterday its best recovery in two weeks. More encouraging news from the Egyptian war front provided the needed factor to support the upturn, and again the rally came in the face of the extended week-end as the holiday today will close all markets until Monday.

Chalet Estates, Inc., Abraham Meitin, secretary, sold the twelve-story apartment house at 120 West Eighty-sixth Street to the Georgene Realty Corporation, representing John Avrutis. The building has been renovated into forty-eight apartments at a cost of more than $100,000 and was sold for cash over a mortgage of $345,000, which has been extended for five years.

WASHINGTON, July 3 (AP) -President Roosevelt called upon farmers today to help with the government's anti-inflation campaign by diverting a larger share of their expanding income to the retirement of an agricultural debt estimated by credit authorities at $10,000,000,000.

Thirty-eight thousand Boy Scouts will observe Independence Day by making a house-to-house canvass for scrap rubber, Clarence H. Low, chairman of the New York City Salvage Committee, said last night. Calling upon New Yorkers to rummage in their homes for articles to give the Scouts, Mr. Low said:

CHICAGO, July 3 (AP) -- Prices of hogs rose 15 to 25 cents a hundredweight today supported by active bidding from Eastern shippers and local packers. The top was $14.90, up 20 cents from yesterday and the highest since July 6, 1926, when a top of $15 was established. Top before permanent ceilings were placed on dressed pork was $14.65.

CHUNGKING China, Saturday, July 4 (U.P.) -- American Volunteer Group pilots, in their last battle under Chinese colors before joining the United States Army air forces, routed eight Japanese bombers that tried to raid the Canton-Hankow railway city of Hengyang, it was revealed today.

SAN ANTONIO, Texas, July 3 -- Robert H. Jackson, associate justice of the Supreme Court, and Walter P. Armstrong, president of the American Bar Association, deeply deplored today the fact that the study of United States history is omitted from the courses of more than three-fourths of the colleges and universities of this country.
The household fats, whose collection on a national scale has been announced, may come back to you -- unrecognized -- in your clothing, shoes, stew pans and the paper and ink you use to write letters.

LONDON, July 3 (U.P.) -- Patriot armies in the Balkans, growing bolder in the face of Axis oppression, have slain thousands of Italians in the mountains of Albania and disrupted vital German communication lines to Russia, reports to London said today.

The clarification of the rules of golf and their application were given another jolt when the sports pages recently carried photographs of the technical big-wig of the U.S.G.A. microscopically inspecting and measuring the face of an iron club at the Hale America tournament in Chicago.

BERNE, Switzerland, July 3 (AP) -- Axis reports tonight declared that "several thousand excellently equipped American troops took part in the fighting at El Alamein" in the Battle of Egypt, but there was no confirmation from any official or other source.

Welfare Commissioner William Hodson said yesterday that sixty-seven of the seventy-one investigators in his department dropped by the Board of Estimate on Tuesday would be restored to the payroll for thirty days without prejudice either to their rights or those of the city.

"WHEN you get thinking that you are smarter than your subconscious," said Katharine Brush, "you are licked. The only good writing you do is almost automatic, you make a conection with a voice that seems to come from outside your head but doesn't, of course.

LONDON, July 4 -- The Duchess of Kent gave birth to a boy this evening at Coppins Iver, Buckinghamshire. The condition of the Duchess and the infant Prince, who is seventh in direct succession to the throne, was reported as satisfactory in a bulletin issued by three attending physicians.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J. -- This Independence Day week-end finds Uncle Sam's official representatives much in evidence among the thousands of visitors and indications are that future week-ends will find even more of the Army, Navy and Coast Guard on hand.

CHICAGO, July 4 (AP) -- Pounding five home runs, two apiece by Vern Stephens and Mike Chartak, the Browns today swept a double-header with the White Sox, 8 to 5 and 8 to 7. Tony Criscola's single scored Harlond Clift with the winning run in the thirteenth-inning nightcap.

Although the influx of 4,000,000 women into the industrial plants of the nation is anticipated before the end of 1942, and the important part women are taking in the war effort is repeatedly acclaimed, there are still virtually no representatives of the distaff side on policy shaping boards in Washington, dedicated to directing the assimilation of women into this effort.

Peter II, exiled King of Yugoslavia, spent part of yesterday in this city almost in the same way as did the thousands of visitors who came here for the Fourth of July. He took a walk and rode unrecognized in the subway. He also visited the top of the Empire State Building and rested in his suite in the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.

A GREAT deal of nutrition education has been conveyed to parents in a tone so positive -- so much of this, so much of that -- and applied so literally, and with such zeal, regardless of the child's needs, that for some time past many experts have been trying to get parents to lay off a little.

ORANGE, N.J., July 4 (AP) -- Frank Bowden of New York and W. Robert Dixson of Syracuse, N.Y., the only seeded domestic players to see action, easily won their opening matches today as the forty-ninth annual New Jersey State tennis championships got under way at the Berkeley Tennis Club.

On the second anniversary of the disastrous bomb explosion behind the British Pavilion at the World's Fair, Flushing underwent yesterday another scare, but one that fortunately had no more serious results than the disruption of the luncheon schedule of a hundred families.
WASHINGTON, July 4 -- The United States Navy communique said:

An acetylene welder in an airplane factory, Miss Frances Keeley, dressed for work in green corduroy trousers and wearing goggles, placed yesterday a wreath at the base of the Eternal Light in Madison Square Park in Independence Day ceremonies of the Minute Men of America, Inc.

The experiment in "humanizing" the technical achievements of engineering inaugurated at the New School for Social Research this year has proved successful, according to Dr. Alvin Johnson, director of the school.

THERE will be held this afternoon at Tanglewood in Stockbridge, Mass., the opening exercises of Dr. Koussevitzky's Berkshire Music Center. The event has more than ordinary significance. It betokens as courageous and public spirited an act as any musician in America could have to his credit in this time of national crisis.

LONDON, July 4 -- Some weeks ago the British people, indeed, the United Nations throughout the world, rejoiced at the news that the British had sent a thousand bombers over Cologne. Two nights later they rejoiced that they had repeated the performance.

Workers in war plants throughout the East were too busy yesterday forging the tools of freedom to take time out to celebrate the Fourth of July. Surveys by Army and Navy officials indicated that virtually all factories and shipyards engaged in production for the armed forces were operating normally except where they were handicapped by lack of materials or other factors unrelated to the holiday.

THE jury of admission has been announced by the Metropolitan Museum for the selection of its big all-American contemporary art exhibition next Winter. The exhibition of painting, sculpture and graphic art, under the auspices of Artists for Victory, will open according to present plans early in December.

RUMSON, N.J., July 4 -- The annual Fourth of July party at the Rumson Country Club was staged in a simpler manner than in the past. A buffet dinner was served on the terrace throughout the evening. Mrs. Wilbur B. Ruthrauff had charge of arrangements.

WASHINGTON, July 4 -- The so-called permanent gasoline rationing system for the seventeen last coast States and the District of Columbia will go into effect two weeks from Wednesday, with a dozen agencies of the government meanwhile exploring every conceivable means of breaking the bottlenecks which have made rationing necessary.

"Free French Week," emphasizing the importance of the Free French movement in the world struggle against Hitlerism, will be observed Wednesday through July 14, Bastille Day, with a series of events arranged by the principal Free French organizations here, it was announced yesterday from Freedom House, 32 East Fifty-first Street.

Food industry leaders, generally opposed to subsidies, have submitted a "formula" to the Office of Price Administration by which the aims of the price-ceiling "break-through" announced last week may be accomplished immediately through distributors, it was learned yesterday.

Careful consideration should be given by the appropriate authorities in Washington to the resolution which has been passed by the Association for the Protection of the Adirondacks with regard to the proposed construction of a railroad across lands which are set apart by the Constitution of the State of New York to be kept forever as wild forest lands.

This Independence Day week-end is providing the railroads with the greatest test of their capacity to carry a maximum number of passengers that they will have had to meet in 1942, and its results will be studied for guidance through the rest of the year.

In spite of their willingness generally to conform to the OPA price regulations, retailers "may have missed a bet" in not discussing price ceilings in their advertising, according to views in important retail quarters here yesterday.

CANBERRA, Australia, July 4 -- Nelson T. Johnson, United States Minister to Australia; Prime Minister John Curtin and Senator J. S. Collings, Minister of the Interior, today jointly laid the foundation stone for the 80,000 [Australian] United States Legation building.

The petroleum industry reported a substantial improvement in profits in the first quarter of 1942, compared with those a year before, although there was a decline from the final quarter of last year. It should be noted, however, that gasoline rationing in the East began only in the second quarter of 1942, and that losses of tankers, which became noteworthy in February, affected only a few of the Eastern companies.

DETROIT, July 4 (U.P.) -- Lieut. Gen. Brehon B. Somervell pleaded with labor today to shun squabbles interfering with war production, so that the nation could destroy the enemies of "everything we hold dear."

The training in good management that industry is receiving by making out reports for the War Production Board and other government agencies will more than offset the expenditure of time and money involved at this time, according to J. Alexander Smith of McKinsey Co., management consultants.

KENTUCKY, says Alvin E. Harlow toward the end of his rich and full-flavored book, has always been a rugged individualist. And as you look back across these lively pages you may be surprised to realize how generally, and in what vital detail, Kentucky's individuality (as well as individualism) stands out.

The appalling line-up of cars at gasoline stations throughout the metropolitan area showed little sign of abatement in its third week. The condition became acute on the week-end of June 20, following orders for the temporary six-gallon ration unit on June 15, and promises to continue until "permanent" rations go in effect on July 22.
J. Donald Budge stands once again as the undisputed master of the tennis courts.
"BACKWARD, turn backward, O Time, in thy flight!" At the close of operations on the Fourth of July, 1914, the following reports were filed for the record:

MADISON, N.J., July 4 -- Dean Lynn Harold Hough of Drew Theological Seminary has arrived safely in England by plane to fill a series of preaching engagements in London, according to word received at Drew University. The trip was arranged through the British Library of Information under priorities for air travel worked out by the State Department.

Praising the American Labor party's rejection of the candidacies of Thomas E. Dewey, Republican, and Attorney General John J. Bennett Jr., Democrat, for Governor, Israel Amter, the Communist candidate, declared last night that national unity in support of President Roosevelt's war policies requires a coalition in State elections of all labor groups, New Deal Democrats and win-the-war Republicans.

A service flag and two honor rolls were dedicated yesterday in the Rockaways and branch villages at ceremonies attended by 2,500 persons. The service flag represented 1,000 men in the armed forces from Inwood, Lawrence, Cedarhurst, Woodmere and Hewlett.

CHUNGKING, China, Sunday, July 5 -- The United States Army's new air forces in China got their baptism of fire by downing at least five planes in three waves of Japanese fighter-escorted bombers that roared out an Independence Day challenge at dawn yesterday over Hengyang, Hunan railway center, authoritative sources reported today.

A suggestion that all of the United Nations issue stamps with designs dramatizing the Four Freedoms, the Atlantic Charter, the basic war and peace ideals and unities, and similar themes, is being placed before President Roosevelt, "America's No. 1 philatelist," by the Office of War Information.

MANCHESTER, Vt., July 4 -- Mark J. Stuart, Winged Foot Golf Club star and 1941 winner of the tournament, was eliminated today from the Robert Todd Lincoln Memorial tourney, annual Over-the-Fourth fixture at the Ekwanok

THERE is an alarmingly growing practice among the service widows of today's war of sending sentimental souvenirs to their boy friends in the fields afar. If the girls go to the theatre, they send the programs to their men at camp; if they go to parties, they send them the favors.

BERNE, Switzerland, July 4 (AP) -- The Axis press and spokesmen displayed caution today in comments on the fighting in Egypt, restricting themselves generally to quoting the Berlin and Rome communiques, which acknowledged counter-attacks by the strongly reinforced British, but said that those attacks had been beaten off.
