THAT "rubber is a vital war munition" we no longer need to be told. What the authors of this valuable book have done is to go into particulars about it. And at this moment it is especially pertinent that they go into particulars about reclaimed rubber -- the "scrap" we have been individually collecting for our country's need.

WASHINGTON, July 4 (AP) -- The House committee on investigation of air accidents declared today the crash of a Transcontinental Western passenger plane near Las Vegas, Nev., Jan. 16, in which Carole Lombard and twenty-one others were killed, was due to the negligence of Captain Wayne Williams the pilot.

WASHINGTON, July 4 -- Army and Navy Air Forces, operating under unified command, have been hammering at Japanese invasion forces in the outer Aleutian Islands, both the War and Navy Departments announced today, but with results of their attacks generally obscured by foggy weather.

HANOVER, N.H., July 4 -- Radio's growing importance in college will receive additional recognition at Dartmouth next week when the campus broadcasting system takes over part of the orientation program for some 200 freshmen registering on Monday.

A change in the dates on which New Yorkers may register for the permanent gasoline rationing, which goes into effect on July 22, was made known yesterday, giving car owners four days in which to file their basic applications at public schools.

BUENOS AIRES, Argentina, July 4 -- Foreign Minister Enrique de Ruiz Guinazu participated in his official capacity today in the Fourth of July celebration here, attending a lunch of the American Society of the River Plate. Ambassador Norman Armour and diplomatic representatives of the other United Nations also were present.
ANNE O'HARE McCORMICK'S discriminating review of "The Problems of Lasting Peace," by Herbert Hoover and Hugh Gibson, I have read with keen appreciation.

Twenty-five art museums throughout the country have joined the American Art Research Council to pool their resources in what promises to be an exhaustive collection of information about the country's art and artists.
PITTSBURGH, July 4 (AP) -- Bucky Walters beat Max Butcher in a hurling duel as the Reds won the opening half of a scheduled double-header from the Pirates today, 2 to 0.
PHILADELPHIA, July 4 -- If the July Fourth tradition about the team that leads the league on that date hold good, "Our Bums" are in again.

Salpiglossis is regarded by many as the most beautiful of the annual flowers. There is good reason for this regard, as this petuniashaped flower in many rich colors with beautiful feathering and streakings of silver, gold and other shadings truly render it one of our most attractive flowers.

WASHINGTON, July 4 -- Dr. Joaquin Espada, Bolivian Minister of Finance, and Alberto Crespo, Bolivian Minister of National Economy, will arrive here tomorrow, accompanied by experts, to discuss with government agencies the program of economic cooperation between the United States and Bolivia.

LONDON, July 4 -- Since last Wednesday Britain has not mined coal in the national property. From this "vesting date" the Public Coal Commission acquired the mineral rights from private owners "to promote the interests and efficiency of better organization of the coal industry."

The flying fraternity once was exclusive. Only a few years ago a pilot or an "aviatrix" was something apart from the common herd -- and the people who had "been up" rode the comet's tail. It was all most exhilarating, except for the drab 95 per cent of the population who never got off the ground without jumping.

Members of forty different nationalities, creeds and races have contributed $3,168,000 of the $4,500,000 sought here by the USO to safeguard the morale of the troops by providing organized offduty recreation, H.C. Brunie, chairman of the city-wide campaign, announced yesterday.

URBANA-CHAMPAIGN, Ill., July 4 -- Gifts for research to the University of Illinois from industry and private organizations totaled $343,340 for the year ending June 30, according to announcement today by Controller Lloyd Morey. The figure brings the five-year total to $1,337,937. Such gifts have increased more than 59 per cent in five years from 1938 to 1942, the statement said.

If botanists could possibly incorporate in names some reminder of a plant's particular habits, amateur gardeners would find less difficulty in growing new and unusual flowers. Occasionally such a helpful botanical name occurs. One may be found in the Ranunculaceae family.

No longer a plaything of the gods of experiment, the stroboscopic or "speed" flashlight is now in daily practical use among photographers with the challenging task of "stopping" action -- and stopping it dead. Formerly limited to scientific revelations in various fields of technical research, the speed lamp today serves the journalist, the commercial photographer and, though unintentionally, even the pictorialist.

New regulations covering identification requirements on the water and shorefront areas of the Third Naval District were issued last week by Rear Admiral Stanley V. Parker, Coast Guard, who is Captain of the Port of New York.

MONTICELLO -- Better entertainment for Sullivan and Ulster County resorts is expected to result from a centralized bureau established at Swan Lake by Charles Rapp. From this bureau will issue the shows that will fill the dramatic menus at about thirty Catskill resorts this Summer.

A jury of admission has been chosen for the exhibition of contemporary American painting, sculpture and graphic arts that is to be held by Artists for Victory, Inc., at the Metropolitan Museum of Art from Dec. 7, 1942, through Feb. 22, 1943.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I. -- Varied enterprises to meet increasing wartime needs continue as the chief activities of Summer colonists in Southampton and near-by watering places. Women here, as in adjacent resorts, are spending most of the morning hours and a large portion of the afternoon in the sewing rooms of the local chapters and branches of several national war relief agencies in the village.
On the most solemn Independence Day of their history, the people of the United States yesterday reaffirmed the Spirit of 1776 and rededicated themselves to freedom and independence.

THE concluding events of the International Festival of Music at the Cambridge theatre and a brief season of London Summer concerts at the Albert Hall have made amends for the scarcity of novelties during recent months and enabled the lover of contemporary art to hear compositions by American and Russian composers.

PUSHING aside the veils alike of the "quaint" and the "queer," eight scholars here present an authoritative and integrated study of those little-known colonial settlers and their descendants, the Pennsylvania Germans.

For the first time since 1930 there will be no national championship tournament at Asbury Park, N.J., this Summer. Instead the tournament will be held in New York City. The American Contract Bridge League so announced in a communication sent to its board of governors last week.

HONOLULU, July 4 -- In the first case to reach a decision since the outbreak of war with Japan Federal Judge D.E. Metzger two days ago awarded to owners of land taken by the government for military purposes a total of $45,050 for seven parcels.

The number of Navy aviation enlistments in this district in June was the largest for any month since the outbreak of the war, Lieut. Comdr. Albert P. Rice, senior member of the Naval Aviation Cadet Selection Board, 120 Broadway, announced yesterday.

The gathering of news on Independence Day this year is different than it was twelve months ago. There is still lots of fishing to be done, many places that afford the chance for recreation, but there are also restrictions and drives and movements within the fishing and hunting legions of our land that seemed perhaps more evident yesterday than they have been.

A contract unique in municipal history, entered into between Mayor LaGuardia on behalf of the city and the Public Health Research Institute of the City of New York, a rcently formed nonprofit scientific institution, is being hailed by public health authorities as "one of the most significant milestones in the history of man's struggle against disease, promising to usher in a new era of cooperation between scientists and municipalities for the benefit of all mankind."

The National Maritime Union has received a letter from the Soviet Sailors Union of the Arctic thanking American seamen for their aid in the battle against the Axis and pledging "increased blows" to smash "Hitlerism forever."

The Wehrmacht of Adolf Hitler, like the vanished phalanxes of Alexander and the soldiers of Napoleon, stood last week before the gates of the Middle East. The Macedonian conqueror had thrust from the north across the Hellespont, which men now call the Dardanelles.

WASHINGTON, July 4 -- Attempting once more to break the Congressional deadlock over parity-price sales of government-held surplus farm commodities, the Senate subcommittee on Agricultural Appropriations voted unanimously today to take to the floor Monday a resolution granting immediate temporary funds with which the now penniless Department of Agriculture might function through the current month.

FOR two months I lived with our troops on Corregidor. I have watched them when all the earth around them was rocking from exploding bombs and shells, quietly standing by their guns and taking it, dependable unto death. I have watched them going out to dangerous posts night after night, whistling, as though it were all in the day's work.

A tired Whirlaway pounded his dogged way through the Empire City stretch yesterday, forging onward to defeat. The flying heels of Tola Rose sped to the victory, and a new track mark as the Army-Navy Day crowd saw records, and new highs of all kinds, and Whirlaway second to the line.

MONTAUK, L.I. -- A twilight swimming meet in the Surf Club pool, the first of a series of such events, will highlight an active sports program at Montauk Beach next week-end. Badminton, tennis, archery, trap shooting, cycling, riding and deep-sea fishing will attract their devotees.
ON my own initiative and responsibility I should like to correct (or at least amplify) Mr. Bartok's article on the Parry Collection of Yugoslav folk music.
LONDON, July 4 (AP) -- Seven "communiques" on sabotage reported by the French Press Service to have been published in underground French newspapers have reached London in the past forty-eight hours.

CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va., July 4 -- The University of Virginia's cosmopolitan student body is the source from which the viewpoints of youth from many parts of the nation will be drawn for the 1942 Institute of Public Affairs, which will open Monday and continue through July 11 at the university.

BALTIMORE, July 4 -- Setting a new production record for a single plant on the Atlantic coast, the Bethlehem-Fairfield Shipbuilding Corporation today sent three Liberty ships sliding into the Patapasco River.

OTTAWA, July 4 -- Two hundred officers and men of the Fifty-first United States Infantry with the band of the 258th Field Artillery took part with Canadian troops in a United Nations flag demonstration in front of Parliament Building here this afternoon in the presence of King George of Greece, the Governor General, the Earl of Athlone and Prime Minister W.L. Mackenzie King.

CLEVELAND, July 4 -- Ore shipments on the Great Lakes failed to reach the 13,000,000-ton mark again last month and A.T. Wood, lakes director for the Office of Defense Transportation, is preparing to crack down on some vessel companies, it was learned today.

Undaunted by war's inroads on motoring, the costly hobby of collecting old cars goes on today among enthusiasts. Three gallons a week is far more gasoline than these early vehicles have used in years -- and the cars still can travel.
WASHINGTON, July 4 (U.P.) -- Senator Ellender of Louisiana said tonight that wartime speed-up in naval construction had more than overcome the losses suffered in the attack on Pearl Harbor.

It was just a four-inch story in THE TIMES recently but it summoned long shadows from the past -- heroic shadows. War drums echo along the Mohawk and the council fires flicker in the land of the Long House.

Changes in our way of life are coming thick and fast and the factors that shape these changes are manifold. The best opinion is that the war will string out until 1944 and government agencies are working on that assumption. Hence the curtailment orders and other restrictions.

Officials of New York's Westchester County War Council sat at attention last week, while Leon Haskell, a husky young seaman whose freighter had just been torpedoed, spoke to them about the dimout. Seaman Haskell let the civilian defenders have it straight. Sailors, he said, swear at the moon for casting a sky glow, get "fighting mad" when shore dwellers forget to dim their lights.

Oriental poppies have just finished a glorious six weeks of bloom -- six weeks, that is, if the garden contained the earliest varieties, such as the double orange Olympia or scarlet King George flowering approximately May 15, or the late pink Echo and the brilliant Wunderkind for the last week of June, with the intervening weeks supplying magnificent flowers from tempting varieties in shades of pink, red, orange or white.

FALL RIVER, Mass., July 4 -- Lieutenant Joe McCluskey, U.S.N., running for the New York A.C., today won the National A.A.U. fifteen-kilometer championship race which featured this city's Independence Day celebration.

With the closing this evening of the National Capital Kennel Club show in Washington the canine world in the Eastern section will start on its annual vacation. This year there will be an unusually long interval, with a hiatus of five weeks before the next scheduled fixture.
The massive 115-horsepower air raid siren atop the seventy-story RCA building was tested at noon yesterday and drew guarded praise from engineers, police observers and city officials.

OTTAWA, July 3 (Canadian Press) -- Styles, colors and finishes of leather footwear -- from infants' soft-sole shoes to men's work boots -- were regulated in an order issued today by Louis Daoust, footwear administrator of the Wartime Prices and Trade Board.

WASHINGTON, July 4 -- A sharp clash has been provoked in the National War Labor Board by the refusal of the four employer members to agree to a maintenance of membership clause voted by the other eight members into a contract between the Caterpillar Tractor Company of Peoria, Ill., and the Farm Equipment Workers Organizing Committee, C.L O., it was revealed today.

LONDON, July 4 -- It is difficult to tell yet whether the week's parliamentary jousting between the government and a small handful of constant critios has strengthened or weakened Prime Minister Churchill's hand. It is true that he received an overwhelming vote of confidence, but the atmosphere of unreality which spread through the whole debate permeated the voting as well.

ANN ARBOR, Mich., July 4 -- War's influence in guiding students to critical fields is graphically shown in statistics recently compiled by the University of Michigan War Board to indicate wartime changes in the make-up of the instiution's student body.

IF the number of ration cards which American housewives must carry to market is increased it will not be because of a shortage of food but because of a shortage of knowledge of how to use what we have.

EVERY one has been saying that with the rationing of gasoline, dimouts and whatnot the Summer theatre season this year would be grim. The facts, such as they are, do not seem to bear out this dire contention.

EAST HAMPTON, L.I., July 4 -- The Garden Club of East Hampton, of which Miss Marguerite Hoguet is president, has invited village officials and members of the Village Improvement Society to meet on Tuesday afternoon for the opening of new nature trails in the locality set aside for the community by Mrs. Lorenzo E. Woodhouse and maintained by the Garden Club.

It was a Fourth of fun without the firecrackers yesterday on Central Park Mall. Not the crackle of Roman candles but the cadence of well-known songs as five high school students competed in the finals of a song contest.

DENVER, Col., July 4 -- What was expected here to be the last National Education Association convention for the duration of the war ended Thursday upon as serious a note as it began. The 6,000 teachers and administrators, representing every State in the Union, realized that education had an important part to play in helping to win the war.

Because of the growing need for guidance among adolescents in wartime, a special War Emergency Committee of the Girls Service League will hold meetings throughout the Summer to learn how problems of youth can be met. Educators, welfare workers, youth leaders and vocational specialists from a number of agencies are serving on the committee, which is headed by Mrs. Timothy Pfeiffer of Riverdale, a member of the league's Girl Guidance Committee.

No longer hampered in its preliminary efforts at wool blending by threatened imposition of a rigid mandatory program, the worsted industry is expected to move more rapidly in development of new blended fabrics for civilian trade during the next few months, it was indicated here last week.

STANTON, Del., July 4 (AP) -- In one of the major upsets of the thirty-day Delaware Park meeting which was brought to a close today, Miss Constance Morabito's Monida came from behind to win the $10,000-added New Castle Handicap to award long-shot players with $32.70 for $2.

According to an old saying of the Midwest, a good farmer will have most of his corn "laid by," cultivated for the last time, by the Fourth of July. And his wife will have green peas and new potatoes from her garden, fryin' chicken from her flock for the holiday dinner. In a good season, that is.
WASHINGTON, July 4 (AP) -- Secretary Ickes today gave a broad hint that nation-wide gasoline rationing would be necessary unless more rubber was contributed to the scrap pile.

Floyd Smith, vice president and chief engineer of the Pioneer Parachute Company, Inc., Manchester, Conn.

STORRS, Conn., July 4 -- The first phase of an educational experiment believed to be unique in this part of the country ended here last week as 13 women and girls completed an intensive short course in practical farming given by the University of Connecticut.

GOSHEN, N.Y., July 4 -- Widow's Pride, owned by Sullivan Mawhinney of Macphias, Me., defeated twelve other 2-year-old pacers today in winning the feature attraction of a five-hour Grand Circuit program at Historic Track.

THE title of this novel stems from the legend of a fifth Horseman who companioned the Four Horsemen of the Apocalypse -- Famine, Death, Pestilence and War. Appalled by their cruelty he dashed on ahead to warn of their coming.

OCEAN CITY, N.J., July 4 -- Miss Stella Walsh, still without a peer among women athletes despite her 31 years, captured three events today in the National A.A.U. women's track and field championships, but her efforts were not enough to stop Tuskegee (Ala.) Institute from winning the team crown for the sixth straight year.

THIS book is at once a Mark Twain "first," the fullest report we have yet had concerning the unpublished Mark Twain Papers now in Mr. DeVoto's care, and some of the best criticism of Mark Twain that has been written.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 4 -- Considerable curiosity was aroused by Lieut. Gen. John L. Dewitt's proclamation the other day which, in effect, permits several thousand German and Italian aliens to return to areas of California from which they were ousted some four months ago on order of Attorney General Biddle.

THERE seems to be a popular misconception as to the method by which composers are able to produce that mysterious entity, that incomprehensible combination of sounds, known as music. Franz Schubert, bespectacled, woebegone, and having just finished a plate of knockwurst and kraut, covering the back of a menu with immortality that streams upon him from a generous muse, is probably the best laboratory example of the non-initiate's "composer."

THE NEW YORK TIMES in publishing a survey of the study of American history in our colleges and universities has undertaken a very significant task, one of great value to the nation and to those interested in forwarding the serious study of our own past.

The first graduation from the school for United States Customs Guards took place last Friday on the steps of the Custom House before 1,000 spectators. Forty men from 21 to 32 years old who had completed their training were sworn into the service by Harry M. Durning, Collector of the Port.

Tour begins in five minutes!"

The Hunter College Summer session will begin tomorrow with an enrollment 4 per cent smaller than that of last year, Professor Broderick Cohen, director of the session, announced yesterday. Late registration, which will be accepted next week, is expected "to raise the total enrollment figure substantially," Professor Cohen said.

METUCHEN, N.J., July 4 -- Two thousand Danish-Americans gathered today on the grounds of the Danish home for the Aged here to celebrate our Independence Day and to mark the thirtieth anniversary of the July 4 festival held annually since 1912 at the Rebild National Park in Denmark -- up to the time of the Nazi invasion.

The Republic of Colombia has decreed that three instead of two years of English shall be compulsory in its university system, according to Dr. Guillermo Hernandez de Alba, Professor of History at both the Colegio Mayor del Rosario and the University of Colombia in Bogota.

WASHINGTON, July 4 (Science Service) -- Plastic lenses for cameras, spectacles and other uses can be protected against scratches and other injuries that have been their principal drawback by coating them very thinly with glass films, Frederick J. Binda of Boston points out in his description of a method on which he has just received United States Patent No. 2287546.

SCHROON LAKE -- Spurred on by the decision of the G.O.P. State Committee to hold the Republican Gubernatorial convention at Saratoga Springs on Aug. 24 and 25, the resorts of Glens Falls, Lake George, Schroon Lake, Warrensburg and Elizabethtown, all linked to Saratoga by the New York-AlbanyMontreal bus artery and the Delaware Hudson Railroad, are elaborating on their entertainment programs.

MONTCLAIR, N.J., July 4 -- The brilliant but occasionally erratic Victor Seixas of North Carolina hammered his way to victory over steady-going Irvin Dorfman of Yale in the freshman final of the Eastern intercollegiate tennis championships today at the Montclair Athletic Club.

MEXICO CITY, July 4 (U.P.) -- The Mexican Government today sent Gerhardt Wilhelm Kunze, German-American Bund leader, back to the United States, where he will be turned over to the Department of Justice for prosecution on charges of espionage.

LOCUST VALLEY, L.I., July 4 -- The Piping Rock Club, scene of many festive society and sporting features in the last thirty years, was never more representatively American than this afternoon at the Army and Navy Day of racing arranged as a benefit by the United Hunts Racing Association and the Club for the Army Emergency Fund and the Navy Relief Society.

The herculean task devolved upon the House Ways and Means Committee of finding methods of taxation by which the Federal revenues may be increased to an amount approximating $26,000,000,000 is nearing completion. Cross of the State Supreme Court refused today to authorize State mediation in a labor ispute involving a war production plant holding that the National War Labor Board was the proper agency for settlement under the national economic policy enun- ciated by President Roosevelt.

WASHINGTON, July 4 -- "A damn good sailor -- in all respects" was lost, presumably captured, in the fall of Corregidor, but not until he had rescued President Quezon of the Philippines, for which he received the Philippine Distinguished Conduct Star and the Silver Star for Gallantry, the Navy Department announced today.

High military officers and leaders in civilian war work in the metropolitan area are expected to attend this week the three-day celebration of the opening nearly a year ago of the branch of the National Catholic Community Service, USO, in the old structure of the disbanded Staten Island Club at 287 St. Marks Place, St. George, S.I.

On June 12 the War, Navy and Post-office Departments jointly announced that the first V-mail letters had arrived from abroad. Five days later the first outbound consignment of V-letters was handled in New York. What we have here is an ingenious method of photographing soldiers' letters to save 99 per cent of their original air-mail weight.

The important contribution that the banking system is making to the nation's war effort is seen in the quarterly banking statements of condition issued last week. Those of the leading Wall Street banks reveal the banking problems peculiar to this district where the government raises a large percentage of its funds but spends a disproportionate part of the proceeds.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, July 4 -- Combination of a fine arts education with an academic education in a liberal arts college is now possible at Western Reserve University as the result of a newly formed plan whereby a student, upon completion of 154 credit hours in five years' time, may obtain the degree of Bachelor of Arts from the university and the certificate from the Cleveland School of Art.

Travel Lines: Provincetown, Mass., refutes rumors that there is oil on its beaches; there are the usual activities, with the same train and bus services as in other years. . . . The house-party cruise tour is carrying vacationists up the Hudson on the Hudson River Day Line to Kingston, thence by motor coach through the Catskills to the St. Regis Hotel, on Lake Switzerland, at Fleischmanns, N.Y. . . .
HAVANA, July 4 -- Cubans enthusiastically joined Americans here today in celebrating the Fourth of July.

QUEEN WILHELMINA, now visiting on this side of the Atlantic, has more lifelong friends in America than she may guess. These are the men and women of her generation who in their childhood used to hear and read about her, the most conspicuous child in the world, the little Dutch girl, fatherless at 10, who would some day be Queen of Holland.

WASHINGTON, July 4 (AP) -- Despite the latest reports from the Army and Navy, there were renewed expressions of concern today about the Aleutian situation.

LOCUST VALLEY, L.I., July 4 -- Full of running all the way, with his rider, Henry Cruz, fighting him the first time around, Harold E. Talbott's Brother Jones staged a repeat performance today as 3,500 contributed to Army and Navy relief at the meet of the United Hunts Racing Association.

The physical fitness of 1,000 members of the City College freshman class has improved 20 per cent since last February, it was revealed by a physical testing program instituted as part of the college's war-training preparation, Professor Frederic A. Woll, chairman of the Hygiene Department, announced yesterday.

TORONTO, July 4 (Canadian Press) -- Stocks failed today to stir trading interest in the two-hour session on the Toronto Stock Exchange, but prices were generally firm except for minor losses in the gold group. Only 53,000 shares changed hands, but this small volume was equal to that of two Saturday sessions in June.

The prolonged spell of rainy weather held down expansion of consumer demand for Summer merchandise last week. Department store volume was estimated as showing a drop of about 7 per cent under the 1941 week. Weather conditions failed to dampen the ardor of merchants in launching their "Retailers for Victory" drive for the sale of War stamps and Bonds and quotas for the week were exceeded by wide margins.

The extent to which flowers are appreciated by the American public may be judged by the fact that each year more than $150,000,000 is spent on blooms for the home and personal adornment. Like literature and music, flowers are today enjoyed by a greater percentage of the public than at any time in the past, and the steady "democratization" of floral appreciation has greatly advanced the florist profession.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., July 4 -- "Any fundamental change in our form of government should be postponed until our boys come back from war," State Senator Pliny W. Williamson, Republican, declared today in an Independence Day address at Butler Field in Scarsdale.

The Treasury is expected to announce this week its first major open-market financing operation in the government's new fiscal year -- a year in which public borrowing will reach proportions never before approached by any government.

AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, Australia, Sunday, July 5 (AP) -- Allied planes shot down six Japanese aircraft and damaged six in aerial combat over Port Moresby, New Guinea, and heavy day and night raids on enemy bases at Salamaua and Lae, it was reported officially today.

WASHINGTON, July 4 -- The sensational capture on our shores of eight self-confessed Nazi saboteurs drives home the realization of the constant peril from these secret enemies armed with weapons of destruction.

HERE Patricia Ross has retold fourteen folktales from Old Mexico with grace and gayety. More literary in style than Anita Brenner's "The Boy Who Could Do Anything" and with less of the quality that suggests the native story teller, these stories nevertheless have flavor and authentic atmosphere and a fine humor that boys and girls will enjoy.

DETROIT, July 4 -- The Navy whipped the Army in baseball today, Lieutenant Mickey Cochrane's Great Lakes Naval Training Station nine blanking the Fort Custer Reception Center, 5 to 0, before 6,939 holiday fans who contributed $10,000 to service athletic funds.

FALL RIVER, Mass., July 4 -- The Most Rev. Francis J. Spellman, Archbishop of New York, paid tribute to George Washington today for the example and services he gave as Father of our Country. Archbishop Spellman spoke at the unveiling of a memorial to Washington presented by the Catholic children of the Fall River Diocese.

LONDON, July 4 -- Striking suddenly and hard at the enemy on the Egyptian front, General Sir Claude J.E. Auchinleck, the British commander, made today what appeared to be a most successful counter-attack on a limited front.

BOSTON, July 4 -- Shut Out, one of the greatest sons of the fabulous Equipoise, gained ample revenge today over Valdina Orphan, his recent conqueror in the Dwyer Stakes, by breaking the Suffolk Downs track record for a mile and three-sixteenths as he captured the $25,000 added Yankee Handicap before a holiday throng of 31,000.

PUERTO RICO PLAN: Rexford Guy Tugwell, Governor of Puerto Rico, was in Washington last week. He talked with President Roosevelt and with Secretary of the Interior Ickes, who has charge of Puerto Riean administration, about the wartime role of the Caribbean isle, the political future of its 2,000,000 inhabitants.

THE Gordon Quartet will play works by Boccherini, Ravel and Mozart today at 4 P.M. at Music Mountain, Falls Village, Conn. The ensemble plans to give eight Sunday afternoon concerts in Hartford, Conn.; two evening concerts in Pittsfield, Mass., and one in Kent, Conn., in the course of Summer.

LEE, Mass., July 4 -- Although this Berkshire community of 4,210 inhabitants is fully conscious of the high honor conferred upon it by the Summer-long visit of Queen Wilhelmina of the Netherlands, her daughter, Princess Juliana, and her two little granddaughters, Beatrix and Irene, they have been received with dignified New England conservatism.

MORE than 300 radio specialists from all parts of this country, attending the Summer convention of the Institute of Radio Engineers held here during the past week, left no doubt in the minds of visiting observers that radio science will play an ever increasing and vital role in winning the war.

BAY HEAD, N.J., July 4 -- The Barnegat Bay Yacht Racing Association season opened today under the auspices of the Bay Head Yacht Club and eighty boats competed.

WASHINGTON, July 4 -- No business in the world's history has ever approximated the size or the scope of the government's purchases under the war program. It is not possible to state how much the government already has purchased or has obligated itself to spend on war, but on midnight of June 30 the Congress had appropriated $205,023,539,537 for the weapons and means with which war is conducted.

A GULF COAST PORT, July 4 (AP) -- Thirty more seamen are dead, victims of Axis submarine attacks, the Navy announced today in reporting two more sinkings of merchant vessels. The thirty men were all members of the crew of a small Panamanian vessel torpedoed in the Gulf of Mexico June 16.

A series of events commemorating the fifth anniversary of the start of Chinese resistance to Japanese invasion has been planned for the near future by the Greater New York City Committee of United China Relief, under the co-chairmanship of Mrs. Robert Low Bacon and Frederick H. Wood.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 4 -- The Wong family, Chinese equivalent of the Smiths, opened its first national convention in this city's Chinatown tonight. Members from New York, Boston, Washington, New Orleans and about forty other cities were present.

CAIRO, Egypt, July 4 -- The latest news regarding the Battle of Egypt indicates that the enemy occupies a position that is shaped like an elongated oval south of British "box" defenses in the area of E1 Alamein and north of a second "box" that is established on the edge of the escarpment some forty miles inland.

FROM time to time this column has let off considerable steam about the ways in which some movies have misconceived the war. Not only have several pictures imaged the combat in antiquated terms but, more lamentable, some have taken a decidedly fictional slant on the peoples involved.

WASHINGTON, July 4 -- Leon Henderson, the fighting chief executive of the Office of Price Administration, who has been holding a lid on retail prices since the over-all price ceilings went into force in May, has a new fight on his hands at present.

AMERICAN airplanes are fighting on nearly every front on the globe and their range is being steadily extended. RICH old Willoughby Knight had the power, and the capriciousness, of the very wealthy: which was the reason so many people might have wished him dead. It was merely his caprice, for instance, that was keeping young Bill Williams out of an all-important job.

With an explosive display that was peculiarly appropriate, the Giants celebrated Independence Day at the Polo Grounds yesterday by taking a double-header from the Braves before a paid gathering of 22,534.

Motor yachting received fair and reasonable treatment last week by the Federal Government. Eastern waterways, instead of being denuded of cabin cruisers and runabouts, are likely to see them laying their usual courses. The 250-gallon allotment means that a good many cruising week-ends and even a short vacation fortnight afloat can be managed by the average owner of small recreational craft.

Double flowering cosmos now in bloom at the New York Botanical Garden are attracting much attention. These flowers are among a score or more of new annuals -- as yet unnamed -- in the all-America trials being grown at the Botanical Garden.

WASHINGTON, July 4 (AP) -- A total of 507 Axis-owned or controlled business concerns in the United States have been liquidated and enemy personnel forced out of scores of other companies in a drive by the Federal Government to eliminate financial and commercial "fifth columnists."

MELBOURNE, Australia, July 4 -- Perhaps the most American incident m Australia's celebration of the Fourth of July was a display of baseball pitching prowess by a real American tobacco-chewing pitcher. His name is Johnny Lund and he is from Portland, Ore.
CLEVELAND, July 4 (AP) -- The Tigers and a civic rally, "Festival of Freedom," kept the Indians from taking both ends of a double bill today.

WHITE MOUNTAINS, N.H. -- All White Mountain hotels now are open and this week marks the start of several entertainment programs, enlarged to meet the requirements of guests deprived of their daily pleasure drives. The train service, with bus connections, makes all resorts easily accessible, and people at last are becoming "train minded" in planning their holidays in the mountains.

AN alert scout who recently returned to "Yankee Doodle Dandy" for a second look reports a slight bit of revision in the early and latter scenes of the film in which James Cagney as George M. Cohan visits President Roosevelt, played in the film by Captain Jack Young.

The Columbia University Summer session will begin Tuesday, with 9,000 students enrolled in the most extensive program of studies ever offered at any university, Columbia University officials said yesterday. The curriculum embraces more than 1,500 courses, given by nearly 600 teachers.

The ingenious and far-ranging fancy of Harry Stephen Keeler has not tried, this time, actually to combine its disparate plot-elements into one single plot. And "The Book With the Orange Leaves" is the better story in consequence.

CHICAGO, July 4 -- There will be no gaping empty spaces in the nation's retail stores this Fall, because of consumer goods shortages, according to manufacturers and distributors in the Merchandise Mart which will open on Monday the International Home Furnishings Market.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Brazil, July 4 -- Foreign Minister Dr. Oswaldo Aranha today depicted a post-war world under American leadership.

THIS first war Summer is going to offer more problems and considerably greater nervousness to the dance world than the first war Winter did. Not that bombs and the like are worrying anybody especially, but the gas and tire situation presents a ticklish uncertainty to the entire field of festivals and schools that betake themselves annually to the hills for their warm-weather sessions.

THE revival of Porgy and Bess, current on Broadway, has been a bigger success than the first production in 1935. Whatever the reasons for the increased popularity of the work, there is no gainsaying that it contains many of George Gershwin's most distinctive tunes.

NEWPORT, R.I., July 4 -- William F. Whitehouse, president of the Newport Casino, has made available the grounds of the Casino for a jamboree in aid of the Navy Relief Society benefit, which will continue for a week, afternoon and evening, beginning on Monday.
WASHINGTON, July 4 -- Following are the texts of the messages of greeting from heads of States, Princes, Prime Ministers and Foreign Ministers received by President Roosevelt on the national holiday:

TOKYO, July 4 (From Japanese broadcast recorded by Reuter) -- Japan is casting off her defensive strategy and turning to "a huge offensive," the Chief of the Japanese Navy Press Section of Imperial Headquarters, Captain Kanji Ogawa, declared today.

PITTSFIELD, Mass., July 4 -- The Wyantenuck Country Club, Great Barrington, of which Rodney S. Jarvis is president, tonight held its initial ball of the season, which was attended by many from South Berkshire and near-by New York and Connecticut resorts.

WESTPORT, Conn., July 4 -- The annual country fair here under the auspices of the Westport Woman's Club will be held on July 23, 24 and 25 on Jessup Green in the center of town. The event will be entitled the Yankee Doodle Fair and its theme and decorations will be patriotic.

THE little lush islands that dot Georgia's coastal waters have been the homes of thousands of plantation Negroes since long before the War Between the States. Visits to the mainland have been few during the years and the African stem from which the songs of the slave islanders flowered has here been less affected by white folks' influence than in the inland regions of the deep South.

NARRAGANSETT, R.I., July 4 -- Narragansett's Summer season was opened officially tonight with the first dinner dance of the season at the Dunes Club, which was attended by officers of the Armed Forces stationed in this area, and many visitors and house guests here for the week-end.

ON the occasion of Lincoln's Birthday this year many of the radio orators paid tribute to his memory as usual by reciting the Gettysburg Address. One of them, forgetting his script for the moment, or using some obscure and unrevealed source, quoted the line, "The world will little note nor long remember what we say, but it can never forget what they did." There were instant cries of "Here! Here!" from his unseen audience.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., July 4 -- Ninety-three starters, fourteen more than the previous high mark of the season, competed today in the sixth Long Island Sound championship regatta of the Summer. It was held by the Larchmont Yacht Club, and was that organization's sixty-first annual event.

BERLIN, July 4 (From German broadcasts recorded by The Associated Press) -- The German High Command announced today that German mobile detachments "are advancing speedily toward the Don" after operations that other military quarters here described as a gigantic break-through on the southern front in Russia.
WASHINGTON, July 4 -- Deputies were announced today by members of the Combined Production and Resources Board that was set up by President Roosevelt and Prime Minister Churchill.

EXHIBITIONS on the calendar for this week include two opening tomorrow at the Grand Central Galleries -- one of recent portraits by American painters associated with the institution, at the Gotham Hotel division of the galleries, and the other, at the Terminal Division, being the annual Founders Exhibition, the twentieth of its kind, to be current until the drawing is held in November.

The closing of public schools last week and the arrival of the annual vacation season left a number of officials of civilian defense puzzled about the effects on their volunteer staffs of these traditional signals for flight from the city.

VICHY, France, July 4 (AP) -- Three Frenchmen were condemned to life imprisonment at hard labor today for the theft of 800 sheets of bread tickets from a ration card distribution center at Tours. Two others received sentences of twenty years and two years at hard labor.

SALISBURY, N.C., July 4 (U.P.) -- The United States has developed "weapons" superior to the 88-MM. gun which the Germans are using in the Egyptian campaign, Major General. Levin H. Campbell Jr., chief of army ordnance, said in an Independence Day address today.

Foremost among the discussions of the Joint Maritime Conference of the International Labor Office, in London last week was the problem of safety measures. Several days were devoted to a frank discussion of conditions prevailing aboard ship and life saving measures necessitated by the war.

MOSCOW, Sunday, July 5 -- The great Battle of Kursk still is raging on the southwestern front. Yesterday was the seventh day of the combat, and at the end of the day the Russians had been forced to yield ground in one sector, where they lost a populated point that had been the center of fierce fighting for forty-eight hours.

BOSTON, July 4 -- Problems of caring for the evacuated populations of American cities and towns in the event of enemy bombing, as well as those relating to the changing food supply, are being intensively studied in a home economic "work shop" conducted this Summer at Simmons College for the benefit of graduate home economists from many States.

PHILADELPHIA, July 4 -- Because of the increased interest in the study of government being displayed by women students, both graduate and undergraduate, the Institute of Local and State Government at the University of Pennsylvania will expand further its training program on the campus this year, it was announced today.

Coat and suit activity featured the apparel markets last week, setting a brisk pace as buyers placed substantial orders for new Fall merchandise, according to the weekly report prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by Kirby, Block Co.

LONDON, July 4 -- The manufacture of furniture and many other household goods will go on a standardized basis beginning Aug. 1. Accessory articles, formerly made for decorative effect, will be eliminated under an order issued today.

WELLINGTON, New Zealand, July 4 -- New Zealanders scanned the Egyptian war situation today and concluded that the moment demanded action, not recrimination. They placed faith in their own often-tested troops to help better a situation in which the eastward drive of the Axis is viewed as a menace not only to the Nile Valley but to the key oil fields beyond.

Retailers of men's clothing indicated yesterday that they would resist higher prices on Fall lines which manufacturers will be permitted to charge under the regulations on seasonal men's clothing to be released by the Office of Price Administration tomorrow.

WASHINGTON, July 4 -- Claude Becker, 24, of Sparks, Nev., has received the Navy Cross award for heroic conduct when the Marblehead was bombed in the Java Sea battle.

Chairmen of the various committees organized in the interests of the fourth annual White Elephant Cocktail Party will meet Wednesday afternoon at a tea to be given at the Stork Club by Mrs. Henry J. Taylor and Mrs. Daniel M.S. Hegarty.

SOUTHAMTON, L.I., July 4 -- The Fourth of July, which has marked the formal opening of many brilliant seasons here for more than fifty years, assumed an added significance this year owing to the wartime emergencies. Members of the Summer colony had already complied with gasoline and tire rationing by abandoning their high-powered motor cars for smaller ones or by using bicycles and horse-drawn vehicles to reach clubs, beaches and estates scattered over wide areas.
PHILADELPHIA, July 4 -- It was a backyard Independence Day for most of the population of this city today.

The Baltimore Elite Giants assumed the lead in the National Negro Baseball League yesterday by defeating the Newark Eagles at the Yankee Stadium, 8 to 4. The game was part of a Ruppert Memorial Cup double-header, and was witnessed by 12,000 fans.

The Very Rev. Robert I. Gannon, president of Fordham University, told 1,500 persons at an Independence Day celebration yesterday morning on the Fordham campus that Americans must make sure that after the war this country shall be "still the United States of America, still the landwhere human dignity is the heart of the way of life."

Awards in the second annual salon of the Manufacturers Trust Company Camera Club, consisting largely of students of the Studio School of Photography, were made in two classes, portraits and general. First and third places in portraiture went to Peggy Brendgard, second to Carl Chadwick.

CLEVELAND, July 4 -- Reports from some of the principal manufacturing centers in the district indicate that industrial employment increased slightly to new high levels in June. Largest additions to working forces were made at expanding aircraft and parts plants, several of which have not yet reached maximum employment.

THE Metropolitan Opera Association is at work drawing up its contracts and signing its artists. Because of the world's uncertainties there will be no long-term contracts. All existing contracts expired this Spring and the new ones will be only for the sixteen-week season, with options for the Spring tour.

According to Leon Henderson, the United Nations will have exhausted their supply of crude rubber by May, 1943. If we cannot produce at least 300,000 tons of synthetic substitute in that year, a performance to him miraculous, it will be impossible to meet all our military and naval requirements, which is as good as saying that victory will be doubtful.

New York's 22,000-odd acres of parks -- there are more than 700 parks, big and little, not counting parkways -- are serving the millions of New York's citizens well in these days when going to more distant places is made difficult, if not impossible, by restrictions on motoring and travel generally.

NEWARK, N.J., July 4 (AP) -- Jersey City moved to within a half-game of the first-place Bears today by beating the leaders in both ends of a twin bill, 6 -- 5 and 3 -- 0, before a crowd of 8,477. It marked the sixth straight time the Bears have been defeated by the Jerseys.

A CORRESPONDENT whose letter appears on this page refers to several books of recent years which have helped to create a better balanced picture of the American Indian. His list could be considerably extended.
WASHINGTON, July 4 (AP) -- Philadelphia and Washington split a double-header today before 6,000, the Athletics winning the first game, 5 -- 2, and the Senators the second, 12 -- 2.

"THE good lads, the enlisted men of the Second Armored Division, 1941, 1942," to whom this book is dedicated by one of themselves, have a treat in store. It is a young book about a young man of 21, "only a year out of the university," in Queen Bess's young and lusty England.
America, which in 1776 declared the indepedence of her own people, today is fighting to free the peoples of all the world, rabbis declared in Independence Day sermons here yesterday.
BOSTON, July 4 -- The Yankees moved one step forward today, took another backward and by this simple expedient managed to solidify their position at the head of the American League flag race.

CHICAGO, July 4 (AP) -- A 12-to-1 shot called Take Wing lived up to his name by galloping through the mud to victory in the $10,000-added Stars and Stripes Handicap today as Arlington Park, crowded with 45,000 fans, sought to raise $100,000 for Army and Navy relief.

WASHINGTON, July 4 -- No single large-scale act of sabotage was committed in this country in the first six months of the war, Attorney General Francis Biddle announced today as plans proceeded for the trial of eight captured Nazi agents next week.

LONDON, July 4 -- While the British made every effort to mark today -- the 166th anniversary of the day when the United States left the Empire -- to United States soldiers and sailors here it was officially just another day.

A strict control, through fingerprints and identification cards, of all hostesses serving as dancing partners to the men in service is being gradually introduced by the USO as a military safeguard. These precautions, which have for some time been required by Army authorities on the West Coast, will shortly be enforced in the East as a protection against sabotage and enemy action, officials believe.

IOWA CITY, Iowa, July 4 -- Forward-looking students at the University of Iowa, with the aid of thirteen professors from seven departments, are attempting to see beyond 1942 into the post-war world. The medium for this attempt is the new course, "The Post-War World," which takes up political, social and economic problems and their historical background. Work has been under way since June 8.

Syria and Lebanon, which the occupying Free French authorities proclaimed republics last year, have each released postage and air-mail stamps commemorating the "Proclamation de l'Independence," the inscription being in both French and Arabic.

NEW PALTZ, N.Y., July 4 -- Surrounded by many friends, Oscar of the Waldorf today turned over his 320-acre estate on the Wallkill River five miles northeast of this town to the Societe Culinaire Philanthropique.

IN concluding his interesting foreword to "Tap Roots" James Street says: "If, in this story, you miss the oft-told tale of the Civil War of Gettysburg and Lee, then I am glad." One is sure in concluding the novel that Mr. Street has plenty of cause for rejoicing.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., July 4 -- A trained group of volunteers newly organized as the Civilian Volunteer Corps of Jersey City will take as its first assignment next Wednesday an educational drive in the interests of the price ceilings of the Office of Price Administration.

Although Mr. Fortune is a man of modest nature, so many questions have been asked about him that H.C. Bailey offers satisfaction to public curiosity. Reginald's father was a well-to-do physician, and he succeeded to that excellent practice; but with his flair for scientific research he combined a vast human interest; and once he had been called in to a crime case -- well, there he was.

With its former fleet of 15,000 horse-drawn wagons down to fewer than a dozen museum pieces, the Railway Express Agency is making a nation-wide canvass, it was learned last night, to explore the road back to demotorization.

BERNE, Switzerland, July 4 -- Private advices tonight indicated that the Fourth of July was not overlooked in those parts of Europe now occupied by the Axis powers. Manifestly outward demonstrations were out of the question, but clandestine broadsheets and other agencies reminded the population of Independence Day.

After a slow start retail trade picked up somewhat in the middle of the week in the three major test markets of New York, Chicago and Los Angeles, particularly on Wednesday, the opening day of the "Retailers for Victory" drive for the sale of war savings stamps and bonds, according to the survey made especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by Meyer Both Reports.

DRESSES to bridge the gap between Summer clothes and the first Fall frocks are black and definitely keyed to the formality of late afternoon. They forecast the new slim silhouette of the WPB regulations and are figure-flattering in their intricately draped and peg-top variations.
ST. LOUIS, July 4 -- The second-place Cardinals dropped an expensive game to the Cubs today, 6 to 5, but came back to wallop them, 9 to 3, in the second half of a double bill before 16,863.

THE trumpet-blowing, ball-balancing seals are very popular with circus goers, and no creature at the Zoo has a more constant and admiring audience than the swimming, diving, barking inhabitants of the sea lions' tank, so that Mr. Tracy's book, which has all the earmarks of truth, should find an appreciative public.

THE publication of Edmund Wilson's volume of essays entitled "The Wound and the Bow" has prompted The Times Literary Supplement to some skeptical, not to say sarcastic, comments on the school of criticism of which he is a distinguished representative.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 4 -- Retail trade in the Twelfth District showed marked reverses last week from the highs of the previous week. In San Francisco sales ranged from 5 per cent higher to 10 per cent lower than in the same week of 1941.

WASHINGTON, July 4 -- A chart of the mood of the City of Washington since the start of the war would be shaped roughly like a letter W. It started high and fell at once with the attack on Pearl Harbor. It rose steeply thereafter and took another dive at Singapore.

A program to enroll 215,000 university and college students in the Enlisted Reserve of the Army to insure "a future source of qualified officer candidates" has been instituted in schools throughout the country and will be continued until the quota is filled, it was announced yesterday by Lieut. Col. Elliott Baldwin of the Second Corps Area Office of the Organized Reserve.
In a letter to THE TIMES Miss Clare Shipman recommended Madagascar as a suitable haven for three to five million refugees from Europe.

CHUNGKING, China, Saturday, July 4 (U.P.) -- General Sir Archibald P. Wavell, British Commander in India, sent Fourth of July greetings today to Lieut. Gen. Joseph W. Stilwell, Commander of American Troops in Southeastern Asia.

All through the morning yesterday residents of Flatbush lined the sidewalks of Ocean Avenue and cheered lustily as several thousand of their neighbors staged a civilian defense parade, which was followed by a patriotic rally in the stadium of Brooklyn College.

IN 1865, at the age of 18, America Collier Moncure tended the tobacco fields on her family's sacked plantation, defied the Northern soldiers who came looting after peace was signed, and killed a carpetbagger who attacked her sister on the night the old mansion was burned.

MOSCOW, July 4 -- The heroic defense of Sevastopol, rather than the news of the city's fall, is in the forefront of the minds of the Soviet people today. As details of the epic struggle become known, the people's hearts are swelling with pride that so small a force of faithful and devoted men should have contained so vast a horde of the enemy during eight months.

POUGHKEEPSIE, July 4 -- Employes of the International Business Machines Corporation's Plant No. 4, working their regular shifts today despite the holiday, took forty-five minutes off to hear Secretary Morgenthau congratulate sixteen banking, industrial and other organizations in Dutchess County for participation of 90 per cent or better in the war savings payroll plan.
WASHINGTON, July 4 (AP) -- Donald M. Nelson took action today to relieve businessmen of some of the mass of government questionnaires, reports and blank forms flooding their desks.

There is no more enticing feature of the small place than a well laid-out and artistically planted path. If the path begins with an inviting gate, or gates, so much the better. The gate may be simply of white picket, woven chestnut, or rustic cedar; or it may be of hand-wrought iron, elaborate and stately.

The sale of war bonds and stamps continued yesterday although stores, banks and other places of business were closed because of the holiday. Clerks in postoffices and sales persons in hotels, restaurants and theatres took care of those who desired to make purchases or to sign pledge cards.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, July 4 -- The Spanish Minister in Cairo apparently is playing a prominent part in German efforts to create discord between Egyptian leaders and Britain, according to a report received here.
WASHINGTON, July 4 -- The State Department announced today that a consular office would be opened in Mombaza, Kenya, in East Africa, in the region between the Red Sea and Madagascar.

ALEXANDRIA, Egypt, July 4 -- All kinds of reinforcements, along with United States-built tanks, guns and other war equipment, were moving along the desert highway today to the Allies' front at El Alamein, seventy miles west of Alexandria.
Let me correct a few points in Anthony Balassy's letter published June 28.

SAN JUAN, Puerto Rico, July 4 (U.P.) -- Secretary Ickes promised the Puerto Rican people today that "as far as it is in my power to achieve it, Puerto Rico will share equally and fully in the freedom, security and opportunities offered by eventual victory."

PRINCETON, N.J., July 4 -- In the feature event of an Independence Day celebration on University Field, Princeton's varsity nine today registered an eleven-inning victory over Swarthmore, 7 -- 6, to start an eight-game Summer campaign.

RECENT seemingly dissociated events have thrown new lights on two important problems in the art world. One is the ability of art to serve purposes that the most skeptical of its critics must admit are practical.

In the vast lands of South America and jungled reaches of Central America aviation has proved the most effective means of transportation. In the air lives hope for Latin America's future development -- and this has been since 1934 the aim of the Inter-American Escadrille.

WASHINGTON, July 4 -- Price Administrator Leon Henderson today disclosed to canners the formula to be used in computing their maximum prices for the 1942 pack of fruits and berries and announced that the higher ceiling prices allowed on them would mean an advance of 15 per cent and more for consumers when the 1942 pack reached the grocers' shelves.

Concerned about mounting unemployment in the needle trades, the city has asked the War Production Board to make three changes in its method of contract distribution to insure a greater volume of war orders for the city's biggest industry, David S. Meiklejohn, director of the city Department of Commerce, disclosed yesterday.
