When battle sweeps into Egypt it stirs the dust of centuries. The Eastern Mediterranean, this land of rivers and flood plains, of deserts and oases, this strip of coast, around from the site of Carthage to the site of Tyre, was a melting pot thousands of years before Ellis Island had a building on it.

Meeting a lively interest in aviation among high school girls, a new program to train them for future jobs in this field is announced today by the Girl Scouts of the United States. The national plan, which will cover two years of instruction, has been worked out to conform with the objectives of the National Aeronautic Association, with which the Wing Scouts, as the new division is called, will be affiliated.

"VAUDEVILLE never did die out. It just went through a dimout due to a change of locale." Ed Wynn was speaking -- Ed Wynn of the tiny hats, the owlish face, the grotesque grimace and the crescendo slippery voice who for more than a generation has tickled the funny bone of the country.

LONDON, July 4 -- After months of preparation the units of the United States Army Air Forces in Britain struck their first blow today at the Axis in Europe in a daylight raid with the Royal Air Force that plowed up Nazi airfields, blasted enemy planes and installations and gunned German flying personnel in the Netherlands. The Allied air attack took in Nazi patrol ships off shore for good measure.

All through the morning yesterday residents of Flatbush lined the sidewalks of Ocean Avenue and cheered lustily as several thousand of their neighbors staged a civilian defense parade, which was followed by a patriotic rally in the stadium of Brooklyn College.

WASHINGTON, July 5 -- New regulations under which American Army forces overseas may acquire services, facilities, supplies and equipment under the Lease-Lend Act swiftly and without payment of cash to the foreign governments concerned were announced today by the War Department.

There will be a city-wide blackout drill tonight, starting at 9:30 P.M. and terminating under a staggered tune arrangement to prevent the overloading of electric equipment, Mayor La Guardia announced yesterday afternoon in his weekly radio "Talk to the People," delivered from City Hall through WNYC, the municipal station.

A veteran Chinese general, who has fought the Japanese in five provinces, rode through the narrow, flag-draped streets of Chinatown yesterday on his first visit to New York. He was greeted excitedly by sidewalk crowds, who, in the memory of the quarter's older residents, had never before seen a top-ranking Chinese military leader in their midst.

The health of the community is of prime importance in the war effort. The practitioner of medicine being the unit about which the maintenance of this revolves, it is important that his movements be unhampered. However, this is being seriously interfered with in our present method of gasoline distribution.

Men are seeking constantly the principle of fixity in life, but the pre-destination of God is directed toward change and growth in man, the Rev. Dr. Frederick W. Norwood, pastor of St. Andrew's-Wesley United Church in Vancouver, B.C., declared yesterday in a sermon at the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church, Fifth Avenue and Fifty-fifth Street.

The decision of the National War Labor Board to take jurisdiction in a dispute involving Montgomery Ward Co. and a C.I.O. union raises questions which bear upon the country's war production. In this decision the War Labor Board places a much broader interpretation on its jurisdiction than many people have felt was intended by the President.

A drive to obtain the pledges of both major political parties and minor groups as well to "peg" State aid for education at $118,500,00 and halt the downward trend in appropriations due to the decline in school population was begun yesterday by the city Board of Education.

COLD SPRING HARBOR, L.I., July 5 -- The election of Mrs. George S. Franklin of New York City and Cold Spring Harbor, as a member of the board of directors and president of the women's auxiliary board of the Long Island Biological Association, has just been announced.

Plans for the erection of a mammoth canvas wall along the Boardwalk of Coney Island to shield store and amusement lights from view at sea were revealed yesterday by Charles Kean, president of the Coney Island Chamber of Commerce.

WASHINGTON, July 5 -- Donald Nelson, Director of the War Production Board, will go to Britain next month for a series of conversations with Oliver Lyttelton, British Minister of Production, on the coordination of Anglo-American war production, it was learned tonight.

CHARLESTOWN, W.Va., July 5 (AP) -- Governor Matthew M. Neely, who had twenty-four years' legislative experience in Washington, entered today the Democratic primary contest for the Senate seat which he vacated in 1941 to take charge of the State government.
BERLIN, July 5 (From German broadcasts recorded by The Associated Press) -- The German High Command issued this communique today:

NEW HAVEN, Conn., July 5 -- A total of 318 scholarships have been awarded to members of Yale's freshman class. The value is $179,000, which is twice as much as reported last year. This is due largely to the fact that the wartime schedule has prevented many students from earning funds for their course.

We didn't expect the all-liquid breakfast to last, but it must be admitted that it has taken a large-sized war to turn people against it. Now the revolution has set in, and more is being demanded to start the day than a glass of orange juice and a cup of black coffee.
JERSEY CITY, N.J., July 5 (AP) -- Jersey City ran its winning streak to six straight before 10,104 today by defeating Baltimore, 5 -- 1 and 5 -- 4, in eleven innings.
In the hurly-burly that is Coney Bobby Roman was lost yesterday. He was 3 years old and yelling.

Announcing that the war fund campaign of the United Service Organizations had raised 65 per cent of its Spring and Summer quota, Prescott S. Bush, national campaign chairman, revealed yesterday that contributions and pledges amounting to $1,456,510 were received last week.

A dual theme will be used in product advertising of Alexander Smith Sons Carpet Company, scheduled to appear this Fall in basically the same publications used by the company during 1941 and the Spring of this year, according to John Devine, advertising manager.

VICHY, July 5- The French Minister of Finances recently declared apropos of the financial situation that budgetary expenditures were now entirely covered by taxes or by normal resources from loans, by which he meant to indicate largely treasury bonds.

PATCHOGUE, L.I., July 5 -- A total of 912 children from Patchogue and near-by villages were attended in the toxoid and vaccination clinics held a few days ago under the direction of Southern Brookhaven town medical division of the Suffolk County War Council.

Bishop Adna Wright Leonard of the Washington, D.C., Area of the Methodist Church, preached yesterday a sermon in the Marble Collegiate Reformed Church, Fifth Avenue and Twenty-ninth Street. He declared that it was a great misfortune when a preacher of the gospel hid his thought in a wilderness of phrases, used so many quotations as to be bewildering and sent his congregation away asking, "What did he say?"

For seven weeks this Summer the Flatbush branch of the Y.M.C.A. will operate four neighborhood Y.M.C.A. vacation centers, it is announced by J. Lawrence Broderick, executive secretary of the branch. Youths who will not be able to leave the city because of gasoline rationing and other reasons will have a chance to carry on wholesome and worthwhile activities during the vacation period.
Camping will be more than a vacation this year for the girls who left this morning for Porter Corners, N.Y., as the twentieth camping season for New York Camp Fire Girls got under way.

PITTSBURGH, July 5 -- Difficulty in obtaining scrap metal, combined with necessary repairs to blast furnaces and open hearth units, caused last week a decline in steel operations of one and a half points to 97 1/2 per cent of theoretical capacity.

WASHINGTON, July 5 -- Birth certificates to prove American citizenship will no longer be needed for persons who seek posts in plants where work on secret or confidential government contracts is being done. Paul V. McNutt, chairman of the War Man Power Commission, stated today that a simple declaration that the applicant was a citizen would be sufficient.

AN EAST COAST PORT, July 5 -- A large American merchantman, crammed beyond lifeboat capacity with the survivors of two torpedoed vessels, was sunk near the northern coast of South America June 15, but not before a courageous Navy officer gave up his life to fire at the attacking submarine.

A three-alarm fire ravaged Kane's Casino, two blocks from the tip of Clason Point in the Bronx, early yesterday, robbing the rambling wooden house of whatever glory remained from its heyday as the borough's most fashionable picnic retreat and the scene of political clambakes galore.

LONDON, July 5 -- The fluctuations of the Egyptian battle entirely dominated the financial markets here last week. Resistance to bad news in the first half of the week was stout but prices nevertheless yielded. There was an even sharper rally toward the end of the week when the news showed that Rommel's onslaught at least was being held.

A syndicate represented by Abraham Beier, attorney, bought from Louis Glass the apartment house at 1920 Eighty-sixth Street, Brooklyn, through Bernard I. Taub, broker. It owns several other properties on the same street.

ORANGE, N.J., July 5 (AP) -- Charles Mattman of Forest Hills, L.I., ranked third on the domestic list, eliminated Rolando Vega of Mexico City, seeded fourth in the foreign group, 6 -- 3, 6 -- 8, 6 -- 1, in the second round of the New Jersey State tennis tournament today.

CHATTANOOGA, July 5 -- Announcing a mass withdrawal of locals from the United Mine Workers of America, headed by John L. Lewis, in a move to return to the C.I.O., whose chief is Phillip Murray, Bernard Borah, regional director of District 50, said here today that he had submitted his resignation.

The trials of the depression of 1929 may well have been spiritual preparation for the nation for these days, the Rev. Dr. Charles Lyon Seasholes, pastor of the First Baptist Church, Dayton, Ohio, said yesterday in his sermon in the Riverside Church.

WASHINGTON, July 5 -- Dmitri Shostakovich's new "Song of the United Nations" was sung for the first time in public tonight at the Watergate of the Potomac by Igor Gorin, baritone, accompanied by the National Symphony Orchestra. Charles O'Connell conducted.

CHICAGO, July 5 (AP) -- Sam ("Golf Bag") Hunt, one of the few living gangsters of the Capone era, was sought by the police today for questioning in connection with the killing of Mike Wade, 54, a Negro employed in Winnetka. He was shot during a traffic argument on the South Side last night.

LONDON, July 5 -- The Economist's index of British commodity prices, based on 1927 as 100, was 110.7 on June 23. This compares with 111.2 a fortnight before, 104.8 a year before and 70.3 at the end of August, 1939.

CHUNGKING, China, July 5 (U.P.) -- The new United States Army Air Force in China has blasted major Japanese airdromes and waterfront targets around Hankow and Nanchang in its first major bombing expedition, it was revealed tonight.

BEAR MOUNTAIN, N.Y., July 5 -- There were so many New Yorkers and Jerseyites sleeping out in Palisades Interstate Park over the Fourth of July week-end that the deer were just about driven out of the woods and the park police had to turn firemen, persuading the metropolitan Dan'l Boones to put out after-dark campfires, banned by wartime blackout regulations.

There is more than a little significance behind the announcement of the opening of the first flight strip "somewhere in the Middle Atlantic seaboard" by the Army Air Force and the Public Roads Administration. This is the opening gun in an extensive program to supply an important addition to our system of airports.

MOSCOW, Monday, July 6 -- The Russian High Command acknowledged this morning that the Germans had driven a wedge into a sector of the Belgorod area of the southwestern front, where the great battle in the highlands is broadening as German infantry follows up tank drives.

CHICAGO, July 5 -- The wheat market staged a rapid recovery last week afer liquidation had carried prices to the lowest levels since mid-October. Conflicting reports on the outlook for speedy passage of farm legislation and the form of such a measure was responsible for part of the erratic price fluctuations.
LOS ANGELES, July 5 -- Registration of workers to help in the Southern California harvest has been started here by the American Women's Volunteer Service, aiding the United States Employment Service.

Jammed railroad and bus terminals yesterday told the story of New York's wartime Fourth of July week-end. It was the heaviest in the history of both these forms of modern transportation and was apparently the direct result of the gasoline rationing system along the Eastern seaboard.

WASHINGTON, July 5 (AP) -- Senator McNary of Oregon, the Republican leader, gave his support today to President Roosevelt's demand that Congress permit the Government to sell surplus wheat for livestock feed at about 83 cents a bushel instead of the parity price of $1.34.

WASHINGTON, July 5 (U.P.) -- The eight Nazi agents who, if convicted, may face an American firing squad for their abortive sabotage mission that brought them to American shores, were held tonight in District jail under a heavy military guard.

New Yorkers who still do not know that they have a city-wide Sheriff will be proud to know that he "got his man" early yesterday morning in a sort of streamlined version of the way a Western Sheriff would have -- unless the movies are all wrong.
Democracy needs a leader, the Rev. Samuel M. Shoemaker, rector of Calvary Episcopal Church, Fourth Avenue and Twenty-first Street, said in his sermon yesterday morning.

Summer starts officially today for 3,000 of the city's children who will attend the eighteen play schools affiliated with the Play Schools Association in settlement houses, churches, private and public schools, community centers and housing projects.

It takes planning for the woman of today to salvage as much time as possible for the business of civilized living. Such things as furnishings and fashions and beauty must not be abandoned in favor of patriotic activities.
Major league baseball, suspending for the moment its heated pennant races, embarks today upon a two-day carnival of all-star competition as its major contribution thus far to the nation's war effort.

Forty-five hundred private telephone subscribers have given the air warden service the right to designate their phones for emergency use during air raids, providing the service with an auxiliary communications network covering the city, it was announced yesterday by the warden service command.
LONDON, July 5 (U.P.) -- Prime Minister Winston Churchill tonight reaffirmed Britain's determination to give China all the "material, moral and spiritual help in our power."

The industry-wide clinic on boys' and students' apparel industry under war conditions will open tomorrow at the Waldorf-Astoria and continue through Wednesday under the sponsorship of the Boys Apparel Buyers Association and manufacturers.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 5 -- "Without Love," Philip Barry's latest play, in which Katharine Hepburn and Elliott Nugent appeared in pre-Broadway performances last Spring, has been purchased by Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer for filming after its forthcoming Broadway production.

Last week the Irving Fisher Index of Wholesale Commodity Prices rose 1.5 per cent to a new high level of 108.2. The principal reason for this sharp gain was the rise of 2.5 cents in the price of gasoline and 2.0 cents rise in fuel oil following the recent OPA regulation.

NEW ORLEANS, July 5 -- Stubborn resistance of the House members of the conference committee on the agricultural bill to the Senate amendment granting authority to sell grains below parity was the main sustaining factor last week in cotton futures.

CHUNGKING, China, July 5 (U.P.) -- The story of the escape of several thousand Chinese troops, cut off in Central Burma, to Chinese lines along the Salween River in Yunnan Province after a month-long march through violent monsoons, was revealed here today by a British medical officer.

The last war inspired memorials to the Unknown Soldier. In every country an altar was raised in honor of one soldier who represented all the brave men who died in battle. This war has produced thousands of soldiers who do not die in battle, but give their lives every day, hopelessly and heroically, for countries already conquered.

BOSTON, July 5 -- Another topflight pitching performance by Larry French today gave the Dodgers an even break in the day's doings here before a crowd of 19,220, Brooklyn taking the nightcap, 2 -- 1, after losing the opener, 6 -- 5, to the Braves.

WASHINGTON, July 5 -- No commercial export shipments exceeding 2,240 pounds may be booked or loaded to Latin America after Aug. 15 unless they are on approved cargo lists prepared by the War Shipping Administration, the Government announced today.

LOS ANGELES, July 5 -- Federal prosecutors are awaiting a signal from Washington to hunt down a Southern California ring of tire bootleggers. The ring has offered huge bribes, threatened to "pour lead" into any one who "squeals" and has pocketed profits exceeding $1,000,000.

SANTIAGO, Chile, July 5 (U.P.) -- Possibility that Axis submarines are lurking off South America's west coast preparatory to launching unrestricted submarine warfare on Pacific Coast shipping was indi cated today as the Chilean Ministry of the Navy and the Pan American-Grace Airways investigated reports that submarines had been sighted off Chile's northern ports.

MERRICK, L.I., July 5 -- Although 95 years old today, James T. Goud Sr., oldest alumnus of the Brooklyn Police Department and a resident of this village for forty years, still fondly tells of his thirty-nine years of police service that began in 1868.

Confidence that New York State would be able to fill its quota of 8,600 doctors for the armed forces of the nation by the end of this year was expressed yesterday by the New York State Medical Society on the basis of a survey covering fifty-eight counties of the State, containing 98 per cent of the population.

PITTSFIELD, Mass., July 5 -- The third season of the Berkshire Music Center was opened this afternoon in the Music Theatre at Tanglewood and an audience of 800, many of whom were students, heard an address by Dr. Serge Koussevitzky, the founder, and a brief program of vocal and instrumental music.

ALEXANDRIA, Egypt, July 4 (Delayed) -- Major Gen. Charles L. Scott, senior United States military observer in the Middle East, said today on his return from the front that General Field Marshal Erwin Rommel's drive into Egypt had been stopped by "beautiful cooperation" among British Empire infantry, artillery, armored and air units.

LONDON, July 5 -- Some girls in Britain's three women's services share their country's most carefully guarded secrets. They are the girls of the Women's Royal Naval Service, the Auxiliary Territorial Service and the Women's Auxiliary Air Force who are attached to the "Hush Hush" headquarters of the Combined Operations Staff, headed by Lord Louis Mountbatten.

WASHINGTON, July 5 -- Endowment of a permanent court of international justice with power to compel obedience to its decrees as the chief instrument of a revived League of Nations comprises one plan proposed for post-war reconstruction.

DETROIT, July 5 (AP) -- Cleveland and Detroit, chief contenders for the American League's third place, took turns today punching each other around in a doubleheader before 31,032 spectators, the Tigers unleashing a sixteen-hit attack to win the opener, 10 to 1, and Mel Harder pitching a three-hitter to give the Tribe the nightcap, 5 to 1.

WITH THE BRITISH EIGHTH ARMY, July 3 (Delayed) -- The British spearhead this morning is several miles beyond our former front positions and General Field Marshal Erwin Rommel has drawn back his forces, which were pressing ever closer on our positions.

Wholesale trading generally was quiet last week, but large numbers of apparel buyers were expected in the markets this week and next to cover Fall requirements, according to a summary of the week's activities prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by leading resident buying offices.

"We are alarmed at the attitude of the people we have seen on the way home," said one [of the officers returning from the Pacific]. "This is a bloody war and the people at home don't seem to know it. The newspapers talk about peace, what we are going to do with the peace, how we are going to control it.

Mrs. Mary A. McGrath of 23 Thames Street, believed to have lived longer as a tenant in one building than any other New Yorker, has donated a flag and plaque in memory of her son, Thomas J. McGrath, who died in his country's service while in the Coast Guard during World War I, to St. Peter's Church in Barclay Street, oldest Catholic church in the city, it was learned yesterday.

BERNE, Switzerland, July 5 (U.P.) -- Italian newspapers today quoted Virginio Gayda, foremost Italian propagandist, as saying that large numbers of American tanks reached Africa in recent weeks and were thrown into action at El Alamein, largely accounting for stiffened British resistance in the Battle of Egypt.

Your editorial, "Faith in Britain," is an excellent treatment of a subject that will become increasingly more important as the war progresses. It opens the entire field of Anglo-American personal relations, principally between American and British soldiers. I entertain the hope that American and British leaders will not commit the error of World War I days, when they apparently ignored the necessity of actively promoting an understanding between American and British soldiers.

WASHINGTON, July 5 (U.P.) -Howard A. Gray, acting director of the Office of the Coordinator of Solid Fuels, reported today that soft coal pile grew by an estimated 5,573,000 tons in May. The country's amount of carbonferous fuel in storage was not enough, however, to assure the nation an adequate protection against possible wartime emergencies, he said.

BOMBAY, India, July 5 -- The presence in India of British and United States armed forces is now acceptable to Mohandas K. Gandhi, the Indian Nationalist leader asserts in the issue of his weekly newspaper, Harijan, published yesterday.

While the fight surges on two great battlefields, in Egypt and in Russia, and Japanese invasion forces enlarge their foothold on our Aleutian outposts, another decisive battle is in progress on our home front. This is the battle against inflation. Less spectacular than the clash of tanks and ships and planes, it is nevertheless crucial.

MOSCOW, July 5 (U.P.) -- Constantine A. Oumansky, former Russian Ambassador to the United States, issued tonight a denial and denunciation of an assertion that he had imparted to Germany in 1941 an American warning to Russia that Adolf Hitler was preparing to attack the Soviet Union.

The Jordan-Willa Corporation, which recently bought the seven-story building at 297 to 303 Cherry Street running through to 542-548 Water Street, paid about $7,000 over mortgages amounting to $41,000 for the property, according to revenue stamps on the deed.
PHILADELPHIA, July 5 -- The Giants were like so many midgets before the pitching of the Phils today at Shibe Park and they dropped both ends of a doubleheader.

ALBANY, July 5 -- Attorney General Bennett has told Gabriel Davidson, managing director of the Jewish Agricultural Society, New York City, that Jewish refugees from Germany may take, hold and transmit real property in this State.
Private advices received here indirectly from Rome indicate that the withdrawal of General Field Marshal Erwin Rommel from his present advanced positions in Egypt to Matruh is envisaged as imminent.

Total shipments of all types of hosiery during May amounted to 11,499,937 dozen pairs, compared with 11,749,506 dozens shipped during May of last year, according to the National Association of Hosiery Manufacturers. Shipments of women's full-fashioned hosiery were 805,899 dozen pairs lower, a decrease of 23 per cent.

Nothing less than the consciousness of what we are sacrificing will give us the final victory," declared the Rev. Dr. Samuel Henry Prince in his sermon yesterday morning at St. Stephen's Episcopal Church, 128 West Sixty-ninth Street.

Recommendations for training or retraining 15,000,000 Americans now in the armed services or war industries to enable them to resume their places in peacetime industry at the end of the war were contained in a report by a Commission on Post-War Training and Adjustment published yesterday by the Institute of Adult Education of Teachers College, Columbia University.

Mrs. Stuart H. Johnson and Miss Eunice C. Johnson will give a luncheon tomorrow at Sherry's, and Mr. and Mrs. Sidney A. Mitchell and Miss Mary A. Mitchell will give a dinner in the evening on the Viennese Roof of the St. Regis for Miss Mary Paige Cartmell whose marriage to Ensign Robertson Alfred, U.S.N.R., will take place on Wednesday.

BALTIMORE, July 5 -- John W. Garrett, former Ambassador to Italy and grandson of one of the founders of the Baltimore Ohio Railroad, bequeathed in his will his "four generations library" to Johns Hopkins University.
WASHINGTON, July 5 (U.P.) -- A temporary truce in the sharp controversy over below-parity sales of government-owned grain surpluses appears likely to be negotiated in Congress this week.

ALBANY, July 5 -- All volunteers in the New York civilian protection services are to be fingerprinted and plans will be made at a series of eight regional conferences called today by Lieutenant Governor Poletti, coordinator of State war plans.

A petition to Congress to establish a special commission to survey the problems of post-war economic reconstruction and to insure full employment for all persons able and willing to work was issued yesterday by 565 clergymen of the Protestant, Catholic and Jewish faiths.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, July 5 -- The American airmen who recently flew over Rumania and bombed the gasoline refineries and storage tanks at Ploesti were not misled by the dummy town, complete with fake oil plants, that the Germans had laid out to divert Allied raiders from their objective, it was learned authoritatively here today.

Such reports as we are allowed to receive from the Aleutians boil down to the disconcerting fact that the Japanese invaders are still there after more than a month of occupation. Apparently they are even extending their operations, for Agattu, an island between Attu and Kiska, on which an enemy landing seems to be in progress, enters the news for the first time.
This refers to the letter by Burton Sloane, in THE TIMES, about "The stupidity of the current subway dimout is the prize achievement."

ST. LOUIS, July 5 (AP) -- Sweeping both ends of a bargain bill with the Cubs, the Cardinals today pared to 8 1/2 games the lead held by the Dodgers who split a pair. The Cards grabbed the opener, 5 to 3, and the nightcap, 11 to 6.
CHUNGKING, July 5 (AP) -- The Chinese High Command issued this communique today:

The State committee of the American Labor party, in a letter signed by Alex Rose, secretary, yesterday urged Representative Matthew J. Merritt to take the lead in seeking a revision of the tax bill to restore the Treasury Department's original schedules for higher personal and corporate incomes, retain the existing $750 exemption for single persons and include joint tax returns for married couples.

The two-story building at 76-75 Ashland Avenue in West Orange, N.J., has been leased for a long term from the Philadelphia Carpet Company by the Roth Paper Box Company, which has been operating in Newark for twenty-two years.
AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, Australia, July 5 (AP) -- General Douglas MacArthur's headquarters issued today this communique:

EAST HAMPTON, L.I., July 5 -Miss Sarah Diodati Gardiner and Miss Florence van Rensselaer have staying with them this week-end at White House Princess Ruspoli and her niece, Miss Marie Therese Berry and Lieutenant Robert D.L. Gardiner, U.S.N. Miss Gardiner gave a luncheon for them at the Devon Yacht Club.

CHICAGO, July 5 -- Large deliveries of cash corn on July contracts through the Board of Trade here had little lasting effect last week on the market. That grain advanced quickly after scattered liquidation early in the week had been absorbed.

CHUNGKING, China, Monday, July 6 -- In a message on the eve of the fifth anniversary of the war of resistance against Japan Dr. Wang Chung-hui, eminent jurist and secretary general of the Chinese Supreme Defense Council, advocated today establishment of machinery to unify the military strategy of the United Nations during the war and an international organization to plan a permanent peace after the war.

OCEANSIDE, L.I., July 5 -- South Nassau Communities Hospital is equipped to continue its normal routine uninterrupted even during a prolonged blackout, Walter S. Boardman, chairman of the hospital's air raid precaution committee, says, following a careful test.

PHILADELPHIA, July 5 -- An appeal for continued unity, in war and peace, among the United Nations to save us from "a world of terror and tragedy" was made by Supreme Court Justice Owen J. Roberts in an address broadcast from here today.

BERLIN, July 5 (From German broadcasts recorded by The Associated Press) -- German and allied forces lunging eastward beyond the Ukraine after spectacular gains of 100 miles or more have driven spearheads to the Don River "on a broad front," the German High Command announced today.
WASHINGTON, July 5 -- President Roosevelt has received additional messages of greeting from the heads of foreign governments on this country's Independence Day. The following were made public today:

CAIRO, Egypt, July 5 (U.P.) A brilliant coup by New Zealand nfantry that resulted in the capture of twenty-two German tanks and forty cannon has helped to give British Empire troops an edge over General Field Marshal Erwin Rommel's stalled and weary forces.

NO one has ever questioned that we Americans are a patriotic people willing to fight and die for our country. No more than others do we avoid stupidities, timidities, blunders, mistaken self-interests and inner confusions, but when the chips are down and our country's fate is at stake, American patriotism can be an inspiring and awesome force.

Reuben Fine of Washington, D.C., winner of the national open tournament in St. Louis last year, won the first national rapid transit championship tournament, under auspices of the United States Chess Federation at the Hotel Capitol last night, outranking Samuel Reshevsky, three times United States champion.

Abraham Cahan, who came to this country sixty years ago from Russia and for forty-one years has been the editor of The Jewish Daily Forward, largest Jewish daily in the world, will mark his eighty-second birthday tomorrow with "business as usual."
ROME, July 5 (From Italian broadcasts recorded by The Associated Press) -- The Italian High Command issued this communique today:

WASHINGTON, July 5 (AP) -- Legislation authorizing a pipeline and barge canal across Florida was opposed by Senator Vandenberg today on the ground that it was "unjustifiable Congressional interference" with Presidential powers.

MANCHESTER, Vt., July 5 -- Johnny Sheary, 17-year-old Troy youth, just out of La Salle Institute, today made golfing history by emerging victorious in the Robert Todd Lincoln Memorial tournament, annual fixture of the Ekwanok Club, one of America's golf shrines.

OTTAWA, July 5 -- It is expected that the House of Commons vote on the amendment to the present National Mobilization Act making conscripted men liable for overseas service in emergency will be taken Tuesday evening and that the measure will be passed with seventy to seventy-five members, mostly from the Province of Quebec, voting against it.
LOS ANGELES, July 5 -- Emil Ludwig has his ideas as to how Germany, the perennial bad boy of Europe, should be dealt with when victory comes to the United Nations.

WASHINGTON, July 5 -- New pricing methods for men's and boys' tailored clothing which go back in most cases to base periods earlier than March, 1942, and which involve "roll-backs" of manufacturers' and wholesalers' quotations, were announced today by the Office of Price Administration.

CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va., July 5 -- Recognition and acceptance as practical ideals of the fatherhood of God and the brotherhood of man, and insistence on observance of a universal moral law, were declared the objectives of a new crusade announced today at the University of Virginia by representatives of three faiths, all of whom agreed that on its success or failure the future of humanity largely depended.

Dr. Alfonso Lopez, President-elect of Colombia, arrived here yesterday at noon from Miami and was greeted at the Pennsylvania Station by Mayor La Guardia, Tabriel Turbay, Colombian Ambassador to the United States, and representatives of the State Department.

BERLIN, July 5 (From German broadcasts recorded by The United Press in New York) -- Large formations of German bombers, fighters and assault planes striking in waves supported the advance of German armored divisions east of the Kharkov-Kursk line, said a communique issued today at Reichsfuehrer Hitler's headquarters.

We count among our acquaintances a young woman who lives in one large room and cooks on one small stove. You call it a stove only if you are fond of hyperbole, for it is nothing but a square "plate" that is run by electricity. With this, a can-opener and some imagination our friend creates delicious dishes.

MONTREAL, July 5 (AP) -- Montreal pitchers weren't as good as Newark batters today, and the Bears made twenty-eight hits good for a twin victory, 12 -- 5 and 8 -- 6. It was the first time the Royals had dropped a double-header this season.

In many respects last week was a curious period, both in the war news and in the markets. The fall of Tobruk, with the subsequent swift advance of the German General Rommel into Egypt, appeared for the Allied Nations on its face a serious military disaster.

OMAHA, July 5 (AP) -- With only his wife for an audience, Michael Kearney, a lawyer, walked up the Douglas County courthouse steps yesterday, took two twpewritten sheets from his brief case and began reading an Independence Day address.
Members of the Sheepshead Bay fleet were among the first to be advised that hereafter fishermen on all craft must have Coast Guard identification cards before going on their regular off-shore trips.

All Americans are called to the utmost service and sacrifice, whether in the armed forces, home, field, factory, office, shipyard or production plant, Bishop William T. Manning declared yesterday at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine in the first of four sermons on "The Present World Situation and Christian Belief."

With the time for filing designating petitions for candidates for party nominations and for delegates to the State and judicial conventions expiring Tuesday at midnight, efforts to block Attorney General John J. Bennett Jr. for the Democratic nomination for Governor appeared yesterday to have made little headway.

PITTSBURGH, July 5 (AP) -- Pitcher Ray Starr captured his twelfth game of the season 5 to 2, today to give Cincinnati an even split in a double-bill with Pittsburgh after the Pirates had taken the opener by 4 to 3, but the National League lost one of its pitchers, Paul Derringer, for tomorrow's All-Star game in New York.

Partly obscured by the smoke of battle over Egypt and by the secrecy with which operations in Russia have always been veiled, the Russian campaign last week definitely entered a new and important phase.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., July 5 -- Swelled by sixteen craft of the Handicap Class, there were ninety-four starters today in the second session of the two-day Sound championship series at the Larchmont Yacht Club. That was one more than yesterday, making the total 187 for the two regattas.
CHICAGO, July 5 (AP) -- The White Sex broke a six-game losing streak today by routing the Browns, 14 to 2, but fell back on their beaten path by dropping the nightcap, 13 to 2.

The thirteen-acre estate of Robert Hammerschlag on Old Croton Lake Road, in Mount Kisco, has been purchased by Jack Mintz, New York business man, through Warren Marks Associates and Wolff Wolff, brokers. The dwelling on the place contains ten rooms and three baths.

BERLIN, July 5 (From German broadcasts recorded by The Associated Press) -- British resistance in North Africa "has stiffened to a certain extent," Dienst aus Deutschland acknowledged tonight, quoting well-informed Berlin military circles in a relatively detailed German version of recent developments there.

Joe McCarthy almost had a relapse his first day back on the job yesterday as the Yankees dropped the opening game of a double-header to the Athletics, 5 to 4, before a gathering of 34,392 at the Stadium. But the New Yorkers finally decided that that was no way to treat a convalescent and cheered him up immeasurably by annexing the nightcap, 4 to 2.

SAN JOSE, Costa Rica, July 5 -- Sixty persons were wounded last night and early today in anti-Axis riots during which irate Costa Ricans wrecked Axis-owned properties in retaliation for the torpedo-sinking in Puerto Limon harbor last week of a United Fruit Company vessel.

By the end of 1943 the United States will have procured 2,100 million pounds of aluminum -- 6.5 times the production of 1939. Plants are now in construction some of which have a capacity greater than that of the whole aluminum industry when the last war was at its height.

CAIRO, Egypt, July 5 -- British mobile forces operating between the "box" defenses that anchor each end of the El Alamein line counter-attacked again yesterday against enemy armored and infantry units and forced them to withdraw at several points after a number of enemy tanks had been knocked out.

CHICAGO, July 5 -- Cash lard continues to be in active demand, with lease-lend purchases plus a liberal domestic call resulting in reducing supplies in cold storage to the lowest level in several years. Stocks at leading Western packing points decreased more than 10,000,000 pounds during June.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., July 5 -- Miss Ruth Stillman heads the surgical dressings unit here of the American Hospital in Britain. The unit has opened its workroom in the basement of the School of Nursing of the Southampton Hospital.

LYNBROOK, L.I., July 5 -- A class of fifteen deaf-mutes is receiving first-aid instruction every Friday night in a special course established by the American Red Cross in the Unity party clubhouse at 2 Hempstead Ave.

In a thrilling two-and-three-quarter-hour final, Francisco Segura of Guayaquil, Ecuador, successfully defended the Brooklyn tennis championship yesterday at the Knickerbocker Field Club against Ladislav Hecht of Prague, the same man he defeated in the 1941 final. Segura won in four sets, 6 -- 4, 8 -- 10, 6 -- 4, 7 -- 5.

MOSCOW, July 5 -- Eugene Petroff [Eugene Petrovitch Katayleft], one of the leading Russian writers, was killed at his post of war correspondent covering the defense of Sevastopol on Thursday. He was 40 years old.

WASHINGTON, July 5 (AP) -- Boston's pennant-hungry Red Sex split a double-header with Washington today, dropping the opener, 4 -- 3, due to a ninth-inning Senator rally, but winning the nightcap handily, 5 -- 0, behind Joe Dobson's five-hit hurling.

MONTCLAIR, N.J., July 5 (AP) -- Lanky Bob Odman, University of Washington junior, used his withering forehand drives to good advantage today to defeat Dick Bender, Princeton University captain, 6 -- 3, 6 -- 2, in the final round of the twentieth annual Eastern intercollegiate tennis tournament.

Some of the best of Joseph Conrad's shorter works will be brought together in one volume entitled "A Conrad Argosy," to be published by Doubleday, Doran late next month. Hans Alexander Mueller, an artist with a strong love for the sea, has been chosen to do the illustrations.

LONDON, July 5 -- With the Western air front quiet through last night and in daylight today, a summary of operations for June showed that the Royal Air Force lost 422 planes in all actions on this front and in the Middle East and the Axis lost 260 planes.

The entire "Porgy and Bess" company, including stagehands and electricians, as well as actors and singers, will travel by special bus today to Fort Monmouth, Red Bank, N.J., where at 5:30 P.M. they will perform the popular Gershwin musical for the hundreds of soldiers stationed there.

WASHINGTON, July 5 -- With two plants in production, government officials have discovered that making synthetic rubber will not cost as much as they thought it would.

Warning New York City motorists to register next Thursday, Friday or Monday at public schools for their basic A books under the permanent gasoline rationing, Lee S. Buckingham, State director of the Office of Price Administration, said yesterday that he believed the Board of Education's arrangements for a fourth day of registration were merely "precautionary."

MELBOURNE, Australia, Monday, July 6 (U.P.) -- Allied bombers, continuing their almost daily raids on Lae and Salamaua, kindled huge fires in the two Japanese invasion bases in Northern New Guinea yesterday, a United Nations communique announced today.

Recalling that true Christianity of today is not different from that of the early ages, and that we must undergo struggles and face trials not unlike those of the early Christians, Mgr. Joseph F. Flannelly, administrator of St. Patrick's Cathedral, declared that "the Church is struggling today in more than one place for its very existence," in his sermon at solemn mass yesterday morning in the cathedral.

SCARBOROUGH-ON-HUDSON, N.Y., July 5 -- Victories in metropolitan A.A.U. championship tests by Miss Alice Crozier and Miss Gloria Callen, both of the Women's Swimming Association, featured the aquatic portion of today's sports program for Army Emergency Relief at the Sleepy Hollow Country Club.

CHICAGO, July 5 -- Oats followed the pattern established by other grains last week on the Board of Trade here. Deferred deliveries of that grain sold at the season's low prices early but rallied to close at net losses of only 3/8 to 1/2 cent a bushel, with July at 46 1/2 cents, September at 47 5/8 and December at 50 1/4.

After another intensive search of the refugee ship Drottningholm at Pier F, Jersey City, the investigators smiled as if they had found what they were looking for, C. Charles Devaux, Nice hotel man, who will live at 150 North Center Avenue, Rockville Centre, L.I., said yesterday when he was released from the liner.

Company, Inc., has reported that it had net assets of $17,559,461 on June 30, and that these were equivalent, after providing for its debentures, to $230.50 for each share of preferrea stock and to $6.62 a share of common stock, comparing with $6.47 a common share on March 31 and $7.06 a share on Dee. 31, 1941.

Professor Halford E. Luccock of the Yale Divinity School, in a sermon yesterday morning on "Restoring the Past or Creating the Future," at the Broadway Congregational Tabernacle, Fifty-sixth Street and Broadway, asserted that in the midst of all the battles today there is the struggle for dominance between those who want to restore a vanished past and those who want to create a better future.

LAKE PLACID, N.Y., July 6 -- Competing in her second major championship, Miss Ann Winslow of the Cedar Lake G.C., Frankfort, N.Y., led a small but select field in winning the qualifying medal in the thirteenth annual Women's New York State golf tournament today.
HAMILTON, Bermuda, July 6 -- Real rationing came into effect here today after many warnings that such a situation might arise.

Advertising linage of all New York newspapers for the first six months of 1942, at 44,905,036, showed a decline of 8.5 per cent from the 49,058,292 for the like period in 1941, according to an analysis yesterday. Declines ranged from 0.79 per cent for one morning newspaper to 19.61 per cent for an evening paper.

The report of the American Power and Light Company and subsidiaries for the twelve months ended on May 31, issued yesterday, shows a consolidated net income, after taxes and charges, of $7,341,814, compared with a net of $11,240,499 in the twelve months to May 31, 1941.

Sales of New York and Brooklyn department stores showed an increase last week of 6 per cent over the July Fourth week of 1941, according to the report issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. The report, however, covered five selling days, against four last year when a majority of stores were closed both on July 4 and the next day, Saturday.

LONDON, July 6 -- Proposals to unify British railroads, either through outright public ownership or by government control, are already considerably advanced, the annual meeting of the National Union of Railwaymen at Blackpool today was told by F.J. Burrows, president of the union, which has 376,355 members.

Four British Boy Scouts, veterans of air raids and blackouts at home, sat through New York's blackout last night at Radio City Music Hall to see "Mrs. Miniver," a picture of their homeland at war. The moving picture was the climax of an eventful day for the boys, who arrived in the city early yesterday morning and who will leave for Washington tomorrow.

WASHNGTON, July 6 -- In an effort to bring the United States into closer cooperation with the wartime economic controls being exerted by the Office of Price Administration, Leon Henderson revealed today that there has been a complete reorganization of the consumer division of OPA.

A world series spirit prevailed at the tenth All-Star game without the crush and the crowd. It was holiday at twilight and in the face of a threatened storm. Indeed, the game was surrounded by threats. Gathering clouds promised rain as game-time approached, and a city-wide practice blackout was announced for 9:30, or along about the time the fans ordinarily would be well on the way home.

HAWTHORNE, N.Y., July 6 -Edward Stephen Horton, 22 years old, who gave his address as 260 Riverside Drive, New York, was accused today by State police of kidnapping, robbery, burglary and illegal possession of firearms. The troopers charged that he had posed as a lieutenant commander and a provost marshal of the Navy in perpetrating the crimes in New York City and Putnam County.

MOSCOW, Tuesday, July 7 (AP) -- The German offensive from Kursk has pushed with overpowering weight 120 miles to the vicinity of the Don River and Voronezh despite desperate Red Army counter-attacks, the Russian High Command acknowledged today.

PHILADELPHIA, July 6 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission denied today a petition of the Middle West Corporation for a rehearing of an order requiring the dissolution of the Central and South West Utilities Company or the American Public Service Company and reduction of the capitalization of both subsidiaries to a basis of all common stock.

BERNE, Switzerland, July 6 -"Five thousand of our prisoners are ready to return," Chief of Government Pierre Laval says in a circular letter issued to the heads of recruiting agencies for French labor to serve in Germany, according to reports from Paris today.

The second bomb warning in Queens war plants within three days sent the police and FBI agents to the Lead-Kote Products Company plant in Long Island City last night. A thorough search of the building was made. Members of the bomb squad found a suspicious-looking suit case that proved on inspection to contain an assortment of Christmas cards.
Carelessness in wartime may cost the lives of hundreds of men and the loss of battles, Mayor La Guardia warned 400 civilians who enrolled at City Hall yesterday for the Signal Corps Training School.

CHICAGO, July 6 -- Large lease-lend contracts for pork and lard made late last week sent top hogs to $15 a hundredweight at the stock yards today despite heavy July marketing by farmers. The price was the highest since July, 1926, and equaled the highest since October, 1920.

Lou Boudreau, their lead-off hitter, put the ball among the cash customers in the upper left-field stand the first time he swung his bat. It was the second ball thrown by Mort Cooper, the National League starting pitcher.

The six-story new-law apartment house on a plot 55.6 by 100 feet at 316-20 East Fiftieth Street was bought by David S. Meister from the Bank of Manhattan Company through Brown, Wheelock, Harris, Stevens, Inc., brokers.

MEXICO CITY, July 6 (U.P.) -- Shortages of labor, equipment and other essentials must not deter the United States from increasing its farm production, United States Secretary of Agriculture Claude R. Wickard told delegates from virtually all the American republics who convened today for the second Inter-American Conference of Agriculture.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., July 6 -- The Westchester County Board of Supervisors petitioned the Third Avenue Railway System and thet Public Service Commission today to extend the transit company's Shore Road bus line in New Rochelle three and a half miles to the Pelham Bay subway line in the Bronx so that soldiers at Fort Slocum, near the Shore Road, would have inexpensive transportation to New York.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., July 6 -- Supreme Court Justice Lee Parsons Davis granted $300 damages today to Hilda B. Proctor, 15-year-old Negro school girl of Yonkers, against the Mount Vernon Arena, Inc., operator of a public roller skating rink at 240 West Lincoln Avenue in Mount Vernon, because the girl was refused admittance to the rink last October, although her white schoolmates were allowed to enter.

WASHINGTON, July 6 -- Donald M. Nelson, war production chief, expressed his opposition today to the manufacture of synthetic rubber from farm commodities on the ground that the plants requested would require "critical material needed for the war effort," as Secretary Ickes and William B. Boyd Jr., chairman of the Petroleum Industry War Council, reported to President Roosevelt that scrap rubber collections through July 3 totaled 334,293 tons, or about 5.07 pounds per capita.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., July 6 -- An application by James B. Schafer, self-styled "master metaphysician," for release from Sing Sing Prison on a writ of habeas corpus was denied today by Supreme Court Justice Lee Parsons Davis.

MOSCOW, Tuesday, July 7 -- Red Army troops, continuing their retreat on the southwestern front under the heaviest pressure, left a number of populated places yesterday and waged fierce battles against German forces west of Voronezh, a vital rail city just east of the Don River, and units south-west of Staryi Oskol, which is on the upper reaches of the Oskol River.

About lawyers and the Declaration of Independence. Traditionally the lawyer has never been regarded as overfriendly to the cause of human freedom. Something of Jack Cade's feelings on the subject is in all of us.

Those sinister Charles Addams cartoons that have enlivened the pages of The New Yorker are to be brought out in book form in the Fall by Random House. The publishers have persuaded Boris Karloff to write the preface for the album, to be called "Drawn and Quartered."

WASHINGTON, July 6 -- Rear Admiral William D. Leahy, Ambassador to Vichy, who was recalled for consultation with President Roosevelt after Pierre Laval returned to power, indicated after a conference with the President today that he soon would be assigned to another post.

Approval has been expressed by the National Association of Real Estate Beards of the program presented to Congress by John B. Blandford Jr., head of the National Housing Authority, by which 90 per cent of public housing for the war emergency will be temporary in character.

Called on to fight over almost every foot of the mile and a sixteenth, the Barrington Stable's colt Ahamo, chestnut son of Omaha, took the featured Ten Point Purse at Empire City yesterday. A crowd of 14,872 persons, biggest week-day gathering of the meeting, rooted home Ahamo, who was one of the five Favorites of the day to finish on top.

WASHINGTON, July 6 (U.P.) -- Ann Agnes Bernatitus of Exeter, Pa., the only Navy nurse to escape from Corregidor, said today that she believed there were about 100 women, seventy of them Americans, on the "Rock" when it capitulated to the Japanese on May 6.

WASHINGTON, July 6 -- The 1,400,000 families along the Eastern seaboard who heat their homes with fuel oil were urged tonight to convert their furnaces to coal as a precaution against an almost certain fuel shortage next Winter.

Dainty as they are delicious, these are designed by the pretty proprietress, once a distinguished mezzo-soprano in a Berlin that was at peace with the world.

Two freakish storms of the hit-run variety struck the metropolitan area yesterday afternoon a little more than three hours apart, causing injuries to three persons and resulting in widespread damage. A church in the Bronx, a trolley car in Queens and three Staten Island houses were struck by lightning.

In discussing the contest he has been sponsoring for the last three years, George Ruppert said many anglers probably were under the impression that in order to win the chief prize of $1,000 they had to catch a record fish.

WASHINGTON, July 6 -- Although the Senate today did its part to bridge for a month the six-day deadlock between the two Houses over the $680,000,000 Agriculture Department appropriation bill, there was no compromise on the essential issue -- the insistence of farm bloc opponents of the President that no government-held grain shall be sold at less than parity.

The Devoe Raynolds Company, Inc., and its subsidiaries had a net profit of $423,036 after Federal income taxes but before provision for possible excess profits tax, according to a report yesterday for the six months ended on May 31 by E.S. Phillips, president. The year before net profit amounted to $310,768.
Park Commissioner Robert Moses announced yesterday that it would be impossible to furnish the Coney Island Boardwalk with a dimout curtain.

For almost a year I have watched with chagrin the members of Robert Moses' staff digging up and disfiguring a small park which occupies only a sixteenth of an inch of green ink on the map of New York, but which has been a treasured place in my life for more than two decades.

Supreme Court Justice Samuel H. Hofstadter heard argument yesterday in support of an application by Richard A. Knight, disbarred attorney, to transfer his trial, on charges of sending annoying letters to members of the bench and bar, from Special Sessions to a jury trial in General Sessions.
ROME, July 6 (From Italian broadcasts recorded by The Associated Press) -- The Italian High Command communique said today:

John Drew Devereaux, grandson of the late John Drew, who has been the Clarence of "Life With Father" since its try-out at Skowhegan, Me., back in the Summer of 1939, has left the cast of that long-lived comedy to join the United States Army.

EL ALAMEIN, Egypt, July 5 (Delayed) -- This village, marked in capitals on any detailed map of the territory between the Libyan frontier and Alexandria, consists of nothing except a few deserted dwellings, most of which were already destroyed in former phases of this war and are now but piles of rubble mingling with the surrounding sand, proving that it would seem that in desert warfare the only victor is the desert.

Former President and President-Elect Lopez of Colombia is making a second official visit to Mr. Roosevelt and the United States, where he is pleasantly remembered. In 1933 he came back to us from London, where he was chief of the Colombian delegation to the World Economic Conference.

Yesterday afternoon the curtain was lifted on the new creations of three New York wizards of hat styling -- Lilly Dache, Sally Victor and John-Frederics. These three have jointly launched trends for the less expensive hats, those spoken of in the vernacular of the trade as the lower price brackets.

WASHINGTON, July 6 (AP) -- Committee approval of proposals for the liquidation or transfer of Axis-influenced business properties, and for the "blocking" of funds acquired for the interest of Axis nations or nationals, was voted today by delegates to the Inter-American Conference on Systems of Economic and Financial Control.

CHUNGKING, July 6 -- "With increased foreign aid the morale of the Chinese Army was never higher," said General Ho Ying-chin, Chief of Staff and Minister of War, on the eve of the beginning of the sixth year of China's war of resistance.

It is five years today since a detachment of trespassing Japanese were fired upon by a Chinese bridge guard outside Peiping, thus furnishing the Japanese with what appeared to them to be a legitimate excuse for attempting the conquest of China. The Chinese can be proud of those five years.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, July 6 -- The latest anti-Jewish measures reported from Berlin make it an offense for Jews to stroll along the streets at a leisurely pace. They must walk briskly, showing they are on a definite errand. They must not carry canes and must not walk more than two abreast, nor can they halt and confront a fellow-Jew they meet on their route.

The American League All-Stars got the jump on their National League foes at the Polo Grounds last night. Starting pitcher Mort Cooper for the older loop was set back in his tracks in the first inning, when two home runs and a double produced all three of the victors' tallies.
WASHINGTON, July 6 (AP) -- Motorists will be required after July 15 to turn in a worn-out auto part before accepting a new part, the War Production Board ruled today.

CAIRO, Egypt, July 6 -- Suffering heavy losses daily and making scant headway against the defenses and the mobile battle groups of the troops of the British Empire, General Field Marshal Erwin Rommel's Axis forces appeared today to be on the verge of losing the initiative altogether in the Battle of Egypt.

ALBANY, July 6 -- Refugees from Axis-controlled territory may be classed as "alien friends" and have the right to hold and transmit real property in New York, according to Attorney General John J. Bennett Jr.

WASHINGTON, July 6 -- President Roosevelt today vetoed a measure which would have deprived of citizenship all persons who are guilty of war fraud. In a strongly worded message to the Congress, the President said that he was returning H.R. 6355 without his approval because a number of its sections were objectionable to him.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., July 6 -- Mayor Thomas D. Taggart announced tonight that the city had granted full use of the facilities of the Municipal Convention Hall to the Army. Formal signing of a lease will be delayed for a few days pending adjustment of some suitable financial reimbursement for the city.

WASHINGTON, July 6 (AP) -- Price Administrator Leon Henderson accused the Amalgamated Sugar Company of Twin Falls, Idaho, today of making "grossly erroneous and misleading statements" in explaning to sugar beet growers the firm's failure to make its usual supplemental payments to them.

A resolution was adopted last night by the New York State Food Merchants Association asking the Office of Price Administration to freeze the price of wholesale milk in an effort to protect the retailers.

The stock market staged yesterday the most substantial over-all climb in more than a month as the recovery movement which was resumed last week broadened to lagging sections. Prices were enlarged from fractions to 3 points under a demand not unlike the spurts enjoyed in previous Julys from reinvestment buying.

A formal call for bids on $17,143,000 city of Detroit, Mich., refunding bonds, the final step in the city's refunding program, will be made today by Charles G. Oakman, city controller. The bids will be opened on July 14.
BERLIN, July 6 (From German broadcasts recorded by The Associated Press) -- The German High Command issued this communique today:

Ending a governmental investigation of each of the 942 persons who arrived here last Tuesday from Lisbon aboard the diplomatic exchange ship Drottningholm, the last of the passengers was cleared and left the ship at 9:30 o'clock last night, six days after its arrival in this port.

CHICAGO, July 6 -- Sales of 1V[ontgomery Ward Co. last month totaled $48,475,720, an 8.31 per cent decline from the $52,871,545 in the corresponding month last year, the Chicago mail order house and retail organization reported today.
BERNE, Switzerland, Tuesday, July 7 -- The Russian military commentator acknowledged in his broadcast this morning the fall of more positions southwest of Staryi Oskol and west of Voronezh.

WASHINGTON, July 6 -- President Roosevelt vetoed a bill which would deprive persons convicted of war frauds of citizenship; sent a message to General Chiang Kai-shek on the fifth anniversary of Japan's attack on China and conferred with Democratic leaders from Congress; his visitors included Secretary Jones, Admiral Leahy, William C. Bullitt, Senator Wagner, Dr. Solon J. Buck and Elmer Davis.

WASHINGTON, July 6 -- The possibility that the Senate-amended bill to create a women's reserve in the Navy might find immediate acceptance with the House faded today when Representative Beverly M. Vincent blocked an attempt of the Naval Affairs Committee to report the revised bill unanimously to the House floor.

WASHINGTON, July 6 -- With 500 planes for support, China can start an offensive against Japan, but if the United States concentrates on the European war theatre "there is always the danger" that China cannot keep on fighting, Major Gen. Chu Shih-ming, Chinese military attache, said in a press conference here today on the fifth anniversary of the Sino-Japanese war.

CHUNGKING, China, July 6 (AP) -- Jubilant Chinese press reports credited the newly formed squadron of the United States Air Forces in China tonight with sinking a Japanese gunboat, destroying more than twenty-five of the invaders' planes and smashing his cantonments, hangars and runways in a blazing display of striking power over a triangular area of 30,000 square miles.

ORANGE, N.J., July 6 (AP) -- Budge Patty of Los Angeles, the nation's top ranking junior player, narrowly escaped elimination from the New Jersey tennis tournament in the first round today at the Berkeley Tennis Club.
They doused the lights last night on the latest American League victory over the National League in All-Star competition.

Answers to a series of questions on Priorities Regulation No. 10, dealing with the allocation classification systems, requiring the use of symbols on all orders, were made public yesterday by the priorities department of the Regional Office of the War Production Board.

WASHINGTON, July 6 -- A bill authorizing the people of Puerto Rico to elect their own Governor, starting in December, was introduced in the House today by Bolivar Pagan, Resident Commissioner for the island.

Although men's clothing manufacturers asserted that Fall price regulations issued yesterday by the OPA to become effective July 11 would wipe out profits for the balance of the year, the general attitude toward the ruling was philosophical.

WASHINGTON, July 6 -- The Office of Price Administration cited today its settlement of the Jewel Food Stores case in Chicago as an example of the way decentralized administration can operate to give prompt relief to retailers in cases of genuine hardship.

Casting aside all thoughts of Summer vacations at favorite resorts, thirty high school girls started work yesterday at one of the more important volunteer civilian war jobs. As plotters for New York City's Aircraft Warning Center, the girls represent the nucleus of a group of eighty volunteers from 16 to 18 years of age now being recruited to replace elder women volunteers on vacation and soldiers released for active duty.

Arabs in French Morocco are openly and actively supporting the Germans and demonstrating against the British, a traveler who left Tangiers three weeks ago reported yesterday on her arrival at La Guardia Field aboard a Pan-American clipper from Europe.

WASHINGTON, July 6 -- Today's War Department communique that announced that American medium tanks manned by American crewsI participated with the British in the I Battle of Libya June 11-12 stated that none of the Americans had been killed or wounded and thatI the American tanks had been hiti repeatedly, but had not been seriously damaged.

Meeting in joint session with Commissioner Kenesaw Mountain Landis at the Hotel Roosevelt yesterday, the major league magnates disposed of their midsummer business in a three-hour discussion which left them barely enough time to rush to the Polo Grounds for the All-Star game. Most of what occurred behind locked doors was, of course, left to conjecture.

Wherever cold air strikes a warmer ocean current fogs accumulate. If the Grand Banks off Newfoundland are foggy it is because of the warm air that sweeps up from the Gulf of Mexico and over the cold water of the Labrador Current. The British Isles are foggy largely because of the Gulf Stream.

A conference between the New York State Department of Insurance and officials of the Rhode Island Insurance Company and the General Insurance Company of Seattle, Wash., was held yesterday in the department's offices here as holders of war damage insurance policies issued by these companies contended that the policies should be canceled to permit the owners to take out Federal insurance.

WOODRIDGE, lXT. J., July 6-Sanctity of the volunteer firehouse fell a victim to wartime needs today when Emil Dross, chairman of the fire fighting division of the Woodridge Defense Council, sent out a call for fifty women volunteers to fight fires during the day when men are away.

New York State still has 6,000 physicians to supply to meet its share of the national quota of 42,000 for the armed forces by the end of 1942, Lieut. Col. Sam F. Seeley, executive secretary of the directing board of the Procurement and Assignment Service, said last night.

BERNE, Switzerland, July 6 -- Joining the ranks of "conservative optimists" regarding the outcome of the battle for Alexandria, Mario Appelius, Popolo d'Italia writer, tonight warned his listeners that Axis supply lines before El Alamein "were in continual peril from intensive Royal Air Force attacks."

BERLIN, July 6 (From German broadcasts recorded by The United Press in New York) -- German shock troops have established bridgeheads on the eastern bank of the Don River, and elsewhere in Southwestern Russia German forces are "encircling Soviet units, which face annihilation," official German Army reports said today.

A new Treasury call was issued yesterday, one that is considerably larger than any of the recent ones. According to the notices received yesterday by commercial bank depositaries, the Treasury will withdraw on Friday a total of $247,000,000 from its accounts with these banks throughout the country.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., July 6 -- Herman Barron of Fenway walked away with the honors at the weekly one-day tourney of the Westchester P.G.A. today at the Elmsford Country Club. Although he was the victor in both the pro-amateur and pro-pro best-ball events, it was his individual subpar 34, 33 -- 67 that highlighted the play.
WITH AN AMERICAN TANK UNIT, in the Western Desert, June 25 (Delayed) -- This war's first battlefield encounter of the United States and German Armies occurred in the desert of Libya June 12.

The Appellate Division in Brooklyn unanimously dismissed yesterday all charges by Special Prosecutor John Harlan Amen's grand jury against C. Ernest Smith, Staten Island political leader and twice president of the Richmond County Bar Association, following a disbarment hearing before Official Referee Leander B. Faber, who returned a report exonerating Mr. Smith.

BERNE, Switzerland, July 6 -- The German occupation authorities will begin evacuating all Jews from the Netherlands at an early date, says a recent dispatch from The Hague to the National Zeitung of Essen, Germany.

FREEHOLD, N.J., July 6 -- Said to have been in "increasingly ill health" for several years and to have been facing the necessity of an operation, Mrs. Adeline Yard Lawrence, widow of Circuit Judge Rulif V. Lawrence, committed suicide by gas in her home here last night. Her body was found by her daughter, Mrs. G.A. Collins, who lived with her.

Both the supply of and the demand for municipal bonds probably will continue to decline as the war proceeds, according to Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc., which will release today its annual "Mid-Year Review of the Municipal Bond Market."

LONDON, July 6 (AP) -- One million German soldiers were reported by the British tonight to be plunging forward toward gaps torn by massed tanks in Marshal Semyon Timoshenko's armies in a supreme German bid for the approaches to the Caucasus.

AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, Australia, Tuesday, July 7 (U.P.) -- United Nation warplanes, ranging over a 2,000-mile front off Northern Australia, destroyed or crippled 284 Japanese planes in three months, official reports showed yesterday, and put up so strong a defense that Japanese attacks on Allied Nation bases dropped from twenty-eight in April to six in June.

Plans for the return to active duty of retired nurses in an effort to relieve the current shortage of trained nursing personnel in the hospitals of Brooklyn, Queens and Long Island have been adopted by the Nursing Bureau of District 14 of the New York State Nurses Association, it was announced yesterday by Miss Emma L. Collins executive director of the bureau.

An eight-game coast-to-coast football schedule for the Army's squad of eighty players and teams of the National League was approved by the War Football Fund at a meeting in the Hotel Commodore yesterday.

KINGSTON, N.Y., July 6 (AP) -- The police held on an unlicensed weapons charge today a German alien, Fritz Paul Helbig, 39 years old, of Hartford, Conn., who was found in a wrecked automobile Saturday night with luggage containing an unregistered Spanish-made automatic pistol and a United States Army uniform.

The West of Central Park Association through its City Planning Committee is urging its members to start now in setting up backlogs of work to be executed at the war's conclusion, according to Ralph A. Brooks, chairman of the committee.

A judgment for $300,995, in favor of Mrs. Florence Stanton Thomson of the Hotel Plaza, executrix of the estate of Samuel C. Thomson, mining engineer, and against the New York Trust Company, was filed yesterday in the County Clerk's office.

WASHINGTON, July 6 -- Monetary stabilization agreements guaranteeing parity with the American dollar were signed today by Secretary of the Treasury Henry Morgenthau Jr., with the Ministers of Brazil and Cuba.

TOKYO, July 6 (From Japanese broadcasts recorded by The United Press in San Francisco) -- In a summary of the China war, Japanese Imperial Headquarters asserted today that 2,338,000 Chinese had been killed on all fronts. The summary covered the war up to the middle of June.

WASHINGTON, July 6 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in 101 leading cities, the Federal Reserve System announced today, shows the following principal changes for the week ended July 1: Increases of $801,000,000 in holdings of Treasury certificates of indebtedness and $790,000,000 in United States Government deposits and decreases of $299,000,000 in reserve balances with Federal Reserve Banks and $446,000,000 in demand deposits -- adjusted.

WASHINGTON, July 6 -- A committee to supervise the administration of the Production Requirements Plan and the allocation classification system has been named by the War Production Board. The committee includes in its membership representatives of such groups as WPB and the Army and Navy Munitions Board.

There is going to be a unique birthday party today. No speeches, no birthday cakes, no candles. And the gifts will be to, not from, the guests. For the guests are the men in uniform, and the event is the first anniversary of the New York City Defense Recreation Committee.

The New York City Women's Council of the Navy League of the United States will sponsor a cocktail party and midsummer frolic, which will include an afternoon and evening swimming party and continuous sports events, on July 16 at the River Club, 447 East Fifty-second Street.

LONDON, July 6 -- Sustained cheerfulness of iddle Eastern groups of shares had a stimulating effect today on other markets. Egyptian Unified rose a point, Sudan Plantations Is 9d, and Iranian Oils 2s 6d.
Little buying was done at the opening of the midsummer floor coverings market here yesterday. Retailers generally have abnormal stocks and only a few new lines were shown.

PITTSBURGH, July 6 -- Safety Director George E.A. Fairley tonight ordered the police to burn hundreds of bamboo pennant canes bearing the label "Made in Japan" confiscated from the stocks from which souvenirs were hawked at last night's performance of the Army War Show.

KEARNY, N.J., July 6 -- The Rev. Richard D. Jones, pastor of Grace Methodist Church, today joined the day shift at the Federal Ship Building and Dry Dock Company as a war worker at 82 cents an hour while on his vacation of two months.

" Pacific Rendezvous" will open this morning at the Rialto. The cast of the topical drama, which was produced by Metro, is headed by Lee Bowman, Jean Rogers, Mona Maris, Carl Esmond, Paul Cavanagh and Blanche Yurka.

Speaking with extreme patience and politeness of the large-scale American military aid that China, nosy in her "most dangerous crisis," still awaits, General Hsiung Shih-fei, chief of the Chinese military mission to the United States, warned here yesterday that if China is conquered Japan may be able "to wage war for 100 years."

GREAT NECK, L.I., July 6 -Some of the sixteen Russian children who live at the newly established "Russian Embassy" at Kings Point on Little Neck Bay have caused some consternation among their neighbors on adjoining estates by inadvertently disturbing some historic rocks that were part of a landmark built in the Sixteen Hundreds by Indians.

SOUTH MPTON, L. I., July 6 -- Plans are being completed for the ball to be held on the night of July 18 at the Elks clubhouse here to assist the Navy Relief Society. There will be divertissements by professionals who have contributed their services.

The claim of Alice Jones, former wife of Leonard Kip Rhinelander, that the estate of her late husband's father, Philip Rhinelander, was obliged under the terms of a 1930 property agreement to pay her life annuities of $3,600 was ordered rejected yesterday by the Appellate Division in Brooklyn.

An appeal to owners of truck fleets and industrial plants to volunteer service of their vehicles for collection of scrap rubber was made yesterday by Eugene F. McCabe, local director of the oil industry's salvage committee. He reported that yesterday's scrap weighed at bulk plants amounted to 207 tons, increasing the citywide cumulative figure to 4,515 tons.

The power of the American League flashed for only a few fleeting moments at the Polo Grounds last night, but, coupled with brilliant hurling, sufficed to sink the National League, 3 to 1, in the tenth All-Star offering of the major baseball circuits before a crowd of 33,694 that contributed $95,000 to the Bat and Ball Fund for the armed services.

Because of the great prestige which he still commands with his countrymen it is good news that Gandhi has come around to the view that "foreign troops [that is, British and American] are necessary to the defense of India." Only a little while ago he was against such intervention.

BUENOS AIRES, Argentina, July 6 -- Germany has acknowledged responsibility for the sinking of the Argentine freighter Rio Tercero, torpedoed by a submarine off the United States coast June 22, according to a summary, made public here today by Foreign Minister Enrique Ruiz Guinazu, of a German note delivered June 30 in reply to Argentina's protest about the sinking.

LONDON, July 6 -- Viscount Halifax, British Ambassador to Washington, conferred with Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden at the Foreign Office here today less than twenty-four hours after he arrived in Britain for his first visit home since the United States entered the war.

Probably Michael Warren, 7 years old, wasn't so far wrong when he decided yesterday that an insecticide sprayer was an excellent weapon to use on the Japanese. But the police and his parents ruled that he was a little young to join the fighting forces.

BERLIN, July 6 (From German broadcasts recorded by The Associated Press) -- The High Command reported today that in Egypt the battle "for the El Alamein position is progressing." Military informants added that "the enemy has managed to bring up strong reserves."

BUFFALO, N.Y., July 6 (AP) -- Buffalo derailed the Jersey City Giants tonight, 4 to 3, but the visitors backed into the International League lead despite the defeat. Newark, erstwhile leader, dropped a pair to Montreal and skidded to second.
CHUNGKING, July 6 (AP) -- The Chinese High Command issued the following communique today:

Senator Charles L. McNary is a longtime friend of the farmer. He is also the Republican leader of the Senate. When he supports the President's demand that Congress permit the Government to sell some of its surplus wheat for livestock feeding at prices below "parity" it is clearly because he believes that the national interests demand this permission.

The proposal of the Board of Education, as announced by James Marshall, chairman of its law committee, that State aid for education be "pegged" at $118,500,000, was supported in principle yesterday by spokesmen for the Public Education Association and the Joint Committee of Teachers Organizations.

I am a sailor in the United States Navy and I want to express my thanks to the many thousands of contributors to the USO. Without this service there would be many a dull evening for the men in the service.

WASHINGTON, July 6 -- A Fourth of July raid by United States submarines on Japanese forces in the enemy-occupied western end of the Aleutian Islands resulted in the sinking of three Japanese destroyers and the setting afire of a fourth, the Navy Department reported today.

Frederic R. Coudert Jr., one of the leading members of the State Senate, faces a bitter fight for re-election, it was indicated yesterday with the disclosure that leaders of the left wing of the American Labor Party planned to endorse his Democratic opponent, Jerry Finkelstein, in the Seventeenth Senatorial district.
