The week-old strike of 250 building service employes, members of the Building Service Employes Union, Local 32-E, at Parkchester, the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company's housing development in the East Tremont section of the Bronx, spread yesterday when 160 painters, members of the Brotherhood of Painters, and forty-eight electrical workers, affiliated with the Electrical Workers Union, Local 3, joined in sympathy by refusing the pass the strikers' mass picket lines.

CHUNGKING, Tuesday, July 7 -- China's unconquered 400,000,000 plunged with mounting confidence today into their sixth year of war, spurred by Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek's declaration that the United States was "bound to deal with her first and most threatening enemy, Japan," and was "beginning to discharge her supremely important duty in the Pacific."

WASHINGTON, July 6 -- A reorganization of the War Production Board which will take all control of raw materials out of the hands of the armed services and free Chairman Donald M. Nelson for international as well as national industrial planning will be announced tomorrow.

Sensing defeat of the Bankhead bill granting loans on major crops at full parity in the reported disapproval of Vice President Wallace and the denunciation of the measure in the Senate by Senator McNary, commission houses and Wall Street poured considerable selling pressure into the cotton futures market yesterday, depressing active months on the New York Cotton Exchange throughout the session and leaving them with final net losses of 14 to 23 points.
GOSHEN, N.Y., July 6 (AP) - Horses from the stable of Ebby Gerry, New York State Racing Commissioner now in the Army Air Corps, dominated the curtailed Grand Circuit program today.

MEXICO CITY, July 6 (AP) -- Conversion of peacetime industry to war manufacturing will deprive United States citizens of "anything beyond the essentials of living" while a shortage of shipping is causing the piling up of surpluses that cannot be moved between countries in the Western Hemisphere, United States Secretary of Agriculture, Claude R. Wickard, told the Inter-American Agricultural Conference tonight.

Dr. Alfonso Lopez, President-elect of Colombia, is scheduled to leave here today for Washington to open the official phase of his visit to the United States by calling on President Roosevelt at the White House.

GARDEN CITY, L.I., July 6 -Mrs. William Patty and Jimmy Hines of the Lakeville Club posted a score of 80 -- 8 -- 72 to win the first woman-pro tournament of the Long Island P.G.A. season at the Garden City Country Club today.

Pressure on transportation has forced Great Britain to introduce a zoning system for the distribution of products, a step which may eventually become necessary in this country, William B.B. Fergusson, managing director of Lord Thomas, Ltd., London, said yesterday at a press conference.
Nine thousand students from all parts of the country will attend today the first classes in Columbia University's forty-third Summer session.
For the second time in thirty-one days, New York City lay last night in total darkness.

LONDON, July 6 (U.P.) -- Italian authorities have slain 800 Croatian peasants and burned six villages to the ground near Fiume, on the Italian-Yugoslav border, in savage reprisal for increased resistance by General Draja Mikhailovitch's patriot armies, a Yugoslav spokesman charged today.

WASHINGTON, July 6 -- Paul V. McNutt, chairman of the War Man Power Commission, today made public a list of 138 occupations essential to war production in which workers are eligible for, although not guaranteed, draft deferment.

Gerhard Wilhelm Kunze, the German-American Bund leader captured in Mexico and wanted in Hartford, Conn., on espionage charges, was held in $50,000 bail following his arraignment in the United States District Court here yesterday before Judge George C. Sweeney.

Fall activity in the wholesale markets here increased yesterday in comparison with the slack business in June as many buyers representing stores throughout the country arrived to begin purchasing for the new season.
WASHINGTON, July 6 -- A message of greeting on Independence Day received by President Roosevelt from Edward Benes, President of the Czecho-Slovak republic, in London, read:

MONTREAL, July 6 (AP) -- Montreal clawed back at Newark tonight, wresting both ends of the twilight-night double-header, and toppling the Bears from the league lead. The score in the opener was 4 -- 1, and in the nightcap 7 -- 3.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 6 -- Paramount has announced that Vera Zorina, who has been tested repeatedly for the role during the last two weeks, will play Maria in "For Whom the Bell Tolls" with Gary Cooper. According to the studio, Miss Zorina has cut her hair to two inches in length, as the Ernest Hemingway story requires, and she will join the company, which is on location in the High Sierras, this week.

MOSCOW, July 6 (U.P.) -- Russian propaganda units are erecting signboards covered with anti-Hitler slogans and cartoons along the front lines facing the Germans, and are bombarding the Germans from the air with German-language handbills detailing the hopelessness of the Axis cause, the official Soviet news agency, Tass, said today.

PANAMA, July 6 -- The possibility of President-elect Alfonso Lopez of Colombia and President Roosevelt exploring the question of a declaration of war by Colombia against the Axis countries as a result of the menace of Nazi submarines in waters south of the Panama Canal is a subject of speculation here.

Wendell L. Willkie and J. Robert Rubin sent an urgent appeal to companies in the amusement and sports fields yesterday to support the 1942 campaign of the Greater New York Fund. The appeal was directed particularly to motion-picture, radio, theatre and sports enterprises.

WASHINGTON, July 6 (AP) -- At Agattu Island, where the Navy reported today the sinking of one of the Japanese destroyers bagged in the submarine raid Saturday in the Aleutians, an American air patrol last Thursday discovered three Japanese transports with escorting vessels.

Ralph Ingersoll, editor of PM, newspaper owned by Marshall Field, has asked that the question of his induction into the Army under selective service be handled by an "impartial board." He made the request in an open letter addressed to his selective service board, which is published in three pages of PM today.
CANBERRA, Australia, July 6 -- Prime Minister John Curtin on the fifth anniversary of the war in China said:

WEST POINT, N.Y., July 6 -- King Peter of Yugoslavia rode in an army jeep, had lunch with two high-ranking upper classmen and reviewed the corps of cadets of the military academy during a five-hour visit to West Point today.

The Chinese Ambassador climbed upon a shaky chair and painted the symbol for "Mei-ling" (the first name of Mme. Chiang Kai-shek) on the Moon Gate, and the Chinese Consul General blandly discussed the advisability of chopping off Emperor Hirohito's head, as the old Japanese Garden in Rockefeller Plaza was rededicated yesterday with Chinese trimmings.

CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va., July 6 -- Building in war for peace was discussed at today's opening sessions of the Institute of Public Affairs at the University of Virginia by Dean G. Acheson, assistant secretary of State, and Sir Clive Baillieu, K.B.E., C.M.G., British representative on the combined raw materials board and head of the British raw materials mission to the United States.

CHICAGO, July 6 -- The wheat market felt today the full effect of the big after-harvest movement of the new crop in the Southwest and prices on the Board of Trade dropped 2 1/4 cents a bushel from Friday's finish before the break was checked.

WASHINGTON, July 6 -- Preparations, apparent to any visitor, gave almost positive proof today that the trial of the eight Nazi saboteurs before the military commission, would be held in the Department of Justice Building.

Mrs. Darrell Hamric of Locust Valley, L.I., gave a luncheon yesterday at the Trouville for Mrs. Edgar L. Marston 2d of Washington. Other guests were Mrs. William Clyde, Mrs. W. Mahlon Dickerson, Mrs. Andrew Duncan MacIntosh and Mrs. Bromley S. Stone.

WITH BRITISH EIGHTH ARMY, in Egypt, July 7 -- Today I saw what must be the strangest mascot cherished by any unit in the Western Desert -- a rooster that has been adopted by a South African medical dressing station.
WASHINGTON, July 7 -- President Roosevelt indicated today that he was opposed to a general wage increase in the steel industry because it would increase the cost of living.

WASHINGTON, July 7 -- The President's offhand discussion of rubber conservation at his press conference today left many of his hearers confused, and this confusion necessarily will be spread among the people by the reporters of the press and the radio.

PHILADELPHIA, July 7 (AP) -- Lightweight Champion Sammy Angott, Louisville, mauled his way to a twelve-round split decision over Bob Montgomery, Philadelphia, tonight in a non-title scrap at Shibe Park before 16,060 paying spectators.
The Ballet Russe de Monte Carlo opened its final series of three performances at the Lewisohn Stadium last night before the largest ballet audience of the Summer season.

CHICAGO, July 7 -- Sales of men's clothing at retail rebounded during June but the retailers remained pessimistic over the outlook for the remainder of the year, according to the monthly business conditions report of the National Association of Retail Clothiers and Furnishers.

WASHINGTON, July 7 -- Congress passed stop-gap legislation today to let the Department of Agriculture have funds for July, pending settlement of the controversy between the House and Senate over the selling rate for government-held surpluses of wheat and corn.

WASHINGTON, July 7 -- The oil shortage on the Eastern seaboard was attacked from three angles today. Secretary Ickes, Petroleum Coordinator, said he had asked the War Production Board to approve a $30,000,000 pipe line relocation program which would bring 200,000 more barrels of oil daily to the East coast.
Mayor La Guardia announced the names of twenty-five physicians yesterday who volunteered as assistant medical examiners to aid in the treatment and identification of victims of possible air raids.

NOROTON, Conn., July 7 -- The proceeds from the All Nations festival, which will be held on Saturday afternoon on the estate here of William Ziegler, will be divided among United War Reliefs. It will be the first time in five years that the annual Summer event will assist a charity other than St. Luke's Episcopal Church.

Government cannot change its objective any more than a single business can without great shifts in leadership, Oswald W. Knauth, president of the Associated Dry Goods Corporation, said last night at the industry-wide clinic of the Boys Apparel Buyers Association at the Waldorf-Astoria.

The Reynolds Tobacco Company has almost completed arrangements for a "stand-by" credit of $75,000,000 from a group of banks in New York, Chicago and other cities, it was learned yesterday. The arrangements do not contemplate immediate use of the funds, it was said.

Renewal of the war between the left and right wings of the American Labor party and opposition to several Representatives whose pre-Pearl Harbor record was isolationist were reflected in the designating petitions filed with the Board of Elections last night. Midnight was the closing time for filing petitions for the primary on Aug. 11.

WASHINGTON, July 7 -- Foreshadowing an early start of a mighty new phase of anti-submarine warfare in American waters, the Navy announced today the invention of a lightweight, highspeed Diesel engine made especially for use in submarine chasers and already in mass production.
In three far-flung areas -- Russia, Egypt and the Aleutians -- the enemy was threatening encroachments yesterday upon territory that is vital to victory.

On June 20 the Children's Village graduated fifty-five boys in a dignified ceremony under the great elms of the campus at Dobbs Ferry. These youngsters received their diplomas with justifiable pride, for graduation from the Village means that they have mastered some genuine lessons in living.

Harry M. Prince, chief civilian protection adviser of the Office of Civilian Defense, has taken issue with the statement of Percy Bugbee, general manager of the National Fire Protection Association, that British fire fighters have come to the conclusion that the stirrup pump is "time-wasting and labor-wasting" in fighting incendiary bombs, which was published in THE NEW YORK TIMES of May 8.

WASHINGTON, July 7 -- The first Order of the Day to be issued by the Secretaries of War and Navy since Dec. 7 today paid special tribute to the Chinese on the fifth anniversary of their resistance against the Japanese aggression And pledged "firm determination to expel the aggressor from every foot of Chinese soil."
LONDON, July 7 -- The stock market continued cheerful today on better news from the battle areas in Egypt. Gilt-edge securities continued in demand at 1s 16d to 1s 18d higher. Home rails improved.

Sheriff John J. McCloskey Jr., who has been gaining a wide reputation as "the crusading Sheriff," yesterday followed up his policy of reducing operating expenses by temporarily closing the Queens civil prison on the top floor of the five-story building housing the Queens city prison in Long Island City.

Civilian defense workers in this vicinity must have been interested in the report which has at last come through of the way their fellow air wardens and the like behaved at Unalaska and Dutch Harbor on June 3. According to Mayor John W. Fletcher of Unalaska, his little force of white men and natives "deliberately exposed themselves, standing in the open amid the din of bombs and anti-aircraft fire, to spot incendiary bombs."

The Citizens Union, through its chairman, Richard S. Childs, started action in Supreme Court yesterday to force Park Commissioner Robert Moses and Public Works Commissioner Irving V.A. Huie to give up their positions as members of the City Planning Commission on the ground that they have no right to hold "dual jobs."

Dr. George D. Strayer, Professor of Education at Teachers College and one of the country's foremost educational administrators, has been retained by the Rapp-Coudert committee to survey the financial aspects of the New York City school system, Senator Frederic R. Coudert Jr., chairman of the legislative subcommittee, announced yesterday.

WITH THE EIGHTH ARMY, in Egypt, July 6 (delayed) -- The continued domination of British and South African aircraft, the reassuring streaming up of reinforcements and the whittling down of enemy tank strength at this crucial juncture warrant a bright view.

Several thousand persons attended a noon-day rally on the steps of Brooklyn Borough Hall yesterday at which Mayor La Guardia and Borough President John Cashmore pleaded for funds for the borough drive of the USO. The program,

BUENOS AIRES, July 7 -- Foreign Minister de Ruiz Guinazu confirmed today that the case of the sinking of the Rio Tercero was now closed, Argentina being satisfied with the German explanations, apologies and promise to pay damages. Whether Congress shares his opinion will become known July 15, when the Foreign Minister is to appear before the Chamber of Deputies to answer an interpellation.

WASHINGTON, July 7 -- Further indication of the growth of American air power in the British Isles developed here today with the appointment of Major Gen. Carl A. Spaatz as commander of United States Air Force in Europe.

After long weeks of negotiations with his German master, Pierre Laval announces to the French people: "Five thousand of our prisoners are ready to return." He does not say that they are on their way home from the prison camps where they have slaved or rotted for two years.

Control stations, operating under the Metropolitan Defense Transport Committee, scattered throughout Connecticut, New Jersey and New York, received their first message yesterday advising them that strategic areas in New York City had been "blocked off."

WASHINGTON, July 7 -- President Roosevelt divided by Executive Order today the duty of administering the property of enemy, neutral and occupied countries and their nationals between Secretary Morgenthau and Leo T. Crowley, Alien Property Custodian.

With an army of 50,000 volunteer women recruited by the Office of Civilian Defense, the Office of Price Administration today will launch a three-day educational canvass in five States, including New York and the District of Columbia, to acquaint 450,000 retailers with the provisions of the general maximum price regulation of OPA.

Net assets of the Lehman Corporation on June 30 were $49,768,843, equivalent to $25.09 on each of the 1,983,977 shares in the hands of the public. On June 30, 1941, the end of the previous fiscal year, net assets were equal to $28.77 a share.

Twenty of the approximately 200 maintenance employes on strike at Parkchester, the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company's housing development in the East Tremont section of the Bronx, returned to work yesterday and received a $2 weekly increase in wages, it was announced by Frank Lowe, resident director of the project.

The six-foot-tall iron picket fence, 400 feet long, which the city Parks Department has just finished erecting around Gracie Mansion in Carl Schurz Park has "no value" as scrap iron in the salvage campaign for war materials, Parks Commissioner Robert Moses declared yesterday.

THE men of Vichy are traitors, opportunists, convinced Fascists, collaborators, allies and admirers of Adolf Hitler. In their eyes the Free French are the traitors and the rebels. But it is the Free French who nobly and unselfishly are carrying on the good fight, who will redeem France and, aided by their allies, liberate the vast majority of their countrymen who are their ardent sympathizers.

CLEVELAND, July 7 -- Darkness scarcely had settled over Cleveland's mammoth Municipal Stadium tonight when jolting Joe DiMaggio received his first quota of this community's version of the Bronx cheer.

Visiting buyers registered in the market for the week ended yesterday numbered 836, which compared with 922 in the preceding week and 1,185 in the similar period a year ago, according to the listings in THE NEW YORK TIMES. Yesterday's registrations totaled 542, as against 247 for last Tuesday.

LONDON, July 7 -- Two spies, one of whom, a British subject born at Gibraltar, had given information to the enemy about British military activities on and around the famous fortress guarding the western gateway to the Mediterranean, and the other a Belgian who was caught in this country before he could do any mischief, went to the gallows today at Wandsworth prison.

Memories of forty years ago in this city when speeding and other traffic violations applied almost exclusively to bicyclists were recalled in the Downtown Traffic Court yesterday when Magistrate Alfred L. Lindau imposed a $1 fine on a youth for riding his bicycle after dark without a light.

LONDON, July 7 -- British propaganda, long a matter of concern as well as a subject for jests in this country, ran the parliamentary gantlet in the House of Commons today. In the debate one of the few topics arousing genuine interest was the handling of relations with the United States.

Questioning of 300 refugee passengers from Europe who were removed from the Swedish liner Drottningholm to the immigration station on Ellis Island continued yesterday, and hearings will be held daily until all cases have been decided.

LONDON, July 7 -- The manner in which the power of the Royal Air Force and the army is harnessed together in time of battle was outlined today in the House of Commons by Prime Minister Churchill when he was asked whether or not General Sir Claude J.E. Auchinleck had direct command over aircraft fighting in Egypt.

CHICAGO, July 7 (AP) -- Producers cent more hogs into the livestock market today, encouraged by the 16-year peak scored yesterday, and prices broke sharply. With 17,000 head offered for sale, buyers would take offerings only at mark-downs ranging from 25 to 40 cents. One load sold at $14.85 early, but nothing got above $14.75 in later trade.

The bonds of friendship existing between Verlin Jenkins, better known as Lew Jenkins, former lightweight champion, and his admirer and protege, Marvin Lee Kennedy, 17-year-old Texas youth, will be more firmly cemented when they both sign up to fight in Uncle Sam's Navy.
MOSCOW, July 7 (AP) -- The Soviet Information Bureau issued this communique today:

The government called on the railroads of the country yesterday to expedite the collection of salvage along their rights-of-way, particularly unused rails, of which 40,000,000 lineal feet are needed immediately by the Army, Navy and Maritime Commission.

MONTREAL, July 7 (AP) -- George Washburn did his best to give Montreal an International League ball game today, but the Royals were reluctant to take it and Newark won the rubber game of the five-game series, 5 -- 1.

ORANGE, N.J., July 7 -- Sidney B. Wood Jr. of Southampton, the ranking player in the Eastern Association, was beaten in the third round of the New Jersey State championship at the Berkeley Tennis Club today.

Aggregate short interest on the New York Stock Exchange fell last month from 534,396 shares at the end of May to 514,158 on June 30, neither figure including the short positions in the odd-lot accounts of odd-lot dealers. These fell from 65,434 to 52,059 shares.

WASHINGTON, July 7 (AP) -- Representative Ploeser reported tonight on the work of House and Senate committees set up to aid small business and appealed over a Columbia Broadcasting System network for public support of their efforts.

LAKE PLACID, N.Y., July 7 -- All the favorites advanced, some of them by exceptionally wide margins, as the first round of match play in the thirteenth annual women's New York State golf championship was completed over the lower course of the Lake Placid Club today.

BREMERTON, Wash., July 7 (AP) -In the Japanese attack on Pearl Harbor, Lieut. Comdr. Francis J. Thomas found himself the senior surviving officer of a bombed, flaming warship. He promptly took command, ran a gauntlet of flame, bombs and gunfire and saved the vessel from destruction.

CAIRO, Egypt, July 7 -- The active stage of the battle of El Alamein is over and both sides appear to be concentrating on preparations instead of attempting to gain an advantage by attacking with battle groups or armored units. Part of this preparation precipitated a rather determined artillery duel, which continued with varied intensity throughout the day.

Wendell L. Willkie, in a surprise appearance last night at a China Resistance Day Rally at Town Hall, told 1,000 persons he regretted that this country had been giving China more words than action and that he hoped by the next anniversary of the outbreak between China and Japan five years ago the situation would be the other way around.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, July 7 -Business Manager Cohn of the Copenhagen National Tidende has been forced by the Germans to resign, travelers from Copenhagen report. He was alleged to have refused to accept the announcement of the death of the leader of the Danish Legion, von Schalburg, killed in action on the Eastern Front.
BERLIN, July 7 (From German broadcasts recorded by The Associated Press) -- The German High Command issued the following communique today:

The law of averages caught up with the form players at Empire City yesterday when two long shots and a daily double that, aided by one of the long shots, paid $368.80, shattered the routine procession of favorites which had sent the winning average to 55 per cent with the close of racing on Monday.

WASHINGTON, July 7 (AP) -- In a severe retrenchment to bring its activities into line with reduced appropriations, the National Youth Administration stated today that it would close all its State offices.

WASHINGTON, July 7 -- Donald M. Nelson, chairman of the War Production Board, wrote today to 25,000 of the largest users of typewriters, asking them to sell to the Army and Navy as many machines as could be spared.

Federal regulations fixing ceilings on retail prices are not legal barriers in suits to enforce minimum resale prices under the State Fair Trade Law, Supreme Court Justice Morris Eder ruled yesterday.

CLEVELAND, July 7 -- The American League baseball team tried to repeat its first-inning feat of last night, but missed by one run tonight against the Army-Navy team. The leaguers tallied three times in the opening frame at the Polo Grounds and tonight they got off to a 2-0 lead.

Two new films will arrive in Broadway houses this morning. "Are Husbands Necessary?" Paramount's screen adaptation of the novel "Mr. and Mrs. Cugat," will be the new attraction at the Paramount. Ray Milland and Betty Field are starred in the comedy.

The Fourth of July has been a high moment in the history of our country for 166 years. It has signified that for the preservation of which we pledged "our lives, our fortunes and our sacred honor." This year the anniversary has become the devout aspiration of the free peoples of the earth, and was celebrated not only by Americans throughout the world but no less earnestly by the United Nations.
WASHINGTON, July 7 (AP) -Nine Army nurses, wearing hurriedly purchased Summer frocks, were decorated today for bravery under fire in the Philippines.

Police Commissioner Valentine announced yesterday important promotions in his department, notably the appointment of Chief Inspector Louis F. Costuma as first deputy commissioner to succeed John J. Seery, whose resignation became effective yesterday.
CHUNGKING, China, July 7 (AP) -- The Chinese High Command issued this communique today:

With a solid tug at one of the spikes in the sixty-six-year-old structure of the Second Avenue elevated, Mayor La Guardia began the demolition of the line yesterday from Fifty-ninth Street south to Chatham Square.

CHUNGKING, Wednesday, July 8 (U.P.) -- Allied planes -- possibly belonging to the United States Army Air Forces -- marked the end of the fifth year of the war in China Monday with the second raid in three days on Canton, main Japanese base in South China, the official Chinese Central News Agency said today.
Trying to see everything and everybody in New York in two days, the four British Boy Scouts who arrived here Monday spent another busy day yesterday.

WASHINGTON, July 7 -- The Commerce Department announced today that total sales during 1941 of 275 credit-granting department stores increased 16.5 per cent compared with 1940. Open-credit sales increased 16.2 per cent compared with 1940, installment sales advanced 16.5 per cent and cash sales 18.6 per cent.

Application was made by Grenville T. Emmet Jr., attorney of 48 Wall Street, in Supreme Court yesterday for the appointment of a guardian at law for the twelve grandchildren of President and Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt in an accounting proceeding of a trust established Nov. 17, 1922, by Mrs. Roosevelt's brother, the late G. Hall Roosevelt.

CLEVELAND, July 7 -- On a field marked by the tread of marching soldiers, sailors and marines, the All-Stars of the American League, triumphant last night in New York over the National League, came back tonight to bury the All-Service stars of Lieutenant Gordon Stanley (Mickey) Cochrane under a 5-to-0 whitewashing in Municipal Stadium.

It is said that the canning season used to begin in France when certain capacious copper kettles made their appearance in well-equipped kitchens. These utensils -- so highly polished that one could see one's face reflected on the surface -- were considered requisite in perfecting preserves.
CAIRO, Egypt, July 7 (AP) -- A joint British General Headquarters and R.A.F. communique today said:

LONDON, July 7 -- Outstanding exploits at sea, on land and in the air brought awards today to a large number of navy, army and air force heroes, including the Victoria Cross -- Britain's highest decoration for valor -- to a 36-year-old Scottish submarine commander, the Military Cross to a Commando officer and a bar to the Distinguished Flying Cross won a few weeks ago by a young Czech night fighter pilot.
I think that your correspondent Gridley Adams in correcting Major Raborg's statement about the genesis of the tank is himself a victim of a faulty memory.

CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va., July 7 -- The necessity for winning a hard-fought war and of assuming the burden and responsibility of leadership in the post-war reconstruction of the world is the obligation and destiny of the United States, Senator Thomas of Utah and William Yandell Elliott of the materials division of the War Production Board, told members and guests of the Institute of Public Affairs at the university of Virginia today.

" Garden-fresh" faces are the specialty of a young Russian cosmetician who brings us beauty out of the berry patch. Sun-ripened strawberries, freshly plucked, are crushed and stirred into her pink satin-like cream.

DES MOINES, Iowa, July 7 (U.P.) -- Colonel Donald C. Faith, commandant of the Women's Army Auxiliary Corps training school, announced plans today for training 330 privates in addition to the 440 officer candidates.

The stock market turned yesterday slightly reactionary in what brokers are accustomed to term a technical reaction. Unsupported by any outstanding news from the various war theatres, the share list eased moderately under slight pressure, although the selling failed to assume proportions even mildly dangerous.

ALBANY, July 7 (AP) -- Assessment rates are increased in twenty-nine counties and are pared in five under a new State equalization table disclosing a $275,152,353 loss last year in assessed valuation of real property and issued today by the State Tax Commission, sitting as a State Board of Equalization.

" No blocks were used in the making of this collection," said Walter Florell yesterday afternoon as he announced his Fall hat styles. "All were made by cutting and manipulating materials and by inserting sections here and there. It's really a tailoring job."

Hubert Pierlot, Prime Minister of the Belgian Government in exile, who had denounced King Leopold's capitulation to the Nazis on May 28, 1940, as "illegal and unconstitutional" and since had accused him of "disdainful silence toward the enemy," appeared yesterday to have moderated his attitude toward the monarch, a virtual prisoner in Nazi hands in Laeken Castle, near Brussels.

Plans for an intensive last-minute drive to increase the collection of scrap rubber in this city before the end of the campaign on Friday at midnight were made yesterday at a meeting of representatives of the oil industry and the War Production Board in the Chanin Building.

PERHAPS the tenth annual All-Star game at the Polo Grounds the other night was not the best or the most thrilling of the series but in many respects it will rank as the most memorable of them all. For one thing it had a more unusual setting than any of its illustrious predecessors.

BERLIN, July 7 (From German broadcasts recorded in New York) -- German planes and submarines sank a heavy United States cruiser and twenty-eight out of thirty-eight merchant ships in a Russia-bound convoy off Northern Norway last week, the German High Command said today.
LONDON, Wednesday, July 8 -- Royal Air Force activity last night was confined to mine-laying in enemy waters. Two bombers were lost.

BAGHDAD, Iraq, July 7 -- A few hours from Jerusalem eastward stands Amman, the desert capital of Trans-Jordan. It is seething with excitement, as is the entire Arab world, over the latest news from the Western Desert.
LONDON, July 7 -- Major Gen. Spaatz, who was here during the Battle of Britain as an observer, has arrived here to take command of the United States Air Forces in Europe.
WASHINGTON, July 7 -- The government may have to requisition every automobile tire in the United States if the war situation gets worse, President Roosevelt said at his press conference today.
LONDON, July 7 (AP) -- A joint communique of the Air Ministry and the Ministry of Home Security said today:

CHICAGO, July 7 -- Sears, Roebuck Co. reported today that sales in June dropped nearly $9,500,000, or 12 per cent, from June, 1941. Volume for the five months through June declined more than $4,000,000, or 1.1 per cent, from the corresponding period a year ago.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 7 -- The possibility that Orson Welles and his Mercury Productions will join United Artists appeared today, when a Welles representative disclosed that negotiations for such a deal are under way with U.A. executives who have arrived in Hollywood to map out plans for bolstering United's production prospect for the coming year.

The War Production Board is adopting a policy of allowing free rein in the building up of inventories of materials in ample supply in order to avoid a transportation bottleneck in the Fall, it was indicated yesterday. Previously, Priority Regulation No. 1 had specified that inventories be kept to a practicable working minimum, and only four products had been exempted from its provisions.

Before her collapse Poland had 1,500 small plants that made alcohol from farm products. Germany is said to have about 36,000 and Russia an unknown but large number. In all these European countries the refuse of the distillery has long been used as cattle fodder, the alcohol as a motor fuel or as the raw material for the production of synthetic rubber.

WASHINGTON, July 7 -- President Roosevelt disclosed today that he was ready to support any liberal candidate for Governor of New York provided that the candidate supported the President's war policies 100 per cent before Pearl Harbor.

ALBANY, July 7 -- All State buildings in urban centers, especially where war production activities are conducted, are now protected by bond insurance, Governor Lehman said tonight in announcing that a "binder" had been placed covering these structures.

TAMPICO, Mexico, July 7 (U.P.) -- General Anacleto Guerrero, military zone commander, said today that planes of the Mexican Air Force attacked an Axis submarine in the Gulf of Mexico thirty miles north of Tampico last Sunday.

WASHINGTON, July 7 -- The trial of the eight Nazi saboteurs recently landed from German submarines is scheduled to open tomorrow in the Department of Justice Building although tonight officials refused even to confirm that the secret inquiry would begin.

CHICAGO, July 7 -- Participants in meetings held here today in connection with the mid-Summer furniture shows heard a forecast of an earlier and shorter 1943 Summer market than had hitherto been announced and warnings that supplies of many lines of consumer goods would be further reduced.

If waste is to be avoided in advertising, management should develop a definite war policy, change it as times indicate, but stick to its broad outlines, according to a booklet entitled "Fifty-seven Ways to Plug Wartime Profit Leaks," issued yesterday by Lewis Advertising Agency, 17 Academy Street, Newark, N.J.

PITTSBURGH, July 7 -- Representative Samuel A. Weiss of Glassport informed authorities here today that he would demand a Congressional investigation of Army War Shows, Inc., and what he called its "outrageous" contracts with concessionnaires.

CHICAGO, July 7 -- Strength in cotton which grain traders regard as forecasting adoption of the 100 per cent of parity program by the Senate, combined with a let-up in hedging pressure, resulted in wheat prices advancing around 1 cent in the early trading today.

Sometimes it is difficult to give advice and on some occasions it is more difficult to accept it. But the recently organized Atlantic States Marine Fisheries Commission expects to have a diversified advisory committee upon whom will rest a full measure of responsibility.

Births in New York City so far this year indicate that 1942 will see the greatest number of babies born here since 1930, Acting Health Commissioner George T. Palmer predicted yesterday. Dr. Palmer said 59,996 births had been recorded for the first six months, a total last exceeded for the corresponding period in 1930, when 62,120 children appeared.

Many member banks of the Federal Reserve Banks in New York City and in a few other large cities as well have been busy this week in bolstering their reserve positions. One of the favorite methods is to sell out short-term government securities, chiefly Treasury bills, and, to a lesser extent, Treasury certificates of indebtedness.
Registration under the permanent gasoline rationing system will begin at 330 public schools in the city tomorrow morning, for the basic A ration book that contains a year's supply of coupons.

" Who's On the Lord's Side? Who?" is the catching title of Pierre van Paassen's new book which Dial will publish in the Fall. The publisher had announced previously that Mr. van Paassen's next book would be a novel, but now advises that the forthcoming volume will be non-fiction and will deal almost entirely with the American scene.

Listing three courses that this city might take to lessen its financial problems, the Citizens Budget Commission said yesterday that the municipality either could develop new sources of revenue, institute an immediate policy of economy or face curtailment of some services.

PHILADELPHIA, July 7 (AP) -- The Pennsylvania-Reading Seashore Line announced today it would provide no transportation facilities for patrons of the new $2,000,000 Camden, N.J., race track, due to open July 18.

BERLIN, July 7 (From German broadcasts recorded in New York) -- The German High Command reported today the capture of Voronezh, strategic Russian city east of the Don River on the Moscow-Rostov railway, in a 130-mile sweep eastward from Kursk.

Ralph Ingersoll, editor of PM, who yesterday charged publicly that the local draft board which classified him as 1A for speedy induction into the Army betrayed prejudice because of dislike for his newspaper policies, appeared before the board for forty minutes last night for a rehearing.

WASHINGTON, July 7 -- The American Federation of Labor cannot cooperate "all the way" with the trade union movement of Soviet Russia "because it does not recognize the Russian trade union movement as a free labor movement," according to the July issue of the monthly publication of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, of which Daniel J. Tobin is president.

WASHINGTON, July 7 -- The Treasury announced the offering today of $2,000,000,000 of 2 per cent Treasury bonds of 1949-51 to obtain new money for financing the war. The issue will be unusual in that the bonds will be issued in two forms, bearer bonds with interest coupons attached and registered bonds.

The mounting difficulties which confront the Administration and Congress in their half-hearted fight against inflation are the result partly of lack of courage, partly of lack of understanding. They are still trying to remove the symptoms of inflation while they neglect its fundamental cause.

Directors of Agnew-Surpass Shoe Stores, Ltd., declared an extra dividend of 20 cents in addition to the regular semi-annual distribution of 40 cents a common share. A similar extra was paid on Sept. 2, 1941.
The kitchen is about to become the pivot head again of the vast, economic war in which the housewife has already been drafted.

DEPARTMENT OF WELFARE Needs 400 Volunteers. Volunteers are needed to (1) visit and list vacancies in apartments, homes, etc., for use in emergency; (2) assist regular staff workers; (3) do clerical work.
GOSHEN, N.Y., July 7 (AP) -- His Excellency, a heat winner in the 1941 Hambletonian Stake, today won the 2:00 trot, unfinished feature of Monday's Grand Circuit program at Goshen Raceway.

Record purchases of United States Government bonds by life insurance companies, a drop in the rate of policy surrenders to a new low level, and a rise in life insurance in force to a new high were among the features signalizing the life insurance business in the first half of 1942, according to a midyear review by Holgar J. Johnson, president of the Institute of Life Insurance.

Helen Gleason, now appearing in "The Chocolate Soldier" at Carnegie Hall, will have the lead in "The Merry Widow," the Franz Lehar revival which Joseph S. Tushinsky and Hans Bartsch will present there next Tuesday evening.

TOKYO, July 7 (From broadcast recorded by The United Press in New York) -- The Navy Ministry, revising upward its list of what the Japanese attack on Pearl Harbor accomplished seven months ago, today asserted that twenty United States naval vessels, including nine battleships, were sunk or damaged and more than 464 planes were destroyed.
Forecasts of the Columbia University Summer session a few days ago said a majority of the students would be men. In former years four-fifths of the students were women. Most of them were teachers.

WASHINGTON, July 7 -- To stop the export by the Axis to Latin America of American dollars seized in Europe, the Uruguayan Government had conferred upon its Central Bank the exclusive right to purchase, import or export American bank notes, the Commerce Department reported yesterday.

Students are registering for the Summer session at Fordham; that of Columbia has begun. These are old friends. In a way they may be said to inherit from the Summer term of the colleges of the University of Cambridge. A new departure is the matriculation of 200 freshmen at Columbia College.

When it is said that Daniel Willard had been thirty-one years president of the Baltimore Ohio, that he was annually re-elected during the decade after he had reached in 1931 the age of 70, though he offered his resignation every year, we have an interesting character. But Mr. Willard's career was unusual in more ways than this.

A charge that the German-American Bund, although formally dissolved, always has been and still remains an agency and tool of Hitler Germany was made by United States Attorney Mathias F. Correa yesterday at the same time that a Federal grand jury returned two indictments naming twenty-nine nation-wide Bund leaders.

A mercifal judgment, meted out five years ago by Special Sessions Justice Matthew J. Troy, then a magistrate, to a young man charged with grand larceny involving the theft of an automobile, rebounded with a unique twist in Brooklyn Felony Court yesterday, but only to Justice Troy's complete surprise.

BUFFALO, July 7 (AP) -- Buffalo dealt the Jersey City Giants a body blow tonight by capturing a double victory, 5 to 4 and 10 to 9, to make it three straight and jolt the visitors out of their slender hold on first place. Both contests were won in the final inning. Pitcher Warren Sandell was charged with both losses.

A group headed by Stranahan, Harris Co., Inc., received yesterday the award of an issue of $1,279,500 of refunding bonds of the city of Toledo, Ohio, on a bid of 101.09 for 2s. The bonds, dated Aug. 1, 1942, and maturing serially from Nov. 1, 1944 to 1954, were reoffered at prices to yield from 0.80 to 1.95 per cent, according to maturity.

Sharp criticism of Thurman Arnold, assistant attorney general in charge of the anti-trust division, and of his associates in the Department of Justice because of their stand on the question of regulation of patents and their use in the nation's war program was voiced yesterday in a report submitted to the National Association of Manufacturers by George E. Folk, the association's special patent adviser.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., July 7 -- According to an announcement made today $175,000 in war bonds were subscribed in the drive held after the Independence Day parade here on Saturday. Several of the committee members have not yet turned in their pledges.

CHICAGO, July 7 -- Sharon Derer, aged 3, Chicago's "budget baby," frolicked with friends at a party on her third birthday anniversary yesterday, while her parents brought up to date the list of her expenses.

WASHINGTON, July 7 -- The resignation of Robert H. Hinckley as Assistant Secretary of Commerce has been accepted by the President, effective on July 1. Mr. Hinckley will take a post with the Sperry Corporation which he described as "work of great importance in the war production program which is closely related to aviation."

BERNE, Switzerland, July 7 -The grave menace of outright famine in many of the occupied countries of continental Europe and "food difficulties" in Germany is foreshadowed in a dispatch to tonight's Tribune de Geneve.

WASHINGTON, July 7 -- Three employer members of the War Labor Board dissented today from a decision increasing wages of New England textile workers, declaring, among other arguments, that efforts to control the cost of living through President Roosevelt's seven-point stabilization program and through effective administration of the Maximum Price Regulation order would "prove to be of much greater value to the working man than the granting of such wage advances."

SPOKANE, July 7 (AP) -- Harry Givan of Seattle, American Walker Cup team member in 1937, banged out a three under par 69 today to lead the field at the half-way mark in the thirty-six-hole qualifying trials of the 1942 Western amateur golf championship.

WASHINGTION, July 7 -- With the words "I am glad to see my old friend," President Roosevelt greeted President-elect Alfonso Lopez of Colombia today on the latter's arrival from New York for a brief White House visit.

WASHINGTON, July 7 -- Rear Admiral Frederick C. Sherman, commander of the aircraft carrier Lexington, was decorated today by Secretary Knox for conspicuous action in destroying sixteen of eighteen bombers which attacked his ship in an action prior to the fatal attack on the carrier in the Coral Sea.
OTTAWA, July 7 -- By 158 votes to 54, the Canadian House of Commons, at 10:50 this evening, voted power to the government to send conscripted men on service overseas.

A Vatican City dispatch broadcast by the German Transocean news agency and recorded last night by THE NEW YORK TIMES said that women were now allowed to enter St. Peter's Cathedral without stockings. The dispatch said this announcement was published in the Vatican organ yesterday.

A quantity of chlorine gas, inactive for twenty years, escaped from a cylindrical tank yesterday afternoon, overcame seventeen persons and drove scores of others, weeping and coughing, to shelter in stores, cellars and houses in the vicinity of Columbus Avenue and West Sixty-eighth Street.

MOSCOW, Wednesday, July 8 -The Russian High Command announced today that fierce battles were continuing west of Voronezh [claimed by the Germans], the vital rail city on the line linking Central Russia and the Caucasus, and in the Staryi Oskol sector, which is about sixty-five miles southwest of Voronezh.

Mayor La Guardia's approval of outdoor smoking by thousands of baseball fans at the Polo Grounds during the city-wide blackout Monday night was condemned yesterday by spokesmen for the Office of Civilian Defense and the Army, both of whom took issue with his contention that the light from cigars and cigarettes would not be visible to an aviator aloft.

WASHINGTION, July 7 -- With the words "I am glad to see my old friend," President Roosevelt greeted President-elect Alfonso Lopez of Colombia today on the latter's arrival from New York for a brief White House visit.

WASHINGTON, July 8 -- The Administration was reported tonight to be seriously considering the appointment of a supreme commander of all American land, sea and air forces. The names of General Marshall, Army chief of staff, and General MacArthur, were both the subject of speculation in this connection.

LONDON, July 8 -- A warning against premature consignment of the battleship to the limbo of obsolescence was sounded by Commander H. Pursey of the British Navy in an article on aircraft versus ships in Brassey's Naval Annual, a new edition of which was published yesterday.
The debutante is dead, at least for the duration, according to Miss Lucy Aldrich, a debutante herself.

BUENOS AIRES, July 8 (U.P.) -The Argentine Navigation Company, owner of the 13,000-ton tanker Victorla, which was torpedoed but not sunk by a U-boat off the United States east coast on April 17, today submitted to the Foreign Office a damage claim of $800,000 against the German Government.

Stressing the increased importance of veterinarians in inspection of meat cattle, milk producers and other livestock providing food for the armed forces and civilians, the New York and New Jersey Veterinary Medical Societies opened yesterday a three-day joint convention in the Hotel Pennsylvania. Two hundred persons attended.

May I be permitted to assure Gullie B. Goldin that if the error of the last war is repeated and there is lack of understanding between American and British soldiers the fault will not be due to any failure on the part of the governments concerned to realize the importance of this aspect of the joint war effort?

SANTIAGO, Chile, July 8 -- Chile's policy of nonbelligerence received additional backing today when the Radical party, the most important in Chile, announced it would accept the resignation of its president, Marcial Mora.

CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va., July 8 -- War and post-war strategy, in its bearing on current events and the future, was reviewed and an American foreign policy was recommended at today's sessions of the Virginia University's Institute of Public Affairs.

No pirate band was ever weighted more heavily with hardware than the groups of Boy Scouts who bore down upon astonished rivermen along the East and North Rivers yesterday and boarded barges and tugs, brandishing axes, crowbars, hacksaws and other tools.

PHILADELPHIA, July 8 -- Adoption of a rule making it possible for a person affiliated with a registered investment company acting as broker in connection with over-the-counter sales of securities to such a registered company or any controlled company to receive remuneration in excess of 1 per cent was announced today by the Securities and Exchange Commission.

With New Deal supporters of President Roosevelt trying to bring out United States Senator James M. Mead as a candidate for the Democratic nomination for Governor, it was learned yesterday that Attorney General John J. Bennett Jr. would continue as a candidate for the nomination even if it should mean a fight on the floor of the State Convention.

Prices of stocks were returned yesterday to the highest levels since last March in a large-scale rally which compared favorably with the best previously made this year. Values generally were enlarged from 1 to 3 points with some issues scoring on even a wider scale, while volume was the heaviest since early last March.

WASHINGTON, July 8 -- Close study is being given by the authorities to a process for the production of butadiene, a synthetic rubber base. The process, perfected by Eugene Houdry, is being tested in a pilot plant at Marcus Hook, Pa., by the Houdry Process Corporation, according to the War Production Board.

WASHINGTON, July 8 -- Mary Heaton Vorse's 'Time and the Town: A Provincetown Chronicle"* is a hit-or-miss affair, but at least it has an appropriate Summery feeling. It tries to be two things, the story of a house and the story of a strongly individualized community. But Mrs. Vorse, who has spent a busy, absorbed lifetime covering wars, social upheavals and labor conflict, just can't keep world events out of her chronicle.

WASHINGTON, July 8 -- A bill to authorize the construction of a barge canal across Northern Florida and at least two pipelines designed to bring 90,000 to 250,000 barrels of oil a day to the Eastern seaboard from Texas and Mississippi was reported favorably to the Senate today by the Committee on Commerce by a vote of 11 to 3.

A double wall of men and metal stands waiting in the forty-mile-wide bottleneck in the Western Desert where the decisive battle for Egypt is still to be fought. On both sides the men are sun-scorched and weary. For weeks they have fought a desperate running battle amid clouds of burning sand in a temperature that has soared as high as 135 degrees since the campaign began.

Production of steel in the first half of 1942 set a new high record of 42,570,247 net tons. This was more than 4 per cent above the 40,868,204 tons produced in the first half of 1941, the previous high for the first half of a year, and 1.4 per cent above the 41,968,742 produced in the last half of 1941, the previous best period.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 8 -- Cary Grant, screen star, and the former Miss Barbara Hutton, were married at noon today in a mountain setting at the home of Mr. Grant's agent, Frank Vincent, at Lake Arrowhead. The Rev. H. Paul Romeis of the Lutheran Church of San Bernardino, read the wedding ritual in a service which lasted six minutes.

WASHINGTON, July 8 (AP) -- The Civil Aeronautics Board ruled today that Pan American-Grace Airways, Inc., had excessive net earnings of $1,375,000 between Aug. 22, 1939, and Dec. 31, 1941, but decided against "recapture" of the amount.

Coney Island on a warm Sunday has its own congestion meter. Elsewhere in town we are solely dependent on the police estimates of the size of a throng. The police figure is the one quoted in the newspapers for Coney Island too.

WASHINGTON, July 8 (AP) -- Officials of the War Production Board and Agriculture Department, testifying today before a Senate special wool industry investigating committee, disclosed that they had been unable to agree on a proposal that the government purchase all domestic-grown wool for the duration Of the war.

Reflecting largely a sharp drop in the output in Texas, production of crude oil last week in the United States averaged only 3,297,150 barrels daily, a decline of 422,300 from the 3,719,450 in the previous week, according to the American Petroleum Institute.

ALBANY, July 8 -- Four of the five Cohen brothers who are regarded as leaders by J. Edgar Hoover, chief of the FBI, were among the first of forty-eight defendants to be arraigned today in Federal court in the alleged lottery ring accused of swindles which netted $10,000,000 a year in Eastern seaboard States.
KINGSTON, Jamaica, July 8 -- In a message opening the Legislative Council yesterday Governor Sir Arthur F. Richards indicated that certain imported foodstuffs were no longer readily available.

Judge Alfred C. Coxe ordered here yesterday a summary Judgment for $63,141 against Nathan and Benjamin Katz, art dealers who traded under the name of Firma D. Katz in Dieren, the Netherlands, in the Spring and Summer of 1939. The plaintiff in the action was Francis A. Kelly, assignee of Thomas Agnew Sons, Ltd., of London.

The gas and rubber shortage has knocked out a number of tennis tournaments and for a while it seemed that Seabright and Southampton, two of the ivy turf court fixtures, would default, but Sidney Wood has come to the rescue with an original plan that will enable them to maintain their continuity of more than half a century.

The British forces in Egypt are fighting with their backs to the wall. Desperately they are trying to retrieve their unfortunate losses at Bir Hacheim, Knightsbridge and Tobruk. To whatever may be attributed the defeat in Libya, the fact remains that if the Axis succeeds in invading the Nile Valley it will be the greatest disaster that has befallen the United Nations since the collapse of France.

The swift pace of the government's sudden drive to wipe out the stealthy network of "singing societies," sports circles and whispering campaigners that remained when the German-American Bund gave up its formal existence some months ago was maintained yesterday.

WASHINGTON, July 8 -- Edward R. Stettinins Jr., Lease-Lend Administrator, will make a special trip to Great Britain soon to study the results of the lease-lend program and discuss the future exchange of goods between the two Allies, it was learned today.

Another large audience was present last night at the Lewisohn Stadium for the performance of the Ballet Russe de Monte Carlo, and quite evidently had a good time. So much so, indeed, that it was inclined to applaud good intentions just as enthusiastically as accomplishments.

WASHINGTON, July 8 -- A United States submarine torpedoed and probably sank a Japanese destroyer in the vicinity of Kiska in the Aleutian Islands last Sunday, the Navy Department reported in a communique issued today.
BUFFALO, N.Y., July 8 (AP) -- The favored "south" defeated the "north," 6 to 1, in the first International' League all-star benefit game before 6,352 tonight.
MOSCOW, July 8 (AP) -- The Soviet Information Bureau issued this communique today:

WASHINGTON, July 8 -- Secretary Stimson has refused permission to Senator Henry Cabot Lodge Jr. to remain in the Army, it was learned tonight. Senator Lodge returned recently from Libya and Egypt, where he was an army observer, in accordance with the directive of President Roosevelt that all members of Congress in the armed services be placed on inactive duty as of July 1.

"This is no sob sister stuff," declared Mrs. Preston Davie yesterday afternoon, announcing the opening of the consultant bureau of the New York City Women's Council of the Navy League of the United States at 595 Madison Avenue.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., July 8 -Many members of the ,Sure'her ;colony are assisting in the worki room of the surgical dressing unit L for the American Hospital in England which is now being used as a base hospital for the United States Army.

PRINCETON, N.J., July 8 (AP) -- Asa Bushnell, acting director of athletics at Princeton University, announced today the 1942 Princeton-Navy and Princeton-Army football games would be played at the Yankee Stadium, New York.

LONDON, July 8 -- An ardent plea for active steps to prevent the complete extermination of the Polish nation under Reichsfuehrer Hitler's rule that has reached London from leaders of the underground movement was read yesterday at a meeting of the Polish National Council by Vice Premier Stanislaw Mikolajczyk.

A banking group headed by the Harris Trust and Savings Bank of Chicago received yesterday the award of an issue of $2,800,000 City of Cleveland, Ohio, refunding bonds in a sale marked by unusually keen competition. The city received seven bids. The successful tender was 101.159 for the bonds as 2s.

SMITHFIELD, N.C., July 8 (AP) -- Sergeant U.R. Mallard of the State Highway Patrol said tonight that he believed that nine men were killed in the crash of an Army bomber in a corn field north of here this afternoon.

LONG BRANCH, N.J., June 8 -- The condition of Walter Skula Jr., 11 months old, was reported "fair" at the Monmouth Memorial Hospital here today after an operation for the removal of a stone the baby swallowed yesterday in the yard of his parents' Summer home at Seaside Park, N.J.

OCEAN CITY, N.J., July 8 (U.P.) -- Bob Odman, third-seeded favorite from the University of Washington, was eliminated from the Atlantic Coast tennis championships today when he dropped a two-set match, 6 -- 1, 6 -- 2, to George Ball, 27-year-old school teacher from El Paso, Texas.
In response to an appeal of the War Production Board, the dairy industry of metropolitan New York organized a committee yesterday for the collection of all scrap materials useful to the war effort.

The 1,000 women volunteers who enlisted in the fight against inflation under command of the Office of Price Administration in this city went forth to battle yesterday armed with kits filled with literature which they delivered to retailers in an effort to teach them the technique and importance of price posting as a measure essential to maintaining the price ceilings set by the OPA on some 200 commodities.

LONDON, July 8 -- The stock markets today saw prevailing conditions dull. The Russian news caused cautious dealing. Gildedge issues, however, improved, the 3 per cent war loan rising to 102 1/8 and others being up 1-16 to 1/8.

A four-day-old baby girl, one of twins born on July 4, was fighting for life last night at Bellevue Hospital after a rare emergency operation. It had been discovered that her esophagus, which connects the mouth and the stomach, did not follow a normal course.

SOMEWHERE IN EGYPT, July 8 -- Flying over the Battle of Egypt is no picnic. It takes very close coordination of fighter planes, but the Germans seldom attack one unless they have greater force. They did not make contact with us while I was flying in a fast two-seater with General Martial Valin, Commander in Chief of all Free French Air Forces.

CHUNGKING, China, July 8 (AP) -- The fight for China has gone into a new phase with fierce battles swirling around two rail-line towns southwest of Nanchang, where the Japanese have struck toward Hunan in a bid for control of a second vital link of a railway system that could be extended from Shanghai to Singapore, the High Command disclosed tonight.

BERLIN, July 8 ( om German broadcasts recorded by The Associated Press) -- The sinking of four additional merchantmen in a "British-American" convoy reported attacked on the Arctic supply route to Russia was claimed today by the High Command, which said thirty-two ships of the convoy of thirty-eight had been sent to the bottom.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 8 -- Governor Olson failed today to win the permission of Lieut. Gen. John L. DeWitt, Western Defense Commander, to use Japanese from California's assembly centers to help in the harvesting of crops in the State to alleviate emergency conditions.

The Treasury's offering yesterday for cash of $2,000,000,000 of 2 per cent bonds due on Dec. 15, 1951, callable in 1949, dispelled any hopes or expectations that might have lingered in bond market circles for the old-fashioned premium of a point or more on new government issues.

Operating profits of department stores and specialty shops last year reached the record high of 5.1 per cent on sales, but about half of these profits were unrealized gains representing the rise in prices on basic inventory, according to the annual report on "Departmental Merchandising and Operating Results" of the Controllers Congress of the National Retail Dry Goods Association.
CAMDEN, N.J., July 8 (AP) -- The horses will run at the opening of the new $2,000,000 Garden State Race Track July 18 even if the only spectators are the judges.

LONDON, July 8 -- The Board of Education has asked all local school authorities to keep the schools open throughout the year. It is not an order from the board, which provides most of the money for the British schools, but merely a recommendation.

NEWARK, N.J., July 8 (AP) --Friedrich Sayle of 312 Laurel Avenue, Union, one of eight New Jersey men against whom the government filed denaturalization proceedings May 12, charging anti-American activities, said today he acted in good faith when he swore allegiance to the United States Sept. 29, 1937.

WASHINGTON, July 8 -- The Office of Price Administration, revealing tonight that this country's tea imports are only half what they were last year, suggested that the prime principle in a tea-stretching code is to measure carefully. The OPA intimates that American women are wasteful of tea.

ISTANBUL, Turkey, July 8 (U.P.) -- Allied military quarters reported today that a huge secret anti-German organization in the Hungarian Army had been smuggling arms to the Yugoslav patriot armies of General Draja Mikhailovitch as well as to Polish and Russian guerrillas operating behind the Axis lines in Russia.

WASHINGTON, July 8 (AP) -- The 1942 cotton crop may fall 1,500,000 bales short of the production goal set by Secretary of Agriculture Wickard. This prospect was indicated today by a department report that cotton in cultivation on July 1 covered 24,005,000 acres, or 3.8 per cent more than was in cultivation a year ago.

The master and one seaman of a small Latvian ship shelled and sunk by a German submarine off the Atlantic coast on June 29 were ordered aboard the submarine after their own vessel had gone to the bottom and were carried off as prisoners, accosting to survivors of the ship who have reached an East Coast port.

Additional answers to questions on Priorities Regulation No. 10, dealing with the allocation-classifications system, requiring the use of symbols on all orders, were announced yesterday by the priorities department of the Regional Office of the War Production Board.

Once more the Congressional farm bloc is playing politics at the cost of plunging the country into inflation. For several weeks the House and Senate have been deadlocked over the question of permitting the Government to sell surplus grain for livestock feeding at less than "parity" prices.

ST. LOUIS, July 8 -- Reassembled tonight after the interruption brought about by the All-Star games, the Giants were ready for the opening of their third Western swing tomorrow night against the Cardinals.
MILWAUKEE, July 8 -- The National League-leading Dodgers opened a strenuous Western tour by beating Charley Grimm's Milwaukee Brewers tonight, 7 -- 6, but nearly lost in the ninth.

WASHINGTON, July 8 -- At least 72 per cent and possibly more of the 2,000,000 men in plants with labor-management committees are members of unions, according to a survey made by War Production Drive headquarters.

Cuba, although lacking sufficient equipment, is beginning to train 100,000 men for military service, Dr. Pedro Cue, publisher of El Mundo in Havana and Professor of Law at Havana University, said yesterday in an interview at the office of Inter-American Affairs, 444 Madison Avenue.

WASHINGTON, July 8 -- The proposal to make second and third class postal services self-supporting, originally written into the pending War Revenue measure, was eliminated today by the Ways and Means Committee on recommendation of Postmaster General Walker.

Imagine the astonishment and chagrin, with which air wardens learned this morning that thousands of baseball fans at the Polo Grounds smoked throughout the blackout Monday night in the presence of Mayor La Guardia and with his approval.

Both attendance and buying at the current floor coverings market here were estimated yesterday as the lowest in the history of the industry. Only a handful of buyers and distributors was in town yesterday, as most of the manufacturers prepared to leave for Chicago, where activity was reported to be somewhat better.
CHUNGKING, China, July 8 (AP) -- Tke Okinese High, aommand oom, muniqu said today:

WASHINGTON, July 8 -- Surrounded by extraordinary secrecy, the trial of the eight Nazi agents seized by the Federal Bureau of Investigation last month on the Atlantic Coast started before the military commission at the Department of Justice Building today.

WITH THE BRITISH ARMY, in Egypt, July 7 (Delayed) -- They call almost imperceptible lines in the sands a ridge in this nearly featureless land. The earth is gray and barren, save for occasional clusters of fig trees, not yet bearing fruit, and a few palms near the sea and patches of green shrub that would scarcely keep a goat alive.

WITH THE BRITISH FLEET IN THE MEDITERRANEAN, July 8 (AP) -- Britain's Mediterranean Fleet is spreading its power over a wide area to protect United Nations supply lines and simultaneously keeping a weather eye open for any enemy attempts to reinforce desert positions through sea-borne landings.

WASHINGTON, July 8 -- A new United States 5-cent stamp, described as a "symbol of freedom of democracy in both the United States and the Orient," went on sale today. President Roosevelt and Dr. T.V. Soong, Foreign Minister of China, were the first purchasers.

ST. LOUIS, July 8 -- In the midst of a desperate drive to overtake the Dodgers, the Cardinals today sold Lean Lon Warneke to the Cubs for the waiver price of $7,500 in a deal that puzzled baseball fans.
MOSCOW, Thursday, July 9 (AP) -- The Russians acknowledged last midnight that the battered city of Staryi Oskol, sixty-five miles southwest of Voronezh, had fallen

CAIRO, Egypt, July 8 -- The German High Command seems inclined to launch its next aerial "Blitz" against Malta. Increased German raiding of the island during the past several days must be considered most significant, since every bomber and fighter that is assigned to that task must be spared from either the Russian or the Egyptian front.

MOSCOW, Thursday, July 9 -- The powerful new German battleship Tirpitz, now on the loose again from her Norwegian fjord refuge and ranging the United States-British supply route to Northern Russia, has been torpedoed twice and seriously damaged by a Russian submarine, the Russian communique announced early today.

Optimism, a chestnut daughter of Snark, piloted by Johnny Longden, was rather a surprise to the 14,588 at Empire City yesterday who again bet more than a million dollars on a seven-race week-day program. The exact figure was $1,022,540 and much of it went in on the entry of Hurriette and By Line, favored in the Demoiselle Stakes, and on Demolition, who was the heavily played second choice.

ORANGE, N.J., July 8 -- Alejo Russell of Argentina and Francisco (Pancho) Segura, the crack South American team, defeated David Smith and Edward Gilbert of Huntington, L.I., today in a second-round match in the New Jersey State tennis doubles championship at the Berkeley Tennis Club.

LONDON, July 8 -- Early this morning, for the first time in many weeks, British and German long-range guns fired at one another across the English Channel. The shelling, which opened up a little before 3 o'clock, thundered for more than an hour.

John W. Hession, as specialist for Hanson Hanson of 25 Broadway, over-the-counter brokers, was responsible for the "inside information'' that ran up defaulted mortgage bonds of the Wisconsin Central Railroad Company, doubling its market value in four months, before a 13 1/4-point "break" on June 30, Attorney General John J. Bennett made known yesterday.

Mr. and Mrs. A. Charles Schwartz gave a dinner last night in the Cafe Pierre for Mrs. David K.E. Bruce, Mrs. Thomas Hitchcock and Lauder Greenway. Mrs. Frederic Worth Goddard entertained with a luncheon in the Caprice Room of the Weylin for Mrs. Dorothy Caruso and the Misses Gloria Caruso and Jacqueline Ingram, who returned recently from Europe.

DENVER, July 8 -- With sugar-beet acreage up about 35 per cent, as compared with a 25 per cent increase for the country, the four-State intermountain beet-growing region embracing Colorado, Nebraska, Wyoming and Montana, is expected to begin harvesting in late September the largest crop in its history.

When a newspaper censors the Government, that's news. Yet this is precisely what has just happened in England. On Monday night the London Daily Mail asked the War Office not to allow it to print a story on a "new, powerful anti-aircraft device" which was scheduled to be announced yesterday.

PRINCETON, N.J., July 8 (AP) -- The retirement of Dr. George H. Shull, noted botanist, from the Princeton University faculty after twenty-seven years of teaching was announced today by Dr. Harold W. Dodds, president of the university.

Small properties figured in most of the Manhattan sales reported yesterday. One deal involved the first change of ownership for an East Side parcel in four decades. Another transaction will result in the remodeling of a West Side house into small apartments.

Warning both manufacturers and retailers of boys' clothing to observe provisions of OPA Price Regulation 177 in every detail and to "clean house" where necessary, Louis Goldsmith, president of Louis Goldsmith, Inc., Philadelphia, asserted that there was no doubt that prices would be policed.

BERNE, Switzerland, Thursday, July 9 -- Striking out with that desperation which characterized the defense of Moscow last December, Russian forces northwest of Voronezh this morning are reported to have turned the tide against the Germans on a small sector of the south-central front in a fierce counter-attack that cut off a strong German spearhead fighting toward Zadonsk.

Franklyn Fischer, 42 years old, a commercial artist who executed a number of murals which decorated buildings at the World's Fair and who is a member of the firm of Fischer Exhibits Company, Inc., of 73 Fifth Avenue, Manhattan, was placed on trial yesterday in Federal Court, Brooklyn, on a charge that he illegally installed a ship-to-shore radio on a motor boat in violation of the law prohibiting aliens from such a privilege.

A final accounting of the estate of Chauncey M. Depew, late United States Senator, filed in Surrogates Court yesterday showed a principal of $7,889,568. The accounting was made necessary by the death of his widow, Mrs. May Depew, residuary legatee.

King Peter II of Yugoslavia told Mayor La Guardia yesterday that he had been agreeably surprised when the Mayor met him at Grand Central Station last Friday because he had expected the Mayor to be busy with civic duties.

The six-story elevator apartment house on a plot 105 by 114 feet at 4064 Bronx Boulevard, southeast corner of 229th Street, the Bronx, was sold by the Val Lang Corporation through Andrew J. Kennedy and William E. Boyland, co-brokers.

With the double-barreled All-Star games out of the way, the two major leagues will resume their regular season play on eight fronts today. In the American League the Western teams will visit the East, and in the National the schedule will be reversed.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 8 --Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer today purchased "Mary Smith, U.S.A.," an unpublished novel by Mildred Cram, and assigned the property to Arthur Hornblow for production. The story deals with a Washington, D.C., white-collar girl whose sweetheart is killed in the war.

The Tirpitz was attacked in the general area where the Germans claimed that they had sunk thirty-two vessels and a heavy United States cruiser out of a thirty-eight-ship convoy carrying supplies and war material to Russia.

Fifty city-owned trucks will be added to the rubber salvage pick-up fleet and Mayor La Guardia will broadcast over municipal radio station WNYC at 9 A.M. today in an effort to make a good finish in the scrap rubber drive.

As the Office of Price Administration again stated that there would be no special sugar allotments for home jelly-making or preserving, there was speculation yesterday by consumers as to why restrictions were placed when warehouses were filled with sugar.

No one has been more astonished or gratified by the instant success of the Victory Stamp corsages placed on sale yesterday in city department stores and specialty shops than their inventor, Mrs. Douglas Gibbons.

WASHINGTON, July 8 -- The War Production Board will have the last word in determining how much of the limited supply of raw materials and finished products will be allocated to the armed forces and how much shall be retained to maintain a "slim" but efficient civilian economy, Donald M. Nelson, war production chief told reporters today.

GOSHEN, N.Y., July 8 (AP) -- The junior trotters in the $1,500 Chester Stake featured the Grand Circuit card at Goshen today and the race resulted in the defeat of the top-heavy favorite, Scarlet Hanover, winner of the Harriman Challenge Stake here last week.

Three midtown theatres will present new films this morning. At the Capitol the attraction will be "I Married An Angel." Jeannette MacDonald and Nelson Eddy are co-starred in the Metro screen version of the Rodgers and Hart stage musical, with Binnie Barnes, Edward Everett Horton, Reginald Owen and Mona Maris in featured roles.

Skeptical of the prospects of Senate-approved loans on basic crops at full parity receiving the sanction of the House and the President, the cotton trade preferred yesterday to mark time. Trading was limited, but prices moved over a relatively wide range.

It is pleasant to know that a certain coffee establishment in this city is conducting its business much as usual these days. We discovered that such was the state of affairs when we questioned the mild-mannered proprietor concerning his stocks.

WASHINGTON, July 8 -- Taking the ground that jams, jellies and fruit preserves are luxury foods because they require about one pound of sugar for each pound of fruit, the Office of Price Administration insisted today that it would not relax the sugar ration regulation governing the home consumption of sugar for making these sweets.

Smarting under the criticism of the Army and the Office of Civilian Defense for his toleration of smoking at the Polo Grounds during last Monday night's blackout, Mayor La Guardia criticized the press of the city yesterday morning before a group of police officials who went to City Hall for promotion.

The War Production Board will not have to worry about conserving shellac and other materials used in the production of records if James C. Petrillo, president of the American Federation of Musicians, has his way.

DES MOINES, Iowa, July 8 -- The first group of basic auxiliaries -- the buck privates of the Women's Army Auxiliary Corps -- must learn to be soldiers before they step into jobs like those they knew at home.

Free French Week, which will dramatize the role of the movement led by General Charles de Gaulle, started yesterday with radio addresses by the general and Wendell L. Willkie, who declared that "whatever may be the cautious and dubious diplomacy of governments, we, the people, repudiate the Laval and the Vichy collaborationists."

Danton Coelho, a member of the Brazilian Treasury delegation, has leased an apartment in 515 Park Avenue through Pease Eiliman, who also report rentals in 60 East Ninety-sixth Street to Frank Tisch; in 205 East Seventy-eighth Street to Henry D. Sforza and Dr. Emil Mandel, and in 7 Park Avenue to Arthur Sauer.
WASHINGTON, July 8 (U.P.) -- Today's report of another enemy destroyer being torpedoed in the Aleutian area was taken as evidence that the Japanese were still pressing their invasion of the islands.

WASHINGTON, July 8 -- Edward J. Flynn, Democratic National Committee chairman, discussed the New York Gubernatorial situation with President Roosevelt today, but would shed no light on whom the President favored.

PHILADELPHIA, July 8 -- Accusing three former members of the National Labor Relations Board of "prejudice, hostility and improper conduct," the Weirton Steel Company asked the Federal Circuit Court of Appeals today for a rehearing of five-year-old charges that the concern had violated the Wagner Labor Act.

The American people are too complacent for their own good and must awake to the fact that they can lose this war, said Colonel Richard C. Patterson Jr., State chairman of the War Savings Staff, at a rally for 6,000 Italian-Americans last night in Manhattan Center, on West Thirty-fourth Street, held to promote the sale of war savings bonds and stamps.

"Fire and Ice, the Art and thought of Robert Frost," is Lawrance Thompson's title for his critical study of the poet, which Henry Holt Co. will have in the bookstores early in August. Mr. Thompson says that after the publisher had accepted the book, he was, unexpectedly, able to obtain much new material and thereupon completely rewrote the study.

The letter headed War Risk Insurance Anomaly, from William Downdney Murray, conveys the impression that the cost of war-damage insurance is excessively high and, in consequence beyond the reach of those not having the ready cash.

From current indications, the men's clothing industry will engage in more aggressive advertising and promotion during the Fall than was necessary in the first half of this year, reports yesterday indicated.
