In the face of sales gains ranging as high as 75 per cent for the first six months of this year, total advertising expenditures declined.

LAKE PLACID, N.Y., July 8 -- Continuing to play the great golf that enabled her to win the qualifying medal, Miss Ann Winslow of the Cedar Lake Club, Frankfort, N.Y., easily reached the quarter-final round today as upsets marked the second round of match play in the thirteenth annual women's New York State championship on the lower course of the Lake Placid Club.
On the bus this morning I could not help overhearing the conversation between two sailors, who, surprisingly enough in these times, were discussing Socrates's famous "Apology."

CHICAGO, July 8 (AP) -- Under selling pressure for the second consecutive day, following establishment of a sixteen-year peak early this week, prices of hogs dropped today as much as 15 cents a hundred-weight. The top was $14.75, against $15 on Monday. Eastern shippers took an increased interest in good and choice steers, however, and these offerings were up 10 to 15 cents.
A new Army camp -- one of the first camouflaged camps in the country -- which has risen in record time from orchard and meadow land in New Jersey, was shown to representatives of the press yesterday.

CAIRO, Egypt, Thursday, July 9 -- British empire troops smashing at General Field Marshal Erwin Rommel's Axis forces near El Alamein, Egypt, were reported today to have cut off and surrounded a large German force of armored, artillery and transport units in a pocket several miles square south-west of the southern extremity of the Axis line.

WASHINGTON, July 8 -- The women of America can and must cooperate with the Federal Government in the fight against inflation, Ruth Ayres, new official of the Consumer Division of the Office of Price Administration, said today in an interview.

GREAT NECK, L.I., July 8 -- Mrs. Harry McNaughton of Plandome carded 39, 39 -- 78, four over women's par, to win low gross honors today in the one-day tournament of the Women's Long Island Golf Association at the Sound View Golf Club.

WASHINGTON, July 8 -- Congressmen campaigning for re-election, as well as other bona fide candidates for public office, may obtain special rations of gasoline to facilitate their electioneering, according to the gasoline rationing regulations announced today by the Office of Price Administration. Registration for the coupon gasoline rationing for motorists in East Coast States opens tomorrow and continues through Saturday.

The birth rate at the Bronx Zoo has risen precipitously, it was announced yesterday. The proud keepers of the Bronx animal kingdom have fifteen additional animals on their hands, including a white-tailed gnu with a mustache described as not dissimilar to that of Adolf Hitler.

CLEVELAND, July 8 -- Success was stamped on baseball's all-star service spectacle today as the major league representatives and Army and Navy players scattered, but there was a question in every one's mind whether another such game ever would be attempted.

One man who appeared yesterday to aid the OPA was enlightened and disappointed when he found that the title "OPA neighbor" meant just what it implied. He learned that when the Office of Price Administration called for volunteers to visit retailers it really did not want "an army of snoopers."

PHILADELPHIA, July 8 (AP) -- The Midland United Company, a Delaware holding company which is reorganizing under the bankruptcy laws, asked the Securities and Exchange Commission today for authority to dissolve two subsidiaries, the Traction Light and Power Company and the Shirley Realty Company, both of Indiana.

PHILADELPHIA July 8 (AP) -- Lowell Thomas, radio commentator, received $95,645 in 1941 for his news broadcast sponsored by the Sun Oil Company, the concern's annual report filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission disclosed today.

WASHINGTON, July 8 -- Steel plate production in June reached 1,050,962 net tons, the second successive month in which the industry has topped the 1,000,000-ton production figure, the War Production Board reported today. May output totaled 1,012,194 tons.

CHICAGO, July 8 -- More than 1,000 employes of the International Harvester Company volunteered today for enlistment in a battalion, to consist of 859 men, for the maintenance of tanks and other equipment of the Army's mechanized forces.
Considerable activity in the sale of one and two family homes in Brooklyn is indicated by reports received yesterday from brokers and others operating in that borough.

WASHINGTON, July 8 -- Those American citizens who favored a neutral foreign policy long after the present war began in Europe, who believed this nation could stay out of the war and encounter no perils as the result of an Axis victory, will view more tolerantly than those who disagreed with them the present course of the Argentine Republic.

Registration for permanent gasoline rationing will get under way today in seventeen Eastern States under a set of regulations designed to make it easy for every motorist, including those whose work makes it inconvenient to sign up at a school near home and those who are off on vacation, to obtain a basic "A" book.

This is a Summer of contrasts, some humorous and some tragic. Few fireworks were shot off on the Fourth in the metropolitan area, but over Hankow and Nanking American boys were carrying on the tradition. A boy lost in the Adirondacks for six days would once have had first page, but this year he got, in this newspaper, only twenty-four lines on the first page of the second section.

WASHINGTON, July 8 -- The crucial battle between United Nations forces and the Axis army of General Field Marshal Erwin Rommel in Egypt held the primary attention of the Pacific War Council as it met today with President Roosevelt for the first time in two weeks for a review of the world military situation.

CHICAGO, July 8 -- Furniture retailers, through directors of the National Retail Furniture Association, urged House and Senate appropriation committees today to give the Office of Price Administration sufficient funds "to assure an orderly execution of the price control law -- if the nation is determined in the continued use of price control."

LONDON, July 8 (AP) -- United States merchant ships were in the Russia-bound convoy that the Germans claimed yesterday to have attacked between North Cape and Spitsbergen, an authoritative British source said today, but he added that he was unable to say whether United States warships formed part of the escort.

RICHMOND, Mass., July 8 -- Raymond L. Buell of this town, a close friend of Wendell L. Willkie, announced his candidacy today for the Republican nomination for Representative in Congress against Allen T. Treadway of Stockbridge, who has represented the First District for thirty years.

WASHINGTON, July 8 (AP) -- Jesse Jones, Secretary of Commerce said tonight that "The American people will have over $30,000,000,000 more income in 1943 than the value of things for which the money can be spent" and termed this "a potential 'inflationary gap' greater than any the world has ever known."

In a move for promotion of unity in time of war, four leaders of the left wing of the American Labor party -- Representative Vito Marcantonio, Eugene P. Connolly, Morris Watson and Max Torchin -- sought last night to avert a series of bitter primary fights with its right wing by proposing an agreement on withdrawals and substitutions of candidates for party and public offices before tomorrow night, the deadline for filing declinations of designations.

WASHINGTON, July 8 -- A London announcement today that the United States will accredit military and naval attaches to the Free French committee of General Charles de Gaulle in the British capital is expected to be followed soon by a formal announcement to that effect here.

A reception and tea will be held at 4:30 o'clock this afternoon at 28 West Thirty-ninth Street for newly accepted candidates for the Women's Army Auxiliary Corps, with the civilian women who served as members of their board of selection as hostesses.

Part of the duties of the twelve Victory Fund Committees in the respective Federal Reserve Districts is to advise the Treasury Department on new government financing. The Treasury also gets advice on this all-important subject from many other sources, but in any case the final decisions are its own.

The prosecution began submitting evidence yesterday in the General Sessions trial of four men, including a Greenwich Village bartender, on charges of criminally bringing into this State the $125, 000 in jewelry and opera furs obtained by four masked gunmen on the night of Feb. 28, 1939, in the Philadelphia hold-up of Mrs. Henry W. Breyer, widow of the ice cream manufacturer, and her daughter-in-law.
ROME, July 8 (From Italian broadcasts recorded by The Associated Press) -- The Italian communique said today:

WASHINGTON, July 8 -- Secretary of State Cordell Hull saw no basic change in the submarine warfare as a result of Argentina's decision to have her ships limit their calls at United States ports to New Orleans, he said in reply to a request for comment at his press conference today.

SPOKANE, July 8 (AP) -- Corporal Marvin (Bud) Ward, in the Army now but still the Mr. Big of amateur golf, today won the medal in the Western amateur championship, of which he is the two-time titleholder.
BERLIN, July 8 (From German broadcast recorded by The Associated Press) -- The German High Command communique toddy said:

BERLIN, July 8 (From German broadcasts recorded by The United Press in New York) -- The German High Command, acknowledging Red Army attacks and counterattacks at several points on the Russian front, said today that the German breakthrough toward the Don River had been widened to the south.

Under President Castillo, secure in his position since the resignation of President Ortiz, Argentina continues to walk the tight rope of neutrality. She demanded, and has been promised, recompense for the Nazi sinking of one of her ships, the Rio Tercero. She will not press her further demand for a Nazi salute to the Argentine flag -- the Nazis do not indulge in such gestures.

Elisabeth Bergner will return the week of June 20 to the part in '"Escape Me Never" she created on Broadway in January, 1935, when the Margaret Kennedy play was first produced under the auspices of the Theatre Guild and Charles B. Cochran.

When Charles Sperber of Sound View started his round in yesterday's Metropolitan Golf Association one-day tourney with an 8 at the Oakland Golf Club in Bayside, he was willing to sell his chances for a war bond prize for less than a thin dime.

Plans to have some means of individual identification for all 14,000,000 residents of New York State, in case of bombing attacks or separation of families in mass evacuation from cities, are being made by the State War Council, Lieut. Gov. Charles Poletti, war plans coordinator for the council, revealed yesterday.

A large run of giant tuna has struck in on the southwest coast of Nova Scotia from Wedgeport to as far east as Chester, according to reports. The Wedgeport Tuna Guide headquarters and the Riverside Tuna Club, near Wedgeport, are anticipating American visitors as a result.

The Standard Oil Company of New Jersey yesterday estimated that its consolidated earnings for the first six months of this year approximated $43,000,000 after all charges and allowing for United State taxes as provided in the proposed Revenue Act recently recommended by the House Ways and Means Committee.

NORRISTOWN, Pa., July 8 -- Eight persons were killed and at least twenty-three were injured tonight when a crowded high-speed trolley car, bound from Philadelphia for Allentown, and a heavy freight car crashed head-on at Washington Square Gardens, about four miles north of here.

A smiling, 14-year-old Negro boy left the Hecksher playground in Central Park yesterday with a green Park Department leaf and a shiny silver pin proudly displayed on his new sweatshirt. He was John Stowers, 2504 East Fourteenth Street, Brooklyn, the winner of the annual city-wide marbles finals.

Yale University has sold to the Woodlawn Holding Corporation eleven acres with a frontage of 485 feet on St. George Avenue (Route 27) in Rahway, N.J. The property was acquired for improvement with one-family and two-family homes for defense workers.

Less than twenty-four hours after rehearing the case of Ralph Ingersoll, editor of PM, local Draft Board 44 announced yesterday afternoon that his classification in 1-A would be continued. Both Mr. Ingersoll, who accused the board of prejudice against his editorial policies, and Marshall Field, owner of PM, will have until July 27 to file an appeal.

WASHINGTON, July 8 (AP) -- Elmer Davis is completing plans for the Office of War Information to control the issuance of government press releases concerning the war effort, his associates said tonight, and when necessary to issue statements under its own name to clarify any situations which might become muddled by conflicting utterances of officials or private individuals.
ROCHESTER, N.Y., July 9 (AP) -- Scoring two runs in the seventh inning with the aid of two errors, Rochester won the opening game of the series, 4 to 3, from the Jersey Giants tonight.

Excellent customer response to reminders that payment must be made by today on charge account purchases made in May or earlier if the accounts are not to be "frozen" was reported yesterday by retail executives here. The government regulation requiring that all charge purchases be paid for by the 10th of the second calendar month following the purchase becomes effective at midnight tonight.

WASHINGTON, July 9 -- Average primary market prices for most industrial commodities have continued comparatively steady since the effective date of the general maximum price regulation, it was said yesterday.
ABERDEEN, Md., July 9 -- Women are loading and firing guns, not just rifles and machine guns but anti-aircraft guns and powerful howitzers for the Army.

LONDON, July 9 -- Certain units of the Polish Army in Great Britain were accused of anti-Semitism by Mrs. Beatrice Rathbone during a discussion in the House of Commons today. She said she was aware that it was not the wish of General Wladyslaw Sikorski, Premier of the Polish Government-in-Exile, who had protested against it.

OSSINING, N.Y., July 9 -- Mrs. F.J. Halloran of the Round Hill Club today set the pace for a field of twenty-two golfers in the one-day tournament of the Women's Westchester-Fairfield Golf Association at the Sleepy Hollow Club.
CHUNGKING, July 9 (AP) -- The Chinese High Command communique:

WASHINGTON, July 9 -- Department store sales for the week ended July 4 were down 1 per cent, as compared with the corresponding week last year, the Federal Reserve Board reported today. This followed an 8 per cent decrease the previous week.

TORONTO, July 9 (AP) -- The Maple Leafs treated their largest home attendance of the season to a pair of victories over Newark tonight, 7 -- 3 and 7 -- 6. A crowd of 15,007, including 1,300 men in uniform, turned out on Boosters and War Funds Night to watch the Leafs score their thirteenth victory in fourteen games in the late affair.

WASHINGTON, July 9 -- Another rebuke for those members of Congress supporting legislative restrictions on the sub-parity sale of surplus agricultural commodities in time of war was delivered by President Roosevelt today when he signed a stop-gap resolution continuing for one month the funds to operate the Department of Agriculture.

MOSCOW, July 9 -- General Serge Ingr, Commander in Chief of the Czechoslovak armies and War Minister in Premier Jan Shramek's government in exile, has given your correspondent his impressions gained in a tour of inspection of Czechoslovak forces now in training in the Soviet Union.

WASHINGTON, July 9 -- Senator James Mead called today for an old-fashioned pow-wow of Democratic leaders, President Roosevelt, Governor Lehman and James A. Farley, to settle the question of who shall be the party candidate for Governor of New York.

LONDON, July 9 -- Minister of the Interior Stanislaw Mikolajezyk of the Polish Government in exile has received assurance from British Minister of Information Brendan Bracken that Nazi terrorists would be tried as murderers after M. Mikolajczyk had described at a press conference the systematic campaign of extermination being carried on in German-occupied Poland.

A "Dickens Digest," comprising four great Dickens novels, in condensed versions, will be published by Whittlesey House in October. Prepared by Mrs. Mary Louise Aswell, who comes by her training in book condensation through several years with The Reader's Digest, the book will include "David Copperfield," "Oliver Twist," "Martin Chuzzlewit" and "Pickwick Papers."

BUFFALO, N.Y., July 9 (AP) -- "I can't believe it -- I can't believe it," a gray-haired woman sobbed tonight when told that her son, Herbert Karl Friedrich Bahr, 29 years old, had been arrested on charges of violating the espionage laws.

Long before a war cloud appeared on the horizon a law was adopted which provided that no layman in the medical administrative corps could receive more than a captain's pay. Promotions were therefore historic events. Even when they occurred, it was impossible, because of the law, to increase pay proportionately.

WASHINGTON, July 9 (AP) -- The Office of War Information said today that Axis broadcasts had disclosed that Balkan guerrillas, employing hit-and-run tactics, had invaded Italian territory as far west as Trieste, where a clash with Italian troops was reported.

A persistent man is J. Reid Spencer, 70 years old, a retired music teacher of 100 Lefferts Avenue, near Ebbets Field in Brooklyn. Mr. Spencer made his fourth appearance in Flatbush Court yesterday with a complaint against the management of the Brooklyn Dodgers baseball team, specifically John Collins, program director, because the strains of the "victory" calliope broke his afternoon rest.

Barclays Bank, Ltd., of London has reported total resources as of June 30 of 683,839,844, an increase of 74,000,000 in a year, according to the New York representative of the bank. Deposits were 643,839,360, up 75,000,000 from one year ago.

Pompion, trained and reared on the lush meadows that border Brandywine Creek in Delaware, won the featured Briarcliff Handicap for Donald P. Ross in a fighting nose finish before 14,777 who wagered $1,001,404 at Empire City yesterday.

DURBAN, South Africa, July 9 (U.P.) -- Survivors of two vessels sunk by enemy submarines off South Africa's east coast reported today that many "European officers" had lost their lives, when they were swept from life rafts in a heavy sea.

PHILADELPHIA, July 9 -- To complete its own liquidation in compliance with a "death sentence" order by the Securities and Exchange Commission, the United Light and Power Company filed today with the SEC a plan for the distribution of the common stock of the United Light and Railways Company to its own stockholders and to contribute to United Light and Railways all other assets remaining after paying current liabilities and expenses.

WASHINGTON, July 9 (AP) -- Secretary Stimson said today that his letter directing Senator Lodge to quit active service as a major and return to the Senate was without political significance and was not intended to have any such interpretation.

LAKE PLACID, N.Y., July 9 -- Upsets continued today in the women's New York State golf championship when Miss Shirley Podret of Dutchess Club, Poughkeepsie, defeated Mrs. Philip Allen of Syracuse, the defending titleholder, 6 and 5, and Miss Kathleen Byrne of Rye eliminated the medalist, Miss Ann Winslow of Frankfort, 3 and 2, to reach the semi-final round at the Lake Placid Club.

WASHINGTON, July 9 -- During the week ended July 8 member banks reserve balances increased $54,000,000 the Federal Reserve announced today. Additions to member bank reserves arose from an increase of $196,000,000 in reserve bank credit, and a decrease of $5,000,000 in Treasury cash, offset in part by increases of $73,000,000 in money in circulation, $63,000,000 in Treasury deposits with Federal Reserve banks, and $12,000,000 in non-member deposits and other Federal Reserve accounts.
WASHINGTON, July 9 -- President Roosevelt and King George II of Greece, whose country was overrun by the Germans and Italians after valiant resistance in 1941, announced jointly today:

AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, Australia, July 9 (AP) -- Lieut. Gen George H. Brett, commander of United Nations Air Forces in the Southwest Pacific, awarded decorations to twenty-three officers and men of the United States r Corps and two Australians yesterday at an advanced operational base.

WASHINGTON, July 9 (AP) -- The White Sox defeated the Senators, 4 to 2, tonight, collecting six of their eight hits in two innings, three in the first and three in the sixth. 3a crowd of 7,000 saw the game.

Willie Roberson, one of the four defendants in the celebrated Scottsboro case who was freed and brought to New York five years ago, is in the Brooklyn City Prison awaiting sentence after being convicted of molesting a young woman in the subway, it was learned yesterday.

Fourteen mayors and the representatives of two others met with Mayor La Guardia in City Hall all day yesterday as the financial board of the United States Conference of Mayors. They discussed the financial difficulties of cities through the country.

WASHINGTON, July 9 -- Admiral Harold R. Stark, Chief of the European Naval Forces of the United States, and Brig. Gen. Charles L. Bolte, Chief of Staff of the United States Army, European headquarters, were designated by the State Department today to represent this government in consultations with the Free French National Committee in London in order to render cooperation "more effective in the prosecution of the war."

ORANGE, N.J., July 9 -- Budge Patty, the national junior champion from Los Angeles, twice came from behind to defeat Frank Shields of New York in the quarter-finals of the New Jersey State championship at the Berkeley Tennis Club today.

John W. Hession, specialist charged with responsibility for running up defaulted mortgage bonds of the Wisconsin Central Railroad before they "broke" 13 1/4 points on the New York Stock Exchange in one day, refused yesterday to tell Attorney General John J. Bennett who had given him the false tip on which he acted.

WASHINGTON, July 9 -- President Roosevelt met with the Cabinet, nominated several vice and rear admirals now on retired list or about to be retired for elevation to rank of full admirals and talked with King George of Greece, after which a joint statement on American and Greek accord was issued.

CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va., July 9 -- The use of news as a weapon in the time of war, as an agency in post-war planning and reconstruction, and as an indispensable adjunct to the maintenance of the traditional liberties of free peoples was explored at today's sessions of the Virginia University's Institute of Public Affairs in discussions which also brought demands for more information and greater candor in its presentation.

A year ago the Germans were advancing on a much wider front in Russia than the sector they are storming now. They were announcing bigger and more spectacular victories. Reading the military communiques and commentaries of last July is the best possible counterpoise to the news of today's offensive, for not only is the present drive very limited compared to the original push, but the tone of the reports is soberer.

The latest application by New York City to make up its water shortage by sinking wells in Nassau Count ywas firmly denied by the State Water Power and Control Commission in a decision made public yesterday.

WASHINGTON, July 9 -- The City of Jersey City asked the Interstate Commerce Commission today to dismiss the petition of the Hudson Manhattan Railroad Company for permission to charge a 10-cent fare between Hudson Terminal in New York and stations in Jersey City and Hoboken.

CINCINNATI, July 9 -- Despite Whit Wyatt's two extremely odd errors on one ball and Captain Dolph Camilli's losing argument with Umpire George Magerkurth, the champion Dodgers opened their sixteen-game Western tour tonight with a 3-2 triumph over the Reds and hung on to their eight-and-one-half-game lead over the Cardinals.
PHILADELPHIA, July 9 (AP) -- Buddy Blair paced the Athletics to a 5-2 victory over the Indians tonight by knocking out a homer in the eighth off Relief Pitcher Joe Heving.

A medium-sized British cargo vessel and a small Norwegian Ship have been sunk by Axis submarines, with the loss of thirteen lives, it was announced yesterday by the Navy Department. Their losses brought the unofficial Associated Press tabulation of ships sunk in our waters by submarine attack to 349.

Check transactions in twenty-three of the principal cities of the nation in the week ended on Wednesday rose 16.9 per cent to $6,407,401,000 from $5,481,495,000 in the corresponding five-day week a year ago, according to the report issued yesterday by Dun Bradstreet, Inc.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., July 9 (AP) -- Charles J. Hardy, president of the American Car and Foundry Company, told stockholders at the annual meeting today that in the near future he hoped for a decision in litigation holding up payment of a common dividend.

CHICAGO, July 9 (AP) -- In the first five months of 1942 the nation's railroads moved approximately as many troops as they did in the first thirteen months of American participation in the World War. Freight traffic in the same period was the highest on record for any five months.

ALBANY, July 9 -- Governor Lehman has designated Justice Frank J. Gregg of Syracuse to convene a special term of the Supreme Court at Newburgh Aug. 3 to investigate with a grand jury the financial affaiirs of Local 17, Hod Carriers and Common Laborers Union, an A.F. of L. affiliate.

Plans for concerted action by organized labor, in cooperation with employers, toward obtaining a larger share of war contracts for New York to ameliorate the growing unemployment problem in this city, were adopted yesterday at an all-day conference in the Hotel Commodore under the auspices of the New York State Federation of Labor and the Central Trades and Labor Council.

Shielded by all the military discipline that will henceforth be their "lord and master," forty-seven women finally emerged yesterday as the first officer candidates in the Second Corps Area of the Women's Army Auxiliary Corps.

EAST HAMPTON, L. I., July 9 -- Mrs. Samuel Seabury is chairman for the East Hampton branch, Hamptons Chapter, of the Red Cross. Mr. Seabury has given the use of a house he owns on Main Street for first-aid classes, beginning today.

WASHINGTON, July 9 -- A score of admirals on the retired list would be created under nominations sent by President Roosevelt to the Senate today for confirmation. They include eighteen vice admirals and rear admirals who have passed the statutory retirement age of 64, but most of whom are on active or advisory service, and two are active rear admirals.
LONDON, July 9 (AP) -- Note circulation continued to advance to a new record high of 807,438,000 with an increase of 5,833,000, the Bank of England weekly statement disclosed today.

WASHINGTON, July 9 (AP) -- A suggestion that the Maritime Commission be ordered by Congress to embark on a wooden-ship construction program to replace fishing vessels requisitioned by the Army and Navy was advanced today before the House Merchant Marine Committee.

Luigi Antonini, Alex Rose and Andrew R. Armstrong, respectively State chairman, State secretary and State treasurer of the American Labor party, rejected yesterday the proposal of its left-wing leaders for agreement on candidates for party and public office in the interest of unity on the ground that the proposal masked a design to force a merger of the Labor and Communist parties.

Six window displays of "salvage sculpture" were unveiled yesterday at Saks-Fifth Avenue. An American eagle, Uncle Sam, a tank, an airplane and other patriotic symbols were modeled of tin cans, rubber and other savage material by Mme. Sabanieff, industrial designer.

ST. LOUIS, July 9 -- The Cardinals threw everything in the book at the Giants tonight at Sportsman's Park by way of helping Mel Ott launch his third invasion of the West. The Giants were blanked, 9 to 0.

A hypothetical air raid on "Sector X" of New York City was staged last night to test plans for bringing in under fire the 27,000 tons of food shipped in daily to feed the 12,000,000 persons of the metropolitan area.

Edward Julius Berwind, chairman of the Berwind-White Coal Mining Company and internationally known capitalist, who died on Aug. 18, 1936, left a gross estate of $34,209,129, and after administration and funeral expenses a net of $31,422,853, according to a transfer tax appraisal filed yesterday.
Mrs. Louise Macy, the fiancee of Harry L. Hopkins, aide to President Roosevelt, will carry a package of loyalties with her when she moves into the White House next month.

LONDON, July 9 -- British bombers raided Wilhelmshaven, important German naval base on the North Sea, in "strong force" last night and dropped bombs weighing as much as two tons each into the shipbuilding yards, which were reported to have suffered great damage from vast fires.

BOSTON, July 9 -- Manager Joe Cronin, pinch-hitting with the bases loaded and one out in the eleventh inning, banged out a long fly that sent Pete Fox home with the run that gave the Red Sox a 2-1 victory over the Tigers today.

WASHINGTON, July 9 -- The following cable message from Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek in reply to President Roosevelt's message of encouragement on the fifth anniversary of the Chino-Japanese war was made public today:
"Spy Ship," a Warner Brothers melodrama, which opens at the Strand, is today's lone film newcomer. Craig Stevens, Irene Manning, Maris Wrixon, Michael Ames and Peter Whitney head the film's cast.

German and allied troops advanced on a front more than 300 miles long west of the Don River and harried Russian forces in disorderly retreat, the German High Command said in its communique yesterday, according to German broadcasts recorded in New York by The United Press.

A Pan American Airways trans-atlantic clipper with fourteen passengers, including Joseph Curran, national vice president of the C.I.O. and president of the National Maritime Union, C.I.O. affiliate, arrived yesterday at La Guardia Field.
OCEAN CITY, N.J., July 9 (AP) -- Both the top-seeded favorite and the defending champion fell victim of upsets today in the women's singles semi-finals of the Atlantic Coast tennis championships.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, July 9 -- The $15,000,000 U-boat base which the Germans have been building for almost two years in Trondheim Fjord, Norway, the hiding place of the now-damaged Tirpitz, is slowly sliding into the sea, it is learned from a reliable source.

WASHINGTON, July 9 -- How the proposed 5 per cent tax on freight and express charges would operate in two ways to increase the difficulties of the Office of Price Administration in maintaining the general price ceiling was described today by Leon Henderson, Price Administrator, in a letter explaining his opposition to the tax to the Ways and Means Committee.

The bill to make mandatory loans by the government on six basic farm crops at 100 per cent of parity advanced another step yesterday when the House Committee on Agriculture approved the measure which previously had passed the Senate.

New York wholesale liquor dealers will appeal to the Office of Price Administration in Washington today for an adjustment of price regulations in an effort to have them conform with the Hollowell Act in so far as discounts are concerned.

WASHINGTON, July 9 -- Loadings of revenue freight in the week ended on July 4 amounted to 753,855 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today. This was 99,586 cars or 11.7 per cent less than for the preceding week, 13,496 cars or 1.8 per cent more than for the corresponding week last year and 116,686 cars, or 18.3 per cent more than during the corresponding week two years ago.

The German High Command reported yesterday that British planes had raided "several places" in the German northwestern coastal zone the previous night and caused civilian casualties, particularly at Wilhelmshaven, according to German broadcasts recorded in New York by The Associated Press.

Approval of full parity loans by the House Agricultural Committee yesterday was the signal for a strong buying movement in the cotton market late in the afternoon by New Orleans interests and commission houses, reversing a downward trend that had been collecting momentum and ultimately regaining the ground that had been lost in the previous session.

PHILADELPHIA, July 9 -- Assailing the practice as a subtle way of watering stock, the public utilities division of the Securities and Exchange Commission made public today the results of a survey showing that from 1930 to 1940 some 89 per cent of the 168 electric and gas companies that were studied listed depreciation charges higher on their income tax reports than they did on their own books.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 9 -- At the order of a Navy lieutenant a dozen of fifteen survivors of the tanker Neosho, lost in the battle of the Coral Sea, dived overboard after him from two whaleboats so that wounded men might take their places in the boats.

Representatives of independent gasoline dealers warned last night that the industry would be thrown into chaos by the contemplated scrapping of dealer rationing when the permanent consumer rationing system becomes effective on July 22.

LEE, Mass., July 9 -- The Jacob's Pillow Dance Festival, which plans a ten-week season in its newly built theatre on the old Carter farm near here, got under way this afternoon with a performance on American folk themes by Ted Shawn, Agnes de Mille, Sammy Spring and groups of dancers both professional and folk.

Now that midsummer is here, the need of New York work horses for water is great. The New York Women's League for Animals is anxious to keep its watering stations going, and if possible to add to their number, since the need to conserve gasoline and rubber must inevitably bring more horses into service on our streets.
There has been considerable informal discussion among off-shore fishermen on the various parts they might assume in patrolling our coastal areas.

WASHINGTON, July 9 -- Seven witnesses have appeared for the government before the military commission trying the eight Nazi saboteurs, Major Gen. Frank R. McCoy, commission president, announced tonight following demands by Elmer Davis, new director of War Information, for some public disclosure of the inquiry's progress.

Perry E. Hall, executive manager of the Victory Fund Committee for the Second Federal Reserve District (New York), presented yesterday the first complete picture of the organization, scope and duties of the committee, which is one of twelve set up in each of the Federal Reserve districts in the country to aid the Treasury Department in the sale primarily of open-market Treasury obligations.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, July 9 -- Naval warfare in the Baltic reached a new high during the last twenty-four hours when another Swedish ship and two German ships were sunk, presumably by Russian submarines.
BOSTON, July 9 (AP) -- Staving off a stretch rush by James C. Braswell's Graustark, Sherrill W. Shapoff's Mixer won today's top offering at Suffolk Downs by a half-length.

A $100,000 campaign to promote the use of printing and other graphic arts by advertisers as an aid to winning the war was started at a meeting of industry members in the Port Authority Building yesterday.
CHICAGO, July 9 (AP) -- Buddy Gremp's third home run of the season in the thirteenth inning today gave the Braves a 4-to-3 victory over the Cubs in the opener of a three-game series.

Without committing one's self to the merits of a book that still waits to be read one may say how refreshingly novel it is to come across a title like "Behind the Urals." Very few books, magazine articles and news comments are concerned with the facts behind anything so substantial as a chain of mountains like the Urals, which divide European Russia from Siberia.
The following German High Command communique was broadcast from Berlin and was recorded here by The Associated Press:

A pool of about twenty-five cabinet makers and woodworking concerns has been formed here for the purpose of obtaining war contracts, Harold Bartos of S.S. Silver Co. said yesterday. It was hoped, he said, that the group with the aid of Mayor La Guardia and Governor Lehman, would be instrumental in bringing much needed war work to this area.

It is just about this time every year that we are tempted to become vegetarians. For it seems that wherever we travel, by bus or by foot, we spy a shop with crates spread out on the sidewalk. Each box is stacked temptingly high with bright yellow squash or scarlet tomatoes, dark green cucumbers or snow-white cauliflower.

SPOKANE, July 9 (AP) -- Corporal Marvin (Bud) Ward, bidding for his third successive Western Amateur Golf Association title, scrambled through two rounds to victories today, but at times he looked more like a week-end dub than a champion.

DALLAS, July 9 -- Since they bear priority ratings of A-10 and better, 67 per cent of the record-breaking volume of unfilled orders held by cotton mills represent contracts connected with the war effort, Dr. C.T. Murchison, president of the Cotton-Textile Institute, told the Cotton Research Congress at its annual meeting today.

The 1,152 bond issues listed on the New York Stock Exchange, aggregating $61,899,239,025 par value as of June 30, had a total market value of $59,112,072,945, according to a compilation by the Exchange issued yesterday. As of May 31, there were 1,166 issues, aggregating $61,956,472,933 par value which had a total market value of $59,257,509,674.

The people in France are 100 per cent pro-American and are waiting and hoping for an American and British invasion of the Continent, A.M. Travers, a passenger on the Drottningholm, said yesterday in an interview at the Plaza Hotel.

L. Daniel Blank and David Silberman are planning to revive Karel Capek's fantastic melodrama "R.U.R.," which the Theatre Guild produced at the Garrick Theatre in 1922. "R.U.R." was Capek's best-known play, credited with having added the word "robot" to the English language.

BERNE, Switzerland, Friday, July 10 -- Stemmed in their eastward advance against Voronezh by the stiffening of Russian resistance some miles west of that city, and baffled north of Voronezh by the desperate character of the fighting in the Russian counter-attack, the Germans in yet another bid to pierce the line of the Don hurled three divisions of tanks and several of infantry against the town of Rossosh during yesterday's fighting.

Regarded as a key figure in the European political game, Mr. Saracoglu has shown his skill as a diplomat and conciliator. With Turkey's interests always in view, he has been firm in defending his country's position against the belligerents.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., July 9 -- A large group of young women at this resort, as well as several from Westhampton and Bridgehampton, have enrolled in the nurses' aides classes sponsored by the American Red Cross, which began its activities this week at the Southampton Hospital under the direction of Miss Mary MacDonald Miller, director of the School of Nursing of the Southampton Hospital.

CHUNGKING, China, July 9 -- In a message commemorating the fourth anniversary of the founding of the Sanminchui Youth Corps, Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek sternly warned Chinese youth they must live rigidly disciplined lives and prepare themselves to bear the heavy responsibilities of this era.

Samuel Feldman, always a fast man with a kited check, had many ways of raising money, but one of the simplest was the one he used in dealing with a woman servant, Walter H. Gahagan Jr., assistant Federal prosecutor, said yesterday in Federal court.

LOURENCO MARQUES, Portuguese East Africa, July 9 (U.P.) -- A United States merchant vessel was torpedoed at midnight June 27 some 200 miles off Cape Corrientes on the east coast of Portuguese East Africa, and fourteen men of _the crew are missing, a dispatch from Inhamban reported today.

WASHINGTON, July 9 -- Senator Russell of Georgia, chairman of the Senate-House committee which has sought unsuccessfuly since May 25 to compose differences of the two Congressional branches over the $680,000,000 Agriculture Department Appropriation Bill, immediately interpreted the President's statement as flat support of the Senate's amendment authorizing the sale of 125,000,000 bushels of government-held wheat for feed at about 83 cents a bushel.

The stock market repeated yesterday its forceful rally of the previous session, and, under the impetus of the heaviest volume of the year, values were extended further as much as 2 points. Large blocks for re-investment, extension of positions by traders and the first sizeable public participation since the opening month of the year marked the day on the New York Stock Exchange.

On this the most glorious day of the greatest of nations no more important announcement for the Latin-American peoples could have been made than that President Roosevelt has approved of a plan under which the people of Puerto Rico would elect their own Governors commencing in 1944 at the time of the regular insular vote or, if the war lasts longer, at the close of hostilities.

PEORIA, Ill., July 9 -- Department of Agriculture chemists, working with such farm products as soy bean oil and corn oil, have produced substances that "look, smell and feel much like rubber," a department announcement said today.

WASHINGTON, July 9 -- Philip D. Reed, chief of the War Industries Branch of the War Production Board, told the House Small Business Committee today that he feared a large number of "small" manufacturers, wholesalers and retailers, would be forced out of business by priorities orders and war needs.

Aided by fifty-two municipal trucks, which picked up 187 tons of scrap rubber from filling stations and delivered them to bulk plants, the local rubber salvage campaign yesterday brought in 310 tons. This was the largest amount collected this month, but failed to beat the June 29 record of 492 tons.
MOSCOW, July 9 (AP) -The Soviet I]ormation Brea broaicost this cmuniqug tody:

Hugh A. Carson of the 107th Infantry Post of New York City was elected County Commander of the American Legion last night at the end of the annual two-day convention in the Hotel Pennsylvania. Mr. Carson, an accountant for the New York Central Railroad, and who lives at 167 Davis Avenue, White Plains, succeeds Lawrence A. McNally as Commander.

Responding to an appeal from Dr. John R. Steelman, director of the United States Conciliation Service, 200 striking employes of the Parkchester housing development in the East Tremont section of the Bronx notified the management last night that they intended to return to work at 8 o'clock this morning.

Franklyn Fischer, 42 years old, a commercial artist, and a member of the firm of Fischer Exhibits Company, Inc., of 73 Fifth Avenue, was found guilty yesterday by a jury in Federal Court, Brooklyn, of violation of the Federal Communications Act, which denies to aliens the privilege of installing ship-to-shore radio telephones on their vessels.

In the Victorian era, they tell us, a lady never under any circumstances emerged from her home until both kid gloves were immaculately snapped about her wrists. More recently the established symbol of gentility appears to be a dainty hat, discreetly tilted over one eyebrow.

The heavy outflow of funds from New York City to other parts of the country, reflecting midyear interest and dividend payments, provided an important feature in the weekly banking statistics released yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.

VICHY, France, July 9 -- The decision of the United States Government to appoint representatives to keep in touch with the [Free] French Committee in London was not announced in Vichy today, nor is it likely to be commented upon officially.

The Yankees hit their half-way mark of the season and three Brownie pitchers at the Stadium yesterday, a spectacle that proved edifying to young King Peter of Yugoslavia. The monarch, watching his first baseball game, lingered long enough to see the New Yorkers take a 3-0 lead, but missed the final flourish of home runs by Tommy Henrich and Charlie Keller, which touched off a 5-2 victory.

Addressing Polish soldiers on the field of battle in many parts of the world by means of a short-wave broadcast yesterday, King Peter II of Yugoslavia hailed them as "valiant fighters of a valiant nation" and "brothers by blood and comrades in the same destiny" who are "on the road to a common victory."

CHUNGKING, China, July 9 -- Chinese troops have recaptured the Fu River town of Nancheng, killed 2,900 Japanese and trapped 30,000 more on a seventy-five mile front in Kiangsi, official reports said tonight, while United States Army planes were credited with shooting down five, and possibly eight, Japanese planes that tried to raid their base.

LOS ANGELES, July 9 (AP) -- The C.I.O. and A.F.L. presented joint demands for wage increases today to a government-sponsored labor-management conference on the aircraft industry -- demands which representatives of both sides estimated unofficially would mean a rise of at least $125,000,000 a year on the Pacific Coast alone.

The record of the American Field Service ambulance section in foreign countries engaged in the war was praised yesterday at a testimonial luncheon given by the Free French Relief Committee, Inc., in conjunction with the field service organization as part of Free French Week.

WASHINGTON, July 9 -- The government will make loans to more than 10,000 college men and women seeking technical or professional degrees in six specified fields, to make certain that their education is completed in the shortest time possible and applied to the war effort.

WASHINGTON, July 9 (AP) -- Predicting that the war would end "probably in 1942 and unquestionably in 1943," Representative May, chairman of the House Military Affairs Committee, said today that there would be no need for the Army to induct married men or youths in the 18 and 19-year group.

WASHINGTON, July 9 -- Lou Holland, Kansas City industrialist and originator of the Kansas City plan for assuring greater participation of small industries in the defense effort more than a year ago, is slated to head the Smaller War Plants Corporation, according to reports here today.
WASHINGTON, July 9 -- Creation of a women's volunteer civilian organization was advocated today by Senator Mead of New York to police price regulations of the Office of Price Administration.

Dry goods jobbers reported yesterday that advance buying for Fall by smaller stores has begun to take on volume proportions, particularly in staple lines such as blankets, domestics, towels, etc. Current volume of jobbers on Summer merchandise, it was said, has been slowed up by broken stocks and inability to secure replacements.

Warning against wage increases demanded by employes of the four "Little Steel" companies, Walter D. Fuller, chairman of the board of the National Association of Manufacturers, predicted yesterday that approval of the demand might be the "detonator that sets off the bomb of inflation."

The thoroughgoing examination on the refugee liner Drottningholm bore fruit yesterday with the arrest of Herbert Karl Friedrich Bahr, one of the passengers. Bahr was described by P.E. Foxwosth, local chief of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, as a graduate of a Nazi espionage school, who was born in Germany and acquired United States citizenship through the naturalization of his father.

Feminine concern over "the shape of things to come" in wartime corsets has been premature. The corset manufacturers have taken government limitation orders in their stride. Ingenuity and cleverness have substituted where rubber was lacking, and from the previews of Autumn corset styles now being held by New York corset concerns the immediate future of foundation garments seems to be not only to conserve more rubber but the American woman's traditional figure as well.

NEWARK, N.J., July 9 -- All New Jersey underwent a twenty-minute air raid alarm test today, which demonstrated the inadequacy of the daylight protective forces and the need for educating the civilian population more thoroughly on correct behavior during a raid alarm.

PERHAPS nobody cares, but the futile Phils have the real Sunday pitcher of baseball if recent records mean anything. The name is Thomas Owen Hughes. Tom is a native Pennsylvania product and right-handed all the way. On Sunday, June 21, he beat the Reds (Vander Meer) 3 to 2.

POPULAR interest in Americana, regional folk ways and local history has inspired whole series of books about American rivers, States, seaports, towns and various other geographical units. Up to the present as far as I know, although such relatively minor bodies of water as the Powder River have been chronicled, such a conspicuous one as the Great Lakes has not.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 9 -Tyrone Power's next film at Twentieth Century-Fox will be "Crash Dive," a photoplay about the submarine service, which Jo Swerling has written from an original story by W.R. Burnett. Power and Archie Mayo, who will direct the film, will leave on July 19 for New London, Conn., to begin the film on location there.
PITTSBURGH, July 9 (AP) -- The Phils fell apart at the seams before an Army-Navy Relief crowd of 29,488 fans tonight after a magnificent seven-inning pitching duel and lost to the Pirates, 9 to 0.

It is well known that there is a very serious shortage of rubber and the facilities for transporting gasoline are practically nonexistent. I possess a car of questionable if not a nuisance value. I can't sell it, as there is no market for it. I do not need it for business and the gasoline I manage to obtain could be put toward real definite war needs.

PHILADELPHIA, July 9 -- Including Federal Government obligations, new issues of securities offered for cash in May amounted to $2,965,000,000, the heaviest monthly volume since the World War, it was disclosed today in a tabulation by the Securities and Exchange Commission.

Physical fitness of American women is about on a par with that of American men, as reflected in the findings of Army doctors who examined applicants for the first WAAC Officers Training Camp at Fort Des Moines.

LONDON, July 9 -- Announcement by Sir Stafford Cripps in the House of Commons today that the Cabinet had decided on secret debate of shipping losses and replacements caused considerable resentment among members who had been led to believe the discussion would be public, and several prominent members announced their intention of boycotting the private session.

By the death of Franchet d'Esperey, his junior by one day, Petain becomes sole Marshal of France. At one time he was one of Franchet d'Esperey's brigadiers. As commander of the First Army Corps at the head of forces that had been retreating, Franchet d'Esperey furiously attacked von Kluck's left and von Buelow's right, drove a wedge between them and forced them to retreat.

To stimulate interest among parents to purchase war stamps and bonds for their babies, the Adelphi Hospital, Greene Avenue and Adelphi Street, Brooklyn, held a baby health and beauty contest yesterday. Four "victory babies," winners in the competition, received paid-up war stamp books, which may be exchanged for bonds.

The Experimental Theatre, which the Dramatists' Guild and Actors Equity founded so that certain plays and players might have a hearing the commercial theatre possibly would deny, yesterday afternoon offered as its Summer production Paul Horgan's "Yours, A. Lincoln."

MOSCOW, July 9 -- A large Allied convoy is announced to have arrived safely in a Russian Arctic port, thanks to a daring attack by a Soviet submarine, which torpedoed and badly damaged the German battleship Tirpitz and routed eleven escorting warships.
A method for making tin cans with fiber bodies on the same machines normally used for the manufacture of metal containers was announced yesterday by the American Can Company.

CHICAGO, July 9 -- The highest prices for wheat since the middle of May were reached today on the Board of Trade following announcement that the House Agricultural Committee had approved the Senate bill which would give farmers government loans of 100 per cent of parity on their 1942 wheat and corn crops, as well as four other major agricultural products.

MOSCOW, July 9 (U.P.) -- The German battleship Tirpitz, damaged by two torpedoes from a Russian submarine, made off to the west at 10 knots, one-third of her top speed, while escorting warships clustered around her, according to crew members of the Allied convoy the Germans were about to attack.
Vice Admiral and Mrs. Wilson Brown have arrived from Boston and are at the Weylin.

WASHINGTON, July 9 -- Representative Martin Dies, chairman of the Committee on Un-American Activities, apologized publicly today to David B. Vaughan, administrative officer for the Board of Economic Warfare, headed by Vice President Wallace, for having identified him last March as a sponsor of the American League for Peace and Democracy, which the committee had cited as a Communist "front" organization.

WASHINGTON, July 9 -- President Roosevelt told Congress today of fifty retired officials and employes of the State, War, Navy and other departments to whom foreign governments, some of them now our enemies, had offered decorations, orders, medals or gifts, and suggested that the existing legal permission for the acceptance of these awards be suspended until the world situation assured "wholly objective consideration of such matters."

The Nazis pushed ahead in Russia yesterday; the Japanese were locked in battle in China; Axis forces held their dangerous position seventy miles west of Alexandria, and in Washington the chairman of the House Military Affairs Committee predicted that the end of the war might come "probably in 1942 and unquestionably 1943."

LONDON, July 9 -- Business on the stock markets here improved today after a quiet opening. Giltedge stocks continued their upward trend with gains of 1-16 to 1/8, while the War Loan 3 1/2 per cents rose to 105 1/2. Home rails improved, both senior and junior issues showing gains of 1/8 to 1/2.

The suburban housewife who would improve her figure and save gasoline at the same time by pedaling to market instead of using the family car will not get a bicycle purchase certificate for either of those reasons, it developed yesterday as bicycle rationing began here.

American soldiers, returning from many foreign fronts at the conclusion of the war, will bring with them a new conception of international relationships, destined to play a large part in framing the post-war world, Mrs. Eleanor Roosevelt said last night, speaking in a symposium at the Girls Commercial High School, Brooklyn.

LONDON, July 9 -- An ominous quiet continues in the Egyptian desert, and yesterday appears to have been one of the quietest days for some weeks. Particularly venomous dust storms, especially in the El Alamein area, contributed to keeping operations at a minimum, but it is more probable that both sides were still completing preparations for the next move.

Operations of the Firestone Tire and Rubber Company and its subsidiaries during the six months ended with April resulted in a profit of $5,193,024, according to the semi-annual statement of John W. Thomas, chairman, issued for publication today.

In the appointment of Dr. George D. Strayer to conduct a survey of the financial aspects of the local school system the Rapp-Coudert committee has made a happy choice that will redound to the benefit of the community. Because of his long years of educational experience and his national reputation as an administrator, Dr. Strayer is in a position to do an impartial, intelligent and valuable job.

A crowd of several hundred gathered on the center island at Times Square at lunch time yesterday at a United China Relief Rally under the auspices of the Film War Service Council, composed of various C.I.O. and A.F. of L. unions. James G. Blaine, director of the Civilian Defense Volunteer Organization, was the principal speaker.

The State Department has never had a more delicate task than the one of maintaining a relationship with the Frenchmen of Vichy and at the same time encouraging the other Frenchmen who are fighting on our side against the Axis. Events will determine whether the task has been at any time worth while.

ELMSFORD, N.Y., July 9 -- Allen Tanner Barnett, 14-year-old son of Vincent G. Barnett, vice president of the Barber Steamship Lines at 17 Battery Place, New York, committed suicide this afternoon by hanging himself at his parents' estate in Greenburgh Township while mentally disturbed, according to Dr. Amos O. Squire, medical examiner of Westchester County.

Registration of motorists for permanent gasoline rationing got off to a smooth start in the city yesterday as more than 150,000 simplified forms were filled out for basic A books -- 142,788 in 330 public schools and an estimated 10,000 in war plants which were visited by special registrars to avoid production delays.

Wendell L. Willkie is "considering" a trip to Russia, China and Australia to see at first hand the conditions in those nations, it became known here yesterday. Like the visit he made to Great Britain in January, 1941, the proposed trip would be taken by the 1940 Republican Presidential candidate as an individual rather than any representative -- official or otherwise -- of the government.
Five more of the twenty-nine leaders of the German-American Bund indicted here on Tuesday were arraigned yesterday in Federal court and all, pleading not guilty, were held in substantial bail.

WASHINGTON, July 9 -- Prices for women's fur coats will remain as they were last year, the Office of Price Administration said today with the issuance of a new price regulation setting last year's sale price as the ceiling rather than the price prevailing in March.

As part of a campaign to force radio stations, soda fountains, bars and restaurants to employ union musicians instead of using recordings, Mr. Petrillo has informed all the record manufacturers that the 140,000 members of his A.F. of L. organization will not make "records, electrical transcriptions or any other form of electrical reproduction of music" after July 31.

GOSHEN, N.Y., July 9 (AP) -- Piloted by the veteran Vic Fleming, Widow's Pride won the $7,675 Village Farm Stake for 2-year-old pacers, feature of the Grand Circuit program at Goshen Raceway today, but only after the tightest finish of the meeting in the final heat.

TRENTON, July 9 -- Republican leaders from all parts of New Jersey met here today at the call of the State chairman, H. Alexander Smith of Princeton, for the announced purpose of giving an "advisory opinion" as to a candidate equipped to defeat United States Senator William H. Smathers, Democrat, who is seeking re-election.

WASHINGTON, July 9 -- The subject of a unified and a supreme military command for the United Nations keeps coming up because of its intrinsic merit. Though the President has discouraged the movement by asking "What is it?" and complaining that nobody is able to tell him, the perfectly clear proposal will not stay dead.

LONDON, July 9 -- Without resistance or casualties on either side British forces have seized the French island of Mayotta in the Comoro group in Mozambique Channel 300 miles from Portuguese East Africa (Mozambique) and 200 miles from the northern tip of Madagascar, it was announced today.

IN ADVANCE POSITIONS of the British Eighth Army in Egypt, July 8 (Delayed) -- In his first meeting with war correspondents since he took charge of the army in the field and halted the German-Italian drive aimed at the Nile delta, General Sir Claude J.E. Auchinleck expressed confidence in the military situation.
Anne O'Hare McCormick's interesting article on Puerto Rico in THE NEW YORK TIMES of July 6 tells only part of the story about the opposition to Governor Rexford Guy Tugwell.

MEMPHIS, July 9 -- Fortunately an agricultural bureaucrat has to drive from Oxford, Miss., to Memphis the first part of the week, attending to numerous cotton and corn crises on the way, and this correspondent had a convenient opportunity to ride over some violently aggressive red clay roads in the hill country and listen for bucolic overtones from the war.

MOSCOW, Friday, July 10 -- The German thrust from Volchansk, at the southern end of the drive toward the Don River, yesterday was in the neighborhood of the small town of Rossosh, on the headwaters of a tributary of the Don, just 100 miles east of Volchansk and 125 miles nearer Rostov than is Voronezh, both on the main Moscow-Rostov railroad.

There is danger of "bootleg or black market" dealing in rationed goods which might return the nation to the "lush days of prohibition" and re-create an era of hijacking, corruption and gang murders, District Attorney Frank S. Hogan warned yesterday.

There's always an air of expectancy just before a John-Frederics showing. The room fills up quickly and there is a hubbub of conversation until the designer takes over the "mike." Then there is silence, for one never knows what the highly imaginative designer will say.

WITH UNITED STATES FORCES IN NORTHERN IRELAND, July 9 (U.P.) -- American and British troops, going through the motions of war side by side, have just completed large-scale manoeuvres embodying every phase of modern combat from fifth column intrigue to a parachute invasion.

CHUNGKING, China, July 10 (U.P.) -- The headquarters of Lieut. Gen. Joseph W. Stillwell commander of all United States Army forces in China, India and Burma, announced today in a communique that fighter planes of the United States Twenty-third Pursuit Group yesterday shot down "a Japanese two-engined observation plane" over Hengyang, in Hunan, on the Canton-Hankow railway, one of the main targets of enemy aerial operations in South China since mid-April.

Republican leaders in New York State expressed satisfaction yesterday with the order permitting candidates for public office to obtain additional gasoline and granting additional gasoline for transportation of voters to the polls at the November election.

With only 350,000 basic A books given out in the city during two days of registration for permanent gasoline rationing, a warning was issued last night by Lee S. Buckingham, State director of the Office of Price Administration, that local motorists who failed to register on Monday faced the prospect of several gasless days after the new ration schedule goes into effect on July 22.

Private Peter Schlavis, 31 years old, who was inducted into the army last month, was held for the Grand Jury yesterday in Felony Court, Brooklyn, after his sister testified that he had struck their mother because she refused to give him money for liquor. Schlavis, who lives at 231 Ninety-fourth Street, Brooklyn, had failed to report to his post when his two weeks furlough expired.
The following German High Command communique was broadcast yesterday from Berlin and recorded here by The Associated Press:

UNITED STATES AIR FORCE HEADQUARTERS, China, July 10 -- Brig. Gen. Claire L. Chennault said today that the offensive begun by this United States Army Air Force in China on July 4 will expand until Japanese air power everywhere is smashed and Japanese cities are bombed regularly.

Herbert Karl Bahr, arrested aboard the Drottingholm as a German spy, impressed his fellow passengers as being "a clean-cut American boy," patriotically upholding the United States whenever the war was discussed, one of his cabin mates aboard the ship disclosed yesterday.

James G. Blaine, chairman of the Greater New York Civilian Defense Volunteer Office, announced yesterday that fingerprinting of the city's population would begin Monday night. He also named Robert K. Christenberry, president of the Broadway Association, as chairman of the War Identification Bureau, which will have charge of the fingerprinting.

NORTH TARRYTOWN, N.Y., July 10 -- One thousand C.I.O. members held a one-hour demonstration here today in protest against management orders for a ten-day shutdown of a Chevrolet factory making trucks for the Army.

WASHINGTON, July 10 (AP) -- Secretary Hull praised the Republic of Colombia today for effective cooperation in inter-American affairs and in the maintenance of the security of the Western Hemisphere. He spoke at a special meeting of the governing board of the Pan American Union in honor of Dr. Alfonso Lopez, President-elect of Colombia.

MOSCOW, Saturday, July 11 -- A German offensive led by General von Schwoelder at Lisichansk, an industrial town 50 miles northwest of Voroshilovgrad on the Donets River, was announced last midnight in the official Soviet communique, which also reported the fall of Rossosh, about 110 miles south of Voronezh and about 20 miles west of the River Don, on whose banks west of Voronezh fierce fighting continued throughout yesterday.

Fire that apparently had been smoldering for several days in a supply of 1,300 tons of rice coal stored in coal bins in the basement of the Manhattan Municipal Building gave firemen under Deputy Chief James Mcbride a tough afternoon of work yesterday.

MEXICO CITY, July 10 -- Mexico, in cooperation with United States customs and health officials, is carrying out a thorough campaign to end illegal opium production that had sprung up in northern sections of the country and the smuggling of the drug across the border, a Mexican official said today.

Dr. Stephen Duggan, director of the Institute of International Education, yesterday described Herbert Karl Bahr, arrested on the Drottningholm as a German spy, as "the only student sent to Germany or a fascist country through the institute who turned against his own country."
AKRON, Ohio, July 10 (AP) -- Development of a tubeless pneumatic tire for use on heavy vehicles was announced today by John L. Collyer, president of the B.F. Goodrich Company.

WITH THE BRITISH FORCES, in Egypt, July 10 -- The battle for the Nile and the Middle East is being directed from trailers scattered through the desert. I made my base in the trailer of Air Vice Marshal Arthur Coningham, Field Commander of the R.A.F.

German broadcasts recorded in New York yesterday by The Associated Press said Russian forces in retreat were being pursued on a broad front in South Russia by German and allied troops. It quoted the German High Command as follows:

Mayor LaGuardia, who has been criticized by the Army and the Office of Civilian Defense for permitting smoking at the Polo Grounds during the city-wide blackout Monday night, came up with a new suggestion yesterday for dimming out the Coney Island Boardwalk and at the same time retaining sufficient illumination to permit stores and concessions to continue business after dark.

In our house the evening meal in the Summer was always "supper." It was a compromise affair -- substantial enough for the adults yet suitably simple for the children. There was a tall earthenware pitcher of milk, a loaf of homemade bread that was cut at the table, soup or a salad, honey or jam, and the inevitable platter of cold meat.

On sentimental grounds, every baseball fan probably rooted for the all-service team in the game with the American League All-Stars. But the very fact that the wishful thinking of the fans did not materialize in a victory for the service athletes should make them feel all the prouder of those athletes.

Thirty-three property owners on East 141st Street, between Willis and Brook Avenues, the Bronx, recently sent a petition to Police Captain John Collins of the Alexander Avenue station, charging neighborhood boys with disturbing the peace of the block by their "rowdyism" and "juvenile gangster methods."

SPOKANE, July 10 (AP) -- The national public links champion beat the national amateur champion today in a quarter-final match of the Western Golf Association's championship when Bill Welch of Houston, back on the scene of his triumph a year ago, eliminated Corporal Marvin (Bud) Ward, 2 up.

FORT KNOX, Ky., July 10 -- Two thousand noncommissioned officers of the armored force forgot the strict letter of military decorum for a minute this morning and gave Major Henry Cabot Lodge Jr., home from the Libyan wars with a first-hand account of armored force troops in actual battle, an ovation which may have outdone anything that ever happened to him at political meetings.

Plans for Amsterdam Houses, the public housing development of the City Housing Authority in the San Juan Hill section of the West Side, were filed yesterday by Atterbury, Corbett Holden, the architects. They call for ten apartment buildings to house 1,020 families and will cost $3,227,000, according to the estimate of the architects.

THE country lawyers, the country doctors and the country editors have spoken. Their books have been high on the best-seller lists. These books have tended to create an impression that only bucolic characters enjoy themselves. Now comes Arthur Garfield Hays with his "City Lawyer: the Autobiography of a Law Practice"* to prove that urban professional people can have a good time, too.

DETROIT, July 10 -- Digressing from his prepared address before the Automotive Council for War Production tonight, Donald M. Nelson praised Lieutenant General Knudsen for the work he did to promote production in the eighteen months before Mr. Nelson took over his present work.

HONOLULU, July 10 -- Lieut. Gem Delos C. Emmons, commanding general of the Hawaiian Department, today announced the award by direction of President Roosevelt of the Distinguished Service Cross to twenty-eight officers and men of the Army Air Corps who in the battle of Midway made the first torpedo-bomber attack in the history of the United States Army.

WASHINGTON, July 10 -- Admiral Chester W. Nimitz, commander in chief of the Pacific Fleet, recently escaped with minor injuries from an airplane crash on the West Coast that cost the life of his pilot, Lieutenant Thomas Morton Roscoe, 29, of Oakland, Calif., it was announced today by the Navy Department.

LONDON, July 10 (U.P.) -- Adolf Hilter, yielding to persistent army pressure, has placed General Field Marshal Walther von Brauchitsch, former German commander in chief, in charge of the German offensive in south Russia over the field commander, General Field Marshal Fedor von Bock, dispatches from Stockholm said today.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 10 -- Loretta Young and Brian Aherne will be co-starred in "The Frightened Stiff," a murder story by Kelley Roos, which Columbia purchased four months ago for $6,000, the studio announced today. Richard Wallace will direct the film.

The Saturday opening of several leading retail stores during July and August will begin today. The list includes several establishments for which the Summer Saturday opening represents an "experiment" designed to meet the needs of customers engaged in war activities and those remaining in the city over week-ends.

ALBANY, July 10 -- Governor Lehman today directed Major John A. Warner, head of the State police, to have his men enforce the 40-mile speed limit "with redoubled vigilance, day and night, and to interpret and apply the new law literally."
The executive board of the United Lutheran Church in America called yesterday upon all the members of the church to give complete support to the nation's war program.

MOSCOW, July 10 (AP) -- Soviet submarines have had "nothing to do" with recent attacks by submarines against Swedish vessels in Swedish territorial waters, an authorized statement distributed by Tass, official Soviet news agency, declared tonight.

Emphasizing the "pressing necessity" for materials for war production, R. Merrill Decker, regional director of the Industrial Salvage Section, WPB, warned yesterday that failure in the voluntary drive to collect scrap would lead to requisitioning by the government.
WASHINGTON, July 10 -- The text of instructions from Elmer Davis, Director of War Information, to all government departments and agencies is as follows:

MEXICO CITY, July 10 -- Representatives of the United States and Brazil differed in regard to an increase in farm production at today's session of the second Inter-American Conference on Agriculture, being held here.
LONDON, July 10 -- Diplomatic relations between the Netherlands and Russia, severed since the Soviets succeeded the Czars, was resumed today.

Net sales of the Davega Stores Corporation in its fiscal year ended on March 31 amounted to $14,415,000, an increase of $2,813,000, or 24 per cent, over the $11,602,000 volume for the previous year, H.M. Stein, president, reported yesterday in the annual statement to stockholders.

The Appellate Division ruled yesterday that Father Divine, Harlem cult leader, must post a $5,000 surety bond if he wishes to avoid immediate enforcement of an order of Supreme Court Justice Charles B. McLaughlin requiring him to pay weekly installments of $100 on an unsatisfied judgment for $5,949 obtained against him more than two years ago by Mrs. Verinda Brown, a former "angel" of his "kingdom."

WASHINGTON, July 10 -- Americans had $2.18 more apiece in their pockets on June 30 than they had on May 31, and almost $20 more than a year earlier, the amounts being $92.04 on June 30 and $72.16 the year before, according to the Treasury's statement of the circulation of money issued today.
MOSCOW, July 10 (AP) -- The Soviet Information Bureau issued this communique today:

Net assets of the United States and Foreign Securities Corporation on June 30 were $24,471,742, according to a report by Ernest B. Tracy, president. This figure was reached by carrying investments in the United States and International Securities Corporation common and second preferred and in the Credit and Investment Corporation second preferred at $1 and valuing all securities without quoted prices at $710,962.

Chicago has a "budget baby" whose parents have kept an accurate record of maintenance and operating costs, if these are the appropriate words, since her birth. Her third year, just completed, called for an outlay of $283.94, and as the child stands today -- without holding on to anything -- she represents a total investment of $779.16.

One of the bitterest battles in corporate history drew to a close yesterday when the Columbia Oil and Gasoline Corporation, a subsidiary of the Columbia Gas and Electric Corporation, announced that it would relinquish control over the rich Panhandle Eastern Pipe Line Company.

NEWARK, N.J., July 10 -- Dressed in a gray ersatz suit of rough texture, Herbert Karl Friedrich Bahr, Nazi spy suspect found by the Federal Bureau of Investigation on the refugee liner Drottningholm in the long investigation of its passengers, received a preliminary hearing here today before Federal Judge William F. Smith.

The sinking of four more Allied merchant vessels by submarines was announced by the Navy Department yesterday. They included two medium-sized British ships, a medium-sized Belgian ship and a small United States ship.

The approximate status of the municipal bond market is reflected in the following list of representative high-grade State, city and county bonds legal for savings banks in New York State, now offered by dealers:

Mayor La Guardia said yesterday that in order to avoid prejudice "we should not sit down to a peace conference for at least a year after hostilities have ceased." He added that in his view the people of the United States would be in trouble if they approached postwar problems from a national rather than a world viewpoint.

The pigeons and birds in Battery Park have been deprived of public feeding since the park has been enclosed in a high board fence. This is a twenty-one-acre tract and has a large bird population which has depended solely on food scattered by the public both Summer and Winter.

PHILADELPHIA, July 10 -- Approval was given today by the Securities and Exchange Commission to two applications filed by the North American Light and Power Company, a subsidiary of the North American Company, as steps toward compliance with an order requiring dissolution of the concern.

BERNE, Switzerland, July 10 -- While the Vichy Government is appealing to the French to buy State bonds, the craze for postage stamps is increasing in France, it was learned here today. The purpose is not collecting but investing.

Leslie MacMitchell, New York University's cross - country and mile star, was sworn in July 2 as an ensign in the Navy and will report July 27 to the Naval Training School at Northwestern University for a two-month indoctrination course, it was disclosed yesterday at N.Y.U.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, July 10 -- Were the pictures of the alleged killers of Reinhard Heydrich, the late Deputy Reich Protector of Bohemia-Moravia, as published in the Prague newspaper Neue Tag on June 25 mere fakes?

The United States will be the most important economic unit in the world when the war ends and the success of post-war reconstruction will depend largely upon the part the country plays in it, according to a report by the Federation of British Industries released yesterday by the National Foreign Trade Council.

Out of the confusion of Congressional manoeuvring over farm legislation there is emerging a pattern -- the pattern of the worst farm bloc bargain yet. Out of that pattern emerges also fresh evidence that the Administration is not giving courageous support to its own program for control of the cost of living.

The Twenty-fifth anniversary of the free Summer concerts in Central Park was celebrated last night at the band shell on the Mall, with Edwin Franko Goldman, whose band has carried on the program for a quarter of a century, as the principal figure in the ceremonies.

A lightening of demand which left the stock market vulnerable to profit-taking checked yesterday the rapid climb of prices of the two previous sessions. Inroads on values were confined generally to fractions, but at that the list managed to close fairly well on balance as the afternoon saw a let-up in selling.

Did the managers of both major league all-star teams work at different purposes? Was McCarthy's primary aim to win the game? Did Durocher direct the National League stars primarily with the view of satisfying the desire of every man selected for the team?

LONDON, July 10 (U.P.) -- The current lull in the R.A.F.'s 1,000-plane attacks and in the Commando raids, both designed to divert some of Germany's strength from Russia, is due mainly to swiftly changing weather that frequently upsets long planning, informed quarters said tonight.

Agencies have been requested by the Advertising Council to seek sponsors for campaigns to promote the sale of idle automobile tires to the government and to push the idea of car sharing, it was learned yesterday. The action was taken at the request of the Office of Price Administration.
