LONDON, July 10 -- The Yugoslav military Cabinet announced today that its High Command had been transferred back from Cairo, Egypt, to Yugoslavia and that the field commander of the 200,000 to 300,000 fighting patriots, General Draja Mikhailovitch, had been named Chief of Staff.

WASHINGTON, July 10 (AP) -- Leon Henderson, Price Administrator, has told Congress that he has established a policy of disapproving price increases asked by industries because of pay rises granted to employes subsequent to April 27.
PRINCETON, N.J., July 10 -- The role of the church in wartime is a controversial issue that has stirred up heated debate among Protestant pastors and church conferences in many denominations.

Shut Out, regarded by the majority as the 3-year-old champion, will try again this afternoon in the $29,650 Empire City Handicap under a weight allotment greater than he ever has attempted. The Greentree Stable star is fresh from his record-breaking victory in the Yankee Handicap and will run in a field of nine over the mile-and-three-sixteenths route at the Empire City track.
It appears necessary to expand a bit on your editorial "Aleutian Fog."

Further increases in cargo war risk rates were announced yesterday by marine underwriters. They added 5 per cent to existing rates on practically all voyages to and from United States Atlantic and Gulf ports and Canadian Atlantic ports.

MELBOURNE, Australia, July 10 -- "All and every one shall bow their heads whenever they see Japanese soldiers," says a Japanese proclamation issued in occupied New Guinea. All are required to learn Japanese, forbidden to write letters, hold meetings and listen to the radio.

LONDON, July 10 -- A civilian airplane crew of two Americans and two Canadians has established the record of crossing the Atlantic five times in nine days on the Montreal-Britain run in the same Liberator, loaded on each flight with freight or passengers or both.

Representatives of banks, investment banking firms and brokerage houses will meet a committee of representatives of surety companies early next week to consider formally proposals which have been drawn up by the surety men for submission to the Federal War Damage Corporation of a plan to insure securities, commercial paper and similar valuables against risks of bombardment.

From time to time there still emanate from Washington statements that the country is too "complacent," and that that is why it is still not making the sacrifices necessary for victory. If Washington, however, would pause to examine the sources of this complacency, it would discover that the greatest single source is Washington itself.
WASHINGTON, July 10 (AP) -- President Roosevelt signed legislation today authorizing the construction of 1,900,000 tons more of combat ships and 1,200,000 tons of auxiliary vessels for the Navy.
LONDON, July 10 (AP) -- The Admiralty issued the following communique today:

NEW CITY, N.Y., July 10 -- The case of Sheriff Edward C. Dormann of Rockland County and two other men accused of operating a short-lived lottery last Spring went to the jury early this afternoon, but at midnight no verdict had been reached.

DETROIT, July 10 (AP) -- The Chrysler Corporation, replying to union charges that its wages are low, declared in a brief submitted to the War Labor Board today that its employes "are among the highest-paid workers in the world."

DETROIT, July 10 -- In the new Ford bomber plant near Detroit, which is gearing itself to produce bombers in greater quantities than has ever been done anywhere before, women will take their place side by side with men, doing the job before them with no handicaps allowed.

Two new films will arrive in Broadway theatres this morning. "Men of Texas," a Universal picture, will be the newcomer at the Rialto. Robert Stack, Broderick Crawford, Jackie Cooper, Anne Gwynne, Ralph Bellamy, Jane Darwell and Leo Carrillo are among the featured players in the action drama. . . .
WASHINGTON, July 10 (AP) -- The Commerce Department said in a statement today that "Axis property and assets are beginning to be sold in Central America to Central Americans."

BUENOS AIRES, July 10 -- The operatic season here reached its height last night with the performance of Bellini's "Norma," which was specially and beautifully staged to celebrate the anniversary of Argentina's independence and in which the chief roles were taken by Metropolitan Opera stars.

NEWARK, N.J., July 10 -- A non-profit plan, designed to provide medical and surgical services for its subscribers, while allowing them to choose their own physicians, went into operation today in New Jersey for the first time when contracts were distributed to 700 employes of Peter J. Schweitzer, Inc., a paper manufacturing concern of Elizabeth, N.J.

Manufacturers of Venetian blinds have completed an exchange of viewpoints on the adjustments made necessary by governmental controls over metal slats, fittings and hardware. They discussed the restrictions at informal meetings held in Atlanta, Houston, Dallas, Los Angeles, Oakland, Portland, Seattle and Chicago. Portland, 200 producers attended the sessions.

American Barge Line The American Barge Line Company reduced the quarterly dividend on its common stock with the declaration yesterday of 15 cents a share. In previous quarters this year 25 cents each was distributed. Patrick Calhoun Jr., president, said the dividend declared reflected greatly increased demands on cash of the company in connection with its naval shipbuilding activities.

W.E. Brown's letter in your issue of July 6 rather misses the point. Every one will agree that if it were a choice between planning the peace and winning the war we should concentrate on the latter. But the two activities, so far from conflicting, are actually interdependent.

New bond financing offered to the public this week amounted to only $4,256,500, compared with $35,575,000 in the preceding period. In this week last year $12,195,000 in new bonds was placed on the market.

LONDON, July 10 (U.P.) -- Military experts said tonight that the Red Army appeared to be carrying out a general withdrawal along a 100- mile Don front between the Voronezh and Rossosh areas, and expressed doubt that it would be possible to prevent a broad German advance across the river.

The contest for the Democratic nomination for Governor between Attorney General John J. Bennett Jr. and United States Senator James M. Mead has developed into a fight between President Roosevelt and State Chairman James A. Farley for control of the Democratic organization in the President's home State.

The financial problems of American cities in wartime were well presented, though not settled, at a meeting of the financial board of the United States Conference of Mayors held in our City Hall on Thursday at the call of Mayor La Guardia. At the latter's suggestion it was decided to allocate $100,000 to a committee which will study the knotty subject of Federal, State and municipal competition for the taxpayer's dollar.

HOLLYWOOD, July 10 -- A strike which may spread to the entire motion-picture industry began today when office employes walked out of the Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer, RKO and Columbia film distribution exchanges in Los Angeles and the Screen Office Employes Guild, A.F. of L., established picket lines.

Sales of leading mail order and chain store companies improved in June, showing an increase of 10.2 per cent over the 1941 month, against a rise of 3.2 per cent in May, according to a compilation made yesterday by THE NEW YORK TIMES. Reflecting the increasing loss of durable goods volume, however, sales losses were noted for the mail order and automotive groups, while the decline noted earlier continued in men's wear trade.

OTTAWA, July 10 -- Proceedings against Colonel George Drew, Ontario Conservative leader, for an alleged breach of the Defense of Canada Regulations based on a statement by him criticizing the report of the Royal Commission on the Hong Kong expedition, have been withdrawn, it was announced in the House of Commons this afternoon by Justice Minister Louis St. Laurent following withdrawal of the charges in the Toronto court by Crown Counsel D.L. McCarthy.
MOSCOW, Saturday, July 11 (AP) -- The Russians announced today that the Red Army had abandoned Rossosh. Thus the Germans cut the main railway linking the Central and Southern Red armies.

LAKE PLACID, N.Y., July 10 -- Miss Shirley Podret of the Dutchess County Club, Poughkeepsie, and Miss Grace Amory of the Cedar Creek Club, Locust Valley, will meet in the thirty-six-hole final of the women's New York State golf championship over the lower course of the Lake Placid Club tomorrow.

WASHINGTON, July 10 -- Indications that the trial of the eight Nazi saboteurs might last much longer than previously expected were seen in a formal statement issued tonight by Major Gen. Frank R. McCoy, military commission president, as the day's session ended.

Ben Wallack's letter discussing the sugar situation seems to be written after the fact. The question of whether or not there is sufficient sugar to obviate the need for rationing was, in January, 1942, not an open question but a hazardous prediction, gauged on forecasts of shipping space to be available, the reaction of American householders to restrictions on their consumption of a staple food and technical developments in producing explosives.

CAIRO, Egypt, July 10 -- Fierce fighting broke out today between British and Axis desert forces on the Mediterranean rim west of El Alamein in a renewal of the battle for Egypt after a lull of more than a week.

Export licenses may be denied in the future to persons found violating any of the statutes, proclamations, executive orders or regulations governing the control of exports, the Office of Exports, Board of Economic Warfare, warned yesterday.

GOSHEN, N.Y., July 10 (AP) -- Court Jester, undefeated black colt owned by Fred Egan and Rupert Parker of Aiken, S.C., won the Senior Village Farm Stake for 3-year-old pacers, feature of today's Grand Circuit racing at Goshen Raceway.

WASHINGTON, July 10 -- The Truman committee was urged to day by Senator Barkley, the mapority leader, to speed its investigation of the acceptance by Senator Chandler of a swimming pool at his home in Versailles, Ky., as a gift from Ben H. Collings.

These hot days when it is impossible to keep one's windows closed day or night, our national form of rudeness, which consists in forcing our neighbors to hear whatever radio programs we select, assumes alarming proportions. Now, moreover, a new lot of daytime sufferers are involved -- those war workers who are on night or swing shift and must get their sleep during the day.
Following is the text of the address by Donald M. Nedson before the Automotive Council for War Production, as recorded by THE NEW YORK TIMES:
LONDON, July 10 -- The stock markets today were quiet in all sections, prices held and the undertone remained firm.

WARDHA, India, July 10 (Reuter) -- Mohandas K. Gandhi is understood to have presented to the Congress Working Committee a draft of a resolution, the upshot of which, informed circles believe, may be the decision to take action on the lines of the 1921 civil disobedience and passive resistance movement.
CHICAGO, July 10 (AP) -- Jimmy Foxx's third hit, a single to left in the eighth inning, today gave the Cubs and Claude Passeau a 3-to-2 victory over the Braves.

The Free Chinese received more kind words than they will know what to do with, on the fifth birthday of their war with Japan. Of things more substantial than kind words they received a great deal less than they would know what to do with. Two of their military representatives in this country, Major Gen. Chu Shih-ming and General Hsiung Shih-fei, made this point, with their customary politeness, in statements addressed to the American public.

The Civil Service Forum, of which Frederick E. Libby is president, announced yesterday that it would appoint a special committee to work for the defeat of Jerry Finkelstein, Democratic candidate for State Senator in the Seventeenth Senatorial District, who also is scheduled for the American Labor party nomination.

SCHENECTADY, N.Y., July 10 -- The war will be fought to a knockout and Poland will never quit fighting, said Ambassador Jan Ciechanowski of Poland here today in an address starting daily beaming of Polish-language programs to Europe over WGEA, General Electric short-wave radio station.

CINCINNATI, July 10 -- His own single, another by Frank McCormick and an error by Peewee Reese gave Bucky Walters his tenth triumph of the season when the Reds won a ten-inning game with the Dodgers tonight, 2 to 1, before 9,379.
CHUNKING, China, July 10 (AP) -- The Chinese High Command said in a communique today:

Women who have endured more walking and less riding with good grace during the fine Summer months need have no fears for the rainy Autumn weather to come. There will be galoshes and rubbers -- enough, rubber manufacturers say, to "keep everybody's feet from getting wet."

WASHINGTON, July 10 -- The Senate Appropriation Committee voted today to allow the Office of Price Administration a fund of $120,000,000 for expenses, but employed limitation devices to impose sharp restrictions upon Leon Henderson, Administrator, in his operations and appointments.

At least three banking groups are expected to submit bids on Tuesday for $17,143,000 of refunding bonds of the city of Detroit. They are headed by the Bankers Trust Company, the Northern Trust Company of Chicago and the First National Bank jointly with Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc.

The first batch of candidates for officers in the Second Corps Area of the Women's Army Auxiliary Corps has been sworn in, a small handful picked from some 3,600 applicants. The tests must have been severe and the choice difficult. Teachers, to whom the community has learned to entrust so many tasks, were the most successful.

The American Government has underlined an interesting distinction in appointing Admiral Stark and General Bolte as representatives to consult with General de Gaulle. What we have actually done is to recognize General de Gaulle as the military leader of the fighting French while withholding recognition from the Free French committee as a government-in-exile.

The Superior Oil Company, of California, announced a net profit of $3,219,748 for the nine months ended with May. This is after Federal income tax and other deductions, and equals $7.61 a share on 423,014 shares of capital stock outstanding.

Retail trade here improved this week, with most stores having sales increases over 1941. The rise for department stores was estimated at about 10 per cent, with at least one establishment here having a gain of 20 per cent over a year ago. Featuring the week were numerous clearances and special promotional events which generally met good consumer response.

Plans for a trucking terminal on the West Side were announced yesterday in connection with the sale of a plot of 100 by 100 feet at 414 to 420 West Thirty-eighth Street by Carrie Stern to the 414 West Thirty-eighth Street Corporation. The property includes a one-story building, loading platform and backing yard and has been leased to the Novick Transfer Company (Shenandoah Valley Route) for its New York terminal.
Four new plays -- the largest number so far this season -- will be testing out their wings next week at the Summer playhouses. The listing includes:

THE NEW YORK TIMES announced yesterday that Arthur Hays Sulzberger, publisher of THE TIMES, had received a letter from John Crawford, a member of its staff, in connection with a communication from Mr. Crawford printed in The Guild Reporter of June 15 which was critical of the work of Louis Stark, a TIMES reporter who won the 1942 Pulitzer Prize for his reporting of important labor stories.
WASHINGTON, July 10 (AP) -- Senator Norris paused today on the eve of his eighty-first birthday to talk about his thirty-nine years in Congress.

One of the most disheartening news items of this war for track and field athletes of this country was contained in a cable message by The United Press from Pernambuco, Brazil, which was published in a recent edition of THE TIMES.

OTTAWA, Ont., July 10 -- A report that three ships forming part of a fourteen-ship convoy were torpedoed last Saturday night opposite Cap Chat in the St. Lawrence River formed the matter of a question in the House of Commons this afternoon by J.S. Roy, member for Gaspe.

PATERSON, N.J., July 10 -- The Wright Aeronautical Employes Association, collective bargaining agency for employes of five plants of the Wright Aeronautical Corporation in Paterson and vicinity, announced that negotiations for a contract were broken off today on the question of the union's demand for a general wage increase of 10 cents an hour.

Hindered by uncertainties over the ultimate fate of the full parity loan bill, the cotton market became quiet and hesitant yesterday as traders tabled buying orders pending the final turn in the legislative situation. Stalled demand and increased selling by commission houses caused active contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange to close 13 to 21 points, or 65 cents to $1.05 a bale, below Thursday's final prices.

WASHINGTON, July 10 -- The Ways and Means committee voted tonight a 1 per cent increase in each surtax bracket over the rates previously decided upon, and prepared to report tomorrow a war revenue bill which will raise about $6,000,000,000 according to estimates.

I note that Teunis Deelman, in a letter to your newspaper, complains that safety razor blades will last "only a few days at best." Mr. Deelman thinks we should "insist on getting better and longer-lasting" blades, "at least while the war is on."
ALBANY, July 10 (AP) -- Professor Coleman B. Cheney, Socialist party Gubernatorial candidate, was inducted into the Army today after his party's appeal for temporary deferment went unanswered.

New State and municipal financing scheduled for next week by eighteen municipalities and thirteen local public housing agencies aggregates $84,361,075, compared with $7,197,019 this week. The weekly average of new offerings for the year to date now stands at $23,299,444.

A call to men between the ages of 18 and 52 years to join the recently organized Engineer Amphibian Command will be issued formally at 8 P.M. Wednesday at a mass meeting at the Hotel Astor, it was announced yesterday by Commander Harold A. Baker of the United States Power Squadrons.

BOSTON, July 10 (AP) -- The Valdina Farms Irish-bred Rounders turned in a sizzling mile effort of 1:37 today to capture the Suffolk Downs feature mile race and label himself a definite starter in next Wednesday's $50,000 added Massachusetts Handicap.

BOSTON, July 10 (AP) -- Cecil (Tex) Hughson drove in three runs with a lusty double and single today to score half his team's tallies as he notched his ninth victory of the season while the Red Sox were defeating the Tigers, 6 -- 1.
MOSCOW, Saturday, July 11 (AP) -- The Soviet Bureau of Information issued the following today:

PHILADELPHIA, July 10 (AP) -- Mel Harder's four-hit pitching gave the Indians a 4-to-2 victory over the Athletics at Shibe Park today. The triumph reserved the Tribe's hold on third place in the American League, four games behind Boston and eight below New York.

CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va., July 10 -- A post-war future of peace and plenty was predicted as a practically assured possibility at today's sessions of the University of Virginia's Institute of Public Affairs. Speakers differed only as to how the result was to be brought about.

June weather here did not deviate startingly from normality for the month, records at the New York Meteorological Observatory in Central Park indicate, David R. Morris, meteorologist, said yesterday. The average temperature in the shade during June was 70.3 degrees, slightly above normal, against 71.2 in June, 1941.

Representatives of the armed services and civic and patriotic groups attended the dedication yesterday of an American flag and bronze plaque at St. Peter's Roman Catholic Church at Barclay and Church Streets.

WASHINGTON, July 10 -- The government will maintain an "open door policy" concerning news and information needed by the public for complete understanding of the war and the steps taken to win it, Elmer Davis, director of the new Office of War Information, promised today.
Displaying excellent foresight, the Yankees hopped on Johnny Niggeling for five runs at the Stadium yesterday before Johnny had retired more than two batters, and that was well.

The Army revealed yesterday that the next steps in its induction of officer candidates for the Women's Army Auxiliary Corps for this area would be the swearing in, "probably on Monday," of twenty additional candidates from among volunteers in the aircraft warning service and the announcement, "within a few days," of an additional number of successful applicants.
Many salt water anglers are still debating whether they should take time out some day and obtain a Coast Guard identification permit before they pack their tackle and go off for a day's fishing.

CHICAGO, July 10 -- If the war is lost, women can blame themselves for it, Mrs. Lorraine L. Blair, founder of the Women's Finance Forum of America, declared here today. They control most of the spending and therefore can turn billions of dollars into war savings bonds that will bring victory, she added.

Tiny hats with capricious trim of marabou, veiling and spangles were Fall millinery forecasts offered at a showing yesterday by Braagaard, 17 West Fifty-seventh Street. A trend toward whimsy was engagingly defined by a diminutive black velvet sailor complemented with two multicolored plumes of simulated ostrich feathers.

WASHINGTON, July 10 -- General Charles de Gaulle, head of the Free French National Committee, today sent Cordell Hull, Secretary of State, a telegram from London expressing "great satisfaction" at the arrival in London of United States representatives to the Free French movement and voicing confidence that collaboration between the Free French and this government would lead to "final victory of the United Nations."

The scrap rubber drive, which started on June 15, came to an end last midnight after a record-breaking collection of 534 tons for the day brought the total for the city to 5,792 tons -- a showing that Eugene F. McCabe, local director of the oil industry's salvage committee, hailed as "very good."

Six thousand Americans of Italian birth or descent cheered for the United Nations and broke into applause when Mayor La Guardia attacked Mussolini during a war bond rally in this city. Why shouldn't they? Some of them may once have thought Il Duce useful.

WASHINGTON, July 10 -- Stocks of domestic and foreign crude petroleum on July 4 totaled 253,280,000 barrels, according to the Bureau of Mines. This represented a decrease of 84,000 barrels in the week, comprising a decline of 180,000 in domestic stocks and an increase of 96,000 in foreign stocks.

CHUNGKING, China, July 10 (AP) -- The Chinese High Command announced today the recapture of Changshu, forty-five miles southwest of Nanchang, in a new repulse of the Japanese and a sharp setback of the invaders' latest push along the Kiangsi rail line to Hunan.

WASHINGTON, July 10 -- Lou E. Holland of Kansas City, was named today by Donald M. Nelson, chairman of the War Production Board, to head the $150,000,000 Smaller War Plants Corporation, set up under terms of a recent Act of Congress to help small producers to share in war contracts. Four directors also were appointed to serve with Mr. Holland.

WASHINGTON, July 10 (Wide World) -- The nation's builders are going to be scraping for materials -- even on military jobs. Such things as lumber, cement and asphalt are being added to the futures list of scarce goods in builders' plans, alongside such metal-precious items as plumbing, guttering and piping.
In the fourth inning of the All-Star game at the Polo Grounds Pete Reiser received credit for a hit on a play that some of us who saw it would like to have explained.

Efforts of those opposed to the renomination of Representative William B. Barry, Democrat, who is under attack as an "isolationist" in the Second Congressional District in Queens, to concentrate their forces met with success in part last night when John B. Ferris and Sidney Ackerman filed declinations of their designations with the Board of Elections a little before the time expired at midnight.
Celebration of Bastille Day next Tuesday by the French colony of New York will find Frenchmen marking the day separately and in-widely divergent moods.

WITH THE R.A.F. IN THE WESTERN DESERT, July 9 (U.P.) (Delayed) -- Snub-nosed bombers and sleek fighters roar in and out of this field in clouds of dust as young fliers from all sections of the United States arrive in increasing numbers.

BUENOS AIRES, Argentina, July 10 -- The first step toward applying the recommendation, of the Rio de Janeiro conference on severing wireless and other communications between this continent and the Axis States, was taken today when the Minister of Interior addressed a letter to the Director General of Posts and Telegraphs asking him whether he was in a position to put the suggestion into effect.

The report of the Western Union Telegraph Company for the five months ended on May 31, issued yesterday, shows a net income of $2,775,217, after operating expenses, taxes and other charges. This was equal to $2.65 a share on the company's 1,045,277 shares of capital stock outstanding. It compares with a net income of $3,044,721, or $2.91 a capital share, for the five months to May 31, 1941.

FREEPORT, L.I., July 10 -- The Coast Guard patrol here is rigidly enforcing the order issued July 1 by Rear Admiral Stanley V. Parker, captain of the Port of New York, requiring passengers on seagoing boats to obtain Coast Guard identification cards.
LONDON, July 10 -- A sharp and "highly successful" action by two light British naval vessels against six German minesweepers off the French coast last night was reported by the Admiralty today.

WASHINGTON, July 10 (AP) -- The Department of Agriculture, declaring that growing conditions rarely have been better at this season of the year for the country as a whole, said today that a "banner year" for production of crops and livestock for the United Nations' war needs appeared to be in the making.

DETROIT, July 10 -- The nation's war goods production will be $45,000,000,000 this year and $70,000,000,000 to $75,000,000,000 the next, Donald M. Nelson said in an address tonight at a dinner of the Automotive Council for War Production attended by 2,000 executives of the automobile industry.

JERUSALEM, July 10 -- The greater numbers of the Arabs, who had shown little interest in the Allied cause in the war, have been forsaking that indifference to show undeniable support for Britain in the face of the danger of Axis invasion of the Middle East, according to Taufiq Ibey Mufarrac, wealthy Egyptian publicist, in a statement to the writer today.

Benjamin M. Harris, 46 years old, a notorious "fence" for book thieves, entered a guilty plea yesterday in General Sessions to criminally receiving 200 rare books and pamphlets a sneak thief had stolen in the last four years from the Harvard-Andover Theological Seminary, Princeton University and Princeton Seminary, and Rutgers University.

Mayor La Guardia, who on more than one occasion has earned critical approval for his disciplined handling of an orchestral baton as well as for his histrionic gifts, exhibited another talent yesterday afternoon at the opening of the "Consumers Front, an Exhibition for Consumer Patriots," in the Entrance Hall of the Brooklyn Museum.
ST. LOUIS, July 10 -- Without fear of successful contradiction, it can be said the Giants today threw away their ball game with the Cardinals at Sportsman's Park.

After his mother had requested that high bail be set for him, Walter Bartholomew, 22 years old, of 8 Ebony Court, Brooklyn, was held in $10,000 bail for the grand jury by Magistrate John F.X. Masterson in Brooklyn Felony Court yesterday for setting a series of suspicious fires on boats in the Gerrittsen Beach and Sheepshead Bay sections of Brooklyn.

A sharp increase in shipments of United States currency to foreign countries in June and a decline in receipts from such countries were reported yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York in its monthly compilation on foreign movements of money. Shipments in June amounted to $1,236,000, compared with revised figures for May of $694,000, and receipts were $783,400, compared with revised figures for May of $864,500.
ST. LOUIS, July 10 -- Without fear of successful contradiction, it can be said the Giants today threw away their ball game with the Cardinals at Sportsman's Park.

Trustees of the Equitable Building, office skyscraper at 120 Broadway, were authorized yesterday by Federal Judge John C. Knox to take out a $16,000,000 war and bombardment insurance policy to cover this property.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., July 10 Mr. and Mrs. Ernest C. Wagner gave a reception this afternoon at Red Top Farm for Captain Gretton Calrow of the British Commission in Washington, who is spending the week with them. Mr. and Mrs. Wagner will give a luncheon tomorrow at the clubhouse of the National Golf Links of America for Captain Calrow.

NEW DELHI, India, July 10 (AP) -- The Royal Air Force, in announcing a new series of destructive raids on the Japanese in Burma, disclosed today that Japanese convoys of troops and supplies are moving steadily toward India under a continual rain of British bombs.

ORANGE, N.J., July 10 -- South America's two representatives, Francisco Segura of Equador and Alexo Russell of Argentina, qualified for the semi-finals of the New Jersey State championship at the Berkley Tennis Club today.

Introduced last night as "the man we are going to make the next Governor of New York State" at a closing session of the twenty-fourth annual convention of the Kings County American Legion, Attorney General John J. Bennett Jr. declared that "in the seven months since Pearl Harbor we have seen the American people respond quickly to the courageous program of President Roosevelt."

The First Piano Quartet, one of the earliest ensembles of its kind consisting of four pianists -- Adam Garner, Henry Holt, Vladimir Padwa and George Robert -- has been engaged for a guest appearance at the Lewisohn Stadium on Saturday evening, Aug. 1, it was announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, July 10 (AP) -- The Chesapeake Corporation won today a $6,990,082 tax argument with the Treasury. The Treasury agreed to abandon claims for that amount of 1936-38 income and excess profits taxes and undistributed profits tax.

Why isn't professional tennis successful? With men like Don Budge, Bobby Riggs, Frank Kovacs et al. in the field, the recent tournament at Forest Hills represented the best tennis that possibly could be offered at the present time. Yet only a mere handful of spectators turned out to see the competition.

Dean Dixon, young Negro conductor, returned last night to the Lewisohn Stadium, where he conducted once last year. He was to have had two concerts with the New York Philharmonic-Symphony this season, but rain earlier this week robbed him of his first date.

IF it be true, as I hold, that a nation like an individual has a soul, a conscience and a mission, it follows that there are some desertions, some denials, which no "sacred egotism," as it is called, can justify.

WASHINGTON, July 11 -- In what he cautiously refrained from making a test of his powers under the President's executive order, but rather of his acceptance as required consultant on war-news publication, Elmer Davis, the new director of the Office of War Information, came to a compromise with the War Department.

LONDON, July 11 (AP) -- The evidence of how German Propaganda Minister Joseph Goebbels is attempting to Nazify and control news in Norway, through secret daily instructions to the press, has just been smuggled out of Oslo.

Retail trade was generally good last week in the three major test markets of New York, Chicago and Los Angeles, according to the survey prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by Meyer Both Reports. Main-floor departments were busy. Clearances were active.

MINNEAPOLIS, July 11 -- Retail trade rallied in the district in the week to gain about 3 per cent over the previous week. Volume of sales was 6 per cent under the corresponding 1941 week. The four-week average was 7 to 8 per cent lower than a year ago.

WOODS HOLE, Mass. -- Cape Cod for years has been a sort of confirmed habit. One hears visitors threatening to try somewhere else. Few of them actually do. Back come the same Summer folks. War seems to have affected habit only in detail.

American submarines are now making the longest patrols in submarine history. Although the German submarine men, because of their intensive activity, seem to be the world's best, actually American submarine men are making longer and more dangerous patrols.

"STEADY as a beagle," Big Mike, the veteran baseball coach, called George after his first lesson as catcher, and thereupon the youngster who was just being initiated into the joys of the diamond won his coveted nickname.

WASHINGTON, July 11 -- Leon Henderson, Price Administrator, declared today that if the proposed Congressional limitations on the funds and authority of the Office of Price Administration should become law provisions for general maximum price regulation must be repealed.

WE have no one today who excels Dr. G.P. Gooch in the range and thoroughness of his knowledge of the history of modern times. Fortunately, his erudition is combined with a lucidity of style and a skill in the arrangement of his material which add to the value and attractiveness of his lectures and publications.

The stock market's movements were restricted yesterday, although the pace of trading for a short session was speeded up. Fractional changes in each direction ruled in the list, and final quotations were about even with the previous close. Business on the Stock Exchange was stepped up to 153,650 shares, the largest for a Saturday in more than a month, against 113,290 shares for the previous two-hour session.

WASHINGTON, July 11 -- When an estimated 20,000 more young women come to work in the nation's capital during the next six months, the unmarried majority of them will be faced with a housing situation which at present includes some 3,000 rooms in boarding houses, 900 rooms in two new hotels, and blueprints for $12,000,000 worth of war dormitories recently authorized by Congress.

NOT for a long time has this department concerned itself with the question of "escape literature" in a period such as the one through which we are living. There is one aspect of the matter which seems to me to have particular importance, and that is the fact that to an increasing extent the phrase is being used with an air of intolerant hostility.

MARSHALING of United Nations' broadcasting strength rather than scattered short-wave expansion has been conspicuous in the high-frequency radio field the past six months. Singapore, Burma, the Philippines are silent.

WASHINGTON, July 11 -- The average daily rate of expenditures for war purposes by government agencies rose to $158,600,000 in June, according to the War Production Board. The Federal Reserve Board estimated that in that month close to 50 per cent of industrial output represented production for war.

Seven public schools that took part in a campaign for the prevention of vandalism under the direction of the Bureau for the Prevention of Juvenile Delinquency, received awards from Mayor La Guardia yesterday at City Hall.

JAMESTOWN, N.Y., July 11 (AP) -- "The record of American labor under our defense and war program is not one to bring comfort and relief to Hitler and the Mikado," Senator Mead told a labor field day gathering at Celeron tonight.

The amateur gardener's year is sharply divided into two parts: that delightfully carefree (in retrospect) season before Japanese beetles come out of the ground -- and the rest of the Summer. This year beetles were reported devouring roses on a New York penthouse terrace as early as June 13, and it will probably be the end of October before the last few stragglers disappear, even though the peak period will have passed by mid-August.
THE fortunes of Dimitri Shostakovich are extraordinary. Indeed, they could only be what they are in wartime, and according to the tempo of this confused and desperate era.

BUENOS AIRES, July 11 -- At the annual Army-Navy dinner last Monday, President Ramon S. Castillo reaffirmed Argentina's neutrality more categorically than ever before. He evidently felt public opinion was behind him, for, not content with hinting that it was by no means certain the United States had the right on her side in her fight against this continent's enemies, he indulged in a tirade against "warmongers."

Biology, chemistry and physics have for many years been accepted as an integral part of the curriculum of a liberal arts college. Since the same basic science courses not only train students in the scientific method but also prepare them for teaching, research and industrial positions, the liberal arts college actively participates in producing scientists.

THROUGHOUT the land a mighty revolution is in progress. American industry is beating the plowshares of peacetime -- the autos, the electric refrigerators, the toasters and the washing machines -- into the swords of total war: planes, tanks and high explosive bombs. It is a revolution to which there can be but one end: the doom of Nazidom.
NEWARK, Del., July 11 -- Participation in the war effort by the University of Delaware has been expanded to include a Civilian Pilot Training Course in cooperation with the Army and Navy.

Officials of C.I.O. marine unions announced last week that their proposals for minimizing wartime dangers to merchant seamen were being given serious consideration by the Navy and that union grievances now being discussed with naval officers were receiving satisfactory attention.

WHITE MOUNTAINS, N.H. -- The White Mountain Garden Club has decided to curtail this season's activities, holding but three more meetings. Two will be held in August and one in September. Mrs. John W. Guider was named president, succeeding Mrs. Lawrence Gilman.

NEW CITY, N.Y., July 11--After deliberating sixteen hours and ten minutes and requesting dismissal at one point because they were unable to "believe the evidence," a jury of nine men and three women returned a verdict of guilty early today against Edward C. Dormann, 40-year-old Sheriff of Rockland County, and two other co-defendants accused of operating a short-lived numbers lottery last Spring.

New York State's American Labor party is a comparatively small organization. In the last gubernatorial election it polled only 416,979 votes in a total of 4,746,584. But in the eyes of the Democratic party those votes loomed large for without them Governor Herbert H. Lehman would not have gained his 64,394-vote victory over Thomas E. Dewey.

THE hobby began conventionally enough with Saint Bernard dogs. But it reached its climax with Gargantua the Great, who was "Buddy" while Gertrude Davies Lintz was bringing him up in her "jungle" on the outskirts of Brooklyn.

A highly articulate Dorset sheep, a beautiful mare fondling her 3-week-old foal and a strutting turkey wrote their own script as they took an unscheduled but prominent part in the dedicatory exercises that marked the opening yesterday at the Bronx Zoological Park of the first farm in that zoo in this country.

PHILADELPHIA, July 11 -- Retail sales last week showed an improvement in metropolitan department stores and women's apparel shops, but still ran behind in nearby communities. Five major department stores in the metropolitan area showed an increase of 28 per cent for the week and 8 per cent for the four-week period.

A LONG Radio Row the week's most interesting development was probably the news that, beginning July 30, a sponsored series of Thursday night broadcasts, based on the Stage Door Canteen, will be on the air over WABC and some forty other stations of the Columbia network.
PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., July 11 -- Long Island Sound's sixth special regatta of the Summer was washed down to thirty-four starters today at the Manhasset Bay Yacht Club.
The residents around Indian Lake in Crotona Park, the Bronx, breathed somewhat easier yesterday, safe in the knowledge that the mystery of the early morning "blood-freezing screams" has been solved.

OAK BLUFFS, Marthas Vineyard, Mass. -- That now popular vehicle of transportation, the bicycle, has a great advantage on Marthas Vineyard, historic little island off the Southern Massachusetts coast. Since the Vineyard is only twenty miles long and nine miles wide, distances between towns are short.

Mail orders in most wholesale markets last week were very light, reflecting, in some cases, the fact that there were so many buyers in town, and in others, indicating a slowness of activity, according to the weekly trade report prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by McGreevey, Werring Howell Company.

ELSWYTH THANE has written biographies and historical novels but apparently is now attracted by the blandishments of light fiction. "From This Day Forward" is a fairly frivolous and amusing love story with a background of bird-stalking -- ornithology, if you like.

WASHINGTON, July 11 -- A restriction which was inserted into the $1,856,000,000 war agencies appropriation bill to prevent one emergency establishment from "pirating" officials and employes of another, with increased salaries as the lure, threw consternation into the ranks of war workers here today.

CINCINNATI, July 11 -- The Dodgers defeated the Reds in a double-header today, but it took them nearly four hours to deliver the knockout punch in the second game, which they won in the fifteenth inning, 3 -- 2.

BOSTON -- "No gas, but plenty of git-up and git" seems to be the phrase for New England this vacation season. Two months ago a great many of those whose livelihood comes from playing host to the rest of America during the Summer months were ready to reach for the black bottle with the skull and crossbones on it.

WASHINGTON, July 11 -- The Office of Defense Transportation is preparing to take over control of all Great Lake tankers and use the New York Barge Canal more fully to get an additional 100,000 barrels of gasoline and fuel oil a day to the rationed Eastern seaboard, Joseph B. Eastman, director, said in testimony made public today.

Whether one is working over old soil or preparing new ground for planting, and whether the work is to be done in Spring, Summer or Fall, there is no part of garden practice more deserving to be stressed than the thorough mechanical preparation of the plot.
A great and destructive defeat of Red Army forces in the south of Russia was reported yesterday by the German High Command, according to German broadcasts recorded by The Associated Press.

ERIE, Pa. -- The venerable flagship Niagara, hero-vessel of the Battle of Lake Erie, has been further restored by the Pennsylvania Historical Commission. The work on its decks, hull and interior has been completed, and according to plans the masts, rigging and cannon are next to be dealt with.

The next two months are ideal for dividing and replanting all kinds of iris. This is the best time, also, to acquire at least a few of the magnificent new varieties now available from iris specialists at moderate cost. One can well afford to throw some of the older sorts "over the fence," if necessary, to make room for these wonderful newcomers that will give such striking flowers next Spring.

QUEBEC -- Golfers among the members of New York's Summer colony in Quebec have been polishing up their games within the past few weeks, in preparation for the Manoir Richelieu Shield tournament at Murray Bay, which starts tomorrow.

BAR HARBOR, Me., July 11 -- Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Train of New York will give a luncheon tomorrow at Sols Cliff, their oceanfront estate, for officers of the Naval Section Base and the Army Signal Corps Station. Luncheons were given this week for the officers by Baron and Baroness Alphonse de Rothschild and by Mr. and Mrs. R. Amory Thorndike.

THE July releases of Victor and Columbia bring forward two albums that make an illuminating juxtaposition. Arturo Toscanini conducts the NBO Symphony Orchestra in Beethoven's Eighth Symphony (M-908, three 12-inch records), and Sir Thomas Beecham directs the London Philharmonic Orchestra in Mozart's Symphony No. 38, in D, known as the Prague (M-509, three 12-inch records).

LAKE GEORGE, N.Y., July 11 -The Colony Opera Guild, composed of artists from the Oscar Seagle Music Colony, opened its third season last evening with Mozart's "Cosi Fan Tutte" in the Wikiosco Barn Theatre on the estate of Mrs. Charles S. Peabody. They will present "Haensel und Gretel" on July 31.

The latest forecast on the duck crop this year is that it is "extremely good" and those who have been surveying the prairie Provinces of Canada declare that they expect the increase this year to equal that of the past four years.

DEHYDRATED MEAT -- Dehydrated meat has now been added to the American food products which can be successfully shipped abroad under the Lend-Lease Act. It occupies roughly one-half the volume and weighs about one-fourth as much as the raw lean meat.

NEWARK, N.J., July 11 -- An alleged racket, in which unauthorized use of the name of the Navy Relief Society was purportedly made by three officials of a C.I.O. union in their efforts to obtain upward of $20,000 was disclosed here today by the Federal Bureau of Investigation.

SOMEWHERE IN ENGLAND, July 11 -- Not far from this town there is a new hospital built by the British which is about to be taken over by the United States Army, it was revealed today. But there will be little change in the staff because the hospital always has been operated by Americans.
Under cover of conditions that were bleak and dismal, the Browns suddenly decided at the Yankee Stadium yesterday that they had played the role of stooges for the world champions long enough.

THERE was much buzz and chatter circulating among film folk on Broadway last week as to what Warner Brothers would do in transposing the great soldier show, "This Is the Army," to the screen. Warners acquired the privilege of filming the sensational hit by popping up with an offer after every one assumed that it would go to Paramount.

Charging the Milk Cap Statistical Bureau of Philadelphia and eleven manufacturers, representing about 75 per cent of the total business booked by the paper disk milk bottle cap industry, with monopolizing and eliminating competition, the Federal Trade Commission ordered the respondents yesterday to cease their practices.

Net profit of the Tung-Sol Lamp Works, Inc., for the five months ended with May has been little more than sufficient to cover dividends of 20 cents a share each paid Feb. 1 and May 1 on the 80-cent no par cumulative preference stock, the company has reported to stockholders.

SIX group exhibitions disregarded the heat and the rain to open last week with a variety of work ranging from ultra-academic to ultra-modern. Five were entirely American in content, the other a mixture of American and European.

George Esselborn's Myth and Corny Shields's Aileen are the leaders over the season in the International Class of sloops on Long Island Sound, according to class figures. Myth, sailed by Arthur Knapp, has a percentage of .819 on the championship.

Max Mencher will be substitued for Edward B. Feinberg as the candidate of the right wing of the American Labor party in the Sixth Congressional District to run against Representative Andrew L Somers, Democrat, it was announced yesterday.

PRINTS by members of the Southgate Photographic Society of war-torn London will go on display Wednesday morning at the Metropolitan Camera Club Council, 106 West Thirteenth Street. The pictures were made during the war and crossed the Atlantic through submarine zones.

Ten children smiled yesterday and 100 others were sad by the banks of the Hudson River. The occasion was a doll contest at the playground at West Seventy-fourth Street and Riverside Park under the auspices of the Department of Parks.

TORONTO, July 11 (AP) -- Newark and Toronto split today's double-header, the league leaders taking the first game in ten innings, 6 to 3, while the Maple Leafs won the seven-inning nightcap, 5 to 2. The Leafs captured the series, 3 to 1.

WASHINGTON, July 11 -- A new approach to the supply problem of the country in a wartime economy lies behind this week's "realignment" of the War Production Board and Donald M. Nelson's assertion on Wednesday that WPB would have the final say on the allocation of available materials.
ROCHESTER, N.Y., July 11 (AP) -- Jumping all over two hurlers for 16 hits, the second-place Jersey City Giants defeated the last-place Red Wings today, 12 to 3.

THE saga of Orson Welles's Mercury Productions reached a momentary impasse at midweek when Mr. Welles's henchmen, asked to leave the RKO premises by Charles Koerner, new head of the studio, established an embattled position in the Hollywood hills north of the Trocadero night club to await the return of their leader from Brazil late this month.

A TRANSATLANTIC Clipper plane brings a cover bearing seven new stamps issued by the Belgian Congo. These are 1-franc purple and black, 1.25fr scarlet and black, head of a native woman; 1.75fr deep brown, spotted leopard; 3.50fr :olive, 6fr bright blue, 10fr violet l !brown, a native soldier; 20fr red violet and black, an okapi.
SAN FRANCISCO, July 11 -- By a unanimous decision, the State Supreme Court today declared unconstitutional a 1940 law barring the Communist party from the ballot.

BALTIMORE, July 11 (AP) -- Theodore Roosevelt McKeldin, a Baltimore lawyer, was drafted as the Maryland Republican Gubernatorial candidate by an authorized party committee today, less than twenty-four hours after Mr. McKeldin said he was not a candidate for the nomination.

Tami Mauriello, Bronx heavyweight contender, will tackle Tony Musto of Chicago in the feature bout of eight rounds at the Bronx Coliseum on Tuesday night. The semi-final, also listed for eight rounds, will bring together Johnny Marcelline and Diogenes Leon.

On his two legs he performed all his land journeys for centuries. He kept on walking most of the time even when he had tamed a four-footed fellow-creature to carry him on his longer and speedier journeys.

GREENSBORO, N.C., July 11 -- A "festival of citizens," white and Negro alike, will be celebrated here tomorrow to draw public attention to the importance of inter-racial cooperation in serving national morale and the unity of the American people. Bennett College for Negro women will play host to an "America Be Strong" rally.

NUTLEY, N.J., July 11 -- Charley Whitehead, sturdy Plainfield golfer who has made a habit of winning the New Jersey State amateur title, today made a good start toward adding the State open crown to his list of triumphs. At the halfway point of the tournament he and Corporal Vic Ghezzi of Fort Monmouth are leading with totals of 142.

To substantiate his praise of the zeal with which women are working in neighborhood defense councils, Aubrey Malloch, director, tells the story of one worker assigned to locate free headquarters. The greatest battles of 1942 were being fought in the "unknown war" on the Russian front last week as the German armies drove across the Don toward the Volga, heart of Russia. The great offensive, so long expected, had at length started -- started with a smashing advance by the enemy who quickly added another acute danger to the one already posed by his advance into Egypt.

PRIZES are regularly offered for novels in manuscript. One award now outstanding packs a chance to win $12,000 with a detective story. Some of the contests are open only to limited groups -- school teachers, college undergraduates, etc., the idea being that if a person feels that he is up against only his peers he is more apt to stir himself and produce a novel.

As a nation, to escape sacrifice is impossible; to succumb to inflation, unforgivable. Whether or not we are to have inflation depends entirely upon whether we meet intelligently and courageously the inescapable demands of wartime sacrifice.

WHEN Mary Heaton Vorse had lived for thirty-five years in Provincetown a village neighbor said, "We've gotten to think of you as one of us." And she could appreciate the compliment of that acceptance, after long novitiate.

LONDON, July 11 -- Both Dutch and British interests here have taken exception to a statement made recently by Jesse H. Jones, Secretary of Commerce, to a committee of the United States Senate, that these two governments had been unwilling heretofore to sell to the United States adequate supplies of raw rubber because they feared price declines after the war if production expanded sufficiently to meet the requirements.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Brazil, July 11 -- The feasibility of setting a ceiling on prices for exports of the United States to Latin America is seriously doubted by American business men in Brazil, it was disclosed today.

PRINCETON, N.J., July 11 -- As another step in reshaping its curriculum to provide training that will be useful to students during and after the war, Princeton University announced today the establishment of Near Eastern and Far Eastern programs of study.

Advocating greater emphasis on courses dealing with the growth and development of this country, Dr. John W. Studebaker, United States Commissioner of Education, has recommended that all students take a social studies sequence through high school and college, to include American history, geography, economics and government.

One of the largest crowds of the season turned out at the Lewisohn Stadium last night to hear Paul Robeson as soloist with the New York Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra under the direction of Alexander Smallens. The famous baritone was received with enthusiasm, as he sang works by Mendelssohn and Mussorgsky, the solo part of "Ballad for Americans" by Earl Robinson and John LaTouche and a group of songs.

WASHINGTON, July 11 -- State Fair Trade prices rather than ceiling prices are to govern in cases where they conflict, and the State Fair Trade Price is the one which has been generally observed by the trade, OPA announced today in clarification of a problem which has arisen in New York and other States.

The Board of Education is to expand its facilities for unemployed men who wish to get war training, George F. Pigott Jr., associate superintendent in charge of the war industries training program, announced yesterday. The board now has twenty-six schools that will provide 5,000 additional war workers with free courses.

Naturally, therefore, Egyptologists have felt the need for a new discussion of ancient Egypt, which would bring into complete and proper focus a generation's findings in archaeological research.

PHILADELPHIA, July 11 -- The first year of active work in the enforcement of the rules of the National Association of Securities Dealers, Inc. -- a test of self-policing on such a scale as to be unique in the industry -- has come to a close with results indicating a solemn acceptance of responsibility by a vast majority of the members and a firm hand in dealing with those who were remiss.

MELBOURNE, Australia, July 11 (Netherlands Indies News Agency) -- The Japanese in the Netherlands Indies are attempting to maintain both a literal and an information blackout over the archipelago.

NEWFOUND LAKE, N.H. -- A new feature for this area is an outdoor cathedral, built on the eastern shore of the lake at East Hebron, near the Hillside Inn, where the Rev. Douglas Horton of New York will give the address this afternoon at the second in a series of nine vesper services.

CHICAGO, July 11 -- Buying of wheat for future delivery to flour mills was absent today, and with a bearish construction placed on the Department of Agriculture's estimate of the crop issued late yesterday, prices of that grain on the Board of Trade declined quickly and the close was about the bottom with losses of 3/4 to 1 cent a bushel.

AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, Australia, July 11 (U.P.) -- Silver Star awards were made today to six officers of the United States Army Air Forces for gallantry in action, including a general who personally led two Flying Fortress bomber raids on the Japanese base at Kupang, on Timor Island.

WASHINGTON, July 11 -- Mutual aid agreements were signed today between the United States and Norway and Czechoslovakia, bringing to nine the governments with which we now have formal pacts dealing with lease-lend and other wartime activities and providing for closer economic cooperation after the war.

NEWPORT, R.I., July 11 -- This city will have a Dimout Ball on Aug. 8, and plans are already under way to make it one of the major entertainments of the season for the Summer colonists. It will be given on the Casino grounds and will be another in the series of benefits for Newport Chapter, American Red Cross.

Captain William Eason, skipper of the thirty-five-ton harbor tug Reeda, paused in his rounds along the New Jersey waterfront yesterday to receive the congratulations of officials of the Todd Hoboken Dry Docks on the completion of twenty-five years of service in the wheelhouse of the little craft.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, July 11 -- A new program of physical education for "self-preservation" is being inaugurated at Western Reserve University under the direction of Robert M. Grueninger, associate Professor of Physical Education. Dr. Winfred G. Leutner, president of the university, announced today, following faculty action.

WASHINGTON, July 11 -- The Congressional farm bloc, biggest, strongest and most potent of the vote-garnering formations on Capitol Hill, is split and fighting within itself. What the battle will produce in inflationary reactions, in effects upon the cost of living, in the effectiveness or lack of it of the Food-for-Freedom Program or in other "solutions" to one of Washington's most baffling muddies in years, depends, it appears, upon who plays the politics, and how.

To Albert La Grange, former purser of the Holland-America liner Pennland, the Cross of Merit of the Netherlands has been awarded by Queen Wilhelmina for heroism displayed when his ship was sunk by aerial bombs off Crete.

RANGELEY LAKES, Me. -- Many Summer visitors are expected to arrive in this lake and mountain resort section this week as the mid-July vacation season gets into full swing. Hotel and resort operators look forward optimistically to the vacation weeks of late July and August, which have always found the Rangeley Lakes region filled.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I. -- Plans have been completed for the Navy Relief Ball to be held on Saturday night at the Elks clubhouse for the benefit of the Navy Relief Society. The Southampton Lodge of Elks has donated the use of the clubhouse for the occasion, and the cost of the orchestra for dancing has been contributed by a member of the Summer colony.

CAIRO, Egypt, July 11 -- Attacking the northern flank of the semi-circular Axis front west of El Alamein, Dominion troops of the British Eighth Army pushed westward five miles along the coastal railway yesterday, capturing 1,500 enemy troops and destroying eighteen Axis tanks in the advance.
PHILADELPHIA, July 11 (AP) -- Shut out for four innings without a man reaching base, the Indians packed their entire attack into the fifth and sixth frames today and defeated the Athletics, 3 to 1.

NEW LONDON, Conn. -- Thousands of Summer visitors have moved into seaside homes and hotels during the last two weeks, awakening doubtful natives to the fact that the present season is one of boom proportions in many respects.

WASHINGTON, July 11 -- A statement was issued by the C.I.O. today, asserting in effect that it was almost the only force left in the United States which was fighting to carry out President Roosevelt's "indivisible" seven-point anti-inflation program.
