WASHINGTON. SOME men of fixed purpose succeed because a sufficiently large number of people understand and approve what they have in mind. Others fail because enough people understand but do not approve. It is one of Thurman Arnold's private tribulations that he cannot get people to comprehend a rather simple economic philosophy.

Each of the Liberty ships under construction as a part of the Maritime Commission's 2,300-ship program for 1942 and 1943 requires 13,425 tons of steel. Seven hundred tons goes into "shapes" and the remainder is for plates. Tankers and larger vessels of the commission's standard building program require between 600 and 1,600 more tons foe each ship, depending on the type.

FROM LIBYA: The young Republi-i can member from Massachusetts was asked a couple of years ago to preside temporarily over the United States Senate. Henry Cabot Lodge Jr. sat in the august chair, tipped it back too far, toppled over.
SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., July 11 -- Members of society here continue to spend the greater part of their time in various wartime enterprises to meet an ever-increasing demand for supplies and funds.

SARANAC INN, N.Y., July 11 -Mr. and Mrs. Philip Harding of London, brother-in-law and sister of Vincent Astor, have leased for the season Camp Tootooch on the Back Bay here, the place of the Rev. Dr. Henry Darlington, rector of the Church of the Heavenly Rest, New York, and Mrs. Darlington.

The British Admiralty has constructed a large number of concrete barges which have carrying capacities that range from 180 to 200 tons and which have endured grueling tests for seaworthiness and water-tightness. The hulls are built of pre-cast slabs connected by means of narrow concrete stiffening members cast in place.

IN this distinguished novel for older girls Gertrude Robinson has given us more than a portrait of a remarkable heroine. She has caught the essential qualities of the pioneer woman --- of, indeed, the American woman in the making.

British kennel clubs and exhibitors have had one more burden imposed upon them because of the war and, as a result of the latest edict of the Kennel Club, it will be increasingly difficult to hold successful shows and matches in the United Kingdom.
WOODSTOCK -- Concerts, war benefits and art exhibitions are on the calendar for this colony as the Catskill season nears the midseason peak.

CHICAGO, July 11 -- A little brown filly named Fad, winner of one of her two previous starts, galloped to an amazingly easy triumph in the $35,000 Arlington Lassie Stakes today and paid off at the longest odds in the fourteen-year history of the race.

Five hundred of the 1,000 elementary and high school teachers who will participate in the New York City Board of Education's Summer Workshop on the War and the Curriculum have already gone into action and are helping revamp curricula and teaching methods to gear the schools to a nation at war and facing a task of post-war reconstruction.

NOT all the significant events of a season concern themselves directly with the creation or the performance of works of art, and in the season that is just behind us at least half a dozen items outside these categories stand out in varying degrees as accomplishments of more than passing moment.
MOSCOW, Sunday, July 12 (AP) -- The Russian midnight communique follows:

Now is the time when the foresighted gardener looks forward to the Fall displays in his borders and makes preparations to assure them. After the lush flowers of the midsummer season begin to look tired and show signs of failing, at least a few bright spots are needed to help postpone the coming of Winter.

WASHINGTON, July 11 -- Declaring that persons should not be deprived of employment because they are aliens, President Roosevelt said today that the employment of aliens, including friendly subjects of enemy countries, would be permitted in war industries and even upon secret military production items under certain conditions.

Endorsement of a ruling by the Federal Trade Commission restraining resident buyers from accepting fees from sellers if they are representing a purchaser of merchandise was given yesterday by J. Perlmutter, managing director of the National Association of Merchandise Brokers, Inc.

An exhibition of war relics and paraphernalia gathered from many fronts of the present war will open with an invitation preview Tuesday night at the Museum of Science and Industry, Rockefeller Center. The occasion will be a benefit for the Greater New York Fund-United Service Organizations Joint War Appeal.

WASHINGTON, July 11 -- The doors of the courtroom where the eight Nazi saboteur-spies are being tried secretly by seven Army generals were opened today in a remarkable departure from rigid Army procedure so that a group of newspaper representatives might view the tribunal, the prisoners and all the other figures in the historic scene.

WASHINGTON, July 11 -- All American soldiers assigned to duty in Britain will receive a War Department handbook designed to inform them about British customs and to bridge over the difference between these and American practices, the department announced today.

CAIRO, Egypt, July 11 -- The best way to knock out tanks is with high-velocity anti-tank guns, with field artillery firing over open sights or with infantry raiders operating at night with bombs. The way not to attack tanks is with other tanks.

The synthetic rubber program, which got off to a poor start because of charges and countercharges as to the responsibility in its delay and the many processes that could be used, now definitely is making excellent progress. On the whole the program is on schedule, and it now appears, barring some unforeseen developments, that enough rubber substitutes will be available within a year for military purposes and for essential civilian demands.

BRANDON, Vt. -- In the same range as the Washingtons, Mansfields and Whitefaces of the East, with their motor car roads to the summit, there are less lofty mountains with foot paths much more interesting because of their own unique formation and their more picturesque surroundings.

EVANSTON, Ill., July 11 -- Cooperating to the fullest extent in the war program, Northwestern University has not forgotten that the day will come when the last shot has been fired and the difficult problems of a return to peacetime conditions must be faced.

Six hundred educators, clergymen, writers and labor leaders joined yesterday in petitioning President Roosevelt to countermand Attorney General Francis Biddle's order for the deportation of Harry Bridges, California C.I.O. director.

THE plaintive note in your article of June 28 which curled finally into the general query, What do radio listeners think of somebody like Lou Holtz, whom they have never seen, prompts me to offer this reply, the situation otherwise hanging like one of those awkward silences which follow a question delivered openly to a roomful of people.

Wartime priorities are quickly changing our homes as well as our way of living in general. Take lamps, for example. All-metal lamps -- brass, chromium, bronze, pewter and painted tin or tole - are disappearing from the stores and, to take their place, a procession of new pottery, wood, glass and plastic models is moving in.

A PARTIAL answer to the question "What has become of Kirsten Flagstad since her return to Europe?" is provided in a letter to Joseph Szigeti written by his daughter from her home in Switzerland. The singer, she said, was the star of three operatic productions in the Zurich Festival last month.
LONDON, July 10 -- Women and girls are contributing thirteen and a half per cent of the labor in Britain's iron and steel industry and the number is constantly increasing.

The story of Russia's military strength is the story of space, endless space. Armies that have crowded all rivals off the face of Europe have marched into Russia and been swallowed up in the vast brown landscape rolling away to the east. Napoleon learned 130 years ago that a battle won in Russia does not have the same meaning as a battle won in Austria; there is always room in Russia for another battle.

A new attendance program, designed to educate students toward an "unlimited cut system" will go into effect at Hunter College in September, it was announced yesterday by Academic Dean Eleanor Hunsdon Grady. The new system allows an unlimited number of class absences for all seniors and those juniors, sophomores and freshmen who earn the grade of C or better.

Sixth columnist is the term applied by the more intolerant New Dealers to those who dare to criticize the Administration's conduct of the war on the domestic front, the inference being that the critics seek to create national disunity in this great emergency. Fortunately, the American people are now quite familiar with the New Deal political device of impugning the motives of those whose charges cannot be controverted.

A striking object lesson of the need for dimming out lights in coastal cities was taught in a Navy Department press release from a Florida port yesterday. The second officer of a British merchant vessel, which was torpedoed within ten miles of the coast at 2:30 A.M. Tuesday, blamed the light of the port, which he said could be seen thirty-five miles out at sea and which plainly silhouetted passing ships for lurking submarines.

Proceedings of the Eighth Pan-American Child Congress held recently in Washington are reviewed in the monthly bulletin of the Children's Bureau. The "Declaration of Opportunities" adopted opens with this one: "Opportunity for every child to grow up within the loving care and affectionate discipline of family life."

In the Summer of 1941 Russia became the victim of German aggression. She was suddenly on our side; and when, after Dec. 9, we ourselves entered the war she became, by force of circumstances, our military ally.
It is an interesting and simple procedure to raise a crop of young bulbs of the Jacobean Lily (Sprekelia formosissima) from seed produced by a blossom on one's own window-sill.

CHICAGO, July 11 -- While the Chicago furniture market ended the first two weeks with a better than expected showing in sales and a none too satisfactory attendance record, John W. McClure, secretary-treasurer of the National Hardwood Lumber Association, came back from a series of Washington conferences with a warning that in all probability there will not be enough lumber of all types to meet government war needs, to say nothing of filling civilian demand.
PRINCETON, N.J., July 11 -Five members of Princetons coaching and athletic administration staffs have resigned since Dec. 7 to enter the armed forces or war industries, a survey reveals.

CHUNGKING, China, July 11 (AP) -- Linchwan, a base for Japan's 30,000-man drive in Kiangsi, was bombed by United Nations planes yesterday "with satisfactory results," Lieut. Gen. Joseph W. Stilwell's headquarters announced tonight, while the resurgent Chinese ground forces reported the Japanese were being driven back steadily toward Linchwan and Nanchang.

A further increase in the ratio of cash to credit sales, continuing at least for several months, was foreseen by retail executives here at the week-end as preliminary estimates indicated about 25 per cent of the charge accounts of customers of local stores were "frozen" when amendments to Regulation W of the Federal Reserve Board became effective last Friday.

The British are doing well with the Kittyhawk bomber, sometimes called the Kitty bomber. It is named for the village on the North Carolina coast where the Wright brothers had their shops during the time they were preparing for the world's first flight by a heavier-than-air craft.

ALBUQUERQUE, N.M., July 11 -- Visiting professors are nothing new in the educational world. Neither are visiting lecturers. But a new turn to an old story has been accomplished at the University of New Mexico this Summer, through the agency of the Department of Government and Citizenship and the office of Dr. James F. Zimmerman, president of the university.

Progressive education strode forward this year, notably through reports on the Six Year Study in the New York City public schools and the Eight Year Study in the colleges. As these reports show, the progressive method turns out students superior in academic work and adaptability.
MOSCOW, July 9 (Delayed) (U.P.) -- The German Army is unable to launch an offensive along the entire Russian-German front in 1942 as it did last year.
The following German High Command communique was broadcast from Berlin yesterday and was recorded here by The Associated Press:

WASHINGTON, July 11 -- The Office of Price Administration said today that Americans were consuming nearly all the sugar they produced and imported. Answering recent statements that sugar stocks were piling up in the warehouses, OPA said the sugar rationing plan must be continued on about its present basis while the small excess of supply over demand was bringing abnormally low carryover stocks back to a sound level.

LEE, Mass., July 11 (AP) -- President Roosevelt, replying to a Fourth of July greeting from Queen Wilhelmina of the Netherlands, predicted closer post-war collaboration between the United States and the Netherlands "in building the better world which will follow the inevitable defeat of Hitlerism."

The second Saturday noon test of the new 115-horsepower super siren atop the RCA Building at Rockefeller Center yesterday was "excellent," it was announced by William C. Wheary, raid-alarm expert for the Office of Civilian Defense at Washington.

BERNE, Switzerland, July 11 -- Diplomatic circles in Berlin, says a dispatch from that capital today, are informed that a movement to restore the monarchy in Spain has been in progress for several weeks. Don Juan, son of the late King Alfonso, has been designated heir to the Bourbon crown.

The pitchfork used by the farmer who captured Rudolf Hess, Nazi leader, when his plane landed in Scotland in 1941 will be on exhibition this week with various implements of war and air raids paraphernalia at the Museum of Science and Industry or New York, 30 Rockefeller Plaza.

Some weeks ago 300 soldiers, brought from training camps as far distant as the Pacific Coast, were assigned to special duty at Camp Upton. Now this detachment has taken over the Broadway Theatre, in New York, where they are putting on "This Is the Army" for the benefit of the Army Emergency Relief Fund.

WASHINGTON, July 11 (AP) -- Although the veteran Bill Dietrich allowed twelve hits, the White Sox defeated the Senators, 5 -- 3, tonight before 6,000 spectators. Early Wynn and Bill Zuber held Chicago to eight hits. The victory gave the Sox a sweep of the two-game series.

UNDER the fiscal year system of running the theatre -- that is, considering a season as lasting from June 1 to the next May 31 -- the current season thus far is practically tops. Since the first day of June eight shows have opened on Broadway, and five of them are hits -- "By Jupiter," "Laugh, Town, Laugh," "Star and Garter," "Stars on Ice" and "This Is the Army."

CHICAGO, July 11 -- Evidence that the ceilings placed by the Office of Price Administration on beef in wholesale and retail channels are a serious threat to the nation's potential beef supply is piling up daily in all market centers, livestock interests in the Chicago stockyards declared today.

Householders heeding the appeal of salvage officials continued yesterday to turn in their scrap rubber even though the salvage campaign had ended formally on Friday at midnight. Calls offering 15,000 pounds of rubber were made by telephone yesterday, Clarence H. Low, chairman of the New York City Salvage Committee, announced.

BOSTON, July 11 -- Loveday, owned by Mrs. William R. Flemming, captured the $10,000 added Hannah Dustin Handicap at Suffolk Downs, where more than $65,000 was realized for the Army and Navy relief funds today.
CLEVELAND, July 11 (AP) -- The count was three and two on gravely ill Tris Speaker today, but baseball's immortal outfielder wasn't ready to strike out.

A series of courses designed to increase civilian participation in the war effort, offered cooperatively by the New York University School of Education and Teachers College in a Summer program, opened last week at the Benjamin Franklin High School, East River Drive and 116th Street.

ASBURY PARK, N.J. -- With hotel reservations for July and August declared to be at the "highest level" in the past twenty years, resort activities in this section are shaped for the entertainment of Summer visitors, many of whom are here to spend their vacations with friends and relatives stationed at near-by Army posts.

COLOMBIAN postage stamps that carry portraits are the subject of the fifth pamphlet, published last week, in the "Philatelic Who's Who" series being released by the Latin-American stamp section of the Pan American Union at Washington, under the direction of Albert F. Kunze.

WHEN we began a pine plantation on the side of our mountain, our older country neighbors warned us not to plant any of the baby trees near butternut trees. "As far as a butternut casts its shade at noon," they informed us gravely, "that shade'll kill anything that grow -- except young butternuts."

ON a sultry afternoon or evening, when not a leaf is stirring and merely breathing seems almost too much of an effort, most Americans find their greatest solace in a tall glass of something very cold.

Visitors to Nova Scotia searching out native folkways will find the Mod which takes place July 24, at St. Ann's, Cape Breton, a unique survival of an ancient custom. "Mod" is the Gaelic word for the literary and musical congress that annually brings out the singers and poets of the Cape Breton area in a competitive display of their talents.

WASHINGTON, July 11 -- Establishment of a Pan-American League of Nations "as soon as possible" was advocated in a press conference here today by President-elect Alfonso Lopez of Colombia, who has concluded a series of conferences in Washington with President Roosevelt and other high officials.
Although many forms of business throughout the country have been affected adversely by the war, one type of enterprise here appears to have escaped ill effects.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., July 11 -The most recent demonstration of what educational cooperation can mean to a community is shown here in Nashville by the establishment of the Nashville School of Social Work by Vanderbilt University, Peabody College and Scarritt College.

VIDKUN QUISLING'S birthday, next Saturday, is Nazily proclaimed as a national holiday in Norway, to take the place of the Norwegian Independence Day, May 17. For Norsemen who may find difficulty in working up enthusiasm over Herr Quisling's natal day, the Nazi historians discover, conveniently, that July 18 is also the anniversary of the greatest battle fought by King Harold I in his drive to establish Norwegian national unity.

CHUNGKING, China, July 11 (U.P.) -- The Japanese who drove through Burma and were stopped at the Salween River in Western Yunnan are suffering from malaria and dysentery, according to a British medical worker who arrived in Chungking from the Salween front.
FRANCONIA, N.H. -- More popular than ever here are the buggies, carriages and carts of the hotels. Peckett's-on-Sugar-Hill is using its century-old coach for picnics and trips.
PITTSBURGH, July 11 (AP) -- The Pirates cut loose with a sixteen-hit barrage, including a jackpot homer by Elbie Fletcher, to rout the Phils today, 12 to 5.

PANAMA, July 11 -- The broken, island-fringed coastline of the Caribbean, wriggling roughly 3,000 miles from the Yucatan Channel to Trinidad, off the coast of Venezuela, has become a happy hunting ground for German submarines.
THE chief theatrical event since last I wrote has been the production of "Lifeline," by Norman Armstrong.

Both Japan and Germany undoubtedly have been restrained in mistreatment of captured or interned Americans by the fact that the United States could apply "effective sanctions" against the many Japanese and Germans in this country, according to a conclusion in the annual report of a special committee of the American Bar Association made public yesterday.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., July 11--To prepare students for civil service translator's examinations and other practical ends, Vassar College will next year offer courses in French, German, Spanish and Russian which will afford intensive training in translation of technical or otherwise difficult material.

MOSCOW, Sunday, July 12 -- The German spearhead east of the Don River has pushed forward a few miles to the outskirts of Voronezh, on the Moscow-Rostov railway, the Soviet High Command said today, but it was indicated that two German thrusts south of Voronezh on the 200-mile front in the southwest had made little or no headway.

THOUGH it is a rare week that does not find a new candidate for favor among the kilocycles, the radio's first-nighters must have been put to it to keep track of them all as they (the new candidates) crowded to the microphone these last few days -- the so-called Summer shows that would make a little hay while the September-to-June stars shine elsewhere or, perhaps, just enjoy a holiday dimout.
PORT HURON, Mich., July 11 (AP) -- The Iris, 72-foot sloop owned by Harry Fletcher of Alpena, swept to an early lead today in the eighteenth annual sailing race up Lake Huron to Mackinac Island.

DOROTHY WORDSWORTH had once written, "Happily we cannot shape the huge hills or carve out the valleys according to our fancy," and it is this spirit that is behind the impersonal charm of her journals. She did not attempt to solve the mysteries of nature, or think it her duty to change the universe, but to understand, feel and record as honestly as possible.

How the peoples suffering under the heel of the Nazi invader are resisting and waging an unceasing campaign of sabotage and opposition in the hope that some day the victory of the United Nations will bring them liberation is told in a new pamphlet, impressively illustrated, issued under the title "The Unconquered People" by the Office of War Information.

Reuben Fine of Washington, open chess champion of the United States, won last week's national rapid transit tournament with the loss of only two games of twenty-two contested, and the feat remains the main topic of discussion in metropolitan chess circles.

The Chinese garden at Rockefeller Center is attracting large numbers of visitors. This garden, just opened, has been named "Mei-Ling," in honor of Mme. Chiang Kai-shek, and provides all the charm for which Chinese gardens are famed.

Synthetic rubber, new plastics, light metals in unprecedented amounts, substitutes for tin and copper, fats collected from households and factories and converted into glycerine -- what is to become of our vast effort to branch out industrially in new directions? Out of the last war came a healthy American chemical industry, optical glass, the commercial airplane, streamlined trains.

At this time of year the Asclepias tuberosa, commonly known as Butterfly-weed, makes a brilliant display by many a roadside. Known as the aristocrat of the Milkweed family the Butterfly-weed puts on a grand show wherever grown. It likes a sandy loam in full sun but will do well in other soils if well drained.

The government drive against spies, saboteurs and enemy aliens brought additional results yesterday as the local office of the Federal Bureau of Investigation announced the arrest here of 158 German aliens, among them thirty women, on charges that they are dangerous to the security of the United States.

A campaign to save from extermination one of the rarest and most beautiful of native wild flowers, the Fringed Gentian, is being sponsored by the Massachusetts Horticultural Society and the New England Wild Flower Preservation Society.

The Navy Department announced yesterday the sinking of five more United Nations merchant vessels by submarines in the Atlantic or Caribbean. A medium-sized American ship was sunk in the South Atlantic and another in the Caribbean, a medium-sized Britisher went down off the Atlantic coast and a small Greek ship was sunk in the Caribbean.

NORMAL, Ill., July 11 -- If the Army and Navy requests for concentrated programs in science, mathematics, and physical science are to be met by the public schools, competent teachers in these fields should be exempt from military service, Dr. J.W. Carrington, director of the Illinois State Normal University Appointments Bureau, said today.

TO the fighting men of Madison Barracks at Sacketts Harbor, N.Y., the name of Private Joe Healey is coming to mean as much as Mary Marlin or Amanda of Honeymoon Hill does to the women of America. For "The Adventures of Private Joe Healey," their own soap opera, comes to them each Monday night over the "Star Spangled Network" -- the country's first camp station, run by and for the soldiers.

CHICAGO, July 11 -- Big Bill Lee didn't last long on the mound today in his third effort to score his tenth victory of the season, but the Cubs' veteran remained long enough to present a 4-to-2 victory to the Braves.

WASHINGTON, July 11 -- Wartime development of transatlantic air passenger service has been cloaked with such secrecy, and subordinated by reports of more dramatic action to suck a degree that the United States has seen it become routine with less fanfare than in peacetime would accompany the setting of a new speed record by an ocean liner.

LITCHFIELD, Conn. -- In spite of gasoline and tire rationing, vacationists arrived in large numbers at the hotels and camps throughout the Litchfield Hills this week-end. Visitors have found that a new type of vacation awaits them here.

Fearful lest they be caught short, the cotton trade here and New Orleans interests rushed to cover yesterday near the end of trading on the New York Cotton Exchange, running the most lackadaisical market in months from slight losses to closing gains of 11 to 16 points, the session's highs, for active months.

BURLINGTON, Vt. -- Golf and tennis tournaments are getting under way in the Green Mountains. Class A and Class B club championships will be held at the Burlington Country Club beginning next Thursday and continuing through Sunday.

The report submitted by George E. Folk to the National Association of Manufacturers drives home a point which has been overlooked in the controversy waged by Thurman Arnold with large corporations that have sought to control markets and prices through patents -- the point that "no patent holder * * * could have stopped the Government from using his patented inventions in any kind of industrial expansion for Government purposes."

THE Chicago Opera will sponsor two events this Summer in Soldiers' Field in Chicago. The first win consist of a concert led by Andre Kostelanetz with Lily Pons as soloist, and the second, on Aug. 8, will be an opera performance.

POCONO MOUNTAINS, Pa. -- Pocono resorts have well-filled and varied schedules for the coming week. The Buck Hill Dramatic Club will present its first major production of the season, Francis Swan's comedy, "Out of the Frying Pan," at the inn on Friday, July 17.

Direct obligations of the Federal Government maturing within the next twelve months amount to more than $7,400,000,000, the largest volume of maturities for any twelve-month period in this country's financial history.

BEAR MOUNTAIN, N.Y., July 11--Miss Marilyn Sahner of Great Neck, L.I., free style swimming champion, retained her metropolitan title at 110 yards today in the A.A.U. meet at the Bear Mountain pool. She triumphed in 1:11.7, with Miss Margaret Sanderson second and Miss Alice Crozier third.
MEMPHIS, July 11 -- When some one in "Sergeant York" asks Mrs. York what the war is about she is troubled and confused.

INTERLOCHEN, Mich., July 11 -- Yielding to pressure from James C. Petrillo, president of the American Federation of Musicians, the National Broadcasting Company has canceled the Saturday afternoon broadcasts by a high school orchestra from the National Music Camp here.

For the past several days I, as a young college student, have been serving my country in the only way I know how. At the beginning of America's entrance in this war I felt vaguely out of things. I could not stand by and watch the fight from the side lines, for the outcome vitally concerns me.

LONDON, July 11 -- The Ministry of Food is preparing several concentration schemes for food-processing industries, including the "soft drink scheme" covering mineral water, fruit drinks and allied industries, starting on Monday. The scheme, while affecting a special branch of the food trade, attracts general interest as a model for other pending food-concentration schemes.

Fourteen thousand butcher shops throughout the city, supplied with red, white and blue window stickers bearing the words "Official Fat Collection Station," were ready last night for the household fat and grease salvage which begins tomorrow.

Retail trade here improved last week as clearances and special promotions met good consumer response. Estimates indicated department store sales would show an increase of 10 per cent or more over the corresponding 1941 week. Some establishments had increases ranging around 20 per cent.
PITTSBURGH, July 11--Dr. John B. (Jock) Sutherland, Brooklyn Dodgers' football coach, today was sworn in as a lieutenant commander in the United States Naval Reserve at the Naval Procurement Offices.

A courier-cargo service that flies key men and essential materials between war production plants and their branches, subcontractors and air shipping points has been put into operation by the New York State wing of the Civil Air Patrol, it was announced yesterday.

THE United States plans to release on Aug. 14 the first anniversary of the Atlantic Charter, a 3-cent purple stamp honoring Czechoslovakia as one of the United Nations and specifically paying tribute to the memory of Lidice, the Central Bohemian village which the Nazis burned to the ground last month after killing the men, placing the women in concentration camps and sending the children to schools.

EVERY so often -- but not often enough -- this observer's highly unpaid scientific consultant, Mr. William L. Laurence, comes around with a blithe tale of some advance in science that may affect the region of sports.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J. -- Vacationing life in this seashore resort has reached its full Summer stride. The strand is dotted with colorful cabana colonies, the complete corps of lifeguards is on duty, and hotels, grills, amusement pier and night clubs are offering entertainment.

WHEN the 5-cent blue stamp commemorating five years of Chinese resistance to Japanese aggression was released at Denver last Tuesday, the first cover canceled contained a letter from Postmaster General Frank C. Walker addressed to Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek in Chungking, China. Mr. Walker wrote:

TRENTON, N.J., July 11 (AP) -- Opening round pairings in the seventh annual New Jersey State championship semi-pro baseball tourney were announced for next Tuesday, Wednesday and Thursday today by James G. Johnson, State commissioner.
WASHINGTON, July 11 -- Here are comparisons between typical individual income taxes now paid by individuals and those which would be paid under rates approved by the Ways and Means Committee.

WASHINGTON, July 11 (AP) -In collaboration with some members of Congress, a staff working under the direction of Summer Welles, Under-Secretary of State, has begun an exhaustive survey of the problems the world will face when the war ends.

Those who mourn the loss of our native chestnut by the blight can now be comforted. The Chinese Chestnuts have arrived. Nearly forty years ago the United States Government set out to circumvent the blight by getting chestnut trees that came from the same place the blight did and had therefore proved their ability to live with it.

PRINCETON, N.J., July 11 -In the battle against inflation the people are ahead of the Government. They want a program that, in many respects, is far more drastic, far more sweeping than anything now being done.

THE result of a decade of conscientious research and careful analysis, this timely volume stresses the sometimes forgotten fact that the essential revolution in government Indian policy occurred more than half a century ago, and not in 1933.

MEXICO CITY, July 11 -- The Inter-American Conference on Agriculture, in session here, approved today the resolution offered yesterday by Dr. Foster F. Elliott of the United States Department of Agriculture, to the effect that the countries of North and South America should increase their production of vegetable oils and fats as a measure of wartime economy.

All signs now point to the automobile's becoming a sociable drawing room on wheels. On a seat-for-seat basis, it is getting mighty popular. The driver is waving good-bye to his old habit of traveling alone, bored by the monotony of covering mile after mile with no company except the car radio.

Seeking all available equipment in the war against sea raiders, the Navy appealed yesterday to owners of radio telephone outfits to offer their sets for sale for use aboard ships along the Atlantic coast.

WITH a 13,000-mile motor tour into all but one of the South American republics, Herbert C. Lanks completed a decade's study of the Pan American Highway system. In telling about it in this book he reports, to quote the publisher's statement, "the first journey by automobile in one sustained tour from the Caribbean to the Straits of Magellan."

Aircraft operations on Federal airways have more than tripled in the last year, Charles I. Stanton, acting administrator of the CAA, recently announced. Commissioning nine new airway traffic control centers, the CAA now has 33,000 miles of airways controlled from twenty-three centers at key locations around the country.

WORCESTER, Mass., July 11 -During the Summer at Clark University, while an accelerated program is being carried out for students who wish to hasten their preparation for service either in war industries or in the Army or Navy, a special War Service Training Program has been undertaken.

Retailers in all major cities and in most smaller communities will join in the campaign to set a new high in sales of war bonds and stamps next Friday, which has been designed American Heroes Day, according to a survey conducted last week by the sales promotion division of the National Retail Dry Goods Association.

On St. Patrick's Day, 1924, Archbishops Hayes and Mundelein of New York and Chicago reached Rome to be made Cardinals. Other names on the front pages were Grover Cleveland Bergdoll, Robert M. LaFollette Sr. and Harry M. Daugherty.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., July 11 -A unique course in rubber technology, in which Ph.D.'s and graduate engineers sit at the feet of practical experts to learn the latest wrinkles in synthetic rubber production in this country, is now being given at Yale University.

ORANGE, N.J., July 11 -- It will be Francisco Segura of Ecuador and Ladislav Hecht who will meet tomorrow for the New Jersey State championship at the Berkeley Tennis Club. These foreign-born stars swept into the final today in straight-set triumphs.

BLOOMINGDALE, N.J., July 11 -- The Camp Bergwald referred to in FBI announcements of the arrest of 158 German aliens is known to residents of Bloomingdale and Pompton Lakes as the D.A.B. Camp, and is on the top of historic Federal Hill, overlooking the two towns.

Hundreds more of the telltale stars are being sewed on the service flags at nearby yacht clubs. Members have peeled off their civilian togs and have left for wartime service with Uncle Sam. The newest branch that is beginning to attract them in large numbers is the now highly-alluring Engineer Amphibian Command.
CAIRO, Egypt, July 11 (AP) -- British headquarters issued this communique today in conjunction with the Royal Air Force:

Supporters of Attorney General John J. Bennett Jr. for the Democratic nomination for Governor were informed yesterday that David K. Niles, former associate of Harry L. Hopkins, close friend of President Roosevelt, had come into New York State in an attempt to get support for United States Senator James M. Mead.

China's scholarly Ambassador, Dr. Hu Shih, compressed volumes of meaning into a simple little lecture on Chinese botany the other day at the dedication of the Chinese Garden in Rockefeller Plaza. America, he pointed out, has many beautiful flowers that came from China -- the forsythia, the wistaria and the gardenia, to name only three.

WASHINGTON, July 11 -- The largest tax bill in history, to yield from $6,250,000,000 to $7,000,000,000 in additional revenues, was ordered reported by the House Ways and Means Committee today after more than four months' study and after a session that was described as stormy.

LEWISTON, Me., July 11 -- Not only will there be less gas and less sugar for the duration for Bates College students, but also less of the arts, if a study made at the undergraduate Summer term now in session is any indication. To better prepare themselves for the roles they must play in the war and the peace afterward, Bates men are concentrating on the sciences, natural and social.

EAST HAMPTON, L.I., July 11 -- The forty-seventh annual Village Fair will take place July 31 in Guild Hall, where the theatre, three art galleries and three gardens will be used both afternoon and evening, instead of on the Village Green.

LAKE PLACID, N.Y., July 11 -- Miss Grace Amory of the Cedar Creek Club, Locust Valley, won the thirteenth annual women's New York State golf championship by defeating Miss Shirley Podret of the Dutchess County Club, Poughkeepsie, 4 and 3, in the thirty-six-hole final over the lower course of the Lake Placid Club today.

MOSCOW, July 11 -- Although the Germans' offensive against Lisichansk, forty-five miles northwest of the important communication and industrial center of Voroshilovgrad, cannot be assessed fully without further information, there is reason to believe that the drive is the most dangerous of the present German operations.
The regular schedule of American bridge tournaments has suffered its first direct casualty since the outbreak of war. The tournament which has been played annually in Hershey, Pa., has been canceled.

Two men with graying temples vanquished much younger adversaries yesterday to become the city's champion horseshoe-pitching doubles team. Competing against four other pairs, each the winner of a borough-wide tournament, the two men won the championship when they nosed out their nearest rivals, John Benish and Andrew Cordiner of Brooklyn.

THIS collection, presented by a veteran student of Lincoln material, has a modest purpose. Mr. Wilson has been gathering "first-hand information" in his favorite field since he was a young man. Much of this information is in newspaper or magazine form and is "now difficult of access, or can only be purchased at prices beyond the reach of the average purse."

The request for voluntary deferment of conventions made last month by Defense Transportation Director Joseph B. Eastman has stimulated a trend toward regional meetings among some women's national organizations, while at the same time raising parliamentary snags puzzling to their leaders.

OCEAN CITY, N.J., July 11 (AP) -- Top-seeded Billy Talbert of Cincinnati stroked his way to an easy victory over Harris Everett of Jacksonville, Fla., ranked second, today to capture the Atlantic coast tennis championship.

WITH BRITISH EMPIRE TROOPS, in Egypt, July 10 (Delayed) -- "They were easy to crack," a tired, grime-covered British veteran said to me today after troops of the British Empire, backed by furious air and artillery onslaughts, had driven Axis forces back five miles along the coastal railroad west of El Alamein in a whirlwind ninety-minute attack that captured the railway station of Tel el Eisa.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., July 11 -- All Yale undergraduates, whether physically qualified or not, are required to register for duty with the Army, Navy, Marines or war industry, under a faculty ruling announced today by Charles R. Walker, secretary of the Yale War Council.

Despite the present lull and the unfavorable outlook for Fall in the men's and boys' clothing industry, the high profits registered during the first quarter of the year will make it possible for a large majority of merchants and producers to avoid losses for 1942, they said yesterday.

WASHINGTON, July 11 -- If the German drive against Marshal Timoshenko's southern Russian Army opens the door to the Caucasus, Germany will get all the oil she needs and Russia will be deprived of 85 to 90 per cent of the available oil she has.

LENOX, Mass., July 11 -- Miss Anna Remsen Alexandre. Mrs. Henry Hollister Pease and Mrs. Newbold Morris will hold a sale of fancy and useful articles on Wednesday and Thursday for the benefit of the New York Exchange for Woman's Work.

Taking care of clothes and making them last is a wartime necessity that reverses our peacetime attitude toward them. In the old days lots of us who did not belong to the one-good-outfit school bought things not to last but to look well for a season, after which we tossed them out.

The Long Island Women's Golf Association championship has been reduced to thirty-six holes and will be played over the Cedar course of the Cedar Creek Club, formerly the Women's National Golf and Tennis Club, on July 21 and 22.

ATLANTIC BEACH, L.I. -- Bicycling to and from the beach clubs at Atlantic Beach has become such a popular form of transportation that a number of the clubs and Silver Point Beach have installed special accommodations for parking.
Conservation must be the keynote with garden flowers as with everything else; and as flowers are more needed now than ever, for the joy and uplift they give, none should be wasted.

Showing an ability to go a route that few had suspected he possessed, Apache, a Belair Stud homebred, yesterday so dominated the running of the Empire City Handicap that he not only won, but cracked the track record in doing so.

The barrage balloon lists badly as it rises over Irpenshaw Flying Field -- and that is because the body of Squadron Leader Buttle is inside. But the reader has scarcely had time to grasp the bizarre grimness of this murder when he is rushed off to a quite preposterous house party in Skye on the way to ever more hilarious mirth and madder glee.

CAMDEN, N.J., July 11 (AP) -- Officials of Garden State Park decline to estimate how many racegoers will be in the stands for the opening of the meeting next Saturday but they freely predict there will be plenty of horses in the stables.

Maximum aid to Russia, to enable her to hold off Hitler and protect the oil fields of the Caucasus, was urged by Rabbi Louis I. Newman in a sermon in Temple Rodeph Sholom, 7 West Eighty-third Street, yesterday.

OTTAWA, July 11 -- With the passage on Tuesday of the second reading of the bill to permit the sending of conscripted soldiers overseas Canada turned one of the most difficult corners that her government and people have had to negotiate since the war began.
Sale of a New York Curb Exchange seat for $850 was reported yesterday, down $50 from the previous sale. The present market is no bid, offered at $850.

THE incomparable Charles Lamb said: "To be strong backed and neat bound is the desideratum of a volume,'' but one must go still further and say that books should be bound in keeping with their contents, so that incongruity could not mar their appeal.

New York games with Manhattan and Fordham are among the twelve contests listed for next Fall by the football team representing the United States Navy Pre-Flight School at Chapel Hill, N.C. The naval eleven, to be coached by Lieut. Comdr. Jim Crowley, will meet the Jaspers at the Polo Grounds on Nov. 14 and return two weeks later to play the Rams.

ONE phase of collecting that seems to attract more newcomers than any other is the game of authors. That is because the rules are so simple. You pick your favorites and compile a list of their first editions, or have some one do it for you, and then you are ready to play.

The seventeenth Hambletonian Stake, officially scheduled for Aug. 12 at Good Time Park, Goshen, N.Y., and twelve other events have attracted a record entry of 289 horses for the four-day Grand Circuit meeting beginning Tuesday, Aug. 11 at the triangular mile track.

Final plans for the establishment of an information center on war jobs for women will be determined at a meeting of the New York branch of the American Association of University Women on Tuesday at 3:30 P.M. The meeting will be held in the Midston House, where the branch is planning to open the bureau to make available to college-trained women the employment needs of government and industry.

CAPTAIN JOHN A. GADE. U.S.N.R. has written his autobiography with some special purposes in mind. One is to acquit the King of the Belgians of any charge of dishonor in connection with his surrender to the invading Germans.

FOR the boy in search of a wartime melodrama this is just about us up to date as it is possible to find. Its time is the late Fall of 1941, its setting Hawaii, where Larry Wilson, visiting his father, an American naval officer, is learning to ride a surf board.
SPOKANE, July 11 -- Two former golf champions, one now representing the United States Army and the other the Los Angeles City Fire Department, win meet tomorrow for the Western amateur links title.

ISTANBUL, Turkey, July 11 -- Fearless Yugoslav patriots a quarter of a million strong have opened widespread offensive operations of their own with assaults upon Axis forces in the south Serbian mountains and across the Croat frontier into Italy, official Yugoslav informants reported today.

PITTSFIELD, Mass. -- An old Berkshire stagecoach has been restored by Manager Lester Roberts of Curtis Hotel, Lenox, for transportation of passengers between the hotel and the railroad station. Deacon Ezra Champlain used the coach to carry mail between Otis and Chester in 1852.

CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va., July 11 -- Victory in war and a peace through which the world might be safeguarded forever from the source of war was predicted by Walter Nash, Minister of New Zealand, and Senator Barkley of Kentucky in addresses at tonight's closing mass meeting session of the University of Virginia's Institute of Public Affairs.

LONDON, July 11 (U.P.)--Erich Guttart has been killed in a skirmish between his storm troopers and guerrillas in the Lublin district of Poland, where, as Gestapo chief, he won the title of "Little Butcher" by staging dozens of executions daily, a Polish Government spokesman said today.

BAR HARBOR, Me.--Much entertaining is being done for officers and enlisted men in this vicinity, and more is in prospect as the Summer advances. Many of the homes of Summer residents have been opened to men of the services, including those of Mrs. Shepard Fabbri, Mrs. Lea McI. Luquer and Miss Frances Coleman.

Neither wholesalers of dry goods nor the smaller independent stores they serve have much to fear from control of inventories, now being studied by committees appointed for the wholesale and retail fields by the War Production Board, it was indicated here yesterday.

Heavy registration for basic gasoline rationing books in the vacation areas of New York State was reported yesterday by Lee S. Buckingham, State Director of the Office of Price Administration, while registration in the city came to a standstill for two days.

LONDON, July 11 -- Two great tasks confront the United States and Britain this Summer while they gather strength for final knockout blows against the Axis in Europe and Asia. These are to keep Russia and China in the war by whatever methods are necessary.
WEST PARK, N.Y., July 11 -Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt does not understand why government officials do not tell the public more about the reasons for rationing and price control, she said today.

MR. BURMAN'S excellent book is rendered doubly valuable in the light of the battle now taking place in Egypt. Its subject is front-page news. Here we find a fine account of the total military effort accomplished by General de Gaulle's Free French forces in the immense region stretching from the Atlantic 2,000 miles across the heart of Africa to the Anglo-Egyptian frontier.
As Germany's Spring drive now becomes a midsummer drive and develops its force in Russia and Egypt, Adolf Hitler's Far Eastern partner stands by. Japan's apparent inactivity is a part of the game.
The following Italian High Command communique was broadcast yesterday from Rome and recorded here by The Associated Press:

ADIRONDACK MOUNTAINS -- This season's legion of vacationists in the Adirondacks are still managing to go places and do things -- they are seeing to it that the motoring curtailment does not confine their vacations to the front porch.

WHITEY, after careful practice, could walk almost as bowlegged as any cowboy in the outfit, and now that he was 10 he considered himself almost a top hand and certainly ready to go out on the round-up.

RETAIL trade improved throughout the country last week as customers responded to seasonal clearance and special promotional events. Reports indicated, however, that while increases over a year ago were shown instead of the decreases of recent weeks, the gains were not in proportion to the sharp rise in purchasing power.

BRIDGETON, N.J., July 11 (AP) -- Joshua Williamson, lanky Negro representing Xavier College of New Orleans, outstripped five rivals in a gruelling ten-event test of brawn and skill today to capture the National A. A. U. all-around track and field championship, contested for the first time since 1921.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, July 11 -- The irritation in Sweden, mounting with every new submarine attack in Swedish territorial waters, reached a peak today when it was announced that the 5,659-ton freighter Luleaa had been sunk in convoy off the port of Vaestervik, about seventy miles south of Stockholm.

ON any of these Summer Sunday afternoons thousands of Bay Area residents, including in this war year a large sprinkling of soldiers and sailors, find their way somehow to Sigmund Stern Grove, out beyond San Francisco's Twin Peaks.
Police Commissioner Valentine anounced in general orders issued yesterday the giving of 186 awards for meritorious service by members of the Police Department since Jan. 1.
NEW DELHI, India, Monday, July 13 (Reuter) -- A United States Air Force communique issued early this morning said:

PHILADELPHIA, July 12 (AP) -Lefty Jake Wade held the Athletics to three hits today to score an 11-to-1 victory and give the White Sox an even spilt in a double-header before 15,756. The Mackmen won the first game, 3 to 2, in ten innings.

Declaring that Christianity was not made "to fit us, but is something into which we must fit ourselves," the Rev. Dr. Harold Cooke Phillips, pastor of the First Baptist Church in Cleveland, Ohio, yesterday decried the fact that we tend to draw the line of belief at the point where Christianity ceases to be comfortable for us and becomes difficult.

SPOKANE, Wash., July 12 (AP) -B. Patrick Abbott, former Hollywood small part actor and now in the Army, won the Western amateur golf championship today with a 7-and-6 victory over Bruce McCormick, Los Angeles fireman, in the thirty-six-hole final.

Prometheus and his fountain and the Victory Garden and its cabbages were secondary attractions in Rockefeller Center yesterday. For the eighth time in as many years Rockefeller Plaza, the north-south street bisecting the development, was closed for one day to pedestrian as well as vehicular travel to prevent its becoming public property.

Max Gordon announces the addition of a fourth production to his Autumn schedule. It will be "Carmen Jones," the adaptation -- for an all-Negro cast -- of Bizet's opera 'Carmen," on which Oscar Hammerstein has been at work off and on for the last four years.

SOMEWHERE IN AUSTRALIA, July 12 (U.P.) -- Three American fliers, lost two months in New Guinea jungles, told today of patching with sheets a 27-year-old Spartan training plane found on an abandoned airfield and actually getting it into the air in a futile attempt to reach their base.

A residence in the New England colonial farm house style and about four acres of grounds on the west side of Bingham Avenue, in Rumson, N.J., have been purchased by Douglas E. Craik of Rumson through William H. Hintelmann. The house was built in 1934 and the property is part of the original "Bingham Farm" tract of the late Dalton Parmly.
Although New Jersey anglers found the offshore fishing to be in the doldrums during the past week, rowboat fishermen in the Shark and Manasquan Rivers were getting good catches of fluke.

DENVER, Col., July 12 -- Women are not being accorded their rightful place in war service, even though the armed forces are being opened to them and they are working in factories, hospitals and elsewhere, Dr. Minnie L. Maffett, president of the National Federation of Business and Professional Women's Clubs, Inc., asserted today.

While "the only way out" of the war is to win it by destroying the Axis aggressors, Americans must give some thought now to the establishment of a lasting peace, Herbert Hoover said yesterday in an address in which he urged consideration of "the dynamic forces in civilization that create war or make for peace."

A system of new classifications of rubber, both natural and synthetic, is being worked out to obtain maximum use of the nation's rubber supply, it was announced yesterday by the Society of Automotive Engineers and the American Society for Testing Materials, which are doing research through a joint committee and two subcommittees.

Surrogates James A. Foley and James A. Delehanty in a statement issued yesterday announced that the Surrogates of New York County had adopted a new rule limiting to $100 attorneys' fees in the settling of estates of officers and seamen of merchant vessels, except for extraordinary services.

LONDON, June 12 -- Dehydrated meat from the United States made its first appearance here a few days ago in a small number of restaurants. The experiment is considered a success and soon British housewives may supplement their fresh meat ration with another food concentrate.

ST. LOUIS, July 12 (AP) -- Catcher Walker Cooper rode the crest of a wave of timely hitting today as the Cardinals gained a double victory over the Braves. St. Louis copped the opener, 5 to 1, on Harry Gumbert's two-hit pitching and pounded out a 9-to-3 triumph in the nightcap as Ernie White and Howard Krist teamed up to hold the Braves to seven blows.
WASHINGTON, July 12 -- The votes of the delegations from New York, New Jersey and Connecticut on important roll-calls in Congress during the period July 4 to 10 are given in the appended tabulation:

While his sick father yelled from the sidewalk, "Jimmy, don't do it!" James E. Lynch Jr., 20 years old, kicked a guard in the abdomen and escaped from a prison van at the entrance to the Bronx Magistrates Court yesterday morning.

WASHINGTON, July 12 -- A minority of the House Ways and Means Committee asserted today that proposed corporation taxes in the $6,250,000,000 revenue bill were too severe, one calling them "a grievous burden for all and a backbreaking burden for many."

PHILADELPHIA, July 12 -Thirty Girl Scout leaders, representing fourteen States, are about to start an intensive aviation ground course. After completing the course the group will form the nucleus of a training corps that will impart the techniques of the program to Girl Scout leaders throughout the country.

The Public Service Commission announced yesterday that it has ordered the Brooklyn Union Gas Company to cancel a new gas rate under which it proposed to supply gas to large consumers for auxiliary or alternative use in the event of an oil shortage.

All believers in God, who has disposed of six dictators in the past, know that Hitler and his partners can not win, Rev. Dr. William Ward Ayer, pastor, said yesterday in a sermon at the Calvary Baptist Church, 123 West Fifty-Seventh Street.
The city's own work relief program has got under way with the placement of 4,259 home relief recipients in jobs in parks, hospitals and other municipal agencies, Mayor La Guardia announced yesterday.
LONDON, July 12 (AP) -- The Air Ministry issued this communique today:

With the aid of 116 volunteer fingerprint technicians, the drive to have every man, woman and child register his fingerprints to make identification easy in case of serious accident will start tonight at twenty-six churches, synagogues and CDVO branch offices throughout the city.

MINEOLA, L.I., July 12 -- In view of a modified ruling from Joseph Eastman, director of the Office of Defense Transportation, the Queens-Nassau Agricultural Society has voted that the centennial program of the Mineola Fair to be held on Sept. 15-19, J. Alfred Valentine, president of the fair organization, announced today.

The Farnsworth Television and Radio Corporation in its annual statement for the year ended with April, to be issued today, will announce its total conversion to war work and report that operations in the last fiscal year, mainly on civilian radio and phonograph equipment, were more than double those of the preceding year.

CINCINNATI, July 12 (AP) -- The Phils had to be content with a lone run in two games with Cincinnati today as Johnny Vander Meer blanked them, 2 -- 0, on three hits, and Elmer Riddle won the nightcap, 2 -- 1. Vandy fanned 13.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., July 12 -- Colonel Robert P. Glassburn, commanding officer of the Army Air Forces Technical Training Center here, announced today that the Army had taken over the Chalfonte-Haddon Hall, Ritz-Carlton and Claridge hotels.

French-American Club Day, part of Free French Week being celebrated here, presented yesterday a round-table discussion on "Free France and the United States" at Freedom House, 32 East Fifty-first Street.

AN EAST COAST PORT, July 12 (AP) -- The physician on a German submarine gave first-aid treatment to a seaman injured when the undersea raider sank a small Panamanian merchantman 150 miles west of a Caribbean island June 23, it was disclosed today.

The world is not in need of new machines as much as it is in need of new men who are devoted to the higher purposes of life, according to the Rev. Dr. Ralph H. Long, executive director of the National Lutheran Council, in a sermon yesterday in the Gustavus Adolphus Lutheran Church, 151 East Twenty-second Street.

FORT MONMOUTH, N.J., July 12 -- Joseph L. Lockard today reached a stepping-stone between his days at Pearl Harbor and an officer's commission when the gold bars of a second lieutenant were pinned upon his shoulders by Brig. Gen. George L. Van Dausen, commandant at Port Monmouth.

A history of "The Flying Tigers," the American Volunteer Group in China, which on July 4 became part of the United States Army Air Force there, will be published by Viking in the early Fall. The book is now being completed by Russell Whalen, radio director of United China Relief.

Outlining work done since their appointment as trustees in reorganization of the Associated Gas and Electric Corporation, Willard L. Thorp and Denis J. Driscoll, in their annual report for 1941, to be made public today, described activities ranging from the consummation of more than $150,000,000 of refundings and the addition of 90,000 kilowatts of generating capacity to the conclusion of more than 140 proceedings before regulatory bodies.

Advertising linage in newspapers of fifty-two cities, measured by Media Records, declined 9.9 per cent in June, bringing the six months' loss to 8.5 per cent. The fact that there were only four Sundays last month as against five in the comparative 1941 period contributed to the decline.

While Senator Barkley last week was telling a Virginia audience that Congress will "rise magnificently" to the present crisis his colleagues were making a mockery of his words. In every direction they seemed bent on taking the easiest way; on appeasing selfish group interests at the expense of the national interest; on exalting demagogy above statesmanship.

Minister of Production Oliver Lyttelton has punctured the tale that Axis tanks in North Africa are air-conditioned. Does it follow that suffering in what is virtually a steel oven cannot be alleviated for the men who must fight behind armor on the side of the United Nations?

WITH A CANADIAN ATTACK FORCE, at a British port, July 12 (Canadian Press) -- The greatest raid and invasion manoeuvres ever held in European waters have been carried out by a Canadian attack force, the Royal Navy and the Royal Air Force as a prelude to what may be major military operations on the European coast, it was disclosed today.

INTERLOCHEN, Mich., July 12 -- Taking of the Interlochen High School Symphony Orchestra broadcasts off the air will be a blow to music enthusiasm of youth throughout the nation, C.M. Tremaine of New York, director of the National Bureau for the Advancement of Music, said today.

VICHY, July 12 -- Despite rationing of commodities and price-fixing measures in France, the cost of living is rising. That is why the government is endeavoring to improve the situation of all persons with modest incomes.

LONDON, July 12 -- Note circulation of the Bank of England continues to leap upward. Last week's increase of 5,800,000 compared with one of 4,600,000 in the same week last year and raised the total to a new high record of 807,000,000, which was more than 159,000,000 above that of a year ago.

ORANGE, N.J., July 12 -- Not since Bill Tilden's heyday has there been anything like the drubbing Francisco Segura gave Ladislav Hecht in today's final for the New Jersey State singles championship at the Berkeley Tennis Club.

A veteran prowler by night of the streets of New York finds the dim-lit and gas-rationed city a friendlier place than for a long time it has seemed to be. Perhaps (he says) it's because the members of the Armed Forces -- our own and those of our Allies -- are all about.

HOLLYWOOD, July 12 -- Lana Turner has been assigned to the role of Gale Joy in the screen version of "Best Foot Forward," George Abbott's musical comedy, which Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer purchased a month ago for $150,000. Rosemary Lane was seen in the part on Broadway.

An Italian broadcast recorded by The United Press in New York yesterday cited an official naval review as saying that three Italian battleships damaged in a British attack on the fleet at Taranto in November, 1940, had been back in service for months.
CAIRO, Egypt, July 12 (AP) -- A joint British Headquarters-Royal Air Force communique said today:

CHICAGO, July 12 -- Harvesting of Winter wheat made rapid progress over a wide area last week under favorable weather conditions. Reports indicate that the quality of the grain is very good, especially in regard to weight, although the protein content in Kansas is estimated at 1/2 to 1 per cent less than last year.

The German High Command announced yesterday, according to German broadcasts recorded by The United Press in New York, that Axis armored units and motorized infantry had pursued the "retreating enemy" relentlessly on the Southern front in Russia and that local resistance had been broken everywhere.

NEWARK, N.Y., July 12 (AP) -The Bears remained in possession of first place in the hottest International League race in years by defeating Baltimore in both ends of a twin bill before 5,000 by identical scores of 5 to 1 today.
The battle for Egypt was renewed at the week-end as General Sir Claude Auchinleck sent his reinforced British Eighth Army smashing furiously against the Axis positions west of El Alamein.

WASHINGTON, July 12 -- Members of the National League of Women Voters have canceled Summer vacation plans, to promote a campaign to get more Americans to vote in the thirty-four State primaries between Tuesday and Sept. 15 than ever before, and to give more attention to their ballots for Congress.

WASHINGTON, July 12 -- Blackout curtains and non-metallic lamps will be basic features of the single rooms envisaged for the war dormitories for girl government workers about to be built here in the District of Columbia.

CHICAGO, July 12 -- Harvesting of the new crop of oats in the big surplus-producing areas in the Central West has started, but receivers do not expect any movement of consequence until the latter part of the month. Trading in futures on the Board of Trade here last week was relatively light and the market developed an easy undertone, although closing trades yesterday showed gains of 1/4 to 7/8 cent a bushel for the week.

WASHINGTON, July 12 -- The Office of Price Administration today authorized State OPA directors to grant increased allotments of sugar to food processes whenever, in their judgment, it is necessary to avoid the waste of fresh fruits and vegetables.

BOSTON, July 12 (AP) -- The Red Sox dropped a double-header for the first time in two months today when the Browns shut them out, 1 -- 0, in the first game behind Denny Galehouse's eight-hit pitching and then took the nightcap, 10 -- 6, with a six-run rally in the ninth inning.

WASHINGTON, July 12 -- The Navy announced today that its largest group of fledgling fliers, 518 strong, has begun courses at the three naval intermediate flight training centers at Pensacola, Jacksonville and Corpus Christi.

FOR fourteen out of the last twenty-one years Frederick Moore served as an adviser to the Japanese Foreign Office on international affairs. The connection was finally severed only by the bombs that fell upon Pearl Harbor. Mr. Moore was a foreign correspondent for The Associated Press before that and spent the five years from 1910 to 1915 in Peiping.

The Bible did not produce the church, but the church produced the Bible, Bishop William T. Manning declared yesterday in the second of a series of four July sermons in the Protestant Episcopal Cathedral of St. John the Divine on the general subject of "The Present World Situation and Christian Belief." In his second sermon the Bishop said:

Winner of the recent Eastern intercollegiate tournament at Montclair, Robert Odman of Seattle made an early exit from the men's Eastern championships at the Jackson Heights Tennis Club, Queens, yesterday.

GRAND RAPIDS, Mich., July 12 (AP) -- America's genius for production -- production far beyond the tremendous progress the nation already has achieved -- will inevitably crush the Axis Powers under a staggering outpouring of war weapons, Lieut. Gen. William S. Knudsen told 200 war manufacturers here today following a Sunday tour of plants that were operating full time.

CHICAGO, July 12 -- Wendell L. Willkie aided today in conferring the name of "Lidice" upon a small public housing project not far from Joliet, hitherto called Stern Park Gardens and which, like the village of the same name in far-away Middle Europe, has about 100 homes, peopled by Czechoslovaks.
General Charles Gates Dawes, former Vice President of the United States, left the Waldorf-Astoria yesterday for his home in Evanston, Ill.

ALBANY, July 12 -- Plans filed in June for construction of industrial buildings in the State, outside New York City, covered ninety-three projects having an estimated value of $15,500,000, the largest amount for any single month since the Industrial Department started keeping these records nineteen years ago.

WASHINGTON, July 12 -- The House is expected to pass the $6,250,000,000 War Revenue Bill next Saturday and send it to the Senate, but there were indications tonight that a supplemental tax bill would be written to bring the revenue up to the Treasury's "minimum" of $8,700,000,000.
WASHINGTON, July 12 (AP) -- The Indians trounced Washington twice today, winning the first game with a tenth-inning uprising and taking the nightcap behind Jim Bagby's steady eight-hit hurling.
The largest single grant in the four-year history of the National Foundation for Infantile Paralysis was announced yesterday by Basil O'Connor, president.

WASHINGTON, July 12 -- Elliott E. Simpson, counsel for the House subcommittee which has expedited the scrap rubber drive, declared today that four large scrap rubber concerns, acting as agents of the Rubber Reserve Corporation, have reaped "enormous profits" from the collection campaign which ended last Friday night.

ANOTHER sport is taking to the twilight zone because of war conditions. Harness racing. Between the dark and the daylight, as Mr. Longfellow put it, the harness hosses (preferred spelling in this corner) will be going cloppity-clop around the Roosevelt Raceway at Westbury, L.I., and thereby hangs a tale.

Alexander Eisemann, a retired member of a former New York Stock Exchange firm, proposed last week a method by which companies making war materials might accept part payment in United States bonds of a special form to help to finance the war.

LONDON, July 12 -- Highways and railroads built within the last six months by British and American engineers in Iran are now carrying two to three times the volume of supplies to Russia they did at the beginning of this year.

NEW DELHI, India, July 11 (delayed) -- The All-India Congress party's working committee agreed tonight, after six days of discussion at Wardha, to adopt Mohandas K. Gandhi's plans for a mass movement of moral pressure to compel Britain to give India full freedom at once.

CHICAGO, July 12 -- Continued large purchases of lard and hog meats by the government for lease-lend and other purposes have resulted in reserve stocks of the various commodities being reduced to a point where packers are forced to rely on fresh receipts of hogs to fill their contracts.

The National Catholic Community Service of the Archdiocese of New York celebrated its first anniversary with a special mass for service men yesterday morning at St. Patrick's Cathedral, followed by a communion breakfast at the Hotel Abbey, Fifty-first Street and Seventh Avenue.

Describing it unblushingly as "the biggest outdoor show ever presented in the world," Larry Sunbrock brought his first annual Wild West Rodeo and Hollywood Thrill Circus to the Polo Grounds yesterday for an eight-day run.

We should go mad if our minds never had a chance to digress from the one big problem of our present day. It may be a good idea to consider the war that is being waged in some quarters on the semicolon.
MOSCOV, July 12 -- Striking, significant changes in Luftwaffe formations and tactics are revealed in the newspaper Red Star by Colonel Altaisky and Major Lyensky.

Some constructive contributions to both the war effort and post-war economy are revealed by the Society of Automotive Engineers through the work of a joint committee of that organization and the American Society for Testing Materials with relation to the rubber shortage.
WASHINGTON, July 12 -- The War Department published today information it has recently received about German glider training and the formation of fully equipped "glider regiments."
Last week the Irving Fisher index of wholesale commodity prices rose from 108.2 to 108.4. With the exception of the agricultural indexes, most of the subgroups showed little or no price change.
CHICAGO, July 12 -- Without wasting even a thought on the sentiment which the occasion evoked, the Giants today wrecked Lon Warneke's first pitching job for the Cubs in five and one-half years.
LONDON, July 12 -- Royal Air Force bombers struck two daring blows in daylight yesterday against German submarine building yards on the Baltic coast.

CLEVELAND, July 12 (AP) -- The extent to which allocations and directives have superseded priority ratings "is indicated by the statement of an Eastern steelmaker that more than 83 per cent of its orders are covered by direct order and less than 17 per cent is available for A-1-a or lower ratings," the magazine Steel reported today.

CHICAGO, July 12 (U.P.) -Wendell L. Willkie, 1940 Republican candidate, said today he would throw his personal influence into State primaries in an effort to revitalize the party by eliminating its isolationist candidates.
LONDON, July 24 -- When the stock markets here were closed on Friday for the week-end, they were unaware that the battle in Egypt was being resumed, and their reactions to this remain to be recorded.

A full-page advertisement intended to show that Attorney General John J. Bennett Jr. was 100 per cent in his support of President Roosevelt's foreign policy before Pearl Harbor and is a liberal is published in THE NEW YORK TIMES this morning.
LIDICE, Ill., July 12 -- In a message to the ceremonies at Lidice, President Roosevelt stated:

General Francisco Franco is steering the Spanish ship of state between the two marker beacons of the pro-Allied sentiment of the majority of his people and the presence of German troops on Spain's northern frontier.

MOSCOW, Monday, July 13 -- Lisichansk and Kantemirovka, on the Don front below Voronezh, have been given up by the Red Army and increasingly severe fighting is in progress beyond those towns, the Russian High Command announced today. The Kantemirovka battle has shifted to the Boguchar area, thirty-five miles to the northeast. the Rostov gateway to the Caucasus.

LONDON, July 11 -- Of all the afterthoughts on the Libyan defeat and its aftermath in the rather futile parliamentary inquiry into its causes with which the critical weeklies and Sunday papers blossomed over the week-end, the most interesting contribution is that of Harold J. Laski, noted Laborite publicist, in an article entitled "Epitaph on a System," published in this week's New Statesman and Nation.

Wholesale volume improved slightly as buyers arrived to place orders for Fall, according to a summary of the week's activities prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by leading resident buyers. Back-to-school wear was becoming more important in all divisions of the apparel and clothing fields, and initial commitments were considered good.

One aspect of the German push toward the Volga will not be overlooked by anxious political strategists. The direction it takes seems to denote an intention to by-pass Turkey. A glance at the map shows that the Nazi spearheads in Russia are already at a point considerably east of a line drawn upward from the eastern border of Turkey.

A drastic reduction in the use of motor vehicles by New York State departments was announced last night, on the eve of the last day on which city residents may obtain their basic gasoline ration books without the penalty of several "gasless" days after permanent rationng becomes effective on July 22.

ANKARA, Turkey, July 12 (Reuter) -- It is reported that the heavy losses suffered by Bulgarian troops in Serbia necessitated the recall of the Sixth and Seventeenth Divisions and their replacement by the Seventh and Ninth Divisions, which were mobilized June 20.

MOSCOW, Monday, July 13 (U.P.) -- The Red Army announced today that the Germans had captured Kantemirovka and pushed eastward into the big bend of the Don River, while on the right flank of their great offensive they seized Lisichansk, 120 miles northwest of

AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, Australia, July 12 (AP) -- Lieut. Gen. George H. Brett, commander of United Nations Air Forces in the Southwest Pacific, today awarded Purple Hearts to ten officers and enlisted men in the United States Air Corps for gallantry in action.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., July 12 -- Dr. and Mrs. Nicholas Murray Butler gave a luncheon today at Leny Cottage, their home in First Neck Lane, for Duke Armand de Richelieu and the Duchess de Richelieu, who have leased a cottage for the season.

WASHINGTON, July 12 -- The War Department issued today a list of names of 297 American civilians who were interned by the Japanese at Shanghai after being removed from Wake Island. Of that number, six were listed as from New York and New Jersey.

In the address that he delivered last month before the American Medical Association Paul V. McNutt made it plain that not enough doctors are joining the Army and Navy and even threatened drastic action to obtain the number wanted if more volunteers were not speedily forthcoming.

Plans for speeding up production by redistributing war contracts to small contractors are being made by a large group in the plumbing, heating and building fields in New York and New Jersey. The American Contractors War Advisory Committee has been organized with headquarters at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel and soon will submit its proposals to the War Production Board, it was announced here yesterday.
LONDON, July 12 (U.P.) -- Gestapo agents were reported pouring into occupied France tonight with orders to prevent anti-Nazi demonstrations expected Tuesday, Bastille Day.

The Yankees and their arch foes, the Tigers, fought tooth and nail for the better part of five hours at the Stadium yesterday before a gathering of 59,541, but in the end it was the Bengals who received the final clawing.

WASHINGTON, July 12 -- The trial of the eight Nazi spies and saboteurs who landed from U-boats on the Florida and Long Island coasts will be continued at 10 A.M. tomorrow before the Special Military Commission.
If ever there was a political football in Washington, it is the gasoline and tire issue. And what is more, there appears to be no one who really knows what it is all about.

In a Gallup survey a few weeks ago a cross-section of American voters was asked: "In the war with Germany do you feel that our chief enemy is the German people as a whole, or the German Government?" Seventy-nine per cent of those answering declared that our chief enemy was the German Government; only 6 per cent named the German people, and 15 per cent had no opinion.

VICHY, France, July 12 (U.P.) -The government today was understood to have flatly rejected a United States proposal that the sever French warships now interned at Alexandria, Egypt, be removed to a South African port or to Martinique under American protection.

When the common wartime danger that binds the United Nations relaxes, their mutual antagonisms may ruin any attempt to make a durable peace, the Rev. Dr. Henry Sloane Coffin, president of Union Theological Seminary, warned in a sermon yesterday at the first Sunday service of the Columbia University Summer session in St. Paul's Chapel.

Roosevelt Raceway in Westbury, L.I., will open its new season with twilight trotting and pacing today. For the past two years the horses raced under lights at the old automobile track, but the war has changed that and now a fifty-five-day meeting will start with week-day programs beginning at 5:30 and Saturday racing at 2:15.

Millions of electric lights contribute to the skyglow over New York City that in normal times can very often be seen seventy-five miles away. To shade or screen all of them properly is a task that can be accomplished only by the voluntary cooperation of millions of residents of the metropolitan area.
"I dreamed of cultivated blueberries shipped by the train load -blueberry specials -- to every part of the country."

ANKARA, Turkey, July 12 -- Reports from Budapest said today that more than 300 Hungarian officers had been arrested during the past week on suspicion of belonging to a secret organization that had been supplying military information and arms to Yugoslav, Russian and Polish guerrillas.
