WASHINGTON, July 12 (U.P.) -- Establishment of a unified command in Alaska, only major American outpost still under independent Army and Navy commands, has been urged upon President Roosevelt by Alaskan civilian leaders, it was disclosed tonight.

CHICAGO, July 12 -- Buying of wheat by flour mills and the action of the Senate in passing the Bankhead bill, which gives farmers government loans of 100 per cent of parity on six major agricultural products, sent prices of wheat up around 7 cents a bushel last week to the highest levels since the middle of May after an early break had carried the September contract to the lowest mark of the season.
The following German communique was broadcast yesterday from Berlin and was recorded here by The Associated Press:

Millions of electric lights contribute to the skyglow over New York City that in normal times can very often be seen seventy-five miles away. To shade or screen all of them properly is a task that can be accomplished only by the voluntary cooperation of millions of residents of the metropolitan area.

RADFORD, Va., July 12 (AP) -- Two workmen were killed and five others injured in a fire late today at the Radford Ordnance Works which is engaged in the manufacture of smokeless powder for the government.

WASHINGTON, July 12 -- Random House, Inc., of 20 East Fifty-seventh Street, New York City, has promised the Federal Trade Commission to cease using the words "complete and unabridged" of publications which are not exact transcripts of a named author's works.

Last week's rather noteworthy recovery in stocks had by Thursday carried the average up 3 1/2 points, to the highest since February 9. Thursday's business was the largest of any day since 1941. The week's movement was one of those for which explanation seemed to differ.

WASHINGTON, July 12 -- Price control saved American taxpayers $6,000,000,000 from June, 1940, through April, 1942, by keeping down the cost of war supplies and would save at least $62,000,000,000 more by the end of 1943, Senator Wagner of New York declared in a radio attack tonight on the attitude of Congress toward the Office of Price Administration.
Mayor La Guardia announced yesterday that he had received clearance from "the military officials" for "surprise drills without previous notice."

Contributions of $844,993 have been received in the last week by the USO War Fund Campaign, bringing the total that has been donated or pledged to date to $14,167,735, it was disclosed yesterday. New York City has thus far raised a total of $3,030,000.

VICHY, July 12 -- Including operations still in progress, the total sum represented by conversions and consolidations of bonds of the State and its dependent organizations since the armistice probably will exceed 100,000,000,000 francs. This takes no account of the very considerable conversions operated by private companies.
CHUNGKING, China, July 12 (U.P.) -- Japanese land and sea-borne forces are threatening the last two important ports still in Chinese bands -- Wenchow and Foochow -- it was revealed tonight.

VALLETTA, Malta, July 12 (AP) -- The R.A.F. destroyed ten Axis planes during raids on the island in the last twenty-four hours, a communique said tonight. The total included four Italian fighters shot down in light raids today.

As a small girl our fondest dream was to possess a dressing table. This object was firmly established in the mind's eye, cloudily caprisoned in a sea of ruffles, with glittering rows of jars and bottles lining its mirrored top. And in the dead center there was the largest jar of cold cream ever conceived, the sort that one supposed must stand on the dressing table of a famous actress.

Divided sentiment in Congress with regard to loans on six basic agricultural products at full parity levels was reflected last week in shifting prices in the cotton market. The market declined early when Administration officials voiced opposition to the proposal, but recovered subsequently when complete acceptance of the measure seemed imminent.

PITTSBURGH, July 12 -- Another artistic bit of elbowing by undefeated Larry French, who limited Onkel Franz Frisch's Pirates to three hits as the Dodgers won the opener, 2 -- 1, gave the champions an even break today. They lost the nightcap, 6 -- 4, before 29,543 and dropped back to an eight-game lead over the second-place Cards.
NUTLEY, N.J., July 12 -- Hitting prodigious tee shots, Charley Whitehead of the Plainfield Club today became the first amateur golfer to win the New Jersey State open championship.

KUIBYSHEV, Russia, July 12 (AP) -- The Moscow News called again today for the immediate establishment of a second front against Germany, declaring "Hitler's back is his weakest spot -- he should be struck there with all the might at our disposal."

WEST PARIS, N.Y., July 12 -The consumer battle against inflation bore results today as delegates from trade union auxiliaries concluded a two-day leadership conference under the auspices of the Consumer Division, Office of Price Administration, Region II, at the Hudson Shore Labor School.

PORTLAND, Ore., July 12 -- The old college pep rally stuff, transplanted to the shipyard, has made workers at the Albina Engine and Machine Works buy more war bonds and pound more rivets into Navy hulls.

CAIRO, Egypt, July 12 -- The British Eighth Army, sparked by reinforcements of eager Australians, had driven Axis forces ten miles west of El Alamein today and had consolidated its new hold in the Tel el-Eisa sector of Egypt after having captured 2,000 tired Germans and Italians and having destroyed eighteen tanks.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., July 12 (AP) -- Ed Shokes's home run in the fifth inning was the only Syracuse hit as the Chiefs beat Jersey City in he second game of a doubleheader before 5,000 today, 2 to 0, after the visitors had taken the opening contest by an identical score.

Major Flikke, head of the United States Army Nurse Corps, won a well-deserved promotion last March and was duly commissioned a colonel in the United States Army. A distinguished "person," highly qualified for the position, she met all the requirements of the law and the regulations thereunder in respect to the granting of commissions to officers.

WASHINGTON, July 12 -- Paul McNutt, chairman of the War Manpower Commission, said today that war plants were rapidly drying up the available labor supply. He said that the country "must move more quickly now to utilize our reserves -- our women, Negroes, older workers, disemployed white-collar workers, aliens and others who are or can be qualified for war jobs."

The benevolent genii of the New York Zoological Society have treated the town to a new pleasure. They have opened in the Zoo what is to be a permanent exhibition of domestic animals. It was needed. What with the circus and the Zoo, wild animals are familiar acquaintances, but the common domestic animals are strangers.

WASHINGTON, July 13 -- Clarence H. Thayer, chief engineer of the Sun Oil Company, and Eugene J. Houdry, president of the Houdry Corporation, experts on the production of synthetic rubber from grain alcohol, told a subcommittee of the Senate Agriculture Committee today that their process was faster, cheaper and more efficient than the butylene or petroleum process now favored by the government's Rubber Reserve Corporation.

IT isn't the principle of the thing, it's the money that has this awed onlooker in a stir over the running of the Massachusetts Handicap at Suffolk Downs tomorrow. It's a "50,000 added" affair and probably only the racing rules or "conditions" of the contest prevented Secretary of the Treasury Morgenthau from entering himself to start in a race for so much loose money at a time like this.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 13 -- The threat of a labor tie-up in the motion-picture industry was postponed tonight for four days when leaders of the Conference of Studio Unions agreed to maintain the status quo in the current Los Angeles Film Exchange strike of the Screen Office Employees Guild until E.J. Mannix, Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer executive and a member of the Film Producers' Labor Committee, arrives in this city.
The German High Command issued the following communique yesterday which was broadcast from Berlin and was recorded here by The Associated Press:

Fire Commissioner Patrick Walsh said yesterday that the registration of all multiple dwellings in the city, which are required to provide air raid protection under a new city law, would begin on Monday at firehouses.

One of the largest public power ownership deals since the acquisition of utilities in the Southeast by the Tennessee Valley Authority is scheduled for early consummation according to the terms of a contract entered into yesterday between officials of the city of San Antonio and representatives of the San Antonio Public Service Company.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., July 13 -- Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt spoke on problems of total war, as met by different kinds of American families, at the opening today of the second three-week session of the Vassar Summer Institute for family and child care services in wartime.

This year's National Horse Show will be confined to one day instead of running through eight days, as in recent years. Amory L. Haskell, president, announced yesterday that the curtailed exhibition would be held the afternoon and evening of Saturday, Nov. 7.

Burton B. Turkus, who has been prosecutor of the Brooklyn murder ring since his appointment by District Attorney William O'Dwyer in 1940, announced yesterday that he had accepted the Republican nomination for Kings County judge.

"Mrs. Miniver" will be held for a seventh week begining Thursday at the Radio City Music Hall, thereby becoming the first film in the theatre's ten-year history to play so long an engagement. Although the picture has not yet completed a full six-week run, it already had been seen by 858,073 persons for the period ended Sunday night, an attendance record for the house.

No matter what efforts the United Nations may make in Europe this year, they should also strike at Japan, according to Sir Earle Page, former Australian Prime Minister and member of the British War Cabinet, now in New York on his way home.
WASHINGTON, July 13 (AP) -- The War Production Board added more than 250 civilian articles today to the list of those whose manufacture is prohibited by the iron and steel conservation order.

Daily men and women in France commemorate the fall of the Bastille. They strike out against tyranny when, forming guerrilla bands, they attack Nazi motor convoys, damage power plants, blow up munition stores. They war against the new absolutism when they assist British commandos raiding the French coast.

There was distinguished violin playing at Lewisohn Stadium last night when Bronislaw Huberman appeared as soloist with the New York Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra, Alexander Smallens conducting. Mr. Huberman played the Mendelssohn concerto, not as if it were a scarred Warhorse of countless campaigns, but as if it were fresh from the composer's pen.
CHICAGO, July 13 -- Mrs. Cure-I mings, whose father is a retiredi wholesale jeweler, was born here! thirty-one years ago. She is a! graduate of Rosemont College.

WASHINGTON, July 13(AP) -- The Office of War Information reported today that the Nazi broadcast regarding hostages in the Netherlands was made in the form of a message to Nethelanders from the German commander there, General der Flieger Christiansen, as follows:

WASHINGTON, July 13 -- Congress is "much less of a luxury than any other department or agency of government," Senator O'Mahoney of Wyoming declared today, adding that its upkeep was hardly more than half the cost of maintaining government publicity bureaus.

There was a sense of opulence in the discreet and not over-large collection that Mme. Pauline invited the press to view yesterday afternoon. Here were her projections for Fall and Winter. This designer has an oriental color sense.

A further sharp decline in the volume of bankers' acceptances outstanding, to the lowest level in more than twenty-five years, was reported yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York in its monthly survey of the market. As of June 30 the total of these bills outstanding in the United States was $162,849,000, a decline of $11,057,000 from the end of the previous month and a drop of $50,083,000 from June 30, 1941.
WASHINGTON, July 13 -- President Roosevelt nominated William L. Clayton to be Assistant Secretary of Commerce; he had no engagements.

The British radio yesterday quoted the German newspaper Schwarze Korps, organ of the Nazi Elite Guard, as admitting that a decisive battle of "encirclement and annihilation" against the Soviets was impossible because of the unlimited space in Russia, according to a United Press dispatch.

A Zurich dispatch broadcast last night by the German Transocean agency and recorded by THE NEW YORK TIMES said that an interesting contribution toward answering the question as to how the German forces succeeded in making their smashing successes in the Don offensive had been made by the Neue Zuericher Zeitung, which ascribed the German successes to the employment of "motorized groups."

An air raid shelter a half block long, complete with sand-bagged entrances, was opened yesterday in the basement of Lavanburg Homes, the city's oldest low-cost housing project, at 124-42 Baruch Place, on the lower East Side.

WESTBURY, L.I., July 13 -- The trotters and pacers started the first twilight meeting in the history of harness racing at Roosevelt Raceway today. With lights barred by the war, night racing is out for the duration and the eight-event twilight card formed what the Old Country Trotting Association hoped would prove the answer to its problem.

Sales of New York and Brooklyn department stores showed an increase of 3 per cent last week over the corresponding period last year, according to the report issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. The average figure is below expectations, as some large stores had sharp increases last week.

The rather remarkable degree of progress made last week by the stock market was not sustained yesterday, and prices turned moderately easier as demand sharply contracted. Bottom prices did not hold through the entire session, however, for when the weaker tendency of the morning failed to attract any sizeable selling, the list reclaimed a portion of the losses.

If there is a shortage of scrap steel, there are some 30,000 printers in the United States, and thousands of us have steel-top imposing tables which weigh from one ton up. These could be replaced with wood tables, covered with sheet metal or stone tops, without putting any of us out of business.

The last day of registration for basic A gasoline ration books passed yesterday, with 250,000 New Yorkers crowding the registration tables in the public schools, but it was estimated that 87,000 local motorists still may have failed to sign up.

WASHINGTON, July 13 -- A bill authorizing President Roosevelt to acquire or requisition for war purposes any automobile or other transportation vehicle and its supplies was introduced in Congress today by Senator Reynolds of North Carolina.
Francisco (Pancho) Segura started out yesterday in quest of another tennis title to add to the New Jersey, Brookline and Tri-State championships.

Officials of twenty-seven local housing authorities yesterday announced plans to sell short-term obligations totaling $32,601,000. On July 21 bids will be considered by twenty-two of these agencies for notes amounting to $28,675,000, while on July 24, five agencies will consider bids on $3,926,000 in notes.

WASHINGTON, June 13 -- The nation-wide salvage campaign is going on a twenty-four-hour-a-day, seven-day-a-week basis from now until the end of the war, Lessing J. Rosenwald, Chief of the Conservation Division of the War Production Board, said today.

CHICAGO, July 13 -- Corn showed independent strength on the Board of Trade here today, with a bullish construction placed on a government estimate of total stocks on hand on July 1 having considerable influence. Commission houses and professionals were on the buying side and there was less September for sale at 90 cents than has been the case recently.

If there was one thing that was apparent above all others throughout Florence Reichman's Fall millinery launching, held yesterday morning in her establishment at 1 West Fifty-seventh Street, it was that she intends to "keep 'em pretty."

CHICAGO, July 13 -- With the period of surplus production of butter, eggs and cheese about ended for this year, the nation has in reserve the largest stocks of these staples in its history to carry it through the Winter, the Department of Agriculture's report on cold storage holdings of food disclosed today.

James Patrick Devereux, 9 years old, son of Major James P. Devereux, American commander captured at Wake Island, was sitting in the cockpit of a Messerschmitt 109 yesterday afternoon at 3 P.M. in the New York Museum of Science and Industry, firing at "the Japs."

CHICAGO, July 13 (U.P.) -- Otto Richard Wergin, held for allegedly aiding German saboteurs, was highly indignant because his community refused to elect him an air raid warden, neighbors revealed tonight.

MACKINAC ISLAND, Mich., July 13 (AP) -- The surprising runaway victory of the underrated Hostess II, adventures of a six-man crew rescued from the yacht Rangoon as it pounded to pieces on a reef and the excitement of a two-hour fire aboard the Minx were recounted tonight as the eighteenth annual Port Huron-to-Mackinac race drew to an end.
WASHINGTON, July 13 (AP) -- Senator Lodge told his colleagues in the Senate today that American soldiers had performed like veterans in the Libyan desert fighting.

More than three tons of scrap metal and rubber have been collected in five large office buildings controlled by the General Realty and Utilities Corporation, reports Sylvan L. Hanauer, secretary of that organization.

WASHINGTON, July 13 -- The action of James C. Petrillo, president of the American Federation of Musicians, A.F. of L., in stopping broadcasts by a high school symphony orchestra as well as his ban against recordings and transcriptions for commercial use were condemned today by James L. Fly, chairman of the Federal Communications Commission.

WASHINGTON, July 13 -- Small groups of soldiers riding in bombers, tanks and trucks dashed over large areas of North Carolina today in the "curtain-raiser" of the Army's 1942 manoeuvres. The troops are using tactics which make last year's mass manoeuvres appear as outdated, in many respects, as the battles of the Civil War.
WITH A FIGHTER SQUADRON, in Egypt, July 13 -The Royal Air Force's incredible weapon, the fighter-bomber, is just about destroying the Axis transport system in the desert.

BEDFORD HILLS, N.Y., July 13 -- In a barn on the Eldon Bisbee estate here the Victory Gardens Cannery, Inc., first large community canning organization in Westchester County, began operating today, and after eight hours of work had put up 150 jars of beets and string beans.

We are continually talking about the amount of money we are spending for war purposes. This amount is of extreme importance to a limited extent to ourselves as present taxpayers, but will be to a far greater extent to our children and grandchildren. I do not, however, see that the amount we spend is particularly important in so far as the war effort is concerned.

LONDON, July 13 (AP) -- France's underground leaders, undaunted by violent new Gestapo oppression, will celebrate Bastille Day tomorrow while Frenchmen the world over observe the occasion by preparing for the day when they will help throw the German conqueror out of their homeland.

OSSINING, N.Y., July 13 -- Father Maurice Feeney of Albany, one of the forty Maryknoll missionaries interned since December in Hong Kong by the Japanese, has induced his captors to release him, according to a letter received at Maryknoll headquarters here from Father Joseph McGinn of Philadelphia, whom Father Feeney has joined in South China.

PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., July 13 -- Jimmy Hines, pro at Lakeville, paired with two different amateur partners today to turn in duplicate cards of 65 and win the amateur-professional best-ball tournament staged under the auspices of the Long Island Professional Golfers Association over the North Hempstead Country Club course.

Leaders of the left wing of the American Labor party, declaring that every peace offer they have made to the right wing of the party has been rejected, issued a statement yesterday that they had no alternative left but to fight for control of the party organization.

The drive to get as many New Yorkers as possible to submit voluntarily to fingerprinting started last night at twenty-six centers throughout the five boroughs under auspices of the new War Identification Bureau of the Greater New York Civilian Defense Volunteer Office.

LOS ANGELES, July 13 -- There is less danger of creating war millionaires than of impairing the ability of industry to cope with post-war problems under the present tax proposals, in the opinion of J. Cheerer Cowdin, chairman of the National Association of Manufacturers' committee on government finance.
PHILADELPHIA. July 13 (AP) -- Elmer Valo's single, scoring Phil Marchildon from second base in the eleventh inning, gave the Athletics a 4-to-3 victory over the White Sox at Shibe Park tonight.
The texts of the majority and minority opinions in the Kern and Sayre case follow.
LONDON, Tuesday, July 14 (U.P.) -- Britain's giant long-range bombers struck at objectives in Germany during the night for the first time in five nights, it was announced today.
The action taken by the Senate on Leon Henderson's OPA appropriation reveals our legislators in a characteristic role.

Axis submarines operating on our side of the Atlantic have sunk eight more ships, it was revealed yesterday. This brought the total number of ships lost in these waters since our entry into the war to 369, according to an unofficial compilation by The Associated Press.

PITTSBURGH, July 13 -- Frank Frisch, his Pirates and a majority of the Pittsburgh fans are in a dither about two ball players -- one of them supposed to be a Dodger and the other a Buccaneer -- and it was a question tonight which of the athletes was heating the local emotions most.
A ten-room house on a half-acre of land in Grace Church Street, Rye, Westchester County, has been sold by Mrs. Carrie M.H. Olmsted to Egbert H. Lillie through E.V. Siedle, broker.

DENVER, July 13 -- The United States most potent "secret weapon" in the war just now is American women, but the Federal Government is not employing it effectually, Dr. Minnie L. Maffett of Dallas, president of the National Federation of Business and Professional Women's Clubs, told the annual meeting of the federation board here today.

CAIRO, Egypt, July 13 -- Saturday night saw units of the British Mediterranean Fleet in action again in a bombardment, jointly with Allied air forces, of Mersa Matruh ["Mersa" means harbor or roadstead; Mersa Matruh is the harbor of Matruh], which the Germans have been trying to use as an emergency port.

MOSCOW, Tuesday, July 14 -- German shock troops have penetrated the defenses of the city of Voronezh, at the upper end of the Don River front, and today fighting is continuing in the municipal area. The weight of numbers seems to be beginning to tell on the defenders of the city.

WASHINGTON, July 13 -- The proposed sale in New York by the Alien Property Custodian of two German-controlled corporations which he had taken over is an isolated instance and will not set the pattern for other such sales, it was explained today by a spokesman for Leo T. Crowley.

Bob Falkenburg of Hollywood, Calif., who recently won the national interscholastic championship, reached the quarter-final round of the Eastern junior tennis tournament on the courts of the West Side Tennis Club in Forest Hills yesterday.

Mayor La Guardia coupled his approval of the de Gaullists fighting for Free France with a denunciation of Pierre Laval and Marshal Petain as he welcomed a gathering of Free Frenchmen at City Hall yesterday to commemorate Bastille Day today.

Otto Preminger leaves today for Hollywood, where he has a four-week assignment for Sam Goldwyn. When he returns he expects to get to work at once on Louis Weitzenkorn's new play, a comedy-drama which has been in his portfolio for some time under the title of "Ah, Take the Cash."

SPRING VALLEY, N.Y., July 13 -- Rockland County had its first surprise blackout tonight and the results were so disappointing that George W. Wallace Jr., county director of civilian protection, declared the area was "far from ready to meet an air raid with any degree of efficiency."

CHICAGO, July 13 -- James C. Petrillo, president of the American Federation of Musicians, declared here today that refusal of the National Broadcasting Company to permit a network broadcast yesterday by the symphony orchestra at Interlochen, Mich., was not "a cancellation on our part."

WASHINGTON, July 13(AP) l-Chairman George of the Senate Finance Committee said today that Congress might be asked to consider in January a revenue measure even bigger than the $6,250,000,000 bill scheduled for House debate this week and ought to establish now a permanent wartime taxation structure.
Major and Mrs. William Deering Howe have arrived from Washington and are at the St. Regis.

WASHINGTON, July 13 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in 101 leading cities, the Federal Reserve System announced today, shows the following principal changes for the week ended July 8: Increases of $79,000,000 in holdings for Treasury bills and $152,000,000 in demand deposits-adjusted and a decrease of $348,000,000 in United States Government deposits.
VICHY, France, July 13 (AP) -- All France, was tense tonight on the eve of Bastille Day after Gestapo authorities had decided to shoot all adult male relatives of hunted saboteurs.

LONDON, July 13 -- Demand for speculative shares such as oils and South African mines became more pronounced today in dealings on the London stock market. There was some demand also for Brazilian bonds and Japanese issues became harder,

CHUNGKING, China, July 13 -- Japan's current seaboard offensive is beginning to mushroom into a full-scale campaign. In the beginning the avowed Japanese objective in the Chekiang-Kiangsi drive, which began shortly after the raid led by Major Gen. James H. Doolittle upon Japan on April 18, was the capture of air bases that might be a threat to the Japanese.
The German High Command reported yesterday, according to German broadcasts recorded by The Associated Press, that Soviet forces were being pursued on a broad front in Southern Russia.

WASHINGTON, July 13 -- The story of the voyage by transport convoy through the Pacific of the first major expeditionary force of United States Marines, whose landing at a South Pacific port was announced June 27, was told here today.
WASHINGTON, July 13 (AP) -- Eleven Navy nurses were officially reported missing today in the Navy's seventh casualty list of the war, which brought the total of casualties to about 11,000.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden July 13 -- The increased activity of British mine-layers off the coast of Norway has compelled the authorities of Tromsoe to offer 500 Norwegian kroner reward for every mine found by the population.

Wilhelmina Helena Pauline Marie, 61-year-old Queen of the Netherlands, Princess of Orange and Duchess of Mecklenburg, will arrive on her first visit to this city at about 10:15 o'clock this morning when her motor car, en route from Hyde Park, crosses the Westchester-Bronx line near a gasoline station on the Sawmill River Parkway Extension.

VICHY, France, July 13 -- There is little chance of an improvement in the grave French food situation for months or perhaps years to come, Max Bonnafous, Secretary of State for Agriculture and Supplies, declared In an interview in Paris today. The French people, he said, must make up their minds to this.

CAIRO, Egypt, July 13 (AP) -- The British Mediterranean Fleet has entered the Battle of Egypt with its guns and its planes, it was disclosed tonight, leaving flames and wreckage at Matruh, the Axis' most advanced supply port some 100 miles behind the front west of El Alamein.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., July 13 -- Mrs. Frederick J. McEvoy gave a luncheon today at the Southampton Beach Club for Mr. and Mrs. J. Ormond Lawson-Johnston, who are visiting her. Later in the day Mrs. McEvoy was a dinner hostess at the Shallows, her home in Halsey Neck Lane, for her guests.
The Army gave golden-winged insignia of service yesterday to 115 women volunteers of the Auxiliary Aircraft Warning Service.
Mayor La Guardia disclosed yesterday that President Roosevelt had decided that he would be more useful as Mayor of New York than as a member of the Army.

LONDON, July 13 -- Beginning tomorrow, Bastille Day, the title of "Free French," now applied to those serving under General Charles de Gaulle and the French National Committee in London, will be a thing of the past, and the movement will enter another phase of its existence as "Fighting France."

LOS ANGELES, July 13 -- Predicting a reduced standard of living for the nation, Richard Gilbert, deputy OPA administrator, told the Federal Aircraft Wage Stabilization Conference today that his office disapproved of the 50 to 60 per cent wage increases proposed by aircraft unions and disclosed that government scrutiny of war plane contracts would result in reduced profits for manufacturers.

Forty-two thousand Boy Scouts in Greater New York started yesterday to do their share in the nation-wide distribution of 25,000,000 pamphlets prepared by the Office of Price Administration to acquaint householders with ceiling prices. The distribution, begun early this month in various parts of the country, is expected to be completed by the end of this week. The quota here is 2,225,000.

VICHY, France, July 13 (U.P.) -- Marcel Deat, newspaper editor, has asserted in Paris that international financial groups and others are plotting to overthrow the government of Pierre Laval, it was learned today. Presiding at a week-end meeting of the National Council of the National Popular Concentration, which advocates collaboration with Germany, he claimed that the bankers had planted men in most of the Vichy Ministries and even in M. Laval's entourage.

WASHINGTON, July 13 -- The President's selection of a military commission -- with the Attorney General added -- instead of a court-martial to try those accused of intended sabotage and treason brings recollection of the famous World War dispute over counterespionage methods between President Wilson and Senator Chamberlain of Oregon.

Reports from various sections of New Hampshire contain encouraging news for anglers intending to spend vacations in the Granite State. Good catches of brook trout, lake trout, landlocked salmon and pickerel have been common.
The two-family house at 538 Sixteenth Street, Brooklyn, has been purchased by Patrick J. Grace from Rosie Sametz through the John Pullman Real Estate Company, Inc., brokers.
My secretary advanced a thought to me this morning which is distinctly worth while.

PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., July 13 -- A canning kitchen will be opened here at 11:30 A.M. tomorrow in the cafeteria of the Port Washington Senior High School under the auspices of the local branch of the American Women's Voluntary Services.

DAYTON, Ohio, July 13 -- William L. Richards of West Chester, Pa., a Quaker who refused to register for the Selective Service Act because "all war is wrong," was sentenced today to five years in prison when he pleaded guilty before District Judge Robert Nevin.

WASHINGTON, July 13 -- Detailed biographies of six New Yorkers and eight Chicagoans who aided the Nazi saboteurs after their arrival in this country was issued today by J. Edgar Hoover, Director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation. His statement follows:

Three hundred sixty-nine ships have been sunk in the Western Atlantic by marauding Axis submarines since Pearl Harbor. This terrific toll, which has handicapped our entire war effort, has been made possible, in part at least, by the sky glow from shore lights that has sometimes silhouetted United Nations ships for the U-boats.

Several phases of the response to the Treasury's recent offering of $2,000,000,000 of 2 per cent bonds, due in 1951, callable in 1949, came as pleasant surprises to all concerned over the week-end. In the first place, allotments in full of subscriptions of $25,000 or less in the amount of $196,000,000 reflected the best response in a long time from the so-called small investors.

Further sharp improvement in customer payments on retail charge accounts, in response to Regulation W of the Federal Reserve Board, was reported by local store executives yesterday. They indicated that receipts have been so heavy during the last few days that the number of accounts which are being "frozen" is now running under the preliminary estimate of 25 per cent.

The stream of small electrical appliances which had been pouring out of plants into the warehouses of distributors and retail stores for the first six months of this year has now become a dribble and within a week or two will cease altogether, distributors reported yesterday.

The largest block of shares of the Home Insurance Company, 493,400 shares of an issue of 3,000,000, will be offered at public auction here by Adrian H. Muller Son, securities auctioneers, on July 29. These shares, together with 800 shares of National Liberty Insurance Company, were pledged as collateral against a loan made by the Royal Bank of Canada and the Chase National Bank to the Home Fire Security Corporation.

WASHINGTON, July 13 -- Attempts to restrict Leon Henderson's power to select his own personnel and control all prices were condemned in the Senate by the majority leader, Mr. Barkley, today on the ground that they would promote inflation and lead to widespread criticism of Congress.

HAMILTON, Bermuda, July 13 -- Two new Bermuda track and field records were set yesterday in the first annual meet organized and sponsored by the American Forces and attended by the Governor of Bermuda, Viscount Knollys; Rear Admiral Jules James, U.S.N.; Brig. Gen. A.G. Strong, U.S.A., and Brigadier Maconochie of the British Forces.

PANAMA, July 13 -- Dr. Gonzalo Restrepo, Colombia's Minister of War, said today that the coast of Colombia was as well protected as it could be, according to an interview in the newspaper Tiempo of Bogota.

William B. Herlands, Commissioner of Investigation, called attention yesterday to the custom of some physicians of taking fees from oxygen service companies whose products they prescribe for patients, and suggested that the city's medical organizations might wish to check the practice.

A lecture on swing by one of its outstanding maestros in the august halls of the Metropolitan Museum of Art was chiefly devoted to the vocabulary of the new art form. One of the reasons that make a person doubt whether swing is really destined for immortality is that whenever people try to explain swing they say almost nothing about music and talk most of the time about the language of swing's devotees.

The eleventh-hour changes in the draft of the new tax bill are said to have been the result of political logrolling among some members of the Ways and Means Committee. The results certainly suggest that sober and intelligent consideration of taxation problems was rudely pushed aside.

Held without bail since Wednesday, Arthur W. Kopell, jewelry dealer, whose office is at 309 Fifth Avenue and who lives at Java Farms, Rockland County, was fined $350 and sentenced to thirty days in the city prison yesterday when he pleaded guilty to thirty-three traffic violations dating from June 24, 1932.

WASHINGTON, July 13 -- The Ways and Means Committee, when it considers tomorrow a new draft of the War Revenue Measure, faces a fight to reduce the 45 per cent tax on corporations, it was strongly indicated today. It was intimated also by Senator George, chairman, that the Senate Finance Committee would insist on more "temperate" rates.

Unless the advertiser can use the war theme as an addition to the "functional" headline, rather than as a substitute for it, he is better off to leave the war alone, comments "Successful Advertising," published by Van Sant, Dugdale Co., Inc., Baltimore.

WITH THE BRITISH EIGHTH ARMY, in Egypt, July 12 (Delayed) -- The Australians, who succeeded yesterday in bettering their positions in the face of opposition and in making a slight bulge in their sector by late afternoon, pressed on during the late evening, with the result that the military situation generally is improved.

WASHINGTON, July 13 -- The Senate and House conferees on the $680,000,000 Agriculture Department appropriation bill agreed today on one of the most controversial of their differences, but their conference barely escaped breaking up over a procedural difficulty which brought harsh words and remained at a deadlock.

A broader use of plastics in Army combat equipment was reported yesterday to the Division of Paint, Varnish and Plastics Chemistry of the American Chemical Society by Lieutenant E. T. McBride of the Office of the Chief of Ordnance of the Army.

PHILADELPHIA, July 13 -- Invitations to participate in the initiation of his program for collaboration between the government and the securities industry during and after the war were extended today to seven financial leaders by Ganson Purcell, chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission.

BERNE, Switzerland, July 13 -With the coming crop yield in Germany indicated as uncertain, reports in the German press today bore evidence that Germany's food dictators were actively concerned with evolving plans for feeding the metropolitan populations.

Maxie Shapiro, East Side lightweight, scored a technical knockout over Mickey La Marr of the Bronx at the end of the fifth round in the scheduled eight-round feature bout at Dexter Park last night before a crowd of 2,500.

WASHINGTON, July 13 -- A reclassification under Selective Service of all men with dependents was ordered tonight on the basis of dividing such deferred men between those whose work is essential to the war effort and those who can be spared from their civilian tasks.

CAIRO, Egypt, July 13 -The destruction by British fighter-bombers of a Fieseler Storch army cooperation plane of the type used by German staff officers to get quickly from place to place in the battle zone was announced today. It will be some time before it is known what officer died when the Storch was destroyed, but he is almost certain to be of senior rank, it was said.
WASHINGTON, July 13 -- An oversize shipyard worker has been assured his abnormal requirements in the way of clothing win be filled, thanks to the help of President Roosevelt.

Three women, bearing five one-pound tin cans, entered a meat market yesterday afternoon, their faces beaming with pride. They were the first to participate publicly in the campaign here to salvage household fats.

BOSTON, July 13 -- Mighty Whirlaway, who has sound reasons to dislike New England -- he was beaten decisively in his only start hereabouts by War Relic last September -- appeared pleased with the Suffolk Downs Oval as he frolicked today to keep himself fit for Wednesday's $50,000-added Massachusetts Handicap.

MIAMI, Fla., July 13 (U.P.) -- The horses and dogs will run in Florida next Winter despite gasoline and tire rationing, the State Racing Commission revealed tonight on the basis of applications for dates and the enthusiasm of race track operators.

The two-story store and loft building on a plot 100 by 120 feet at 1490-98 Madison Avenue, northwest corner of 102d Street, was sold by the Risalpur Realty Corporation to an investing syndicate controlled by Arthur Cutler.

Lidice, in Czechoslovakia, was, as Wendell Willkie said in his speech on Sunday, "a mining village, a mile off the main highway, with some lovely old inns, a blacksmith or two, a shoemaker, a wheelwright, a tailor." It did not look much like American villages of today or yesterday, but no doubt its way of life was something like that of American small towns of a generation ago.

Anthony Cramer lived in a furnished room at 171 East Eighty-third Street here from March, 1941, until June 27, when he disappeared, it was said yesterday by Mrs. Marie Rucker, manager of the six-story building there.

Democratic National Chairman Edward J. Flynn and Tammany Leader Michael J. Kennedy took the leadership yesterday of the efforts being made, with apparent White House approval, to block the nomination of Attorney General John J. Bennett Jr., who is being sponsored by State Chairman James A. Farley.

Mrs. Janet (Mother) Roper, who has charge of the missing seamen's bureau at the Seamen's Church Intitute, 25 South Street, was honored by the merchant marine heroes of the freighters and tankers at the institute yesterday on the occasion of her fifty-third anniversary of service at the institute.

The Weather Man, who has made good so far this S,mraer on his promises of showers, dangled the promise again yesterday before heat-weary New Norkers, who saw the temperature rise to 88 degrees at 4:30 P. 1Vf. for the second highest of the year.

A revolutionary movement in Catholic secondary education, the establishment of the "Catholic High School Literature Series," has been so well received in its initial stages that work is now going ahead to complete the series. This was revealed yesterday by Sister Mary Theresa Brentano, editor of the anthology.

GREAT LAKES. Ill., July 13 -- Babe Barna's tenth inning home run with Babe Young aboard today broke up a ball game between the Giants and Lieutenant Mickey Cochrane's Great Lakes Naval Training Station team and brought the Polo Grounders a 5-to-3 victory.

The Republican organization in Queens County found itself last night without a candidate for the State Assembly in the Fourth Assembly District, one which shows consistent Republican tendencies in voting.

WASHINGTON, July 13 -- The Office of Price Administration established today dollars-and-cents ceiling prices, chiefly at manufacturing levels, for more than 1,700 individual cotton piece goods items, including terry towels, cotton and cotton-mixture blankets, corduroys and other products.
INTERLOCHEN, Mich., July 13 -- Dr. Joseph E. Maddy protested today to William Green, head of the American Federation of Labor, against the banning of high school symphony orchestra broadcasts.
WASHINGTON, July 13 -- American troops and equipment engaged in the battle of Egypt are "first class," Senator Lodge of Massachusetts told the Senate today.

Operations of the United Fruit Company in the half-year ended on July 4 resulted in earnings of $9,941,000 before deduction for Federal taxes, according to the report of Samuel Zemurray, president, issued for publication today.

WASHINGTON, July 13 -- Eight men and six women who served as "immediate contacts" for the eight Nazi saboteurs after the agents landed on the Long Island and Florida coasts from German submarines have been arrested as the result of a three-week round-up by the Federal Bureau of Investigation, Attorney General Biddle announced today.

WASHINGTON, July 13 (AP) -- Young Walter Masterson, Washington right-hander, handcuffed the Indians with three singles to blank the Indians, 7 to 0. tonight. This was the Senators' only victory in the three-game series.

WASHINGTON, July 13 -- The Federal Trade Commission today ordered the Bible Institute, Inc., the Bible Institute, American Plate Glass Company and H. W. Lederer, who is president of the three corporations, with principal offices at 244 west Thirty-fourth St., New York, to desist from deceptive acts and practices in promoting the sale of the Bible and other religious publications, and also the sale of hand-bag mirrors.

WASHINGTON, July 13 -- Chairman James L. Fly of the Federal Communications Commission expressed "great concern" today over lags in the registration of diathermy machines -- devices created by science to heal the sick but capable of being used by spies as a means of radio communication.
Crash! A hammer rained blows on a nail. Whirr! A drill twirled, biting out a hole. Bzzzzzz! A saw rasped through a plank.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 13 -- RKO today acquired an optional right to film the life of Charles Dana Gibson and to use his paintings in a picture to be produced in February by David Hempstead under the title "Gibson Girl." Ginger Rogers is expected to play Mrs. Gibson in the film.

A representative group of civilians in Alaska is urging President Roosevelt to establish a unified command of the Army and the Navy in that area. At present the two services consult and coordinate, but they do not have at their head a single responsible officer who can give orders to them both.

The destroyer Tashkent performed a feat that will be cited in naval textbooks of the future as an example of daring blockade running. It will be forever remembered as one of the most striking examples of the gallantry, greatness and beauty of the human spirit revealed by the glorious defenders of Sevastopol.

CAIRO, Egypt, July 13 (AP) Seven United States ambulance drivers of the American Field Service are now missing as a result of operations in the present desert campaign, the organization, announced tonight.

In his eighth start since he won the $100,000 added Santa Anita Handicap last year. Bay View finished first in the Fordham Purse before 12,742 racegoers at Empire City yesterday. The 5-year-old son of Sweep All had failed to gain brackets at Belmont and Delaware Parks, even though heavily backed.

George P. Rea, first paid president of the New York Curb Exchange, has been elected president of the Drexel Institute of Technology and will assume his new duties on Aug. 1. He resigned from the Curb Exchange post, effective June 30.

Buying activity was reported light yesterday at the National Domestics and Linen Show, which opened at the Hotel New Yorker, where it will continue for the balance of the week. A total of 125 buyers registered for the opening day, slightly less than the number recorded on the first day of last year's event.

Willie Roberson, one of the defendants in the Scottsboro case who was freed five years ago this month, and who was convicted last Tuesday of annoying a young white woman on a BMT subway, was sentenced yesterday to ninety days in the workhouse by Magistrate Robert F. Mahoney in Bay Ridge Court.

With traders anxiously awaiting final settlement of Congressional disagreement over farm legislation, the cotton market yesterday experienced its slowest full-day session in several years. On the New York Cotton exchange active contracts were susceptible to scattered Southern selling while moving throughout the day beneath the previous close.

In a four-to-one decision, with Presiding Justice Francis Martin dissenting, the Appellate Division upheld yesterday the removal by Mayor La Guardia last February of Paul J. Kern as president of the Municipal Civil Service Commission and Wallace S. Sayre as a member of the commission.

As the only newspaper man with the United States Fleet during the Coral Sea batle (aboard the carrier Lexington) Stanley Johnston of The Chicago Tribune wrote a series of accounts that appeared recently in newspapers throughout the nation.

NEWARK, N.J., July 13 -- Edward A. Cornez of Laurelton, Queens, one of three men charged with fraud in collecting funds for a supposed Navy Relief show, surrendered today and was held in $10,000 bail by United States Commissioner Joseph Holland pending a hearing Thursday afternoon.

WASHINGTON, July 13 -- Jesse Jones, Secretary of Commerce, answered today the charges made yesterday by Elliott Simpson that four rubber scrap dealers were making large profits out of the scrap rubber salvage campaign. Mr. Simpson said they had been enabled to profit because they had been selected as agents for the Rubber Reserve Corporation, a Federal agency, over which Mr. Jones has authority.

Nobody with all his wits about him, we concluded after a recent unhappy experience, should ever try to trace the origin of the johnnycake. To do so, even in the interest of adding to culinary lore, means to go down in inglorious defeat.

WASHINGTON, July 13 -- The Office of Price Administration reminded housewives today that fruit crops were ripening in many parts of the country and stated that sugar rationing regulations permitted the local War Price and Rationing Board to release "any reasonable amount" of sugar to housewives with the understanding that with each pound of sugar four quarts of fruit would be canned.

CHUNGKING, China, July 13 (AP) -- Foochow, one of two Chinese-held ports menaced by twin Japanese drives on the Chekiang, Fukien seaboard, has been relieved by counterattacking Chinese troops who landed from boats and drove the invaders out of near-by Futuou Island, the Chinese announced today.

MOSCOW, July 13 -A significant feature of all reports of the recent fighting is the superiority possessed by the Germans in numbers of men as well as in amounts of materiel. Gregory Alexandroff, Communist party propaganda chief, apparently hints at an explanation of this in an article in today's Pravda that urges coordination of United Nations strategy so that a double blow can be struck against Germany.
VICHY, France, July 13 -- The highest transatlantic fares on record will be charged by the Portuguese liner Quanza, which will sail from Lisbon at the end of this month for New York.

The wholesale markets here assumed a much livelier aspect yesterday as arriving buyers showed interest in a broader range of Fall merchandise, including dry goods and accessories, as well as ready-to-wear. The number of arrivals was substantially larger than a week ago, but still fell somewhat short of the comparative period a year ago.

Former Governor Alfred E. Smith urged the "little fellows" in New York City to give their modest contributions to 70,000 volunteer workers making a door-to-door canvass during the final three weeks of the war fund drive of the United Service Organizations here. He made his appeal in a broadcast last night from Station WMCA.

In commemoration of Bastille Day, the Free French weekly, Pour La Victoire, has issued a special edition of the newspaper with messages from President Roosevelt, Maxim Litvinoff, Soviet Ambassador; Viscount Halifax, British Ambassador, and other diplomats.

Matthias A. Harrington, Chief Inspector of the Bureau of Weights and Measures of the Markets Department, has been cleared of charges brought against him last May by Commissioner of Investigations William B. Herlands, it was announced last night by Markets Commissioner Daniel P. Woolley.

Special playing cards that combine instruction in aerial warfare with recreation were distributed yesterday to field units of the Third Air Force at Tampa, Fla., according to an announcement by Brig. Gen. Carlyle H. Walsh, the commanding officer.

CHICAGO, July 13 (AP) -- Hog prices slumped today despite light supplies. The market was weak and prices declined as much as 20 cents to a top of $14.70. Best prices were 15 cents lower than last Friday and 30 cents under the 16-year peak equaled early last week. Salable receipts totaled 15,000 head and big packers took an additional 8,000 direct.
MOSCOW, Tuesday, July 14 (AP) -- The Soviet Information Bureau issued this communique today:

Nine women who already have had a taste of military life, were inducted here yesterday afternoon, as officer candidates in the Women's Army Auxiliary Corps. As soon as they had bound themselves to a new kind of war job, they returned to their volunteer posts as plane plotters with New York City's Aircraft Warning Center.

A blinding shower that fell just before the sixth race did little to relieve the heat for the 11,483 racegoers at Empire City yesterday, but it seemed to improve the running of Mrs. Andrew Schuttinger's Fleetborough.
The honors for asking questions usually go to the fair sex, but war has topsy-turvied even that opinion. Today women are answering questions and getting paid for it.

A group of seventy-four investment firms and banking institutions headed by the First National Bank of New York, Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc., and Lazard Freres Co. submitted yesterday the winning bid for an issue of $17,143,000 of city of Detroit, Mich., refunding bonds, the tender showing a net interest cost to the city of 2.59958 per cent.

DENVER, July 14 -- All activities of the National Federation of Business and Professional Women's Clubs, Inc., henceforth will be directed to aid United Nations victory, the Federal board agreed today at its annual meeting. Directors continued to advocate greater opportunities for women in the war effort.

LONDON, July 14 -- Confidence that Britain is turning out all of the right type of weapons for modern war and that she will hold the edge in the quality of guns, tanks and aircraft to the end was expressed today by Production Minister Oliver Lyttelton, speaking in the House of Commons on the highly controversial topic of production.

Mathieson Alkali Works, Inc., had a net profit of $556,092 for the first six months of this year, after $925,000 provision for Federal taxes, E. M. Allen, president, reported yesterday. This is equal to 57 cents a share on 828,171 shares of common stock and compares with $997,344 or $1.10 a common share for the first half of 1941 when Federal tax charges were only $450,000, $475,000 less than this year's.

WASHINGTON, July 14 -- Establishment of an "office of technical development," operating with an appropriation of $100,000,000 with which to finance first stages of the development of worth-while inventions that can accelerate the tempo of the war output effort, has been approved by the War Production Board and will be organized soon as a working entity.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 14 -Gregor Rabinovitch, European film producer, has been signed by United Artists to head a production unit which will film "Russian Girl," a photoplay to be based on the Soviet picture, "Girl From Leningrad."

WESTBURY, L.I., July 14 -- The Brookville, feature of today's Grand Circuit program at Roosevelt Raceway, was the only race completed, and it went to Toronto, a recent winner at Goshen. Six heats were staged before the program was curtailed by weather.
ALBANY, July 14 (AP) -- Despite continued war industry expansion, factory employment in New York State dropped 2.7 per cent and payrolls 3 per cent in June, the State Labor Department reported today.
The Queen whose domain might have included tins city had it not been for the fall of New Amsterdam 278 years ago arrived yesterday on her first visit.

LONDON, July 14 -- Fighting France put on a display here today commemorating Bastille Day that attracted more than twenty thousand spectators, the majority of whom were refugees from their native country in which the traditional holiday was either sternly suppressed or frowned upon.

PEEKSKILL, N.Y., July 14 -They are making "commando killers" out of the dress salesman, the butcher's boy, the advertising solicitor and the high school student from Brooklyn and the Bronx here at Camp Smith, headquarters of the New York Guard, and Governor Lehman himself told the guardsmen today it was "a very real probability" that they would have to help repel "enemy raids" and attempts at "mass sabotage."

Designers require inspiration Sometimes they get it from a painting, sometimes from a flower or it may be from a symphonic poem. Sally Victor got the inspiration for her Fall hat collection from the "V-Army" -- the men and women of the invaded countries who battle on for freedom without benefit of arms.

WASHINGTON, July 14 (AP) -The Census Bureau reported today that cotton consumed during June totaled 966,940 bales of lint, and 127,218 bales of linters, compared with 957,015 and 132,390 during May this year, and 875,812 and 126,405 during June last year.

NEWARK, N.J., July 14 (AP) -Frank Kelleher blasted his twentieth and twenty-first homers of the season and Aaron Robinson his fourteenth tonight as the league-leading Newark Bears took the measure of the Baltimore Orioles, 5 -- 2, in a twilight-arclight engagement.
CHICAGO, July 14 -- The shortage that was a subject of controversy a year ago has finally caught up with mahogany, George N. Lamb, secretary of the Mahogany Association, said today.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, July 14 -The special 100-man "ultra-Aryan" guard for Major Vidkun Quisling, head of the Nazi-sponsored government in Norway, has been judged insufficient quantitatively and qualitatively and is to be doubled, it was learned today.

WASHINGTON, July 14 -- The Navy disclosed today that a Marine Corps aviator, Major Lofton R. Henderson of Gary, Ind., dived his blazing plane down the smokestack of a Japanese aircraft carrier during the Battle of Midway.

Declaring that the city had no money to pay salary awards made by the courts to various groups of city employee under the McCarthy Salary Increment Law, Mayor La Guardia warned the City Council yesterday that a general payless furlough for all city employes might occur next April unless the law was amended meanwhile.

Two new films will arrive in Broadway theatres today. "The Pride of the Yankees," Samuel Goldwyn's screen version of the life of the late Lou Gehrig, with Gary Cooper portraying the baseball player, will have its world premiere tonight at the Astor Theatre.

CHICAGO, July 14 (AP) -- Hogs at principal markets continued in light supply today and sellers obtained prices up to 10 cents a hundredweight above yesterday's weak market on all weights and sows. The top here was $14.80, or 20 cents under the recent sixteen-year peak.

WASHINGTON, July 14 -- A new emergency fleet of sailing vessels will help the United States deliver to the other American republics the minimum foodstuffs and replacement parts needed for the maintenance of their economies and bring back essential raw materials needed for our war effort.

WASHINGTON, July 14 -- Housewives have a war job right at home in the "hard, dirty, unromantic chore of getting in the scrap," according to the Bureau of Industrial Conservation of the War Production Board. The country's 40,000,000 homemakers are charged with the responsibility of keeping war factories from closing down for lack of vital materials.

NEWARK, N.J., July 14 -Charged with having violated tire-rationing regulations, Meyer Solodar, operator of the Square Deal Tire Company of Dover, N.J., was sentenced here today by Federal Judge William Barker to serve a year in a Federal penitentiary and pay a $5,000 fine and was placed on probation for five years at the end of his prison term.

Preliminary meetings of the Book Mobilization Committee, a temporary organization sponsored by the Book and Magazine Union, Local 18, C.I.O., to study the role of the book industry in the war, will open today at the Hotel Algonquin.

CHICAGO, July 14 -- Corn futures closed higher today on the Board of Trade for the third straight day and went to the highest prices in about two months. Commission houses and professionals bought on the belief that the House and Senate would work out a compromise agreement in regard to the Commodity Credit Corporation selling wheat for feed purposes that would offer less competition with corn than the Senate version of the bill.

The pretense that the United States is on friendly terms with Vichy was all but dropped yesterday when Acting Secretary of State Sumner Welles revealed that Laval had rejected two proposals made by President Roosevelt for the disposal of the French warships at Alexandria, and that Mr. Roosevelt had thereupon informed Laval that he believed the British would be amply justified in destroying the warships to prevent their capture by the Axis.

The birth rate in this city rose last week to 18.5 to each 1,000 of population, Thomas J. Duffield, Registrar of Records in the Department of Health, reported yesterday. In the same week last year the rate was 16 and in 1940 it was 12.7.

Kings County Judge Louis Goldstein ordered yesterday a "thorough investigation" by a grand jury into all matters involving the funds of the general organization of New Utrecht High School in Brooklyn, with particular reference to the case of Max Cohen, a former teacher at that school, who recently pleaded guilty to third-degree forgery in connection with the theft of $16,000 from the organization funds.

LONDON, July 14 (U.P.) -- The German Gestapo chief for the Yugoslav puppet State of Croatia, a Major Helm, has been assassinated in a street in Zagreb, and his bodyguards, running amuck with revolvers and hand grenades, have murdered 700 persons in the crowded main square of the city, Yugoslav officials said tonight.

Arriving here from Washington, Ted Schroeder of Glendale, Calif., the highest ranking amateur in competition this season, went out to the Jackson Heights Tennis Club in Queens yesterday and won two matches without the loss of a game in the Eastern clay court championships.
MOSCOW, July 14 (AP) -- The Soviet Information Bureau broadcast this communique today:
The New York Chapter of the American Red Cross announced yesterday the creation of a Labor Bureau to serve as a clearing house for the Red Cross activities of all labor unions in Greater New York.
East Side properties figured in most of the Manhattan sales reported by brokers yesterday. Executors disposed of several holdings, and investors were the buyers in several cases.

From now on adjudication of manufacturers' and wholesale ceilings will be handled locally by the regional office of the Office of Price Administration, A.G. Antolini, associate regional price director, said yesterday.

Under the honorary chairmanship of General John J. Pershing 5,000 Free Frenchmen and American friends met last night at Manhattan Center, 311 West Thirty-fourth Street, and reaffirmed their devotion to the cause of the United Nations and the liberation of France.

Hank Borowy obviously was trying to get in out of the sun as quickly as possible yesterday. He mowed down the Tigers with a scant two singles at the Yankee Stadium, blanked them, 3 to 0, and was off the mound only 1 hour 24 minutes after he had served his first pitch.

Convoys to protect merchant ships from submarine attack have now been introduced into the Caribbean Sea and eventually will be put into effect in the Gulf of Mexico, Secretary of the Navy Frank Knox revealed yesterday at a press conference here.
The four-story garden-type apartment house at 83-09 Thirty-fifth Avenue, Jackson Heights, Queens, has been sold by Samuel Reznick to a client of Goodman Mabel, attorneys.

ST. LOUIS, July 14 (AP) -- The fighting Cardinals, who never know when they're down, staged another one of their explosive last-minute rallies today to defeat the Braves, 7 to 5, after being shut out for the first five innings.

United States Senator James M. Mead, whose candidacy for the Democratic nomination for Governor is being pushed by leaders opposed to Attorney General John J. Bennett Jr., issued another statement in Buffalo yesterday calling for party harmony on the selection of a candidate.

WASHINGTON, July 14 -- Two proposals by President Roosevelt for removal of the nine French naval vessels now at Alexandria, Egypt, to safe havens have been rejected by the Vichy Government. Therefore, in the view of the United States Govern ment, the British would be wholly justified in destroying the warships.

One thing, to start with, for an Englishman to remember about the United States is that it is practically impossible for an American to keep in mind the distinction, if any, between Great Britain and England without developing a violent headache.

A tall young man appeared in our office one day last week -- the ambassador, he disclosed, for a small city company that is still in its infancy. With a modest gesture that did nothing to disguise the unmistakable pride he has in his concern's achievements, he set before us a blue-and-orange packet concealing a bar of candy.

JERUSALEM, July 13 (Delayed) -- The notable part that the Holy Land is playing in supplying essential articles for the armies of the United Nations in the Middle East was described in a public statement by the chairman of the Palestine War Supply Board, Sir Douglas Harris, when he stated this afternoon that new industries established since the outbreak of the war, many by refugees, had aided considerably in saving valuable shipping space.

PATERSON, N.J., July 14 -- A threatened strike of 18,000 employes at the five plants of the Wright Aeronautical Corporation in this area was averted today as company and union negotiators announced an agreement had been reached on all points for a new contract, except on a proposed general wage increase, which issue both sides agreed to submit to the War Labor Board for settlement.

Jean Leonard Musa, a naturalized citizen of Swiss birth, was arrested yesterday accused of giving the Vichy Government information and propaganda service without registering with the State Department as an agent of a foreign power.

Warning that the United States "must plan on a period of years during which our one big business will be war, and most other businesses will be directly or indirectly subsidiaries of that big one," the Cleveland Trust Company in the current issue of its business bulletin released yesterday predicts that acute shortages in many lines of civilian goods may develop by the end of this year.

Four persons were slightly injured shortly after 9 o'clock last night when a southbound train on the Pelham Bay line of the Interborough subway sidewiped a single car parked on a switch between the Pelham Bay and Buhre Avenue stations.

WASHINGTON, July 14 -- The Battle of Midway Island, fought early last month over an area of hundreds of miles in the Pacific Ocean, took a toll of more than twenty Japanese vessels and 275 airplanes, at a cost to American forces of one destroyer sunk, the carrier Yorktown put out of commission but not sunk and a loss of only 307 lives.

WASHINGTON, July 14 (U.P.) -- Dr. Grace Langdon, director of the nursery school program of the Work Projects Administration, reported today a great increase in "locked-up" or "door-key" children as more mothers go into war industry.

Conferences were resumed yesterday at the offices of the New York Central Railroad in the Grand Central Terminal Building between representatives of the Eastern and Southeastern railroads and the Brotherhood of Locomotive Firemen and Enginemen on the union's demands for wage increases and readjustments in working conditions.

WASHINGTON, July 14 (AP) -- A group of 400 local and independent meat packers from all parts of the country issued a statement today criticizing Secretary Wickard and Price Administrator Henderson for a "price squeeze" which they said threatened them with financial ruin.

Touched off by another wave of inflationary sentiment, a stimulant that has periodically bobbed up in recent trading, the stock market eliminated yesterday the losses sustained since the recovery was halted on last Friday. The fairly heavy buying which set in on some pivotal issues, particularly United States Steel, encouraged demand for a representative list of stocks.
I read with great interest the Associated Press story about George A. Hamid, who is fighting the suggestion made by Joseph Eastman, Director of Transportation, to close all fairs for the duration.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., July 14 -Gordon Davis Rex, 35 years old, a restaurant worker, of 944 Stuyvesant Avenue, Union, N.J., who was arrested yesterday on an Erie Railroad ferryboat after boasting loudly that "Hitler will win the war," was sentenced to ninety days in the Hudson County Penitentiary today on a disorderly conduct charge.

When the far-reaching purpose of Japanese aggression became manifest in 1936 the Army warned that we must pile up stocks of essential raw materials, among them rubber. Congress refused to heed. Now we are at war, and the production of synthetic rubber to take the place of the raw material which we have lost is still lagging.

Although it is not yet openly admitted, the plain drift of Government policy is toward the use of lavish subsidies to avoid the harsh necessities of real inflation control. This has been clearly indicated in the Congressional manoeuvres over farm prices. While insisting on authority to sell surplus grains for livestock feeding at less than "parity" prices, the Administration has acquiesced in a program of 100 per cent parity loans on six basic crops.

LONDON, July 14 -- The War Cross, Czechoslovakia's highest military decoration, today was awarded to Lidice, village recently razed by the Nazis after the assassination of Reinhard Heydrich. Thus Lidice, whose entire male population was exterminated, was honored like Malta for the heroism and sacrifices of the civilians.

HARTFORD, Conn., July 14 (AP) -- Dr. Wolfgang Ebell of El Paso, pleaded guilty in Federal Court here today to a charge of conspiring to violate the Espionge Act of 1911 by furnishing military secrets of the United States to Germany and Japan.

WASHINGTON, July 14 -- The Navy tonight made public the following tables on ship losses inflicted on the Japanese by the Navy and on the Navy by the Japanese. The first table includes all Japanese losses announced in all of the Navy's communiques, including the one issued tonight, which described in detail the battle of Midway.

LOS ANGELES, July 14 -- The C.I.O. United Auto Workers' dream of having the wage scale at the Ford Motor Company's Willow Run plant in Michigan adopted for Pacific Coast aircraft manufacturers faded out today.

At least two demonstrations took place in France yesterday on the occasion of Bastille Day, one in Vichy and the other in Marseille, according to private advices to THE NEW YORK TIMES from the European Continent. The demonstrations occurred in connection with appeals from General Charles de Gaulle, leader of the Fighting France movement, who asked for demonstrations from patriotic Frenchmen throughout both zones of France.

CAIRO, Egypt, July 14 -- During German counter-attacks yesterday, Australians holding the end of the British salient west of El Alamein inflicted such heavy casualties on the Nazy infantry that the enemy failed to renew attacks today.

LONDON, July 14 -- The news from Russia had a restraining influence today on the Stock Market, particularly the oils. Gilt-edge issues were firm and Brazilian bonds well maintained, but Egyptian unified 4s declined u2 1/2.

CAMDEN, N.J., July 14 (AP) -The War Production Board today denied direct communications service to the new Garden State Racing Association track, several miles east of here, acting under a ruling which limits the use of scarce and critical materials by the telephone industry.

The Little, Brown-Atlantic Monthly Press biennial prize novel contest, one of the largest of the manuscript garnering competitions, has this year drawn a blank. After eight weeks of considering the best manuscripts from among the 646 submitted the judges have invoked the term of the contest in which they reserve the right to reject "any or all" entries.

AN ALASKA PORT, July 14 (AP) -- In the first eyewitness account of operations against Japanese occupying Kiska in the Western Aleutians, evacuees from a lonesome Aleutian island described the courageous work of young Navy fliers who blasted enemy forces with thousands of pounds of bombs in continued attacks.

WASHINGTON, July 14 -- The Senate adopted with a rush today a restriction in the war agencies appropriation bill of $1,856,000,000 which would prevent the Office of Price Administration from enforcing in all rationed States its recent 2 1/2-cent gasoline price increase to cover added transportation costs.

LONDON, July 14 -- The expansion of the United States forces in Britain proper was suggested in the appointment today of Major Gen. Mark W. Clark, forty-six-year-old New Yorker and former Chief of Staff of ground forces in the United States, as commander of the ground troops here.

PITTSBURGH, July 14 -- Holding the Pirates to three singles under the Forbes Field lights, Whit Wyatt breezed to his tenth triumph tonight as the Dodgers fell upon Bob Klinger and Aldon Wilkie for ten safe blows to win, 5 -- 1, before a crowd of 21,254.

Volunteer workers, the vanguard of what later is to be a small army, continued to make progress last night in their gigantic undertaking of fingerprinting the city's 8,000,000 persons as a civilian defense measure.

A summons was served yesterday on John W. Hession, stock trader charged with responsibility for running up defaulted mortgage bonds of the Wisconsin Central Railroad on the Stock Exchange for four months before a spectacular one-day break in the price, for his appearance tomorrow in Essex Market Magistrate's Court.

But Crushing of Fleeing Units Is Announced -- Trap North of Voronezh Reported The German High Command reported yesterday that the German offensive on the Don River front in Russia had been broadened to the south and that stubbornly defended Soviet positions had been breached, according to German broadcasts recorded by The United Press in New York.
SYRACUSE, N.Y., July 14 (AP) -Ken Jungels walked Frank Sauer with the bases loaded in the tenth inning to force in the run which gave Syracuse a 2-to-1 victory over Jersey City tonight.

WASHINGTON, July 14 -- The war revenue bill was reported formally today by the Ways and Means Committee with a revised estimate of $6,144,000,000 as the yield, but a minority report signed by Representative Knutson, who said that Chairman Doughton concurred in his views, declared that the measure had been arrived at through "a series of trades and shameless log-rolling."

MOSCOW, Wednesday, July 15 -- Red Amy forces are battling fiercely in Voronezh against a German assault army that has lost 35,000 men killed or wounded in ten days, the Soviet High Command announced today, and other Soviet troops have lessened a long-range threat to Moscow by hurling back a German offensive on the Kalinin front.

WASHINGTON, July 14 -- Shop records in ten of the departments of the Ford Motor Company, compiled by plant executives and not hitherto published, show a total slowdown of about thirty-three and three-fourths hours in the same production units for the month of February, 1942, as compared with March, 1941.

NEW DELHI, India, July 14 (AP) -- Parachute troopers of the Indian Army were credited by military quarters today with breaking up a murderous campaign of rapine and train-wrecking by the Hurs, a tribe of bearded, turbaned fanatical Moslems who have spread terror in Sind Province, near India's troubled Northwest Frontier.

The Volunteer Rescue Army, Inc., the first corporation organized under the religious corporations law to lose its charter in this city for irregularities, was dissolved yesterday by Supreme Court order in Brooklyn.

Elliott E. Simpson, counsel for the House subcommittee at Washington which is investigating the rubber situation, repeated yesterday his charge made Sunday that four large scrap rubber concerns, acting as agents of the Rubber Reserve Corporation, were making "a bonanza" of "vast profits" out of the scrap rubber collection drive which ended Friday.

The governors of the Society of the New York Hospital and the trustees of Cornell University were hosts last night at the Hotel Roosevelt at a farewell dinner to fifty-one physicians and 105 nurses who will be inducted today at Fort Banks, Boston, as the staff of the Ninth General Hospital, United States Army.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., July 14 -- Many members of the Summer colony have purchased tickets for the Navy Relief Ball to be held on Saturday night at the Elks Clubhouse for the benefit of the Navy Relief Society. Divertissements by professional entertainers who have donated their services for the occasion will be presented during the evening.
The Nazis continued their dangerous drive deep into the heart of Russia yesterday, but in Egypt weary armies were still locked in bloody stalemate less than eighty miles west of Alexandria.

The Government's loss is industry's gain with the resignation of Robert H. Hinckley as Assistant Secretary of Commerce to become assistant to President Thomas A. Morgan of the Sperry Corporation. As head of the Civil Aeronautics Administration and later in charge of civil aviation matters in the Commerce Department, Mr. Hinckley has shown broad vision and devoted interest in the "air-conditioning," as he termed it, of America.

Tami Mauriello of the Bronx easily defeated Tony Musto of Chicago in the eight-round feature attraction last night at the Bronx Coliseum before 8,000 fans. There were no knockdowns and the only damage was a cut over Musto's left eye.

The Federal Government's drive to provide rental quarters for war workers in vital New Jersey defense areas affords owners of existing properties suitable for conversion a splendid opportunity to perform a patriotic service and at the same time put their structures on a useful and economically sound basis, points out Warren J. Lockwood, New Jersey FHA State Director.

Wary of the farm legislation solution now being shaped by a compromising Congress, New Orleans interests, locals and commission houses sponsored enough liquidation in yesterday's quiet market to hold prices most of the session moderately below the previous close.

" The Merry Widow," which has not been seen on Broadway since Donald Brian's 1931 revival, will open a two-week engagement at Carnegie Hall this evening. This will be the second revival of an operetta there this Summer under the auspices of Joseph S. Tushinsky and Hans Bartsch, the other having been "The Chocolate Soldier."

An Italian broadcast recorded by The Associated Press yesterday reported the Italian High Command had claimed that Axis forces had made effective attacks in Egypt and taken a "great number" of British prisoners, including a battalion commander.

WASHINGTON, July 14 -- The Federal Trade Commission issued cease and desist orders today against six resident buyers in New York City and five representative New York manufacturers and wholesalers of fur garments, millinery and women's ready-to-wear apparel, charged by the commission, respectively, with taking and paying brokerage fees and commissions, although the buyers were acting as agents for retailers for whom they purchased various types of merchandise.

WASHINGTON, July 14 -- Donald M. Nelson, chairman of the War Production Board, and Jesse H. Jones, Secretary of Commerce, who are charged jointly with responsibility for the success of the synthetic rubber program, waged personal but separate fights today before Congressional subcommittees to defeat Senatorial moves to strip the WPB of priorities and allocations powers n building and operating plants and in distributing the depleted stockpile of crude rubber.

The National Boxing Association issued its quarterly ranking of fighters yesterday, and the recent depression in the ring business left the list with the fewest changes in years, The Associated Press reported.
