SAN FRANCISCO, July 14 -- A burst of machine-gun fire and the appearance of flares outside the Golden Gate early today caused ocean-front residents to believe the long predicted Japanese attack on San Francisco might be under way.

The formal entrance of William F. Brunner of Queens as a candidate for Congress against William B. Barry, isolationist member from the Second district in Queens, featured the substitution of designations filed with the Board of Elections by the deadline, midnight last night.

A strike yesterday of supply truck drivers employed by the New York Telephone Company jeopardized the delivery of telephone materials to Manhattan, Bronx, Weestchester, Putnam, Rockland and Orange Counties.

LONDON, July 14 -- The threat of trouble in India is seen here in a long resolution adopted today at Wardha by the All-India Congress party working committee in which the British are asked to withdraw their rule from the country.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., July 14 -- John Rosch resigned today as city historian here because Mayor Chauncey T.S. Fish and the City Council refused to erect in front of the old high school on Main Street a large patriotic "dioramic tableau," made like stage scenery, that he had painted to spur war bond drives.
The following Italian High Command communique was broadcast yesterday from Rome and was recorded here by The Associated Press:

Joseph Maria Gomez, 34 years old, who was reported to be the son of a former Ambassador of Colombia to Washington, was held in $1,500 bail by United States Commissioner Garrett W. Cotter yesterday after he had waived a hearing for grand jury action on the charge that he stole two "A" gasoline rationing books last Monday night from Public School 29, at Washington and Albany Streets.

An easing of the rules governing travel by enemy aliens living in the Southern Federal District of New York was announced yesterday by United States Attorney Mathias F. Correa. Effective today, they apply to persons living in the counties of Columbia, Dutchess, Greene, New York (Manhattan), Orange, Putnam, Rockland, Sullivan, Ulster, Westchester and Bronx.

Net assets of the American Superpower Corporation on June 30 last were $5,652,603, equivalent to $79.61 on each share of first preferred stock, against $6,219,998, or $73.15 a share at the end of last year. In the first half year the corporation disposed of 41,160 shares of United Corporation $3 cumulative preference stock in exchange for 13,720 shares of its own first preferred, which were tendered for retirement.

WASHINGTON, July 14 -- The deadlock on the 1943 Department of Agriculture appropriation bill continued tonight, although House conferees notified Speaker Rayburn at noon that they had reached "a compromise" under which they would waive their original demand that the Commodity Credit Corporation be banned from selling surplus stocks at below parity prices.

Provisions for rebates of excess profits taxes over a fixed percentage and a tax credit of at least a part of the amount of War Bonds purchased by firms and individuals should be included in the pending tax bill, Henry H. Heimann, executive manager of the National Association of Credit Men, asserts in the group's monthly business review, released today.

Despite the difficulties of transportation, Britain has fulfilled all her commitments to supply Soviet Russia with war materiel, with the exception of one tank, the British Information Service announced here yesterday.
The following German High Command communique was broadcast yesterday from Berlin and was recorded here by The Associated Press:

Henri Bernstein, French playwright, called on Frenchmen everywhere in a Bastille Day address last night over station WMCA "to pray for those dear to us who suffer, who live in indefeasible dignity with that horrible thing called hunger."

An increase in the number of inquiries from wholesale buyers was the chief result noted yesterday by Worth Street selling houses to the publication by the OPA of individual dollar-and-cents ceiling prices for terry towels, cotton and cotton-mixed blankets, corduroys and other allied products.

CHUNGKING, China, July 14 (U.P.) -- China is conscripting 6,000,000 new soldiers to swell her total of trained fighters to 26,000,000 -- the biggest army the world has ever known -- in an attempt to crush the Japanese within three years, General Cheng Cheh-yuen, director general of military training, announced today.

WASHINGTON, July 14 -- The White House announced that President Roosevelt signed an executive order Saturday shifting the merchant marine training functions from the Coast Guard to the War Shipping Administration.

A quarantine was placed yesterday on dogs in the Borough of Richmond by the city's Board of Health, which acted after six rabid dogs had been discovered on Staten Island since July 1. The order prohibits moving any dog into or out of the island and requires all dogs there now to be held on short leash when in public.

Total investment in the domestic steel industry at the close of 1941 was $4,405,263,785, compared with $4,265,933,908 the year before, according to the annual statistical report of the American Iron and Steel Institute. Total earnings of the industry after depreciation and depletion, but before interest charges, were $356,366,357, or 8.09 per cent on the investment, against $321,222,100, or 7.53 per cent, in 1940.

The Gulf, Mobile Ohio Railroad reported a net income of $1,064,784 for the five month ended with May, after all charges and taxes. This was equal, after provision of $25,000 for sinking fund requirements and dividend requirements on 305,750 shares of $5 preferred stock, to 66 cents each on 609,847 shares of common stock.

A War Work Information Bureau designed to help women find war jobs has been opened by the New York Branch of the American Association of University Women at their headquarters in the Midston House, 22 East Thirty-eighth Street, it was announced yesterday during a meeting of the organization.

Children in England have never been better fed, clothed or looked after than during the three years of the war, Evan Davies, superintendent of schools of Willesdon, London, told a group of teachers attending a "workshop" on "The War and the Curriculum" at the New York University School of Education yesterday morning.

Visiting buyers registered in the market for the week ended yesterday numbered 1,410, which compared with 836 in the preceding week and 1,405 in the similar period a year ago, according to the listings in THE NEW YORK TIMES. Yesterday's registrations totaled 694, as against 542 for last Tuesday.
Yesterday was the hottest day of the year, with a top of 91 degrees at 6 P.M., which also equaled the record for the date, reached in 1927. The previous high for the year was 89 on May 30.

As one who witnessed the rise of the Nazi movement in Germany and met many Nazis, including the Fuehrer, between 1930 and 1940, may I add a footnote to your editorial of July 13 on the distinction which you suggest must be made between Hitler and the German nation?

A dispatch from Moscow says that the Germans are using their air force as a mobile unit, shifting it rapidly from front to front as necessity dictates, sometimes as much as 500 miles. That statement suggests to the nonmilitary mind that one of this war's lessons has not been learned as well as it should have been learned by the United Nations.

Among those who leased residential quarters as reported by brokers yesterday were Sarah Field Splint, associate editor of Woman's Home Companion, and Gertrude Rossiter, editor of Fashion Accessories, who took apartments in the New Weston, Madison Avenue and Fiftieth Street.

Outstanding export licenses, which are valid except that they have not already been granted an official shipping priority rating, have been relegated to the blanket category "D," the Board of Economic Warfare, Office of Exports, disclosed yesterday in its new Current Controls Bulletin No. 35.
WASHINGTON, June 14 -- A three-way deadlock on the War Labor Board may send the "Little Steel" wage dispute to President Roosevelt, according to reports today.

Paul V. McNutt told the American Medical Association at its last meeting that doctors responded more patriotically to their country's call in the last war than in this one. One has only to look beneath the surface to discover, if not justification, at least many and varied causes, which cannot be discussed in detail here.

The nights on the African desert are cold and black after the blinding heat of days when even the bleached rocks cast no shadow. The nights in the great bend of the River Don are not unlike those in the Mississippi Valley, humid and murmurous as the dust settles over the rolling plains.

The ban recently placed by James C. Petrillo, president of the American Federation of Musicians, on the National Broadcasting Company's presentation of the Interlochen High School Symphony programs was viewed in radio circles here yesterday as part of some general strategy which the union leader is planning in connection with his order forbidding the making of records and electrical transcriptions after July 31.

SCARSDALE, N.Y., July 14 -Bill Goldbeck, Mount Kisco pro, toured the Sunningdale Country Club 6,410-yard lay-out in a sub-par 70 today with a pair of amateurs from his home club, Howard Logan and Howard Oden. Each of the amateurs helped with four strokes, resulting in a twin victory for Goldbeck at identical scores of 32, 34 -- 66.

CHICAGO, July 14 -- Directors of the National Association of Broadcasters today tackled the problems dropped in the lap of the radio industry by James C. Petrillo through his recent edict banning employment of musicians for transcriptions and recordings.

The Appellate Division's four-to-one decision on Monday did not leave Paul J. Kern and Wallace S. Sayre much hope of regaining their positions on the Municipal Civil Service Commission. One must say, however, that the minority opinion, maintained by Presiding Justice Martin, seemed as logical as the majority verdict, supported by Justices Townley, Glennon, Cohn and Callahan.

CINCINNATI, July 14 (AP) -- Ray Starr hurled three-hit ball for the Reds today but lost to the Phils 2 to 1, on the strength of a fly ball off the bat of Rube Melton that went for a two-run homer after two Red outfielders collided and were momentarily dazed.

The first prosecution of a filling station proprietor on a charge of selling gasoline illegally since the OPA regulations became effective, yesterday resulted in Joseph Brecher, 50-year-old part-owner of a station at 58-09 Rust Street, Maspeth, Queens, being fined $100 in the Long Island City Court.

Raymond G. Pollard, former assistant Commissioner of Borough Works in Queens, lost in Supreme Court yesterday in his attempt to compel Borough President James A. Burke of Queens to reinstate him to the position he held under Borough President George U. Harvey.

The French colony of New York, with the de Gaullists more active than adherents of the Vichy regime, celebrated Bastille Day in a series of church services, receptions and gatherings culminating in the mass meeting last night at Manhattan Center.

New life insurance for the first half of this year increased 8.9 per cent over the corresponding six months of last year, while the total for June was one-tenth of 1 per cent less than for the similar month of 1941, according to the Association of Life Insurance Presidents in a report to the Department of Commerce.

WASHINGTON, July 14 -- Regulations requiring truck operators to have their trucks loaded to at least 75 per cent of capacity on return trips have been canceled by the Office of Defense Transportation, Joseph B. Eastman, ODT Director, announced today.

A shot fired by one of two patrolmen who were pursuing three hold-up men fatally wounded Helen Casey, 24 years old, of 444 East 136th Street, the Bronx, as she was riding in an automobile through West Eighteenth Street near Tenth Avenue at 8:15 o'clock last night.

CHUNGKING, China, July 14 -- The newspaper Ta Kung Pao pictures post-war China as intensively industrialized, militarily and economicaly self-sufficient and enjoying a standard of living comparable to that of any other peoples in the world.

MOSCOW, July 14 -- The Soviet Information Bureau gave a luncheon today for the Anglo-American Press Association, and there was an exchange of views between for eign correspondents and high Soviet officials, well-known Soviet writers and political workers.

Mayor La Guardia's refusal to grant local tax exemption on property that may be bought by the Vichy French Government in New York has embroiled him in a dispute with Cordell Hull, Secretary of State, it was learned yesterday.

BERNE, Switzerland, July 14 -Finland's national aspirations are today spread before the world by Field Marshal Baron Carl Gustav Mannerheim in a statement appearing in the Axis publication Berlin-Rome-Tokyo."

The first upset of the Eastern junior tennis championship occured yesterday when Mitchell Polstein of New York City came from behind to eliminate the second-seeded contender, Tom Falkenburg of Hollywood, 3 -- 6, 6 -- 4, 17 -- 5, in their postponed second round match on the courts of the West Side Tennis Club in Forest Hills.

WASHINGTON, July 14 -- A plea for understanding of France and a promise that France would remain "faithful to her traditional friendships" were made at a Bastille Day reception today by the French Ambassador, Gaston Henry-Haye, who declared that France would rise again "still imbued with an ideal."

SOMEWHERE IN AUSTRALIA, July 14 -- A luncheon embodying ideas borrowed from the Japanese was served today at one of the messes in this American camp. It was an experiment undertaken in an attempt to solve the problem of how to feed our troops, if the time comes, in the island areas northward of Australia where the supply problem is greatest.

Works by three New York composers, Aaron Copland, William Schuman and Paul Creston, were performed by Alexander Smallens at last night's concert of the New York Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra at the Lewisohn Stadium.

BOSTON, July 14 -- With the shadow of Seabiscuit and the Suffolk Downs "graveyard of champions" in his way, Whirlaway tangles with seven rivals in the eighth running of the $50,000-added Massachusetts Handicap tomorrow and if he wins he'll be the biggest money-winner in all turf history.

Mayor La Guardia put his signature yesterday on a local bill banning the wearing of bathing suits or other scanty attire on streets or boardwalks more than 200 feet from a bathing beach under Park Department control.

Public offering of a block of 84,375 shares of Republic Drill and Tool Company common stock will be made today at $4 a share, by Craigmyle, Rogers Co. The offering includes 78,125 shares originally reserved for conversion of option warrants, which are being offered on behalf of the company, and 6,250 shares, which are offered by the underwriters for their own account.
WASHINGTON, July 14 -- Following is the text of a Navy Department communique issued this evening:

Supreme Court Justice Benjamin F. Schreiber granted yesterday a motion by defendants to consolidate into one action ten suits brought by stockholders of Standard Oil Company of New Jersey for recovery of more than $100,000,000 losses alleged to have been suffered by the company through its pre-war agreements with I.G. Farbenindustrie, the German chemical trust.

OTTAWA, Ont., July 14 (Canadian Press) -- Newspaper men have been listed under Section 15 of the National War Services Regulations. This section provides that from time to time the War Service Minister may furnish to Selective Service Boards lists of industrial or servicing activities deemed to be essential to the successful prosecution of the war.

Retail prices in June receded 0.1 per cent below the previous month, the first time in several years that quotations eased for two consecutive months, according to the Fairchild retail price index. During the previous month prices declined to the extent of 0.2 per cent.

To us of a younger nation the history of older peoples, with its ebb and flow of fortune, of conquest and subjection and long periods of distress, is apt to seem mournful. Yet our elder brothers have, like us, great moments of pride and elation imperishable in memory. One of ours is the Fourth of July.

AUSTIN, Texas, July 14 (AP) -- The city of San Antonio and the San Antonio Public Service Company were restrained today by a temporary court order against further steps toward the condemnation or purchase by the city of the company's electrical properties.

CHUNGKING, China, July 14 -- "The coming of American air forces to China has given a tremendous stimulus to Chinese morale, civil and military," declared T.E. Tsiang, Minister Without Portfolio, today.

Although well aware that some future government action may automatically cancel all their preparations, representatives of the United States Atlantic Tuna Tournament affiliated clubs met yesterday at the Hotel New Yorker and approved plans for their fifth annual contest, scheduled for Aug. 17 and 19.

Efforts to promote a more widespread "Shop at Home" movement by smaller local stores have been stimulated by gasoline rationing and rubber conservation measures. Latest to sponsor this theme is the Wholesale Dry Goods Institute, whose member wholesalers serve small independent stores.

LITTLE NECK, L.I., July 14 -One of the best golf rounds of the entire season was played today by Mrs. J.B. Balding, member of the Cedar Creek Club, in winning the low gross award in the one-day event of the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association on the Sound View course.

Rudolf Garvin, 25 years old, and Hermann Peter Stadler, 38, aliens, and residents of Zurich, Switzerland, were named yesterday in an indictment handed up by the Federal grand jury to Judge Robert A. Inch in the United States District Court, Brooklyn.
For two hours yesterday afternoon the College Room of the Hotel Astor was the scene of informal gymnastics that probably could not be duplicated outside a jitterbugs' convention.

CHICAGO, July 14 -- The Giants made a lot of menacing gestures in the direction of the left-handed Vern Olsen and the Cubs at Wrigley Field today, but they added up to just so much wasted effort and Mel Ott's band sank ingloriously under a 3-to-0 whitewashing.

It is best to embark upon the idyllic adventure of a Summer-in-the-country -- or a long-awaited two-weeks-with-pay -- both forewarned and forearmed against mosquitoes. The armor is a jar of fluffy, meadow-sweet vanishing cream -- second cousin to citronella.

WASHINGTON, July 14 -- Treason indictments under which the penalty may be death will be sought against all the fourteen New York and Chicago men and women who aided the eight Nazi saboteurs now on trial here, it was implied today.
The apartment house for sixty-six families at 429-33 Fairmount Avenue, Jersey City, has been sold by the New Jersey Title Guarantee Trust Company, in liquidation, to the 429 Fairmount Corporation.

Utility executives have become alarmed over the issuance of an order by the Federal Power Commission which applies to rates charged in the transmission and sale of electric energy. Known as order No. 95, this latest regulation goes far beyond any order of a similar nature prescribed by the commission.
A speeding automobile, driven by the stunt driver John "Lucky" Kelly, crashed into a field box at the Polo Grounds at the conclusion of the Rodeo there last night, injuring ten persons.

Colonel Bob Neyland, once the producer of bone-crushing football teams at Tennessee, and Major Wallace Wade, who did a superbly efficient job at Duke, have been named the coaches of the All-Army team, which is expected to raise $1,000,000 for Army Emergency Relief by playing eight games against the crack squads of the National Football League.

The demand for a readjustment of gasoline quotas to give to New York City and other urban centers some of the excess supplies now assigned to vacation areas attained new force yesterday in the face of a warning that the city may be without any gasoline, except for essential uses, by late September.

In line with Governor Lehman's suggestion that families in the State open rooms in their homes for occupancy by war workers, particularly in busy and crowded defense centers, Edward M. Weinfeld, State Commissioner of Housing, announced yesterday that a series of "war guest campaigns" would be held in various cities, starting with Niagara Falls on July 20.
CHICAGO, July 15 -- A feud that had been smoldering since the season opened blazed up today as the Dodgers flattened the Cubs, 10 -- 5, in the first of a four-game series at Wrigley Field.
CAIRO, Egypt, July 15 (AP) -- A joint British Headquarters-Royal Air Force communique said today:

WASHINGTON, July 15 -- A two-month Congressional deadlock over an Agriculture Department program to convert Government-owned surplus wheat to the war needs of the United Nations by feeding it to livestock to produce meat, eggs and milk came to an end today as the House gave way to a Senate proposal designed to make the program effective.

Unlike the commandos "who hit and run," the new Engineer Amphibian Command that the United States Army is now organizing "will not run," Lieut. Col. R.L. Salzmann, personnel procurement officer, Corps of Engineers, last night told 2,000 men at a recruiting rally under the auspices of the United States Power Sqadrons at the Hotel Astor.

Reporting on results for the first half of 1942, Lewis H. Brown, president of the Johns-Manville Corporation, informed stockholders yesterday that operations had continued at new high records. Sales of $48,754,848 were the highest for any six months in the history of the company and represented an increase of 25.6 per cent over the $38,812,510 for the same period of 1941.

Mayor F.H. La Guardia will swear in Dr. Ernest Lyman Stebbins today at City Hall as Commissioner of Health to succeed Dr. John L. Rice, who is giving up the administrative duties of the department because of ill health.

Mohandas K. Gandhi is one of the great souls of this generation. If all mankind were to adopt the spiritual essence of his teachings there would not be any more wars. Yet the effect of what Gandhi is now saying and doing may be to defeat everything for which he stands.

With his hands and feet bound and his throat encircled by a cord that had been stretched between two uprights of his four-poster bed, Walter Robert Shook, 21-year-old worker in the war materials plant of the Sperry Corporation at Garden City, L.I., was found dead at 4 P.M. yesterday in his home at 95-08 Queens Boulevard, Elmhurst, Queens.

LONDON, July 15 -- Restoration of the school-leaving age to fifteen years with the possibility of extending it another year is being considered by the government, the Earl of Selborne said in the House of Lords today, replying in a debate on education.

CHUNGKING, China, July 15 (U.P.) -- Japanese forces have captured two Chekiang Province seaports, Wenchow and Juian, ten miles apart and about 225 miles below Shanghai, to prevent the Allies from using them as air and naval bases, a Chinese Army spokesman said today.

John Corigliano, the assistant concert master of the New York Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra who occupies the first desk during the Summer season, last night appeared as the soloist with the orchestra at the all-French concert conducted by Alexander Smallens at the Lewisohn Stadium.

Henry A. Arnold, one of the youngest officials in the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation organization, was elected a vice president of the corporation yesterday and placed in charge of all I.T.'s principal South American operating properties.

CALCUTTA, India, July 15 (U.P.) -- Members of the American Volunteer Group had such a good time fighting the Japanese in Burma and China against terrific odds that twenty-two of them now are going to take a fling at another long-shot venture.

WASHINGTON, July 15 -- Travelers were asked today by Joseph B. Eastman, director of the Office of Defense Transportation, to limit themselves to one bag where possible because of the crowded condition of coaches and Pullman cars during periods of peak travel.

CHICAGO, July 15 -- Restaurant sales jumped 22 per cent during June by comparison with 1941, the monthly report of the National Restaurant Association showed today. The East South-Central and West South-Central groups topped the regional lists with gains respectively of 49 and 36 per cent. Both these areas are scenes of a rapid expansion of war production activities.

BORDENTOWN, N.J., July 15 (AP) -- Speaking before the twenty-seventh annual convention of the State Federation of Colored Women's Clubs here today, Mrs. Eleanor Roosevelt, wife of the President, said permanent peace would come to the world when a spirit of mutual responsibility for human welfare prevailed.
LONDON, July 15 (AP) -- Advocates of a second land front in Europe to help Russia pressed firmly tonight for quick action.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 15 -- Anna Lee, English film actress, was signed today by Universal for the leading feminine role in "Flesh and Fantasy," Charles Boyer-Julien Duvivier production in which Boyer and Edward G. Robinson will be seen. Thomas Mitchell, C. Aubrey Smith and Dame May Whitty will play supporting roles, and Duvivier will direct from an episodic scenario by Ernest Pascal.

The policemen who arrested the three men who shot and killed Patrolman Michael J. Moroso on Dec. 8, 1932, in front of 236 East Ninety-ninth Street, were among members of the police department who won departmental honors yesterday in orders issued by Commissioner Valentine.

An eloquent clemency plea by a lawyer on behalf of 17-year-old Alfred Chester Ames, which was joined in by the prosecutor, brought a suspended sentence for the youth yesterday in General Sessions. The youth had previously pleaded guilty to first-degree manslaughter in the shooting of Samuel Friedman, 47, a steel salesman, because of Friedman's previous mistreatment of the boy's widowed mother.

Reader interest in war news, editorials and columnists continues to be high, according to a survey by The Minneapolis Star Journal, released yesterday by the Advertising Research Foundation as Study 52 of the continuing study of newspaper reading.

LONDON, July 15 (UP) -- The Italians have sent their entire Second Army Corps into action against the Yugoslav patriot armies of General Draja Mikhailovitch, who have killed or captured more than 4,000 Axis troops since mid-June, it was reported here tonight.

A Queen made a request yesterday. Wilhelmina of the Netherlands, on her first visit to the Seamen's Church Institute at 10 o'clock yesterday morning, asked to be allowed to shake hands with all the Netherlands seamen that were in the audience of 400 whom she addressed. Officials were a little worried.

MEXICO CITY, July 15 -- The mining industry in Mexico is entering a new phase, due to the fact that silver is now being used in alloys for the manufacture of war equipment and commercial articles in the United States, according to a statement made yesterday by Raul Bailleres, president of the Bank of Mining Credit, here.

The inadequacy of the forthcoming tax bill as a war taxation measure will be so obvious as to be a distinct shock to public confidence. The government's need clearly calls for much more than is to be proposed. The evidence supplied by public opinion polls indicates that the people understand this need and are more realistic than any one in Washington as to how to meet it.

PITTSBURGH, July 15 -- Philip Murray, president of the C.IO., declined comment tonight on the reported decision of the War Labor Board granting a 44-cent daily pay increase to workers in Little Steel, but other union sources indicated that it would be met with vigorous opposition tomorrow.

A dinner was given last night for Miss Marion Kohn in the Victorian Suite of the Carlyle by officers of the Motor Transport Division of the American Women's Voluntary Services. Miss Kohn has been appointed a lieutenant in the division.

A "mighty proud and happy family" told last night of the thrill they had on reading of the heroism of John Cornelius Cullen, as they sat in the dining room of their one-family home at 215-33 Forty-ninth Avenue, Bayside Hills, Queens.
MOSCOW, July 15 (AP) -- The Soviet Information Bureau issued this communique today:

The three-story dwelling at 1258 Nelson Avenue, the Bronx, has been sold by the Central Savings Bank to John Stone through Elroy-Clark Co., Inc., brokers. Amend Amend represented the sellers. Henry Pleus was the attorney for the buyer.

WASHINGTON, July 15 -- Gifts of supplies to the British people for relief purposes are being sharply curtailed because of the demand for shipping space for military supplies. An agreement as to this affect was reached by President Roosevelt and Prime Minister Churchill.

DES MOINES, July 15 -- Soldiers in fatigue suits peeled off their jackets and worked in shirt sleeves under a broiling sun today, to get their former barracks ship-shape for the influx on Sunday of the vanguard of the Women's Army Auxiliary Corps.

The Navy's communique on the Battle of Midway, published yesterday, more than a month after the event, offers heartening confirmation of the strength and skill of our fighting services but the communique and the supplementary material that accompanied it are not the candid documents that the great victory deserves.

The report of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company and its principal operating subsidiaries for the twelve months ended on May 31, issued yesterday by Walter S. Gifford, president, shows a consolidated net income after all expenses and charges, of $194,527,627.

WITH THE BRITISH EIGHTH ARMY, at El Alamein, July 14 (Delayed) (AP) -- The Germans tried all day yesterday to crack the Australians' lines on the northern front here, and when the Australians held firm the enemy tried to break through the South Africans' positions.

WASHINGTON, July 15 -- Warmaking is the avocation of a democratic government; the real vocation of most of those who form it is politics. Therefore, the interest of Washington is very great in the manoeuvres over the Democratic nomination for Governor of New York.
WASHINGTON, July 15 (AP) -- The War Production Board reported today that appropriations approved and proposed for carrying on the war program totaled about $223,000,000,000.

Merger of the Manhattan Savings Institution and the Citizens Savings Bank, two of the oldest savings institutions in this city, was announced yesterday. The combined organization will take the name of the Manhattan Savings Institution and will rank as the twentieth largest mutual savings bank in the United States.

Three hundred and seventy-two passengers and crew members, including three women, were rescued from a medium-sized American merchant ship that was torpedoed and sunk about 400 miles off the Atlantic coast two weeks ago, it was revealed by the Navy yesterday.

BOSTON, July 15 (AP) -- The Red Sox and the White Sox split a double bill today, Boston lambasting Edgar Smith, 10 -- 1, in the opener and the Pale Hose surging back with a swarm of base hits to capture the nightcap, 11-6.

WESTBURY, L.I., July 15 (AP) -- Pay Up, a bay colt owned by R.H. Johnston of Charlotte, N.C., won the Matron Stake for 3-year-old trotters at Roosevelt Raceway today under the guiding hand of Lee Smith, who drove Johnston's Bill Gallon to victory in the 1941 Hambletonian.

Three physicians, convicted by a General Sessions jury last June 25 on ten counts of conspiracy and abortion in conducting an "abortion mill" at 116 East Sixty-third Street, were sentenced yesterday by Judge Jacob Gould Schurman Jr. to Sing Sing terms, while their so-called "runner," who solicited physicians and pharmacists to send "patients" to the place, escaped with a one-year penitentiary term.

MOSCOW, July 15 -- Although the position at Voronezh remains highly critical, and the whole situation on the Don front must be considered full of menace to the Allied cause, the defenders of the city have made powerful sorties in the last two days and placed the Germans on the defensive at several places.

WASHINGTON, July 15 -- The War Revenue Bill was sent to the House floor today for a three-day debate starting tomorrow, the Rules Committee granting a "closed" rule under which only amendments by the Ways and Means Committee can be offered.

Although the War Production Board's Bureau of Industrial Conservation has based its salvage campaign upon cooperation between industry and government, R. Merrill Decker, regional director of the industry salvage section of the board, declared yesterday that the need of scrap materials was so vital to the war effort that failure of the campaign necessarily would call for requisitioning.

The two five-story tenements on a plot 49.8 by 100 feet at 192-94 Henry Street, between Clinton and Jefferson Streets, have been sold by the Central Savings Bank to a client of Haskel Jacobs, attorney. Sale was for cash above a $9,900 first mortgage.

WASHINGTON, July 15 -- A temporary upward adjustment in milk prices was granted today by the Office of Price Administration for the benefit of the New York metropolitan area retail food stores that were caught with abnormally low March, 1942, ceiling prices for fluid whole milk in glass or paper containers.

Minor difficulties caused by various wartime restrictions apparently are not discouraging rod-and-reel enthusiasts from pursuing their favorite sport at the lakes and ponds in near-by Westchester and Putnam Counties.

NEWARK, N.J., July 15 (AP) -- In a travesty on baseball the league-leading Newark Bears today hammered the Baltimore Orioles into submission by 23 to 3 for their fourth straight victory and a sweep of the series.

A careful sampling just completed by the Treasury Department showed that New Yorkers who signed pledges to buy war savings bonds during the campaign from June 14 to 28 had kept their promises almost unanimously, Harold N. Graves, assistant to Secretary Morgenthau, declared yesterday at a reception to executives and key workers of the drive in the Hotel Roosevelt.

German and allied troops were advancing rapidly along the entire offensive front in Southern Russia, throwing back the Red Army rear guard and partly dispersing or annihilating it, the German High Command reported yesterday, according to German broadcasts recorded by The United Press in New York.

A scheme through which a group of Polish and Russian immigrants were enabled to buy visas permitting them to enter this country before they were entitled to do so under the quota laws was charged yesterday in Federal court. The indictment, handed up on the basis of evidence presented by J. Gerard Cregan, assistant United States attorney, named as defendant Maximiliano Birnbaum, alias Max Burns, an artificial flower dealer of 817 West End Avenue.

WASHINGTON, July 15 -- Following an announcement that the Defense Supplies Corporation would defray the increased cost of bringing gasoline into Eastern States, Senator Russell of Georgia withdrew today an amendment to a pending appropriation bill which would have blocked enforcement of a 2 1/2-cent increase in the ceiling price in States served by pipelines.

LONDON, July 15 -- Business on the stock markets today was particularly quiet and prices closed irregular. Grit-edged issues remained firm with the 3 1/2 per cent war loan harder at u105 15-16. Little change was seen in the home rails.

Once in pre-war days ships shuttling between Sweden and England carried large quantities of wood pulp for the publication of British books and newspapers. And in those normal times Sweden imported considerable quantities of printed books from England.

Another wave of inflationary psychology filtered yesterday over the stock market as prices were enlarged to a new peak for the recovery movement. Since values had on Tuesday almost reached the tops set on last Thursday, the push to send them beyond that level was necessarily only slight.

CANBERRA, Australia, July 5 -- Pieces of Japanese Zeros planes from the New Guinea front are giving headaches to American Army postoffice officials. American soldiers and airmen have become insatiable souvenir hunters, especially for pieces of Japanese planes brought down in action. Some scraps they send home weight ten pounds.
Favorable effects of the war on some lines of business associated with defense activity were indicated in large leases and expansions reported by brokers yesterday.
Several business executives are among the latest tenants added to the rosters of apartment houses in Manhattan.

CINCINNATI, July 15 (AP) -- After losing their tenth straight game to the Reds in the opener, 6 -- 2, the Braves today put together a five-run fifth inning in the nightcap to beat Paul Derringer, 7 to 2.

The importance of selecting men of college caliber for training as future officers in the armed forces was impressed upon 200 education officials by a joint Army, Navy and Marine Corps committee at a conference yesterday in the Hotel Commodore.

WASHINGTON, July 15 -- President Roosevelt was reported today to have decided to ask Congress in the near future for statutory wage and salary controls and authority to grant subsidies to business so as to hold the price ceiling against the increasing threat of inflation.

WASHINGTON, July 15 (AP) -- The House Naval Affairs Committee was told today that three "sales engineers" stood to make commissions on millions of dollars of government war work in a plant which the government itself built.
WASHINGTON, July 15 (AP) -- The War Department announced today a list of 156 American civilians from Wake Island interned by the Japanese at Shanghai.

The Brooklyn Trust Company has sold through Hosinger Bode, Inc., brokers, the one-family houses at 39-62 Forty-seventh Street, Sunnyside, Queens, to Mrs. Alice Dorn and at 80-01 Eighty-sixth Street, Jackson Heights, to Henry A. Hiller.

LOCUST VALLEY, L.I., July 15 -- Mrs. J.B. Balding of the Cedar Creek Club won her second tournament in as many days as she paced the field in the weekly one- day event of the women's Long Island Golf Association over the Creek course at her home club with a 40, 40 -- 80 today.
Beyond all doubt the main difficulty that stands in the way of Americans understanding England and the English understanding America is that they speak a common language -- so they think.

WASHINGTON, July 15 -- A new patriotic song, "Spirit of Liberty" was sung publicly for the first time tonight by Lily Pons, accompanied by the National Symphony Orchestra, at a Watergate Concert for the benefit of Army and Navy relief, Andre Kostelanetz conducted.

WASHINGTON, July 15 -- The Senate voted without contest today to give the Office of Price Administration $125,000,000 of operating funds -- $5,000,000 more than its Appropriations Committee had recommended and $50,000,000 more than the House recently allowed.

With world consumption likely to reach 7,500,000 carats, against 5,500,000 carats in 1941, the demand for industrial diamonds this year will equal or exceed current production for the first time in the history of the industry, according to a review prepared by Sydney H. Ball of the engineering firm of Rogers, Mayer Ball, and issued yesterday by The Jewelers' Circular-Keystone.

Supporters of United States Senator James M. Mead for the Democratic nomination for Governor are seeking to arrange a conference of leading Democrats with President Roosevelt to discuss the situation, it was learned yesterday. This is in accordance with Senator Mead's recent suggestion that the President, James A. Farley, Democratic State Chairman, and Governor Lehman confer with a view to reaching agreement on a nominee to head the State ticket.

WASHINGTON, July 15 -- The discovery of the daring saboteur invasion of this country came when a solitary young Coast Guardsman on the Long Island shore saw two Germans emerging from the sea at midnight and another standing on the beach, the United States Coast Guard revealed today in a graphic story of the incident.
SOMEWHERE IN AUSTRALIA, July 15 -- Dear Benny Goodman, Tommy Dorsey and Glenn Miller:

When Conservation Order No. M-31 was first issued last February we studied it with what we thought was conscientious care. We learned, for example, in our perusal of this pamphlet, which is less formidably known as the tin order, that such miscellaneous stuff as canned coffee and spaghetti and mushrooms would soon be part of the past.

Stocks of finished and unfinished gasoline in the United States at the close of last week were 85,658,000 barrels, a decrease of 1,356,000 from the 87,014,000 a week earlier, the American Petroleum Institute announced yesterday. A year ago, these stocks amounted to 87,922,000 barrels.

ISTANBUL, Turkey, July 15 (U.P.) -- Turkish sources said today that vast Axis reinforcements were going to North Africa by way of ports on the Greek mainland and on Crete, indicating that General Field Marshal Erwin Rommel had stopped only to rest and had by no means given up his plans to attempt to reach the Middle East through Egypt.

Those trees that grandfather planted to fill the gaps made by his worthy but sometimes avaricious ancestors are not all going into American houses of the future. Some of them have already been earmarked for milady's back, to keep her warm as well as covered.

PITTSBURGH, July 15 -- In the face of some fancy flinging by Truett (Rip) Sewell on Forbes Field today, the Giants folded like a punctured accordion and submitted quietly to a 6-2 beating from the Pirates.

Bright in the official blue and yellow colors of Sweden and bearing the Norwegian name "Budkavlen," a trim Fairchild training airplane lifted out of La Guardia Field yesterday afternoon to begin a nation-wide tour of the United States to raise $300,000 for the training of Norwegian pilots in Canada.

A new chain of receiving stations for salvage materials will be set up soon throughout the city, Clarence H. Low, chairman of the New York City Salvage Committee, said yesterday. The announcement was made after householders and merchants complained that they had no place to turn in their scrap rubber since the oil industry's rubber salvage drive ended last Friday.

Bob Falkenburg of Hollywood and Charles Oliver of Perth Amboy will meet in the final round of the Eastern junior tennis championship on the courts of the West Side Tennis Club in Forest Hills this morning.
Hamilton Wilson has been elected a vice president of Field, Richards Co. of Cincinnati and Cleveland, it was announced yesterday.

In your report this morning of my Bastille Day broadcast on WMCA the last paragraph reads: "Mr. Bernstein, rejected by the French Army during the last war, enlisted with the British and fought in the Battle of Flanders. He came to the United States after the German occupation of Paris in 1940."

Likelihood that the coming production limitation order of the War Production Board would disrupt the cosmetic industry seriously was discounted in well-informed trade quarters here yesterday. The WPB is expected to issue the order soon and predictions were that it would prove "very satisfactory" to the industry as a whole.

WARDHA, India, July 14 (Delayed) (U.P.) -- Mohandas K. Gandhi warned tonight that India's masses, despite a strict injunction to shun violence, might riot in the nation-wide anti-British movement that he threatened unless London accepted a "final" demand to free India at once.
WASHINGTON, July 15 -- Leon Henderson, Price Administrator, warned OPA employes today not to engage in political activity, adding:
The following German High Com mana communique was broadcast from Berlin yesterday and was recorded here by The Associated Press:

" Her Cardboard Lover," which opens at the Capitol, is this morning's lone film newcomer. Norma Shearer and Robert Taylor head the cast of the comedy romance, which was directed for Metro by George Cukor. Included among the featured players are George Sanders, Frank McHugh, Chill Wills and Elizabeth Patterson.

Joseph T. Sharkey, vice chairman of the City Council, turned over a number of threatening letters from supporters of the German American Bund to the FBI yesterday with a request that they be investigated.

MEXICO CITY, July 15 (AP) -- Measures pledging the American countries to raise the living, wage and educational standards of their people through "greater production and equitable distribution" by means of lowered trade barriers were approved by the second Inter-American Agricultural Congress today.

British and Dominion shipyards have added more than 500 warships of all classes to the fleet since the war began and have multiplied by ten the peacetime production of destroyers, H.C. Forraby, British Broadcasting Corporation naval commentator, revealed last night, according to a statement released here by the British Information Services.

WASHINGTON, July 15 -- The General Federation of Women's Clubs is mobilizing its 2,500,000 members into a drive to force a clean-up of vice conditions which it finds are rife around many Army and Navy areas.

LONDON, July 15 (U.P.) -- The Royal Air Force made four strong sweeps over Northern France today, one by nearly 200 Spitfire fighters, shooting up German targets scattered over a 200-mile stretch of the coastal area from the Cherbourg peninsula to Etaples, below Boulogne.

SINCLAIR LEWIS has a game which he calls the cliche game. One person is chosen as "it." Then that person proceeds to ask questions which require obviously stereotyped answers. The reply to "What is it that you're behind?" is, naturally, "the eight ball." Or, if you are asked the direction to a street corner, you say, "I'm a stranger here myself."

CHICAGO, July 15 -- Wheat prices fluctuated today in a most erratic manner on the Board of Trade, having a range of around 1 1/2 cents a bushel. An early upturn was followed by a sharp break on the announcement that the House had agreed to permit sales of up to 125,000,000 bushels of government-owned wheat at 85 per cent of the corn parity price.
A single stroke stood between Ted Schroeder and defeat yesterday in the Eastern clay court championship at the Jackson Heights Tennis Club in Queens.

ST. LOUIS, July 15 (AP) -- Explosive hitting combined with effective pitching today brought the Cardinals victory over the Phillies, 7 to 3 in the opener and 9 to 4 in nightcap of a double-bill played for the benefit of the Tuberculosis Society of St. Louis.
WASHINGTON, July 15 -- The statement of Secretary Jones on the rubber situation before the Senate Banking and Currency Committee today was as follows:

LONDON, July 15 -- British sources today reported definite and favorable progress in the battle against Nazi submarines, which looms as an important factor in all second front considerations. A Royal Air Force commentator noted "definitely good results" in the American-British drive.

BUENOS AIRES, Argentina, July 15 -- Foreign Minister Enrique Ruiz Guinazu's appearance today before the Chamber of Deputies to inform it of the steps he had taken to obtain satisfaction from Germany for the sinking of the freighter Rio Tercero on June 22 caused the Socialist and Radical Deputies who constitute the majority to express the strongest disapproval of the government for accepting a mere German apology and promise not to repeat the offense.

LONDON, July 15 -- The enemy has been handled so severely in recent day attacks on British positions at Tel el-Eisa, west of El Alamein, Egypt, that General Field Marshal Erwin Rommel decided late yesterday to try a night attack.

William Saroyan was not fooling when he said he would present his own plays on Broadway. Rehearsals for them will begin within two weeks, and the New York opening is set for Monday evening, Aug. 17. Mr. Saroyan will direct. David Lowe will have charge of production in association with Cleon Throckmorton, who will design the settings and solve such technical problems as arise.

Gold Shower, possessed of speed but never noted for fighting things out at the end, doubtless surprised even his admirers when he led virtually from start to finish of yesterday's $7,275 East View Stakes for juveniles at Empire City to score by a length in 1:08, a new stake record and only three-fifths of a second slower than the five-and-three-quarter-furlong track record.

MOSCOW, July 15 -- The destruction of the Palace of Peterhof, near Leningrad, by German soldiery during the Winter battles for the city was officially confirmed today in a Soviet radio announcement. This may well prove to be Germany's greatest act of vandalism in Russia.

An art, formerly pushed into the background as a thing of the past, and countenanced only by the expert or the "foolhardy," has been reborn en masse. It came to life via the War Production Board, one government agency with which every American woman is familiar.

VICHY, France, July 15 (U.P.) -- Photographs that downed Allied airmen supposedly took of themselves and the French patriots who shielded them were presented today at the German court-martial at Paris of thirty men and women accused of aiding the enemy.

WASHINGTON, July 15 -- To balance steel production among the various products needed for war, a quota system for the various steel products and for each producer who makes them was announced today by Reese H. Taylor, chief of the iron and steel branch of the War Production Board.

The Equity Corporation has called a special meeting of stockholders for Aug. 11 to consider approval of a contract with the Empire Trust Company of New York under which the banking institution will provide the investment company and its subsidiaries with investment service.

BERNE, Switzerland, July 15 -- Speaking in terms of Yugoslavia -- which applied equally well to Hungarian-annexed Transylvania -- Premier Nicholas von Kallay of Hungary, answering an interpolation by Serbian Deputy Popovitch in the lower house of Parliament in Budapest, revealed for the first time officially that Hungarian troops were engaged last January in the Batschka in putting down "organized, open revolt."

Because Austria now is within the territorial limits of the German Reich, Federal Judge Edward A. Conger ruled yesterday persons born in that country must now be considered alien enemies within the meaning of the Alien Enemy Control Act.

To Roberto Ortiz, President of Argentina, in his last years Fortune showed cruel malice. Attacked by a fatal malady, he lingered in the shadow of total blindness. Moral suffering was added to the physical. After his withdrawal from the duties of his office and after his resignation he had to see his rooted, passionate beliefs and most cherished public policies impaired or reversed by his substitute and successor.
LONDON, July 15 -- The appointment of Lord Burghley, M.P., as controller of American supplies and repairs in the Ministry of Aircraft production was announced today.

The second annual report of the Discretionary Common Trust Fund of the Pennsylvania Company for Insurances on Lives and Granting Annuities, issued yesterday, showed that the managers of the fund during the year ended on June 30 held to a program of maintaining two-thirds of the portfolio in bonds and preferred stock and one-third in equities.

WASHINGTON, July 15 -- As a result of the decision of central bankers and economists of Latin America last week to recommend to their government's adoption of substantially the same anti-Axis controls as those of the United States, the value of the American dollar on the Argentine "black" Bourse has dropped 50 per cent.

Since the Indians have been edging closer to second place and have developed into a distinct pennant threat, the Yankees slapped them down with more than ordinary enthusiasm before 11,214 spectators at the Stadium yesterday. Receiving gilt-edge pitching for their fourth successive game, the New Yorkers romped off with their fourth straight victory, 4 to 0.

WASHINGTON, July 15 -- The War Labor Board voted eight to four tonight, the labor members dissenting, to direct the four "Little Steel" companies to award a wage increase of 5.5 cents an hour or 44 cents a day to their 157,000 employes.
CHUNGKING, China, July 15 -- "China will not allow Japan to transfer a single soldier out of this country," said Dr. Wang Shihchieh, Minister of Information, at a press conference here today, adding:

Reports that are permitted to come out of the War Labor Board indicate that the Administration is preparing another of those little melodramas in which a labor union is "defeated' by getting substantially what it wants, while the Administration once more enacts the role of "combating inflation" at the same time as it actually adds fuel to the fire.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., July 15 -- Members of the executive committee announced today that the annual dance to mark the conclusion of the fifty-second invitation tennis tournament at the Meadow Club will be held on the night of Aug. 1 in the Colonial Ballroom and the Japanese Room of the clubhouse.

A syndicate of twenty investment firms headed by Phelps, Fenn Co. was the successful bidder yesterday for $7,176,000 of series A refunding bonds of the Atlanta, Ga., Housing Authority, naming an interest cost basis of 1.87282 per cent. This was part of a $15,378,000 refunding program by the authority on which proposals were considered yesterday.

A charge that thousands of New York City school teachers who are giving up two weeks of their vacation this Summer to do war work for the Board of Education have nothing constructive to do but sit around twiddling their thumbs, chatting with each other, or simply acting bored, was made yesterday before the board meeting by Dr. Bella V. Dodd, legislative representative of the Teachers Union.

WASHINGTON, July 15 -- The price-control program, instituted to prevent inflation, is "in danger of breaking down," Leon Henderson, Federal Price Administrator, told the House Small Business Committee today. He attributed the situation to failure to tie price controls to wage, fiscal and monetary policies, lack of a subsidy system and the unwillingness of Congress to appropriate larger amounts for enforcement.

Edward McLoughlin, deputy superintendent of insurance for New York State, has been named chairman of the committee appointed by Superintendent Louis H. Pink to study the possibility of bridging any gap that may exist between Federal bombardment insurance coverage and regular insurance provided by private companies, Mr. Pink announced yesterday.

Work clothing cut during May under Government contracts for the most part exceeded the amount cut for civilian use, with the exception of overalls, according to statistics released yesterday on this processing of cotton, leather and allied garments and uniforms by the Bureau of the Census.

MOSCOW, Thursday, July 16 -- Russian troops have lost Boguchar, in the Don River bend, and Millerovo, on the Moscow-Rostov railway, but are counter-attacking fiercely at Voronezh and beating back a German assault army at several points, the Soviet High Command announced today.

Black is leading in purchases of popular price Fall dresses. Blue, however, is likewise strongly favored and much interest has been shown in a new shade designated "MacArthur rose," a fuchsia hue. While the tailored or dressmaker styles continue popular, the dressy types have gained headway recently, particularly those with peg tops and drape skirts.

CHICAGO, July 15 -- Neville Miller, president of the National Association of Broadcasters, today called on James C. Petrillo, president of the American Federation of Musicians, to call off his order which forbids 140,000 members of the union making transcriptions and recordings for radio, juke boxes and other public reproducing equipment.
WASHINGTON, July 15 -- General recruiting for the Women's Army Auxiliary Corps will start Monday, July 20, at all recruiting stations throughout the country, the War Department said today.

LONDON, July 15 -- The production debate in the House of Commons came to its foreordained inconclusive end today when Sir Andrew Rae Duncan, Minister of Supply, took the floor to carry on the defense of the present program. Sir Andrew implied that talking about production might well do more harm than good.

WITH THE BRITISH EIGHTH ARMY, west of El Alamein, Egypt, July 15 -- General Field Marshal Erwin Rommel, in his most determined effort to break through the British lines since the Eighth Army stopped him west of El Alamein, sent his best tank shock troops, supported by Italian infantry, into action at dusk last night against the British position near Tel el-Eisa.

IT may be that the best football team in sight this Fall will be the all-Army team. For some weeks the chatter was all about the famous coaches who were on the Navy side. Bernie Bierman, Somnolent James Crowley, Sam Barry, Potsy Clark, Matty Bell and other master technicians of gridiron strategy were assigned to duty with the naval aviation cadets.

The Messrs. Tushinsky and Bartsch, who have found considerable pay ore this Summer at Carnegie Hall, turned their attention last evening to the Franz Lehar operetta, "The Merry Widow," offering it as the second of their series of revivals at popular prices.

Increased danger of ship collisions, because of blacked-out harbor lights, submerged wrecks, crowded convoys and other navigation difficulties under the existing emergency conditions, has made necessary an advance in the wartime marine surcharge rates on cargo shipments, and a new schedule has been made effective immediately, marine underwriters announced yesterday.
The following Italian communique was broadcast from Rome yesterday and was recorded here by The Associated Press:
The old one about the problem one noisy neighbor can pose for half a dozen others cropped up again yesterday in Yorkville Court, with a couple of new wrinkles.

WASHINGTON, July 15 -- Rear Admiral Ben Moreell, chief of the Navy Bureau of Yards and Docks, said in a circular letter today that the "Administration policy" with respect to labor "should be carried through all of our dealings with the representatives of labor."

Patrolman Harry J. McDonald, formerly a plainclothes man attached to Inspector Michael Murphy, who is head of the Police Commissioner's confidential squad, was restored to duty at the close of his departmental trial before Third Deputy Police Commissioner Michael A. Lyons at Police Headquarters in Brooklyn.

Richard Percotti, 32 years old, an unemployed truck driver, who had been arrested twice but released on charges of stealing automobiles, was shot fatally about 1 P.M. yesterday as he sat in a barber chair in the Tunnel Barber Shop at 116 Sixth Avenue, Manhattan. Percotti, wounded in the head, staggered out of the shop and fell dead on the sidewalk.

Erich Ewald Fittkau, 43 years old, got rid of his unwanted United States citizenship yesterday at the United States Court House and by night-fall was safely interned on Ellis Island -- which was also what he wanted. It happened very quickly, and that, too, pleased Fittkau.

WASHINGTON, July 15 -- Sufficient rubber will be produced in 1942 and 1943 to meet the essential requirements of the armed forces and the war workers of the nation, but no one should use his automobile for unnecessary travel, Jesse Jones, Secretary of Commerce, told the Senate Banking and Currency Committee today.
LONDON, July 15 (AP) -- An Ad miralty communique said today:

There is an important "banquet" scheduled for the lower East Side this morning. Bacon and eggs will fill the festive tables and the grapefruit juice will flow. In the center of it all will be a 13-year- old girl, "tops" to all her pals in the crowded tenement district.

WASHINGTON, July 15 -- Sufficient rubber will be produced in 1942 and 1943 to meet the essential requirements of the armed forces and the war workers of the nation, but no one should use his automobile for unnecessary travel, Jesse Jones, Secretary of Commerce, told the Senate Banking and Currency Committee today.
LONDON, July 15 (AP) -- An Ad miralty communique said today:

There is an important "banquet" scheduled for the lower East Side this morning. Bacon and eggs will fill the festive tables and the grapefruit juice will flow. In the center of it all will be a 13-year- old girl, "tops" to all her pals in the crowded tenement district.

LONDON, July 15 (U.P.) -- United States officials are sitting in on Royal Air Force conferences, helping to select targets where British bombers can strike the most damaging blows against German submarine strength and relieve the Allied shipping crisis, especially in American waters, it was reported tonight.
LONDON, July 16 -- The stock markets opened steady today and one or two good features developed later. Gilt-edged issues retained their rises and home rails were steady.

AMAGANSETT, L.I., July 16 -- Ira Baker, local station agent, told tonight how, unwittingly, he had sold railroad tickets to the four alleged German saboteurs, who are among eight now on trial in Washington before an Army commission.

There is a new pleasure in Babylon the Great. The Museum of Costume Art is showing garments and fabrics of far ages and countries and of our own time. If our eyes don't deceive us, trees are clothes and clothes are trees. In vain did Dr. Isaac Watts try to make children humble by reminding them that "the poor sheep and silkworm wore That very clothing long before."

WASHINGTON, July 16 -- One of the major conversion operations in connection with war production has been achieved with the perfection of processes to substitute steel for brass in the manufacture of cartridge cases for artillery shells, Secretary Stimson said today.

Two medium-sized United States merchant ships and a medium-sized Norwegian freighter have been torpedoed and sunk by enemy submarines, the Navy announced yesterday. Twenty-seven crew members perished in the sinking of one of the American ships in the Gulf of Mexico on July 9, while 16 lives were lost in the other sinkings.

A lively dispute over the relative merits of the music which emanates from Ebbets Field in Brooklyn appeared likely yesterday as tenants and neighbors of an apartment house at 100 Lefferts Avenue, in the vicinity of the Dodgers' baseball field, pledged petitions for and against the musical sounds which allegedly interrupt the afternoon rest of J. Reid Spencer, 70-year-old retired music teacher and fellow-tenant.

Seven German decorations, including an Iron Cross, first-class, suspended on its faded red, white and black ribbon, are hung on a card marked "Scrapped," at the entrance to the Girl Scout Salvage Shop at 120 East Eighty-sixth Street.

NEWARK, N. J., July 16 -- The story of a factory built largely with machinery and other equipment stolen piece by piece from other factories was related by police today in announcing the confiscation of the Usta Glass Works of 395 Mulberry Street and the arrest of one of the two alleged owners on a charge of grand larceny and receiving stolen property.
A. Perry Osborn, acting president of the American Museum of Natural History, announced yesterday the reorganization of the museum's scientific staff because of the retirement of four members.

WASHINGTON, July 16 (AP) -- Representative Satterfield, Democrat, of Virginia, said today that correspondence found on a captured enemy submarine had confirmed the report that cargo-carrying submarines were supplying U-boats preying on shipping off the American coast.

PITTSBURGH, July 16 -- Master Melvin Ott subjected his Giants' battle array to a severe shake-up at Forbes Field tonight, gave the old maestro of the screw ball, Carl Hubbell, the pitching assignment and walked happily off the field with a 3-1 victory as the reward for his strategy and the superb pitching of his veteran southpaw.

Payments for subscriptions to the new $2,000,000,000 issue of 2 per cent government bonds occasioned wide changes in the New York City banking statistics in the week ended Wednesday, it was revealed yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.

CALHOUN, Ga., July 16 (AP) -- Roland Hayes, Negro tenor, asserted today that he was beaten and he and his wife were jailed by Rome, Ga., police. The charge of beating was promptly denied by the Rome chief of police.

HONOLULU, July 16 -- Lieut. Gen. Delos C. Emmons, commanding the Hawaiian Department, prefaced intensive manoeuvres beginning tonight by addressing his troops throughout the islands this afternoon over a radio hook-up.

A clubroom for the use of officers in the armed services of the United States and the United Nations was opened formally yesterday at the Hotel Delmonico with a cocktail party in the afternoon and a dance in the evening. Thirty officers and seventy other persons attended the afternoon reception and 100 officers and seventy-five young women were present at the dance.
The following German High Command communique was broadcast from Berlin yesterday and was recorded here by The Associated Press:

Mayor La Guardia yesterday warned all householders using coal to obtain their Winter supply before September, as he said he was trying to work out a plan with Federal authorities under which the National Government would extend credit to coal dealers and users to enable them to stock up early.

DENVER, July 16 -- Dr. Margaret Hie Ding Lin, graduate of the Foochow College, Forest Park University and the University of Illinois, became a member of the International College of Surgeons tonight, the first woman so admitted.

WASHINGTON, July 16 -- With Vice President Wallace casting the deciding ballot, the Senate voted 31 to 30 against a proposal to require confirmation of future appointments in the Office of Civilian Defense receiving $4,500 yearly or higher pay.

The Administration has won one victory in its fight on inflation. The House of Representatives, after a two-month deadlock, has consented to the sale of Government-held surplus wheat for livestock feeding at a price below "parity." It is a gain, but the victory is strictly limited and its cost has yet to be disclosed.
INDIANAPOLIS, July 16 -- Leading experts in syphilis research met here today as guests of the State Board of Health to review results of the massive arseno treatment of early syphilis.
CINCINNATI, July 16 (AP) -- The Reds collected eleven hits off five pitchers tonight to beat the Braves, 7 to 6.

May I express my admiration for Mayor La Guardia's neat and vigorous style when he says, on the question of non-taxing Vichy's grandiose new property on Fifth Avenue: "I know of nothing in international law or custom which gives to a vassal State under the domination of a nation at war with our country the rights and privileges of the predecessor government."
WASHINGTON, July 16 -- Any effort by professional entertainers to exploit the war bend sale campaign for personal publicity will be closely checked, Secretary Morgenthau said today.

The grumbling and dissatisfaction of American housewives over the high cost of food during the present war crisis may not be groundless, but recent statistics prepared by the Bureau of Agricultural Economics at Washington prove that such complaints overlook the fact that the percentage of wage earners' income required so far this year to buy food for the family is the lowest in thirty years.
As long as eyes are mirror clear -- it matters little whether they are brown or violet, round or almond-shaped, wide-apart or narrow-set -- they may be made beautiful lovely frames.

There is no cause for apprehension over the ability of the Triborough Bridge Authority to meet in full all of its current obligations, including interest on its outstanding bonds, despite the drastic reduction in the use of its facilities, according to the official report of the Authority covering the six month period ended on June 30.

Newspaper advertising of New York department stores declined 361,833 lines during June, compared with the corresponding month a year ago, according to Media Records, Inc. The June total this year was 2,515,911 lines, compared with 2,877,744 lines in June of last year.

State police searched the woodland area in the vicinity of Rhinecliff, Dutchess County, last night after receiving a report that five or six parachutes had been seen falling late in the afternoon. A nine-State police alarm was sent out.
WASHINGTON, July 16 -- The House entered today upon three days of general debate on the $6,144,000,000 war revenue measure with expectations that a final vote would be taken Monday.

Dr. Ernest Lyman Stebbins of the College of Physicians and Surgeons at Columbia University was sworn in by Mayor La Guardia yesterday morning as the new Health Commissioner to succeed Dr. John L. Rice, who is withdrawing because of poor health.
You have given some space to the origin of the word "tank," familiar in this generation as a fighting tool. The name as applied to a "creeping vehicle" was first known to me about 1888 or 1890.

CHUNGKING, China, July 16 (UP) -- Chinese forces have recaptured Tsingtien, twenty-three miles up the Wu River from the Chekiang Province seaport of Wenchow, killing or wounding 500 to 600 Japanese, and they have killed several hundred more invaders in successful local offensives in Honan Province, it was announced in a war communique here today.
Furniture on a smaller scale has come to town to solve some of the space difficulties of city apartment dwellers, as it already has solved them for families living in defense houses.

LONDON, Friday, July 17 (U.P.) -- Polish guerrillas have killed the local German Gestapo chief and four of his henchmen during a pitched gun battle on the outskirts of Lublin, in virtually the same spot where the Gestapo chief for the entire district was killed several days ago, private advices said today.

Details of Bastille Day demonstrations in unoccupied France on Tuesday were broadcast yesterday by a spokesman for Fighting France in a French language program of the British Broadcasting Corporation, heard here at a short-wave listening station of the Columbia Broadcasting system.

Acting Borough President Maurice A. FitzGerald of Queens jumped quickly to avoid a wetting on a rubber salvage pile in Maspeth yesterday and learned of a chiseling trick that some junk dealers have used during the national rubber salvage campaign.
WASHINGTON, July 16 (AP) -- George Case's single in the tenth scoring Bobby Estalella from third enabled the Senators to defeat, the Tigers, 6 -- 5, tonight before 6,000 fans.

The response to a call for volunteers to serve as commissioned officers and privates in the newly formed Engineer Amphibian Command yesterday kept the Coral Room of the Hotel Astor filled to near capacity throughout the day. Beginning at 7:30 A.M., when Lieut. Col. R.I. Salzmann and his assistant, Lieutenant Hayes, interviewed the first applicants, a steady stream of recruits filed past their desks without letup.

WASHINGTON, July 16 -- Horace Ward of Chevy Chase, Md., a "socially inclined" sales engineer, told the House Naval Affairs Committee today of earning $431,463 in commission fees for obtaining war contracts during an eighteen-month period, and then expressed a belief that large commissions for the work are "wrong."

BUENOS AIRES, Argentina, July 16 -- In defiance of the state of siege regulations, which forbid any public discussion of international affairs, a vigorous indictment of the Castillo government for failing to honor obligations assumed at the Rio de Janeiro conference appeared today in a book entitled Campo Minado [Minefield], by a former Deputy, Adolfo Lanus.

PITTSFIELD, Mass., July 16.Lieutenant and IV[rs. John West Jackson of Pittsfield were istantly killed last night in an automobile collision at Lakeland, Fla., according to word received here today from Major Wilfred E. Brown of the Ninth Bombing Air Corps.

WASHINGTON, July 16 -- A further restriction on production of bicycles was ordered today by the War Production Board. It will necessitate a sharp reduction in the quota of bicycles already allotted for rationing this month, the Office of Price Administration said.

WITH THE BRITISH EIGHTH ARMY, in Egypt, July 16 -- A battle is raging this noon a few miles north of my position in the defenses of El Alamein. It is between elements of the Australian forces and a combined German-Italian contingent in which it is likely that there are more Germans than Italians, the latter having been relegated at this crucial time to something of the position of camp-followers.

Supreme Court Justice Morris Eder dismissed yesterday a stockholders' accounting action brought against eight directors of the Industrial Finance Corporation, parent company of the Morris Plan companies. The suit was instituted by the partners in Seymour Hayman Co., brokers, and other stockholders, for recovery of $800,000 spent by the company in 1930-1932 for purchasing and trading in its own stock.

CHICAGO, July 16 -- Thanks to the timely hitting of Arky Vaughan, Pistol Pete Reiser and Muscles Medwick, the Dodgers gained an even break in the near twilight of Wrigley Field today by taking the nightcap, 2 -- 1, after being shut out in the opener by Southpaw Johnny Schmitz and the Cubs, 7 -- 0.

Robert Falkenburg, 16-year-old Hollywood, Calif., high school student, won the Eastern junior tennis championship yesterday by defeating Charles Oliver of Perth Amboy, 6 -- 3, 6 -- 4, 17 -- 15, at the West Side Tennis Club in Forest Hills.
MOSCOW, July 16 (AP) -- The Soviet Information Bureau issued this communique today:

Morris Halperin, assistant to Alexander Korda, owner-producer of United Artists, is planning to bring Emmet Lavery's new comedy, "Murder in a Nunnery," to Broadway early in the Fall. The play is an adaptation of the English novel of the same name by Eric Shepard.

LONDON, July 16 (AP) -- Two convoys carrying war supplies to a Russian port, one including American ships, fought off German submarines and bombers for days at a time and reached port with the loss of only a few vessels, survivors reported tonight.

Voters of the city of Baltimore, Md., will be asked at the election next November to authorize the issuance of $32,000,000 in bonds, it was learned yesterday. The purpose of this contemplated financing is to provide funds for a supplemental water supply in the upper Patapsco River.

PITTSBURGH, July 16 -- The policy committee of the C.I.O. United Steel Workers of America awaited tonight the return from Washington of President Philip Murray before taking any action on the War Labor Board's ruling granting a 44-cent daily increase to "Little Steel" workers.

MEXICO CITY, July 16 -- As the second Inter-American Conference on Agriculture ended today with the adoption of seventy-six resolutions, President Manuel Avila Camacho of Mexico delivered an address in which he declared that the limitation on sources of supply caused by the war were beginning to have "certain effects" on the economic life of American countries, while restrictions on export markets were becoming more "serious."
NEWARK, N.J., July 16 (AP) -- New Jersey's two Republican Representatives, who have been serving with the armed forces, announced today they would return to their Congressional duties.

WASHINGTON, July 16 -- The Florida Barge Canal and Pipeline Bill, designed to help in moving gasoline and oil to the Eastern seaboard, was under bipartisan attack in the Senate today as a measure containing a program which conflicted with the Administration's coordinated supply plans involved projects rejected by government experts, and gave no hope of effective relief to rationed States within three years.

DENVER, July 16 -- Adoption of a resolution urging "other inflation controls," including wage stabilization, and a brief executive committee meeting today ended the annual meeting of the board of directors of the National Federation of Business and Professional Women's Clubs, Inc.

Informed that George B. Doyle, Erie County Democratic chairman, had started actively to promote the candidacy of United States Senator James M. Mead, Attorney General John J. Bennett Jr. declared yesterday that he was in the contest for the Democratic nomination for Governor to stay, had the support of more than 700 of the 1,014 delegates to the Democratic State Convention and expected to be nominated and elected.

War relief shipments to England henceforth may be curtailed a little more than they have been during the past seven months, but they "certainly will not be discontinued and there will be no reduction in our activities," it was announced yesterday by spokesmen for the two leading organizations here that regularly send clothing and other supplies overseas.

VICHY, France, July 16 -- Pierre Laval, Chief of Government, today made public in Paris "essential parts" of the exchange of notes that led to the French rejection of the American proposals for transference of the French warships interned in the Egyptian port of Alexandria.

Warners' "The Big Shot" will be the new attraction arriving this morning at the Strand. Humphrey Bogart is starred in the action drama. With Irene Manning in the feminine lead the film's supporting cast also includes Chick Chandler, Richard Travis, Susan Peters, Stanley Ridges and Minor Watson.
The "riddle of the sands" was still unanswered yesterday as Axis and British armies remained locked in stalemate at El Alamein, and the battle for Egypt was still undecided.

Bank clearings at twenty-three leading cities amounted to $6,854,280,000 for the week ended on July 15, a gain of 7.2 per cent over the $6,394,153,000 for the week ended on July 16, 1941, according to Dun Bradstreet, Inc., and an increase of 7.0 per cent over the previous week's volume of $6,407,401,000.

Defending the work program mapped out by the Board of Education for the 35,000 New York City school teachers, Dr. John E. Wade, Superintendent of Schools, declared yesterday that the Summer project "is a war-work program from beginning to end." Every activity, he maintained, is directly related to the war program.

Although the Soviet armies are counter-attacking, the underlying situation on the Russian front is still extremely grave. The Germans are spending all they have -- tanks and planes, oil and blood -- in a prodigal and desperate effort to immobilize the Red Army before the Summer ends.

PHILADELPHIA, July 16 (AP) -- Chet Laabs, who knocked in five runs to beat the Athletics last night, drove in four more today to lead the Browns to their sixth straight triumph. They beat the Mackmen again, 5 to 1, before a ladies' day crowd of 6.581.

UP until Japan's menacing stalk and final pounce upon the Netherlands East Indies few enough Westerners had any precise information about the isles of spice and rubber. What they did know was apt to be a confused memory of the novels of Conrad and Maugham, the sprightlier type of travel book that emphasized the unadorned charms of Bali and some good but hasty journalism.

Plans for immediate participation by the baking industry in the War Production Board's industrial salvage campaign were set in motion at a luncheon in the Roosevelt Hotel yesterday, attended by fifty-five representatives of leading firms in this area.
The following Italian communique was broadcast from Rome yesterday and was recorded by The Associated Press:
