WASHINGTON, July 16 -- Continuing the steadiness which has characterized commodity markets since the imposition of the General Maximum Price Regulation, the Bureau of Labor Statistics index of prices of nearly 900 price series in primary markets remained unchanged at 98.5 per cent of the 1926 average during the week ended on July 11.

WASHINGTON, July 16 (AP) -- Representative Boykin of Alabama put before Congress today additional details of the small submarine chaser which some builders of small boats say is the answer to the submarine menace.

MOSCOW, July 16 -- The Russians officially announced tonight that the German offensive plunging across Southern Russia toward the Volga and the Caucasus had gained ground in two months only at the terrific cost of 900,000 casualties, compared with Red Army losses of 399,000 in the same period.

In this business of explaining the American people and the English people to each other there is one task about which the Ministers of Propaganda in London and the agencies of information in Washington need not worry. Everybody knows without further instruction that both nations hate plans and logic and foresight and preparation.

Mrs. John Jacob Astor gave a luncheon yesterday at the Weylin for Mrs. James P. Polk, Mrs. Garrow T. Geer Jr. and Mrs. George Whitney Jr. Mr. and Mrs. G. Hamilton Colket of Ridgewood, N.J., who are at the Pierre, entertained with a dinner at the hotel for Mrs. Walter Victor Cotchett and Edward Wade.

Toward the end of February of this year our Government received from Marshal Petain formal assurances that the French fleet would be kept out of Germany's hands. To be sure, the question then involved French ships which were in French ports; the danger had not yet developed that French ships stationed with the British fleet at Alexandria might fall into Hitler's hands.

Representing one of the first trade reactions to the controversy between Congress and Price Administrator Henderson, action strongly endorsing President Roosevelt's anti-inflation program and supporting Mr. Henderson has been taken by the National Association of Blouse Manufacturers and the National Skirt Manufacturers Association, Benjamin H. Lerner, executive director, said yesterday.
The postoffice clerks' and letter carriers' salaries range from $1,700 to a maximum of $2,100. Five per cent is deducted for the pension fund, for an approximate weekly wage of $38 at the maximum.
Mayor La Guardia held a thirty-five-minute conference with high police officials at police headquarters yesterday morning on a topic which he declined to disclose.

WASHINGTON, July 16 -- The value of farm products bought by the Department of Agriculture for lease-lend and other requirements in fifteen and one-half months has risen to $1,396,182,224. Dairy products and eggs and pork products continue to lead the list, both in volume and cost.

All provisions of the Hollowell act, restricting discounts of wholesale liquor dealers, become effective on July 19, and deals previously undertaken which are not completed by that date are subject to the provisions of the new law, officials of the State Liquor Authority warned yesterday.

Traffic during the first six months of this year on the five bridges operated by the Triborough Bridge Authority declined 25 per cent from the same period last year, and during May and June showed a drop of 40 per cent from the same months in 1941, according to the six-month report of the Authority released for publication today.

LONDON, July 16 -- In view of the shrinkage in Germany's imports from Southeastern Europe, it will be a miraculous achievement if Germany maintains her present reduced scale of rations for the rest of this year, in the opinion of Dingle M. Foot, Parliamentary Secretary to the Ministry of Economic Warfare.

In her recently released book "What's in a Novel" (Columbia) Professor Helen E. Haines, Professor of Library Science at the University of California and a member of the teaching staff at Columbia this Summer, leads a fight against the "stigma of trivialty" that she holds still rests on the novel.
Banks and other institutional owners figured in most of the Manhattan real estate sales reported yesterday. Several holdings long in one ownership passed into new hands.
ST. LOUIS, July 16 (AP) -- Stan Benjamin scored on Danny Litwhiler's high infield bounder in the tenth inning to give the scrappy Phils a 4-to-3 triumph over the Cardinals tonight.

WASHINGTON, July 16 -- A joint statement covering new regulations relating to coffee imports under General Imports Order M-63 was given out today by the Board of Economic Warfare, War Production Board, Office of Price Administration, Commodity Credit Corporation and the Office of the Quartermaster General, War Department.
It appeared for a time yesterday that Alfred E. Smith had six fingers on one hand.

WASHINGTON, July 16 -- It may be that an Anglo-American land offensive in Western Europe, "a second front," has already been decided upon and a date set much earlier than generally has been guessed. Some observers in Great Britain have noted preparations and growing troop concentrations on which they base the suspicion that this is so.

BERNE, Switzerland, Friday, July 17 -- An official Russian military commentator said in a broadcast from Moscow this morning that a Soviet counter-drive was developing in the direction of Orel from the northeast. This was apparently aimed at drawing off the weight of both the Rzhev attack and that against the Don front.

Two of the National Broadcasting Company's local "remote" dance band programs, which ordinarily go on the air soon after midnight tonight, will be canceled by order of James C. Petrillo, president of the American Federation of Musicians, a spokesman for the union said yesterday.

Air raid sirens howled through the seventy-seven floors of the Chrysler Building at 3 P.M. yesterday. Eight thousand regular occupants of the building and an estimated 2,000 visitors promptly and calmly took shelter in the sections of the building designated for that purpose and remained there for the duration of a ten-minute test.

The German High Command said yesterday that "pursuit" of Red Army forces in South Russia "continued relentlessly," and that efforts of encircled Soviet detachments to break out to the east had been thwarted, according to a German broadcast recorded by The United Press in New York.

WASHINGTON, July 16 -- The United States has closed its consular office in Finland and has requested Finland to cease her consular activities in this country by Aug. 1. The action was announced in a note delivered in Helsinki today by the United States Legation and a statement by the State Department shortly after the Finnish Minister, Hjalmar J. Procope, had concluded an hour's conference with Sumner Welles, Under-Secretary of State.
Sidney B. Wood Jr. was added to the list of victims of Francisco (Pancho) Segura for the season yesterday.

A fivefold increase in the operations of the copper-recovery program will be needed to keep war production at capacity, Ernest A. Tupper, chief of the inventory and requisitioning branch of the War Production Board, declared at a conference in the local office of the Copper Recovery Corporation yesterday.

KUNMING, China, July 16 -- Exhausted and near starvation, two aged American Presbyterian missionaries and ninety British "Jungle Commandos" arrived here today after a sixty-two-day march across 430 miles of malaria-ridden, bandit-infested mountain country.

BUENOS AIRES, Argentina, July 16 (AP) -- Anti-Axis Argentines demonstrated noisily for democracy today at the funeral of their beloved former President, Roberto M. Ortiz, and called for a break with the Axis over unrestricted U-boat warfare.

WESTBURY, L.I., July 16 (AP) -- Supreme Hal, a gelding from the Sullivan and Mawhinney Stable of Machias, Me., and driven by Franklin Safford, won the Matron Stake for 3-year-old pacers, feature of this evening's Grand Circuit program at Roosevelt Raceway.
LONDON, July 16 (AP) -- A joint Admiralty and Air Ministry communique today said:
The touch that trainer Hirsch Jacobs has with a horse again was illustrated at Empire yesterday, where 13,499 attended to see the victory of Flaught in the featured Tuxedo Purse.

DES MOINES, July 16 -- The Army is making an enthusiastic job of dusting off the welcome mat for the impending influx of the Women's Army Auxiliary Corps at Fort Des Moines, four miles south of this midwestern community of 150,000 persons.
WASHINGTON, July 16 -- The Navy Department moved today to control the price and quality of ready-made uniforms which must be purchased by officers and chief petty officers out of their own funds.
PRINCETON, N.J., July 16 -- Nazi military successes in Russia have given rise to renewed demands both here and in England for a second front against Hitler in Europe.

Guerrilla warfare in Yugoslavia is developing in major proportions, with several irregular armies operating against the Germans in various sections of the country, Budislav Gregor Angeiinovic, former Yugoslav Minister in Vienna, said yesterday when he arrived here aboard a Pan American Airways Clipper.

The name of Arnold Rothstein, gambler, whose murder in 1928 remains unsolved, was brought into Supreme Court yesterday in a suit involving promissory notes given by his friend, Frank Costello, Chicago and New York sportsman. Costello asked the court to vacate judgments for $35,000 entered against him on the notes in 1929.

Yankee pitching eased off slightly at the Stadium yesterday but Yankee hitting took in all the slack as the McCarthymen continued their steamroller advance. They beat the Indians, 8 to 5, for their fifth successive victory and their eighth in their last ten starts while they increased their lead over the second-place Red Sox to seven and a half lengths.

Henry Epstein, Solicitor General of New York State and chairman of the Conference on State Defense, in a radio address yesterday over station WOR, commended the House Ways and Means Committee for rejecting the proposal advanced by the Treasury Department to tax the income from State and municipal bonds.

LONDON, July 16 -- Secret discussions of the shipping situation got under way today in both branches of Parliament after each house had weighed the question of letting the British public know details of what was called the gravity of the situation.

CHICAGO, July 15 (AP) -- The first verification of an Australian nurse's belief that muscle spasm is a damaging and ever-present symptom of infantile paralysis was reported today in The Journal of the American Medical Association.
HONOLULU, July 16 -- A large contingent of Negro soldiers, mostly from Harlem, now man anti-aircraft batteries in the cane fields near Pearl Harbor.

WASHINGTON, July 16 -- Senator Byrd of Virginia, asserting that the fight upon inflation in this country had reached "a very critical stage," warned Congress today that the proposed "wholesale subsidies" would not apply adequate brakes and called for "courageous and effective" steps to establish controls over wages and all other elements entering into the cost of products for sale.
WASHINGTON, July 16 -- The Army took steps today toward organization of a Norwegian battalion in which citizens of Norway, or American citizens who speak Norwegian, may volunteer for service.

PHILADELPHIA, July 16 (AP) -In one of the first cases of its kind in wartime, the Securities and Exchange Commission directed today a hearing to determine whether the term "victory series" of securities as used by an investment company in a registration statement is misleading.
Lists of new apartment leases issued yesterday by renting agents indicated a continuance of the demand for suites in buildings on the East Side.
WASHINGTON, July 16 -- No fanfare or widespread publicity will mark the opening of general recruiting for the Women's Army Auxiliary Corps on Monday, according to WAAC headquarters.

Yesterday's statement of the twelve Reserve Banks showed holdings of United States Government securities to be the highest on record, having increased $128,877,000 during the past week. Note circulation was at the highest of the year to date, while the reserve ratio was at the lowest.

Following substantial declines in deposits in the first four months of this year and a small net gain in May, deposits in the mutual savings banks in New York State rose substantially in June, the Savings Bank Association of the State of New York reported yesterday.

Splendid catches are being made by anglers in Southern New Jersey waters, according to the latest bulletin circulated by Percy H. Jackson, director of the seventh annual Cape May County contest now in progress. Those fishing in the surf and inland waterways, as well as those dropping lines from piers and party boats, are enjoying a high degree of success.

WASHINGTON, July 16 -- The War Production Board today ordered mild curtailments and restrictions in the production of cosmetics and toilet preparations in a regulation designed to save 17,400,000 pounds of chemicals and an unestimated amount of packaging materials.

WASHINGTON, July 16 -- Fifty-one Southern railroads, including the Atlantic Coast Line Railway, Seaboard Air Line, Illinois Central, Louisville Nashville and Florida East Coast, asked permission of the Interstate Commerce Commission today to increase all basic fares for passenger transportation in coaches in their territory to 2.2 cents a mile.

John C. Cullen, the 21-year-old Coast Guard seaman who made the first contact with the four Nazi saboteurs who landed on a Long Island beach in mid-June, said yesterday that the German agents did not live up to the popular American conception of clever enemy spies.

All records for employment in this country were broken in May, according to a report made public yesterday by the National Industrial Conference Board, based on a survey by its division of industrial economics.

GREAT NECK, L.I, July 16 -- High-class performances were the order of the day as Mal Galletta of North Hills and Paul Engels of Hempstead posted 70 -- 8 -- 62 to anex low-net honors in the best-ball handicap tournament held by the Long Island Golf Association at the Lakeville Club today.
WASHINGTON, July 16 (AP) -- The War Department made public today the names of fifty-six civilians interned by the Japanese at Shanghai, all members of the American Merchant Marine.
BOSTON, July 16 (AP) -- Lee Ross of the White Sex turned in a. six-nit pitching gem today to defeat the Red Sox, 3-2.

The Equitable Life Assurance Society of the United States had $7,803,585,000 of life insurance in force on June 30, a record and a gain of $196,282,000 since the first of the year, according to Thomas I. Parkinson, president.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., July 16 -- To further the work of the Kips Bay-Yorkville Nutrition Program, a unit of the government's program to make the country nutrition-conscious, Mrs. Fenton Taylor gave a luncheon today at Sideways, her home in Halsey Neck Lane.

LONDON, July 16 -- The first daylight raid on the Ruhr proper was made by a few planes of the Royal Air Force today. Similar attacks on objectives on Northwestern Germany and the Netherlands cost one plane.
SYRACUSE, N.Y., July 16 (AP) -- A four-run rally in the seventh which drove Leo Washburn to the showers gave Syracuse a 6-to-4 victory over Newark tonight.

Catholic residents of this city joined yesterday with many thousands throughout the nation, including men in the armed services, in the celebration of the Scapular feast of Our Lady of Mount Carmel, which has been observed annually since 1251.
Mr. and Mrs. Andrew Van Pelt are expected to arrive today from their home in Radnor, Pa., and will be at Hampshire House.

The city's nightly dimout is now "almost as perfect as it is humanly possible to make it," but the real effectiveness of its blackout machinery cannot be known until after a "surprise" drill has been held, Mayor La Guardia declared yesterday, addressing 600 civil service employes in the auditorium of Hunter College, 117 East Sixty-eighth Street.

LONDON, July 16 -- Responsible quarters here took today the gravest view of developments in India. They were convinced that an early test of strength between the British Government and Mohandes K. Gandhi was inevitable.

WASHINGTON, July 16 -- Striking back at recently formed "landlord protective associations" which he charged are trying to "torpedo" rent control efforts of the government, Leon Henderson, Federal Price Administrator, said here tonight that responsible real estate interests are cooperating with his office in keeping rents at normal levels in defense areas.

The decision of the War Labor Board in the "Little Steel" case is thoroughly bad in principle. It will have ominous effects in many directions. It is obvious that the living standard of the whole country must fall, and that no group can be protected against this fall except at the cost of a still greater fall in the living standard of every one else.

WASHINGTON, July 16 -- The French Government at Vichy has protested the greater recognition accorded to the Fighting French under General Charles de Gaulle by the United States, but the protest will be ignored by the State Department.

NORTH PATCHOGUE, L.I., July 16 -- The Biblical plague of locusts that annoyed the ancient Egyptians has had its counterpart here in an invasion of crickets during the past month which, if not checked, threatens literally to eat a dozen families out of house and home, not to mention their clothing.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 16 -- Hunt Stromberg, who recently joined United Artists as a producer, today signed Barbara Stanwyck to a term contract and acquired screen rights to Gypsy Rose Lee's novel, "The G-String Murders," from United Artists as a vehicle for her.

Mayor La Guardia held the hands of ten pretty girls in the middle of Duffy Square at noon yesterday, rolled each tip of their ten fingers on an ink pad and then stamped the impressions on permanent records for identification.

ALBANY, N.Y., July 16 -- Harold Hammond, director of the traffic division of the National Conservation Bureau in New York City, was chosen chairman today of a fact-finding organization to serve as technical consultant to the State War Transportation Committee of which Carroll E. Mealey is chairman.

WASHINGTON, July 16 (AP) -- Taking note of a one-third increase in the North American waterfowl population to 100,000,000. Secretary Ickes today proclaimed a seventy-day hunting season for wild duck, choice autumn dish for many a huntsman's table.
MANY of the boys in the baseball dugouts are saying that this year belongs to the pitchers. The hitting hasn't been much in any direction. The moundsmen are getting the headlines. And deservedly so.

Prices of cotton fell sharply yesterday under pressure from commission houses and locals and New Orleans operators who were disconcerted over shifting sentiment in Washington on the full-parity loan issue and the report that President Roosevelt soon would urge enactment of legislation restricting wages and farm product prices.

LONDON, July 16 (AP) -- A British military commentator confirmed today Russian reports that German divisions recently withdrawn from occupied France had arrived on the Eastern Front, but he said there had been no reduction in the regular Nazi garrison holding Western Europe against invasion.

Negotiations to settle claims for back pay and mandatory increments totaling about $417,000, owed to staff members in the four city colleges, are being conducted between a committee of the Board of Higher Education and the Mayor, it was revealed yesterday by Nicholas Bucci, Assistant Corporation Counsel.
CAIRO, Egypt, July 16 (AP) -- A joint British Headquarters and R.A.F. communique said today:

The broadcasting of copyrighted music without permission, by a radio station which accepts advertising accounts, constitutes a "performance for profit" of the music, and is an infringement of the rights of the copyright owner, Federal Judge Alfred C. Coxe ruled yesterday.

A plan is announced in Washington to provide loan scholarships for 10,000 students now taking "accelerated" college courses in engineering, physics, chemistry, medicine, veterinary science, dentistry and pharmacy. The students will receive $25 a month in addition to fees and tuition.

CHICAGO, July 16 -- Scattered liquidation and hedging pressure developed in the wheat market today and prices on the Board of Trade dropped 2 cents a bushel from yesterday s finish at one time. Trader sentiment was bearish from the start with weakness in cotton and talk of anti-inflation legislation having a part in creating the belief that lower prices were in order.

WASHINGTON, July 16 -- A zone delivery scheme by which some newsprint producers are attempting to collect higher than ceiling prices for newsprint is illegal, the Office of Price Administration ruled today.

Trading in stocks dwindled yesterday to the lightest since the start of the month. The reason behind this inactivity was not difficult for financial circles to spot. For all eyes turned to Washington as the Administration made a sudden move to attempt a halt in the inflationary psychology which has been sweeping the nation.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, July 16 -- The crew of the Norwegian freighter Karma, which arrived at Goeteborg Saturday with mounted machine guns and a fully armed guard of five German marines, revolted after the later were disarmed by the Swedish authorities.

PHILADELPHIA, July 16 (AP) -- The Securities and Exchange Commission approved today the sale of Southeastern Kansas properties of the Kansas Utilities Company for $2,300,000 to the Continental Gas and Electric Corporation which will transfer the properties to Eastern Kansas Utilities, Inc., a subsidiary organized for this purpose.

The Transue and Williams Steel Forging Corporation reported yesterday for the six months ended on June 30 a net profit of $221,462, after depreciation, Federal income and excess profits taxes and other charges. This is equivalent to $1.64 a share on 134,965 shares of common stock and compares with a net income of $138,053, or $1.02 a share, in the first half of last year.

LONDON, July 16 (AP) -- Note circulation increased 5,132,000 to reach a record peak of 812,570,000, the Bank of England's weekly condition statement disclosed today. Reserve decreased 5,232,000 to 18,946,000 and other securities decreased more than 500,000.

A movement has developed in States which have safety laws requiring the periodic inspection of automobiles to suspend or relax such laws during the war in view of the shortage of gasoline and rubber. There are seventeen such States, and Connecticut is the first that has acted.

Following closely the Nazi pattern of attempting to destroy democracy through the youth of conquered countries, the Japanese have burned the library of the University of the Philippines, Colonel Carlos P. Romulo, aide de camp to General Douglas MacArthur, revealed yesterday.

The appointment of General Semyon Timoshenko, commander of the southern Red Armies, as the chief of the supreme military command of the United Nations, was called for last night at an American-Russian victory rally in the Hotel St. George, Brooklyn.

DETROIT, July 16 (AP) -- A sit-down strike, called by the company a protest against discontinuance of a telephone service for employes, halted operations at the Ford Willow Run bomber plant for more than an hour tonight.
LOS ANGELES, July 16 -- The Administration's aircraft wage stabilization conference which began ten days ago as the largest collective bargaining undertaking in history, came to an abrupt end today.

WASHINGTON, July 16 -- Lauchlin Currie, administrative assistant to President Roosevelt, has arrived in Chungking, China, to confer with Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek as the President's personal representative, the White House announced today.

A renewal of the Federal Bureau of Investigation's drive to intern dangerous enemy aliens was disclosed yesterday with the announcement by P.E. Foxworth, assistant FBI director, of the arrest of six employes of a Yorkville restaurant.

PITTSBURGH, July 16 -- About 10,000 A.F.L. building tradesmen quit work on war construction projects today in protest against the action of the War Production Board of review which virtually froze wages at present levels on the undertakings.

WASHINGTON, July 16 -- Department store sales for the week ended July 11 were up 10 per cent as compared with the corresponding week last year, the Federal Reserve Board reported today. This followed a 2 per cent decreas the previous week.

TRENTON, July 16 -- Tear gas guns were turned on a group of thirty recalcitrant convicts in the New Jersey State Prison and sixteen were felled by the fumes on Monday afternoon as guards quelled a disturbance that threatened to turn into a riot, it was disclosed today by Principal Keeper John L. O'Hara after he had completed an investigation of the incident.

CHICAGO, July 16 -- An eight-point plan for organic union of Presbyterian and American Episcopal churches, as adopted by a joint commission of the two groups, was made public today by the Rev. Dr. William McInnes stated clerk of the Presbytery of Chicago.

In a recent issue of THE TIMES a military officer returned from the Far East severely condemned the American people for their "apathy" in the present war. He told us that we "must expect to get down in the mud and fight like hell."

WASHINGTON, July 16 -- The National War Labor Board promulgated today a national wage stabilization policy according to which wage earners are entitled to maintain their peacetime purchasing power standards as of Jan. 1, 1941.

"Beef continues to be the best buy," are the words of good counsel addressed to housekeepers by the Consumers Service Bureau of the New York Department of Markets. Accordingly, a meat loaf, well-seasoned with judicious amounts of freshly chopped thyme, seems the indicated choice for the Sunday dinner.

WASHINGTON, July 16 -- Ten of the fourteen accomplices of the eight Nazi saboteurs now facing death will be prosecuted as accessories after the fact, a crime punishable by ten years imprisonment if the invaders are shot. Three will be held as dangerous alien enemies and one will be detained for further investigation.

MOSCOW, Friday, July 17 -- Further successes for Voronezh's defenders were reported in a Soviet communique early today. On several sectors near that important city east of the Don River the initiative is now in Soviet hands and the Germans have been forced on the defensive, it was said, with one determined sortie having broken through Nazi defense lines and destroyed more than 100 anti-tank guns.

MELBOURNE, Australia, July 16 (U.P.) -- Five United States Army Air Force pilots received silver stars here today for heroism and daring in fighting over the Philippines, Java and Northern Australia, it was announced today.

Frederick F. Greenman was elected Republican leader of the Seventh Manhattan Assembly District last night by a vote of 86 to 51 over Victor R. Kaufmann at a meeting of members of the county committee of the district in the district clubrooms at 2307 Broadway.

Contracts awarded last month for building construction and engineering project amounted to $1,190,264,000 in the thirty-seven States east of the Rocky Mountains. This was nearly 57 per cent more than the dollar volume of August, 1941, when the total was $760,233,000, the all-time high up to that point.

The first mass examination in four years for police lieutenants seeking promotion to captaincies got under way yesterday at Stuyvesant High School. Five hundred and fifteen officers sat down to ponder knotty questions dealing principally with emergency problems that might arise under war conditions.

In the Summer of 1925 a young Negro girl won a prize and received a debut appearance at the Lewisohn Stadium before an audience of modest size. But when Marian Anderson returns for a Lewisohn Stadium concert these days the only limit to the audience is the seating and standing capacity of the amphitheatre.

Shoe production during June exceeded trade expectations and was estimated at 40,000,000 pairs by the Tanners Council of America yesterday. While slightly below the May output and moderately lower than June, 1941, the figure brought the six-month total to 250,939,000 pairs, the highest first half production level on record.

WASHINGTON, July 16 -- A threat to employ the full power of the government to prevent "pirating" of skilled labor and effect the efficient use of manpower in war industries was made today by Paul V. McNutt, chairman of the War Manpower Board, if a decentralized system of preventing the stealing of workers announced today does not prove efficacious.
WASHINGTON, July 16 (U.P.) -Women working on assembly lines at war factories need serviceable clothes with "safety first" features and plenty of room.

BELLPORT, L.I., July 16 -- A forty-eight hour search for Jackie, a pet parrot owned by Mr. and Mrs. Bruce Lachlan of Pearl Street here, which literally had local firemen up two trees, ended late today when Jackie decided his vacation was over.

The Tri-Continental Corporation on June 30 had net assets of $13,443,351, equivalent to $95.08 for each share of preferred stock, against $92.37 on March 31. Gross assets covered bank loans and the principal amount of debentures at the rate of $2,436.25 for each $1,000 of face value.

BOSTON, July 16 -- Reeling off a mile in 1:36 2-5, Sherill W. Shapoff's Mixer captured today's best offering at Suffolk Downs, a $1,500 allowance mile, scoring by three and three-quarter lengths over W.I. Lunt's Valdina Valet.

The Third General Hospital of the United States Army, the Mount Sinai Hospital unit, will go into active service on Aug. 15, it was announced yesterday. The unit will be sent to a training center and eventually overseas.

Four men who in March, 1939, sold to a jewelry "fence" in this city the $125,000 in gems that masked gunmen had stripped the month before from Mrs. Henry W. Breyer, widow of the ice cream manufacturer, and her daughter-in-law, when they were returning in their automobile from the opera to their homes in the outskirts of Philadelphia, were convicted speedily yesterday in General Sessions for criminally possessing the loot.
JERSEY CITY, July 16 (AP) -- After dropping four straight to the league-leading Bears, Baltimore routed Jersey City tonight, 10 to 1, in the opener of a three-game series.

CAIRO, Egypt, July 16 -- A tank engagement that may have a decisive effect on the outcome of the Battle of Egypt raged during most of today in the central sector of the front that extends southward from the region of El Alamein.

LONDON, July 17 -- Brendan (Paddy) Finucane, 21-year-old ace of the Royal Air Force, led his wing on the biggest mass attack by fighters on enemy targets in France and did not come back, it was disclosed today.

The morale of the Norwegian people in the face of Nazi cruelty and oppression is increasing daily, and although the nation had been at peace 129 years it has learned the methods of war swiftly since the German occupation and will continue to fight the Nazis if the war goes on another thirty years, Lieut. Col. Ole Reistad, commander of the Royal Norwegian Air Force in Canada, declared here yesterday on his arrival from England.

HONOLULU, July 17 -- Under the assumption that the Japanese are able to land troops on Oahu, soldiers of a "Blue" defending army in the Hawaiian Department manoeuvres are today battling large forces of "Red" invaders on muddy trails high in the mountains.

WASHINGTON, July 17 -- More than 13,000,000 women, representing over one-fourth of total employment, are now working in this country, Miss Mary Anderson, director of the Women's Bureau, Department of Labor, said today, and "2,000,000 more employed women will be needed by the end of 1942, and at least 5,000,000 more women than are employed now will be needed by the end of 1943."

The Army "Parachute Ration," hitherto issued only to parachute troops for use in emergencies, has been accepted officially for use by all armed forces when "they are far removed from the facilities of regular field kitchens or established mess units," it was announced yesterday by Colonel John P. Welch, Second Corps Area Quartermaster at Governors Island.
MOSCOW, July 17 (AP) -- The Soviet Information Bureau issued the following communique today:

Merchandise inventories of New York City department stores at the end of June were 85 per cent higher than for the same period of 1941, according to the report issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. June sales of these stores declined 4 per cent under the same month a year ago.

WITH BRITISH ARMORED UNITS in Egypt, July 17 -- The largest tank battle since the British withdrawal from Libya is still raging, with no decisive results yet known. At the time of writing -noon -- several enemy tanks have been knocked out -- all German.
Charities will receive more than $400,000 under the will of Mrs. Caroline Stetson, George H. Stetson's widow, who died on Jan. 3, an estate tax appraisal disclosed yesterday.

According to the Nazis in Norway, this is to be a day of rejoicing for the Norwegian people. It is none other than Quisling Day, the birthday of the Premier who gained and holds his office by licking German boots. It corresponds roughly to Benedict Arnold Day in the United States, or, as many Frenchmen look at the situation, to Laval Day in France.

Two 17-year-old girls from Pennsylvania who posed as sisters and who were arrested here on July 7 for shoplifting are fugitives from justice in connection with a $600 robbery of a gasoline station in Barnesville, Pa., a probation report revealed yesterday.

LONDON, July 17 -- Prices on the Stock Exchange today were well maintained, business consisting mainly of the usual weekend evening up. Gilt-edge issues remained firm, while the home rails improved fractionally.

Perhaps it was the muggy, oppressive weather that got the assorted domestic and semi-domestic pets at Flatbush, Red Hook, and other points in Dodger-land into a bad mood yesterday, but toward evening the thing was beginning to get the police down.
Billy Rose, 42-year-old Broadway and World's Fair impresario, was notified by his local draft board yesterday that he had been placed in Class 1-A.

A crushing victory that will bring complete defeat of our enemies and a lasting peace were called for last night by Attorney General John J. Bennett Jr., a past State Commander of the American Legion and candidate for the Democratic nomination for Governor, at the Bronx County American Legion Convention in the Concourse-Plaza Hotel.

WESTPORT, Conn., July 17 -- According to the will of Kathryn Turney Long, who died here July 3, worthy men and women probate, worthy men and women of talent in the vocal and dramatic arts whose ambitions are frustrated or hampered by lack of means to pursue their education and training will become the principal beneficiaries in the estate estimated to be worth $250,000.

"WAR," said Clemenceau, "is too important a matter to be left to the generals." "The generals;" said Adolf Hitler, "are imprisoned in the coils of their technical knowledge." These epigrams, which are at least three-fourths true, might well have been used to introduce William B. Ziff's "The Coming Battle of Germany."* For here is a book by a civilian authority on aviation which treats our military and naval traditionalists as so many chicken-hearted dolts.

Marlene Dietrich, motion-picture actress, was named defendant yesterday in an action in Supreme Court for $4,141 brought by Lilly Dache, Inc., milliners. Miss Dietrich asked that the suit be transferred to United States District Court because she is a resident of California and the plaintiff concern is here.
LONDON, July 17 -- The full text of Mohandas K. Gandhi's resolution as amended by the All-India Congress Working Committee at Wardha, India, became available here today.

Why is there grumbling after every All-Star baseball game? National League adherents shout that the American League plays to win and not to satisfy the fans, while admirers of the junior loop assert that the Nationals present a circus of stars but do not give the spectators a good brand of baseball.

VICHY, France July 17 -- As has been customary for some time, a large part of the comment evoked by publication of the diplomatic exchanges between France and the United States concerning the French warships in Alexandria, Egypt, consists of repetition of the points set forth in the previous French notes.
The letter written by Harry Philip Edwards inspires me not only to tell him the reasons for his classification, but to write of another complete class of eligibles not used by the government.

Faced by special problems created by the war, Dr. Ernest Lyman Stebbins, epidemiologist, began his duties yesterday as City Health Commissioner. Mayor La Guardia swore in Dr. Stebbins to succeed Dr. John L. Rice, who has been in poor health for several months, on Thursday.
ALBANY, July 17 -- Governor Lehman today designated Sunday as "Women's Independence Day." In his proclamation he paid tribute to the pioneers of women's rights. It read:

The life of missionaries in the Pacific islands is no bed of roses. Famine, pestilence and flood are familiar catastrophes in times of peace. Now that the Japanese have spread their dragnet of invasion, existence for the missionary has become more hazardous and complicated.

Corporation Counsel William C. Chanler asked Supreme Court Justice Felix C. Benvenga yesterday to dismiss as without legal basis the taxpayer's suit brought by Richard S. Childs, chairman of the Citizens Union, which aims at the removal of Park Commissioner Robert Moses and Public Works Commissioner Irving V.A. Huie from membership in the City Planning Commission, on the ground they are holding "dual jobs."

WASHINGTON, July 17 -- The prosecution this afternoon plunged into the evidence against the four Nazi saboteurs who landed from a submarine in Florida, after completing its case in the morning against the four enemy agents who came ashore near Amagansett, L.I., Major Gen. Frank R. McCoy, president of the Military Commission, announced on the ninth day of the trial.

DETROIT, July 17 -- Industrial inventories here continued to recede in June despite a determined effort on the part of buyers to build up stocks to a more substantial level, the Purchasing Agents Association of Detroit reported today.
WASHINGTON, July 17 (AP) -- In the first twilight game ever played in Griffith Stadium the Senators defeated the Tigers today, 3 -- 0.

PITTSBURGH, July 17 -- The policy-making committee of the United Steel Workers of America (C.I.O.) voted tonight to accept the decision of the War Labor Board granting a 44-cent daily wage increase to the 157,000 employes of Little Steel companies, after which Philip Murray, president of the C.I.O. and the U.S.W.A., said he would move to have "the principles embodied in the basic War Labor Board decision" extended to all steel companies.

The best advice for persons who are disposed to laugh at stories of enemy parachutists dropping into the Hudson Valley is: don't. It is far better to see little men who aren't there than not to see little men who are there. Maybe the parachute flurry was preposterous. So was the story of spies landing from submarines on Florida and Long Island beaches -- but they did land.

The approximate status of the municipal bond market is reflected in the following list of representative high-grade State, city and county bonds legal for savings banks in New York State, now offered by dealers:

Regarded by many as the keenest sprinter now in training, Doublrab seems sure to be a heavy favorite for today's $5,000 added Fleetwing Handicap, feature at Empire City, for which a field of six has been named. Doublrab, several times a stake winner, and also a record holder, is in with 130 pounds, but more than a few are convinced he can carry that load for the short six-furlong distance of the Fleetwing.

LORAIN, Ohio, July 17 -- Secretary Harold L. Ickes saw rolling mills here turn steel into pipe to bridge 550 miles from Texas toward the East and hailed the workers as helping open a second front in Europe.

The Navy Department announced yesterday the sinking of four more United Nations merchant vessels by submarines -- three in the Atlantic and Caribbean and one in the Indian Ocean. Two were American, one British and one Dutch.

The liquor industry's price structure, already destined for adjustment after the Hollowell act becomes effective in this State tomorrow, is likely to undergo a thorough overhauling at the hands of the Office of Price Administration, it was learned yesterday.

WASHINGTON, July 17 -- The starting of the permanent gasoline rationing system in Eastern States Wednesday will mark the end of the quota system of distribution of gasoline to filling stations. Thereafter every filling station owner will be able to get replacement stocks to match the number of coupons he collects from customers and turns over to his supplier.

WASHINGTON, July 17 -- Continuing the upward trend which began three years ago, the marriage rate in 1941 rose to 12.6 per 1,000 population, which was the highest ever recorded in the United States. J.C. Capt, director of the Census Bureau in the Department of Commerce, estimated that there were 11,679,000 marriages last year, an increase of 114,000, or 7.3 per cent over 1940, and 304,000, or 22.1 per cent, over 1939.
This city will bid farewell to its first women soldiers today as forty-two inducted into the Women's Army Auxiliary Corps depart for their training station, Fort Des Moines, Iowa.

Ralph Barton Perry's letter, "No Obstacle Seen in Future Dealings With Russia," in THE TIMES of July 12, is calculated to make the heavenly hosts weep and the netherworld imps shake with sardonic laughter at man's wriggling, squirming way of life.

CHICAGO, July 17 -- Sears Roebuck Co. sent into the mails today to the farm areas and to an expanded list of urban sales prospects a Fall and Winter catalogue 196 pages smaller than a year ago, and showing drastic war-spurred changes in the character of the merchandise offered.

THERE is now going about the country a husky gent, well wired for sound, who played football for Syracuse nearly a score of years ago. His name is Brooks Mendell, and he should be carrying a label reading: "Danger! Highly Explosive!"

WASHINGTON, July 17 -- Senator George, chairman of the Senate Finance Committee, indicated today after a White House conference that President Roosevelt had insisted upon the removal of "inequities" in the pending House war revenue measure, and that if this were done it would bring the bill far nearer to the Treasury's goal of $8,700,000,000.

The Lukens Steel Company declared yesterday a dividend of 30 cents a share on the common stock, increasing the total of dividends in the company's 1942 fiscal year to $1 a share. In the 1941 fiscal year disbursements on the common stock were 50 cents a share.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, July 17 -- Kept in ignorance of the American point of view concerning the decision of the United States Government to close American consulates in Helsinki and the Finnish consulates in the United States, Finnish public opinion has been as "surprised" by the State Department's measure, according to the official explanation, as was the Finnish Government itself.

Both nations, America and Britain, enjoy the blessings of free and unfettered public discussion, but they exercise the right in their own separate way. When the English people listen to both sides of a question they do so literally by putting speakers for both sides on the same platform.

The proposition of the National War Labor Board, that wage-earners axe entitled to maintain their peacetime purchasing power standard as of Jan 1, 1941, defies elementary logic and simple and arithmetic. It proposes that, at a time when the production of civilian goods is being drastically reduced, the workers of the country should be able to maintain not merely ordinary peacetime living standards, but approximately the highest living standard ever achieved.

WASHINGTON, July 17 -- The House Naval Affairs Committee approved unanimously today a bill which would make it a criminal offense for any person to accept a contingent fee for obtaining a Navy contract, and Representative Vinson, the chairman, declared that profits of agents in this field "were shocking."

MOSCOW, Saturday, July 18 -- Russian troops counter-attacking south of Voronezh were reported today to have hurled the Germans back across the Don River, but the Nazis still were making progress toward Stalingrad at the southern end of the long Don front, where the invaders are using 1,000,000 men.

PITTSBURGH, July 17 -- Business in the Pittsburgh district lost ground last week, according to the Bureau of Business Research, University of Pittsburgh. The setback resulted more from the failure of some industries to show the usual gain in production in the week following Independence Day than from further declines in operations.

VICHY, July 17 (UP) -- General Michel, German economic and financial dictator in occupied France, announced today that 1,600 more French factories must close to free workers for German war production. He warned that further heavy sacrifices lie ahead for French industry.

WASHINGTON, July 17--Japanese forces today hold the westernmost Aleutian islands of Attu, Kiska and Agattu and have erected temporary housing for troops on them, the Navy stated today in its first comprehensive communique indicating the actual...

Leaders of the right wing of the American Labor party yesterday charged that the left wing, in entering Representative Andrew L. Somers as its candidate in the Sixth Congressional District and Representative James A. O'Leary as its candidate in the Eleventh Congressional District, had furnished "living proof that Vito Marcantonio and his followers have in no way abandoned their alliance with the worst elements of the American isolationist movement."

WASHINGTON, July 17 -- To prevent loss and damage to the 1942 grain crop for which adequate storage facilities do not exist and cannot be provided under present conditions of war emergency, the Interstate Commerce Commission today ordered the establishment of a control system effective July 22 to govern the movement of grain into the market for storage and of "cash grain" for dealers, processors and distributors dependent on that market for their supply.

WASHINGTON, July 17 -- A means for ready adjustment of ceiling prices by retailers, wholesalers and manufacturers who are suffering hardships under the General Maximum Price Regulation because their March prices were abnormally low was provided by the Office of Price Administration today.

American heroes of the first World War as well as those of the present conflict were honored yesterday at a war bond rally in Fourteenth Street, between Fifth and Sixth Avenues, under the auspicies of Hearn's Post of the American Legion.

WASHINGTON, July 17 -- Senate and House conferees on the $1,861,000,000 war agencies supplemental appropriation bill became deadlocked today over the amount of operating funds which should be allowed the Office of Price Administration in the current fiscal year for its fight against inflation.

Quarters in a building in the midtown section of Manhattan will be used for one of the largest music libraries in the country as a result of the renting of the entire second floor in 115 West Forty-fifth Street by the Tams-Witmark Music Library, Inc.

PHILADELPHIA, July 17 (AP) -- The Securities and Exchange Commission approved today a voluntary plan for the complete reorganization of the Community Light and Power Company system including the merger of Community with two subsidiaries to effectuate compliance with the "death sentence" clause of the Holding Company Act.

HAWORTH, N.J., July 17 -- Playing her home course, Miss Maureen Orcutt captured low gross honors in the weekly one-day tournament of the Women's New Jersey Golf Association at the White Beeches Golf and Country Club today with a score of 38, 39 -- 77.

New regulations to insure equal treatment of retailers by wholesale liquor dealers and to limit discounts by wholesalers to retailers, effective Sept. 1, were published yesterday by the State Liquor Authority. Henry E. Bruckman, chairman of the Authority, said the rules were intended to "eliminate undue stimulation of sales of alcoholic beverages" which is "detrimental to the liquor industry and contrary to interests of temperance."

In a brief two minutes, Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt turned from saleswoman to customer yesterday as she visited the war savings stamp and bond booth in the Arnold Constable store, Fifth Avenue and Fortieth Street.
WASHINGTON, July 17 (AP) -The Navy Department issued this communique today:
Wing Commander Brendan (Paddy) Finucane had accounted unquestionably for more than thirty German fighter planes and had probably shot down at least a dozen more.

MOSCOW, July 17 -- Moscow was roused to enthusiasm by a new war play by the popular young poet and playwright Konstantine Simonoff, who, though spending most of his time at the front as a war correspondent, found time to write "Russian People," certainly the best theatre piece seen here since the outbreak of the war.

Harold Abair, a 33-year-old homeless sheet-metal worker who lost both his forearms in a subway accident, was held in $500 bail on a charge of felonious assault by Magistrate Abner Surpless in Brooklyn Felony Court yesterday because he struck and injured an investigator of the Department of Welfare with the stumps of his arms.
The following German High Command communique was broadcast yesterday from Berlin and was recorded here by The Associated Press:

WASHINGTON, July 17 -- A high Administration official said tonight that President Roosevelt may ask Congress in a new cost-of-living message for broad, flexible authority to control wages and for additional power to clamp down on farm prices.

Word has reached here of the founding in Mexico City on May 10 (the anniversary of the book burnings in Germany) of an anti-Nazi German publishing firm known as Das Freie Buch (The Free Book.) The house will print in their original language the work of anti-Nazi Germans, many of whom are now published only in translation.

Umberto Sortero, 28 years old, of 60 East 108th Street, made an idle boast last Thursday night. "I," he declared to friends at a party, "can drive a car better with one hand than most guys can with two." Umberto failed to make good.

WASHINGTON, July 17 -- The attitude of the Vichy government toward the French warships at Alexandria and questions in general entering into relations between the Laval government and this country were discussed today by Gaston Henry-Haye, the French Ambassador, at the State Department.

LONDON, July 17 -- The U-boat yards at the Baltic cities of Luebeck and Flensburg and the port works there, used by the Germans on the supply lines to their North Russian front, were bombed by big four-motored planes of the Royal Air Force in late daylight yesterday, the Air Ministry reported today.

WASHINGTON, July 17 -- By a voice vote today the Senate passed the $93,000,000 Florida Barge Canal and Pipeline Bill after a two-day fight, and after Vice President Wallace broke a tie to save the waterway from elimination from the program.

DES MOINES, July 17 -- Those who question the usefulness of the Women's Army Auxiliary Corps may well study the figures released today at Fort Des Moines, training headquarters for the unit. Up to June 15, preliminary requests from military sources for personnel to be supplied by the corps totaled 80,000.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 17--Jean Arthur's next vehicle at Columbia will be "Come One, Come All," an unproduced play by Frank Ross and Robert Russell dealing with the housing shortage in Washington, D.C., the studio announced today.

Court proceedings that may bring death to one alleged Nazi agent and long prison terms to others were set in motion yesterday as the government's campaign against subversive elements moved forward in the metropolitan area. At Newark an assistant United States attorney, Thorn Lord, received authorization to seek a grand jury indictment against Herbert Karl Friedrich Bahr, Drottningholm passenger who according to the Federal Bureau of Investigation is an admitted agent of Hitler.

WASHINGTON, July 17 -- Lessing J. Rosenwald, chief of the Conservation Division of the War Production Board, said today that details of the advertising campaign designed to stimulate the flow of scrap metal into war production had been worked out and that the campaign would get under way Monday.

In a two-hour match that produced the best tennis of the week, Ted Schroeder of Glendale, Calif., defeated Harris Everett of Jacksonville, Fla., yesterday in the Eastern clay court championship at the Jackson Heights Tennis Club in Queens.
"Drums of the Congo," which opens at the Rialto, will be this morning's sole film newcomer. The Universal action drama features Stuart Erwin, Ona Munson, Peggy Moran, Richard Lane and Jules Bledsoe.

Sentiment in the market for that class of revenue bonds which depend exclusively upon toll charges for interest and amortization is beginning to improve somewhat now that the initial effect upon earnings of those facilities from the drastic restriction in vehicular traffic is being disclosed.
BOSTON, July 17 (AP) -- The Red Sox gained an even break in their four-game series with the White Sox by capturing the twelve-inning finale today, 2 -- 1.

A five-point program, based upon a report by George A. Sloan, commissioner of the city's Department of Commerce, was recommended by Mayor La Guardia yesterday to Federal agencies at his conference in the office of Paul V. McNutt, chairman of the War Man Power Board.

Concessions in values which ran to a point or more in some of the key issues were suffered in the stock market yesterday as traders tried to pierce the confusion in Washington over inflation, wage and price controls, and the move on the part of the Administration to press for its full tax proposals.

WASHINGTON, July 17 -- At the request of several Latin-American governments, a project is well under way for sending public health nurses of the United States to other republics to aid public or private welfare agencies in improving and expanding their nursing services.

WITH THE SOVIET AIR FORCE, on the Southwestern Russian Front, July 17 (UP) -- Powerful and fast American-built Airacobras, flown by Soviet pilots, have shot down seventy German planes in two three-day periods on this front with a loss of only three of their own number and a few others damaged.

The Intercontinent Aircraft Corporation of Miami, Fla., the largest war industry in that State, has been bought by Vultee Aircraft, Inc., it was announced yesterday by G.M. Williams, vice chairman of the board of Vultee.
Leading export advertising agencies joined yesterday to form the Association of Export Advertising Agencies in a move to increase their assistance to the war effort by joining their forces.

CHUNGKING, China, July 17 (AP) -- Supplies for China are flowing from Russia to Chungking over a 2,800-mile highway, most of which has been constructed since the war with Japan began five years ago, an official announcement disclosed today.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Brazil, July 17 -- The government announced today that President Getulio Vargas had accepted the resignations of Francisco da Silva Campos, Minister of Justice; Major Filinto Mueller, chief of the Federal District police; Lourival Fontes, director of the Press and Propaganda Department, and Vasco Leitao da Cunha, Under-Secretary of Justice.

CHICAGO, July 17 -- The fates that sometimes are kind to the Dodgers made it fairly easy for them to leave Wrigley Field today still holding an eight-game lead over the second-place Cardinals. The champions won the finale with the Cubs, 10-5, the same score as in the opener on Wednesday, and with the same losing pitcher, Claude Passeau.

The provocative odor of chicken, golden brown and thoroughly delicious, will pervade American kitchens from now until the end of next week if the Department of Agriculture has its way. Broilers, eight to twelve weeks old and weighing two and a half pounds, and fryers, twelve to twenty weeks old and weighing three and a half pounds, are a current Victory Food Special.
WASHINGTON, July 17 (AP) -- Appointment of Colonel C.R. Smith of New York as Chief of Staff of the recently organized transport command was announced today by Brig. Gen. Harold L. George.

WASHINGTON, July 17 -- The Federal Communications Commission was asked today by Senator Vandenberg to investigate the action of James C. Petrillo, president of the American Federation of Musicians, in forcing the National Broadcasting Company to suspend the weekly broadcasts of the National High School Orchestra from its camp at Interlochen, Mich.

The four-story and basement apartment house on a plot 37.5 by 100 feet at 866 Southern Boulevard, the Bronx, has been sold by the American Female Guardian Society and Home for the Friendless to a client of Harry A. Schwartz, co-broker in the deal with George A. Bowman, Inc. The property is assessed for $22,000.

BALBOA, Canal Zone, July 17 -- Definite progress is being shown in curbing Nazi submarine attacks on United Nations ships in the sea lanes of the Panama Sea Frontier, Lieut. Gen. Frank M. Andrews, commanding the Caribbean defense area, declared here today. General Andrews had just returned from the United States after conferences with high Army officials.

Operations of the Caterpiller Tractor Company in the three months ended with June, resulted in a net profit of $1,341,651, equal to 71 cents a share on 1,882,240 shares of common stock compared with $1,886,268 or $1 a share for the second quarter of last year, on net sales of $29,931,115 and $26,533,621, respectively.

Several important changes in the point scoring for the United States Atlantic tuna tournament scheduled for Aug. 17 and 19 were announced yesterday by officials in charge of the annual fixture. They are designed to enliven the rivalry among the competing clubs and to maintain interest at a high pitch throughout the event.
PITTSBURGH, July 17 -- Giants 11, Pirates 2!

The fight to obtain commissions for women doctors in the Army Medical Reserve Corps continued yesterday following a statement from Secretary of War Henry L. Stimson that women had little expectation of commissions in the Medical Corps of the Army but would be employed or commissioned in the Women's Auxiliary Army Corps.

WASHINGTON, July 17 -- Continuing active revolt in Korea against the Japanese resulted in heavy destruction to a Japanese air base on the Island of Quelpart, or Saishu, late in March, according to word just received here by the Korean National Front Federation and made public today.

"Let Freedom Sing," the topical revue, may arrive here by the first of September, according to the present plans of the American Youth Theatre, sponsor. Negotiations are now under way to obtain the Longacre Theatre. Harold J. Rome, Earl Robinson, Marc Blitzstein and Lou Cooper have agreed to supply th9 music, while John Latouche, Lewis Allan and Roslyn Harvey are writing the lyrics.

CHICAGO, July 17 -- Three Chicagoans were arraigned today before United States Commissioner Edwin K. Walker on charges of aiding one of the eight Nazi spies and saboteurs now on trial before a military commission in Washington.

Following deliberation of one hour yesterday a jury of seven men and five women in Federal court, Brooklyn, found George Sternberg, a radio salesman, 4022 Surf Avenue, Sea Gate, guilty of conspiracy to smuggle platinum out of this country in violation of the National Defense Act.

Operating revenues of the Erie Railroad for June, totaling $11,474,074, were the largest for that month in the company's history and rose $2,242,193, or 24.29 per cent, over June, 1941, Robert E. Woodruff, president, reported yesterday.
ST. LOUIS, July 17 (AP) -- The Cardinals crushed the lowly Phils, 10 to 1, today to take the series, three games to one.

Despite the difficulties of material supply and of production limitation placed by the War Production Board. Pullman Inc. invested about $12,500,000 of new money and added 157 new light-weight sleeping car units to its fleet in the first six months of this year, according to a statement made yesterday by David A. Crawford, president.

General Sessions Judge George L. Donnellan went through an unusually long Summer calendar of weekly sentences yesterday in what court attaches considered record time. In two hours and a half he disposed of indictments against thirty-one offenders, including a woman, suspending sentences, however, on thirteen of them.

DETROIT, July 17 -- Leaving Gene Sarazen off the 1939 Ryder Cup team has turned out to be a blessing in disguise, for it has resulted in two team matches unique in golf history -- Ryder Cuppers vs. challengers.

CONCORD, N.H., July 17 (AP) -- Francis Po Murphy, former Republican Governor, who recently became a Democrat, will oppose Senator Bridges for re-election, the Democratic State chairman, Roberr E. Early, indicated today.

The two fundamental facts in the relations between the United States and Finland are that the American people do not desire to break with the Finns and the Finnish people are desperately anxious to maintain their ties with this country. It is against this background that the reluctant decision of the State Department to close the Finnish consulates in this country and American consulates in Finland must be considered.

A "Records for Our Fighting Men" drive was launched yesterday at 4 P.M. in Times Square when a group of chorus girls, soldiers, sailors and plain citizens were invited to hurl 2,000 old phonograph records at the gaping mouths of Hitler, Mussolini and Hirohito.
The six-story apartment and store building on a plot 25 by 100 feet at 854 Seventh Avenue has been sold by the Bank for Savings to the Rofel Realty Corporation through Nathan Sugarman, broker.
WASHINGTON, July 17 -- President Roosevelt confirmed today the reports that he was considering asking Congress for new legislation to head off the increasing threat of inflation.
LONDON, July 17 (AP) -- An Air Ministry communique said today:

State and municipal financing scheduled for next week by forty-two municipalities and local housing authorities aggregates $40,478,000, compared with $84,586,075 this week. The weekly average of new offerings for the year to date now stands at $25,412,776.

WASHINGTON, July 17 -- Extraordinary efforts being made by the Axis powers to smuggle platinum and commercial diamonds out of the United States have created an outstanding task for the enforcement officers of the United States Customs, Commissioner William R. Johnson reported today to Secretary Morgenthau.

The Navy's belated communique yesterday on the Aleutian fighting makes it quite clear that the Japanese seizure of Kiska, Attu and Agattu was a secondary part of the enemy operation that ended so disastrously for them at Midway.

WESTBURY, L.I., July 17 -- Trotting a 2:05 mile in the first dash, William H. Strang's His Excellency came back to win the second brush of the Westbury Free-for-All at a mile and sixteenth in the Grand Circuit feature of today's Roosevelt Raceway card.

CHICAGO, July 17 -- Prices of wheat declined close to 2 cents a bushel on the Board of Trade today, with the September and December selling within about 1/2 cent of the seasonal low as a result of continued pressure of hedging sales and scattered liquidation.

The appearance of two sizable municipal loans lifted the total of new bond financing this week to $26,819,000, compared with $4,256,500 placed on the market last week. In this week last year a total of $20,424,000 of new bonds was offered for public subscription.

WASHINGTON, July 17 -- The United States will ultimately possess the world's largest and most powerful air-borne Army, Lieut. Gen. Henry H. Arnold said tonight as he announced the formation of a new unit known as "the troop carrier command."

The German High Command announced yesterday that Voroshilovgrad, "the biggest and most important city of the industrial Donets region," had been stormed and captured by German infantry after days of heavy fighting west of the Donets, while to the east of the river mobile columns had swept forward and cut Stalingrad's westward railway link, according to broadcasts recorded by The Associated Press.

WASHINGTON, July 17 -- Some progress has been made toward finding war employment for New York City's 400,000 unemployed, "but not enough to solve the problem," according to Mayor La Guardia, who attended a conference on the subject today at the office of Paul V. McNutt, chairman of the War Manpower Commission.

MOSCOW, July 17 -- Across the broad, featureless Don steppes, whose wheat is now shoulder high, Marshal Semyon Timoshenko's men are now conducting one of war's most difficult operations -- a fighting retreat against a force superior in tanks. The terrain offers
As a parting shot, the Yankees let the Indians have both barrels at the Stadium yesterday, to the delight of a ladies' day crowd of 10,175.

Controller Joseph D. McGoldrick sold yesterday by allotment to the usual twenty-four banks and trust companies $45,000,000 of New York City revenue bills. The bills will bear interest at the annual rate of 0.60 per cent. Of the total, $10,000,000 will mature on Oct. 5, 1942, and $35,000,000 on Oct. 13, 1942.

The sharp decline in construction work in New York in the face of a ban on private building work, priorities and other war restrictions was shown in a report issued yesterday by William Wilson, Commissioner of Housing and Buildings, giving a comparison of building permits in the five boroughs for the first six months of 1941 and 1942.

It has been my pleasure to write several times concerning the curious antics of the old Highlanders. The serious illness of the ever-popular Tris Speaker brings to mind another freakish incident which occurred when the Yanks were enjoying their adolescent era in the strange environment of the Polo Grounds.
A number of leases for quarters in buildings in Park and Fifth Avenues were among the contracts for residential space reported by brokers yesterday.

NEW BRAUNFELS, Texas, July 17--A hearing on an injunction sought to prevent the city of San Antonio from condemning and purchasing San Antonio Public Service Company properties was temporarily sidetracked in District Court today when the city filed a plea of privilege.

PITTSBURGH, July 17 -- International officials of four A.F. of L. building trades unions ordered an "immediate" end late today to work-stoppage demonstrations which have virtually halted building operations on more than $100,000,000 worth of war plant projects in this area for two days.

LONDON, July 17 -- Yugoslav patriots are battling Italian regular troops six miles from the port of Fiume and have swooped down three times from the Julian Alps in daring raids against Italian garrisons near Trieste, thirty miles inside Italy, it was reported tonight.

Army authorities said yesterday that careful investigation was continuing of reports of parachute landings Thursday night near Rhinebeck, N.Y., but there had been no confirmation of these reports and that no new information was available.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., July 17 (AP) -- Jersey City tonight dropped its fifth straight decision and its ninth game in its last eleven starts as Baltimore made it two in a row in the three-game series with a 5-to-1 victory behind the seven-hit pitching of Elmer Burkart.

MELBOURNE, Australia, July 17 (AP) -- Private Edward J Leonski, former New York City grocery clerk and self-styled Dr. Jekyll and Mr. Hyde, was condemned to the gallows by a United States military court today for the strangulation murders of three Melbourne women.

CAIRO, July 17 -- Although the situation in the battle area was still subject to momentary change, the latest word today indicated that the British and Dominion troops everywhere held their positions against German attacks last night and this morning.

Liquidation by commission houses and New Orleans interests was responsible yesterday for another sharp setback in cotton futures. Weakness in grains and adverse developments on the full-parity loan issue engendered the selling that drove prices downward most of the day and left active futures on the New York Cotton Exchange with net losses of 23 to 26 points, or $1.15 to $1.30 a bale, the session's low marks.

New York, which until now has been the principal American terminal for neutral foreign passenger liners trading from Portuguese and Spanish ports, is to be dropped altogether as a port of call for ships flying these flags, according to local shipping men.

Questioned on reports that he was about to announce his support of Senator James M. Mead for the Democratic nomination for Governor, President Roosevelt said yesterday in Washington that he had absolutely no news about the New York political situation, but had been reading some fool stories in the newspapers about an alleged contest for the leadership of the State Democratic organization.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., July 17 -- A large group of soldiers stationed in this vicinity were guests of honor at the first in a series of weekly entertainments for service men held this afternoon at the Beach Club. The event, at which young women of the Summer colony acted as hostesses, included a swimming party, dancing and supper.

CHUNGKING, China, July 17 (AP) -- A fourth and "very satisfactory" air raid on Hankow, big Japanese base on the Yangtze, was announced today by the headquarters of Lieut. Gen. Joseph W. Stilwell, commander of American forces in China, while aground the Chinese reported they were inflicting casualties on the Japanese in fighting in four provinces.

PHILADELPHIA, July 17 (AP) -- Stocky Chet Laabs continued his batting rampage today, socking two more homers and driving in six runs as the Browns beat the Athletics in a double-header, 4 to 2 and 11 to 1, to oust Detroit from fourth place.
CAIRO, Egypt, July 17 (AP) -- A joint British Headquarters-R.A.F. communique said today:

Retail trade here eased off somewhat this week. Department store sales were estimated as about even with or slightly under the comparative week last year. Volume in heavier lines, including home furnishings, continued to sag and improvement elsewhere was not sufficient to offset this.

LAS VEGAS, Nev., July 17 (U.P.) -- Lana Turner, red-haired screen star, was married in an elopement today to Stephen Crane, 27-year-old Hollywood mercantile executive and former New York and Chicago broker.

WASHINGTON, July 17 -- The newly established Smaller War Plants Corporation will do everything possible to help small business but it "cannot be the miraculous balm that will heal all the wounds resulting from the transition of inustry from the pursuit of the arts of peace to those of war," Lou E. Holland, corporation chairman, said today.

Many lawyers are of the opinion that under the ordinary insurance provision inserted in mortgages several years ago a property owner cannot be compelled by a lender to furnish war risk insurance at the former's expense, according to Nathan D. Shapiro, counsel for the Municipal Property Owners Association of New York.

WASHINGTON, July 17 (AP) -- Donald M. Nelson, chairman of the War Production Board, has assumed personal direction of the government's rubber program, it was learned today, with indications that a showdown on remedies for the rubber shortage is in the making.

Mayor La Guardia was accused last night by Jercy C. Magnus, president of the New York Board of Trade, of having driven business out of the city through excessive taxation. Mr. Magnus wrote to the Mayor that business men were "profoundly shocked" by the fact that 400,000 were unemployed in the city, with the likelihood that 50,000 others would soon lose their jobs.

Robert K. Christenberry, chairman of the War Identification Bureau, announced yesterday that mobile units would be set up to take fingerprints of large groups in the current campaign to fingerprint New Yorkers for identification in case of air raid or other war casualties.

CHICAGO, July 17 -- Onions may soon join the ranks of the speculative commodities, it was learned today. Trading in onion futures on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange looms as a possibility as a result of the growing interest in the Exchange on the part of onion growers and dealers, marketing authorities reported.

The greater responsibility of the church due to a world at war will be the theme of sermons tomorrow in the houses of worship of New York City. One clergyman will preach on "The New Slavery," another on "A New Point of View About Religion" and another on "The Bible and the Winning of Freedom."

TWO exhibitions have newly opened in New York galleries. American portraits of the late eighteenth and early nineteenth century, together with some later genre paintings, have gone on view at the John Levy Gallery. A remarkable Copley portrait in blue and yellow (reproduced) is said to be shown for the first time in this country, having had a long sejourn in Bavaria.

ATHENS, Ga., July 18 -- Operating under a code of statutes drawn up by President Harmon W. Caldwell and adopted by the Board of Regents in the Summer of 1940, the University of Georgia has rapidly revitalized its entire educational program, permitting maximum war emergency cooperation.

DURHAM, N.H., July 18 -- Observing demonstration classes, participating in active discussion groups, and using a curriculum laboratory, elementary grade teachers are learning the latest teaching methods in a workshop plan begun this year at the University of New Hampshire Summer School.

CHUNGKING, China, July 18 (AP) -- The Japanese have been blasted out of Wenchow after holding that southern Chekiang Province seaport less than a week and additional setbacks have been inflicted upon the enemy on several other active fronts, the Chinese announced tonight.

STATE COLLEGE, Pa., July 18 -- Teaching young men why we are fighting is just as important as teaching them how to make the machines for fighting, according to Dr. William S. Dye Jr., head of the Department of English Literature at the Pennsylvania State College.

BUFFALO, N.Y., July 18 -- A new one-year program for the master arts degree, designed especially for prospective high school teachers, was announced this week by the University of Buffalo. It will be offered in addition to the present master's curriculum.

For the first time since the Federal Reserve System was established twenty-eight years ago holdings of United States Government securities by the twelve central banks last week crossed the $3,000,000,000 level. By rising $128.877,000 last week total holdings reached $3,037,551,000, which is equivalent to nearly 12 per cent of the total assets of these banks.

RETAIL trade leveled off last week in many sections of the country. Customer response to clearances of seasonal merchandise remained fairly good, but substantial volume increases over a year ago were harder to obtain even in heavy-payroll areas.

The interest of young Americans in science as a course of study is demonstrated by the fact that more than 10,000 high school seniors competed for the scholarships awarded by the Westinghouse Electric and Manufacturing Company in the first annual "science talent search" sponsored by Science Service.

BERNE, Switzerland, July 18 -- The world wheat pool organized in London by the United States, Canada, Australia and Argentina is evaluated by German economic writers as a wartime emergency measure which, however, it is asserted, overlooks some fundamental facts and in general is predicated on false premises.

One of the most delicate operations, requiring the steadiest of nerves and the utmost concentration, was performed early yesterday morning by a surgeon who a half hour earlier had narrowly escaped serious injury in the automobile he was driving at top speed to the emergency operating room.

War compels government authorities to ration commodities, but not postal paper. The present year has heard no diminuendo in the roar of stamp-producing presses throughout the world. A review of what those printing machines did during the first six months ended June 30 shows that ninety-three republics, kingdoms, dominions, colonies and protectorates released at least 850 major and minor varieties of stamps.

Any one member of the United Nations who sees a fatal danger to the common cause and fails to give a full and frank warning to the other members would be disloyal to the common cause. China could do no greater disservice to her allies than withholding from them a full, frank and forthright communication of the facts in the Far East as she sees them.

The New York regional office of the War Production Board has been investigating the Stanley plan of subcontracting for the last two weeks, with a view to determining whether it can be applied here, it was learned yesterday.

THIRTY-FIVE years ago come tomorrow an unknown experimenter -- with crude instruments hurriedly placed on a Lake Erie vessel -- succeeded in reporting the results of a yacht race to a shore listening post by "wireless telephone." It was the first sports "broadcast" on record.

BOYS and girls read more biographies than they used to, nor is this surprising when one considers what strides have been made in the writing of biography for young people during the last decade. At first thought the junior or senior high school years might seem to be the time when biographies make their strongest appeal.

Under distinguished patronage and with the active cooperation of executive committees comprising many men and women of prominence, a series of Wednesday afternoon "after duty" parties is now being held in the Cotillion Room of the Pierre to advance the work of the Citizens Committee for the Army and Navy, Second Region Council, Inc. The fetes had their inception last Wednesday and will be continued through this month, August and September.

Expansion of public school functions, in directions prompted by wartime exigencies as well as along certain lines well established in the pre-war years, is evidenced in much of the new State school legislation of 1942.

CAMDEN, N.J., July 18 -- With some of the weirdest trappings racing, or any other sport, has had, the new plant near here of the Garden State Racing Association opened its forty-nine-day meeting today. Against a background of partially landscaped grounds and a grandstand on which the paint had scarcely dried, thoroughbreds ran eight races, which is to be the daily card.

Many an amateur photographer's hopes of superlative vacation color pictures have been dashed. Color tones that were intriguing to the eye may be wrong. Aunt Martha's face may show unexpected blueness that makes her look terrible.

A centennial celebration honoring Edward Anthony, who opened the first photographic supply house in the United States at 308 Broadway, will be observed at the Waldorf-Astoria on Thursday. The event is sponsored by Agfa Ansco.
