A memorial plate will be placed on the Broadway building, which has not changed in appearance since 1842, and historical photographic collections will be exhibited.

MOSCOW cinemas at present are two documentary films, one of the defense of Sevastopol, the other of the beleaguered city at the other end of the front, Leningrad. Moscow audiences emerge from the performances into streets thronged with people clad in brightly colored Summer clothes -- bright in contrast with the ubiquitous drab uniforms.

One of New York's youngest and most energetic museums -- the Museum of Costume Art, 630 Fifth Avenue -- reaches its fifth birthday this year. In view of this anniversary, the museum issued a report last week that indicates the already wide usefulness of this newcomer among the city's institutions.

LONDON, July 18 -- Pounding away at German war industries in the Ruhr Valley, the Royal Air Force struck again today in its third successive daylight attack in that area. Fast Lancasters, Britain's latest four-motored bombers, carried out the operation without loss.

NEW DELHI, India, July 18 (Reuter) -- Mohandas K. Gandhi's "quit India" resolution was denounced by the Moslem League today as a "challenge to the British Government, the United States and all other parties in India."

The General Water Gas and Electric Company notified stockholders yesterday that $200,000 would be provided out of cash income for the annual installment on the company's $2,100,000 bank loan before dividends are paid on the $3 cumulative preferred stock.

The Huntington (L.I.) Yacht Club has decided to make its fourth annual distance race a daylight one, instead of attempting an overnight affair. It will be held on Aug. 2, starting at 8 A.M. in Huntington Bay, and the course will be out around Stratford Shoal and back, it being figured that even with light airs the craft will be back in port before dark.

NEWPORT, R.I, July 18 -- One of the largest afternoon entertainments planned for this Summer here is the garden party and fair to be held next Saturday at Beechwood, the estate of Count and Countess Paul de Kotzebue, as a benefit for the Newport Chapter of the American Red Cross.

PITTSBURGH, July 18 (AP) Lefty Kenny Heintzelman regained his early-season pitching effectiveness today, allowing only three hits as the Pirates took the opener of a three-game series with the Braves, 3 to 0.

Maintenance of the economies of the Latin-American nations is so important to the war effort that their needs should be placed ahead of our own civilian requirements in order to achieve "real hemispheric solidarity," Joseph M. Marrone, executive secretary of the Inter-American Commercial Arbitration Commission, declared yesterday upon his return from a business trip through Latin America.

Up until a few months ago gasoline economy was something the operators of big commercial fleets of trucks, buses and automobiles faithfully practiced and the private car owner only talked about. But the war, with its rationing of fuel, is changing that picture.

With the Federal Government launching an investigation to determine the efficiency and adequacy of the nation's telegraph communications facilities, and Congress getting set to enact necessary legislation for the merger of the Western Union Telegraph and Postal Telegraph Companies, the future of the domestic telegraph industry appears to hinge on its performance during the war period and the speed with which it can bring its operations more closely into line with competing methods of communication.

Arturo Toscanini and members of the NBC Symphony, which today perform for the first time on the air the new Seventh Symphony of Dmitri Shostakovich, yesterday exchanged greetings by radio and cable with the composer at Kuibyshev.
Mr. and Mrs. Charles W. Mitchell of Chestnut Hill, Philadelphia, are at the Waldorf-Astoria.

WASHINGTON, July 18 -- Congressional investigation of the Bureau of the Budget, the fitness of its directive personnel and its alleged conversion to a policy of deficit financing through large governmental expenditures will be recommended "urgently" to the Senate Monday by a special subcommittee of inquiry of its Committee on Appropriations.

The designation of Representatives Andrew L. Somers and James A. O'Leary, Democrats, for renomination by the left wing of the American Labor party was defended yesterday by Representative Vito Marcantonio. In reply to an attack on him by Luigi Antonini, State chairman; Alex Rose and Andrew R. Armstrong, right-wing leaders, for supporting "isolationist" Representatives. Mr. Marcantonio said:

It is time, and perhaps even high time, to conclude and sum up the informal inquiry which has been going on in this column for several days concerning Americans and Englishmen, and what they understand of each other and when they have another guess coming, and what they have in common and when they speak another language.

Tami Mauriello, popular Bronx heavyweight, and Clarence (Red) Burman, veteran Baltimore performer, head the card that will bring boxing back to Madison Square Garden. The pair will clash in a ten-round battle on Thursday night.

SEATTLE, July 18 (U.P.) -- The building of merchant ships this year already represents a deadweight measure in excess of the 10,000,000-ton quota set by President Roosevelt and the launchings outstrip the nation's losses of merchantmen from enemy submarine action.

A "clean-up" haul of 212 tons of rubber that was still lying at filling stations after the rubber salvage drive officially ended on July 10 has brought the city's total to 6,004 tons, Eugene F. McCabe, local director of the petroleum industry's salvage committee, announced yesterday.
FLAGSTAFF, Ariz. -- The war has produced a decided effect upon the life of the Grand Canyon National Park of Northern Arizona. But, strangely, it has had some beneficial angles.
BERNE, Switzerland, July 18 -- Swiss regulations issued today will cut the meat ration in half, beginning next month, the meat coupons for August having to serve throughout September also.
Tax payments by realty owners in New York for the fiscal year that ended June 30 were "the best in the city's history," William Reid, Acting Deputy City Treasurer, revealed yesterday.

PHILADELPHIA, July 18 -- A boat load of schoolboys from Buffalo's Lafayette High carried the West Side Rowing Club to victory in the intermediate eight-oared race which featured the seventieth annual championships of the National Association of Amateur Oarsmen on the relatively calm water of the Schuylkill River today.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I. -- Arrangements will be made during the week for the annual invitation tennis tournament to be held at the Meadow Club from July 27 to Aug. 1. Instead of the regular elimination tournament of former seasons, there will be a round robin tournament with twelve of the leading players of the country competing.

AS a kid in Sunday school I used to do quite a bit of wondering about the prophet Jeremiah. You remember Jeremiah. He was the gloomy fellow who went around telling every one else how bad things were and how, before they got better, they were likely to get a lot worse.
HERE'S fun! The three-page release, dated July 15, 1942, from the office of Commissioner Kenesaw Mountain Landis, the big baseball boss, begins judicially as follows:

The annual tournament for the State championship will be held under the auspices of the New York State Chess Association at Cazenovia Junior College, Cazenovia, Aug. 8-16. A splendid field is indicated by the reports from the office of the president, Dr. C. Harold King of Colgate University.

"The Eagle Brood," by Hal Borland in the Sunday Magazine, is splendid. There are so many boys and men leaving home today to give their lives, if necessary, for their country. They, as well as those at home, need some clear-cut creed to guide them.

Through the cooperation of educational experts supplied by the Federal government, students in 300 colleges and universities, representing all sections of the country, are engaged this Summer in studying everyday living problems that have emerged as a result of the war.

Under the original State IV[oftgage Moratorium Law no holder of an open mortgage made prior to July 1, 1932, could foreclose it for default in the payment of the principal of the mortgage, if the owner of the property paid the interest and the real estate taxes when due.

With a number of day nurseries reported opening in the Bronx under private auspices, that borough's plans for a child care program under the CDVO are rapidly taking shape. The first step is already taken in the selection of Mrs. Samuel P. Ward, former social worker, as chairman for its Child Care Bureau, announced today by Mrs. Robert V. Russell, borough chairman of training.

THIS is a grand book. It is an account in words and photographs of Russia and the Russians in the war. Miss Bourke-White is the author of prose and pictures alike, and both alike are simple, clear, vivid and rich in color, humor and detail.

Two shipyards and three machinery plants have been designated by the Maritime Commission to receive its M burgee-pennant, the Victory Fleet flag and merit insignia badges for outstanding production performances.

Huddled in inland cave cooperatives and other improvised factories, the women and even children of China are cutting and stitching to fill one of their largest recent consignments of the war -- clothing for 5,000,000 men in China's army.

DALLAS, Texas, July 18 -- W. Lee O'Daniel, junior United States Senator from Texas filling the unexpired term of the late Morris Shephard, is making a fight for his political life in the Democratic primary campaign being waged.

LONDON, July 18 (AP) -- Yugoslav informants said today that Yugoslav patriots under General Draja Mikhailovitch are operating along the Danube, presenting a menace to the German's riverborne oil from Rumania.

Efrem Kurtz directed the New York Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra in an all-Russian program at the Lewisohn Stadium last night. The first half of the program was devoted to two living Russian composers -- Reinhold Gliere and Aram Khatchaturian, and the second half to the most popular of the nineteenth century figures, Tchaikovsky.

A recent headline in THE TIMES has informed us that "The British will purchase tea for us under pooling plan just agreed upon," while a still more recent headline advises us that the "Tea shortage spurs OPA to plan code, with careful measuring the prime factor."

DETROIT, July 18 -- Still smarting from the sting of last year's defeat at the hands of Bobby Jones's challengers, the American Ryder Cup team, captained by Craig Wood, national open "holdover" champion, today delivered a terrific knockout blow to Walter Hagen's forces.

MIAMI, July 18 (AP) -- A gunman fatally shot four persons here last night -- a man, his wife and her young son, and a passing motorist whom he kidnapped. The autoist's bullet-riddled body was found in a vacant lot and the man, woman and child were mortally wounded in their apartment.

PHILADELPHIA, July 18 -- Walter C. Pew Jr., son of the general manager of the Sun Oil Company, has applied here for a license to marry Sophie Boychuck, an attendant at one of the Sun company's gasoline service stations.

There was deep concern in Washington and elsewhere last week because the President's program to prevent an upward spiral in the cost of living, announced twelve weeks ago, seemed already to be bogging down. Price Administrator Leon Henderson declared that the Whole campaign against inflation was in peril of collapse and President Roosevelt was reported to be planning to ask Congress shortly for new powers to meet the threat, including statutory wage and salary controls.

Daylilies add their special grace to July as they gleam in sunlight and shadow along the roadsides. The garden, however, will be adorned not by this coarse, reddish orange daylily which everyone knows but by any number of distinguished new varieties bred for color, form and an extended period of bloom.

CLINTON, N.Y., July 18 -- A re-evaluation of all extra-curricular activities in the light of their contribution to the war effort is in prospect at Hamilton College as the result of student-faculty discussions begun with the opening of the Summer session.

The Kimberly-Clark Corporation reported yesterday for the six months to June 30 a net profit of $1,039,855, after taxes and charges, equivalent to $1.52 a share on the common stock. For the first six months of last year net income was $1,280,047, or $2.01 a common share.

LONDON, July 18 -- The Allied position to the south of El Alamein, Egypt, was reported intact tonight, and word was received that planes of the United States Army Air Forces had landed fierce blows on enemy shipping at Tobruk and in the Gulf of Bomba while British naval aircraft were destroying thousands of gallons of Axis gasoline in a raid on Matruh.

WASHINGTON, July 18 -- There are no indications that Finland had taken to heart the warning when the United States announced this week that it was withdrawing its consuls from Finland and asked Finland to take its consuls out of the United States by Aug. 1.

The flood of inflation talk last week failed to alter the conservative pattern of Fall developments in the major wholesale markets here. There was little if any direct reflection of the threat to price control arising from OPA's difficulties with Congress or the controversy over the wage decision in the Little Steel case.

WASHINGTON, July 18 (AP) -- Petroleum Coordinator Ickes announced today the award of contracts totaling $35,000,000 to seven companies for construction of a 550-mile oil pipe line from Long-view, Texas, to Norris City, Ill., with two smaller branch lines from Norris City to Mount Vernon, Ind., and Enfield, Ill.

Making black-out candles, knitting afghans, tending children, serving as clinical aides, and performing innumerable other wartime tasks into which their teenage zest and ingenuity lead them, 347,000 Girl Reserves are busily converting vacation hours into community service.

Retail trade here lagged somewhat last week, with few gains noted over a year ago. Department store sales volume was estimated as running about equal to or slightly under 1941. Best activity developed in connection with seasonal clearance sales.

The schedule has been announced for the annual Summer tournament of the American Contract Bridge League. The tournament has been moved from Asbury Park, N.J., to New York City, at the Park Central Hotel.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., July 18 -- Seventy-two sailing craft struggled through the special regatta of the Echo Bay Yacht Club today. Canvas was filled to start with, but it collapsed entirely at the end, making the wind-up a drift.
DES MOINES, July 18 -- Wartime Washington has a rival in mushroom expansion -- Fort Des Moines, training center for the Women's Army Auxiliary Corps.

WHEN I first approached Aaron Copland, Jerome Kern and Virgil Thomson and outlined my project for creating a gallery of musical portraits of great Americans, it was because I had been thinking of symbolizing the spirit of America in music.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., July 18 -- One of the most efficiently organized and smoothly running defense organizations at this end of Long Island is the Defense Council for Southampton Township, with its eight casualty stations and two first-aid posts, completely equipped and in working order, which have been in operation since last December.

Attorney General John J. Bennett received a five-minute ovation from delegates and visitors to the Richmond County American Legion convention at the Lincoln Hotel, Midland Beach, yesterday. Then, after he delivered a five-paragraph speech strictly avoiding politics, the convention went into a "fifteen minute adjournment" to permit him personally to greet those present.

SALAMANCA, N.Y., July 18 -- The Cattaraugus County Democratic Committee, at a meeting here today, endorsed Senator James M. Mead for the nomination for Governor as "a win-the-war candidate," withdrawing a previous endorsement of the candidacy of Attorney General John J. Bennett Jr.

UNDER a title that is so general to be almost completely uninformative this book opens up a fascinating and entirely specific field. It is a translation of an early seventeenth-century report on China and the Chinese, the long preface by Father Nicholas Trigault to the four-volume diary of his fellow Jesuit, the famous missionary, Father Matthew Ricci.

WASHINGTON, July 18 (U.P.) -- Experiments with the drug colchichine on insects have produced results which suggest "a step toward weird possibilities even for the human race at some future time," the Catholic University of America reported today.

This year many gardeners are finding space for a few vegetables, even though that may mean the sacrificing of some precious flowers. But the better these vegetables are grown the less space it will take to supply the needs of the table and, therefore, the more space there will be for flowers.

ENGLAND and America are asking today if there is a way to meet and beat the German panzer divisions. In the shuttling warfare of the Libyan and Egyptian deserts, Field Marshal Rommel has more than once shown the astonishing striking power of these tank forces, when they are used with skill and determination.

WASHINGTON, July 18 -- Manpower requirements for war are working an extraordinary change in the nation's industrial picture. Shifts of large segments of the population into war work are being made necessary by the increase of the armed forces at an even greater rate than had been anticipated last Winter.

WESTPORT, Conn., July 18 -- Vintage vehicles that bore the popular sobriquet of "horseless carriages" in yesteryear will be resurrected an Antique for Automobile Derby to be held next Saturday. at the Fairfield Hunt Club here as a benefit for United China Relief.

Regardless of the notable drop in the number of scheduled major bench shows, especially in the East, the general picture in the dog world is regarded as considerably brighter than six or eight months ago in the opinion of American Kennel Club officials.

THE war, which has cut the British Isles off from hue Continent, has also made Scotland more conscious of her contacts with Europe than she has been since the days when David Plume was equally at home, and equally renowned, in Paris and Edinburgh.

MADRID, Spain, July 18 (U.P.) -- A bitter attack by General Francisco Franco on democracy and communism today marked his formal announcement of Spain's new totalitarian-type Parliament, which will be convened in October.

YEHUDI MENUHIN, who has long held out against joining any group bargaining collectively for musicians, has joined the American Federation of Musicians. His message to James C. Petrillo, the president, dated May 27, was as follows:

The following statement issued by City Treasurer Almerindo Portfolio shows receipts and payments for the month of June, 1942 and 1941, together with receipts and payments from July 1, 1941 to June 30, 1942, and for the similar period of 1941:

OTTAWA -- Canada's new stamp issue with design themes associated with the war effort paid for itself three times over on the first day of sale, according to Postmaster General Mulock. By July 3 philatelists and first-day cover addicts had invested $25,000 in the series, and less than a week later the figure stood at $40,000.

Probably the friends and relatives of the girls who are going into the Army will want to deluge the girl soldiers with presents. The girls are in the same spot as the first boys to join up were -- their families sent them wonderful and lavish things that turned out mostly to be a problem.

I added growing plants to my kitchen walls -- and have found a great aid in growing those that thrive on moisture. I've hung pots of maidenhair fern on wire wall racks over the sink; the steam arising from dishwashing and laundry has made them flourish as never before.

WICHITA, Kan., July 18 -- Through private donations, community chest, State Board of Welfare, fees and university funds, the speech correction laboratory of the Universtiy of Wichita has trained 3,429 children and supplied teachers for branch work in seven towns in Kansas and one in Oklahoma since July, 1934, it was reported here.

WASHINGTON, July 18 -- The Federal Bureau of Investigation, in the busiest twelve months of its history, the year ended June 30, produced evidence that brought 1,471 convictions for espionage, sabotage, Selective Service Act violations and other un-American activities, Director J. Edgar Hoover reported tonight.

Soldiers are tireless tourists, particularly American soldiers. All over the country, these days, they are visiting places that revive for them memories of our history. But nowhere is the soldier on leave more interested in a monument to valor than at the Alamo, in San Antonio.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, July 18 -- A report here today said that on July 12 the Finnish radio broadcast in German a denial from Field Marshal Baron Carl Gustav Mannerheim of responsibility for an article appearing in the Axis magazine Berlin-Rome-Tokyo.

The privately operated radio stations along the three American coasts are drastically reducing their operator staffs, and several of them have closed, according to officials of the American Communications Association, who have appealed to authorities in Washington to do something.

Basing their opinion on firsthand information received from various points, game officials of New Hampshire anticipate that sportsmen will have exceptionally enjoyable times on their hunting expeditions in the Granite State during the coming Fall season.

It is almost three months since Commander in Chief Franklin Roosevelt ordered an "all-embracing" attack against inflation on the home front. The battle joined was as crucial as any of World War II. On its outcome depended the stability of the American economy and the successful functioning of the arms production program.
Holders of temporary gasoline ration cards began a mad scramble yesterday to trade in their unused stubs for fuel before the cards lose all value next Tuesday midnight.
NEW ORLEANS, July 18 -- A.J. Higgins, head of Higgins Industries, Inc., announcing the closing of the plant at Michaud, said:

CHICAGO, July 18 -- Occupation, a fast-breaking strong-finishing colt owned by John Marsch, Chicago contractor, captured the $62,900 Arlinton Futurity impressively today in stake record time -- 1:10 2-5 for six furlongs.

Southern California's eight major aircraft plants were protected against 1,860 potential "bottlenecks" in warplane production in June by the work of the Aircraft War Production Council, Inc., the monthly reports of its committees on engineering and standards and material revealed yesterday.

Volume on the New York Stock Exchange slumped yesterday to the lowest in twenty-four years. The figure of 99,810 shares set statisticians to leafing over records of the past. They found no smaller day later than Aug. 17, 1918, when turnover was 98,546 shares. The volume of the preceding Saturday was 153,650 shares.

New jobs, new processes, workers who have never been in a machine shop in their lives, women who must solder and rivet -- how are we to solve a huge training problem? The United States Office of Education does it with films.

BOSTON, July 18 -- Mrs. A.R. Smith's Through Bound shattered his own track record for five and one-half furlongs today by reeling off that distance in 1:04-5 over a slow track as he captured the $15,000 added Mayflower Stakes, getaway day feature at Suffolk Downs.
TREES OF THE COUNTRYSIDE. By Margaret McKenny, with lithographs by Alice Bird.

Nazi armies smashed across the Russian steppes last week as Hitler continued his climactic campaign for victory. The German main effort in the Voronezh-Voroshilovgrad sector resulted in the capture of more territory and the strengthening of Nazi bridgeheads across the Don.

DETROIT, July 18 (AP) -- In a letter to employes idle because of a strike at the tank plant of the Fisher Body Division of General Motors near Flint, E.F. Fisher, the division's general manager, appealed today for a return to work and termed the strike "a national disgrace."
MOSCOW, July 18 (AP) -- The Soviet Information Bureau issued this communique today:

A bespectacled London University Professor of Political Science, whose weak heart barred him from military service in World War I, has been one of His Majesty's Government's most trenchant critics in World War II. Since the aerial blitz of 1940, Harold J. Laski has asked Britons, "Where do we go from here ?"

WASHINGTON, July 18 (U.P.) -A new Army Air Force unit, to be known as the Foreign Service Concentration Command, is being set up here to coordinate the flying groups assigned to service overseas, it was learned at the War Department today.

President Roosevelt's executive order transferring the national merchant marine training program from the Coast Guard to the War Shipping Administration marked the end of a months-old tug-of-war between two government agencies.

WASHINGTON, July 18 -- The Office of Price Administration today ordered all contract carriers by truck and water to adjust their rates on Aug. 1, so as not to exceed the highest levels permitted by the General Maximum Price Regulation.

The Wehrmacht hammered hard last week along both flanks of its colossal pincers drive toward the Middle East. Across the undulating steppeland of Russia's Don basin the German columns kept coming up, pushed steadily onward to the Caucasus and the Caspian. In the stormy wasteland of Western Egypt Marshal Rommel's army struggled to open the way to Alexandria, the Nile and the Suez.

LONDON, July 18 -- A remarkable document, drawn up by the working committee of the All India Congress party and made public from Wardha last week, in which the British were requested to relinguish their power forthwith, may bring India once again to the boiling point.

A PERSONAL letter from one of our progressive museum directors who is earnestly interested in contemporary American art raises some interesting points about the artist, sales and education. He first points out that by comparison with the theatre, concerts and books, art is not available to the public as an investment or a commodity to be freely indulged in by purchase.

IN a speech recently delivered before the American Library Association, Edgar Ansel Mowrer, one of the best-known of American foreign correspondents, discussed the problem of information in wartime, and in closing touched upon the role of books in the war.

LONDON, July 18 -- Never since the Battle of Britain has the nation stood in greater peril, Oliver Lyttelton, Minister of Production, said today in serving warning that the next eighty days may be "among the gravest ever faced."

JUST a few years ago, a cold soup would have seemed to many people as incongruous as a steaming ice-cream soda or a sizzling beaker of beer. Now, although cold soup in hot weather is firmly established, most housewives still serve no more than two or three varieties.
WASHINGTON, July 18 (AP) -- Federal rent control will be ordered into effect Aug. 1 in about twenty additional war-production rental areas with a total population of about 5,000,000.

BEHIND RED ARMY LINES on the Don Front, July 18 (AP) -- The German break-through to Voronezh has failed to disturb smooth mechanical movements and communications behind the Russian front.

The lake region of Vermont, long neglected, is coming into its own, and Orleans County, where many of the loveliest of the lakes are found, is now an objective for vacationists. Lake Memphremagog, extending from Newport, Vt., well into Canada, is the giant of the group.
LAKE PLACID -- The annual senior tennis tournament will open tomorrow at the Lake Placid Club. Play will continue through Saturday.

CHICAGO, July 18 (AP) -- Dick Erdlitz, quarterback of last Fall's Northwestern football team, has rolled up 153,747 votes to lead all departments of the poll being conducted to name the college all- stars who will meet the Chicago Bears on Aug. 28 in Soldier Field.

THE Salzburg Players, an ensemble of twenty-eight, most of whom were members of the Vienna Philharmonic Orchestra and who played together in the Mozart chamber orchestra performances in Salzburg, will make its debut in this country next Saturday evening at "Claremont," the estate of George Chavchavadze in Bernardsville, N.J.

WASHINGTON, July 18 (Science Service) -- Two inventions in the field of light-polarizing films or sheets have prominent places in this week's crop of 817 patents issued by the Patent Office here. Both were obtained by Edwin H. Land of Boston, pioneer inventor of devices of this type, and both are assigned to the Polaroid Corporation.

Fresh from her triumph in the Long Island girls open tennis tournament at Bayside, Miss Lilliam B. Lopaus of City Island will head a field of sixteen competitors in the girls invitation tourney at the Ardsley Country Club starting tomorrow and continuing through Wednesday.

BOSTON, July 18 (U.P.) -- The War Labor Board announced today that a strike at two Everett chemical plants had been certified to it but that it would not consider the merits of the dispute until the strikers returned to work.

UNLESS this department's memory has slipped since last it listened to the radio at 7 A.M., there has been a slight change in the kilocycle fare, early in the morning. The comedy programs are not so numerous and the most carefree of them pause now and then to indicate that these are grave times.

While the last-minute changes made by the Ways and Means Committee in the proposed 1942 revenue bill, in respect to corporations, are estimated to yield a substantially increased revenue, the nature of these changes is such as to bear more heavily than justified upon enterprises having no excess profits.

BERNARDSVILLE, N.J., July 18 -- Claremont, the estate here of Prince George Chavchavadze, concert pianist, and Princess Chavchavadze, will form a picturesque setting for a series of intimate "Moonlight Serenades" to be given for the benefit of the United Service Organizations and other war relief agencies.

American industry has just experienced the most comprehensive revolution in its history. The process of conversion from peace to wartime activity has been about completed, War Production Chief Donald M. Nelson announced recently, in making known a realignment of executive functions in the board.

NEW SULFA DRUG -- Sulfametazine is the latest sulfa compound. A research group headed by Dr. D.W. Mecartney (Crumsall Hospital, Manchester, England), state in The Lancet that it is a near relative of sulfadiazene. They tried it with excellent results in seventy-three cases of lobar pneumonia and a few cases of meningococcal meningitis and gonorrhea.

Rear Admiral Howard L. Vickery, vice chairman of the United States Maritime Commission, said last week that shipyard labor now offered no serious problem and that the capacity of the country's shipyards was adequate to meet the demand for 23,000,000 dead-weight tons of shipping through the 1942-43 period.

The Second World War began at Danzig, the free city on the Baltic at the head of the Polish Corridor, on Sept. 1, 1939. Last week the war returned to Danzig when British four-motored bombers dived through a Summer thunder storm in broad daylight to raid the city at house-top altitude.
The following paragraph from a recent "About" column in THE TIMES Magazine reads like a bit of pro-Nazi propaganda:

NEW DELHI, India, July 18 (AP) -- Awards of the Order of the Purple Heart to seven officers of non-combat branches of the United States Army for meritorious service in Burma were announced today by Lieut. Gen. Joseph W. Stilwell's India headquarters.

WITH regard to the role of artists in the war, the discussion in these columns last Sunday has brought a highly gratifying response. Several times the available space could be filled with the report of work already done or in the doing, suggestions of things to be done and ways of doing them, and general approval of the artist taking the initiative without waiting for government help.

THE Jacob's Pillow Dance Festival -- the first under the new auspices at Ted Shawn's old farm near Lee, Mass. -- got off to an auspicious start last week, on a perfect day, in an ideal new theatre and with a program so simple and unpretentious that it seemed to have grown out of the surroundings.

AFTER its happy experience with the Tchaikovsky B flat minor Concerto, Victor is hopeful that its new recording of Grieg's Concerto in A minor (DM-900, three 12-inch records) will have a similar reception. The Tchaikovsky album, by Horowitz, Toscanini and the NBC Symphony, sold about 100,000 copies in the first two months of its existence.

ANN ARBOR, Mich., July 18 -- Physical training of a type recommended by the Army and Navy is rapidly getting 1,850 University of Michigan students into wartime fighting condition. Today, after four weeks of the first compulsory hardening program in the university's history, one official predicted that "there won't be enough fat left on their bodies to poke a finger into by the end of Summer."

THE second major casualty in RKO's current economy program occurred this week when Pare Lorentz, producer-director of the notable documentaries, "The River," "The Plow That Broke the Plains" and "The Fight for Life," was ordered to halt production on his first commercial entertainment film, "Name, Age and Occupation," and to vacate his offices at the studio.

WASHINGTON, July 18 -- The House completed general debate today on the tax bill of $6,144,000,000, with indications that it would be passed Monday, when many of the absentee members return to cast their votes.

Soviet guerrillas defending the homeland are honored by and pictured on a 30-kopecs light blue stamp received from the U.S.S.R. Dated 1941 but only recently released, this war item carries an inscription meaning "In answer to the call of the Great Leader of Peoples, Comrade Stalin, the sons of the Soviet Land are joining the ranks of the People's Volunteer Army."

Summer vacationists this year want (1) rest and relaxation to build up a reserve of energy for the efforts of wartime; (2) activity of their own choosing; (3) excitement and imagination in food and the new idea of living, and (4) the stimulation of new faces and new ideas.

Retail trade fell off somewhat last week in the three major test markets of New York, Chicago and Los Angeles, with clearance sales developing most activity, according to the survey prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by Meyer Both Reports.

CINCINNATI, July 18 -- The Giants edged closer to third place today by nudging the Reds out of the ball game at Crosley Field, 3 to 1. The Giants now are only a game and a half out of third place with ownership of the berth hinging on the outcome of their double-header with the Reds tomorrow.

In sun-baked fields over the countryside last week, as in the biting cold of last Winter, the civilians who serve as the eyes and ears of the Army's First Fighter Command were keeping twenty-four-hour watch for planes overhead. On the hundreds of posts in the New York area under direct supervision of the Army, a majority of those now signed up for daylight duty are women volunteers.

TUCSON, Ariz., July 18 -- Eastern capitalists have invested more than $6,500,000 in a million acres of cattle-grazing lands and improvements around Tucson in ten years. Business executives, using mechanized and intensified methods, are becoming livestock experts.

Frank Ruland, chairman and legislative representative of the New York State Legislative Board of the Brotherhood of Locomotive Engineers, issued a statement yesterday commending the labor record of Attorney General John J. Bennett Jr., candidate for the Democratic nomination for Governor.

America's yachtsmen continue to go to sea, but more and more in government ships of war rather than in pleasure craft. Hardly is the ink dry on the commissions and warrants of those skippers who have entered the Engineer Amphibian Command from the ranks of yachting before another call comes from Uncle Sam.

CHICAGO, July 18 -- An overnight accumulation of hedging and liquidating orders appeared on the Board of Trade at the opening today, and the distant deliveries of wheat dropped 1 1/2 cents a bushel to a new seasonal low before sufficient support from mills and professional traders developed to stem the tide.

OMAHA, July 18 -- The farmer, it was suggested the other day, has been too busy this Summer even to look up and ask, "How'm I doing?" But the question has been asked for him and the answer is that he is doing all right. He is doing so well in fact that he will provide the country this year with the greatest volume of food ever produced in a like period.

WASHINGTON, July 18 -- Some of the toughest fights of this war are being fought and won for America by little units of Navy gunners who ride United States merchant ships over the world's convoy routes.

Actual details of Treasury proposals for inventory reserves, expected when the new tax bill reaches the Senate, possibly this week, are being awaited in retail circles with considerable interest. The proposals, intended to remove from taxable income profits arising from increased inventory valuation, were first broached before the Ways and Means Committee in June, but definite action was deferred.
ONE Midsummer Drama Festival going merrily on, unaffected by war's alarms or the tire shortages which have hit the straw-hat circuit elsewhere, is that of Pasadena Playhouse.

General Foods Corporation is taking over the canning plant established in the Bahamas by Axel Wenner-Gren, Swedish financier, it was learned yesterday when a report to that effect from Nassau was confirmed here by John S. Prescott, vice president, secretary and temporary treasurer of General Foods.

Travel Lines: According to George J. Beer, member of the British Chamber of Commerce in Mexico, travelers visiting Mexico should buy their tickets at the Mexican port of entry and never in the United States of America because the Mexican Railway charges double for tickets sold on foreign territory.

Coale went to sea -- is seventeen paintings, several of them full of lively and stirring action Mr. Benet, in his foreword, advances the theory that when Mr. Coale "first started off on his travels he intended to let his pictorial record speak for itself."

CHICAGO, July 18 -- No one except the Axis powers need worry about the earnestness of American civilians. They may be less braggart than they were when the country was young, but they have not changed in character: They are proud of America and energetic.

FROM contemporary evidence it is possible to derive a pretty clear idea of what it meant to render unto Caesar the things which are Caesar's. In the Princeton University Library a number of papyrus tax-registers dating back nearly to the beginning of the Roman rule in Egypt tell some interesting facts about the price of the occupation.

BUFFALO, July 18 (AP) -- A three-day strike at the American Magnesium Corporation's plant ended today when workers, moved by patriotic appeals from fellow-employes and Army officials, voted to return to their jobs tomorrow midnight.

RYE, N.Y., July 18 -- Four of the forty-one teams which started play this morning in the Apawamis Club's sixth annual invitation best-ball golf tournament carded 67 to tie for medal honors in the eighteen-hole qualifying round. When cards were matched a birdie 3 on the third hole gave the top honor to the all-Apawamis pair of Revell McCallum and Will N. Robins, who posted 31, 36 -- 67.

MEDFORD, Mass., July 18 -- Only if individual colleges make an active effort to share the results of their Summer's experiment with changing curricula will it be possible to decrease the variability and variety of plans of accelerated study, Bills Y. Wessell, dean of the School of Liberal Arts of Tufts College, declared in an interview here today.
WASHINGTON, July 18 -- The Senators put a stop to the Browns' winning ways today when Alex Carrasquel defeated the visitors, 3 -- 0. The setback ended a St. Louis streak of eight straight victories.

GENERAL DRAJA MIKHAILOVITCH has, according to American short-wave broadcasters, set up a radio station high in the mountains of Yugoslavia, and frequent reports of his stout fight against Axis invaders are flashed to the New York area.

Special police guards were assigned last night to three power stations in the Lower Bronx after a letter carrier making his rounds had taken from a mall-box a note addressed to the police of the Simpson Street station warning them that "the power house will be blown up tonight."

WASHINGTON, July 18 -- Although the American home has not yet felt the impact of war to the same degree as American industry, the shortages of the future are foretold by the War Production Board in a survey of conversion of the $3,800,000,000 civilian durable goods industries, and items such as electric fans, radios and sewing machines that no longer are being produced.

"AS far as I'm concerned," says Greer Garson with tart emphasis, "MGM means Metro's Glorified Mrs." And the facts are with her. In four out of the five films in which she already has appeared, Miss Garson has been wedded for better or for worse to as many screen husbands.

New lows for the current movement in cotton futures were made yesterday. Continued selling by commission houses and New Orleans interests, prompted by President Roosevelt's confirmation of reports that he is preparing an extensive program for curbing inflation through wage and farm products price controls and higher taxes, dominated the day's activity on the New York Cotton Exchange.

Mrs. Charles Alonzo Cornish of Gillette, N.J., has announced the engagement and forthcoming marriage of her daughter, Miss Katharine Dunn Cornish, to William Stephen Thomas of this city and Philadelphia, son of Mrs. William Sturgis Thomas of New York and the late Dr. Thomas.

I have read the article "We Hold These Truths," by Henry Steele Commager, with a great deal of interest, but I am dismayed to read the following lines: "And on July 4 the Declaration was formally adopted. The bells rang, in Philadelphia, all that day and most the night * * *"

SOMEWHERE IN AUSTRALIA, July 18 (U.P.) -- Sergeant Lewis Coburn, 24 years of age, of Niagara Falls, N.Y., who received the Order of the Purple Heart yesterday "for meritorious acts essential to the service," probably is the champion aerial gunner of the war.

OTTAWA, July 18 -- Two very skillful attempts were made during the debate this week on the subject of how the government proposes to continue financing the war to introduce the suggestion that the time has come to have recourse to the issue of "national currency" as a supplement to taxation and borrowing.
WASHINGTON -- To the motorist about to leave on a vacation and with a brand new "A" ration book in his wallet, government officials direct a few words of caution: Don't lose your ration book!"
PUTTING a gate at the top of the stairs, placing a valued ornament out of reach, are rule-of-thumb solutions to the problem of striking a balance of freedom and responsibility for young children.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, July 18 -- This week Hungarian Premier Nicholas von Kallay was called upon to make a "frank" revelation in his Parliament regarding an open revolt in the Hungarian-occupied Batschka district of Yugoslavia last January.

JERSEY CITY, July 18 (AP) -- Baltimore made a clean sweep of its three-game series with Jersey City today, winning the final game of the set, 4 -- 2, behind the five-hit hurling of Ken Trinkle as the Little Giants went down to their sixth straight defeat.
WASHINGTON, July 18 -- In a joint statement the Army and Navy announced today a labor policy to be followed in some 100 government-owed and privately operated plants.

With the arrival of hot, arid Summer weather the gardener is likely to wish that he had given more attention to the selection of flowers that can withstand heat and drought. Little can be done about the situation for this year, but now is the ideal time to make notes of what can be used for another season.

A new peak in hourly and weekly earnings and payrolls was reached in May, the regular monthly survey of twenty-five manufacturing industries by the division of industrial economics of the Conference Board disclosed yesterday.

A strip of the Atlantic seacoast between forty and seventy miles wide from the Canadian border to the Carolina capes and that part of the ocean within 200 miles of the shore was designated as a "vital defense area" yesterday by the Army, which banned from it virtually all civilian and military aviation not "necessary to the war effort."

Nelson Eddy in Concert Favorites. Nelson Eddy, baritone, with orchestra conducted by Robert Armbruster. (Columbia M-507, four 10-inch records.) Mr. Eddy's drawing powers are so impressive that this album will probably become a best-seller no matter what a reviewer will say of it.

WITH THE BRITISH NAVAL AIR SERVICE, in Egypt, July 18 (AP) -- British naval dive-bombers attacking Matruh last night and early today turned the jetties into sheets of flames that could be seen for twenty miles and also planted heavy explosives amid a concentration of Axis vehicles inland.

THE recent death at Sevastopol of war correspondent Eugene Petrov, whose dispatches were published here by The North American Newspaper Alliance, was a sharp reminder that in this war Russian artists, writers and film workers alike play a dual role as civilians and soldiers -- when they are not making films about the war they are at the front, fighting it.

WAR atmosphere is incidental to most light novels nowadays, though it seldom has any direct bearing on the action of the story, which as a rule sticks closely to the sure popularity of young love. In this one. which ripples along easily and pleasantly, the cornerstone of the plot rests on the fact of war.

The protest made by both Catholic and Protestant clergy in the Netherlands against Nazi, activities there centered about the establishment of the National Socialist Labor Service and encroachment by the authorities of the occupying forces in the fields of education and nursing, it was revealed yesterday when the text of the declarations was received here.

When, once in a blue moon, a new shrub appears on the horticultural horizon, it is welcome news indeed to the garden enthusiast. While "new" annuals and perennials make their debut with incredible regularity, a new shrub is so rare as to rate a floral fanfare.

The chemical compound from which most synthetic rubber derives is butadiene, a word that may soon become as familiar as gasoline. Until a short time ago America's huge petroleum reserves were regarded as the chief source of butadiene; it was thought that by 1944 and at a cost of $650,000,000 the big oil and rubber companies could produce 1,000,000 tons of synthetic.

MOSCOW, July 18 -- Today's dispatches report a new German offensive in the south. After a number of feints and tentative attacks to feel out Soviet defenses, several enemy infantry divisions with heavy tank support have taken the initiative with an offensive concentrated in a narrow area, it is said.

AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, Australia, July 18 (U.P.) -- Lieut. Gen. George H. Brett awarded ten Silver Stars today to American fliers and members of the Army Medical Corps, mostly for their gallantry in defense of the Netherlands Indies.

WASHINGTON, July 18 (AP) -- The War Production Board announced tonight the appointment of twelve noted American chemists and chemical engineers as a committee to advise WPB on technical processes related to the war effort.

DENVER, July 18 -- American railroad men have achieved a "remarkable record" in keeping the country's transportation lines open and running smoothly in the face of stupendous burdens involving wartime troop and freight movements, Joseph R. Eastman, director of the Office of Defense Transportation, told the educational conference of the Brotherhood of Railway and Steamship Clerks, Freight and Express Handlers and Station Employes, in its week-long session here.
The White Sox, acting with customary reckless abandon, tossed away a chance to score a run in the first inning at the Stadium yesterday, and in the end that cost them the ball game.

WOODS HOLE, Mass., July 18 -- The Children's School of Science here has entered its twenty-ninth consecutive Summer session. Although enrollment is only forty-two as against a normal attendance of more than eighty, this is an appreciably higher figure than had been expected.

THE Army and Navy surgeons were prepared when the Japanese swooped down on Pearl Harbor on Sunday morning, Dec. 7, 1941 -- prepared with sulfa drugs. With them an unparalleled record in surgical annals was established. For ten days, twenty-four hours a day, teams of men in white operated in relays in blacked-out quarters.
LONDON, July 18 -- General Field Marshal Erwin Rommel cannot sit indefinitely where he is. He must either smash through to Alexandria and Cairo or go back to Libya.

An English woman visiting this country some years ago, after having attended meetings of several garden clubs, made the remark that no one in America seemed to do any gardening except women well past middle age. This may have been true, to some extent at least, in the past.

MILLS COLLEGE, Calif., July 18 -- Unique in the programs of Summer sessions, East or West -- and far reaching in its implications -- is the Casa Pan-Americana, one of the departments of study at Mills College. It is writing a new page in the history of inter-American relations, with a rational approach thereto.

LI PAO-SHAN (pronounced Lee Bowshan) is a typical chiupa (pronounced jooba -- a Chinese doughboy or Tommy. He is a bright, eager farm lad: diligent, inherently honest, possessed of amazing stamina and ability to undergo extreme hardships uncomplainingly, with courage to challenge the hated Japanese despite their overwhelming arms, and beating them every time he has met them on anything like equal terms.
AUBURN, N.Y., July 18 (AP) -- Three Auburn golfers and one from Elmira moved into the semi-final round of the Finger Lakes tournament today.
AT SEA WITH THE UNITED STATES PACIFIC FLEET, June 18 (Delayed) -- Japanese are dying in Kiska Harbor today as the war of the Aleutian mists begins again after three days of storms and gluethick fogs.

CHICAGO, July 18 -- The biggest golfing extravaganza in history -- and the most unusual -- opens at the popular Tam o'Shanter Country Club on Monday with top-ranking Negroes competing against white players for the first time in any major tournament and with the professionals shooting for $15,500, richest of all pro prizes.

Launching this week of a campaign to invigorate the nation-wide collection of scrap steel and other "waste" materials essential to war production could not come at a better time for the steel industry, which is putting up $1,500,000 to finance the job, with other interests supplying $250,000 more of the cost.

Federal agents and the police arrested fourteen more enemy aliens late Friday night and early yester-morning in Manhattan and Brooklyn. The aliens, thirteen Germans and one Italian, included one woman. All were removed to Ellis Island for hearings before enemy alien boards.

A PSYCHIATRIST receives as a patient a woman who does not know whether or not she murdered her husband. She has been tried and acquitted, but since the trial she has begun to doubt that the story she told the jury was true.

LOS ANGELES, Calif. -- The recent words of Secretary Stimson, that danger of an attack on the West Coast is appreciably lessened by the battle of Midway, came as a tonic to ease the worries of the nation's film capital. Hollywood is a city of lights -- all kinds of lights.

ST. LOUIS, July 18 -- The twin battle of the southpaws today ended in a draw as the Cardinals took the opener, 7 to 4, and the Dodgers won the nightcap, 4 to 3, to hold their eight-game margin over the second-place Redbirds.

THERE have been reports that musicians have been performing at the front for the Russians. Valentin Katayeff, writing in the Central European Observer, describes one of those front-line appearances. It was in a forest clearing 300 yards behind the firing line.

THE Commonwealth Club of California has awarded one of its two gold medals for literature to Lesley Byrd Simpson for the scholarship and research in his book, "Many Mexicos" (Putnam's). Mr. Simpson is an associate professor of Spanish at the University of California and is now on leave as a naval officer in Washington, D.C.

POCONO MOUNTAINS, Pa. -- Several leading Summer events have been announced in this region. The Buck Hill Art Association's eleventh annual purchase prize exhibit will open this week at The Inn, Buck Hill Falls, with sixty of the country's leading artists represented.

SOMEWHAT reluctantly James Whitney, C.P.A., takes on another job of sleuthing. He does not know that it is going to be a murder case, and neither does John J. Clayton, who employs him. but that is what it turns out to be, and Whitney is just stubborn enough to stay with it after the police have warned him that they want no amateurs butting in.

CHUNGKING, China, July 18 -- General Ma Pu-ching has been appointed Commissioner of Reclamation in the Tsaidam basin of Western Chinghai Province and has transferred his troops from his former stronghold at Liangchow [Wuwei] northwest of Lanchow in the Kansu panhandle astride the Marco Polo route.

The West Fifty-second Street night club sector will make its all-out effort in the interest of war bond sales on Wednesday evening at what is described as "the city's most glamorous block party" of the war. War bonds will be sold to music.

AN American submarine rises in the Southeast Pacific. The men who spend their days and nights stalking Japanese warships and transports gather around the radio as their ship rests on the surface, recharging its batteries.

LIDICE still lives. The Nazis wiped out the village of that name in Czechoslovakia, and Americans out in Illinois renamed a workers' village to commemorate the crime. Lidice, Ill:, is a subdivision of Stern Park Gardens, a 25-year-old community near Joliet.

The sinking of four more United Nations merchant vessels, three American and one British, was announced yesterday by the Navy Department. Three were lost in the Atlantic and one in the Indian Ocean. According to the unofficial Associated Press tally, 383 Allied and neutral merchant ships have now been sunk in the Western Atlantic since Pearl Harbor and at least twenty-five American cargo ships have been lost in the Pacific.

"VICTORY ON WEST HILL" is not an easy kind of novel to describe. Robert L. Duffus has packed a good many important observations into an unusually small space. Touching upon even a few of them in a review, one runs the risk of suggesting that his novel is a pretty solemn and allegorical work and something the reader who has had a hard day at the office would rather look into another time.

Both retail and wholesale business has begun to level off, according to the market report prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by Kirby, Block Co. Buyers were in the market in large numbers last week, but purchases were generally conservative and in line with actual needs only.

WASHINGTON, July 18 -- Scattered here and there in the forty-eight States are Germans, Italians and Japanese, still ardently embracing the ideals of their homelands, despite long residence here, and regardless of the benefits they have enjoyed in the United States.

THE scene is the stage of the Unicorn Theatre in London. The play is "The Rat and the Beaver," with Felix Gardener as the Rat and Arthur Surbonadier as the Beaver. In the last act of the play the Rat is supposed to shoot and kill the Beaver.

THIS novel about the Dutch and the Dutch East Indies has a strong present interest because it gives a convincingly inside angle on the attitude of the Dutch in conquered Hol land and in their island empire in the recent months before the islands were invaded.

German tanks and motorized infantry have reached the lower Don River east of Rostov on a broad front in a continuing southward thrust, the German High Command reported yesterday, according to German broadcasts recorded by The Associated Press.

CINCINNATI, Ohio, July 18 -- With more than 2,800 men and women from homes from California to Connecticut studying this Summer at the University of Cincinnati, the campus was described by President Raymond Walters as a "huge wartime educational center."

Red, white and blue form a colorful bedding scheme in the borders now in full bloom at the New York Botanical Garden. The patriotic effect is achieved by using red and white geraniums and petunias and blue ageratum. Also of interest here is the brilliant display of waterlilies coming into their full glory, near the greenhouse, and the model Victory vegetable garden, in which early crops are now being harvested.

The New York Union Printers' baseball team reached the final round in the Eastern division play-off tournament by defeating Baltimore at Dexter Park, Woodhaven, yesterday, 15 to 3. Accompanying the local nine into the championship round was the Washington team, which blanked Boston, 10 to 0.

Two masters of the art of politics, President Roosevelt and James A. Farley, Democratic State Chairman, have come into collision over the choice of a Democratic candidate for Governor of New York. Mr. Farley's choice is John J. Bennett Jr., Attorney General of the State for the past eleven and a half years and an aspirant for the gubernatorial nomination since 1936.

BUENOS AIRES -- On July 13, centenary of the birth of Jose Manuel Estrada, writer, orator, educator and diplomat, Argentina placed on sale a 5-centavos brown stamp carrying his portrait and inscribed with his name and 1842-1942.

Because he is widely recognized by the American public as the private citizen who has long advocated price control as a check to inflation, and months ago submitted his plan to the government, Bernard M. Baruch is accepted as champion of those groups to whom inflation, if not held down, would bring financial disaster.

In a letter published in THE NEW YORK TIMES of June 7 I suggested that the representatives of Czechoslovakia and Hungary should convene in America, as the Czechs and the Slovaks did twenty-four years ago, and agree on a constructive program as a contribution to a United Nations victory.

WASHINGTON, July 18 -- Contracts with the Higgins Corporation of New Orleans for the building of 200 Liberty Ships were canceled today by the Maritime Commission, which also announced curtailment of all further ship plant construction throughout the country because of the need for using available steel for building ships.

LOS ANGELES, July 18 -- Victory against Germany, Italy and Japan cannot be won until our own Army, Navy and Air commands are brought under a single head who, in turn, will coordinate America's war effort with the military heads of the other United Nations according to Wendell Willkie, the 1940 Presidential nominee, who arrived in this city today.

THE Great Lakes are the Ohio River of the North. They and it are the two great natural waterways to the West. Over both slid the canoe of explorer and fur trader. Later both carried emigrants to the Western prairies.

ATHOUGH it is our own impression, based on snatches of conversation overheard in trains and buses, that the big news of the month is Alan Ladd, whose first film, "This Gun for Hire," has just hit town, some mention must be made of a modest little project just announced by Ealing Studios -- namely, the filming of the history of the B.B.C. (British Broadcasting Corporation), which has the formidable austerity of any government controlled agency.

LONDON, July 18 (U.P.) -- The Fighting French headquarters of General Charles de Gaulle said tonight that it had received reports of widespread demonstrations throughout unoccupied France on Bastille Day.

DES MOINES, July 18 -- Forty-seven separate items are included in the government issue of clothing for the members of the Women's Army Auxiliary Corps, as listed for the processing which the first group will undergo here on Monday. However, this total includes a number of articles intended for cold weather use, which will not be handed out to the corps members at this time.

Ted Schroeder of Glendale, Calif., and Francisco (Pancho) Segura of Ecuador will meet in the match of the Eastern season to date at 2:30 o'clock this afternoon at the Jackson Heights Tennis Club in Queens.

MOSCOW, Sunday, July 19 -- The Red Army fought back against a powerful German offensive rolling southward and southeastward toward the lower Don River, a Soviet communique said today, and Russian counterattacks gained ground in a stab at the enemy flank near Voronezh.

The Citizens Union has sent to all New York City candidates for the State Legislature a long questionnaire on issues the Union regards as important. The answers will be used as part of the basic for its recommendations of candidates at the primary and general elections.

According to reports from many sections of the country, Sundays are regaining some of their old-time social importance. Everywhere people are going to church in increasing numbers. There is more leisure for visiting. Once again the Sunday dinner may become a function at gastronomic importance.

WASHINGTON, July 18 -- Acting six weeks after he had signed a Congressional declaration of war against Hungary, Rumania and Bulgaria, President Roosevelt to day declared a state of war to exist between the United States and the three Balkan countries and made nationals of those countries here subject to internment.

The magnitude of this war has been indicated in the titles given to its encounters: The Battle of France, the Battle of Britain, the Battle of the Atlantic. An even vaster concept is beginning to take shape: The Siege of Asia. If Asia holds out the United Nations can win a clear-cut and conclusive victory.
PRINCETON, N.J., July 18 -- In these days of war prosperity one-half of the nation's non-farm families have a total cash income of less than $35 a week.

PASSED: The Maryknoll missionaries -- their headquarters are at Ossining, N.Y. last week told a story about a colleague stranded in Hong Kong when the Japanese captured the city. Father Maurice Feeney, a native of Albany, was interned along with other missionaries by the Mikado's army.
SYRACUSE, N.Y., July 18 (AP) -- With Lloyd Christopher pacing their thirteen-hit attack, the Newark Bears earned a split in their two-game series here by downing the Chiefs tonight, 11 to 6.

PRINCETON, N.J., July 18 -- Training in fundamental commando techniques began this week for 800 cadets in the Princeton University Field Artillery unit of the Reserve Officers Training Corps with the opening of a specially designed obstacle course on a wooded hillside near Lake Carnegie.

The opening of a new two-story plant in Brooklyn, built by a small manufacturer engaged 100 per cent in subcontracting for war production, was celebrated yesterday when Seal-O-Strain Corporation moved to new quarters. From manufacturing heating equipment and boxes through which to strain fuel being fed into tanks, the company in the last two years has changed over entirely to war production.

SOUTH HADLEY, Mass., July 18 -- Through the cooperation of faculty members and civic and industrial leaders in the Connecticut Valley, a series of radio programs arranged by members of the Mount Holyoke History Department are bringing to radio listeners in this community a picture of historical origins and developments of problems which confront the world today
Please permit a few words in a most popular cause -- that of the so-called draft dodger" on the government payroll.

EAST HAMPTON, L.I., July 18 -- Next Saturday afternoon the New York Historical Society will dedicate its newly acquired East Hampton house on Ocean Avenue as a museum and memorial to the Thompson family at a reception and tea to which several hundred persons from all the Hamptons will be invited.

WASHINGTON, July 18 -- Motorists in East Coast metropolitan areas served by subways, elevated railroads and commuter trains will find it difficult to get supplemental gasoline rations even if they have formed car-sharing clubs, if existing public facilities are deemed adequate, according to an OPA ruling issued today.

WHEN Producer Samuel Goldwyn made it known to all and sundry some time back that his film biography of Lou Gehrig, "The Pride of the Yankees," was not going to be a baseball picture, strictly speaking, but more of a "human drama," as it were, a few of the practicing skeptics began smirking behind their mitts.

TWO volumes of a series published in England which deal with the seasons and their effect on outdoor occupations. The first tells of fish and fishing, fresh water fishing, fishing at the sea's edge, the great whales and seals, inshore fisheries, trawlers of the deep and the herring industry.
LONDON, July 18 (AP) -- The Air Ministry issued this communique today:

With four of the six components declining, THE NEW YORK TIMES index of business activity fell to 127.0 for the week ended July 11 from 129.3 in the preceding week. The figure was 128.6 in the week ended July 12, 1941.

Sabotage in Austria has taken try with an iron fist, Archduke Felix of Austria told this writer yesterday. The 24-year-old Prince of the House of Habsburg explained that he had just received detailed information from underground sources in Austria, telling of the wrecking of plants and of nightly shootings and bombings in Vienna.

THE International Society for Contemporary Music has decided on the programs for its festival which will be held from Aug. 1 to 9 under the sponsorship of the University of California in Berkeley. Thirty-five works will be played in a series of seven afternoon concerts.

INTERLOCHEN, Mich., July 18 -- Dr. Joseph E. Maddy today put the question of student music broadcasts directly up to James L. Fly, chairman of the Federal Board of War Communications and of the Federal Communications Commission.

BEAVER, Pa., July 18 (U.P.) -- A "wildcat" strike at the propeller plant of the Curtiss-Wright Corporation ended today as members of the C.I.O. United Steel Workers of America returned to work after draft boards had threatened to reclassify deferred workers.

Lured by the promise of cool mountain and seashore breezes, thousands of happy vacationers crowded Grand Central Terminal and Pennsylvania Station yesterday in numbers that railroad officials estimated were exceeded only by the July 4 week-end rush.

A child's needs in health and nutrition can be stated fairly simply, but we can't be so categorical in conveying information on his emotional needs, says Dr. Augusta Bronner, consulting director of the Judge Baker Guidance Center. Individual differences must be taken into account, and this problem in spreading parent education is one topic of a workshop, "Programs for Parents," in which Dr. Bronner shares at Harvard's Summer School.

IN large full-page drawings and a simple text this author and artist describe a day spent by Ann and Bill at the seashore on the Pacific Coast. Hermit crabs and sea-horses, sand dollars, starfish, Mike the pelican, a baby octopus, and -- much more attractive -- a baby seal which had lost its mother and which Bill promptly christened Jerry, are only some of the finds which the children made.

WESTBURY, L.I., July 18 -- Rounding out the first week of the thirty-five-day harness racing meeting at Roosevelt Raceway today, the percentage of winning favorites took a decided nose dive as six out of eight choices disappointed their followers.

Nature has established no uncrossable bars to a federation of man, concludes Dr. John R. Swanton, veteran anthropologist of the Bureau of American Ethnology, in a paper on the evolution of nations published by the Smithsonian Institution. Whether they are mighty empires or small primitive tribes, nations have no common pattern of evolution.

Major Victor W. Dyas, Canadian recruiting officer, and Major J.M.C. Gamble, assistant military attach with the Canadian Legation at Washington, arrived here yesterday to facilitate the enlistment into the Canadian Army of Canadians living in this country.

"CAN Indians get together?" It is an odd title yet a significant one, for it tells us much in four words. It gives us an intimate and revealing glimpse into the minds of those who framed it. It reveals to us the premises and assumptions on which they base their consideration of the Indian problem.

MONTICELLO -- A new athletic championship tournament comes to the Sullivan County vacation area with the announcement that the Eastern amateur handball title matches will be held over the Labor Day week-end at the courts1 of the New Concord Hotel, Kiamesha Lake.

ALTHOUGH it was the National Broadcasting Company that announced the signing of Raymond Gram Swing, it will be the Blue Network that presents him, beginning Sept. 28, on a schedule that calls for four fifteen-minute broadcasts a week at 10 P.M. . . .
Doublrab, now being called the equal of Roseben and other mighty sprinters, ran a race before 21,370 at Empire City yesterday further to entitle him to ranking with the great speed horses.

The University of Wisconsin 1940 boxing team was a real fighting squad. It battled its way to six victories in seven dual engagements and won two N.C.A.A. titles. Today, when the youth of America is called upon to do fighting of a more serious nature, eight of the nine members of that fine combination are continuing with Uncle Sam's forces.

LONDON, July 18 -- The seriousness of the shipping position which led this week to a secret debate in Commons has resulted in considerably reduced British food imports for some time. Although the trend of these imports continues down major deterioration in nutrition is not likely this year.
The following German High Command communique was broadcast from Berlin yesterday and was recorded here by The Associated Press:
CHICAGO, July 18 (AP) -- Lou Novikoff, the Cubs' rampaging outfielder, was the hero of a two-run eighth-inning rally today that beat the Phils, 2 to 1.

While shoe production will drop about 20 per cent in 1943, no marked shortage of footwear for civilian use is expected during the first half of the year, according to estimates made yesterday by manufacturers.

Because of the threat to trademarks by government regimentation, business concerns were urged by various trade associations last week to acquaint themselves thoroughly with the provisions of the bill pending in Congress, which will repeal and codify all existing enactments.

LAKE PLACID -- Going camping this Summer? With automobile travel restricted as it is, the answer may still be "yes," but the camping probably won't be in tents; most likely it will be in leantos, arrived at on foot with all your possessions on your back.

DES MOINES, Iowa, July 17 -- After visiting Des Moines last February, H.V. Kaltenborn, the radio voice of warning, remarked that Iowa was only mildly interested in war news and that a visitor to Iowa would never know a war was going on.

An interpretation of the New York State Safety Responsibility Law, making it applicable to all owners of cars involved in accidents, whether the vehicles are parked or in motion, was given yesterday in Queens by Supreme Court Justice Charles W. Froessel.

WASHINGTON, July 18 -- Japan is moving more of her seasoned troops northward to the frontier of Manchukuo and Siberia, according to reports reaching Washington from usually reliable private sources in the Orient.

A comparative study of democracy in action through an examination of the Governments of England, Switzerland and pre-Vichy France is being made by thirty-one students who are enrolled in the course in European democracies at the Hunter College Summer session.

IT was in 1937 that Walt Disney first became interested in the story of Felix Salten's "Bambi" as a feature production. At that time most of his personnel were in production on "Snow White" and even the rights to Salten's book were owned by Sidney Franklin.

HAMILTON, N.Y., July 18 -- That a college student's failure to participate in extra-curricular activities should not be regarded as a mark of inferior intelligence is shown by a survey conducted at Colgate University under the direction of Dr. Wendell H. Bash of the Sociology Department.

Harry Bridges, president of the International Longshoremen and Warehouse Men's Union, and Pacific Coast director of the C.I.O., was among 1,500 persons who attended a testimonial dinner at the Hotel Commodore last night honoring Austin Hogan, president of the Transport Workers Union of Greater New York, Local 100, on the occasion of his departure for military service.

Cable advices to the New York office of the International Transport Workers Federation told yesterday of a London conference to consider a new collective agreement with the Greek seamen. Negotiations are under way there for the unification of the Greek seafarers' movement and solidification of the new pact between the Greek Government in exile, the Greek seamen and the Greek shipowners.

"There won't be any waste space on board ship when we're through here and have gone to sea," said the young midshipman detailed to guide the visitor. "So it's really a pretty good idea having everything a bit on the snug side while we're in training."

HONOLULU, July 18 -- The Hawaiian Department Army manoeuvres ended today at noon with Army spokesmen announcing that "American troops taking part in comprehensive manoeuvres repelled a theoretical Japanese attack today under the most adverse circumstances the umpires could conceive of and ended the two-day war games with a general feeling of calm confidence."

Definition of the goals for which the United Nations are fighting will be the chief aim of the third Conference on Science, Philosophy and Religion to be held at Columbia University Aug. 27 to 31 with leading scientists, theologians, writers, educators and administrators of government bureaus of the United States and Canada participating.

IF this should chance to meet the eye of Lester Lockwood, a theatrical agent in the Bronx, I'd like him to know that I have been thinking of him all morning. I first began thinking of him about dawn when a postman arrived with a letter from him addressed to S.J. Philbin, on which two cents were due.

ENGLISH reviewing today has many merits, but C.E. Vulliamy, writing in The Spectator, notes that in one respect it is unfortunately lacking. He has been impressed by this deficiency through reading Merle M. Bevington's survey of "The Saturday Review: 1855-1868" -- a book which he commends whole-heartedly as "yet another of those happy examples of American scholarship which have now become so justly celebrated.''

Leo Cantor, triple threat halfback from U.C.L.A., and Hubert Barker, plunging fullback from Arkansas University, have signed contracts with the Football Giants, according to an announcement by John V. Mara, president of the New York club.

DUBUQUE, Iowa, July 18 -- Forsaking the traditional semester system, the University of Dubuque went on a new quarter basis last month which will permit a student to finish his four-year academic program in two years and five months if he so chooses.

DENVER, July 18 -- Soldiers and sailors wounded by bomb and bullet at Pearl Harbor were patients today at clinics held at the Fitzsimmons General Hospital of the Army here in the presence of more than 200 delegates to the International College of Surgeons.

Staying in one's own back yard can be a very pleasant procedure. For one thing, the dollars usually spent in traveling are at liberty -- some of them at least -- for use in making one's own private corner of the out-of-doors, whether porch, terrace or back-yard garden, an oasis of comfort and coolness.

Immediately following the resignation of Robert H. Hinckley as Assistant Secretary of Commerce, Jesse Jones announced the appointment of William A. M. Burden of New York to the post of special assistant in matters relating to civil aviation.

VICHY, France, July 18 -- At today's Cabinet meeting Chief of Government Pierre Laval reported on his conversations in Paris with the occupying authority, with particular reference to the departure of French workers for Germany.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., July 18 -- Radcliffe College students receive much of the essential part of the training of a Renaissance apprentice in a new drawing and painting course at Harvard Fogg Art Museum. Although they are not expected to become professional artists they learn appreciation through experience in various techniques of drawing and painting.

JOHN K. WINKLER, who specializes in tycoons, is following up his biographies of J.P. Morgan, F.W. Woolworth and the du Pont dynasty, with a book about James Buchanan Duke, the man who taught Americans to smoke cigarettes and who made so much money out of it that he was able to spend about $100,000,000 in creating Duke University and still had enough left to make his daughter one of the richest girls in the world.

WASHINGTON, July 18 -- Stocks of domestic and foreign crude petroleum on July 11 totaled 251,311,000 barrels, according to data reported to the Bureau of Mines, United States Department of the Interior. Compared with the total of the preceding week, this represents a decrease of 1,969,000 barrels, comprising decreases of 1,966,000 and 3,000 barrels in stocks of domestic and foreign crude, respectively.

WHEREVER you find Toby Dyke there you will also find George, and it is lucky for Toby that this is the case, for Toby is a detective who needs somebody like George to set him on the right track. Presumably George has another name, but since we are never told what it is we are compelled to be more familiar than our respect for his ability would incline us to be.

THE sports theme is the dominant one in the Fall Fashion openings sponsored by the Associated Apparel Manufacturers of Los Angeles in that city this past week. The outdoor life of California is reflected in the brilliant colorings and casual styling employed by our West Coast designers.

That crunching sound which now is heard throughout the land is the July lyric of the native epicure, American as Iowa or the Mississippi River. It rises from the measured meeting of tooth and kernel upon the cob. It is tantalizing to hear and a deep delight to indulge.

LOS ANGELES, July 18 (AP) -- Meyer Phillip Grace, 39, a former pugilist, and Channing Drexel Lipton, 25, a filling-station employe, were arrested today on a charge of attempting to extort $250,000 from Louis B. Mayer of Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer, reputed to be the country's highest paid executive.

BLOOMINGTON, Ind., July 18 -- Indiana University four years ago decided to take a critical look at itself, and as a result President Herman B. Wells and the board of trustees were able to report today that about forty major changes had been made in organization, curriculum and services.
