Cabbies and traveling public alike engaged in a renewal of "hack service" at the Grand Central Terminal yesterday without "a hitch or a flourish" almost as they had done it at the turn of the century in that same vicinity.

LONDON, July 18 (U.P.) -- Usually reliable informants said today that a second front was unlikely in Western Europe within the next few months unless "considerable" reinforcements of American troops arrived.

KUIBYSHEV, Russia, July 18 (U.P.) -- Men, oil, tanks and planes, including American fighters and bombers, are pouring into the Volga Valley and converging on the Don River front in a bitter battle to stem the German offensive against vital life-lines of the Soviet Union.

WHEN that man Saroyan makes up his mind to do something about the theatre it follows that there shall be noise and action. With some Broadway producers he has something in common. That would be the noise.

WASHINGTON, July 19 -- The colleges and universities of the United States are "confused" in their effort to facilitate the national war effort because of "the failure of the government to develop a comprehensive plan for the utilization of institutions of higher education," the American Council on Education, in a letter to four governmental leaders, declared today.

WASHINGTON, July 19 -- Development "as rapidly as possible of all lines of communication with the Soviet Arctic and the Soviet Far East" is necessary because of the Japanese occupation of some of the Western Aleutian Islands and the threat to communications between this country and the Soviet Union, according to a report published today by the Foreign Policy Association.

LONDON, July 19 -- Two French-Canadian priests and two students have recently arrived in Britain, it was announced today, after spending ten months as prisoners in a Nazi camp and more than a year as fugitives in occupied and unoccupied France.

LONDON, July 19 -- Despite marked relative inactivity induced by the increasing gravity of the news from the Russian front, misgivings over shipping losses and a feeling of uncertainty left by the earlier setback in the African campaign, the stock markets presented a remarkably firm front last week.

HYDE PARK, N.Y., July 19 -- More than a thousand persons attended the outdoor USO benefit concert of the Dutchess County Philharmonic Orchestra on the estate of President Roosevelt here this afternoon.

Construction of a newly developed type of concrete building for Wright Aeronautical Corporation, "somewhere in New Jersey," is now under way and the plant is expected to be ready for manufacturing in a short time, the company announced yesterday.

Officers and civilians returning from the Far East urge and urge again that the American public has not yet begun to realize the seriousness of the situation there. The same warnings come from embattled Europe. The warnings have been relayed to the nation by press and radio, without commensurate result.

ST. LOUIS, July 19 -- In the twilight of the eleventh inning Pete Reiser raced toward the centerfield wall, caught a terrific drive from Enos Slaughter with one hand and the next second crashed into the barrier, dropping the ball.

WASHINGTON, July 19 -- The War Production Board limited today the amount of critical materials which may be used in manufacture of officers military insignia and took steps to prevent the sale of such insignia and its use as costume jewelry by women and girls "and even by civilian men as tie holders and collar pins."

An oppressive pall of heat and humidity clamped down on New York yesterday, driving millions of persons to beaches, parks and the open highways. It was the hottest day of the year, with the temperature reaching an official peak of 92 degrees at 4:30 P.M.
LONDON, July 19 -- There has been growing discontent among the worsen of Britain over the disparities in wages that exist between men and women in almost every field of activity.
Who's going to stop Pancho?

The German High Command announced yesterday, according to German broadcasts recorded by The Associated Press, that the German armies driving deeper into Russia's southern flank were encountering "almost bottomless roads," but were continuing to pursue the "defeated Russians while the German Air Force smashed and destroyed communications and troop concentrations.

Market attendance was good last week, but ordering for Fall was cautious and in most cases limited to actual needs, according to a summary of the week's activities prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by leading resident buyers.

LONDON, July 19 -- The British Board of Trade has announced that its index of commodity prices at the end of June, based on 1930 at 100, stood at 159.8, compared with 160.7 at the end of May, 142.4 on June 30, 1941, and 98.1 at the end of August, 1939.

KEARNY, N.J., July 19 -- Three destroyers were launched here this afternoon within thirty minutes at the yard of the Federal Shipbuilding and Dry Dock Company, a subsidiary of the United States Steel Corporation.

WASHINGTON, July 19 -- The Office of Price Administration today announced revision of the fats and oils price structure in four steps designed to facilitate the orderly marketing of imported vegetable oils, tallows, greases and marine animal oils and to adjust contracts with the government or its agencies.

The latest report of the Memorial Hospital of New York is so instructive and simply worded an account of the cancer problem today and the methods adopted by physicians, chemists, biologists and clinicians to solve it that it ought to be read by any one who takes the slightest interest in scientific progress.

YONKERS, July 19 -- Mrs. Edith P. Welty, member of the Yonkers Common Council and an independent Republican, disclosed today that she had consented to run for State Senator as an independent candidate in the Twenty-sixth District.
WASHINGTON, July 19 -- Tire rationing rules were revised today to prevent beer, soft drinks and other "unessential" trucks from getting new, or recapped, tires after July 28.

A major lesson to be learned from the recent United Nations defeat in Libya and the dangerous situation in the Middle East -- where the war still can be lost -- is the necessity of carefully planned and coordinated air support for ground armies.

Bishop William T. Manning of the Protestant Episcopal Diocese of New York took issue yesterday with those who insist that it is un-Christian to pray for victory in this war. In a sermon at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine the Bishop declared that it was "not only right but our bounden duty to pray for victory."
LONDON, July 19 -- Gas made from coal or coke or charcoal in a device attached to the back of cars and trucks is being urged here now more than ever as a logical substitute for precious gasoline.

Unless those who sit around the peace table at the end of the wax have before them the plan and purposes of God, men will fail in their efforts to form a lasting peace, the Rev. Dr. Paul Mansfield Spencer declared yesterday at a special service marking the thirty-third anniversary of his pastorate at the Church of the Strangers, 309 West Fifty-seventh Street.

Net assets of the Massachusetts Investors Trust rose to $14.61 from $14.22 in the quarter which ended on June 30, according to a report released today. The number of shares outstanding rose to 6,037, 912 from 5,942,499. In the quarter the trustees bought $1,000,000 of Treasury bills.

NEW DELHI, July 19 (Reuter) -- Sir Firoz Khan Noon, new defense member of the Viceroy's Council and formerly High Commissioner for India in London, issued a statement today strongly criticizing the policy of the Congress party.

PITTSBURGH, July 19 (AP) -- The Pirates broke away from sixth place today, beating the Braves twice and squeezing into fifth place ahead of the Cubs. They took the opener, 8 -- 7, and the second, 9 -- 0.

DETROIT, July 19 -- Too bad Walter Hagen's challengers were unable to make a slightly better showing in the foursomes of the Ryder Cup challenge match, annual motor city charity golf feature. Loss of all five matches yesterday to Craig Wood's men hung millstones around the challengers' necks, and the Ryder Cup team today won the third event, 10 to 5, thus taking a 2-to-1 lead in the series.

VICHY, France, July 19 -- According to an estimate just published, French tax receipts from direct and indirect taxation covered approximately 60 per cent of the total expenditures of the State for the first eighteen months following the armistice.
PORTLAND, Ore., July 19 (AP) -- Henry J. Kaiser, West Coast shipbuilding man, proposed today that nine of the nation's shipyards be turned over to production of giant aerial freighters.

The French themselves say that there are but two kinds of Frenchmen -- those who stand firm against the Nazi enemy and those who collaborate with him. Among those who resist are the numerous Christians -- Catholics and Protestants -- whose consciences recognize the spiritual danger embodied in Hitlerism.

Thirteen weeks ago the President announced his seven-point program to control the cost of living. In the interval the general level of prices has shown virtually no advance. The cost of living is only slightly higher. Yet the underlying forces making for inflation have grown stronger.

ISTANBUL, Turkey, July 19 (U.P.) -- Travelers arriving from Berlin said today that the German capital was a city of armless, legless, eyeless war wounded, of cabbage and potatoes, watery beer and of plentiful money but little to buy.

Father Divine, the Harlem cult leader whom his followers look upon as "God," announced yesterday that he had moved from New York City to Philadelphia because of the "antagonistic and malicious" attitude that the people, public officials and press of this city had shown toward him.

Professor Clarence T. Craig of the Oberlin School of Theology, preaching yesterday morning in the Broadway Congregational Tabernacle, at Fifty-sixth Street, declared that "all men today are concerned about the high cost of living, but very few give any thought to the cost of Christian living."

WASHINGTON, July 19 (AP) -- Plans for permanent universal military training of American youth are being studied by Representative James W. Wadsworth Jr., Republican, of New York, and War Department officials.
The Rev. Dr. Harry Emerson Fosdick forecast in his sermon yesterday morning at Riverside Church, Riverside Drive and 122d Street, that "it is a world family now or else collective suicide."

BERNE, Switzerland, July 19 -- Recent speculation in authoritative American quarters on the post-war trend of British-American relations and world economic readjustments moves the Voelkischer Boebachter, Berlin newspaper, to conclude that American wartime economic policy is predicated on illusions.

CHICAGO, July 19 -- Conflicting influences again dominated the action of domestic wheat markets last week, but the rapid harvesting of the new Winter-wheat crop brought in sufficient hedging pressure to keep prices on the downgrade the greater part of the time and the active futures on the Board of Trade sold at new seasonal lows and the July went into new ground for about two months.

A hay ride may be all right in the country, but in the Bronx, on the hottest day of the season, with a cityfied driver starting the horse on a twenty-mile round trip with a load of laughing collegians in the back -- well, then it is time for Patrolman James Drum to step in.

The address by Paul V. McNutt before the American Medical Association last June emphasized what we have long known -- that qualified doctors are essential in successfully carrying out both our military and industrial effort. He threatened governmental action if more doctors did not volunteer.

Your editorial "Gandhi and India" in THE TIMES of July 16 is most timely. It presents a perfect picture of the present situation in India. It deserved being forwarded by wireless through some recognized friends of India to the leaders of the All-India Congress, including Gandhi, as well as the Moslem group and the Untouchables.

Indecision among legislators regarding the full-parity loan issue on six basic crops and the knowledge that President Roosevelt intends soon to suggest to Congress more comprehensive curbs on threatened inflation were the chief price-depressing factors in the cotton market last week.

CINCINNATI, July 19 -- The Giants couldn't do much with Bucky Walters at Crosley Field today, but they had their usual good fortune against the left-handed Johnny Vander Meer and broke even with the Reds in a double-header that attracted 17,335.

NEW DELHI, India, July 19 (London Times dispatch) -- British, and more particularly American, reaction to the resolution of the All-India Congress Working Committee at Wardha has evidently disconcerted the Congress party leaders and newspapers, it was indicated today.

CAIRO, Egypt, July 19 -- Captured twice in one day during recent desert fighting, a brigadier who commanded the New Zealand forces at E1 Ruweisat, in the central sector, managed to escape on both occasions.

Somebody has remarked that a "quick bread" is all its name implies -- quick to make and quick to disappear. And these, though they be the salient virtues, are not the only ones. For a quick bread -- so designated because it is made with a leavening that acts more speedily than yeast -- is endowed with a special talent of being able to transform the scantiest meal into something substantial.

The movement for a third-party State ticket, long rumored as a possibility, assumed definite shape yesterday when the three leading State officers of the American Labor party announced that its State executive committee would meet Monday, July 27, to fix the date and place for the State convention and make all arrangements for nominating A.L.P. candidates for Governor and other State offices.

ALBANY, July 19 -- The State Treasury is $71,789.29 richer because of an intensive drive conducted during the fiscal year just closed to salvage waste material from State institutions. Governor Lehman gave the drive an impetus more than six months ago when he directed that all waste material be saved and sold.
" Laugh, Town, Laugh!" will terminate its career on Saturday night at the Alvin, where it opened five weeks ago.
CHICAGO, July 19 (AP) -- The Phils pumped out thirteen hits today to win the first game of a double-header from the Cubs, 8 -- 5, but dropped the second, 8 -- 4.

Deliveries of gasoline under the dealer quota system, which ends tomorrow at midnight, were made yesterday to filling stations throughout the city, but virtually none of the fuel was sold to motorists, who in some cases formed queues leading to the station pumps.

WASHINGTON, July 19 -- The $6,143,900,000 revenue bill is expected to be passed tomorrow by the House and sent to the Senate where hearings on the bill will start late this week. Final passage is not expected until September

MOSCOW, Monday, July 20 -- The city of Voroshilovgrad has been evacuated by the Red Army before German troops advancing on the southern front, it was acknowledged officially this morning. The enemy advance southward from Millerovo toward Rostov had threatened the Russians at Voroshilovgrad with encirclement and abandonment of the city had been expected.
MOSCOW, Monday, July 20 (AP) -- The Russians announced yesterday that United States and British tanks, as well as planes, were bolstering the Russian lines in the imperiled south.

The Rev. Dr. Raymond C. Knox, chaplain emeritus of Columbia University, declared in his sermon yesterday morning at St. Paul's Chapel, on the campus, that "the winning of freedom is a spiritual struggle."
" Paddy" Finucane was one of the few to whom the many owe so much. His very name epitomized his fighting spirit, and his shamrock-marked Spitfire was always in the van of aerial battle.
WASHINGTON, July 19 (U.P.) -- The Navy Department announced tonight that two medium-sized United States merchant ships had been sunk by enemy submarines, one by torpedo and the other by shell fire.

ANKARA, Turkey, July 18 (Delayed) -- General Draja Mikhailovitch of Yugoslavia has launched a campaign to stamp out Communist partisan bands accused of marauding Serbian and Bosnian villages in territory controlled by the Loyalist Yugoslav armies, according to reports reaching foreign military intelligence sources in Turkey today.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 19 -- Charles R. Rogers, United Artists producer, has borrowed George Murphy from Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer, Priscilla Lane from Warner Brothers and Carole Landis from Twentieth Century-Fox to head the cast of his forthcoming "The Powers Girls," his company announced.

As the first step toward organization of "a unified national budget of war appeals," Winthrop W. Aldrich, president, and Sir Robert R. Appleby, vice president, of the British War Relief Society, will explain to the executive committee of the National Budget Committee for War Appeals tomorrow proposed expenditures in the British War Relief appeal for $7,500,000.

Last week the Irving Fisher index of wholesale commodity prices dropped from 108.4 to 108.2 The farm products index had the sharpest downturn of the year, declining by 0.9 per cent. In this index, lower price quotations for poultry and potatoes exceeded higher prices for eggs and oranges.

In this year of "gas"-less grace, Gotham for the first time in a long history has become a Summer resort. And 1942 -- along with the sugar ration and the frozen silhouette -- has introduced the strange phenomenon of outdoor sports amid the skyscrapers.

PATERSON, N.J., July 19 -- Employes of five plants of the Wright Aeronautical Corporation in this area ratified today a contract made by committees representing the company and the Wright Aeronautical Employes Association, an unaffiliated union which is the bargaining agent for 18,000 production workers.

Dr. John L. Rice, who resigned as Commissioner of Health last week, can look back on eight years of distinguished service to the people of this city. He would not take credit for the decline in the death rates of pneumonia, infectious diseases and diseases of infancy, which seem to be part of a general trend.

When Mr. Churchill was in Washington last month, a great many people were puzzled by his stout optimism in regard to the Egyptian front. At that time Marshal Rommel had driven the British out of Matruh and was pushing full speed toward Alexandria. The capital was gloomy and anxious over the outlook, but the Prime Minister was cheerful.

The four-story apartment building for forty-four families at 77-9 Pennington Avenue, Passaic, N.J., was sold by the Fidelity Union Trust Company of Newark, as trustee, to Edward Monett of Westfield, N.J., for investment. It is on a plot 100 by 172 feet and was sold for cash over a mortgage of $98,000.

CAIRO, Egypt, July 19 -- Troops of the British Empire held their positions yesterday on the crescent-shaped front that extends southward from the region of El Alamein, despite counter-attacks by the Axis forces of General Field Marshal Erwin Rommel.

WASHINGTON, July 19 -- Vice President Henry A. Wallace, through absenteeism in the Senate, as well as through close contests there, has become a voting Vice President with a record unmatched so far as Congressional memory reaches.

CHICAGO, July 19 -- Harvesting of the new oats crop is now well along toward completion in parts of Illinois and Iowa, and the threat of a fairly liberal movement of new grain led to liquidation and hedging pressure on the market which carried prices off sharply.

Increased employment of Negroes in war industries, indicating a relaxation in racial discrimination and acceleration of Negro labor's contribution to the war, was reported in the findings of a survey made public yesterday by William H. Baldwin, president of the National Urban League.

WASHINGTON, July 19 -- In a summary of its wartime activities the Federal Trade Commission reported today that it is being called upon constantly by other government agencies to use its investigative, legal, accounting and other services in the futherance of the war effort.

AKRON, Ohio, July 19 (AP) -- Upsetting expectations, 14-year-old Charles Weeks 3d of Massillon won the all-gauge title at the fifth annual Midwest skeet shoot today by breaking 150 consecutive targets.

CHUNGKING, China, July 19 (AP) -- A smashing come-back against the major Japanese drives in Chekiang and Kiangsi Provinces was reported today by the Chinese High Command, which announced the recapture of Juian, Chekiang seaport, and the breaking of the invaders' grip on the Hangchow-Nanchang railway along a fifteen-mile stretch by the seizure of Iyang and Hengfeng.
WASHINGTON, July 19 -- The Washington Post announced today that for the duration of the war it would "report briefly, if at all, on any purely social event."

Petroleum Coordinator Harold L. Ickes believes that the pipe line to be constructed between the Texas oil fields and Norris City, Ill., should be extended to Bayonne, N.J., Mayor La Guardia announced yesterday in his weekly radio "Talk to the People" from his desk at City Hall

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., July 19 -- Mr. and Mrs. Robert Jay Williams gave a buffet luncheon today at Northwick, their place at North Sea, for Mr. and Mrs. J. Oakley Radway, whose marriage took place recently and who are at their Summer home in Quogue for the season.

A special meeting of holders of common stock of the Community Power and Light Company will be held in Newark on Aug. 17 to consider a proposed merger of the concern and General Public Utilities, Inc., into the Southwestern Public Service Company, which forms part of a plan of integration and simplification announced on July 10.
Active renting of apartments in buildings on Riverside Drive, West End Avenue and other thoroughfares on the West Side was reported by managing agents over the week-end.

Because he is busy with defense construction work in Connecticut, John J. Campagna of Campagna Sons, Inc., builders, has sold his residence, on a plot of about three-quarters of an acre, at South and Sunny Ridge Roads, in Harrison, to William L. Searles of Rye.
For two and one-half years Patrolman Joseph Russo of the Riverside Drive station has been the bane of dog owners. In that time he has served 3,000 summonses for various violations concerning pets.
MOSCOW, July 19 (AP) -- The Soviet Information Bureau issued this communique today:
LONDON, July 19 -- The entire international statistical position of wheat is overshadowed by the enormous surplus in the United States. Commenting on this Broomhalls Corn Trade News says:
NEWARK, N.J., July 19 (AP) -- Newark swept both ends of a double-header with Montreal today, 6 -- 5 and 4 -- 0.

The five-and-a-half-story showroom building at 13 East Fortieth Street has been purchased by a client of Adams Co., who negotiated the sale in cooperation with Horace S. Ely Co. It is on a lot 25 by 100 feet and is assessed at $100,000.

BOSTON, July 19 (U.P.) -- A four-day strike at the Monsanto Chemical Company and the New England Alcohol Company which had threatened to disrupt war production in more than 250 New England industries, employing 500,000 persons, was settled tonight.

PHILADELPHIA, July 19 (AP) -- The Tigers and Athletics divided a double-header today, Detroit winning the opener, 2 to 1, to end a six-game losing streak and Philadelphia romping off with the nightcap, 4 to 3, to snap a string of five defeats.

The death a few days ago of Joseph J. McAuliffe, who retired last year as managing editor of the St. Louis Globe-Democrat, may be said to mark the end of an era in St. Louis journalism. He was among several now gone from that scene who were known to newspaper men the country over as the makers of St. Louis legend.

The movement for voluntary fingerprinting of New Yorkers as a precaution during the war was commended yesterday by Professor Samuel H. Prince of King's College, Halifax, N.S., who preached at St. Stephen's Episcopal Church, 128 West Sixty-ninth Street.

CHICAGO, July 19 -- Dry and hot weather prevailed over the greater part of the big surplus grain-producing areas last week, which experts say is an ideal condition at this season. Not only did the favorable weather conditions facilitate harvesting of small grains in the Southwest, West and Central West, but also resulted in corn and soy beans making the best growth of any week so far this season.

PHILADELPHIA, July 19 -- Joe Angyal will go into naval aviation training in the immediate future as the possessor of the most prized championship in the seventieth annual National Association of Amateur Oarsmen meet. The 26-year-old New York City fireman today slammed to a smashing five-length triumph on the Schuylkill River as the two-day rowing show came to an end.

SENECA FALLS, N.Y., July 19 -- Ninety-four years ago today and tomorrow, a group of women and men "radicals" adopted a declaration of woman's rights as they met in a little Wesleyan chapel in Seneca Falls.
ONE thing that the National Boxing Association's ratings brought pleasantly to light was the number of fighters where good fighters are really needed: in the service ranks.

Following tremendous publicity, and in a spirit reflective of the enthusiasm and the gratitude that the people of this nation feel today toward Russia, defending in oceans of blood humanity's cause, the American premiere of the much-heralded Seventh Symphony of Dmitri Shostakovich, musical banner-bearer of his people, was given yesterday afternoon in Radio City by the NBC Symphony Orchestra, under the leadership of Arturo Toscanini, to shattering applause.
WASHINGTON, July 19 (AP) -- The Browns ended the Senators' five-game winning streak with a vengeance today, taking both ends of a double-header, 5 -- 3 and 6 -- 3.

George J. Atwell, president of the Thompson Starrett Company, Inc., and long influential in Tammany, announced yesterday the organization of a State-wide committee to support the candidacy of Attorney General John J. Bennett Jr. for the Democratic nomination for Governor.

The mass slaughter of defenseless populations by the Nazis will be condemned at a mass meeting to be held tomorrow evening in Madison Square Garden under the joint auspices of the American Jewish Congress, the Jewish Labor Committee and B'nai Brith.

Idle machines, vacant industrial space and the sight of jobless men scanning "Help Wanted" signs in front of employment agencies combine to present an unhappy and incongruous picture in the metropolis of a nation whose manpower and resources generally, have been mobilized.

NEW ORLEANS, July 19 -- Fresh doubts as to the fate of the full parity loan bill and anti-inflationary talk in Washington threw the cotton futures market into a state of nervous uncertainty most of the last week and except for a momentary recovery period around mid-week, the trend was decidedly lower.

MOSCOW, July 19 -- A call to the armies of the South to stem the enemy's advance toward territory "whose capture would increase tenfold the threat to our land" was published by Red Star, the army newspaper, this morning.

Bent on ending the home stand with a grand flourish, the Yankee steamroller regaled a crowd of 40,785 at the Stadium yesterday by landing on the White Sox with crushing force and literally smothering Jimmy Dykes's hapless Chicagoans in both ends of the double-header.

WASHINGTON, July 19 -- A shortage of power to a degree which would impede war production was predicted today by the Brookings Institution unless a comprehensive program of expansion, conservation and more effective utilization was undertaken immediately.

ALFRED WOLFE, born Alfred Wolfhechel in Denmark fifty-five years ago, is a deep sea fisherman with the barnacles on, not the sporting variety that pursues tarpon and tuna for thrills and photographic trophies. Halibut, herring and salmon netted and hooked out of Pacific waters from the Columbia River to Kodiak Island have provided him a living for forty years.
WASHINGTON, July 19 -- Government officials who have been complaining about the congestion at railroad terminals are, it now develops, themselves partly to blame.

A sudden decision on the part of Buddy Rosar to insure for himself at some distant date the life of a Buffalo policeman almost caused the Yankees to be caught without a catcher for their double-header with the White Sox at the Stadium yesterday.

The production of Johann Strauss's "The Gypsy Baron," which was presented at the Cosmopolitan Opera House June 19 and 20 and then repeated on June 27 because of its initial success, will be presented at the Lewisohn Stadium on Thursday night, July 30.

LONDON, July 19 -- The Economist's index of British commodity prices, based on 1927 as 100, was 111.7 on July 7. This compares with 110.7 a fortnight before, 111.2 a month before, 105.2 a year before and 70.3 at the end of August, 1939.
LONDON, July 19 (AP) -- The Air Ministry tonight issued the following communique:

NEW ORLEANS, July 19 -- The Maritime Commission's order Saturday stopping construction of the huge Higgins Corporation shipyards here for the reason that the necessary steel was needed more for "existing construction" of ships was described by Mayor Robert S. Maestri as "a disaster and a staggering blow at the progress and faith of a great city."

Tokyo's claims of damage inflicted upon the United States Navy in the Battle of Midway early in June were put out yesterday in a radio address to the Japanese people by Captain Hidake Hirade, chief of the navy press section of Imperial Headquarters, according to a Japanese broadcast recorded by The United Press at San Francisco.

JERSEY CITY, July 19 (AP) -- Jersey City snapped its six-game losing streak by taking the first game of its double-header with Toronto, 7 -- 2, today, but earned no more than an even break, as the Leafs came back to annex the nightcap, 4 -- 1.

The United Fruit Company, perhaps the largest concern in the United States trading with South and Central America, announced yesterday that it had adopted as a "fundamental policy" the development in this hemisphere of natural products formerly imported from the Far East.

CHUNGKING, China, July 19 -- The Chinese are having more money today than ever before in their history. Recent statistics show that deposits in Chinese banks amounted to 2,500,000,000 Chinese dollars, which is more than three times the deposits in 1936.

In so far as financial markets were governed by last week's war news, little was reflected except uncertainty. The actual war dispatches varied in their implication and, during most of the week, markets were virtually motionless: this notwithstanding that, in the general view, there seemed to be much discouragement over the Russian campaign.

LONDON, July 19 -- Undaunted by an estimated 1,000,000 reprisal executions, conquered Europe's underground "V" army was keeping 645,000 square miles of Axis-occupied territory in constant turmoil tonight, one year after the mysterious "Colonel Britton" broadcast over the London radio the call for its mobilization.
The USO National War Fund now has raised $15,156,417 toward its Spring-Summer goal of $20,000,000, Prescott S. Bush, national campaign chairman, announced yesterday.

The Office of Scientific Research and Development was established to conduct research for the Army and Navy, and the National Inventors' Council to tap the country's general ingenuity. But there was no office to test inventions that would provide us with substitutes, speed up transportation by land and sea, examine and standardize industrial processes and such widely different products as trucks and tugboats.
The following German High Command communique was broadcast from Berlin yesterday and was recorded here by The Associated Press:

CHICAGO, July 19 -- Fifty thousand Chicagoans of Slavic origin rededicated themselves to the defeat of the Axis powers today at a patriotic celebration in Soldier Field. The occasion was the 532d anniversary of the Battle of Grunwald, in which the Slavs united to defeat the Teutonic warriors.

Fifteen-day woodcock seasons again have been allotted for this Fall, according to an announcement by Secretary of the Interior Harold L. Ickes. Hunters will be permitted to seek them from sunrise to sunset during those periods, subject to four-a-day bag and eight-bird possession limits.

SOUTH ORANGE, N.J., July 19 -- Residents of the Newstead section of South Orange announced today that they were prepared for either land or air invasion by enemy troops, regardless of what is being done by the Army or their own municipality.

WASHINGTON, July 19 -- An informed official indicated today that President Roosevelt might step into the muddled wage control problem to bring about agreement within his Administration on the question.

BOSTON, July 19 (AP) -- The Indians shaved the Red Sox's grip on second place to a single game today as they took both ends of a double-header, winning, 10 -- 7, with a three-run twelfth inning in the opener and taking the second, 4 -- 0, on Mel Harder's three-hit shut-out.

Results of cancer experiments in many institutions in the last two years "begin to form a discernible picture clearer than has ever been available before, though it still contains gaps," it is declared in a review of recent cancer investigations by Dr. C.P. Rhoads, director of the Memorial Hospital for the Treatment of Cancer and Allied Diseases.

LOS ANGELES, July 19 -- Although white Americans have been guilty of an attitude toward Negroes that had "some of the unlovely characteristics of an alien imperialism," they are dropping race prejudice under pressure of the war, Wendell L. Willkie said here today.

LONDON, July 19 -- Boston bombers of the Royal Air Force attacked German objectives in the Lille and Bethune areas of occupied France this afternoon while squadrons of Spitfires and Hurricanes dived on Nazi warships off the Breton coast, hitting the bridge of one armed vessel and bombing a new type of enemy minesweeper.

RIDGWAY, Pa., July 19 (AP) -- At least eight persons lost their lives in a "flash" flood which devastated towns and villages, made hundreds of persons homeless and caused uncounted property damage over a wide area in North Central Pennsylvania today.

LONDON, July 19 -- Decorating some Czech airmen with their country's Military Cross and medal for gallantry today, Dr. Edouard Benes, President of Czechoslovakia, said that the next time he visited their squadron he hoped it would be on a second front on the European Continent.

Stephen Vincent Benet announced yesterday that Margaret Walker of Birmingham, Ala., is the winner of the 1942 Yale Series of Younger Poets competition. Her book, "For My People," a collection of poems, will be published in the Fall by Yale University Press.
WASHINGTON, July 19 -- The trial of the eight Nazi sabotage agents who sneaked ashore from submarines will probably be completed early this week.

PITTSBURGH, July 19 -- Despite the recent War Labor Board decision which granted C.I.O. workers in "Little Steel" a 44-cents-a-day pay increase, the Weirton Independent Union intends to press its demands for a general increase of $1.25 a day.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., July 19 -- Carl Buhr's Tidsfordriv, Jack Chayne's Gadgette and Dorothy Quortrup's Ripple sailed away with War Bonds for prizes by winning in their divisions in the annual regatta of the Handicap Class conducted by the New Rochelle Yacht Club today.
BERGENFIELD, N.J., July 19 -- Gypsy, an audacious pet crow with an impish heart and a weakness for glittering objects, is conducting a reign of confusion in this peaceful community.

MOSCOW, July 19 (U.P.) -- Russian warships, planes and submarines fought an all-day battle recently with 200 German planes and a submarine fleet attacking a large Allied convoy bound for Murmansk, enabling it to arrive with minimum losses, the newspaper Pravda reported today.

STAMFORD, Conn., July 19 -- In the most tantalizing session of the Summer the ninth of the Long Island Sound championship regattas was held today by the Stamford Yacht Club and it was barely squeezed within the time limit.
Nurses as well as patients are getting attention these troubled days. With 3,000 nurses being called to the armed forces each month, a shortage on the home front is in sharp evidence.

The Social Science Research Council of 230 Park Avenue yesterday announced the presentation of sixty-five awards, totaling $77,700, for the academic year 1942-43. These awards provide for research and study in economics, political science, sociology, statistics, political, social and economic history, cultural anthropology, social psychology, geography and related fields.

Additional wartime protection for the Port of New York is planned in a seven-point program made public yesterday by the Coast Guard. Formation of a new Coast Guard contingent, known as the Port Security Regiment and described as "a fast-moving, hard-hitting group of picked men," is part of the program.

PITTSBURGH, July 19 -- The tight scrap situation and an increase in the number of necessary furnace repairs prevented any important increase in steel production last week. Steel ingot output throughout the country moved up fractionally to 98 1/2 per cent of rated capacity.

MOSCOW, July 19 (AP) -- Tass, official Soviet news agency, today reiterated reports that French merchant ships were taking reinforcements and supplies to General Field Marshal Erwin Rommel's armies in North Africa.

Because "there is no mercy among people today," the modern world needs "the mercy of God more than ever before," the Rev. Walter P. Kellenberg, vice-chancellor of the Archdiocese of New York, declared yesterday at solemn mass in St Patrick's Cathedral.

The order issued Saturday by Lieut. Gen. Hugh A. Drum restricting civilian flying along the Atlantic seacoast left operators of airports in the metropolitan area completely confused yesterday. They knew no more about it than what they had read in the newspapers, and, not having received any definite instructions, carried on "as usual."

RYE, N.Y., July 19 -- Hardit S. Malik, trade commissioner for India, and Dr. William A. Hillis of the Greenwich Country Club, a dentist, won the sixth annual Apawamis Club member-guest invitation golf tournament today. With a best-ball score of five-under-par, they defeated Revell McCallum and Will N. Robins of Apawamis, yesterday's medalists, 3 and 1.
MOSCOW, July 19 -- The American or Briton visiting Russia today quickly learns the meaning of the terse Russian question:
RIO DE JANEIRO, Brazil, July 19 -- At midnight all private and official automobiles -- about 22,000 -- were barred from operation in Rio de Janeiro to conserve gasoline.
RIO DE JANEIRO, Brazil, July 19 -- At midnight all private and official automobiles -- about 22,000 -- were barred from operation in Rio de Janeiro to conserve gasoline.

PITTSBURGH, July 19 -- The tight scrap situation and an increase in the number of necessary furnace repairs prevented any important increase in steel production last week. Steel ingot output throughout the country moved up fractionally to 98 1/2 per cent of rated capacity.

MOSCOW, July 19 (AP) -- Tass, official Soviet news agency, today reiterated reports that French merchant ships were taking reinforcements and supplies to General Field Marshal Erwin Rommel's armies in North Africa.
WASHINGTON, July 19 -- Seneca Falls Day was celebrated by the National Woman's Party with a reception held at the party headquarters, Alva Belmont House, here.

DETROIT, July 20 (AP) -- A plan to register all women in the Detroit area available for war production work in arms factories was announced today by Ernest Kanzler, chief of the automotive branch of the' War Production Board, and Edward L. Keenan, regional representative of the United States Employment Service.
The heat wave continued for its second day in the city yesterday with undiminished ardor, but the official forecast was for somewhat cooler weather today.

As part of their Summer war duties, New York's teachers are taking courses in subjects ranging from aeronautics and air raid precautions to clothing conservation, according to a report issued yesterday by the Committee on Civilian Defense in the Schools, of which Assistant Superintendent C. Frederick Pertsch is Administrator.

WASHINGTON, July 20 (AP) -- Fresh evidence of the enormous amount of war materials and other supplies being delivered to Britain came today in a Navy Department announcement of the posthumous award of the Distinguished Service Medal to the commander of a North Atlantic naval force.

Switching to the buying side in the cotton market late yesterday, New Orleans interests assembled sufficient pressure to return prices 10 points from the session's low levels which its earlier selling and commission-house liquidation had established, but this support was unable to bridge completely losses that had exceeded, for the third successive session, 20 points.

BUFFALO, July 20 -- Buddy Rosar, father of a new 8 1/2-pound boy, said tonight he would report to the Yankees tomorrow night in Cleveland after Joe McCarthy, manager of the world champions, announced he had fined the Yankee catcher $250 for leaving the club without permission.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., July 20 -- Many prominent women of the Summer colony have volunteered to serve in the new canteen for service men of the armed forces stationed in this vicinity, which will open here on Thursday afternoon in a building adjacent to the Morris studio in Main Street.

WESTBURY, L.I., July 20 -- Under a Nassau County ruling that had just become effective, the last two events of the Roosevelt Raceway twilight harness racing program were staged under arc lights tonight.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, July 20 -- On a site near ancient Jubeil, or Byblos, which according to Roman tradition was the oldest city in the world, Australian Army engineers have uncovered part of a burial ground dating back 400 years before Christ.

With Russia much in the news today, it was interesting to see that in his Fall and Winter collection Erik paid the courageous country special honor. The hat that attracted most attention was the "bashlyk," taken from the draped hood worn by the peasants of the Caucasus.

WASHINGTON, July 20 -- With almost eleven long days of evidence piled up against the eight Nazi saboteurs who landed on the Long Island and Florida seacoasts last month, the government rested its case today and left it to the defense to start making the answers before the military commission tomorrow.

Because a "word of mouth" campaign has proved the most effective in recruiting volunteers, Mrs. Walter G. Bunzl, new director of recruiting for the Greater New York Civilian Defense Volunteer Office, will aim at creating an "esprit de corps" among OCD workers as one of the first tasks in her new job, she revealed yesterday.

WASHINGTON, July 20 -- The conference report on the $1,858,939,210 first supplemental national defense appropriation bill was approved today after Representative Taber, leader of the fight against providing $120,000,000 for the Office of Price Administration, announced that he had withdrawn his objections because the dispute was holding up funds for eighteen other war agencies.

Filling stations throughout the metropolitan district were "raided" yesterday by motorists in large numbers seeking to Till their gasoline tanks against the start of the permanent rationing system along the Eastern seaboard at midnight tonight Lines began forming as early as 7 A.M. and shifted from place to place as dealers' pumps went dry.

TRENTON, N.J., July 20 -- The engagement of Dr. Leland Spencer of Cornell University, an authority on problems of milk production and distribution, to direct an extensive study of the cost of milk distribution in New Jersey was announced here today by State Secretary of Agriculture Willard H. Allen.

An audience of 14,000 heard Yehudi Menuhin play with the New York Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra last night at the Lewisohn Stadium, wholly unaware that the soloist had not rehearsed with the group. There were no slips in coordination to reveal the fact.

It is always pleasant to learn that a young soldier has been able to carry his art along into the armed service. This has happened with Joe Russo of Brooklyn. Joe, who is 23 now and with General MacArthur's forces, began to play the bass viol when he was 8 years old.

The present Japanese campaign to clean up South China in a hurry is meeting with obstacles. Among these are the few but effective fliers of the United States Army Air Force and possibly some new heavy artillery. More important, certainly, is the unbeatable quality of the Chinese soldier.

WASHINGTON, July 20 -- The House passed today by a vote of 392 to 2 the largest tax bill in history, estimated by Secretary Morgenthau to produce $6,271,200,000, to bring the total cash income of the Federal Government next year to about $24,000,000,000.

PITTSBURGH, July 20 -- Larry French, bouncing back from his disastrous meeting with the Cardinals on Saturday, tonight sent the Dodgers back home six and one-hall games ahead of the second-place Redbirds by shutting out the Pirates, 5 -- 0, on five hits.

WASHINGTON, July 20 -- The opening of a new front in Europe "now" was urged upon President Roosevelt and members of Congress today by delegates of the Committee of Industrial Organizations headed by Joseph Curran, president of the National Maritime Union.

WASHINGTON, July 20 -- Under a project being studied by government agencies, thousands of pieces of machinery made idle by War Production Board curtailment orders affecting civilian industries would be acquired by the government and shipped to Latin-American nations for the production of goods which now occupy space on south-bound vessels.

WASHINGTON, July 20 -- Aroused by the order of President James C. Petrillo of the American Federation of Musicians that amateur talent must be shut off the air, James L. Fly, chairman of the Federal Communications Commission, will urge a study of Mr. Petrillo's actions in this and other situations, the chairman said today.

BOSTON, July 20 (AP) -- The Navy awarded the Navy Cross today to Lieutenant Robert B. Kelly, 29-year-old New Yorker, for "distinguished conduct and extraordinary courage in combat" as commander of a torpedo boat which sank a Japanese cruiser in the Philippine Islands.

Magistrates Courts spokesmen denied yesterday charges of case-fixing, bail bond and other irregularities in the Women's Court laid before Mayor La Guardia recently by the court's Social Service Bureau.

The New York State War Ballot Commission opened offices yesterday at 2 Lafayette Street and four uniformed members of the armed forces were the first to obtain applications for election ballots, which will be sent to them later.

Father Divine, Harlem cult leader who announced on Sunday that he had moved his residence from New York to Philadelphia because of "disrecognition" here, failed yesterday to file a $5,000 bond required by the Appellate Division as a condition of granting, pending appeal, a stay of a Supreme Court order directing him to pay $100 a week toward satisfaction of a $5,949 judgment obtained two years ago but still unpaid.

The Giants came home last night prepared, despite a couple of casualties, for a stand that will keep them in the East for more than a month. Manager Mel Ott was highly satisfied with the team's third invasion of the West. The Polo Grounders played .500 ball on the trip, winning six games and losing as many.

A couple of fellows named Joe, Phillips of the Links Club and Katz of Kissena Park, managed to share in the lead twice, once with each other and once with other partners, when the Long Island P.G.A. amateur-pro one-day tournament ended in a three-cornered tie at the Oakland Golf Club in Bayside yesterday.
The following German High Command communique was broadcast from Berlin yesterday and was recorded here by The Associated Press:

Inflation, about which we are hearing so much, means higher prices. That definition, if accepted, as it generally is, creates an interesting and rather startling paradox. For everybody wants higher prices for labor or whatever he has to sell, but nobody wants inflation.

ARDSLEY-ON-HUDSON, N.Y., July 20 -- The fourt seeded players reached the semi-final bracket of the seventh annual girls invitation tennis tournament for the Mrs. G. Roy Lucas Trophy at the Ardsley Country Club today.

CHICAGO, July 20 (AP) -- A group of landlords and real estate owners from twenty cities today contended that OPA rent ceilings were too low in many defense areas and called upon Leon Henderson, Price Administrator, to hold a conference within ten days to consider revisions.

LONDON, July 20 -- Recognition that the big bomber is the most useful component of any nation's air force was given in Jane's "All the World's Aircraft, 1941," published today. The experience of the war has vindicated the faith placed by United States designers in that type of machine, the foreword holds.

Canadian holdings in the common and preferred shares of United States Steel Corporation declined moderately in the second quarter of 1942, according to the company's quarterly report on stockholders. Common shares owned in Canada were 105,652, comparing with 107,317 three months before and 106,200 at the end of 1941.

William J. Mericka Co., Inc., of Cleveland, and associates won yesterday the award of a new issue of $480,000 city of Akron, Ohio, refunding bonds on a bid of 101.281 for 2 1/4s. The bonds, dated Aug. 1, 1942, will mature serially from Sept. 1, 1943 to 1966.
WASHINGTON, July 20 (AP) -- A suggestion that all future wage increases be paid in bonds cashable after the war came from William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor, today.

The campaign of Thomas E. Dewey for Governor on the Republican ticket, which has been under way for several years, was formally launched yesterday with the opening of a "Dewey for Governor" headquarters at 1 East Forty-third Street by a committee of twelve men long associated with Mr. Dewey in the Young Republican Clubs.

The regular monthly meeting of the board of trustees of the Police Pension Fund yesterday was marked by loud arguments which, according to Police Headquarters sources, featured the balloting on the retirement application of Inspector Camille C. Pierne, suspended Brooklyn officer.

MOSCOW, Tuesday, July 21 (U.P.) -- The Soviet radio reported today that Russian infantry with tank and plane support had captured an inhabited place northwest of Voronezh and severed communications between German units. The Germans lost fifty tanks in attempts to hold positions east of the Don, the radio said, and at one point Russian troops swam across the river and forced the enemy to retreat.

WASHINGTON, July 20 -- William Phillips, former United States Ambassador to Rome, has been sent to London as chief of the United States Office of Strategic Services in the British capital, it was learned today.

The noise from machinery in a small factory on the East Side making vital war materials is such that tenants in an adjacent apartment house cannot get to sleep until 4 o'clock in the morning, Magistrate Raphael P. Koenig was told in Municipal Term Court yesterday.

Eleven railroads carried on their fight for a 10 per cent increase in commutation rates in intra-State traffic at the first of a series of hearings before the Interstate Commerce Commission in the Hotel St. George, Brooklyn, yesterday. In February the New York State Public Service Commmission denied their plea for higher rates.
CAMDEN, N.J., July 20 (AP) -- A crowd of 6,814 turned out today for the second day of racing at America's newest race track, Garden State Park. A total of $303,578 was wagered on the eight-race card.
VICHY, France, July 20 -- The methods of managed economy that have been adapted in French industry under German aegis are to be attempted now in agriculture, it was learned today.

LONDON, July 20 (U.P.) -- The wife of Leopold III, King of the Belgians, has given birth to a son, who has been named Alexander Emmanuel Henry Albert Maria Leopold, the German radio announced today in a Brussels dispatch.

PHILADELPHIA, July 20 -- Representatives of the financial industry and the Securities and Exchange Commission in an unprecedented meeting here today laid the groundwork for a continuing study of war and post-war problems of mutual concern.

Earnings of the General Electric Company for the first half of this year were 21 per cent below those of the corresponding six months of 1941, despite an increase of 37 per cent in net sales billed during the period, according to the semiannual statement of Charles E. Wilson, president, issued for publication today.
OLEAN, N.Y., July 20 (AP) -- Flood waters of the upper Allegheny River receded rapidly today in the Olean area after taking three lives and driving 2,000 persons from their homes.

MOSCOW, Tuesday, July 21 -- Red Army forces in the Voronezh area have seized several Don River crossings and are continuing their powerful blows at the enemy, who has been forced on the defensive and is feverishly building fortifications and planting mines on the river banks, the Soviet High Command announced in a communique this morning.

The Southern Pacific Railroad may move to reopen hearings to import temporarily Mexican track workers to fill a vital labor shortage in its maintenance of way forces, it was said yesterday by W.H. Kirkbride, chief engineer for the company.

WASHINGTON, July 20 -- The Civil Aeronautics Authority began today a survey of the potential effect of new restrictions along the East Coast upon the contract flying schools which it maintains as "direct feeders" for Army and Navy flying services.

The response to letters sent out by the Yonkers Savings Bank urging 1,827 mortgagors to purchase bombardment insurance from the War Damage Corporation, with the policies to be filed with the bank, has been "considerable," according to a round-up on savings bank activities conducted by the New York State Savings Banks Association.

The German forces have resumed large-scale operations in Southern Russia after heavy rains and are continuing the pursuit of retreating Red Army troops, the German High Command announced yesterday, according to German broadcasts recorded by The Associated Press.

AMSTERDAM, N.Y., July 20 -- Before the largest crowd ever to attend a baseball game in Amster dam, the Yankees defeated their farm club, the Amsterdam Rugmakers, today, 9 to 5, with a thrilling tenth inning rally. A crowd of 4,034 paid to see the game.
LONDON, July 20 -- The week opened quietly, war news having an effect on practically all sections of the London market. Gilt-edged securities remained steady, practically no changes being recorded.

CHUNGKING, China, July 20 -- According to an official broadcast from Shanghai the Italian-owned liner Conte Verde, the repatriation ship due at Lourenco Marques, Portuguese East Africa, on Wednesday, is carrying 636 Americans aboard, of whom about 400 are missionaries, diplomats and newspaper men from Shanghai.

WASHINGTON, July 20 (AP) -The men of the Army have "one objective -- to get the job done, to train to perfection and then go over and finish the job," Representative Vreeland of East Orange, N.J., said today when he returned to his seat in Congress after almost seven months of Army training.

Beaten eleven lengths his last time out, Mrs. C. Tumin's bay colt Burgaway broke on top in the Glenwood Purse at Empire City yesterday and stayed there for the full five and three-quarter furlongs to turn back the favored Ben Gray by a length and a half.
Fifty passengers on a northbound Eighth Avenue bus became panic-stricken last night at about 8 o'clock when a passenger, shouting angrily, stabbed his wife and himself with a clasp knife.

LONDON, July 20 -- Members of the Women's Royal Naval Service, knows as the "Wrens," are now acting as "grease monkeys" for the British Fleet Air Arm. In the past few months large numbers of "Wrens" have been trained in the maintenance and repairs of aircraft and soon they will be able to take over most of the servicing of navy planes ashore.

LONDON, July 20 -- An official bulletin of the Norwegian Government announced today that Norway had definitely abandoned the pre-war project of a Nordic defensive bloc and, instead, based her hope of future security on attachment to her Atlantic allies, Great Britain and the United States.
LONDON, July 20 (AP) -- An Air Ministry communique said today:

Despite the turn in favor of the Russians on the Upper Don and strong resistance in the south the Soviet armies are still in great peril. They cannot continue to give up territory without abandoning resources vital to their continued effectiveness. They cannot afford to yield the oil fields of the Caucasus, upon which they depend for almost the whole of their gasoline supply.

WASHINGTON, July 20 -- Simplification of sizes and standards of all hand tools is contemplated under terms of a limitation order issued today by the War Production Board. The order is made immediately applicable to hand shovels, spades, scoops and telegraph "spoons" (long-handled shovels used for digging holes for telegraph poles), but is expected to be extended to many other lines in the near future.

Apparently even fish are altering their habits in this changing world. At least that is the impression being given rod and reel devotees now seeking striped bass in the popular Cuttyhunk Island area, according to information from Dick Waterhouse.
I wonder whether our Congressmen will ever learn to consider their constituents as fairly intelligent and mature people who do not need to be petted and babied.

A tie-up of all naval construction work in the New York area, involving projects amounting to $100,000,000, was threatened yesterday by building craftsmen of the American Federation of Labor in protest against employment of 1,100 men of the Work Projects Administration on construction of the $4,000,000 Naval Reserve Officers Training School at Fort Schuyler in the Bronx.

Major Gen. Robert M. Danford, commandant of the City Patrol Corps, said yesterday that Miss Lena Guenther, 35-year-old sergeant in the Staten Island unit of the corps, had been dropped from the rolls for a reason he would not state.

CHICAGO, July 20 -- Johnny Lehman of Chicago, one of the last of 210 golfers who trudged around Tom O'Shanter's rugged layout today, came in with a sub-par 71 to pace the field in the first eighteen-hole qualifying trials of the All-American amateur tournament.
MOSCOW, Tuesday, July 21 (AP) -- The Soviet Information Bureau's communique of last midnight:

WILLEMSTAD, Curacao, July 20 (AP) -- A.S. Oppenheim, presiding at the annual stockholders meeting of the Royal Dutch Petroleum Company, today expressed confidence in a rapid growth of his companies and the petroleum industry in general after the war, Aneta, the Netherlands Indies news agency, reported.

A controversy arose yesterday as to who is authorized to revive Karel Capek's play, "R.U.R." The Theatre Guild, original sponsor of the work here twenty years ago, owns the production rights, according to Warren P. Munsell, general manager, the Guild having renewed its rights last Autumn from Paul Selver, translater of the play into English and controller of the basic rights.

PATERSON, N.J., July 20 -- Working at night after the heat of day forced them to lay their tools aside, eighty employes of the Wright Aeronautical Company completed here last night a recreation hall for soldiers. All materials for the building were paid for out of $1,824 contributed by the workers in the various Wright plants in this area and the men who erected the building worked on their normal day off from engine building.

" Mrs. Miniver," the first picture to play seven consecutive weeks in the ten-year history of the Radio City Music Hall, will enter its eighth week on Thursday, the management reported yesterday. At the close of business on Sunday night, total attendance for the engagement stood at 1,002,603 persons, with 84,024 persons having seen the film from Thursday through Sunday.
MOSCOW, July 20 (AP) -- The Soviet Information Bureau issued this communique today:

MOSCOW, July 20 (AP) -- A Tass correspondent "with the Northern Fleet" described today a battle lasting three days and nights between German planes and Soviet warships escorting a British and American convoy that reached a Russian port without damage to any of its transports.

We've got to try and live with the weather and so we don't want to speak unkindly of it, but decent regard for the truth forces us to admit that yesterday and Sunday were about the meanest, red-hottest, body-scorching, nerve-biting, viscid, clammy, sticky, damp, moist, unpleasant, superhumid alleged days that have ever shown their fire-tipped snoots in these parts.

SALEM, N.H., July 20 (AP) -- The Mill B. Stable's Lovely Dawn took the feature today as Rockingham Park began its tenth season. Laying well off the pace for most of the mile and sixteenth. Apprentice Charlie Wahler called on his mount as they hit the stretch and Lovely Dawn stormed past the pacesetters to win by half a length.

WASHINGTON, July 20 -- A bill which would make it unlawful to pay or receive a commission or contingent fee in connection with the negotiation of a government contract was adopted by the House today and sent to the Senate. It would also make it illegal for any person who had been employed by the Federal Government during the preceding five years to represent business men in dealings with government agencies.

PITTSBURGH, July 20 (AP) -- Some 300 local representatives of the C.I.O. United Steel Workers Union from a score of States headed here tonight to formulate new demands on the country's major steel companies.

Five previously undisclosed sinkings were revealed yesterday, involving the loss of three United States vessels, a fourth United States ship of Panamanian registry and an unarmed Swedish merchantman, with seventy-seven seamen reported dead or missing and 130 rescued.

IT may be recalled that J.J. Dykes, the strong but not silent manager of the White Sox, had a luxurious watch thrust upon him rather roughly when he was in Boston recently. The presentation ceremonies made a deep impression on James. On his arrival in New York later he said to nobody in authority:

BERNE, Switzerland, July 20 -- Despite implicit assurances given in France by all official agencies recruiting skilled labor for German factories, there seemed scant likelihood today that any prisoners of war will be released in the near future.

MACKINAC ISLAND, Mich., July 20 (AP) -- Charles E. Sorenson's White Cloud, a 60-foot ocean-going cutter that made a disappointing showing in her first Great Lakes race, today won the annual Chicago-to-Mackinac yacht race. White Cloud made the 333-mile haul up Lake Michigan in 38 hours 14 minutes and five seconds.

DETROIT, July 20 (U.P.) -- Walter P. Reuther, member of the United Automobile Workers (C.I.O.) executive board, protested tonight to Donald M. Nelson, war production chief, against the use of steel for temporary barracks and warehouses while a shortage of the material "is forcing a creeping paralysis on vital war industry plants."

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 20 -- "This Land Is Mine," a screen story by Jean Renoir which Renoir and Dudley Nichols have contracted to produce at RKO, will go before the cameras in October with Charles Laughton, Maureen O'Hara and George Sanders heading the cast, RKO announced today.

LONDON, July 20 (U.P.) -- A small, antiquated Netherland freighter, part of an Allied convoy, twice rammed and finally sank a German U-boat recently and then picked up survivors of a torpedoed vessel while Nazi planes rained bombs about her, it was disclosed today by the official Netherland Indies News Agency.
WASHINGTON, July 20 -- A campaign to halt profiteering on beer and soft drinks, particularly in areas near Army camps, has been started by the Office of Price Administration.

BUFFALO, N.Y., July 20 (AP) -- Pushing a move to draft Senator James M. Mead of Buffalo for the New York State Gubernatorial nomination, members of the executive committee of the Erie County Democratic Committee said today that, despite Senator Mead's insistence that he is not a candidate, "the office should seek the man."

The possible solution of the 5 1/2-year-old Redwood murder mystery hinged last night upon one phase of a "confession" by a California vagrant to police in San Francisco, it was declared by Prosecutor John J. Breslin Jr. of Bergen County.

WASHINGTON, July 20 (AP) -- The Army gave commercial airlines today a vastly increased task of carrying men and materials all over the world, while at New Orleans, Andrew J. Higgins, shipbuilder, said that he planned to build 70-ton flying boats at his shipyard.

CHICAGO, July 20 -- An accumulation of scattered selling and hedging orders over the week-end gave the wheat market an easier undertone in the early trading today, the decline being helped along by professional pressure in sympathy with weakness in cotton.

WASHINGTON, July 20 -- Lawyers and political scientists, vigilant to see that all due and possible civil liberties are preserved and protected in time of war, have written in to question the procedure of a military commission in the trial of those German and American citizens accused of intended sabotage and espionage.

PHILADELPHIA, July 20 -- The Columbia Gas and Electric Corporation received today from the Securities and Exchange Commission permission to expend as much as $9,477,000 to acquire part of the concern's outstanding debentures by purchases on the New York Stock Exchange and by a direct purchase of $27,800 principal amount from the Columbia Corporation, a wholly owned subsidiary.

CHICAGO, July 20 (AP) -- An active deimand for live hogs today again saw prices tot 'hoice animals reach the $15 top, equaling the best price in tile last 16 years. The Department of Agriculture ani nouneod the following pork meat products had been purchased in the week ended July 118 by the Agricultural Marketing Adminis; lretion. Cured pork meat. 9,789.900 pounds: i Wiltshire side. 3.145.000 pounds: frozen pork meat.

OLD ORCHARD, Me., July 20 (AP) -- Making his first start of the season, Volo Song, 2-year-old brown colt owned by Will Strang of Brooklyn and driven by Ben White, raced two sparkling heats to win the $5,000 trotting stake today on the opening Grand Circuit card at this beach track.

AT SEA WITH THE PACIFIC FLEET (Delayed) -- Kiska Harbor may earn a place in history as the dreariest tomb ever to receive the corpse of an invader's hope to conquer the world. It may be that Honshu's hopeful little men have chosen the foggy bay under the black peaks of Kiska's hills to launch their last serious attempt to invade and conquer the United States.

The unit idea in furniture that began in higher-price modern groupings has been developed as an answer to the need for simpler modes of wartime living and is offered in new designs in a show opened yesterday at R.H. Macy Co.

An intensified salvage campaign having as its goal the collection of sufficient scrap material to keep war production at capacity was launched formally yesterday as Lessing J. Rosenwald, chief of the Bureau of Industrial Conservation of the War Production Board, notified State and local groups of the part they are expected to play in the program.

Women looking for a military life scurried out of offices and homes yesterday as enrollment for 150,000 "buck privates" for the Woman's Army Auxiliary Corps began throughout the nation. At the same time their officers reported for training at Fort Des Moines, Iowa.

President-elect Alfonso Lopez of Colombia returns to Bogota this week after one of those frequent visits to the United States which always strengthen the friendship between his country and our own. Senor Lopez is, indeed, a successful traveler who makes friends wherever he goes, not only here but in the countries of Latin America.

Defense areas show the best prospects for increased or normal retail sales of fur coats during the coming season, according to the results of a nation-wide questionnaire made public yesterday by Benn Mandel, fur buyer of this city.

BERGENFIELD, N.J., July 20 -- One fleeting day of fame has proved too much for Gypsy, the roguish crow. At 11 o'clock this morning he was taken into custody by an agent of the A.S.P.C.A. and carried off to the association's lock-up in Rockleigh, eight miles from here.

CHUNGKING, China, July 20 (U.P.) -- United States Army fliers have bombed fifty to sixty grounded Japanese planes at the South China port of Canton, and have made a second destructive raid on Japanese may headquarters at Linchwan, it was announced today.

CHUNGKING, China, July 20 -- The coming of the American Army Air Forces and the beginning of an aerial offensive against Hankow and other air bases from which Japanese bombers daily during the bombing seasons in 1939, 1940 and 1941 took off to blast away at comparatively defenseless Chungking are engendering optimism in this wartime capital.

Following the lead taken by national advertisers and retail stores, Sears, Roebuck Co., in its Fall and Winter catalog issued yesterday, is going in heavily for the promotion of war bonds and other government programs. Copy stresses the importance of collecting scrap metals, the need for cooperating in civilian defense activities, and makes appeals for the Red Cross civilian defense activities, and makes appeals for the Red Cross War Relief Fund and the U.S.O.

A large commercial building without a vacancy in fifteen years was sold yesterday. It is the eighteen-story structure at 114-16 Fifth Avenue, southwest corner of Seventeenth Street, which was purchased by Benjamin Winter, operator, from William F. Kenny, the contractor.

After a lapse of about ten days, the Treasury yesterday called upon its depositaries throughout the country to repay to it on July 24 a total of $238,000,000, representing approximately 10 per cent of the $2,400,000,000 of government funds now on deposit with those institutions.
A League of American Nations was suggested here last night by the Colombian President-elect, Alfonso Lopez, who visited President Roosevelt in Washington last week by invitation.

A book on the State Department that appears from meager advance information to be at least in part a "blast" is on its way for September publication under the Farrar Rinehart imprint. The author is Robert Bendiner, managing editor of The Nation.

When you are about 15 years old you wear a red-and-white gingham dress and you have a "best friend" and you like sweets. After school, unbeknown to your respective families, you and your favorite companion frequent the local confectionery.

MINEOLA, L.I., July 20 -- Colonel Edward C.O. Thomas, Nassau County Director of Civilian Protection, disclosed today that he had asked Mayor Herbert Mirschel of Hempstead to rescind an order he is reported to have issued to the Hempstead police directing that there be no further efforts to "regulate" wartime lighting restrictions in village stores "until the dimout is in force in adjoining villages and communities."

Acting to meet the tight shipping situation with regard to regular cargo vessels, and unwilling to await completion of the emergency fleet of sailing ships to be constructed under the plan recently announced by the government, exporters here are planning to set up a private agency to place their cargoes aboard the smaller vessels already in service, it was learned yesterday.

Sixteen public officials, friends and former associates of the late John Purroy Mitchel, Mayor of New York City from 1914 to 1917, paid tribute to his memory yesterday at his grave in Woodlawn Cemetery, in the Bronx. It was the twenty-second annual pilgrimage to his grave by the "Mitchel Commissioners and Associates."

BOSTON, July 20 (AP) -- Queen Wilhelmina of The Netherlands told city and State officials tonight that her "oppressed people had full confidence in their American Allies and, despite their plight, would help them to the utmost toward final victory."
I am sending excerpts from a letter from a friend of our children who is a naval flier in the Pacific:

Another German-American Bund leader, Karl A. Bachmann, pleaded guilty yesterday to the charges of conspiracy to discourage compliance with the Selective Service Act, on which twenty-nine chiefs of the Bund were indicted two weeks ago.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., July 20 -- Colonel Frederick L. Devereux, Westchester Director of Civilian Protection, warned today that he would order telephone service suspended throughout his jurisdiction during future test blackouts if the public persists in a practice which in previous tests has caused an increase of from 200 to 500 per cent over normal telephone use.

One way of measuring with what great strides history has marched in the last year is to recall that it was just a year ago today that President Roosevelt sent to Congress his special message urging an extension of the period of military service for the National Guard, the Reserve officers and the young men who had been called into the Army under the Selective Service Act.

Sales of New York and Brooklyn department stores showed no change last week in comparisoni with the corresponding week a yearI ago, according to the report issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. For the preceding week the bank had report an increase of 3 per cent.

WASHINGTON, July 20 -- A United States Flying Fortress crew wrote a new chapter in the record of the Army Air Forces over Rangoon, Burma, by fighting off twenty-three enemy airplanes and completing its objective despite the wounding of four crew members and virtual destruction of the plane, the War Department learned in a message received today.

CAIRO, Egypt, July 20 -- While troops of the British Empire continued to hold their positions on the battlefront in Egypt, planes of the Royal Air Force struck yesterday at the Axis's advanced landing ground at El Daba in an attack that was described as the heaviest single air raid ever directed against an airfield in Africa.

HARTFORD, Conn., July 20 (AP) -- Seven registered conscientious objectors from camps in IVfassachusetts, Maryland and North Carolina, the first to come into Connecticut, arrived in Hartford today and were assiguued jobs for the duration of the war on Hartford County dairy farms, Arthur Geary, placement officer of the United States Employment Service, said.

While Tami Mauriello, his rival in Thursday night's feature ten-round bout at Madison Square Garden, rested, Clarence (Red) Burman, Baltimore heavyweight concluded boxing preparations for the match with a two-round drill with Marty Clark yesterday at the Roxy Gymnasium.

The trustees in reorganization of the $1,000,000,000 Associated Gas and Electric Corporation System have formulated plans for a new service organization for its far-flung utilities set-up, it was disclosed yesterday. Under the new arrangement, a radical departure from past practice, the A.G. E. service unit would be completely independent of the system and would have to compete for business against other concerns in the utility engineering and service field.

The defense information center at Pershing Square, which, through daily lectures, moving pictures and displays, is doing all it can to encourage civilian participation in the war, added two more items of interest to its schedule yesterday.

Midyear reinvestment funds helped yesterday to keep the stock market in higher brackets, but trading continued too light to permit any major extension in values. The minor demand did not appear, however, until a smattering of selling in the morning failed to uncover any weak spots.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., July 20 -- Alex Watson, Hudson River professional and his amateur partner, 17-year-old Wesley Curtis of Dunwoodie, carried off top honors in the weekly pro-amateur best-ball event of the Westchester County Golf Association at the Bonnie Briar Country Club today.

Mayor La Guardia's campaign to coax New Yorkers to volunteer for fingerprinting as a precautionary measure for identifying possible air raid victims is, of course, an excellent idea. Yet, like so many excellent ideas, it is born to certain defeat because it is a request, not a demand.

MILWAUKEE, July 20 -- Declaring that "the war may be a long one," Joseph B. Eastman, director of the Office of Defense Transportation, told 350 delegates attending the annual conference of the American Association of Motor Vehicle Administrators here today that a bumpy road lies ahead if the essential needs of civilians are to be met.

BOGOTA, Colombia, July 20 -- President Eduardo Santos, accompanied by members of his Cabinet, today opened the Colombian Congress for 1942. In his message to Congress the President said that the Presidential period now ending had been marked by calamities of war unprecedented in history.

WASHINGTON, July 20 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks of the Federal Reserve System in 101 leading cities shows the following principal changes for the week ended July 15: Increases of $722,000,000 in holdings of United States Government bonds, $107,000,000 in holdings of Treasury bills, $820,000,000 in United States Government deposits, $124,000,000 in loans to brokers and dealers, and $168,000,000 in demand deposits -- adjusted.

NEWARK, N.J., July 20 (AP) -- Held to four hits by the combined efforts of George Washburn and Randy Gumpert and unable to capitalize on ten walks off Washburn, Montreal was handed its eighth straight defeat today by Newark.

WASHINGTON, July 20 -- Under the parliamentary rules in effect in the House consideration of the tax bill today, the official debate on the changes was limited to five-minute speeches by Representatives Doughton and McLean, but a half hour more was consumed by members demanding to know what was the situation.

Mrs. Walter J. Kelly of Chicago arrived in town yesterday and erased some of the creases from the brows of worried salvage executives. Her success story of the Windy City's fat and grease salvage campaign, which she has helped direct, gave impetus to a similar drive just getting under way here.

With the government urging Hollywood to conserve raw film stock, Samuel Goldwyn yesterday called upon the heads of the major motion-picture studios to reduce their current production schedules by at least 40 per cent. He also said that now was the time for the large theatre circuits to take the lead in eliminating double features. "

CHICAGO, July 20 -- Unprofitable branch lines of two railroads with headquarters in Chicago today were ordered scrapped as transportation systems and their metal salvaged for use in war production. The lines include fifty-seven miles of Illinois Central trackage between Red Oak, Ill., and Dodgeville, Wis., and twenty-eight miles of the Chicago and North Western System between Sycamore and Caledonia, Ill.

The Metropolitan Museum of Art has installed a collection of arms and armor in the residence of the late George Blumenthal, at 50 East Seventieth Street, and opened it to the public as a temporary branch museum.
