Election of new officers completed the reorganization yesterday of Jay-Thorpe, Inc., women's apparel and fur specialty shop at 24 West Fifty-seventh Street. Charles Jay Oppenheim Jr. was elected chairman of the board, while Harry A. Hatry was chosen president.

CHICAGO, July 20 -- Montgomery Ward's Fall and Winter catalogue, announced two days later than that of its rival, contains a long list of smaller electrical household equipment, such as irons, motors, paint sprayers, hair dryers, roasters, toasters and waffle irons, that were dropped from the Sears, Roebuck mail order lines because of priorities and other troubles.

The eight-room residence with three baths on a plot 70 by 100 at 345 Rye Beach Avenue, Rye, Westchester County, has been sold by the Troy Savings Bank to Mrs. Mildred E. Holman through Herbert L. Williams, Inc., and Suzanne Gedney, co-brokers.

WASHINGTON, July 20 -- Prices of foods not under OPA control advanced 4.8 per cent between mid-May and mid-June, it was announced today by the United States Bureau of Labor Statistics. Controlled food prices, on the other hand, showed an average decline of 1 per cent.

WASHINGTON, July 20 -- The service of the American home in the war effort will receive its own distinguished service award, if the individual household has lived up to all the requirements of a "V Home," it was announced today by James M. Landis, director of the Office of Civilian Defense.

In an artificially created glacial atmosphere, mocking the torrid temperature prevailing outside, I.J. Fox of 393 Fifth Avenue presented its annual fur fashion show yesterday afternoon as a benefit for the Army and Navy Relief Societies.

WITH UNITED STATES ARMY AIR FORCES IN SOUTH CHINA, July 20 -- Colonel Caleb V. Haynes has given the Japanese notice that he is not going to direct his American bomber command in China from a swivel chair. He led the American raid on Hankow last Thursday, and the pilots around this base said that it was the prettiest bit of explosive laying they had seen.

Arthur G. Abrecht, former publicity manager for the Hamburg-American Line, was found dead in a vacant lot at Burns and Thornton Streets, Forest Hills, Queens, yesterday after he had been reported missing from his home at 68-12 Burns Street, six blocks away.

BERNE, Switzerland, July 20 -- Discussing price control as a continental problem for Europe, Dr. Hans Fischboeck, Reich Commissioner of Prices, told members of the Netherlands Social Economic Cooperative in The Hague recently that unwarranted price differences between countries must be avoided because they threatened to disrupt clearing agreements and currency relations set up by Berlin, it was learned here today.

NORTH TARRYTOWN, N.Y., July 20 -- Members of the United Auto Workers, Local 664, returned today to the manufacture of Army trucks in the Chevrolet plant here after a ten-day shut-down, but declared that they would demand that the Army and the War Production Board investigate "the continued lay-off and the reduced work week."

THE Chinese still continue to beat back the Japanese. But if some people who are close to Mr. T.V. Soong in Washington are correct, the Chinese are running short of even so elementary a war material as the common or garden variety of rifle bullet. Our blindness to the need for keeping China slugging away at Japan in the only theatre of war that gives us steady contact with the Japanese is appalling.

WASHINGTON, July 20 -- In a buffer zone which includes Allegany, Cattaraugus and Chautauqua Counties in Western New York, deliveries to filling stations are to be cut 25 per cent after Wednesday to prevent excessive sales of gasoline in the counties adjoining the Eastern rationing area, the War Production Board announced today.

Morris Sterling, alias "Kid Puggi," 51 years old, who gave his address as 901 Prospect Avenue, the Bronx, was returned to that borough last night from Camden, N.J., where he was arrested last Saturday as a fugitive in connection with his escape on March 2 from the Bronx police.

The General Electric Company and the United Electrical, Radio and Machine Workers of America, C.I.O., have agreed through collective bargaining to a maintenance of union membership formula affecting 100,000 employes in the company's thirty plants in various parts of the country covered by agreements with the union, it was announced yesterday by Albert J. Fitzgerald, president of the organization.

WITH THE AMERICAN FIELD SERVICE, in the Western Desert, June 28 (By air mail) -- No one was more shocked by the disaster at Tobruk than the men themselves. Now that the desert stronghold has fallen, we can tell how it felt to be in the retreat.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., July 20 -- President Roosevelt soon will "step in to prevent a general break-through in the Administration's anti-inflation program," Senator Lister Hill of Alabama, the Democratic whip, said here today.

PRINCETON, N.J., July 20 -- The largest collection of Arabic manuscripts in the world and one of the three best collections of Western European manuscripts in this country, together described by Dr. Harold W. Dodds, president of Princeton University, as "one of the word's greatest collections of books and manuscripts," have come to rest in the university library through the generosity of Robert Garrett of Baltimore.

A residence of fifteen rooms and four baths occupying a tract of two and one-half acres in Hewlett Bay Park, Hewlett, L.I., has been purchased by Lawrence A. Slesinger from Danforth Miller. The house is of English design with a large living room paneled in English walnut from a sixteenth-century English home brought to this country by Mr. Miller.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., July 21 -- John R. Longo, independent Democratic foe of Mayor Frank Hague, has been put back in Class 4F by Army physicians at the Newark induction center, it was disclosed here today. Longo was deferred because of a slight injury to his left foot following an operation thirteen years ago.
With the aid of five unearned runs in the second inning against Paul Derringer, the Dodgers defeated the Reds at Ebbets Field yesterday, 8 to 4.

VICHY, France, July 21 (U.P.) -- Press dispatches from Paris said today that "terrorists" there killed a policeman and a passer-by and wounded a 7-year-old girl and several other persons while fleeing after a bombing attempt on a public establishment in the Rue Clisson, behind the Austerlitz railway station.

NEW CITY, N.Y., July 21 -- Rockland County became the first county in the State to adopt civil service under State supervision under the Fite law when the county Board of Supervisors accepted today a State survey that places all public employes in a civil service classification.
NIAGARA FALLS, N.Y., July 21 -- Officials of the New York State Golf Association today were congratulating themselves for having decided to go ahead with their plans to hold their championships.

MANAGUA, Nicaragua, July 21 -- The United States dollar bill is the most welcome visitor again appearing in Nicaragua and brings back memories of the boomtime Nineteen Twenties when the cordoba and the United States dollar circulated together at par.

WASHINGTON, July 21 -- A determined effort will be made in the Senate Finance Committee to correct what some members speak of as disastrous faults in the record-breaking $6,271,000,000 tax bill passed yesterday by the House.

SAN FRANCISCO, Calif., July 21 -- Police Captain Bernard C. McDonald announced today that a Bergen County (N.J.) detective would arrive here, probably on Thursday, to question James A. Boyd, a vagrant who had "confessed" to slaying R. Norman Redwood, New York sandhog union official, for $5,000 in February, 1937.
SOMEWHERE IN AUSTRALIA, July 20 (Delayed) -- Major Robert D. Van Auken of Bergenfield, N.J., left today by hospital plane for South Australia to recuperate from wounds he received in air combat.
A number of cosmetics, including leg make-up, may join the growing list of war casualties, it was said yesterday.

ALBANY, July 21 -- Governor Lehman directed Mayor Benjamin F. Barnes of Yonkers today to close immediately places where gambling and bookmaking were being conducted there. He also directed that the Mayor report to him the conditions on gambling and bookmaking in Yonkers.

An increase in the general death rate, largely among older persons stricken by the heat, was reported for New York City for last week by Thomas J. Duffield, Registrar of Records in the Health Department. The death rate was 9.5 per 1,000 population, compared with 8.6 the week before and 8.4 in the corresponding week of 1941.
SALT LAKE CITY, July 21 (AP) -- An increase to $1 an ounce in the price of silver was offered today as a possible remedy for bottlenecks in the production of strategic minerals for the war effort.

The new coupon rationing system governing sales of gasoline in the seventeen States along the Eastern seaboard went into effect last midnight, terminating the temporary "meal ticket" system in operation since May 15. Most of the service station pumps in the metropolitan area were dry as the change occurred, but many dealers were expecting fresh deliveries today.

WASHINGTON, July 21 -- Acting at the request of Admiral Ernest J. King, Commander in Chief of the Navy, the House Naval Affairs Committee approved today a bill which would authorize expenditure of $975,634,000 more on naval establishments, including $399,494,000 for aviation facilities and $315,000,000 for "miscellaneous structures and advance bases."
"You ought to see some of the goofy descriptions we turn in," the genial, gray-haired police officer said.

WASHINGTON, July 21 -- Despite a speech in opposition by Representative Beverly M. Vincent, the House passed today by voice vote the conference report on the bill to form a women's reserve in the Navy and sent the measure to the White House.

WITH BRITISH NAVAL AIR SERVICE East of Matruh, July 20 (Delayed) (AP) -- Guns of British warships poured salvo after salvo of high-explosive shells into battered Matruh early today, delivering the severest plastering of the war to this Axis-occupied port on the fringe of the Egyptian desert.

PHILADELPHIA, July 21 -- The International Hydro-Electric System, top holding company of a system with a consolidated capitalization of $479,737,885, was ordered today by the Securities and Exchange Commission "to embark on a program of liquidation leading to dissolution."

Water J. Damrosch, dean of American conductors and composers, yesterday joined in the fight against the cancellation by the National Broadcasting Company of the broadcasts of the concerts of the National High School Orchestra at Interlochen, Mich., on orders from James C. Petrillo, president of the American Federation of Musicians.
WASHINGTON, July 21 (AP) -- Wayne L. Morse, in his warning today concerning work stoppages, said:

News that escapes from Germany, Italy and Japan is often of such a nature as to puzzle and confuse, and is undoubtedly meant to do so. The Germans, particularly, enjoy presenting a propaganda picture of a strong, united German people completely convinced about the war and working with dogged earnestness to carry it through to victory.

WASHINGTON, July 21 -- The Rubber Reserve Company will purchase all rubber produced in Ecuador during the next five years, except that required for essential domestic needs, under the terms of an agreement announced tonight by the State Department, the Reserve Company and the Board of Economic Warfare.

WASHINGTON, July 21 -- United States submarines have sunk three more Japanese destroyers in the vicinity of Kiska, in the western Aleutian Islands, the Navy announced this evening. A communique also stated that Army bombers had recently made several attacks on the Japanese encampment at Kiska and on ships in the harbor there.

LONDON, July 21 (U.P.) -- Former Squadron Leader F.J. Rutland, British World War air hero who has been detained by the Home Office since last December, was employed for five years by the Japanese as a spy in the United States "in close touch with American naval intelligence," Admiral Sir Roger Keyes told the House of Commons today.

Miss Elena Guenther, 35-year- old sergeant in the Staten Island unit of the City Patrol Corps, asserted last night that she would go to City Hall today to demand from Mayor La Guardia a public hearing on her elimination from the rolls of the organization.
PHILADELPHIA, July 21 (AP) -- The Cardinals found the offerings of Pitcher Tommy Hughes much to their liking tonight and trounced the Phils, 6-1, to open their current swing through the East.

WASHINGTON, July 21 -- On the basis of a secret report made to him last week by a special committee of the War Production Board, Donald M. Nelson issued a statement today advising against "any undue optimism about the possibilities of immediate construction of cargo planes of any new type."

WASHINGTON, July 21 -- The Office of War Information announced tonight that United States armed forces had suffered 44,143 casualties since the start of the war, this total consisting of 4,801 dead, 3,218 wounded and 36,124 missing.

Partly as a result of its coal company's having ceased to report losses, the Delaware Hudson Company, a holding agency which controls the Delaware Hudson Railroad and the Hudson Coal Company, reported yesterday a net income of $2,840,625, or $5.55 a share, in the first six months of the year, against $1,414,433, or $2.76 a share, in the same period last year.

Can you spare a record? Any kind of record, new or old, cracked or whole. The American Legion and its Auxiliary have begun a campaign, the goal of which is 37,500,000 phonograph records to be sold as scrap to finance new record libraries for service camps at home and abroad.

The General Foods Corporation in its semi-annual report for publication today shows net earnings of $5,329,535 for the first six months of this year. The net was equal, after $337,500 for dividends on the 150,000 shares of $4.50 preferred stock, to $1.01 each on the 5,251,440 shares of common stock.

BOSTON, July 21 (By Netherlands News Agency) -- Queen Wilnelmina of the Netherlands visited the Boston Navy Yard today, but work continued uninterrupted by request of the Queen who declared that "every minute in these days is precious."

WASHINGTON, July 21 -- If the nation's motorists will reduce their driving 40 per cent below their 1941 mileage, the rubber industry told the government today, a two-year supply of tires can be provided for all cars on the road.

Immediate steps should be taken by business to prepare for training the increased sales personnel which will be needed in the post-war period, Ladson Butler of the Jam Handy Organization warned yesterday at a luncheon meeting of the Sales Executives Club of New York in the Hotel Roosevelt.

WITHOUT provocation, Barrister John T. (Terry) McGovern began to argue his case for Cooperstown, N.Y., generally recognized as the birthplace of baseball and now the proud guardian of the Baseball Hall of Fame erected in that hallowed spot through the combined efforts of baseball authorities and local patriots.

WASHINGTON, July 21 (AP) -- The Office of Price Administration announced today that price ceilings soon would be imposed on pulpwood, at levels "much lower" than the current market, to protect existing ceilings on prices of such products as newsprint.
WASHINGTON, July 21 -- President Roosevelt disclosed today that he had approved a radio speech which Secretary Hull will deliver on the international situation and post-war policies.
MOSCOW, July 21 (AP) -- The Soviet Information Bureau issued the following communique today:

WASHINGTON, July 21 (AP) -- On the eve of coupon gasoline rationing in Eastern seaboard States Senator Bridges declared today that he felt that nation-wide gasoline rationing should be started without delay.

The American people will hold the Nazis to "strict accountability" for their crimes of oppression on an inevitable day of reckoning, President Roosevelt declared last night in a message read to 20,000 persons at Madison Square Garden.

With the old master, Carl Hubbell, at the controls, the Giants whizzed along closer to third place as they wrested a bitter battle from the Pirates, 6 to 5, at the Polo Grounds before 8,937 Hubbell rooters in a twilight-night game last evening.

DETROIT, July 21 (AP) -- The Tigers defeated the Senators today for the first time in five starts by belting their old team-mate, Bobo Newsom, for eight hits that produced a 6-4 victory. Rookie Hal White pitched a five-hitter to gain his seventh victory.

WASHINGTON, July 21 -- Admiral William D. Leahy, retired, former Chief of Naval Operations and until recently Ambassador to France, has been ordered to active duty to be chief of staff to the Commander in Chief, President Roosevelt. This was announced by Mr. Roosevelt at his press conference today. The President made clear that, as Commander in Chief of the armed forces, he himself would continue to direct American world strategy.

Reporting a 45 per cent drop in mill inventories of scrap iron and steel in the last eighteen months, Robert W. Wolcott, chairman of the American Industries Salvage Committee, asserted yesterday at the opening of an intensified salvage campaign that huge stocks of dormant scrap must be tapped if war production is to continue at its present pace.

Warren W. McSpadden of the American Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals said yesterday that that organization in cooperation with the Civilian Defense Volunteer Office, was recruiting 1,000 aides to care for the 325,000 dogs, 400,000 cats and 6,000 horses of New York in case of air raids.

George Blumenthal, who collected so many beautiful things, meant that his house in East Seventieth Street should be a branch of the Metropolitan Museum, of which he had been president. Finding it impossible to determine what capital and income would be necessary for its perpetual maintenance, he left it to the Museum with the proviso that certain structural parts of it be there set up and the house and land thereafter sold.

It is exactly thirteen months ago that Hitler launched his treacherous attack upon Russia. That attack may have been a fatal error. It is still too early to say. But when the attack on Russia began it certainly presented a hitherto undreamed-of opportunity to the enemies of Hitler.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., July 21 -- Mrs George L. Wrenn is executive chairman in charge of recreation and entertainment at the clubhouse of the Malcolm R. White Post of the American Legion, which has turned over for the duration his home here and all of its facilities, five days and evenings a week, for all service men of the armed forces serving in this area.
MOSCOW, Wednesday, July 22 (AP) -- The Soviet midnight communique follows:

Jean Leonard Musa, who is in Federal custody as an alleged secret agent of the Vichy government, was negotiating for employment in the General Bronze Corporation at the time of his arrest last week, it was disclosed yesterday.

BUENOS AIRES, Argentina, July 21 (AP) -- Foreign Office sources said tonight that Argentina had agreed to send 1,000,000 tons of grain, mostly wheat, to Spain in exchange for iron and industrial products under a barter agreement reached with the Spanish trade mission in Buenos Aires.

In an article of July 13 some lines of a speech of mine have been rightly quoted. Apparently the commentator only had knowledge of the two sentences reported by an agency and did not know the rest of my speech, the conclusions of which were the very opposite of what he insinuates to me.

OTTAWA, July 21 -- A proposal to re-establish the Communist party as a legal organization in Canada after it had been banned for more than two years has been approved by a House of Commons committee studying defense regulations, an authoritative source said tonight.

While the women's court committee of the Social Service Bureau had received no response from Mayor La Guardia to its charges of case fixing, bail-bond deals and other irregularities in the Women's Court, members of the committee were confident yesterday of some official move to improve the situation.

MALMOE, Sweden, July 21 (AP) -- Gunder Haegg, 26-year-old Swedish fireman who has averaged a world track record a week for the past month, tonight clipped four-tenths of a second from the accepted world standard for the rarely run 2,000 meters.

JAMES GOULD COZZENS has always seemed to me too clever a writer. The precise artistry of his books, their high professional polish, their sardonic wit and the cold-blooded, almost surgical, manner with which they dissected human character and motives were impressive and admirable. But there was something slightly chilly about the intellectual atmosphere of a Cozzens novel; a shrewd penetration rather than a warm compassion.

MILWAUKEE, July 21 -- The rising need for steel in the war effort has resulted in a government policy of requisitioning worn-out automobiles for scrap metal, according to Merrill Stubbs, chief of the War Production Board's automobile salvage section.

When Brig. Gen. "Jimmy" H. Doolittle sits down to dine he likes best to be confronted with a thick, rare steak, two vegetables in addition to potatoes, gravy, salad and cake with a lot of chocolate sauce! At least, that is what the wife of the leader of the famous bombing expedition against Japan told a group of women in Washington not long ago.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 21 -- Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer has assigned Anita Loos to write a photoplay under the title "Women in Uniform" as a vehicle for Joan Crawford to follow her current film, "Reunion." George Haight will produce the picture, and Miss Loos has left for Des Moines, Iowa, headquarters of the Women's Auxiliary Army Corps, to obtain material for her scenario.

The Board of Elections continued yesterday to reject primary designating petitions filed by insurgent candidates on varied grounds. The petition of George W. Thompson, candidate for the Democratic nomination for Congress against James H. Fay, organization designee in the Sixteenth Congressional District, was rejected on the ground that Thompson's petitions bore a star, emblem of the Democratic party, at their head.

LONDON, July 21 -- Belgians throughout Britain today observed the anniversary of their constitution, obtained in 1831. Officers and men of Free Belgium paraded at Chelsea Barracks where Camille Gutt, National Defense Minister, told them to be of good faith and to have courage "for the worst is past."

BOSTON, July 21 (AP) -- The Braves, after filling the bases by expert bunting, gained a 17-inning victory over the Cubs today, 4 to 3, when Johnny Cooney singled cleanly to right-center against Right-hander Hiram Bithorn with none out.

LONDON, July 21 -- Business on the Stock Exchange today was small but more cheerful than of late. The oil and store shares were outstanding, improvement being noted in Shell, Iranian, Ultramar and Mexican Eagle.
SALEM, N.H., July 21 (AP) -- Mrs. L. Palladino's Layaway today won the Antrim, six-furlong feature at Rockingham Park, in the fast time of 1:12 1-5.

A full picture of the Autumn future in hats was presented last night by the forty-eight designers and hat makers who participated in the Millinery Stabilization Commission's semi-annual fashion show, held in the grand ballroom of the Hotel Astor.
LONDON, July 21 -- The creation of a limited diversion on the European Continent is being discussed by high British and American military, naval and air leaders it was reported reliably today.

ATLANTIC CITY, July 21 -- Colonel Robert P. Glassburn, commanding officer of the Army Air Force's replacement training center here, announced today the taking over of three more hotels at this resort.

Percy C. Magnus, president of the New York Board of Trade, submitted a list of twenty-three names to Mayor La Guardia yesterday for appointment as members of a commission to study the city's relation to post-war conditions.

Young people in every part of the United States and Canada expressed their opinions on subjects ranging from the proper time to plan for peace to the propriety of slacks for girls in school in the first "Poll of Junior Opinion" conducted by the Parents Institute of New York City.

MOSCOW, Wednesday, July 22 -- The retreat of Marshal Semyon Timoshenko's southern armies still continues. Giving this news, a supplement to the midnight communique describes how Soviet tanks are fending off the attacks of enemy machines and covering the withdrawal in some sectors.

HEMPSTEAD, L.I., July 21 -- Mayor Herbert Mirschel of the village defied today Colonel Edward C.O. Thomas, Nassau County Director of Civilian Protection, in a dispute over dimout enforcement here. The Mayor said his order to Hempstead police not to enforce the lighting restrictions until they were enforced in adjoining communities still stands and he threatened to "fire" the village's Deputy Director of Civilian Protection if he seeks to enforce them.

SYDNEY, Australia, July 21 -- At a conference between Prime Minister John Curtin and the executive board of the Coal Miners Federation it was agreed that miners would work more hours daily and leaders would discipline strikers.

Flaught scored his second straight victory for Mrs. Ethel D. Jacobs when he led virtually from start to finish of yesterday's Tuckahoe Purse at Empire City, where 12,579 persons wagered $875,804. In with 106 pounds, the chestnut son of Firethorn lasted to win by half a length under the strong handling of Nick Wall.

"Spring Again," it now appears certain, will not resume at the Playhouse on Sept. 7, as had been planned and announced when it closed for the Summer last June 6. The comedy, in which Grace George and C. Aubrey Smith were co-starred, will go on the road, however, starting its trek with a week at the Maplewood (N.J.) Theatre late next month before heading for Chicago at a date not yet announced

WASHINGTON, July 21 -- Successful test flights have been held for a new type of six-place plane designed for training bomber crews, the War Department disclosed tonight. The craft's body, wings and tail are made entirely of plastic known as duramold.
WASHINGTON, July 21 (AP) -- An order issued by the Office of Defense Transportation will speed up coal shipments to New England, Senator Brewster of Maine said today.

Mayor La Guardia asked thirty representative real estate operators at City Hall yesterday to give him their suggestions on the best way to meet the shortages of fuel oil and coal before cold weather arrives.

TOLEDO, Ohio, July 21 (AP) -- Bill Poland, New York City fighter, who knocked out Harry Bobo a year ago, had another major fistic upset in the making for eight rounds tonight, but in the ninth Lee Savold of Des Moines protected his heavyweight ranking with a knockout before more than 9,000 fans at Toledo's "Bomber for MacArthur" show.

Moscow, Wednesday, July 22 (AP) -- German tanks and motorized infantry were reported concentrating in the southern Don-Donets basin for a smash at Rostov and Stalingrad early today, but the Russians said the Nazi left flank near Voronezh to the north was "in deadly peril" under savage Russian counter-attacks.

Valuable assistance in bolstering the efficiency of the nation's defense program and in making the home front safe is being obtained in various States through utilizing the services of game protectors.

The one-story taxpayer at 2532-2552 Grand Concourse, the Bronx, has been bought by Charles Walzer, operator, for cash above a mortgage of $156,000. It is on a plot 125 by 100 feet, and contains eight stores. Goodman Mabel represented the buyer and Samuel Sprung the seller.

BERNE, Switzerland, July 21 -- Although presented as a consequence of successful operations against "insurgents," the accord signed last Saturday between Croatia and Italy represents rather the shattering of certain illusions entertained by Rome, it was indicated in private advices received here.

CHUNGKING, China, July 21 -- In a number of ways Japanese op erations in the seaboard campaign mark a distinct departure from the usual Japanese tactics, according to a Chinese war correspondent. "Flying units" are bearing the brunt of the fighting instead of main columns driving along communication lines.

Officials of twenty-two local housing authorities sold yesterday $28,675,000 of temporary loan notes to various banking and investment institutions. Of the total the Chemical Bank and Trust Company and associates bought $17,735,000; the Girard Trust Company, Philadelphia, $5,775,000; Salomon Brothers Hutzler, $4,375,000, and Harvey Fisk Sons, Inc., $790,000.

Selective buying, mostly of a reinvestment nature, managed yesterday to keep the stock market at an improved level, although trading expanded only slightly. Stocks displayed no nervousness over the tax bill as passed by the House, as most traders realized that the measure faced innumerable changes in the Senate.
With the cool curiosity of a Sherlock Holmes, we have conducted an inquiry into the beauty habits of the business woman. We are sorry to say they are most unbusinesslike!

CLEVELAND, July 21 -- Such a startling development as almost being caught without a catcher because some member of the cast saw fit to take French leave while seeking a berth on a police force may have placed the usually serene Yankees in a strange light the past few days, but nothing ever seems to disturb them on the ball field.

VICHY. France, July 21 (AP) -- Dispatches from Brussels reported that reinforced patrols cruised the streets of the capital of Nazi-occupied Belgium today and that all monuments were guarded on this Belgian Independence Day which the people were forbidden to celebrate.

J. Reid Spencer, 70-year-old retired music teacher, of 100 Lefferts Avenue, Brooklyn, whose sensitive ears have picked up dissonant music from Ebbets Field, heard nothing from there yesterday. If he had, however, he probably would have forgotten his perennial threat to sue the Brooklyn Dodgers, for in Ebbets Field they played Mr. Spencer's own composition, the "Canzonetta" in E flat major.
LONDON, July 21 (AP) -- The Admiralty issued the following communique today:

CHICAGO, July 21 (AP) -- Luke Appling's single in the tenth inning with Myril Hoag on second base gave the White Sox a 5-to-4 victory tonight over the Red Sox before a crowd of 14,071. Chicago tied the score in the ninth when Taft Wright doubled and Dario Lodigiani singled.

After a medium-sized United States merchant vessel was torpedoed in the Caribbean on June 3 with the loss of fifteen men, two young American seamen among the thirty-two survivors were picked up by the submarine, whose commander gave them rum in a tin cup and argued with them about the war.

VENTURA, Calif., July 21 (AP) -- Joan Crawford, who rose from a job as a dancer in a Chicago revue to be one of the screen's top actresses, was married early today to Phillip Terry, a film player. He was her third husband.

ST. LOUIS, July 21 (AP) -- Two home runs in the first two innings enabled the Browns to defeat the Athletics, 4 to 3, tonight. Walt Judnich hit one with two mates on base in the first and Harlond Clift followed suit in the second with none on base.

CHUNGKING, China, July 21 (U.P.) -- United States Army bombers, smashing at the Japanese for the third straight day, have sunk two ships on the Yangtze River near Kiukiang, important base on the enemy supply routes for the Kiangsi and Central China fronts, Lieut. Gen. Joseph W. Stilwell's headquarters announced today.

Trade interests veered yesterday from their recent hesitant course in the cotton market and furnished most of the demand that raised prices. Active futures on the New York Cotton Exchange at the close showed gains of 18 to 26 points, or 90 cents to $1.30 a bale, the session's best marks.
HARTFORD, July 21 -- Gerhard Wilhelm Kunze of New York, national German bund leader, pleaded guilty in Federal court today to a conspiracy to spy on this country.

BERNE, Switzerland, July 21 -- Judging by those who are received in Switzerland for periods of three months, French children in general are more than a year behind medical standards for their ages, notably as regards weight and size, it was said here today.
LONDON, July 21 -- On the eve of the first birthday of the Royal Air Force Ferry Command it was stated here tonight that 99 1/2 per cent of all the bombers flown over the ocean had arrived safely.

Visiting buyers registered in the market for the week ended yesterday numbered 1,038, which compared with 1,410 in the preceding week and 1,031 in the similar period a year ago, according to the listings in THE NEW YORK TIMES. Yesterday's registrations totaled 398 as against 694 for last Tuesday.

Disposal by auction of the machinery and equipment of the Spring Products Company, 47-39 Austell Place, Long Island City, began yesterday, registering another casualty in the field of civilian production because of inability to obtain materials due to war priorities.

Your recent editorial "The Rubber Crisis," that concluded "there seems nothing for it but to carry out the rubber program as it stands, relying chiefly on the oil companies," perhaps was based on a misconception.

OLD ORCHARD, Me., July 21 (AP) -- The Grand Circuit's mile competitive record for a 2-year-old pacer was lowered to 2:01 1/4 today when Kings Counsel, owned jointly by E.P. Gray of Bellows Fall, Vt., and Dr. Hugh M. Parshall, his driver, won the second heat of a $5,000 stake in a photo finish with Ty Thomas's Cleveland-owned Adios.

Money invested by patriotic buyers of war savings bonds and stamps will be used by the Federal Government for socialization of the private power industry in the Northwest, Z.E. Merrill, president of the Mountain States Power Company, charged yesterday in assailing the Bone bill pending in Congress.

Warning that millions of Americans who depend on oil heating will spend an uncomfortable Winter if present conditions continue, the war service committee of the American Society of Heating and Ventilating Engineers yesterday urged President Roosevelt to make a fireside chat to awaken the American public to the "extremely somber" outlook.

When speakers take to their soap-boxes tomorrow night at Seventieth Street and First Avenue to discuss the coming Congressional elections, would-be hecklers will face disappointment, for the speakers will be members of the New York City League of Women Voters and the topic will be presented in a manner that probably is unique in political "stumping" history -- "from a strictly nonpartisan point of view."

The New Deal drive to "stop Bennett" and get the Democratic gubernatorial nomination for United States Senator James M. Mead formally opened last night with the release in Washington of an appeal signed by a number of prominent New Yorkers asking Mr. Mead to make the race, coupled with a separate letter from Senior Senator Robert F. Wagner endorsing his colleague.

WASHINGTON, July 21 -- President Roosevelt made public today a report from William R. Boyd, chairman of the Petroleum Industry War Council, which disclosed that 454,155 tons of scrap rubber have been added to the nation's stockpile as a result of the country-wide collection between June 15 and July 10.

WASHINGTON, July 21 -- President Roosevelt announced at his press conference that Admiral William D. Leahy has been ordered to active duty as Chief of Staff to the Commander in Chief. His visitors included the Peruvian Ambassador and Fernando Carbajal, president of Rotary International; Secretary Hull, Donald M. Nelson, Sir Owen Dixon, Sir Earl Page and Wayne Coy.

TRENTON, July 21 -- Gill Robb Wilson, State Director of Aviation and a former Presbyterian minister, announced today his candidacy for the Republican nomination for United States Senator, putting himself in a spirited primary fight with Albert W. Hawkes, Kearny industrialist, and Joseph A. Bower, Montclair banker and treasurer of the Republican State Committee.

WASHINGTON, July 21 -- Two young Navy fliers in a dive bomber shot down seven Japanese Zero planes in two successive days of fighting in the Coral Sea, as a sideline to the performance of their attack missions.
Mr. and Mrs. F. Murray Forbes of Wellesley, Mass., are at the Ritz-Carlton.
The following German High Command communique was broadcast from Berlin and was recorded here by The Associated Press:

Vinnie Rossano of Red Hook ended the victory string of George (Sonny) Horne of Valley Stream, L.I., in the main six-round bout at the Queensboro Arena last night before a crowd of 4,000. Each weighed 153 pounds.

WASHINGTON, July 21 -- Friction over the arrest of the four saboteurs on Long Island developed today between the Federal Bureau of Investigation and the United States Coast Guard as the trial of the eight invaders proceeded for the twelfth day.

WASHINGTON, July 21 -- A reciprocal trade agreement between the United States and Uruguay was signed in Montevideo today by William Dawson, the American Ambassador, and Dr. Alberto Guani, the Uruguayan Foreign Minister.

Because of the "difficult situation which arises as a result of the scarcity of ocean tonnage due to war conditions," the allowed period of suspension from excise tax payments on merchandise exported or sold for export should be extended from six to at least twelve months. exporters urged yesterday in a special petition to the Treasury Department.
TRENTON, July 21 (AP) -- The first decrease in living costs since December, 1939, was reported today by the New Jersey Department of Agriculture.
As Broadway bowed in tribute to fighting men the world over yesterday with the opening of the Times Square Service Men's Center, missing from the ceremony was the stirring beat of a band.

PITTSBURGH, July 21 -- The policy-making committee of the United Steel Workers of America (C.I.O.) sent formal notice tonight to the management of "Big Steel" companies of its intention to reopen wage negotiations on the general basis of the standard established by the decision of the War Labor Board.

WASHINGTON, July 21 -- Andrew J. Higgins, president of the Higgins Shipbuilding Corporation of New Orleans, said tonight that he "felt encouraged" that the Maritime Commission would rescind its cancellation of his contract to build 200 cargo ships.

In the July 19 issue of THE TIMES' financial section Joseph M. Marrone of the Inter-American Commercial Arbitration Commission is quoted as follows: "Despite wartime restrictions on foreign trade, business men in this country have a 'patriotic duty' to keep their Latin-American customers supplied and to fulfill the spirit as well as the letter of their contracts."

WASHINGTON, July 21 -- While President Roosevelt, at a press conference today, asserted that whatever he had to say about wages would be stated in a message to Congress, it was reported in White House circles that the President's views would not be embodied in legislation but rather an Executive order.

Predicting that in the post-war period the fashion industries here will have the greatest opportunity in their history, Anton De Haas, Professor of International Relationships at the Harvard Graduate School of Business Administration, yesterday urged the creation of an Academy of Fashion, through which designers and manufacturers can cooperate in the creation of styles "truly interpretive of the American way of life" that will find favor in Europe and Latin America.

This Winter the northeastern part of the country will shiver indoors with the thermometer standing at 60 degrees or less unless the warnings of General Brice P. Disque, War Coordinator of the Anthracite Industry, are heeded. Even if Mr. Ickes' pipe lines and the projected barges and canals were ready for service now at least 400,000 home oil-burning furnaces must be converted to burn coal.

Since Hitler invaded Poland nearly three years ago the gladly accepted demands on the American public for war relief have steadily increased both in number and in the amount of money needed. Since Dec. 7 the requirements of our own fighting men and their families have grown beyond all anticipation.

"Priorities on Parade," which arrives at the Paramount, will be this morning's lone film newcomer. Featured in the Paramount romantic musical, the story of which is set in a war plant, are Jerry Colonna, Ann Miller. Betty Rhodes, Johnnie Johnston and Vera Vague.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., July 21 -- Westchester County concluded a successful blackout and civilian protection mobilization test at 9:59 tonight. The surprise drill was supposed to include the Putnam County area, but ten minutes before the Westchester blackout ended, civilian protection officials learned that the Putnam authorities had not been notified and had failed up to that time to observe the blackout.

NEWARK, N.J., July 21 (AP) -- Dimout regulations cost Montreal a 3-3 tie with Newark tonight. The Royals scored three times in the ninth inning, but when the 9:25 P.M. deadline struck with only one out in the home half the score reverted back to the end of the eighth. That gave the Bears a 3-0 decision.

BERNE, Switzerland, July 21 -- Finland's onerous financial situation, necessitating increased taxation wherever it can be applied, has led to a situation that threatens to cause the resignation of Finance Minister Vaino A. Tanner, if not of the entire government, in the opinion of competent Finnish observers.

WASHINGTON, July 21 -- The Senate began consideration today of a bill which Senator Barkley warned, would result if enacted in "rivalry, confusion and chaos" in the government's effort to manufacture sufficient synthetic rubber to meet military and essential civilian needs.
Mayor La Guardia declared yesterday that because of the state of war between Belgium and Germany it was no crime for a Belgian to kill a German at every opportunity.

An executive meeting of the Council on Books in Wartime was held yesterday at the Book Publishers Bureau to discuss the future structure and activities of the organization. Recently a board of directors of seventeen representatives of the book industry was formed and yesterday Franklin F. Hopper, director of the New York Public Library, joined this group, which is headed by Warder W. Norton.

CHICAGO, July 21 -- Installment paper is being liquidated steadily, and automobile and other finance companies are continuing to seek new avenues of employment for idle funds, the regular quarterly meeting of directors of the American Finance Conference disclosed here today.

WASHINGTON, July 21 (AP) -- William M. Leiserson, chairman of the national railway labor panel, announced tonight the selection of three members of the panel to serve as an emergency board to investigate labor disputes involving thirty-four carriers.

The nine-story apartment house containing fifty-four apartments at 345 West Eighty-eighth Street near Riverside Drive has been sold by Bud A. Lipman and Oscar Lieberman to the Merriam Management corporation.

CHICAGO, July 21 -- Hedging pressure against the movement of the new Winter wheat crop was the smallest in several days, and with a little mill buying and closing of spreads between wheat and corn the wheat advanced today around 1 cent a bushel from the previous close before profit-taking checked the upturn.

WASHINGTON, July 21 -- Liberalization of sugar allowances to take care of the needs of industrial users in areas where war plant operations have brought a sharp increase in population will be announced shortly by the Office of Price Administration.

I have read with interest in THE NEW YORK TIMES Henry J. Kaiser's suggestion to the Maritime Commission that nine of the nation's big shipyards be turned over to the building of giant aerial freighters. Let us hope his recommendation will meet with early acceptance by our government.

On Aug. 1 the brokerage commission for war risk insurance on cargo shipments will be reduced to 5 per cent from 10 per cent where the rate of premium is in excess of 1 per cent of the value of the goods shipped, which applies to most shipments these days.

FORT DES MOINES, Iowa, July 21 (AP) -- Director Oveta Culp Hobby of the Women's Army Auxiliary Corps pledged to England and China tonight that the women of the United States "shall be with you in the bitter struggle that is still ahead of us."

LONDON, July 21 -- The worst conditions of German-controlled Europe continue to prevail in Greece and some parts of Poland and occupied Russia, in all of which "there can be no doubt that deaths from starvation have occurred," the House of Commons was informed today by Dingle M. Foot, Parliamentary Secretary to the Ministry of Economic Warfare.

The German High Command reported yesterday that Rostov was in flames and under concentric attack from three directions, and that German troops were rapidly advancing to the southeast, despite difficult terrain and strong mine barrages, according to German broadcasts recorded by The Associated Press.

Seven weeks ago today the Japanese made their first assault on the Aleutian Islands. This was the attack on Dutch Harbor. Several days later came the Japanese claim that several of the western Aleutians had been occupied. This claim was at first dismissed by our own naval authorities with the light-hearted comment that "none of our inhabited islands or rocks are troubled with uninvited visitors up to this time."

If India were only India the storm gathering to a head in the sullen cities and waiting villages from the Indus to the mouth of the Ganges would cast a very large shadow over the ravaged face of Asia. If India were only India it would still be one of the most complex and difficult problems in the world.

Emil K. Ellis, counsel to the City Council committee which investigated the Municipal Civil Service Commission and Paul J. Kern, its former president, said yesterday that he would file suit in Supreme Court against the city to collect a fee of $197,968 for his work.

The threatened strike of 22,000 A.F. of L. building craftsmen on naval construction projects in the New York area was postponed yesterday for twenty-four hours at the request of Secretary of the Navy Frank Knox to give government authorities time to adjust the controversy over the employment of WPA workers at Fort Schuyler in the Bronx.
WASHINGTON, July 21 -- Shipping losses during the week of July 12 reached the highest level since the beginning of the war, the War Shipping Administration said today.

JERSEY CITY, July 21 (AP) -- Bobby Coombs, brilliant Jersey City righthander, gave the Little Giants a two-to-one edge in their three-game series with the Toronto Maple Leafs today as he notched a one-hitter to shade Joe Sullivan and Jack Hallett in a thrilling pitchers' battle, 1 to 0.

WASHINGTON, July 21 -- Admiral William D. Leahy's appointment as "Chief of Staff" to President Roosevelt, the commander in chief of the Army and Navy, comes at a time when the global war in which we are engaged is approaching its supreme crisis.

WASHINGTON, July 21 -- The laws against treason will be applied to any one in a labor organization who tries to bring about a work stoppage over jurisdictional disputes, according to a declaration made by Wayne Lyman Morse, public member, at a meeting of the War Labor Board today.

LONDON, July 21 -- Swarms of Spitfires skimmed the treetops over the coastal areas of Occupied France and Belgium again this evening in the second of their mass raids at zero altitude. The Second Eagle Squadron participated in this one.

A series of robberies in the garment district was believed solved yesterday with the arrest of Anthony Albanese, 31 years old, of 129 Cherry Street, who was seized ten minutes after he and a partner allegedly held up the Beacon Frocks, Inc., 1385 Broadway, and fled with its $1,860 payroll.

WITH BRITISH EIGHTH ARMY IN EGYPT, July 20 (Delayed) -- Although enemy artillery and infantry are still making sporadic attempts to shove the British forces, particularly Australians, off strategic ridges they have taken during the last ten days, even the traditional German endurance has not proved equal to the task.

ALBANY, July 21 -- Steps to provide tags for all children of the State for purposes of identification were approved at a meeting of the State War Council this afternoon. The plan, which does not apply to either New York City or Rochester, which have their own identification systems, is to have each county and local war council purchase tags at a cost of about one cent each.

AT SEA WITH THE PACIFIC FLEET, June 18 (Delayed) -- When the Japanese have been driven out of Kiska and the Aleutians have been blocked as a road to conquest, the people concerned with such things will find time to pin medals on the men flying and fighting this command's Catalina flying boats.

HACKENSACK, N.J., July 21 -- Prosecutor John J. Breslin Jr. of Bergen County decided tonight that he would mend a detective to San Francisco to question James A. Boyd, 59 years old, former New York lumber company salesman, who made a "confession" Monday to the slaying of R. Norman Redwood, business agent of a sandhogs union, who was killed at his Teaneck home on Feb. 17, 1937.
The texts of the letters to Senator Mead, signed by nineteen New York State Democrats and Senator Wagner, were as follows:

Frank J. Wall, vice president of the New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad, admitted yesterday at an Interstate Commerce Commission hearing in the Hotel St. George, Brooklyn, that the railroad's revenues had increased $16,000,000 in the first five months of this year as compared with the same period last year.

DETROIT, July 21 -- A laboratory to be used for developing new food uses for agricultural products was opened by Henry Ford at his Dearborn laboratories today with his old friend, Dr. George Washington Carver, Tuskegee scientist, present as a guest of honor.

GLEN HEAD, L.I., July 21 -- After the first round had been completed in the Women's Long Island Golf Association medal play championship over the Cedar Creek course today four contestants were tied for the lead at 83.

GLEN HEAD, L.I., July 21 -- After the first round had been completed in the Women's Long Island Golf Association medal play championship over the Cedar Creek course today four contestants were tied for the lead at 83.

CAIRO, July 21 -- While the British Eighth Army and Axis troops eyed each other yesterday without carrying hostilities farther than sporadic shelling and patrol raiding, the Royal Air Force again took the fight to the enemy's camp and chalked up impressive totals of Axis airplanes destroyed or damaged, trucks blasted and supply vessels bombarded.

A United Press dispatch from Chungking, published in THE NEW YORK TIMES July 14, attributed to Chinese Communications Minister Chang Kia-ngau the statement that Allied planes were delivering war supplies to China from India "in quantities as large as truck fleets ever brought in over the Burma Road."

CAMDEN, N.J., July 21 (AP) --H.R. Dulany Jr.'s Visiting Nurse moved into the picture for Saturday's stake offering when she raced three-quarters of a mile in 1:10 4-5 to set a new track record while beating four opponents at the new Garden State Park today.

CHICAGO, July 21 -- Johnny Lehman, Chicago insurance salesman, who calls himself "just an old gray-haired man," split medal honors today with youthful Johnny Holmstrom of Rockford, Ill., at the completion of Tam o'Shanter's thirty-six-hole qualifying trials in the All-American amateur tournament.

Edwin Franko Goldman and the Goldman Band gave the audience of 11,000 that assembled last night on the Mall in Central Park a program of modern music, most of it by American composers. The crowd has greeted old favorites with greater applause, but nevertheless its attitude was decidedly cordial.

MILWAUKEE, July 22 Enactment by all State Legislatures of laws setting a 40-mile speed limit for the duration of the war as a means of conserving tires, was recommended today in a resolution adopted by the American Association of Motor Vehicle Commissioners at the closing session of the annual national conference here.

Although there is a waiting list of women willing to serve the Women's Auxiliary Aircraft Warning Service of the First Fighter Command at night, there is a desperate need for daytime volunteers, Mrs. Edward V. Rickenbacker, wife of the World War flier, declared yesterday.

The new management installed by Brewster Aeronautical Corporation after its release from control by the Navy on May 20, 1942, yesterday faced some thirty stockholders at an adjournment of the annual meeting, and won a resolution of "thanks and appreciation" after G.A. Van Dusen, the president, had endeavored to answer all but censorable questions.

Standard Brands, Inc., reported yesterday for the six months ended on June 30 a consolidated net income of $2,864,877 after all charges and taxes, but prior to provision for possible inventory losses. The net was equal, after preferred dividend requirements, to 19 cents a common share.

WITH BRITISH TANK FORCES, in Egypt, July 22 -- This battlefield is covered with dead men and burning trucks, wrecked guns and charred supply dumps, and a fierce battle of infantry, artillery and tanks rages.

NEWARK, N.J., July 22 (AP) -- Montreal ended a nine-game losing streak today by defeating the league-leading Newark Bears, 3 to 1, behind the five-hit pitching of 20-year-old Chet Kehn. The defeat also ended a five-game winning streak for the Bears.

I think it is well established that war brings destruction of homes, lives and morals. There is nothing we can do to stop planes from dropping bombs on us. If we and our homes are to be destroyed in that manner, I am willing to take it. However, when I look at the newspapers and see that some homes are being deliberately broken up, I complain.

LONDON, July 22 -- Rubber from Japan has already reached Germany, while shipments of machine tools needed by the Japanese have been delivered to them with the compliments of the Nazis, it was said here today.

LONDON, July 22 (AP) -- Viscount Simon, Lord Chancellor, told the House of Lords today that he had heard "no whisper of any intention" on the part of Great Britain to return to the gold standard after the war. In answer to a question the Lord Chancellor said:

A syndicate headed by Phelps, Fenn Co. was the successful bidder yesterday for $878,000 of Series A bonds of the New York City Housing Authority, receiving the award on a bid of par for a combination of interest rates that represented a net interest cost to the authority for the funds of 1.8101 per cent.

LONDON, July 22 -- Three hundred British planes bombed the Ruhr last night. Many of them were the newest and heaviest type of bombers. They carry bombs that weigh 4,000 pounds -- one of which contains enough concentrated destruction to level a whole city block.

WASHINGTON, July 22 -- Any one who willfully attempts to violate the new gasoline rationing plan will be prosecuted, Leon Henderson, Administrator of the Office of Price Administration, declared today as the new plan went into effect in rationed areas.

SALEM, Ore., July 22 (U.P.) -Senator Rufus C. Holman of Oregon contends that "criminally obsolete, woefully inadequate and poorly distributed" defense installations guard the West Coast of the United States and Alaska.

WASHINGTON, July 22 -- The Maritime Commission announced this afternoon that after a special meeting at which it heard Andrew Jackson Higgins and carefully considered again the matter of cancellation of contracts with the corporation of New Orleans for 200 Liberty ships it "regrets that in the face of the available facts it cannot rescind the action taken on July 18."

WASHINGTON, July 22 (AP) -- The Navy Department today issued Casualty List No. 8, showing one dead, four wounded and six missing from New York State, and one dead, one wounded and one missing from New Jersey, for the period from July 1 to July 10.

WASHINGTON, July 22 -- The War Production Board placed all long staple cotton, both domestic and foreign, under tight restrictions today, which will apparently restrict its use to military fabrics. Its normal uses were for high strength cotton fabrics, such as balloon cloth, airplane fabrics, typewriter ribbon, tracing cloth, and for shirts, raincoats and women's wear.

WASHINGTON, July 22 -- A long-simmering quarrel between the Department of Agriculture and the Office of Price Administration has been brought to a head with a decision today by the former to increase the price it is paying for butter from 36 to 39 cents a pound in order to get more butter for lease-lend shipment, it was learned tonight.

AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, Australia, Thursday, July 23 -- A Japanese invasion force has landed at Buna, about 100 miles across the southeastern arm of the island of New Guinea from Port Moresby, last Allied outpost north of Australia in the southwestern Pacific, a communique announced today.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., July 22 -- Playland, Westchester's $10,000,000 amusement center on Long Island Sound at Rye, will be closed for the Winter after Labor Day and may not be reopened next Spring if wartime restrictions become more acute, County Park Commission officials disclosed today.

WASHINGTON, July 22 (AP) -- J.A. Krug, chief of the power branch of the War Production Board, expressed confidence today that war production would not be crippled by a shortage of electric power. "We have sufficient electric power," he said, "to meet all the requirements of war production and for essential civilian needs, if used wisely -- as far as we can see ahead."

VICHY, France, July 22 -- The first action toward the application of the French labor charter promulgated by the government last October was instituted here at a meeting of the Interministerial Committee for the Charter held this morning under the presidency of Chief of Government Pierre Laval.

Gay H. Brown, chief counsel for the New York State Public Service Commission, charged yesterday at an Interstate Commerce Commission hearing that Long Island Railroad trains were overcrowded and the cars dirty. The information came out in the cross-examination of Albert E. Stewart, superintendent of passenger transportation for the New York zone of the Pennsylvania and Long Island Railroads.

The report of the Public Service Corporation of New Jersey and subsidiaries for the twelve months ended on June 30, issued yesterday, shows a net income after operating expenses, taxes and other charges of $16,649,740. This was equal, after preferred dividend requirements, to $1.23 a share on the corporation's 5,503,193 shares of common stock outstanding and compares with a net of $22,861,191, or $2.36 a common share, in the twelve months to June 30, 1941.

WITH THE BRITISH EIGHTH ARMY, in Egypt, July 22 -- A unit of the American Field Service is at present on duty at the front line of this desert war. It comprises twenty vehicles that are the gifts of American persons and organizations.

WASHINGTON, July 22 -- President Roosevelt conferred at the White House today with Maxim Litvinoff, the Soviet Ambassador, presumably on the subject of opening a second front in Europe, as the German armies advanced in their attempt to take Rostov and Stalingrad.

Rostov, gateway to the Caucasus, appeared to be close to semi-encirclement yesterday, and the Nazis were driving hard toward Stalingrad on the Volga. The German successes in Southern Russia, near the lower reaches of the Don River, were but slightly tempered by continued Russian assaults against the German bridgeheads at Voronezh and by reports that the Russians were massing large reserve forces along the Don and the Volga to meet the German thrust.

A library of 2,000 volumes and more than 4,000 unbound books and pamphlets dealing with significant social legislation in the United States, Great Britain and Puerto Rico during the last fifty years, has been presented to Columbia University by Samuel McCune Lindsay, Professor Emeritus of Social Legislation, it was announced yesterday.

Assurances that Mayor La Guardia would be supplied as quickly as possible with the data he has requested on the fuel oil situation were made yesterday in a statement by B.H. Belknap, vice president of the Real Estate Board of New York in charge of its management division.

CHUNGKING, China, July 22 -- Although Tokyo is talking about the benefits expected from the "Korea-Singapore Railway," much mileage still is to be fought for, much of it in some of the most difficult territory the Japanese have yet encountered.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 22 -- Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer today purchased "Feast of Reason," a forthcoming novel by Dorothy Walworth, and assigned the story to Sam Marx for screen production. The property was bought from galley proofs and, like Metro's "The Women" of two seasons ago, the film will have an entirely feminine cast.

The semi-annual statement of the Pepsi-Cola Company, announced yesterday by Walter S. Mack Jr., president, shows consolidated earnings of $7,135,361 for the first six months of 1942 after all charges, but before United States and Canadian income and excess profits taxes.

WASHINGTON, July 22 -- The Senate, with nine of its ninety-six members present and with a voice vote, today passed legislation, opposed bitterly by the Administration, which would strip from the War Production Board its authority over the manufacture of synthetic rubber from alcohol drawn from agricultural products, and create an independent agency to promote and control this phase of the war program.

Directors of the Bank of Montreal authorized yesterday the regular quarterly dividend payment of $2 a share, but beginning with the next dividend, have decided to reduce the annual rate to $6 from $8 due to increased taxes.

WASHINGTON, July 22 -- A concentrated drive to persuade 70,000 eligible nurses to sign up with the Red Cross First Reserve will start on Monday, July 27, with a nation-wide radio campaign, it was learned today at Red Cross national headquarters.
The text of the statement of James A. Farley, attacking the Mead candidacy, follows:
NEW DELHI, India, July 22 (U.P.) -- Mohandas K. Gandhi, Indian Nationalist leader, said today that he "would rather be shot" than submit to or cooperate with Japan or any other Power."

The stock market displayed a surprising amount of self-assurance in most of yesterday's session, but a late break in the steels brought considerable sympathetic selling. The general list failed to be materially disturbed, however, and the strength in the rails supplied sufficient background so that the closing was only irregular.

Three more sinkings were announced by the Navy yesterday, with a loss of at least thirty-five lives. The machine-gunning of a dinghy bearing survivors, the use of a tin can to send heliograph messages and the heroism of a 25-year-old seaman who gave his life for his shipmates were among the stories told.

Since Ed Wynn is set on closing "Laugh, Town, Laugh!" next Saturday night, any tardy lovers of nonsense must hop up to the Alvin in a hurry. For Ed's potpourri of pleasures is the best of the 1942 vaudeville shows, with nothing but its cleanliness against it. As coordinator of a variety bill, he is, of course, the peerless performer-genial, comical and magnetic.

John Francis Dwyer, Navy aviation radioman, reported wounded in action, is 20 years old and had to obtain the permission of his parents, Mr. and Mrs. James F. Dwyer of 38-25 Corporal Kennedy Street, Bayside, Queens, when he enlisted in the Navy on March 9, 1941.

CHICAGO, July 22 -- Mill buying of wheat futures and a further advance in the price of the cash article compared with the September, coupled with a removal of the embargo against shipments of free wheat to Kansas City, lifted prices on the Board of Trade today around 1 cent a bushel at the extreme.

WASHINGTON, July 22 -- The National War Labor Board today directed the J.I. Case Company of Racine Wis., to include a maintenance-of-membership provision in its contracts with the United Automobile Workers, Congress of Industrial Organizations, but denied the union's request for the check-off of union dues.

PHILADELPHIA, July 22 (AP) -- Bunching fourteen hits behind John Beazley's shut-out pitching, the Cardinals scored an easy 7-0 victory over the Phils today in the second game of their series. It was Beazley's eleventh victory this season.

Michael James Getto will serve as the new head coach of the Brooklyn Football Dodgers this year, it was officially announced yesterday by Dan Topping, president of the club, following a meeting with the former All-America tackle.

MOSCOW, Thursday, July 23 (AP) -- The million-man German Army pounding at the Caucasus and the Volga has driven a deep wedge roughly half way between Rostov and Stalingrad, and the sorely pressed Russians have fallen back on the outer defenses of Rostov for a finish fight, the Russians indicated officially early today.

The Theatre Guild announced yesterday that Richard Rodgers, Lorenz Hart, and Oscar Hammerstein 2d will soon begin work on a musical version of Lynn Riggs's folk-play, "Green Grow the Lilacs," which the Guild produced for sixty-four performances at the Guild Theatre in 1931.

We have yet to see any one demonstrate how it is possible to continue to increase wages in the face of a growing scarcity of goods without bringing on inflation. Nor have we heard any one contend that inflation is from labor's standpoint a satisfactory means of achieving "equality of sacrifice."

A "selective service" yardstick for nurses, putting the question, "How can I best serve my country at this time?" squarely up to the individual nurse as well as to her employer, was submitted yesterday to the National Nursing Council for War Service at its annual meeting, held in the Henry Hudson Hotel, 353 West Fifty-seventh Street.

WASHINGTON, July 22 (AP) -- The Office of Price Administration and the Department of Agriculture sought a solution tonight to a "squeeze" between prices of livestock and meat products which appeared to be creating a shortage of pork and beef in Eastern centers.

OLD ORCHARD, Me., July 22 (AP) -- Colby Hanover, the early Hambletonian favorite, out-trotted several of the strongest contenders he will meet in that famed stake today when he captured two of the three heats in the $9,078 National Stake on the kite-shaped track.

WASHINGTON, July 22 -- Arthur B. Newhall, Rubber Coordinator, said today that the War Production Board would try to provide tires "for essential driving" for every serviceable automobile in the country, when men representing the news services asked him to comment on the plan of the Rubber Manufacturers Association to cope with the civilian tire problem.

CHICAGO, July 22 -- Wholesale butter prices rose 1 1/4 to 1 1/2 cents a pound here today as the government announced it would support the market for 92 score butter, popular consumer grade, at 39 cents a pound. This is the highest price paid for butter in the wholesale market since December, 1927, and the highest July price since 1929.

CHICAGO, July 22 (AP) -- Luke Appling's double with two mates on base in the sixth inning today broke up a pitchers' duel between Buck Ross and Charley Wagner and gave the White Sox a 2-to-0 victory over the Red Sox.

Swing came out in the open last night and 20,000 New Yorkers jammed a block in West Fifty-second Street to hear the music. From nightfall until nearly dawn name bands from "Swing Street" left their dimly-lighted clubs to "send" their best "jive" under the arc lights.

LOS ANGELES, July 22 (AP) -- Eight Southern California men were named in a secret indictment returned in Washington yesterday charging conspiracy to break down the morale of the military and naval forces of the nation, Russell K. Lambeau, Assistant United States District Attorney, said-tonight.

New York is faced with the prospect of a serious shortage of physicians as well as nurses owing to the war, officials of civilian protection services in the metropolitan district were informed yesterday at the last of a series of regional meetings on plans of the State War Council to meet emergencies.

CAIRO, Egypt, July 22 -- An attack that by early today was being pressed along the entire front extending southward from the region of El Alamein was begun last night by United Kingdom and Dominion troops on the central sector.

SOMERVILLE, Mass., July 22 (AP) -- Physicians disclosed today that they had set up an emergency device consisting of two water bottles and a length of rubber tubing in an effort to save the life of Ethel House, 12, whose heart was forced far to the right of her chest when she fell on a picket fence.

Good reasons for elation among members of the salt-water fishing fraternity partial to Southern New Jersey are contained in the latest announcement from Percy H. Jackson, director of the annual Cape May County contest now in progress.

TENAFLY, N.J., July 22 -- Representative Frank C. Osmers Jr. of Haworth announced today that he would not be a candidate for renomination by the Republicans in the Ninth Congressional District and at the expiration of his present term on Dec. 31 would apply for active duty in the Army.

Why should Congress worry so much about the money necessary to carry on the work of the Office of Price Administration? Suppose Mr. Henderson does employ a few men who are not yet expert in the work of their particular position? What happens?

WASHINGTON, July 22 -- The Office of Price Administration today ordered residential rents cut back and established in eighteen more defense rental areas varying in size from Key West, Fla., with population of 14,078 to Milwaukee, with 987,181. In fourteen of the areas rents will be rolled back to March 1, levels; two areas will have July 1, 1941, ceilings; one will have April 1, 1941, and one Jan. 1, 1941.

Work stoppages due to labor disputes cost 254,653 "man-days" of war production in June, an increase of 117,353 days over May, the War Labor Board reported yesterday. The time lost in June was .09 per cent of the total war work done, compared with .06 per cent in May.

Retail promotional activity in women's Fall coats and suits is now gathering momentum. Not enough time has elapsed as yet, however, to get an accurate idea of probable consumer response. However, some special orders are coming through from buyers calling for special sizes and colors.
CAIRO, Egypt, July 22 (AP) -- A joint British Headquarters and Royal Air Force communique said today:
NEW DELHI, India, July 22 (Reuter) -- Today's communique from air headquarters contained the following:

CHUNGKING, China, July 22 -- Pienkwan, a small town in northwestern Shansi, recently retaken by Chinese forces, is typical of Japanese exploitation in occupied China. When the Japanese captured Pienkwan for the third time in March, 1939, the puppet government, immediately organized, announced a levy of money and materials.

DETROIT, July 22 (AP) -- Tall Sid Hudson achieved his long-sought fifth victory today by holding the Tigers to five hits in a twilight game while Roy Cullenbine's two-run homer in the fifth gave the Senators a 2-1 triumph to square the series at one game each.

Captain Randolph Churchill, 31year-old son of the Prime Minister of Great Britain who is on his way to lngland from Egypt by way of the Western Hemisphere route, predicted yesterday that the United Nations would be victorious by the end of next year, "if we're lucky," otherwise by the end of the following year.

The appointment of Admiral Leahy as "Chief of Staff to the Commander in Chief of the Army and Navy" is a step in the right direction. His duty, as the President describes it, will be to do "leg work, index work and summary work" in the field of military strategy for the benefit of the President himself.

ST. LOUIS, July 22 (AP) -- The Athletics scored nine times in two innings today to overcome a 6-run deficit and defeat the Browns, 11 to 8. It was only the second defeat for St. Louis in its last thirteen games and this one appeared to be in the bag until Connie Mack's men came to bat in the fifth inning trailing by an even half dozen runs.
London, July 22 (AP) -- An Air Ministry communique said today:

PATERSON, N.J., July 22 (AP) -- The first National Boxing Association president ever elected to succeed himself, Abe J. Greene announced tonight a coordination program to place the sport in the front line of war endeavor.
A shortage of meat developed in some areas, mostly in the East, yesterday in the midst of the country's campaign to produce abundant food for victory.

Of the 9,000 shoppers entering the average supermarket in a week, 39 per cent are men, according to a survey just completed by Sherman K. Ellis. Of these about 10 per cent accompany women, while the other 29 per cent shop alone.
MOSCOW, Thursday, July 23 (AP) -- The midnight Soviet communique said:

The perturbation expressed in your editorial of July 17 about the ruling of the War Labor Board will, I think, seem unfounded to many of your readers. In effect, you are arguing that the steel workers should suffer a cut in their real wages (measured by purchasing power) and in their relative wages (measured by the admitted profits of the steel corporations).

NIAGARA FALLS, N.Y., July 22 -- Ray Billows again hoisted the flag of the Dutchess Club in Poughkeepsie to the top of the pole when he led a field of almost 100 players home in today's qualifying round of the twentieth annual New York State amateur golf championship.

BERNE, Switzerland, July 22 (AP) -- Joseph Cardinal Van Roey, Primate of Belgium, was disclosed today to have written a strong letter of protest to German military authorities against their order to Belgian coal miners to work one Sunday and holiday in each month.

If there is any one best way of persuading American labor leaders that this is a war for freedom a threat of being prosecuted for treason isn't it. No doubt Public Member Wayne Lyman Morse of the War Labor Board was suffering from frayed nerves when he made this threat on Tuesday.
CLEVELAND, July 22 -- The Yankee steamroller almost came to a halt today when for nine innings only Charlie Keller's twelfth homer kept the world champions locked in a 1 -- all tie with the Indians.

Axis forces have crossed the Don River on a wide front above its confluence with the Donets, seventy miles northeast of Rostov, the German High Command reported yesterday, according to German broadcasts recorded by The United Press.

More than half of the estate of Mrs. Margaret P. Daly, widow of Marcus Daly, Montana copper mine operator, will go for payment of estate taxes. Mrs. Daly died at her Summer home in Bitter Root Valley, Hamilton, Mont., on July 14, 1941, leaving an estate valued in excess of $12,000,000.

WASHINGTON, July 22 -- President Roosevelt met with legislative leaders and with the Pacific War Council; he appointed Secretary Ickes as fishery coordinator; his visitors included Soviet Ambassador Litvinoff, Manuel Quezon, Secretary Morgenthau, Major Gen. Follett Bradley and Vice Admiral Frederick J. Horne.

The farewell to neutrality uttered by the Norwegian Government-in-Exile is a straw in a rising wind. Norway's representatives in London reject the idea of a Scandinavian federation after the war on the ground that a union of Norway, Sweden, Denmark and Finland would not be strong enough within its exposed frontiers to defend itself from one or more of the Great Powers.

"Big Jim" Farley, the man who was responsible more than any one else for the nomination of Franklin D. Roosevelt for President in 1932, staked his political life last night in a blast directed at Mr. Roosevelt's candidate for Governor, James M. Mead.

The ten-story structure known as the Hotel Churchill and the adjoining three-story and basement dwelling at 250-56 West Seventy-sixth Street have been sold by the Bank for Savings to the Seventy-sixth Street Hotel Corporation.

Forty members of a society of Italian war veterans who had pledged undying fealty to Mussolini have been seized here and taken to Ellis Island as dangerous alien enemies, P.E. Foxworth, assistant director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, announced yesterday.

Stocks of gasoline in the United States at the close of last week amounted to 84,069,000 barrels, a decline of 1,589,000 from the 85,658,000 reported a week earlier, according to the American Petroleum Institute. A year ago these stocks were 86,291,000 barrels.

MOSCOW, Thursday, July 23 -- The Germans are approaching Rostov, gateway to the Caucasus, in their southern drive. The Soviet midnight communique, giving this news, announced that battles were continuing in the regions of Novocherkassk, about twenty miles northeast of Rostov, and Tsimlyansk, on the Don River, 125 miles from Rostov and some distance west of the river's loop.

The action of a United States Government agency in banning the importation of silver by private interests is considered generally to be for the purpose of preventing a sharp rise in the price of the metal in Latin America. The heavy demand for silver in industry here in recent months has resulted in consumption outstripping production, particularly since the domestic output is being purchased by the Treasury Department at 71.11 cents an ounce.
MOSCOW, July 22 (AP) -- The Soviet Information Bureau issued the following communique today:
A Berlin broadcast recorded yesterday by Reuters, British news agency, quoted Lutz Koch, a German war correspondent, who, in writing of the "heavy and fierce fighting for El Alamein," stated:

Automobile owners in the metropolitan area took the first day of permanent gasoline rationing in their stride yesterday. Many walked from their homes to rapid transit lines, leaving their cars at home to avoid an expected rush at filling stations that failed to materialize.

The long drought for boxing will end at Madison Square Garden tonight when the first program of the Summer season is staged by Mike Jacobs, with the air conditioning apparatus in shape and Tami Mauriello hoping to continue his heavyweight victory streak at the expense of the veteran Clarence (Red) Burman in the ten-round feature bout.

Wide disparities between the official rates for the pound sterling and the rates payable for the currency in New York have been sharply reduced in the Spring and early Summer of this year. Banks that felt unable to pay more than $2 are now paying as much as $3.65 for 1 notes and at rates $3.55 and $3.50 for $5 and 10 notes.

The names of eight new tenants have been added to the roster of London Terrace, apartment development in West Twenty-third Street, where suites have been taken by Rafael Vazques, Lieutenant Joseph Burger, Irving Antel, W. Mark Sulkes, Joseph D. Noe, Milton Stoll, Joseph DeCubas Sr. and Mary Navarro.

With the exception of anniversary and clearance sales, most stores are in favor of curtailment of big store-wide promotions, according to a survey made by the sales promotion division of the National Retail Dry Goods Association, the results of which were made public yesterday. Questionnaires were sent to approximately 250 stores located in the East.

Dr. Frank Anthony Calderone, district health officer of the Lower East Side in the city Health Department since 1938, has been appointed secretary of the department, Commissioner Ernest L. Stebbins announced yesterday. Dr. Calderone succeeds Goodhue Livingston Jr., who has resigned to enter Federal service at Washington.
