WASHINGTON, July 22 (AP) -- A.N.Williams, president of the Western Union Telegraph Company, told a House subcommittee today that under the proposed merger of Western Union and Postal Telegraph his company could utilize only about 4,750 out of Postal's 9,900 workers.

The twelve Federal Home Loan Banks report net incomes for the six months ended June 30 of $2,133,591, compared with $1,627,182 in the same period last year, it was revealed in the consolidated statement of the banks released yesterday by Everett Smith, financial representative.

Sharply at 9 o'clock the glass-paned door is unlatched to admit cooks from every corner of the city. All day long the experts arrive, bringing wares to be sold in the friendly shop -- a mirror-lined room with a view, through the big bay window, of an old and rather stately street.

ALBANY, July 22 (AP) -- New York City's Jewish parochial schools are conforming to State requirements, Louis J. Gribetz attorney for twenty-six of the institutions, told the State Board of Regents today.

Initial conferences between New York business men and WPB officials on the problem of inventories held yesterday in the Chanin Building "produced much valuable information from a very cooperative cross-section of retailers and wholesalers," Eaton V.W. Read, chairman of the Wholesale and Retail Inventory Policy Committee of the WPB Office of Civilian Supply, said last night.

NORFOLK, Va., July 22 -- The bodies of twenty-nine crewmen of a German submarine sunk by a destroyer on Atlantic patrol -- the first enemy dead to be landed on American shores in this war -- were brought here and buried with full military honors in near-by Hampton.

Twenty thousand elementary school pupils and their teachers will take part in New York City's first large-scale experiment to do away with semi-annual promotions, it was announced yesterday by Dr. Benjamin B. Greenberg, assistant superintendent of schools.
BOSTON, July 22 (AP) -- Pitching a two-hit game, Claude Passeau chalked up his fourteenth victory today to give the Cubs a 2-to-1 triumph over the Braves.

WASHINGTON, July 22 -- Women's part in the war savings campaign will be increased twofold within a month, Miss Harriet Elliott, head of the Women's Division of the Treasury's War Savings Staff, predicted today following a two-day conference with Mrs. Henry Morgenthau Jr. and four women regional advisers.

May I call attention to the dangerous misuse of a word? Yesterday I heard a preacher say in a sermon that a wave of hate is rising in all countries of the earth and that America also has concentration camps. This phrase may have been used in a careless way, but it may have fateful consequences.

WASHINGTON, July 22 (AP) -Harold L. Ickes, Petroleum Coordinator, today set the August production rate for all petroleum liquids at 4,038.500 barrels daily, almost 200,000 barrels a day over the July output schedule.

Ray Starr was seeing double at Ebbets Field last evening. In fact, he saw too many doubles, because a trio of two-base hits drove in four Dodger runs as the Brooks beat the Reds, 5 to 1, in a twilight-night game before 20,956.
President Roosevelt intervened yesterday in the threatened strike of 22,000 A.F. of L. building craftsmen employed on Navy construction projects in the New York area costing $100,000,000.

CHUNGKING, China, July 22 (U.P.) -- Daw Mya Sein, outstanding woman leader of Burma, said today that her countrymen had no desire to be reconquered by Britain but were "anxiously waiting" to cooperate with the Allies in driving out the Japanese.

SOMEWHERE IN AUSTRALIA, July 21 (Delayed) -- Lieutenant Robert Vaught of Johnson City, Tenn., got a new engine for his pursuit plane the other day. When it was installed he took off from this advanced air base to give it some "slow time," the airmen's equivalent of breaking in that motorists give new automobiles.

As stylists consult their notebooks for solutions to possible wool shortages, an age-old art is rapidly becoming the focal point of a new fashion. The quest for warmth without wool has led to a popular "curtain call" for quilted fabrics encasing a snug insulating layer of cotton batting.

May I call attention to the dangerous misuse of a word? Yesterday I heard a preacher say in a sermon that a wave of hate is rising in all countries of the earth and that America also has concentration camps. This phrase may have been used in a careless way, but it may have fateful consequences.

WASHINGTON, July 22 (AP) -Harold L. Ickes, Petroleum Coordinator, today set the August production rate for all petroleum liquids at 4,038.500 barrels daily, almost 200,000 barrels a day over the July output schedule.

PHILADELPHIA, July 22 -- On a scale never before attempted in the East, Pennsylvania, with the exception of only four counties ravaged by flash floods last weekend, underwent a test blackout tonight from 9:15 to 9:45 o'clock.

WASHINGTON, July 22 -- Deaths from diphtheria in 1940 totaled only 1,457, dropping to a new low rate of 1.1 deaths per 100,000 population as against forty per 100,000 in 1900, and representing a decrease of 14,063 from the total of 15,520 deaths reported from this disease in 1921, the Bureau of the Census reported today.

CHUNGKING, China, July 22 (U.P.) -- Daw Mya Sein, outstanding woman leader of Burma, said today that her countrymen had no desire to be reconquered by Britain but were "anxiously waiting" to cooperate with the Allies in driving out the Japanese.

LONDON, July 22 -- London Transport announced today a dividend at the rate of 1/4 per cent on the quoted C stock for the year ended on Dec. 31, 1942. Payment will be made on Aug. 21. The interim payment in 1941 was at the rate of 3/4 per cent, with the final payment 2 1/8 per cent, making 2 7/8 per cent for the year.

Reconstruction on a large scale of slum areas on the lower East Side is suggested in a report issued yesterday on the relation of tax delinquency to the housing problem prepared by the Citizens Housing Council. Among other recommendations the report urges a change by the city in its taxing policy to facilitate a wide rebuilding program for the blighted sections.

Over in Sailors Snug Harbor on Staten Island ancient seafarers long since relegated by age and infirmities to the quiet haven's halls are quickening their steps and talking about getting back into the merchant marine to help out Uncle Sam.

The sole film newcomer this morning will be Metro's "Crossroads," which will open at the Capitol. Heading the cast of the romantic drama are William Powell and Hedy Lamarr. Basil Rathbone, Claire Trevor, Margaret Wycherly, Sig Rumann, H.B. Warner and Philip Merivale appear in supporting roles.
Mr. and Mrs. Kenneth M. Spence of 117 East Seventy-second Street have gone to Edgartown, Martha's Vineyard, where they have leased the house of Mr. and Mrs. Winthrop Brainard for the Summer.

CHICAGO, July 22 -- Warrants for the arrest of Mrs. Elizabeth Dilling, author of "The Red Network," and two other Chicagoans on charges of conspiracy to break down the morale of the military and naval forces were issued today by Edwin K. Walker, United States Commissioner.

WASHINGTON, July 22 -- Eleven high-ranking members of the new Army Specialist Corps, who will hold the relative ranks of colonel or lieutenant colonel in the Administrative Organization, were named today by President Roosevelt in nominations sent to the Senate for confirmation.

WASHINGTON, July 22 (AP) -- The award of a distinguished service medal to Colonel Francis G. Brink of Marathon, N.Y., and Lieut. Colonel Warren J. Clear of Newton. Mass., for services in the Southwest Pacific war theater was announced today by the War Department.

CHICAGO, July 22 (U.P.) -- R.A. Coward's Marriage ran a mile and a quarter in 2:02 2-5 at Arlington Park today to take the $7,500 added Grassland Handicap and set a new American record for a turf course.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., July 22 -- Many young members of the Summer colony acted as hostesses at the second in a series of entertainments for service men stationed in this vicinity, held this afternoon at the Beach Club. About thirty soldiers and members of the Coast Guard were guests of honor.

Less than twenty-four hours after a policeman caught Anthony Albanese, 31 years old, fleeing from a hold-up in the garment center, the grand jury handed up an indictment accusing him of first-degree robbery and second-degree assault in the use of a pistol.
CHICAGO, July 22 (AP) -- For fourteen hours today, 158 golfers -- playing two tournaments -- attempted to avoid a traffic jam on the Tam o'Shanter course.

GLEN HEAD, L.I., July 22 -- When the Long Island Women's Golf Association changed its medal play championship from fifty-four holes to thirty-six in deference to gas and tire rationing its reckoning did not include a play-off.
The following German High Command communique was broadcast from Berlin yesterday and was recorded here by The Associated Press:

A group of seventy aqueduct patrolmen employed by the City Board of Water Supply in Supreme Court yesterday lost a suit to compel the city to pay them salary increments up to a maximum of $2,280 a year.

WASHINGTON, July 22 -- Three of the German saboteurs landed here by submarine have testified before the military commission in this city, it was revealed today shortly before the secret trial was recessed unexpectedly until Friday, apparently on request of the defense counsel.

WASHINGTON, July 22 -- The House passed by voice vote and sent to the Senate today a bill authorizing the Navy to spend $974,634,000 for naval shore facilities, including $30,000,000 for "a kind of secret training and a kind of secret weapon," as indicated by Representative Vinson, chairman of the Naval Affairs Committee.

While the City Department of Markets disclosed it had received no reports of any shortage of meat here, a spokesman for the department explained that the department was "looking into the situation" and had "not fully documented" all its information.

The problem of preventing inflation is pre-eminently one of controlling the buying power of the consuming public. Prices of staple goods can easily be controlled; but trying to control retail prices in the face of ever-mounting money incomes, particularly on the part of people in need of goods, is a difficult if not an impossible problem.

CHUNGKING, China, July 22 (U.P.) -- Chinese armies have recaptured Kienteh, large county seat sixty-five miles southwest of Hangchow, after a severe five-day battle, and are heavily attacking Wenchow, Chekiang Province seaport, which has changed hands three times since July 11, a war communique said today.

DETROIT, July 23 (AP) -- Pitcher Alejandro Carrasquel, Venezuelan right-hander who went through the first months of the American League season with one victory, scored his third in a week today as the Senators defeated the Tigers, 5 to 3, to clinch the series.

When Konstantine Simonoff's play, "Russian People," opened recently in Moscow it caused quite a bit of excitement in the Soviet capital. Ralph Parker, correspondent there of THE NEW YORK TIMES, cabled this paper: "Its performance abroad would be an important contribution to an understanding of the situation in Russia.''

WASHINGTON, July 23 -- A three-point price adjustment and subsidy program designed to make more meat available for consumers in Eastern cities and to ease the squeeze on smaller packers was announced today by Secretary of Agriculture Claude Wickard.

This nation is daily being "forced closer and closer toward an inflation which would dislocate our whole economy and be disastrous to our war effort," according to an interim report of the executive committee of the Chamber of Commerce of the State of New York, made public yesterday.
WASHINGTON, July 23 -- Twenty-eight persons were indicted as seditionists today when sealed papers were opened in the District of Columbia District Court.

WASHINGTON, July 23 -- An increase of more than 10 per cent in the country's steel ingot capacity by the middle of next year has been recommended to the War Production Board by its iron and steel branch. The increase would bring capacity to 98,279,970 tons as compared with a current rated capacity of 88,569,970 tons.

A new process of color photography that will enable amateurs to develop color films in their home darkrooms was demonstrated for the first time last night at a dinner at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria held in celebration of the hundredth anniversary of the founding ,by Edward Anthony of the firm that is now Afga Ansco.

Walter Sandt, who was suspended last February as air raid zone warden in Queens after heading the so-called revolt of Queens wardens, was quietly restored to duty about a week ago as zone commander of Zone 1, 106th Precinct Ozone Park, Queens.

Establishment of a special government agency to provide loans for manufacturers and other exporters who have goods already made up for Latin-American customers, but who are unable to obtain shipping space promptly because of the war conditions, was advocated yesterday by F.J. Emmerich, vice president of the Block International Corporation.

While Price Administrator Leon Henderson warned yesterday that a shortage of meats in various cities throughout the country might continue from four to six weeks and urged packers not to concentrate shipments in areas with high price ceilings, and while Secretary of Agriculture Wickard forecast that lend-lease shipments would be reduced somewhat within the next few weeks, New York City reported no shortage of meats.

The arrest of an autograph hunter who allegedly mixed a bit of extortion with his literary pursuits was announced yesterday by United States Attorney Mathias F. Correa. The Duke and Duchess of Windsor, Queen Wilhelmina of the Netherlands and Edna St. Vincent Millay were among the notable persons whose handwriting was sought by the young man, according to Mr. Correa.

Come what may in the way of enemy bombs, New York City's gas, electric and telephone services are "ready for the worst," utility officials said yesterday, and they hope the public has been sufficiently educated by now to know what to do -- and what not to do -- about telephones, gas jets and electric lights.

Driven Snow, Nydrie Stable color-bearer who was second in her previous start, was a driving winner at Empire City yesterday in the Golden Bridge purse which brought together juvenile fillies over the five and one-half furlong distance.

JUDGING by our historical fiction, we Americans who buy, rent and borrow books never tire of refighting the Revolution and the Civil War. Whether regarded romantically or realistically, their fascination seems endless, Less of a current fashion, but probably more significant and inspiring to the entire nation, is the winning of the West.
The continued German threat to the Middle East coupled with the current Russian defeats are the latest of a long succession of serious setbacks for the United Nations.

Heavy government expenditures in connection with the war and the return flow of funds here from out-of-town banks following the payment for subscriptions to the new $2,000,000,000 issue of 2 per cent in the previous week, together served to ease materially the reserves position of member banks both throughout the country and in New York City during the week ended on Wednesday, according to statistics released yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.
Your recent editorial condemning the proposed barge canal across Florida, especially for the reasons stated, which, to quote your phrase, "will not bear scrutiny," has come to my notice.

SALEM, N.H., July 23 (AP) -- Charlie Wahler, young apprentice jockey from Philadelphia,, who recently refused a scholarship offering free tuition at a conservatory of music, took full charge of the program at Rockingham Park today when he rode four winners in the first five races.

The various motion picture studios, in cooperation with the industry's War Activities Committee, will jointly sponsor the distribution of "The World at War," the government-financed documentary feature spanning the last ten years of world history, it was learned yesterday.

In this country our political leaders do not have to make one kind of speech for home consumption and another for foreign consumption. The speech that says what nearly all Americans want to hear, as Secretary Hull's radio address did last night, is also fit to be rebroadcast in eight foreign tongues, as Secretary Hull's address was.

LONDON, July 23 -- The British Government declined flatly today to let Parliament in on whatever plans it has for a second front, but the tenor of its statement coupled with an announcement that Britain was digging deep into her remaining manpower aroused speculation as to whether a decision has been reached on an invasion of Europe to help Russia.

WASHINGTON, July 23 -- The Twelfth Federal Reserve District, with headquarters at San Francisco, led all others in June on percentage increase of department store sales over May and June 1, 1941. The district showed an increase of 14 per cent from June, 1941, and a 5 per cent increase over May, 1942.

LONDON, July 23 (AP) -- The Bank of England's weekly condition statement issued today again disclosed a record high for note circulation which increased 2,688,000 to 815,258,000. Reserve figures were lowered 2,704,000.
PRINCETON, N.J., July 23 -Since the fall of Tobruk Prime Minister Churchill's popularity with British voters has suffered the sharpest drop of his twenty-six months in office.

Reflecting the increased payments by charge account customers because of the Federal Reserve Board's credit regulations, retail credit collections in June scored a record increase, according to the twenty-store index of the Credit Bureau of Greater New York, issued yesterday.
WASHINGTON, July 23 -- The government began a double-barreled move today against the tactics of James C. Petrillo, president of the American Federation of musicians.

Organization of an unofficial, voluntary group to encourage, evaluate and promote ideas that will enable the civilian population to contribute more effectively to winning the war was announced yesterday with the opening of Victory Center at 745 Fifth Avenue.

AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, Australia, Friday, July 24 (AP) -- United Nations dive-bombers attacked a new Japanese base on the northern coast of New Guinea yesterday and left a 5,000-ton transport loaded with oil burning in a renewal of offensive action that has cost the Japanese three transports in three days, General Douglas MacArthur's headquarters reported today.
Mayor La Guardia fingerprinted four labor leaders in his office at City Hall yesterday as part of the drive to form a complete civilian identification file of all residents of the city.

Offering will be made today of $1,000,000 Sunoco Products Company serial debentures to mature from July 1 next to 1967, inclusively, by the G.H. Crawford, Inc., Columbia, S.C.; R.S. Dickson Co., Inc., Charlotte, N.C.; McAlister, Smith Pate, Inc., Greenville, S.C., and A.M. Law Co., Spartanburg, S.C.

Three finalists have been chosen in the nation-wide sculpture competition for a monumental figure of "Christ, the Light of the World," to be erected in Washington, the National Catholic Welfare Conference announced yesterday.

The Baldwin Locomotive Works and wholly owned subsidiaries reported yesterday for the twelve months ended on June 30, consolidated net profit of $4,463,145 after provision of $9,037,250 for taxes on income and $300,000 for contingency reserve.

LONDON, July 23 -- The stock markets responded today to the more cheerful news from Egypt with more activity than has been noted lately. The Home Rails were cheered with the 1 per cent interim dividend on The London North Eastern second preference.

LOS ANGELES, July 23 -- Death and disablement are taking an appalling toll of young men and women who rushed into factories to help turn out materials necessary for defense of their country L. Metcalfe Walling of the Department of Labor said today.

The Giants let the Pirates have it with both barrels yesterday. One shot was a two-run homer by Johnny Mize and the other a three-run homer by Babe Young as the New Yorkers defeated the Pittsburghers at the Polo Grounds, 6 to 4, and took undisputed possession of third place, for which they had been tied with the idle Reds.

The weakness in some of the pivotal shares, notably United States Steel, which carried over from the previous session and then was accentuated, depressed yesterday the remainder of the stock market. Prices were undermined from major fractions to 2 points as the losses eclipsed any for the last two months under an avalanche of sales at noon, although selling in other portions of the session was not pressing.

Frank J. Fell Jr., Vice president and controller of the Long Island Railroad, testified yesterday at an Interstate Commerce Commission hearing that the Long Island Railroad had operated for the past six years at a deficit of $3,269,000. The hearing is one of a series being held in the Hotel St. George, Brooklyn, on the application of eleven railroads for a 10 per cent increase in commutation rates for New York State traffic.

German and Slovak troops have broken through the fortified bridgehead around Rostov and have reached the outskirts of the city, the German High Command reported yesterday, according to Berlin broadcasts recorded by The United Press.

LOURENCO MARQUES, July 22 (Delayed) -- The Japanese are doing their utmost to obtain needed supplies of rice from Indo-China, but are having transport difficulties that have cut down their supplies to a mere dribble, it can now be reported.
MOSCOW, July 23 (AP) -- Soviet gorier Information Bureau issued this communique today:

WASHINGTON, July 23 -- Tire and tube quotas for August, announced today by the Office of Price Administration, show an increase compared with July. They reflect the increasing applications by essential vehicle operators for rationing certificates, officials stated.

MINEOLA, L.I., July 23 -- The death yesterday of a ten-months-old Sea Cliff girl was attributed today by Lieutenant William Vaughan, in charge of the Nassau County Homicide Bureau, to the mistake of a physician in administering an injection of morphine in the belief that it was a cough serum.
Mrs. Donald de Lisser was a luncheon hostess yesterday at the Stork Club to Mrs. Glenn Dickinson, Mrs. Daniel M.S. Hegarty and Mrs. Henry J. Taylor.

NEWARK, N.J., July 23 (AP) -- Bob Feller, former Cleveland pitching ace who usually monopolizes the spotlight, will find himself crowded by other stars in a benefit show for the American Red Cross and Navy Relief Society at Ruppert Stadium Saturday.

The New Deal drive to "stop Bennett" and win the nomination of Senator James M. Mead as the Democratic candidate for Governor continued in full force yesterday while State Chairman James A. Farley sat back, quietly confident that he still had the delegate strength sufficient to block the White House push and put over Attorney General John J. Bennett Jr.

WASHINGTON, July 23 -- Spokesmen for labor and management called on President Roosevelt today and assured him that they wished to do everything possible to help win the war and to that end had begun for the first time in their history a joint canvass of ways and means of carrying out their common pledge.

The huge, capacity audience at the Lewisohn Stadium last night came, for the most part, to see and hear the Kostelanetz family -- Andre Kostelanetz as guest conductor and his wife, Lily Pons, as soprano soloist. But as a choice tidbit it received first New York performances of Virgil Thomson's portraits in tone, sketched from life, of Dorothy Thompson and Mayor La Guardia.

WASHINGTON, July 23 -- Japanese attempts to pacify the Philippines with the use of threats, executions and coaxing propaganda have failed notably, it was indicated today by a selection of Japanese broadcasts collected by the Foreign Broadcasting Monitoring Service and released through the Office of War Information.

European prisoners of war have been provided with means of carrying on "the intellectual life of their nations" under the international treaty ratified by thirty-five nations at Geneva in 1929, Dr. Darius A. Davis, executive secretary for war prisoners of the World's Alliance of the Young Men's Christian Association.

WASHINGTON, July 23 -- William Griffin, publisher of the New York Enquirer, who was indicted on sedition charges today, was endorsed five years ago by Senator Wagner and others as a candidate for Mayor of New York City.

Representatives of all divisions of the book publishing industry, from editors to shipping room staffs and booksellers, met last night at a book mobilization conference called by the Book and Magazine Union, Local 18, C.I.O., to discuss the industry's responsibilities in the war and to adopt specific practices.

An air raid kit, easily put together at home at a cost of less than a dollar, was described yesterday by Miss Mabel Woolger, its inventor. An invaluable companion during a possible air raid, fire or other emergency, the kit was made from an ordinary folding clothing box and is 11 inches long 7 1/2 inches wide and 2 1/2 inches deep and weighs 2 3/4 pounds.

LOURENCO MARQUES, Portuguese East Africa, July 22 (Delayed) -- A United States submarine early in May sank the big Japanese liner Taiyo Maru off Hong Kong, resulting in the drowning of hundreds of Japanese, including the personnel of an entire department of one of the great Mitsui industrial organizations, it now may be revealed.

When theatrical folk and other "night owls" visit the home of Colin Keith-Johnston, the English actor, and his wife these evenings, they are likely to receive a sudden and early good night in this tactful way:

The British National Insurance Act has been tested for a generation. It has done much good, but it does not enable physicians to practice competently. The economic status of the patient rather than his medical need receives primary consideration. Doctors find it difficult to cooperate with hospitals, with specialists or with one another and to pursue post-graduate studies.

Marked by heavy mid-month settlements, bank clearings at New York and for the country at large rose sharply in the week ended on Wednesday. Transactions of $7,280,451,000 for the twenty-three leading cities surpassed all previous weekly records since the week of March 18, and increased 14.3 per cent over the $6,372,369,000 volume for the corresponding week of 1941, according to the report of Dun Bradstreet, Inc.

The Office of Price Administration, now engaged in a "top to bottom" investigation of the liquor industry's pricing methods in this area, has completed its preliminary survey of retail price and discount practices and is preparing a questionnaire to be presented to wholesalers, it was learned yesterday.

WITH UNITED STATES ARMY AIR FORCES in China, July 22 (delayed) -- The present trend of the Sino-Japanese war could be thown into "high reverse" and the Japanese probably "driven into the the sea" through the shipment of more medium or heavy bombers and fighter planes to this front, Colonel Caleb V. Haynes, head of the United States Bomber Command in China, said today.
Following is the transcribed text of Secretary Hull's ratio address last night as recorded by THE NEW YORK TIMES:

WASHINGTON, July 23 -- Weakening prices for certain agricultural products, particularly fresh fruits, vegetables and livestock, largely accounted for a decline of 0.2 per cent in the week ended on July 18 in the Bureau of Labor on Statistics composite index of 889 series priced in primary markets.

Reporting on operations for the half-year, the Shell Union Oil Corporation announced yesterday a net profit of $7,228,950 after all charges, equal to 55 cents a share on 13,070,625 shares of common stock. In the first six months of 1941 the net profit amounted to $7,829,945 or 60 cents a share.

WASHINGTON, July 23 -- The War Labor Board today denied the request by the Inland Steel Company for a stay of its July 26th deadline when the company is required to take a stand on the board's decision in the "Little Steel" case which was handed down on July 16.

CLEVELAND, July 23 -- Ernie Bonham, powerfully framed forkball specialist of the Yankees, seemed to have his eleventh victory and fifth shutout of the year all wrapped up today, but with two out in the ninth and the Indians apparently all set to be snuffed out by a 2-0 score, a number of unforeseen developments upset everything, including the Yanks.

Serge Koussevitzky's second concert at the Berkshire Music Center on Sunday, Aug. 2, will be dedicated to the Treasury Department's war bond campaign. Half the proceeds will be turned over to the Treasury, and Bonds and Stamps will be sold at Tanglewood on the afternoon of the concert.

The British Ministry of Economic Warfare reports that locomotives receive priority in Germany as high as armaments. The Germans view their internal rail problem as the British view the Battle of the Atlantic. Their fate depends upon it. The Nazis are reported to be building trains and other railway equipment with the urgency with which Britain and America are turning out ships.

LONDON, Friday, July 24 -- German bombers, in what was reported to be the heaviest attack on Britain in several weeks, struck in the northeastern and eastern coastal districts of England and in the West Midlands last night.

A thick, delicious porterhouse steak may prove a bit hard to come by in some urban shops, but that is small cause for hysteria. Such is the opinion of Mrs. Frances Foley Gannon, who is the competent director of the Consumers Service Bureau of the New York Department of Markets.

MANNEAPOLIS, July 23 (AP) -- A prospective buyer of the Minneapolis St. Louis Railroad actually was on hand today to submit a bid when the road's assets go on the auction block tomorrow in one of the final steps of a reorganization that already has taken nineteen years.

WASHINGTON, July 23 -- The buying of soldiers' clothing, equipment and general supplies in the United Nations where men are stationed has enabled the Army to succeed in shortening its supply lines considerably. The War Department said today that the strategic gain in this move was emphasized by the reduction in the number of cargo vessels needed, thereby saving space for shipping combat materials.

OTTAWA, July 23 -- Culminating an all-day debate on the third reading of the amendment to the National Mobilization Act, which will make overseas service obligatory for all conscripted men, P.J.A. Cardin, former Minister and Quebec leader, declared for himself, his party and Province:

LOURENCO MARQUES, Portuguese East Africa, July 23 (U.P.) -- Two persons died aboard the liner Conte Verde, which brought part of a group of about 1,500 Americans and other non-Axis nationals here from Japan and Japanese-occupied territories, it was revealed today.

Concerned more with inflation than with the revival of agitation for a showdown on the full-parity loan measure, commission houses sponsored yesterday a considerable amount of liquidation in the cotton market. The full impact of this speculative selling was felt near the end of trading on the New York Cotton Exchange.

CHICAGO, July 23 (AP) -- In the shadows of dusk today, Lawson Little of Monterey, Calif., winged around the Tam O'Shanter course in 67 to tie Byron Nelson of Toledo, Ohio, for the first-round leadership in the $15,000 golf tournament.

WASHINGTON, July 23 -- Declaring that the war was at a critical phase, Secretary Morgenthau asked the Senate Finance Committee today to add an extra $2,400,000,000 to the country's tax bill with the two-fold aim of combating inflation and contributing to national unity.

Buying activity this week in the wholesale markets here did not vary much from the pattern set earlier in the month. Volume continued restricted in comparison with the heavy ordering a year ago at this time. Further activity at wholesale from this point on will be shaped by consumer response to August promotional events which will soon reach their active stage.

WASHINGTON, July 23 -- The individuals named in the indictments for sedition, with a brief identification provided by the Justice Department, together with the publications and organizations listed by the Grand Jury as factors in the alleged conspiracy, are as follows:
WASHINGTON, July 23 -- The Army Air Forces today prepared to shift a program under which it has trained in the past year about 4,000 aviators for the Royal Air Force of Great Britain.

Through an improvement in the manufacturing processes the Standard Oil Company of New Jersey has been able to increase the capacity of plants for making butyl rubber to 132,000 tons annually from the 60,000 originally planned, W.S. Farish, president, announced yesterday.

The retailers of New York City will sponsor a "Victory party" for the sale of war bonds and stamps in front of the Public Library at Forty-second Street and Fifth Avenue Tuesday evening, it was announced yesterday.

CHUNGKING, July 23 (U.P.) -- Allied planes have made two raids on Hong Kong and the near-by Kowloon Peninsula, bombing a Japanese airdrome, a fortress, barracks and gasoline depots, the newspaper Ta Kung Pao said without confirmation today.

Two youths from Kentucky, who are building bombers at the Glenn L. Martin plant in Baltimore, came to town in a 1920 Model-T Ford yesterday on their first visit to New York and ran into a minor disaster almost immediately.

MONTGOMERY. Ala., July 23 (U.P.) -- Governor Frank M. Dixon tonight rejected a contract proffered by the War Production Board, under which cotton mills operated by the Alabama State Prison would manufacture 1,750,000 yards of osnaburg for the Army, because he considered the proposed deal a "Federal attempt to abolish segregation of races in the South."

LONDON, July 23 -- Soviet Ambassador Ivan M. Maisky has been no less active in London in the past few days than Maxim Litvinoff, Russian Ambassador to the United States, has been in Washington. Mr. Maisky has been conferring intermittently with members of the government, including Prime Minister Churchill, Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden, Sir James Grigg, War Secretary; A.V. Alexander, First Lord of the Admiralty, and Sir Archibald Sinclair, Air Secretary.

The Continental Can Company, Inc., and its wholly owned subsidiaries showed net earnings of $6,719,800 for the twelve months ended with June, after deducting $8,172,119 for depreciation and estimated income and excess profits taxes, according to the report issued yesterday of J.F. Hartlieb, president.

OLD ORCHARD, Me., July 23 (AP) -- The 4-year-old His Excellency, owned by Will Strang of Brooklyn and driven by Tom Berry, gained his third straight Grand Circuit victory of the season in straight heats in the Goldsmith Maid Stake for aged trotters today.

The creation of a new Committee for the Coordination of Women's War and Post-War Activities and the appointment of Mrs. Ambrose N. Diehl as chairman were announced yesterday by Mrs. Harold V. Milliken, president of the National Council of Women.

The curls that cascade from under a service cap must be sleek and ship-shape in front and clear the collar in back. Such are the recommendations to the trim young women who are climbing into uniform for the first formal dress inspection of their lives.

Payment of "grossly excessive and exorbitant" compensation to three officers of the Sperry Corporation was charged in Supreme Court yesterday in a stockholder's accounting action brought by Frederick W. Scholem against nine present and former directors of the corporation.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., July 23 -- The new canteen, organized by a group of prominent women of the Summer colony, was opened this afternoon in a building adjacent to the Morris Studio in Main Street. The project is designed to meet the needs of all service men stationed in this vicinity for a lounge, recreation center and a place to obtain free refreshments while on leave.
PORT DALHOUSIE, Ont., July 23 (AP) -- The Toronto Argonauts scored 11 points today to take the lead in the sixtieth annual Royal Canadian Henley Regatta at the end of the opening day's competition.

Henry J. Kaiser, who has shown himself to be something of an industrial wizard in shipbuilding and other construction fields in the Far West, has proposed that a fleet of giant flying boats be built immediately by shipyards. He would have nine yards designated, three each on the Atlantic, Pacific and Gulf Coasts, to turn out air transports each capable of carrying to Europe at least 100 men with equipment or equivalent cargo.

It is rather rare for a retired music teacher to remain so steadily in the public eye as J. Reid Spencer of the Ebbets Field neighborhood in Brooklyn has been doing. Mr. Spencer is a lover of music, but not of the organ music that is played for the Dodger games.

LONDON, July 23 -- In a speech at Nottingham tonight Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden made an important pronouncement about Britain's war effort, war aims and relations with her allies and former enemies in the post-war world.

LONDON, July 23 (U.P.) -- Several ships from an American task force that has been operating with the British Home Fleet have been subjected to attacks by enemy planes, but have escaped without damage or fatalities in their first action, it was revealed today by Rear Admiral Robert C. Giffen, commander of the force.

Yesterday's statement of the twelve Reserve Banks showed holdings of United States Government securities to be the highest on record, having increased $9,138,000 during the past week. Note circulation was also the highest for the year.

A German broadcast recorded yesterday by the United Press in New York said that a Bulgarian court-martial, sitting in the Yugoslav city of Bitolj, had condemned eleven persons to death for Communist activity. The broadcast, by the Transocean agency, quoted a Sofia report.

WASHINGTON, July 23 (U.P.) -- Andrew J. Higgins, president of the Higgins Corporation, announced today that the American Federation of Labor had offered to advance sufficient funds to complete the firm's New Orleans shipyards.

We Americans have got to tighten up if we want to win the war. We do not like war -- who does except the Germans and the Japanese ? -- so when things appear to be going our way on the battlefront, we indulge in wishful thinking, get over-optimistic, prophesy that the war will end in 1942, restoring us to our lives of peace, confort and luxury.

Mrs. Erna Haupt, mother of one of the eight Nazi saboteurs now on trial before a military tribunal in Washington, was arraigned yesterday in Chicago Federal court. Arraigned with her was Walter Wilhelm Froehling, another of the group of ten persons against whom charges of aiding the eight submarine-riding invaders have been filed.

Tami Mauriello, the Bronx boy who grew from a middleweight to a ranking heavyweight in one year, knocked out Clarence (Red) Burman, Baltimore heavyweight, in the ninth round of the scheduled ten-round feature bout at Madison Square Garden last night.

Henry Feinstein, a candidate for the Democratic nomination for the Assembly against Irwin Steingut in the Eighteenth district, Brooklyn, who was ruled off the primary ballot earlier this week by the Board of Elections, made public last night a letter to Governor Lehman, asking for an investigation of the board.

Incendiary bombs should be attacked with "a direct jet of water" rather than "a coarse spray," as previously advised, according to instructions issued here yesterday by the director of the Second Civilian Defense Region, 111 Eighth Avenue, and James M. Landis, director of the OCD in Washington.

More than 1,000 prisoners have been taken and 131 British tanks destroyed in bitter hand-to-hand fighting in which Axis forces repulsed British attacks at El Alamein on the Egyptian front, and support by German planes was a factor in beating off the British, the German High Command reported yesterday, according to a Berlin broadcast that was recorded by The Associated Press.
WASHINGTON, July 23 (U.P.) -The Navy is preparing to recruit women for shore jobs so officers and men can be released for sea duty.
The following German High Command communique was broadcast from Berlin yesterday and was recorded here by The Associated Press:
The threatened strike of 22,000 A.F. of L. building craftsmen on $100,000,000 of naval construction work in the New York area appeared to have been averted yesterday.

The danger that France may "form a solid Fascist bloc unless the United Nations embark on an immediate course of action" was stressed yesterday by General Francisco J. Aguilar, Mexican Minister to Vichy for the last sixteen months, one of fifteen transatlantic passengers who arrived at La Guardia Field aboard a Pan American Airways clipper.

MELBOURNE, Australia, July 23 -- The High Court of Australia, in one of the most important opinions affecting State's rights in the history of the Commonwealth, ruled today that the Federal Government's uniform income tax legislation was valid and dismissed the attack on it by the four States of Victoria, Queensland, South Australia and West Australia.

New orders received by furniture manufacturers in June dropped off 44 per cent from the May level for the sharpest decline in nearly five years, Seidman Seidman, certified public accountants, reported yesterday. Commitments in the month were down 35 per cent, compared with 1941.

Workmen are to start today razing the famous Bridge of Sighs, the fifty-foot steel structure sixty feet above Leonard Street, which joins the abandoned old Tombs Prison, between Centre and Lafayette Streets, to the untenanted old Criminal Courts Building on the block to the north.

Sister Edward Mary lifted her white vested arms yesterday morning and, placing with accustomed precision a starched cap on the head of the young woman in front of her, welcomed another nursing sister into her fold. The ceremony, that of "capping" a nurses' aide, was repeated twenty-three times to mark the completion of the second Red Cross Nurses Aide course at St. Vincent's Hospital.

At exercises held yesterday in the lobby of 26 Broadway, John A. Brown, president of the Socony Vacuum Oil Company presented a book to the employes containing an alphabetical list of the 1,719 employes of the company now in the country's armed forces.

Facilities for thorough experiments with numerous birds and animals will be available at Maine's newly acquired Swan Island "outdoor laboratory," according to Commissioner George J. Stobie of the Pine Tree State's Department of Inland Fisheries and Game.

WASHINGTON, July 23 -- An international agency to keep peace (by force, if necessary) was called for by Secretary Hull tonight in a world-wide radio address in which he made a significant contribution to discussion of the post-war world by declaring that the four freedoms would not necessarily and automatically be set up "everywhere in the world" in the event of victory of the United Nations.

LOURENCO MARQUES, Portguese East Africa, July 22 (delayed) -- One of the United States bombers that raided Tokyo last April 18 flew over the Imperial Palace and thereby created an internal political crisis that resulted in a sweeping shake-up of the air defense command and the rumored suicides of two high army officers, it was revealed here today by a correspondent who has arrived from Tokyo.

JERSEY CITY, July 23 (AP) -- Jersey City annexed the opener of its six-game series with the Montreal Royals tonight by capturing the first game of a double-header, 9 to 4, and then the second game was called in the eighth due to dimout restrictions with the score tied 0 -- 0.

IT was at the Empire City track and Racing Secretary John Blanks Campbell was talking across the luncheon table. This tourist tuned in, hoping to learn something about horses, Mr. Campbell, being a genial soul, didn't call the Pinkertons to toss out the intruder. He just went on talking.
SOMEWHERE IN BURMA, July 19 (Delayed) -- Civil war has broken out in Arakan Province, in Burma, between the pro-British community of 400,000 Moslems and Burmese adherents of the Japanese.

Michael Sparber, 23 years old, of 403 West Fifty-sixth Street, former stock superintendent in Gimbel Brothers storerooms on the first two floors of 337 West Twenty-seventh Street, was held in $25,000 bail by Magistrate Koenig in Felony Court yesterday.

LONDON, July 23 -- A Merchant Navy Club for officers and men was opened today in a former restaurant in Soho by United States Ambassador John G. Winant and Labor Minister Ernest Bevin. The place, paid for with a $75,000 contribution by the International Ladies Garment Workers Union of the United States, was packed with men from freighters and tankers who are sailing the seven seas at constant risk of their lives.

ST. LOUIS, July 23 (AP) -- For the second day in a row the Browns saw the Athletics pull a fifth-inning rally to tie the score, but this time the Browns recovered and won, 9 to 6, to take the series, two games to one. It also was St. Louis's twelfth victory in its last fourteen contests.

WASHINGTON, July 23 -- The Congress of Industrial Organizations complained to President Roosevelt today that the International Association of Machinists, A.F.L., had publicly urged defiance of the waiver of premium pay for Saturday and Sunday work which was accepted by the American Federation of Labor and the C.I.O. last Spring at the request of the President.

WASHINGTON, July 23 -Shortages of teachers in elementary and rural schools and of those instructing in high school and college subjects taught principally by men were reported today at the Annual conference here of administrators and supervisors.

Shortly after the war declaration the necessity for using prudence instead of gas and rubber was bellowed over the country. The man who used his automobile "recklessly," to transport less than a capacity crowd on anything but an urgent mission, was taught to look at his action as pro- Axis.

SAN FRANCISCO, Calif., July 23 -- After "about two minutes" of questioning tonight Detective Lieutenant Theodore Morgan of Bergen County, N.J., bared as a hoax the "confession" of James A. Boyd, a 59-year-old vagrant, to the 1937 murder of R. Norman Redwood, business agent of a New York sandhogs union, at his Teaneck, N.J., home.

WASHINGTON, July 23 -- A new shortage of steel for aircraft manufacture has again threatened to disrupt the President's production schedules for 1942 and 1943. This shortage is said to be the direct result of revised allocations of steel for armament by the Army and Navy Joint Munitions Board, which has issued a "rerating directive" that affects priorities for aircraft production which had previously been established by the War Production Board.

MELBOURNE, Australia, July 23 -- As a force of 1,500 to 2,500 Japanese consolidated their first foothold in Papua, the southeastern part of New Guinea, Prime Minister John Curtin said today that this new landing was a clear indication that the Japanese threat to Australia would continue to be immediate and grave until Japan was completely defeated.
MOSCOW, Friday, July 24 (AP) -- The midnight Soviet communique follows:

CHICAGO, July 23 -- Operations in the wheat market today were on a reduced scale as traders acted with extreme caution pending further developments in the anti-inflation program. There was no material pressure on the wheat market, either from professional traders or cash interests, but support was lacking and the finish was near the bottom with losses of 3/8 to 7/8 cent a bushel.

CAIRO, Egypt, July 23 -- The attack launched by troops of the British Empire Tuesday night in the central sector of the Egyptian front continued throughout yesterday in all three sectors, and steady but not startling progress was made.

MOSCOW, July 23 -- Disturbing news from the south is making the Russian public increasingly conscious that eight weeks have passed since the agreement was reached between London, Moscow and Washington that the creation of a second European battlefront this year was a task of immediate importance.

TRENTON, July 23 -- Governor Edison struck hard today at the most vulnerable point in the political armor of Mayor Frank Hague of Jersey City when he dismissed the entire Hudson County Tax Board for dereliction of duty and "wilful disregard" of their lawful responsibilities.

In a bid for a larger share of the top-notch radio programs the Mutual Broadcasting System yesterday announced an attractive set of discounts, ranging up to 75 per cent, which will enable advertisers to use more stations for the money they are now spending.

What appears to be a new and promising chapter in the relations between Government and finance was opened this week at the meeting of the Securities and Exchange Commission and representatives of the securities exchanges and the investment banking community.

NIAGARA FALLS, N.Y., July 23 -- Although not quite in the mood he was in yesterday when he set a new record of 67 for the Niagara Falls Country Club course in winning the qualifying medal of the twentieth annual New York State amateur golf championship, Ray Billows of Poughkeepsie today progressed into the quarterfinal round with considerable ease.

The block party given by the A.W. V.S. in that part of West Fifty-second Street devoted to night clubs and the entertainment of those who love to linger till "Dawn's whiskered cat stretches out her long tongue" was a hilarious triumph, a marriage of business and pleasure.

While the current meetings of the Railway Labor Executives Association in Chicago are described as routine, the managements would not be surprised if the question of demands for increased wages may not be in the backs of the minds of the officials assembled.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., July 23 -- An inquiry was started by FBI and postal authorities here today after some postcard messages, termed by officials "obviously seditious" were received by Yale students.

WASHINGTON, July 23 -- Department-store sales in the week ended July 18 were 5 per cent higher than in the corresponding week a year ago, the Federal Reserve Board announced today. This compared with a 10 per cent increase the preceding week.

WASHINGTON, July 23 -- Labor leaders reiterated at the White House today their opposition to freezing wages or changing the authority of the War Labor Board and at almost the same time a Democratic group in the Senate called on Congress and the Administration "to stop puttering around with half-measures" and pass legislation to control all prices, profits, costs, rents and wages.

WASHINGTON, July 23 (AP) -- President Roosevelt today signed legislation authorizing the construction of a pipeline and a navigable barge channel across Florida. The measure is designed to help relieve the shortage of transportation for moving oil and gasoline to the eastern seaboard.

A_ splendid opportunity is afforded all male citizens who are not over 55 to become members of the New York State Guard, a fine group of men, ready, able and willing to do their duty in any emergency whenever called upon.

PHILADELPHIA, July 23 (AP) -- The last-place Phils dealt the pennant-seeking Cardinals a damaging blow at Shibe Park tonight, coming from behind twice to take a 4-to-3 victory. The defeat put the Cards seven games back of the first-place Dodgers.

BERNE, Switzerland, July 23 -- Foreshadowing further restrictions in Italy, Minister of Supplies Renato Ricci asserted in the Italian press today that "every effort will now be turned toward intensification of our autarchic sufficiency."
The following Italian communique was broadcast from Rome yesterday and recorded here by The Associated Press:
LONDON, July 23 (AP) -- A joint communique of the Ministries of Air and Home Security said today:

WASHINGTON, July 23 -- President Roosevelt signed the Agriculture Department Appropriation and Florida Barge Canal and Pipeline Bills, nominated Ingram Stainback to be Governor of Hawaii and conferred with a group of labor and industrial leaders; his visitors included Secretary Jones, Joseph E. Davies, William Green, Daniel J. Tobin and members of the A.F.L.-C.I.O. labor war board.

Richard Allen Knight, the disbarred lawyer whose many eccentricities, including standing on his head in the foyer at a Metropolitan opera performance, showered him with publicity in the last few years, meekly pleaded guilty yesterday in Special Sessions on two "informations" accusing him of sending annoying letters in the last nine months to a judge and numerous prominent lawyers in the city.

WASHINGTON, July 23 (AP) -- A 360 per cent increase in naval ship construction over a year ago and development of an air arm "which will provide the United States with the strongest offensive force in naval history" were reported tonight by the House Naval Committee.

CAMDEN, N.J., July 23 (AP) -- Jerome H. Louchheim's Black Grip qualified for the coming 2-year-old fixtures at Garden State Park today when he breezed to a two-length victory over C.E. Nelson's Uncle Billies and M. B. Goff's Lord Win.

TRENTON, July 23 -- The New Jersey Senate, meeting today in special session, ordered its special investigations committee to inquire into the gasoline rationing situation in the State, after Senate President I. Grant Scott, Republican, of Cape May, told the legislators that there have been reports of "discrimination" against certain parts of the country.

BERNE, Switzerland, Friday, July 24 -- Backed by enormous quantities of reserves in men and materiel and supported by tremendous aerial bombardment, German forces driving toward the Caucasus were in contact with the main body of Russians on the Don fortifications at three points yesterday and were forced to at least a temporary halt, according to the military spokesman in Moscow early today.

WASHINGTON, July 23 -- W.J. Donald, president of the American Trade Association Executives, today was named chairman of a special advisory committee which will work with the War Production Board in the task of reducing the number of report forms which the war agency requires of business.
WASHINGTON, July 23 -- Chief Justice Harlan Stone, it was learned tonight, has been asked by President Roosevelt to make an independent inquiry into the rubber situation.

MOSCOW, July 23 -- Persons reaching here from Leningrad by air said today that life in that city was now much more nearly normal than during the days of tight siege last Winter, when, with a minimum of food and with almost no fuel, lighting or transport, Leningrad's residents withstood many hardships.

WASHINGTON, July 23 -- The House, after three hours of delaying tactics by some Southern members and nearly four more hours of bitter controversy, passed tonight legislation setting up procedure by which men and women in the armed forces and auxiliaries may vote in the November elections.
The once flourishing branch of the publishing business that used to supply little pocket-size language guides for American tourists has taken a wartime twist.
CHICAGO, July 23 (AP) -- A seventh-inning rally that disposed of Bill Dietrich today gave the Red Sox a 5-to-4 victory over the White Sox in the finale of the series.

The War Shipping Administration announces that during the week of July 12 shipping losses reached the highest level since the beginning of the war. It also announces that, despite the increase of shipbuilding, sinkings of United Nations vessels "have greatly exceeded new construction."

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 23 -- United Artists announced today that Benedict Bogeaus, president of the General Service Studios, has completed arrangements with Sister Elizabeth Kenny, Australian nurse who discovered a cure for infantile paralysis, to film her life for United Artists.

MOSCOW, Friday, July 24 -- With large forces of Axis tanks and mechanized infantry beating at the defenses of Rostov, the Russians reported today that their hard-pressed armies had fallen back in one sector of that critical front after repulsing seven atacks throughout yesterday.
WASHINGTON, July 23 -- The following is the prepared statement that Secretary Morgenthau made before the Senate Finance Committee today:

While consumer response to promotional events improved toward the end of the week, retail trade here was rather spotty during most of the period. Day-to-day sales results were decidedly uneven and department-store volume ranged from under a year ago to about 4 per cent above the comparative 1941 figures.

CLIFTON, N.J., July 24 (AP) -- Tippy Larkin, whose climb up the fistic ladder has been blocked repeatedly by injuries, met another setback today when a 22-caliber rifle he was cleaning at his home discharged and sent a bullet through his right shoulder.
The only criticism that can possibly be made of the Giants' shift of Babe Young from first base to the picket line is that it wasn't made earlier.

Eight years ago today Chancellor Dollfuss of Austria was murdered. Though Hitler did not seize the little republic at the crossroads of Europe until four years later, the assassination marked the beginning of the end of a free Austria. The Nazi putsch failed, but this first attempt of Nazism to strike across the Reich's border had its deadly repercussions upon the rest of Europe.

WASHINGTON, July 24 (AP) -- The Department of Agriculture said today that stocks of old wheat in interior mills, elevators and warehouses on July 1 were estimated to be 141,789,000 bushels -- the largest on record.

WAYNESBORO, Tenn., July 24 (AP) -- An Army observation plane crashed near here just before noon today, killing Major Gen. Frank C. Mahin, commanding officer of the Thirty-third Division at Camp Forrest, and two fliers.

MOSCOW, Saturday, July 25 -- German tanks and infantrymen were beating against Rostov, the Russian bridgehead to the rich Caucasus, over the bodies of thousands of Nazi dead, the Soviet High Command announced early today in one of the gravest moments in Russian history.

Out at Fort Sill, the Oklahoma Army post of a long and interesting tradition that centers in the Indian wars, there is a local bestseller situation. In 1937 the University of Oklahoma Press published "Carbine and Lance: The Story of Old Fort Sill," by Lieut. Col. W.S. Nye.

WESTFIELD, N.J., July 24 -- A surprisingly large field of forty-five started today in the weekly one-day tournament of the Women's New Jersey Golf Association for war stamp prizes. The New Jersey association champion, Mrs. William Hockenjos of Crestmont, won low gross honors with 39, 43 -- 82 at the Shackamaxon Country Club.

ALBANY, July 24 (AP) -- "Women make better air raid wardens than men," said Major Gen. William N. Haskell, State civilian protection director. He called today for 120,000 more New York women to enroll for air warden duty.
WASHINGTON, July 24 (U.P.) -- President Roosevelt will defer requests for new anti-inflation legislation until after Congress completes an unofficial recess which began tonight.

Portable museums, or "musettes," to teach our armed forces how to tell a rattlesnake from a harmless snake or how to distinguish poison ivy from mint and a toadstool from a mushroom, are being planned by the Department of Education of the American Museum of Natural History, it was announced by the museum yesterday.

ALBANY, July 24 -- In a forty-nine-word memorandum Governor Lehman today dismissed the charges filed against Mayor La Guardia by Frank P. Beal of the Stop Illegal Assessing Committee of Brooklyn. Mr. Beal, who represented ten civic workers, was formerly executive secretary of Community Councils.

Of the periodic crises that have marked the course of the war none has weighed more heavily than this on the minds of the Allied commanders. Britain lived through Dunkerque. Russia saw the invaders at the gates of Moscow. This country watched the fall of Corregidor.

As a follower of baseball for many years, I have always wondered why a club retains a manager year in and year out even though he makes no headway with his team. In other sports the coaches must produce or lose their jobs to men better qualified for the position.

As an aviation cadet now in training, John Kieran's recent column "Commando Sports Preferred" interested me greatly. It is-my opinion that they would be the solution to a great American problem, for this country needs fit men in peacetime as well as now.
The following German High Command communique was broadcast yesterday from Berlin and recorded here by The Associated Press:
LONDON, July 24 (AP) -- The Air Ministry issued this communique today:

MEXICO CITY, July 24 (U.P.) -- The Argentine Embassy, acting on authorization of the Foreign Office at Buenos Aires, tonight repudiated statements attributed to the Argentine Foreign Minister, Dr. Enrique Ruiz Guinazu, allegedly deploring the hemisphere policy of the United States.

PATERSON, N.J., July 24 (AP) -- Three hundred employes of the giant Wright Aeronautical Corporation ceased work in a wage dispute today, and the head of an independent union warned of "a complete shutdown" if the company's present policy persists.

MELBOURNE, Australia, July, 24 -- Scratching the beach at Carnot Bay, sixty miles north of Broome, Northwest Australia, for cigarette "butts," an aboriginal woman named Connie found a small tube containing 10,000 [Australian] worth of diamonds, it was revealed today.
WASHINGTON, July 24 -- Stocks of domestic and foreign crude petroleum on July 18 totaled 250,505,000 barrels, according to data reported to the Bureau of Mines, Department of the Interior.

The German High Command announced yesterday that German Army and Elite Guard troops and Slovak detachments had captured Rostov by storm and were engaged in mopping-up operations there while other German forces "broke the resistance of Soviet troops newly brought up" in the Don River bend, according to Berlin broadcasts recorded by The Associated Press.

LOURENCO MARQUES, Portuguese East Africa, July 23 (Delayed) (AP) -- Hunger and cold intensified the privations of many Americans and Canadians in the Orient who feII into the hands of the Japanese at the outbreak of the Pacific war.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, July 24 -- Shortly after last midnight eight explosive bombs and many incendiaries, including at least two "Molotoff cocktails," landed about 500 yards from King Gustaf's Summer residence at Borgholm, on Oeland Island.

CHICAGO, July 24 -- Meat marketing authorities saw little chance today for much relief in the nationwide meat shortage until late September or early October. Marketing of the largest stocks of hogs ever raised on American farms will start early in the Fall, but the market men said some time is required in getting the new meat into retail channels.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 24 -- A daring rescue mission during which he took a Catalina patrol bomber through Pacific squalls off Palmyra Island won the Distinguished Flying Cross today for Lieutenant Sumner E. Atherton Jr., 26, of West Lebanon, N.H.

The recent appointment of Admiral William D. Leahy as Chief of Staff to President Roosevelt represents only one of the many changes in the organization of the Home Front dictated by the inexorable pressure of emergency. But like so many of the other changes, Admiral Leahy's appointment is a compromise and is the result -- probably a temporary, not a permanent, result -- of the varying forces that represent democratic government.

WASHINGTON, July 24 -- A joint conference to end the dispute involving the threatened strike of American Federation of Labor building crafts on $100,000,000 of naval construction in New York will be held in New York on Monday, it was reported today following an exploratory meeting in the office of Malcolm Miller, assistant commissioner of the Works Progress Administration.

WASHINGTON, July 24 -- The withholding tax feature of the House-approved revenue bill, providing for the impounding of 5 per cent of all salaries starting on next Jan. 1 as credits against income tax due in 1944, provoked sharp debate in the Senate Finance Committee today.

Incorporating the colors of the flags of the twenty-two nations of the Western Hemisphere, a "New World Flag" was unveiled yesterday at the Hotel New Yorker, as well as in Mexico City, Havana, Montreal and other cities, as an expression of hemispheric solidarity on the 159th anniversary of the birth of Simon Bolivar.

EAST ALTON, Ill., July 24 (U.P.) -- The executive council of A.F.L. unions operating in the Western Cartridge Company plant here, demanded today that the War Department take over operation of the company immediately to prevent a general walkout of workers.

DETROIT, July 24 -- The Ford Motor Company has presented for government approval a "tire replacement plan" under which the rubber substitute thiokol would be used to keep the automobiles of war workers on the road.

The Meat Trade Institute, through its counsel and executive director, Joseph Cohn, advised City Markets Commissioner Daniel P. Wooley yesterday that "the large majority of independent packers, wholesalers and manufacturers" did not share the optimistic view of the city's meat situation expressed by representatives of the major packers at a conference with Mr. Wooley on Thursday afternoon.

BUENOS AIRES, Argentina, July 24 -- Acting on instructions given by the government late last night, the police seized today all available copies of the book "Campo Minado," by former Deputy Adolf Lanus, in which Nazi activities in Argentine are studied and the charge is made that relations exist between President Ramon S. Castillo and the so-called Nationalist movement.

WASHINGTON, July 24 -- Labor and management in 200 mines in Eastern Pennsylvania were asked today by Donald Nelson, War Production Chief, to increase the output of hard coal to meet the country's war and heating needs. The appeal was made with the backing of the United Mine Workers, Anthracite Industries, Inc., and the Coordinator of Solid Fuels.

Hearings on the application of eleven railroads for a 10 per cent increase in commutation rates within New York State were adjourned yesterday after an all-day session in the Hotel St. George, Brooklyn. Since Monday, at hearings under the auspices of the Interstate Commerce Commission, railroad representatives have testified as to the need for the additional revenue.

SOMEWHERE IN AUSTRALIA, July 23 (Delayed) -- We have not heard as much about aviation aces in this war as we did during the World War but it is not because there are none. In one American fighter group operating from the undisclosed operational base at which this dispatch is written there are four.

Vincent C. Stanley, president of the Gamewell Company, has written to preferred and common stockholders asking them to approve a written agreement of the company, the Holtzer-Cabot Electric Company, and E.H. Rollins Sons, Inc., under which Gamewell would dispose of a substantial part of its holdings of capital stock of Holtzer-Cabot, its wholly-owned subsidiary.

The Rev. Dr. George Paull T. Sargent. rector of St Bartholomew's Episcopal Church, Park Avenue and Fifty-first Street, has appointed Mrs. William O'Donnell Iselin to enlist church members in civilian defense activities.

Officials of five local housing authorities yesterday sold a total of $3,926,000 of temporary-loan notes to various banks and investment firms. The largest item consisted of $1,520,000 of notes, due Aug. 17, 1943, of the Denver, Col., Housing Authority, of which Salomon Brothers Hutzler received the award of $520,000 at 0.80 per cent and R.W. Pressprich Co. received $1,000,000 at 0.79 per cent.
WASHINGTON, July 24 (AP) -- The tin salvage program for householders, previously restricted to thirty-six metropolitan areas, will be enlarged to take in 104 new cities.

CHICAGO, July 24 -- Taylor M. Whichard, 33, a Texas marksman and convict, offered today to attempt to "eliminate" Adolf Hitler in exchange for the dropping of all criminal charges pending against him.

Blackout tests were held in Nassau and Suffolk Counties last night, the warning for the drill coming in Nassau with advance notice of a week, but in Suffolk without advance notice. They lasted an hour.

For the last eighteen months retail business has been brisk as a result of fear of shortages and rising prices and it was understandable why store advertising budgets did not show a rise proportionate to the increase in sales. But now, despite the fact that sales are slumping, advertising is still lagging behind, it was pointed out in retail circles yesterday.

The report of the Panhandle Eastern Pipe Line Company and subsidiaries for the twelve months ended on June 30, made public yesterday, shows a consolidated net income, after all expenses and charges, of $5,078,183. This compares with a net of $4,483,740 in the twelve months to June 30, 1941.

ANKARA, Turkey, July 24 -- As a kindness to an American traveler who had come so far to see him, Shukru Saracoglu, Premier and Foreign Minister of Turkey, granted me the first exclusive interview since his assumption of the Premiership a fortnight ago.
Covering by shorts near the end of trading on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday brought active contracts from losses of as much as 10 points to closing gains of 1 to 2 points.

LONDON, July 24 -- America is drawing closer to German-occupied Europe not only with troops but with political warfare as well. Murray Brophy, government radio expert, is negotiating with the British for the erection of American transmitters in these islands to reach a greater number of Axis nationals, as well as conquered peoples.

NIAGARA FALLS, N.Y., July 24 -- Playing what he termed his best round of golf since he shot into fame in 1935, Ray Billows of the Dutchess Club, Poughkeepsie, today gained the final round of the New York State amateur championship for the sixth time in eight years.

SEABRIGHT, N.J., July 24 -- On turf trod by the world's best tennis players for over half a century, seven doubles teams gathered today to carry on the Seabright Lawn Tennis and Cricket Club invitation tournament in wartime.

WASHINGTON, July 24 -- The War Department cut some red tape from its operations today by abolishing all the subsidiary purchasing agencies within the service commands, formerly known as corps areas. As a result, each commanding general of the nine service commands will be solely responsible for all purchasing within his command and will need to audit only one purchase account instead of perhaps a score, as has been done under the old system.
Religious News Service Writer

LOURENCO MARQUES, Portuguese East Africa, July 22 (Delayed) -- This is a report of my personal experiences while imprisoned in Japan on charges of espionage immediately after the Japanese attack on Pearl Harbor.
MOSCOW, Saturday, July 25 (AP) -- The Soviet Information Bureau's midnight communique follows:

In order to maintain the prestige and identity of established American flag shipping services and in order to support the efforts to safeguard the future of the American merchant marine being undertaken by the War Shipping Administration, provision should be made by that agency to permit expenditures for both publicity and advertising in all future General Agency contracts, the Propeller Club, Port of New York, declared yesterday in a special resolution.

Adhering to a precedent established more than a year ago, the cost of food increased again between the middle of May and the middle of June. And this despite the fact that certain foods were "under ceiling" -- that is, carefully controlled by the General Maximum Price Regulation.

Samuel Buchler, 60 years old, a disbarred lawyer and former rabbi at Sing Sing, was arraigned in General Sessions yesterday on an indictment containing ten counts of grand larceny, two of petit larceny and one of practicing law in his Jewish court of arbitration, at 377 Broadway, although he had been disbarred ten years ago.
LONDON, July 24 -- Raiding the Ruhr and Rhineland in strong force last night, British bombers again dropped two-ton high-explosive missiles on the German industrial city of Duisburg.

I have read your editorial in today's issue criticizing Dean Wayne L. Morse, public member of the National War Labor Board, because of his remarks made at a public hearing before this board last Tuesday, in connection with the jurisdictional dispute between the Building Construction Trades, A.F. of L., and the United Electrical, Radio and Machine Workers of America, C.I.O., at the Frigidaire plant of General Motors Corporation, Dayton, Ohio.

The Dodgers and Pirates continued going in opposite directions at Ebbets Field last night, as the Brooks scored their fourth victory in a row and the Pittsburghers lost their fourth in succession. With a 6 -- 4 victory before a gathering of 10,798, Brooklyn maintained its seven-length margin over the Cards.

I have noted several instances reported in the press recently of waste and corruption in connection with the war effort. The latest item, printed in THE NEW YORK TIMES of July 17, stated that a "socially inclined" sales engineer had reported, before the House Naval Affairs Committee, earnings of over $400,000 as commission for obtaining war contracts.
MOSOOW, July 24 (AP) --The Soviet Information Bureau issued the following communique today:
I would like to reply to Elsie Testa's letter. Miss Testa seems to have doubts concerning the intelligence of the men and women of America.

Directors of the Virginia-Carolina Chemical Corporation authorized yesterday the dividend declaration of $5 a share on the 6 per cent cumulative participating preferred stock for payment on Aug. 20. The previous payment, $1 on Dec. 18, 1941, was the first since 1937.

FORT DES MOINES, Iowa, July 24 -- Nine out of ten of the white officer candidates at the Women's Army Auxiliary Corps school are college graduates, two-thirds of them have taught school or held clerical positions and 10 per cent are 40 or older.

WASHINGTON, July 24 -- Personnel of the appeals board now being set up under the commercial vehicle rationing program for District 2, covering the States of New York, Connecticut and New Jersey, was announced today by the Office of Defense Transportation. Seventeen such boards are being established in various parts of the country.

LONDON, July 24 -- After an Allied offensive is under way on the Continent of Europe, the troops will be followed closely by several contingents of women of all nationalities of the United Nations -- women who have already been trained to aid in the immediate relief of the populations of the Nazi-occupied countries as they are freed.

WASHINGTON, July 24 -- Speaker Rayburn blocked consideration by the House today of a resolution which would call upon the Maritime Commission to stay, for thirty days or longer, the cancellation of its contract with Andrew J. Higgins of New Orleans for the construction of 200 Liberty ships.
JERSEY CITY, N.J., July 24 (AP) -- Montreal evened its current six-game series with Jersey City tonight by taking the second game of the set, 2 to 1, behind the four-hit hurling of young Bob Chipman.

WASHINGTON, July 24 -- Between Jan. 1 and July 4 28,585 cases of jaundice developed among Amy men, apparently as the result of inoculation with yellow fever vaccine, Secretary Stimson said at a press conference today.

Pointing out that violators of the Federal automobile use tax regulations are subject to a $25 fine or thirty days in jail, Joseph T. Higgins, Collector of Internal Revenue, Third New York District, warned yesterday that "it is the intention of the Internal Revenue service to vigorously pursue to a conclusion any violation."

CAIRO, Egypt, July 24 -- British warships have hurled 2,000 shells into the port of Matruh in six night bombardments, ruining it as an Axis base, and the Royal Air Force has wrecked twenty-four more Axis planes in new devastating raids on El Daba airfield between Matruh and the bogged-down Egyptian land front before El Alamein, it was revealed tonight.

CHICAGO, July 24 (AP) -- Jake Wade beat Dick Fowler tonight in a pitching duel and gave the White Sox a 2-to-1 victory over the Athletics before a crowd of 7,492. Both Chicago runs were scored on errors by Billy Knickerbocker and Bob Swift.

LONDON, July 24 -- The stock market finished the week quietly. There were no outstanding price movements because commitments were being kept to a minimum over the week-end. Gilt-edge issues held steady at yesterday's prices.

WASHINGTON, July 24 -- Retail prices for canned fruits and berries may be stepped up as much as 25 per cent on many items as a result of price concessions granted packers by the Office of Price Administration, it was revealed by OPA today.

OLD ORCHARD BEACH, Me., July 24 (AP) -- Voloway, a bay son of Volomite, owned by the E.T. Lyle estate of Syracuse, N.Y., won the twenty-four-pace stake feature today in the grand circuit program at Old Orchard Beach's kite track.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., July 24 (AP) -- The International Brotherhood of Electrical Workers, A.F.L., said today that its members would strike Tuesday at three principal manufacturing plants of the Tennessee Coal, Iron and Railroad Company, largest Southern steel producer.

EPHRATA, Wash., July 24 (AP) -- The sharp eyes of William E. Edwards, 18-year-old Rock Springs, Ga., soldier, have brought him promotion. By his swift eyesight and action Edwards prevented probably serious injury to Colonel William E. Matheny, commander of the Second Air Force base here.

Two new films will arrive in Broadway theatres this morning. At the Rialto, the newcomer will be "Tombstone, the Town Too Tough to Die." Richard Dix, Victor Jory, Kent Taylor, Frances Gifford and Edgar Buchanan head the cast of the Paramount Western. . . .

LONDON, July 24 (U.P.) -- Italian bombing planes virtually wiped out at least four Yugoslav villages in the region of Sarajevo in mass reprisal against townspeople accused of aiding patriots who ambushed an Italian military column, killing two high officers, private advices said tonight.

The host drives down to the railroad station to meet his week-end visitors, and if they are the right kind of people, businesslike in their attitude, they will be on the train they had promised to take.

NEW CITY, N.Y., July 24 -- County Judge John A. McKenna amplified today the rebuke he administered two weeks ago to the jury during the trial of Edward C. Dormann, former Sheriff of Rockland County, in sentencing Dormann to five to ten years in Sing Sing prison for conspiracy and operation of a short-lived numbers lottery last Spring.

LONDON, July 24 (U.P.) -- Hundreds of American sailors, part of the first contingent to arrive in London, were turned loose on their first leave in months today and they revealed that they had shot down three or four German planes in a recent brush with the enemy.

Only four have been named for today's $10,000 added Yonkers Handicap, getaway-day feature at Empire City, but it looks like one of the best races of the meeting, for the horses named are Apache, Tola Rose, Boysy and Barrancosa. The first is William Woodward's best 3-year-old, who won the Empire City Handicap in track record time.
