LOS ANGELES, July 24 (U.P.) -- Prospects that Pacific Coast football will continue this Fall brightened tonight as Governor Culbert Olson and Lieut. Gen. John L. De Witt, in command of the Western Defense Sector, approved the schedules of nine California universities and colleges.

Mayor La Guardia appealed yesterday for action by all the countries of the Western Hemisphere against "a moral invasion which is as detrimental to our interest as a territorial invasion." He spoke at ceremonies commemorating the 159th anniversary of the birth of Simon Bolivar, South American liberator.
The following Italian communique was broadcast yesterday from Rome and recorded here by The Associated Press:

WASHINGTON, July 24 -- How by coordination through "democratic processes and friendly consent" the United States increased the rate of munition production for the second quarter of 1942 nearly 400 per cent over 1941, and the Canadians increased their production rate by 300 per cent, was told today.

ALBANY, July 24 -- Backed by an official opinion of Attorney General Bennett, the Secretary of State, Michael F. Walsh, declined today to accept a certificate of incorporation of the Welders Association Inc., of Watertown, which proposed to incorporate under the Membership Law.

CAIRO, Egypt, July 24 -- The British drive against the German positions on the front in El Alamein area was slowed down yesterday for the consolidation of positions. Severe fighting was reported in some limited area, but there were no further heavy attacks on either side.
The Dow Chemical Company and subsidiaries reported yesterday for the fiscal year ended on May 31, 1942, net profit of $9,221,486 after $10,079,126 reserve for Federal income and excess profits taxes.

WASHINGTON, July 24 -- New electrical motors will be available henceforth only for the most important war and civilian requirements and other applicants must get along with used equipment, the War Production Board ruled today. In general large motors of any kind (used or new) are not available for other than war or essential civilian uses, but there are believed to be 1,000,000 or more used motors above one horsepower available in the country.
CHICAGO, July 24 (AP) -- Eleven of America's top 3-year-olds were named today for the $85,000-added Arlington Classic -- the Waterloo of champions in the past.

MEXICO CITY, July 24 -- Mexico is holding to the policy of not sending her army overseas, but will increase her armed forces to 150,000 regular troops by Spring, according to a statement today by General Salvador Sanchez, the Chief of Staff.

WASHINGTON, July 24 -- The American Federation of Labor's counter-proposal on cooperation with the British and Soviet Trade Union movements in the war effort has been accepted by the General Council of the British Trade Union Congress, according to a cablegram received here today by William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor.

TEHERAN, Iran, July 24 -- The Axis drives toward the Caucasus and the Suez Canal have stiffened the courage and backbone of the people of Iran, who are determined to give all the help required by the Allies in accordance with the terms of the treaty signed after Britain and the Soviet Union occupied their country last September, Prime Minister Ali Soheily said in an interview today.

Three hundred children, representing twenty-one nationalities, greeted a miniature Hitler with boos and hisses yesterday at a pageant and folk festival at the Educational Alliance, East Broad-day and Jefferson Street.

WASHINGTON, July 24 -- New York State wholesalers and retailers of wines and liquors were warned by the Office of Price Administration today that they must continue their customary discounts and other price differentials made during March, in accordance with the General Maximum Price Regulation.

CLEVELAND, July 24 (AP) -- Catcher Jim Hegan singled home Les Fleming in the twelfth inning tonight to give the Indians a double victory over the Senators, 4 to 3 and 5 to 4, in the city's first twilight-night twin bill.

Edward J. Flynn, National Democratic Chairman and Bronx County leader, announced formally yesterday his endorsement of Senator James M. Mead of Buffalo for the Democratic nomination for Governor. He thus aligned himself with President Roosevelt and a group of New Dealers in opposition to James A. Farley, the State chairman, who is managing the pre-convention campaign of Attorney General John J. Bennett Jr. of Brooklyn.

MOSCOW, July 24 -- Hungarian cavalry and infantry are giving considerable help to the German Army in the fighting on the River Don's upper reaches. There have been large skirmishes between Magyar horsemen and mounted Cossacks and Bashkirians, while south of Voronezh several brigades of infantry have sought to hold ground east of the Don, but have been routed by Russian infantry.

LONDON, July 24 -- The United States Air Force has taken over the whole job of maintaining and repairing American planes, whether they are flown by the Royal Air Force or their own crews, it was disclosed today. The British will look after the upkeep of the planes of their own manufacture.
BOSTON, July 24 (AP) -- Max Lanier, stylish left-hander of the Cardinals, needed little of his team-mates' sixteen-hit attack today as he blanked the Braves, 8 to 0, on six hits.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., July 24 -- Under conditions reminiscent of the famous "battle of the ballots" here in 1938, the five duly-sworn members of Governor Edison's new Hudson County Tax Board went to their office in the county court house today to assume their duties and were denied admittance by County Police officials, acting under instructions from the county's chief legal adviser.
WASHINGTON, July 24 -- The War Shipping Administration requisitioned for military use today the Argentine tanker Victoria, damaged by an Axis torpedo April 17.

First harbingers of a new cycle of fashion are the fabrics on which it is founded. Ever since curtailment of importations from world-famed looms in France and the woolen mills of England have brought into high relief the creative and artistic abilities of American fashionists, the spotlight has focused brightly upon the yardages turned out by American textile designers.

WASHINGTON, July 24 -- The House followed the Senate's lead and passed, 104 to 18, today the bill which, if President Roosevelt approves it, will wrest from the War Production Board its authority over the manufacture of synthetic rubber from alcohol drawn from farm and forest products, and give this control to a new agency, independent of the WPB.

WASHINGTON, July 24 -- An announcement that a sixth of the eight Nazi saboteurs had taken the stand in his own behalf today seemed to indicate that the defense counsel wished all of the accused to testify.
Mr. Edelman asked recently in your columns the reason why professional tennis players do not attract the gate they had been drawing at the amateur championships.

Finland gave world-wide currency yesterday to a suggestion that the United States might help extricate her from her position as an ally of Germany and as a possible sacrifice to Soviet Russia in the event of a United Nations victory.

The changelessness of the message of religion in a changing world will be emphasized in sermons tomorrow in the churches of New York City. A greater use of parish houses for defense purposes will be urged and Mayor La Guardia will be commended for locating in these buildings many of the city's fingerprinting stations.

The plan for the consolidation of the Pittston Company and its subsidiary, the United States Distributing Company, is understood to be making progress and its submission to stockholders is expected soon. Among other things, the plan provides for the exchange of two common shares of Pittston for each one now held.

ST. LOUIS, July 24 (AP) -- A home run by Chet Laabs with one runner on base in the eleventh inning gave the Browns a 3-to-1 victory over the Red Sex in the second game of tonight's double-header. Boston won the opener, 5 to 3.

CHICAGO, July 24 -- Prices of wheat held within narrow limits until near the close today, when increased pressure developed and disclosed a lack of support, and the finish on the Board of Trade was near the bottom with losses of to 7/8 cent a bushel.

Franklyn Fischer, 42 years old, a commercial artist, head of the Fischer Exhibits Company, Inc., of 73 Fifth Avenue, was sentenced yesterday by Judge Robert A. Inch in Federal Court, Brooklyn, to serve a year in a Federal prison. Fischer, a native of Vienna, was convicted a week ago of violation of the Federal Communications Act in having a ship-to-shore telephone on his yacht, a privilege denied to aliens.
Ralph Ingersoll, 41-year-old editor of the newspaper PM, volunteered yesterday for enlistment in the Army.

MOSCOW, July 24 -- The danger of Rostov has increased in the last twenty-four hours and the Germans now are fighting within the region of the city. Though the advance was achieved only at considerable loss, German tank superiority is proving decisive and, handicapped by the terrain, the defenders are unable to make full use of their anti-tank weapons and are relying mainly on aircraft to harass and disperse enemy columns.
DETROIT, July 24 -- Apparently unmindful of having had a sizable winning streak snapped yesterday, the Yankees lost no time today in setting themselves to the task of building a new one.

In answer to your editorial condemning Dean Wayne L. Morse as a public member of the National War Labor Board, I wish publicly, as I have in the private sessions of the board, to join Dean Morse in indignant condemnation of jurisdictional strikes as inexcusably disregardful of both the best interests of labor and the safety of the American people in a desperately critical hour.

BERNE, Switzerland, July 24 -- A special communique from General Draja Mikhailovitch's Yugoslav headquarters received here late today announced that Chetnik forces have launched a large-scale drive in the Hercegovina area against positions occupied by Axis troops.

WASHINGTON, July 24 -- The Treasury has decided to continue its voluntary War Bond sale campaign during September. Originally Secretary Morgenthau had intimated that he would allow July sales to be the criterion of the success of the voluntary plan as against compulsory saving.

William Griffin, publisher of The New York Enquirer and one of the twenty-eight persons just indicted in Washington for an alleged conspiracy to damage the morale of the men of the armed forces, was placed under arrest late yesterday afternoon.

May I take issue with the recent statement of Bill Brandt, of the National League publicity department, which appeared in Mr. Kieran's column concerning the shortest home run on record? I'd like to tell you about a home run which makes Mr. Brandt's circuit blow a long, towering smash.

WASHINGTON, July 24 (AP) -- A new plan of reorganization for the Denver Rio Grande Western Railroad, intended to meet objections to prior reorganization plans, was issued today by the Interstate Commerce Commission.

Much conservation of man-hours and scarce materials necessary for the speeding up of war production has been accomplished through suggestions made by their employes, according to announcements made yesterday by the General Electric Company and the General Motors Corporation.

Word comes from Chungking that Colonel Robert L. Scott of the Twenty-third Pursuit Squadron "detoured and flew over Mount Everest, clearing the top of the world's highest mountain by well over a mile," during a recent flight from India to China. One's thoughts go back to those trouble-loving Britishers who tried so hard to get up Everest on foot during the Nineteen Twenties.

LONDON, July 24 (AP) -- Germany, pinched for shipping space after almost three years of war, has started a campaign to salvage vessels sunk along the European coast and is pushing a program for the construction of standardized merchantmen similar to the American "Liberty Ships," British sources declared today.

WASHINGTON, July 24 -- President Roosevelt held a Cabinet meeting, held his press conference, signed the bill exempting from the amusement tax theatres operated within service camps and posts and issued a joint statement with King Peter of Yugoslavia pledging collaboration between the countries; his visitors included Albert Goss, Representative Casey, King Peter and the Yugoslavian Ministry and Myron C. Taylor.

WASHINGTON, July 24 (AP) -- Secretary Knox said today that anti-submarine operations and security requirements made Navy control of coastal ship-to-shore radio stations essential. Operators, he added, must be naval personnel.

LONDON, July 24 -- Manganese, an essential ingredient in making steel for armaments, was a greater lure than oil for Germany when she invaded Russia, Sir Thomas Holland, principal of Edinburgh University and an authority on metals, said today in his opening address to the British Association conference on mineral resources.

Further progress has been made in the first six months of this year in the program of the Ogden Corporation for sales of investments in and the liquidation, reorganization and integration of subsidiary companies, B.H. Brewster, president, said yesterday in his semi-annual report to stockholders.

MINNEAPOLIS, July 24 (AP) -- The forty-third attempt in nineteen years to sell the Minneapolis St. Louis Railroad brought a bid today of $2,010,000 by Walter W. Colpitts of Coverdale Colpitts, New York engineers.

PORT DALHOUSIE, Ont., July 24 (AP) -- Buffalo's West Side Club long a power in Canadian and United States rowing and sculling circles, tonight appeared on the verge of losing the Royal Canadian Henley title -- a title it had won both last year and the year before.

The tax-exempt field for the third consecutive week had the new-issue market pretty much to itself this week with two offerings accounting for $4,878,000 of the total of $5,878,000 in new bonds offered here for public subscription. This compares with $26,819,000 in new bonds placed on the market last week and with a total of $139,963,000 offered a year ago.

PHILADELPHIA, July 24 (AP) -- Eugene G. Grace received $537,724 as president of the Bethlehem Steel Corporation in 1941, a rise of $59,580 over his 1940 income. This made him again the second highest paid executive in the country.

The directors of the St. Joseph, South Bend Southern Railroad Company yesterday announced that the New York Central Railroad Company had offered to purchase on or before Oct. 1 the road's 1,640 shares of 5 per cent non-cumulative preferred stock at $100 a share and the 4,800 shares of common stock at $22.50 each.

WITH THE UNITED STATES AIR FORCE, in Australia, July 24 (U.P.) -- The Allied bombing of the Japanese landing forces at Buna, New Guinea, was one of the biggest operations in this South Pacific area since the Battle of the Coral Sea, returning American airmen reported today.

PHILADELPHIA, July 24 -- Three special masters recommended to the Federal district court today that Morgan S. Kaufman, a Scranton attorney, be disciplined for "grossly unprofessional conduct" in his financial transactions with J. Warren Davis, former judge of the Third Circuit Court of Appeals.
WINNIPEG, July 24 (Canadian Press) -- Net profit of $446,000, compared with $292,000 last year, is shown in the 273d annual report of the Hudson's Bay Company, released here today.

MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, July 24 (AP) -- The shape of Argentine foreign policy, as illuminated by recent events, including last week's closed session of the Chamber of Deputies in Buenos Aires, was authoritatively said today to offer scant prospect of future concessions by Argentina in favor of the United Nations' cause.
Seven new plays will be tried out in the Summer theatres next week, a figure that forms the high-water mark of the present rural season. Listed according to their opening dates, they are:

Much has been made of the spectacle of Americans breaking their necks to bet on the horses. There has been a lot of hullabaloo over the waste of gasoline, rubber, money and time in getting to tracks. I've also heard it said that the money handed through the mutuel windows should be helping the country win the war (in spite of the fact that the turf is taking care of its end).

BERNE, Switzerland, July 24 -- Secretary of State Cordell Hull's speech on the war and its aftermath is so full of substance that comment cannot be immediate. Moreover, in countries where the press is regimented censors are still busy with blue pencils deciding what parts shall or shall not be printed.

The Bronx Zoo, which recently added a bucolic touch to its environs with the opening of a major exhibit, "Farm-in-the-Zoo," is going all-out for rustic life. A hay wagon taxi service will be put into service today and will shuttle over a two and one-half mile course every Saturday and Sunday of the Summer.

LONDON, July 24 -- While Rear Admiral Robert C. Griffen, commander of a United States naval task force in British waters, was received at Buckingham Palace today by King George, sailors and marines of his force started to enjoy their first day of leave by sightseeing in London.

The Tokyo radio broadcast yesterday a Domei dispatch in which a Japanese corresponden on Kiska Island at the western end of the Aleutians reported that United States bombers were attacking Japanese forces there two or three times a day, dropping bombs through the fog.

A centralized information service planned to find "a post for every woman on the victory front" will be launched Wednesday at the Hotel St. Regis during a luncheon for leaders of national women's organizations. This "liaison office between all women's volunteer organizations and the supporting public" is already quartered at 113 West Fifty-seventh Street and is designated as the National Information Bureau on Women's War Activities, according to its temporary chairman, Mme. Yolanda Mero-Irion.

LOURENCO MARQUES, Portuguese East Africa, July 24 -- The Japanese people are enduring the limit of hardships in daily life, but their warlords' constant harping on victories keeps their morale up and they have been told that their sea losses have been very small.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., July 24 -- The aid of many additional members of the Summer colony has been enlisted to serve in the workroom of the surgical dressings unit of the American Hospital in Great Britain, which is open all day on Monday, Tuesday and Wednesday, and on Thursday nights in the basement of the School of Nursing of the Southampton Hospital.

Five new playgrounds have just been completed along the border of the Belt Parkway within the two and one-quarter miles between Owls Head Park and Fort Hamilton on the Brooklyn shore of the Narrows, the Park Department announced yesterday.

WESTBURY, L. I., July 24 -- Beating his own record by a half second, A. C. Kinsella's Ronald equalled the season's mark at Roosevelt Raceway tonight by winning the fifth race, a one-mile pace, in 2:05. John Dill, in the sulky behind Ronald, rated the pacer along carefully in second position, six lengths back of the leader, until they entered the last turn, and won by two lengths going away.

WASHINGTON, July 24 -- After the chairman of the Tire Rationing Board of Steuben County had protested, among others, against granting the Erie Railroad Company's application for permission to abandon a seventy-three-mile line from Painted Post to Avon, N.Y., the Interstate Commerce Commission today denied the request.

Is it possible that there is a higher law even than Mr. Petrillo's slightest word? The Government thinks there might be, and has had the temerity to move against him from two different directions. The Attorney General has authorized the filing of an injunction suit under the anti-trust laws to stop Mr. Petrillo from preventing his musicians' union members from making recordings for the radio.
VICHY, France, July 24 -- Latest reports on the recruiting of French workmen for German factories were given to the Cabinet today by Hubert Lagardelle, Minister of Labor.

Italian broadcasts recorded by The Associated Press in New York said that the Italian High Command claimed yesterday the occupation of Siwa Oasis, thirty miles inside Egypt and sixty miles southeast of Jarabub, Libyan Oasis village reported recaptured earlier from the British.

IN August, 1936, Arthur Koestler visited Portugal and rebel Spain for The London News Chronicle. A Hungarian with a background of Leftist politics, he was taking his life in his hands. But he managed to get an interview with the Fascist General Queipo de Llano before his past caught up with him. Escaping by way of Gibraltar just in time to avoid arrest, Koestler later published the substance of his interview.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 25 -- Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer today announced signing of one-picture deals with five band leaders, Harry James, Tommy Dorsey, Jimmie Dorsey, Bob Crosby and Vaughn Monroe, under which they will appear with their orchestras in forthcoming Metro films.

WASHINGTON, July 24 -- A Joint Statement pledging the United States and Yugoslavia to the vigorous prosecution of the war was issued today by President Roosevelt and King Peter when the monarch called at the White House to say farewell before returning to London.

Summer dullness depressed trade activity this week and was also reflected in a moderate let down of industry's record operations, Dun Bradstreet reported yesterday in its weekly review. Retail selling was mainly active in clearance lines.
CHICAGO, July 24 -- Gib Sellers, the village golfsmith of Walled Lake, Mich., shattered par today to take the lead in the Tam o' Shanter $15,500 open tournament.

The Navy Department announced yesterday that a medium-sized United States merchant vessel had been torpedoed and sunk by a submarine in the Caribbean area on June 8. This was the first such announcement in nearly forty-eight hours.

AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, Australia, July 24 (AP) -- A group of United States Army fliers received Silver Stars from Lieut. Gen. George H. Brett today for parts in bombing attacks on the Japanese airdrome at Rabaul, New Britain.

Listings released yesterday by the New Jersey Council naming the current leaders in the various classes of the Governor's fishing tourney indicate that interest in the competition has mounted greatly during the last few weeks.

DETROIT, July 24 -- General Motors Corporation disclosed today with War Department approval that the new Army tank plant built by its Fisher Body division has been completed and is rolling out the all-welded M-4 type of land dreadnought in trainload quantities.

How old does an old landmark in New York have to be to qualify? The bridge between the Tombs Prison that was and the Criminal Court Building that was, derelicts both, dates from 1903. In London in 1904 the last Newgate Prison was torn down. There had been a prison on the site for nearly seven hundred years.

AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, Australia, Saturday, July 25 -- Allied planes poured 45,000 pounds of explosive and fire bombs into the new Japanese bridgehead in the Gona area of Northern Papua yesterday, setting huge fires and forcing several supply ships to flee before they could unload, it was announced today.

The stock market returned yesterday to a shiftless state, and in so doing simply mirrored the many uncertainties in the war picture and the developments on the home economic front. Traders adopted again a watchful waiting attitude and held to the sidelines pending more definite news on taxation and anti-inflation measures.

MEXICO CITY, July 24 -- Twelve of the thirty-two survivors of a freighter sunk July 12 in the Caribbean arrived here today by a Pan American plane. The remaining twenty will be flown here from Merida, Yucatan, tomorrow or Sunday, and all will travel by plane to Laredo, Texas, en route to New Orleans, where they are scheduled to board another American merchant vessel.
COLORADO SPRINGS, Col. -- Somewhat flabbergasted but game and determined, the upland folk of Colorado are playing host to one of the biggest Summer crowds of outlanders in her history.

I know I but repeat what has been said so often and so plainly by the critics when I ask why can't the producers wake up to the truth that America not only needs, but wants, sensible fare from Hollywood.

SYRACUSE, July 25 (AP) -- Oscar F. Soule, Onondaga County rationing board chairman, said today he was resigning in protest "against the manner in which rationing has been handled by OPA," particularly in the matter of gasoline.

WHEN American tanks first reached North Africa the British Tommies nicknamed them "becushioned buggies" because of their linings of sponge rubber. Those soft linings saved a lot of broken elbows and cracked kneecaps (a light tank traveling at high speed throws its crew about like dice in a box).
Even the Bronx cheer has gone bucolic. Yesterday, when the zoo began using a hay wagon as a taxi, what rang through the air was not the familiar borough note of derision but the crow of a rooster.

SANTA FE, N.M. -- To the Pueblo peoples of the Southwest the month of August is a time for prayer and for ceremonial dancing. Corn will long since have been planted and its cultivation completed, but if the crop is to mature, in August must come the life-giving rains.

IT was Emerson who said, "The cause of peace is not the cause of cowardice. . . . If peace is to be maintained, it must be by brave men, who have come up to the same height as the hero. . . . "This sentiment was expressed in his essay "War," printed for the first time in the Aesthetic Papers in 1849.

A YOUNG American professor, Mitchell Drake, goes to Mexico to search for his brother, Arthur, who has disappeared. Mexico is not new country to Drake; he was born there, as was also his brother, and there are still people there who remember them.

SOME strange prophecies are being made under the stress of these times. Frank Swinerton, the English novelist, writing in the current Harper's Magazine on "The Writer in Wartime," remarks that E.M. Forster has said over the radio that he does not think there will be any more professional authors.

It was John J. Jones's earnest intention to forego his Summer vacation in the country this year and stay, patriotically, in the city. His presence in town might not advance the national war effort to any great extent.

THE Shostakovich Seventh symphony has come with a tremendous burst of trumpets and popular acclaim at the moment of presentation, the first in America, by Arturo Toscanini and the NBC orchestra. This happened just a week ago today.

BEAU STARK jumped from the deck of a river steamboat in a vain attempt to save the life of a slave who had gone overboard. Henry Clay and his niece witnessed his heroism, and when Stark found himself in the same stagecoach with them on the way from Wheeling to Baltimore he was pleased with the admiration both gave him.

WASHINGTON, July 25 -- Exiled Austrians should be allowed to enlist in the war against the Axis, Senator Pepper of Florida declared today in a special Mutual Network broadcast commemorating the anniversary of the assassination of Chancellor Engelbert Dollfuss in the Nazi putsch of 1934.

"WHEN is a left-over not a left-over?" is a culinary conundrum best answered by the use of herbs. Herbs and spices -- a strategic leaf or two of bay and a pinch of sage -- will account for probably nine-tenths of the gastronomic successes of all time.

A GYPSY fortune teller warns Jim Tyler that she sees death in his hand and that it is coming soon. Jim, who is a reporter on The Star, disappears soon after, and there is every indication that he has been murdered to prevent his appearance before the grand jury which is investigating political corruption in the city.

CHICAGO, July 25 -- Shut Out clinched the 3-year-old championship today by galloping to victory in the $88,250 Arlington Classic at Arlington Park, under one of the most magnificent rides ever delivered by Eddie Arcaro.

With Howard Barlow conducting and Ania Dorfmann as piano soloist, last night's Beethoven program at the Lewisohn Stadium proved to be a pleasant occasion for an audience of more than 7,000. Miss Dorfmann appeared in the C major Concerto, and Mr. Barlow began the program by directing the New York Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra in the "Leonore" Overture, No. 3, and ended it with the Sixth Symphony.

RETAIL trade last week shook off some of its mid-summer lethargy as many stores started their special promotions of Winter coats and furniture. Reports varied on the extent of customer response, with volume increasing, however, toward the end of the week.

LOURENCO MARQUES, Portuguese East Africa, July 25 -- Japan's war lords made full preparations for war before sending a "peace" envoy to Washington last Autumn, and they now are believed to be trying to outflank the Soviet Union by seizing American outposts in the Aleutians.

A PRODUCTION of "Macbeth" by John Gielgud might well have made the big night even of a peacetime theatre season. In a war year and with the accumulated expectation of a provincial pre-London run amounting to more than six months, the importance of this opening was doubled.

CHICAGO, July 25 -- Prices of wheat rose 1 1/2 cents a bushel on the Board of Trade as the result of announcement that a bill would be introduced into the Senate shortly seeking to change the basis for computing the so-called parity prices on agriculture products from a 1909-14 to a 1919-29 base.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., July 25 -- Yale has put into full operation, three weeks after the opening of the Summer term, its required physical fitness war service program, with 3,175 of the 3,202 undergraduates enrolled.

CHICAGO, July 25 (AP) -- An increase of 220,320 in membership over last year was reported by the C.I.O.-United Automobile, Aircraft and Agricultural Implement Workers of America in its secretary-treasurer's report for the fiscal year ended April 30.

CHAPEL HILL, N.C., July 25 -- On the University of North Carolina campus this week the South -- years ago labeled the nation's economic problem No. 1 by President Roosevelt -- came a step nearer realizing its "unlimited possibilities as the richest potential region in the United States."

WHAT with one thing and another it appeared last week that the old debate "Resolved, that double features are a crime against civilization" was about to flare up again. In New York Samuel Goldwyn, the white knight of the quality producers, broke a stout lance over the noggin of the Grade B picture, which is inevitable as long as double features continue.

The volume of all services rendered by the Seamen's Church Institute to active merchant seamen in the first six months of 1942 showed substantial increases in all departments over the services in the same period last year, according to the semi-annual report made public yesterday.

With iris planting time at hand the progressive gardener will not let the season pass without securing at least a few of the newer -- and much finer -- varieties that are now available at such moderate price. This is especially true this year, because the Tall Bearded iris, among hardy plants, requires about the minimum of care and is therefore ideal for wartime beds and borders.

IN "All the Trumpets Sounded" -- the title has its origins in John Bunyan -- Mr. W.G. Hardy, already known for his "Father Abraham," has attempted, with some success, the re-creation of Moses. In a general way, it may be said that in making the great leader of Israel the hero of a novel he has followed the realistic method of Werfel, Thomas Mann, Sholem Asch and other novelists of the modern school.

The New York Football Giants will start pre-season training at State Teachers College, Superior, Wis., on Aug. 6, according to President John V. Mara. Between thirty-five and forty veterans and newcomers are expected to report to Coach Steve Owen.

THE historical side of this immensely entertaining novel set in England and the Mediterranean must be dealt with first despite the author's disclaimer of a factual foundation fur much of it. It was a critical time: the opening years of the reign of the Scottish King of England whose fatuous attempts to wrest freedom from his subjects led, afterward, to civil war and the establishment of a Commonwealth.

An offer of 1,500 topographical and climatic maps of Japan, China, Siberia and Central and North America, the results of thirty years of labor, was made yesterday to the Army, Navy and other government agencies by Professor John Hastings of the City College Economics Department.

A thousand men, women and children, some in foreign costumes, marched through the streets of the Chelsea district yesterday in support of that area's civilian defense program. The various units were cheered along the three-mile route that ended at Chelsea Square Park on Twenty-seventh Street near Tenth Avenue.

The United Nations are confronted with tremendous tasks of this greatest of all wars. Victory has to be won. They must also squarely face the problems of the future peace. The world must be made safe for common humanity.

Eleven safeguards for business, free enterprise and the public if government subsidies become inevitable are suggested by Hector Lazo in a study entitled "Subsidies as a Solution for the Squeeze," available here last week. Presenting what he termed a "practical proposal for the subsidy program." Mr. Lazo asserted these safeguards were essential in addition to the four standards developed by government spokesmen to prevent possible abuse by business.

GORDON GRANT, whose drawings of ships have delighted boys and girls and their elders over a long period of time, has now written a story for the younger children. It is built around a fresh and fascinating idea which gives this artist-author an opportunity not only to draw a fine collection of typical sailing vessels but pictures of sea captains, sailors and pirates, and even a portrait of the redoubtable "Davy Jones" himself.

Much of the discussion of the artist and his part in the war, it seems to me after reflection, has come about through a natural confusion of two issues. The patriotism of the artists is unquestioned. But one issue is economic security for the artist -- something that, worse luck, the artist has never had and that has come to the fore again with renewed intensity in the present national situation.

A GREAT many people are looking for Ben Fettridge, who has disappeared along with a large sum of money which does not belong to him. Up at Tamarack Inn, in the Adirondacks, Elbert Jones, a mild-mannered public accountant, happens to mention that he has had a telephone call from Fettridge asking Jones to meet him the following day in Plattsburg.

As this is written, in the third week of July, the Spring-Flowering Sweet Peas are in full blossom. If they "perform" as they have for the past two seasons, they will still be giving profuse bloom four weeks hence.

THIS novel is the faithful and competently told story of a woman's life from 15 to 40 from 1903 to 1928. In those years pretty Blanche Rankin took a deal of shaking by the winds of fate and managed somehow to keep a precarious footing.

Many gardeners I know have much trouble with moles, just as I have had. I tried several methods of extermination with varying results. However, just recently I discovered a very inexpensive and efficacious remedy and want to pass on the information to other gardeners.

PRINCETON, N.J., July 25 -- According to advices just received here, students and faculty of the Princeton-Yenching School of Public Affairs at Yenching University, near Peiping, China, which was closed by the Japanese on Dec. 8, 1941, are trekking on foot across 2,000 miles of war-torn country to Chengtu, in Free China, where Yenching-in-exile will be opened in the Fall.

WASHINGTON, July 25 (AP) -- To speed oil to the East, sixty-car tank trains are moving from Southwestern oilfields to one-point Eastern destinations, the Office of Defense Transportation disclosed today.

LONDON, July 25 -- Taking up his duties this week in British West Africa, Resident Minister Swinton confirmed that the linking up of production with that of Free French Africa and the Belgian Congo would be his chief task.

WASHINGTON, July 25 -- Steps to relieve the squeeze on wholesalers and retailers handling goods from large-volume soup manufacturers who early last season had made substantial "opening price allowances" on some varieties of canned condensed soups were taken by the Office of Price Administration today.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Brazil, July 25 (AP) -- The Brazilian Government was disclosed tonight to have demanded an immediate satisfactory solution to "the unjustified imprisonment" of Brazilians by the Germans in occupied France, under threat of taking "measures suggested by the circumstances" if satisfaction is not forthcoming.

As a nation we are united in declaring that we must not have inflation. As individuals and in groups we still cling to the hope that somehow we can escape the sacrifices necessary to avert inflation. Labor does not want inflation; but it does want higher wages. Agriculture does not want inflation; but it does want "parity" prices.

To make certain that no vessels suitable for observation or rescue work in the anti-submarine patrol have been overlooked, the Coast Guard Auxiliary, comprised of yachtsmen and largely members of the Power Squadrons, has been ordered to take a complete census.
BARNEGAT, N.J., July 25 -- Two months ago Conrad H. Carlsson, 58-year-old junior engineer on a merchant vessel, was rescued off this resort after his ship had been torpedoed.

MUSTANG, born in a stable on the Horseshoe Ranch, was Sam McSwain's colt. For four and a half years Mustang lived on the ranch, his devotion for Sam McSwain increasing until it was like the devotion of a dog for his master.

WASHINGTON, July 25 -- Secretary Knox ordered today a speed-up of the program enlisting yachtsmen and small-boat operators in offensive operations against enemy submarines. In a statement by the Secretary commending the patriotic desire of these yachtsmen to join in the fight against the nation's enemies, he said:

CANBERRA, Australia, July 25 -- By Federalists and Unificationists alike the High Court's judgment validating a uniform income tax for Australia is regarded here as a landmark in constitutional history.

Present indications are that the natural rubber industry will be among the great casualties of the war. Spurred by the force of necessity, American industry and research are developing a synthetic rubber industry with which natural rubber will not be able to compete even if the price should be lowered well below the 20-cent-a-pound level that prevailed for about two years before the attack on Pearl Harbor.

Come peace and the certain boom in every type of normal airplane travel, there is likely to be a surplus of all kinds of aviation equipment and personnel -- with the exception of the radio ranges and the radio engineers needed to install them.

WASHINGTON, July 25 -- Reports reaching Washington today from 3,500 rationing boards in the Eastern section of the nation have convinced officials of the Office of Price Administration that the time and effort given to devising a foolproof method of gasoline rationing have been spent profitably.

When Columbia selected the Cauca Valley town of Palmira for holding the republic's Eighth National Agricultural Fair and Exposition, beginning on July 4, the postal administration paid philatelic tribute to one of Colombia's foremost romanticists, Jorge Isaacs (1837-1895), whose sentimental idyll "Maria" is associated with Palmira and is recognized as the most famous Spanish-American novel.

Between 150 and 200 is the prediction of the race committee on the number of craft that will be daily entries in the Larchmont Race Week, which will start on Wednesday and continue through next Sunday. That would be a large gathering, considering the difficulties which have confronted yachting this year.

WASHINGTON, July 25 (AP) -- Emphasizing that current shortages of meat in some parts of the country were only temporary, the Department of Agriculture predicted today that a record supply of hogs would be sold and slaughtered during the marketing year beginning Oct. 1.

THE creative accident of combining Fatty Arbuckle's pants and Ford Sterling's shoes is responsible for the picture easily recognized by most of the world as Charlie Chaplin. Further enhanced with mustache, cane and derby this picture, familiar to millions, has become a symbol of the "little fellow." There have been more ingeniously designed clowns.

With fewer buyers here than in the preceding week, activity in the wholesale markets last week was fair, with some lines reporting a smaller volume than last year, according to the report prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by McGreevey, Werring Howell, Inc.
