Senator Thomas's suggested revision of the parity computation method in order to create higher parity prices on wheat and cotton swung the pendulum of cotton prices sharply to the plus side yesterday, but hedging on the new crop in the waning minutes of trading on the New York Cotton Exchange backed quotations moderately from the session's highs.

The Office of Price Administration has begun an investigation of reports that counterfeit gasoline ration books have been offered for sale, it was disclosed here yesterday at headquarters for Region 2, which covers New York, New Jersey, Pennsylvania, Delaware, Maryland and the District of Columbia.
CHICAGO, July 25 -- Eighteen thousand civilians are "going to war" in Chicago. Not with guns do they march -- but with gauges and tools and test tubes and mathematics -- and with trained minds.

SEABRIGHT, N.J., July 25 -- Ted Schroeder of Glendale, Calif., and Sidney Wood of Southampton and Victor Seixas of Philadelphia and William Talbert of Cincinnati completed the second day of competition without a setback in the round-robin doubles tournament at the Seabright Lawn Tennis and Cricket Club today.

Individuals who decry fishing as merely a lark and a method to fritter away precious hours will not find any solace or support for their views in George Ruppert's latest announcement concerning the current salt-water angling contest bearing his name.

QUINCY, Mass., July 25 (AP) -- The Champlin, one of four destroyers built this year at the Fore River yards of the Bethlehem Steel Company, was launched today. Two of the four have been delivered to the Navy.

IT would be quite superficial to say that "The Just and the Unjust" is the fictional treatment of a murder trial in extenso; it is that indeed, but it is very much more than that. Through capable handling of character and a digging into the roots of human behavior it becomes, in essence, a presentation and an analysis of what might be called the American way of discipline.

CHICAGO, July 25 (AP) -- Thornton Lee, the White Sox southpaw who won twenty-two games last year, started his first game of the 1942 season today, pitched ten innings and permitted only six hits, but lost the decision to the Athletics' Phil Marchildron, 2 to 1, when the Philadelphia pitcher doubled in the tenth and scored on Elmer Valo's single.

A sale of farm specialties consisting of hand and home made articles from the Farm and Garden Shop at Rockefeller Center, to be held Tuesday and Wednesday in the Regence Room of the Weylin, has been announced by Mrs. David Marvin Goodrich, president of the New York Division of the Woman's National Farm and Garden Association, Inc., and chairman of the Farm and Garden Shop.

College and university endowment funds earned as high a rate of return in 1941 as they did in 1940, owing to increased holdings in common stock and additional income from real estate, it was revealed yesterday in a survey on "College and University Investments and Income, 1925-41," conducted for the American Council on Education Studies by J. Harvey Cain, accounting officer of the Board of Higher Education.
The following Italian High Command communique was broadcast from Rome yesterday and was recorded here by The Associated Press:

Following establishment of a weekly survey on the hours in which critical machine tools are available for war production, some 362 companies in this area have been provided with war work to take up machine tool time which otherwise would have been idle, Reeves L. Kennedy, regional manager of the Production Service Department of the War Production Board, announced yesterday.

LONDON, July 25 -- In the campaign for the opening of a new front in Western Europe ten munition workers representing the employes of seven London factories took to 10 Downing Street today a petition calling upon Prime Minister Churchill to start an offensive against the Nazis at once.

The report of the Gamewell Company and its subsidiaries announced yesterday for the fiscal year ended on May 31, shows a net profit of $1,217,675 after Federal and Canadian income and excess profits taxes.

NIAGARA FALLS, N.Y., July 25 -- Pulling one of the greatest upsets in the history of the championship, Alex Stevenson, 21-year-old clerk in a chemical plant, today annexed the New York State amateur title when he defeated Ray Billows of Poughkeepsie, four-time winner of the crown, 5 and 4, in the final at the Niagara Falls Country Club.

FOR THE COMING WEEK: If the hardy 'mums have not already received their final pinching back (to induce stocky, spreading growth) this should be done at once; as they are now in vigorous growth, a top dressing of plant food is desirable. . . . Beans are of best quality when picked young -- before the pods begin to get "lumpy" -- and the younger they're picked the more continuously they will bear.

WASHINGTON, July 25 -- Munitions production in the first half of this year was one and a half times that of all 1941, Donald M. Nelson, head of the War Production Board, announced today, and June production was nearly three times that of last November, the month before Pearl Harbor.

Retail trade was generally fair last week in the three major test markets of New York, Chicago and Los Angeles, according to the survey made especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by Meyer Both Reports. Clearances of all kinds were active.

Captain George J. Barendse, popular transatlantic shipmaster of the Holland-America Line, received congratulations from officials and employes of the line last week on the completion of forty years in its service. He last commanded the big liner Statendam, which was destroyed by fire when the Germans bombed Rotterdam during the invasion in 1940.

Plans now being considered by Treasury officials contemplate the flotation for cash to the public this Fall, probably in October, of a huge long-term government bond issue of between $5,000,000,000 and $10,000,000,000.

NEW CITY, N.Y., July 25 -- State Police arrested twenty motorists in Rockland County today for speeding. The arrests followed a State-wide order for troopers to arrest all motorists maintaining more than forty miles an hour for the statutory one-quarter of a mile.

WASHINGTON, July 25 -- The Treasury Department has provided space in the Shubert-Belaseo Theatre Building on Lafayette Square, now used to house government files, for an American Theatre Wing Stage Door Canteen.

The Germans announced yesterday that Novocherkassk, twenty miles northeast of Rostov, had been stormed and captured and that a wide battle was raging for Don River crossings at Rostov and east of it, according to Berlin broadcasts recorded by The Associated Press.

BOSTON, July 25 -- Mistakes made by the colleges and secondary schools of America in dealing with the shortage of qualified teachers that followed the first World War must not be repeated when the present conflict brings about an even more serious shortage, President Bancroft Beatley of Simmons College warned today in a report prepared for the college corporation.

A project now under study in Washington gives us what may be a long look into the future. It is so complex that the War Production Board, the Bureau of Economic Warfare, the Coordinator of Inter-American Relations and the State Department have all been mulling it over.
Two streaks net head-on at Ebbets Field yesterday, with the result that both were cracked and in a manner that brought no pleasure to the Dodgers or the 12,850 fans who were eyewitnesses.

An abnormally high registration of students for defense trades in the city's vocational schools has opened a Summer-long assignment for a group of women volunteers now assisting at the medical examinations of 26,000 new entrants for the September term.

WHEN a child's general nutrition is under par, or if he is anemic, or suffering from rickets, parents can take him to a pediatrician, or to the family doctor, and find out about a good all-round diet, or get specific advice for the specific defect.

Extensive preparations are being made for the Victory Garden Harvest Show which will take place Aug. 12 and 13 at the Horticultural Society of New York. This is being given for the benefit of Army Emergency and Navy Relief organizations.

Deliveries of war materials by plants of General Motors Corporation in the United States totaled $370,959,781 in the second quarter of 1942, within $36,000,000 of deliveries in the whole of 1941, it was announced yesterday by the corporation.

PHILADELPHIA, July 25 -- Enio Conti of Brooklyn, former Bucknell guard; Elwood Gerber, also a guard; Robert McDonough, rookie end from Duke, and James O'Connor, Philadelphian, who played end on the Cornell freshman team two years ago, are in the group slated to leave Monday for the Eagles' training camp at Two Rivers, Wis.

SHORT-WAVE listening post are as integral composites of total warfare as are panzer divisions, paratroops and stukas. They are simultaneously reconnaissance units collecting vital information and munitions plants manufacturing the missiles of psychological offensive.

ST. PAUL, July 25 -- Mrs. Ernest Lundeen became the first person today to file for the Farmer-Labor Senatorial nomination. However, Harry H. Peterson, associate justice of the State Supreme Court, has the endorsement of the State Farmer-Labor Association, left-wing faction of the party and may become a candidate before filings close next Thursday.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Brazil, July 25 -- Dr. Oswaldo Aranha, Brazilian Foreign Minister, at a press conference today, said of the speech of Cordell Hull, United States Secretary of State, that in reiterating his views on the attainment of a better world of human brotherhood, he loomed as a "judge analyzing and weighing world problems in the balance scale of justice."

CHUNGKING, China, July 25 (U.P.) -- Japanese forces, continuing the campaign against airfield sites within bombing range of cities in Japan, have seized Sinchang, in the eastern coastal hump of Chekiang Province, fifty miles southwest of Ningpo, the Chinese High Command announced tonight.

CHICAGO, July 25 (AP) -- The value of properly prepared vitamin mixtures is now recognized by the American Medical Association, which in 1935 disapproved such compounds and called their use "shotgun vitamin therapy."

NEW LONDON, Conn., July 25 -- Newest of the eleven accredited junior colleges in the Connecticut Conference, New London Junior College enters its fourth year with full approval by the Connecticut State Department of Education to grant the degree of Associate in Arts, it was announced today by President Richard P. Saunders.

Sales of series F and G war savings bonds in New York State so far in July are running three times those of last month and are expected to go well over $100,000,000 for the month, it was estimated yesterday by the Treasury's New York War Savings Staff.
FEW books show so strikingly as this substantial volume of Mr. Strausz-Hupe, through the sheer force of facts presented with the precision of a scholar, the gulf between western and German thinking.
ST. PAUL, July 25 -- Mrs. Ernest Lundeen, widow of the Senator, filed today for the Farmer-Labor nomination for the Senate.

FROM American radio laboratories comes word that commercial television development work still goes on, despite the huge need of Uncle Sam's expanding armed might for all sorts of new electronic gadgets for modern warfare.

This week's boxing is headlined by Friday night's bout at Madison Square Garden between Ray Robinson and Sammy Angott. The welterweight who has won thirty-two professional bouts will be back to action for the first time since his May battle with Marty Servo in an over-the-weight match against the lightweight champion.

PHILADELPHIA, July 25 -- The program of collaboration initiated last Monday by the securities business and the Securities and Exchange Commission was moving ahead rapidly today, sobered but not impeded by the afterthought of many interested observers that perhaps insufficient attention had been paid to the question shared by every mind and expressed by only one -- the problem of the very survival of the industry itself.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., July 25 -- The anti-Hague forces in the impending "Second Battle for the Books" in Hudson County were mapping their campaign strategy today, with the duly-sworn members of the new County Tax Board calling upon the Governor to use his executive powers to establish their rights and get possession of the records of the tax office.

A nation-wide teacher-training program, intended to meet the serious shortage of instructors in the fields of physics and mathematics, is under way this Summer, sponsored by the United States Office of Education.

WASHINGTON, July 25 -- President Roosevelt is the first Chief Executive of the United States ever to direct personally, as Commander in Chief, the wartime military strategy of this country. When this week he named Admiral William D. Leahy, former Chief of Naval Operations and Ambassador to France, as his Chief of Staff, the President explained that it was to take some of the detail work in this connection off his shoulders.
MOSCOW, July 25 (AP) -- The Soviet Information Bureau issued this communique today:

Iilton P. Jackson, Assistant Surveyor of Customs of the Port of New York, retired yesterday after forty years in government service. He joined the Customs Department in 1902 and has been active in it since that time, with the exception of a few years prior to 190E, when he transferred to the Immigration Service.

IT was good to see Tom McCable, the director of athletics at Holy Cross, stroll in under his own steam again. Tom was confined to a hospital bed for several months, during which he lost no less than fifty pounds. Now he's up and around and the doctors have given him a clean bill of health. Maybe they didn't notice that Tom is suffering from a slight case of football fever.

Unless a last-minute political miracle occurs, the Democratic party in New York State is about to stage an object lesson in what happens when an immovable object collides with an irresistible force -- and the result will probably be advantageous only to the Republicans.

KURT STEEL is known to his many admirers as the author of the Hank Hyer detective stories. In this new book, however, Hank Hyer does not appear. It is the story of James Morgan, an aeronautical engineer, and his experiences with Nazi spies and saboteurs.
IN a typical Temple Bailey world, Cecily Merriman works her way from the desert of Arizona to a palatial Maryland home of which she is to be mistress.

AS the demand for manpower to run our stupendous war machine develops it is more and more apparent that the engineer has become indispensable to the success of our entire war effort. Not only is he filling vital needs in designing and directing the machines of the three battlefronts of the Army, the Navy and the air forces but at the same time he forms that absolutely essential "fourth front," the engineer in industry.
The first important grass court tennis tournament of the season starts tomorrow and continues through Saturday at the Maidstone Club, East Hampton, L.I.

Setting a track record for the second time during the meeting, William Woodward's Apache yesterday captured the $11,650 Yonkers Handicap as 19,931 persons witnessed the getaway day program of Empire City's most successful session.

Increased costs to the consumer resulting from a readjustment of food industry price ceilings through an amendment to General Maximum Price Regulation will be negligible compared to the price rise if the industry should collapse because of the inequity of the order on the trade today, Paul S. Willis, president of Grocery Manufacturers of America, Inc., declared yesterday.

Officials of the American Communications Association declared here last week that the installation of naval personnel in the radio coastal stations of the country, as proposed by Secretary Frank Knox of the Navy, would seriously imperil the merchant marine and at the same time result in the dispersal of "the best trained bunch of radio operators in the world."

FORT MYERS, Fla., July 25 (AP) -- Nine members of the crew of a B-24 bomber operating from the Army Air Base here received official commendation today for sinking a German submarine June 21 in the Gulf of Mexico, Major George B. Woods, Group Intelligence Officer, announced.

In the forefront among groups and individuals facing and meeting new conditions of motoring are the automobile clubs. It is estimated that they number in their memberships one out of every fifteen car owners in the nation. Thus their experience is an accurate sampling of the driver's dilemma today.

Continuing the policy successfully inaugurated at this year's show, the Westminster Kennel Club again has designated amateurs to handle the judging assignments at the sixty-seventh exhibition, scheduled for next Feb. 11 and 12 in Madison Square Garden.

CLEVELAND, July 25 (AP) -- The Indians unloosed a characteristic ninth-inning rally for four runs today, but the result was only to make everybody's dinner hour late because Washington, thanks to George Case's single and Bill Zuber's effective relief pitching, finally blasted out a 10-to-6 triumph in thirteen innings.
FORT DES MOINES, Iowa, July 25 (AP) -- Veteran Army officers at the Women's Army Auxiliary Training School lauded the country's first women soldiers today at the end of the first week of the school.

The stakes in the New York State Gubernatorial campaign are high. The Governor's chair, at the head of the nation's wealthiest State, is important in itself. Of equal importance this year is control of the State's political machines, since it is likely to mean control of the delegations those machines will send to the 1944 Presidential nominating conventions.

WEST HEMPSTEAD, L.I., July 25 -- Rheinhold Rudolf Barth, described by the FBI in Washington as an expert in the sabotage of railroads, was employed in the engineering department, of the Long Island Railroad as an architectural engineer or in the pump department, when he was not crossing the Atlantic between Germany and the United States.

BAR HARBOR, Me., July 25 -- Large numbers of the Summer colonists are taking active part in the various activities of the American Red Cross on Mount Desert Island. Sewing rooms, surgical dressing rooms, and canteen rooms have been established both at Bar Harbor and at Northeast Harbor and the women of both colonies are devoting most of their mornings and many of their afternoons to the work.

Rails were the only features of a stock market which drifted narrowly and closed steady yesterday. Trading was slightly larger than in the previous two-hour session but the market was the narrowest of the month. Of the 377 issues traded, 138 rose, 101 fell and 138 were unchanged.
Of the eleven baseball games listed against service nines by Brown University, two will be staged this week, when the Brunonians engage in three contests during a four-day period.

The question of an adequate supply of electric power to meet the sharply increased demands of intensified war production was clarified considerably last week. For several years, through careful planning and the installation of new generating facilities, the nation's utilities have been in a position to meet all anticipated power requirements and thus far the power and light industry has been one that has caused no effective "bottleneck" in the war production program.

ASBURY PARK, N.J. -- A military ball and fashion show, sponsored by members of the Summer colony, will be held at the Deal Golf Club on Friday evening for the benefit of the ambulance fund of the American Red Cross, Monmouth County Chapter.

ONCE a month Air Warden Smith foregoes the pleasure of sleeping in his own comfortable bed under the roof of a comfortable apartment house in midtown. He packs his pajamas, toothbrush, shaving kit and blanket and reports at his sector headquarters for the dog watch. In Mr. Smith's particular sector, which its wardens boast is about as efficient as any in New York City, a different warden sleeps at headquarters every night of the week.

NEWPORT NEWS, Va., July 25 (AP) -- The Navy will launch the Essex, first aircraft carrier to be put in the water since the United States entered the war, at the Newport News Shipbuilding and Dry Dock Company plant Friday.
WASHINGTON, July 25 (AP) -- Senator Norris expressed the belief today that post-war surveillance of Germany, Italy and Japan could be carried out without armies of occupation.

In the coming national championship tournament, which will begin on Aug. 3 at the Park Central Hotel here, the American Contract Bridge League will announce the details of its various activities on behalf of war relief.

WASHINGTON, July 25 (AP) -- Three Army Air Corps officers who took part in a bombing raid on Tokyo April 18 received the award of the Military Order of China today from Major Gen. Chu Shih-Ming, Military Attache at the Chinese Embassy in Washington.

Increasingly concerned over the wartime campaign of prohibitionists to curtail, restrict or eliminate the sale of liquor for the duration, the liquor industry is planning to unite and intensify its own efforts to head off the movement, it was learned yesterday.

CONTINUING his very successful method of reinterpreting old, and generally forgotten, crimes, Mr. Shearing has based his new novel on an article by William Roughead, to whom the hook is dedicated. The period is the Eighteen Seventies, a time when mediums and table-rapping and so forth were exciting a great many people.
"THE one definite thing which can be said about the Reformation in England is that it was an act of State."

WASHINGTON, July 25 -- President Roosevelt has accepted the resignation of Admiral William D. Leahy as Ambassador to France with the Navy's cordial "well done" in recognition of the long and stubborn fight by the veteran officer to prevent the Vichy regime from falling irrevocably within the German orbit.

LONDON, July 25 -- Protection for the world's mineral resources and the men who place them at the disposal of civilization was recommended today at the closing session of the British Association conference.

BATTLE SHOCK -- Dr. George Ungar of the Fighting French forces implies in Nature that if vitamin C is given to soldiers just before a battle it would protect them from death by shock. Guinea pigs injured to an extent that would otherwise have caused 100 per cent mortality always survived when vitamin C was immediately injected under their skins after the injury.
WASHINGTON, July 25 (AP) -- Forty-three industrial plants have been selected by a Navy board to receive the Army-Navy award for outstanding work on war production contracts.

DESPITE heat, war and high water four group exhibitions and three one-man shows opened last week. The group event at Kraushaar's included some new things and a selection of individual paintings seen during the last season. It is a lively and varied showing.

DETROIT, July 25 (AP) -- Hal Newhouser, 21-year-old pitcher for the Detroit Tigers, will report for induction into the Army Monday morning, his draft board said tonight. Newhouser, classified 1A, tried to enlist in the Army Air Corps, but the draft board reported it had not received the necessary release from the Air Service. Newhouser has passed his preliminary physical examination.

LONDON, July 25 -- International regulation of the production and distribution of essential raw materials is necessary if the promises of the Atlantic Charter are to be realized, Sir Stafford Cripps, Lord Privy Seal, said in a speech here today, declaring that when peace is restored the principles of economic warfare must be converted into economic welfare.

With one or two cargo carriers sunk every day, with tin so scarce that brewers have been ordered to bottle beer in glass, the business of dehydrating vegetables, fruits and eggs is booming. Production, which had shriveled to about 5,000,000 pounds of dried vegetables annually worth a paltry $500,000, received a tremendous impetus after the lease-lend bill was passed.

VIENNA is in blackout. The Vienna whose hospitality, whose Gemuetlichkeit made it a second home for Mozart, Beethoven, whose atmosphere inspired Brahms, Schubert, Haydn, Mahler, Suppe, Milloecker, Lehar and a dozen others, the Vienna of Johann Strauss is dark.

Premier Mussolini flew to Libya following upon the Axis capture of Tobruk June 21, but returned home when the Axis drive was halted, the Rome radio revealed yesterday, according to The Associated Press.
WASHINGTON, July 25 -- Write letters as cheerful as possible to men in service, the Red Cross urged in a statement today. If the letters cannot be cheerful, it said, they should be factual.

A few weeks ago THE NEW YORK TIMES published a letter from Dr. Enrique Gil, a member of the bar and Alternate Professor of Political Economy in the faculty of law and social sciences of the University of La Plata. This followed a communication earlier in the year by Alejandro E. Shaw, a well-known Argentine financial writer and economist.
ST. LOUIS, July 25 (AP) -- The Red Sox made twenty hits off an assortment of St. Louis pitchers today but had to go to the tenth inning before they could beat the Browns, 9 to 8.

Fearing that left-wing control of their State convention would wreck the American Labor party's chances of influencing the selection of a Democratic candidate for Governor this year, a group of union leaders and liberals united yesterday in an appeal for the election at the Aug. 11 primary of right-wing delegates.

LOURENCO MARQUES, Portuguese East Africa, July 25 -- The Japanese faced increasing difficulties in operations around Hong King this Spring, partly because of United tSates submarine attacks on enemy convoys.

Reactions to the Ways and Means Committee's version of the Revenue Bill of 1942, passed by the House of Representatives on July 20, have been generally dispraising. No matter what may be said against it, however, one should recognize that administratively the bill is free of radical and business-baiting provision.

The recent loss of the Swedish food relief ship Stureborg, while operating under charter to the Swedish Red Cross, brings the total of Swedish shipping losses in the war to 150 vessels, according to Swedish maritime labor circles. The lost ships represent a total of 637,000 tons and cost the lives of 909 Swedish and foreign crew members.

CHICAGO, July 25 -- The controversy between James C. Petrillo, president of the American Federation of Musicians, and the radio industry was heightened here today with the cancellation by the National Broadcasting Company of the Grant Park concert, of which Mr. Petrillo is a sponsor.

LOURENCO MARQUES, Portuguese East Africa, July 25 (AP) -- The Japanese repatriation ship Asama Maru, which brought United States, Canadian and Latin American nationals from Eastern Asia to exchange for Japanese, is expected to sail for home tomorrow.

GREAT BARRINGTON, Mass. -- This South Berkshire community of 5,700 inhabitants is to celebrate two centennial anniversaries in September. One is the arrival of the first railroad train on the old Housatonic Railroad on Sept. 28. This train brought passengers from Canaan, Conn., and Sheffield to attend the first fair of the Housatonic Agricultural Society, which was held Sept. 28 and 29, 1842.

BERNE, Switzerland, July 25 -- Direct connection with the talk of an Allied second front on the west coast of Europe was seen in an announcement from Berlin today that during the past week the Nazi forces in the north of France had engaged in extensive manoeuvres. German land, sea and air forces participated, Berlin said.

EVERYBODY said it would never rain again, and most of the inhabitants of the dust bowl had moved on either voluntarily or with the urging of the government. But Big Joe said it had to rain some time, and Little Joe and Babe and Uncle Pete stuck with him on it.

MAKING its second entry into the field of feature film production, The March of Time is doing a full-length factual dramatization of the United States Marine Corps under the succinct title, "We Are the Marines."

THE romance of the horse in wartime -- the cavalry charge, the galloping teams of the combat train, the courage and faithfulness of the officers' mounts and the affection between them and their riders -- continue to be celebrated in story in spite of tanks and the increasing motorization of field artillery.

LONDON, July 25 -- Royal Air Force bombers, continuing their new practice of penetrating deep into the Rhineland by daylight, attacked targets in Mannheim and Frankfort on the Main today. Other planes attacked objectives in Belgium and the Netherlands.

The role of the United States Coast Guard in the war is growing in importance and plans are now being worked out to increase the personnel to at least three or four times its present figure, it was reported here last week.
The following German High Command communique was broadcast from Berlin and was recorded here by The Associated Press:

NEW MILFORD, Conn., July 25 -- Two 8-year-old boys were charged today with disrupting a large part of this town's business by taking about "a bushel" of mail for five concerns, including two banks, from postoffice boxes and tearing it up.

PATERSON, N.J., July 25 -- Representatives of the War Labor Board will meet here on Monday morning with management and employes of the Wright Aeronautical Corporation to attempt to settle a dispute over cuts in incentive bonuses that caused two work stoppages in two days.

WASHINGTON, July 25 -- Government controls of prices and rents are "doing a good job of holding prices down," Leon Henderson, OPA Administrator, reported today, but he added that uncontrolled food prices on agricultural commodities protected by provisions of existing law were showing "a definitely inflationary tendency."

ANOZZLE of the biggest vacuum cleaner on earth, Selective Service Brand, Model 1941, was poked into the city room of The Charlotte (N.C.) News. To the relief of bedeviled editorial executives, it sucked up Reporter, Feature Editor and odd-job-filler Edward Thomas Marion Lawton Hargrove and deposited him upon the sands of Fort Bragg's Artillery Replacement Center, where he became Private Hargrove, Army serial number 34,116,620.

WHITE MOUNTAINS, N.H. -- Mrs. Harvey Dow Gibson has been named honorary chairman for the annual horse show and Mount Cranmore Carnival for the benefit of the Memorial Hospital at North Conway, which will take place on Aug. 20, 21 and 22.

The hope of a better world that Secretary of State Cordell Hull has held forth should be a "clarion call to the peoples of the world who are still in bondage and should hearten those groups inside Germany who pray that the retribution which will be meted out to their nation will not utterly destroy it," Rabbi Louis I. Newman said in Temple Rodeph Sholom, 7 West Eighty-third Street, yesterday.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., July 25 -- Women of the Summer colony here as well as a large group of young matrons and debutantes of this and recent seasons are active in several projects to raise funds for furthering various wartime enterprises.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., July 25 -- Magnus Konow's International class sloop Frolic, Charles Vanderlaan's Atlantic boat Minkie II, W.A. Olsen's Class S boat Penguin and Frank Campbell's Star class Rascal won today in the special regatta of the Horseshoe Harbor Yacht Club.

It may seem a bit far-fetched to start talking in the sweltering days of late July about house plants to bring cheer to apartment dwellers next January or February. But the Winter gardener who looks ahead is the one who is going to have the most satisfactory results, and it is none too soon now, not only to make plans but to begin to assemble the plants themselves.

WASHINGTON, July 25 -- The first contingent of a corps of former newspaper reporters, photographers and newsreel cameramen, who left their civilian jobs several months ago to enlist in the Marine Corps as "combat correspondents," has arrived in Washington to await assignment to the fighting zones, the Marine Corps announced today.

WASHINGTON, July 25 (AP) -- The War Labor Board told the American Federation of Labor and the Congress of Industrial Organizations today that when they failed to settle jurisdictional dispuates without stoppages of work the board would invoke arbitration.
WASHINGTON, July 25 (AP) -- British signal officers, studying techniques of communication and air raid detection of the United Nations, said today:

WASHINGTON (Science Service), July 25 -- For the second time in a fortnight a two-man navy-civilian inventor team of this city has received a patent on a garment based on expanded cellular rubber, useful to the armed forces.

HARRY L. HOPKINS is referred to in Washington today as "the Assistant President." Almost every one, from Cabinet members and ranking diplomats to humble government clerks. uses the title. Not only his unique position as a White House guest and the man closest to the President, but the increasing authority he wields and the mantle of mystery flung about him, have made this New Deal old-timer the liveliest topic of capital conversation.

WHATEVER the changes time may bring in literary fashions, however divergent the new schools of poetry from the romanticism of the early nineteenth century, Byron will always tempt the biographer, if only by the fascination of his personality.

Immediate expansion and development of the Fire Watchers Service has been ordered by James M. Landis, Federal Director of Civilian Defense, as a precaution against damage from fire bombs in air raids, it was announced yesterday by George S. Van Schaick, regional director of the Second Civilian Defense Area.

George Sturgis of Boston, president of the United States Chess Federation, has announced his views on the status of Samuel Reshevsky and Isaac I. Kashdan, both of New York, who tied for first place this year in the biennial tournament for the national championship and divided the first and second prizes.

Today I went into a store to buy a ready-made Summer suit. The trousers, as is usual in such cases, were about three or four inches too long. I asked whether an inch of the excess could be left on as a cuff. I was reminded that it was against the law to have cuffs on trousers.

Considerable spottiness featured retail trade here last week, although improved volume was noted toward the end of the period. Hot weather checked early response to August sales promotions of fur and cloth coats and furniture volume slipped below last year.

Van Lingle Mungo, former Dodger right-handed hurler, has been purchased by the Giants, it was announced last night. The former fast-ball ace was bought from the Minneapolis team of the American Association in a straight cash transaction and may be able to join the Giants tomorrow.
WASHINGTON, July 25 -- A program to salvage about 100,000,000 pounds of essential chemicals from waste paints was announced today by the War Production Board.

WASHINGTON, July 25 -- A marked increase of money incomes of half the families living in cities in the first quarter of this year was reported by the Bureau of Labor Statistics today on the basis of a sample survey. These incomes increased from the rate of $2,082 a year in the corresponding quarter of last year to $2,217 a year.

PRINCETON, N.J., July 25 -- The Congressional race that is attracting the widest national attention is that of Representative Hamilton Fish, leading Republican isolationist before Pearl Harbor, who is running for re-election in the Twenty-sixth New York district.

CAIRO, Egypt, July 25 -- During the week that ended today, United States bomber planes carried out seven raids against Axis targets at Tobruk and Bengazi, in Libya, and Suda Bay, Crete, it was announced today in a communique of the Middle East Command of the United States Army Air Forces.

A tale of revenge in the making, to gladden the hearts of United Nations merchant sailors whose ships have been damaged in the Battle of the Atlantic, came out of the Regional Office of War Information yesterday under the prosaic heading of a salvage report on scrap materials.
As the Nazis claimed the capture of Rostov last week and pressed toward the Volga on a broad front, conferences in London and Washington discussed the problem of the "second front."

WASHINGTON, July 25 -- Three highly trained Nazi saboteurs, ordered by the German High Command to destroy vital war industries here as associates of the eight men now on trial, are the objects of a nation-wide search, J. Edgar Hoover, director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, announced through the Department of Justice today.

WASHINGTON, July 25 (AP) -- Chairman George predicted today that the Senate Finance Committee would reject Treasury proposals to increase individual and corporation income rates in the House-approved $6,271,000,000 revenue bill, but would seek to find possible new fields of taxation.

An information and recreation center for the 2,700 men in training at the Navy Midshipmen's Training School in New York City, with headquarters at Columbia University and aboard the Prairie State, was opened yesterday afternoon in Earl Hall, Broadway and ll7th Street.

WASHINGTON, July 25 -- Axis victories have ushered in a third phase in the Nazi Propaganda Ministry's battle for air-tight control of the minds of the German people. After six months of defensive propaganda and improvisation, Dr. Joseph Goebbels has been rescued by the German Army and is now resuming his promises of victory and ultimate peace for the Germans.

CAMPOBELLO, N.B., July 25 (AP) -- Plans for a model college war council, drawn up by young people attending the International Student Service Summer Training Institute at President Roosevelt's Summer home on Campobello Island, have been approved by Mrs. Roosevelt.

WASHINGTON, July 25 -- Posters issued by the Federal Bureau of Investigation in its search for Walter Kappe, Joseph Schmidt and Rheinhold Rudolf Barth carried detailed descriptions of the men. Because Kappe and Schmidt have been previously arrested, the posters bore front and side face pictures of these, men and also their fingerprints.

ONE of the first projects of German Arciniegas, the noted Colombian historian and novelist, when he became Minister of Education early this year, was to inaugurate a series of reprints of famous literary and historical works which have long been out of print, at the uniform price of one peso (present value, 57 cents in terms of American currency).

IT would be quite unfair to this astute ghost story to reveal much of the plot. It is a clever and original one, with a solution which may be guessed some time before the end, and that is a good thing, because it would be too confounding if it were sprung without warning.

At Cambridge last week the students cheered Queen Wilhelmina for herself and her glorious people. The dean of the college recalled the early friendships between Dutch and American scholars. The University of Leyden, founded in 1575, attracted famous professors, Lipsius, Scaliger, Heinsius, Grotius.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, July 25 -- Premier Vidkun Quisling's persecutions of Norwegian churchmen and teachers have proved too much for a number of his own followers, and it is reliably reported that nearly 10,000 members have resigned from the National Samling since the beginning of the trouble last February.
WILLARD PRICE knows the Japanese better than the average foreign resident of Japan because he was not tied down to the regular routine duties of a diplomat, a journalist or a business man.

A NEW and enterprising record company has taken the field, and its first releases indicate that it will contribute something of value. It is the Bost Records Company, with offices at 29 West Fifty-seventh Street.

VIRGINIA WOOLF seems to exercise an extraordinary fascination on our literary critics. They are apparently eager to avail themselves of every opportunity of commenting on her distinctive qualities as a writer.

WITH THE BRITISH NAVAL AIR SERVICE, in the Western Desert, July 25 (AP) -- Naval aircraft, pressing their virtually nonstop offensive, bombed a concentration of Axis tanks, armored cars and motor transport southeast of El Daba early today.

Highly important conversations are now proceeding in London with regard to the proposal for a second front on the European Continent. There are weighty decisions to be made. The critical stage which has been reached by the German campaign in Russia lends force to the Moscow demand for a military effort in Western Europe on the ground that it would divert German strength from the Eastern front.

A dozen-multiple-toned prints by Rene P. Piperoux, engineer-photographer, presented as a side-attraction to his exhibition of Fifty portrait studies, have stolen the show at the Camera Club, West sixty-eighth Street, where they are exhibited for the first time.

THE look of things -- houses, roads, farmhouses, fields -- in our Vermont town has changed little since my childhood. Elm trees are rather taller; in the village the Old Burying Ground's hedge has been replaced by a stone wall; there are garages, but just about where the livery stables were; roads are improved in quality out of all recognition, but they run just along the old lines.

HEN Teresa Wright left WBroadway's -- and more specifically, Oscar Serlin's -- "Life With Father" -- for the enticements of Hollywood her contract with Samuel Goldwyn contained several stipulations. ; There would be no leg art, no whispered romances for the columnists, no orchid and ermine setting for her background.

LONDON, July 25 (U.P.) -- A roundup by German Elite Guard troops of 15,000 to 18,000 alien refugees in occupied France for shipment to concentration camps in Poland has precipitated a new and grave crisis between Berlin and the Vichy government, it was revealed today.

WASHINGTON, July 25 -- The Navy announced today that five Japanese vessels had been sunk and another damaged and probably sunk in recent operations of United States submarines in Far Eastern waters. The communique declared that the submarines had sunk one modern Japanese destroyer, one medium-sized tanker and three cargo vessels. The ship damaged and believed sunk was a cargo vessel of medium size.

PORT DALHOUSIE, Ont., July 25 (AP) -- Toronto's Argonauts won the sixtieth annual Royal Canadian Henley Regatta today, compiling 60 points during the three-day competition to dethrone Buffalo's West Side Club which finished second with 43.

The University of Montevideo, Uruguay, will establish a Department of Philosophy in 1943, it was revealed here yesterday by Dr. Emilio Oribe, Professor of Literature in that university. Dr. Oribe, who is touring the United States as a guest of our State Department, said that this course would be modeled on similar courses of philosophy in Columbia, Harvard and Yale in the United States.

POCONO MOUNTAINS, Pa. -- Charitable affairs and lectures are included in the Pocono schedule for the week. Pocono Manor will have a benefit bridge party for the Save the Children's Federation, Inc., on Wednesday. The Barrett township auxiliary of the Monroe County General Hospital will hold a bazaar at Buck Hill Falls on Friday.

THE EARTH swings around sun, one swing a year, spinning on its axis, one spin a day. Whether by original intention of nature or by some astronomical accident of long ago, its poles of daily rotation are not perpendicular to the plane of its annual revolution.

WASHINGTON, July 25 -- The "leadership, foresight and direction" of J. Edgar Hoover have put the Federal Bureau of Investigation in "the forefront among all the law enforcement agencies of the world," President Roosevelt said in a letter to Mr. Hoover today, coincident with the graduation exercises of the nineteenth class of the FBI National Police Academy.

Mayor La Guardia yesterday appointed Joseph Diehl Fackenthal of 35 Prospect Park West, Brooklyn, a member of the Board of Education, to succeed James G. McDonald, also of Brooklyn, who resigned last Friday. Mr. Fackenthal, a lawyer, was directed to investigate procedure in the board's bureau of supplies, the Mayor declaring that he was not satisfied with its operation.

IT should be evident by this time that the two-party system as it has existed in the United States since the period of the Civil War has completely broken down. The traditional names Democrat and Republican no longer reflect any accepted body of political principles and policies, nor is there anything approaching agreement among those who still continue to bear either of these party names.

The "little housekeeper" of, old-fashioned story books is a reality this Summer in low-budget homes where mothers are working; and many are cooking according to approved dietetic rules. Among them are the girls who have studied cooking at the Children's Aid Society, turned out not as accomplished dietitians but versed in the rudiments of proper nutrition, economical marketing and food preparation.

For the ninth consecutive week the police tested the city's permanent air raid warning sirens at noon yesterday but the official reports on their effectiveness were not obtainable at Police Headquarters as Commissioner Valentine ignored questions on the subject.

DETROIT, July 25 -- While FBI agents swooped down on the homes of 120 suspected enemy aliens in Detroit this afternoon, other Federal officers were conducting simlar raids in Western Michigan, concentrating largely in the St Joseph-Benton Harbor district.

BEER PROFITEERS: Threats of civil suits -- even criminal action -- were made against the owners of some taverns and restaurants near Army cantonments last week. The Office of Price Administration charged that these men were "picking the pockets of soldiers, sailors and marines" by doubling the prices on soft drinks, tripling the prices on beer.

A clean lard bucket for a cleaning pail, tag ends of soap, pieces of cloth that small hands can wring out, are a few of the improvised play materials appreciated by small children C. Madeleine Dixon suggests these, writing on "Play" in National Parent-Teacher. Screens made from the cardboard that comes in laundered shirts fastened in sections with Scotch tape is another of Miss Dixon's ideas.

URBANA-CHAMPAIGN, Ill., July 25 -- A project which if applied on a national scale would mean a tremendous salvage of native American abilities, and at the same time a saving in the money spent for college and university education, has been carried out for two years in Illinois.

WASHINGTON, July 25 -- Improper allocations and faulty management of inventories of available steel by the War Production Board, rather than the officially indicated general shortage of this metal, were blamed today by a subcommittee of the House Merchant Marine and Fisheries Committee for the recent cancellation by the Maritime Commission of the controverted 200-ship contract of Andrew J. Higgins, New Orleans shipbuilder.

CHICAGO, July 25 -- Rebellion flared in the Tam o'Shanter open golf tournament today when Joe Kirkwood, veteran trick shot star, refused to wear a number on his back at the start of the third round of the $15,000 meet and was summarily disqualified by President George S. May of the Tam o'Shanter Club.

NEWARK, N. J., July 25 -- Toronto scored twice in the ninth inning today to culminate a gallant uphill battle and trip league-leading Newark, 8 to 7, before a Red Cross-Navy Relief Society Day throng of 16,030. A long program preceded the benefit game and the final out wasn't registered until 8:25 P.M. with the lights of Ruppert Stadium switched on.

William Griffin, publisher of The New York Enquirer, will be examined by a government physician tomorrow to determine if he can be removed from St. Clare's Hospital for arraignment in Federal Court on an indictment charging conspiracy to damage the morale of the men in the armed forces.

LILLIAN GISH resumed her screen career when she returned to Hollywood this week. The wistful, fragile star of the silent screen had her picture taken on the lawn at Pickfair, where she was the guest of her contemporary, Mary Pickford, and then departed for British Columbia to appear with Paul Muni in "The Commandos Come at Dawn," which Lester Cowan is producing for Columbia.
LOURENCO MARQUES, Portuguese East Africa, July 23 (Delayed) -- More than 2,000 American civilians remain behind in Japanese-occupied China where they face the tightening conditions of war.

THERE is nothing in all human history quite like the first drift of exploring, trapping, trading Americans across the Great Plains to the Pacific. It is in our blood still, whether or not our personal ancestors had a part in it and whether or not we ever saw the Big Horn Mountains, the Wind River Range and the gorges of the Snake River.

PERSONS who write the blurbs for book jackets rarely run out of adjectives. Neither, I suppose it will be said at once, do book reviewers. But here is a novel which represents an unusual occupational hazard for all concerned.

Sir Robert Sinclair, deputy to Captain Oliver Lyttelton, British Minister of Production and member of the United States-British Combined Production and Resources Board, arrived here yesterday for conferences with Donald M. Nelson and to see for himself the mighty American war industry "for which all England has great admiration."

WASHINGTON, July 25 -- The United States is now spending $160,000,000 a day to win the war. Before the present calendar year ends daily expenditure is expected to total $200,000,000. By the end of the current fiscal year on June 30, 1943, the daily rate must be higher still to bring war expenditures during this fiscal year to what Secretary of the Treasury Henry Morgenthau Jr. this week called the "inconceivable" sum of $77,000,000,000.

AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, Australia, Sunday, July 26 (AP) -- Four Japanese planes attacked the port of Townsville, in Northeastern Australia, last night, but no damage or casualties resulted, said a communique issued today.

STOCKBRIDGIE, Mass., July 25 -- Mahkeenac Boat Club members and guests had an opening luncheon today at the clubhouse on the west shore of Mahkeenac Lake, to mark the fifty-first anniversary of the organization, of which Giraud Foster is president.

MORE women than the regular company of light-fiction addicts should be able to enjoy this novel. It is still distinctly a book for women. Lady Appleby -- Midge to her friends -- who tells the story. is an altogether feminine creature, feminine in a sense instantly recognized by other women but not so quickly pounced on by men.

NORTHAMPTON, Mass., July 25 -- A board of advisers has been established at Smith College to meet the need for a more systematic means of advising the freshmen and sophomores concerning their scholastic problems. Composed of twenty to thirty members of the faculty, it is designed to assist the deans in advising students during their first two years in college.

UNLESS you are an alumnus of Morris High in the Bronx, or a one-time patron of those Catskill pensions where folks reportedly have a wonderful time, or an ex-habitue of the smokier basements on Fifty-second Street, the chances are that the name of Julie Oshins would have left you with no more than a vague look until "This Is the Army" came along.

The war can produce tenseness to such a point that something must be done for relaxation. We've noticed that a lot of our friends have taken to silly games, nothing more taxing than double canfield, and that while they're playing they unwind their war tenseness.

These days the soaring mercury is likely to turn one's thoughts to the tall pines of the forest-shrouded Northwest. Especially do those who have followed the scenic rail routes of the West recall the cool, deep canyons to whose rim the train seems to cling precariously in an effort to give passengers the best possible view.

THE July issue of "The Country Dancer," the little quarterly magazine published by the Country Dance Society, contains a leaflet on "The C.D.S. in Wartime" which merits a bit of serious consideration.

MISTRESS Jane Withers, that uningratiating gamin who used to inspire good citizens to thoughts of mayhem (and worse), has grown up practically overnight. Only yesterday she was the cinema's meanest moppet, yet here she was, a refined little lady fairly glistening with glamour, a miniature femme fatale.

When the Twentieth Amendment was pending in Congress Representative Woodrum said there would be no more short sessions of Congress. Other opponents predicted that Congress would have to sit all the year. But "after this" doesn't mean "because of this." The depression and the war have to be taken into account.
Eight hundred persons were arrested here in May and June in the drive against vice promoters and prostitution, District Attorney Frank S. Hogan disclosed in a report yesterday.
PHILADELPHIA, July 25 (AP) -- Scoring two runs in the first inning and adding two more in the seventh, the Cubs scored a 4-to-1 victory over the last-place Phils at Shibe Park tonight.

Faced with wartime transportation problems, Saratoga will open its annual race meeting tomorrow. Racing at the Spa, traditional mid-Summer highlight in New York, was inaugurated in 1864, and many of the most memorable stakes had their beginning at the course approximately thirty-five miles north of Albany.

LOURENCO MARQUES, Portuguese East Africa, July 23 (Delayed) -- Americans can take it. There is the case of Edwin Koons, Presbyterian missionary who was imprisoned by the Japanese in Korea, where, he said, he received the "water cure" when other less elaborate methods of punishment failed to make him agree he had been engaged in espionage.
For the last two years the School of Education of Rutgers University has been conducting a study of the educational services and needs of New Jersey.

CHICAGO, July 25 (AP) -- Balloting to name the all-star collegiate eleven which will oppose the Chicago Bears on Aug. 28 at Soldier Field approached tomorrow's midnight deadline with three schools -- Minnesota, Northwestern and Notre Dame -- having double representation on the team.
BOSTON, July 25 -- Enos Slaughter slammed his eighth home run of the season to give the Cardinals a 6-3 verdict over the Braves today. It was Pitcher Howie Krist's eighth victory of the season.

A program of trips and visits, designed primarily to stimulate war activity among students, is being conducted by the Hunter College Summer session, it was announced yesterday by Professor Broderick Cohen, director. The program will not only acquaint students with the war work women are doing, Professor Cohen said, but it will also show the girls how they can help in the fight for victory.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., July 25 (AP) -- Jersey City lost the opener of its double-header with Montreal tonight, 3 -- 2, and struggled to a 2-2 tie in the second game which was halted in the ninth by dimout restrictions. The Jerseys dropped to third place behind Toronto in the International League standings.

OLD ORCHARD BEACH, Me., July 25 (AP) -- My Birthday, a longshot owned by Miss Ruth Fraser of Chester, S.C., and driven by 22-year-old John Simpson, won the final dash today in the $6,000 Maine Pacing Derby in the program ending Old Orchard's first week of Grand Circuit racing.

Adolf Hitler's legions stood last week at the gates of the Caucasus. Almost a mouth had passed since the Wehrmacht launched its great 1942 offensive in Southern Russia. At a frightful cost in men and machines it had driven to the western bank of the storied Don, over-running some 30,000 square miles of steppeland rich in grain and herds.

EACH of eight persons believes that he or she is the only one who knows that George Faulkner is lying dead in his room with a knife in his throat, and each has an understandable reason for not revealing that knowledge to the rest of the week-end party at Ravensmoor, the home of George Faulkner's brother Frank.
LOURENCO MARQUES, Portuguese East Africa, July 23 (Delayed) -- The Japanese guards at Manila's internment camp, Santo Tomas University, frequently asked us: "How can you Americans be so happy here?"
WASHINGTON, July 25 -- A controversy over the relation of wage increases to inflation loomed this week as one of the hottest economic-political issues facing President Roosevelt.

A mystery that puzzled art scholars for years has been solved at the Metropolitan Museum of Art. It has concerned the famous set of "Unicorn Tapestries," for which John D. Rockefeller is said to have paid $1,200,000 and which he gave to the Metropolitan Museum in 1937 for exhibition at The Cloisters, its branch in Fort Tryon Park, devoted to medieval art.

CAMDEN, N.J., July 25 (AP) -- The Howe Stable's Cassis, a brown son of Bull Dog, had on his running plates at Garden State Park today when he came from far back to score by two lengths in the $5,000 added Benjamin Franklin Handicap, hanging up a new track record of 1:10 1-5 for the six furlongs.

A WAY back in 1900 Professor George C.D. Odell began accumulating, arranging and checking information about the New York theatre, and he has been doing it ever since, working fifteen or sixteen hours a day.

For years Americans have been learning geography by the most pleasant method imaginable. They have learned about their own country at first hand and from automobile road maps. They have learned about the far corners of the world from newspaper accounts of famous flights and from the National Geographic Society, which itself seemed always to be sending out a new expedition to find and report on some unknown corner of the planet.

THE British Broadcasting Corporation has revealed some of its findings on the results of music in English war factories. In general, it states, an "appropriate" use of music increases output by counteracting monotony or occasional depression and by contributing to cheerfulness.

RECORD: Some delving into Congressional memories last week disclosed the fact that Vice President Henry A. Wallace has established a record for voting on legislation. The presiding officer of the Senate casts a ballot only when there is a tie on the floor.

WESTBURY, L.I., July 25 -- Hugh Bell, veteran driver from Freehold, N.J., who is the leading winner of the meeting, piloted the Mill Spring Farm's Ridgewood to a double victory in the featured Avenger Special Trot at Roosevelt Raceway today.

LEXINGTON, Ky., July 25 -- Instruction in better living will supplant the conventional educational fare for Kentucky mountain children in the public schools, if experiments being conducted this Summer by the University of Kentucky's College of Education prove successful.

WASHINGTON, July 25 -- Further declines in prices for certain domestic agricultural commodities, particularly barley, hogs, cotton and wool tops, contributed to a decrease of 0.5 per cent in the Bureau of Labor Statistics' daily index of spot market prices of twenty-eight basic commodities during the week July 17 to 24.

The names of 203 officer candidates accepted by the Women's Army Auxiliary Corps in the Second Service Command, which includes New York, New Jersey and Delaware, were released yesterday by the recruiting and induction office at the Army Building, 39 Whitehall Street.

WASHINGTON, July 25 (U.P.) -- Senator Connally said today that he was investigating the feasibility of an "individual excess profits tax" to bring the $6,270,300,000 tax bill nearer the Treasury's goal of $8,700,000,000 and to "mop up" incomes swelled by the war.

LONDON, July 25 (U.P.) -- Dr. Eduard Benes, head of the Czechoslovak Government in exile, held out today hope of peace in "perhaps less than a year" if the Allies invaded Europe within the next ninety days and forced Adolf Hitler to withdraw strength from the Russian battle front.

The long-promised "France Libre" series from "etablissements francaises dans l'Inde" (French establishments in India), which comprise philately's French India, reached New York last week. Printed by the Free French, now the Fighting French, in London, the stamps were sent to the French colony in Asia and thence came to the United States by way of New Caledonia and Hawaii.

OTTAWA, July 25 -- With the statement by P.J.A. Cardin, Quebec leader in the House of Commons, on Thursday afternoon, that when it was passed Quebec would obey the overseas military service law, the disagreement that has threatened to disunite Canada in the middle of this dangerous war has been, or should be, closed, it was believed today.
SOMEWHERE IN AUSTRALIA, July 24 (Delayed) -- Lieutenant Ben S. Brown had heard that two American correspondents were visiting this advanced air base so he sent word that he would like to see us.

BALTIMORE, July 25 -- The rate of production in the country's shipyards now far exceeds that called for by the President's two-year shipbuilding program for 1942-43, Rear Admiral Emory S. Land, chairman of the Maritime Commission, told workers at the Bethlehem-Fairfield Shipyards today.

WESTMINSTER, Md., July 25 -- An integration of the student's complete educational program, through the medium of the liberal arts curriculum, from high school to a future career or participation in the national war effort, is the keynote in educational philosophy at Western Maryland College today.

It is a characteristic of British educational history that idealism in education reaches a peak of intensity during a period of war. The president of the British Board of Education recently stated: "The three previous advances in education coincided with a period of war; -- in 1870, in 1902 and in 1918.

WHEN you see him -- a serious, bespectacled man with the build of a football tackle -- talking quietly with a little group of players in a Radio City studio, you suspect that you have wandered into a discussion group.

ST. LOUIS, Mo., July 25 (U.P.) -- Private Prescott F. Dennett, who says he is a thirteenth-generation American, has made a blanket denial of charges by a Federal grand jury in Washington that he was conspiring to promote revolt and break down morale in the nation's armed forces.

NEWPORT, R.I., July 25 -- Although the debut of Miss Anita Grosvenor, daughter of Lieut. Comdr. Theodore P. Grosvenor, U.S.N.R., and Mrs. Grosvenor, planned for next Saturday, was immediately canceled after the death of the young woman's grandmother, Mrs. Robert E. Strawbridge of Bryn Mawr, while she was visiting Mr. and Mrs. William F. Whitehouse this week, at least three other young ladies are to make their official bows to society here during the Summer.

LAKELAND, Fla., July 25 -- Objection as well as approval is being heard in Florida concerning the measure President Roosevelt signed on Thursday authorizing the spending of $44,000,000 on a barge canal across the northern part of the State.

MOSCOW, Sunday, July 26 -- The Russians announced today that enemy forces, breaking through Rostov's defenses at separate points, had entered the edge of the city. The communique also referred to heavy German counter-attacks in the Voronezh sector and the arrival there of further Axis reinforcements.

The era of unsung heroes in the merchant marine is passing in New York City. Applauding the courage of those who man the ships that are threading the life line of supplies through dangerous seas, a group of women are charting a course to recreation ashore for this forgotten group.

DETROIT, July 25 -- Even the Tigers seem finally to have resigned themselves to the fact that there is little or no likelihood of anything derailing the mighty Yankees as they go thundering along to another American League pennant.

BERNE, Switzerland, July 25 -- Admiral Fricke, Chief of Staff for German naval operations, in a statement appearing in the Deutsche Allgemeine Zeitung expresses confidence in the ability of the German U-boats to turn the Battle of the Atlantic into the decisive battle of the war.

Usually a steady stream of vehicles snarls traffic on July 25 at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Columba, at 343 West Twenty-fifth Street, as automobiles are blessed on the feast of St. Christopher, patron saint of travelers. But yesterday's flow was feeble, amounting only to fifteen, because of gasoline and tire rationing.

Litigation that is to have a bearing on the income available for a hundred leased railroads has been started in the Federal Court in Newark, N.J., and is being watched closely by dealers in and owners of guaranteed railroad stocks.

MOSCOW, Sunday, July 26 (U.P.) -- German forces, wantonly wasting lives under murderous Soviet fire, have smashed into outlying streets of Rostov "at several places" and forced the defenders to retreat, while fierce battles spread eastward along the Don River, it was announced officially today.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., July 25 -- Police recovered last night the body of 12-year-old Oliver Goodwin, missing since Thursday after three youths, who had been swimming with him in Deal Lake, broke down and admitted that they had been afraid to report his drowning because they were "afraid of going to jail or getting the electric chair."

LONDON, July 25 -- Adolf Hitler's plans for using his Elite Guard forces of thoroughly indoctrinated young Nazi zealots not only to police the lands occupied by the Germans but to quell possible uprisings within the Reich, as revealed in a secret document captured by the British in Libya last March, were made public here today by the Ministry of Information.

THERE is more than one objective upon which the American people today present a thoroughly united front, and outstanding among these is the defense of Alaska. There is no dissent to the proposition that the invading Japanese must be driven from every inch of territory upon which they have set their impious feet.

WASHINGTON, July 25 (AP) -- The War Department today announced the names of forty-one United States soldiers, including one New Yorker, who were killed in action or who died of wounds in the Alaskan area. The deaths occurred during the Japanese attack on Dutch Harbor on June 3, 1942, and in subsequent air operations in the Aleutian Islands.

ACCORDING to all indications this will be one year in which we can find attractive separate jackets for almost every occasion. This bit of good fortune is due to some extent to the new WPB ruling that dresses with jackets may no longer be sold as a single unit.
An extensive reorganization of the Air Warden Service is now under way in order to promote greater efficiency, it was learned yesterday.

In a desperate bid to keep their winning streak going, the Giants tossed a delayed-action bomb into the ranks of the Reds yesterday at the Polo Grounds, but the timing was faulty, the marksmanship could have been better and the explosive content should have been more powerful to produce the desired result.

NEARLY everybody is busy in Oxford these days. Not everybody, of course. When the sun is not too hot there are always a few gatherings of talkers in shirt sleeves on the weather-beaten benches around the old Court House: and in the evening people drift leisurely through the square, drop into the drug store for cold drinks under the whirring fans or talk softly in groups under the store balconies.

"Velvet flash," a new technique n flash-bulb photography, is introduced by Kenneth Murray in Photography Handbook No. 10. Ordinary flash bulbs are dipped in ethyl violet dissolved in ordinary household alcohol. Though slowing might effectiveness down one to two diaphragm stops, "velvet flash" has the advantages of soft illumination, no after image of the filament to disturb the subject, and undistorted tonal gradation.

The retailers committee of the New York War Savings Staff announced yesterday that scores of celebrities, including public officials and stars of the stage, radio and screen, would appear at its "New York for Victory" war bond block party in front of the New York Public Library on Tuesday evening.

Joey Varoff, 140, East Side, got the decision over Mexican Joey Silva, 135 1/2, Philadelphia, in the main six-round bout at the Queensboro Arena last night before a crowd of 2,500 who contributed to Manhattan and Queens Air Raid Warden Headquarters.

LONDON, July 26 -- The ascendancy which the industrials gained over the other securities on the Stock Exchange was increased last week. The index number at 81.4 reached its highest point since Jan. 9. Gilt-edge issues remained steady while the movements elsewhere were small and erratic.

In the world crisis we are seeing many long-standing prejudices giving way for the betterment of American democracy, the Rev. John Walter Houck, pastor, declared in his sermon yesterday at the Pilgrim Congregational Church, Grand Concourse and East l75th Street, the Bronx.
WASHINGTON, July 26 -- President Roosevelt is considering naming Governor Lehman of New York as supreme Federal arbiter on wages, according to a report in authoritative circles today.

WASHINGTON, July 26 (AP) -- Members of Congress who voted to establish a separate government agency to encourage the manufacture of synthetic rubber from farm products said today that they believed they had the votes to over-ride a veto.

LOURENCO MARQUES, Portuguese East Africa, July 23 (Delayed) -- With the release of United States newspaper men from Japan, an insight into Japanese propaganda methods can now be provided. One of these consists in sending slugging squads to concentration camps to extract, by persuasion if possible and by force if necessary, statements from prisoners testifying to their good treatment, which are then broadcast or printed in the Japanese-controlled press.

To Keenan Wynn has gone the leading male role in "Strip for Action," the Howard Lindsay-Russel Crouse comedy recounting the adventures of a burlesque troupe while preparing entertainment for an Army camp. Late September will see it bestowed in the National Theatre.
CHICAGO, July 26 (AP) -- The White Sex and Athletics broke even in two close games today, Chicago winning the opener in the ninth, 2 to 1, and losing the second in ten innings, 3 to 2.

Declaring that the most far-reaching evil of the present war is its threat to "the family, foundation society of church and State," the Rev. Francis F. Reh, Professor of Moral Theology at St. Joseph's Theological Seminary, Dunwoodie, N.Y., appealed yesterday at solemn mass in St. Patrick's Cathedral for prayers for a speedy peace after victory "in the name of the family, God's beloved little society."
A spectacular fire, followed by a gasoline explosion, swept the Westminster Garage, 425 Coney Island Avenue, Brooklyn, late yesterday afternoon, causing injuries to three firemen.

CHUNGKING, China, July 26 (U.P.) -- Chinese troops, driving west from the twenty-five-mile stretch of the Hangchow-Nanchang Railway they recovered in Kiangsi Province a week ago, have raided the next two station towns on the line, Kweiki and Yingtan, it was announced today.

What police described as an ingenious scheme to collect insurance on an automobile, after first stripping it of its most valuable parts -- four new tires -- was foiled early Saturday morning, the police said, with the arrest of two Brooklyn youths in the act of destroying the car in a deserted section of King's Point, Long Island.

LONDON, July 26 -- The pilfering of art treasures from occupied lands is being steadily carried on by the Germans. This slow methodical looting is in sharp contrast with the speed and violence of the attack that overcame the invaded lands.
LOURENCO MARQUES, Portuguese East Africa, July 24 (Delayed) (AP) -- "American! This is Japan!"

Dushan M. Pavlovich, 62 years old, a former attache of the Yugoslav consulate in Chicago, was found dead yesterday morning in his one-room apartment in the Allerton House, 302 West Twenty-second Street.

WASHINGTON, July 26 (AP) -- The plea of the Army, the Navy's shore establishments and the Maritime Commission for rail to build spur lines and sidings is being answered, in part, by the Federal Government's requisitioning of abandoned and non-essential railroad trackage.

CHICAGO, July 26 -- Continued favorable weather in the big surplus producing area east of the Rocky Mountains resulted in the small grain harvest making very rapid progress last week, and only a small percentage of the acreage of Winter wheat, oats, rye and barley remains to be cut except in the Northwestern States, and considerable progress was made in the latter, excepting Spring wheat and flaxseed.

WASHINGTON, July 26 (U.P.) -- Donald M. Nelson's report showing tripled war production since last November drew high praise from Congressional leaders tonight, and Representative Vinson, chairman of the House Naval Affairs Committee, said it showed the country was getting "away from business as usual."

CHICAGO, July 26 -- Oats developed independent strength last week in sympathy with the cash market. Although harvesting of the new crop is about completed in the big commercial producing areas, except in the Northwest, country offerings have been small and it is the general belief of the trade that the after-harvest movement will prove disappointing.

Coast Guardsman John C. Cullen, the discoverer of the Nazi spies who landed on Long Island, yesterday afternoon had an opportunity to learn how his home community feel toward him, when a service flag dedication ceremony was held under the auspices of the Bayside Hills Civic Association at Constitution Mall, Bell Boulevard and Fifty-third Avenue, Bayside.
