THERE is now footloose in Sweden a 26-year-old fireman who makes fast time between fires. His name is Gunder Haegg, and this distant observer doesn't know whether he is a hook-and-ladder laddie or a hose-cart hero when on duty. But between rides on the red wagons he goes at a remarkable pace on foot. By all accounts, he is the greatest runner in the world at the moment.

Asserting that "the bar has a capacity for far greater service in the war than it has either performed or been called upon to perform thus far," Henry Ward Beer, president of the Federal Bar Association of New York, New Jersey and Connecticut, announced yesterday a plan to mobilize lawyers for both mental and manual work in the war.

An unnamed baby sea lion, not yet two months old, put on an act like a veteran professional yesterday afternoon at the Central Park Zoo, attracting a crowd of several hundred persons. He was coy and daring, he grimaced, he shook his head and, in a rare moment, bleated like a sheep.
LONDON, July 26 -- The small shopkeepers of Britain -- who are now almost exclusively women -are worried.

CANBERRA, Australia, July 26 -- John J. Dedman, Minister of War Organization and Industrial Research, announced today that the government had ordered the simplification of clothing to economize on materials and labor. The manufacture of certain types of garments and the use of non-essential trimmings will be prohibited after tomorrow.

LOURENCO MARQUES, Portuguese East Africa, July 25 (Delayed) -- A week after Japan went to war the war lords suddenly flooded the Tokyo markets with food for the first time in a year, in an obvious attempt to lift morale. But as quickly as those surpluses gave out food queues sprang up again and the alarming spread of dietary ailments continued.
KOTZEBUE, Alaska, July 26 -- Up here near the top of the world the war has revived an almost forgotten art, the building of snow igloos. The Eskimos are putting them up for air-raid shelters.

LONDON, July 26 -- Andre Philip, member of the French Chamber of Deputies for Lyon, who for the past two months has been hunted by the Gestapo [German secret police] throughout France, has arrived in Britain on the invitation of General Charles de Gaulle, leader of the Fighting French, it was disclosed today.
The urgent need for a greater toughness in our approach to the war is emphasized not only by our defeats, but by some distressing symptoms within the services as well as in the body politic.

A nation-wide campaign to stamp out the "Seventh Column," or carelessness that causes accidents and robs America of 102,500 lives each year, will be opened by the Liberty Mutual Insurance Company today with a full-page insertion in a weekly picture magazine, to be followed tomorrow by page-sized copy in seventeen key newspapers.
Religion does pay, said the Rev. Dr. William Pierson Merrill, pastor emeritus, in a sermon yesterday in the Brick Presbyterian Church, Park Avenue and Ninety-first Street.

LONDON, July 26 -- Between 50,000 and 60,000 persons jammed themselves into Trafalgar Square under the Nelson Column this afternoon and cheered speakers demanding that the government open an offensive against the Nazis in the West immediately, even though it should lead only to repulse and a new Battle of Britain.

Earnings of the Union Carbide and Carbon Corporation and subsidiaries increased to $26,622,158 before tax deductions in the second quarter of this year from $24,422,766 in the first quarter of 1941 and $23,138,182 in the second quarter of last year.
ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., July 26 -- Father Divine opened today his first seashore "heaven" in what was formerly the Brigantine Hotel on the island just north of Atlantic City.

LOURENCO MARQUES, Portuguese East Africa, July 23 (Delayed) -- Hong Kong's terrors are still fresh in the memories of evacuees here on their way home, especially in the memories of Maryknoll missionary priests who had been stationed at the rest house at Stanley, where the British made their first landing 100 years ago and where they made their last stand last December.

WASHINGTON, July 26 -- The Federal Government has reduced the 1943 appropriations for "non-essential" agencies by $1,313,983,208 and has taken steps toward "a more prudent fiscal policy," but the need for further reductions in both war and non-war agencies is necessary and urgent, the Joint Committee on Reduction of Non-essential Federal Expenditures declared today.

CHICAGO, July 26 (AP) -- Plans for establishment of an International Labor Federation in competition with the American Federation of Labor and the Congress of Industrial Organizations were announced today at a conference of independent labor unions.

President Roosevelt's program for price stabilization met a major defeat when the National War Labor Board granted a wage increase to the employes of "Little Steel," according to the current issue of The Guaranty Survey, publication of the Guaranty Trust Company.

Countless millions of householders, air raid wardens and firemen and policemen of both the regular and the auxiliary varieties have been told by OCD during the past few months that if they find an incendiary bomb in their own or somebody else's attic they should apply a fine spray of water to it.

The Germans are nearing the Volga, and that means that they are deeper in Russia than they have ever been, in this war or the last. For the second time in a year they are fighting in the streets of Rostov, but it is a long, long time since any invader crossed the Don and threatened the great waterway which is to European Russia what the Mississippi is to the United States.

PITTSBURGH, July 26 -- The simultaneous establishment of a new peak in the American capacity to produce war materials and record allocations to lease-lend nations have placed such excessive demand upon the steel industry that some of our war plants are expected to shut down shortly or curtail their operations in coming months.
MOSCOW, July 26 (AP) -- The Soviet Information Bureau issued this communique today:

WASHINGTON, July 26 (AP) -- A measure creating a military supply board to direct the immediate construction of a fleet of cargo-carrying airplanes was drafted today by Senators Lee of Oklahoma and Johnson of Colorado for introduction in the Senate tomorrow.
All available evidence points to a compelling need for a strong program of immediate action if anti-inflation is to be more than a pious hope.

LONDON, July 26 -- United States Army fighter pilots flew Spitfires today with the Royal Air Force on a large-scale sweep over Northern France, in the course of which, in one of the biggest battles on the western air front in some weeks, formations of the Nazis' new Focke-Wulf 190s were bested and nine of the enemy destroyed to a loss of three Allied planes.

The United Service Organizations War Fund Campaign has received a $10,000 contribution from the war chest of the Masons of the State of New York, Prescott S. Bush, national campaign chairman, announced yesterday.

The problem of looking as smooth and cool as lemon ice in a temperature of 90 degrees (humidity ditto) is partly psychological, psychiatrists say. It's simply a matter of thinking "cool" thoughts. Results tend to be somewhat more effective, however, if the chilly cerebrations are accompanied by more tangible cooling systems.

CHICAGO. July 26 (AP) -- Industrial accidents killed 4,354 workers in twenty-three States during the first six months of 1942, an increase of 13 per cent over the same period a year ago, the National Safety Council announced today.
WADESBORO, N.C., July 26 -- Air Force fighters and bombers will sweep over a 5,000-square-mile area of the Carolinas as "flying artillery" beginning tomorrow in the Army's first wartime manoeuvres.

WASHINGTON, July 26 (U.P.)--James M. Landis, Civilian Defense Director, called upon the Federal Government tonight to provide compensation for air raid property damage and for personal injuries to defense workers whose jobs "are replete with hazard and danger."

CALCUTTA, India, July 26 -- Frequent bombing and strafing raids by the Allies on the Japanese and their Burmese satellites in the Akyab area prevent the Japanese from undertaking large-scale operations against the Moslem revolt in Northern Burma.

ST. CATHARINES, Ont., July 26 (Canadian Press) -- One of the proudest young farmerettes in Ontario today is Patricia Abbott, 18- year-old daughter of Lieut. Col. and Mrs. Charles F. Abbott of Toronto and newly crowned "Miss Farmerette 1942."

Gustave Kotanyi, who revived Johann Strauss's operettas, "The Bat" and "The Gypsy Baron," early this year, will present a third Viennese operetta at the Cosmopolitan Opera House the evenings of Aug. 18, 21 and 22. The work is "The Beggar Student" by Strauss's friend, Karl Milloecker.
Demands for an investigation of gasoline rationing are being made ready by gasoline dealers in several Eastern States in concerted drive upon Congress, it was disclosed last night.

Surgeon General Thomas Parran of the United States Public Health Service issued a twofold appeal to American housewives yesterday in connection with the nation's fat and grease salvage campaign. His statement was released here by Paul W. Zeckhausen, executive secretary of the New York City Salvage Committee.
As exporters of textile machinery we were very much interested in the article by Charles E. Egan, "Seeks Machinery for Latin America," in THE TIMES of July 21.

As a member of the executive committee of the Dance Profession-Victory Ball for Navy Relief I should like to express publicly my abiding gratitude for the heart-warming interest, the unprecedented generosity which the committee met at every step. The ink was hardly dry on our invitations when acceptances began to pour in.

Detectives operating the police mobile crime laboratory disproved a murder suspect's explanation in fifteen minutes yesterday and then obtained a confession from Carmello Rodriquez, 22 years old, of 116 East 116th Street, that he had beaten to death Mrs. Isabella Moralis, 29, of 60 East 114th Street.

CHICAGO. July 26 (AP) -- The Inland Steel Company today completed "Little Steel's" acceptance of the recent War Labor Board order for union security and pay increases, but said it "reserved the right" to test the union security provision in the courts.
Seven new films will reach Broadway theatres this week. The order of their arrival follows:
WASHINGTON, July 26 -- Hitherto unknown behavior of the human brain is being revealed by war wounds.

LOURENCO MARQUES, Portuguese East Africa, July 23 (Delayed) -- Enough information on the systematic terror and torture with which the Japanese military and police are trying to exterminate the "white barbarians" in the Far East has leaked out in Japan to make some Japanese who are sensitive to world opinion frankly ashamed.

WASHINGTON, July 26 -- Owen Lattimore, political adviser to Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek, declared in a radio address today that "we Americans, dedicated to the proposition that all men are equal, have, in the Chinese allies who are determined to make their side of the Pacific Ocean equal to ours in political democracy, economic security and human dignity."
In our extreme youth a party meant just one thing -- ice cream and lots of it.
The names of persons prominent in the field of music appear in the latest lists of apartment leases in Manhattan. The new rentals cover wide areas on the East and West Sides.

The Christian churches eventually will reunite "in the fellowship of the one holy Catholic and Apostolic Church" but are not yet prepared for such a union, Bishop William T. Manning declared yesterday morning in the last of four July sermons delivered by him in the Protestant Episcopal Cathedral of St. John the Divine on the general subject of "The Present World Situation and Christian Belief."

Seventeen four-year honor scholarships to Columbia College, yielding $500 a year each, have been awarded to graduates of high schools and preparatory schools in twelve States, it was announced yesterday by Bernard P. Ireland, assistant director of admissions at Columbia University.

WATCHUNG, N.J., July 26 (AP) -- Miss Patricia McWhorter of Elizabeth, victor in two events last night in a meet at Irvington, added to her laurels today by winning the one-mile open A.A.U. free-style swim for women in Watchung Lake.

ANKARA, Turkey, July 25 (Delayed) -- Further reports from Yugoslavia give fresh details of the campaign of General Draja Mikhailovitch's hard-pressed forces in Western Serbia and Northern Bosnia and Croatia against the Germans, the Croatian Ustashi and the Italians.

CLEVELAND, July 25 -- Furnace yards and Lake Erie docks will be holding 50,000,000 tons of ore, sufficient to keep steel mills and other war industries operating for seven months, when the Great Lakes shipping season ends next December, vessel men disclosed today.

With almost perfect Summer weather on the first Sunday under permanent gasoline rationing automobile travel on highways in the New York area yesterday was reported "fairly heavy," although it was still about 50 per cent less than on the corresponding Sunday a year ago.

LOURENCO MARQUES, Portuguese East Africa, July 26 -- It was a good story at the time and it's still funny -- how the Japanese sought to save face after the Doolittle raid, but didn't quite succeed, all because some doubting Japanese knew wet paint when they saw it.

The Greater New York Safety Council will ask 10,000 taxicab drivers in New York City to pledge this week their best efforts to save lives and tires, in the "On-and-Off-the-Job" accident-prevention campaign recently announced by the council.

Despite numerous market-depressing political developments and the glowing reports emanating from the Cotton Belt on the progress of what bids fair to be the largest crop in several years, prices of cotton futures underwent comparatively few changes last week.

VICHY, France, July 26 -- In an address to French war veterans in Lyon Admiral Jean Abrial, who was in command of the port of Dunkerque at the time of the British retreat, declared that the British decision to abandon France had freed France from any obligations and justified the signing of the armistice.
Both Frankie Frisch and Lippy Leo Durocher lost arguments with Umpire George Magerkurth at Ebbets Field yesterday, but Durocher, the Dodgers and 31,844 Flatbush fans won everything else.

PHILADELPHIA, July 26 (AP) - The Phils won a doubleheader today for the second time this season but Clyde McCullough, Cubs' catcher, stole some of the glory when he hit three home runs in successive trips to the plate in the first game.
WASHINGTON, July 26 (AP) -- The Navy announced today the promotion of thirty noncommissioned marines from New York to temporary warrant rank.

WASHINGTON, July 26 (AP) -- Representative Lyndon Johnson, Democrat of Texas, home from a tour of active naval duty as a lieutenant commander in the Southwestern Pacific, says that the Japanese Zero fighter planes are "tough babies to handle."

Achievement of "relatively stable labor-management relations" in the "once turbulent automobile industry" has been marked by a "striking change in the attitudes and tactics of both management and union," the Twentieth Century Fund reported yesterday in advance sections of a report on the automobile industry released by Evans Clark, executive director of the fund.

PITTSBURGH, July 26 -- Dried eggs in powdered form have been so successful that general use of the comparatively new product is expected, according to Harry Atkins of Davenport, Iowa, who came here to attend the annual convention of the American Poultry Association.

CHICAGO, July 26 -- Clouds, high, white and fleecy, hung over the towering, wild peaks of Southeastern New Guinea. Those ramparts of rock climb 14,000 to 16,000 feet into the tropic skies guarding the Japanese-held ports of Lae and Salamaua from inland assault.
Any American woman may have good reason this year to "cry over spilt milk," since waste of that precious commodity might indirectly deprive her of a new hat or coat.

ANKARA, Turkey, July 25 (Delayed) -- Alarming reports of the sudden resumption of German shipments of heavy and light artillery, tanks, planes and bomb stores from the Reich through Yugoslavia into Bulgaria reached foreign military intelligence sources in Turkey today.

Buying in the wholesale markets last week was active but conservative, according to a summary of the week's activities prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by leading resident offices. Some easing of prices was noted on non-priority goods.

CHICAGO, July 26 -- Trading in wheat, corn and rye fell off materially last week but more interest was shown in oats and soy beans than recently. However, the aggregate business on the Board of Trade was the smallest in some weeks, totaling 83,865,000 bushels, or a daily average of about 14, 000,000.

NEWARK, N.J., July 26 (AP) -The league-leading Newark Bears battled to an even break with the Toronto Maple Leafs today before a crowd of 5,000. The Bruins won the opener. 8 to 7, but dropped the nightcap, 4 -- 3.

Although the duck-hunting regulations have been liberalized and a ten-day extension in the length of the season has been approved for this Fall, it is not generally believed that the population of these birds will be more sharply depleted than usual.

AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, Australia, Monday, July 27 (AP) -- United Nations Commando troops stationed in Northeast New Guinea jungles clashed recently with Japanese patrols in the Salamaua area and killed approximately sixty of the enemy, said a communique issued today.

CHICAGO, July 26 -- A four-foot putt, worth $2,500 if it dropped, was missed by Byron Nelson on the eighteenth green today and sent the Toledo pro spinning dizzily into a play-off with Clayton Heafner for the Tam o' Shanter $15,000 golf open championship.
LONDON, July 26 (AP) -- The Air Ministry issued this communique today:

JERSEY CITY, N.J., July 26 (AP) -- Jersey City regained second place today by taking both ends of a double-header from the Montreal Royals, 3 -- 0 and 4 -- 2. The Little Giants also captured the marathon series, three games to two, with two other games ending in deadlocks.

HARTFORD, July 26 -- A score or more of government witnesses arrived here this afternoon as government prosecutors made final detailed preparations for the opening of an espionage conspiracy case that may develop sensational disclosures of Axis operations in this country.

CHICAGO, July 25 -- Congressional efforts to bring about higher prices for agricultural products and the Administration's anti-inflation program which is regarded as opposed to better than full parity returns tended to drive speculators and other interests out of the wheat market last week, and professional operators curtailed their lines pending further development.

Professor George C.D. Odell's marathon writing and research project that started back in 1900, the recording in an unlimited number of volumes of the annals of the New York stage, has reached the thirteenth volume. The new volume covers the years 1885 to 1888 in 723 pages.

Both war news and taxation plans were uncertain last week; the mood of the general community was not cheerful. So far as concerned dispatches from the front, the British Army seemed to be holding its own in Africa; but Russia's campaign before Rostov appeared to be going badly, with all that this implied.

WITH THE BRITISH EIGHTH ARMY, in Egypt, July 26 -- An Australian patrol operating northwest of El Alamein returned today with word of having destroyed a number of enemy vehicles and guns and having engaged an enemy staff car at short range, routing it.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y. July 26 -- With ten named for the American Legion Handicap and twelve for the Flash Stakes, Saratoga's annual race meeting will start tomorrow faced with one of the gravest problems in its history.

There ought to be the widest possible support for the safety campaign now being dramatized by the Liberty Mutual Insurance Company. Carelessness in factory, on the highway and in the home is costing more than 100,000 lives and injuries to more than 9,000,000 persons a year.

LONDON, July 26 (U.P.) -- German occupation authorities have shot or hanged 250,000 persons in a ruthless campaign intended to wipe out Polish intellectual life and crush the last shred of resistance to the Nazi regime, Stanislaw Mikolajczyk, Deputy Premier of Poland's Government-in-Exile, said tonight.

MOSCOW, Monday, July 27 -- The German tank force that broke into Rostov's defense area on Saturday advanced again yesterday, but not without suffering severe losses the Russian High Command announced this morning. Bitter fighting continued in other sections of the outskirts of the city.

Last week the Irving Fisher index of wholesale commodity prices rose from 108.2 to 108.4. The farm products index continued to move upward after the temporary reaction of tile previous week. Prices were much higher for livestock, poultry and oranges as compared to the decreases in raw cotton and grains, thus causing an increase of 0.9 per cent in the index.

Users of oil burners for household heating have been slow to heed the call to conversion, and while this tardiness cannot be justified or defended, it is easy to understand. Because for the average American home owner the elaborately modern heating unit in his basement with its automatic mechanisms as sensitive as the human skin in their reactions replaced the automobile as an object of his pride and joy.
MOSCOW, Monday, July 27 (AP) -- The Soviet lnformation Bureau's communique of last midnight:

REVERSIDE, Calif., July 26 (AP) -- Frank Kritzer, 57-year-old engineer, committed suicide by setting off a 200-pound dynamite blast in a cave on the San Bernardino Desert, Coroner R.E. Williams reported today.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 26 -- The screen version of "Du Barry Was a Lady" will go before the cameras at Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer next month with Red Skelton, Gene Kelly, Virginia O'Brien, Rags Ragland and Lucille Ball, whose as assignment was announced previously, heading the cast, the studio has announced.

CHICAGO, July 26 -- Ceiling prices were bid for lard futures at the end of last week, with the September, October and December quoted at $12.90 a hundred pounds. Trading in July lard ceased at the close on Thursday at the ceiling level.

NEW DELHI, India, July 26 (U.P.) -- A sudden wave of realization that aggressive hordes menace India from east and west, reflected in new demands by leaders of varied groups for national mobilization, may compel the All-India Congress party to temper its projected independence movement, Indian leaders said today.

GUAYAQUIL, Ecuador, July 26 -- The restriction on the circulation of American dollars, which have been the standard of exchange, has resulted in a drop in value from fourteen to seven sucres in the open market. The central bank has been prohibited from buying dollars and laborers returning from work on the Panama Canal have been forced to sell them on the street as low as six sucres.

The Long Island State Park Commission announced yesterday plans for a series of horseshoe-pitching tournaments for novices -- defined as persons who have not previously won a prize in a contest conducted by the commission -starting on Aug. 16, a Sunday, at North Valley Stream, Hempstead Lake, Heckscher, Belmont Lake and Wildwood State Parks.

A strong and continuing effort by the National Aeronautical Training Association, backed by the National Aeronautic Association, has borne fruit. Congress has passed a bill adding the four words "mechanics and ground technicians" to the civilian pilot training act of 1939.

AN EAST COAST PORT, July 26 (AP) -- An American seaman told of spending four days as a prisoner aboard a German submarine after the raider had torpedoed his ship and then picked him up while swimming in the ocean.

DETROIT, July 26 (AP) -- FBI agents raided an additional sixty homes of enemy aliens in the Detroit area today and seized firearms, cameras, binoculars, shortwave receiving sets and other prohibited articles.
SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., July 26 -- David S. Cowles of New York gave a luncheon today at the studio of Mrs. E. Morton Tilton in Foster Street. The guests were seated at small tables in the garden.
ALBANY, July 26 (AP) -- Curtailed use of automobiles was credited officially today for much of a 32.8 per cent decline of New York State crime generally in May, compared with last year.

When the Giants started swinging at the Reds yesterday at the Polo Grounds they were knee-deep in a mixture of fruits and vegetables. When they finished they were hip-deep in fourth place, a game and a half behind Bill McKechnie's crew.

DES MOINES, Iowa, July 26 (AP) -- The Japanese invasion route has followed the southward course in an attempt to gain materials for manufacture of mustard gas, Dr. O.R. Sweeney, head of the Iowa State College Chemical Engineering Department, said today.

The only possible way in which we can hope to head off inflation is by a well-rounded program that sees the problem as a whole and deals with it as a whole. The first step in that program is to remove excess purchasing power from the hands of the whole public. This must be done on the principle of equality of sacrifice.

WEST POINT, N.Y., July 26 (AP) -- The largest class of plebes ever to enter the United States Military Academy will answer their first reveille tomorrow and begin the long, hard climb to the gold bars of a second lieutenant in the United States Army.

WITH THE BRITISH EIGHTH ARMY, in Egypt, July 26--The Germans on this front are using materiel captured from the Russians. Evidence of that was submitted yesterday when an Australian patrol operating northwest of El Alamein came back with a 76.2-mm. gun mounted on a tractor.

MICHIGAN CITY, Ind., July 26 (AP) -- Three persons were killed and at least ten 'teen-aged boys and girls were injured, several critically, today when an eastbound South Shore Railroad electric train struck a truckload of forty children at the edge of Michigan City in U.S. Road 12.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, July 26 -- The separation of the Norwegian Church from Premier Vidkun Quisling's State became a fact when six leaders of the Norwegian Church met secretly in Oslo a few days ago and constituted a provisional church council, it was learned today.

WASHINGTON, July 26 -- The Office of Defense Transportation announced today that with the heaviest long-haul tonnage demands in history being placed upon the nation's steam freight locomotives, it is seeking to avert a motive power shortage by taking steps to increase the efficiency of locomotive operation.

LOURENCO HARQUES, Portuguese East Africa, July 23 (Delayed) -- The most serious conditions seem to prevail in military concentration camps at Zentsuji and Singapore, according to accounts given by released prisoners to American newspaper men in their party on the exchange ships.

LONDON, July 26 -- The announcement of further extensive price controls by the government, following closely upon the fact that in June the Board of Trade's commodity index showed its first fall since the outbreak of the war, has drawn fresh attention to the general situation in regard to commodity prices in Great Britain.

CHICAGO, July 26 -- Corn continued to show a very firm undertone last week, and while closing of spreads between wheat and corn tended to depress the latter at times, there was very little other pressure on the market with the result that prices averaged higher.

Despite war problems, commercial credit and collection conditions in twenty-one Latin-American markets during the first half of 1942 continued the upward trend which has been noted since July, 1940, according to the semi-annual survey by the Foreign Credit Interchange Bureau of the National Association of Credit Men, released for publication today.

Organization of the price section of the regional office of the Office of Price Administration has been completed and the office is now prepared to handle price problems of the widely varied industries of this area, according to Sylvan L. Joseph, regional administrator.

After carrying an inch and a quarter hypodermic needle in his heart for seven years, Fire Lieutenant Thomas F. Blackburne of 1261 Pawnee Place, the Bronx, died yesterday in Mount Sinai Hospital of pneumonia and complications that followed the removal of the broken needle Thursday.

BOSTON, July 26 (AP) -- A hurler suspended two weeks ago for "indifferent pitching" came out of the "doghouse" today with a one-hit nine-inning relief masterpiece that enabled the Braves to divide a double-header with the Cardinals.

Police Headquarters here received a report late yesterday afternoon that the three Nazi saboteurs sought by the Federal Bureau of Investigation had been seen in Suffolk County during the day and had tried to hitch-hike to the Bridgehampton, L.I., railroad station.

LOURENCO MARQUES, Portuguese East Africa, July 24 (Delayed) -- The Japanese had Malaya and Burma in the bag four months before the fateful morning of Dec. 8 [the day of Pearl Harbor, according to Japanese time] when they pulled the string.

J.S. Allard, vice president in charge of the export sales division of the Curtiss-Wright Corporation, has been granted a leave of absence by that organization and reports for duty in Washington today as a lieutenant-colonel, United States Army Air Forces.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., July 26 -Numerical tops for the season were reached today in the tenth regatta of the championship series or Long Island Sound, held by the Larchmont Yacht Club. There were 105 starters. The previous high was 94.

VICHY, France, July 26 -- Subscriptions for the new 3 1/2 per cent rente opened on the occasion of the conversion of the 5 per cent rente of 1939 and the 4 1/2 per cent Treasury bonds of 1932 have been closed.

SEABRIGHT, N.J., July 26 -- The first round-robin doubles tournament held by the Seabright Lawn Tennis and Cricket Club in the fifty-five-year history of its invitation fixtures came to an end today with Ted Schroeder of Glendale, Calif., and Sidney B. Wood Jr. of Southampton the winners.

LONDON, July 26 -- In a broadcast to the United States today Sir Stafford Cripps appealed for sympathy with Britain and understanding of her position in the conflict that is developing between the government and Mohandas K. Gandhi and his followers in the All-India Congress party.

The German High Command announced yesterday, according to Berlin broadcasts recorded by The Associated Press, that German troops had forced a crossing of the Don River southeast of Rostov in heavy fighting. Russian attempts to establish an "orderly and cohesive defense front" on the southern bank were reported to have failed.

GUAYAQUIL, Ecuador, July 26 -- The restriction on the circulation of United States dollars, which have been standard exchange here, has resulted in a drop in value of from 14 to 7 sucres in the open market, it was disclosed today.

An executive order requiring all city employes and the members of their families to have a New York City war identification card, which, in most instances, will mean compulsory fingerprinting, has been issued by Mayor La Guardia, it became known yesterday.

WITH THE BRITISH EIGHTH ARMY, at El Alamein, Egypt, July 26 (AP) -- After mid-week clashes, in which both sides lost heavily, a lull has come in the desert war and the Germans are furiously digging in all along the front that extends from the region of El Alamein to the Qattara Depression.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., July 26 -- Philip Cowen, a founder of The American Hebrew and its publisher for twenty-seven years, observed his eighty-ninth birthday with a family dinner this evening attended by thirty relatives and later an open house for friends, many of whom came from New York.

WASHINGTON, July 26 -- New and substantially increased warrisk insurance rates for exports, excluding, however, United States Territories and insular possessions, were announced today by the War Shipping Administration.

ST. LOUIS, July 26 (AP) -- Four hit pitching by Denny Galehouse and a ninth-inning double by First Baseman George McQuinn brought the Browns a double victory over the Red Sox today and boosted them within three games of second place.

Governor Lehman formally abandoned yesterday the candidacy of Lieutenant Governor Charles Poletti, his first choice as his successor, and joined President Roosevelt in backing United States Senator James M. Mead for the Governorship, as against Attorney General John J. Bennett Jr.

WASHINGTON, July 26 (U.P.) -- Elevation of General George C. Marshall, Army Chief of Staff, to be Commander in Chief of all United Nations forces has been under serious consideration here, it was disclosed tonight.

DETROIT, July 26 -- Paced by Charlie Keller, who exploded two home runs while burly Red Ruffing hurled another of his deft mound masterpieces, the Yankees today continued merrily on their way to making a shambles of what is left of the American League pennant race.

In view of the alarming position in which the Russian armies have been placed, it is encouraging to learn that the British are now bombing German railways. Duisburg, the latest large target for a British bombing attack in force, is a great German railway as well as shipping center.
BOMBAY, India, July 26 (Reuter) -- Mohandas K. Gandhi made an attack on Japanese policy in an article headed "To Every Japanese," published in his weekly newspaper Harijan today.
WASHINGTON, July 26 (AP) -- The War Production chief, Donald M. Nelson, forecast by indirection today a few of the drastic wartime restrictions the nation still must face.

Mayor La Guardia's weekly "Talk to the People" by radio dealt yesterday with a wide variety of topics, ranging from a warning against peace proposals from the Axis powers to establishment of a "toyery" for children in West Harlem.

CLEVELAND, July 26 (AP) -- Colonel (Buster) Mills slugged a triple and three singles in five times at bat and drove in four runs today as the Indians gained a 7-to-1 victory over Washington in the nightcap of a double-header. Sid Hudson shut out Cleveland in the first game, 2 to 0.

WITH THE ROYAL AIR FORCE IN BRITAIN, July 26 (AP) -- Battle-trained Royal Air Force pilots have given their approval to the United States-built Mustang fighter planes, American equivalents of the famous Hurricanes.

WASHINGTON, July 26 -- Provisions under which the Commodity Credit Corporation will assume insurance and surcharge costs in connection with certain imports of cocoa beans were announced today by the four cooperating agencies, the Commodity Credit Corporation, Board of Economic Warfare, War Production Board and Office of Price Administration.

BERNE, Switzerland, July 26 -- Despite the preponderating factor of materiel -- or possibly because of it -- lines of communication by land, sea and air are likely to determine the issue of this war, and lines of communication loom very large at present.
The following German High Command communique was broadcast yesterday from Berlin and was recorded here by The Associated Press:

DALLAS, Texas, July 26 (AP) -- Possibility that Senator W. Lee O'Daniel's confident campaign refrain, "There ain't gonna be no run-off," would boomerang grew as the last tabulation of the day in the Texas Democratic primary failed to give him the necessary majority.

The three-story building containing twenty-four apartments at 279 Goldsmith Avenue, Newark, N.J., has been sold by the West End Building and Loan Association to David Shoshkes. The Krasner-Herman Company was the broker and mortgage financing was arranged by the New Jersey Realty Company.

MOSCOW, Monday, July 27 (AP) -- Soviet artillerymen fighting desperately from the southern bank of the Don in the Tsimlyansk area, 120 miles east of Rostov, hurled tons of explosives into the German forces on the northern bank, it was reported today.

The world is a cruel battlefield today because men of power are animated by an inhuman spirit, the Rev. Dr. M. Stephen James, pastor of the First Reformed Church of Albany, declared yesterday in a sermon in the Marble Collegiate Reformed Church, Fifth Avenue at Twenty-ninth Street.
ATLANTA, July 27 (AP) -- OPA officials announced today that baseball players are not considered essential users of gasoline "in respect to the war effort or to public welfare."
CANBERRA, Australia, July 27 -- "Almost positive evidence" of activities of enemy agents is causing anxiety in governmental circles today.

CAIRO, Egypt, July 27 -- An attack by troops of the British Empire, described as "operations of limited character," began last night in the northern sector of the front that extends southward from the region of El Alamein. The fighting continued today.

Growing apprehension over several items reportedly included in the 1942 loan program of the Commodity Credit Corporation yesterday occasioned a selling wave in the cotton market, touching off early in the session a downward movement that was virtually unimpeded during the day.

Brother A. Leo, acting secretary of the alumni office of Manhattan College, announced yesterday that the college has to date sent 669 of its men into military service and that 76 per cent of them had been commissioned officers.

ALBANY, July 27 (AP) -- Major traffic law violations are increasing in New York despite a sharp decline in highway travel, a State Motor Vehicle Bureau report on operator license revocations disclosed today.

A false analogy vitiates the conclusions drawn by Anne O'Hare McCormick in her interesting article on the crisis in India appearing in THE TIMES of July 22. She says: "Washington cannot advise London on policy in India any more than it would accept British advice on our policy in Puerto Rico."

The decision of the United States Supreme Court in the Milligan case -- the case most nearly similar to that of the eight Nazi saboteurs, which will come before it tomorrow -- invalidated the trial and conviction of Lambdin P. Milligan by a military commission in 1864.
MOSCOW, July 27 (AP) -- The Soviet Information Bureau issued this communique today:

A thousand animal aides are needed to care for pets wounded during air raids, it was announced yesterday by Sydney H. Coleman, executive vice president of the American Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals. Mr. Coleman spoke at the Pershing Square CDVO Information Center.

WASHINGTON, July 27 -- Resolutions calling on the Maritime Commission to suspend, pending completion of Congressional investigations, the recent cancellation of its contract with Andrew J. Higgins of New Orleans, for speedy construction of 200 Liberty ships, were blocked today on both sides of the Capitol.
WASHINGTON, July 27 -- Denial of additional gasoline to traveling salesmen would imperil vital businesses, Office of Price Administration officials in charge of gasoline rationing were told today.

The War Production Board's recent order fixing the basis of production of each item in the cosmetic field will be complied with fully by the industry, but nothing in the new order gives any excuse for "hoarding or excessive conservation'' of cosmetic materials, representatives of the Toilet Goods Association declared yesterday at a luncheon in the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.

In the event that the Nazis should raid New York from the air, which in my opinion they could very well do any time and don't only because they know it would stimulate the war effort, some if not all of the hospitals have provisions for getting their staffs through police lines.

Along the furrowed flagstone walks in the friendly borough of Brooklyn the good people saunter of a Sunday morning. Small children tug contentedly at their young parents' hands as little groups progress along the high streets above the river, or peer reflectively through tall iron grilles at a constant pageant of passing boats.

LONDON, July 27 (AP) -- British airmen who were in the Hamburg raid last night said that, although the size of the attacking force was short of the 1,000-plane standard set in June, perfect visibility and the weight of the 4,000-pound explosives dropped made the results "better than the 1,000-bomber job on Bremen."

LONDON, July 27 -- An interview by Kanji Kauno, former Washington correspondent of the Asahi, that has been published in the daily newspaper Noticias at Lourenco Marques, Portuguese East Africa, reports that last August Admiral Kichisaburo Nomura, then Japanese Ambassador to the United States, made a proposal that President Roosevelt and Prince Fumimaro Konoye, then Premier of Japan, hold a conference in Alaska to settle differences between the two countries "without Cabinet interference."

VALLETTA, Malta, July 27 (AP) -- Twelve Axis planes -- three German bombers, eight German fighters and one Italian fighter -- were destroyed by the Royal Air Force when the enemy made two attacks on this island today, a communique announced.

CHICAGO, July 27 -- Manager Joe McCarthy reduced his Yankee roster by one today when he announced the optional release of Outfielder Tuck Stainback to the Newark Bears. But no sooner had he done this than there loomed the possibility that Stainback, subject to recall by the world champions on 24-hour notice, may be fetched back sooner than expected.
WASHINGTON, July 27 -- Only once before in contemporary times has a special session of the Supreme Court been called, but ample authority exists in Section 338 of the Judicial Code, which says:

WASHINGTON, July 27 -- An overall goal of 17,000,000 tons of iron and steel scrap has been set for the last half of this year under the national salvage program set up by the conservation division of the War Production Board, it was disclosed today.
Mr. and Mrs. William Creighton Peet of Washington are at the Plaza.

WASHINGTON, July 27 (AP) -The Federal Trade Commission said today it had ordered the Agricultural Insecticide and Fungicide Association, New York, and twenty-six manufacturers of insecticides fungicides and related products and eleven officers and directors of the association to halt certain practices "having the tendency and effect of restraining and suppressing competition in the sale and distribution of their products."

HAVERSTRAW, N.Y., July 27 -- Letchworth Village, the home for the feebleminded maintained near here by the State Department of Mental Hygiene, is so seriously overcrowded that the physical health of many of its child inmates is being affected, and the institution, because of a change in the method of hiring attendants, is being forced to employ "inferior" ones, according to the thirty-third annual report of the institution's board of visitors, made public today.
The following German High Command communique was broadcast from Berlin yesterday and was recorded here by The Associated Press:

Sales of New York and Brooklyn department stores showed a decline of 3 per cent last week from the comparative week a year ago, according to the report issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. For the preceding week the bank had reported a decrease of 1 per cent in sales volume.

Publicly announced gifts and bequests in seven large cities for the first six months of 1942 showed an increase of 63 per cent over the same period in 1941, according to a semi-annual study of philanthropy issued yesterday by the John Price Jones Corporation, fund-raising counsel.

New one-man rubber parachute boats, which can be inflated in ten seconds, are being supplied to pilots in the nation's armed forces for emergency use in the event their planes are forced down over water, it was announced yesterday by the United States Rubber Company, manufacturers of the boats.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., July 27 -- Amid difficulties, expected and unexpected, the racing at Saratoga, which goes back to 1864, got under way for 1942 with Scotland Light winning the American Legion Handicap and Breezing Home taking the Flash Stakes over a sloppy track in approved thoroughbred fashion.

Tough Coast Guardsmen to bring the enemy back alive are being prepared for action at the Manhattan Beach Training Station of the service in Brooklyn, it was disclosed yesterday by Lieutenant Jack Dempsey, the former heavyweight boxing champion, who is in charge of athletics there.
WASHINGTON, July 27 -- Seven vesting actions involving firms owned by Japanese interests or in which they owned a large share were announced today by Leo T. Crowley, the Alien Property Custodian.
Mayor La Guardia accepted two new ambulances at City Hall yesterday as gifts from the American Women's Voluntary Services, and assigned them immediately to Harlem and Polyclinic Hospitals.

An intensive consumer education program is being worked out for National Frosted Foods Week, Oct. 19 to 24, to implement the government's suggestion that civilian consumption of quick-frozen perishables be increased to alleviate the shortages of canned goods. Clyde F. Winter, president of Frosted Food Retailers of America, announced yesterday.

Analysis of Fall men's clothing business booked thus far has shown that clothiers expect an entirely different type of buying from that which prevailed during World War No. 1, manufacturers said yesterday. The Fall business, which has been better than expected, indicates a trend toward serviceable and conservative clothing and furnishings, sellers declared.

The much-maligned and little-defended men of the box office came into their own yesterday. Bouquets instead of customers' ire were tossed at the treasurers behind the ticket windows not only by Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt but by the Army, the City Council and theatrical producers.

The right wing of the American Labor party last night endorsed the candidacy of Senator James M. Mead for Governor and withdrew in his favor its threat of a third-party ticket. This wing controls the party's State Committee, has controlled all State conventions in the past, and represents to a larger degree than the left wing the last-ditch New Deal vote in the State.

CHUNGKING, China, July 27 -- United States Army fighter planes, battling beneath a full moon, routed fifty Japanese bombers that took off from Hankow to make their first raid of the year on Chungking tonight, letting only four of them get through to attack the outskirts of this Chinese capital.

WASHINGTON, July 27 -- The first "flying nurse" to be inducted into the Army Nurse Corps for special assignment to the air-ambulance service signed this morning in the Eighth Corps Area. She will be assigned to Randolph Field, in Texas.

Axis submarines, ranging from the Straits of Florida to the coast of Canada, have taken to preying on "small fry" and have sunk two fishing boats, costing the United Nations the loss of cargoes of 40,000 pounds of onions and nineteen swordfish.

A new directive that designates clearly the deferred classification until further notice of all married men with wives and children and married men with no children who maintain bona fide family relationships in homes was announced yesterday by Colonel Arthur V. McDermott, New York City draft director.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., July 27 -The newly appointed Hudson County Board of Taxation was frustrated in its second attempt to gain access to the records of the old board today after Special Assistant Attorney General John Warren served formal demands for the data on county officials.

From the land of the Samurai, of the tea-drinking ceremony and the cherry festival, of pet crickets and firefly lamps, of studied smiles and forms of courtesy carried to a point never reached in the Western World comes a shipload of refugees to tell of vile indignities, torture and murder inflicted upon helpless prisoners by the Japanese soldiers and police.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., July 27 -- Johnny Vasco, Sunset Knolls pro, and Charles Goldman, Fenway amateur, carded a 30, 37 -- 67 to take first prize in the pro-amateur best-ball tournament sponsored by the Westchester County Golf Association over the Metropolis Country Club course today.
WASHINGTON, July 27 (U.P.) -The Adjutant General's office will receive applications for allowances for soldiers' dependents soon after Aug. 1.

WASHINGTON, July 27 -- Secretary of State Cordell Hull declared today that the United States had not recognized Austria as legally absorbed into the German Reich. His statement was made in response to questions that were prompted by confused statements on the subject by speakers in various parts of the country during the recent observance of Austrian Day.

WASHINGTON, July 27 -- An assertion that Daniel J. Tobin, president of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, A.F. of L., was not "conspiring with William L. Hutcheson (president of the United Brotherhood of Carpenters) to bring John L. Lewis into the American Federation of Labor," was made today by the International Teamster, monthly organ of the Tobin union.

The German High Command reported yesterday the capture of Bataisk, "strongly fortified and tenaciously defended town" about five miles south of Rostov on the railway leading to the oil port of Baku, on the Caspian Sea. The German communique, quoted in Berlin broadcasts recorded by The Associated Press, said that the German Air Force had cleared the way for the troops that took the town.
Though yesterday's rainfall was one of the heaviest in the city's recent history it was not technically a cloudburst, according to the Weather Bureau, but rather a "series of local thunderstorms."
Tenants of the Pare Vendome apartment house group in West Fifty-sixth and Fifty-seventh Streets heard conflicting opinions yesterday on the value of their four new air raid casualty stations.

LOURENCO MARQUES, Portuguese East Africa, July 26 (Delayed) -- While the Japanese attacked Pearl Harbor, thousands of Japanese troops were sneaking through sewers at Hong Kong to strike at the British Empire forces from the rear in another "sneak" attack.

WASHINGTON, July 27 -- The Office of Price Administration today established a schedule of mark-ups which jobbers and "secondary jobbers" of domestic woolen and worsted civilian apparel fabrics are permitted to make under Maximum Price Regulation No. 163.

The Equity Corporation yesterday reported that on June 30 it had net assets equivalent to $40.69 each on the $3 convertible preferred stock, entitled to $50 in liquidation, compared with $42.59 a share on Dec. 31 last, and $49.14 a share on June 30, 1941.

CHICAGO, July 27 -- Professional sentiment turned to the bear side of the wheat market on the Board of Trade today, easiness in cotton and lack of aggressive mill or other support furnishing the incentive for the pit element to take a stand on the selling side.

TRENTON, July 27 -- Complying with the request of Governor Charles Edison, Attorney General David T. Wilentz today appointed John Warren of Jersey City as a special assistant and directed him to take appropriate legal action to determine the status of the new Hudson County Tax Board.

Averting a threatened strike of some 22,000 A.F. of L. building trades workers on $100,000,000 of naval construction in the New York City area, an agreement was reached here yesterday by representatives of the Navy Department and the Building Trades and Construction Trades Council.

CHICAGO, July 27 -- Representatives of the Inland Steel Company and the C.I.O. United Steel Workers of America resumed contract negotiations today at the company's office at Indiana Harbor, Ind. It was the first meeting since January, when negotiations were broken off.
ALBANY, July 27 -- Queen Wilhelmina of The Netherlands was the guest today of the capital of New York, a city rich in Dutch tradition.

Japan's Prime Minister, General Hideki Tojo, told an audience of 20,000 persons at Osaka yesterday that "Japan is determined to destroy the United States and Great Britain," the Transocean [German] News Agency reported in a Tokyo dispatch broadcast by the Berlin radio and recorded by The Associated Press.

SYDNEY, Australia, July 27 (AP) -- Silver Stars have been awarded to men of the United States Navy who helped bring General Douglas MacArthur from the Philippines and who rescued nurses and Army and Navy officers from Corregidor.

The Atlantic Refining Company yesterday announced that it has discovered a new chemical manufacturing process which may be employed to speed up substantially the government's program for the production of synthetic rubber. The product of the new process, Robert H. Colley, president, is ethyl benzene, an intermediate in the production of styrene, one of the two principal ingredients of the Buna S-type of synthetic rubber.
MOSCOW, Tuesday, July 28 (AP) -- The Russians issued this communique today:

John Bubak, who helped a friend haul a body through the streets on July 15 without a license, was sentenced yesterday to a year in prison. The friend, John O'Brien, received a two-year probation in custody of his sister, Mrs. Grace McArdle of 96-14 Avenue M, Brooklyn.

LONDON, July 27 -- Too much talk of Allied offensive action in Western Europe without deeds to back it up is wearing thin the nerves of the French people in the occupied zone, according to Andre Philip, member of the Chamber of Deputies for Lyon, who has just arrived here to serve with General Charles de Gaulle, leader of the Fighting French, after two years encouraging resistance within France.
WASHINGTON, July 27 -- Secretary Morgenthau said today that more than 70 per cent of all radio stations in the country had agreed to sell war bonds directly for the Treasury.

Members of the Association of Stock Exchange Firms are pre-dominantly in favor of the principle of mandatory service fees for customers but are highly "selective" on the charges that should be levied, according to response to a questionnaire addressed last month to 541 member firms.

WASHINGTON, July 27 (U.P.) -- Newspapers and radio commentators who use "punch adjectives" in expanding communiques and war dispatches from foreign correspondents were criticized in a three-and-a-half-hour debate in the Senate today.

King Peter of Yugoslavia visited Police Headquarters yesterday morning. As guest of Commissioner Valentine, he spent two hours inspecting the various bureaus and was an interested spectator at the morning line-up.

A series of violent rainstorms that began early yesterday morning and continued in various parts of the city and suburbs most of the day disrupted commuter service between Westchester and Manhattan in the early rush hour and led to two deaths in the metropolitan area.

SOMEWHERE IN AUSTRALIA, July 27 -- "One of the members of the crew called out on the interphone that there were pursuit planes on our right," said Captain Maurice Morgan. "I looked over that way and it looked as though the whole Japanese force was having manoeuvres.

Mayor La Guardia modified the vigor of his executive order directing all city employes to have themselves and their families fingerprinted, when he was asked yesterday about resentment against the order on the part of some city employes.

TORONTO, July 27 (Canadian Press) -- Sid Gordon's single with the bases loaded, two out and Jersey City trailing, 2 -- 1, in the ninth inning started the Little Giants on the road to a 5-2 triumph ever Toronto tonight. The victory extended Jersey City's second-place lead over the Maple Leafs to a game and a half.

Chalky Wright will defend his world featherweight boxing championship against Charley (Lulu) Costantino in a fifteen-round bout at Madison Square Garden on Sept. 25, it was announced yesterday by Nat Rogers, matchmaker for the Twentieth Century Sporting Culb.
CHICAGO, July 27 -- The Tam o'Shanter money scramble, better known as the $15,000 golf open, came to an end today like a fantastic nightmare, with Byron Nelson the winner.

WASHINGTON, July 27 -- Consumers should buy fish, poultry and other protein foods in greater abundance during the temporary shortage of beef, veal and pork, the Consumer Division of the Office of Price Administration urged today.

One of our Washington dispatches reports that the Coast Guard is about to set up "a corps of horse marines, mounted guardsmen, to patrol desolate stretches of the coast line." The horse marine, one foot on sea and one on shore, and two on a horse, stirs the curiosity of a learned correspondent.

Despite the fact that production of all electrical appliances has been ended, the electrical manufacturing industry this year will surpass in 1941 record output of $4,000,000,000, according to unofficial estimates yesterday. The increase will run at least 10 to 20 per cent ahead of 1941, it was said.

WASHINGTON, July 27 - Enactment of legislation to assure a single international telegraph communication system is a necessity, James Lawrence Fly, chairman of the Federal Communications Commission, declared today, thus emphasizing his advocacy of this program despite the opposition of certain unnamed high Navy officials.

WASHINGTON, July 27 -- Secretary of State Cordell Hull was not prepared to comment at his press conference today on the reports of Japanese mistreatment of Americans as sent from Portuguese East Africa, where returning Americans are transshipping for the United States.
SOMEWHERE IN AUSTRALIA, July 25 (Delayed) -- Americans at an advance air base are greatly interested in the peculiar speech of those Australian aborigines who use pidgin English.

LONDON, Tuesday, July 28 -For fifty minutes Sunday night British bombers to the number of about 600 dumped fire and explosives on Hamburg, Germany's largest port and most heavily defended submarine building center.

CHICAGO, July 27 -- Cook County's six major governments reduced their total debts by more than $39,000,000 in the year ended June 30, a compilation of the quarterly statements showed today. The governments are the city of Chicago, the school board, the park district, the sanitary district, the county, and the forest preserves.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., July 27 (AP) -- Collecting three home runs among a dozen hits off Ira Hutchinson, the pace-setting Newark Bears defeated Rochester tonight, 8 to 0. George Washburn scored the shutout.

To his ever increasing schedule Max Gordon, who is expected here from the Coast on Thursday, has added another important item. He has acquired the dramatic rights to "Old Soldiers Never Die," a British wartime novel by the Scottish author, James Ronald, now residing in Connecticut. Mr. Ronald will dramatize it too, and if all goes well, the production should reach the boards by Thanksgiving.

Out of the refreshed terrain of the Polo Grounds and Ebbets Field a pair of double-headers bloomed for today, with the Cubs as the Giants' opponents and the pennant-aspiring Cardinals facing the league-leading Dodgers.

RALEIGH, N.C., July 27 (AP) -Herman Hickman, line coach at North Carolina State College and former guard at the University of Tennessee, has been selected by the War Department as line coach for the Army's eastern All-Star football team.

CAMDEN, N.J., July 27 (AP) -Brad Brodsky's Blenweed made it two victories in a row, while the Christiana Stable's Zacorel, the favorite, broke down nearing the sixteenth pole in the feature race at Garden State Park today.

LONDON, July 27 -- Walter Nash of New Zealand, who has come to London to take part in Cabinet conferences, expressed the opinion today that it would be a huge mistake for the Pacific War Council, Australia, New Zealand, the United Kingdom or any one else to imagine that the wisest procedure at the present time was to do nothing.

With telephone tips on the supposed whereabouts of three German saboteurs coming in to the Federal Bureau of Investigation by the thousand, a new telephone number was set up yesterday for calls of this sort. P.E. Foxworth, assistant FBI director, revealed the number was REctor 2-3533 and he asked that any one with information on any of the three men described last Saturday call that number.
CHICAGO, July 27 (AP) -- The lowly spuds futures market, normally the most docile of all commodities contracts, went on one of its rare rampages on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange today.

Professor Plank in his letter seeks a remedy to alleviate the shortage of engineers. The same shortage obtains with regard to physicists and chemists. Thus, one of our large universities had no more than a dozen young men majoring in physics. Despite this no steps have been taken by the authorities to develop this part of our national asset.

WASHINGTON, July 27 -- Asserting that Hitler had made good his threat to cut the supply lines of the United Nations and that it was "utter folly" for the United States to try to build ships faster than the U-boats could sink them, Senator Lee of Oklahoma introduced a bill today to provide for the construction of a large fleet of transatlantic air freighters.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., July 27 -- A lecture on "Victory Through Air Power" will be given here under the auspices of the Schola Cantorum of New York on the night of Aug. 14 by Major Alexander P. de Seversky, aviation expert and author. Part of the proceeds will be donated to the British War Relief Society and to the American Hospital in Britain, surgical dressings unit, Base Hospital No. 1.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 27 -Columbia today acquired screen rights to the radio program "Crime Doctor" by Max Marcin, and signed Warner Baxter to star in two films a year to be based on the air show. Ralph Cohn will produce the "Crime Doctor" pictures, and the studio has engaged Graham Baker, formerly an RKO producer, to write the scenario for the first of the series.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 27 -- accused of exacting an automobile valued at $950 from Tony Martin, radio and screen singer, as a "fee" for "facilitating his enlistment" as a chief specialist in the naval reserve, Lieut. Comdr. Maurice N. Aroff went on trial today at a general court-martial, a rare experience for a naval officer.

Louis Stark reports from Washington that the President is considering naming Governor Lehman as "supreme Federal arbiter on wages." In this case Mr. Lehman "would be ensconced in the Labor Department, 'above the battle,'" and "entrusted with the task of bringing order out of the conflicting views on wages now held by various Government agencies."
LONDON, July 27 (AP) -- The Air Ministry issued this communique today:

LOURENCO MARQUES, Portuguese East Africa, July 27 -- The diplomatic evacuation ship Gripsholm is scheduled to sail at 7 A.M. tomorrow for New York, via Rio de Janeiro, with the 1,525 Americans and other anti-Axis nationals from the Far East who were transferred to her here.

Replying to criticism voiced by Oscar F. Soule, Onondaga County Rationing Board chairman, of "lack of support from the Washington office," Lee S. Buckingham, State OPA director, asserted yesterday that OPA officials had spent much time recently "planning additional improvements for the operation of local boards."

WASHINGTON, July 27 -- President Roosevelt was reported today to have requested Supreme Court Justice Samuel I. Rosenman of New York to examine the wage-policy proposals now in the hands of administration officials in order to supply him with data on methods of coping with the situation.

While the new rationing program involving State-owned automobiles will hamper the work of many departments, New York conservation leaders intend to make every effort to maintain the essential activities of the Fish and Game Division in behalf of wildlife management.

WASHINGTON, July 27 -- The National War Labor Board refused today to give a general wage increase to 1,200 employes of the Remington-Rand Company and in doing so applied the wage stabilization formula used in the recent "little steel" case.

WASHINGTON, July 27 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in 101 leading cities shows the following principal changes for the week ended July 22, according to the Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System today.

The eleventh bi-weekly collection of salvaged tin cans will be made by Sanitation Department trucks tomorrow and Thursday, it was announced yesterday by Clarence H. Low, chairman of the New York City Salvage Committee.

Depositories of government funds were again called upon by the Treasury yesterday to repay to it on July 30 and July 31 a total of $214,484,000, representing 10 per cent of the government's deposits in all depository banks as of July 25, less the amount of the call which was payable yesterday. One-half
LONDON, July 27 -- A restraining influence was placed on the stock market today by the news from Russia. All sections where prices were changed showed fractional declines.

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., July 27 (AP) -- Racial issues, raised both by a Negro organization and a Congressional candidate, overshadow other issues in tomorrow's biennial State-wide Democratic preferential primary election.

WASHINGTON, July 27 -- The trail of a shortage of aircraft steel -- threatening to cause and continue occasional shutdowns of production plants -- which seemed last week to lead to the door of the Army and Navy Munitions Board, when further pursued doubles back to the War Production Board itself and to those responsible for policy commitments of raw materials.
LONDON, July 27 (U.P.) -- Guerrilla warfare against the Axis was reported tonight in five European countries -- Yugoslavia, Greece, Rumania, Albania and Poland.

WASHINGTON, July 27 -- This government will finance the building of 625 miles of "all-weather pioneer road" from the southern border of Mexico to Panama in a move to increase trade with the Central American republics.
CINCINNATI, July 27 (AP) -- Bad news developed for critics of overemphasized football today.

Smart furs in jackets, three-quarter length and full length coats were paraded yesterday at the formal opening of the newly enlarged budget shop at Gunther, 666 Fifth Avenue, which now holds sway on an entire floor.

The death of Roger B. Whitman, conductor of the daily column in The New York Sun which was called "First Aid for the Ailing House," will be regretted by many home owners. He had for some years been a counselor to whom they turned for advice on knotty problems, and his book of the same title as his column was their uniquely useful bible when something needed fixing, which is practically always.

WASHINGTON, July 27 -- Disregarding Secretary Morgenthau's plea for action against two "special privileges, the Senate Finance Committee today rejected his recommendations for mandatory joint income returns and the taxation of income from outstanding issues of State and municipal securities.

LOURENCO MARQUES, Portuguese East Africa, July 24 (Delayed) -- Still maintaining their traditional "so-sorry-for-you-but-we-need-this" attitude, the Japanese have steadily tightened their grip on Shanghai's historic International Settlement.

WASHINGTON, July 27 (AP) -- Behind closed doors, the Senate Naval Committee approved today a $974,634,000 naval expansion program which contemplates a $30,000,000 expenditure for secret training and a mysterious new weapon.

ALBANY, July 27 -- Clergymen of St. Andrews Liberal Episcopal Church in New York City are entitled to perform the marriage ceremony, and Chapter 579 of the laws of this year, sponsored by Senator Buckley, is unconstitutional, Attorney General Bennett today advised A.C. Stuart Williams, counsel for the church.

A refunding program by Nassau County will get under way today when Lehman Brothers and the Chase National Bank, as refunding agents, offer to holders of certain outstanding bonds of the county, maturing between 1943 and 1947, to exchange them for a new issue of $5,660,000 of refunding bonds, maturing from 1951 to 1960.

To Quisling and his employers the system was ideal, and they immediately took steps to put Nazi appointees and Nazi ideas in control.

Frances Morehouse wrote a letter, published July 20, which accused American radio of denying that we are in total war. This is a gross misstatement about the war work of American broadcasters in general, and on behalf of the Columbia Broadcasting System in particular we wish to point out that the statement is based on ignorance.

Gross income of the Phillips Petroleum Company and its subsidiaries increased to $69,403,336 in the six months ended with June from $62,431,726 for the first half of last year, according to the semi-annual statement issued for release today.

The death of Roger B. Whitman, conductor of the daily column in The New York Sun which was called "First Aid for the Ailing House," will be regretted by many home owners. He had for some years been a counselor to whom they turned for advice on knotty problems, and his book of the same title as his column was their uniquely useful bible when something needed fixing, which is practically always.

WASHINGTON, July 27 -- Disregarding Secretary Morgenthau's plea for action against two "special privileges, the Senate Finance Committee today rejected his recommendations for mandatory joint income returns and the taxation of income from outstanding issues of State and municipal securities.

SOMEWHERE IN AUSTRALIA, July 27 (AP) -- Five United States naval officers who escaped from the Philippines in a primitive native outrigger sailing boat just a step ahead of the Japanese have arrived in Australia after an adventurous three-month journey.

Frances Morehouse wrote a letter, published July 20, which accused American radio of denying that we are in total war. Gross income of the Phillips Petroleum Company and its subsidiaries increased to $69,403,336 in the six months ended with June from $62,431,726 for the first half of last year, according to the semi-annual statement issued for release today.

CHICAGO, July 27 (A.P.) -- Making further readjustments to the new price scale for lease-lend pork, hogs dropped 25 to 35 cents today. Top price declined, to $14.55 a hundred pounds, fully 60 cents under the 22-Year peak reached last Tuesday. Since Thursday, hog values have slumped drastically and are now the lowest in a month.

ALMOST every subscriber must have heard of the double-barreled All-Army football team that is being mustered to play seven or eight games in different sectors with National League professional teams for the benefit of the Army Emergency Relief. Colonel Bob Neyland, who used to tutor Tennessee in gridiron strategy, and Major Wallace Wade, former football boss at Duke, are the Army officers who are in the throes of gathering this All-Army football team.
WASHINGTON, July 27 -- Congress went into an unofficial recess today and is not expected to take up any major legislation until September.

WASHINGTON, July 27 (AP) -- The United States has agreed to ease Chile's acute petroleum shortage as soon as possible, Ambassador Rodolfo Michels said today after conferring with Secretary of State Cordell Hull and Under-Secretary Sumner Welles for an hour and a half.

Messages sent yaterday from the semi-annual meeting of the national council of the National Maritime Union to President Roosevelt and Prime Minister Churchill urged immediate opening of a second front.

OTTAWA, July 27 -- The ordinarily very quiet proceedings of the House of Commons were disturbed this morning during the debate on the Hong Kong report when an incident arose between the Prime Minister, W.L. Mackenzie King, and some members of the Conservative Opposition.

CLEVELAND, July 27 (AP) -- The Red Sox clung to second place in the American League today, tallying four runs in the last two innings to turn back the threatening Indians, 8 to 5, in the opener of a four-game series.

AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, Australia, Tuesday, July 28 -- Allied patrols have made contact with Japanese forces near Oivi, fifty-five miles inland from Japanese-held Gona Mission on the northeast coast of New Guinea, where Allied bombers have blown up an ammunition dump in a new raid, a United Nations communique disclosed today.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., July 27 -- Led by Ted Schroeder of Glendale, Calif., and Francisco (Pancho) Segura of Ecuador, a dozen of the leading available players of the country will start out tomorrow in the fifty-third Southampton invitation tennis tournament at the Meadow Club.
VALLETTA, Malta, July 27 (AP) -- The following British communique was issued today:

August sales events are getting off to a mixed start, according to comment in the wholesale markets here yesterday based on orders and reorders received from retailers. As was expected, stores in the industrial areas are faring best. Elsewhere, trade results are spotty and tending to run under the peak volume figures of July and August last year.

Except for the heightened demand in the railroad section, trading was dull yesterday in the stock market and only the semblance of a recovery tone was in evidence. Prices moved up to their tops for the session during the noon hour, but later in the afternoon the list turned ragged and the close showed mixed tendencies.

WASHINGTON, July 27 -- The War Production Board today issued an order providing for the allocation of viscose rayon staple fibre to wool manufacturers. Rayon allocation is now made under the wool conservation order M-73 but after Oct. 1, the allocation will be handled under a separate order, M-176, issued today.

At a time when this country is organizing on an increasing scale a volunteer land army of city girls to be sent wherever there is need for farm help, a publisher has appeared with a volume of experiences of an English "farmer's girl."

WASHINGTON, July 27 -- A history-making special session of the Supreme Court will be held on Wednesday to consider whether the highest tribunal shall receive petitions to file writs of habeas corpus from the eight Nazi saboteurs now on trial before a military commission.

Objections to the probate of the will of Charles H. Hastings, disposing of the fortune he inherited from his father, a California "Forty-niner," have been filed by his 90-year-old cousin, Mrs. Ida A. Cargill of Glendale, Calif., and three other distributees of his estate.

Net sales of the General Motors Corporation in the second quarter of this year amounted to $437,991,168, a decline of 36 per cent from the $669,898,241 reported the year before, according to a report yesterday. Net profit was $24,613,218, against $53,579,568, a decline of 54 per cent, reflecting the change from automobile production last year to munitions production in 1942.

Mayor La Guardia opened a fingerprinting unit of the War Emergency Identification Bureau of the Greater New York City Civilian Defense Volunteer Office yesterday afternoon in a show window of R.H. Macy Co.

We need all the rubber that we can make without unnecessary delay. Nevertheless the Gillette committee has introduced a bill which would create an entirely separate and unnecessary agency for the conversion of grain-alcohol into rubber, hamstring WPB and make it difficult to administer priorities rationally.

CHICAGO, July 27 (AP) -- Midwestern players were chosen today to fill nine of the eleven starting positions in the collegiate all-star football line-up that will oppose the Chicago Bears, national pro champions, at Soldier Field, Chicago, Aug. 28.

WASHINGTON, July 27 -- The President's Committee on War Relief Activities, under the chairmanship of former Ambassador Joseph E. Davies, was reconstituted by President Roosevelt today in an executive order as the President's War Relief Control Board.

LONDON, July 27 (U.P.) -- British Government leaders, convinced that ships are not available for large invasion forces, seem anxious to stem the mounting public clamor for a second front in Europe this year, well-informed persons said today.

WASHINGTON, July 27 -- To facilitate the conversion of oil-burning heating equipment on the East Coast to coal because of the expected oil shortage this Winter, the Federal Reserve Boar liberalized credit restrictions today.
PHILADELPHIA, July 28 (AP) -Johnny Vander Meer, Eric Tipton, Dick West and Ray Starr specialized in one-man shows today as they led the Reds to twin victories over the Phils, 8 -- 1 and 3 -- 1.

INDIANAPOLIS, July 28 -- A jury was obtained in ninety minutes as the sedition trial of William Dudley Pelley, former leader of the Silver Shirts of America, opened in the United States district court here today before Judge Robert C. Baltzell.

Gasoline rationing and the rubber shortage caught up with the rollerskating brigade yesterday morning when boys and girls in the Summer play schools, who were "at home" to visitors, discovered that their guests were fewer than had been expected.

LONDON, July 28 (AP) -- Britain's new secret anti-aircraft guns had their first real test last night. Birmingham was the principal target of the German raiders, but other points in the Midlands, the eastern counties and the Greater London district got their share of enemy attention.

Leaders in the welfare field appealed yesterday for additional child care as an important factor in the war, at the opening of a campaign sponsored by the New York City Committee on Child Welfare of the State Charities Aid Association to increase the availability of foster homes.

LOURENCO MARQUES, Portuguese East Africa, July 27 (Delayed) -- American civilians who were arrested and detained in Japanese-occupied territories and are now being repatriated are still speculating about the reasons for their arrests and the basis of the espionage charges generally lodged against them.
LONDON, July 28 -- Post-war problems, especially that of employment in national reconstruction, were discussed by three speakers in London today.

CHICAGO, July 28 -- With a heavy undertone prevailing in the wheat market, anti-inflation talk, unfavorable war news and the early break in cotton induced professional traders to take the selling side at the start today. Houses with Southwestern connections also were sellers, presumably in the way of spreading with Kansas City as the latter showed relative strength.

WASHINGTON, July 28 -- In a brief statement on the meat shortage President Roosevelt disclosed today that there were already 4,000,000 men in the armed services. The President explained that abnormally large meat supplies were required for this force and to provide supplies for overseas units.

MAMARONECK, N.Y., July 28 -- Just when it seemed that two Long Islanders, Roy M. Ward of Bethpage and Mal Galletta of North Hills, were about to share honors in the annual William Henry Beers Memorial tourney today at Winged Foot, along came Pat Gavin of the Hickory Club to repel the invaders.

WASHINGTON, July 28 (U.P.) -- The War Labor Board warned the American Federation of Labor and the Congress of Industrial Organizations tonight that if they failed to settle a jurisdictional dispute at the General Motors Corporation's Frigidaire division, Dayton, Ohio, by 10 A.M. tomorrow it would appoint an arbitrator whose decision would be final and binding.

CHICAGO, July 28 (AP) -- The market for hogs steadied today after yesterday's sharp decline, associated with adjustment to the new price scale for lease-lend pork, and prices improved much as 10 cents a hundred weight, principally for weighty butchers and sows.

Representative Martin Dies of Texas, chairman of the House Committee on Un-American Activities, was accused last night of maintaining "an agency of civil political war" and creating "an American political police" at a meeting of the Union for Democratic Action in the Hotel Astor.
