Mrs. Inez Cheyne, 44 years old, a widow, who lives at 201 St. James Place, Brooklyn, and John Carl Borrs, 36, a German, who took out his first citizenship papers some time ago and gave his home address as 269 Henry Street, Brooklyn, were held in $5,000 bail each in the Felony Court yesterday for a hearing next Wednesday in a series of alleged frauds on the Provident Loan Society.

CHUNGKING, July 28 (U.P.) -- Free China's confidence in the United States Army Air Force was further strengthened today as observers, both Chinese and American, called the futile Japanese raid against the capital last night "an unprecedented disgrace" for the Japanese.

Several paintings, newly acquired or secured on the basis of extended loan, were placed on view yesterday at the Museum of Modern Art, 11 West Fifty-third Street. They are not shown as a group, but have been distributed through the galleries on the third floor.

Joseph T. Sharkey, vice chairman of the City Council, announced yesterday that the Council would hold a special meeting in City Hall on Tuesday afternoon to introduce Mayor La Guardia's amendments to the McCarthy Salary Increment Law, which are designed to sidestep payment by the city of $1,000,000 in back pay and salary increments granted under a recent Court of Appeals decision.

CHICAGO, July 28 (AP) -- Elmer Layden, commissioner of the National Football League, today named a staff of twenty officials to handle professional games this Fall and revealed that the veteran Red Friesell would not be on the whistle line.

WASHINGTON, July 28 -- Secretary Stimson was accused today by Representative John W. McCormack, majority leader, of injecting himself into Massachusetts politics with his letter to Senator Lodge upon the latter's recent return from a mission in Libya as an Army major.

WASHINGTON, July 28 -- The echoes of centuries of Anglo-Saxon struggle for civil liberties, from Magna Charta onward, will be heard in the Supreme Court chamber tomorrow when the justices will be asked to decide whether they will entertain habeas corpus pleas from seven of the eight defendants charged with sabotage and now on trial before a Military Commission, appointed by the President and headed by Major Gen. Frank McCoy.

Rather than impose the kind of taxation that is really necessary, many members of the Administration or of Congress seem willing to take the risk, if not to accept the certainty, of inflation. Such a choice can be approved, however, only by those who still do not understand the nature of inflation.

When Constance Rourke, biographer of Audubon and author of other books on our American past, died in 1941 she left a "great mass" of incomplete manuscript and notes for an ambitious history of American culture. These Van Wyck Brooks has worked over, and while he confesses that what he has been able to draw together is necessarily fragmentary, many of Miss Rourke's intended subjects are covered.

CHICAGO, July 28 -- Buying at the monthly Chicago Shoe Fair held by the Shoe Travelers Association of Chicago was limited to women's novelty lines and play shoes for early Fall showing and to slippers for holiday trade, with less than the normal fill-in business on Summer goods developing.

CHICAGO, July 28 -- Although scarcely designed as a paradise for home run clouters, Comiskey Park offered no serious obstables to the Yankees today. The world champions blasted no fewer than three circuit blows into the distant stands, which measure anywhere from 352 to 440 feet away from home plate, and on the wings of these three shots the aYnkees went soaring off to an 8-to-3 victory over the White Sox.
LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Wednesday, July 29 (AP) -- A run-off in the Senate race was indicated today on the basis of reports from yesterday's Democratic primary.

Even a culinary cloud can have a silver lining. For if the butcher looks upon the world with melancholy eye these days -- and parts reluctantly with pork chop or steak -- the fishmonger's face is wreathed in smiles. And that fine source of protein that swims in the sea is enjoying a sudden, salutary popularity -- even to the political favor of the Mayor of New York!

LONDON, July 28 -- Surreptitious listeners in Germany tonight heard the voice of Air Marshal Sir Arthur T. Harris -- the man who sends British bombers against the enemy -- warning them that they had no chance against the combined might of the Royal Air Force and the United States Army Air Forces save to overthrow Reichsfuehrer Hitler and the Nazis and make a just peace with the United Nations.

MOSCOW, July 28 -- Russian reports concede that the Germans, greatly superior in strength, have advanced beyond Rostov and that the retreating garrison, after a stubborn four-day defense of the city, is fighting severe battles in the most difficult circumstances.

A production program of forty-five feature pictures and 185 short subjects for the 1942-43 season was announced yesterday by Ned E. Depinet, president of RKO Radio Pictures, at the company's eleventh annual sales convention at the Waldorf-Astoria.

I cannot agree with your editorial of July 25, "Anniversary in Vienna." There you stated that the assassination of Chancellor Dollfuss by the Nazis eight years ago "marked the beginning of the end of a free Austria."

Earnings of the United States Steel Corporation for the first half of 1942 show more graphically than any mere discussions what taxes are doing to stockholders. Earnings before taxes were 42.3 percent higher than in the first half of 1941.

Mrs. Mortimer H. Hess, vice chairman of the woman's division of the New York City Salvage Committee, issued a call yesterday for volunteers to spur the government's program of salvaging waste kitchen fats for use in explosives. The committee's ultimate goal, she explained, is the establishment of the block captain system for this section of the salvage campaign.

CLEVELAND, July 28 (AP) -- Ulysses Lupien's base-cleaning double with the bags filled in the second inning gave the Red Sox a 3-to-1 victory over the Indians tonight and stretched Boston's hold on second place to two games.
The following German High Command communique was broadcast from Berlin and was recorded here by The Associated Press:

WASHINGTON, July 28 -- The Supreme Court will meet tomorrow in an unprecedented special session to determine whether seven of the eight Nazi saboteurs have any legal avenue of escape from their trial by the Military Commission, which has authority to order them put to death.

The three-story apartment house Ion a plot 38 by 100 feet at 32-56 i Eighty first Street, Jackson Heights, Queens, has been sold by Mary K. Miller to an investing client through James C. McCormick, Inc. It contains twelve suites and is assessed for $30,000.

WASHINGTON, July 28 (AP) -- Leaders of the Congress of Industrial Organizations and spokesmen for the Aluminum Company of America urged the War Labor Board today to act quickly on dispute over wages and organization, but they disagreed sharply on what the decision ought to be.

MOSCOW, Wednesday, July 29 -- German troops pouring into the Caucasus have made another crossing of the lower Don at Tsimlyansk and have reached Bataisk, fifteen miles south of Rostov, in their attempt to cut the Stalingrad-North Caucasian Railroad, the Russians announced early today.

Using a strong left hand to good advantage, Jackie Cooper, 148 pounds, of Chicago, outpointed Pete De Ruzza, 151, Mamaroneck, in the star bout of eight rounds before 3,000 fans at the Queensboro Arena last night. The only knockdown came in the fourth, when Cooper was dropped for no count.

LONDON, Wednesday, July 29 -- The German Air Force undertook on Monday night its heaviest attack on Britain in many weeks. The greatest force of the German raids was directed at the Birmingham section, but marauders also were over the London area, where they were met by fire from new anti-aircraft guns operated by mixed crews of men and women.

Escaping from France to England, Mr. Andre Philip, member of the Chamber of Deputies for Lyon, brings the United Nations both an encouragement and a warning. Encouraging is his assurance that the French people will rise up to aid us in the event of our opening a second front.

LONDON, July 28 (U.P.) -- Sixteen battalions of Yugoslav guerrillas have driven Italian occupation forces from most of the former province of Bosnia and have forced authorities to declare a state of siege in the district of Zagreb, capital of the Axis puppet State of Croatia, reports reaching London asserted tonight.

Serge Rubinstein, managing director of the Chosen Corporation, and Henry W. Wilson, president of the Panhandle Producing and Refining Company, have acquired more than 22 per cent of the outstanding stock of the latter company, according to an announcement yesterday by Mr. Wilson.

Most cotton traders apparently preferred yesterday to mark time until the government released the July 15 parity prices on agricultural commodities and outlined more definitely the character of the new loan program of the Commodity Credit Corporation. However, there was just sufficient buying support from the trade in the cotton market late yesterday to rally prices to levels near the previous close.

CHUNGKING, China, July 28 -- Japan's Lieut. Gen. Tomoyuki Yamashita, who led the conquest of Malaya and Singapore, has arrived with his troops in Manchukuo, within striking distance of the Siberian border, the Korean Provisional Government here reported today.

WASHINGTON, :July 2S -- Strict curtailment in the use of heating oil and gasoline this Winter in the Atlantic Seaboard States was foreI cast as a necessity today by Jubal R. Parten, director of the transI portation division of the Office of Petroleum Coordinator.

OTTAWA, July 28 -- The debate in the House of Commons on the findings of the Royal Commission on the Hong Kong expedition, in which about 2,000 Canadian soldiers were killed or taken prisoner, ended this evening with the rejection, by 130 to 34 votes, of the Opposition amendment calling for the complete reorganization of the Department of National Defense.

WESTBURY, L.I., July 28 (AP) -- A sailor and a soldier were among the four persons who correctly coupled Pine Ridge Beverly with Fortune in the first two races today at the Roosevelt Raceway trotting program and received $360.80 each in the daily double.

Mrs. Walter Douglas, honorary vice president of the New York Division of the Woman's National Farm and Garden Association, Inc., gave a luncheon yesterday at the Hotel Weylin in connection with the two-day Farm and Garden Shop sale which closes today in the Regence Room there.

TORONTO, July 28 (Canadian Press) -- Big Jack Hallett held Jersey City to six hits tonight, struck out thirteen and pitched Toronto to a 3-1 triumph. The victory left the Maple Leafs half a game behind the second-place Little Giants.

WASHINGTON, July 28 -- Several hundred business firms have been warned by the War Production Board that if they do not voluntarily sell some of their typewriters for the use of the armed services the machines will have to be requisitioned.

LONDON, July 28 (U.P.) -- The Daily Telegraph, which often reflects the views of Prime Minister Churchill, took the lead today in a press campaign to tone down public clamor for an immediate second front by warning that there must be "some reasonable chance of success" before Europe can be invaded.

Volume on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday held even at the laggard pace of Monday and totaled 264,940 shares, against 259,530. Stocks drifted irregularly and closed dull and mixed, with 190 of the 589 issues rising, 112 falling and 217 making no change.

One of the problems that must be faced in world-wide post-war reconstruction is the management of international systems of communication. Radio and wire telegraphy and telephony have removed the barriers once interposed by oceans and continents. But the various systems of international communication are generally in the hands of governments abroad and of privately owned companies here.

Three members of the old Lepke-Gurrah gang were convicted quickly yesterday in General Sessions Court for the murder thirteen years ago of Hyman Leder, a pocketbook manufacturer. Leder was slain with a piece of iron pipe in front of his plant at 12 West Twenty-first Street, because he resisted the demands of gangsters then in control of a union.

German forces driving into the Caucasus have widened and deepened their penetration south of the Don and have reached or crossed the river along virtually the whole curving front of the big Don bend, the High Command said yesterday, according to Berlin broadcasts recorded by The Associated Press.

The Senate Finance Committee has made two eminently proper decisions in rejecting the Treasury's proposal for mandatory joint income returns and for the taxation of income from outstanding issues of State and municipal securities. Both proposals are bad in principle, despite the Treasury's frequent insistence that they are needed to close "loopholes" and put an end to "special privileges."

Organization of a nation-wide drive during August to rally the fullest support of retailers and the consuming public for the government's maximum price regulations was revealed yesterday by Lew Hahn, general manager of the National Retail Dry Goods Association.

The semi-annual statement of the Celanese Corporation of America, sent yesterday to stockholders by Dr. Camille Dreyfus, president, showed for the first six months of this year a consolidated net profit of $3,357,820 after provision for Federal taxes on income, compared with $3,149,921 the year before.

The Giants used the bludgeon and the rapier on the Cubs in their double-header before 10,805 at the Polo Grounds yesterday and the Bruins were so bewildered by the tactical changes that they dropped both ends of the twin bill. The New Yorkers hammered the first one loose from the Chicagoans with seventeen hits for a 9-5 victory and pried loose the second with four safeties, 3 to 0.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 28 -- Lieut. Comdr. Maurice N. Aroff, assistant in the Office of Naval Officer Procurement for the Twelfth Naval District, once refused an automobile as a gift from Tony Martin, radio and film singer, defense counsel declared today at the conclusion of a session of Aroff's trial by general court- martial.

BERNE, Switzerland, July 28 -- Twenty-eight more Frenchmen have been sentenced to death by German military courts and executed. This news is made known in a brief dispatch issued by the Vichy news agency.
MOSCOW, Wednesday, July 29 (AP) -- The Soviet midnight communique said:

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 28 -- Gene Kelly, Broadway dancer, whom Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer brought to the Coast in February, will play the male lead opposite Lana Turner in "Nothing Ventured," a story by Ian McLellan Hunter and Aileen Hamilton, which will go before the cameras next month.
PHILADELPHIA, July 28 (UP) -- The May Department Stores Company paid its officers almost a million dollars in salaries and bonuses in 1941, the Securities and Exchange Commission reported today.

The report of the Consolidated Edison Company of New York and subsidiaries for the twelve months ended on June 30, issued yesterday by Floyd L. Carlisle, chairman, shows a consolidated net income after all expenses and other charges, of $30,398,845.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., July 28 -- Famous Victory, an Irish-bred colt, was a galloping winner on a heavy track today as wagering and attendance fell to new lows for this State since it has had the mutuel form of betting. With only 3,241 present, the betting on the seven races and daily double reached $177,408.
MOSCOW, July 28 (AP) -- The Soviet Information Bureau issued this communique today:

The one-story garage building containing about 1,000 square feet on the northwest corner of 160th Street and Park Avenue, the Bronx, has been sold by the New York Trust Company to the Randall Commercial Body, Inc., through Samuel Levy. It is assessed for $22,000.

Mayor La Guardia, seated at a sewing machine, put the first stitches yesterday morning in the first of 50,000 fur-lined vests to be donated to the merchant seamen by workers of the fur industry. Before he got the machine to running the Mayor blew a fuse, but the power was soon restored.

Blue stamp foods listed for August by the Agricultural Marketing Administration and announced yesterday by Frank J. Brechenser, assistant regional director, include a number of fresh fruits and all fresh vegetables, thus offering a healthful and varied hot weather diet.

ST. LOUIS, July 28 (AP) -- It took just a single inning -- in which the opposition counted five times on two hits -- to cool the fevered Browns tonight and let the Senators achieve a 9-to-4 triumph in a twilight battle. Harlond Clift hit his sixth home run of the season in the eighth inning.

CHICAGO, July 28 -- Retailers and wholesalers here, following conferences with War Production Board representatives today and yesterday on the question of inventory restrictions, said they have come away from the individual interviews with the belief that inventory control is inevitable.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., July 28 -- Visitors here for the racing season are already showing activity in the community's war work. Saturday will be Russian War Relief Day. Mrs. John A. Slade will be chairman for the event and Mrs. Marjorie Peabody Waite and Mrs. Elizabeth Ames co-chairman.

BERNE, Switzerland, July 28 -- A recent brief announcement by the German Government on the liquidation of financial obligations and property rights of the Yugoslav State under an agreement signed in Berlin July 22 by Germany.

Two Chinese fliers who have fought against numerical Japanese superiority in the air since 1937 declared yesterday that with increased aid in planes from the United States the Chinese could "knock hell" out of the Japanese.

WASHINGTON, July 28 -- The American people were urged by President Roosevelt today to cooperate to the utmost in the national scrap salvage campaign because scrap of all sorts is vital to the war effort.

In your editorial of July 21, "Inflationary Taxes," you state "the Treasury declared that it would rather have a bill that was too small than accept the logical alternative, a sales tax. It is a bungled job, for which the House and the Administration must share responsibility."
BAY SHORE, L.I., July 28 -Some members of the Metropolitan Rod and Gun Writers Association who set themselves up as weather prophets received a severe jolt here yesterday.
DOVER, England, July 28 (AP) -- The Germans' big guns on the coast of France between Calais and Boulogne went into action for two hours early tonight.

The role of song in inspiring our armed forces and strengthening the morale of civilians was praised last night by President Roosevelt in a telegram read to a meeting of 300 song writers in the Park Central Hotel. Mr. Roosevelt's message said:

WASHINGTON, July 28 -- The Senate Finance Committee, according to Senator George, its chairman, is giving a good deal of thought to the question of compulsory sales of war bonds and may want to take "very definite action" to decrease the amount that commercial banks will have to absorb in financing the country's $53,000,000,000 deficit for this fiscal year.

What more pleasant responsibility could bring a Congressman to his feet than that of pointing out the high qualifications of his constituents? Representative Plumley, Republican, of Vermont has felt impelled to set at rest what he intimates may be a lack of appreciation of his State's high literacy.

TRENTON, July 28 -- Supreme Court Justice Joseph L. Bodine reserved decision today on the application of Special Assistant Attorney General John Warren for a peremptory writ of mandamus to compel Hague-dominated officials of Hudson County to release county tax records to the members of the new Hudson County Tax Board appointed by Governor Charles Edison, who removed members of the old board last Thursday on charges of dereliction of duty.

WASHINGTON, July 28 -- The Gillette committee, continuing its investigation of the country's synthetic rubber program, heard testimony today that butylene, a refinery gas, was the most desirable base for production of synthetic rubber from oil.

ALLAHABAD, India, July 28 (AP) -- Sir Stafford Cripps was bitterly attacked by two of the top Indian leaders today in the latest round of the fight over the Indian Nationalist resolution proposing withdrawal of British rule from India.

CAIRO, Egypt, July 28 -- Little change appeared likely to be made in the front in El Alamein area as a result of combined attacks by British, Australian and South African units that were still going on last night, it was disclosed today.

Brig. Gen. Thomas W. Darrah, deputy director of the Office of Civilian Defense for this district, declared yesterday that there was no reason for confusion or misunderstanding on how to deal with incendiary bombs.

Bishop William T. Manning officiated yesterday at the dedication of the Civilian Welfare Council's Reconstructive Surgery Ward, first of its kind in the world, at the Manhattan General Hospital, Second Avenue and Seventeenth Street.

Net profit of Loew's, Inc., for the forty weeks ended on June 4 amounted to $7,245,811, against $7,206,466 for the corresponding period ended on June 5, 1941, after increasing its reserve for contingencies by $1,500,000 and reserve for Federal taxes by more than $1,600,000.

WASHINGTON, July 28 -- The Maritime Commission does not intend to rescind or suspend its dropping of the Higgins "assembly line" method of producing cargo carriers, Admiral Emory S. Land, the chairman, indicated today.

WASHINGTON, July 28 -- Elmer Davis, Director of the Office of War Information, urged James C. Petrillo today to withdraw his order that after Aug. 1 members of the American Federation of Musicians must not "play or contract for" any sort of musical recordings or transcriptions.

CHICAGO, July 28 -- Secretary Wickard warned today that consumers might be forced to readjust their eating habits because of the current meat shortage. The record number of pigs on the farms, he said, should remedy the pork shortage, but he was less optimistic over the future of beef supplies.

A split in the "crucial" doubleheader was the best the Cardinals could get yesterday at Ebbets Field and they were thankful for that much. For, in a nerve-racking, weird second-game seventh inning surrounded by lightning, thunder, darkness and the definite threat of rain, it became a farcical race against time, which, eventually, was won by the visitors.

TRENTON. N.J., July 28 -- Charging there existed a conspiracy "to dissolve the company illegally and to dissipate its assets," State Senator John E. Toolan, counsel for a stockholder, today urged Vice Chancellor Wilfred H. Jayne to restrain directors of the Barber Asphalt Corporation of Perth Amboy permanently from completing negotiations for sale of a roofing plant on its sprawling property.

Visiting buyers registered in the market for the week ended yesterday numbered 714, which compared with 1,038 in the preceding week and 810 in the similar period a year ago, according to the listings in THE NEW YORK TIMES. Yesterday's registrations totaled 298 as against 398 for last Tuesday.

National income was $12,000,000,000 greater in 1941 than the previous year, according to a report issued yesterday by the division of industrial economics of the Conference Board. During the year dividend and interest payments dropped $2,500,000,000 behind those in 1929 and were only $431,000,000 higher than the 1940 level, the board said.

WASHINGTON, July 28 -- A maximum work week ceiling of six eight-hour days, or forty-eight hours a week, was proposed for 12,000,000 workers in war plants by eight government agencies today in a joint statement of policy.

HARTFORD, Conn., July 28 -- The trial of the Rev. Kurt E.B. Molzahn, a Lutheran clergyman of Philadelphia, on charges of spying for Germany opened in Federal court here today, and by the time court recessed for the night ten jurors had been selected and there were indications that two more jurors and two alternates would be chosen early tomorrow.

President Roosevelt reaffirmed at his press conference in Washington yesterday his support of Senator James M. Mead for the Democratic nomination for Governor against Attorney General John J. Bennett Jr.

TRENTON, July 28 -- The invitation extended to New York State to join New Jersey and Pennsylvania in a surprise tri- State blackout sometime next month has been declined, according to word received here by Leonard Dreyfuss, director of civilian defense of New Jersey.

WASHINGTON, July 28 -- Concessions designed to relieve certain classes of food distributors of difficulties created for them by price ceiling regulations were granted today by the Office of Price Administration.

The first criminal charge of violation of the rationing laws was handed up here yesterday in the case of a man who at once admitted having sold 30,000 pounds of sugar without receiving ration certificates from the two men who bought it.

The city of Seattle, Wash., announced yesterday that it would enter the market on Aug. 12 with an issue of $7,900,000 of municipal light and power revenue bonds. This issue was originally offered for sale on June 22, but had to be postponed because of priorities on materials required to complete the operation.
THE uses that various sports can be put to in a war are astonishing. The Air Corps, for instance, is looking for skeet shooters now. They have some. They could use more.

WITH BRITISH EIGHTH ARMY IN EGYPT, July 28 -- United Kingdom troops selected to breach the enemy minefields and take objectives in early hours of yesterday morning returned to their base before dawn today. They achieved success by routing the enemy from his positions, inflicting heavy casualties and taking prisoners.

HARTFORD, Conn., July 28 -- William J. Cox was today reinstated as highway commissioner by Governor Hurley, who suspended him nearly six months ago when State Attorney General F.A. Pallotti filed with the Governor charges of misconduct, material neglect of duty and incompetence in the conduct of the highway commissionership.
"Motor mechanic" hands are not confined to men during these war days. More and more women are handling tasks that have placed long magenta fingernails on the casualty list.

WASHINGTON, July 28 -- Permanent gasoline rationing, effective in the Eastern States since Wednesday, will bring a cut of about 10 per cent in the number of automobiles in operation in the rationed area, the Office of Price Administration predicted today.

Harry Bridges, Pacific Coast longshoremen's leader, declared yesterday that the idea of a longshoremen's battalion in the Army to expedite the unloading of war cargo abroad was being carried out rapidly and that recruiting was now going on in West Coast States.

An agreement under which A.F. of L. building trades craftsmen will take over next week from 1,100 WPA workers construction jobs on the Navy's $4,000,000 training school project at Fort Schuyler, the Bronx, was signed yesterday by representatives of the union, the Navy and the WPA.

General 10 per cent pay increases and a $20 weekly minimum wage for some 1,500 home office employes of four major motion-picture companies were established under a contract signed yesterday by the United Office and Professional Workers of America, C.I.O. and the employers.

The Supreme court of the United States will meet in extraordinary session today in order, as Chief Justice Stone announced, "that petitions for writs of habeas corpus on behalf of certain persons now being tried by a military commission appointed by the President may be submitted to it."

More companies with securities listed on the New York Stock Exchange paid dividends in the first half of 1942 than in the first half of 1941, according to an article in The Exchange, official magazine of the institution. Of the dividend-payers, 24.6 per cent reduced their distributions and 25 per cent paid more.

A German broadcast recorded yesterday by The United Press in New York said British forces attacked German and Italian positions near El Alamein during Monday night with "strong infantry and tank formations" but were repelled with counterattacks that inflicted heavy losses upon them.

Arthur Curtiss James, railroad industrialist and philanthropist, who died June 4, 1941, left an estate of $35,525,652 at the time of his death. An accounting filed in Surrogate's Court yesterday covering the period between July 24, 1941, and June 4, 1942, showed that the estate had increased to $37, 304,490 through income and capital increases.

The six-story loft building on a plot 25 by 80 feet at 15 East Seventeenth Street has been sold by Standard Properties, Inc., (Jvseph K. Aniger and Hyman Ratner) to a client of 1Vf. Morgenthau-Seixas !Company, Inc., brokers. Sale was i for cash above a ten-year mortgage of $18,000.

The heat and humidity from which the city has been suffering have exacted an increased death toll for the second consecutive week, according to the vital statistics report released yesterday by Health Commissioner Ernest L. Stebbins.

WILMINGTON, Del., July 28 -- Swooping down out of the sky at more than 100 miles an hour, a single-engine light airplane with a grappling-hook device on the under side of its tail leveled off about twelve feet above du Pont airport today and snatched a glider and its three passengers into the air with less trouble and more certainty than a hawk nails a chicken.
WASHINGTON, July 28 -- The anti-inflation dilemma with respect to wages was the subject of a series of conferences in the White House today.

WASHINGTON, July 28 -- The Office of Price Administration reporting critical sugar shortages in Louisiana and Texas, announced tonight that submarine warfare in the Caribbean and diversion of shipping had caused the outlook for future sugar supplies from Cuba and Puerto Rico to "take a turn for the worse."

CANBERRA, Australia, July 28 -Commenting on Tokyo's claim that five Australian ships have been torpedoed in Australian waters, Prime Minister John Curtin said "What Tokyo says about the war is what the enemy would say. Allied Headquarters tells Australia how the Pacific war is going.

William Griffin, publisher of The New York Enquirer and one of twenty-eight persons indicted in Washington last week for alleged conspiracy to break the morale of the armed forces, has been examined at St. Clare's Hospital by a government physician and today he is to be taken to Federal court, it was learned yesterday.
The Turf Committee of America announced yesterday through The Associated Press that racing's war relief contributions from tracks and individuals have reached $1,162,935.50.

CHUNGKING, China, July 28 (AP) -- The Chinese High Command announced today that the Japanese had been routed in heavy fighting near the Japanese-occupied town of Kiangshan, in Chekiang Province near the Kiangsi border.

ABOARD A UNITED STATES WARSHIP, in the Caribbean Sea on a Recent Date (AP) -- Convoying of merchant ships through the Caribbean is blazing what naval officers believe will be a trail of safety for shipping in that former happy hunting ground for Axis submarines.

The east and west sides of the midtown section shared in the apartment rental activity reported yesterday by brokers. A number of leases were for quarters in the large residential buildings in Park Avenue.

Hitler must be slipping. Every Saturday at noon exactly, the City of New York hands him an invitation to fly over and bomb us with about the most disastrous loss of human life imaginable and he hasn't accepted -- yet.

The four-story building containtng two stores and six apartments at 1434 Bedford Avenue, Brooklyn, has been sold by the Dime Savings Bank to a client for investment through the Charles Partridge Real Estate Company.
The following Italian High Command communique was broadcast from Rome and was recorded here by The Associated Press:
LONDON, July 28 (AP) -- The Air Ministry and the Ministry of Home Security issued this communique today:
QUINCY, Mass., July 28 -- Another formidable warship was launched today. The cruiser Baltimore slipped into the Fore River from her ways at the Bethlehem Steel Company's shipyards.
SALEM, N.H., July 28 (AP) -W.I. Lunt's Blue Booties, with George Hettinger up, popped out of the pack today to win the featured Grafton Claiming Purse at Rockingham Park.

WASHINGTON, July 28 -- The Office of Price Administration today set Up "self-executing" formula for establishing ceiling prices for sellers of new lines of women's, girls' and children's outerwear garments which are not in the same category as the clothing which they delivered during the last selling season and for merchants who were not in business during the last selling season.

LOURENCO MARQUES, Portuguese East Africa, July 24 (Delayed) -- Brig. Gen. James H. Doolittle's raid on Japan provided the thrill of a lifetime for a group of Americans at an internment camp midway between Tokyo and Yokohama.

WASHINGTON, July 28 -- President Roosevelt disclosed today that the chances were that he would veto the bill passed by the Congress to force the War Production Board to share its authority over the synthetic rubber program with an independent agency, created to promote the use of farm and forest products in the manufacture of this vital commodity.
ROCHESTER, July 28 (AP) -- Feasting on inept Rochester pitching, the league-leading Newark Bears swept both ends of a doubleheader from the last place Red Wings tonight, 6 -- 1 and 8 -- 4.

Chungking, which has probably been bombed more times than any spot on earth except Malta, had what a United Press dispatch describes as a three-hour tea party in its air raid shelters on Monday night. For the first time in eleven months a group of Japanese planes set out from Hankow to bomb the Free China capital.

The Peruvian colony and fellow South Americans here celebrated yesterday the 121st anniversary of the independence of Peru with a luncheon and entertainment attended by Farncisco Pardo de Zela, Minister Plenipotentiary of Peru and other officials.

LONDON, July 28 -- A few days ago I took off from the United States. Early yesterday a Savoy chambermaid came in to pull the window curtains. "Sirens wake you, sir?" she wanted to know. I hadn't heard the sirens.

VALLETTA, Malta, July 28 (U.P.) -- Malta's defenders need to bring down sixteen more enemy planes in three days to shatter their monthly record of 154 for April. And at this moment -- 9 A.M. -- it looks as if the anti-aircraft gunners and Spitfire fighter pilots might make it.

The pamphlet report of E.I. du Pont de Nemours Co. for the six months ended on June 30, released for publication today, shows current assets of $250,549,745 and current liabilities of $94,025,288, compared with $319,004.453 and $169,179,521, respectively, on Dec. 31, 1941.

The Nazi tide of conquest had flowed across the Don on a broad front yesterday, had seeped deep into the North Caucasus and had rolled to within fifty miles of Stalingrad, key industrial city on the Volga.

Poles in America and Americans of Polish descent will observe one minute of silence at noon tomorrow as a "solemn protest agnln-qt the unspeakable outrages inflicted on Polish women by the Germans," it was announced yesterday by the Polish Information Center, 151 East Sixty-seventh Street.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., July 28 -- Ted Schroeder of Glendale, Calif., and Ladislav Hecht of Kew Gardens both scored double victories today as the round-robin Southampton invitation tennis tournament started on the Meadow Club turf.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., July 28 -- A large subscription already has been reported for the tennis dance to be held on Saturday night in the Colonial Ballroom and the Japanese Room of the Meadow Club to mark the conclusion of the club's fifty-second annual invitation tennis tournament, which opened today.

Despite a heavy downpour that scattered a crowd of 20,000 on the steps and pavement in front of the Public Library at Fifth Avenue and Forty-second Street, the "Victory party" war bond and stamp sale sponsored by the retailers of New York City last evening proved a great success, with bonds sales of $1,405,000 and stamp sales of $30,000 reported at the close.

A freakish thunderstorm that struck isolated sections of the city yesterday evening, after a hot, humid day, wrecked the orchestra shell, the stage, and four small buildings in the Lewisohn Stadium at 136th Street and Amsterdam Avenue, where ushers and electricians were preparing for a concert by the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra, with Jascha Heifetz as violin soloist.
WASHINGTON, July 28 -- The War Production Board took back today some of the authority which its chief, Donald M. Nelson, had delegated to the Army and Navy Munitions Board.

BOSTON, July 28 (AP) -- After a shut-out pitching performance by Johnny Sain for eight innings, the Braves had to load the bases to squeeze in the winning run in the ninth today to defeat the Pirates, 4 - 3.

So many questions concerning deferment from military service were telephoned or brought personally to Selective Service headquarters in this city yesterday that officials there were constrained to clarify further the clarification orders issued on Monday to all local draft boards, in connection with a new directive dealing with the dependency claims of registrants.

"Pierre of the Plains," Metro's remake of the Edgar Selwyn play, which arrives at Loew's Criterion, is this morning's sole film newcomer. John Carroll, Ruth Hussey and Bruce Cabot head the cast of the action drama, and Evelyn Ankers, Sheldon Leonard, Reginald Owen and Henry Travers appear in supporting roles.

MOSCOW, July 27 (Delayed) -- In some of the darkest days of the war the Moscow Ballet has staged a most brilliant and sparkling new production, the full-length ballet "Don Quixote," by Gorsky, with music by Minkus. "Don Quixote" is an old favorite of the Moscow ballet public, but yesterday's premiere had new dances by Goleizovsky and new, sumptuous settings designed by Zacharow.

The first of a series of noonday concerts was opened yesterday at Bowling Green before a crowd that filled the sidewalks to capacity, and several hundred persons listening from the windows of the neighboring office buildings.

Maxwell Anderson's newest play, "The Eve of St. Mark," will be offered on Broadway by the Playwrights Company, of which Mr. Anderson is a member. This is in addition to forthcoming presentations throughout the country by amateur groups under the aegis of the National Theatre Conference.
CLEVELAND, July 28 (AP) -- The Youngstown Steel Door Company. i maker of railroad freight car doors !and parts, today reported net profit

The United States Steel Corporation did not quite earn its preferred dividend in the second quarter of 1942, reporting yesterday a deficit of 4 cents a share on the common stock for the period. This reflected the need of appropriating from the quarter's earnings $12,819,050 for additional taxes applicable to the first quarter's results.

Herbert Askwith, a member of the voluntary committee in charge of air raid precautions at the Parc Vendome apartment house group in West Fifty-sixth and Fifty-seventh Streets, said yesterday that its four air raid casualty stations were intended merely to supplement and not to replace the city's official stations.

SOMEWHERE IN AUSTRALIA, July 28 -- On the basis of facts that have been published concerning the Japanese thrust from the north coast of Papua, it is apparent at this juncture that the action is chiefly harassing, but there is no doubt it holds dangerous possibilities.

A meeting of stockholders of the Morris Essex Railroad, a subsidiary of the Delaware, Lackawanna Western Railroad, which was called for yesterday to provide for election of a new board of directors, was adjourned until Friday to permit stockholders to examine the proxies submitted at the meeting and the minutes of a meeting of M. directors in February.

Herbert Askwith, a member of the voluntary committee in charge of air raid precautions at the Parc Vendome apartment house group in West Fifty-sixth and Fifty-seventh Streets, said yesterday that its four air raid casualty stations were intended merely to supplement and not to replace the city's official stations.

SOMEWHERE IN AUSTRALIA, July 28 -- On the basis of facts that have been published concerning the Japanese thrust from the north coast of Papua, it is apparent at this juncture that the action is chiefly harassing, but there is no doubt it holds dangerous possibilities.

A meeting of stockholders of the Morris Essex Railroad, a subsidiary of the Delaware, Lackawanna Western Railroad, which was called for yesterday to provide for election of a new board of directors, was adjourned until Friday to permit stockholders to examine the proxies submitted at the meeting and the minutes of a meeting of M. directors in February.

James H. Rand Jr., president of Remington Rand. Inc., said yesterday at the annual meeting here that production in the first quarter of the fiscal year, beginning on April 1, was $15,242,000, an increase of 35 per cent over the 1941 period.
LONDON, July 28 -- The stock market continued quiet today, although a little selling was evident and the tendency was to mark down prices slightly, mainly in the industrial section.

LOURENCO MARQUES, Portuguese East Africa, July 25 (Delayed) -- Well informed foreign observers, here from the Far East, believe that only a military-naval defeat would cause Japan to withdraw from the countries she has invaded and that she plans complete Japanese supremacy, militarily, politically and economically, in all Eastern Asia.

With the nation facing a crisis in the form of shortages created by patent cartels, the time is ripe for freeing industry, from these "indefensible restrictions," Thurman Arnold. Assistant Attorney General, declared last night at a meeting of the American Business Congress in the Hotel Pennsylvania.

WASHINGTON, July 28 -- Elimination of local train services in districts where parallel bus service is reasonably adequate was urged on Public Service Commissions today by Joseph B. Eastman, Director of Defense Transportation.
WASHINGTON, July 29 -- A digest of the government's brief filed with the United States Supreme Court in habeas corpus proceedings for the seven Nazi saboteurs follows:

WASHINGTON, July 29 -- Silver will practically cease to be a precious metal in the old sense of the word after Oct. 1, when its civilian use will be severely restricted to divert it into war production.
CAIRO, Egypt, July 29 -- Carrying out their second heavy raid in two days, bomber planes of the United States Army Air Forces attacked Axis shipping in Suda Bay, Crete, at dusk yesterday.

PITTSBURGH, July 29 -- The Pittsburgh Press, a Scripps-Howard paper, suspended publication late today after its A.F.L. circulation drivers had struck for the third time in six weeks in protest against the dismissal of fourteen drivers.

ALBANY, July 29 -- A war refugee may establish a lien upon the frozen bank account of an alien depositor, the Court of Appeals ruled today. A unanimous decision was given in the ease of Maurice Feuchtwanger, a Jewish refugee from France who instituted an action against the Central Hanover Bank and Trust Company of New York City and the Banque Jordaan, France.

Silk shirts in the last war were considered an index to the economic state of the country. Obviously, that won't be the case now, and we may have to fall back on the sales figures for cigars. These are booming, and in June set a thirteen-year high, with a total of 532,000,000, or 11 per cent higher than a year ago.

WASHINGTON, July 29 -- Philip Murray, president of the Congress of Industrial Organizations, condemned today the House-approved revenue bill on the ground that it followed "a soak-the-poor line throughout," and demanded that the Senate Finance Committee eliminate loopholes which "allow the wealthy to evade their duties to the nation."

In compliance with the Amy's dimout rule, the umpires called the twilight game between the Dodgers and the Cardinals at Ebbets Field exactly at 9:14 o'clock last night. At that point, with one out in the home half of the seventh, the Brooks were in front, 4 -- 3, and that's how it remained.

Medals of valor will be awarded to nine members of the Department of Sanitation and certificates of commendation will be given to 139 members, Commissioner William F. Carey announced yesterday. The presentations will be made by Mayor La Guardia in the Fall at a ceremony at City Hall.

In an auction that lasted more than three hours yesterday afternoon, 493,400 shares of Home Insurance Company capital stock and 800 shares of National Liberty Insurance capital stock were bought in for $14,284,162.50 by the Royal Bank of Canada and the Chase National Bank of New York, each bank acquiring one-half of the shares offered.

MILWAUKEE, July 29 (AP) -- The Allis-Chalmers Manufacturing Company reported today net income for the second quarter of 1942 amounted to $886,389, or 50 cents a share on 1,776,092 common shares. This compared with a first-quarter net of $1,201,096, or 67 1/2 cents a share.

SOMEWHERE IN AUSTRALIA, July 29 (U.P.) -- A furious fifteen-minute fight between a disabled American bomber and a pack of six Japanese Zero fighters was described by Lieutenant Robert Price of IVferidian, Miss., when he landed his bomber safely at its base today.

On the complaint of Benjamin Victor of 725 Southern Boulevard, the Bronx, a war worker, that a burglar alarm which rings nightly is "detrimental to the health by causing a lack of sleep," John Davis, proprietor of the Davis Auto Laundry at 724 Southern Boulevard, was summoned yesterday to Bronx Magistrates Court.

WASHINGTON, July 29 -- To allow the building up of reserve stocks of fuel oil for next Winter's needs, the War Production Board today suspended deliveries from Aug. 3 to Sept. 15 for the operation of heating and cooling equipment in the seventeen East Coast States and the District of Columbia, which are already under gasoline rationing.

A policy of stiffening resistance by women physicians to conciliatory measures put forth by the Surgeon General's office, apparently as a salve for their rejection as members of the Medical Reserve Corps, was indicated yesterday in an admission by Dr. Emily Barringer of New York, who said that she had advised at least temporary refusal in a special instance of the inferior rating offered.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., July 29 -- The four members of the Hague-dominated Hudson County Board of Taxation filed libel and conspiracy suits in the New Jersey Supreme Court today against the seven trustees of the City Affairs Committee of this city, asking an aggregate of $8,400,000 in damages on the ground that the defendants presented "false and malicious" charges resulting in the dismissal of the board by Governor Charles Edison.
DETROIT, July 29 -- Henry Ford will observe his seventy-ninth birthday anniversary tomorrow.

WASHINGTON, July 29 -- The War Shipping Administration stated today that it was prepared to provide open policies of cargo war risk insurance covering imports to the United States. The step, which becomes effective Saturday, was taken to make the automatic coverage readily available to American importers.

DANBURY, Conn., July 29 -- Directors of the Danbury Agricultural Society announced today that the seventy-third annual Danbury Fair, originally scheduled to be held here the first week in October, had been canceled.

PHILADELPHIA, July 29 (AP) -- A minority group of New York stockholders of the Brill Corporation, charging that controlling interests in the company had been acquired by the American Car and Foundry Company "through a fraudulent acquisition of its controlling Stock," asked the Federal district court today to appoint a receiver to conserve Brill assets.

WEST ORANGE, N.J., July 29 -- The mystery of a "subversive" juke box was solved this evening by a "detective" of the Federal Communications Commission, aided by an agent from the Newark office of the Federal Bureau of Investigation.

WITH BRITISH EIGHTH ARMY, July 29 -- One of the features of desert warfare and an inevitable aftermath of any fluid action is that a number of officers and men who are classified as missing or taken prisoner manage to turn up days, perhaps weeks, after their supposed internment.

ABOARD THE LINER GRIPSHOLM, July 28 (Delayed) -- Admiral Kichisaburo Nomura, former Japanese Ambassador to the United States, informally invited Joseph C. Grew, former United States Ambassador to Japan, to a conference while they were at Lourenco Marques, Portuguese East Africa, but Mr. Grew curtly declined the invitation, it was learned today.

A strike of office workers employed in the Warner Brothers home office and New York exchange, 321 West Forty-fourth Street, was called last night by the Motion Picture Office Employes, Local 23,196, A.F. of L., following breakdown in contractual negotiations, according to a union spokesman.

The account of how Japan was driven into war with the United States is one of the most sensational stories in a war in which the sensational has become commonplace. Although told nearly seven months after the event, the report published yesterday from Otto Tolischus, correspondent of THE TIMES in Tokyo when hostilities began, is news of the highest interest and importance.

Securities and Exchange Commission proposals that over-the-counter dealers be made to tell a customer the independent market at the time of a deal recalls the action taken last month by the San Francisco Stock Exchange. It required its members to tell customers how much profit they made in "riskless" dealer transactions in listed securities, whenever the amount of the profit was greater than the normal Stock Exchange commission.
ALBANY, July 29 (AP) - Governor Lehman called upon Raymond J. Whitney, City Manager of Yonkers, today for strict enforcement in that city of laws against gambling and bookmaking.
STOCKHOLM, Sweden, July 29 -- Sweden received an unexpected and sharp warning today from the official spokesman of the Wilhelmstrasse.

The need for a toughening of our national fiber, if we are to face successfully bloody defeats and the black days that are at hand, is more than a problem of the fighting services; it is a national problem.

WASHINGTON, July 29 -- Experts in aircraft design, manufacture and transportation gave united support before Senatorial committees today to the opening of new supply lines of men and materiel to battle fronts by the production of cargo planes in larger numbers than combat craft.

SAROTOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., July 29 -- Attendance and wagering perked up a bit today despite the heavy track as the veteran Sunny Jim Fitzsimmons saddled the 2-year-old fillies that ran one, two in the Atlantis purse. Flight, bred by C.A. Stone, carried the colors of Mrs. Whitney Stone to victory, while Shannon, a homebred from the Wheatley Stable of Mrs. H.C. Phipps, was second.

A new rule to force over-the-counter dealers to disclose to their customers the best bid-and-asked prices for a security at the time of a sale or purchase has been proposed by the Securities and Exchange Commission. A draft of the rule was mailed yesterday for the study of the securities industry.

CARACAS, Venezuela, July 29 (AP) -- A pact designed to relieve economic strain caused by curtailment of Venezuelan oil production and to supply foodstuffs difficult to obtain because of reduced shipping has been signed by government and petroleum company officials.
WASHINGTON, July 29 (AP) -- The Department of Agriculture reported today that the general level of farm prices advanced 3 points between mid-June and mid-July.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 29 -- Patricia E. Bouchard, a Stanford University student, declared today at a general court-martial that she heard Lieut. Comdr. Maurice N. Aroff suggest, "in a laughing way," after he had sworn in two ensigns, that they "get something" for him.

I am just a "boy," born in 1874, but my father is still in good health, so I am not in Methuselah's class, I hope. But I can add my testimony that Clyde Fitch borrowed the lines you quoted in your "Seahorses on Shore" editorial.

LONDON, July 29 (UP) -- Yugoslav patriots have occupied a Dalmatian village and destroyed harbor installations along the Dalmatian coast, General Draja Mikhailovitch reported tonight, and Axis occupation authorities were striking back with mass executions of hostages.

The soft heart behind the gruff manner of Detective Edward (Duke) Wiessner, veteran member of the Missing Persons Bureau Staff, was revealed yesterday when Duke -- as he is known to scores of reporters -- filed an application for retirement.
LONDON, July 29 -- A total of 6,178,681 tons of German and Italian shipping had been captured, sunk or damaged up to June 30, according to figures issued by the Admiralty today.

WASHINGTON, July 29 -- All who have even a nodding acquaintance with the oppressions of sovereigns that produced Magna Carta and the triumph of the English parliamentary party over the Stuart kings will see the importance of the current proceedings before the Supreme Court of the United States.

MOSCOW, Thursday, July 30 -- Russian resistance on the Don River line appeared to be stiffening today as reports were received here of battles in three sectors, but the Soviet midnight communique revealed that the German thrust toward Stalingrad extended to a point southwest of Kletskaya, which is near the Don about eighty airline miles northwest of Stalingrad.

LONDON, July 29 -- Oliver Lyttelton, Minister of Production, gave in the House of Commons today some details of the British-Belgian agreement under which Britain will purchase rubber produced in the Belgian Congo.

CALCUTTA, India, July 27 (Delayed) (AP) -- British refugees reported today that Japan had recalled 8,000 regulars who pursued British and Chinese detachments up the Chindwin River valley in the Burman campaign and had left few, if any, skeleton outposts in all the malarial jungle area bordering Assam.

WASHINGTON, July 29 -- Lend-lease transfers of all kinds of weapons to the United Nations to date are "somewhat less" than 12 per cent of this country's total munitions output, the Office of War Information reported today, but in planes and tanks the proportion is "much higher."

LONDON, July 29 -- The issue of a second front came to be somewhat mixed up with the suppres- sion of The Daily Worker today when delegations from all parts of England, Scotland and Wales visited Whitehall to demand termination of the ban upon the Communist party organ.

TORONTO, July 29 (AP) -- Good pitching and a 10:03 deadline to permit the visitors to catch a train produced a nine-inning 1-1 deadlock between Jersey City and Toronto tonight in the final scheduled contest between the teams this season.

ALBANY, July 29 -- Public employes who joined the reserve corps prior to April 1 are entitled to pay for the difference between their armed service pay and that which they received from the City of New York, the Court of Appeal ruled today in the case of two firemen against the Fire Commissioner, Patrick Walsh.

HARTFORD, Conn., July 29 -- Grave charges were made by the government this afternoon in the opening address to the jury chosen to try the espionage conspiracy case of the Rev. Kurt E.B. Molzahn, Lutheran pastor, of Philadelphia, and the only one of the five accused who is being tried.

Father Divine, Harlem cult leader who announced recently that he had moved his residence to Philadelphia because of "disrecognition" here, was ordered yesterday by Supreme Court Justice J. Sidney Bernstein to show cause why he should not be punished for contempt of court for failure to make seven weekly installment payments of $100 each due up to date under an order issued on June 12 by Justice Charles B. McLaughlin.

Losses ranged from fractions to more than a point in yesterday's dull session of the New York Stock Exchange. The United States Steel earnings report, the slashed dividend of Westinghouse Electric and news of heavy secondary offerings to be made after the close of the market depressed prices.

Yale University serve as the site of the training grounds for the Eastern division of the All-Army football team, now taking form under the direction of Colonel Bob Neyland, it was announced officially yesterday.

WASHINGTON, July 29 -- A detailed program showing women every move they must make to aid the salvage program will be available soon to supplement the general outline given to women in the official War Production Plan published last week.

WASHINGTON, July 29 - Harold E. Talbot, chairman of the WPB's air transportation committee, told the Truman committee today that the War and Navy Departments were convinced that wooden cargo planes were feasible and had let orders for a "considerable number," but that neither department planned such huge planes as the seventy-five-ton ships urged by Henry Kaiser, West Coast shipbuilder.

WASHINGTON, July 29 (U.P.) -- Some grain, coal and other kinds of freight destined for exportation were exempted today from the Office of Defense Transportation order prohibiting the movement of export freight into port areas without permits.

The Greater New York Industrial Union Council, C.I.O., indicateed yesterday a closer working unity between A.F. of L. and C.I.O. unions in this city when it announced that "there are no local unions affiliated with the C.I.O. in New York City which take into membership workers employed in the building construction fields."

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., July 29 -- The winning streak of Francisco (Pancho) Segura came to an end today when the little Ecuadorian suffered his first setback in singles after winning four successive tennis tournaments.

CHICAGO, July 29 -- The Yankees tackled the White Sox in their first twilight-night double-header tonight, but the confusion of lights proved too much even for the world champions. Before 27,553 onlookers, the mighty McCarthy juggernaut got all strung up in its own mechanism and lost both engagements to the White Sox.

The tax bill now before the Senate Finance Committee will have wide influence and many effects over and above its primary object of increased revenue. These accessory influences and effects on the national economy and social conditions are therefore worthy of serious consideration.
The following German High Command communique was broadcast from Berlin yesterday and was recorded here by The Associated Press:

WASHINGTON, July 29 (U.P.) -- Harry Hopkins, adviser to President Roosevelt, came out of Russia a year ago this month with the most vital secrets of Russia's armed strength -- secrets known only to the Soviet High Command. Premier Joseph Stalin disclosed the secrets to Mr. Hopkins and sent the American representative home with a note to President Roosevelt in which Mr. Stalin promised to stand firm against Nazi aggression.

BERNE, Switzerland, July 29 -- In his weekly publication, the Reich, Dr. Joseph Goebbels, German Propaganda Minister, attempts to make light of the threat of a second front and terms any Anglo-American invasion of Europe "an undertaking dictated by sheer madness" that "is bound to have disastrous results for the United States and England."

INWOOD, L.I., July 29 -- Tony DeVincenzo, Brooklyn, upset James Lichtman, second-seeded entrant from New Rochelle, 6 -- 3. 6 -- 1, in the quarter-final round of the Metropolitan junior tennis championship at the Inwood Country Club today.
A priorities suit by the War Production Board against the Carnegie-Illinois Steel Corporation was settled yesterday in Federal District Court in Newark by a consent decree and stipulation.

WASHINGTON, July 29 -- The Office of Civilian Defense made public today a letter sent by its director, James M. Landis, to Mayor La Guardia suggesting that the latter permit Army and OCD experts to demonstrate in New York City in the presence of the local press the newly recommended or jet-of-water system for extinguishing incendiary bombs.

In addition to reporting semi-annual earnings, the Wheeling Steel Corporation announced yesterday a 25-cent dividend on its common stock, representing half the amount paid to stockholders in preceding quarters.

OMAHA, July 29 (AP) -- A statement that the meat shortages in many cities may become nationwide due to curtailed cattle feeding was stressed in a brief of information prepared by the National Livestock Advisory Council and given to the Office of Price Administration in Washington today.

CHICAGO, July 29 -- Price ceilings on meats will be held firm against demands from merchants and packers that they be punctured to allow a wider profit margin, J.K. Galbraith, deputy ad ministrator of the Office of Price Administration, said today.

Continued confidence that the New Deal drive to stop Attorney General John J. Bennett Jr. and nominate Senator James M. Mead as the Democratic candidate for Governor had failed to crack the Bennett lines was manifested yesterday by Democratic State Chairman James A. Farley.

A $1,682,000 loan on the development known as Larchmont Acres, Larchmont, Westchester County, has been arranged by Ivor B. Clark, Inc., and Win. A. White Sons. co-brokers, and insured by the Federal Housing Administration.
MOSCOW, Thursday, July 30 (AP) -- The Soviet midnight communique said:

PHILADELPHIA, July 29 -- The first volunteer regiment of the Coast Guard is being organized to patrol the Philadelphia water front and to protect the ships in port, it was announced today by Captain Eugene A. Coffin, captain of the port, Fourth Naval District.

INDIANAPOLIS, July 29 -- A mysterious "oracle" prompted William Dudley Pelley to organize the Fascist Silver Shirts of America, according to excerpts from a 450-page autobiography read at Pelley's sedition trial in United States District Court here today over protests of defense counsel.

LONDON, Thursday, July 30 -- A major force of British bombers flew through storms and icing clouds -- dirt, British fliers call it -- to attack Hamburg on Tuesday night for the second time in three nights. They bombed from low altitudes under a cloud bank over Hamburg, at 1,000 feet and lower, destroying trains and goods, interrupting communications and leaving tremendous fires.

Why not give us seamen a break? Since completing a long voyage through belligerent zones I have been catching up on the newspapers. I've read countless stories about the "unsung heroes of the merchant marine." It all sounded fine and I had a swell time in Philadelphia, where the USO has opened all its facilities to merchant seamen.

For their number, there is probably no group that destroys more rubber and other useful war materials than the garage cowboys who pick up and deliver cars in New York. Any one who lives near the big apartment buildings can testify to the truth of this assertion.

The Navy announced yesterday the sinking of a small United States merchant vessel by a submarine about 150 miles off the Atlantic coast on July 24. Eighteen men, including a passenger, were lost when the ship went down "less than a minute" after she was struck by two torpedoes.

WASHINGTON, July 29 -- President Roosevelt has directed the formulation of a National War Service Bill, under which the total man power of the country, estimated at 60,000,000 labor units, would be mobilized in a total war effort for assignment to essential services in factories, on the farms, in the laboratories and even to the education of young people under military age for scientific pursuits.

After a poll last night among 219 right-wing candidates for New York County delegates and alternates to the American Labor party State convention, in which Senator James M. Mead received 198 votes, the right-wing conference formally called for Senator Mead's nomination for Governor at the party convention of August 22.

In an earnest drive calculated to arouse even greater interest in the Giant-Dodger twilight game at the Polo Grounds on Monday for the benefit of the Army Emergency Relief, elaborate ceremonies are planned for tonight.

As part of its accident-prevention campaign the Greater New York Safety Council has asked each of 10,000 taxicab drivers in the city to post a red-white-and-blue sticker immediately back of the driving seat where it can be seen by his passengers. This sticker, taking the form of a pledge, declares that the driver will avoid quick stops, hold down speed, and wait for lights in order to save lives and tires.

At least $100,000,000,000 of bombardment insurance has been placed with the Federal War Damage Corporation, and final figures may run as much as one-third higher, according to a round-up of insurance views yesterday, which place at close to $200,000,000 the premiums being paid this month to carry the government protection for a year.

LONDON, July 29 -- Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden told the House of Commons today that the British Government favored the establishment or re-establishment after the war of an international court of justice, and has noted with interest references to this in the recent speech by American Secretary of State Cordell Hull.

Cleveland E. Dodge was re-elected chairman of the Interdenominational Committee for Religious Education on Released Time at the annual meeting yesterday in the Downtown Association. He reported to the committee, which was organized a year ago, that there is an attendance of 113,000 children at classes on religion held once a week during the public school year.

Harold McCracken, archaeologist and explorer, who is familiar with the Aleutians, said yesterday the islands were a "second front" and that the Japanese could not be bombed from their strategic foothold but must be "chased with bayonets into the Bering Sea," The United Press reported.
WASHINGTON, July 29 -- An abstract of the defense brief in the case of the seven Nazi saboteurs follows :

LONDON, July 29 -- The alertness of the British patrols of light naval vessels was rewarded last night when a force of E-boats was intercepted off the coast of the Netherlands. A short sharp engagement ensued, said the Admiralty, as a result of which the E-boats retired eastward with one seriously damaged and burning.

Expansion of the salvage organization here to meet the demands expected from the intensified drive for usable material was announced yesterday by Clarence H. Low, chairman of the New York City Salvage Committee. At the same time, he said, there will be a reorganization and coordination of activities to eliminate duplication.

Mayor La Guardia said yesterday that he had endorsed Representative Vito Marcantonio in his campaign for re-election as a member of Congress from the Twentieth District in Manhattan, but said he had not yet decided whether he would speak for the candidate at a forthcoming rally.

At the same time that representatives of various groups in the retail food industry met at the City Department of Markets yesterday afternoon to organize a retailer-consumer advisory council as a check against unwarranted food prices, the Meat Trade Institute, Inc., wrote Price Administrator Leon Henderson that the meat shortage situation in New York City was more acute than last week.

WASHINGTON, July 29 -- An article in the current issue of the United Mine Workers Journal attacks the War Labor Board's decision in the Little Steel case as "quite an amazing output of factual jugglery."

Most business concerns should be able to step up the efficiency of their office procedure to enable them to comply with the government's request for typewriters without any great sacrifice in output of paper work, Dr. Coleman L. Maze, president of the National Office Management Association, declared yesterday.

According to a Berlin broadcast that was recorded by The Associated Press, the German High command reported yesterday that an overnight air raid on port installations at the Suez Canal had scored hits on quays, fuel dumps and shipping.
LARCHMONT, N.Y., July 29 -- Race Week at the Larchmont Yacht Club, which opened for its five-day session today, drew 170 starting craft, by far the largest number this year.

To be effective at the battlefront, or for carrying out any precise plan of strategy, war production must be balanced. It must be balanced "horizontally" -- as between different finished items, such as planes, tanks and ships -- and balanced also "vertically," so that raw materials -- steel, aluminum, copper -- are available in the right amounts at the points where they are needed.

A home-made gas mask that can be constructed in fifteen minutes from materials found in the home was demonstrated yesterday by the inventor, Dr. Simon Ruskin, who was the principal speaker at the graduation exercises of the American Women's Voluntary Services Teachers School of Air Raid Precautions at the New York Museum of Science and Industry, 30 Rockefeller Plaza.

WASHINGTON, July 29 -- Pricing methods which manufacturers may use to establish ceilings for new lines of consumer goods and building materials introduced after April 1, last, and to which the usual March base for ceiling prices is therefore inapplicable, were established by a new regulation announced today by Price Administrator Leon Henderson.

MONTCLAIR, N.J., July 29 (AP) -- Miss Shirley Fry of Akron, Ohio, top seeded, and Miss Lillian Lopaus of City Island, N.Y., the defending champion, were among the second-round winners today in the Montclair Athletic Club's third annual girls' invitation tennis tournament.

Despite the destruction of its band-shell by lightning and wind the night before, Stadium Concerts, Inc., kept faith with its audience last night and presented the New York Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra in a concert at the Lewisohn Stadium.
ANKARA, Turkey, July 29 -- The highest quarters in Turkey are not nervous over the apparent German successes on the Don River and Black Sea fronts.
WASHINGTON, July 29 -- The command of the Aleutian Islands and the fighting units in them has been unified under a naval officer, the Navy Department announced today.

MIDDLETOWN, Ohio, July 29 -- Obsolescent equipment which was tagged "scrap" and scattered in three localities in two States a year ago today went into service as a major producer of alloy steel in a new plant established here by the American Rolling Mill Company.
LONDON, July 29 -- The stock markets were quiet again today owing to the news from Russia, but the undertone remained firm. Gilt-edge issues were fractionally lower and the home rails declined.

WASHINGTON, July 29 (AP) -- Industrialists and civic leaders from seven Western New York counties which will be brought into the gasoline rationing program Aug. 22 protested today that the order was "discrimination" unless it was part of a nation-wide rationing plan.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 29 -- The first printed newspaper, supported by advertising, to be issued at any of the assembly or relocation centers housing a total of some 100,000 Japanese evacuees of the Far West, is off the presses at Manzanar in the Owens Valley.

WASHINGTON, July 29 -- The basic formula by which the Office of Price Administration will shortly increase wholesalers' and retailers' ceilings on prices of canned fruits and berries by 15 to 25 per cent to cover higher raw material and labor costs was announced today by the Office of Price administration.

The formal closing of the "Draft Willkie" committee's headquarters at 11 West Forty-second Street was announced yesterday by Stanley M. Rinehart, chairman of the group. The committee has been inactive for several weeks, since Mr. Willkie made it clear, in a statement, that he would do nothing to encourage its efforts.

The opening date of "The Pirate," starring Lunt and Fontanne, has been deferred from Oct. 19 to Oct. 26 at the Martin Beck. This was brought about by adding a second week to the Washington booking, which will keep the S.N. Behrman play there from Oct. 12 through Oct. 24.
ST. LOUIS, July 29 (AP) -- Scoring four runs on four hits in the ninth, the Senators wiped out a spectacular seventh-inning rally by the Browns today to win, 11 to 10.

Bequests of $30,000 each to Columbia, Princeton and Harvard Universities and $5,000 to the 100 Neediest Cases of THE NEW YORK TIMES were contained in the will of Mrs. Ines Stross, late of 145 Central Park West and widow of Ludwig Stross.
A nine-room apartment in 455 East Fifty-seventh Street has been rented by Earl J. Johnson, vice president of The United Press, through Gilliam McVay, brokers, and Douglas L. Elliman Co., agents.

An investment banking group headed by Shields Co. won yesterday the award of $1,200,000 of bonds of the Washington Suburban Sanitary District in Maryland on a bid of 100.087 for 2 1/4s. The bonds, to be used for water and sewer improvements, are dated Aug. 1, 1942, and are to mature on Aug. 1, 1943 to 1982.

CHICAGO, July 29 -- Liquidation of a long line of September wheat purchased recently when talk was rife of a full parity government loan program set wheat prices off about 1 cent a bushel in the early trading on the Board of Trade today.

Sammy Angott, lightweight champion, wound up his training yesterday for tomorrow night's non-title bout at Madison Square Garden with Ray Robinson. Planning an easy sparring session with J.D. Shans at his Summit camp, Angott let go a right hand that staggered his partner and drove him across the ring.

VICHY, France, July 29 (UP) -- Sixty thousand German troops, chiefly Elite Guards and motorized infantry, paraded in Paris today and continued westward "to occupy new positions" coincident with demonstrations of strength throughout the occupied zone and manoeuvres behind the "new West-wall" along the coast of northwestern France, reports from German-occupied Paris said.

Michael J. Quill, international president of the Transport Workers Union, C.I.O., announced yesterday, after a thirty-minute conference with Mayor La Guardia at City Hall, that the union and the Board of Transportation would begin next week a discussion of changes in hours, wages and working conditions of employes of the city's unified transit lines.

WASHINGTON, July 29 -- Regarding the order issued today restricting deliveries of fuel oil in the East, an OPC spokesman said that theatres, hotels and restaurants did not qualify as industrial users. However, they are not expected to be hard hit by the order, since they have little use for heating equipment in the Summer months and probably will get enough fuel to take care of their water-heating requirements.

Earnings of the International Business Machines Corporation in the first half of this year increased $3,483,070, to $11,888,406 before providing for United States Federal and Canadian income and excess profits taxes, from $8,405,336 in the corresponding half of last year, according to the semi-annual report issued yesterday.

A recent purchase on the West Side by Frederick Brown has been turned into a resale by the operator who announced yesterday that he had sold the twelve-story and penthouse apartment building at 305 West Seventy-second Street to an investing client of the Wood, Dolson Company, broker in the purchase and resale.
LONDON, July 29 (AP) -- The Admiralty issued the following communique tonight:
WASHINGTON, July 29 -- Justice James W. Morris, in denying a writ of habeas corpus late yesterday in District Court to seven of the Nazis on trial for sabotage, ruled as follows:

Stocks of finished and unfinished gasoline throughout the country at the close of last week amounted to 82,281,000 barrels, a decrease of 1,788,000 from the 84,069,000 a week earlier, according to the American Petroleum Institute. A year ago these stocks amounted to 85,073,000 barrels.

MOSCOW, Thursday, July 30 (AP) -- The Russian Armies of the south were reported throwing reserves into the bitter battle against the Germans today and the Soviet midnight communique indicated that the Nazi steamroller had made little if any progress in the last twenty-four hours.

WASHINGTON, July 29 -- In a move to develop untouched reserves of zinc ores, plans are being made for establishment by the Bureau of Mines of a $350,000 pilot plant and laboratory to conduct tests of a reduction process.

Wide disparity in the price views of fur shippers and buyers continued at the sale conducted yesterday by the New York Auction Company. Not more than 20 per cent of the major offerings of skunk, American opossum and red and gray fox changed hands, according to estimates at the sale.

Stonehenge and other ancient British remains were the first studies in antiquity of Sir Flinders Petrie, who seems to have "commenced" as antiquarian at 8. He began his Egyptian explorations in 1881. In the sixty years since archaeology and Egyptology have made extraordinary advances. In these Sir Flinders took a long and memorable part.

CHICAGO, July 29 -- All butter futures attained new twelve-year price peaks on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange today, recording gains of 0.15 to 0.25 cent a pound. The November delivery led the advance and closed at 40.3 cents a pound.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., July 29 -- Miss Gloria Callen of the Women's Swimming Association added two American back-stroke records to her collection in the Larchmont Yacht Club's fifty-yard pool tonight, raising her total to 37.

ALBANY, July 29 (AP) -- Gold in the National Bank of Rumania, removed from Poland hours ahead of invading Nazis in the Fall of 1939, can be attached by an American corporation, the Court of Appeals ruled today.
MOSCOW, July 29 (AP) -- The Soviet Information Bureau issued the following communique today:

WASHINGTON, July 29 -- The United States is expected to announce soon details of an agreement with the Brazilian Government under which this country will buy surplus Brazilian coffee and cocoa for a post-war food stock-pile.
The following Italian High Command communique was broadcast from Rome yesterday and was recorded here by The Associated Press:
CHICAGO, July 29 -- Control of one of Chicago's oldest wholesale grocery houses passed into Eastern hands today when the C. D. Kenny Company of Baltimore acquired Sprague-Warner Co.

CLEVELAND, July 29 (AP) -- Roy Weatherly came up with the bases loaded and the score tied in the eleventh inning today and smacked a hit to the right center field fence to give the Indians a 7-to-6 decision over the Red Sox, preventing Boston from sweeping the three-game series.

After landing an 853-pound broadbill swordfish off Tocopilla, Chile, not long ago, S. Kip Farrington Jr. showed two definite tendencies. One was to become more enthusiastic than ever about fishing for broadbill and the other was an ambition to set down some of his thoughts to interest younger anglers.

FRANK KNOX, Secretary of the Navy, calls "Global War: An Atlas of World Strategy,"* by Edgar Ansel Mowrer and Marthe Rajchman, a "cheeky" book. Maybe it started out to be that. But long before Mr. Mowrer finishes with the exposition which is supposed to elucidate Miss Rajchman's fascinating maps he winds himself up in a veritable cocoon of "maybes," "ifs" and "on the other hands."
A national information bureau to coordinate all phases of women's volunteer war activities was launched yesterday by leaders of women's war organizations.
