WASHINGTON, July 29 -- For five-and-a-half hours today the Supreme Court listened in extraordinary session to the debate of the government and of counsel for seven of the eight Nazi saboteurs on the legality of President Roosevelt's orders barring them from the civil courts, and on their demands for writs of habeas corpus.

A newspaper drive to promote the conversion of oil burners to coal will be opened soon by the D.L. W. Coal Company, in cooperation with more than 4,000 "blue coal" dealers as far west as Chicago, it was announced yesterday. Insertions of 255 lines and 400 lines will run over a period of twelve weeks.

A book that is said to be the most documented work thus far on Axis sabotage in America is being prepared for publication at Harpers. It is "Sabotage: The Secret War Against America" (Sept. 15). The authors are Michael Sayers, a writer on fifth column activities, and Albert E. Kahn, formerly secretary of the American Council Against Nazi Propaganda and editor of the confidential news bulletin, The Hour.

The nations of Latin America are now striving to replace European cultural ties with democratic cooperation from North America through scientific and cultural exchanges and agreements as well as reciprocal trade treaties, Dr. Mariano Picon Salas, head of the Press Department of Venezuela, declared here yesterday in an interview in the Office of the Coordinator of Inter-American Affairs at 444 Madison Avenue.

The Russian armies are pledged to a desperate stand at Stalingrad. The loss of that city would be a double calamity. Stalingrad is not only the last main rail link to the Caucasus but the greatest producer of tanks in Russia. It has spiritual significance as well as strategic value.

BOSTON, July 29 (AP) -- The Pirates and Braves split a double-header today, Pittsburgh taking the opener, 3 -- 0, behind the five-hit pitching of Truett Sewell, after which Jim Tobin hurled Boston to a 6-5 triumph.

German troops pushing the Russians back south of the lower Don have crossed the Manych and Sal Rivers, which flow northwesterly into the Don thirty and sixty miles above Rostov, the High Command said yesterday, according to Berlin broadcasts recorded by The United Press.

Current demand for lingerie has been well maintained, reports in the wholesale markets here yesterday indicated. Tailored or lace-trimmed white slips are being reordered in practically all price ranges, while an active call continues for gowns and pajamas of sheer batiste.

DALLAS, July 29 (AP) -- Federal Judge T. Whitfield Davidson ruled today that a company engaged in secret war production was within its rights in denying a National Labor Relations Board agent access to its plant.

DETROIT, July 29 (AP) -- The revamped Tigers smashed a five-game losing streak today by scoring eight runs in the seventh inning to defeat the Athletics, 12 to 7, in a twilight game. Rudy York hit his first home run in six weeks with one aboard in the sixth for his fifteenth of the season.

Japan's hopes of moving southward by sea met with disaster in the Battle of the Coral Sea. But the Japanese have taken the initiative again, this time by land. They have carried their invasion of New Guinea into Papua, with the obvious intention of marching over the mountains on Port Moresby.

Reporting on operations in the first half of the year, A.W. Robertson, chairman of the board of the Westinghouse Electric and Manufacturing Company, informed stockholders that the Company produced $238,271,213 worth of equipment, virtually all of it for the war.

As a means of obtaining additional tank cars to bring fuel oil to the East Coast this Fall and Winter, the Port of New York Authority renewed yesterday its appeal for the institution of some form of oil rationing in the Midwest area.

Three new films will open in Broadway theatres this morning. At the Roxy, the newcomer will be "They All Kissed the Bride," a romantic comedy starring Joan Crawford and Melvyn Douglas. Featured in the cast of the Columbia production are Allen Jenkins, Billie Burke. Andrew Tombes and Helen Parrish. . .

LONDON, July 29 -- Angry words and disorder rarely seen in the House of Commons and a serious split in the Labor party today followed the government's proposals to increase supplementary pensions by 2s 6d weekly and to make other allowances, which many government critics held to be niggardly.

Council President Newbold Morris, Republican-Fusion member of the Board of Estimate, announced yesterday that he had sponsored Mayor La Guardia's amendments to the McCarthy Salary Increment Law, which will be considered at a special meeting of the Council in City Hall on Tuesday.

The General Maximum Price Regulation, together with the continued upward trend in costs, has given rise to a fairly general decline in profit margins, which are expected to narrow further if the present control system is continued, according to the findings of a survey which was released yesterday by The Conference Board.
MOSCOW, July 29 (U.P.) -- Events of the utmost importance, of which every American and Briton should know, are taking place.

Declaring that "there is no present need to draft or to lure American women from the home for war work," the directors of the Catholic Daughters of America adopted yesterday a resolution saying that "American women will be ready to answer the call if our government is in need of their services."
Mrs. John A. McVickar Jr. gave a luncheon yesterday in the Cafe Pierre for Mrs. Lucius Wilmerding, Mrs. Alfred D. Mittendorf, Mrs. Alfred N. Wheeler and Mrs. Rodman B. Montgomery.
The six-room bungalow on a plot 50 by 100 feet at 45-18 166th Street, Flushing, Queens, has been sold by William Chapin to Grace O. Gifkins through the Halleran Agency, broker.

A graduate nurse in the United States today is in somewhat the position of an able-bodied young man in a country which enlists its soldiers by voluntary service. Should she or should she not enlist with the nursing units of the Army and Navy, which are now recruiting nurses at the rate of 3,000 a month?

That the Giants and the Cubs split a double-header at the Polo Grounds yesterday was a news item of only secondary importance. Outranking the twin bill was the debut of that old Giant-hater, Van Lingle Mungo, in a New York uniform.

SALEM, N.H., July 29 (AP) -- The Coldstream Stable's Bullpen and Moretto ran one, two today in the $2,500 added Maplewood Stakes at Rockingham Park. Installed the 3-to-2 favorite in the field of six juveniles, the entry dominated the entire running of the five and one-half furlong event.

WASHINGTON, July 29 (AP) -- WPA announced today that in order to make additional thousands of women available for war production jobs, $6,000,000 had been allocated for "war nursery schools" to care for 50,000 children of working mothers.
The beautiful city of Budapest, situated precipitously on the banks of the Danube, is renowned for three reasons -- its bridges, its music and its apple strudel.

LONDON, July 29 -- German Elite Guard troops, shifted from the Russian front and equipped with new arms and vehicles, marched through the streets of Paris "in a westerly direction" today, the Berlin radio reported in another apparent attempt to bluff the Allies out of an invasion of the Continent.

Six children, some of them barely able to walk, sneaked past two policemen yesterday afternoon and crashed the preview opening of the Harlem Toyery at 39 West 135th Street, which will start lending toys today. Fifty more children, a bit older and more visible to the policemen, were kept outside, but remained clustered around the door, peering in with envious eyes.

Mayor La Guardia said yesterday that a surprise air raid drill or blackout would be held some time before next Wednesday for the entire city. The Mayor would not disclose the date of the drill because he wants to see how the city responds to an unexpected alarm.

Leaving her comfortable quarters at the Delmonico Hotel, 502 Park Avenue, Mrs. Marguerita Sour, member of the American Women's Voluntary Services, Tenth Division, started out early yesterday morning on a one-woman neighborhood salvage collection.
Two men were killed and a third man was seriously injured at the New York Navy Yard in Brooklyn yesterday when the cable of a crane broke and the men were struck by a falling 225-pound steel beam.

The continued absence of any substantial demand rather them any exceptionally active selling pressure of commission houses, New Orleans interests and hedges, was the prime reason for another decline in cotton prices yesterday. On the New York Cotton Exchange active contracts held under the previous close most of the day and closed with net losses of 12 to 14 points, near the session's low levels.
The Vesey Street salesrooms had one of the busiest days in some time yesterday when ten parcels of realty were sold there at auction.

By retiring $1,267,000 principal amount of its debentures, 695 shares of its preferred stock and 11,800 shares of its common stock in the second 1942 quarter, the Niagara Share Corporation of Maryland improved the net asset position of its securities.

WASHINGTON, July 29 -- Nine general permits relieving motor carriers engaged in special operations from restrictions contained in Order No. 17 were issued today by the Office of Defense Transportation.

ALBANY, July 29 -- The State Education Department made public today a list of 150 high-school students to whom have been awarded Cornell scholarships which entitle the holder to a reduction of $200 a year from the regular tuition fees.

The proclamation in which President Roosevelt last week declared Rumanians, Hungarians and Bulgarians to be subject to the alien enemy regulations was cited yesterday with the announcement that two Rumanians and one Hungarian had been taken into custody.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., July 29 -- Members of the Garden Club of Southampton held a meeting this afternoon at Leny Cottage, the home of Dr. and Mrs. Nicholas Murray Butler. Mrs. John D. Beals Jr. presided. A feature of the meeting was a lecture on "The Garden in Wartime" by Mrs. Mary O. Lamson, landscape architect. Mrs. Butler gave a tea later.

WANAQUE, N.J., July 29 (AP) -- The North Jersey District Water Supply Commission has instructed Charles Capen, its chief engineer, to protest to United States Senators and Representatives from New Jersey against a Federal proposal to build a barge canal across Central New Jersey, Commissioner Samuel Ferster said today.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 29 -- "Hands of Mercy," a film based on the exploits of eighty Army nurses during the siege of Bataan, has been scheduled by Paramount for Fall production, the studio announced today. Mark Sandrich will produce and direct the picture, and he and Allan Scott will write the scenario.

WITH THE BRITISH EIGHTH ARMY, in Egypt, July 29 -- An Australian patrol, accompanied by several tanks, penetrated a few thousand yards into enemy territory just before dawn this morning and met with almost no opposition.

NORTHAMPTON, Mass., July 30 -- The Navy Department will set up a naval training unit at Smith College to prepare about 900 women for commissions as ensigns, Dr. Herbert J. Davis, president of the college, stated here today.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 30 -- Diana Barrymore, daughter of the late John Barrymore, and Bramwell Fletcher, 38-year-old stage and screen actor, were married today after a three-year courtship that began backstage in New York.
LONDON, July 30 (UP) -- The Bank of England condition statement issued today reported an increase of almost u9,000,000 in note circulation for the week and placed the total at u824,148,000.

WASHINGTON, July 30 (AP) -- Harry Hopkins, Presidential aide, and Mrs. Louise Gill Macy, New York fashion writer, stood before the marble fireplace in President Roosevelt's Oval Study in the White House shortly after noon today and repeated their marriage vows.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, July 30 -- In case of a British invasion, Norway will be plunged by the National Samling into a "most horrible" civil war. Vidkun Quisling, German-appointed Premier of occupied Norway, warned listeners in the course of a speech delivered at Stiklestad yesterday.
WASHINGTON, July 30 -- The Supreme Court opened the way late today to pass upon the fate of seven of the eight Nazi saboteurs a few minutes after the tribunal meets at noon tomorrow.
The flow of income to the various States and regions during the past year showed abrupt changes, the Conference Board reported yesterday.

LONDON, July 30 (UP) -- Second-front speculation was rife and newspaper comment took a new turn today when The Daily Telegraph, which strongly supports Prime Minister Winston Churchill, asserted that the appointment of an American general to command Allied land forces on the Continent would be welcomed in Britain.

Frederick (Big Freddie) Bertolotti, characterized by the District Attorney's office as a bookmaker and associate of criminals, was held in $10,000 bail in Special Sessions yesterday, accused of making loans to city employes at interest rates as high as 80 per cent.

It is not necessarily the fault of our dentists if we have mixed feelings to ward them, and they, being full of understanding, will expect these contradictory feelings to continue as we see them called away to war.

Officials of the City of Seattle, Wash., issued yesterday a call for bids of $7,900,000 of municipal power and light bonds to be opened on Aug. 12. The sale of these obligations originally was scheduled for June 22, but was postponed.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 30 -- Presidents or other spokesmen of nearly fifty colleges and universities of the Far West, meeting on the Stanford campus, recommended today a drastic change in Selective Service methods to get every student into his proper wartime job.

WASHINGTON, July 30 (U.P.) -- A few hours before her wedding today to Mr. Hopkins, Mrs. Louise Gill Macy explained that she and Mr. Hopkins felt that "the grave days of war through which we are passing, with the sacrifices being made everywhere by the American people, make a simple and private wedding preferable just now."

Operating the motor corps of the New York Chapter, American Red Cross, on an emergency war basis has made its present staff of 315 volunteers insufficient to meet all needs, Mrs. E. Stanley Conan, commander of the unit, declared yesterday at her office in the organization's headquarters at 315 Lexington Avenue.

LONDON, July 30 -- A warning that Great Britain will not tolerate civil disobedience was given to Mohandas K. Gandhi's All-India Congress party today from the floor of the House of Commons by Leopold S. Amery, Secretary of State for India.

A demonstration in Randalls Island Stadium last night by the Chemical Warfare Service of the Army closed the controversy that has raged over the "jet" and "spray" methods of dealing with incendiary bombs.

The response yesterday to the appeal made by the Addressing Machine and Equipment Company for typewriters for the armed forces was overwhelming, Irving R. Ritchie, manager of the typewriter division, reported last night. The offer to buy machines as agent for the government was made yesterday morning in the first of a series of insertions in metropolitan newspapers.

JERSEY CITY, N. J., July 30 (AP) -- A Chancery Court order approving purchase of 536.76 outstanding shares of capital stock for $805,140 removed today the final barrier preventing the Prudential Insurance Company of America from changing from a stock to a mutual company.

WASHINGTON, July 30 -- Henry Morgenthau Jr., Secretary of the Treasury, said at a press conference today that he intended to finance the war as long as possible without "forced loans" and declared he hoped to continue on the present voluntary basis of war bonds sales at least until the end of this calendar year.

WASHINGTON, July 30 -- Senator Walter F. George, chairman of the Senate Finance Committee, said today that the tax burden on both corporations and individuals next year would be so high that Congress would be compelled to provide exemptions in part on money spent repaying debts and meeting other fixed obligations.

A month ago, as auditors were about to go over the books of a trustee's fund in the office of Fox Wintner, lawyers, at 31 Nassau Street, William H. Dixon, 55 years old, a lawyer who had joined the staff forty years before As an office boy, said: "Excuse me; I'll be back in twenty minutes."

James C. Petrillo, president of the American Federation of Musicians, offered a detailed defense last night of his ban on the manufacture of recordings for radio and other nonprivate use. He charged that the Federal government was "protecting" radio stations, advertising agencies and record makers, which, he said, had "combined" against the A.F. of L. union.

WASHINGTON, July 30 -- President Roosevelt signed today the bill authorizing the Women's Reserve in the Navy, and the Navy Department at once announced details of the new organization in which 1,000 women will become comissioned officers in the Navy for the first time in history.
MINNEAPOLIS, July 30 (AP) -- A take-off crash of an Army ferry command cargo plane on Wold-Chamberlain Airport today killed ten Northwest Airlines employes, eight of them "up just for the ride."

LONDON, July 30 -- Details of recent Axis cruelties in Slovenia, including the destruction of fifty-eight villages, were made public tonight by Dr. Michael Krek, Vice Premier of the Yugoslav Government in exile.
LONDON, July 30 (Reuter) -- Ernest Bevin, Minister of Labor, paid high tribute to Britain's women today in a speech on the progress of the war.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 30 -- Two young ensigns came to the defense of Lieut. Comdr. Maurice N. Aroff at a general court-martial trial today with assertions that he had called the Navy the greatest thing in the world" and "always respected it."

An announcement issued yesterday by E.H. Burgess, chairman of the Traffic Executive Association for Eastern Territory, stated that because of war demands the railroads in this territory had withdrawn all transportation schedules. His statement follows:

WASHINGTON, July 30 -- When the qualified voters of Virginia go to the polls next Tuesday to choose nominees for various offices that are to be filled in the November election, their most interesting and important decision, so far as the rest of the country is concerned, will be the choice they make between the Democratic candidates in the Eighth Congressional District.

WASHINGTON, July 30 -- Department store sales in the week ended July 25 were 5 per cent higher than in the corresponding week of 1941, the Federal Reserve Board announced today. The increase was the same as that recorded a week ago and for the four-week period ended July 25.
Ray Robinson comes back to the ring wars tonight at Madison Square Garden where he will meet the lightweight champion, Sammy Angott, in a non-title fight.

Bank clearings for the week ended on Wednesday were slightly below those of the previous week, but increased 8.2 per cent over the total for the comparable week a year ago. The volume for the twenty-three major cities, according to Dun Bradstreet, Inc., was $6,221,598,000, compared with $5,49,448,000 for the 1941 week.

Formulation of standards which will save materials, make fuller use of the nation's production facilities, and make price control more effective by pegging prices to quality will be spurred by a new contract between the government and the American Standards Association, it was revealed in a joint announcement yesterday by War Production Board Chairman Nelson and Price Administrator Henderson.

LONDON, July 30 -- Ice cream paradoxically has become a warm issue here. The Yanks' ration, more ample by some 50 per cent than that the Tommies, and even that of the R.A.F., from today will no longer include ice cream -- at least at American Army posts.

It is encouraging to find Congress paying close attention to experts in the aviation field in the matter of providing cargo-carrying aircraft. There is conflict of opinion as to whether concentration should be on large flying boats or on land aircraft of the giant bomber type, converted for cargo. Ideally, large quantities of both land and water-going types would be desirable.

German parades are a common sight in Paris. No doubt Hitler's Elite Guards marched swiftly and stiffly as wooden soldiers up the empty stretches of the Champs-Elysees. Perhaps they goose-stepped under the ironic shadow of the Arc de Triomphe. Certainly the Parisians averted their gaze from the spectacle.

Commission house liquidation and a little hedging near the end of trading on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday sent prices on active futures contracts to final net losses of 10 to 11 points. It was the fifth successive day that the market had declined and the closing prices were the lowest since early in June.

PITTSBURGH, July 30 -- An injunction suit instituted against the Jones Laughlin Steel Corporation by the Office of Price Administration which charged the corporation with violation of price ceilings in the purchase of scrap iron, was dismissed by Judge F.P. Schoonmaker in the Federal District Court today.
BUFFALO, July 30 (AP) -- The Bears rode over the Bisons for a 12-to-1 decision tonight. Buffalo's fifth straight defeat resulted in the loss of fifth place as Baltimore moved up a notch.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, July 30 -- Reports on the Nazi "mercy killings" of incurably wounded or otherwise permanently incapacited men on the Eastern Front have led the German Army's Psychological Service to make a special broadcast in an attempt to dispel these and other "rumors."

The Alfred A. Knopf literary fellowships, awarded annually in the past to three authors with works in fiction, biography and history "in progress," have been revised in several respects. Opening the application period for the 1943 awards, the publisher announces the discontinuance of the fiction grant, explaining that the program primarily aims to assist writers in the long task of research attendant upon factual writing.

German tank forces have severed at several places the last important rail connection between the oil-rich Caucasus and the rest of Russia and have cut off the Soviet route of retreat eastward in the big bend of the Don River farther to the north, the German High Command declared yesterday, according to Berlin broadcasts recorded by The Associated Press.

A bearded young man who wanted to get back to Germany in the worst way, and figured out just about the worst possible way, became a resident of the German-Japanese-Italian colony at Ellis Island yesterday. He had been wandering along the waterfront, asking people which ship would be the next out for Germany, when the G-men caught him.

Convinced that a real sort of "new world," based on "the freedom of the human being," must be established through international cooperation following the war, the Netherland Government has decided to establish an economic mission here so it can cooperate closely with the United States in post-war planning, Pieter A. Kerstens, Netherland Minister of Commerce, Industry and Shipping, announced last night.

LONDON, July 30 -- The government and leaders of the Labor party are displeased and disconcerted by the rebellion of party members in the House of Commons lover the question of pension increases, which are not large enough to suit them.

The Committee on Discrimination in Employment of the State War Council through its chairman, State Industrial Commissioner Frieda S. Miller, reported yesterday that "industrial employment opportunities in New York State for Negroes, Jews and persons of foreign birth have increased to a marked degree in the seven months since Pearl Harbor."

Vice Admiral R.R. Waesche, commandant of the United States Coast Guard, informed the National Maritime Union yesterday that casualties among seamen in ship sinkings have been reduced by improved equipment and precautionary drills.

WASHINGTON, July 30 -- A major step in centralizing Army procurement operations was taken today with the announcement that the Ordnance Department would take complete charge Saturday of buying and maintaining automotive vehicles used by the troops.

CHICAGO, July 30 -- Deaths from motor vehicle accidents in the United States in June were reduced 32 per cent below the same month of a year ago, the greatest decrease for any one month in the country's history, the National Safety Council reported today.

MAMARONECK, N.Y., July 30 -- Something new in the war relief effort was introduced at the Winged Foot Golf Club today when the Westchester Golf Association held its first annual mixed Scotch foursome tournament under the slogan of "two cents a blow for USO." Forty teams competed.

The presentation of Johann Strauss's "Gypsy Baron," originally scheduled for last night at the Lewisohn Stadium, had to be abandoned because of the recent demolition of the shell by lightning. Instead an orchestral concert was given with Fritz Reiner conducting and Jascha Heifetz as soloist, which attracted an audience of 8,000.
The meat shortage in the New York metropolitan area is "constantly easing," it was disclosed yesterday in reports received from packers by City Markets Commissioner Daniel P. Wooley.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., July 30 -- Mrs. Dodge Sloane had as luncheon guests today at the track restaurant Mr. and Mrs. Walter M. Jeffords, Samuel D. Riddle and Gaines Gwathmey. Another party included Mr. and Mrs. Edward Small Moore, William Woodward and his daughter, Mrs. Charles Arthur Moore 2d.

THOSE soldiers in the field -- and the sailors on the sea and the Coast Guards on the coast and the United States Marines from the halls of Montezuma to the shores of Tripoli -- think up some odd things to put in their letters. For example, to wit and viz:

WASHINGTON, July 30 -- Stop-gap regional registration of women for war work will be held in Detroit and other critical areas until the War Man Power Commission or some other agency is given legislative authority to hold a nationwide compulsory registration, it was indicated today by officials of the commission.

ST. LOUIS, July 30 -- Just when the rejuvenated Browns were beginning to look hopefully at second place, along came the Senators to defeat them three times in a row, winning today's final game, 11 to 6.
" This Is the Army" will give a special matinee on Tuesday, Aug. 18, for the benefit of the Actors Fund, with prices ranging from $1.10 to $2.75. The all-soldier cast voted to hold the performance.

Willy Bolle and Emil Detzel, furniture dealers, of 1495 Third Avenue, whose firm sponsors regular German-language radio programs over the air, have been taken into custody by the Federal Bureau of Investigation, it was learned yesterday.

AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, Australia, Friday, July 31 -- Allied interceptors yesterday shot down nine of forty-nine Japanese planes that raided Port Darwin, on the Australian north coast, a United Nations communique announced today.

Although no bluefish have been caught in the surf recently, Frank Tuma of Montauk reports that there are plenty of good-sized striped bass and quantities of weakfish for the surfmen who have any means of reaching his sector of Long Island.

BERWICK, Pa., July 30 (AP) -- One thousand striking employes at the tank-producing plant of the American Car and Foundry Company voted tonight to return to work at midnight in response to a direct telephoned appeal from President Roosevelt, a union leader announced.
INDIANAPOLIS, July 30 -- Testimony that copies of William Dudley Pelley's publications, alleged to contain seditious writings, were extensively circulated was heard today in Federal Court.

MONTCLAIR, N. J., July 30 (AP) -- The four top-seeded players in the Montclair Athletic Club's third annual girls' invitation tennis tournament advanced to the semi-final round today and only Miss Lillian Lopaus of City Island. N. Y., 1940 winner of the tourney, was forced into an extra set.
CLEVELAND, July 30 -- The Indians climbed back to a virtual tie with second-place Boston today by rallying to wallop the Red Sox, 4 to 3, and finish the four-game series with an even break.

LONDON, Friday, July 31 -- Following a heavy British bomber attack on the German coal and steel-producing center of Saarbruecken over Wednesday night, the Royal Air Force struck-continued fighter and fighter-bomber blows over the French coast from dawn to dusk yesterday.

Since the Federal income and excess profits tax provisions of the Bethlehem Steel Corporation were virtually a flat 80 per cent of earnings, it follows that about this proportion of the retroactive wage and salary increases costing $5,600,000 from Feb. 6 to midyear came out of taxes.
PHILADELPHIA, July 30 (AP) -- Shortstop Bobby Bragan, who made his debut as a full-game catcher, lined a triple that drove in one run tonight to help the Phils to a 4-to-2 victory over the Reds.

WASHINGTON, July 30 -- The Senate adopted and sent to the White House today a bill authorizing the Navy Department to spend $974,634,000 for the establishment or expansion of naval shore facilities. The measure was said by Chairman Vinson of the House Naval Affairs Committee, to provide $30,000,000 for secret training with "a kind of secret weapon."

MOSCOW, Friday, July 31 (AP) -- Inspired by the call of Joseph Stalin to obey the example of some of the great heroes of the most desperate hours of Russia's history, the Red Army hurled the Germans back in their thrust at Stalingrad yesterday and waged a battle to annihilate those of the enemy who crossed the Don south of Tsimlyansk, the Russians announced today.

HARTFORD, Conn., July 30 -- Counter-espionage as well as espionage methods in the United States were revealed to a Federal jury today by the Rev. Aleksi Pelypenko, Ukrainian Roman Catholic priest, testifying for the government in the conspiracy case against the Rev. Kurt E.B. Molzahn.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., July 30 -- With only three fewer starters than in the opening yesterday, when 170 craft competed, the second program of the Larchmont Yacht Club's race week was held today, and again it was in a light condition that kept many away.

SOMEWHERE IN BRITAIN, July 30 -- Deadly looking pursuit planes with the markings of the United States Army Air Forces swept low across the airport here in line and in V formation at a recent display of their might, the first given by an all-American fighter station in this country.

It was a rather bitter letter from a seaman in the merchant marine that appeared on this page yesterday. Of what avail was it, this young man inquired, to have him and his kind referred to in print and speech as "unsung heroes of the merchant marine" if they were barred from USO and other public entertainments merely because they do not wear uniforms?

MOSCOW, Friday, July 31 -- The Russians pushed the Germans back somewhat yesterday in the sector southwest of Kletskaya, some eighty miles from Stalingrad, and continued to hold off enemy assaults on the southern Don at Tsimlyansk, though superior Nazi forces pushing southward and southeastward from Bataisk, below Rostov, extended their progress at some points.

An American sea captain has been taken prisoner by a submarine which presumably intended to transport him to Germany. This was made known by the Navy yesterday when it announced the sinking of a medium-sized American merchant vessel on July 9 in the South Atlantic about 1,000 miles off the northern coast of South America.

" Wings for the Eagle," a Warner Brothers' action drama starring Dennis Morgan, Ann Sheridan and Jack Carson, will be the film newcomer today at the Strand. Featured in the picture, which is the 3,000th film to be made by the studio, are George Tobias, Russell Arms, Don DeFore and Frank Wilcox.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., July 30 -- The only filly in the race, Pomayya, trained by the World War aviator, Hugh Fontaine, won for her breeder, Mrs. Dodge Sloane, today as 4.106 turned out for the races. This was a drop in attendance from last year's 5,804, but the weather was bright and every one seemed more cheerful than on the first three days of Saratoga's meeting.

LONDON, July 30 -- Isolationism is dead, but "old isolationists never really die; they merely dig their toes in in new positions," Archibald MacLeish, Librarian of Congress and assistant director of the United States Office of War Information, told an audience at the Rede Lecture at Cambridge University today.

While the battle for delegates between the Mead and Bennett forces continued within the ranks of the Democratic party yesterday in the race for Governor, the State committee of the American Labor party, committed to Senator James M. Mead and support of President Roosevelt, embarked on a daring manoeuvre designed to convince the Democrats that under no circumstances would it accept Attorney General John J. Bennett Jr. as a joint party nominee.

PAWLING, N.Y., July 30 -- The Pawling Preparatory School will not open for the Fall term, Dr. Frederick Luther Gamage. 82- year-old headmaster emeritus and founder, announced today after a meeting of the school's board of trustees.

As the heat wave abated slightly yesterday sixty guests of the greeting card industry sat down to an old-fashioned Christmas dinner at a "Christmas in July" party at which a display of new greeting cards was linked with the war bond drive.

LONDON, Friday, July 30 (AP) -- Flight Lieutenant John Joseph Mooney of East Hempstead, L.I., and Pilot Officer Leroy Skinner of Webb City, Mo., members of the second American Eagle Squadron of the Royal Air Force were reported today as missing after fighter sweeps over German-occupied territory.

CHUNGKING, China, July 30 -- Lauchlin Currie, personal representative of President Roosevelt, assured the Chinese today that operations in Europe would not prevent the United States from providing increasing military assistance to China.

DETROIT, July 30 (AP) -- The Tigers staged a 6-run rally in the eighth inning to defeat the Athletics, 11 to 5, in the opener of a double-header today, but the Macks took the nightcap, 7 to 6, on tight relief pitching by Roger Wolff.

WASHINGTON, July 30 -- The National War Labor Board has received panel reports in a series of textile eases which may not only determine the applicability of President Roosevelt's Wage policy affecting inequalities and substandard wages but also have a bearing on demands for removal of North-Side wage differentials.
AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, Australia, Friday, July 31 (AP) -- General Douglas MacArthur's command issued this communique today:

WASHINGTON, July 30 -- During the week ended July 29 member bank reserve balances decreased $6,000,000. Reductions in member bank reserves arose from increases of $101,000,000 in money circulation and $65,000,000 in non-member deposits and other Federal Reserve accounts, offset in part by a decrease of $115,000,000 in Treasury deposits with, Federal Reserve Banks and an increase of $41,000,000 in reserve bank credit.

Excess reserves of reporting member banks throughout the nation declined $100,000,000 during the week ended Wednesday, it was revealed yesterday by the Federal Reserve Board. The total of excess bank reserves now stands at $2,200,000,000.
MONTREAL, July 30 (Canadian Press ) -- The Royals tonight put a double stop to their five-game losing streak, twice downing Jersey City, 3 -- 1 and 12 -- 1.
The historic names used in Mr. Stalin's message evoke some parallels with the present situation.

WASHINGTON, July 30 -- President Roosevelt signed the bill authorizing the Women's Reserve in the Navy and attended the Hopkins-Macy wedding; his visitors included Sol Rosenblatt. Representative Jere Cooper, Secretary Jones, Norman Davis, Ambassador Litvinoff and Secretary Hull.

WASHINGTON, July 30 (U.P.) -- Pleas of innocence were entered in Federal district court today by seven of twenty-eight persons indicted a week ago on charges of a nation-wide conspiracy to undermine the morale of the armed forces.

DETROIT, July 30 (AP) -- A Federal grand jury indicted two companies and four individuals today on fraud charges growing out of the sale of 1,400,000 shares of stock in the bankrupt La Reine Gold Miners, Ltd., also known as the La Reine Molybdenum Mines, Ltd.

WASHINGTON, July 30 -- Leon Henderson, Price Administrator, this morning found a service station employe in Washington who recognized neither Mr. Henderson nor the gasoline-rationing regulations which he had promulgated.

" The less said about meat, the better," according to the Consumers Service Bureau of the New York Department of Markets. At the end of a conscientious survey of city shops, the department's scout reports only two items the prices of which have budged from last week's high level.

EAST HAMPTON, L.I., July 30 -- With eight of the first fifteen ranking players of the country entered, the annual East Hampton invitation tennis tournament for the Woodin Cups started today at the Maidstone Club.

Yale University having been picked as the training site of the Eastern division of the All-Army football team, Colonel Robert R. Neyland yesterday completed the organization of his coaching, training and managerial staff. The soldier squad starts work next week for its game with the New York Football Giants at the Polo Grounds on Sept. 12.

WASHINGTON, July 30 -- The Treasury cannot help out commercial silver users by releasing any of its stocks of non-monetary silver, Secretary Henry Morgenthau Jr. said this morning. The Treasury still has about 5,000,000 ounces of silver but considers the amount too small to be of material assistance to silversmiths and other users of the metal.

Mayor La Guardia opened the Harlem Toyery, a free lending library for toys at 39 West 135th Street, yesterday, declaring it was interesting and fascinating. He said he did not know why some one had not thought of it before. After the opening ceremony there was a joyous rush of fifty children for a choice selection of the 1,000 donated toys.
BUFFALO, July 30 (AP) -- The new Curtiss Commando (C-46), military transport plane, has passed exhaustive tests and is already in quantity production.

Yesterday's statement of the twelve Reserve Banks showed holdings of United States Government securities to be the highest on record, having increased $63,694,000 during the past week. Note circulation was also the highest for the year.

CAIRO, Egypt, July 30 -- British artillery fired briskly at enemy gun emplacements and vehicle groups yesterday in the central sector of the Egyptian battlefront. The barrage did not presage anything important, but merely established more firmly the institution known as "shoots."

WASHINGTON, July 30 -- An order directing that evidence be procured and forwarded to the Attorney General of the United States for the prosecution of the Arkansas Power and Light Company and its officers and employes responsible for attempting to destroy books and records sought by the commission was announced today by the Federal Power Commission.

Metropolitan retail liquor dealers are in full sympathy with the Office of Price Administration's "top-to-bottom" investigation of the liquor industry and hope that it will clear up the chaotic conditions existing in their division of the business and restore public confidence, members of the Metropolitan Package Store Association, Inc., declared yesterday at a meeting at the Park Central Hotel.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., July 30 -- Ted Schroeder or Glendale, Calif., the top-ranking player in the field, and Sidney Wood, former Wimbledon champion, dominated their respective divisions at the close of play today in the Southampton round-robin invitation tennis tournament at the Meadow Club.
LONDON, July 30 (AP) -- An Air Ministry communique said today:

Whether we revel in an outdoor Summer or take our ultraviolet in brief doses to and from the office, few of those lily maids are left who rejoiced a few months ago at the first pale rays of an April sun. A cosmetic checkup is more than due.

FAIRFIELD, Conn., July 30 -- Mrs. Russell Holman of Innis Arden won low gross honors today in one of the smallest fields to take part in the weekly one-day tournaments of the Westchester and Fairfield Women's Golf Association. She shot 42, 42 -- 84 at the Country Club of Fairfield.

It was the prophet Joel's prediction that "Your old men shall dream dreams, your young men shall see visions." William Dudley Pelley, founder of the Fascist Silver Shirts of America, now on trial for sedition in Indianapolis, had what must be described as a vision.

DETROIT, July 30 (AP) Freight-carrying airplanes will go far toward solving the world's distribution system after the war, but the "family airplane" to replace the family car is still somewhat remote, Henry Ford said today.

A steamship of a neutral nation arrived yesterday at Baltimore from Lisbon with 586 passengers, among whom were forty-two children coming here under the care of the United States Committee for the Care of Refugee Children, and 350 Jewish refugees. Many of the remaining passengers were Polish technicians going to Canada.
The following German High Command communique was broadcast yesterday from Berlin and recorded here by The Associated, Press:

Brig. Gen. Frank O'D. Hunter, who has just arrived in England, was until recently assigned to the United States Army Air Forces headquarters in Washington and was with the Eighth Air Force at Bolling Field, D.C., The Associated Press said. He was in England for several months in 1940 as a military observer.

The visit here yesterday of Republican State Chairman Edwin F. Jaeckle revived speculation as to the make-up of the Republican State ticket to be selected at the Saratoga convention Aug. 24 and 25, overlooked somewhat in recent weeks because of the lively row within the Democratic party.

After a conference yesterday with Lou Holland, chairman of the Federal Small War Plants Corporation, Mayor La Guardia said he hoped to reach a formula with Federal authorities which would permit greater participation in war work by the city's small manufacturers.
MOSCOW, Friday, July 31 (AP) -- The Soviet midnight communique follows:

Southpaw Vern Olsen had a neat one-hit shut-out for four innings at Ebbets Field last night, but when Louie Novikoff hit a home run off Johnny Allen in the fifth to give the Cubs a 2-0 lead, the Dodgers, already incensed at a couple of decisions, got really tough.

CHUNGKING, China, July 30 (UP) -- Japan now has in Manchukuo, facing Russia, twenty-four divisions, or a maximum of 600,000 men, compared with thirty-three divisions when the Pacific war started last December, a Chinese military spokesman said today.

A series of test mobilizations of air raid wardens to determine how quickly they could reach their posts in an actual raid on New York was held last night beginning at 8 o'clock, without advance notice.

A resolution recommending increased State aid for education and a reduction in the local real estate tax was made public yesterday by Wilford B. Reamer, president of the New York State School Boards Association, and James Marshall, former president of the local Board of Education.

By a directive of the Treasury Department, the New York Cotton Exchange auctioned yesterday on the Exchange floor nine seats defaulted by enemy nationals. These were sold for $3,000, one at $3,050, two at $3,100, two at $3,150 and one at $3,200.

I may be just envious of the hundreds of thousands who have been blessed by the silencing of the Second Avenue Elevated, and it may be that there are very good reasons for keeping the Third Avenue line in operation at this time, but there would seem to be no excuse for the number of trains that are kept roaring over its tracks -- each with only a sprinkling of passengers.

In announcing a dividenc( of 75 cents a share on the common stock, against 95 cents in the first :two quarters of the year, James L Hill Jr., president of Sterling Prodi ucts, Inc., pending tax legislation and the necessity for carrying heavier inventories, persuaded the i directors to conserve cash resources.

Brooklyn police found twenty- four ripe bananas in the borough yesterday after a frantic search for the fruit which was urgently needed for the diet of a 15-month-old baby suffering from celiac, a rare form of dysentery.

LONDON, July 30 -- The arrival in this country of four commanders of the United States Army Air Forces was announced today coincidentally with an announcement in the House of Commons by Sir Stafford Cripps, Lord Privy Seal, that the British Government has "intentions" in regard to a second front.

Leading men's hat manufacturers will show their 1943 Summer lines to the trade tomorrow, with wholesale prices generally continuing at last year's levels. Some new bodies will be introduced, Manufacturers stated yesterday that no attempt has been made to narrow the number of offerings for next year.

American Army transport pilots were praised for their service in the evacuation of civilians from upper Burma by the Rev. Dr. Frederick Dickason, Burma missionary, in a message received here yesterday by the American Baptist Missionary Society.

WASHINGTON, July 30 -- Robert P. Patterson Under-Secretary of War, will complete his second year of service in the War Department tomorrow. Judge Patterson took office as Assistant Secretary of War on July 31, 1940, and on Dec. 20 of the same year was elevated by President Roosevelt to the new post of Under-Secretary of War.

Net billings of the Bethlehem Steel Corporation in the first half of 1942 set a new record of $665,770,000, and it is estimated they will be at least $1,400,000,000 and probably $1,500,000,000 for the year, Eugene G. Grace, president, said after the quarterly meeting of directors yesterday.

CHICAGO, July 30 -- Wheat showed a rather firm undertone in the early trading today with commission houses and shorts on the buying side, but the bulge weakened the technical position and when increased pressure made its appearance later, including hedging by the Southwest, the support was not aggressive and prices dropped 1 5/8 cents a bushels from the top.

Despite stabilizing operations by houses responsible for off-the-board offerings after the close, volume on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday was 250,640 shares, the smallest in a week. Prices drifted irregularly and closed dull and mixed.

In fact, though not in form, the seven Nazi saboteurs whose fate is being decided in Washington are having a civil trial under the fairest possible conditions. Much of the testimony given before the military commission has necessarily been withheld in the Supreme Court hearings, partly, no doubt, because it contained military secrets, and partly because it was irrelevant.

LONDON, July 30 -- Although the stock markets were brighter today there was no improvement in the turnover. Gilt-edge issues were unchanged and the home rails were steady. The hope that the London Midland-Scottish Railway would resume interim ordinary dividend payments after a twelve-year lapse was disappointed.

VICHY, France, July 30 (UP) -- German-controlled Paris newspapers said today that the German Army displayed numerous new types of motorized equipment, including a three-man troop-carrying car similar to the American jeep, during a long parade in Paris yesterday, which was Adolf Hitler's answer to the British-American "radio propaganda threat of a second front."

WASHINGTON, Judy 30 -- Whatever its merits as a rubber conservation measure, a proposed country-wide rationing of gasoline would have no effect on the petroleum shortage in the East Coast area, Secretary Ickes said today.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., July 30 -- Members of the Garden Club of Southampton are harvesting their Victory Garden, comprising an acre of herbs, planned last Winter by Mrs. Robert Malcolm Littlejohn, who donated an acre of land at Little Cote, her estate in Great Plains Road, for the project.

WASHINGTON, July 30 -- Except for a sharp advance in the livestock market and seasonally higher prices for citrus fruits commodity markets continued comparatively steady during the week ended July 25.

WASHINGTON, July 30 -- In a ruling today, the Office of Price Administration established a provision for adjustable pricing contracts and granted permission to sellers of woolen and worsted civilian apparel fabrics who have petitions for adjustment pending to make deliveries of goods at prices which may later be adjusted.

WASHINGTON, July 30 -- The Administration was urged by Senator Taft today to adopt a different fiscal policy, exert greater control over farm prices and wages and take the control of prices away from Leon Henderson and turn it over to a commodity control board.

Prince Wilhelm of Hesse has been killed in action on the Eastern Front, where he served as captain in an infantry regiment, said a Stefani news agency dispatch from Berlin broadcast by the Rome radio and recorded by the United Press in New York.

WASHINGTON, July 30 (UP) -- Representative Warren J. Magnuson of Washington said today he had heard reports that Japanese forces had occupied the Pribilof Islands, about 200 miles north of Dutch Harbor, but a House colleague from whom Mr. Magnuson had received his information said that the reports were "entirely unconfirmed."
Like the Navy, the Army has recognized the need for the physical toughening of its men and, particularly in recent months, various hardening processes have been started.

WASHINGTON, July 30 -- Specially treated wooden soles may be the answer to the lack of top-grade leather for the soles of women's shoes, it was reported today by the consumer division of the Office of Price Administration.

Theodore Stitt, Brooklyn attorney and a former newspaper man in that borough, was sworn in by Mayor La Guardia at City Hall yesterday as a justice of the Domestic Relations Court to fill the unexpired term of Justice John Warren Hill, which ends on Oct. 31, 1944.

Exemption of all pre-1918 automobiles from proposed legislation to junk over-age cars for scrap metal for war was sought yesterday by the Automobile Old Timers, Inc., at an open meeting held in the Hotel Roosevelt.
The Manufacturers Trust Company has been appointed paying agent for Cairo Bridge Commission bridge revenue bonds in the amount of $2,275,000 on 3 1/4 s and $500,000 on 3 1/4 s, dated Feb. 1, 1942.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 30 -- Warner Brothers today assigned Olivia de Havilland and Dennis Morgan to the leading roles in "One More Tomorrow," an unproduced play by Edwin Gilbert formerly titled "Reminiscences," which the studio acquired last November.

JERSEY CITY N.J., July 30 -- A complex shuffling of city and county officials, in which Frank Hague Eggers, nephew and secretary of Mayor Frank Hague, will become a member of the City Commission at next Tuesday's meeting, was announced today by Mr. Hague at City Hall.

WASHINGTON, July 30 -- Henry J. Kaiser, West Coast dam and ship builder, breathing the gospel of "doing the 'impossible' and getting things done," told Senate committees today that, given the materials and a go-ahead signal, he could in ten months produce a 70-ton cargo plane which could fly a 20-ton load to Honolulu, and in fourteen months could build a 200- tonner having a proportionately increased load capacity.
Do the people of our country, and especially do those who govern our country, realize what inflation really is like?

FORT HANCOCK, N.J., July 30 -- Sandy Hook Lighthouse, unfailing beacon to mariners since 1764 except for a brief period during the Revolutionary War, has been extinguished for the war's duration in conformance with wartime regulations, it was announced today by Brig. Gen. Philip S. Gage, commander of the defenses of New York Harbor.

CHUNGKING, China, July 30 (AP) -- Major John E. Allison, who flew Harry Hopkins to Moscow last year, scored one of the most spectacular individual performances by the United States Air Forces in China today by shooting down two of three Japanese bombers destroyed out of a nine-plane enemy squadron raiding Hengyang, Hunan Province.

The United States Rubber Company's shipments of war products in the first half of this year were more than three times as large as those for the corresponding period a year ago, F.B. Davis Jr., chairman and president, declared in the semi-annual statement of operations, issued for publication today.

The New York Stock Exchange yesterday approved member and member firm participation in the secondary distribution by Dillon, Read Co. of 100,000 shares of the capital stock of the Standard Oil Company of California at 21 net until 10 A.M. today, and thereafter, if available, at last sale plus an amount equal to commissions on the Exchange.

A suggestion that the city colleges establish a central institute for consumers to which housewives and others could go for information was advanced yesterday by Dr. Persia Campbell of the consumer services division of the Civilian Defense Volunteer Office at a conference on wartime economic problems held yesterday at Hunter College.

TRENTON, July 30 -- John Spislander, 37 years old, who is unemployed, talked himself into serious trouble today to the great relief of his next-door neighbor, Louis Mack, 60. Tonight Spislander is under arrest on charges of breaking, entering and larceny, and Mr. Mack has regained his life's savings of $20,883.

BARCELONA, Spain, July 30 (AP) -- Carlton J. Hayes, United States Ambassador to Spain, told a meeting attended by many Spanish officials and business men today that the United States realized the difficulties of Spain's position "between the sword and the wall."

NEWARK, N.J., July 30 -- An alleged adventure in deception by Warner J. McFarlane, who purportedly posed in a series of exploits as an Army major and an FBI agent, was unfolded here today by the Federal Bureau of Investigation after it had arrested him on a charge of impersonating a representative of the War Department.

Passenger revenues of the New York, New Haven Hartford Railroad increased nearly 80 per cent in June, compared with June, 1941, the company announced yesterday. These revenues were $4,533,332 in June, compared with $2,635,469 in June, 1941, bringing this revenue for the first half of the year to $21,896,556, against $13,968,351 in the same period last year.

An atmosphere of unreality surrounds lay arguments concerning whether or not a second front should be opened. For if the question merely concerned the desirability of a second front, as so much of that discussion assumes, the answer would be simple and easy.

Edward L. Shea, president of the North American Company, indicated yesterday that the $1,000,000,000 utility system would terminate its litigation against the Securities and Exchange Commission if an acceptable solution to the company's problems under the "death sentence" could be worked out.

In your issue of July 23 Mark Starr of the International Ladies' Garment Workers Union comments on the increased sum of money received by certain officers of the Bethlehem and Republic Steel Corporations. He suggests that in raising these sums the companies do not appear to be actuated by any fear of inflation.
WASHINGTON, July 30 -- Maxim Litvinoff, the Soviet Ambassador, conferred for a quarter of an hour with President Roosevelt today but refrained from indicating the nature of the conversation.
MOSCOW, July 30 (AP) -- The Soviet Information Bureau issued this communique today:

NYACK, N.Y., July 30 -- A dream of many householders -- to read their own gas and electric meters -- will come true for the consumers of the Rockland Light and Power Company for eight months of the year, at least, starting next month.

The Selective Training and Service Act has earned deserved praise for the democratic fairness with which it has operated. The necessity of Washington's latest order to local draft boards, however, itself reveals that the problems of selective service administration are becoming more complicated.

BERNE, Switzerland, July 31 -- Crop prospects in Central and Southeastern European countries are ostensibly viewed more favorably in German official quarters as harvesting approaches and a report issued by the Dienst Aus Deutschland, a semi-official news agency, predicts that the yield throughout those areas will exceed the averages of 1940-41.
CANBERRA, Australia, July 31 -- In an effort to consolidate its position against the government, the executive of the federal opposition has just concluded a two-day meeting.

CHICAGO, July 31 -- The Association of Commerce entered a guarded protest against a WPB store inventory-control program for retailers today when it released a summary of Midwestern store opinion on the subject and added that:

Adverse weather conditions took toll of retail trade here this week. Department store volume was estimated as running around 5 per cent under the comparative 1941 week. Winter coat and furniture promotions met only fair consumer response.

We believe that the country drew a long breath of relief yesterday at the Supreme Court's unanimous decision in the saboteur case and at the reasons briefly cited for it. The Court's full opinion, which will be made public later on, will go into our constitutional histories beside the Milligan decision, delivered in 1866.

LONDON, July 31 (AP)--Mounting British and American offensive preparations, coupled with continuing strategy conferences, caused observers to believe tonight that a decision had been reached to aid the impatient Russian allies with as quick and positive action in Western Europe as the combined Anglo-American resources would permit.

VICHY, France, July 31 -- The French Admiralty announced tonight that a French destroyer, aided by a group of navy planes, had freed a French cargo ship that had been stopped in the Mediterranean by a British submarine.

WASHINGTON, July 31 -- President Roosevelt has signed legislation fixing pensions for dependents of members of the regular Army, Navy, Marines and Coast Guard who died during peacetime as a result of service-incurred disabilities.

New York City had its first surprise air raid drill and blackout last night and observers agreed that it was highly effective in view of the fact that the public had no advance warning when it would come.

CLEVELAND, July 31 (AP) -- The Athletics, aided by Bob Johnson's three-run homer in the fifth inning, beat the Indians tonight, 6 to 4, in a contest marked by five errors. Oris Hockett hit for the circuit for Cleveland.

PONTIAC, Mich., July 31 -- A jurisdictional dispute between rival grocery clerks' unions of the A.F. of L. and the C.I.O. forced the closing of three large war production plants here in Pontiac, and brought a day of street fighting and a threat of a critical food shortage to Oakland County until Governor Van Wagoner announced this evening that the leaders had agreed to arbitration.

PHILADELPHIA, July 31 -- Moderate rationing of gasoline and oil in the Midwestern States would provide the Atlantic Coast with its minimum requirements of fuel, Mayor La Guardia of New York declared in a letter received today by Mayor Bernard Samuel of Philadelphia.

Steadily during tile war effort research is disclosing new things and new methods that will be available to all of us when peace comes. In the laboratories of large companies important strides have been made in chemical, mechanical and other fields. Many of them cannot be revealed at present.

ST. LOUIS, July 31 -- The Yankees had their second successive try this evening at baseball's latest wartime innovation, the twilight-night double-header, and this time contrived to score a partial success, demonstrating that world champions are never to be baffled for long, no matter what the conditions.

LONDON, July 31 -- Private Bill (Feets) Adams of Grand Rapids, Mich., and his buddy, Private Jack Weiland of Mitchell, S.D., said today that they did not think of the incident as a matter of applied democracy -- it just seemed a natural thing to do at the time.
ALBANY, July 31 (AP) -- Republican committee chairmen from about twenty-five counties will confer on the State political situation Monday with the State chairman, Edwin F. Jaeckle.
Five new plays and a musical will have tryouts in the Summer theatres of the East next week. They are:
LONDON, July 31 (Reuter) -- Wartime nurseries for babies of mothers working in war industries are spreading throughout Britain. Today London alone has 153, with another 145 in preparation.

WASHINGTON, July 31 -- Inability of the Office of Price Administration and the United States Department of Agriculture to come to an agreement upon the method to be adopted in establishing a pricing compromise for canners of vegetables was reported today as responsible for delays in the formal announcement of a program.

WASHINGTON, July 31 -- Assurance was given today by Donald M. Nelson, chairman of the War Production Board, that if the proposal of Henry J. Kaiser to build 5,000 cargo planes in shipyards could be accomplished without disrupting the output of military aircraft the West Coast dam and ship builder would "get plenty of action" from the WPB.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., July 31 -- Ted Schroeder of Glendale, Calif., and Sidney Wood of Southampton finished on top of their respective groups in the round-robin tennis tournament at the Meadow Club today when each scored his fifth successive victory.

LONDON, July 31 -- Beginning today the British police will halt motor cars to prevent nonessential driving in the British Isles for the duration of the war. Only doctors, midwives, nurses, commercial travelers and others on necessary errands will hereafter be allowed on the streets and highways in automobiles.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, July 31 -- The reply of Vidkun Quisling, Norwegian Premier, to last Sunday's manifesto to the Norwegian churchmen proclaiming a definite breach between the church and State and forming a "provisional church council" heralds new reprisals against the Norwegian Bishops.

WASHINGTON, July 31 -- Housewives, as sellers of surplus kitchen fats, have been made subject to a price ceiling, of 4 cents a pound for the waste fats they deliver to the local butcher as part of the fats-salvage campaign. The new regulation, announced today by Leon Henderson, Price Administrator, will be effective tomorrow and will take the place of the average 6 cent price housewives have been getting.

Perhaps we didn't get the whole story. But from what appeared in the papers, the rebellion put on by a bunch of hifalutin professional golfers at the recent Tam O'Shanter tournament was enough to turn a strong stomach.

Supreme Court Justice J. Sidney Bernstein cut $2,500 yesterday off of the $10,000 bail set in Special Sessions for Fred (Big Freddie) Bertolotti on a charge of violating the State banking law, but refused to reduce the bail any lower.
The establishment of a free legal advice clinic for men in the armed services was announced yesterday by Mrs. Edgar W. Leonard, Greater New York chairman of the American Women's Voluntary Services.

The statement made yesterday by the Socony-Vacuum Oil Company, Inc., that overland supplies of oil to the rationed area on the Atlantic Coast recently have been running very slightly in excess of essential requirements gave an indication of what the oil industry has been doing to meet the situation caused by the decrease in the tanker movement because of submarine activity and diversion to the war effort.

NEWARK, N.J., July 31 -- Dr. Leopold W.A. Brandenburg, Union City physician, was convicted by a jury in Federal Court here this afternoon on a charge of concealing a fugitive from justice, during which time he performed a skin-grafting operation with the object of altering the fugitive's fingerprints.

MEXICO CITY, July 31 -- About 26,000 acres in the Tiajuana district were returned to Mrs. Susana Lucero de Regnier, an American, recently through a Mexican Supreme Court decision subject to endorsement by the Department of Agriculture, government officials announced here.
BOSTON, July 31 Gene (Junior) Thompson threw a three-hitter at the Braves today to give the Reds a 5-2 decision and the opening tilt of a four-game week-end series.

Sales of war savings bonds were sharply higher in July and attained a level in excess of 90 per cent of the quota set for the month by the United States Treasury, according to the Monthly Review of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, issued yesterday.

Your editorial of July 29, "International Communication," is a timely and constructive comment in this field. There is pending in Congress a bill to permit the merger of companies engaged in domestic telegraph communications. Chairman James Lawrence Fly of the Federal Communications Commission has urged that the bill be broadened to permit as well the merger of companies in the international field.

CHICAGO, July 31 -- Scattered liquidation developed in wheat futures today and with a lack of aggressive support until late in the session all deliveries declined to a new seasonal low level. A little buying by mills and covering by shorts caused a late rally but the finish on the Board of Trade was at losses of 5/8 to 1 cent a bushel.

WASHINGTON, July 31 (AP) -- Walter P. Hedden, director of port development of the Port of New York Authority, proposed today the marshaling of transportation facilities "in an intensive shuttle service" from Great Lakes ports eastward to bring badly needed fuel oil to the Atlantic seaboard States.

There are more than 7,000 islands in the Philippines, solitary outpost of Christianity in a teeming Orient. In Luzon, largest of the 300 inhabited islands, is the Philippine capital, Manila. Mainly English-speaking, the people of Manila are oriental in feature and temperament; but spiritually they are worlds apart from the Japanese, whose armies are now in possession of the islands.

Carrie Rossman purchased the six-story tenement on a plot 25 by 105 feet at 296 East Second Street, between Avenues C and D, through the P. Zaccaro Company and H.V. Mead Co. The parcel is assessed at $20,000 and was sold subject to a first mortgage of $7,500 held by the Bowery Savings Bank.
MOSCOW, Saturday, Aug 1 (AP) -- Last midnight's Soviet communique follows:

In your July 23 editorial, "What Makes Inflation," you state that the corporation executive who seeks to enrich himself out of the war will find the chances of getting away with it practically nil because the Treasury Department will disallow excessive compensation.

Alone among its northern neighbors, Sweden has contrived to stay out of two world wars. The visitor to Scandinavia in the interim between these upheavals was a little puzzled at first by the difference he felt in the atmosphere and outlook of these countries, as compared to the rest of Europe.

British and American naval officers of high rank and prominent civilians joined in a special ceremony yesterday at which swords were presented to six honor graduates of a special course in naval training on the U.S.S. Prairie State.

Earnings of the Texas Company and its subsidiaries, excluding those in Europe, are estimated at $15,270,746 or $1.40 a share for the first half of this year, according to the report of W.S.S. Rodgers, president, announced yesterday.

A trick of stretching one's sugar ration that seems to us very much like black magic has been evolved by the Florida Agricultural Experiment Station. With it, one starts out with two cups of sugar and winds up with the equivalent of more than two and a half cups.

PITTSBURGH. July 31 -- Wage negotiations between the United Steel Workers of America (C.I.O.) and the United States Steel Corporation subsidiaries which began today were adjourned until Thursday after the union had presented demands closely paralleling concessions granted by the War Labor Board in the "little steel" case.

The approximate status of the municipal bond market is reflected in the following list of representative high-grade State, city and county bonds legal for savings banks in New York State, now offered by dealers:

WASHINGTON, July 31 -- Sales of wholesalers advanced 11 per cent in June, 1942, compared with June, 1941, according to J.C. Capt, Director of the Census. This gain was the smallest recorded for nineteen months except for the 7 per cent increase shown in May.

The account in THE TIMES of the situation in Japan and China and the plight of our people still held captive there merely re-emphasizes the urgent necessity of our rendering greater aid to China in her fight against Japanese aggression. While our habits of life are very little changed, and we enjoy most of our usual comforts, our friends, the Chinese, the British, the Dutch and the Russians, are suffering the extremities of hardship.

Declaring that the milk industry in New York has been caught "in the vise of conflicting governmental regulations," J.O. East-lack, secretary of the New York Metropolitan Milk Distributors' Bargaining Agency, issued a statement yesterday emphasizing the necessity for a solution of "the existing conflict in the governmental policies."

A service flag and plaque were dedicated yesterday at R.H. Macy Co. in honor of 1,371 employes now in the armed forces. More than 3,000 clerks and others working in the store witnessed the ceremony in the Broadway building on the street floor.

HARTFORD, Conn., July 31 -- In the midst of a legal argument over the admissibility of testimony about a conversation, presumably connecting the Rev. Kurt E.B. Molzahn, Lutheran pastor of Philadelphia, with an alleged conspiracy in violation of the 1917 Espionage Act, the trial of the Rev. Mr. Molzahn before Federal Judge Joseph Smith and a jury was recessed late this afternoon until Monday.

WASHINGTON, July 31 -- A Navy spokesman estimated today that the Japanese had thrown a force of possibly 10,000 men into the westernmost Aleutian Islands, of which about half are actually occupying territory ashore and half are either manning or living on warships and transports in the area.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., July 31 -- There is a place for the garden hose as well as the sand box in the attics of suburban homes, Westchester County civilian defense officials agreed today, following last night's demonstration in New York City of the efficacy of the "jet" method over the "spray" method in dealing with incendiary bombs.

Five minutes daily of prayer for Divine guidance and "for the protection of those engaged in the service and defense of their country" has been asked of the 150,000 members of the National Society, Daughters of the American Revolution, by its president general, Mrs. William H. Pough.

Two Broadway theatres will present new film attractions this morning. At the Rialto, the newcomer will be "A-Haunting We Will Go," a Twentieth Century-Fox comedy-melodrama with Stan Laurel and Oliver Hardy. Among the supporting players are Dante the magician, John Shelton, Sheila Ryan and Elisha Cook Jr.
ALBANY, July 31 (AP) -- Allocation of large quantities of auxiliary fire-fighting equipment by the Federal Civilian Defense Office to twenty New York cities was disclosed today.

National Newspaper Week, which will be celebrated this year from Oct. 1 to 8, will have for its theme "American Newspapers Go All-out for Victory," Vernon T. Sanford, chairman of the Newspaper Association Managers public relations committee, announced yesterday.

The spirit of Mr. Cullen's letter last week, in which he asked for an end to jibes hurled at American bettors on horses because it's that willingness to take a chance which marks us as a nation, needs refutation.

CHICAGO, July 31 (AP) -- With eight other horses daring to oppose him, Whirlaway, turfdom's all-time money winning champion, probably will go to the post a 2-to-5 favorite to win the $31,600 Arlington Handicap tomorrow.

German, Rumanian and Slovak troops have crossed the lower Don River on a 150-mile front and have thrust spearheads 110 miles south of the river, the German High Command declared yesterday, according to Nazi broadcasts recorded by The Associated Press.
Two interesting letters which recently appeared on the sports pages of THE TIMES prompt me to write you.

Chief Magistrate Henry H. Curran announced yesterday that beginning today street-walking cases would be arraigned in Women's Court instead of in the district courts and that he was assigning an extra magistrate to the Women's Court.
LONDON, July 31 (AP) -- An Air Ministry communique today said:

There has been no considerable change in the general fishing picture at Peconic Bay during the past ten days. There are still plenty of weakfish and kingfish as well as porgies in the bay, but the season nevertheless continues to be a quiet one as far as angling activities are concerned.

The weakness exhibited by the stock market in the last week, as a result of serious inroads into earnings and dividends by tax contingencies, found yesterday some relief. The earnings report of Bethlehem Steel, which showed a better than anticipated quarter profit, was held primarily responsible for the change of price direction, and the early strength in this issue brought considerable heart to other industrial sections.

TO the best of deponent's knowledge and belief, nobody died of laughter over the Revolt on the Links that occurred in the Chicago district just a week ago today. But it might have happened. It isn't often that golf produces a good loud laugh all around. For the most part, golf is a dreadfully serious game. But those who follow sports are still chuckling over the Revolt on the Links.

"SUPPOSE," says Katherine Anne Porter in her generous, precise and stimulating introduction to "Fiesta in November: Stories From Latin America,"* "suppose we agree with the rude old prophet who remarked that all men are liars; I still trust the artist most; I believe he lies less than other men."

A refreshing wind from the west blew through committee rooms of the Senate when Henry J. Kaiser, ship and dam builder from that Pacific Coast, proclaimed his faith that nothing is "impossible" for American industry. Urging his plan of having shipyards convert part of their facilities immediately to the construction of cargo airplanes, he declared that these could be produced in quantity without curtailing the present production of cargo vessels.

The New York Academy of Medicine, as beneficiary of two-thirds of the residuary estate of Miss Fanny Norris, will receive approximately $170,796 to establish a fund in memory of her brother, the late Dr. Charles Norris, former Chief Medical Examiner of New York City.

In a market ruled by cautious waiting, cotton prices moved unevenly yesterday and closed 5 to 6 points higher. Covering of short positions near the end of trading on the New York Cotton Exchange accounted for a late upswing after liquidation earlier had caused losses up to 9 points.

BRIARCLIFF MANOR, N.Y., July 31 -- The possibility of a return match between Ray Billows, Poughkeepsie ace, and young Doug Ford, who crashed in the semifinal round of the New York State amateur championship at Niagara Falls last week, loomed up today when both qualified for the first flight in the ninth annual Briar Hills invitation golf tourney.

Examination of publication schedules for August reveals that in keeping with a trend of recent years a number of strong titles will be brought out. Once August was looked upon by publishers as a sort of breathing period between early Summer publications and Fall.

One hundred and four "American beauties" paraded proudly before an auditorium of cheering friends and relatives at the twenty-seventh annual Baby Beauty contest for babies of the lower East Side held yesterday at the Educational Alliance, East Broadway and Jefferson Street.

This being Aug. 1, the world is about equally divided between those who are safely past their vacations and those who still face them. It is unfortunate that a complete exchange of views cannot be had between these two great groups; but even if it were physically possible it is unlikely, human nature being what it is, that any substantial lesson could be taught or learned.

WASHINGTON, July 31 -- Secretary of State Cordell Hu'l today received a collective note emanating from the Belgian, Norwegian, Czechoslovak, Greek, Luxembourg, Netherland, Polish and Yugoslav Governments and the French National Committee, asking that President Roosevelt address a last warning to Germany and the other Axis powers against the "barbaric and inhuman crimes" committed daily in the occupied countries.

SARATOGA SPRINGS. N.Y., July 31 -- Mr. and Mrs. John A. Morris entertained with a luncheon today at their cottage before the races for Mr. and Mrs. James Bruce of Baltimore, Mrs. James Russell Lowell of New York and George H. Bull.
CHICAGO, July 31 (AP) -- Chicago's Auditorium theatre and hotel, once a center of midwestern culture, will awaken soon to the shouts of soldiers and sailors having fun.
As had long been anticipated, July ended yesterday with somber news.

Stockholders of the Morris Essex Railroad elected an independent board of directors yesterday to replace one chiefly representative of the Delaware, Lackawanna Western Railroad, which leases the M. E. This procedure was undertaken as a step toward compelling the Lackawanna to pay the M. E.'s income taxes.

New bond financing virtually came to a halt this week when only one new issue was offered here for public subscription. The issue amounted to $1,200,000 and made the weekly total the smallest since the week ended Dec. 12, 1941, and one of the smallest since the outbreak of the war in Europe in 1939.

LONDON, July 31 -- The recent warning of Herbert Morrison, Home Secretary, that British women may soon be called on for compulsory fire-watching duties was followed today by a recommendation from the Committee of National Expenditure, which has been inquiring into national fire service affairs, that women should be recruited to replace nearly all the men in administrative duties.

WASHINGTON, July 30 -- Colonel Kenneth C. Royall, the powerfully built lawyer for the Nazi prisoners, who was so thoroughly questioned by Justice Frankfurter in the Supreme Court, is a former law student of the justice at Harvard. Despite the barrage of questioning from his former professor, the colonel "got a big kick out of it," Mrs. Royall said to friends.
SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., July 31 -- Many guests have arrived to spend the week-end at estates in the colony and attend the finals of the annual invitation tennis tournament tomorrow at the Meadow Club.
BUFFALO, N.Y., July 31 (AP) -- The Bears defeated Buffalo, 5 -- 2, tonight, running the losing streak of the Bisons to six in a row and burying them deeper in the second division.

LONDON, July 31 -- Light British coastal craft engaged enemy shipping in the English Channel and the North Sea today in the face of Nazi air fighters and shore batteries and succeeded in inflicting damage, probably sinking one enemy vessel, the Admiralty announced.

Ray Robinson, the Harlem sharpshooter, is Sammy Angott's master. He proved that conclusively at Madison Square Garden last night when he spotted the lightweight champion three of the first four rounds -- one because of a low punch -- and then proceeded to deal out an unmerciful lacing to his rival.
