The International Committee of Bankers on Mexico filed in the Supreme Court here yesterday its final account in the action started some years ago to obtain a judicial settlement of its accounts from the time it was formed in 1919 to date. The statement showed that in the twenty-three years of its existence it recovered about $45,000,000 for bondholders, less expenses of about $5,777,000.

When the Germans rushed through Yugoslavia in the Spring of 1941 there was consternation in the Allied countries over what appeared to be the collapse of the Serbs. In the other World War they had fought to the last ditch and died by thousands in a ghastly retreat rather than surrender.
MOSCOW, July 31 (AP) -- The Soviet Information Bureau issued this communique today:

INDIANAPOLIS, July 31 -- A parallel between Axis propaganda and the program advocated since America's entry into the war by William Dudley Pelley's magazine, The Galilean, was drawn today by prosecution witnesses as the government ended its direct case against the former Silver Shirt leader who with two associates is being tried on sedition charges in Federal court.

WASHINGTON, July 31 -- Senator George, chairman of the Senate Finance Committee, appointed today a subcommittee, headed by Senator Brown, to rewrite a provision in the House tax bill imposing a limitation upon the tax-free contributions of corporations to self-operated employe pension funds.

Commuters from Bay Shore. L.I., and members of the Association of Long Island Commuters appeared at the Public Service Commission, 80 Center Street, yesterday to protest against the Long Island Railroad's discontinuance of service on its Summer schedule of a Bay Shore stop on the South Shore train that leaves Pennsylvania Station at 5:37 P.M.

PRINCETON, N.J., July 31 -- While there may still be confusion in the minds of the people about the rubber situation, car owners throughout the country are willing to turn over tires to the government if the need arises.
WASHINGTON, July 31 -- The text of the Supreme Court's decision in the Nazi saboteur case was as follows:

As a step in its effort to increase its control of the Florida East Coast Railway, the estate of Alfred I. du Pont made public yesterday an offer to buy $3,000,000 of the company's 5 per cent bonds at 16 1/2 per cent of the principal amount. Under the Interstate Commerce Commission's plan of reorganization, holders of the bonds would receive stock control of the reorganized company.

Bonds called before maturity for payment in July amounted to $46,488,000, compared with S42,067,000 in the preceding month and $252,490,000 in July, 1941. While bond prepayments were slightly larger last month than in June, they were, nevertheless, the smallest for any July since 1933, when the total was $12,509,000.

DENVER, July 31 -- Denver's garret ghost of Moncrieff Place resolved into a man of mystery tonight while police delved deeper into his eerie story of skulking for nine months beneath the roof of the man he had slain.

WASHINGTON, July 31 -- Secretary Perkins reported today that the June level of civil non-agricultural employment was the highest on record, accounting for 41,415,000, an increase of 152,000 for the month. The June peak, according to the Secretary of Labor, exceeded the previous peak of December, 1941, by 335,000, and the June, 1941, level by 1,940,000.

FORT DIX, N.J., July 31 -- The public relations officer at Fort Dix announced today that Winston Churchill had arrived at the 1229th Reception Center, without a big black cigar in his mouth and without a guard of honor.

Rain and the war industries had their effect yesterday on the twenty-third annual outing of students and alumni of the Institute for the Crippled and Disabled, but the 900 participtants had a fine time anyhow, thanks to a jazz band, decks of cards and their own unquenchable spirit.
DETROIT, July 31 (AP) -- The Red Sox squelched a ninth-inning Detroit uprising after Charley Gehringer had delivered a two-run pinch homer and shaded the Tigers today, 7 to 6.

WASHINGTON, July 31 (AP)--Robert P. Patterson, Under Secretary of War, reported today that shortages of raw materials had taken the place of transport of finished supplies as the most urgent immediate problem of the war.

Most of the recommendations in Senator Taft's "five-point program" are in the right direction, even if they fail to go far enough. He is right in contending that a sound Government fiscal policy is more important than any price-control scheme. He is right in opposing rigid price-fixing on minor items that have no substantial effect on the cost of living.

Pastors and visiting preachers tomorrow will urge parishioners, no matter of what age, to do some definite work every day or at least every week to help obtain victory. The message will be delivered either by reading a formal request or incorporating such a plea in their sermons.

MOSCOW, Saturday, Aug. 1 -- The Red Army has retreated deeper into the Western Caucasus below Bataisk, but reinforced Soviet legions were reported early today to have stalled a big Nazi drive in the Kletskaya area, some eighty miles northwest of Stalingrad, where the Russians rushed trainloads of reserves to the front.
WASHINGTON. July 31 (U.P.) -- Assistant Attorney General Thurman Arnold asked Congress today to enact amendments to the antitrust laws to curb what he termed "the misuse of our patent system."

BUENOS AIRES, Argentina, July 31 -- By a resolution of the Director General of Posts and Telegraphs, published today, no radio station will be allowed to broadcast local Argentine news unless it is supplied by an Argentine agency.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 31 -- Paramount today tested Ingrid Bergman for the role of Maria in "For Whom The Bell Tolls," the part to which Vera Zorina was assigned three weeks ago after extensive tests of her own. The first rushes of Miss Zorina's work in the picture were unsatisfactory, nevertheless, and Sam Wood, director of the film, is understood to have requested her replacement.

BERNE, Switzerland, July 31 -- More assertions respecting German fortifications along the Western European coast are contained in an official communique circulated today by D.N.B., German official news bureau. It states:

NEWPORT, NEWS, Va., July 31 -- The first aircraft carrier of the Navy to be launched since Pearl Harbor and since the recent decision of our naval experts to concentrate on building carriers at the expense of battleships slid down the ways this afternoon at 2:49 P.M.

EAST HAMPTON, L.I., July 31 -- Miss Doris Hart of Miami, eleventh in the national ranking. furnished a surprise in the women's invitation tennis tournament at the Maidstone Club today when she defeated Miss Hope Knowles of Avon, Conn., 6 -- 4, 6 -- 1.

Robert Brennan, Eire Minister to the United States, arriving here yesterday aboard an American Export flying boat at La Guardia Airport, declared that the Irish people "are determined more than ever to remain out of the war." The Irish diplomat was returning to his Washington post after a five-week vacation at home.

Concurrently with the announcement yesterday by Captain Kenneth G. Castleman, director of the Office of Naval Officer Procurement at 33 Pine Street, that recruiting for 1,000 women appointed for voluntary emergency service by the Navy Department is already under way, arrangements were being completed for the departure for Fort Des Moines, Iowa, of another group of New York women entering the Women's Army Auxiliary Corps training camp there.
Renting of apartments yesterday covered a wide area in the city. The leasing was featured by a demand for suites in the West Side and Washington Heights areas.

The arrest of Mimo D. Guzman, a 42-year-old Filipino who has spent years exhorting members of the "dark-skinned races" to unite against the United States was announced yesterday by J. Edgar Hoover, director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation. His activities were linked to Japan's nationalistic and militaristic Black Dragon society.

WASHINGTON, July 31 -- John F. Dulles of New York City, chairman of the Federal Council of Churches commission to study the basis for a just and durable peace, conferred today with Vice President Wallace and Sumner Welles, Under-Secretary of State. after his return from a visit of four weeks in England.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., July 31 -- If turnabout really is fair play, Long Island Sound and its overhead constituents were not unkind to sailors and boats today in the third program of the Larchmont Yacht Club's race week, but those who were in it aboard 131 craft wished the weather were in some worse place than wartime censorship discard.

In its second expansion move in two months, the Edwards Employment Agencies, Inc., will transfer its commercial offices to larger quarters in the building at 20 Cortlandt Street. The change will be made on Monday.

WASHINGTON, July 31 (AP) -- Horace C. Young, in describing the huge plane his corporation proposed to build, said it would have a flying deck 200 by 180 feet from which twelve fighter planes could take off. It would carry enough helium gas to lift thirty-six tons.

WASHINGTON, July 31 -- Condemnation of the closing of the Pontiac plant of the General Motors Company by a dispute between C.I.O. grocery clerks and American Federation of Labor clerks was expressed today by William Green, president of the A.F. of L., and William H. Davis, chairman of the War Labor Board.

Lieut. Comdr. David M. Collins, U.S.N.R. gave a dinner last night in the Fountain Room of the Biltmore for Rear Admiral Randall Jacobs, Chief of the Bureau of Naval Personnel, and his staff, who came from Washington for the graduation exercises of the U.S.S. Prairie State and the presentation of swords to the newly commissioned ensigns at the New York Yacht Club.

WASHINGTON, July 31 -- One of the first things the State Department wants to learn from Joseph C. Grew when our former Ambassador to Japan gets back to the United States is whether Admiral Kichisaburo Nomura really gave Mr. Grew the opportunity to snub him at Lourenco Marques.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., July 31 -- Five, including Apache, have been named for the Wilson Stakes and seven have been entered for the United States Hotel Stakes, twin features tomorrow on the day that will mark completion of the first week of Saratoga racing.

NEWARK, N.J., July 31 -- Herbert Karl Friedrich Bahr, seized by the Federal Bureau of Investigation aboard the diplomatic exchange ship Drottingholm on July 19, was named as a link in a Nazi espionage conspiracy among nine persons in a superseding indictment returned today by a Federal grand jury here.

LONDON, July 31 (U.P.) -- Nine Bosnian towns captured by General Draja Mikhailovitch's Yugoslav forces have been burned to the ground by incendiary bombs rained from Italian planes, and Axis occupation forces have warned that every town taken by the patriots will be treated similarly, private advices from the Continent said tonight.

ST. PAUL, Minn., July 31 (AP) -- Bob Hamilton, a 26-year-old Hoosier from Evansville, Ind., ironed a 67 out of the hilly Keller public course today to take top billing at the close of the first round of the $5,000 St. Paul golf open.
After an inspection tour of city defense facilities yesterday Lieut. Gov. Charles Poletti, chairman of the State War Council, said he was "much impressed."

Plans to cut the unit of trading on a dozen stocks from 100 to ten shares and to move another dozen ten-share-unit stocks from Post 30 onto the main floor were announced yesterday by Emil Schram, president of the New York Stock Exchange.

WASHINGTON, July 31 -- The Office of Defense Transportation took control today of all new buses not already sold by manufacturers and will use the vehicles as "trouble shooters" wherever the need for additional transit facilities arises.
I think that big league baseball sooner or later will be stopped for the duration of the war. so why not have a series of special all-star games for charity at the conclusion of the current season?
LONDON, July 31--The stock markets finished the week quietly, the coming holiday also checking further business.
New securities offered to the public here in July were further curtailed, with bond flotations the smallest for that month since 1933 and stock emissions the lowest for any month since July, 1938.

WASHINGTON, July 31 -- Industrial diamond cutting and skilled office work, including stenography, are a few of the occupations in which the War Manpower Commission is planning the placement of the nation's disabled service men and physically handicapped men and women who constitute a reservoir of "unused man power" estimated to contain 4,000,000 persons.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 31 -- Procedure said to have been followed by Lieut. Comdr. Maurice N. Aroff in speeding up the enlistment of Tony Martin, radio and film singer, as a chief specialist in the Naval Reserve caused "a good deal of irritation" among both officers and men in the local office of naval officer procurement, a trial board was told today at the general court-martial of Commander Aroff.
CAIRO, Egypt, July 31 -- A mixed force of American and British bombers last night launched a mass attack on Tobruk harbor. The raid was described today as "successful."

WASHINGTON, July 31 -- President Roosevelt's power to order trial of the eight Nazi saboteurs before the military commission instead of in the civil courts was unanimously sustained by the Supreme Court today in a session lasting only four minutes.

The crucial Brooklyn delegation to the Democratic State Convention will vote to a man for Attorney General John J. Bennett Jr., and any talk of defections to the candidacy of Senator James M. Mead is "too silly for discussion," State Chairman James A. Farley, principal Bennett backer, declared yesterday.

SALEM, N.H., July 31 -- Willie Turnbull, up on Mad Crusader, was shunted to second place by the camera in the seventh race at Rockingham Park today and the 17-year-old Hot Springs, Ark., youth lost his chance of becoming the first jockey to ride eight winners on a single program.

From the railroads, the Pullman Company and the Railway Express Agency came announcements of continued heavy increases in traffic yesterday. The Pennsylvania's net income for June and the six months was substantially larger than last year's levels.

LONDON, July 31 -- It is often the small things that have the greatest effect on the morale of the nation. While this country could stand a good resounding victory, oddly enough the recent introduction of candy rationing has done more to cheer up these people than almost anything that has happened on the home front for months.

James C. Petrillo, president of the American Federation of Musicians, turned down last night the plea of Elmer Davis, director of the Office of War Information, that he rescind his ban on the manufacture of recordings. The Department of Justice in Washington immediately prepared to file suit today or Monday in Chicago to enjoin the union from enforcing the Petrillo order.
CHICAGO, July 31 (AP) -- Hog prices dropped 15 to 25 cents today as producers, evidently encouraged by the upturn in the last two sessions, unloaded 10,000 salable head.

WASHINGTON, July 31 -- Attorney General Biddle denied today that Solicitor General Fahy or any other officer of the Department of Justice had ruled that Associate Justice Murphy could not draw Army and Supreme Court pay at the same time. The Attorney General said:
The two-family house at 311 Avenue F. Brooklyn, has been sold to Yetta Cohen by the Bank for Savings for cash above a purchase money mortgage of $7,250 for ten years. Angelo Abate was the broker.

LONDON, Saturday, Aug. 1 -- The Royal Air Force was maintaining last night its almost unbroken offensive against German centers and communications in Western Europe, supply routes in the North Sea and bases and railways in the occupied Low Countries and France, reports early today indicated.

OTTAWA, July 31 (Canadian Press) -- New schedules classifying goods eligible or ineligible for subsidy from the Commodity Prices Stabilization Corporation were announced today by the Wartime Prices and Trade Board.

NEWARK, N.J., July 31 -- Lieut. Col. George R. Smith, 32 years old, and Major J.J. Simandl of 242 West Lane Avenue, Freeport, L.I., were killed at 9:20 o'clock tonight when their Army basic training plane crashed in a forced landing in a parking lot at 614 Frelinghuysen Avenue near the plant of the Weston Electric Instrument Company.

AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, Australia, Saturday, Aug. 1 (U.P.) -- Allied bombers have attacked and probably hit a Japanese cruiser south of Amboina, in the Southwest Pacific, a United Nations communique announced today.

PHILADELPHIA, July 31 -- A violent electrical storm, the most severe of the Summer, took a toll of nine lives in the Philadelphia area this afternoon, flooding the cellars of scores of homes and industrial plants, inflicting great damage on farm crops and playing havoc with transportation facilities.

The concert of the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra, scheduled for last night at the Lewisohn Stadium with Fritz Reiner as conductor, was canceled because of the rain. Tonight Howard Barlow will lead the orchestra in Tchaikovsky's Sixth symphony and the rest of the program will feature the First Piano Quartet in their own arrangements of various works.

WASHINGTON, July 31 -- Stocks of domestic and foreign crude petroleum at the close of last week totaled 249,262,000 barrels, according to data reported to the Bureau of Mines, Department of the Interior.. This represents a decrease of 1,243,000 barrels, comprising decreases of 1,146,000 and 97,000 barrels in stocks of domestic and foreign crude, respectively, from the previous week.

Alan Rutherford Stuyvesant, member of the American Field Service ambulance detachment assigned to the Free French forces in French Equatorial Africa, who was reported missing when Bir Hachiem was yielded to the Axis, is a prisoner in a prison camp in Italy, according to information received yesterday at the American Field Service headquarters, 60 Beaver Street.

WASHINGTON, July 31 (U.P.) -- The "Big Three" of the meat packing industry -- Armour Co., Swift Co. and Wilson Co. -- will submit for audit the sales records of all their branches for the purpose of refunding to wholesalers and retailers charges in excess of fixed maximum prices for beef and pork, it was announced tonight.

AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, Australia, Saturday, Aug. 1 (AP) -- Allied action against enemy bases at Guadalcanal, in the Solomon Islands, disclosed that Japanese infiltrations into the island had been going on for about six weeks, a military spokesman said here today.

WASHINGTON, July 31 -- Strict educational requirements for women desiring to become officers or officer-candidates in the Women's Reserve were set forth today by the Navy Department along with an official announcement that Smith College would be the training center for officers.

NEWARK, N.J., July 31 -- Federal Judge Guy L. Fake dismissed today a motion by tax officials of Hillsborough Township and Somerset County in which they sought removal from Federal Court jurisdiction of a suit by Mrs. Doris Duke Cromwell to set aside a tax levy of $13,834,924 filed against her by Hillsborough Township.

Despite the fact that some Canadian newsprint plants may be forced to shut down in order to divert electric power to war plants, no shortage of newsprint for American use is in sight this year, according to well-informed sources yesterday.

Before the last of them are gone some one should pay proper tribute to the wild berries that have been fattening the birds and delighting the hearts and palates of those who know where to find them. There isn't room here to do them justice, but notes for a proper essay can be set down.
The following German High Command communique was broadcast yesterday from Berlin and was recorded here by The Associated Press:

WASHINGTON, July 31 -- Permission to advance the prices of domestically distilled spirits, including gin, whisky, liqueurs and cordials, to the extent necessary to cover increased costs of production resulting from War Production Board orders and higher taxes, was granted by the Office of Price Administration today.

Confronted with a heated dispute yesterday between attorneys over adjournment of a motion to punish for contempt of court Father Divine, Harlem cult leader and head of the "Peace Mission," Supreme Court Justice Benjamin F. Schreiber cried, "Peace, let's have peace about this."
Bernie Smart's letter in THE TIMES last Saturday made me chuckle, particularly his proposal advocating one-year contracts for big league baseball managers.

VICHY, France, July 31 -- On the anniversary of the assassination of the great French Socialist leader Jean Jaures twenty-eight years ago, it was noted today that the Socialist newspapers of unoccupied France have been allowed to devote much space to Jaures and his socialism and that elsewhere in the press there is to be found much speculation on the future government in France.

MIAMI, July 31 (U.P.) -- Armed military patrols have been intensified along the entire east and west coast of Florida's 1,200-mile shoreline in an effort to prevent possible landing attempts by enemy espionage agents or saboteurs, Brig. Gen. E.A. Evans, commander of the Florida Gulf sub sector, revealed tonight.

MOSCOW, July 31 -- The order "Not a step back!" given to the Red Army along the whole front has echoed today throughout the press, and dispatches described many examples of resolute defense on the lines where Marshal Semyon Timoshenko is making a stand with his back to the main routes to Russia's grainland and oil fields.

The report of the Commonwealth Edison Company of Chicago for the first six months of this year, issued yesterday by Charles Y. Freeman, chairman, shows consolidated net income, after accruals for taxes of $9,978,151. This is equal to 78 cents a capital share, and compares with an adjusted net income of $13,493,311, or $1.06 a share, in the first six months of 1941.

CHICAGO, July 31 -- With bookings of Fall and early Winter orders virtually completed, opinion among Chicago manufacturers of men's clothing is that the much discussed shortage of all wool lines is unlikely before 1943. While patterns are less varied by comparison with last year's output, one clothing executive said here today that the character of the shipments to the firm's retail clientele was very little different from that of 1941.

WASHINGTON, July 31 -- United States business concerns had more direct investments in properties in Germany at the end of 1940 than in 1929 or 1936 but less in Japan, a Commerce Department reported today. Total direct investments abroad at the end of 1940 were $7,000,000,000, as compared with $7,528,000,000 at the end of 1929.

CHICAGO, July 31 -- With bookings of Fall and early Winter orders virtually completed, opinion among Chicago manufacturers of men's clothing is that the much discussed shortage of all wool lines is unlikely before 1943. While patterns are less varied by comparison with last year's output, one clothing executive said here today that the character of the shipments to the firm's retail clientele was very little different from that of 1941.
Chess players will gather this week at Cazenovia for the annual meeting of the New York State Association slated at Cazenovia Junior College.

SOMEWHERE IN AUSTRALIA, Aug. 1 -- The air war in the Southwest Pacific area is being fought at much higher altitudes than any one had anticipated. As a result the officers responsible for the tactical use of our airplanes have met with unexpected problems.

SARATOGA SPRINGS -- As the seventy-eighth racing season got under way last week the visitor noted the effects of the war in dimming social activity. All of the night clubs in the Saratoga lake area are open, but at each, one is aware of the absence of the young men, except the few one sees on furlough.

INTERLOCHEN, Mich., Aug. 1 -- The idea that the National Music Camp is a commercial enterprise because it charges students a tuition fee is wrong, C.M. Tremaine of New York, camp treasurer and director of the National Bureau for Advance of Music, said today.

Women seem to have gone all out in every sense for the stockingless fad this Summer. Not only in the suburbs, but in the city itself, young, middle-aged and elderly, are discarding hose. Unless it is intended as a conservation measure, which I doubt, I cannot see any sense in it -- that is, in most cases.

A CHARACTERISTIC of Mr. Aldridge's novel more immediately apparent than his gift for dramatic exposition, descriptive power and expert knowledge of the far-flung background of events is his ability to persuade us that his main characters are drawn from living models and that their experiences and reactions have a significance beyond entertainment.
MONTICELLO -- Resorts in Sullivan County expect to accommodate a considerable number of racing enthusiasts who will attend the Hambletonian, harness-horse classic, at Goshen, N.Y., Aug. 12.

The first four men picked by Colonel Bob Neyland for the Eastern division all-Army football team, which starts training this week at Yale University for the Tribune Fresh Air Fund game against the New York Giants on Sept. 12 at the Polo Grounds, are former professional stars.

The increasing demands of war have caused the Eastern railroads to issue the unusual announcement that they have "withdrawn" freight train schedules previously published or advertised. They will, however, continue to operate these trains as closely as possible to the fast schedules they have established in the last fifteen years.
LONDON, Aug. 1 -- Two more clubs opened today for American officers, soldiers and sailors. One is in Edinburgh. The other, for officers, is on the Thames near Maidenhead.

Should a bomb be dropped on any part of New York City, aid would be set rolling toward the scene of the incident within a few moments of notification to the emergency communications system, recent drills have shown. Since its completion several months ago the system has had weekly tests that have resulted in a quick, efficient method of procedure, officials in charge said yesterday.

An increasing number of war labels are appearing on incoming mail from belligerent as well as neutral countries, Most of these labels, or poster stamps, reflect the exigencies of countries overrun by the enemy. Some make a plea for sympathy and support.
LONDON, Aug. 1 -- British tenacity in the face of war emergency, it was evident today, is no greater than British tenacity and singleness of purpose in enjoying traditional holidays.

The stress of war days, with their priorities, taxes and necessary savings, is bringing back to our homes a great deal of old-fashioned simplicity and practicality. Over-ornamentation, fancy ideas and self-conscious decorative stunts are giving way to quiet restraint and closer attention to the actual needs of living.

Have you heard that General Rommel learned his tank tactics right here in America, studying the campaigns of that brilliant Confederate General, Stonewall Jackson? That's the story which appeared in the Martinsburg, W. Va., Journal not long ago and has now got pretty well around the country.
THE most extraordinarily simple and revolutionary practice in the employment of musicians in wartime is to be found in the operation of the band here at the United States Naval Training Station.

The nomination of Vito Marcantonio, Andrew L. Somers and James A. O'Leary for Congress by the left wing of the American Labor party was attacked yesterday by the party's right wing as "a shocking example of political irresponsibility."

RUTHERFORD MONTGOMERY'S tales of wild life in the West, "Carcajou," "Yellow Eyes." "Gray Wolf," and others, are among our most satisfactory and convincing wild animal stories. Now in "Ghost Town Adventure" he has turned to human beings for his characters, using the unique setting of a deserted mining town.

LEWISBURG, Pa., Aug. 1 -- Students attending the twelve weeks Summer term at Bucknell University to accelerate their programs are working harder than they did in the regular session, and liking it, despite the belief expressed in some circles that acceleration would place too great a burden on the students and result in inferior work, President Arnaud C. Marts declared today.

A combined birthday party and New Year's celebration ends in tragedy when Veronica Barton (Mrs. William Raymond Barton 3d) is found dead in her gas-filled room. Veronica's sister, Kathy, knows that Veronica has been threatened with scandal and disgrace if she could not raise a large sum of money without the knowledge of her husband or her mother-in-law, and Kathy is therefore prepared to believe that Veronica has taken her own life.

THERE is a general belief that ministers' sons always turn out badly. Of course it isn't true; it is just that they can't possibly be as good as people expect them to be considering their upbringing, and any little dereliction on their part gets more attention than do the graver sins of children from non-clerical homes.

CAMDEN, N.J., Aug. 1 (AP) -- Tommy Heard's $100 bargain horse, Boysy, who runs over the new Garden State Park track as though he owned it, came back for a repeat victory today in the $5,000 added Quaker City Handicap, feature of the thirteenth day program.

Many socially prominent women who in other seasons have been familiar figures at one resort or another, to which they usually go in July and August to avoid the heat of Manhattan, are right in our midst this Summer in New York. It is not gas or tire rationing that keeps them here, but the war tasks which they have assumed, to which they have buckled down with all seriousness.

SCHENECTADY, Aug. 7 -- Officials of the War Production Board and representatives of sixteen major labor unions of Eastern New York, affiliated with the American Federation of Labor, the Congress of Industrial Organizations and Railroad Brotherhoods, participated on the Union College campus today in a conference on "Labor in the War."

Wartime regulations covering the several restrictions applying to photographic activity are contained in a printed card published by Popular Photography and approved by the War Department Bureau of Public Relations and the Office of Censorship.

"NOAH'S ARK" is a collection of woodcuts of the ark as it appeared in the books of the fifteenth century. Published by Edmond Byrne Hackett. The Brick Row Bookshop, Inc., this brochure is printed on yellow cream stock with marbled paper sides and leather colored spine.

The amateur photographer who progressively improves in technical perfection soon realizes that without some understanding of negative retouching or print spotting his results lack that something which spells perfection in the final print, be it indoor or outdoor composition, pictorialism or portraiture.

WHEN Cora Thurston learned the truth about her first husband she resolved that their son should never be like his father. She had fallen in love at first sight with the big, blond lumberman, who to her looked like a Viking, and married him after no more than a few days' acquaintance.

The City-Wide Citizens Committee on Harlem, of which Algernon D. Black and the Rev. A. Clayton Powell Sr. are co-chairmen, made public yesterday a report of its subcommittee on Crime and Delinquency, with several recommendations for decreasing crime and juvenile delinquency among Negroes.

The murder which is occupying the attention of the police of New Orleans at the time of Peter Piper's arrival in that city is known as the Cain and Abel murder. It is followed by another sudden death which may possibly be suicide, and then by several other indubitable murders.

The Red Cross training courses which have been held at their city headquarters for the past year have followed members of the Carroll Club to their Summer camp in Pawling. A steady schedule of classes is maintained for vacationers at the country lodge, and along with other war-allied activities occupies almost as much time on the program as the customary sports and athletic events.

The city's machinery for keeping track of civilian casualties during enemy air raids and for reuniting families, relatives and friends separated because of enemy action has been set up by the emergency division of the Department of Welfare and is ready to function at a moment's notice, it was revealed yesterday.

Broadest participation of retailers in OPA's price-control program since the General Maximum Price Regulation became effective on May 18 is expected to result from the "August for Compliance" drive which gets under way tomorrow.

I would like to make a few comments on the subject of enemy aliens in this country, or "citizens of countries with whom the United States happens to be at war," as I am told they prefer to be called. I am a volunteer working down at the Federal Court House, in the Department of Enemy Aliens Travel, and, after four weeks at the job, I feel rather strongly on several points.

CARACAS, Venezuela, July 17 -Industrial diamonds from the rich deposits of Venezuela's Gran Sabana region, near the border of Brazil and British Guiana, are going to the Axis, according to miners, diamond buyers and officials of the isolated village of Santa Elena, where this correspondent has just spent a week.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Aug. 1. -- Women's colleges should accelerate their academic programs to meet the growing demand for trained women in business and industry, Miss Fredricka Belknap, director of the personnel bureau at New Jersey College for Women, said today in her annual report to Dean Margaret T. Corwin.
MOSCOW, Aug. 1 -- Today is the twenty-eighth anniversary of Germany's declaration of war on Czarist Russia.
The refusal of the Indian Congress party to take a positive stand in fighting the imminent Axis invasion of India, is a sad disappointment in all capitals of the United Nations.

LONDON, Aug. 1 -- French hostages saw their own coffins recently as Nazi executioners drove them through the streets of Chavannes in the Eure-et-Loire Department, according to a document issued this evening by General Charles de Gaulle's headquarters of fighting France here.

THE tanker's bunk room swelters. All day the Caribbean sun has burned the deck plates and little spots have jigged before your eyes from the reflected glare. Night has brought no relief. The bunk-room ports are dogged down so no light will escape seaward for U-boat lookouts to see.

VICHY, France, Aug. 1 (U.P.) -Chief of Government Pierre Laval revealed today that widespread precautions have been taken to prevent a French uprising led by followers of General Charles de Gaulle if British and United States forces undertake a sudden invasion of the Continent.

MOSCOW, Sunday, Aug. 2 -- The Germans have made big strides forward from the Bataisk sector of the Western Caucasus. They followed railroads in their drives to the Salsk and Kushchevka districts, mentioned this morning in a Russian communi que for the first time. Salsk is on the main Stalingrad-Krasnodar rail line, and Kushchevka is on the line running southward from Rostov.

LONDON, Aug. 1 -- A big question mark hangs over two battlefields -- one in Egypt and one on the banks of the Don River. The British public is watching both with mounting anxiety and an increasing sense of frustration resulting from the feeling that at this decisive stage of the war their country is not ready to play an effective part.

ONCE again a storm is brewing in India. All signs point to hard times ahead, both for the Indians and the British. That means, of course, that the rest of the members of the United Nations are also facing a crisis in that far-off land inhabited by one-fifth of the human race.

HOLLYWOOD. EXCEPT for the sandstorms, when all hands on the set crawl into pup tents to lie doggo until the gale howls itself out, the Salton Sea, where "Wake Island" is finishing, obliges with as close a version of that atoll as can be found within a day's bomber flight of Hollywood.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Brazil, Aug. 1 -- Negotiations on economic agreements between Brazil and the United States, which have been in progress three months, ended last night when Jefferson Caffery, United States Ambassador, signed six agreements. He left for the United States today.

NEW YORK'S "Music Hall on the Air," broadcast each Sunday for the past decade over the WJZ coast-to-coast network, currently is making new plans for the coming radio season. Also, currently, it is celebrating ten years of musical broadcasting under the guidance of Erno Rapee, chief musical director.

THE recent course of retail trade did not materially change last week. Early reports on consumer response to August sales events, while not discouraging, revealed a mixed tendency. The war production areas, as expected, made the best showing.

The Giants and Dodgers tangle tomorrow night at the Polo Grounds in another of those internecine affairs which never fail to send the baseball fever in the two boroughs soaring. But this jamboree will be more than just another major league game.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 -- A special House committee of Easterners recommended today a broad extension of rationing of petroleum products to alleviate "a dire and dangerous shortage of gasoline, residual oil and domestic heating oil" in the East.

DOVER, N.J., Aug. 1 -- Colonel W.E. Larned, commanding officer at Picatinny Arsenal, announced today that this ammunition plant's tremendous expansion, under which the number of employes has more than tripled in eighteen months, had stopped and that a "considerable reduction" in personnel was expected.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 -- This country's willingness to purchase surplus Brazilian coffees and store them in a stock-pile for post-war use has made an extremely favorable impression on that country but has not removed one of its major worries connected with the trade disruption caused by the war.

MOSCOW, Aug. 1 -- Twenty-eight years ago today, at 6 o'clock in the evening, Berlin time, German Ambassador Pourtales informed Russian Foreign Minister Sazonov at St. Petersburg of Germany's declaration of war against Czarist Russia.

JERICHO, L.I., Aug. 1 -- Second Lieut. Robert M. Harrison, about 23 years old, was burned seriously this morning before bailing out of his burning fighter plane and parachuting into a field adjoining Cedar Swamp Road, where Mrs. James A. Hewlett of Oyster Bay Road and her gardener, Wallace Collins, came to his aid.

STATE COLLEGE, Miss., Aug. 1 -- Citizens of Lee County, Miss., located in the northeast tier of counties where per capita income is lowest in the Magnolia State, made a long stride in their program to improve their social and economic conditions in a work conference recently conducted there.

MR. YOUNG'S new novel is light. The most delicate of satire, the most tolerant of moods, see to that. It is nourishing, for it is built up on the solid foundation of an understanding of human nature acquired throughout a more varied career than falls to the lot of most literary men.

People who follow vacation trends near New York find the field presents a new picture this year. For while travel agents and resort directors say that workers are taking their usual "two weeks with pay," the places they choose for holidays are with very few exceptions "close to home."

WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 -- Reports prevalent here that the government had signed a contract for the production, by July 1, next, of 600,000 tons of synthetic rubber by the Houdry process, and at 5 cents a pound, were denied officially tonight.

LONDON, July 17 -- The women of France are beginning to stir in revolt. Both in occupied France and in the France of Chief of Government Pierre Laval and Chief of State Henri Philippe Petain they are organizing increased resistance to the miserable living conditions which they and their families have been forced to endure since Reichsfuehrer Hitler took over their country in the Summer of 1940.

Joseph Sage, defending champion from Split Rock, and his predecessor, Tom Strafaci of Dyker Beach, will meet for the municipal public links championship and the Newbold Morris Trophy in a thirty-six-hole final at the Clearview Golf Club in Bayside, Queens, starting at 8 o'clock this morning. Both recorded hard-earned semifinal triumphs yesterday also over the thirty-six-hole route.

An over-the-weight ten-round meeting between Ray Robinson and Freddy (Red) Cochrane, welterweight champion, scheduled for Sept. 10 at Madison Square Garden for the benefit of the USO has been canceled.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Aug. 1 -- County Clerk Harold Mercer, who heads the Westchester automobile license bureau, will confer with Connecticut Motor Vehicle Commissioner John McCarthy on, Monday to discuss an allegedly growing tendency by Connecticut police to arrest New Yorkers who are employed in defense plants and whose automobiles are equipped with New York license plates.

DETROIT, Aug. 1 -- A revolutionary development in bomber turret construction which adds greatly to the fire power was demonstrated today at the new plant of the Briggs manufacturing company plant during a tour of inspection by Lieut. Gen. Henry H. Arnold, chief of the Army Air Forces.

That a more equitable distribution of the world's minerals and fuels is essential for the preservation of international peace is taken nowadays for granted. The Atlantic Charter implies that there are "have" and "have-not" nations. Though Dr. Kirtley F. Mather, Harvard's Professor of Geology, is all for the planetary exploitation of mineral resources, he punctures this "have" and "have not" theory in an American Philosophical Society address.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 -- A meeting of the International Wheat Council, which is to work out details connected with a "relief reserve" of 100,000,000 bushels of wheat, was called today by the United States in a definite move toward preparing to feed famine-stricken nations after the war.

A step toward countering the shipping shortage, preventing unnecessary sinkings and relieving some of Central America's economic troubles, is indicated in the State Department's announcement that our Government will finance the immediate construction of an "all weather" highway from the railhead in Mexico to the Panama Canal Zone.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 -- Edward H. Foley Jr., general counsel of the Treasury Department for three and a half years, has resigned to enter the army as a lieutenant colonel, saying, "I feel I shall be able to make a contribution more directly related to the war effort."

MORE than one date can be given for the opening of the present war. For the Abyssinians the war against the aggressors began in the Autumn of 1935. For the Chinese it began with the annexation of Manchuria and renewed with full fury in the Summer of 1937.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 -- President Roosevelt joined today with the Office of Petroleum Coordinator and other government agencies in an appeal to householders of the East to convert their oil furnaces to coal-burning equipment if the conversion were at all feasible.

New York's museums play a much larger part in the daily life of the country than the casual visitor is likely to suspect. Some indication of their contribution to practical matters that affect many persons is provided by a report from the Cooper Union Museum for the Arts of Decoration, which recently ended its forty-fifth year of service.

It is extremely unfortunate that the decision of the United States Supreme Court in Betts v. Brady, handed down on June 1, has attracted little public attention or criticism, while other recent civil-liberty cases scarcely more important or far-reaching have been widely debated.

The cyclic back-to-the-country movement which manifests itself during and after war and depressions has recurred. Sales of farms and rural homes to city folk have decidedly quickened this year as retired people and those unrequired by draft lists and assembly lines seek hoped-for security in the hinterlands from possible bombs and economic perils.

A YEAR or so ago Charles Daugherty wrote in "So Sailors Say" an excellent story for boys from 9 to 12, describing a Summer at the seashore, and telling how a boy built his own boat and learned to sail her. "Street of Ships" is for older readers, from 12 on.

WADESBORO, N.C., Aug. 1 (AP) -- An attack with air support, smartly planned and smoothly executed, carried the Blue forces under Major Gen. Alvan C. Gillem Jr. to decisive victory yesterday over Major Gen. Fred L. Walker's Reds as another outstanding problem in the Army's first wartime manoeuvre came to a close.

Although 1,000 letters requesting applications for entry into the Women's Reserve of the Navy were on hand here yesterday, nothing could be done about them since application blanks had not been received from Washington.

The annual Summer tournament for several national contract bridge championships, two of them restricted to master players and labeled "world" championships, will begin in New York tomorrow afternoon and will last through next Sunday.

CORAL GABLES, Fla., Aug. 1 -- War is affecting many classrooms at the University of Miami, college administrators said here today. Shifting of students' interests toward mathematics and science has been especially noticeable, although courses in language, literature, and the social sciences seem to be holding their own.

Captain Peter Lagaay, known to thousands of American tourists who traveled on the Statendam, Rotterdam, Veendam, Volendam and Westernland on voyages across the Atlantic or in cruise services, was in New York last week on leave after two years of active war duty.

The two words most deeply engraved on the minds of the American and British peoples at this moment are: Second Front. These two words, together, are just now the most explosive words in the world. They can be the most dangerous words in the world. They can be the most hopeful.

Right now the Federal Bureau of Investigation looms larger in the public consciousness than ever before. Events of the past few weeks have dramatized the work that has brought the FBI, in the words of President Roosevelt, "to the forefront among all the law enforcement agencies of the world."

DURHAM, N.C., Aug. 1 -- The charge that most Americans cannot truly become "good neighbors" to the people of Latin America simply because they do not know the languages and cultural backgrounds of Latin-Americans was answered in some measure this Summer when Duke University operated its first Institute of Spanish Studies.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 -- Such wartime inflation as may now exist or such as might develop later on will not be the result of a spending spree by American labor, according to a report issued today by Secretary Perkins. The figures are based on a sample survey of the incomes and expenditures of city families.

WASHINGTON Aug. 1 -- American shipyards set new world records in July by delivering seventy-one ships of 790,300 deadweight tons, Rear Admiral Emory S. Land, chairman of the Maritime Commission, announced today.
The Navy announced last night that an Axis submarine was believed to have been sunk by a Navy plane after she had torpedoed a medium-sized Panamanian merchant ship more than two weeks ago.
SALEM, N.H., Aug. 1 -- Mrs. W. R. Flemming's Loveday came from far back today to win the $5,000 added Granite State Handicap for her second consecutive stake victory at Rockingham Park.

The First Piano Quartet, which has previously confined its performances to radio broadcasts, last night made its first New York concert appearance at the Lewisohn Stadium. The four men took over the second half of the program, for the New York Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra withdrew for the evening after playing Tchaikovsky's "Pathetique," Howard Barlow conducting.

Although the airlines of the United States are now busy expanding the scope and increasing the tempo of their services, as recently requested by the Army Air Forces Air Transport Command, passenger plane service within the United States is still being maintained.
