In the last twelve months seventy-nine persons out of every 1,000 in New York City have been patients in hospitals in the metropolitan area, according to a report on hospital statistics, made public yesterday by the Welfare Council of New York City.

HAMILTON, Bermuda, Aug. 1 -- Bermuda's business activity is "on a scale perhaps unequaled," the annual report of the Bank of Bermuda said today, while the colony's other bank, N.T. Butterfield Son, Ltd., in its annual report notes the "abnormal state of affairs which exists in this colony."

Beethoven: Quartet No. 9, in C, Op. 59, No. 3. Budapest String Quartet. (Columbia M-510, four 12-inch records). Every new recording by the Budapest boys is almost sure to be an event. Their new version of the third Rasoumovsky Quartet not only falls into this category but takes unquestioned rank as the best available version of a great and abiding work.

COOPERSTOWN, N.Y., Aug. 1 -- Baseball will pay its respects to its birthplace again Monday when the St. Louis Cardinals and Philadelphia Athletics play the annual major league exhibition at Doubleday Field.

Twenty-eight years ago today the Germans invaded Luxembourg in the first World War. Aug. 2, 1914, when the Kaiser's armies on their march into France and Belgium overran the little Grand Duchy was a Sunday, too, Joseph Bech, former Foreign Minister of Luxembourg, recalled yesterday in an interview at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.
FREEDOM is a word that has recently been much in our thoughts and on our lips. From the ancients down many wise things have been written and said about freedom. Here are a few of them:

An expansion of the training-within-industry program along broader lines, intended to cut down labor turnover, accidents and waste by providing for instruction for all phases and levels of management, is being worked out by the War Manpower Commission and will go into operation in this region about Sept. 1, it was learned yesterday.

AUSTIN, Texas, Aug. 1 -- To meet imperative war demands and create a backlog for a post-war "air age," a program to prepare engineers to design airplanes, skilled workmen to build them, pilots to fly them and administrators to handle the business end of air transportation is going on at the University of Texas.

Tomorrow will be the seventieth birthday of King Haakon VII of Norway. It will be spent in exile, but not in idleness. He has been in England since June, 1940, acting as head of the Norwegian Government in London, the focus of resistance to the Nazi occupation.
LONDON, Aug. 1 (AP) -- The Air Ministry issued the following communique today:

ADIRONDACK MOUNTAINS -- Cultural, sports and social events will move into full swing at the Eastern Adirondack colonies this month. An outstanding event scheduled at Schroon Lake is the Colony Opera Guild's production of Humperdinck's "Haensel und Gretel."
WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 (UP) -The War Manpower Commission is considering a recommendation that President Roosevelt order the armed forces to stop all voluntary recruiting, it was learned tonight.

NIPPONESE broadcasters in Batavia are lecturing people in the Antipodes on the subject of truthful propaganda. "There must be no lying," say the puppets of Zipangu. "One must lay all one's cards on the table."

LENOX, Mass., Aug. 1 -- The first of a series of concerts by the Berkshire Music Center Orchestra was conducted by Serge Koussevitzky in the music shed here at Tanglewood tonight, under the auspices of the Koussevitsky Music Foundations, Inc.

Just as Indian Summer brings a brief but most welcome interval after Jack Frost has invaded the countryside, so the Autumn-flowering crocus bring to the gardener's heart a sort of second Spring uplift with their cheerful and generously produced blooms.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 (Science Service) -- Xanthone, xanthene and xanthydrol are chemicals which can be expected to figure as munitions of war in the never-ending campaign waged by man against insects to save his daily bread, his house and clothing, and even his health and life.

This column has conceded that the new revenue bill, as passed by the House of Representatives; is free of radical and business-harassing administrative elements. It is creditable that under the guidance of sound advice the Treasury introduced into the bill, through the Ways and Means Committee, some long sought administrative improvements.

Training of housewives and entire families in how to spend their consumer dollars most effectively, how to spare goods needed for the military forces and how to guard against chiseling under price controls will soon begin on a mass scale, it was announced last night by the consular service division of the Greater New York Civilian Defense Volunteer Office.

WHITE MOUNTAINS, N.H. -On Tuesday and following days, twenty-second annual open White Mountain golf championship tournament will be held at Maplewood Club. Usually more than 100 entries are made for the event. The annual golf championship for men guests at the Crawford House, Crawford Notch, will be held Tuesday through Thursday.

Some New York stores are still Elysian fields of luxury that make you feel, while you're in them that nothing sordid and certainly nothing so gauche as war could exist in the same world. So if you want to indulge in a little harmless escapism, try going around to some of the gift shops for a present, say, for your country hostess.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 -- The Navy today released a dramatic account of the escape from the doomed Philippines of two officers and sixteen men of the American minesweeper Quail, who traveled 2,000 miles in a thirty-six-foot launch and finally landed safe in Australia after having run gauntlets of Japanese warships.

AURORA, N.Y., Aug. 1 -- Wholehearted compliance with recently issued fire regulations has resulted in several valuable gifts to the Wells College Library. The gifts, most significant of which are a first edition of Moby Dick and autograph letters of Henry Wells, had lain for years in the attic of an Aurora residence.

Wall Street has been slow to make up its mind about Securities and Exchange Commission proposals to adopt a "full disclosure" rule for the over-the-counter trade. Stock Exchange officials agree that the purposes are excellent, but suspect that there may be "bugs" in their application.

CHUNGKING, China, Aug. 1 -- Chungking is pleased at reports that Oriental languages, especially Chinese, are being popularized in Britain and America. English has been popular, almost a second language, in China long before the outbreak of the war.

OVER four hundred years ago Europeans who first came into contact with the Malayan natives found them an indolent people who esteemed nothing so much as peace, leisure and spices. A few decades earlier, in 1506, Alvaro Telez discovered the island of Sumatra, where he observed "a river running with oil."

PARTS of this spirited travel book sound as though Mr. Morehouse had been going around the United States too often and too fast, with the result that the United States is now going round in his head. His trips since Dec. 7, 1941, of which this is a record, covered some 12,000 miles of driving, in addition to some train riding and flying and a jaunt around the West Indies.

LONDON, Aug. 1 -- American food is to be served at United States Army posts in the United Kingdom this month. The soldiers have been eating the British ration cooked by American mess sergeants and have gone without morning fruit juice and fruits, which they have sorely missed.

"FAMILY morale is the basis of all morale." But if the public at large is agreed in the acceptance of this axiom, public knowledge is less widespread as to the breadth and detail of the subject and less sure on the answer of what to do about it.
CHICAGO, Aug. 1 (AP) -- Bob Zuppke is leaving his pigs and silos down at Mahomet, Ill., for one last fling as a big-time football coach.

STANFORD UNIVERSITY, Calif., Aug. 1 -- With both government and industry calling for increasing numbers of trained specialists, Stanford University students are on their way to answer this need by beginning their college training earlier and by speeding up their educational program and attending the year around, a midquarter summary of Stanford's present enrollment figures reveals.
The following German High Command communique was broadcast from Berlin yesterday and recorded by The Associated Press.

DETROIT, Aug. 1 -- Suspension of thirteen members of the U.A.W.C.I.O., was ordered today by General Motors officials as 7,000 other war production workers returned to their jobs in the Pontiac Motors division, which was closed yesterday by a picket line of members of the C.I.O. retail clerks union in a jurisdictional dispute.

J. Lewis Luckenbach, president of the American Bureau of Shipping, reported last week at the semi-annual meeting of the board of managers that the bureau had classified more than twice as many vessels in the first six months of 1942 as in the same period last year.

WELLESLEY, Mass., Aug. 1 (AP) -- The trustees of Wellesley College announced today the appointment of a joint executive body of three women to assume the duties of Miss Mildred McAfee, president of Wellesley College, in expectation of her official appointment as head of the new women's naval reserve.

THAT new play by Emil Ludwig, about which there was a fleeting note on this page a fortnight ago, is called "Ulysses' Return." Gilmor Brown's Pasadena Playhouse of sunlit California is to try it out Dec. 9, with Onslow Stevens in the title role and with the author helping out during rehearsals.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Aug. 1 -Physical fitness is not being treated as a war or an emergency problem at Pembroke College, where a four-year plan of compulsory gymnasium work has long been considered an important part of the curriculum.

THE union shop is a phase of industrial democracy. The cardinal principle of democracy is majority rule. Refusal to grant a union shop on the pretense that such a step would be "unfair" to the non-union minority is in fact completely unfair to the majority in the plarit. The unionist majority has struggled for years to raise wages, adjust working hours and set fair standards of work.

The statement of policy signed by the heads of eight Government agencies concerning the working week seems for the most part an eminently sensible document. It is issued as a "guide," and not as an order, and therefore retains the essential element of elasticity.

THIS is an appealing story of two children in a Slovak village. Andrusik Hrusik, the little orphan who has been living since his mother's death on the charity of neighbors, is sent to Poruba to make his home with a well-to-do cousin, Pan Doktor Hrusik.

WRITERS in California, especially those who have been touched by the movie industry, present an interesting phenomenon. Caught in a milieu of extravagance, they turn to the exploration of the simple and humble.

IT is significant that Admiral William D. Leahy is referred to throughout a Navy fond of nicknames as just "Bill" or "Bill Leahy." The man who held many of the Navy's most important positions, including that of its ranking officer and who now has been chosen by President Roosevelt as his Chief of Staff, is as comfortable as an old shoe.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 -- The movement in prices of basic commodities not regulated by the Office of Price Administration was mixed during the period July 24 to 31. Average prices for agricultural commodities advanced slightly while certain raw industrial commodities declined.

NOT long ago a local radio show -- one of those cereal serials which flourish in this Breadbasket of America as Chicago's poet-laureate, Carl Sandburg, calls it, was plagued during rehearsals by the failure of the sound effect engineers to produce anything that would sound like a log chain being dragged across the floor.

A CERTAIN number of discussions about the family in wartime have reminded this reporter of Mark Twain's jest about the weather, but among the groups which have been doing something besides talking about war's impact on the home is Vassar's Summer Institute. which was concluded yesterday.
PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 1 (AP) -Merrill May's timely single in the twelfth inning and Tommy Hughes's brilliant pitching gave the Phils a 2-to-1 triumph over the Pirates today.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 1 -- Another of the many entertainments planned in aid of the Red Cross, will be the bridge tournament to be held Thursday afternoon at the home of Mrs. Clarence B. Dolan, and for which there have been many reservations.

THIS novel has to do with a fifth column plot designed to prepare the way for a Nazi invasion of Britain. It tells how the well-laid plans, aided and abetted by traitors to their own country, are exposed and nullified through the efforts of Mark Chantrey, an official of the Ministry of Domestic Security, and his secretary, Persis Grant, themselves suspected of being concerned in the plot.

Food merchants are faced with a decrease of about 30 per cent in the amount and variety of available products during the Fall and early Winter, according to the New York State Food Merchants' Association, which opens its forty-first annual convention at the Hotel Pennsylvania this afternoon.

LONDON, Aug. 1 (AP) -- British observers concluded, after reconnaissance today on the results of last night's raid, that at least half of Duesseldorf had been damaged by fire and explosives and that the heavy industries there would feel the loss of veteran munitions workers killed, wounded or driven from their homes by bombs.

Flying conditions in the Egyptian desert are tricky. In the harsh, white glare of the African sun judgment of height or distance is difficult The endless wasteland is like a tawny sea in which desert tracks are indistinguishable. Enemy transport is prudently dispersed, offers a poor target. Mirages shimmer on the horizon.

Unfavorable weather affected retail trade here last week. Department store volume was estimated as running about 5 per cent under a year ago. Consumer response to August sales promotions of furniture and Winter coats was not particularly brisk and in most instances sales ranged under the comparative 1941 period.

In a bizarre contest that went far to prove that "everything happens in Brooklyn," the Dodgers yesterday halted a ninth-inning rally and beat the Cubs, 9 -- 6, for their second straight victory over Jimmy Wilson's men.
PRINCETON, N.J., Aug. 1 -One of the biggest problems in the war, a problem which grows more critical every day, is the mobilizing of industrial manpower to insure a steady flow of war production.

German Army forces have captured the Russian railway junction town of Salsk, about 100 miles southeast of Rostov, and have crossed the Stalingrad-Krasnodar railway on a broad front "in pursuing the beaten enemy in the east," the German High Command announced yesterday, according to Berlin broadcasts recorded by The Associated Press.

If the United States landed eight saboteurs on the German coast and they were arrested, the brief remainder of their lives would presumably go something like this: They would be rushed to Gestapo headquarters in the Albrechtstrasse in Berlin. Confessions would be wrung from them by endless hours of questioning, beatings, brutal torture.

One of the most important jobs facing the men's clothing industry is the promotion of suits, topcoats and overcoats of mixed wool fabrics, which are expected to dominate the market next year, merchants in the industry said yesterday.

JOSEPH TUSHINSKY, figuratively speaking, has moved Carnegie Hall into the Forties. The 32-year-old impresario, with esthetic propensities and with a keen eye on the box office, invaded the Hall with a light operetta troupe on June 23, and has been there ever since.

It is customary after the regulations for the duck-hunting season are announced to hear many discordant voices among the hunters, but apparently the prelude to the next season will be a different one. Thus far criticisms of the seventy-day waterfowl shooting period, an extension of ten days over 1941, and the shooting hours from sunrise to sunset, have been far from severe.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 -- The Coast Guard called today upon residents of the Atlantic and Gulf coasts who own horses to join, with their steeds, the Mounted Beach Patrol. If they own horses, but cannot spare their own services, they are asked to lend their horses for some one else to ride.

SYPHILIS -- The Hyman-Chargin-Lauffer five-day drip treatment of syphilis is making its way abroad. In the Archives of Dermatology and Syphilology an account is given of the treatment of 233 syphilitics in Santiago, Chile, with massive intravenous doses of hydrochloride of arsenoxide (oxiarsolan).

IGLOOS FOR DEFENSE: Reports from Alaskan missionary priests last week told of Eskimos, who had forgotten how to build snow igloos, learning once again under the pressure of war. Snow igIoos are harder to see from the air, better bomb shelters than the wooden shacks the Eskimos had grown to like.
Games for the entertainment of patients at the Naval Hospital in Brooklyn are being constructed by a group of girls in that borough at a minimum cost.

BUENOS AIRES, Argentina, Aug. 1 -- The Argentine Government announced today that Waldo Frank, United States author and lecturer, had "ceased to be persona grata to the Argentine Government and people."

BUENOS AIRES, Argentina, Aug. 1 (U.P.) -- Waldo Frank's farewell to Argentina entitled "Mi Adios, Argentina," asserted that Argentina's attitude "secretly humiliates and offends Argentines in the eyes of their own Hispano-American world" and that "Argentina, whose historical role has been that of moral greatness and spiritual leadership, now is living in the midst of the greatest moral and spiritual crisis in history without morality."

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Aug.1 -- The old and dignified law firm of Clark, Gagliardi Cunningham, occupying the entire seventh floor of the North Court Building opposite the County Court House here, was thrown into an uproar today by the discovery in a safe of a tubular, brown-paper package labelled "warning -- dynamite."

To ease the path of British subjects here who wish to volunteer for military or civil service in the United Kingdom, new instructions have been sent by the Foreign Office to all British Consuls in the United States, the British Information Services reported yesterday.

New Yorkers who have long been used to stepping to the curb and raising a finger whenever they wanted a taxicab are encountering considerable change. With new taxi regulations in effect, the customer now has to walk to the nearest cab stand to get service, and he may even have to wait a minute or two until an empty cab rolls in.

Stern outlines of the automotive picture now are beginning to take definite form. In the near future the "one-third of a nation" who operate private cars will be able to visualize where they may drive from there in -- until the war is won.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Aug. 1 -A 12-year-old boy was shot by the Germans in the Pripet Marshes, south of Minsk in a region overrun by the Germans in the early stages of the war in Russia, but in which strong Russian guerilla units still are inflicting heavy losses on the Germans, reports a war correspondent of Dagens Nyheter in a dispatch datelined "An Airfield 200 Kilometers East of the Pripet Marshes."
A loss of 7,176,344 man-hours of work because of strikes in war industries in the first half of this year was disclosed by a survey released yesterday by the National Association of Manufacturers.

AL JOLSON, the gentleman who knows what to do with a song, has made arrangements to terminate his absence from the air, agreeing to fill the 9:30 to 10 P.M. shift on Saturday nights over WEAF and the NBC Red Network.
SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 1 -Ted Schroeder of Glendale, Calif., won the Southampton round-robin invitation tennis tournament today with a five-set victory over Sidney Wood at the Meadow Club.

In reply to the recent warning of British Air Marshal Sir Arthur T. Harris that the German people faced ever-increasing aerial assaults unless they overthrew their leaders, the German Foreign Office retorted yesterday that the people of the Reich could "take it," according to a Berlin broadcast recorded by Reuter.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 (AP) -Class I railroads had estimated net income, after interest and rentals, of $289,100,000 in the first six months of 1942, compared with $169,993,733 in the same period of 1941, the Association of American Railroads reported today.

ELIZABETH BOWEN has been noted for some years as a witty and psychologically talented novelist and now, in "Bowen's Court." she presents herself as a biographer, a double-barrelled biographer, to be exact, of unusual stature. She is both objective and intense.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 -- Evidence increased today that the Senate, and perhaps the House would sustain a Presidential veto of the synthetic rubber agency bill, even if the expected accompanying "move" by the President should fall materially short of the objectives of the measure.

A sample poll of city housewives to discover how well integrated they are in the war program, and what special problems aggravated by the war would benefit by group discussions, will be taken this week by the consumer division of the Greater New York CDVO.

Renewed activity up-State in behalf of Owen D. Young for Governor on the Democratic ticket brought the charge yesterday from State Chairman James A. Farley, principal backer of Attorney General John J. Bennett Jr., that the candidacy of James M. Mead was dead, and that his supporters were turning to Mr. Young in desperation.

The National Maritime Union's national council charged last week that the carrying capacity of the country's merchant marine was not being fully utilized and it adopted a resolution instructing the union's national office to confer with the Maritime Commission in connection with information supporting the charge.
MILLWOOD, N.Y., Aug. 1 -Two women were killed and fifteen persons injured, five of them seriously, when a passenger car and a bus collided head-on on Route 100 here tonight.
At their quarterly meeting next month the delegates to the American Kennel Club will be asked to ratify amendments to the rules applying to dog shows, obedience tests and field trials.

Federal and State civilian defense officials yesterday ended a three-day inspection of the city's preparations for defense against enemy attacks, and expressed satisfaction with the civilian protection machinery set up by Mayor La Guardia and his aides.

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 1 -- Although still traveling at stratospheric levels which keep them well beyond the range of all their American League rivals, the Yankees again seem to be suffering from engine trouble.
LONDON, Aug. 1 (AP) -- The crash of an American bomber in Northern Greenland and the rescue of its crew of three was disclosed tonight through the British Air Ministry.

Continuing its broadened program to help college youth solve the problems found in a democratic land, the International Student Service has arranged for an ambitious assembly, to be held at the American University in Washington early next month.

Some gardeners say "I have all the common kinds of flowers." I do not know where to draw the line between the common and the rarer kinds. Some that are not common in one State are in another. In some States Mallow is very common, yet some people saw one in my garden for the first time.
CAIRO, Egypt, Aug. 1 (AP) -- A United State Air Force communique said today:

PITTSBURGH, Aug. 1 (U.P.) -- The Pittsburgh Press, afternoon and Sunday newspaper, failed to resume publication today after some A.F.L. union employes declined to return to work when the management refused to pay them for time lost due to a strike of truck drivers.

THE Promenade concert season which has just begun will compensate us for the dearth of novelties during the past two years -- a dearth due not to indifference on the part of promoters but to the need of avoiding heavy financial responsibilities.

Occasionally we find a lovely, hardy plant that merits attention and a more popular place in our gardens. One such is the pentstemon or beardtongue, a most interesting and beautiful member of the figwort family. Its tall, tender stems, rising gracefully from compact foliage close to the ground, carry blossoms that resemble the foxglove.

WHEN the German Wehrmacht swept across the eastern frontier on June 22 of last year a good many observers expected a Russian collapse within a matter of weeks. Today, after more than a year of bitter battle, the Red Army, and no less the civilian population itself, are still fighting with an unbroken spirit that has aroused the admiration of the world.

OAKLAND, Calif. -- Within a month of the discontinuance of service of the Second Avenue elevated line in New York the familiar little cars that ran from Queens to City Hall and South Ferry began arriving here to aid in the transportation of workers between this city and the three big shipyards in Richmond, building seagoing carriers that are immediately commissioned, loaded with war supplies for the United Nations, and sent on their way.

Mayor La Guardia yesterday appointed Hubert T. Delany, 41 years old, of 133 West 145th Street, a justice of the Domestic Relations Court to fill the vacancy caused by the absence of Presiding Justice John Warren Hill, who has joined the Army as a major.

Another phase in the regimentation of American industry under the all-out war effort became effective yesterday when the entire cooking appliance industry, except the electrical division, became the guinea pig for the first concentration-of-production experiment in this country.

After months of negotiations with American authorities and Greek Government officials in this country, the Committee for the Welfare of Greek Merchant Seamen reports that its efforts to establish a home in this country for Greek seamen have been productive of results and that, as a consequence, more than 225 Greek merchant sailors soon may be released from detention at East Coast points.
BRIARCLIFF MANOR, N.Y., Aug. 1 -- It was rough going for the two medalists in the ninth annual Briar Hills invitation golf tournament today.

The British Broadcasting Corporation, in its French-language transmission to Europe, yesterday warned the French people not to believe Nazi-inspired rumors of allied landings on the continent, the Columbia Broadcasting System short wave listening station reported.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 -- Condemning what it declared to be "amazing" conflicts in the views of officials and delegated authorities in governmental agencies responsible for relieving the gasoline and fuel oil shortages on the Eastern seaboard, a special House Investigating Committee recommended today that all control of petroleum products, including rationing, transportation and price-setting be consolidated under a single head.

German panzers cut the principal railroad to the Caucasus last week, rumbled to within fifty miles of Stalingrad on the Volga and were pushing southward from Kushchevka toward the Maikop oil fields, 136 miles away.

PRINCETON, N.J., Aug. 1 (AP) -- The Princeton University baseball team laid down a ten-hit barrage against three pitchers today to defeat the Riegel Ridge semi-pros of Riegelsville, Pa., 11 to 2, at Brokaw Field. It was the fourth victory of five starts in the Summer circuit for the Tigers.

FEW issues of recent months have interested correspondents of this column as much as the Seventh symphony of Dmitri Shostakovich and the critical discussions which have followed its recent performance.

The proposal now being studied by Paul V. McNutt, chairman of the War Manpower Commission, for transfer of some unemployed workers in New York's war-restricted industries to other jobs outside the city might, if adopted, aggravate the very malady it was designed to cure.

LENOX, Mass., Aug. 1 (AP) -When some music critics belittled the Seventh symphony of Dmitri Shostakovich, Soviet composer, they were criticizing the work of a "genius who possesses the most tremendous appeal to the masses of any composer since Beethoven," says Dr. Serge Koussevitzky.

Agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation and New York City detectives have arrested eighty-seven enemy aliens, in metropolitan New York, including a Japanese who had two dozen marked maps showing air and sea routes in the Pacific Coast area, it was announced yesterday by P.E. Foxworth, director of the local FBI office.

A FEW weeks ago a tall, bushy-haired young man landed in England. Since then he has been traveling about the country, absorbing its atmosphere. Midst the rubble of Coventry he has talked with men and women who have survived attacks from the skies. He has dropped in on workers at their homes.
MOSCOW, Sunday, Aug. 2 (AP) -- German troops have reached the Salsk and Kushchevka areas, the Russian High Command acknowledged this morning.

IF you are looking for light but not too flimsy Summer reading, for a book that keeps you entertained and never throws you out of balance, we suggest Cecil Roberts's latest novel. It is about a gifted, lucky young playwright who, a generous Hollywood offer in his pocket and wanderlust in his heart, left idyllic Henley-onThames to live and love and see the world.

Manager Mel Ott pressed one of his famous cripples into service as dusk was settling over the Polo Grounds yesterday and the Giants gained an even break in a twin clash with the Cardinals that attracted 23,588 fans, 604 of them service guests.

MONTREAL, Aug. 1 (AP) -- The Jersey City Giants took both ends of a double-header from the Royals today, winning the opener, 7-4 and the nightcap, which was called at the end of the fifth to allow the Little Giants to catch a train, 4-2.

CAIRO, Egypt, Aug. 1 -- Orange-red explosions of "flaming onion" anti-aircraft shells and starlike bursts of ordinary anti-aircraft missiles punctured the pale, moonlit skies over Cairo early this morning during an Axis air raid. Though a small affair, it was the most severe yet.

BERNE, Switzerland, Aug. 1 -In an atmosphere of suspense and with newspapers and radio featuring the ominous developments of the war, Switzerland celebrated today the 651st anniversary of her Confederation, founded on Aug. 1, 1291.

NEW ORLEANS, Aug. 1 -- The astounding failure of the average school to train its students to live in a democracy was emphasized in the recently completed survey of Louisiana schools -- a survey which stressed the place of the schools as "pivotal forces of a democracy" and introduced for the first time new and radical procedures which may well revolutionize the entire method of survey conducting.

I THINK it is mostly the loneliness that gets me. Perhaps, since I am reading the story of "Jane Eyre," a forlorn and solitary child, this is a fitting sensation, lending color to my interpretation of "our heroine"; or perhaps, chameleonlike, I merely borrow the emotion.

Citizens of the nations opposed to the Axis still have inadequate realization of the threat of the totalitarians to "the freedoms and the future of every one of us as individuals," George S. Messersmith, United States Ambassador to Mexico, said on July 18 in his address before the International Women's Club in Mexico City.

Indicating the hesitancy that has encompassed traders for several days, the cotton market yesterday experienced a very quiet session, its volume curtailed as traders awaited specific information on the crop estimate and the 1942 loan program.

LONDON, Aug. 1 -- Swarming in such force that they overwhelmed the anti-aircraft batteries and searchlights of Duesseldorf last night, British bombers dropped a record-breaking tonnage of high explosives and incendiaries on that important steel-producing center of Hitler's Reich.

Although trading in stocks on the New York Stock Exchange last month was the third largest of this year, because of increased activity in the early part of the month, the turnover for July was the second smallest for the month in twenty-four years, or since 1918.

LIDO BEACH, L.I., Aug. 1 -Representatives of the Women's Swimming Association annexed the three titles at stake in the Metropolitan A.A.U. meet conducted today in the pool of the Lido Beach Club. Proceeds of the program went to the USO.
Ready and eager to render streamlined service to the war effort in the recruitment and training of war man power, the colleges and universities of this country find themselves on the sidelines.

Uncle Sam no longer makes daily weather forecasts to the public. But vegetable, fruit and flower plants know nothing about restricting their use of water, nutrients and other necessary raw materials to help win this war. They keep growing in spite of the Japanese.
I READ your article in THE TIMES Of July 19 on those "Early Morning Wags."

During the 1941-42 season art property sold at Gimbel Brothers yielded $5,255,000, the store announced yesterday. This figure includes sales from the Kende Auction Galleries as well as from the William Randolph Hearst, Clarence H. Mackay and other collections displayed on the store's fifth floor.

Waldo Frank, novelist, historian and critic, has lectured on American civilization and culture at the National Universities of Mexico, Argentina, Bolivia and Peru, and last year he was invited to speak on inter-American relations in the world crisis by universities of Argentina and Chile.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 1 -- Apache, leading from start to finish, easily won the Wilson Stakes before 9,745 persons today, but the remarkable thing about his race was the fast time of 1:37 flat for a mile over a track just about a slow as the Saratoga strip gets.

American seamen, whose losses in the war have been proportionately higher than in the armed services, according to claims based on records kept by the unions, are becoming disgruntled, but they intend to go right on sailing their ships until the war is won.

ROCKFORD, Ill., Aug. 1 -- After devoting itself for nearly a century exclusively to the higher education of women, Rockford College will open its academic doors this Fall to men. The co-educational touch comes as a result of the war and the present-day shortage of trained engineers.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 -- Secretary Hull believes that Colombia's leadership has been "indispensable" in promoting closer inter-American relations, it was revealed today when the State Department made public an exchange of telegrams between the Secretary and Dr. Alfonso Lopez, President-elect of Colombia, upon the latter's recent departure after a visit to the United States.

John Kirby and his orchestra use St. Louis Blue as a point of departure rather than give you the music straight, but it's warm none the less, and No Blues at All is even warmer (Victor). Harry James and his orchestra are sweet and soft in But Not for Me, but far from both in The Mole (Columbia).

Dealing with midsummer plant pests and diseases and seeking to maintain an uneasy balance between plant injury on one hand and the trouble involved in using control measures on the other are something like walking a tightrope. If one leans too far to either side the fun and recreation which the garden should provide are lost.

THERE is rather more melodrama than usual in this latest of Mrs. Miller's stories of young love. The gangster atmosphere might be expected from the title, which, of course, indicates Chicago. To bring the whole thing up to date, the gangsters are working with or dominated by Nazi leaders, and sabotage of war industries is their intent.

DETROIT, Aug. 1 (AP) -- The Red Sox pushed over three runs in the seventh inning to defeat the Tigers, 9 to 8, today in a seesaw battle marred by five errors, two of which gave Boston three unearned runs in the first inning.

LENOX, Mass. -- This afternoon's concert at Tanglewood, the second in three week-end series of six arranged by the Berkshire Music Center, has been dedicated to the War Bond and Stamp campaign. Ruth Posselt, violinist, win appear as soloist in the Tchaikovsky concerto.
CHUNGKING, China, Aug. 1 (AP) -- Lieut. Gen. Joseph W. Stilwell's headquarters issued this communique today:

LAST week the Museum of Modern Art placed on view five canvases, three of them recently added to the permanent collection and two consigned as extended loans. Another interesting item, lent by Miss Adelaide M. de Groote, is a walking-stick carved by Gauguin.

INDIANAPOLIS, Aug. 1 -- William D. Pelley, leader of the disbanded Silver Shirts, will be the first defense witness when his sedition trial is resumed in the Federal court Monday, hs attorneys said today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 -- With the House of Representatives in unofficial recess (nothing short of a Presidential summons could assemble sufficient numbers to make its chamber appear to be a going business) and the Senate also quorumless pending floor action on the Tax Bill, the Congressional campaigns are now on in full cry.

SOMEWHERE IN AUSTRALIA, Aug. 1 -- Almost the entire Southwest Pacific war area has burst into activity within the last ten days and the initiative has rested solely with the Japanese. It has been emphatically demonstrated that what is known among Americans here as the "forgotten war" is not forgotten by Tokyo.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 -- The week's war news, with its revival of the possibility of a second European front, emphasized the need for rubber for the war machine of the United Nations, but brought no clarification of the actual situation with regard to supplies.
BOSTON, Aug. 1 -- The Boston Braves bunched three of their seven hits off Ray Starr in the tenth inning today to gain a 2-1 triumph over the Reds.

Orders continued to arrive in desultory fashion in the wholesale markets here last week, according to the market report prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by Kirby, Block Co. There was no concentration of volume and fewer buyers were in the market.

While a considerable portion of American educators are convinced that the goal of higher education should be to train people to make a living, the true function of higher education, nevertheless, remains what it has always been, the spiritual preservation of the State.

Golfers of the metropolitan district are carrying on despite war and gas rationing by maintaining their tournaments, which, however, are often curtailed in length, as in the case of the women's Scotch foursomes which will be contested at the Nassau Country Club under the auspices of the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association on Aug. 11. This match for the past six years has been a thirty-six-hole affair, but will be limited to eighteen this year.
MOSCOW, Aug. 1 (AP) -- The Soviet Information Bureau issued the following communique today:
OTTAWA, Aug. 1 -- After being in almost continuous session since last November, with only short breaks for Christmas and Easter, the Canadian Parliament is closing its doors until Jan. 26 next year.

A fleet of ten automobiles that will be sent to Greece for use by the International Red Cross to speed the distribution of medicines and other supplies to the stricken civilian population was blessed here yesterday by the Right Rev. Athenagoras, Archbishop of the Greek Orthodox Church in North and South America.

BAR HARBOR, Me., Aug. 1 -The first of the series of five buffet suppers to be given at the Bar Harbor Club on Sunday evenings during August will take place tomorrow. Many large parties will be given and supper will be followed by keno and bridge.

In many households nowadays all the hopes and expectations once spread over a big family are concentrated on one or two children. When families consisted of twelve or thirteen or even fifteen children, Professor Ada Hart Arlitt points out in her book, "Family Relationships," fathers and mothers saw just one-twelfth or one-fifteenth as much of an individual child's faults and goings-on as they do now with a single child.

AN ADVANCED ALLIED AIR BASE in Australia, Aug. 1 (AP) -- The crew of a United States Flying Fortress which fought off a dozen Japanese Zero fighter planes over the New Guinea coast and returned to its base with some 200 bullet holes in the bomber described the encounter today.

The pattern set by Miami for transforming a famous resort town into a military center is now being followed by Atlantic City. Day by day Atlantic City is ]justing itself to a new life. Tffytown-onth e-Boardwalk ha become a Replacement Training Center for the Army Air Forces Technical Training Command and soldiers are pouring in by the thousands.
PEEKSKILL, N.Y., Aug. 1--Getting your picture in the papers can work wonders -- even for a dog. At least it has for "Corporal" Hash, the popular mascot fox terrier of Camp Smith here.

Cuba's postal administration made available last week photographs of the designs selected for five stamps soon to be issued to direct the attention of the people in the island republic to the menace of fifth-column activities in wartime.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Aug. 1 -Without fanfare or confusion, and with the efficiency of the engineer, the Massachusetts Institute of Technology has been waging a relentless war against the Aixs. It is a war that is being carried on not alone on the campus, in classroom and overcrowded laboratories, but in temporary laboratories atop the gray structure that fronts the Charles River, and in guarded buildings in Boston and Cambridge.

LENOX, Mass., Aug. 1 -- The first of the series of concerts conducted by Dr. Serge Koussevitzky tonight at Tanglewood proved to be the outstanding social event of the midsummer. Most of the boxes were occupied and many have been taken for the series of six concerts over three week-ends.

NUNNALLY JOHNSON, Twentieth Century-Fox's interpreter of John Steinbeck, began work last week on the screen adaptation of "The Moon Is Down" with a single sentence of advice from Mr. Steinbeck to guide him, In New York recently he asked the author for his suggestions, and all that Steinbeck said was: "Tamper with it."
HERE it is the first Sunday in August and this department is just getting around to the 1941-1942 edition of the honor roll it established last year as an annual institution.
The schedules for the Victory Garden Harvest Show of the New York Horticultural Society, Aug. 12 and 13, are now available from the secretary, 598 Madison Avenue, New York.

Up to the present time the amount of rainfall has been plentiful, but from this period on watering is likely to demand special attention in the garden if there is to be no check to plant growth. This is especially important in the vegetable garden.

Maps, with their far-away names set in pale blue seas and varicolored lands, have always been one of the most satisfactory kinds of wall decoration. Now, when you want to be able to see at a glance where the big news is happening, without having to thumb through a heavy atlas, maps on the wall make a great deal of sense.

Before the war changed matters decisively for residents of the Eastern States, the automobile pampered the Summer traveler and his family in many ways. On going away for a two weeks' vacation they left almost nothing at home for the burglars, except the piano, the lawn-mower, the gas meter and the kitchen stove.
ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Despite wartime restrictions, boating and fishing continue popular with Summer visitors here, each day finding hundreds enjoying these sports.

THE patriotic housekeeper's responsibilities are not static. They vary as the fortunes of war bring changes in available supplies, in transportation facilities, in national policy. A woman bent on making her full potential contribution on the home front needs to keep her ears cocked for new government orders and her kitchen on a highly flexible basis.

Another over-the-weight bout involving a champion, but not his championship, tops the local boxing schedule for the week. This encounter is set for Thursday night at Madison Square Garden, where Albert (Chalky) Wright, the featherweight king, clashes with Allie Stolz of Newark over a ten-round route.

With traditionally sweat-stained August fresh upon us, the cool of Autumn seems a long way off. We are still wincing from the blasts that July blew our way. But only a few nights ago the first katydids were out and doing in their own strident fashion; and the weather-wise assure us that the first frost will come six weeks after the first katydids.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 1 -- Several hundred members of the Summer colony and their tennis-week house guests attended the tennis dance held tonight in the Colonial Ballroom and the Oriental Room of the Meadow Club to mark the end of the club's fifty-second annual invitation tennis tournament The visiting tennis stars were the guests of honor at the event.

Rafael Leonidas Trujillo Molina has again been elected President of the Dominican Republic, after having been out of office for several years. Word comes from Trujillo City that he signed a decree last month authorizing the issuing of a series commemorating the election.

What to do if the grocer fails to display ceiling prices on cost-of-living foods; if the landlord demands a seemingly unjustified rent increase or refuses to paint the apartment; if the sugar ration book has been lost or the local rationing board has rejected the application for extra gasoline, are among the questions that have made wartime life complex for many civilians.

Main floor and basement departments were busy in retail stores in the three major test markets of New York, Chicago and Los Angeles, according to the survey prepared for THE NEW YORK TIMES by Meyer Both Reports.

A man prepares to dress for a party but puts on his pajamas and goes to bed. We misplace glasses and keys and wonder what we did with them. Students decorate notebooks with cryptic designs. Every one of us "doodles."

CHICAGO, Aug. 1 -- Four youths, all of prominent families in Evanston, were in seclusion today following their arraignment before United States Commissioner Edwin K. Walker on charges of impersonating agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 -- The military trial of the eight Nazi saboteurs who landed on the East Coast from U-boats in June ended today, and the seven Army generals immediately began to formulate the recommendations they will make to President Roosevelt, who will ultimately decide whether the Germans shall live or die.

"SHE is a Marseilles or a Shanghai, American style, shot through with overtones of Christy Minstrels, the code duello, white steamboats on a chocolate-colored river, coffee and cotton, wine in cobwebbed bottles, vine-festooned patios, and Basin Street jazz." So Mr. Sinclair describes the old belle who sits for her portrait in this new addition to Doubleday, Doran's Seaport Series.

Patrolman Thomas Slow of Queens Village, who is attached to the Eighty-second Precinct in Brooklyn, was suspended from duty yesterday pending investigation of the accident in which a fellow-policeman was injured in Friday night's blackout.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 -- The War Labor Board unanimously granted maintenace of membership clauses in two C.I.O. contracts today, but two employer members in a separate opinion strongly urged that unions receiving such preferred treatment be required to prove their responsibility, through financial and other statements, and be forbidden to make contributions to political parties.

BERNE, Switzerland, Aug. 1 -Difficulties are piling up on Vichy, France, according to private advices reaching here today. In the first place, despite reports of the rush of skilled workers volunteering for armament jobs in Germany to release prisoners of war, not one single captive has been freed since Pierre Laval broadcast his appeal on June 22.

LONDON, Aug. 1 -- Progress on two production fronts -- agriculture and coal mining -- were in the limelight in British commodity news this week. While the agricultural development is cheering, the coal position continues to be a cause for concern.

Despite a lack of certain varieties, the British people have plenty of food and health conditions "are excellent," Dr. Hulby R. Owen, public health director of Philadelphia and head of civilian defense activities in that city, reported yesterday on his arrival at La Guardia Airport aboard an American Export Airlines transatlantic plane.

ALTHOUGH it is not an academic certainty, Edgar Kennedy should have been the victim of an occupational disease by now. However, despite the fact that he is practically the screen's foremost example of hypertension, Mr. Kennedy, the citizen and farmer, continues to function with the bland equanimity of his contented cattle.

So Mr. Sinclair describes the old belle who sits for her portrait in this new addition to Doubleday, Doran's Seaport Series.

NATURE made the Great Plains, but man made the Cow Country. In the making he gave America one of the great chapters of history. It is of the history as well as the geography of the Cow Country that Professor Dale writes in this book.

The gas and tire shortage is no obstacle at all to the millions of New Yorkers -- and their visitors -who get their salt-water bathing, surf-casting, tennis, golf, moonlight strolling and whatever you like without going outside the metropolitan area.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 -- An era of rigid enforcement of regulations against rising prices for food, clothing and other necessities, including rents, is being ushered in by the Office of Price Administration, in the opinion of observers here. During the last ten days landlords, retailers and wholesalers in several sections of the country found themselves facing courts for failure to observe the OPA's regulations.

Murder, kidnapping and espionage combine to provide thrills for Marty Prentiss, a reporter who has just returned to New York after trying his luck elsewhere. The first person upon whom Prentiss calls is Tiny Tim Lannahan of the Homicide Bureau, and that is how he happens to be present when a body, apparently that of a derelict, is discovered on Pier I.

Because she plays a saxophone and because the Woman's Army Auxiliary Corps needs a band, the first basic auxiliary from this area left yesterday for Fort Des Moines with seven officer-candidates as the second group to depart from the Second Service Command headed West.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 (AP)--The biggest primary election month of the year opened today with candidates in sixteen States vying for twelve Senate and 164 House seats and several Governorships.

PURSUANT to Special Order No. Something-or-other, some good football players in uniform are already on the march. The travel directed is necessary in the military service. In other words, Colonel Bob Neyland and Major Wallace Wade are rounding up their men for that All-Army football team.
ST. PAUL, Minn., Aug. 1 -- Shooting sub-par golf, Gene Kunes, a veteran but little-known campaigner from Philadelphia, today took the lead in the St. Paul open tournament.

A SURVEY of seven Eastern United States plants employing music undertaken by Amy Lee, staff writer for the National Association of Music Merchants, comes to the same conclusions as the report of the British Broadcasting Corporation on music in English plants, quoted here last week.
ATLANTA, Aug. 1 (AP) -- If Southern football looks strange of face this season, and a bit ragged around the edges, here's why:

Many green-fingered gardeners who have been compelled, by the exigencies of war, to leave their carefully tended gardens and to live in apartments, may well make the acquaintance of the little plant known as the African Violet or Saintpaulia -- named for Baron von St. Paul, who discovered the species.
BUFFALO, Aug. 1 (AP) -- Buffalo snapped out of a losing string of six games tonight and hammered Newark, 8 to 4. It was the first reverse for the champions in six starts this week.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 (U.P.) -The War Production Board soon will halt new construction by electric utility concerns -- principally the Rural Electrification Administration -- to save critical war materials, it was learned today.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Aug. 1 (AP) -- Edwin F. Jaeckle, New York State Republican chairman, urged today in a letter to Republican County chairmen that a tentative resolutions committee be chosen before the State convention so that "intensive consideration" can be given to the State platform.

CHUNGKING, China, Aug. 1 -- United States fighter pilots shot down nine Japanese planes over Hengyang yesterday, raising the Japanese losses over that Hunan Province air base to at least seventeen in two days, Lieut. Gen. Joseph W. Stilwell announced today as the Chinese reported a new Japanese landing on the coast of Chekiang Province.
BOSTON, Aug. 1 -- More than a thousand students from Northeastern University are working on war jobs in conjunction with their regular study programs, a school survey disclosed today.

If the measure of a people's patriotism is their demand for flags, then American loyalty has leaped into the heights since Pearl Har bor. A survey of city flag sellers revealed yesterday an industry besieged with orders, from both civilians and the government, most companies reporting a demand that was either "terrific" or "very high."

Promising developments both for military use and later for cargo use in peacetime are implicit in the new method of launching gliders which has been demonstrated by the Army's Air-Borne Command and All American Aviation, Inc. Under this method the towing plane swoops like a hawk for its prey while in flight at 100 miles an hour, drops a man-made talon and snatches the loaded glider from the ground.

THE man who already lives upstairs will have no need of this book. But the man who lives downstairs and isn't fully aware of the enchantments of living upstairs will do well to read it, if he reads no other. By the time he has finished it, he will run upstairs two steps at a time, or else -- he will not go so far as to finish the book.

CHESTERTOWN, Md., Aug. 1 -Drawing parallels between the history and destiny of the Kent counties in the Old World and the New, Noel Hall, British diplomat, speaking tonight at the Kent County tercentenary celebration, warned the Axis that, though the democratic peoples of England and America might be "slow starters," they "get there in the end."

A case of mistaken identity, based on the fact that an elderly man dropped dead of a heart attack at Intervale Avenue and Kelly Street, the Bronx, at 7:30 A.M., plunged the family of Samuel Rossman, 74-year-old retired shoemaker, who lives a short distance away, at 891 Dawson Street, into a period of unnecessary mourning yesterday.

MONTAUK, L.I., Aug. 1 -- On Aug. 15 the Montauk unit of the American Women's Voluntary Services will sponsor an all-day carnival at the Montauk Surf Club. There will be a bazaar and games, and aquatic events directed by Miss Ethelda Bleibtrey.

OLD ORCHARD BEACH, Me., Aug. 1 (AP) -- Colby Hanover, favorite in the coming Hambletonian Stake at Goshen, was an upset victim today in a $3,000 stake for 3-and four-year-old trotters as the Old Orchard kite track brought its two-week Grand Circuit meeting to a close.
HAMPTON INSTITUTE, Va., Aug. 1 -- "Life-centered" is the Summer school at Hampton Institute this year, which has an enrollment of 452 students, 126 of them candidates for advanced degrees.
Ramsey S. Black, third assistant postmaster general, announced officially last week that the Postoffice Department "does not have a Lidice stamp under contemplation."

NO Hamlets incapable of action, no scatter-brained Ophelias, are the energetic stage craftsmen enrolled as members of the American Theatre Wing War Service. Against our sea of contemporary troubles they have taken arms as seamstresses and first-aid workers, campaign speakers and blood donors, canteen cooks and assembly-line trainees, and finally, of course, as entertainers to the fighting men and even the tired laborers in war plants.

MONTCLAIR, N.J., Aug. 1 (AP) -- Miss Gloria Evans, 16-year-old Montclair player, registered the first upset in the Montclair Athletic Club's third annual girls' invitation tennis tournament today. She defeated Miss Lillian Lopaus of City Island in a semi-final match, 6 -- 2, 6 -- 4.

More local yachting ranks are being depleted by the call of the Army, especially the Engineer Amphibian Command. The head of the North River Power Squadron, Burgess P. Wallace, commander, has relinquished his post to accept a captaincy at the Amphibian training station, Camp Edwards, Mass.

A FURTHER testimonial to the spirit of the nation's artists and to their desire to help in the war comes from Captain William McK. Spierer of the 603d Engineer Camouflage Battalion, Fort George G. Meade, Maryland, who has been promoted since his previous communication.

Lawrence Kelly, 14 years old, of 624 East Seventeenth Street, buttonholed Mayor LaGuardia for five minutes yesterday afternoon on the East Side River Drive at Twenty-second Street and emerged from the conference with the Mayor's promise to look for a job for his father, an unemployed steamfitter.

THE most highly valued of British literary distinctions is the Hawthornden Prize, founded in 1919 by Alice Warrender and awarded annually for the best piece of imaginative writing published during the preceding year by a British author under 41 years of age.

HIGHLIGHTS of the week: The A.F. of L. Motion Picture Office Employes, Local 23196, called a strike of office workers employed in tl4e Warnet Brothers home office here and in the company's New York exchange.

Determination of the recording industry to go ahead "as best we can" despite the order of James C. Petrillo, president of the American Federation of Musicians, forbidding 180,000 musicians to make recordings, was voiced by Edward Wallerstein, president of the Columbia Recording Corporation, yesterday.

CHICAGO, Aug. 1 -- Fears that an impending movement of Spring wheat would furnish considerable hedging pressure and the purchase of 100,000 bushels of No. 1 Northern Spring wheat to come here from the Northwest with more offered at an attractive basis started liquidation today by scattered longs after a small upturn early.
EAST HAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 1 -- Miss Louise Brough, national girls' champion from Los Angeles, upset the top-ranking player in the women's invitation tennis tournament at the Maidstone Club today.
SOMEWHERE IN ENGLAND, Aug. 1 -- The night sky over the airport throbbed with the sound of heavy bombers when I arrived. They were British Lancasters, heading for Duesseldorf.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 1 -- The Public Service Company of Indiana bond case, involving not only the right of the National Association of Securities Dealers, Inc., to discipline its members for alleged violations of selling agreements but the validity of the traditional underwriting contract itself, will be resumed before the Securities and Exchange Commission on Aug. 18.

The report of Canada Dry Ginger Ale, Inc., for the nine months ended on June 30, issued yesterday, shows a net profit of $1,016,799, after deducting $916,289 for Federal and Canadian income and excess profits taxes and other charges.

More local yachting ranks are being depleted by the call of the Army, especially the Engineer Amphibian Command. The head of the North River Power Squadron, Burgess P. Wallace, commander, has relinquished his post to accept a captaincy at the Amphibian training station, Camp Edwards, Mass.

A FURTHER testimonial to the spirit of the nation's artists and to their desire to help in the war comes from Captain William McK. Spierer of the 603d Engineer Camouflage Battalion, Fort George G. Meade, Maryland, who has been promoted since his previous communication.

Lawrence Kelly, 14 years old, of 624 East Seventeenth Street, buttonholed Mayor LaGuardia for five minutes yesterday afternoon on the East Side River Drive at Twenty-second Street and emerged from the conference with the Mayor's promise to look for a job for his father, an unemployed steamfitter.

He gave notice to his 190,000,000 countrymen that their nation had never faced a graver moment -- not even in a past that has been scourged by invading Tatars, Mongols, Swedes, Poles, French and another generation of Germans.

THOUGH he has achieved fame as a writer, movie and radio actor, musical encyclopedist and a wit of sorts, Oscar Levant's first love would seem to be music. Not merely answering questions about music, though he would probably prefer to talk about music next to playing or hearing it.

FOREMOST among the labor questions of the day and most difficult for government agencies to adjust is the much contested demand for the closed shop. It is no secret that many cases of acquiescence in decisions on the matter by one side or the other have, beneath the surface, been mere patriotic concessions to the needs of war production.

IN Boswell's "Journal of a Tour to the Hebrides With Samuel Johnson," he remarks, "We reckoned there would be some inconveniences and hardships and perhaps a little danger." Dr. Peregrine and his wife and two sons were not counting on any of those things when they went to Acarsaid for a holiday.

NEWARK, N.J., Aug. 1 -- Dr. Samuel L. Hamilton, chairman of the trustees of the Newark Public Library, denied in a statement today there was anything "unsavory" in the situation that led to the decision of Miss Beatrice Winser to retire Sept. 1 as librarian of the institution and expressed regret that Miss Winser was ending her fifty-three-year association with the library over "a picayune mess."

LONDON, Aug. 2 -- The House of Commons soon will pass a bill giving exclusive criminal jurisdiction over all members of the United States armed forces serving in the British Isles to the American authorities. The bill passed all its stages in the House of Lords last week.

Congressional leaders and earnest organs of opinion clamor for Director Elmer Davis of the War Information Office to go on the air again, this time on all the networks, to give the country news of the war in his canny and dispassionate way. It is argued that the sound of his calm Hoosier voice at stated intervals would have a salutary effect on the national morale.

Asking his listeners to turn aside their thoughts of the war for a while and concentrate on "the deeper insight" of life, the Rev. Dr. Charles Reynolds Brown, dean emeritus of the Yale Divinity School, discussed in a sermon yesterday morning "the divine power of God," which he described as the source of our confidence and courage.

VICHY, France, Aug. 2 -- A woman clambered atop a table on the Avenue d'Orleans in Paris yesterday, screamed "riot -- the Americans demand it," and touched off a melee of gunfire and slugging in which one person was killed and nine were injured gravely, the government announced tonight.

The Carnation Company has sold privately to a group of insurance and investment companies, through Kidder, Peabody Co. and A.E. Ames Co., as agents, $2,050,000 of 4 per cent first preferred stock and $4,000,000 of 3 per cent fifteen-year debentures, it was announced yesterday.

LENOX, Mass., Aug. 2 -- The Berkshire Music Center Orchestra, conducted by Serge Koussevitzky, having scored a sensational success at its opening concert last night, was heard this afternoon in the second program of the series it is presenting here in Tanglewood under the auspices of the Koussevitzky Music Center, Inc.

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 2 -- Determined to stamp out the last semblance of rebellion against their continued rule as overlords of the American League, the Yanks today closed their third western jaunt of the campaign by treating the Browns to two thrashings while a crowd of 19,519 looked on helplessly.

At 7:30 yesterday evening, with 27,698 Flatbush fans yelling for just one more base hit, Lou Stringer knelt in front of Pistol Pete Reiser's grounder, carefully relayed the ball to Phil Cavarretta -- and the Cubs salvaged one contest of their four-game series at Ebbets Field.
BOSTON, Aug. 2 (AP) -- Home runs proved the decisive factors in a double-header divided by the Braves and Reds today. Cincinnati won the nightcap, 4 to 2, after the Braves triumphed, 7 to 0.

CHICAGO, Aug. 2 -- On the eve of the opening of the seventh annual convention of the C.I.O.'s United Automobile Workers of America, President R.J. Thomas expressed today the "disappointment" of labor at "the lack of imagination which has thus far been displayed by those in charge of our armed forces, and those who have been entrusted with supplying them."

MOSCOW, Aug. 2 -- All Moscow newspapers this morning published messages from London and New York in which popular movements in favor of the early opening of a second front were described, including an article reported to have appeared recently in The Washington Post.

A masked gunman, who entered and left so quickly that witnesses could give only a sketchy account of his movements, shot and killed two men early today in the Whitehouse Association, a chartered bridge club on the second floor of 846 Seventh Avenue, between Fifty-fourth and Fifty-fifth Streets.

The Summer wears on, and still the solution of New York's unemployment problem is not in sight. With the coming of Winter, the city's roster of jobless "employables" may rise from 400,000 to 500,000 unless the conferences of Federal, State and municipal officials bear fruit promptly.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 -- Transactions to which Maximum Price Regulation No. 157 applies are limited to those directly and immediately related to the present war-procurement program of the nation for textiles, apparel and similar articles, it was made clear by Price Administrator Leon Henderson today as an amendment to the regulation was announced.

WADESBORO, N.C., Aug. 2 (AP) -- In their dispersed bivouacs on opposite sides of the brown, sluggish Pee Dee River, the Red and Blue forces engaged in the Army's first war-time manoeuvres had an opportunity today to study in detail the results of their participation in the most recent problem.

Jesus is our lawyer, said Bishop Robert Nelson Spencer of the Episcopal Diocese of West Missouri, preaching yesterday in the Cathedral of St. John the Divine. He took his text from the First Epistle of St. John, Chapter I, Verse I: "We have an advocate with the Father, Jesus Christ the righteous."

A practical program to help industrial and business concerns to prepare now for post-war problems was announced yesterday by William P. Witherow, president of the National Association of Manufacturers, 14 West Forty-ninth Street. Printed in booklet form, the program is being sent to the association's 8,000 members.
MOSCOW, Aug. 2 (AP) -- The Soviet Information Bureau issued this communique:

OTTAWA, Aug. 2 (Canadian Press) -- Coupon rationing of tea and coffee goes into effect tomorrow, with the quota for each person set at one ounce of tea or four ounces of coffee a week -- but not both -- the Wartime Prices and Trade Board announced tonight.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 -- Arthur E. Pew Jr., vice president of the Houdry Process Corporation, today made public a letter he had written to Senator Gillette, chairman of the subcommittee of the Senate Agricultural and Forestry Committee, charging that a tabulation presented to the committee by officials of the government's Rubber Reserve Company "distorted" the true facts concerning requirements for critical materials of the Houdry process.

PITTSBURGH, Aug. 2 -- Philip Murray, president of the Congress of Industrial Organizations, proposed in a letter today to William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor, a reopening of negotiations to establish organic unity between the organizations in the interest of America's war program.

On Aug. 3, 1776, another Spitfire let go its guns in the cause of liberty. It was a Spitfire on this side of the Atlantic and it had wings of canvas, not metal, but its task was the same as the R.A.F. fighter plane's today, to make tyranny tremble and let freedom ring.

Three Swedish steamers under charter to the Greek War Relief Association will leave Montreal the first part of this week with 15,000 tons of grain and fifty tons of medical supplies for the relief of the starving Greek people. Included in the cargoes will be ten automobiles, donated by William G. Helis, national vice president of the association, to be used in connection with the distribution of the food.

The Board of Education's war industries training program has prepared 130,000 workers so far, it was announced yesterday by John E. Wade, Superintendent of Schools, as he made public a report summarizing the program's first year of operation.
The following German High Command communique was broadcast from Berlin yesterday and recorded here by The Associated Press:
CLEVELAND, Aug. 2 (AP) -- The Indians took second place today, 4 points ahead of the Red Sox as they swept a double-header from the Athletics, 4 -- 3 and 4 -- 2.

While gasoline dealers took indignant exception to the report of a special House investigating committee, which had charged in Washington that bootlegging of gasoline was interfering with the rationing program, an independent inquiry disclosed yesterday that there is gasoline bootlegging in the city even under the permanent coupon system of rationing.

As Nazi submarines continue to sink United Nations shipping and as large numbers of Allied planes are grounded in many parts of the world for lack of spare parts, the need for a great fleet of cargo planes becomes increasingly apparent.

The sinking of the first Russian vessel in American waters, announced yesterday by the Navy Department, brought to a stewardess and a dishwasher -- the first women crew members to be killed in a torpedoing -- the immortality that other Soviet women have won by guerrilla fighting behind the Nazi lines.

Motorists driving in the city must use only their parking lights, or shaded headlamps that are no brighter, under a new traffic order by Police Commissioner Valentine made public yesterday by Mayor La Guardia in his weekly radio "Talk to the People" from City Hall.

Apathetic trade demand, attributable chiefly to continued favorable reports on crop conditions and to a general desire to await the government's estimate on Aug. 8 of the season's yield, caused the cotton market to lose further ground last week.

The German High Command announced yesterday that German armored units and motorized infantry were pursuing Soviet troops "in the direction of" the Kuban River, 125 miles south of Rostov and athwart the approaches to the Maikop oil fields.

The fog which shrouds the Aleutians has not been dispelled by the statement of a Navy spokesman that the Japanese invaders of the western islands may number 10,000. If the occupation force is indeed so small, the mystery of why it has been allowed to remain for two months is only deepened.

The report of the City-Wide Citizens Committee on Harlem, just issued, is none the less valuable because it underlines facts which have been of common knowledge and makes recommendations which should have been acted upon long ago. There are some truths that cannot be uttered too often.

SOMEWHERE IN AUSTRALIA, Aug. 2 -- Today's communique from General Douglas MacArthur's headquarters reported several different actions in the Southwest Pacific area, the most significant of which was an Allied air raid for the second successive day on Kukum, on the north shore of Guadalcanal Island in the Solomons.

Progress in the Negro's "struggle for fuller equality" during the past year was announced yesterday by the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, 69 Fifth Avenue, which made public its report for 1941.

VICHY, Aug. 2 -- The question of food and supplies remains as one of the main government preoccupations. In order to improve the insufficient transport, which is one of the chief obstacles to a proper distribution of supplies, measures have been taken to increase the use of the railway cars in service and new reductions have been made in the transportation of passengers.
Five new films will open in Broadway theatres during the week.
LONDON, Aug. 2 (AP) -- The Air Ministry issued this communique today:

The rates charged by the New York Telephone Company to hotels, apartment houses and clubs for private branch exchange facilities were held to be reasonable in a decision announced yesterday by the Public Service Commission. The ruling also upheld as adequate the compensation received by hotels for outside service to guests.

CAIRO, Egypt, Aug. 2 -- Bomber planes of the United States Army Air Forces scored two direct hits and several near misses yesterday on an Axis merchant vessel that was discovered off the Libyan coast near Derna. The ship was soon down by the stern, and was sinking when the raiders left the scene.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 -- The special military commission named by President Roosevelt to try the eight Nazi saboteurs landed on our shores from German U-boats met in an extraordinary session here today instead of taking its usual Sunday recess.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 2 -- With overtones of caution, the Tax Institute of the University of Pennsylvania reported today that, contrary to general expectation, State tax yields during the first five months of 1942 ran 10 per cent higher than in the corresponding period of last year.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 -- Unemployment insurance payments during June dropped for the third consecutive month, Paul V. McNutt, Federal Security Administrator, announced today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 (U.P.) -- WPB Vice Chairman William L. Batt expressed confidence today that Russia would be fighting next Winter, despite the fact that the United States and Britain had been able to send her only "too little" assistance.
LONDON, Aug. 2 -- Squadrons of the Fighter Command of the Royal Air Force carried on the offensive against Nazi stations in occupied territory last night and during daylight today.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Aug. 2 -- Spencer Tracy will be starred by Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer in "America," a film about an industrial immigrant family, which King Vidor will produce and direct after Tracy completes his current assignment in "Keeper of the Flame" with Katharine Hepburn.

MOSCOW, Aug. 2 -- The spreading of the southern front to the neighborhood of Salsk, 100 miles southeast of Rostov, effectively cuts the last main railroad to the Soviet Black Sea Fleet's bases. It also seriously complicates transport of the grain of the Kuban steppes and the oil of the Maikop fields.
BUENOS AIRES, Argentina, Aug. 2 -- Waldo Frank, United States writer, was assaulted in his home this morning by six men and injured.

The intimation that there was bribery in the Women's Court contained in a report issued by the women's court committee of the Social Service Bureau on June 8, was without basis in fact, according to a report made public yesterday by William B. Herlands, Commissioner of Investigation, after being submitted to Mayor La Guardia.

CHICAGO, Aug. 2 -- Operations in lard futures have shrunk to a point where business is almost non-existent, as price ceilings on that commodity have resulted in liquidation by interests on both sides of the market. There are only fifty uncompleted contracts outstanding on the Board of Trade, a large part of which are for September delivery.

LA JOLLA, Calif., Aug. 2 (AP) -- Japanese sea divers who used to work off the California coast retained the exact location of kelp beds which yield agar-agar, and as a result this country is without a source of supply of this essential medicinal item, scientists reported today.

MOSCOW, Monday, Aug. 3 -- A communique issued today indicated little change anywhere on the southern front, but said that the Red Army was exacting a heavy toll of German troops and materiel. Press dispatches reported that Soviet air squadrons rushed to the Western Caucasus had slowed the German drives in the Kushchevka and Salsk areas, south and southeast of Rostov.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., Aug. 2 -- Race Week at the Larchmont Yacht Club wound up today with a total of 804 starters being checked over the five sessions. There were 159 out today. The number far exceeded the expectations of most yachtsmen.
CHUNGKING, China, Aug. 2 (Reuter) -- Tonight's Chinese communique said:

Newspapers, magazines and trade papers reaching nearly three out of every four families in the United States will be enlisted during National Wine Week, Oct. 11 to 18, to put over the biggest promotion ever undertaken by the industry.

PATERSON, N.J., Aug. 2 -- Five hundred more workers in the Wright Aeronautical Corporation's warplane engine plant here will be laid off temporarily, beginning tomorrow, because of the failure of raw materials to arrive at the plant.

POMONA, N.Y., Aug. 2 -- Rockland County's newest and best equipped air raid observation tower, a twenty-foot wooden structure in an apple orchard on the farm of Gordon Concklin, was dedicated this afternoon at a ceremony attended by 300 persons, including Major Charles Blackwell, regional director of the Auxiliary Aircraft Warning Service.

The Roosevelt Distinguished Service Medals, awarded annually since 1923, except last year, by the Roosevelt Memorial Association, have been won this year by Secretary of War Henry L. Stimson, Booth Tarkington and Dr. Rufus M. Jones, founder of the American Friends Service Committee.

CHICAGO, Aug. 2 -- Wheat prices declined to new seasonal low levels last week, with mild liquidation and a lack of confidence on the part of buyers sending the September delivery down to around $1.16 a bushel, or about 16 cents under the current government loan price, and about 21 cents under the high reached last January.

LONDON, Aug. 2 -- The critical position reached on the Russian front and the imminence of the August holiday week reduced business in the stock market almost to a mere trickle in the closing days of last week. Even in these grim times some relaxation must be permitted to the hard-worked and in many cases overworked civilians, and no apology is needed for the slackening activity in the next few days.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 -- The Department of Agriculture said today that although evidence continues to accumulate of new high records for agricultural production this year, food requirements continue to mount for military, lease-lend and civilian use.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 2 -- Ted Schroeder of Glendale, Calif., winner of the singles on Saturday, and Sidney B. Wood Jr., runner-up, joined forces today to win the doubles cups in the Southampton invitation tennis tournament at the Meadow Club.

With only two full weeks remaining before the delegates begin assembling for the Democratic State convention Aug. 19, the results were still in doubt yesterday in the fight for control of the party in the State, being waged between supporters of President Roosevelt and the New Deal and the State organization headed by James A. Farley.

BRIARCLIFF MANOR, N.Y., Aug. 2 -- Chester T. Birch's attempt to win his home club's invitation tourney for the fourth time was frustrated today by Ray Billows, golfing ace from the Dutchess Club, Poughkeepsie, who has twice gone to the final in the national amateur championship.

Pointing out that while "we must give our full strength" in the struggle of the United Nations for justice and liberty for all men everywhere, Bishop William T.
