Manning declared yesterday morning that "at the same time we must stand more earnestly for right conditions here in our own land until the ideals of justice and liberty are more fully realized.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Aug. 2 (AP) -- Senator John D. Bankhead has suggested to General George C. Marshall, Army Chief of Staff, that Northern Negro soldiers be quartered in Northern States only, the Senator revealed today in a letter to John Temple Graves of The Birmingham Age-Herald.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Aug. 2 (AP) -- The Newark Bears tightened their hold on first pleace in the International League today with two victories over the Buffalo Bisons, 7 to 1 and 7 to 4, before 4,500 spectators.

THIS way for the big show! The Giants and Dodgers are ready to go at it in the gloaming at the Polo Grounds, and the only safe prediction is that at the twilight's last gleaming the Army Emergency Relief will not be the loser.

A letter from Mme. Chiang Kaishek received by the American Woman's Voluntary Services was made public yesterday expressing her pleasure that Chinese women in this country were cooperating with the organization through the formation of the all-Chinese unit in New York's Chinatown. Mrs. Josephine Hong is chairman.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 -- The Army and Navy have requested the Red Cross to collect a new quota of 2,500,000 pints of blood during the next twelve months, it was announced today by Chairman Norman Davis. To supply the amounts about 50,000 donors a week would be required, he said.

In a short-wave broadcast directed to the workers of the occupied countries of Europe, Emil Rieve, president of the Textile Workers Union of America, C.I.O., declared yesterday that the workers of America, while doing their utmost in the fight against fascism, were also continuing their fight for social and economic reforms, even in wartime.
DETROIT, Aug. 2 (AP) -- The Tigers suddenly came to life today and captured both ends of a double-header from the Red Sox, 8-to-4 and 6-to-2.

The city's new $550,000 live poultry terminal at Fifty-third Avenue and Twenty-first Street, Long Island City, Queens, was formally dedicated last night with speeches, but no chickens. The chickens will start arriving at 7 o'clock this morning when the market opens for business.

Shipments of the United Aircraft Corporation in the first half of 1942 were $242,708,318, the highest in the company's history, and in the second quarter of this year they were at the high record of $132,592,433, according to the semi-annual report approved by the Navy Department and issued for publication today.

After being cudgeled into submission by Manager Mel Ott's two homers in the first game at the Polo Grounds yesterday, the Cardinals squeezed through to victory in the nightcap before 35,841 fans, 1,336 of them service guests.
Two large duplex apartments in 322 East Fifty-seventh Street have been leased by Thomas Fizdale and Alfred C. McKelvy through Culver, Hollyday Co., brokers.

CHICAGO, Aug. 2 -- Oats developed independent strength and prices averaged somewhat higher due to relatively small receipts from the country despite harvesting and threshing being in full blast, and reports indicating that farmers were not inclined to part with their grain.

The nation's contract bridge experts gathered her last night for their sixteenth annual national championship tournament, moved this year from Asbury Park, N.J., where it always has been held before, to the Park Central Hotel.

Last week the Irving Fisher index of wholesale commodity prices remained at 108.4. Although there was pronounced price activity in the farm products group, the index remained unchanged because higher quotations in oranges, cattle, corn, and oats were practically balanced by lower quotations in wheat, hogs, raw cotton, poultry and lamb.

AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, Australia, Monday, Aug. 3 (AP) -- Allied planes shot down six Japanese aircraft over the Kokoda-Gona area of Southeastern New Guinea yesterday as cooperating Allied ground patrols dispersed Japanese outpost groups in a jungle fight near Kokoda, it was announced officially today. Three Allied planes were reported missing.
EAST HAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 2 -- The name of Miss Louise Brough was added today to the long and distinguished list of winners of the William H. Woodin Gold Cup at the Maidstone Club.

BOMBAY, India, Aug. 2 (UP) -Mohandas K. Gandhi, leader of Indian Nationalism, warned today that unless India received complete independence now, her "hidden discontent may burst forth into welcome for the Japanese should the latter land in India."

LONDON, Aug. 2 -- The Yanks are taking London in their stride these days, especially the men who have been here a while. They have learned pub crawling, where to get the best whiskey and beer for the least money, how to shoot the good old Army game of dice with pounds, shillings and pence, and how to get on with English girls.

ELKRIDGE, Md., Aug. 2 (AP) -- Corbit Bishop, the hunger-striking conscientious objector, was still holding out tonight against food despite an order from Selective Service Headquarters in Washington that he break his thirty-six-day fast.
On the Pacific Coast interest in catching sharks has increased with the rising value recently placed on shark livers.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 (U.P.) -- The Middle East offers the best possibilities for the opening of a second front by the United Nations, Alexander Kiralfy, naval and military writer, declared tonight on the Mutual Broadcasting System's American Forum of the Air.
Tonight is the night! In their twelfth battle of the National League campaign the Giants and Dodgers will try to push the league's service relief drive over the top.

Prepared and acted by employes of the Bridgeport (Conn.) Brass Company, a fifty-minute condensation of their full-length musical show, "Ready! Aim! Fire!" is slated for presentation on Aug. 17 at the Stage Door Canteen here, it was announced yesterday by Herman W. Steinkraus at his home in Westport, Conn.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 -- Sales of war savings bonds in July reached $900,900,000, the second highest monthly amount on record, Secretary Morgenthau announced today. The highest total was in last January, when $1,060,546,000 worth of these bonds were sold.

"Faith in the importance of the individual as against his importance as a member of some national or social grouping, is in danger of being dimmed by participation in total war," said the Rev. W. Glenn Roberts, associate executive secretary, of the Brooklyn Church and Mission Federation, who preached at Tompkins Avenue Congregational Church, at McDonough Street, Brooklyn, yesterday morning.

The dog days have come again in the national capital and the public is faced with renewed examples of petulance and repeated bickerings between the factions in the halls of Congress and between Congress and the Executive.
AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, Australia, Aug. 2 (AP) -- A communique issued by General Douglas MacArthur's headquarters today said:

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Aug. 2 -- Entire districts of Hamburg were laid waste by last week's Royal Air Force bombardments and the casualties ran into thousands, said a sailor on a Swedish ship that arrived at Goeteborg yesterday from the German city.

We read in the news frequently these days that action on some more or less pressing issue pending at Washington may be postponed until after the election. The following from Noah Brooks's "Lincoln" seems to be pertinent:

World peace will follow recognition of the supreme importance of man's spiritual life over his material existence, the Rev. Thomas Lester Graham asserted yesterday at solemn mass in St. Patrick's Cathedral, of which he is one of the staff.

With Germany's military forces thrusting into the Caucasus region, attention again is being focused on the vast oil resources of the Soviet Union and their importance in the immediate future on the military operations of both the United Nations and the Axis Powers.

Another issue of "tap" bonds, United States of America 2 1/2 per cent Treasury bonds of 1962-67, goes on the market today. Like their predecessors of May 5, they may not be held by commercial banks which accept demand deposits, but both these and the former bonds, which are identical, have been made more attractive by a new provision.
Two articles appeared in your paper July 26 dealing with the subject of a second front, one by Hanson W. Baldwin and the other by Edwin L. James.

Fifteen football stars were added yesterday to the Eastern All-Army squad that will report to Colonel Bob Neyland at Yale University, New Haven, on Wednesday to start preparations for an eight-game schedule.

A girl can get her exercise and keep her attractiveness with a few simple precautions -- such as a bottle of cool, fresh-scented protective lotion for face, hands and arms ($1.50 for a generous amount in a tricky blue jar), which effectively banishes the specter of weatherbeaten complexion and calloused hands.

PITTSBURGH, Aug. 2 (U.P.) -- A labor dispute which had forced the Pittsburgh Press to suspend publication of afternoon and Sunday editions for five days was settled tonight and the newspaper will resume publication tomorrow.

MONTCLAIR, N.J., Aug. 2 (AP) Fifteen-year-old Miss Shirley Fry of Akron, Ohio, the nation's seventh-ranking girls' tennis player, spotted Miss Gloria Evans of Montclair the first set today and then hit her stride to register a 4 -- 6, 6 -- 1, 6 -- 3 triumph in the final of the third annual Montclair Athletic Club girls' invitation tournament.

CHICAGO, Aug. 2 -- At no time last week were corn prices above the finish of the previous week, weakness in wheat and fears that the program of the government to sell cash wheat at a low price would curtail the demand for corn were factors in the market.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 2 -- Prince and Princess Windisch-Graetz gave a luncheon today at Rosemore, their home in Great Plains Road, for Archduke Otto of Austria and his brother, Archduke Felix, who are spending the week-end with them.

Although the figures made public by the National Safety Council with regard to motor vehicle accidents show a decline of 32 per cent in fatalities for June of this year as compared with June, 1941, and of 15 per cent for the first six months of this year as compared with the same period of last year, the traffic toll picture is still disheartening.
The importance of handicrafts in relieving the war-time tension of children was stressed by Dr. Florence Brumbaugh, principal of the Hunter College Elementary School, in an interview yesterday.

Midsummer may seem a little premature for discussion of Christmas greeting cards, but not if you are in that business. The industry has been putting on a display at the Waldorf-Astoria and showing how it keeps up with the times.

Manufacturing and financial leaders are expressing concern over the inability of companies to build up post-war reserves for the postwar period, according to the August letter of the National City Bank of New York. "When taxes go as high as 90 per cent on earnings above an arbitrarily designated base," declares the bank, "income during the war is hard to figure.

ST. PAUL, Minn., Aug. 2 (AP) -- Dutch Harrison, the Arkansas Traveler, came from nowhere today with a great round of 69 to tie youthful Chick Harbert for first place in the $5,000 St. Paul golf open tournament. The pair will enter an 18-hole play-off tomorrow afternoon for the championship.

This week the people of India, nearly one-fifth of the earth's population, will be going through another tormenting crisis. Last April the Congress party, largely representing the Hindu-majority, rejected the Cripps proposals for post-war independence, mainly on the ground that they did not insure Indian unity.
PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 2 (AP) -- The Pirates swept a double-header with the Phils today, 4 to 2 and 3 to 2, to wrest fifth place from the Cubs.

LONDON, Aug. 2 (AP) -- Official British sources declined today to disclose whether the recent flare-up of night Channel battles, in which the British said at least fifteen German warships had been sunk or damaged, was due to the feeling out of continental coastal defenses or to increased Nazi patrols to guard against commando raids or an invasion.
LONDON, Aug. 2 -- German fighting units turned their guns on one another in an unusual Channel engagement last night, the British Admiralty reported today.
ROCHESTER, N.Y., Aug. 2 (AP) -- Rochester and Jersey City divided a double-header here today, the Red Wings winning the first game, 8 -- 6, and the Little Giants capturing the nightcap, 4 -- 1.

In a world where God is the central reality the incredible is sure to occur, said the Rev. Dr. Harry Emerson Fosdick, pastor, in his sermon yesterday in The Riverside Church at 122d Street and Riverside Drive.
MOSCOW, Monday, Aug. 3 (AP) -- The Soviet Information Bureau issued this communique today:

LONDON, Aug. 2 -- King Haakon of Norway will be 70 years old tomorrow. His birthday already has brought messages of congratulation from heads of States and diplomatic representatives of the United Nations, as well as countless other individuals.
BUENOS AIRES, Argentina, Aug. 2 (UP) -- From his hospital bed, Waldo Frank issued today a statement to the Argentine people, saying:

WELLINGTON, N.Z., Aug. 2 -- A severe earthquake shook the lower half of North Island, the more densely populated of New Zealand's two main islands, at 3:50 A.M. today, driving residents in nightgowns and pajamas from homes as chimneys toppled and window panes broke.

Taking note of recent warnings by President Roosevelt and Harold L. Ickes, Petroleum Coordinator, that failure to convert fuel burning heaters to coal burners may result in heatless homes next Winter, Mayor La Guardia announced yesterday that he had canvassed all the city's financial companies to get credit assistance for home-owners who could not afford the change-over.

LONDON, Aug. 2 -- The Economist's index of British commodity prices, based on 1927 as 100, was 111.6 on July 21. This compares with revised 111.5 a fortnight before, 110.7 a month before, 105.4 a year before and 70.3 at the end of August, 1939.

A total of $16,443,040 has been contributed to date to the USO War Fund by 2,947 of the 4,410 cities and communities which have been conducting Spring and Summer campaigns with an aggregate quota of $20,000,000, it was announced last night by Prescott S. Bush, national campaign chairman.

WITH THE BRITISH EIGHTH ARMY, in Egypt, Aug. 2 -- When German infantrymen, trying to break through the Eighth Army's line around El Alamein, retreated under heavy shell fire, they were halted and driven back into battle by German military police with drawn pistols.

The Metropolitan Opera Association took in $1,956,827 last season and its production costs amounted to $1,974,872, or only $18,045 more than its income. Yet because of real estate taxes and mortgage interest, the association's operating deficit was $214,374.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Aug. 2 -- Operating under a "spare-time" plan for selling war stamps and bonds, Westchester women rung up sales in June to the impressive tune of $600,000. Mrs. Winifred B. Holton Jr., chairman of the Women's Division for Westchester's War Savings Staff, announced today that a report of this sales record had been sent to Washington headquarters over the week-end.

A demand for a better world is growing among the citizenry in England, while there is genuine alarm in the churches over the weakening of basic religious convictions, according to the Rev. Dr. Henry Smith Leiper, American Secretary of the World Council of Churches. Preaching yesterday at the West End Presbyterian Church, Amsterdam Avenue and 105th Street, he said:

Although there was some pickup in reorders for Fall merchandise, general market activity last week dropped off slightly from the week before, according to a summary of the week's activities prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by leading resident buyers.

Women who have ideas on how routine household operations can be cut down so that more time can be made available for war work are invited by the Farm Security Administration to join a new movement called the "Family Front."
BERNE, Switzerland, Aug. 2 -- Chief of Government Pierre Laval's present trip to Paris is believed here today to be concerned chiefly with recruiting skilled workers for German armament plants.

Answering the letters of Mary M. Moore and Edward Atwater in regard to the siren tests on Saturday noon, they would receive proper notification should a real raid come during the test period. Air warden sector headquarters are manned twenty-four hours a day.

SCHENECTADY, Aug. 2 -- Unanimous support of the Treasury's policy of voluntary purchasing of war bonds as against compulsory savings was given today by delegates of Eastern New York unions affiliated with the American Federation of Labor, the Congress of Industrial Organizations and the Railroad Brotherhoods.

A puzzled man meandered yesterday through the grand ballroom of the Hotel Pennsylvania, which was unusually crowded for a Sunday. It was the opening day of the forty-first annual convention of the New York State Food Merchants Association.
Investments in housing properties featured realty activity reported in the Bronx over the weekend.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 -- It is apparent that the creation of a British-American High Command is now being seriously considered by responsible officials in both Washington and London.

PERTH AMBOY, N.J., Aug. 2 -- A dazzling "V" composed of 1,500 flares reminiscent of an old-fashioned political torchlight parade wound up tonight the "United We Stand Victory Rally" that this industrial community of 40,000 staged to demonstrate the solidarity of its employers and its workers in an all-out drive for victory.

Decline in stocks, last week, was again attributable chiefly to reduction in earnings of industrial companies, due to estimated heavy taxes. War news played little part, except in so far as the loss of Rostov by the Russians removed from the market any distinct support.
LONDON, Monday, Aug. 3 -- Viscountess Aston was taken to task editorially today for declaring at Southport, Saturday that Russia was not fighting for Britain but was fighting for herself.

The annual report of the Moore-McCormack Lines, Inc., shows a net income for 1941 of $13,595,439 after $405,000 Federal income taxes and $225,000 for excess profits tax, and all other deductions. The net income for 1940 was $5,342,598 after $187,000 Federal income taxes and $13,000 excess profits tax.

The Pennroad Corporation reported yesterday that it had bought 136,500 shares of its own common stock between Jan. 1 and June 30 for $429,401, an average cost of $3.15 a share. It pointed out that it was the company's policy to continue these purchases, although it had no commitment for this.

Retail advertising supporting the OPA fight against inflation is increasing steadily. The ad of John Wanamaker, New York and Philadelphia, which appeared yesterday and was headed "There is a third front and it must be held -- the front against inflation," evoked highly favorable comment among customers and government officials, according to store executives.

The present rate of production of the Packard Motor Car Company is twice the volume ever attained in its history, George T. Christopher, president, declared yesterday in the semi-annual statement on operations.

BUENOS AIRES, Argentina, Aug. 3 -- The police believe that they have identified one of the six men who attacked Waldo Frank, the American author, in his apartment yesterday. Identification was made through a hat that the assailants left in Mr. Frank's apartment.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 -- An unofficial moratorium on some of the war services of the motor corps of the Red Cross chapter here has been set for Wednesday in an effort to impress the Office of Price Administration with the value of the services and obtain special gas rationing status for motor corps groups.

On a note of discord and keen disappointment the Army Emergency Relief game between the Giants and Dodgers at the Polo Grounds last night ended with Brooklyn triumphant by 7 to 4. The contest fell short of nine full innings because of wartime military regulations.

CHICAGO, Aug. 3 -- Larger estimates of the North American wheat crop and favorable weather conditions in the Northwest started a moderate selling movement on the Board of Trade early in today's session that carried prices to a new seasonal low before short covering and commission house support on resting orders checked started a rally.

CHICAGO, Aug. 3 -- As the American Federation of Labor's executive council prepared for tomorrow's opening of a ten-day business session, a definite -- though unofficial -- belief was indicated in both A.F. of L. and C.I.O. camps here today that President Roosevelt himself had been largely responsible for Philip Murray's latest "peace bid" to William Green.

FORT DES MOINES, Iowa, Aug. 3 -- Two hundred and fifty young women, including a native of Siberia and a couple of sharpshooters who probably won't get to use that skill in the WAACS, arrived today to begin training as officer-candidates in the Women's Army Auxiliary Corps.

Government control, plus the demand for war purposes, has caused a rather tight situation to develop in silver. Despite the increased demand for the metal, it is hardly likely that the current demand in arts and industry in the United States and Canada is running in excess of the 135,000,000 ounces produced annually in the Western Hemisphere.

MOSCOW, Aug. 3 -- Grave and threatening as is the situation in the western Kuban steppe, today's reports hint at a certain stiffening of Russian resistance in fighting of a more stationary nature than during the last few days.

Only a few hours after he had described himself at a press conference as "the all-out-war candidate" behind whom all groups and individuals supporting President Roosevelt's war program could unite, Senator James M. Mead of Buffalo, New Deal candidate for the Democratic nomination for Governor, was accused yesterday by Democratic State Chairman James A. Farley of having made an isolationist speech in 1941 at the time Charles A. Lindbergh was making similar utterances.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 -- Model airplanes will be grounded by an order issued today by the War Production Board freezing all consumer stocks of balsa wood and prohibiting its use except for specific types of life-saving, aircraft and technical apparatus to be delivered to government agencies or for lease-lend purposes.

MOSCOW, Aug. 3 (AP) -- Throughout Moscow, Ivan Ivanovitch -- the Russian counterpart of the United States John Jones -- read an increasing display of "second front" news from Britain and America today, seemingly with greater interest than anything else in his newspapers.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 -- The Navy Department has waived the age of 54 of former magistrate, now Lieut. Comdr. Overton Harris of New York City and sent him to combat service, for which he volunteered. It is understood that his excellent physical condition and a World War record, early in which Lieut. Comdr. Harris won the Navy Cross, influenced the exception that was made in his case.

LONDON, July 21 (By Air Mail) -- A man who crosses the Atlantic by boat has one definite advantage over the man who travels by air. He can accustom himself to the change gradually and more naturally. By the time he reaches home waters he can respond to the rhythm and tempo of these islands.

Josef Lhevinne, pianist, was the soloist last night with the New York Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra at the Lewisohn Stadium and there was an audience of 7,500 to hear him play the Tchaikovsky B flat minor piano concerto. The rest of the program, conducted by Howard Barlow, consisted of Wagnerian excerpts.
John Van Antwerp :iVfaclVfurray, former United States Ambassador i to Turkey, and Mrs. MacMurray have arrived at the Biltmore from Greenfields, Brooklandville, Md.

MUSKEGON, Mich., Aug. 3 (AP) -- A war-plant worker charged with destruction of defense materials told United States Commissioner E.C. Farmer on arraignment here today that he destroyed the parts in a rage over a union limitation on the number of units a workman could produce daily.

VALLETTA, Malta, Aug. 3 (Reuter) -- Following a raidless night, Axis planes made a number of attempts to cross the coast of Malta today, but each time the planes were driven off by British fighters. Civilian damage today was negligible, and there were only a few casualties, according to official announcements.

The German-controlled Rome radio yesterday broadcast, in an Italian-language program directed to the United States, the first Axis comment on the trial of the eight Nazi saboteurs. It was recorded at the Columbia Broadcasting System short wave listening station in New York as follows:
TORONTO, Aug. 3 (AP) -- Toronto emerged from an eight-day slump today to take a twin bill from the league-leading Newark Bears before a crowd of 15,000.

CANBERRA, Australia, Aug. 3 -- The government has yielded to the insistent demand of business men for the abandonment of the proposed limitation of company wartime profits to 4 per cent. Prime Minister John Curtin explained that the decision had been reached owing to the insuperable difficulty of providing a just application of the principle.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 -- Threat of a fuel oil shortage along the Atlantic seaboard this Winter spurred four government agencies into action today as they sought ways of averting distress to householders and workers.

CAIRO, Egypt, Aug. 3 -- The German Government has offered to a Turkish military mission in Berlin an immediate shipment of German fighter and bomber planes. This correspondent, who arrived in Cairo yesterday from Ankara after a stay of several weeks in Turkey, learned that the German offer was made last Friday.

FORT DIX, N.J, Aug. 3 -- Fourteen convalescent Filipino soldiers, who were wounded while serving under General Douglas MacArthur at Bataan, Corregidor and Subic Bay, in the Philippine Islands, were naturalized at special ceremonies today at the Tilton General Hospital here.
The part housewives can play in the transformation of waste fats into glycerine and important oils for war industries was demonstrated yesterday by a typical New York housewife and a butcher.

BAY SHORE, L. I., Aug. 3 -- Out on Great South Bay, which borders the lower side of Long Island, as does its Sound on the north, another race week started today. It was the twenty-seventh annual event of the several yacht clubs stretching from Cedarhurst out to Shinnecock.

MOSCOW, Tuesday, Aug. 4 -- Soviet troops fighting in the Don River elbow eighty miles from Stalingrad and in the Salsk-Kushchevka area of the Western Caucasus were reported officially early today to have killed more than 9,500 Germans in a successful twenty-four-hour stand.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 -- Secretary Morgenthau's proposal to tax income from future issues of State and municipal securities was assailed today by Mayor La Guardia of New York, who warned the Senate Finance Committee that unless Congress demonstrated an understanding of the wartime problems of local governments "the whole system may blow up."

The ferryboat Brooklyn, a veteran of the Staten Island run, has sacrificed business-as-usual to devote her time to the war. She is tied up at Pier 32 on the East River, in the shadows of Manhattan Bridge, and 162 Coast Guardsmen are aboard her, learning to be better Coast Guardsmen.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 3 (AP) -- Dunbar W. Bostwick's Miss Thelma defeated a field of Hambletonian prospects twice tonight in the top event of the opening Grand Circuit program at the Saratoga raceway.

STANDISH, Mich., Aug. 3 (AP) -- A woman who said she swam miles to shore from a yacht that foundered in Saginaw Bay yesterday brought the first inkling today of the fate of a fishing party of thirteen.
STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Aug. 3 -- Rumors current here early this year of the imminence of a Russo-German separate peace have been revived.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 -- President Roosevelt today sent to the Senate the nomination of Randolph Evernghim Paul, New York lawyer and Treasury tax expert, to succeed Edward H. Foley as General counsel of the Treasury. Mr. Foley has resigned to become a lieutenant colonel in the Army.

BERNE, Switzerland, Aug. 3 -- Resistance to the Italian occupant continues unabated in Montenegro, according to advices reaching here. The nature of the country is such that motorized columns operate only with difficulty. On roads that can be traveled by automobiles the insurgents throw sharp pieces of rock and pieces of metal, which pierce tires.

Because the revenue bill now before Congress may contain retroactive provisions that will affect the final net income of General Mills, Inc., for the fiscal year ended on May 31, the company has issued its fourteenth annual report in preliminary form, with net income given as $5,135,111, equivalent to $6.05 a share on 655,054 common shares.

The American Women's Voluntary Services will benefit from the national amateur tennis championship matches which will be held from Aug. 27 to Sept. 7 at the Forest Hills Stadium, Queens. A major part of the proceeds will go to A. W. V. S. units in the New York area.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 3 -- Tony Martin, the singer, wearing the uniform of a chief boatswain's mate in the Navy, testified today that he and Lieut. Comdr. Maurice N. Aroff cooked up a false story about a $950 automobile which Aroff is accused of asking for and taking from Martin as "a fee" for "facilitating" a special job for him in the Navy.

LONDON, Aug. 3 -- Haakon VII, King of Norway, tall and lean and with the healthy complexion of a seafaring man, celebrated his seventieth birthday here in London today far from his kingdom by accepting the stirring tribute of thousands of Norwegians who for a brief spell this afternoon transformed Kensington Gardens into a bit of their native soil.

HENGYANG, China, Aug. 3 (U.P.) -- United States Army fliers lashed out against the Japanese today, dropping three and a half tons of bombs on Fuchow, an enemy stronghold in Kiangsi Province already besieged by Chinese ground forces.

COOPERSTOWN, N.Y., Aug. 3 (AP) -- The Cardinals gazed quietly today at Connie Mack's plaque in the Baseball Hall of Fame, then went out on historic Doubleday Field, where their bats were almost as respectfully silent as the Old Man waved his scorecard.

AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, Australia, Tuesday, Aug. 4 (AP) -- Allied bombers set fire to a Japanese cargo ship in a raid yesterday on Salamaua and Lae, New Guinea, General Douglas MacArthur's headquarters announced today.

That bribery "could and did take place" in the Women's Court was "the opinion" rather than "a charge" of the Women's Court Committee of the Social Service Bureau, Mrs. Alice Withrow Field, chairman of the committee, declared yesterday.

CHICAGO, Aug. 3 -- The Chicago wholesale market week got under way today with buyer attendance equal and in some trades more numerous than last year at the large wholesale dry goods houses and giftware shows and about 10 per cent below in the apparel lines.

The stock market assumed yesterday a slightly better tone on a resumption of speculative interest in the railroad section, and the general list closed irregularly higher. While cautionary notes cropped out in some sections, the market showed indications of closely following the pattern set at the corresponding time last year.

INDIANAPOLIS, Aug. 3 -- William Dudley Pelley, leader of the defunct Silver Shirts, testified today in Federal court, where he is on trial for sedition, that his writings have been misinterpreted by the government and that he never intended to harm its chances of winning the war.

BABSON PARK. Mass., Aug. 3 -- War production is being hampered considerably by the lack of working capital resulting from delays of as much as six months in payments for government work. Henry H. Heimann, executive manager of the National Association of Credit Men, declared here tonight.

The loss of four more ships was announced by the Navy yesterday, while word from Nassau, the Bahamas and Buenos Aires indicated that two others in all likelihood had been additional victims of the Nazi submarine drive.

BALTIMORE, Aug. 3 (AP) -- Gilbert A. Dailey, collector of customs, said today $50,000 of undeclared jewelry had been seized from the bag of a passenger aboard a refugee ship which docked here last week. Mr. Dailey said the diamonds, emeralds, set rings and brooches were found by customs inspectors at Fort Howard when a passenger aboard the Portguese ship Nyassa, was being given a final check-up.
LONDON, Aug. 3 (AP) -- A joint communiqu of the Ministries of Air and Home Security said today:
MOSCOW, Tuesday, Aug. 4 (AP) -- Last midnight's Soviet communiqu follows:

The urgent need for 3,000 nurses a month -- 2,500 for the Army and 500 for the Navy -- and methods of recruiting them were discussed yesterday at a conference of nurses representing Red Cross units of the North and Middle Atlantic States, at American National Red Cross headquarters, 300 Fourth Avenue.

VICHY, France, July 18 -- One of the industries of France that has managed best since the Armistice is that of the Paris dressmakers, who are described as the haute couture. The principal fashion houses have in fact never known such prosperity.

That business in the Broadway theatres is on the upward trend was confirmed yesterday after comparing most of last week's receipts with those of the week immediately preceding. In all instances the intake was not lower than the previous week. Leading the field were Uncle Sam's revue, "This Is the Army," $47,647; "Stars on Ice," $33,634; "By Jupiter," $25,055; "Sons o' Fun," $24,208, and "The Merry Widow," $19,000.

LONDON, Aug. 3 (U.P.) -- Italian warships, supporting the war against Yugoslav patriots, have bombarded villages along the Montenegrin coast, and Axis air and ground forces have burned or blown up hundreds of villages in the interior in a futile attempt to stamp out rebellion, a Yugoslav spokesman asserted today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 -- Lieut. Comdr. Mildred H. McAfee was formally inducted into office today as director of the new women's reserve in the Navy in a ceremony during which the regular Navy oath was administered by Secretary Knox She is the president of Wellesley College and the first woman officer in American Naval history.

ALBANY, Aug. 3 -- The chairmen of fifteen Republican county organizations, meeting here today with State Chairman Edwin F. Jaeckle, developed plans for a house-to-house canvass to obtain names and addresses of men and women serving in the armed forces.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Aug. 3 -- The Westchester Board of Supervisors voted today an appropriation of $200,000 from which local communities may borrow between now and the end of the year for the wartime protection of life and property.
HARTFORD, Aug. 3 -- Testimony concerning a Pacific Coast invasion plot was given here today in the espionage conspiracy trial of the Rev. Kurt E.B. Molzahn, a Philadelphia pastor.

It may not be long before the general price ceiling is pierced by so many holes that it will become a sieve "drowning us out," A.F. Guckenberger, secretary of the New York State Food Merchants Association, declared yesterday at the group's forty-first annual convention at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

REYKJAVIK, Iceland, Aug. 3 (AP) -- A German plane bombed and machine-gunned a remote military installation in Southern Iceland yesterday, United States military authorities announced today, adding that there were no casualties and only negligible damage.

MAMARONECK, N.Y., Aug. 3 -- The pro-amateur division of the Westchester P.G.A. one-day golf tournament finished in a four-day deadlock at the Winged Foot Club today when Tony Tiso, Vernon Hills pro, came from among the last of the field of forty-five teams.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 -- The new head of the WAVES is known as "Miss Mac" to most of her students at Wellesley, where a board of three will carry on in her place while she is on leave of absence for the duration.

Under the terms of the Ryan-Hollowell act, a State law that requires liquor distillers and wholesalers to notify the State Liquor Authority one month before price changes are put into effect, retail liquor dealers in New York will not be permitted to increase prices today under the recent announcement of the Office of Price Administration that would permit price advances above the ceiling levels.
MOSCOW, Aug. 3 (AP) -- The Soviet Information Bureau issued the following communiqu today:

Several large stores here and elsewhere are considering changing the end of their fiscal year from Jan. 31 to July 31. The change is being made for accounting and tax purposes, but specific comment was withheld yesterday.

The Irving Berlin musical, "Holiday Inn," co-starring Bing Crosby and Fred Astaire, will have its world premiere tonight at 8:30 at the Paramount. The initial showing, which is a reserved-seat benefit for the Navy Relief Society, will realize more than $15,000, according to the management. Yesterday all but 200 of the theatre's 3,600 seats already had been sold, the management reported.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Aug. 3 -- Ingrid Bergman, who was Ernest Hemingway's own first nomination for the role of Maria in his story "For Whom the Bell Tolls," was today signed by Paramount for the role, replacing Vera Zorina, the studio announced.

NEW ORLEANS, Aug. 3 (AP) -- Testimony was given today that the maritime commission signed commitments for millions of dollars on the Higgins Corporation shipbuilding plant between July 10, when the decision wan made to close the plant, and July 18, when the commission announced withdrawal of its contract for 200 Liberty ships.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 -- Twenty-one naval aviators have been decorated and cited for their exploits in raids on the Marshall Islands early in February. All of the men were officers and received their awards from Secretary Knox in the name of the President.
The following German High Command communiqu was broadcast from Berlin yesterday and recorded here by The Associated Press:

The letter from the merchant seaman in the July 30 issue of THE NEW YORK TIMES, in which he reported that he had had an entertaining time at the USO Club in Philadelphia but had not had as happy an experience in New York, has caused us genuine concern.
CHICAGO, Aug. 3 -- The Department of Justice began a showdown battle with James C. Petrillo, president of the American Federation of Musicians, in Federal court today.

WADESBORO, N. C., Aug. 3 (AP) -- Camouflage, notably as concealment from aerial observation, is a vitally important factor in modern battle and is, therefore, being stressed to the fullest extent in the current Carolinas manoeuvres, the first staged by the Army since the United States entered the war.

NEWARK, N.J., Aug. 3 -- Thousands of landlords flocked today to register rented residential quarters at 102 schools in nine North New Jersey counties in compliance with rent-ceiling regulations. H. Russell Phillips, Federal area rent director, expressed himself as "highly gratified" with the "smoothness of the first day's operations."

LONDON, Aug. 3 -- Neutral accounts of painstaking German defense manoeuvres along the "invasion coast" of Norway emphasized today that Adolf Hitler's generals were taking more and more seriously the threatened second front.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 -- Ordering a stop put to the practice by some sellers of adding local transportation charges to maximum prices of finished textile piece goods, Leon Henderson, Federal Price Administrator, today issued a ruling on the meaning of the phrase "f.o.b. point of shipment" as used in the maximum price regulation covering finished piece goods.

Lieutenant Dave Allerdice, former Princeton forward passing ace, and Private George Cafego, star running back of the unbeaten 1938 and 1939 Tennessee teams, head the sixteen players added yesterday to the Eastern Army All-Star football squad now assembling at Yale University in New Haven.

A committee for Delaware Hudson Company 4 per cent bonds headed by Charles T. Adams of Chicago urged yesterday that bondholders appear next week at hearings before the Senate Committee on Interstate and Foreign Commerce on the McLaughlin bill to provide for adjustment of railroad capital structures without recourse to bankruptcy.

CHICAGO, Aug. 3 -- A lively and unpredictable convention of the United Automobile Workers, C.I.O., was indicated today as 1,700 highly articulate delegates, gathered in the first session, wildly cheered their president's virtual demand for a "second front now" and then gave equally vociferous cheers for a British Army officer who proposed that "armchair strategists" be loaded "into the first landing boat" of an invasion.
In describing the visit of Queen Wilhelmina to the capital of New York THE TIMES of July 28 stated that Governor Lehman "spoke of the voyage of Hendrik Hudson." The Queen must have been amused.

A "portable" edition of the American Guide Series book on Washington, replacing the four-and-a-half-pound edition put out by the Government Printing Office in 1937, has been released by Hastings House. This WPA Writers Program volume drew high praise when first released but the praise was likely to be coupled with remarks such as "not even Samson would carry it from depot to hotel."

ST. PAUL, Aug. 3 -- While his pretty blond wife rode behind him in an Army jeep and tossed him smiles after every shot, young Chick Harbert easily won the St. Paul open golf championship today or love, money and fame.

WITH UNITED STATES BOMBER FORCES, in the Middle East, Aug. 3 (AP) -- Shaded from the sun by the wing of a Flying Fortress, George Macdonald of Seattle spoke his mind today about North Africa and the desert.

The Westinghouse Electric and Manufacturing Company announced yesterday that it intended to abandon the company's wage and salary payment plan under which all employes shared in earnings over and above their regular pay. Steadily mounting taxes and the renegotiation of contracts with the government were given as reasons for discontinuance of the "bonus" plan.

One of the gayer plaid furnishing schemes of the season revolves around an upholstery fabric woven originally to supply a manufacturer of sports roadsters, but which, since car sales have been frozen, now provides an ingenious idea for the college dormitory room.

LONDON, Aug. 3 -- British planes attacked railway trains and Nazi troop stations in the Netherlands and barge traffic along the Netherland coast and German raiders struck at Bank Holiday crowds in several parts of England during exchanges of fighter and fighter-bomber action today.

LONDON, Aug. 3 -- Some 7,000 Britons saw Canadian soldiers beat American soldiers in a seven-inning baseball game in the Wembley Stadium today, but they didn't seem to have the foggiest idea of what was going on.

Nothing could be simpler, it would seem, than to write the proper kind of letter to a soldier far from home. Yet the military authorities have found it desirable to issue some advice on this subject. The wrong kind of letter can cause the distant service man to absent himself without leave; can, in fact, cause all sorts of trouble.

Enlargement and reconstitution of the Shipbuilding Stabilization Committee, which originally was formed eighteen months ago to lay the groundwork for the shipbuilding wage stabilization agreement, was made known yesterday by Paul R. Porter, chairman of the committee and representative of the War Production Board, who presided at a meeting of the committee at the Hotel New Yorker.

The city of Boston, Mass., announced yesterday that it will open bids tomorrow on a new issue of $3,000,000 of notes. The new issue will be dated Aug. 7 and will be payable on Nov. 6, 1942. Interest basis is to be named by the bidders.
PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 3 (AP) -- Bonuses in stock and cash totaling $1,273,560 were awarded during 1941 to 10 executives and 14 emloyes by E.I. du Pont de Nemours Co.

An interim report made public yesterday by United China Relief headquarters here revealed that four Christian colleges had been re-established in the interior of China; that relief had been provided for 361,445 refugees from Hong Kong, the East Indies and Burma, and that aid had been sent to 21,000 orphaned children.

BERNE, Switzerland, Aug. 3 -- Spanish refugees in France are much concerned about the future, according to private advices received here, now that General Francisco J. Aguilar, the Mexican Minister, has been definitely called home.

Tire and gasoline rationing, particularly the latter, continued last month to whittle down vehicular traffic in this area, according to figures gathered yesterday on the number of motorists using bridges and tunnels to New York City last month.

When the ill tidings of April 9, 1940, reached us Norwegians who were outside Norway our first question was this: Where is the King? When we received the answer and heard of the stand he had taken we said: We knew it. And at the same moment we knew we had the right leadership for our fight for freedom.

The American Jewish Joint Distribution Committee, chief American agency for aiding distressed Jews overseas, spent $9,285,000 during 1941 and the first five months of this year for the aid of 950,000 Jews in fifty-two countries on five continents, according to a report issued yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 -- The conditions statement of weekly reporting member banks of the Federal Reserve System in 101 leading cities shows the following principal changes for the week ended July 29: Increases of $170,000,000 in holdings of Treasury bills, $357,000,000 in demand deposits-adjusted, and a decrease of $271,000,000 in United States Government deposits.
AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, Australia, Aug. 3 (AP) -- General MacArthur's headquarters today issued this communiqu:
WELLINGTON, New Zealand, Aug. 3 -- It was estimated today that the damage caused here by yesterday's earthquake would run into millions of dollars.

MEXICO CITY, Aug. 3 -- Mexico contributed further to continental defense today with the official announcement that the Mexican Aviation Company had received a permit to extend its service in the country by a passenger, mail and express line from Mexico City to Ixtepec, Oaxaca State, and Tapachula.

Coming out fairly strong on the buying side early in the afternoon when the market had sagged to its new low levels and losses of 13 to 16 points, New Orleans operators and the trade, augmented by the prevailing paucity of contracts, pushed cotton prices again toward the session's high marks.

Justin R. Whiting, president of the Commonwealth Southern Corporation, called yesterday upon the stockholders of the $1,000,000,000 utility system "to make themselves heard" on the question of Federal taxation.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 -- President Roosevelt congratulated King Haakon VII of Norway on his seventieth birthday anniversary today, declaring that "the inflexible determination shown by the Norwegian people in their flight to roll back the black shadows of nazism owes no little of its strength to the example set by Your Majesty's own superb courage."
CULVER, Ind., Aug. 3 -- Favorites overcame their opposition with little difficulty in today's qualifying play of the national junior and boys tennis tournament at Culver Military Academy.

The Association of Life Insurance Presidents sent a telegram yesterday to Senator Walter F. George, chairman of the Senate Finance Committee, urging in behalf of life insurance policy holders that the committee restore the $40,000 specific exemption of life insurance policy proceeds in the estate tax provisions of the revenue bill of 1942.

One of our Washington reporters, James B. Reston, presented in our news columns yesterday a rather dismal picture of the lack of unity that still exists between American and British officials in the conduct of the war. There is no agreement on the allocation of many scarce raw materials.

CHUNGKING, China, Aug. 3 (AP) -- Some of Japan's best airmen made another unsuccessful attempt over Hengyang today to wrest mastery of the skies from Americans, it was reported by Lieut. Gen. Joseph W. Stilwell's headquarters.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 -- Simon Lake, veteran inventor and builder of submarines, today shifted Congressional focus from big cargo planes to bigger submersibles as a means of outwitting the U-boats for the transport of men, munitions and supplies to the battle fronts.

Reflecting in part comparison with extremely large sales gains a year ago, the volume of New York and Brooklyn department stores showed a decline of 11 per cent last week, according to the "flash" report issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.

The attack on subversive remnants of the German-American Bund that United States Attorney Mathias F. Correa began a month ago by causing the arrest of all twenty-nine of the bund's national leaders was renewed yesterday with the filing of petitions for the denaturalization of nine more bundists.

KEARNY, N.J., Aug. 3 -- A trailer-truck containing 2,000 gallons of cleaning fluid plunged off a main highway here this afternoon, killing the driver and causing a fire that destroyed a large quantity of cork used in war manufacture at the plant of Congoleum-Nairn, Inc.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 (U.P.) -- Patrick A. Gibson, special assistant to the Attorney General, today recommended government scrutiny of international cartel agreements and licensing of all patents to permit Federal enforcement of "reasonable royalty rates."

CHICAGO, Aug. 3 (AP) -- A moderate hog supply encountered strong demand today and prices surged up 15 to 25 cents on all weights and sows. The top quotation reached $15, only 15 cents under the twenty-two-year high established July 21. Shippers and small packers were active competitors for 180 to 240 pound offerings at $14.75 to $14.90.

LONDON, Aug. 3 (U.P.) -- Reconnaissance photographs of the results of last Wednesday night's R.A.F. raid on Saarbruecken showed that the Erhardt Schmer engineering works there had been destroyed, and serious damage done to sheds and adjoining smaller buildings at the Eich Dudelinger Burbacher iron works, the Air Ministry said today.

The five-story storage warehouse at 202-04 Murray Street, with the two-story building at 38-44 Goble Street, and a large tract of additional land, at Newark, N.J., has been sold to the Federal Storage Warehouse by the C. B. Ice Company.

In the matter of lighting this city is coming more and more to recall the Golden 'Nineties, and possibly even earlier decades. Clarence Day's renowned parent might think Police Commissioner Valentine's order that horseless carriages run on their parking lights a good thing, indeed, war or no war.
CAIRO, Egypt, Aug. 3 -- British bomber planes were over Tobruk, Bardia, Solum, Sidi Barrani and Matruh Saturday night, pressing their attack on the Axis supply organization, it was disclosed today.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 3 -- Prince and Princess Dimitri Djordjadze entertained at a small luncheon before the races today for Mrs. Harrison Williams. The hosts will be joined tomorrow by Mrs. Benjamin Moore, sister of the princess.
From a scientific viewpoint, such as is given by Lyle Thorpe in his survey of Connecticut Lakes, the stories of "big fish" are nothing more than the maximum size a certain species reaches.

Before a record crowd for a single game at the Polo Grounds, the Dodgers defeated the Giants, 7 to 4, in a twilight contest for the Army Emergency Relief fund last night. The attendance was 57,305, with estimated receipts of $80,000.

The Republican party throughout the country was urged yesterday by Wendell L. Willkie, its 1940 Presidential candidate, to take the nation's war aims out of politics in the Congressional and State campaigns this Fall by pledging complete support to a three-point program of "basic principles" 'dedicated to complete and final victory over totalitarian aggression and the establishment of a more stable world when the peace is won.

An Army private on a team assembled hastily at the last minute led a field of thirty-six mixed teams of four as the sixteenth annual national contract bridge championship tournament got under way at the Park Central Hotel here yesterday.

The New York State Committee of the Communist party announced last night that its State convention. would be held in Manhattan Center, Thirty-fourth Street and Eighth Avenue, on Aug. 28 and 29, with more than 500 delegates expected to attend.

Haakon VII, King of Norway, was 70 yesterday. He has been King for thirty-six years. A Danish Prince when Norway decided to become an independent kingdom, he was selected and elected by the people of Norway and their Parliament. He has described his post accurately as that of "a very constitutional President for life."

Combined net earnings of the Commercial Investment Trust Corporation, which include those of the National Surety Corporation, amounted to $6,887,842 for the first six months of 1942, according to the financial report to stockholders released today.
CARACAS, Venezuela, Aug. 3 -- An editorial in the Ahora deplores the attack on Waldo Frank in Buenos Aires.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 3 -- A large subscription has been reported for the "hour of music," a lecture-recital on the compositions of Johannes Brahms, to be given Sunday afternoon at the Southampton Beach Club by Dr. H. Emile Enthoven, pianist, conductor and composer, for the benefit of the new service men's club at the Malcolm R. White Post of the American Legion.

Time was when men were honored in France for courage, for service to their country, or for distinguished work in science, literature or the arts. As could be expected, the currency of honor under "Chief of Government" Pierre Laval, who comes and goes at Hitler's whistle, is debased.

With its publication in The City Record today, the new police regulation requiring all drivers to use parking lights only when operating their cars during dimout hours will go into effect technically half an hour after sunset this evening.

BERNE, Switzerland. Aug. 3 -- Foreign observers are much struck by the fact that at the very time when German reports insist on the progress made in Russia and on the futility of any effort to create a second front on French soil, more than one person "moving in international circles" seems anxious to impart "authentic information" regarding the possibility of a "negotiated'' peace.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 3 -- Mrs. Andrew Schuttinger, wife of the well-known trainer and former jockey, captured two races today, but she doubtless would have swapped both for a victory in the featured Molly Brant Handicap, in which her color-bearer ran fourth.

A hundred government employes in nineteen States are represented in the first Civil Service Hobby Show, which opened yesterday at the Sachs auditorium, 505 Eighth Avenue. The show will continue for two weeks.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 -- The Commonwealth of Pennsylvania came into conflict with the Federal Government today when E.A. DeLaney, Deputy Attorney General of the State, asked the National Labor Relations Board to re-open a case involving the unionization of mine supervisory employes because two groups of the employes involved are certified State mining officials in their capacity as safety officials.
CHUNGKING, China, Aug. 3 (AP) -- Lieut. Gen. Joseph W. Stilwell's headquarters issued this communiqu today:

WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 -- Three newspapers, The New York Daily News, The New York Daily Worker and The Washington Times Herald, were accused in the House today of abuses of the rights of freedom of the press for which it was asserted punishment should be imposed.

It is good to learn that beginning this Fall every Freshman entering the University of Oklahoma will be required to take a comprehensive course in American history. In this experimental program the staffs of the history and government departments are to cooperate in giving the students a well-rounded picture of the democratic principles and historic background of the United States.

With 2,500 bond men and stock brokers in the New York Federal Reserve District acting as a voluntee sales force under the direction of the Victory Fund Committee of this district, a campaign was opened here yesterday as part of the nation-wide effort to sell an unlimited amount of the latest Treasury "tap issue.

OCEANSIDE, L.I., Aug. 3 -- Tony Longo and his amateur partner, Charles J. Levy, both of Inwod, shot a remarkable first nine, 29, six under par, which coupled with their second nine of par 36 for 65, gave them top honors in the weekly one-day amateur-pro bestball tournament of the Long Island Professional Golfers Association at the Oceanside Golf Club today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 -- The War Labor Board, by a unanimous decision today, increased the wages of 21,000 New York City building service employes represented by the Building Service Employes' International Union, A.F. of L. The board acted in a dispute of the union with the Realty Advisory Board on Labor Relations over terms of a master agreement covering 2,225 apartment, office and loft buildings in Manhattan.

The Treasury Department has consented to a postponement in the delivery of silver from smelting companies produced from domestic ores to ease the tight situation now prevailing in the supply situation of that metal. according to Handy Harman. local bullion dealers, in a letter to their customers.

MELBOURNE, Australia, Aug. 3 -- Nearly a hundred Red Cross men and women are serving with the United States Expeditionary Forces in the Southwest Pacific, covering territory as broad as the United States and as long as the distance between New York and the coast of France, it was revealed today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 -- Permission to raise prices above March level on 158 commodities. varying from anchovies to soap chips, was granted to the United Grocery Company, low-margin wholesale grocery establishment of Irvington, N.J., by the Office of Price Administration today.
ROCHESTER, N.Y., Aug. 3 (AP) -- Jersey City belted fifteen hits to rout the Red Wings tonight, 11 -- 4.
BUENOS AIRES, Aug. 3 (U.P.) -- The press gave unprecedented prominence today to discussion of the attack made on Waldo Frank after he had been declared persona non grata by the Argentine Government.
It looks like coffee, it smells like coffee, it even tastes like coffee -- but it isn't coffee! The newest beverage in New York is made of roasted barley malt, and it doesn't keep you awake.

BRONXVILLE, N.Y., Aug. 3 -- This exclusive residential community was transformed for a few hours tonight into a realistic battleground when 200 officers and men of the New York Guard roared through its quiet streets to capture 100 "saboteurs" who had theoretically destroyed the local railroad station and barricaded themselves behind the high school.

MOSCOW, Aug. 3 -- Beside the dusty roads of the Kuban steppes a traveler today would see strange, irregular black heaps. Their jet blackness strikes the eye with a shock in this landscape of yellow corn, whitewashed cottages and golden sunflowers.

LONDON, Aug. 3 (UP) -- Reports that an American would become supreme commander of Allied forces in the European theatre have aroused considerable resentment in Britain and tonight a dark horse seemed to be coming to the fore -- Canadian Lieut. Gen. Andrew G.L. McNaughton.

A German tank army driving southward into the Caucasus is approaching the upper course of the Kuban River, 125 miles south of Rostov and some fifty miles above the oil center of Maikop, the High Command said today, according to Berlin broadcasts recorded by The United Press in New York.

Consolidated net profit of Crucible Steel Company of America for the second quarter of 1942 was $1,457,162, equal after preferred dividends to $2.35 a share of common stock, comparing with revised net profit of $1,148,123 or $1.66 per share in the first quarter.

One of the strangest episodes of the war is Government hoarding of silver. That metal has come suddenly into great demand. It is needed as a substitute for copper, zinc and nickel. It is also needed for a wide variety of new war purposes. The use of silver bearings in airplanes, for example, makes possible increased speed and greater ability to withstand shock and vibration.

The twenty-seventh and last man of a gang of blackmailers, some of whom posed as detectives and were alleged to have extorted more than $1,000,000 from men victims under threats to arrest them on sex charges, pleaded guilty yesterday in General Sessions, as Assistant District Attorney Herman T. Stichman was about to begin presenting evidence against him.
The twenty-eight-family apartment house at 2566 Radcliff Avenue, the Bronx, has been sold by Fannie Weinstein to Joseph Savino through Guzzo Scully, brokers.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 -- On the ground that it would interfere with efforts to stabilize prices and would be profiteering on the part of the railroads, Leon Henderson, head of the Office of Price Administration, asked indefinite postponement or dismissal today by the Interstate Commerce Commission of a plea by the railroads serving New York for a 10 per cent increase in intrastate commutation fares.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 -- The verdict of the military commission which tried the eight Nazi saboteurs was delivered to the White House today for review by President Roosevelt.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 -- President Roosevelt signed today a bill increasing the salaries of about 86,000 government custodial workers, including charwomen, uniformed guards and mechanics. It adds about $15,768,000 to the annual cost of the government.

The most sensational revenge slaying for a gamblers' double-cross since Arnold Rothstein was shot fourteen years ago came to light yesterday when Max Fox, 48-year-old grandfather and once the city's biggest betting commissioner, surrendered to the police for the murder early yesterday morning of two men in the White House Bridge Association, 846 Seventh Avenue.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 4 -- Mrs. George Barton French gave a tea with music this afternoon at the Southampton Beach Club for Mrs. Ambrose D. Henry of New York, who has joined her for the Summer. Pink and yellow gladioluses were used in the decorations.

BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Aug. 4 (U.P.) -- One British soldier was killed and several American soliders were injured in a knife fight in a Randalstown dance hall, it was revealed today at an inquest in the County Antrim Coroner's Court.

LONDON, Aug. 4 (U.P.) -- In remarking that Russia was fighting for Russia, not for Britain, Lady Astor was only seeking to promote British-American good feeling, she said today in a letter to The Daily Herald. In a speech on Saturday Lady Astor said that Russia had not become Britain's ally until she had been invaded, whereas the United States had aided Britain before it was actually endangered by the Nazis.

Covering of short positions and price-fixing operations caused a decided upturn in the cotton market yesterday and led active contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange to final net gains of 16 to 18 points. The continued scarcity of offerings and an improved technical position resulting from the recent sharp decline aided the rise.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 -- Cargo-carrying submarines have taken a place alongside the proposed freighter planes in the official studies for combating the U-boat menace, it was disclosed today after an executive session between a Senate subcommittee, the Under-Secretaries of War and the Navy and War Production Board experts.

LONDON, Aug. 4 -- Prince George of Kent, third child of the Duke and Duchess of Kent, was christened by the Archbishop of Canterbury in the country today. President Roosevelt was one of the Prince's eight godparents. The Prince's full name is Michael George Charles Franklin, the latter after the President.

At St. Anthony, Newfoundland, yesterday a tablet was unveiled, with suitable ceremonies, in honor of the fiftieth anniversary of the landing of Dr. Wilfred Grenfell on the coast of Labrador. Dr. Grenfell's heart was moved by the plight of just one family in a poor hut, a dying fisherman, a destitute wife and children.

GLADSTONE, N.J., Aug. 4 -- A wartime emergency hospital built in an old carriage house at Hamilton Farms here, the estate of Mrs. Charles Suydam Cutting, who completely equipped it with modern facilities, was formally opened today with an inspection by officials of the New Jersey Defense Council.

CHICAGO, Aug. 4 -- A slight improvement in the reported demand for flour brought in sufficient buying of wheat futures by mills and shorts today to advance prices on the Board of Trade 3/4 to 1 1/8 cents a bushel. Closing sales were at the top.

Among those reported yesterday as having signed contracts for commercial quarters were Dorothy E. Halperin, who leased an office for an employment agency in the Newsweek Building, southeast corner of Broadway and Forty-second Street; and James A. Cresamoles, who leased space in the same building for the sale of drawings and war posters.

PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., Aug. 4 -- Mrs. Charles Leichner of Fresh Meadow, former metropolitan and Long Island champion, took low gross honors with a score of 40, 39 -- 79 in the weekly one-day tournament of the Women's Metropolitan Golf Assocaition over the North Hempstead C.C. course today.

Mildred Helen McAfee, president of Wellesley College, has been a member at large of the Educational Council, which, with the Bureau of Naval Personnel, has drawn up the plans for the Woman's Reserve in the Navy. Her appointment as lieutenant commander of the Reserve was predicted nearly a month ago.

The Nazis' invasion of Belgium and the Netherlands and their acquisition of tremendous collections of fine diamonds were recalled in Federal court yesterday as Werner von Clemm, an importer, went on trial for an alleged conspiracy to sell diamonds in this country for the Germans.

The leasing of apartments to a number of doctors featured renting activity yesterday. Rentals to seven members of the medical profession were reported by the J.H. Taylor Management Corporation as follows: Drs. Earl Brown, Peter Schwartz, and E.N. Munnell, in 235 E 22nd St; Drs. Katherine F. Woodward, and Herman O. Mosenthal, in 210 E 68th St; Dr. Anthony Wollner, in 205 E 69th St; Dr. Henry Friedman, in 240 Central Park South.
CINCINNATI, Aug. 4 (AP) -- The Reds stood off a seventh-inning rally by the Cardinals today to save a 4-3 victory for Johnny Vander Meer.

Under the heading "You're a liar, Congressman Holland," The Daily News prints today an editorial page statement signed by its publisher, Joseph M. Patterson, in connection with a declaration made in Congress Monday by the Pennsylvania Representative concerning the publishers of The News and of The Washington Times-Herald.

NEW ORLEANS, Aug. 4 -Frank O. Higgins, general manager of the Higgins Corporation, today charged, when testifying at a House subcommittee hearing here, that although his company's shipbuilding plant was closed because of a shortage of steel there existed "all over the country a black market in steel."

WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 -- If college trained women really want to be patriotic and put their intelligence to work along essential productive lives they should forget their diplomas, roll up their sleeves and learn how to be industrial workers.

The I. Miller Sons Company, incorporated in Delaware, reported yesterday for the fiscal year ended on April 30 a consolidated net income of $275,118 after charges, taxes, minority stockholders' interest and a depreciation charge of $102,483, compared with $127,880 in the previous fiscal year.

For the first time this year advertising linage in eight New York newspapers in July registered an increase over the corresponding month of last year, according to a compilation yesterday based on Media Records figures. The total gain, however, was only 0.94 per cent, with four of the papers accounting for the increase.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 -- President Roosevelt presented the Congressional Medal of Honor today to Lieut. Comdr. John D. Bulkeley of New York, who won acclaim for his daring torpedo-boat raids on Japanese warships and for other war missions in the Far East, including the transfer of General Douglas MacArthur and President Manuel Quezon from the Philippines.

Registrations of out-of-town buyers in the market for the week ended yesterday totaled 580, which compared with 714 in the preceding week and 761 in the similar period a year ago, according to the listings in THE NEW YORK TIMES. Yesterday's arrivals totaled 306, against 298 for last Tuesday.
There was despair down at Army Recruiting Headquarters yesterday.

HAVANA, Aug. 4 -- It was announced tonight that the members of President Fulgencio Batista's entire Cabinet had presented their resignations as a means of facilitating the formation of a national unity government.

Four of the country's highest ranking contract bridge stars won the national championship for mixed teams of four here yesterday in the second day of the national tournament under way at the Park Central Hotel.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 4 -- Mr. and Mrs. John A. Morris gave a dinner tonight for Mrs. Jackson A. Moffett of San Francisco, their house guest. Others in the party were Mrs. Duncan A. Holmes, Mrs. Alexander Stoller, George H. Bull, W. Goadby Loew and Carter Bowie of New York.

CHICAGO, Aug. 4 -- The American Federation of Labor will start tomorrow a nation-wide campaign to mobilize its 6,000,000 members and their families, an estimated 24,000,000 persons, behind a united drive "to stabilize the cost of living and make price control effective," President William Green said today.

TAHAWUS, N.Y., Aug. 4 -Construction began today on a $4,500,000 30-mile railroad in northern New York's mountain wilderness to transport iron and metal alloys to the country's blast furnaces from long idle mines.

That culinary structure known as the sandwich has come a long way since the afternoon in the middle of the eighteenth century when the fourth Earl of Sandwich discovered that meat concealed between silces of bread could be neatly consumed without interrupting one's whist game.

LONDON, Aug. 4 -- Experts of the Royal Air Force and the British Ministry of Aircraft Production have now got possession of a Focke-Wulf 190, Germany's latest fighter plane, intact and are studying it in test flights and in the engineering laboratory, officials announced today.

Miss Pauline Betz of Los Angeles, winner of the women's crown last year, and Ted Schroeder of Glendale, Calif., national intercollegiate titleholder, lead the field that will start play today in the Eastern turf championships at the Westchester Country Club, Rye.

INDIANAPOLIS, Aug. 4 -Charles A. Lindbergh testified for fourteen minutes in Federal court today as a defense witness at the sedition trial of William Dudley Pelley, leader of the disbanded Silver Shirts.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 -- Three panels of the War Labor Board, combining their efforts to adjust two sets of disputes, in the cotton textile industry of New England and of the South, reached today varying conclusions which, it was indicated, may affect 485,000 textile workers.
CHICAGO, Aug. 4 (AP) -- The White Sox scored their fourth straight victory today and climbed within three games of fifth-place Detroit by defeating the Tigers, 5 to 4, behind the veteran Ted Lyons.
MOSCOW, Wednesday, Aug. 5 (AP) -- The Soviet Information Bureau's midnight communique follows:

The German High Command yesterday reported the capture of Voroshilovk, Caucasian industrial center, 180 miles south of the Don, ninety-five miles south of Salsk and twenty-five miles above the Rostov-Baku railroad on its southeasterly stretch skirting the Caucasus Mountains.
In the score of years between the end of the first World War and the outbreak of the second one Britain made substantial progress in building modern homes for her people.
PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 4 (AP) -The Phils made five hits yield four runs and a 4-to-2 victory today, but the losing pitcher, Jim Tobin of the Braves, stole the show.

HARTFORD, Aug. 4 -- With the introduction of a military map of a northern section of Mexico and several letters, the government today rested its espionage conspiracy case against Rev. Kurt E.B. Molzahn, a Philadelphia pastor.
The unreliability of the French population explains, in part, the concern obviously felt by the German High Command whenever plans for a second front seem to take shape in London and Washington.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 -- Chairman George of the Senate Finance Committee announced today that he favored amending the House-approved tax bill to permit partial exemption from individual income tax of premiums on life insurance policies.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 -- Army orders for arge quantities of wool cloth, which will use the bulk of the domestic wool clip now available, will be placed in the near future, the War Production Board and the War Department announced today in a joint statement.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 4 -- The Third Circuit Court of Appeals today dismissed the appeal of William Fox, former motion picture producer, from a District Court judge's refusal to let him change a plea of guilty to a charge of conspiracy to obstruct justice and defraud the government after two juries had failed to return a verdict as to the guilt or innocence of the two men named co-conspirators.

A new muscle-strapping procedure that is supposed to increase walking, running and fighting ability from 35 to 50 per cent was yesterday by Dr. Albert revealed J. Kilberg, director of surgical research for the Academy of Foot Research. Dr. Kilberg spoke before the Podiatry Society of the State of New York at its forty-sixth annual convention in the Hotel Pennsylvania.

CAMDEN, N.J., Aug. 4 (AP) -Argonne Woods, a 5-year-old chestnut son of Broadside, who was claimed in April by J.H. Miles for $3,750, took the main award in the mile and one-eighth Sharon Hill Purse when he covered the distance in 1:50 3-5 to set a new track record and hang up his seventh triumph for his new owner at Garden State Park today.

The Commercial Credit Company, in its semi-annual report to stockholders, issued yesterday, said the governmental decrees prohibiting the manufacture and sale of motor vehicles and other consumer goods had caused considerable shrinkage in its business in those departments.

There was more booing at the Polo Grounds last night and the raucous catcalls from the crowd of 14,693 persons was another indictment of twilight baseball. For, in the wake of Monday night's unsatisfactory ending, the dimout regulations brought to a halt the game between the Giants and Dodgers, nullifying a 4-run Brooklyn outburst in the top half of the tenth.

From 40 to 50 per cent of the retail charge accounts of local stores, which were frozen on July 10, when the Reserve Board's credit restrictions went into effect, have now been "defrosted," it was estimated yesterday by Edward Malloy, president of the Credit Bureau of Greater New York.

While Max Fox was being arraigned yesterday morning in Homicide Court as the slayer of Robert B. Greene and Morris Wolen in revenge for being "squeezed out" of their betting commission business, Sam Boston, partner of the slain men, entered District Attorney Frank S. Hogan's office and announced that he was ready to answer all questions on his gambling relations with the slayer and slain.

MOSCOW, Aug. 4 -- Fighting on the Don and Caucasian fronts is along the lines that recent dispatches have made familiar. Col. Gen. Paul Ludwig von Kleist's tanks and motorized infantry have continued their advance in the Salsk sector, where a most alarming situation is developing, according to today's reports.

Stories of Japanese submarine crews machine-gunning survivors of a United States freighter torpedoed in the North Pacific and of a British trawler attacked off the East Coast of Australia came yesterday from Seattle and Melbourne.

LONDON, Aug. 4 -- Last week when Sir Stafford Cripps announced that there would be no further government statement on the progress of the war, members of Parliament protested that there were several things they wanted to tell the government that could be told only at a secret session.

BAY SHORE, L.I., Aug. 4 -From across the clam flats, oyster beds and eel bottoms that lie in the direction the sun sinks, there came an air-momentum today that made lively going in the second session of the Great South Bay Yacht Association's Race Week.

CLEVELAND, Aug. 4 -- Fire, terror of the jungle, swept the Ringling circus menagerie today, killing about fifty trained and wild animals, but tonight the "Big Top" and the Midway carried on with all their bright lights and glittering colors.

If combinations in restraint of trade are being made as a result of the misuse of patents, existing anti-trust laws are adequate to deal with them in the same way they deal with misuses of other recognized property rights, according to George E. Folk, special patent adviser to the National Association of Manufacturers, in a book, "Patents and Industrial Progress," to be published today by Harper Brothers.

At the request of the State Department of Insurance, rating organizations are now working upon new rate schedules looking toward a cut in the rates for motorists whose A cards limit their driving to a minimum, Louis H. Pink, State Superintendent of Insurance, said yesterday.

The Belden Manufacturing Company of Chicago, declared yesterday a dividend of 37 1/2 cents a share payable in war bonds or war savings stamps on Sept. 1 to stock of record of Aug. 17. Three months ago the company paid 35 cents a share in cash.

The Madison Personal Loan Corporation, formerly at 119 West Fifty-seventh Street, and four of its officers and employes, were permitted yesterday in General Sessions to change previous guilty pleas to not guilty of violating the banking law in charging alleged illegal fees on loans.

VICHY, France, Aug. 4 -- Important indications on the transportation crisis affecting the European continent are given by Jacques Gascuel in French Documents, a weekly bulletin. He declares it is no longer a secret that Germany and all other continental countries are suffering from acute transport difficulties.
Mrs. A. Collins Boardman has arrived from Peiping, China, and is at the Hotel Weylin.

Before the week ends, the somber reports from Russia may be supplemented by bad news from India. In that waiting land, heavy with dissension and suspense, a new war front may be opened -- not the Second Front for which everybody is looking, but another sector of the world-round battle line where Allied force has to be dispersed and difficult decisions have to be taken.

SALEM, N.H., Aug. 4 (AP) -Rockingham Park will add a morning card of six races to its regular afternoon nine-race program on Army-Navy Day tomorrow to become the first track in New England racing history to offer such a double-header.

Led by heavy purchases by three large life insurance companies, aggregating $250,000,000, sales of the Treasury's "tap issue" of 2 1/2 per cent bonds continued heavy yesterday in the New York Federal Reserve District, it was announced by Perry E. Hall, executive manager of the Victory Fund Committee for this district.
