A plea for additional funds to carry on the work of the Foster Parents Plan for War Children, 55 West Forty-second Street, was made yesterday by Mrs. Edna Blue, executive chairman. Fifteen thousand children have been cared for by this organization since its inception five years ago.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 (U.P.) -The Navy Department named sixteen New York and four New Jersey men among the dead, wounded and missing in its ninth casualty list of the war.

SOMEWHERE IN AUSTRALIA, Aug. 4 -- The Japanese have established themselves in the Gona-Buna area of New Guinea in sufficient strength so that nothing short of a sea-borne expedition is likely to push them out. That statement is not meant to suggest that such an expedition against Gona and Buna is imminent.

The farm and garden shop sale to be held today and tomorrow in the Hotel Pennsylvania is the third in the series of Summer sales in New York hotels offered by the New York Division of the Woman's National Farm and Garden Association.
CHICAGO, Aug. 4 -- The American Federation of Labor will confer with the Congress of Industrial Organizations in an effort to establish one big organization of labor.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 4 -- Bitterly condemning the New York accounting firm of Haskins Sells for certifying "obviously manipulated" financial statements, the Securities and Exchange Commission ordered the withdrawal today of the class A stock, $1 par value, of the Associated Gas and Electric Company from registration on the New York Curb Exchange and the Los Angeles Stock Exchange.

Beef rose to a new high yesterday as Elsie, that much-talked-about member of the bovine family, walked up the stairs of Cavanagh's Restaurant, 258 West Twenty-third Street, accompanied by her ten-month-old son Victory, to have lunch with officials of the Borden Milk Company, which owned them, and members of the American Jersey Cattle Club, to which Victory was later given.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 4 -- Two naval intelligence officers substantiated today testimony of Tony Martin, the singer, that he and Lieut. Comdr. Maurice N. Aroff, on trial by general court martial, agreed to tell a false story that Martin sold his Studebaker automobile to Aroff for $600 cash and a $500 war bond.

Three hundred jobs, paying from $63 to $100 weekly, are open at the Board of Education, it was announced yesterday. These jobs fall in the category of emergency training program for war industries. Fifteen thousand persons are enrolled in these classes in forty schools; the shortage of instructors has been caused by teachers going into war industries or into the armed forces.

MOSCOW, Wednesday, Aug. 5 -German troops have made another fifty-mile advance in the Caucasus to threaten Tikhoretsk, an important junction on the Soviet railway system, and also have gained in the Don River elbow northwest of Stalingrad, the Russians announced early today.
BOSTON, Aug. 4 (AP) -- With Phil Marchildon pitching four-hit ball, the Athletics came from behind today to defeat the Red Sox, 6 -- 4, in the opener of a three-game series.
Coal appears to be climbing into the classification of a collector's item, along with paintings, sculpture and rare books.

Although some did not obey, the majority of New York motorists complied last night when the new order went into effect for driving cars with parking lights only, during dimout hours. The order became effective half an hour after sunset.

The Omaha Housing Authority of Omaha, Neb., announced yesterday that it will open bids on Aug. 12 on a new issue of $3,681,000 of bonds to refund a like amount of bonds issued on Oct. 1, 1940. Under the terms of sale, bidders are to stipulate serial maturities for each April 1, beginning April 1, 1943, and ending not later than 1998.

Formal notices of violation of the General Maximum Price Regulation in charging higher than ceiling prices or in ignoring posting and filing requirements were sent to sixty Yonkers retailers yesterday by Sylvan L. Joseph, regional administrator of the Office of Price Administration.

ALBANY, Aug. 4 -- The preprimary expense statement of Hamilton Fish, who is fighting to retain his seat in Congress, indicated that twenty-three persons, several of them non-residents of the State, contributed a total of $2,164.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 4 -- The first phase of what was described as a nation-wide investigation of alleged frauds involving millions of dollars of government clothing contracts opened today when a Federal grand jury heard evidence against a manufacturing firm in Souderton which was closed by government order last year.

BERNE, Switzerland, Aug. 4 -Putting teeth into existing legislation for the punishment of crimes against the security of the State, the Swiss Federal Council today issued a decree placing the examination and trial of all persons accused of such crimes in the hands of the military.

NEW DELHI, India, Aug. 4 (U.P.) -- American planes flying almost blind through the heavy monsoon downpours have repeatedly bombed the Myitkyina airdrome and kept the Japanese from restoring that important air base in Northern Burma, it was announced today by Colonel Carl L Naiden of the United States Army Air Forces in China.

State Chairman James A. Farley, leader of the forces backing Attorney General John J. Bennett Jr. for the Democratic nomination for Governor, charged yesterday that Senator James M. Mead of Buffalo, the New Deal contender, had shown by his continuing opposition to the St. Lawrence River power and seaway project that he was not, even after Pearl Harbor, a 100 per cent supporter of President Roosevelt's war program.

As a past president of the India League in England and a supporter for many years of the movement for Indian self-government, I feel that I should make clear my strong opposition to the present policy of Mr. Gandhi.

Men's Summer hat lines for next season, now being introduced to the trade, include many numbers woven of cotton yarns which are processed to simulate straws which the industry formerly imported from the Far East.

A 10-year-old girl was a witness yesterday to the slaying of Philip Hochman, 53, for twenty years owner of the Wilkinson Avenue Dairy and Grocery at 3198 Westchester Avenue, the Bronx, who was shot by one of two bandits who escaped through the vacant lots in the Pelham Bay section.

WASHINGTON, Aug.4 -- Experiments conducted by the Government Printing Office in the use of plastics in place of metal for the production of news and advertising cuts have given "extremely satisfactory results," spokesmen for the office said today.

Despite the varying estimates of the loads that can be carried and the time required to build giant air-cargo carriers, there is now rather general, though somewhat belated, recognition of the necessity for as full development as possible of our air-cargo and air-transport services.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 -- King Peter II of Yugoslavia left this country with the conviction that "nothing can ever stop the United States in its onward march to victory," it was disclosed today in an exchange of telegrams between the exiled Yugoslav monarch and President Roosevelt.

TORONTO, Aug. 4 (AP) -- Tommy Byrne's pitching and batting gave Newark an even break with Toronto tonight. The young left-hander, racking up his fourteenth victory against two defeats, struck out 14 and didn't issue a pass while the Bears gained a 4-to-2, eleven-inning triumph in the second part of a double-header.

Vinnie Rossano, Red Hook boxer, outpointed George Kochan of the Coast Guard in the feature bout of eight rounds at the Queensboro Arena last night. The fight was briskly waged, and thrilled the crowd of 4,000 fans to the final second.

INDIANAPOLIS, Aug. 4 -- After testifying at the Pelley trial today that he believed "the majority of the people of this country were opposed to getting into war -- that is, before we were attacked," Charles A. Lindbergh was asked if he had sought to determine whether public opinion had changed since the attack.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., Aug. 4 -The imaginary exploits of the dashing "Captain Jack von Wiegand," who received nation-wide publicity in 1928 when he told a thrilling story of shooting down twenty-two Allied planes as a member of Baron von Richthofen's Flying Circus during the first World War, were brought to an end today -- at least temporarily -by the heavy hand of the Federal Bureau of Investigation.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 -- President Roosevelt said today that he hopes to send to Congress on Thursday his veto of the bill sponsored by the farm group to set up a separate agency for promoting the production of synthetic rubber from agricultural commodities.

NEW DELHI, India, Aug. 4 -The British Government charged today that the great majority of members of the All-India Congress Working Committee were appeasers of Japan and that Mohandas K. Gandhi favored prompt negotiations with Japan for the independent India he was seeking to establish now.

German tank columns are now less than 100 miles from the Maikop oil fields. They are rolling south of Rostov toward the bend of the Kuban River. Just beyond this bend lies Maikop. It is the third largest oil-producing area in the Soviet Union.

The first pools of small contractors to bid on local war contracts are now being formed under the auspices of the recently established American Contractors War Advisory Committee, it was revealed yesterday by P.H. Wolf, head of the committee and chairman of the Association of Plumbing and Heating Contractors of Greater New York.
The following German High Command communique was broadcast from Berlin yesterday and recorded here by The Associated Press:

LONDON, Aug. 4 -- The House of Commons today passed the bill for the transfer of criminal jurisdiction over members of the American armed forces from the British courts to American military tribunals. It was passed through all stages at one sitting just as had been done in the House of Lords.

LONDON, Aug. 4 -- The holiday mood was still evident in the stock market today where, although the tone was firm, the turnover was very small. British funds were idle and there were few changes in foreign bonds except in the Brazilian section which hardened.

The progress made by the Governments of Bolivia and the United States under war conditions was praised yesterday by officials of both countries at a luncheon given by the Pan-American Society in India House, 1 Hanover Square.

There was no timidity yesterday among buyers, but the war news prevented the stock market from extending the modest rise of Monday. The railroad and liquor issues were still the main avenues of trading and the modest gains in those groups were fairly well maintained.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 -- If you think you look well in blue, here are a few pointers on how to be a candidate for an officer in the WAVES, the new feminine naval reserve.

The Children's Aid Society from its founding eighty-nine years ago has bent its efforts to care for the most underprivileged group, often the children of emigrants, of whatever nationality or race, then coming to our shores.

VICHY, France, Aug. 4 (U.P.) -Serge Tretiakoff, Russian Czarist leader and former industrialist, has been charged by the German Gestapo with being a Soviet secret agent, advices from German-occupied Paris said today.

COLUMN HALT! About face! In listing the No. 1 skeet team of the Army Air Corps in this corner yesterday there was included one "Private Dudley Lee Braun," who in professional skeet shooting competition through 1941 averaged 99.66, which is 'way uptown in the skeet world.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 -- Full and exact details of the short-cut purchase of steel by the Higgins Corporation of New Orleans will be required before the War Production Board and the Office of Price Administration can know what if any laws were violated and whether such transactions will impede or disarrange the war raw materials priorities and allocations program.

LONDON, Aug. 4 -- Reverberations from the now famous German-language broadcast a week ago by Air Marshal Sir Arthur T. Harris, chief of the Bomber Command of the Royal Air Force, in which he warned the German people their land would be bombed to bits, city by city, came today in the House of Lords, where it was called "silly nonsense," un-British and an unfortunate mistake.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 (AP) -- The Senate Patents Committee was told today that a German chemical trust in 1940 and 1941, before this country's entry into the war, arranged to file applications for patents in France and England in the name of the Standard Oil Company (New Jersey).

A board of officers of the Navy Yard in Brooklyn has recommended the scrapping of guns of early American wars, long on display in the Yard as "atmospheric props," so that the metal may be used to manufacture modern arms, it was announced yesterday by the Third Naval District.

On Friday the All-India Congress Committee, under the leadership of Mohandas K. Gandhi and Jawaharlal Nehru, will take the terrible decision whether or not to throw its "nonviolent strength" against the British, and, indeed, against ourselves and the rest of the United Nations, in an effort to secure immediate "independence" for India.

Consolidated earnings of the Socony-Vacuum Oil Company, Inc., for the first half of 1942 were estimated yesterday by John A. Brown, president, at approximately $13,500,000, including full equity in the six months' estimated earnings of the Standard-Vacuum Oil Company, in which Socony-Vacuum has a 50 per cent interest and after allowance for a 45 per cent income tax rate against 1942 earnings.
A German Transocean news agency broadcast, recorded by THE NEW YORK TIMES, reported the following Finnish communique:

With the $4,450,000 goal of the Greater New York War Fund of the United Service Organizations in sight, fifty leaders of uncounted thousands of volunteer canvassers in Manhattan were exhorted yesterday to do everything possible to raise in small contributions a little more than $200,000 that is still needed.
Unusually light voting marked primary balloting yesterday in Kansas, Missouri, Virginia and West Virginia.

Cups and statuettes that in other times represented the prizes of peaceful combat on the fields of sport went into the war effort yesterday when Holcombe Ward, president of the United States Lawn Tennis Association, turned over to the WPB some 270 athletic trophies at the Fifth Avenue office of A.G. Spalding Brothers, which had served as a clearing house.

LONDON, Aug. 3 -- Spokesmen for Allied Governments-in-Exile said tonight that Reichsfuehrer Hitler had shifted 3,000,000 persons from "danger spots" in the occupied countries so that they could not aid any American-British invasion forces, and that thousands more were being torn from their homes daily and moved deep into the interior of Europe.

Last May you were good enough to publish my plan for an individual excess income tax, a special tax upon that portion of a person's net income in excess of that received in a prior base year, such as 1940 or 1941. Since then the plan has been adopted by Senator Tom Connally and advocated by many others.

The principal department stores here and in other cities have acted or are actively considering moves to change their fiscal years from twelve months ending on Jan. 31 to twelve months ending on July 31. The present department store "year" calls for inventory taking and balancing of books at one of the most active periods of the year, with resultant strain on personnel and some interference with merchandising.
PITTSBURGH, Aug. 4 (AP) -Frank Gustine's only hit of the game, a looping single in the last half of the eleventh inning, gave the Pirates a 2 -- 1 victory today over the Cubs.

CHICAGO, Aug. 4 -- Retailers were urged here today by Daniel L. Jones, president of the Corset and Brassiere Association, to cooperate fully in observing rubber and other priorities restrictions and to utilize the cloth-saving Fall styles as a promotional argument for corset and foundation garment sales.

Reversing a trend of two weeks, the death rate in the city last week dropped to the lowest level of the year, Health Commissioner Ernest L. Stebbins announced yesterday. In contrast to the week before, when the death rate was 10.1 for each 1,000 population, last week's was 8.5.

LONDON, Aug. 4 -- The chalk writing on the ancient castle walls in the old flagged courtyard was a little incongruous. It said, "This Way to Ebbets Field, Dodgers vs. Giants." Another chalk legend said, "Garbage Here."

A special offering of 28,700 shares of General Electric was sold on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday. The special offering was made at 11:32 o'clock, and immediately there were bids for 74,362 shares. Accordingly it was closed immediately, and the shares were allotted on the basis of 38.6 per cent of the bids.

A reception in honor of Representative Vito Marcantonio, leader of the left wing of the American Labor party and candidate for renomination in Republican, Democratic and A.L.P. primaries in the Twentieth Congressional District, was held yesterday afternoon in the Hotel Pennsylvania, with 500 trade unionists present, but with Mayor La Guardia absent.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 -- The probability that greater use will be made of Pacific Coast ports in the movement of vital cargoes to and from South America was seen by foreign traders here today in an announcement from the Board of Economic Warfare advising exporters to act immediately to make any adjustments necessary to "meet any redirection of shipments without delay or confusion."

The City Council adopted yesterday a bill sponsored by Mayor La Guardia for cutting the entrance pay for new patrolmen from $2,000 to $1,320. Passage of the bill by a vote of 19 to 4, came after Republican and American Labor party members of the council had sharply criticized the Mayor for trying to "bludgeon" them into voting for the bill.

The British people want to know about the possibilities for cooperation with America after the war, according to Miss Barbara Ward, 28-year-old foreign editor of the English weekly, The Economist, who arrived in this county for the first time five days ago.

CHICAGO Aug. 4 (AP) -- Buyers for the Eastern Seaboard continued to bid actively for choice live beef in the Chicago livestock market today and a strong cattle section temporarily took the spotlight away from hogs, which reacted. Better steers and yearlings advanced 10 to 15 cents a hundredweight and a top of $16, new high on the crop, was paid for choice prime 1,430-pound bullocks, others going at $15.90.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 -- President Roosevelt declared today that operators of a "black market" in steel should be put in jail. He was commenting at his press conference on testimony of a New Orleans shipbuilder that he had been able to buy steel in eighteen-ton lots in the "black market," which always knew in advance just the type of steels that would be required.

From a big British freighter lying at a Staten Island dock, sixty-two happy Chinese seamen hurried down the gangway yesterday afternoon, free to roam the city under new government regulations designed to make thousands of Chinese seafarers happier men.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 -- President Roosevelt will finish the review of his findings and evidence in the military trial of the eight Nazi saboteurs within two or three days, the Chief Executive announced at a press conference this afternoon.

As yet there is no "hint of Autumn in the air," but college shops springing into action in Manhattan and its environs testify that Summer is on the wane. Forthcoming fashions that they are showing reveal the impact of these days of stress -- as styles have always, mirrored historic eras.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 -- The Yankees' return East from their triumphant sweep through the West crashed into what might be termed an unforeseen development tonight when the Senators, behind Sid Hudson's robust pitching, tripped the world champions, 4 to 3, before a crowd of 19,000 at Griffith Stadium.

Harold Bell Wright has written his first novel in ten years. The 70-year-old author, who has never written for the critics and whom the critics in turn have largely ignored, is one of the few writers of modern times whose sales on a single book exceeded 2,000,000 copies.
ROCHESTER, Aug. 4 (AP) -- Ira Hutchinson of Rochester hurled his eleventh victory of the season tonight as he turned back Jersey City, 10 -- 1.

A plea for 2,000 volunteer health assistants to aid the Health Department nurses in schools, clinics and health centers was made yesterday by Miss Amelia Grant, director of the Bureau of Nursing, Department of Health, 125 Worth Street.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 -- Extension of driving limitations to owners of passenger cars in all parts of the country appeared inevitable soon, spokesmen for the War Production Board conceded here tonight after a meeting at which rubber conservation was the major topic.

The Bowery Savings Bank has lost patience with the Collyer brothers of Harlem, reputed to be wealthy members of an old New York family, who have lived secluded in their decrepit home at Fifth Avenue and 128th Street for many years, hiding from the curious eyes of their neighbors.

The General Maximum Price Regulation is not an end in itself, but merely the initial step in a broad program to combat the inflationary spiral, Geoffrey Baker, assistant price executive, Food Branch, Office of Price Administration, declared yesterday at the forty-first annual convention of the New York State Food Merchants Association at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt spoke twice last night at a general meeting in two sections sponsored by the Interracial Student Group of Teachers College, Columbia University; first before 1,300 persons in the McMillin Academic Theatre, 116th Street and Broadway, then before an overflow in the Horace Mann Auditorium, four blocks north.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., Aug. 4 -Mayor Hague, long the dominant power in New Jersey Democratic politics, lost two decisions on his main front in Hudson County today through adverse rulings of the State Supreme Court and the State House Commission, both sitting in Trenton.

Nearly two-thirds of the voting members of the National Association of Securities Dealers, Inc., have approved an amendment to the association's by-laws establishing minimum capital requirements for membership, Wallace H. Fulton, executive director, announced yesterday.

The report of the Atlas Corporation for the six months ended on June 30 shows a net asset value of $11.01 a share, compared with $11.42 a share on Dec. 31 and with $11.81 a share on June 30, 1941, Floyd B. Odlum, president of the company, announced yesterday.

The ten-story and basement building at 161-63 Grand Street and 223-25 Centre Street, diagonally opposite Police Headquarters, has been sold by Robert J., John S., Gouverneur M.W. and Ethel Turnbull to a client of Eli Bensky and Samuel Marcus for investment.

Belden Roach of 993 Park Avenue, who died on July 25, bequeathed $25,000 to the Naval Academy at Annapolis, the income to be used in the preparation and publication of material dealing with United States naval history. Legacies of $10,000 each were left to New York, St. Vincent's and Mount Sinai Hospitals.

BUENOS AIRES, Argentina, Aug. 4 -- All groups in the Argentine Senate concurred today in strongly condemning the attack Sunday upon the American author Waldo Frank. Party spokesmen, ranging from Socialists to Conservatives, declared the incident outraged the sentiments of the Argentine people.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 -- In the Coral Sea and Midway battles a single Navy fighter squadron shot down a record total of fifty-four Japanese planes, plus eighteen additional craft probably downed, while losing only four United States fighters, only two of which were shot down by the enemy, the Navy Department disclosed today.

CULVER, Ind., Aug. 4 -- A major upset occurred in a third-round match in the boys' division of the National juniors and boys' tennis championships at Culver Military Academy today, when unseeded Macdonald Mathey of Princeton, N.J., defeated Sam Handel of Philadelphia, seeded first, 6 -- 2, 6 -- 4.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 4 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission approved today an amended plan of recapitalization of the Empire Gas and Fuel Company, providing among other things for the issuance of $21,534,800 of 3 1/2 per cent sinking fund debentures to be dated Jan. 1, 1942, and to mature Jan. 1, 1962.

CHICAGO, Aug. 4 -- The National Canvas Goods Manufacturers Association, Inc., re-elected officers at its national defense conference and convention ending here today and took steps to secure an easing on priorities restrictions covering iron and steel pipes and tubes for the awning industry.

The overwhelming majority of citizens rightly consider it an outrage that a private individual can and does order a school band off the air, and that he can and has ordered the country's musicians not to make records to be played over the radio or in public places. So strong is this opinion that the Department of Justice has proceeded to prosecute Mr. Petrillo for violation of the Sherman anti-trust act.

Universal's "Invisible Agent," which opens at Loew's Criterion, is this morning's lone film newcomer. The topical action drama, which was produced by Frank Lloyd Productions, features Jon Hall, Ilona Massey, Sir Cedric Hardwicke, Peter Lorre, J. Edward Bromberg and Albert Basserman.

Thirty store proprietors in North Queens were before Magistrate Jenkin R. Hockert in the Flushing Magistrate's Court yesterday answering summonses for violations of the dimout regulations for stores. Magistrate Hockert dismissed two of the defendants; reserved decision in one case after trial; found three defendants guilty and deferred sentence till today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 -- The United Kingdom paid $38,928,797 in the year to July 31 on its $425,000,000 loan from the Reconstruction Finance Corporation, it was announced today by Jesse Jones, Secretary of Commerce.

From Narragansett, R.I., comes an encouraging report for those who are still looking forward to a run of bluefish -- a few barrels of three to four pound bluefish were recently taken from a trap off there.
" The Morning Star," the Emlyn Williams play, will open at the Morosco Theatre on Sept 14, after a week's engagement in Philadelphia. Gladys Cooper has the leading role.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 -Under a revised War Production Board order issued today to save steel the manufacture of inner spring mattresses must cease on Sept 1. Production of studio couches, sofas and lounges in which iron or steel are used must stop Nov. 1.

Somehow the devotees of protective skin lotions and tanning aids take for granted that the sun that broils their skin only smiles benevolently upon their hair. The penalty for this delusion is a thatch of streaked, bleached tresses brought back to town by enthusiastic vacationers, along with their improved tennis techniques and gorgeous tan.
LONDON, Aug. 4 -- Food production on the royal farms at Windsor will be doubled next year, according to orders just issued by King George VI, it was announced today.

CHICAGO, Aug. 4 -- A proposed resolution, threatening to rescind the United Automobile Workers' voluntary waiver of "bonus" pay for Saturday and Sunday work during war time, threw the U.A.W.C.I.O. convention into turmoil here today because a large percentage of the delegates felt the resolution should be backed up by abolition of the "no strike" agreement.

When the Nazis issued their edict against the Jews one of their first victims was Professor Richard Willstaetter of the University of Munich. A Nobel Prize winner and the recipient of many honors from chemical societies here and abroad, his scientific activities were ended, with a loss to the world that can hardly be calculated.

CHUNGKING, China, Aug. 4 (U.P.) -- Chinese troops, striking after United States Army bombers had thrown the enemy into panic, stormed the west and south gates of Linchwan [also known as Fuchow], Japanese stronghold in Kiangsi Province, yesterday in the first big scale Chinese-American war operation, a Chinese Army communique said tonight.

NEW DELHI, India, Aug. 4 (Reuter) -- Following is the text, issued by the Government of India, of the original "Quit India" resolution drafted by Mohandas K. Gandhi and rejected by the All-India Congress Working Committee in favor of the modified version submitted by Pandit Jawaharlal Nehru.

While not wishing to dispute Mrs. Margaret McLean's personal impressions concerning enemy aliens, as expressed in her letter in THE NEW YORK TIMES Aug. 2, I do believe that one inaccurate statement of fact and one slightly misleading comparison should not go uncorrected.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Aug. 4 -Paramount will take the Somerset Maugham story "The Hour Before Dawn" off the shelf again for Vera Zorina, and put the actress and dancer in the film as soon as she has completed a couple of small chores.

AN ADVANCED ALLIED BASE, in the Southwest Pacific, Aug. 4 (U.P.) -- Allied planes have wiped out the Japanese-occupied New Guinea settlement of Kokoda and Australian jungle fighters supported by native black troops have routed a large Japanese patrol, military sources revealed tonight.

BERNE, Switzerland, Aug. 4 -- Some French officials abroad -- mostly diplomatic -- are receiving orders from Vichy suggesting that they should close their establishments in foreign countries and return to France "with a view to residing there in the future."

An order excluding American motion pictures from theatres in unoccupied France and French North Africa after Dec. 31, 1942, has been issued by the Vichy government film authorities, it was learned here yesterday. American films have not been shown publicly in occupied parts of the country since the Germans took over.

Our Washington dispatches report that the War Production Board has reached the conclusion that nation-wide restrictions on the use of passenger cars, for the purpose of saving rubber, have now become inevitable. According to The Associated Press, the Board reached this conclusion in July; decided then that country-wide rationing of gasoline was the best approach to the problem, and actually prepared the printed forms required to put such rationing into effect.

Two more merchant ships have been sunk by submarines in the Atlantic, the Navy disclosed yesterday. Fourteen men are missing, but there are ninety-five survivors, who have arrived at East Coast ports.

PITTSBURGH, Aug. 5 (AP) -- The Pirates exploded foul singles with two out in the seventh inning tonight to score the only runs in their 3-0 victory over the Cubs. Truett (Rip) Sewell was never in trouble as he pitched his twelfth victory.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 5 -- To provide further protection for the West Coast and its shipping lanes against enemy submarine and air attacks Lieut. Gen. John L. DeWitt ordered today a broad extension of "dimout" regulations to include within their provisions some areas 150 miles inland.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 (AP) -The Commerce Department estimated today that construction in the United States hit a new high of $3,297,000,000 in the second quarter of 1942, and calculated that the whole year would set an annual record of $11,726,000,000.

John S. McDermott, new Class A governor of the New York Curb Exchange, has been appointed to the committees on arbitration, business conduct, public relations and outside supervision. John Whitney, new Class B governor, has been appointed to committees on outside supervision and communications and commissions. H. Walllace Cohu, a Class B governor, has been appointed to committees on member firms and outside supervision.

Great Britain is fighting the battle of India in America by a whispering campaign against Gandhi, in the opinion of Louis Fischer, American correspondent who arrived here by Pan American clipper yesterday after spending eight weeks in India, including a week as the guest of the Indian leader.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 -- Whenever discussion of the actual trend of the war arises in an American group these days some one is pretty certain to charge the press with gilding the ugly truth. Mr. Justice Douglas of the Supreme Court of the United States, in a recent speech to newspaper publishers in Oregon, urged his hearers to report the facts as they are, and analyze and headline them with brutal candor.

A hoarder of gasoline and America First Committee literature, a Japanese who still had a camera and a German with a great deal of contraband radio equipment were among the fifteen persons seized Tuesday night and taken to Ellis Island as dangerous alien enemies, it was revealed yesterday by P.E. Foxworth, assistant director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation.

Edwin Franko Goldman held his nineteenth annual memory contest last night at the concert of the Goldman band on the Mall in Central Park. Twenty-five anonymous excerpts were played and the audience was asked to write out its guesses. More than 2,000 submitted answers.

Lorin Maazel, 12-year-old conductor, who made his debut here three years ago at the World's Fair and who conducted the NBC Symphony Orchestra last Summer, conducted last night the New York Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra's concert at the Lewisohn Stadium.

MEXICO CITY, Aug. 5 -- President Manuel Avila Camacho's Rightist policy, supported by the extraordinary powers vested in him as result of Mexico's entry into the war on the side of the democracies, is beginning to produce economic benefits for Mexico through the confidence American capital has developed regarding investments in this country.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 -- Queen Wilhelmina of The Netherlands was officially welcomed to the White House late today by President Roosevelt and Mrs. Roosevelt, and was the guest of honor at a State dinner tonight at which the President paid tribute to her "great leadership and high achievements."

MOSCOW, Thursday, Aug. 6 (AP) -- A new German push south and west of Stalingrad by Nazi tank and infantry columns seeking to complete a pincer movement on the great steel city has brought fighting on the central front to Kotelnikov, ninety-five miles from Stalingrad, the Soviet High Command announced today.

The Wabash Railroad issued a call for bids yesterday for $2,000,000 of Series A ten-year equipment trust certificates dated Aug. 1 and maturing $200,000 annually. Bids are to be not less than 99, the bidder to set the coupon rate. The bids will be opened on Aug. 15.

VICHY, France, Aug. 5 -- Chief of Government Pierre Laval, on his return from consultation with the occupying authority in Paris, was received in conference by the Chief of State, Marshal Henri Philippe Petain, today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 -- In urging Senators to vote a 5 per cent sales tax for the duration and six months afterwards, Jay Iglauer declared today that such a levy would be "distinctly deflationary" and not inflationary as Treasury officials contended.

Nfany telegrams and letters from retailers and merchant groups in all sections of the country have been received by the National Retail Dry Goods Association pledging complete support for the OPH compliance drive being sponsored this month by the organization, it was announced yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 -- Reports of three engagements in which our planes and pilots defeated Japanese fliers in spite of heavy odds were received today by the War Department.

Negotiations that were started Tuesday at the request of Mrs. Elinore M. Herrick, regional director of the National Labor Relations Board, to settle the strike of employes of Warner Brothers home office and New York exchange, were broken off yesterday after a conference at the office, 321 West Forty-fourth Street.

The voice of college youth spoke through Cathleen Dugan, Smith '44, yesterday afternoon at a veryto-the-point college showing by Mary Lewis. In her forthright manner, not without a good bit of humor, Miss Dugan told what girls want and feel about clothes today.

The thirty-third annual casting tourney of the Belmar Fishing Club, Belmar, N.J., is slated to be held on Sunday. However, according to Chairman Louis Guarino, the event will be staged in modified form this year and will be open only to club members.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 -- Regulations governing the duties, qualifications, living quarters and tenure of service for hostesses and librarians at the Army camps, posts and stations were issued by the War Department today.

Local political glories fade fast. Little Tim Sullivan is but a name. Big Tim Sullivan is remembered for his nickname. He was a great man in his day. He used to give Christmas dinners to 5,000 persons. In 1892 he told Boss Croker that the vote in his election district was: Cleveland, 388; Harrison, 4.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 -- Accusing officers of the Navy's Bureau of Ships of negligence or wilful misconduct in the planning and production of "a vehicle important to the success of any invasion attempt," Senator Truman, chairman of the Senate War Program Investigating Committee, dispatched today a confidential report of inquiry findings to Secretary Knox, for such action as he might see fit to take.

One can understand the reluctance with which many members of the House of Commons voted for the bill, passed this week, transferring criminal jurisdiction over members of the new A.E.F. from British courts to American courts-martial. There were some misconceptions.

Encouraged by consistent sales gains over the low level of two years ago, the shrimp industry plans to continue its consumer advertising on a broad scale this Fall, George Burgess, president of the Shrimp Canners National Advertising Association, announced yesterday.

AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, Australia, Thursday, Aug. 6 (U.P.) -- The Japanese have advanced sixty miles inland in New Guinea with comparative ease because the area up to that point was indefensible as a result of enemy air control over the north coast, but the penetration does not threaten the Allied position on the island, an authorized spokesman said today.

LONDON, Aug. 5 -- The old agitation for a definitive statement of Great Britain's war and peace aims cropped up today in the House of Lords in a new form, but it was quickly squelched by Viscount Simon, the Lord Chancellor.

HARTFORD, Conn., Aug. 5 -Two letters from Gerhard Wilhelm Kunze, German-American Bund leader, one declaring the war would cost President Roosevelt his head, stirred the big crowd in the court room today at the trial of the Rev. Kurt E.B. Molzahn, Philadelphia pastor, on charges of espionage conspiracy.
UTICA, N.Y., Aug. 5 (AP) -Women ground crews for Army planes will be trained at New York's first aircraft mechanics school for girls, to be opened here within a month.

While some wholesalers are observing the letter and spirit of the Price Control Act, many are now ignoring it sprovisions, A.F. Guckenberger, executive secretary of the New York State Food Merchants Association, declared yesterday, in announcing that he had sent a letter of protest on behalf of the members to officials of the Office of Price Administration.

CLEVELAND, Aug. 5 (AP) -- An estimated 2,100 maintenance, installation and repair workers of the Ohio Bell Telephone Company struck in Cleveland and other Ohio cities today as a result of a wage dispute.

LONDON, Aug. 5 -- Withrop W. Aldrich, head of the British War Relieff Society of America, said today that the $7,500,000 allotted to that organization by Community Chest drives would maintain all its services here without curtailment.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 -- The War Production Board announced today that it has made up a list of 500 import items from all parts of the world which will receive "emergency shipping priorities" as vital to the nation's wartime economy.

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 5 (AP) -- The Indians massed five of their eleven hits off four pitchers for six runs in the fourth inning tonight for an 8-to-5 victory over the Browns, who pummeled two Cleveland pitchers for twelve scattered blows.

CAIRO, Egypt, Aug. 5 -- Direct hits scored by heavy bomber planes of the United States Army Air Forces on an Axis ship in the eastern Mediterranean yesterday raised the total of enemy ships sunk or badly damaged by air attack in the last ten days to nine.

CINCINNATI, Aug. 5 -- A "stay-away" of union pressmen in a dispute over wages and vacations forced all three daily newspapers of Cincinnati to suspend publication today, but it appeared that the presses might roll again tomorrow.

Organization of the first pool of small contractors under the auspices of the American Contractors War Advisory Committee to bid on war orders here was announced yesterday, following a meeting at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel. The first group, comprising general contractors of this city, includes these companies:
RENO, Nev., Aug. 5 -- Mrs. Dorothy Graham Bennett obtained a divorce here today from James W. Bennett on the ground of cruelty.

LONDON, Aug. 5 -- The American Red Cross has opened ten combination dormitory-recreation clubs for Yanks footloose on leave in the British Isles, including Northern Ireland. This chain of clubs will be expanded as more doughboys, gobs and marines start exploring the country.

LONDON, Aug. 5 (U.P.) -- Dr. Pieter S. Gerbrandy, Netherland Premier, told the people of German-occupied Netherland in a radio broadcast tonight that the tide was beginning to turn in favor of the United Nations and urged them to stand by for a call to action, Aneta, the Netherland Indies news agency reported.

Thomas J. Curra, New York County Republican Chairman, wrote yesterday to A. Charles Mucciolo, candidate for nomination for Representative in the Twentieth Congressional District against Representative Vito Marcantonio, expressing confidence that a majority of the enrolled Republicans of the district would vote for him next Tuesday and "thereby fittingly rebuke your opportunistic and demagogic opponent who should be running on the Communist ticket alone."

LONDON, Aug. 5 -- Stock markets were today mixed. Internationals were the most active feature. Brazil Traction and Canadian Pacifics were higher. Giltedged issues and home rails showed little movement.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 -- The War Labor Board, by a 7-to-2 vote today, proposed for the first time that its "Little Steel" formula for wage adjustments be applied universally so that all employers who may wish to grant voluntary wage increases shall require governmental approval before they can act.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 (AP) -The Civil Aeronautics Board today ordered American Export Lines, Inc., of New York to divest itself of control of American Export Airlines, Inc.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 -- Agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation have been asked to make an investigation of the War Production Board's branches to discover if possible leaks through which dealers in steel were able to solicit orders from war-contract holders before the contractors knew their bids had received favorable action, it was reported tonight.
BOSTON, Aug. 5 -- The Red Sox snapped out of their recent lethargy today behind Cecil (Tex) Hughson's three-hit pitching and uncorked a fourteen-hit barrage to shut out the Athletics, 7 -- 0.

The Children's Health Service of the New York Diet Kitchen Association has devoted sixty-nine years to the health and welfare of babies and children in New York. It now maintains five health centers in congested areas where 15,000 children are under its care.
The plan of Henry J. Kaiser, West Coast shipbuilder, to mass-produce seventy-ton Mars flying boats as cargo carriers is, unfortunately, a theoretical promise rather than a practical possibility.

LONDON, Aug. 5 (AP) -- British and United States service chiefs, seeking swifter means of relieving the desperate Russian war situation than the Royal Air Force bombing offensive, were reported tonight to be reviewing alternatives to a mass invasion of the Continent.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 5 -- Mrs. Hattie Meyers of Oakland, mother of Tony Martin, the singer, provided a climax of a day of drama in the court-martial of Lieut. Comdr. Maurice N. Aroff by speaking out from the witness chair today to the uniformed members of the court:

New York City has done pretty well in the USO fund-raising campaign. In a genial competition like this we can make invidious comparisons without hurting other people's feelings. Some cities decided not to try to raise money in the Summer, and so divided their efforts into a Spring campaign and a Fall campaign.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Aug. 5 -Line Coach Herman Hickman, no midget himself, rubbed his eyes in awe today as he caught his first glimpse of a part of the Eastern All-Army football team, which tomorrow starts six weeks of special gridiron detail at Yale in the interest of Army Emergency Relief.

Approximately 1,000 security dealers, under the direction of the First Boston Corporation and Merrill, Lynch, Pierce, Fenner Beane as dealer managers, will begin today the solicitation of exchanges of publicly held preferred shares of the Empire Gas and Fuel Company for a new issue of $21,534,800 of 3 1/2 per cent sinking fund debentures, due on Jan. 1, 1962.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 5 -- Indictment of a clothing manufacturing concern in the Souderton district on a charge that it defrauded the government by converting 2,500 pairs of soldiers' trousers to its own use and profit was asked today of the Federal grand jury by the Department of Justice.

MELBOURNE, Australia, Aug. 5 -- The Australian Food Council has laid down a policy of continuing to feed the armed forces in the Southwest Pacific, to feed Australians to an extent necessary to maintain a total war effort and to share in feeding the Allied nations outside the Pacific zone.
It is the favorite boast of New Yorkers that their city has the most and best of everything, and so it has. Unfortunately, this is too true with regard to panhandlers, beggars and chiselers.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 -- Exception was taken today by Mrs. Roosevelt to published criticisms of Queen Wilhelmina, and the "unfriendly tone" of some press reports. These were deplored by the First Lady on the dual ground of their "untruth" and the violation of the rule of "courtesy to the stranger," especially when the visitor is the guest of the nation.
SYDNEY, Australia, Aug. 5 -Sir Carl Jess presided at the inaugural conference of State organizers of the newly formed National Women's Land Army.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 -- A recommendation that arrangements be made to at least double the present production of cargo planes to meet the submarine menace has been made by a special committee of War Production Board experts, Donald M. Nelson, WPB chairman, disclosed tonight.

The American Woolen Company and its subsidiary, the Pocono Company, reported yesterday a net profit of $1,659,401 for the first half of 1942 after provision of $13,100,000 for Federal income and excess profits taxes and an appropriation of $1,000,000 for war contingencies.

Members of the largest class yet graduated from New York's Naval Reserve midshipmen's school -their number having been swelled to 664 by the first contingent of officers trained at Columbia University -- received commissions as ensigns yesterday morning at exercises aboard the U.S.S. Prairie State, training vessel moored in the Hudson River at 136th Street.

LONDON, Aug. 5 (U.P.) -- German submarines no longer regard the American coast as a soft spot and may have been forced to seek other waters in which to prey on Allied commerce, official British sources said today.

"Pink drinks for pale people" are the latest wrinkle at the tiny sweet shop that flaunts a patch of periwinkle awning in the soberest section of Madison Avenue. You buy the drinks -- or rather the makings for them -- in the form of a slender flask of the distilled essence of red raspberries.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Aug. 5 -- The first picturization of the American ferry service into China over the Himalayas will be made at Paramount, where producer Walter MacEwen starts "Night Plane From Chungking" in two weeks. The story is by Lester Cole, and will star Robert Preston, Albert Dekker and Ellen Drew, with Ralph Murphy directing.

The Federal Reserve Bank of New York disclosed yesterday the results of its special survey of commercial and industrial loans of all member banks in the Second Federal Reserve District, which was made in conjunction with similar surveys by the eleven other Reserve Banks.

SALEM, N.H., Aug. 5 -- Little Rockingham Park pulled out all the stops today with the first double-header in American turf history and realized approximately $80,000 for the Army and Navy relief funds.

Finished and unfinished gasoline stocks in the United States continued to decline last week, and at the close of the week were 81,324,000 barrels, off 957,000 from the 82,281,000 a week earlier, according to the American Petroleum Institute.
MOSCOW, Thursday, Aug. 6 (AP) -- Last midnight's Russian communique follows:
ANKARA, Turkey, Aug. 5 (Reuter) -- The Turkish National Assembly tonight unanimously passed a vote of confidence in Premier Shukru Saracoglu's Cabinet.

LONDON, Aug. 5 (U.P.) -- Yugoslav patriots, following up their capture of the towns of Prozor and Gorni-Vakuf, about fifty miles west of Sarajevo, were said here today to be continuing progress northward along the River Vrbas toward the towns of Jajce and Travnik, which are between forty and fifty miles north and slightly west of Gorni-Vakuf.
PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 5 (AP) -Tommy Hughes limited the Braves to five hits tonight as the Phils won their second straight encounter from the Bostons, 5 -- 2.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 -- The Senate Finance Committee does not intend to make any substantial increase in the rates on individual and corporation income as contained in the House tax bill, Senator George, the chairman, said tonight.
The following German High Command communique was broadcast from Berlin yesterday and recorded here by The Associated Press:

LONDON, Aug. 5 -- Britain's royal ordnance factories are now producing four and a half times as many guns as they did in the last twelve months, Sir Andrew Rae Duncan, Minister of Supply, said today in defending their work in the House of Commons.
CULVER, Ind., Aug. 5 (AP) -- California and the Southern entries continued to dominate the play in the national junior and boys' tennis championships today.

Richard Allen Knight, the disbarred lawyer who pleaded guilty in Special Sessions July 23 to sending annoying letters to a judge and many prominent lawyers as an offshoot of unsuccessful litigation in connection with the estate of his father-in-law, the late Lewis Cass Ledyard Jr., was sentenced yesterday to a three-month workhouse term.

Sam Boston, the 57-year-old gambling "king," whose partners in a betting commission racket, Robert B. Greene and Morris Wolen, were shot dead early Monday morning in a small card club on Seventh Avenue, was held in $10,000 bail yesterday in West Side Court as a common gambler under the vagrancy law.
CINCINNATI, Aug. 5 (AP) -- The Cardinals took advantage of Cincinnati misplays tonight to whip the Reds, 5 to 0, and even the two-game series at Bucky Walters's expense.

The executive committee of the National Association of Insurance Agents has completed the draft of a wholly revised constitution that will be submitted to the membership at the annual convention at Chicago on Sept. 21.

PEORIA, Aug. 5 -- Production of synthetic rubber from corn and wheat in commercial quantities at the rate of about seven pounds from each bushel may be possible soon as a result of a process developed at the northern regional research laboratory, a unit of the Department of Agriculture.

BRIARCLIFF MANOR, N.Y., Aug. 5 -- Although he was routed by his nemesis, Ray Billows, the practice Douglas Ford of Green Valley got in the Briar Hills invitation tourney last week-end stood him in good stead today when he qualified for the New York State junior golf championship.

With the announcement that it is virtually discontinuing the importing of titles from England, Penguin Books makes known its plans for an expanded list of American-manufactured publications. Penguin will shift its direction toward titles of a more popular nature than those it imported.

REYKJAVIK, Iceland, Aug. 5 (AP) -- The Germans have made their second long-range aerial attack in forty-eight hours on isolated points in Iceland, the United States Army announced today in a communique declaring a lighthouse on tiny Grimsey Island was machine-gunned by bombers.

One of the little international ironies of our time has been that, though we never tired of showering praise on the Chinese in China, we did not allow Chinese sailors to come ashore in the United States. These men were facing risks just as great as those of the Chinese soldiers in the field, but all they were allowed to see of the United States was the view through a porthole.

Chalky Wright, Los Angeles boxer, who holds the featherweight championship of the world, will step out of his class tonight to battle Allie Stolz, speedy Newark lightweight, in the star bout of ten rounds at Madison Square Garden. Although he will not be seeking Wright's crown, the bout is an important one for Stolz, inasmuch as a victory will virtually assure him a chance at the 135-pound crown, now held by Sammy Angott.

CHICAGO, Aug. 5 (AP) -- The White Sox were unequal to the task of pounding out a victory over the Tigers today, so they stole the game, 1 to 0, when Don Kolloway, rookie second baseman, sneaked home with the only run of the game in the sixth inning.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 (AP) -The Agriculture Department announced today the basis upon which it will determine the sale price of 125,000,000 bushels of government-owned wheat which Congress recently authorized it to sell for livestock feed under the war food program.
MIAMI, Fla., Aug. 5 -- Cradled in a decaying freight wharf here is the Navy's answer to the insistent public demand for aggressive warfare against German submarines.

BOMBAY, Aug. 5 (U.P.) -- A member of the All-India Congress Working Committee said today that a one-week "ultimatum" would be sent to the British Viceroy before the start of a civil disobedience campaign.

Your editorial quotation from Paul Wilstach's "Hudson River Landings" in the issue of Aug. 3 was "This Battle of Tappan Zee was the only naval engagement in the Hudson, or for that matter elsewhere in Northern waters, during the war."

CHICAGO, Aug. 5 -- The City Council unanimously passed today an ordinance, introduced by Mayor Kelly, making it unlawful for women to drink alcoholic beverages at a saloon bar. The Mayor immediately signed the ordinance, which will go into effect Aug. 16.

HARTFORD, Aug. 5 (AP) -- The Connecticut Supreme Court denied today a claim by the executors of the will of Robert B. Hirsch of Stamford, a New York silk merchant who died in 1924, for a State succession tax refund of $147,065 on his estate of about $2,500,000.

CHICAGO, Aug. 5 -- Philip Murray, president of the Congress of Industrial Organizations, speaking before the convention of the United Automobile Workers, today, declared that while he was praying for labor peace the American Federation of Labor only recently violated "the rules of common decency" by presuming to speak for the C. I. O. in a 'back-door agreement" with the British Trade Union Congress.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 -- Casualties of the Navy in dead, wounded and missing were 272 between July 11 and July 25 inclusive. This represents all casualties reported to next of kin.

MOSCOW, Thursday, Aug. 6 -- A dangerous German advance in the direction of the lower Volga was revealed in a Soviet communique early today. Operations were reported to be continuing in the region of Kotelnikov, a railway town on the trans-Caucasian line fifteen miles south of the point where the Don turns westward to flow toward Rostov.

PRINCETON, N.J., Aug. 5 -Princeton University has been selected by the Navy Department as a center for the indoctrination of reserve officers and three university dormitories will be taken over in the Fall for the housing and training of 1,000 prospective officers.

Abraham Herman Kimmel, 54 years old, of 2425 Kings Highway, Brooklyn, was seized yesterday on a charge of impersonating an officer of the Federal Government. P.E. Foxworth, assistant director of the FBI, charged that Kimmel, an itinerant buyer of old gold, appealed to the patriotism of housewives so that they would part with their gold trinkets for a minimum price.

ROCHESTER, Aug. 5 (AP) -- A city-wide test blackout tonight interrupted the Jersey City Giants and Rochester Red Wings for 36 minutes during the sixth inning of their International League game, but it didn't stop the Giants from capturing a 5-to-4 victory.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 -- A statement from Donald Nelson, chairman of the War Production Board, explaining how shortages of raw material are limiting war production and facing a "balancing" of the whole program will be issued over the week-end.

INDIANAPOLIS, Aug. 5 -- William Dudley Pelley, leader of the disbanded anti-Semitic Silver Shirts, was convicted on eleven counts of a sedition indictment in Federal Court tonight by a jury composed of farmers and tradesmen from small towns in Southern Indiana.

The report of the American Water Works and Electric Company and subsidiaries for the twelve months ended on June 30, made public yesterday, shows a consolidated net income after taxes, expenses and other charges, of $2,838,785.

CINCINNATI, Aug. 5 -- Circulation of false propaganda by "professional prohibitionists," as distinguished from "sincere idealists," was alleged and denounced tonight by Robert Barry, director of public relations of the National Distillers Products Corporation, in an address at a banquet in honor of the officers of the Tavern Association.

Net sales of the American Viscose Corporation for the first six months of 1942 increased $6,301,916, or about 17 per cent, to $44,432,044 from $38,130,128 in the corresponding half of last year, according to the semi-annual statement released yesterday.
MOSCOW, Aug. 5 (AP) --The Soviet Information Bureau issued the following communique today:

WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 -- Ruling against the representations of New York State liquor dealers, Leon Henderson, Federal Price Administrator, decided today that the General Maximum Price Regulation must prevail in all instances where the Hollowell, act, a New York State law fixing liquor discounts, is in conflict with the Federal regulation.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Aug. 5 (AP) -The Army's Dick Shaughnessymissed a double sweep in the national skeet championships today when he "dropped" a bird in a shoot-off for the small (.28) gauge title with Lovell S. Fratt of Indianapolis.

CRYSTAL SPRINGS, Miss., Aug. 5 (AP) -- At least twelve persons were killed and about thirty-six injured when a crowded bus of the Teche Greyhound Lines and an Illinois Central passenger train were in collision at a midtown crossing here today.

BAY SHORE, L.I., Aug. 5 -That rascal old Boreas, who so often plays tricks, threatened today to ruin Great South Bay's widely heralded reputation for breezes. There was not a breath early in the afternoon with which to start the third session of Race Week here.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Aug. 5 -Clare Boothe Luce, playwright, war correspondent and commentator on national and international affairs, declined in a letter made public today to become a candidate for the Republican nomination as Representative in the Fourth Connecticut Congressional District, a declination that was accepted by many persons as only a tentative withdrawal of her bonnet from the political ring.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 -- Owners of obsolete printing plates cannot acquire any new metal after Oct. 1 as the result of an order issued today by the War Production Board. Printers and publishers who obtain new metal must certify on their purchase orders that they do not have any obsolete plates in their possession.
LONDON, Aug. 5 -- Following is the text of a statement on India made tonight by Sir Stafford Cripps:
WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 (AP) -- A spokesman for three North Carolina textile mill managements today challenged the authority of the War Labor Board to set wartime wage levels above peacetime standards.

German Elite Guard forces have taken the important railway junction of Kropotkin by storm after hard fighting, the German High Command reported yesterday, and bridgeheads have been established across the Kuban River between Kropotkin and Armavir, forty miles to the south, according to Berlin broadcasts recorded by The Associated Press.

BOMBAY, India, Aug. 5 -- The Working Committee of the All-India Congress party, nearing a showdown with the British Empire on the issue of independence, adopted today a resolution stating that India would become an ally of the United Nations if she were granted freedom.

It seems certain that the present deadlock in Egypt cannot continue long. One side or the other must break it soon, for neither army can remain locked in a blind passageway. The uneasy pause undoubtedly masks desperate efforts by both Rommel and Auchinleck to rush up men and supplies.

LONDON, Aug. 5 -- While Royal Air Force bombers groped through storms of snow and ice over Western Germany last night their comrades in Britain shot down six of thirty Nazi raiders who scattered explosives and incendiaries in Southern and Southwest England and South Wales, it was reported today.

FORT BELVOIR, Va., Aug. 5 (U.P.) -- General Marshall, Chief of the Army Staff, personally welcomed today the son of General Pershing, his World War I superior, into the ranks of commissioned officers.

It took the American Women's Voluntary Services in California five months to persuade a farmer that women could help with the labor shortage. Now the organization is so besieged with requests from farmers that it does not know how to meet all of them, according to Mrs. Charles R. Jeffs of San Francisco.

Cotton prices suffered a relapse yesterday as commission houses and local traders who were buyers on the preceding day applied selling pressure that depressed the market as much as 19 points at one time and brought active contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange to net losses of 9 to 11 points.

A new ruling by the American Red Cross will make impossible the shipment of food parcels addressed to individual prisoners of war, it was announced yesterday by Anne Morgan, chairman of the prisoners' committee of the Coordinating Council of French Relief Societies in New York, 451 Madison Avenue.

OTTAWA, Aug. 5 (Canadian Press) -- Some 30,000 Canadian women will be wearing the King's uniform before another year is out if the present rate of expansion of the women's services continues, it was stated today.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., Aug. 5 -The five-man Hudson County Tax Board appointed by Governor Charles Edison finally got possession of the board's office and records in the court house this afternoon under a writ of mandamus signed earlier in the day by Supreme Court Justice Joseph L. Bodine.

Difficulty in selecting a leading woman for "Strip for Action" has set back the scheduled premiere at the National from Sept. 23 to Sept. 30. This means that rehearsals of the Howard Lindsay-Russel Crouse comedy are now slated to start next Monday and that the fortnight's engagement in Pittsburgh will not get under way until Sept. 14.
Mrs. Laurence Boocock has arrived from Spofford, N.H., and has joined Mrs. H. Stagg McKim at the Hotel Weylin.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 (AP) -Wage, salary, dividend, business profit and other income payment to individuals were estimated today by the Department of Commerce to have reached a record-breaking total of $52,071,000,000 in the first half of 1942.

The report of the Radio Corporation of America and subsidiaries for the first six months of this year, issued yesterday by David Sarnoff, president, shows a net income, after all charges, of $3,024,121. This was equal, after dividend charges, to 10 cents a share on 13,881,016 common shares, and compares with $4,101,095, or 18 cents a common share, in the first six months of 1941.
Following is a summary of Tuesday's primary results:
WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 (AP) -The Treasury will offer for sale tomorrow $1,500,000,000 of seven-eighths of 1 per cent certificated of indebtedness due in eleven and half months.

Following a special meeting of the Board of Estimate yesterday at which local legislation fixing the entrance pay of police rookies at the rate of $1,320 a year was adopted, Police Commissioner Valentine said 110 new policemen would be appointed today or tomorrow.
LONDON, Aug. 5 (AP) -- An Air Ministry communique said today:

WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 -- To buttress the fight against inflation, Secretary Jones was reported today to be preparing to go to Congress when its informal recesses end soon after Labor Day and ask authority for government lending agencies to spend not more than $1,000,000,000 to subsidize producers who are "squeezed" by price ceilings set by Leon Henderson, Federal Price Administrator.
A large terrace apartment in the Hotel St. Moritz, Central Park South, has been leased by Elisabeth Bergner, the Austrian-born stage and screen actress.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 5 -- W.E. Boeing's Devil's Thumb, second in the Flash and first in the United States Hotel Stakes, made more definite than ever his superiority among the local 2-year-olds when he won the $4,850 Saratoga Sales Stakes by five lengths before 7,095 persons today.

CHICAGO, Aug. 5 -- Persistent scattered liquidation kept the grain markets on the downgrade today, with all deliveries of the major products selling within striking distance of the lowest levels of the season. At no time was there any disposition to rally, although wheat came up about 1/2 cent a bushel from the bottom in the late trading.

James A. Farley, Democratic State Chairman, announced last evening the appointment of Lieutenant Governor Charles Poletti as chairman of the tentative platform committee to present a draft of the party platform to the Democratic State Convention, and Mr. Poletti's acceptance of the post.

MOSCOW, Aug. 5 (U.P.) -- Major Gen. Follett Bradley said today that while American supplies were flowing steadily to Russia, deliveries were becoming more and more difficult because of the shipping problem.

Justice Denis O'Leary Cohalan said yesterday in Bronx Supreme Court, in connection with a habeas corpus petition in behalf of Moses Elisberg, who was sentenced Sunday to thirty days in the work-house by Magistrate Robert Levis for criticising the United States conduct of the war, that if he had been the magistrate he would have come to another conclusion.

The Germans are driving down the Caucasus peninsula with a concentration of force on one objective that is bringing them nearer each day to the goal of this campaign. Already in the oil country, they are pounding at the main railway and the main pipe line connecting Rostov with the Caspian Sea.

A twilight game with a rational, completely satisfactory ending -particularly to Dodger fans -- was played at Ebbets Field last night. Beating the dimout deadline with plenty to spare, the Brooks blanked the Giants, 4 -- 0, and Max Macon, the young southpaw, used this occasion to solidify his position in Flatbush.

SPRINGFIELD, N.J., Aug. 5 -Charles P. Burgess of the home club carded 35, 40 -- 75 to lead a field of 135 in the New Jersey State seniors' mid-Summer golf tournament over the upper course of the Baltusrol G.C. today.

BERNE, Switzerland, Aug. 5 -It was learned from a usually reliable source in Vichy today that late yesterday afternoon the Papal Nuncio protested to Marshal Henri Philippe Petain, French Chief of State, against the "inhuman arrests and deportations" of Jews from the French occupied zone to Silesia and occupied parts of Russia.

CONSTANCE ROURKE'S recent death went largely unnoticed, yet it was one of the most unfortunate calamities that could have befallen American criticism. Ten years after its publication her "American Humor: A Study of the National Character" remains the soundest and freshest interpretation of the growth of a native American literature that we have.

Archibald MacLeish, assistant director of the Office of War Information and Librarian of Congress, returned to this country from England yesterday after spending two weeks there during which he organized a London branch of the OWI.

POTTSTOWN, Pa., Aug. 5 (AP)--A one-day-old walkout which virtually shut down operations at the Bethlehem Steel Company plant here ended tonight as strikers voted to return to their jobs with the 7 A.M. shift tomorrow.

Recent unfavorable fuel oil developments give additional force to my recommendation, which the New York State War Council is now considering, that it establish promptly a State Fuel Administration along the lines of a similar 1917-18 World War State agency.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 -- Proposals for setting up a system of grade labeling on all dyed fabrics were issued today by the Federal Trade Commission in one of the first moves to extend such labeling into the textile field.
Every parent realizes early in the game, as the highly inaccurate euphemism goes, how important and desirable it is to win the respect, admiration and, if possible, the affection of his children.

Basic wardrobes for the teacher, the teen-aged and college girl were displayed yesterday at a fashion show at John Wanamaker. The Butterick designs emphasize simplicity and practicability. The dresses were all cut within government regulations, yet in such a way as to appear full and allow free action.

A petition for a rehearing in the wage-hour case against the A.H. Belo Corporation, publishers of The Dallas (Texas) Morning News, has been filed with the United States Supreme Court by the Solicitor General, acting on behalf of L. Metcalfe Walling, administrator of the wage and hour division of the Department of Labor, Mr. Walling announced yesterday.

BOSTON, Aug. 5 (AP) -- Mayors of fifty East coast cities asked today for the appointment of a single fuel-oil czar to relieve a shortage in seventeen Atlantic coast States which, some of them said, could not be overcome through voluntary sharing by nonrationed States.

An appeal to members of the All-India Congress party to put aside their efforts for Indian independence at this time and to give whole-hearted support to the warring United Nations was made public here yesterday by a committee headed by Herbert Agar, editor of The Louisville Courier-Journal.

Two new films will arrive in Broadway theatres this morning. At the Capitol, the newcomer will be "Tarzan's New York Adventure," with Johnny Weissmuller again playing the title role. Maureen O'Sullivan, Johnny Sheffield, Paul Kelly and Chill Wills are featured in the Metro action drama, the last in the series at that studio

VICHY, France, Aug. 1 (Delayed) (UP) -- The German Gestapo has broken up a spy ring operated by a married woman, the mother of several children, which informed the British by portable short-wave radio of the imminent departure of three German warships from Brest, and has sentenced eleven of its members to death, reports from Paris disclosed today.

CHUNGKING, China, Aug. 5 (U.P.) -- American bombers yesterday blasted wharves, warehouses and ships at Hankow, Japanese-held Yangtze River port, United States Army headquarters announced today. United States fighter planes and anti-aircraft guns destroyed at least three Japanese raiders over Kweilin, Kwangsi Province capital today.

IT seems that Clark Calvin Griffith, also called The Fox, is going ahead with his program of baseball-at-all-hours down in Washington, D.C., but Horace Stoneham and his Giants are going back to the old routine of afternoon games for the duration. Some magnates never were for night baseball or twilight baseball from the start. There never has been a night game at Braves Field, Fenway Park or the Yankee Stadium.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 -- Miss Elizabeth Reynard, recently Professor of English at Bernard College, was commissioned as assistant director of the Women's Naval Auxiliary Reserve by Rear Admiral Randall Jacobs and was immediately assigned to assist Lieut. Comdr. Mildred McAfee with the training program for women reservists.

Stocks and commodities were bogged down yesterday by the heaviness of the war news and the inroads suffered in the first hour of trading were never rectified. Prices were whittled fractions to more than a point in the first hour, the heaviest period of the session, and, although the closing was quiet, values were around the lows of the day.
The Hungarian Chief of Staff has resigned, allegedly for reasons of health, and thirty-three staff officers have been expelled from the Rumanian army, a British broadcast reported yesterday.

LOS ANGELES, Aug. 5 -- Mrs. Bert Friedlob, who was known on the screen a few years ago as Jeanette Loff, died in a Hollywood hospital last night of ammonia poisoning. Beverly Hills police said that she took ammonia Saturday morning, either accidentally or intentionally.

In your recent editorial "Inflation Is Taxation" you developed a brand new but evidently correct viewpoint on inflation and its effects. You referred to the inflation that we experienced after the first World War, which caused a depreciation of 50 per cent in all our life insurance policies and a 50 per cent depreciation in all our savings.

A dinner was given last night on the Starlight Roof of the Waldorf-Astoria for the Bolivian Minister of Finance and Senora Joaquin Espada and Bolivian Minister of National Economy Albert Crespo, by Simon I. Patino, Bolivian Minister to Vichy, and Senora Patino, who were unavoidably detained in Canada.

Representative Hamilton Fish, Republican Representative from President Roosevelt's home district, declared in a campaign broadcast over WJZ last night that he would "rather win the war" than be re-elected but that he would be disappointed if he did not receive more votes than "all three of my opponents combined" in the primaries in Orange, Dutchess and Putnam counties next week.
RYE, N.Y., Aug. 5 -- The finest array of tennis talent to gather for any tournament of the season to date started play today in the Eastern grass court championships at the Westchester Country Club.

An Austrian baron and a visitor from Canada won the men's national bridge pair championship yesterday in the American Contract Bridge League's sixteenth annual tournament under way at the Park Central Hotel.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 -- Norman H. Davis, National Chairman of the American Red Cross, announced today that "substantial relief supplies" for American war prisoners of Japan in the Far East were now en route on the exchange ship Gripsholm, and that a cargo has been assembled and will be dispatched on a relief ship as soon as arrangements for its safe conduct can be obtained.

TRENTON, N.J., Aug. 5 (AP) -Miss Ruth Strouse, 24 years old, of Lumberville, Pa., a clerk in a Trenton rationing board office, was released today on her own recognizance by United States Commissioner Marvin A. Spaulding to await Federal grand jury action in the alleged theft and sale of gasoline rationing coupon books.
Among families having cases of celiao disease there is considerable anxiety over the possibility of being unable to procure bananas for such cases.
JERUSALEM, Aug. 5 -- Wartime construction has revealed another historic find to be added to the many antiquities already uncovered in this part of the world.

MOSCOW, Aug. 5 -- An article by an officer of the inner security services, reprinted from the Leningrad press by the Moscow Pravda, gives several examples of how the Germans sought to undermine Leningrand's morale last Winter when the severe cold placed the beleagured citizens under an unprecedented strain.

The property formerly occupied by the New York Pie Baking Company at 629-35 East Fifteenth Street and 642-44 East Sixteenth Street has been sold by Louis A. Nettleton, who acquired it under foreclosure of a mortgage of $110,000. It consists of three and five-story brick buildings from 100 feet on Fifteenth Street and fifty feet on Sixteenth Street.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 5 -- More than thirty Coast Guardsmen and service men from units stationed in this vicinity were guests of honor this afternoon at the third in the series of entertainments arranged for them at the Southampton Beach Club. Young women of the Summer colony acted as hostesses at the supper and dance that were held after a swimming party and beach games.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 -- Special measures to ensure the safety of women working in plants producing weapons of war were suggested today by the Women's Bureau in a bulletin entitled "Hazards to Women Employed In War Plants on Abrasive-Wheel jobs."

A call for more volunteer auxiliary firemen was made yesterday by assistant chief John J. McCarthy as an information booth and recruiting center for Civilian Defense volunteers was dedicated in the War Stamp window of Bloomingdale's, Sixtieth Street and Lexington Avenue.

Total market value of shares listed on the New York Stock Exchange rose $1,024,758,117 last month, according to a compilation issued yesterday by the Exchange. Average price per share of all listed stocks on July 31 was $23.42 compared with $22.73 at the end of June.

BERNE, Switzerland, Thursday, Aug. 6 -- Four days of fierce fighting in Northeastern Bosnia has ended with the withdrawal of Bulgarian forces from several strategically important positions, according to General Draja Mikhailovitch's communique received here today.

TORONTO, Aug. 5 (AP) -- George Washburn and Joe Page unfolded a couple of four-hit pitching jobs against the Maple Leafs tonight, to pace the Bears to 3-2 and 7-1 triumphs for an even split of a six-game series.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 -- A campaign to enroll 66,000 eligible nurses in the Red Cross first reserve for service with the armed forces, regardless of civilian needs, was initiated today at a joint conference held by Norman H. Davis, chairman of the American Red Cross; Major Gen. James C. Magee, Surgeon General of the Army, and Rear Admiral Ross McIntire, surgeon general for the Navy.

Aided by the willingness of union officials to make wage adjustments where necessary to facilitate obtaining war orders by the New York garment trades and to alleviate unemployment in the metropolitan area, local raincoat manufacturers planned to bid today at the Philadelphia Quartermaster Depot on production of 1,000,000 raincoats currently sought by the Army.

As the result of representations by leaders of the right wing of the American Labor party that a letter from her had been used in behalf of left-wing candidates, Mrs. Eleanor Roosevelt, wife of the President, has declared that she recognizes the right wing under State Chairman Luigi Antonini as the real leadership of the Labor party.

The city of Boston awarded yesterday a new issue of $3,000,000 of notes to the First Boston Corporation and the Chemical Bank and Trust Company on their joint bid of an 0.57 per cent basis. The notes will be dated Aug. 7 and will be payable on Nov. 6, 1942.

LONDON, Aug. 5 -- In a White Paper published today, the British Government formally and finally repudiated the Munich agreement whereby the Sudetenland was wrested from Czechoslovakia and ceded to Germany as the price of "peace in our time."
