BUFFALO, N.Y., Aug. 6 (AP) -- The Bisons scored a 4-to-3 victory in the opener of a double bill, then lost, 4 to 0, as they opened a series of five games with Jersey City tonight.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 6 -- Army preparations to take the offensive advanced today with disclosure of the formation of two divisions of troops to be moved into battle by planes and gliders, and creation of a new American-Canadian super-commando unit.

Only four years have passed since those uneasy August days when the Runciman mission sat in Prague while a forgotten man named Konrad Heinlein, now buried in the scrap heap of Hitler's discarded tools, was stirring up trouble in the Sudetenland. The war for Europe had already begun, but the statesmen who watched the storm gathering still hoped they could curb his growing appetite by throwing sops to Cerberus.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 6 -- In open court today Lieut. Comdr. Maurice N. Aroff denied a Navy charge that he "did wilfully, knowingly, wrongfully and corruptly ask, accept, receive and take" from Tony Martin, radio and screen singer, a $950 automobile for "facilitating" Martin's enlistment as a chief specialist in the Navy.

LONDON, Aug. 6 (AP) -- The increase of 9,168,000 in note circulation for the week ended yesterday was the highest since the Christmas seasonal advances in December, 1941, the Bank of England weekly condition statement showed today, and placed the total at a new record high of 833,316,000.

Though reputedly poor, our enemies seem to have sufficient metals, oils and munitions to take any place almost at will, while to judge by the alarms coming from our priority boards, in a land of plenty we have a scarcity of almost everything necessary for a like result.
MOSCOW, Friday, Aug. 7 (AP) -- Last midnight's Soviet communique follows:

WASHINGTON, Aug. 6 -- Records of thirteen underwriters' organizations have been subpoenaed by a Federal grand jury at Atlanta to see whether prosecution of some 300 stock fire insurance companies shall be undertaken under the Sherman Anti-Trust Act.
DETROIT, Aug. 6 -- Max Stephan must die for treason against the United States, despite his boast that "Germany will not let me hang."

Allan Sproul, president of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York and chairman of the Victory Fund Committee for the Second Federal Reserve District, announced yesterday that the committee, with the approval of the Secretary of the Treasury, had appointed Laurence G. Payson as assistant executive Victory Fund manager for this district, and Francis T. Ward as vice chairman of Region 8, which includes Manhattan and the Bronx.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 6 -- Department store sales for the week ended Aug. 1 declined 6 per cent as compared with the like week last year, the Federal Reserve Board reported today. For the four weeks ended Aug. 1, sales were 3 per cent above a year ago.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Aug. 6 -- In case of a German victory every European nation would be forced to buy everything from the Reich at arbitrary prices. Likewise no European nation would be allowed to export anything before needs of the commodity were fully satisfied -- the Germans to be sole judges in both cases.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 6 -- Neva-Wet Corporation of America, 500 Fifth Avenue, Neva-Wet Bottling Company, Inc., of 683 Fifth Avenue, New York, and Samuel Howard Lefkowitz and Irving Lefkowitz, officials of both companies, have been charged by the Federal Trade Commission with misrepresentation.

The dispute over India has passed the point where logic or consistency can have much weight. It does not matter whether a completely unbiased court would say that the Congress party under Gandhi and Nehru, the Moslems under Dr. Jinnah, or the British Government as represented by Stafford Cripps comes nearest to being right.

Five resident buying exporters have filed a brief with the Post-office and War Departments petitioning for an amendment or modification of the Postmaster General's order and subsequent interpretative ruling restricting the size and number of parcel post packages accepted for export, it was revealed yesterday by Charles Ballon of Hartman, Sheridan Tekulsky, counsel for the exporters.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 6 -- An agreement for bringing Mexican agricultural workers into the United States to fill the wartime demand for farm labor has been concluded with the Mexican Government by the State Department, it was announced tonight.

We feel that Bertrand Russell's letter in THE TIMES of Aug. 5 has completely misrepresented the present move of the India National Congress. Dr. Russell does not seem to realize the forces that have driven the Congress to take this step.
Among the apartment rentals reported yesterday was one to Count Wladimir Czaykowski in 823 Park Avenue. He is on the staff of the Polish Consulate General.
CAIRO, Egypt, Aug. 6 -- United States workmen engaged in one of the greatest mass salvage operations in naval history have completed a huge project that doubters said could not be done.

Senator James M. Mead, favored by President Roosevelt for the Democratic nomination for Governor, twice yesterday repudiated support at this time by the left wing of the American Labor party, alleged by its right wing leaders to be communist, and expressed confidence in the present right wing State organization of the party, which endorsed him for Senator in 1938 and 1940.

CHICAGO, Aug. 6 -- Hardware stores, which in recent years have seen the drug stores invade their field, are getting ready to give the drug stores competition in the sales of such items as tooth paste, shaving supplies, stationery and various drug sundries that can be sold without a drug license.

Purchase of both the dramatic and screen rights to a new stage version of Count Leo Tolstoy's "War and Peace," produced recently in Moscow, was announced yesterday by Alexander Korda. The new play adaptation was written by I. Sundakov, a director of the Malik Theatre Group of Moscow.

Two men holding quite different views about Army service appeared before Federal Judge Matthew T. Abruzzo in Brooklyn yesterday. One was sentenced to two and one-half years in a Federal prison camp as a draft evader, the other got a promise of a suspended sentence if investigation verified his story that he was wearing an Army uniform because he had been unable to find work since his discharge for physical disability.

MIAMI, Aug. 6 -- Months of planning, organization and work have completed the second phase in transforming the waters east, south and west of this city into their vital function as a highway for transport of essential materials needed to feed the war machine of the United States.

SOUTHAMPTHON, L.I., Aug. 6 -- Many women of the Summer colony will act as supervisors in the surgical dressings workrooms of the Hampton Chapter of the American Red Cross. which will be opened here on Monday morning. Mrs. Charles Morgan and Mrs. Cecil Fairbank are co-chairmen of the program for the Hampton Chapter, which also has workrooms in East Hampton, Westhampton, East Moriches, Bridgehampton, Mastic, Quogue and Center Moriches.

Sales of $263,808,670 reported by the National Dairy Products Corporation in the semi-annual statement of L.A. Van Bomel, president, established an all-time high record and were 32 per cent over the $199,857,290 volume for the first six months of 1941.

CULVER, Ind., Aug. 6 (AP) -- For the tenth consecutive year the national junior tennis singles crown will go to a Californian. This was assured today when four Golden State players in the national junior tennis tournament forced all other competition to the sidelines as they advanced through the quarter-finals.

Three government witnesses testified in Federal court yesterday that Werner von Clemm, importer, had told them shortly after Germany's conquest of Belgium that he could bring diamonds into this country from Belgium.

ALBANY, N.Y., Aug. 6 (AP) -- Lieutenant Governor Charles Poletti, who will direct the writing of the Democratic party's 1942 State platform, declared today it will not be a "one-man political essay" and called upon the public for ideas.

Mrs. John Jacob Astor, chairman of the Navy League Center, and her executive committee gave a t and reception at 270 Park Avenue yesterday for the donors of equipment for a new mpbile canteen unit, which the league will operate in this city under orders of the Third Naval District headquarters.

CHICAGO, Aug. 6 -- Overriding a unanimous recommendation from its international officers and executive board, the United Automobile Workers Union, at a stormy convention session today, voted down a proposal to raise monthly dues from $1 to $1.50 to build up a "post-war reserve fund" and extend organizing.
Sales of properties by institutions featured reality trading in Manhattan yesterday.

Yesterday's statement of the twelve Reserve Banks showed holdings of United States Government securities to be the highest on record, having increased $192,481,000 during the past week. Note circulation was also the highest for the year, while ratio of reserve was at the lowest.
LONDON, Aug. 6 -- The stock markets today saw business dull and prices, where changed, lower. Gilt-edge issues were firm. The 3 per cent war loan gained 1-16 at 102 3-8.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 6 -- The War Production Board has approved a plan for the construction of 500 seventy-ton Mars flying boats as cargo carriers and the construction, on a experimental basis, of a 200-ton twin-hull flying boat.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 6 -- The Office of Defense Transportation will allot new school buses to school districts according to a plan formed by the National Council of Chief State School Officers, calling for the reorganization of all routes to eliminate duplications, less-than-capacity loads and unnecessary trips.

WASHINGTON, Aug 6 -- In unprecedented and colorful ceremonies, President Roosevelt today transferred from the United States Navy to the Royal Netherlands Navy a 173-foot steel submarine chaser which was named the Queen Wilhelmina and put in commission by the Queen herself.

Another of the long succession of Treasury calls was announced yesterday when the Treasury notified depositary commercial banks in the New York Federal Reserve District that it will withdraw $74,186,000 on next Monday and a like amount the following day.

CHICAGO, Aug. 6 -- Expressing regret that this country has "only a handful of women physicians and surgeons" when they could be used to free men doctors for military services Dr. R.R. Spencer of the National Institute of Health, Bethesda, Md., predicted today that medicine holds a great opportunity for the women of America.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 6 (U.P.) -- The Agriculture Department today disclosed plans for the sale of 125,000,000 bushels of government-owned wheat to livestock and poultry producers at prices of from 74 to 99 cents a bushel.
NEWARK, N.J., Aug. 6 (AP) -- George Washington appeared for induction into the Army today, but was turned down.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 6 -- Technical Sergeant Robert L. Golay, 22 years old, of Fredonia, Kan., who returned to the United States from Great Britain last Sunday, told reporters here today of his experiences during the first American bombing attack on Nazi-held positions in the Netherlands on July 4.

A thousand persons attended a freedom for India rally last night at the Town Hall under the auspices of the Post-War World Council and applauded leaders of Chinese, Indian and American liberal thought who demanded immediate freedom for India to win her nearly 400,000,000 people as active allies of the United States.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Aug. 6 (AP) -- Age triumphed over youth today in the national skeet championships when H. Lutcher Brown, veteran Texas gunner, won a 50-target shoot-off for the 20-gauge title with 20-year-old Dick Shaughnessy.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Aug. 6 (AP) -- Colonel Bob Neyland, head coach of the Eastern All-Army football team, wasted no time today in telling his squad of tanned soldier huskies that he "hated to lose," and, he promptly added, "I don't propose to lose."

LONDON, Aug. 6 (U.P.) -- Yugoslav patriot forces, using two captured German Junkers-88 dive bombers, have seized two more towns, one of them only fifty-two miles from Zagreb, capital of the puppet State of Croatia, and have killed several hundred Axis troops, Allied sources reported tonight.

HONOLULU, Aug. 6 -- Three Army flying officers, who headed a crew of ten that took a Flying Fortress over Wake Island last Friday [Saturday at Wake] on a special mission and knocked down four of six attacking Japanese fighters, sat in the lounge of an Air Corps rest camp at Oahu Beach today and told how they did it.

Indian nationalists, bent on self-government now and not later, as the British have promised, have allowed their zeal in distrusting the British to reach a point where many intelligent Indians meet all explanations and offers with completely closed minds.

AFTER taking time out to give three cheers for High-Up Hank Greenberg, Allan Tolmich and Chuck Fenske, three notables of the sports world who recently won their way to commissions in the Army Air Force, this observer plunged into a paper-covered book just received, the same being G.I., as the boys in camp would call it, or Government Issue spelled out.

PEEKSKKILL, N.Y., Aug. 6 -- The Twenty-second Regiment of the New York State Guard, a New York City unit of 702 officers and men, was reviewed at Camp Smith this evening by Mayor F.H. La Guardia on the eve of the outfit's departure after a ten-day training encampment.

Because of her faith in democracy and its guarantee of equality of opportunity, Miss Elsie D. Papajohn, a 22-year-old Brooklyn girl of Greek parentage, will sponsor a new naval vessel tomorrow -- and thus realize what she says has always been her "fondest wish."

The girls of the Women's Army Auxiliary Corps Band were still without a piccolo player yesterday, and still dejected over the failure of the lone applicant who could play that instrument to pass the physical examination. But their gloom was lightened considerably when two pairs of sisters, one of them twins, applied for enlistment in the band.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 6 -- Queen Wilhelmina of the Netherlands told a joint session of Congress today that the motto of her government-in-exile and the Dutch people generally was "no surrender," even if most of her people were now under the Axis yoke.

LONDON, Aug. 6 -- When the Allied Armies attempt to batter their way through Adolf Hitler's Continental defenses they may be headed by an American general, it can be said today with almost as much certainty as anything in wartime.
BAY CITY, Mich., Aug. 6 (AP) -- Coast Guard rescue of two more survivors has written a final chapter of the tragic adventure of thirteen persons whose fishing cruiser capsized in Saginaw Bay Sunday.

BOSTON, Aug. 6 -- Bill Butland, who spends most of his time sunning himself in the Red Sox bullpen, came out of semi-retirement today and shut out the Athletics, 2 to 0, for his first victory of the season.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Aug. 6 -- The first effect of the new coast dimout regulations, affecting territory up to 150 miles inland from the Pacific, has been to cause a switch at Columbia from night to day shooting on "The Desperados," a Technicolor subject.

CAIRO, Egypt, Aug. 6 -- Officers of United States forces, acting as advisers and instructors, played a small, but valuable part in the maintenance and repair of United States-built and British tanks during recent battles in Cyrenaica and Egypt.

Representative Hamilton Fish Jr. characterized as "a direct falsehood" yesterday a copyrighted story published in the Washington Post which stated that the Representative was "trying to explain to the government why he never paid income taxes on a secret fee of $25,000 he got from General Rafael L. Trujillo, dictator of the Dominican Republic, in 1939."

Bank clearings for the twenty-three principal cities of the nation during the week ended on Wednesday aggregated $6,875,059,000, an increase of 10.5 per cent from the volume of the preceding week and of 9 per cent from the $6,309,923,000 total of the corresponding week a year ago, according to the report of Dun Bradstreet, Inc., announced yesterday.

Justices Frederick L. Hackenburg, Bernard A. Kozicke and Thomas F. Doyle in the Appellate Division of Special Sessions granted yesterday a certificate of reasonable doubt to Moses Elisberg, 45 years old, of 532 East 171st Street, the Bronx, on his thirty-day workhouse sentence by Magistrate Robert Davis in the Bronx Magistrate's Court for criticizing the government's conduct of the war.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., Aug. 6 -Legal proceedings to recover control of the Hudson County Board of Taxation and to prevent the installation of voting machines in the county will be instituted by the forces of Mayor Frank Hague, it was announced today by County Counsel J. Emil Walscheid.

One excursion the visitor to Beirut is sure to take is to Dog River to the northeast, as the Arabs call what to the Greeks was Wolf River. It runs through a narrow ravine into the Mediterranean. This was the pass by which invading armies escaped the hills.

Writing in "The Changing Indian," a book just released by the University of Oklahoma Press, John Collier, Commissioner of Indian Affairs, reports that the Indian is a fast increasing race in the United States and in the Western Hemisphere as a whole.

CHUNGKING, China, Aug. 6 (AP) -- The Chinese High Command said today that its forces were attacking a chain of outposts that the invaders had established between the port of Wenchow and the Kiangsi-Chekiang rail line to the northwest.

MOSCOW, Aug. 6 -- The enemy force reported attacking in the neighborhood of Kotelnikov is powerful and Stalingrad's defenders face a threat from the southwest, for Kotelnikov lies ninety-five miles in that direction from the Volga city.

In your editorial of Aug. 1 "In Free Bosnia" you stated that the guerrillas under the command of General Draja Mikhailovitch destroyed port installations on the Dalmatian coast and raided Zagreb, capital of Croatia.

EAST WILLISTON, L.I., Aug. 6 -- A match of cards decided the championship today in the twelfth annual best-ball tournament of the Long Island Golf Association and gave the title to Ray Torgerson and Norman Files. The Lakeville Country Club team, last to finish, scored a gross of 70, and their handicap of four gave Torgerson and Files a net of 66, which two other teams had equaled.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 6 -- President Roosevelt vetoed today the synthetic rubber bill sponsored by the farm group and established his own fact-finding committee, headed by Bernard M. Baruch, to investigate the rubber situation with a view to determining the need for nation-wide gasoline rationing and other alleviative measures.

Joseph J. Randazzo, 21 years old, of 247 Elizabeth Street, was committed to the Tombs yesterday by Magistrate Thomas A. Aurelio in the Homicide Court on suspicion of being one of three men who shot and fatally wounded Frank Servido of 7 Pitt Street in the hold-up of a poolroom at 1 Pitt Street on May 16.

CHICAGO, Aug. 6 -- The American Federation of Labor's pact with the British Trade Union Congress for establishment of an Anglo-American trade union committee and interchange of delegates was no "back-door agreement" and should constitute no obstacle to the pending labor peace negotiations between the A.F.L. and the C.I.O., William Green, A.F.L. president, said today.

MELBOURNE, Australia, Aug. 6 -- A statement yesterday by William Morris Hughes, leader of the United Australia party, that criticized the defensive character of United Nations strategy in the Southwest Pacific, stressing the steady Japanese extension in Northeast New Guinea and Papua, caused vigorous discussion at a meeting of the Advisory War Council today. The Ministers and Opposition members disagreed on the extent to which the strategy should be more aggressive.

CHICAGO, Aug. 6 (U.P.) -- Thurman Arnold, assistant United States attorney general in charge of the Anti-Trust Division, will come here to prosecute the government injunction suit against James C. Petrillo and his American Federation of Musicians, Daniel Britt, special assistant to Attorney General Biddle, said today.

"Goofy" togs are gone so far as the college girl is concerned. She wants and is going to get only good, wearable, practical clothes. As a group of collegiennes sauntered by yesterday on Saks Fifth Avenue's runway, it appeared to us that they are going to look discreetly boyish in their everyday togs and prettily feminine in their off-campus hours.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 6 -- Andrew Schuttinger, who has had considerable success at the meeting with his wife's horses, saddled Carillon today to capture the featured Elizabethtown purse for J.M. Roebling, breeder of the daughter of Case Ace.

Preliminary tests of new plastic duplicate printing plates in newspaper plants, intended to relieve the shortage of metals, are now being completed by the Theodore Moss Company, 33 Flatbush Avenue, Brooklyn, it was announced by the company yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 6 -- Complaining that one of the hardest things to find in investigating the problems of steel shortages was an administrator who knew where he was going, Senator Truman, chairman of the committee investigating the defense program, urged today that Donald M. Nelson, War Production Board chief, "take the bull by the horns and cut off a few heads" in his organization.

A medium-sized United States merchant ship with 406 men, women and children aboard, was torpedoed and sunk by a submarine in the Gulf of Mexico late last month with the loss of twenty-five lives and numerous injured, the Navy disclosed yesterday.

Musk-laden perfumes are just the ticket for sparkling-cold Winter days or for gala evenings, but when the humidity is creeping toward the saturation point, a heavy clinging scent is decidedly off key. Sweet pea, lilac, violet, lily of the valley and honeysuckle essences are more to the point, wafting a welcome breath of the country to frazzled city dwellers.

Speedy mobile formations of the German Army, striking southwestward from Voroshilovsk across the Kuban River in the northern slopes of the Caucasus, have cut the railway that winds from Baku to the Black Sea, the German High Command said yesterday, according to Berlin broadcasts recorded by The Associated Press.

Eva Tanguay, once among the highest paid of vaudeville performers, has just celebrated her sixty-fourth birthday in a sick-bed in Hollywood with the remark "I'll get well. I'll walk again." She hasn't stirred from bed for four years.

WITH THE BRITISH EIGHTH ARMY, in Egypt, Aug. 6 -- Almost by definition, a period of lull in war is when official communiques mention patrol activity. Yet only comparatively speaking does a lull mean a calm or imply a suspension of hostilities -- far from it.

Sales of war bonds and stamps in stores in greater New York in July amounted to $6,187,000, William M. Holmes, president of Bonwit Teller and chairman of the retailers' committee of the New York War Savings Staff, announced yesterday.

In a nation-wide Gallup survey, the results of which are announced today, voters were asked: "Do you think that Roosevelt and Churchill should have the final decision on the military and naval plans of the war, or do you think these plans should be decided by the military and naval leaders of the United Nations?"

Trading interest in stocks slackened to such a degree yesterday that prices were hardly ruffled, and this in spite of the discouraging news from the Russian front. The lack of any real selling again indicated to Wall Street that securities are in strong hands, and the small amount of buying was represented as coming from investment sources.

LONDON, Aug. 6 -- The British Secretary for War, Sir James Grigg, announced in Parliament today that a Palestine regiment consisting of separate Jewish and Arab infantry battalions was to be created at once for general service in the Middle East.

CHICAGO, Aug. 6 (AP) -- Edgar Smith, the most unfortunate pitcher in the majors, today received solace for his ill luck as he won his third game of the season by holding the Tigers to six hits while the White Sox blasted out a 4-to-1 victory.

Prisoners of war interned in Germany are now guarded by cripples and old men, and the camps are administered by women, according to information collected from liberated prisoners of war and made public here by France Forever, the Fighting French movement.

Upset victories by unseeded teams eliminated two of the favorites from the running last night in the national masters' contract bridge team tournament which, with other bridge championship contests, is under way at the Park Central Hotel.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., Aug. 6 (AP) -- With returns from heavily populated Shelby County (Memphis) giving him a heavy majority there, Governor Prentice Cooper took the lead tonight in his contest for renomination against former Representative J. Ridley Mitchell in the Democratic primary.

CAIRO, Egypt, Aug. 6 -- British artillery opened up a bit yesterday against Axis gun emplacements, infantry positions and truck concentrations in the northern and central sectors of the Egyptian front, and, in the center, German guns replied.

OTTAWA, Aug. 6 -- The formation of a combined special United States-Canadian force for offensive warfare was confirmed here by Defense Minister Ralston, and he gave some further details of Canada's share.

BUFFALO, Aug. 6 -- After circling Buffalo Airport for eight hours while its crew struggled to repair a damaged landing gear, a giant Curtiss Commando transport (C-46) plane made a "belly" landing just before 7:30 o'clock tonight without injury to its seven occupants.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Aug. 6 -- A fight for control of Hollywood's camera men has flared on Twentieth Century-Fox's production, "My Friend Flika," now on location in Utah.

LONDON, Aug. 6 (Reuter) -- When Germans tried to cross the Manych River, tributary of the Don, "it rose in fury in tempestuous floods devouring man and country and swept over the invaders." This description was broadcast by the German war reporter Horst Slezina on the Berlin radio tonight.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 6 -- The text of Queen Wilhelmina's address to Congress today was as follows:

RYE, N.Y., Aug. 6 -- Francisco (Pancho) Segura of Ecuador and Alejo Russell of Argentina made their exits from the singles in the Eastern grass-court tennis championships at the Westchester Country Club today as play was brought to the semi-final round in the men's and women's divisions.
LONDON, Aug. 6 -- British bombers roared to an attack over the Ruhr again last night and also dropped explosives in other parts of Western Germany.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 6 -- The Yankees' advance upon the Potomac, which followed on the heels of their sweep through the West, ended on a rather extraordinary note tonight as the world champions plunged down to their second nocturnal defeat in three days.
All that Manager Mel Ott and his Giants needed was to get away from that twilight-arclight nonsense from which they had suffered for three consecutive evenings.

Declaring that inflation could be as great a national calamity as a successful invasion by enemy troops, Miss Elizabeth Thomas, of the rent division of the regional office of price administration, urged women last night to use all their power to make Federal rent control effective.

BRIARCLIFF MANOR, N.Y., Aug. 6 -- The boys from Syracuse, twelve strong when the New York State junior championship got under way at the Briar Hills Golf Club today, were still in command after the first two match play rounds were completed.

WEST MILFORD, N.J., Aug. 61 -- The only practicing physician in this Passaic County lake resort township has been called to active service with the Army Medical Corps, and unless the Army Procurement and Assignment Service redeems what one of its officials termed a "moral obligation" to find a replacement, the community will be without the services of a doctor for the duration of the war.

CLEVELAND, Aug. 6 (AP) -- Telephone subscribers encountered delays in placing tool calls and getting information today as hundreds of women operators employed by the Ohio Bell Telephone Company in Northeastern Ohio joined 2,100 maintenance and repair workers on strike for higher pay.

Until July 4 the Japanese had it pretty much their own way in the skies over China. The Chinese had neither planes nor anti-aircraft guns. They had to fight chiefly by night for fear of strafing from the air. Lacking aerial observation, they could only guess where the enemy was concentrating for the next attack.

ALBANY, Aug. 6 -- In one of several eleventh-hour decisions in election cases, the Court of Appeals today denied to Professor Louis A. Warsoff of Brooklyn permission to appeal from an Appellate Division order which was adverse to Dr. Warsoff.

BAY SHORE, L.I., Aug. 6 -- Outstanding today in Great South Bay's fourth session of its Race Week was the Star Class contest. Bill Picken, Atlantic Coast champion, won with his Fo Fo after an uphill struggle that kept the accompanying spectator craft close at hand.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 6 (AP) -- The International Wheat Council has instructed its secretariat to make a comprehensive report on measures being taken by each country to control wheat production, the State Department said today.

The American Contract Bridge League will lead an effort by the nation's card players to supply a $500 scholarship for the child of any American soldier, sailor or marine killed in the war, William E. McKenney, league secretary, announced yesterday during the sixteenth annual national contract bridge tournament, which is being held this week at the Park Central Hotel.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 6 -- Assured of wage and hour concessions by their workers, representatives of twelve of the largest raincoat manufacturers in the New York area conferred here today with officers of the Quartermaster Depot regarding contracts for making 1,000,000 raincoats for the Army.

By vetoing the bill of the farm bloc, which called for a separate authority to control the production of rubber from crops, and by appointing a commission which consists of Bernard Baruch, Dr. James B. Conant and Dr. Karl T. Compton to recommend a solution of the rubber problem, the President has taken a step of which the public will approve.

ON THE INDIAN-BURMESE FRONTIER, Aug. 6 (AP) -- Along the monsoon-swept coast of Arakan, in Lower Burma, Japanese Army outposts are isolated and appear powerless immediately to seize any military advantage from India's threatened civil disobedience against continued British rule.
PRINCETON, N.J., Aug. 6 -Both Prime Minister Churchill and President Roosevelt have been criticized for trying to plan and direct too much of the war strategy themselves.
The following German High Command communique was broadcast yesterday from Berlin and was recorded here by The Associated Press:
WASHINGTON, Aug. 6 (AP) -- Death has been decreed as the penalty for "bad actors" in the Yellowstone.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 6 -- William H. Davis, chairman of the War Labor Board, has proposed that President Roosevelt act soon to control all voluntary Wage increases of a general nature in order to supplement the wage adjustment policies of the board, which he felt would be negated if employers were permitted to make wage adjustments at will.

The Phelps Dodge Corporation and its subsidiaries had a consolidated net income of $5,532,999 in the six months ended with June, Louis S. Cates, president, disclosed in the semi-annual statement issued yesterday.

Electric companies are beginning to use in place of copper wire triple strands of steel, twisted like manila cord and so strong that it may be strung from poles 600 feet apart without danger of breaking from ice formation, the service organization of the Electric Bond and Share Company disclosed yesterday.

LONDON, Aug. 6 (AP) -- A "most urgent warning" that Netherlanders who aided Allied landing parties or as much as showed themselves on the streets in event of an Allied invasion would suffer a blood bath was sounded by German military authorities in the Netherlands today.

WESTPORT, Conn., Aug. 6 -- Amos R.E. Pinchot, noted New York attorney and publicist, is a patient in the Norwalk Hospital as a result of an attempt to end his life Tuesday evening at the home of Mr. and Mrs. William P. Eno on Shore Road in the Saugatuck district of Westport, it was learned tonight.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 6 (AP) -- The Department of Agriculture announced today prices at which it would sell 125,000,000 bushels of government-owned wheat for feed to encourage greater production of livestock, dairy and poultry products for the war.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 6 -- Creation of an Army Transportation Corps of the Services of Supply, "to coordinate, direct, and speed the flow of men, equipment, and supplies into the war effort," was announced today by Robert Patterson, Under-Secretary of War.

LONDON, Aug. 6 (U.P.) -- Women's Volunteer Services are "indispensable" in government plans for civilian resistance to any invasion thrust aimed at London, Sir Ernest Gowers, the capital's senior regional commissioner, said today.

A 34-year-old civilian inspector assigned to the sub-assembly division at the Navy Yard in Brooklyn was arraigned before United States Commissioner Jacob A. Visel in Brooklyn yesterday, and freed in bail of $1,000. The defendant, Samuel Sheber of 2724 Pitkin Avenue, was accused of having sought a bribe of $2,500 from a contractor on whose work he had to pass judgment.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 6 -- The text of President Roosevelt's message vetoing the bill to promote the production of synthetic rubber from grain alcohol was as follows:

Mrs. William H. Davis of 130 East Seventy-fourth Street and Washington, will leave this week to spend the remainder of the season at Peckett's, Sugar Hill, N.H. Mr. Davis, who is Chairman of the National War Labor Board, will join her there later this month.

MONTREAL, Aug. 6 (AP) -- After Newark had taken the first game of an International League double-header, 13 -- 4, tonight, Chet Kehn of the Royals pitched a six-hit, 2-0 shut-out to gain an even break for Montreal.

Despite the rapid development of air transportation, we cannot expect cargo planes to replace merchant ships in this war, or even to take over the major share of the burden of overseas transportation. There are many considerations that militate against any such development.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 6 -- Secretary Knox officially asked the Senate Naval Affairs Committee today to investigate statements made by Senator Truman of Missouri about the manner in which the Bureau of Ships dealt with Higgins Industries, Inc., of New Orleans.

An acute shortage of beauty shop operators, which has already placed curls at a premium in boomtowns throughout the country, is making itself felt even in New York, according to officials of the National Association of Cosmetologists and Hairdressers.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 6 -- Among those who are serving as patronesses of the victory bargain box at the Grand Union Hotel, sponsored by the Saratoga branch of Bundles for America, are Mrs. Hiram C. Todd, Mrs. Robert T. Stone, Miss Edyth McCoon, Mrs. Chauncey Olcott, Mrs. Sydney J. Smith, Mrs. George Alexander McKinlock and Mrs. Edward Maguire, all of New York.

PITTSBURGH, Aug. 6 -- Lamdris Ford, 16-year-old Negro roustabout of Pittsburgh, confessed today to District Attorney Russell H. Adams that he and another Negro started the $200,000 fire in the animal tent of the Ringling Brothers and Barnum Bailey Circus in Cleveland Tuesday.
Fishermen who will hereafter limit their activities to bay fishing in Long Island waters along the south shore need not obtain Coast Guard identification cards.

SOMEWHERE IN AUSTRALIA, Aug. 6 -- The most discussed topic in Australia today is the supply question. Have enough fighting men been sent here from the United States? Have enough military supplies been sent? Are enough planes coming over and are they the right types?

TORONTO, Aug 6 (AP) -- Ben Hogan, crack shotmaker from Hershey, Pa., set a blistering pace in the first round of the Canadian open golf tournament today with a record-breaking 65 over the Mississauga Club's 6,543-yard championship course.

Federal Reserve support of the market for government securities in the week ended on Wednesday resulted in the purchase by the Open Market Committee of the Reserve System, acting for the twelve central banks, of $192,481,000 of these securities, mostly short-term.

Allie Stolz defeated a champion last night. The Newark battler, recognized as leading challenger for the lightweight crown, registered an easy triumph over Chalky Wright, ruler of the featherweight division, in the star bout of ten rounds at Madison Square Garden.

Gustave Kotanyi's production of Johann Strauss's operetta, "The Gypsy Baron," which was presented with marked success in June at the Cosmopolitan Opera House, came to performance last night at the Lewisohn Stadium, where it attracted an audience of 8,000.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 6 -- W.J. Schieffelin Jr., appearing for the Chamber of Commerce of the State of New York, today told the Senate Finance Committee that it would be better to have no tax bill at all until after the election, "rather than a bill to go into effect in September or October dominated by election politics."

BOMBAY, India, Aug. 6 (U.P.) -- Mohandas K. Gandhi announced tonight at the zero hour of the Indian independence crisis that he would make a last appeal to the British Government to avoid conflict and that if the response were favorable, there might be some basis for negotiations.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 6 -- Marked advances in wholesale prices for foods not controlled by the Office of Price Administration largely accounted for an increase of 0.2 per cent in the Bureau of Labor Statistics Index of prices of 889 series in primary markets during the last week of July.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 6 (AP) -- The Federal Circuit Court of Appeals held today that Henry Steers, Inc., owes the parents of Vito Cifrondello, 15, of Newark, N.J., damages of $1,675 for his death by drowning Aug. 7, 1936. The decision, written by Judge John Briggs Jr. was unanimous.

Advertising linage for eight New York newspapers for the first seven months, totaling 50,860,038, was down 7.4 per cent from the 54,957,571 for the corresponding period of 1941, according to an analysis yesterday. Losses ranging from 3.04 per cent to 18.47 per cent were registered by seven of the group, while one morning newspaper showed a gain of 0.76 per cent.
BERNE, Switzerland, Aug. 6 -Great nervousness in both occupied and unoccupied zones of France was reported tonight in private advices.

HARTFORD, Conn., Aug. 6 -- Gerhard Kunze, father of the Bund leader, Gerhard Wilhelm Kunze, told a Federal jury today that the Rev. Kurt E.B. Molzahn of Philadelphia asked him last February to make his son stop using Mr. Molzahn's name "in the mails."
LONDON, Friday, Aug. 7 (AP) -German bombers were reported to have dropped their new-type phosphorus fire bombs in a short, sharp attack on an East Anglian town early today.
Three theatres in Rockaway Beach, Queens, have been sold to the Perial Amusement Corporation by Da-Gel Enterprises, Inc.

Ferrero's death at this time recalls first his long and steady opposition to fascism, his early dread of dictatorship in Germany. Fifteen years ago Mussolini denounced him as "an anti-Italian, anti-Roman, anti-Fascist, anti-everything alive and strong in this Italy." That would be an epitaph honorable enough if Ferrero had no other title to fame.

When the National Theatre Conference gets the Otto Harbach-Oscar Hammerstein 2d-Jerome Kern "Gentlemen Unafraid," under its new title of "Hayfoot Strawfoot," it will have not an operetta but a play with music. Since St. Louis saw the original some years ago, Mr. Harbach has written new dialogue, and there are new lyrics to the Kern songs.

An appeal for an allocation of contracts on metal work, to be negotiated rather than bid upon in competition with other sections of the country where costs are lower, has been forwarded to the War Production Board by the Coordianted Metal Industries of Greater New York, a pool recently set up to obtain war work, it was announced yesterday.

Activity in the wholesale markets here did not reveal any particular increase this week. Further results of August sales promotions were awaited, but it was becoming clear that trade figures in many areas would run below the peak noted last year.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 6 -- A plan for the acquisition of the Northern Texas Company by the Dallas Railway and Terminal Company, including substantial capital contributions to the latter by the Electric Power and Light Corporation, parent holding company of both subsidiaries, was filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 6 -- New training centers for nurses will be established in "strategic areas" throughout the country with part of a $3,500,000 appropriation for nursing education, Paul V. McNutt, Federal Security Administrator, said today.

AN ADVANCED ALLIED BASE, Southwest Pacific, Aug. 6 (U.P.) -- The Japanese, resorting to many tricks they used in the Bataan campaign, suffered heavy casualties before they captured the tiny airfield at Kokoda, sixty miles from Port Moresby in the mountainous New Guinea wilds, military authorities revealed today.
PORTLAND, Me., Aug. 6 (AP) -- Representative Joseph W. Martin Jr., Republican National Committee chairman, said today:

WASHINGTON, Aug. 6 -- The International Appliance Corporation of Brooklyn, N.Y., today was denied all priority assistance for a period of two months by terms of a suspension order announced today by the director-general for operations of the War Production Board.

The American Laundry Machinery Company declared yesterday an extra dividend of 30 cents and the regularly quarterly of 20 cents a share on the common stock, both payable on Sept. 1. The current declarations bring dividends to $2.20 a share so far this year, against $2.30 in the similar 1941 period.

Brooklyn right wing candidates for delegates and alternates to the State Convention of the American Labor party expressed an overwhelming preference for Senator James M. Mead for the party nomination for Governor at a rally at the Hotel St. George last night.

MOSCOW, Friday, Aug. 7 -- The Russians officially reported today their capture of an "advantageous defense line" in the Don bend battle for Stalingrad, but simultaneously acknowledged that their hard-pressed soldiers had withdrawn to new defense positions in the Caucasus.

ALBANY, Aug. 6 -- The State Health Department coupled a prediction of a record low 1942 death rate today with a warning that further losses of its physicians and technicians to the military service would weaken public health services.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 6 -- At her first press conference, and the only one ever held here by a reigning sovereign, Queen Wilhelmina assured a group of newspaper women today that, although overwhelmed by force, the people of the Netherlands had never submitted and never would, that with great courage they were enduring present suffering, privation and loss, and that with undiminished fortitude they would proceed to rebuild their lives and fortunes when they came back.

Applications for commissions with the WAVES, the women's reserve of the Navy, are arriving at a rate of 800 a day, it was announced yesterday by the Office of Naval Officer Procurement, 33 Pine Street. Four thousand letters have been received.

Here's a share-the-car plan that is highly successful with a group of young suburban matrons. One afternoon the women, all neighbors, got together and each made for herself a little white flag on a staff. Now when any one of them is planning to take her car to go on any errand she plants her white flag on the front lawn.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 6 -- A proposal for closer coordination between this country's War Shipping Administration and the shipping officials of other United Nations was made here today by business men who complained that the regulations of the War Production Board and the WSA concerning cargoes which vessels may bring into United States' ports are far more stringent than those of Allied nations.

A Japanese Imperial Headquarters communique said yesterday that the Japanese had occupied the Kai, Tanimbar and Aroe groups of islands and thus had advanced to within 300 miles of Australia and 150 miles of Northwestern New Guinea, according to a Japanese broadcast recorded by The United Press in New York.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 6 (AP) -- Two daring rescues of fifteen stranded Army airmen from the bleak and treacherous ice cap of interior Greenland were disclosed by the Navy today in an announcement crediting the accomplishments to Lieut. Col. Bernt Balchen of the Army and Lieutenant A.Y. Parunak of the Navy.
ITHACA, N.Y., Aug. 6 -- Problems of women workers in war industries were examined today at a conference at Cornell University.
ITHACA, N.Y., Aug. 6 -- Problems of women workers in war industries were examined today at a conference at Cornell University.
MOSCOW, Saturday, Aug. 8 (AP) -- Last midnight's Soviet communique follows:
There seems to be considerable confusion in the local press as to the status of the American chess championship. I should like to summarize the facts for your information.

Development of a new American war standard designed as a control in mass production was revealed yesterday by the American Standards Association. This standard, it was stated by P.G. Agnew, secretary of the association, shows the manufacturer how he can keep continuous check of his production processes by means of a quality control chart.

AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, Australia, Aug. 7 (AP)--General Douglas MacArthur was described today by Norman Stockton, correspondent of The Melbourne Herald, as an "offensive-minded" leader who "has been placed in the position where apparently he cannot take the offensive."
The following German High Command communique was broadcast yesterday from Berlin and was recorded here by The Associated Press:
John Kieran's article "Skeet Gets a High Rating," which appeared in THE TIMES recently, is very timely and covers the situation perfectly.
CHICAGO, Aug. 7 -- An unexpectedly large number of merchants this week attended the first of the two Fall market weeks here and estimates of buyer attendance and purchases were today revised upward.

HEWLETT, L.I., Aug. 7 -- Posting a score of 71, one under par, F.W. Beardslee of the home club and J.B. Cornell Jr. of Forsgate captured the medal today in the eighth annual invitation-member golf tournament for the Arthur Man Memorial Plaque at the Seawane Club.

For the second time at a White House press conference President Roosevelt came yesterday to the support of Senator James M. Mead, candidate for the Democratic nomination for Governor, in answering the charge of State Chairman James A. Farley that Senator Mead in a speech in 1941 had shown an isolationist tendency.

MOSCOW, Aug. 7 (Reuter) -- Facing immense hazards, week after week, to bring British and United States convoys into harbor with arms for the Red Army, Soviet submarines in the Arctic have already sunk 107 German ships, totaling 547,000 tons -- the bulk of them since December.

Strong opposition to the proposed rule of the Securities and Exchange Commission under which dealers would have to reveal the best independent markets to their customers when making trades has been expressed by District 13 of the National Association of Securities Dealers.

It would be fitting for President Manuel Quezon of the Philippines to warn Mohandas K. Gandhi against underestimating the reality of the Japanese menace, and there is some indication that a cable was duly forwarded to the Hindu leader yesterday.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 7 -- Thurman Arnold, head of the anti-trust division of the Department of Justice, indicated in the Federal District Court today that the government would file anti-trust suits against the Radio Corporation of America, General Electric Company, American Telephone and Telegraph Company, and others in the communications field.

BAY SHORE, L. I., Aug. 7 --With a plentiful supply of a stirring mixture of nitrogen and oxygen, and with powder puffs overhead and slaps of water underneath, ninety-six starters, the largest number so far, were out today in the fifth session of Great South Bay Race Week.

CHUNGKING, China, Aug. 7 (U.P.) -- United States Army headquarters announced today that American bombers had wiped out at least ten Japanese planes on an airdrome near Canton yesterday, while the Chinese High Command reported the killing of more than 1,000 Japanese soldiers in Kiangsi Province and north of Hankow, where a munitions train was blown up.
The twilight contest at the Polo Grounds on Monday night between the Giants and Dodgers was a patriotic and financial success, but as a ball game it was strictly a flop.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 7 (AP) -- There were plain indications today that the Navy had balked at the plan of Donald M. Nelson to have Henry J. Kaiser go ahead with the building of cargo planes.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 7 o;P) -- Education sources disclosed today a special committee of the War Man Power Commission was considering a proposal for wart/me "democratization" of American colleges through direct money grants to students, as a means of assuring an adequate supply of Army and Navy officer material and other trained personnel for the general war program.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Aug. 7 -- The first picture announced to deal with the training of the Army's new glider pilots will be made by Twentieth Century-Fox, and will be called "Condors of the Air."

CHICAGO, Aug. 7 -- The United Automobile Workers, C.I.O., re-elected today by virtually unanimous vote the union's president, R.J. Thomas, and secretary-treasurer, George F. Addes and voted two administration-backed candidates, Walter P. Reuther and Richard T. Frankensteen, into the newly created posts of vice presidents, but the convention then had a sharp battle before it finally approved a compromise amendment to increase officers' salaries.

CAIRO, Egypt, Aug. 7 -- Assisting the all-out Allied drive against Axis supplies for General Field Marshal Erwin Rommel's army in Africa, heavy bombers of the United States Army Air Forces last night raided Tobruk Harbor, now the premier Nazi port in Africa.

As you are well aware, the only major New York City colleges which have extended their rivalry beyond the diamond, cinder paths and basketball court to the football field in recent years have been Fordham and N.Y.U. Previously, Manhattan and City College had met annually, but with the rapid rise of the Jaspers to gridiron power this contest began to lose importance and was finally omitted from the schedule.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 7 -- Donald M. Nelson, War Production Board chairman, gave the go-ahead signal today for construction by Henry J. Kaiser, West Coast ship-builder, of 500 seventy-ton cargo-carrying planes, modeled on the Mars flying boat built for the Navy by the Glenn L. Martin Company.

AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, Australia, Saturday, Aug. 8 -- Allied bombers, carrying out a heavy raid on the Japanese invasion base at Rabaul, New Britain, yesterday, dropped fifteen tons of bombs on the main Japanese airdrome there, it was announced today.

AT AN ADVANCED ALLIED BASE, Australia, Aug. 7 (U.P.) -- Lieutenant Robert G. Rose of Roaring Springs, Texas, owes his life to a pair of devil-may-care privates who braved crocodiles, Japanese bullets and fire to drag him from his blazing plane after it had crashed on a New Guinea river.

In their sermons tomorrow clergymen of the New York area will point out that there is no "ceiling" on religion and will stress that it is more necessary than ever with a world at war. Preachers will comment on the developments in India and the attitude of Mohandas K. Gandhi, who, although not a convert to Christianity, has for his only decoration in the hut in which he lives "a small framed painting of Christ."

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Aug. 7 (AP) -- Digging into the bag of tricks he used at Tennessee, Head Coach Bob Neyland of the Eastern All-Army football team today gave his soldier stars a few of the plays he is planning to use against the New York Giants next month.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 7 -- In a frank discussion of the general war situation tonight, the Office of War Information told the American people that it was still possible that this could be the decisive year of the conflict if we fought it totally.

Of the 1,239 stock issues on the New York Stock Exchange, 402 had short interests at the end of last month and twenty-seven had short interests of 5,000 or more shares or in which there had been a 2,000-share change since the end of June.

The article "Law Student Gets Delay from Army" appearing in THE NEW YORK TIMES states: "Law students and college students who have completed two years of the course and who plan careers in law will be permitted to complete their courses and earn their Bachelor of Laws degrees before entering active military service.''

WHEN the British and the Germans were seesawing back and forth in the battle for Cyrenaica, a wit suggested that a popular song be written around the refrain of "Who's in Bengazi today?" Since that time the spectacular advance of General Rommel has knocked the light-heartedness out of those who think the outcome of the battle for the Middle East will determine the whole course of World War II.

CHICAGO, Aug. 7 -- Lacking hedging pressure or mill buying the wheat market drifted today within relatively narrow limits. Failure of good support to appear on an early upturn led to profit taking by operators who bought yesterday and when increased professional pressure made its appearance prices dipped around 5/8 cent a bushel from the early high.
LONDON, Aug. 7 -- The stock markets continued quiet today and the undertone remained firm. Gilt-edge issdues and home rails were unchanged.

I have read with interest and not a little wonderment the recent statement of Mr. Ickes that householders who are able to convert their heating equipment from oil to coal and do not convert may find themselves as a class refused heating oil.

CHICAGO, Aug. 7 -- J. Loy Maloney, managing editor of The Chicago Tribune, tonight characterized as "outrageous and ridiculous'' the calling of a Federal grand jury to investigate the Tribune and Stanley Johnston, its correspondent, who provided the information in the dispatch which was made the subject of the investigation.

NEW LONDON, Conn., Aug. 7 -This year's edition of the National Amateur Athletic Union men's swimming and diving championships started with a world record mile tonight as twilight swimming came to the handsome plant in Ocean Beach Park.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 7 -- What penalties the eight Nazi saboteurs will pay for their invasion of this country on a mission of destruction remained a mystery today as President Roosevelt continued study of the recommendations of the Military Commission.

LONDON, Aug. 7 -- The nearest approach to good news this country has heard in a long while came today during a speech by Albert V. Alexander, First Lord of the Admiralty, at a luncheon in aid of the Minesweepers Dependents Fund.

Were the shackles of convention not quite so firmly drawn, a good many sophisticates might emulate the Indians and indulge in a rousing corn dance at this time of the year. For ever since the chiefs and squaws decided, with great good judgment, that the golden ear's time of abundance deserved an all-out celebration the height of the corn season has been a period of delight for Americans, redskin or paleface, who enjoy good food.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 7 -- The vagaries of that uncertain sport which is our national pastime claimed Carl Owen Hubbell as a victim tonight, although the Giants hammered out a 6-to-4 decision over the Phils before a gathering of 6,011 at Shibe Park.

Four teams of contract bridge masters won their way last night to the semi-final round of the national masters team-of-four championship, one of the contests being decided in the national bridge tournament at the Park Central Hotel here.
HOLLYWOOD, Aug. 7 (AP) -- Manuel Ortiz of California won the world bantamweight championship tonight by a decisive margin over the titleholder, Lou Salica of New York, in a twelve-round bout.

Police Commissioner Valentine disclosed yesterday that he had taken extra precautions to prevent an influx of gamblers into the city from Yonkers following Governor Lehman's order to officials of that city to investigate allegations of gambling there.

Mayor La Guardia's efforts to amend the McCarthy Salary Increment Law to save a maximum of $1,770,000 in city payroll costs were sidetracked by the City Council yesterday after a five-hour committee hearing in City Hall at which civil service groups joined several Council members in opposing the amendments.

VALLEY STREAM, L.I., Aug. 7 -- A converted delivery truck, reconditioned by the Ford Motor Company and equipped with the latest medical appointments provides the Red Cross Motor Corps of this village with an ambulance to carry out routine assignments in its day to day service and to serve as a mobile hospital unit in an emergency.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 7 -- Queen Wilhelmina of The Netherlands decorated five American naval officers today for gallantry in the battle for The Netherlands East Indies and attended President Roosevelt's press conference where she praised the free press of the democracies as a vital weapon in their struggle for victory over the Axis.

A trap he inadvertently set for himself, according to the police, resulted in the arrest yesterday of 21-year-old William Page Bryant for the hold-up murder of Philip Hochman, Bronx grocer, on Tuesday.
The leasing of eighteen apartments in London Terrace featured rental activity yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 7 -- A statement that a West Virginia sheet steel plant, the Parkersburg Steel and Iron Company, described as capable of producing 2,500 tons of material monthly for tanks, armored cars, airplane hangars, shipyards and other war essentials, is in danger, despite steel shortages, of shut-down and liquidation for lack of business, was made to the Senate committee investigating the defense program today by John M. Budke, president of the concern.

A total of $16,577,100 of new bonds is scheduled for award next week by twenty-six municipalities and one public housing agency. This compares with $3,980,148 this week and with the weekly average for the year to date of $24,500,393.

RYE, N.Y., Aug. 7 -- The two players who met in the final of the women's Eastern tennis championship last .year faced each other in the title round of the national tournament at Forest Hills. There is the prospect that history will repeat itself in 1942.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 7 -- A compilation of Congress' fiscal activity showed today that the staggering sum of $205,514,657,286 had been appropriated or authorized for expenditure between June 1, 1940, and June 30, 1943, to provide the country's defense and war needs.

BERNARDSVILLE, N.J., Aug. 7 -- Mrs. Philip Cudono of Crestmont easily won low gross honors in the weekly one-day tournament of the Women's New Jersey Golf Association by playing perfect golf to card 39, 36-75 over the Somerset Hills course today.
ST. LOUIS, Aug. 7 (AP) -- Airplanes of paper were envisioned today by the McDonnell Aircraft Corporation as a partial answer to the industry's critical shortage of aluminum and steel.

NEWARK, N.J., Aug. 7 -- The Enemy Alien Hearing Board here has recommended to Francis Biddle, United States Attorney General, that three members of the German-American Bund whose citizenship was canceled by court action be interned for the duration, E.E. Conroy, agent in charge of the Newark office of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, disclosed today.

LONDON, Aug. 7 -- Urgent conferences on means to save Russia now as an essential to winning the war were reported in session at Moscow today among strategists and diplomats of the United Nations. This information came from sources whose identity could not be disclosed.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 7 -- Wayne Lyman Morse, dean off the University of Oregon Law School and a public member of the War Labor Board, declared today that unauthorized and outlaw strikes have been on the increase, and that while they have not reached serious proportions, "they nevertheless are shocking to national morale and thoroughly in conflict with the nation's war effort."

Revold Molski, survivor of a topedoed ship, said yesterday that he had been shocked by the "apathy" of New Yorkers toward the war. A tall, lean, weatherbeaten man of about 40, with a wife and two children, Molski spent four months as a construction worker on Army bases in Trinidad.

MOSCOW, Saturday, Aug. 8 (U.P.) -- German armored forces have slashed eighty miles deeper into the Caucasus to the area of Armavir, railway and pipeline city at the gates of the Maikop oil field, and have stormed past Kotelnikov on the road to Stalingrad, less than 100 miles distant, a Red Army communique said today.

WESTPORT, Conn., Aug. 7 -- The condition of Amos R.E. Pinchot, 68-year-old New York lawyer and publicist, was reported "still critical" this afternoon by Dr. Eugene Beck, who is treating the attorney in the Norwalk Hospital for injuries reported to have been self-inflicted.
The first service flag to appear on "Steamship Row" on lower Broadway was broken out yesterday at noon on the second-floor flagstaff of 1 Broadway, office of the United States Lines.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 7 -- The leadership of the country in the war effort has been "far from brilliant,'' it was charged today in an editorial appearing in the Catholic Standard and Times, publication of the Archdiocese of Philadelphia, which also urged that "something should be done about it."

The American Locomotive Company reported yesterday for the six months ended on June 30 a net profit of $2,551,731 after provision for normal and surtax rates of 45 per cent and excess profits tax at the rate of 90 per cent, as provided in the revenue bill passed by the House on July 20.

While retail trade here responded to cooler weather conditions this week, comparison was with the extremely high sales figures a year ago, when departmnt-store volume for this city showed an increase of 47 per cent over 1940. Accordingly, a decline of substantial proportions, possibly 15 per cent or more, was anticipated.

MELBOURNE, Australia, Aug. 7 -- Australian newspapers, discussing General Douglas MacArthur's headquarters' reply to criticism of the defensive character of Allied strategy in the Southwest Pacific, strongly deprecate assumptions of invincibility in New Guinea such as have repeatedly preceded disasters in the earlier stages of the Pacific war.
LONDON, Aug. 7 -- Duisburg was blasted again, the Air Ministry reported today on operations by the Bomber Command of the Royal Air Force over German territory last night.

A story from Vichy a few days ago told of the "thriving" business of the Paris dressmakers. What remains of the once famous haute couture has obtained special privileges from the Nazis for the use of textiles, and manufactures luxurious dresses at prices for which the sky is the limit.

MONTREAL, Aug. 7 (Canadian Press) -- Catcher Aaron Robinson's triple with the bases loaded in the eighth inning was the blow that enabled the Bears to defeat Montreal, 6 -- 4, in an International League game tonight.

In your editorial of Aug. 3 you condemn the bad drivers. I do not deny that some drivers are reckless, nor do I have any knowledge of the statistics you quote, but one thing is certain. The average driver stops at red lights ninety-nine times out of a hundred and, especially in these times when gasoline is hard to get and tires irreplaceable, the great majority of the drivers do keep to a safe speed.

LONDON, Aug. 7 -- Another warning that Japan is gathering her forces for an attack on the Eastern Maritime Provinces of Russia was voiced today by a Chinese spokesman. He was Dr. George K.C. Yeh, director of Chinese information here.

Title to the three-story and basement dwelling at 38 East Third Street, southwest corner of Second Avenue, has been conveyed by Mrs. Esther Hart Hawks and Sarah Hart to the 38 East Third Street Corporation through the Harris Management Corporation.

Though the game was started early the National League-leading Dodgers almost ran into the Army dimout at Ebbets Field last night. As it was, they met a dimout of another sort when the Braves beat them, 2 -- 1, in eleven innings behind the courageous pitching of A1 Javery.

Cutting through the so-called "confusion" resulting from the apparent conflict between the Hollowell act restricting discounts on wholesale liquor sales in this State and the regulations of the Office of Price Administration, liquor wholesalers and distillers have worked out a "compromise" under which it will be possible to observe both laws, it was learned yesterday.

TORONTO, Aug. 7 (AP) -- Little Ben Hogan, the big money and shot maker from Hershey, Pa., needed 71 strokes today in the second round of the Canadian open golf tourney and reached the halfway point with a total of 136, one stroke behind Ralph Guldahl and Craig Wood, who tied for first place.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 7 -- New corporate financing in June sagged to what many observers here feel is somewhere near the irreducible minimum, it was disclosed today in a consolidated tabulation of all securities dealings compiled and made public by the Securities and Exchange Commission.

CHUNGKING, China, Aug. 7 (U.P.) -- The influential newspaper Ta Kung Pao, reflecting China's great concern over the Indian crisis, today urged the All-India Congress committee at Bombay to avoid "extreme action" as Abbot Tai Hsu, supreme leader of Chinese Buddhists, took Mohandas K. Gandhi to task for even considering negotiations with Japan.

The Public Service Commission announced yesterday that it had ordered the Long Island Railroad Company to restore Train No. 38 to its original schedule, effective with the new September timetable, so that it will again stop at Bay Shore in Suffolk County.

Reports of Monday night's baseball game at the Polo Grounds stated that for the first time in the history of the park spectators were permitted to stand on the field to watch a regular league contest.

A final book by Guglielmo Ferrero, the Italian historian who died in exile in Switzerland a few days ago, will be published by Putnam Sept. 11. It is "The Principles of Power" and completes the trilogy of which "The Gamble" and "The Reconstruction of Europe" were the earlier studies.

Yesterday will go down in history to 110 prospective members of the New York City Police Department as a day of utter confusion. They may never learn just what happened, but they will not be alone in their bewilderment, for some high ranking police officers are also confused and somewhat embarrassed.
BUFFALO, Aug. 7 (AP) -- The Bisons tonight defeated the Jersey City Giants twice, 3 to 2 and 7 to 2, to make it five victories in their last six starts.

BRIARCLIFF MANOR, N.Y., Aug. 7 -- Douglas Ford, 19-year-old Green Valley representative who has been playing sensational golf in the metropolitan area the last few years, today gained the final round of the annual New York State junior championship for the third time in three years.

In all its statements the Administration continues to view the prospects of inflation with grave concern, but in its actions it continues to add fuel to the inflationary fires. While one branch of the Administration talks solemnly of "stabilizing" wages, another branch keeps boosting wage rates, and if it cannot find one argument for doing so it finds another.

Emil K. Ellis, counsel to the City Council committee that investigated the Municipal Civil Service Commission and Paul J. Kern, its former president, filed two causes of action in Supreme Court yesterday to collect fees and expenses incurred in the investigation, which were disallowed by Controller Joseph D. McGoldrick on July 21.

NEW DELHI, India, Aug. 7 (U.P.) -- The British Government of India today forbade the closing of shops or restaurants, under penalty of fines and imprisonment, in what was regarded as a direct challenge to Mohandas K. Gandhi's projected civil-disobedience campaign.

Air Marshal Harris's broadcast to the German people, in which he warned them that their country would be reduced to rubble "city by city" unless they overthrew Hitler, has evoked criticism in England. In the House of Lords one member denounced it as "un-British' boasting.

Mrs. Winthrop Aldrich, vice chairman of the Greater New York Civilian Defense Volunteer Office, criticized yesterday those women with plenty of spare time who refuse to participate in volunteer defense work. She spoke at the Pershing Square Information Center and the address was carried by station WNYC.

CHICAGO, Aug. 7 -- A motion to dismiss the anti-trust suit brought by the government against James C. Petrillo, president of the American Federation of Musicians, and eight other officers was filed today in District Court by the union attorneys, Joseph A. Padway of Washington and Henry A. Friedman of New York.

Philip Licht, treasurer of Wagnet Memorial Lutheran College, Staten Island, for the last six years, was arrested yesterday afternoon at his home in Rockville Centre, L.I., on a bench warrant issued by District Attorney Farrell M. Kane of Richmond Country, on a charge of grand larceny in the first degree.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 7 -- Mrs. Rodgers Denckla gave a dinner with dancing tonight at The Galley for Mr. and Mrs. Angier Biddle Duke of Washington, D.C., who are visiting Air. Duke's mother, Mrs. T. Markoe Robertson, and Mr. Robertson at Wyndcote.

CHAUTAUQUA, N.Y., Aug. 7 -- Reserves rather than profits are the chief concern of business and industry since the country has been at war, Walter D. Fuller, chairman of the board of the National Association of Manufacturers, declared here today before the Chautauqua Institute Assembly.
BOMBAY, India, Aug. 7 -- Following are excerpts from Mohandas K. Gandhi's speech today:

Unable to supply its dealers with complete vacuum cleaners, Landers, Frary Clark, manufacturers of the Universal machine, has worked out a program offering parts needed to keep existing machines in service, and will distribute newspaper mats to its authorized outlets for their use in promoting the new service, it was announced yesterday.
NEWARK, N.J., Aug. 7 (AP) -- A last-minute rush of landlords seeking to file rent forms has forced the OPA to set two additional days for registration.

TRENTON, Aug. 7 (AP) -- Production on large war contracts was halted in some departments and slowed in others by a work stop-page today at the cable and wire plants of the John A. Roebling's Sons Company in the community of Roebling, near here

A letter from Werner von Clemm to one of his European representatives, intercepted by the British censors at Bermuda, was introduced as evidence by United States Attorney Mathias F. Correa yesterday at von Clemm's trial in Federal court.

Sinking of the Uruguayan merchant ship Maldonado by a German submarine, the commander of which forced the freighter's captain, at machine-gun point, to submit to being taken prisoner, was reported yesterday at Hamilton, Bermuda, by thirteen survivors who had drifted five days before being rescued.

LONDON, Aug. 7 -- Outside the old Covent Garden Opera House, which has been converted into one of the biggest dance hails in London, two stalwart young women, wearing khaki uniforms and bright red caps, can be seen walking to and fro. On the other side of the street a pair of British soldiers, similarly capped in red, also are slowly walking.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 7 -- Even War Production Board officials are amazed at the way the supply of silk stockings has lasted, although production has fallen 93 per cent in the year since the freeze order was sent out.

Tiny fragments of capsules believed to have contained tear gas were found last night on the floor of an Independent subway car, furnishing a clue to two mysterious attacks that brought tears to the eyes of hundreds of passengers on the Eighth Avenue line yesterday morning and afternoon.

For the first time since September, 1939, no new issues of bonds were offered here for public subscription this week. Last week a single issue for $1,200,000 was marketed. This week, a year ago, six issues aggregating $8,306,100 were offered.
BOSTON, Aug. 7 (AP) -- The Commercial Bulletin will say tomorrow:

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 7 -- A plan for the dissolution of the Traction Light and Power Company, and one other subsidiary of Midland United Company, was approved today by the Securities and Exchange Commission.

MOSCOW, Saturday, Aug. 8 -- The mechanized columns of Col. Gen. Paul Ludwig von Kleist have struck deeply southward in the Caucasus, and early today the Russians announced that fighting was going on north of Armavir, which is on the Kuban River and in the Caucasus Mountain foothills.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 7 (AP) -- A chestnut son of Blenheim II out of Annie Gowdy brought $7,500 as the yearling thoroughbreds consigned by the Claiborne Stud Farm of Arthur B. Hancock of Paris, Ky., were sold at the annual Saratoga Springs sales tonight.

The British Government's announcement Thursday of the formation of a Palestinian armed force was decried yesterday by Pierre Van Paassen, chairman of the Committee for a Jewish Army of Stateless and Palestinian Jews, 535 Fifth Avenue, as "not an answer to the demands for a Jewish army."

BOMBAY, India, Aug. 7 -- In the setting of a canvas pavilion fitted with electric fans and a public-address system, Mohandas K. Gandhi called on his nationalist followers today to rise with him in an unprecedented mass campaign of civil disobedience aimed at driving the British out of power in all India.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 7 -- President Roosevelt endorsed today a War Production Board campaign to build up a stockpile of 17,000,000 tons of steel scrap to insure uninterrupted production of steel, the No. 1 war metal, in 1943.

Describing the tin-can collection record of this city as "extremely bad," Nathan M. Ohrbach, newly appointed chairman of the Tin-Can Salvage Committee, announced yesterday the formation of a citizens' committee to reorganize and revitalize the salvage campaign, and set next Wednesday as the day on which a mammoth collection campaign in the five boroughs of the city will open.

BERNE, Switzerland, Aug. 7 -- According to private advices from France, the shooting of Henry Gachelin, secretary-general of Jacques Doriot's French Popular party for the Department of the Seine-et-Oise, may be considered symptomatic of the trend in the occupied zone.

Signers of war bond pledges who designated banks as the places of purchase will receive "reminders" from the banks if they fail to fulfill their promises, it was reported yesterday from war bond headquarters, 1270 Fifth Avenue.

Mattie is gone now. She Good-Bye succumbed to offers of to Mother's higher wages in war Helper work or has taken a job vacated by the same incentive. At first her leaving seemed like disaster itself. Now a calmer view can be taken.

WEST POINT, Aug. 7 (AP) -- Two thousand cadets, the entire corps save for the 400 plebes who entered the military academy on July 15, depart tomorrow by motor convoy and train for a week of manoeuvres with the Fourth Armored Division at Pine Camp, N.Y.

A noon-day rally in aid of the Army Emergency Relief was held yesterday on the steps of the Sub-Treasury Building at Wall and Nassau Streets, on the 153d anniversary of the founding of the War Department by President George Washington on the same site.

The U.S. Atlantic tuna tournament, originally scheduled for Aug. 17 and 19, has been canceled. The competition was slated to be held on a telegraphic basis, but Chairman Walter F. O'Malley has announced that for various reasons the event will not be held again until "the first season after victory has been achieved."

PATERSON, N.J., Aug. 7 -- A man with no record his birth or parentage received a "birthday" today from Common Pleas Judge Joseph A. Delaney under what is believed to be the first application of a new State law permitting the issuance of birth certificates to American-born persons of unknown parentage.
Next week's list of Summer theatre tryouts is briefer than it has been in recent weeks, to date including only the following:

WASHINGTON, Aug. 7 -- Emil Schram, president of the New York Stock Exchange, asked the Senate Finance Committee today to modify the capital gains tax in the pending revenue bill to encourage holders of capital assets to take profits and thus increase Treasury receipts.

General expectations of a rather high estimate of the cotton crop in the government's report due this morning induced traders to inject selling pressure on the cotton market late yesterday, causing prices to recede from earlier gains that had accrued from covering operations of New Orleans interests, commission houses and locals.

Right in the continental United States we are losing a major battle. It is the battle of accidents. William A. Irvin of the United States Steel Corporation, head of the War Production Fund to Conserve Manpower, points out that since the beginning of the war the Nazi Luftwaffe has killed 43,300 British civilians by air raids, while in 1941 we killed 102,500 fellow-Americans through accidents alone.

LOS ANGELES, Aug. 7 -- The Japanese invasion of the Aleutians has been costly and will continue to be costly to the enemy, said Artemus L. Gates, Assistant Secretary of the Navy for Aeronautics, here today on a visit to the aircraft plants.

To the thousands of week-end golfers who feel pretty pleased when they break 100, the kind of golf that is being played in the Canadian open tournament at Toronto is just plain miraculous. In the first round at the long, 6,543-yard Mississauga Club course nine players turned in cards of 70 or better, while Ralph Guldahl and Craig Wood were tied at 66 and Ben Hogan capped the climax with a 65.

Measures that may bring dimmed-out New York City into close approximation of blacked-out London were in evidence yesterday as white paint was applied in rectangular patches along the curbing of city streets designated for military use.

Interest in the field of finance in the last week centered primarily in the latest subscriptions to the Treasury's "tap issue" and in the sale by the government of $1,500,000,000 of seven-eighths of 1 percent certificates of indebtedness. There were no flotations of new bonds for sale to the public by State or municipal bodies or by corporations, a condition unequaled since the outbreak of the war in Europe in September, 1939.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 7 -- Vagrancy maintained her victorious stride today, but only by virtue of a disqualification which brought cheers and boos from many of the 6,779 persons who watched the running of the sixty-third Alabama Stakes, which stretches back to Civil War days.

The sixteen-family, apartment house on a plot 50 by 100 feet at 1610 Bedford Avenue, Brooklyn, was sold by J.G. Janson to a client of the Bulkley Horton Company, co-brokers in the deal with G.L. Turner. The property is assessed for $48,000.
