VICHY, France, Aug. 7 (U.P.) -- Henry Gachelin, close collaborator of pro-totalitarian leader Jacques Doriot and secretary of the French Social party in the Seine-et-Oise I Department. died in an Arpajon hospital of gun wounds suffered in l an ambush near his home, it was learned today.

"Bombs Over Burma," in which Anna May Wong, Noel Madison and Leslie Denison are the principals, will be this morning's new film arrival at the Central Theatre. . . . The Rialto has decided to hold over the Laurel and Hardy comedy, "A-Haunting We Will Go," for a second week.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 7 -- President Roosevelt's special committee to survey the nation's rubber situation went to work today on two park benches.

District Attorney Frank S. Hogan and Chief City Magistrate Henry H. Curran became involved yesterday in what may prove to be an uncompromising feud. It concerns the question whether an assistant prosecutor should be stationed in the Jefferson Market Women's Court to handle evidence against prostitutes.

Many a trend has been set because of the college girl's whims. This year it is evident that she has made her will known and that it is being followed. The showing held at the Tailored Woman yesterday afternoon gave added color to the picture that has been developing during the week.

To develop boys who are "tough" physically, the New York City school system has revised its health education program so that high school students will receive training to prepare them for later induction into the Army, it became known yesterday.

BOGOTA, Colombia, Aug. 7 --Dr. Alfonso Lopez was inaugurated President of Colombia for the 1942-46 term today, and in an address to a joint session of Congress he reaffirmed the international policy of the country, stressing the necessity for solidarity, good neighborliness arid cooperation with American countries.

A tract of ten acres fronting on Monmouth Road and Park Avenue, Oakhurst, N.J., and containing three cottages has been sold by the estate of William Campbell Clark to Joseph Deeley through the Joseph G. McCue Agency. This place is said to have been developed by John Wilkes Booth.

PITTSBURGH, Aug. 7 -- With an inference that peace negotiations between the two big labor organizations were stymied before they could be started, Philip Murray, president of the Congress of Industrial Organizations, telegraphed a complaint to the War Labor Board tonight against the American Federation of Labor for alleged failure to establish tribunals to arbitrate jurisdictional disputes affecting the war effort.

On the condition that he read the Bible and also learn the story of the life of St. Francis of Assisi, Mathias Stonitsch, 53 years old, of 1911 Avenue U, Brooklyn, who was found guilty of robbing a church poor box, received a suspension of sentence on a six-month jail term in Coney Island Court yesterday.

ALBANY, Aug. 7 (AP) -- A Statewide training program for a civilian defense driver corps to transport ambulance and rescue squads and supplies in emergencies and to move children from danger zones was approved today by a group of traffic experts.

The map tells the somber story of the battle for the Caucasus. It tells something more. The Nazi tank divisions driving deeper into the isthmus between the Black Sea and the Caspian are like moving fingers pointing up the connection between this front-and the next. In that graphic picture the relation between this bitter contest and the strangely inactive battleground in Egypt is strikingly drawn.

A truce in the battle for possession of the four-story boarded-up brownstone dwelling at 2078 Fifth Avenue, which Langley Collyer and his blind and crippled brother, Homer, have occupied since 1919, was reached after Langley Collyer had walked all the way downtown to see his lawyer.

CHICAGO, Aug. 7 (AP) -- Buyers exerted pressure against hogs weighing more than 240 pounds, which are taking up a larger portion of receipts at the present time, and prices on these types dropped 10 to 15 cents a hundred pounds today. Sows shared the decline of heavy butcher hogs.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 7 -- Wendell L. Willkie will probably leave soon for a flying trip to the battlefronts of the Middle East and Russia, it was indicated today after a long conference with President Roosevelt.

The German High Command reported yesterday that its troops and their Rumanian allies had pushed through the sweltering heat of the North Caucasus to a point within thirty miles of the Maikop oil fields.
LONDON, Aug. 7 -- Compulsory fire guard duty for all British women between the ages of 20 and 45 in Britain's vulnerable areas was announced today by Home Secretary Herbert Morrison.

PITTSBURGH, Aug. 7 (AP) -- The Pirates won their fifth straight tonight with a 13-6 victory over the second-place Cardinals. Pittsburgh went on a splurge in the second inning, scoring eight runs on seven hits.
VICHY, France, Aug. 7 -- Pierre Laval, Chief of Government, reported to the Ministers Council today on his talks with the German authorities on the questions of food supplies and labor.

The Consolidated Oil Corporation reported yesterday for the six months ended on June 30 a consolidated net income of $8,423,448 after all charges, reserves and provision for $6,000,000 United States income taxes, equal to 64 cents each on the 13,128,160 capital common shares.

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 7 (AP) -- Chet Laabs's twentieth home run and Vernon Stephens's twinkling feet, which carried him across the plate from second base on Mike Chartak's infield hit in the eighth inning, helped the Browns to a 3-to-2 triumph over the Tigers tonight.
BUENOS AIRES, Argentina, Aug. 7 -- By order of the government-appointed Mayor of Buenos Aires the film "Secret Agent of Japan" has been banned throughout the Federal capital, it was disclosed today.
MOSCOW, Aug. 7 (AP) -- The Soviet Information Bureau issued this communique today:

The absence of the usual weekend evening-up operations, combined with strength in the industrial leaders, enabled the stock market yesterday to end slightly higher. While the news from the Russian front was a little brighter, the optimism of the dispatches was too limited to bring out any sizable market support.
CULVER, Ind., Aug 7 (AP) -- Dixie annexed two boys' national tennis titles today in the annual junior and boys' tournament.

OTTAWA, Aug. 7 (Canadian Press) -- The wartime rate of the National Hockey League hangs tonight on the case that President Frank Calder presents in a brief he is preparing for Canada's manpower czar, Elliott M. Little.

With reports here indicating the Philadelphia Quartermaster Depot has extended the time for bids on 1,000,000 raincoats sought by the Army until Monday, efforts continued in the needle trades here yesterday to develop broader manufacturer participation in the bidding.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Aug. 7 (AP) --An Army-Navy dual between a keen-eyed ensign and an unerring private, both of whom shattered 100 straight targets, enlivened today's 12-gauge shooting in the national skeet championships.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 7 -- Between twenty and thirty millions of dollars is to be spent by the government on the construction of ore yards and docks at Escanaba, Mich., the dredging of its harbor and the improvement of railroads operating from Escanaba to Superior, Wis., and Ironwood, Mich., to provide a second route for the transportation of iron-ore from the Upper Great Lakes.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 7 -- Two more women were appointed today as officers for the Washington headquarters of the Women's Naval Reserve Corps, and thereby the complement of officers on the administrative staff of WAVES was nearly filled.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 7 -- The prosecution sought to prove today that Lieut. Comdr. Maurice N. Aroff benefited financially through business dealings with Los Angeles men whose sons were enlisted or commissioned in the Navy after seeking his advice.

The 1,150 bond issues listed on the New York Stock Exchange, aggregating $63,992,198,940 par value as of July 31, had a total market value of $61,277,620,583, according to a compilation by the Exchange issued yesterday. As of June 30 there were 1,152 issues, aggregating $61,899,239,025 par value which had a total market value of $59,112,072,945.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 7 -- Stocks of domestic and foreign crude petroleum at the close of the weekend on Aug. 1 totaled 248,336,000 barrels, according to data reported to the Bureau of Mines.
LONDON, Aug. 7 -- British industry's "front line" job, Labor Minister Ernest Bevin has told building trades here, is the housing of American troops.

The steel-making capacity of the United States rose 628,350 net tons in the first half of 1942 through the construction of new furnaces and the enlargement of others, thereby lifting the total to 89,198, 320 net tons annually, according to the American Iron and Steel Institute.
LONDON, Aug. 7 -- British industry's "front line" job, Labor Minister Ernest Bevin has told building trades here, is the housing of American troops.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 7 -- Men's work clothing will have fewer pockets, fewer buttons and buckles and no unnecessary yardage as a result of a limitation order issued by the War Production Board today. Covered by the order are waistband overalls or dungarees, bib-overalls, overall jumpers or coats, one-piece work suits, work pants and work shirts.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 7 (AP) -- Declaring his company was being made the object of a "vicious smear campaign," William S. Farish, president of the Standard Oil Company of New Jersey, today contradicted what he called "reckless assertions" made before the Senate Patents Committee by C.R. Starnes, Texas oil operator.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 7 -- Philip Morris Co., Ltd., Inc., and the R.J. Reynolds Tobacco Company have been charged by the Federal Trade Commission with misrepresentation of Philip Morris and Dunhill cigarettes and Revelation smoking tobacco, in the one case, and Camel cigarettes and Prince Albert smoking tobacco, in the other.

Eager to prepare for war emergencies, 3,616,254 persons, more than the combined number for the previous thirty-one years, completed Red Cross first aid training in the year ended June 30, the organization reported yesterday.

Queen Wilhelmina didn't need to say or do anything more to endear her and her people to Americans, but her three days at Washington have had that effect. Busy days they were. She made a speech to Congress that was a model of clear statement, eloquent without rhetoric. She made a short speech in acknowledgment of the submarine chaser given her, bearing her name and flying the flag of her country.

The approximate status of the municipal bond market is refleeted in the following list of representative high-grade State, city and county bonds legal for savings banks in New York State, now offered by dealers:

WASHINGTON, Aug. 7 -- The publication by The Chicago Tribune and some other newspapers of a news dispatch said to have contained confidential information concerning the Battle of Midway is to be investigated in Chicago by a Federal grand jury.

COLONEL BOB NEYLAND, Corps of Engineers, U.S.A., now has work in progress at New Haven, Conn. Colonel Bob is handling a detachment of the All-Army football team that will play the Giants in New York and the Great Big Bears in Boston come September. Not all of Colonel Bob's assigned officers and enlisted men have reported for duty as yet, but he has gone to work with the men on hand.

HARTFORD, Conn., Aug. 7 -- Two defense witnesses were heard today in the Federal trial of the Rev. Kurt E.B. Molzahn of Philadelphia, accused of conspiracy to violate the Espionage Act of 1917. Adjournment was taken to Monday.

The Most Rev. Francis J. Spellman, Archbishop of New York, who in his capacity as Military Vicar for the Catholics in the Armed Forces of the United States, has been making a tour of some of the Army camps in the Far West and Middle West, is expected home soon.

CHUNGKING, China, Aug. 8 -- American planes inflicted extensive damage on White Cloud airdrome, docks and harbor buildings and destroyed several Japanese planes in a raid on Japanese-held Canton this morning, Lieut. Gen. Joseph W. Stilwell's headquarters announced.

Back on the home heath, the Yankees yesterday required only a few inhalations of the Stadium's exhilarating climate to shake off the lethargy that had settled down Upon them during the last few days of their recent road tour.

IN choosing the years when Louisiana was ruled first by Spain. then by France, and then became a part of the United States through the Louisiana Purchase as a background, the author has selected a complicated setting for her story.

IT is not usually considered a compliment to state, in the argot of show business, that an actor's acting is "strictly from hunger," but it is quite all right in the case of screen actor Sharkey. Nicely regulated hunger is the basic element of Sharkey's style.

AMONG the Summer art colony exhibitions, current or about to open, and not previously mentioned in these columns, is the show of water-colors, oils, sculpture, crafts and work in black and white at the Mystic Art Association. It became current July 13. The exhibition in Mystic (Conn.) will be on through Aug. 22.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 8 -- The President's Committee on Fair Employment Practice of the War Manpower Commission announced today the vacating of findings of discrimination against the Carl L. Norden Company of New York City and the Titeflex Metal Hose Company of Newark.

THERE is a certain charm to Hope Field's novel. "Stormy Present," which is comparable to primitive oil paintings done by ambitious but untutored hands. A tree or a cow is out of focus and the colors blur a little, but the whole succeeds in giving a picture of the painter, if not of the scene.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 8 -- The gasoline and fuel oil shortage in the East Coast States has given increasing concern to government agencies in the last week as time brings closer the problem of heating homes and office buildings and factories this Winter.

MOSCOW, Sunday, Aug. 9 -- The steel net that the Germans are throwing around Krasnodar and Russia's Black Sea ports closed tighter today as the southern battle zone shifted to Kropotkin, a communications hub and center of a rich agricultural district about forty miles nearer to Rostov than Armavir on the Baku rail line. In the Armavir region latest reports indicate a further Russian withdrawal.

Election of thirty-one presidents of the State and Regional Clubs of the Columbia University Summer Session was announced yesterday by Professor Harry M. Ayres, direcor of the Summer Session. Every section of the United States is represented.
The following German High Command communique was broadcast from Berlin yesterday and recorded here by The Associated Press:

IN the beginning this is Bill Griffith's case, but it proves too much for him and he calls on his friend Tony Hunter for help. What has started out to be a simple job of shadowing assumes sinister proportions when a diamond broker named Walter Hager is murdered and some valuable diamonds are missing.

Although government purchases of cotton textiles for the armed forces and lease-lend shipments have declined from their high rate in May, market sources yesterday predicted that this year's output would set an all-time record for the industry.

With the approach of the season for sowing of new lawns and the remaking of old ones the gardener's thoughts turn to the type of lawn he shall put in and what kind of seed to use. But of just as vital importance is the preparation of the soil in advance of seeding, and this is a job that can be done' now.

As fascism has marched across Europe the American motion picture has retreated. After December next, by recent Vichy decree, none can be shown in unoccupied France. None are allowed now in any part of Europe except Sweden, Switzerland, Spain, Portugal, Finland (but one doubts that new films are reaching that tragic little country) and Turkey.

The War Department recently announced that pilots and mechanics for a "grasshopper" air force, to serve as the eyes for the Army's field artillery, will be selected from among officers and enlisted men of the Army Ground Forces. Observation balloons, which previously served as the eyes for this branch of the service, are now being replaced by small, low-powered observation planes.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 8 -- Local Draft Boards have been told that the War Manpower Commission has ruled that metallic and non-metallic mining activity is "essential to the support of the war effort," Selective Service spokesmen made known today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 8 -- The War Department, because of physical limitations and priorities, and to avoid discriminations against families of men serving overseas, has found itself compelled to urge the Congress not to demand the immediate payment of allowances to service men's dependents for which much agitation and action are in progress on and off Capitol Hill.

THE verbal battle which raged for more than a week in the Paramount executive offices as to Vera Zorina's suitability for the role of Maria in "For Whom the Bell Tolls" ended the other day when the studio relieved the dancer-actress of the assignment and borrowed Ingrid Bergman from David O. Selznick.
MOSCOW, Sunday, Aug. 9 (AP) -- Last midnight's Soviet communique follows:

CHICAGO, Aug. 8 -- A walkout of 3,000 unionists is threatened for Monday at the Los Angeles plant of the Aluminum Corporation of America unless wage issues are settled at once, R.J. Thomas, president of the United Automobile Workers-C.I.O., declared here today.

Secondary schools throughout the United States are beginning to introduce two-year courses in the study of American history and the problems facing a democracy, Dr. Erling Hunt, chairman of the history department at Teachers College, Columbia University, declared yesterday.

THE Civil War, of course, ranks high as a favorite theme with our native historical novelists -- though whether it is outclassed by the Revolution, statisticians must decide. Again and again, in fiction, the battles of Shiloh, Antietam, Gettysburg have been bloodily refought, triumphantly re-won, and there is practically no aspect of the War Between the States which has not been covered in exhaustive detail.

Elmer Davis, the writer and radio commentator who recently was appointed director of the Office of War Information, made public yesterday a pamphlet, "Four Freedoms -- the Rights of All Men Everywhere," which he describes as "an attempt to translate into simple details these basic principles for which the American people and the rest of the United Nations are fighting."

At an induction ceremony delayed twenty-four hours so that he could appear, Mayor La Guardia suggested yesterday to 107 rookie policemen that they might do well in their chosen profession if they shunned liquor, gambling, politics, "punks" and the press.
To help civilians get an insight into the mysteries of camouflage, the Museum of Modern Art will open an exhibition on Wednesday devoted to that subject.

No one has mastered the primer of soils without an understanding of one major consideration. Soils are acid, alkaline, or neutral; and flowers and vegetables have preferences as to the one in which they will thrive best.

MELBOURNE, Australia, Aug. 8 (U.P.) -- The Australian Government has agreed to a diversion of United States war supplies to "more urgent places," it was revealed officially today. American supplies were allocated to Australia on a large scale, Prime Minister John Curtin said in a speech replying to reports that Australia was not receiving enough equipment to halt the Japanese southward drive.

Plans for the nation-wide "war on fuel waste" campaign, Aug. 17 to 22, to encourage fuel conservation in the home as well as in industry, were announced yesterday by the American Society of Heating and Ventilating Engineers. The campaign is designed to save fuel and use it more efficiently for power generation and heating in those areas where supplies are short of normal needs.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 8 -- Nine leaders in the American war effort will speak over the Columbia broadcasting network between 2 and 2:30 tomorrow on the critical needs of war production and the Army-Navy production award, the Office of War Information announced today.

LENOX, Mass., Aug. 8 -- Governor Leverett Saltonstall is honorary chairman of the benefit concert for Russian war relief to be given at Tanglewood next Friday. Dr. Serge Koussevitzky, conductor, and members of the orchestra, comprising students of the Berkshire Music Center, are donating their services.

HARRISBURG, Pa., Aug. 8 -- The Pennsylvania Historical Commission is conducting a five-front morale campaign to inculcate a loyalty among Pennsylvanians and a pride in their part in building the nation.

GRANTED that there is not much fun in modern war, this business of making a tank go isn't so bad. Probably there are worse jobs. No doubt there are more exciting ones, like flying, but there are certainly duller ones, too, like potting away in a machine-gun nest or being a plain, ordinary, slogging foot soldier who, in no matter what war, always gets the dirty end of all the sticks.

SINCE circumstances made it unavoidable last week to interrupt the season's honor roll, annually assembled in these columns, in the middle of the L's with a "to be continued" line, let us hasten to relieve the suspense of those dancers whose names begin with letters in the latter half of the alphabet and who doubtless have spent a sleepless week.

I have developed the habit of writing on-the-spot garden notes to myself and it has proved so useful and amusing that I think other gardeners may enjoy it too. I use indestructible green garden labels in a large size and with a soft pencil make memorandums which can be placed in the garden and left there for months at a time.

BOMBAY, India, Aug. 8 (U.P.) -Mohandas K. Gandhi tonight summoned India's millions to rise up in a struggle "for freedom or death" after the full committee of the All-India Congress approved his call for mass passive reistance against British rule.

WITH "Holiday Inn," which brought a gayly festive air to the Paramount last week, Hollywood has again shown that despite its glaring inadequacies in other directions it has the magic touch when it comes to making escapist entertainment.

THE London drama critics are in the middle of the heaviest wave of theatregoing they have enjoyed since the war began. As I write, I have three consecutive visits to the theatre behind me, and five more to go before seeing eight new productions in nine days -- which, you must allow, is good going, especially at this time of year.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 8 -- As Hitler's Panzer legions plowed their bloody path eastward across the Caucasus during the past week, it became increasingly obvious to close observers here that, whether Hitler so prefers or not, his future plans must be laid in the same direction.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 8 -- The War Department issued an appeal today for 100,000 skilled mechanics and technicians, from 18 to 44, to serve in the Air Force, Signal Corps and Ordnance Department. Although they would enlist as privates, the statement said that "in view of their skills, it is expected that most of them will shortly receive non-commissioned officer or techician ratings and rapid promotion may be expected."

The next six weeks may prove to be the most crucial in the war. Hitler's armies have now reached the upper edge of the Caucasus. If he can conquer the Caucasus he has a source of oil supply for Germany and at the same time will have cut off the source of 80 per cent of Russia's supply.

The appointment by President Roosevelt last week of Bernard M. Baruch to head a committee to investigate the rubber situation is considered a constructive step in eradicating some of the public confusion relative to the new synthetic rubber program, the greatest chemical engineering job ever undertaken by any nation.
MONTREAL, Aug. 8 (AP) -- The Royals beat the Newark Bears by 5 -- 4 in ten innings today after trailing most of the way.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 8 -- Slide rules and principles of aerodynamics are all in the day's work for two young women engineers working for the Civil Aeronautics Administration here. They talk of impact resistance, propeller currents and helicopters as familiarly as most women chat about skirt lengths and laundry soaps.

THE eleventh annual National Ceramic Exhibition, which was scheduled to open at the Syracuse Museum in October, has been postponed until a later date. This decision was voted on by the trustees of the museum in view of transportation problems.

With funds on hand to finance the first five months of its $5,424,092 budget for the program year, which started April 1, United China Relief is dependant on campaigns to be held in the late Summer and Fall to complete the program and make possible other important projects now being worked out, Paul G. Hoffman, national chairman, announced yesterday.

The post-war problems of the Forties will exceed in intensity those of the Twenties and call for long-term planning and arduous preparation, Dr. Samuel H. Prince, Professor of Economics and Sociology at Dalhousie University, Halifax, declared last week at a Columbia University Summer Session forum.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 8 -- Olympus and Halberd won Saratoga's two big features, which were eagerly watched today by 13,334, the largest crowd so far this season. Once again the wooden stands looked like the spa of old with many of racing's and the country's most distinguished citizens present for the $7,000 Merchants and Citizens Handicap and the $8,000 Saratoga Special, in which the winner takes all.

LONDON, Aug. 8 (Reuter) -- The crypt of St. Clement Danes church in the Strand, London, which was closed nearly a century ago, has been rediscovered. The church was burned to a shell in one of the big raids in May, 1941. Today E.A. Young, chairman of the Church Council, found the long-forgotten entry to the crypt under a monumental slab in fire-scarred remains of the church.

OMAHA, Aug. 8 (AP) -- Endorsement of a candidate by a labor leader today enlivened the State primary campaign in which chief interest centers on the Democratic and Republican candidates seeking the Senatorial seat now held by George W. Norris.

The International Transport Workers Federation celebrated last week the first anniversary of the opening of its American office in downtown Manhattan. The operations of the organization for the last year have been highly successful and include the forming of three new affiliations and the general improvement of relations with maritime unions of the Latin-American countries.

TUNING in on that WABC-Columbia variety show which takes to the air on Friday nights at 10, a reasonable percentage of the listening audience -- 95 per cent, say -- must be pretty certain that the poky-voiced Herb Shriner is direct from the cornfields of Indiana. They would be partly right about that.

Long before the immediate prospect of killing frosts starts speculation as to what can be saved for bloom indoors the foresighted gardener starts to make provision for his Winter display. Many flowers now in their full glory in the garden provide excellent material for softwood cuttings.

American soldiers and sailors on leave in London are fishing in Hyde Park these Summer days. Transatlantic photographs show them on the banks of the Serpentine, pensively watching their lines, hoping for the best.

HEWLETT, L.I., Aug. 8 -- Close contests were common at the Seawane Club golf course today during the first two rounds of match play in the eighth annual Arthur Man memorial member-guest best-ball tourney. Only two of the day's dozen top-flight duels ended before the eighteenth green.

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 8 (AP) -- Defending fourth place, the Browns defeated Detroit, their closest rival, today, 6 to 4, for their second straight victory over the slumping Tigers, who now have lost five in a row.
BUFFALO, Aug. 8 -- President Roosevelt was characterized here today by Senator James M. Mead as the "leader of the forces of freedom in the war for survival."

LONDON, Aug. 8 -- Now that United States troops have begun to spread into all parts of England, Scotland and Wales, British women are faced with problems of hospitality under increasingly difficult conditions.

"The Noble Years," candid portrait of a woman flower vendor, by Arthur M. Selwyn, took first place in the monthly print competition of the Manhattan Camera Club last week. Judged by J. Ghislain Lootens, F.R.P.S., F.P.S.A., the show was described as one of the best displays of work by an individual club ever presented.

An air-mail cover received by Colonel Hans Lagerloef from Ivar Sellergren, an army captain in Visby, Sweden, brings two stamps, 10-ore red and 90o pale blue, which Sweden has issued to commemorate the establishment of her public school system a century ago.

LONDON, Aug. 8 -- Although the war has changed trade practices here considerably, early August has retained the character of a holiday season. Interest thus has been diverted from immediate problems and post-war reconstruction has come in for some attention.

ONE of the woman guests at a tea party a short time ago was of the busy, rather talkative type. She spoke about her household, her children, her car, the difficulty of getting tires. And "Oh, my dear," she said, "there'll be quite a lot of other things that will get scarce."

THE Chinese philosopher Mencius, a contemporary of Aristotle in the fourth century B.C., was, like his better-known predecessor, Confucius, a man of great wisdom. Among his admonitions to princes was one which might well be recommended to the attention of the totalitarian dictators.

The Ruhr, lighting the sky with hundreds of iron-furnace flares, is a hard mark to miss with a two-ton bomb, even on a cloudy night. In that region, smaller than Rhode Island, crowded with mines, mills, immense cities and an almost continuous forest of smokestacks, three-fourths of the coal of the Reich is mined and an almost equal proportion of the heavy industry of the country established.

BOSTON, Aug. 8 -- John Whitlow Wyatt, who hadn't lost to the Braves since 1940 and had beaten them ten times, had his mastery shattered today when Manuel Salvo, swarthy right-hander, blanked the Dodgers, 2 -- 0, on three hits.
CHICAGO, Aug. 8 (AP) -- The parents of Herbert Hans Haupt, one of the Nazi saboteurs who was electrocuted in Washington today, were not officially informed of their son's death.

THE two literary fellowships offered by Afred A. Knopf for 1943 will be for history and biography. There will be no award for fiction. The value of each fellowship has been increased from $1,200 to $2,500, one-half of which will be an outright grant and one-half an advance against royalties.

The past week's arrivals of stamps from abroad include a limited supply of five British items overprinted "M.E.F." (initials of Middle East Force) in black. They were issued in 1941 for use by civilians in Abyssinia, Cyrenaica, Eritrea and Somaliland, African territories which British troops had wrested from Italian control.

WHEN some future Herodotus delves into the records to write his history of the current war, Yale University will be able to supply all, or nearly all, the answers. For two years now the Yale collection of war literature has been accumulating, and it has assumed such proportions that it promises to dwarf all similar undertakings.

LONDON, Aug. 8 -- Britain is really "sold" on the idea that unity of command alone will provide the means of checking the rate at which the war is now being lost and of eventually winning the conflict. There must be unity within Britain's three fighting services, the British believe, and the same singleness of purpose among the United Nations.
Mrs. Robert King Awtrey, wife of Captain Awtrey, Postmaster General of the United States Navy, is visiting her father, George Flint Warren, at his Summer home in Water Mill.

Though a number of county fairs have been canceled owing to war conditions, the Mineola Fair will be held according to recent announcement, from Sept. 15 to 19, and the New Jersey State Fair from Sept. 27 to Oct. 2 at Trenton. Announcement follows modification of a request from the Office of Defense Transportation made earlier in the season that State and county fairs be abandoned this year to avoid strain on transportation.

Larger proportionate retail trade gains in many smaller cities of the Middle and Far West, coupled with fears of transportation difficulties, are primarily responsible for contrasting showings in Fall wholesale market activity in important buying centers, according to comment in merchandising circles last week.

DANVILLE, Ky. Aug. 8 -- A new core curriculum, designed to fulfill the objectives of the liberal arts college in the first two years of general education, was submitted to the faculty of Centre College of Kentucky after more than two years of study by a special committee of professors.

A MID the flood of "quickies" about the Far East in general and Japan in particular that was loosed by Pearl Harbor it is refreshing to find a book about Japan of which not a line has apparently been added or changed because of recent events.

Representative Vito Marcantonio, who is seeking renomination on the American Labor, Democratic and Republican tickets in the Twentieth District, took time out from his political efforts last night to appear as counsel for ten men who were brought into Night Court on disorderly conduct charges.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 8 -- The people of this country are even now looking forward to a vast purchase of goods after the war ends, the Chamber of Commerce of the United States announced today as the result of a preliminary survey.

Nothing has stirred me so greatly as the recent issue of THE TIMES Magazine with its article by Pearl Buck on the race significance behind this war. That it has a sinister significance too many have told us. That it can have a positive significance if we have courage, generosity and wisdom, Pearl Buck tells us.

CORONER LEE SLOCUM of Taunton, Conn., does his stuff again and in the same old way. That is to say, he permits the witnesses in the inquest on certain bones found in the ashes of Alastair Tinsley's house to ramble on at their own sweet will.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 8 -- Harsher penalties for conspiracy to commit sabotage and harbor or assist saboteurs will be asked from Congress, Attorney General Biddle said today, not long after six of eight saboteurs were electrocuted, and President Roosevelt sentenced one to serve a life term and another to serve thirty years.
Axis efforts to capitalize on Mohandas K. Gandhi's campaign to end British rule in India were shown yesterday by the Tokyo and Berlin radios, according to The Associated Press.

NEWARK, N.J., Aug. 8 -- A chain of women whose duty it will be to protect and comfort children whose parents are absent during a daytime air raid or other emergency is forming throughout the State. Already forty-three communities have completed the organization of "block mothers."

COLUMBIA, Mo., Aug. 8 -- An unusual agreement will enter its final phase here this month when Dr. W.W. Charters, until recently director of educational research at Ohio State University, assumes a full-time position in the same capacity at Stephens College.

HAMILTON, N.Y., Aug. 8 -- Lending weight to an argument for the accelerated college program, which has received little emphasis to date, the sixty freshmen who entered Colgate University for a special term last month ranked far above preceding freshmen in their social and natural science achievement tests.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 8 -- The new Meridian Hill Hotel, built in less than eight months to house 718 women government workers, was officially opened today at luncheon where Mrs. Roosevelt endorsed the project as an "excellent prventive" against flu epidemics such as raged in Washington during the last war because of crowded living conditions.

American artists who want to help in the war but have not known how to go about it will be assisted by the Office of War Information, according to a statement by Elmer Davis, director, published in the current issue of The Art News.

LENOX, Mass., Aug. 8 -- The series of concerts by the Berkshire Music Center Orchestra, under Serge Koussevitzky, which began here at Tanglewood last week, continued with a program given tonight in the music shed. Widely disseminated accounts of the superior work accomplished by the student orchestra at its initial appearances had aroused increased interest, with the result that the attendance was larger than at the opening concert a week ago.

The American Committee for Protection of Foreign Born announced last week that it had completed a survey of conditions affecting alien seamen in American ports and had prepared a memorandum on the subject and forwarded it to the War Shipping Administration, the Department of Justice and other interested agencies.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Aug. 8 -- Since Aug. 1 the entire coast of Norway has been in a state of emergency, according to an interview granted by the German Commander in Chief in Norway, Col. Gen. Nikolaus von Falkenhorst, to the Deutsche Zeitung in Norvegen, in which he emphasized the "impregnability" of Norway.

A silent crowd stood outside the gates of the District of Columbia jail all yesterday morning. It had been drawn there by reports that the eight Nazi saboteurs who had landed in this country from German submarines were to be executed. It watched Army officers hurry into the jail, guarded by helmeted, impassive sentries, speculated on who they were.

LIKE tom-toms calling to the fight, the thump of "V" signals knocked on wood heralds the dawn over Europe as BBC radio guns aimed at the Continent go into action. In America it is just before midnight. First one hears strong tone signals from the half dozen short waves pointed at Europe.

BAY SHORE, L.I., Aug. 8 -- With the last craft to finish today getting a gun salute, Great South Bay's twenty-seventh annual Race Week wound up with 564 sailboat starts checked for the six days. There was a fleet of ninety-six this afternoon.
SALEM, N.H., Aug. 8 (AP) -- George D. Widener's Rosetown won the tenth running of the $5,000 added Rockingham Handicap today, bringing to a close the Summer meeting at Rockingham Park.

CHICAGO, Aug. 8 -- Bearish sentiment predominated in the wheat market at the opening today with professional traders selling on weakness in cotton, but the decline uncovered a good demand for futures from mills and a rally of 1 1/4 cents a bushel from the bottom followed which carried prices to new high levels for the week.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 8 -- Hundreds of West Coast Japanese quartered at the Santa Anita assembly center outside Los Angeles assaulted an evacuee of Korean ancestry Tuesday and military police hastened into the race track to rescue the victim, the Army disclosed today.

WASHINGTON, D.C., Aug. 8 -- President Roosevelt, Commander in Chief of the Army and Navy of the United States, added to his many war duties this week the task of pressing for an end of organized labor's own seven years' war.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 8 (AP) -- William H. Davis, chairman of the War Labor Board, told Philip Murray, president of the Congress of Industrial Organizations, today that the board would "take and retain jurisdiction until final settlement" of jurisdictional disputes between unions of the C.I.O. and those of the American Federation of Labor.

Tarleton Winchester, European traffic manager of the United States Lines, arrived yesterday aboard a Pan American transatlantic clipper at La Guardia Field and related the latest quip now circulating throughout Germany lampooning the Nazi rulers.

! The American Women's Voluntary Services are going swiftly forward with plans for the coming Itennis championships at Forest Hills under their sponsorship. The benefit, which will be held from I Aug, Z7 to Sept. 7 in the Forest I-Iills Stadium, will be in charge of a senior committee under the chairmanship of Mrs. William C. Breed, the honorary chairmanship of Dwight Davis and the honorary vice chairmanship of Julian iVfyrick.

Backing out of a driveway at night is quite a feat. The ruby tail light and its apertures illuminating the license plate are too faint to show the driver his rearward course. Therefore he goes slowly in reverse and "works" the car out to the street.

Pieter van Beelen, former chief officer of the Holland-America liner Pennland, was decorated by Queen Wilhelmina last week with the Netherlands Cross of Merit, for bravery under fire during the Crete campaign. T. Elink-Schuurman, consul general of the Netherlands, notified Mr. Beelen of the award and presented to him the orange and blue breast ribbon pending arrival of the medal from London.

CHICAGO, Aug. 8 -- Alleging "confusion, waste and nonsense" in Washington, Walter P. Reuther, newly elected vice president of the United Automobile, Aircraft and Agricultural Implement Workers' Union, C. I. O., told its convention today that "unless leadership is revised, the United States is in danger of losing the war."

Peter Leventritt and Joseph Low of New York took the lead in the national contract bridge masters' pair tournament after the third session of play at the Park Central Hotel yesterday, getting a 65 2-3 per cent score of 768 1/2 match-points to bring their grand total to 2,052.

For the first time in over a decade the Horticultural Society of New York, 598 Madison Avenue, will stage a midsummer show on Aug. 12 and 13. This exhibition, which is part of the Victory Garden Harvest Show movement, will feature gladioli, annuals, perennials and vegetables, in addition to other exhibits of rare and interesting plant material.
SYRACUSE, N.Y., Aug. 8 -- Dr. William Pearson Tolley, president of Allegheny College and a graduate of Syracuse University in 1922, has been selected as the seventh chancellor of Syracuse University.

Shipping organizations in New York last week were waiting for materialization of plans to establish an industry-wide system of club and recreational facilities for the country's seamen, and all agreed that the idea, if properly carried out, would meet a need that has long been felt.

A resolution calling upon the War Production Board to extend use of the Stanley Plan for bringing prime contractors and subcontractors together was adopted yesterday by the priorities and procurement committee of the American Business Congress.

The American Federation of Musicians, the recording companies and radio stations are locked today in a major battle over the economic relation of the musician to "canned" music. What for years had been a subject of academic discussion moved last week into the realm of actuality when the union refused to rescind its ban on the making of recordings and the Department of Justice instituted an anti-trust suit against the union.
Between appointments the other afternoon Dr. Ira Gabrielson, recently named Deputy Coordinator of Fisheries, found time for a brief chat on many conservation topics.

SOMEWHERE IN AUSTRALIA, Sunday, Aug. 9 -- General Douglas McArthur's air forces are cooperating with United Nations naval units that are attacking Japanese positions in the Solomon Islands. The cooperation consists of heavy raids on Japanese bases from which aid might be sent to the island region where our offensive is under way.

All thirty-nine members of the crew of a medium-sized American freighter were saved after she was torpedoed by an enemy submarine in the Atlantic several hundred miles off the coast of South America about the middle of last month, it was announced yesterday by the Navy.

TWO murals (together with sketches and studies) painted by Anton Refregier for the Plainfield (N.J.) postoffice, have been placed on view at the ACA Gallery in Eighth Street and may be seen there through Friday. The murals were commissioned under the program of the Section of Fine Arts.

The world last week entered the final month of the third year of the war begun on Poland's plains. On the battlegrounds now girdling the globe the aggressors still held the initiative. Their victims, still retreating or unable to advance, were facing new crises. What hope had been held in anti-aggressor ranks that 1942 might see a turn in the tide seemed to be dimming.

MANY persons who write well feel that they never can hope to reach a vast popular audience because neither their emotional nor intellectual reactions are attuned to the mental and emotional reactions of the mass of readers.

THIS is a bubbling, youthful book full of resentments, suspicions, angers and violent objection with a much smaller share of tenderness and joy. It has a headstrong strength that is blurred by an extravagant tendency to wild and rapturous writing, some of which rings true but much of which falls flat as a flounder.
Jive and joy jumped into a fashion show yesterday. Gimbel Brothers opened its College Super Market with a style presentation that was definitely designed for the campus set.

CLOSE on the heels of hearing that July expenditures for the war program made a new high of $4,500,000,000 and of hearing also that some $205,000,000,000 has been appropriated so far for that program, came a summary statement from the Office of War Information at the close of the week which made clear that it takes more than dollars to win a war.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 8 (AP) -- A cotton crop of 13,085,000 bales this year, the largest since 1937, was forecast today by the Crop Reporting Board of the Department of Agriculture.

MOSCOW, Aug. 8 (U.P.) -- Major Gen. Follett Bradley, special envoy of President Roosevelt, conferred with Soviet leaders today on means of facilitating increased aid to Russia, while the Moscow radio broadcast a statement that "the day of the opening of the second front approaches."

Reflecting the surprisingly high crop estimate by the Department of Agriculture, quotations on the New York Cotton Exchange dropped yesterday 38 to 40 points, or $1.90 to $2 a bale, and to the lowest levels since Jan. 2. Final prices on active futures were at net losses of 37 to 38 points.

LEWISTON, Me., Aug. 8 -- When the school year opens in September the Bates Christian Association, an all-college organization, will once again send out deputations of its members to churches of surrounding communities where they conduct services.

IN these days when faith in the common man is being proclaimed by all protagonists of democracy such a novel as this, describing in very realistic terms the life of an American from the cradle to Pearl Harbor, is a veritable broadside reinforcing effectively the judgment of the philosophers.

CAZENOVIA, N.Y., Aug. 8 -- With forty competing in four divisions, the annual meeting of the New York State Chess Association opened today at Cazenovia Junior College. Ten of the experts were seeded in the State championship class, in which Israel A. Horowitz, American Federation champion in 1936, rules as the favorite.

Although pushing plans to utilize small size vessels for shipments to Latin America as a means of relieving the demand on regular shipping, consideration of sailing schooners in the program now being worked out by the Export Managers Club of New York has been temporarily abandoned because of the apparent unwillingness of the Navy Department to have the motorless vessels "cluttering up the ship lanes," it was learned yesterday.
BAR HARBOR, Me., Aug. 8 -- Many members of the Summer colony at this resort are engaged in active participation in the USO drive in an effort to meet Bar Harbor's quota of the national fund.

In THE TIMES of July 12 Ralph Barton Perry raised the important question of the "intellectual and moral foundations" of our present association with Russia. Professor Perry's appeal for fairness cannot fail to sound a responsive chord. I am entirely in agreement with him when he asks for magnanimity and understanding.

Philip Licht, treasurer of Wagner Memorial Lutheran College in Staten Island and former manager of the St George, S.I., branch of the Bank of the Manhattan Company, admitted in the lineup in Police Headquarters yesterday that he stole $12,500 of negotiable securities of the college under his control.

General activity decreased in the wholesale markets here last week, according to the report prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by McGreevey, Werring Howell Company. Fewer buyers were in town and mail in most cases was light.

Miss Dudley Kenyon will be hostess at a tea Tuesday afternoon at the Stork Club for the cbmmittee of juniors and debutantes who have taken part in the month's dance marathon at the Club for the entertainment of officers of the United Nations sent daily by the Officers' Service Committee of the United Service Organizations.

An investigation, which may lead to prison terms, fines or suspension of business licenses, has been started in this city by the Office of Price Administration into specific complaints of violation of the maximum price order and other OPA regulations in several industries, it was disclosed last night.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 8 -- Less than half of 1 per cent of the 1,400,000 oil-fired domestic furnaces in the northern half of the Eastern Seaboard had been converted to coal-burning between January and June this year, despite the threat of fuel oil shortages this Winter, Harold L. Ickes, War Petroleum Coordinator, said today.

MEXICO CITY, Aug. 8 -- Mexico's forthcoming rubber production industry -- now being greatly encouraged by both this government and that of the United States -- is a future peacetime measure rather than a war emergency, according to a statement made by a rubber expert of the Federal Department of Agriculture.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 8 -- The cargo-plane program calling for freight lines in the skies is coming into being, translated from idea into action with signatures on dotted lines.

GOSHEN -- Thin-wheeled sulkies behind high-stepping horses will spin over the triangular mile track at Good Time Park this week in the twelfth annual running of the rich Hambletonian, classic of the harness-racing world. The central feature of the $100,000 Grand Circuit meeting, the $40,000 stakes will be run off on Tuesday, the second day of the condensed three-day racing schedule.
ARE YOU PROUD of your telephone voice? Use it to serve your city! Use it for an important job in Civilian Defense!

LONDON, Aug. 8 -- The air raid sirens sounded in London late this afternoon on the second anniversary of the beginning of the Battle of Britain. Anti-aircraft guns went into action; but the Nazi intruder appeared to carry no threat of a revival of that dread "blitz" period of the enemy's heavy daylight attacks in 1940.

The arrest of two more civilian inspectors of construction at the Navy Yard in Brooklyn on charges of bribery was announced yesterday by P.E. Foxworth, director of the local offices of the Federal Bureau of Investigation. He described the two as Albert L. Rodkin, 38 years old, of 232 East Sixth Street, and Harry G. Schechtman. 30, of 1,800 East Fourth Street, Brooklyn.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Aug. 8 (AP) -- Realistic, first-hand accounts of major naval engagements in the Philippines, the Coral Sea and at Midway Island have been added to the Naval Academy's stepped-up program for producing junior officers.

BOMBAY, India, Sunday, Aug. 9 -- Mohandas K. Gandhi and other Indian Nationalist leaders were arrested today within a few hours after the All-India Congress party had approved a resolution authorizing a mass campaign of civil disobedience to support its demands for immediate Indian independence.

Ninety Nassau County women, comprising perhaps the first unit of social service aides to complete training, are now on furlough awaiting assignments. Ten weeks of studies at the Mineola County Court House prepared them for special wartime services under the county Department of Public Welfare and the county War Council.

SOMEWHERE IN PALESTINE, Aug. 8 -- A 10-year-old boy with closely cropped hair and sad blue eyes clicked his heels and, after an embarrassed moment during which he shifted an object from his right to his left hand while he held them behind his back, came to a salute, reddening.

The forthcoming investigation by the Office of Price Administration into the pricing policies of food wholesalers in this area has apparently made little impression on the violators and new infractions are being uncovered daily, particularly with regard to sales of fluid milk, A.F. Guckenberger, secretary of the New York State Food Merchants, asserted yesterday.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 8 (AP) -- Senator Abbe lowered the Saratoga Raceway mile track record tonight to 2:03 for the second evening in succession as he triumphed over the veteran campaigner, Little Pat, in the $1,000 Stars and Stripes Free-for-all pacing special.

IT was to be a vacation in this town of 4,000 on the left bank of the Ohio, where the showboats used to call and life is still lived pleasantly. Showboats? That suggested something. The Water Queen, the Floating Palace, the Golden Rod have long since quit these waters.

The ominous decree of "four gallons a week" has made many suburbanites wonder whether they were really so wise in moving out to their little mortgage-covered cottage, a long stone's throw from the station. Dwellers in more rural districts have envisioned a return to the days when life on a farm meant seclusion with the mail-order catalogue.

BURLINGTON, Vt. -- Vermont is quieter than usual this Summer, with a number of August events canceled, including the Green Mountain Festival of the Arts at Middlebury and the annual State amateur open golf tournament at Burlington. However, a number of other events are still on the schedule.

CHICAGO, Aug. 8 -- Alsab, the celebrated $700 bargain horse, making his first start since his second to Shut Out in the $53,000 Belmont Stakes on June 6, ran out of the money in a $2,500 six-furlong handicap at Washington Park today.

MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, Aug. 8 (UP) -- A crowd of 2,000 persons stormed through the streets tonight in an anti-Axis demonstration while the government officially protested to Germany over the sinking of the Uruguayan ship Maldonado.

College shop openings drew crowds in most stores in the three major test markets of New York, Chicago and Los Angeles, according to the survey made especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by Meyer Both Reports.

MELBOURNE, Australia, Sunday, Aug. 9 (AP) -- Prime Minister John Curtin declared today that Washington communique disclosing operations by United Nations forces in the Solomon Islands represented "the consummation of a series of preparations on the part of the United Nations, including Australia, which had been proceeding for some weeks."

BUFFALO, N.Y., Aug. 8 (AP) -- Senator James M. Mead, member of the Truman Senate Committee currently investigating America's steel shortage, tonight forecast "a big steel shortage next year," but minimized the effect of alleged "black markets."
HARTFORD, Conn., Aug. 8 -- The Rev. Kurt E.B. Molzahn of Philadelphia will take the stand Monday or Tuesday to defend himself against charges of spying for Germany and Japan.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 8 (AP) -- The Department of Agriculture today announced details of the Commodity Credit Corporation's cotton loan for 1942. The program calls for an average rate of 16.02 cents a pound on seven-eights-inch middling.

BRIARCLIFF MANOR, N.Y., Aug. 8 -- As was expected after his sensational qualifying round in which he made a 69, Douglas Ford, 20-year-old Green Valley golfer, annexed the New York State junior championship for the second time in three years at the Briar Hills Club today.
Trading on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday was the smallest since July 18 and the narrowest since June 13. Prices closed with fractional losses. Volume was 101,100 shares.

FORT DES MOINES, Aug. 8 (AP) -- Presenting their first formal review for their director, Mrs. Oveta Culp Hobby, the first 800 members of the Women's Army Auixliary Corps stepped out with a military cadence which belied their less than three weeks of training.
CHUNGKING, China, Aug. 8 (Reuter) -- Tonight's Chinese communique included the following:

THREE persons arrive simultaneously at the fortress-like home of Stanley Kerr in the wilds of Montana. Each of them is determined that Kerr must die, and each has a different reason. Kerr does die very soon after their arrival, and the question is: Who killed him?

MURRAY BAY, Que., Aug. 8 -The Canadian Red Cross was the beneficiary of the bridge and bingo party tonight at the Manoir Richelieu. It was well attended and preceded by several dinner parties. One of the largest parties was that given by Mr. and Mrs. Henry Ralph Miller.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 8 -- In order to assist printers and publishers in determining the zone price differentials applicable in their purchase of newsprint, the Office of Price Administration today made available to them a list classifying all the counties of the nation according to the previously established price zones in which they are located.

While favored by cool weather which stimulated interest in between-season and early Fall merchandise, retail trade here this week showed a considerable decline in dollar volume as compared with last year. Department store volume was estimated as 10 to 15 per cent under the 1941 week.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Aug. 8 (Reuter -- Maikop oil fields were set on fire by the Russians today as German artillery began shelling Maikop and Krasnodar, according to a Rome report. German troops, equipped with most modern machinery for counter-acting fires in old fields, are driving forward in an effort to minimize the destruction.

LOS ANGELES -- From "Little Tokyo" to the "Latin Quarter" will be the transformation of an extensive area of downtown Los Angeles, if plans now maturing among landholders can be carried out. Thus Los Angeles, losing one of its chief tourist attractions, will substitute another.

THE Metropolitan Opera Association's first financial report revealed that there is likelihood in the near future of a new American opera to be composed by William Schuman, winner of this years music critics' prize, to a libretto by Christopher La Farge, novelist and poet.

Export freight flowing through United States ports exceeds the maximum reached in the last war, according to George C. Randall, manager of port traffic of the Association of American Railroads. He said recently that between, 2,500 and 3,000 cars -- about 25 per cent more than in 1940 -- are being unloaded daily in export movements at ports.

PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., Aug. 8 -- Sixty-eight craft sailed today in the special regatta conducted by the Manhasset Bay Yacht Club. Among the chief winners was the Atlantic Class Rosie, sailed by Mrs. Garrison R. Corwin, who did a fine job as skipper.

VICHY, France, Aug. 8 (U.P.) -- Chief of Government Pierre Laval has informed the French Council of Ministers that the Vichy government would maintain a hands-off attitude if Allied troops landed on French soil in a second-front invasion of Europe, it was revealed tonight.

HAVANA, July 29 -- Fifteen American students and teachers are here attending the Summer school at the Havana University as part of a movement to develop closer relations between the United States and Latin America on a spiritual basis.

CAIRO, Egypt, Aug. 8 -- The Allied air forces offensive against Axis shipping made further inroads in the last two days on ships and lighters that were trying desperately to inject sufficient reinforcements into the Nazi forces in Africa to enable them to regain the initiative they lost at El Alamein.
SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 8 -- Many luncheons were given today in the Terrace Restaurant at the track, where one of the largest throngs of this season attended the races.

Members of the Liberal and Labor Committee to Safeguard the American Labor party began yesterday a door-to-door canvassing campaign and mailed letters to the 190,000 enrolled party members, urging them to go to the polls at the primary election Tuesday and by voting for right wing candidates eliminate left wing influence in the party.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 8 -- United States naval and other units have attacked "in force" Japanese installations in the southeastern section of the Solomon Islands, in the southwestern Pacific, and the attacks are continuing, the Navy Department announced in a communique this afternoon.
RYE, N.Y., Aug. 8 -- A 19-year-old blond California girl is the new women's eastern turf court tennis champion.

THE cool serenity of the large Fountain Court at the Frick Collection in Seventieth Street, just off Fifth Avenue, remains unimpaired, contrasting with multiple wartime changes that are to be observed elsewhere. It looks just as it did when the remodeled Frick mansion was opened to the public back in 1935.

IT is possible that more exciting pictures of air fighters than those by Sir William Rothenstein will be drawn, but it is difficult to believe that any artist will be as successful as Sir William in depicting the character of the men engaged in defending England against the Nazis.

NOW that enthusiastic San Franciscans have been pouring more than $20,000 a week into the Curran Theatre box office to see a vaudeville show with a dozen participants and one set of scenery, George Jessel, the master of ceremonies, is worried.

MONTCLAIR, N.J., Aug. 8 -- John G. Kroel of the Oritani Field Club, Hackensack, led the way into the semi-final round of the New Jersey veterans' tennis championship as play started at the Montclair Athletic Club today. After winning from Bradley Slattery of New York by default, Kroel, seeded third, turned back George H. Schwartz, Garden City Casino, 6 -- 0, 6 -- 2.
The representation of solid, three-dimensional objects in two-dimensional picture form involves the use of a reducing factor which photographers and artists call perspective.

WESTBURY, L.I., Aug. 8 -- A trotting rivalry that promises to develop into quite a feud was resumed at Roosevelt Raceway today, as Symbol Gantle and Ridgewood clashed again in the Metropolitan Special, a free-for-all trot which featured the day's program.

The greatest injury that could possibly be done to the nation in this emergency would be to tax industry engaged in war work to the point of weakening its productiveness. While we must combat inflation and maintain fiscal equilibrium, industrial enterprise must produce materials for the prosecution of the war.

"Do you really want to do something about this war?" is the challenge the City Island Y.C. is giving to its members. Anticipating that the answer will be "yes" a special course in celestial navigation has been organized. It is being conducted at the clubhouse every Thursday evening for ten weeks and will provide an opportunity for applied study, including sextant work.

The sabotage trial has moved to its grim end. Some Americans asked: "Why did we have to try them? Why didn't we just set them up against a wall and shoot them?" Others were troubled by the unnecessary secrecy with which the Army veiled the proceedings.
INDIANAPOLIS, Aug. 8 (U.P.) -- Attorneys for William Dudley Pelley, convicted Wednesday on eleven counts of sedition and conspiracy, petitioned Federal Judge Robert C. Baltzell today for a new trial.

ANNANDALE-ON-HUDSON, N.Y., Aug. 8 -- The Institute for Economic Education at Bard College, residential unit of Columbia University, has just submitted a detailed report on the aspect of its work carried on through grants from the Alfred P. Sloan Foundation.

The national tournament which is still in progress today at the Park Central Hotel has to some extent verified two oft-repeated assertions of bridge authorities: First, that any national tournament will be a success in New York; and second, that interest in bridge increases in wartime.

The letter of Messrs. Cohen and Griswold published in your issue last Sunday regarding the decision of the United States Supreme Court in the case of Betts vs. Brady is, of course, very important on the question of the rights of a person charged with a serious offense to have the benefit of counsel on his trial.

The wartime shortage of wool has inspired the creation of cotton rugs which are surprisingly attractive and durable. Made of smooth, long-fibered cotton and woven on regular wool looms, they are not to be confused with the bathroom type of rug Some of the designs and weaves, in fact, are so successful that they promise to be popular even after wool again becomes plentiful.

FIFTY years ago, last Tuesday, dawn broke with flaming face on Fall River, Mass. The sun did not slip slowly through the venerable oaks and elms to work itself, and the town, to sweltering August heat. It smote suddenly and fiercely, blocked the faded brick and frame dwellings in hot light and deep shadow, while the birds feebly protested in the thick foliage.

TORONTO, Aug. 8 -- Craig Wood, United States open champion, won the Canadian open golf title today by shooting a par 72 in the final round for a seventy-two-hole score of 275 -- thirteen strokes under par for the distance.

Sixty-five social investigators of the Department of Welfare, most of them long-time employes, were dismissed yesterday as a result of the pending controversy between Mayor La Guardia and the City Council over amending the McCarthy Salary Increment Law.

In THE NEW YORK TIMES Magazine of July 26, there is a very interesting article by Nicholas Murray Butler entitled "Should There Be Two New Parties?" The writer, however, speaks of international relations and says that all our Presidents from McKinley on, naming them individually but leaving out Coolidge and Hoover, supported a constructive plan for international relations.

MUNCIE, Ind., Aug. 8 -- Alertly aware of the dual role the colleges should play during the war period, Ball State Teachers College has completed plans for an all-out cooperation with the national defense program and also for the maintenance of high educational standards when the Fall quarter opens Sept. 8, with a two-day orientation period for freshmen.

Funeral services were read in London last week over the Munich compact, which Hitler made in September, 1938, and which he broke in March, 1939. The boundaries of the Czecho-Slovak Republic now stand on the books of the United Nations as they stood before the cession of the Sudetenland.

GREENPORT, L.I., Aug. 8 -- Miss Elsie D. Papajohn, whose letter to President Roosevelt brought her the assignment of sponsoring the minesweeper YMS 185 at the Greenport Basin and Construction Company today, promised that the United States would bring peace and good-will not only to this country and its Allies but also to the people of enemy nations who are being led to destruction by their leaders.
NARRAGANSETT, R.I., Aug. 8 -- The Summer season at Narragansett is now in full swing with every available house occupied and each week-end sees hotels and inns filled to capacity.

AFTER a careful scrutiny of every page of this book one will be unable to say that it makes a case either for alcohol as a beverage or against it. In their exploration Drs. Haggard and Jellinek have been as completely objective as it seems possible to be.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 8 -- The American Red Cross today chartered the Swedish motorship Kanangoora, which is now at San Francisco, to carry relief supplies to American and other United Nations prisoners of war in the Far East.

Despite the claim of supporters of Senator James M. Mead that he now has a majority of the delegates to the Democratic State Convention, State Chairman James A. Farley stood pat yesterday on his estimate that Attorney General John J. Bennett Jr. was assured of the votes of more than 670 of the 1,014 delegates.

THERE was nothing unusual about the departure of a big 4-motor transoceanic airliner the other day from a leading Eastern American flying field, but several men aboard were there for very special duties. One of the most important concerned radio.

COLONEL PRIMROSE and Mrs. Grace Latham have another mystery on their hands. It concerns the death of Lawrason Hilyard, a dollar-a-year man occupying an important position in the O.P.M Hilyard is supposed to know all that there is to know about prometheum, If you don't know what prometheum is, consult your dictionary, and little good it will do you unless your dictionary is better than ours.

PRINCETON, N.J., Aug. 8 -- The United States went to war exactly eight months ago this week. If the American public, which has so often been ahead of its leaders, were to draw up a war program for the immediate future based on those eight months' experience, what would it embrace?

ALBANY, Aug. 8 (AP) -- Close cooperation of Federal, State and local government agencies on emergency wartime fiscal policies to maintain a sound home economy while financing war all over the world is urged by a committee of the Council of State Governments.

The seizure of thirty-three enemy aliens, among them a former radio instructor in the National Youth Administration, was announced yesterday by P.E. Foxworth, director here of the Federal Bureau of Investigation.

UP on Fifty-second Street, the offices of the Theatre Guild are electric, in a quiet way, with the excitements attendant on the start of that body's twenty-fifth season. Locally, the season is to open the week of Oct. 5, when the St. James receives a revised "Without Love."

MOSCOW, Aug. 8 -- Extracts from articles that are reported to have appeared recently in the United States press criticizing the State Department's continuance of diplomatic relations with Finland had prominence in today's Moscow newspapers, running alongside other articles, of a type now frequent, reporting a popular demand in Britain and America for an immediate second front.
Announcement is made by Dogs for Defense of a new program necessitated by the requirements of the Army in the work of obtaining and training dogs for patrol and guard duty.

WINDING up its run at the Music Hall this week, Metro's "Mrs. Miniver" is, after a record ten-week tenancy, still maintaining a box-office pace that would be considered exceptionally strong even for the first week of a better-than-average attraction at that house.

FROM the initials of the Air Transport Auxiliary these British and American women take the nickname ATAgirls. Their job is to ferry new planes from factories to flying bases, and their assignments may be anything from the small and deadly Spitfire to sizable twin-engined craft.

THE energetic War Savings Staff of the Treasury Department is putting the finishing touches on a new half-hour program to promote the sale of war bonds, it may be reported this morning. If Secretary Morgenthau gives the O.K., it should start either Aug. 22 or 29 over the Mutual Broadcasting System, which is contributing the time.

DETROIT, Aug. 8 -- Detroit's housing shortage, for years a major civic problem, has become so acute under the influx of war-plant workers that official city agencies declare they can no longer cope with it.

SAN ANTONIO, Texas, Aug. 8 -- Plans to establish a social service school at Our Lady of the Lake College are rapidly nearing completion, Dr. John L. McMahon, president, announced today. Miss Rita M. Fleming of New York has been appointed director of the graduate school.

ATLANTIC CITY, Aug. 8 -- Two more of Atlantic City's palatial beachfront hotels, well known to all of the resort's visitors, and a smaller side-avenue hostelry were added tonight to the ever-growing list that have been taken over by the Army Air Force's Replacement Training Center here.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, Aug. 8 -- Increased income from tuitions, produced by the nationwide accelerated educational program, is the forerunner of serious financial problems for liberal arts colleges, in the opinion of Robert D. Fisher, fiscal vice president of Western Reserve University.

Air Commodore H.N. Thornton, British air attache in the United States, yesterday denied reports from Washington of disagreement between Britain and the United States on the methods or objectives of a combined air assault on Germany.

IN the Land o' Goshen (N.Y.) the corn is green and higher than a man's head. The apples are coming along and the Hambletonian is coming up. Wednesday is the great day of the harness hoss year. The three-day meeting at Goshen will begin on Tuesday, but the "buggy whip Derby," the Trot for the Tiara over the Good Time track, will take place on Wednesday.

One of the most practical and economical plans yet devised to augment the nation's supply of electric power for essential war-production purposes has been formulated and forwarded to Washington for consideration by government officials directly interested in the power problem, it was disclosed yesterday.

George Le Boutillier, vice president of the Pennsylvania Railroad, unfurled a service banner yesterday in honor of the 12,127 employes of that company who have entered the armed services.
