Except for some increase in interest in Fall apparel, wholesale volume last week was only fair, according to a summary of the week's activities prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by leading resident buying offices. Most retailers, having covered a large part of their Fall needs earlier in the year, were conservative in placing further commitments.

Freedom and democracy, justice and human personality are holy causes, dearer to us than physical existence, which are threatened now and all but overwhelmed by war, the Rev. Dr. Daniel A. Poling of Philadelphia, president of the World's Christian Endeavor Union, declared in his sermon yesterday at the Marble Collegiate Reformed Church, Fifth Avenue and Twenty-ninth Street, where he formerly was pastor.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 9 -- A national industrial nutrition program aimed at conservation of man power as well as increased production was announced today by Paul V. McNutt, administrator of the Defense Health and Welfare Services and chairman of the War Manpower Commission.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 9 -- In a last-minute effort to avert a citywide strike of employes of the Philadelphia Transportation Company, which operates the trolley, subway, elevated and bus lines here, union and company negotiators have agreed to meet tomorrow morning.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Aug. 9 (AP) -- The Providence Journal today arranged for a poll to be taken in Indiana, Ohio. Michigan and Illinois on a proposal that the people in those States agree to an immediate gasoline-rationing program in order to share their fuel oil and gasoline with already-rationed New England.

CHICAGO, Aug. 9 (AP) -- The White Sox, aided by the pitching of Ted Lyons and the timely batting of Bob Kennedy, slapped a double defeat on the Indians today, 11 to 1 and 3 to 2, and boosted their record to eight straight triumphs.

The riots that broke out yesterday in Bombay, Allahabad and elsewhere in India following the arrest of Gandhi, Nehru and other leaders of the Congress party apparently have not extended to Calcutta. If this means that the non-cooperation movement has little support in India's greatest industrial center, it is fortunate for the United Nations, for the Calcutta area produces more military supplies than Free China, the Middle East and Africa put together.
MOSCOW, Aug. 9 (AP) -- The Soviet Information Bureau issued this communique today:

The German High Command issued three communiques yesterday to report the progress of its troops in the Caucasus. The communiques, quoted in Berlin broadcasts recorded by The Associated Press, announced the capture of Maikop, center of an important Russian oil region, and Krasnodar, described as an armament-manufacturing center.

CINCINNATI, Aug. 9 -- The Reds and Cubs struggled through the longest major league ball game of this two-thirds-gone season today, with the Cubs winning, 10 -- 8, in an eighteen-inning rally for two runs off Elmer Riddle.

CAIRO, Egypt, Aug. 9 -- Air activity continued to increase yesterday over the El Alamein front and several combats resulted. On the ground Allied patrols operated and artillery shelled Axis positions but the general lull continued.

A heavy downpour of rain that fell steadily for thirteen hours before slackening, caused minor damage throughout the city and metropolitan area yesterday. Streets and cellers in outlying sections were flooded and there were several automobile accidents.

A good deal is said and written to the effect that the weapons we are sending against the Axis are unsatisfactory or inferior. But the weight of evidence is the other way. The Japanese Zero fighter plane has been much praised; but, as in many other instances of the discussion involving weapons, confusion arises from a failure to understand the technical strengths and weaknesses of specific types.

Sale of a new $30,205,000 issue of Long Island Lighting Company first mortgage Series F 3 1/4 per cent thirty-year bonds for the purpose of refunding three outstanding series has been authorized by the Public Service Commission The bonds to be called total $29,961,000, bear 4 per cent interest and mature between 1960 and 1963.

The contract for the construction of a large irrigation project in the Valsequillo district in the State of Puebla, Mexico, one of the main items in the Mexican agricultural development program, has been awarded to Samuel R. Rosoff, Ltd., it was announced yesterday.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 9 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission is highly pleased with the results of the system of special offerings which it offered to all national securities exchanges on Feb. 6, last.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 9 -- The establishment of a second front in Europe is literally "a life-and-death matter for the future of the French people," the Foreign Policy Association declared today.

President Roosevelt told the nation yesterday that while "great progress" has been made to date in the battle of production, the country's productive genius had really just begun to get into its stride and that to win the war "an unceasing flood of warships and materials must pour forth from the factories, shipyards and mines" throughout the land.

MASSILLON, Ohio, Aug. 9 (AP) -- The Army and Navy saluted today this highly industrialized city of 30,000 for what it is doing to help win the war. It was the first time an entire community was so honored.

A CARIBBEAN PORT, Aug. 9 -- How twenty-six survivors from a torpedoed ship were kept headed safely and surely shoreward for seventeen days by Third Mate Robert Hudson Nicholls of New York City with only a watch and a chart as navigation aids, was revealed today.

Churches and synagogues of fifteen communions and creeds will make their appeals for financial assistance simultaneously this Fall and Winter, the United Church Canvass Committee, 297 Fourth Avenue, announced yesterday.
The following Italian High Command communique was broadcast from Rome yesterday and recorded here by The Associated Press:

LONDON, Aug. 9 -- Each dispatch from India was read tonight in Whitehall with fingers crossed and bated breath. By arresting Mohandas K. Gandhi and many of his followers and outlawing the All-India Congress party as an illegal association, the government of India, with the War Cabinet's approval, has taken a bold step designed to short-circuit incipient open rebellion.

MOSCOW, Monday, Aug. 10 (U.P.) -- Red Army counter-attacks have checked a German pincers drive on Stalingrad, but a scorched-earth retreat in the Northwestern Caucasus continues, the Russians reported today.

Yesterday may have been pretty dreary for most civilians here, but for the soldiers, the sailors and the Marines who were in town on leave, it was a wonderful day, rain or no rain, and they spent it in their usual haunts, apparently having a good time.

SPRINGFIELD, Mass., Aug. 9 -- James C. Petrillo, president of the A.F. of L American Federation of Musicians, has threatened to blacklist the Springfield Municipal Auditorium if the nonunion Boston Symphony Orchestra plays in it as scheduled for the coming season.

Their twin bill with the Athletics postponed yesterday, the Yankees will oppose the Athletics at the Stadium this afternoon in a double-header that will conclude the three-game series. The first game will start at 1:30 o'clock.

MOSCOW, Monday, Aug. 10 (AP) -- Russian troops fighting desperate defensive actions were giving way today before two German drives aimed at the Caucasian oil center of Maikop, it was indicated in a communique issued today.

Defeat of seven Representatives with "isolationist" records, who are running for renomination in tomorrow's primary election, was urged yesterday by the directors of Vote for Freedom, who include Mrs. J. Borden Harriman, Richard B. Scandrett Jr., Herbert Agar, William Agar, Mrs. Ward Cheney, Russell Davenport, Christopher Emmet, George Field, Arthur J. Goldsmith, Mrs. Raymond V. Ingersoll, Mrs. Beatrice Kaufman, Dr. Frank Kingdon, Lewis Mumford, Mrs. Dorothy Pratt, William Jay Schieffelin and Roderick Stephens.

The leaders of both right and left wing factions of the American Labor party reported yesterday they were assured of victory in tomorrow's primary election and certain of electing a majority of the members of its State committee and of the delegates to its State convention.

CAZENOVIA, N.Y., Aug. 9 -- Dr. Edward Lasker of New York today shared the lead in the annual tournament of the New York State Chess Association by defeating Dr. Max Herzberger of Rochester, a former pupil of Dr. Albert Einstein, in the second round at the Cazenovia Junior College.

TEANECK, N.J., Aug. 9 -- The record of no robberies in three years enjoyed by this township of 26,000 inhabitants was broken at 3:52 o'clock this morning when Miss Florence Graf, 35 years old, of 284 James Street, was seized, struck and robbed of her pocketbook just after she had alighted from a taxicab in front of her home.

NEW ORLEANS, Aug. 9 -- Favorable crop news and bearish yield guesses in advance of the official estimate yesterday were not enough to keep cotton futures prices down most of last week, and when the market finished on Friday active positions maintained the best part of extreme gains of $1 a bale for the week.

LONDON, Aug. 9 (AP) -- Royal Air Force reconnaissance photographs taken in Western Germany disclose that the recent big British raids over the Ruhr and Rhineland caused damage "which is certain to have far-reaching effects on the enemy's production of armaments and munitions," the Air Ministry news service said tonight.

It seems the new season will get under way next week, and scheduled to start the escape from the dog days is "The Saroyan Showcase," due at the Belasco next Monday, although the producer may jump the gun by presenting a series of "public previews" beginning Thursday.

CHICAGO, Aug. 9 -- Repercussions of the war upon the grocery trade will make themselves felt in the program of the National Food Distributors Association, which opens here Aug. 20, E.J. Martin, executive secretary, reported here today.

JERUSALEM, Aug. 7 (Delayed) (U.P.) -- The Jewish Agency and the National Palestine Council today issued a joint manifesto endorsing British War Secretary Sir James Origg's announcement that a Palestine regiment, consisting of separate Jewish and Arab infantry battalions, would be created at once for general service in the Middle East.
Motion picture producers have notified Federal authorities they are prepared to cut their "raw stock" film consumption by almost 20 per cent and still maintain the industry's present standards.
LONDON, Aug. 9 -- There is no such thing as moving day for London's housewives in wartime -- unless, of course, they are evicted by bombs.

While we spend our time arguing which process is the best, our rubber shortage daily becomes more and more acute. Valuable months already have been lost; that more valuable time will continue to be lost seems inevitable. Most of this delay is as needless as it is fruitless.

EL CERRITO, Calif., Aug. 9 (U.P.) -- A crowded Greyhound bus, its driver unconscious after a collision with an automobile which caused one death, ran wild for a mile and a half today downtown through this city before a fire truck brought it to a halt with a block and tackle.

PITTSBURGH, Aug. 9 (AP) -- The Cardinals pared a full game from the lead of the idle Dodgers today by downing the Pirates in both ends of a bargain bill, 4 -- 3 and 2 -- 1. The nightcap was called at the end of the eighth because of the Pennsylvania Sunday law.
MADRAS, India, Aug. 9 (Reuter) -- Chakravarthi Rajagopalachari, former Premier of Madras, who recently resigned from the Congress, issued the following statement today:

CHICAGO, Aug. 9 -- Corn sold at the lowest levels on the current downturn last week and at one time threatened to go into new seasonal low ground. Scattered liquidation developed on the break and futures showed losses of 3/4 to 1 cent a bushel for the week.

Representatives of the United States, Great Britain, the Fighting French and Lebanon patriotic societies paid tribute yesterday to the Lebanese volunteers who fought under the banner of Free France with the British in the Libyan campaign.

RALEIGH, N.C., Aug. 9 (U.P.) -- Two men were killed and five severely injured in the crash of a medium-sized Army bomber in a take-off at the airport here early today. One of the seven occupants of the bomber was killed instantly and the other died at a local hospital where the injured men were taken for treatment.

FORT DIX, N.J., Aug. 9 -- Although Assessor Zach T. Potter said that, "I see no reason in fighting the U.S. Army -- you just can't do it," it became known today that New Hanover Township was preparing a protest in connection with the condemnation proceedings that the Department of Justice has filed to facilitate the taking over of Pointville, "capital" of a 700-acre tract in the center of the military reservation here.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 9 -- With one motion today the Giants overcame the weather and the Phils at Shibe Park to bag a double-header and advance to within one point of third place. They won by 3 to 2 and 2 to 0.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Brazil, Aug. 9 (U.P.) -- The Swedish liner Gripsholm, carrying 1,400 American diplomatic representatives, newspaper men and other nationals repatriated from Japan and Japanese-controlled territory, is expected to dock here about 9 A.M. tomorrow.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 9 -- The Senate Finance Committee, which intends to finish its hearings on the House-approved tax bill week, will hold a special executive session tomorrow morning to vote on the Treasury's proposal striking at special provisions favoring individual income taxpayers in the community-property States.

Originally slated to be held in Texas, the thirty-fourth annual national fly and bait casting tournament will be held later this month at Chicago. Scheduled for Aug. 26 to 29 at San Antonio, the scene of the event was shifted because the new site, especially in wartravel days, is more centrally located.

LONDON, Aug. 9 -- Selective activity in industrials and Latin-American bonds provided the Stock Exchange with its principal business last week. Despite this demand the period was the most inactive for many months owing to the influence of the holidays and the gravity of the Russian military situation.

JOHN F. HASEY of Bridgewater, Mass., won't be 26 until next November. But already he has encountered enough first-hand experience of what life and fighting are like in this momentous fifth decade of the twentieth century to last a lifetime. Right now he is just out of a hospital after enduring further plastic surgery so that he wouldn't forever have to go on talking through a tube in his throat.

BOMBAY, India, Aug. 9 (U.P.) -- Flower garlands draped around his thin neck, Mohandas K. Gandhi handed himself over to police for the sixth time in the cause of Indian independence today with a parting word to his followers, "Remember the slogan, either we get freedom or die."

VICHY, Aug. 9 -- According to the most recent statements published by the principal French credit establishments, their total deposits stood on May 31 in round figures at 103,000,000,000 francs, compared with 99,000,000,000 on April 30.

LONDON, Aug. 9 -- The Bank of England's circulation continues to soar, this week's increase being due largely to the demand for holiday currency. The latest rise, 9,167,000, which was the largest weekly increase this year, compared with 8,600,000 in the same week last year and makes the total increase this year to date 83,400,000, against 51,170,000 in the same period last year.

Campus old-timers and freshmen alike are hauling out trunks and embarking on the inevitable hunt for clothes, cosmetics, and school trivia to arm them for the "call to learning." Simultaneously, forehanded cosmetic firms bob up alertly with ingenious kits tailored to fit the routine of college life and the simple needs of young skins.

HAVANA, Cuba, Aug. 9 -- A volunteer Feminine Civil Defense Corps, which will begin registration of women between the ages of 18 and 60 on Sept. 1, has been organized here under the leadership of Dr. Maria Gomez Carbonell, it was announced today.

If Americans are not bewildered concerning the status of our war production, it is not because they lack good reason to be so. It is only two weeks ago that Donald M. Nelson, head of the War Production Board, gave a rather glowing account of what we had achieved.

Republican voters of the Twenty-sixth Congressional District were called upon yesterday by Wendell L. Willkie, titular leader of their party, to defeat the attempt of Representative Hamilton Fish Jr. to win the Republican renomination for his seat in tomorrow's primary.

Japanese Imperial Headquarters declared yesterday, according to a Tokyo broadcast that was recorded by The Associated Press, that the navy had dealt a staggering blow to a combined British and United States fleet in an air and sea engagement near the Solomon Islands, sinking or damaging more than twenty-eight warships and transports.

Mrs. A.M. Sobel of New York and Charles H. Goren of Philadelphia won the contract bridge masters' pair championship, most coveted bridge crown for which American players compete, and the Waldemar von Zedtwitz gold cup that goes with it, in the national tournament at the Park Central Hotel yesterday.

It probably betokens some serious lack of gastronomic imagination that the first dish of an American dinner has no name. Beside the savory antipasto of Italy, the delicate hors d'oeuvres of France, the intricate, irrestible smorgasbord of Scandinavia -- an American "first course" pales by comparison.

The crime laboratory on wheels, an experiment of the New York City police, is at first sight a good thing. It will save a great deal of exertion for the authorities. By performing the work of a half dozen squads of specialized investigators it will save time and thus reduce the criminal's chances of making a getaway.
The foreign exchange market last week was colorless. Business was limited to a few routine transactions, resulting in a firm array of prices.

The Prudential Life Insurance Company of America sold the one and two story buildings containing four apartments and five stores at 680-84 Scotland Road, Orange, N.J., to a New York investor. The property has a frontage of 140 feet and includes a fifty-car garage.

Until the unexpectedly high estimate of the crop by the Department of Agriculture precipitated a rush of selling in the cotton market on Saturday, activity for the week on the New York Cotton Exchange had been very slow, with price fluctuations rather insignificant.

Joseph Peter Remi, 25 years old, of 172 Madison Street, was held without bail in Felony Court yesterday for a hearing Thursday on a technical grand larceny charge because Patrolman Michael Palmieri remembered the license number on an automobile used in a recent slaying.
The Navy would like to know: "Miss (or Mrs.) Would-be WAVES, are you a lexicographer? Or an engineer, architect, astronomer, accountant, journalist, meteorologist?

Franz Werfel's recent book, "The Song of Bernadette," was praised by the Rev. Francis X. Shea at solemn mass yesterday morning in St. Patrick's Cathedral as "a novel on faith" in which "war-torn America sees a lamp of Heaven, lighting the way through the shadows of the day and the blackout of night."

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 9 (AP) -- After taking two in a row from the Tigers, the Browns forgot they were in a battle for the first division today, committed eleven errors and dropped both ends of a double-header to those same Tigers.

WITH THE BRITISH EIGHTH ARMY in Egypt, Aug. 9 -- A number of British officers who fell into German hands in the desert warfare have slipped out through the enemy's fingers, it was revealed today. They are now among their own comrades with tales of adventure and other things to tell and also able to fight again against their recent captors.

LONDON, Monday, Aug. 10 -- Two German planes, among a number that carried out light raids over five different sections of England last night and early today, sneaked over a South Coast town during the night and dropped incendiary bombs in a residential area, causing a number of casualties and some property damage.

The "landslide" for Senator James M. Mead in his candidacy for the nomination for Governor at next week's Democratic State Convention, declared to be under way in a statement issued by his campaign committee, seemingly had not extended to the central and western parts of the State yesterday.
The following Imperial Headquarters communique was broadcast from Tokyo yesterday and recorded by The Associated Press:
PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 9 (U.P.) -- Flash floods in sections of Bucks, Montgomery, Lancaster and Chester Counties took two lives and caused property damage of more than $1,000,000 today.
LONDON, Aug. 9 (AP) -- The Ministries of Air and Home Security issued this communique today:

CHICAGO, Aug. 9 -- Industrial and shipping demand for cash oats has been unusually active recently, and the movement to terminal markets decidedly disappointing. Wet weather has delayed the completion of threshing over a wide area and some damage is reported to have been done to the quality of the grain remaining in the fields.

The Eastern railroads have made a start toward complying with a request of the government that they use some of their machine shops in the manufacture of goods required for the war effort. This has not always been easy, because machines designed to make or repair parts for locomotives and cars are not readily adaptable to other purposes.

LONDON, Aug. 9 (U.P.) -- Germany's new type Focke-Wulf-190 fighter plane has a top speed of 375 miles an hour and a cruising speed of 326, it was revealed tonight after exhaustive tests with one of the planes captured in England.

LONDON, Aug. 9 -- In a little courthouse somewhere in the British Isles tomorrow morning two men belonging to the American forces will be tried before a United States general courts-martial, one for raping an English girl and one on a charge of manslaughter.

AUCKLAND, New Zealand, Aug. 9 -- Reports of the United Nations attack against the Japanese-held Solomon Islands today stirred the keenest interest throughout New Zealand and further news was eagerly awaited.

MIAMI, Fla., Aug. 9 -- A Statewide drive to block the spread of vice and veneral disease in Florida was started tonight with a roundup of diseased prostitutes who will be confined at six detention camps throughout the State.

After two-and-a-half months of reading through the 750 manuscripts submitted in Harper Bros.' 125th anniversary non-fiction contest, preliminary readers have placed the final contenders in the hands of the judges. The judges are J. Donald Adams, editor of THE NEW YORK TIMES Book Review; Harry Scherman, president of the Book-of-the-Month Club, and the editors of Harper's.
MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, Aug. 9 (U.P.) -- Foreign Minister Alberto Guani said today that "since the torpedoing of the steamer Maldonado was pure and simple piracy, Uruguayan reprisals are in order."
James McMonigle's burning eyes brought him a $50 fine, or fifteen days in jail, in week-end court yesterday.

PLYMOUTH, Vt., Aug. 9 (AP) -Lieut. Governor Mortimer R. Proctor of Vermont said today that while our American way of life is at a cross-roads in the present conflict "probably no war in history has been fought with less enthusiasm."
Licia Albanese, soprano of the Metropolitan Opera, has leased an apartment in 400 Park Avenue, it was disclosed yesterday by William A. White Sons, brokers.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 9 -- Byron Price, Director of Censorship, today issued a statement clarifying the procedure of his office regarding cable confirmations.

CHARLESTON, S.C., Aug. 9 -- The magic of modern surgery first saved the life of Private Donald Volk of Farmingdale, Long Island, and then restored him to usefulness although less than one year ago, he had been pronounced hopelessly crippled.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Aug. 9 -Charles Boyer has picked Universal's Arapahoe Indian, Acquanetta, for a featured role in his first production for this studio, "Flesh and Fantasy," in which Barbara Stanwyck is starred. Julien Duvivier is co-producer.
" Christianity is self-preservation," the Rev. Dr. Harry Emerson Fosdick declared yesterday in his sermon at The Riverside Church.

Churlish commentators have noted more than once that the tall iron fences around the playgrounds for children with which our parks are generously sprinkled look a bit like cages. What if they do? Unlike the railings around Gramercy Park, set up in another age, these fences do not serve to keep the children of the few -- along with the trees and the grass and the flowers -- safe from democracy.

A spokesman for forty teachers who are to be dismissed from the city school system on Aug. 31 asked yesterday that the Board of Education reconsider its decision and give the teachers sabbatical leaves for the Fall school term instead.

LOS ANGELES, Aug. 9 -- Nearly 300 youths were arested last night and early today as authorities pressed their campaign to stamp out juvenile gangsterism which has plagued Los Angeles and adjoining cities for months.

Despite gasoline rationing and a speed limit of forty miles an hour, automobile accidents in the State increased in the six months ended June 30. The death toll showed a small decrease from the comparative period in 1941, according to the semi-annual statistical report issued yesterday by John Splain, Commissioner of the Bureau of Motor Vehicles.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 9 -- Senator Vandenberg urged today that President Roosevelt put "the best fiscal minds of the country" at work immediately on a plan of war financing which would combine taxation with government borrowing in one comprehensive program.

The most important problem confronting the world today is the preservation of Christianity, the Right Rev. H.P. Almon Abbot, Bishop of the Episcopal Diocese of Lexington, Ky., declared yesterday in his sermon in St. Thomas Episcopal Church, Fifth Avenue at Fifty-third Street.
Various forms of economic control must continue "for a considerable time after the war," according to a League of Nations report, the opening section of which was made public here yesterday.

PITTSBURGH, Aug. 9 -- One thousand striking pitmen and helpers of No. 3 open-hearth department of the Homestead works of the Carnegie-Illinois Steel Corporation tonight yielded to the persuasion of Federal authorities and union officials and agreed to return immediately to their jobs pending mediation of their wage grievances.

A demand for immediate elimination of singing telegrams, kiddiegrams, use of messengers for dog-walking and other nonessential services, on the grounds they constitute a serious impediment to wartime communications, was made known yesterday on behalf of Joseph P. Selly, president of the American Communications Association, C.I.O. affiliate.

LENOX, Mass., Aug. 9 -- The exceedingly favorable impression made by the Berkshire Music Center Orchestra, under Serge Koussevitzky, at its initial concert last week was reinforced at the appearances of the student ensemble here in Tanglewood last night and this afternoon.

Unfavorable war news, coming on top of recent evidence of the extent to which federal taxes were cutting into earnings of industrial companies, had its natural result on sentiment, and was reflected in a dull and reactionary market. Further advance of the German armies into Russia was coupled last week with the complicated situation which arose in India.
A former Chinese dance hall proprietor from Shanghai, who is chief cook on an Allied merchantman, wants post-war Shanghai to have a Coney Island.

A nine-point program for intensifying the output of ships, coupled with a plan for organization and extension of labor-management committees in shipyards, was adopted yesterday at the closing session of a two-day conference of delegates of the Industrial Union of Marine and Shipbuilding Workers of America, C.I.O., representing 150,000 workers on the Atlantic Coast.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 9 -- The Atlantic Charter is a world-wide charter, Manuel Quezon, President of the Philippine Commonwealth, said today in a radio talk over the Columbia Broadcasting System.
LONDON, Monday, Aug. 10 (AP) -- The Glasgow Herald apparently was the only British provincial newspaper today to blame the British Government for the current situation in India.
The Socialist Party issued yesterday a statement condemning the arrest of Mohandas K. Gandhi and Pandib Jawalarlal Nehru in India and urged that no American men or arms be used in India.
WASHINGTON. Aug. 9 -- George John Dasch and Ernest Peter Burger were understood to have displayed open relief when informed they would escape the electric chair.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 9 -- Many members of the Summer colony entertained this afternoon at the Hour of Music, a lecture-recital on the compositions of Johannes Brahms, which was given by Dr. H. Emile Enthoven, pianist, composer and conductor, at the Beach Club for the benefit of the new Service Men's Club at the Malcolm R. White Post of the American Legion.

The Rev. Hugh D. Darsie of the Flatbush Christian Church (Disciples), Dorchester and Marlborough Roads, Brooklyn, predicted the realization of a warless world after the present war in his sermon yesterday morning. Members of neighboring churches attended a union service.

Father has gone to war, mother's gone to the war factory and the children are in the street, where they are rapidly becoming a major threat to war production, officials of the Child Study Association and the Committee for the Care of Children in Wartime, pointed out yesterday.

Pullman, Inc., reported yesterday for the six months ended on June 30 a consolidated net income of $9,376,922 after all charges, including provisions for Federal taxes at an assumed rate of 50 per cent and an appropriation of $5,000,000 for a special reserve, equal to $2.84 each on the 3,302,897 capital shares outstanding.

Shipments of all kinds of hosiery during June totaled 10,989,589 dozen pairs, a decrease of 7.9 per cent from June, 1941, according to figures issued for publication today by the National Association of Hosiery Manufacturers. The June shipments were the lowest for any month since July, 1940.

ALBANY, Aug. 9 -- Best in show and best American-bred at the eighth annual all-breed exhibition of the Mohawk Valley Kennel Club, held at Albany Academy today, went to the Sirarno Kennels' Kerry blue terrier, Champion Sophisticated Lady, put down in perfect condition by Ed Sayres Sr.

CHUNGKING, China, Aug. 9 (U.P.) -- The official Central News Agency said today that United States Army planes inflicted heavy casualties and leveled Japanese defense works in continued cooperation with Chinese troops battering at Linchwan [Fuchow], highway center fifty miles southeast of Nanchang, Kiangsi Province, the past few days.

Last week the Irving Fisher index of wholesale commodity prices declined from 108.4 to 108.1. The principal price change was the decrease in fuel oil. This was mainly responsible for the drop of 1.8 per cent in the fuel and lighting index and the 0.5 per cent drop in the finished goods index.
Seven new films will have their Broadway premieres this week. The schedule follows:

The baby carriage industry offers an example of the day-to-day changes in advertising plans made necessary by the war. A few weeks ago the Thayer Company was all set to go ahead with one of the biggest promotions in the history of the industry.
SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 9 -- With a single sale of $5,000 under his belt, 13-year-old Ira Nadler of New York City today is combining pleasure with patriotic service in this resort town.

RYE, N.Y., Aug. 9 -- For the first time in the history of the tournament, rain forced a cancellation of the final round of the Eastern grass-court tennis championships today and the abandonment of plans for holding the matches at the Westchester Country Club.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 9 (AP) -- A special committee charged with determining the need for government controls over wholesale and retail stocks will report within ten days to the War Production Board's Civilian Supply Division, the board said today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 9 -- The offensive operations "in force" of United States naval and other units against Japanese installations in the southeastern section of the Solomon Islands were reported as continuing by the Navy Department this afternoon.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 9 -- Leon Henderson today requested coffee roasters holding old contracts at prices lower than the Office of Price Administration's maximums to void these contracts with coffee importers voluntarily and make payment at the higher permissible ceiling levels.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 9 -- A general order designed to uncover alien interests in property held in this country under jurisdictional supervision was issued today by Leo T. Crowley, alien property custodian.

WITH THE UNITED STATES GROUND FORCES, Somewhere in Britain, Aug. 9 -- United States forces are in Britain for the express purpose of opening a second front, said Major Gen. Mark Wayne Clark, 46-year-old commander of the United States ground forces in the European theatre of operations, in a frank intervie that will go a long way toward clearing the atmosphere on both sides of the Atlantic and in Russia.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 9 -- James G. Patton, president of the National Farmers Union, decried today demands for higher farm prices, declaring that the war effort required national unity and not "partisan hog-trough tactics by farmers, labor or big business."

PITTSBURGH, Aug. 9 -- The need for more steel furnace repairs last week took steel ingot output down one point to 98 per cent of rated capacity. There were also a few cases where blast furnace relinings resulted in less pig iron, thus affecting steel output.

BERNE, Switzerland, Aug. 9 -- Consternation has been caused in Swiss commercial and industrial circles by receipt of the "blacklist" established by the Treasury Department in Washington, which, according to opinion here today, is very sweeping in character.

The Rev. Dr. Raymond C. Knox chaplain of Columbia University for the last thirty-four years, observed his last Sunday before retiring as chaplain emeritus with services yesterday at St. Paul's Chapel on the campus.

MELBOURNE, Australia, Aug. 9 (AP) -- The Australian public and press tonight hailed the news of the Allied attack on Japanese bases in the Solomon Islands with enthusiasm restrained only by the cautious meagerness of the early official reports of the fighting.

Summonses for violation of the automobile headlight dimout regulations, promulgated a week ago by Police Commissioner Valentine, are not to be issued until Aug. 20 except in cases of flagrant disobedience, the police announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 9 -- William H. Davis, chairman of the War Labor Board, today called for an increase of organized cooperation between employer and management groups as a prelude to industry-wide collective bargaining which he regarded as the next logical development in labor relations.

MOSCOW, Aug. 10 -- Russian rear-'ard forces in the region of Armavir and Kropotkin still are.beLug driven back, and the front in he Northern Caucasus is now re'ported to be wide German tanks and trucks are streaming forward along minor roads across

LONDON, Tuesday, Aug. 11 -- Tangled railroad tracks and smoldering ruins of German War factories lie in the wake of a heavy attack made Sunday night by the Royal Air Force at Osnabrueck, important industrial town northeast of the Ruhr and junction for Nazi shipments from that area to the North Sea and Baltic ports.

AUCKLAND, New Zealand, Aug. 10 -The United Nations' attack in the Solomon Islands. the first big offensive action against the Japanese in the Pacific, took the enemy completely by surprise, it is reported here. United Nations naval and air units are said to have f struck hard and swiftly, with Jap- I anese retaliation coming only after the attackers had got in the first telling blows.

LONDON, Aug. 11 -- Despite sporadic outbreaks of violence in India following the arrest of Mohandas K. Gandhi and several of his followers, there was a generally more hopeful attitude here today regarding the long-term outlook for India.

The statement of the Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company and its subsidiaries, for the six months ended June 30, shows a net profit of $4,123,961, after depreciation, interest, dividends and equity in the undistributed earnings of subsidiaries not wholly owned, Federal and foreign income and excess profits taxes, a provision of $1,500,000 for contingencies and a reserve of $6,751,247 for Far Eastern losses.

PITTSBURGH, Aug. 10 (AP) -- The Pirates hammered Mort Cooper from the box for the second time in the series today as they downed the second-place Cardinals, 6 to 4, in a play-off of the sixteen-inning 5-5 deadlock the teams waged last Saturday.
CHICAGO, Aug. 10 (AP) -- The White Sex won their ninth straight game tonight when they defeated the Indians, 3 to 1, before a crowd of 12,520.

Very few Americans will sit down with a copy of "How Collective Bargaining Works," just issued by the Twentieth Century Fund, and read its 986 pages from cover to cover. The importance of the document, however, is indicated by the fact that it carries the endorsement of Chairman W.H. Davis of the War Labor Board and Chairmnn Harry A. Millis of the National Labor Relations Board.

A three-day clinic to acquaint business men with the workings of the end-use code will be conducted by the War Production Board in the Hotel Pennsylvania starting today. Donald M. Nelson, chairman of the WPB, has invited representatives of chambers of commerce and trade associations throughout the country to attend sessions today and tomorrow.

Frieda S. Miller, State Industrial Commissioner, yesterday addressed a plea to Paul V. McNutt, chairman of the War Manpower Commission, to "go all the way toward clearing loyal aliens, so that their skills may be available to the war effort as needed."
RIO DE JANEIRO, Brazil, Aug. 10 (AP) -- South American diplomats and nationals returning from Japan fear that their continent is on Japan's invasion timetable if Eastern Australia falls.

Westchester County and parts of Northern New Jersey, still suffering from Sunday's severe rainstorm were hit again yesterday afternoon by brief but torrential downpours. Overflowing rivers and sewers flooded streets, marooning hundreds of persons and stalling automobiles on the highways.

A reorganization of the traffic division of the Police Department that is expected to reduce its personnel by 1,000 men is under consideration as a result of the sharp curtailment in automobile traffic since gasoline and tire rationing began, it was learned yesterday.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Aug. 10 -- Samuel Goldwyn has engaged Arthur Kober to write a screen vehicle for Danny Kaye, Broadway musical comedy star, whom the producer signed to a one-picture contract last Spring. Kober will base the photoplay on a stage play, "Sometimes I'm Happy," which he wrote last season as a Broadway vehicle for John Garfield, but which never materialized because of the war.

SEATTLE, Aug. 10 -- Work on the giant, hard-hitting Flying Fortresses at the Boeing Aircraft Company plants here came to a dead stop this afternoon. For a half-hour not one rivet gun chattered; the batteries of whining drills were quiet and the deep boom of the big drop hammers was stilled.
Mrs. Frederick W. Drury and Miss Frances Sands Drury of 18 East Sixtieth Street have gone to Great Barrington, Mass., for the remainder of the Summer.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 10 -- A Newport humming as never before in its history and jammed to the eaves with ensigns and civilian workers in the war effort found its population further swelled for the week by thirty-two tennis players as competition began today at the historic Casino in the twenty-sixth annual invitation tournament.

CAIRO, Egypt, Aug. l0 -- While complete stagnation of the front that extends southward from the region of El Alamein has been avoided recently only by patrol fighting and artillery activity, observers in this area are crediting the Russians for the breathing space that may provide a rested and refitted British Eighth Army for the next desert battle.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Brazil, Aug. 10 -- General Hideki Tojo, the war lord Premier of Japan, is string to establish himself as undisputed dictator over the Japanese people and has made Emperor Hirohito a virtual prisoner in the Imperial Palace, denied even access to the dally newspapers.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 -- The War Production Board took control today of the 1942 crop of six fruits used for drying to assure ample supplies for the armed services and for lease-lend needs. The fruits named are apples, apricots, peaches, pears, prunes and raisins.
NEW DELHI, India, Aug. 10 (UP) -- British Imperial troops were called out today in Bombay, Poona and Lucknow.
The Yankees, whose chief objective these days consists of solidifying their position at the head of the American League, took one step backward yesterday, then another forward.

Among today's primary contests none has evoked wider interest or involves more important issues than that of New York State's Twenty-sixth Congressional District, in which Hamilton Fish seeks renomination for the seat in Congress he has held for twenty-two years.

Sales of leading mail order and chain store companies showed an average increase of 5.3 per cent in July over the same month last year, according to a compilation made yesterday by THE NEW YORK TIMES. The figure compares with a gain of 10.2 per cent in June.
CAMDEN, N.J., Aug. 10 (AP) -- The Christiana Stable's Wessex, a son of Alfred the Great, finally earned his initial set of brackets in the third race at Garden State Park today.
MILWAUKEE, Aug. 10 -- Twelve men, buried under tons of glass and crumbled masonry, were believed dead in the ruins of a four-story warehouse that collapsed without warning today.

LAS VEGAS, Nev., Aug. 10 -- The crew and eighteen passengers of a Western Air Lines transport plane forced down on a desert lake bed and marooned when a torrential storm filled the dry bed with water, were rescued today.

In a world where sugar and spice and virtually everything nice is a bit on the scarce side, it seems strange indeed to hear of a sudden new surplus rather than a sudden new shortage. And yet reports emanating from the United States Department of Agriculture indicate that one homely staple and standby -- evaporated milk -- is plentiful now as it never was before the war.

If fresh water anglers are looking for a lake where there are no restrictions on the amount of perch they catch, they had better start for Bantam Lake, Litchfield, Conn., at their earliest convenience.
A High Command Communique, broadcast from Berlin and recorded here by The Associated Press:

WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 -- In forty years, from 1900 to 1940, the death rate for all ages in this country decreased from 17.2 per 1,000 persons to 10.8, a decline of nearly 38 per cent, the Census Bureau indicated today.

Swiss traders here expressed bewilderment yesterday over published reports that commercial and industrial circles in Switzerland were shocked by the United States blacklist, which they deemed "very sweeping in character." Importers of Swiss merchandise pointed out that, currently, business has been generally satisfactory, and while there have been some difficulties with the authorities adjustments have been accomplished without serious inconvenience, they said.
AT SEA, Aug. 9 (Delayed) (AP) -- An entire whaleboat crew of a destroyer escort vessel plying the Atlantic has been commended as a result of the thrilling rescue of two men in heavy seas.
The German radio broadcast yesterday what it described as "further details," furnished by the Japanese, on the Battle of the Solomons. The broadcast, recorded by The Associated Press, said:

George De Vincentis, a husky 29-year-old public links player from Forest Park, stole the show in the eleventh annual World Telegram hole-in-one contest when he placed a No. 6 iron shot four inches from the pin on the 135-yard special hole at Bayside links today.

MOSCOW, Aug. 10 (U.P.) -- Major Gen. Follett Bradley, special United State envoy facilitating American war deliveries to the Red Army, declared today that he had "absolute faith the Russians will stand fast."

Considerable interest has been aroused in the sugar trade over reports that the Office of Price Administration and the United States Tariff Commission have begun a study to determine whether increased labor, fuel and other production costs justify an increase in the ceiling price of sugar.

PITTSBURGH, Aug. 10 -- The C.I.O. United Steel Workers of America and representatives of five subsidiaries of the United States Steel Corporation broke off contract negotiations today when, according to a union statement, the corporation refused to grant demands already recommended by the War Labor Board to 157,000 employes of "Little Steel" plants.

CHICAGO, Aug. 10 (AP) -- Mrs. Russell Mann of Omaha, defending the women's Western amateur golf title, fired a record-tying, par-equaling 77 today to take medalist honors in this forty-second competition among the nation's leading feminine players.

Net asset value of the Chicago Corporation on June 30 was $23,506,426, equal to $49 a share of outstanding convertible preference stock, comparing with $50.76 a share on Dec. 31, 1941. The preference stock at present has claim to $52.25 a share, representing the original stated value of the stock plus $2.25 in dividend arrears to June 30, 1942.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 -- Senator Clark of Missouri told the Senate today that he would seek to force a vote on legislation making its permissible for the War and Navy Departments to make soldiers' dependency payments before Nov. 1 if the Senate Military Affairs Committee refused to report out a bill to this end.

CAZENOVIA, N.Y., Aug. 10 -- Milton L. Hanauer of the Marshall Chess Club, State champion in 1926, is making a bold bid for his old title at the annual meeting of the New York State Chess Association at Cazenovia Junior College.

New York is one of the five American cities named by the National Noise Abatement Council as winners of achievement awards for "outstanding accomplishment in the elimination of needless noise" and for "distinguished service" to the council's wartime program, William Reynolds, council president, announced yesterday.

Dr. Albert G. Odell, college official, psychiatrist and member of the staff of The Sanitarium, Clifton Springs, N.Y., was elected Grand Master of the Grand Council of Royal and Selected Masters of the State of New York, at the 119th annual assembly of the Masonic organization yesterday in the Masonic Temple, Clermont and Lafayette Avenues, Brooklyn.

Bob Montgomery, Philadelphia lightweight, concluded training at Summit, N.J., yesterday for his engagement with Bobby Ruffin of Astoria at Madison Square Garden Thursday night when three ten-rounders, are scheduled. Montgomery boxed a round with Cliff Dyes and three rounds with Cleo Shans, who is to meet Maxie Shapiro in one of the tens.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Aug. 10 -- A new attack by Premier Vidkun Quisling on the Norwegian church occurred today when he dissolved by decree the Provisional Church Council that was formed in Oslo by five church leaders July 25.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 10 -- Samuel D. Riddle was host at the restaurant today at the racetrack to Mr. and Mrs. W. Plunkett Stewart and her daughter, Miss Averell Smith, and Mrs. Spalding L. Jenkins, who have arrived to be house guests of the Riddles.
CHUNGKING, Aug. 10 (Reuter) -- A Chinese communique:

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 10 -- A naval court of six officers ended the court-martial of Lieut. Comdr. Maurice N. Aroff today by drawing up an unannounced verdict, indicating that the defendant had been found guilty, to some degree at least, on all charges and specifications.

A team of contract bridge masters representing the New York Bridge Whist Club won the national masters' team-of-four championship in the tournament which, after eight days of play, came to a close at the Park Central Hotel here yesterday.

Among those reported yesterday as having taken new residential quarters was Jacques Rosenstein, a Dutch financier, who leased an apartment of seven rooms and three baths at 140 Riverside Drive through the Apartment Renting Company, Inc., brokers.
Miniature scale models of apartments are being used by the Gresham Management Company, Inc., to aid foot-weary home-seekers, according to J. Edgar Muir of that organization.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Brazil, Aug. 10 (U.P.) -- Three big Japanese liners -- the Yasakuni and Iwata Maru, believed converted to aircraft carriers, and the troop-laden Nitta Maru -- were among the first ships sunk by United Nations submarines in the Pacific, United States newspaper men who arrived here today from the Far East reported.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 -- A letter authorizing Henry J. Kaiser, West Coast shipbuilder, to prepare and submit engineering plans, along with complete data on the facilities and the materials which would be necessary, for the construction of 500 Martin Mars cargo-carrying planes, was issued today by Donald M. Nelson, chairman of the War Production Board.
LONDON, Aug. 10 -- A moving offer from a man in Connecticut to King George was disclosed at Newcastle today by George Carter, director of demolition and reclamation.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 -- Indictments for treason or misprision of treason knowledge of it, will be asked against the fourteen New York and Chicago confederates of the eight Nazi saboteurs, it was learned today after a conference between Attorney General Biddle and his staff.
PERKASIE, Pa., Aug. 10 -- Pearl S. Buck, the author, has issued the following statement on the arrest of Mohandas K. Gandhi and the rioting in India:

The report of the Western Union Telegraph Company for the first six months of this year, made public yesterday by A.N. Williams, president, shows a net income after operating expenses, taxes and other charges, of $3,695,014. This was equal to $3.53 a share on the company's 1,045,277 shares of capital stock outstanding, and compares with a net of $3,435,899, or $3.29 a share, in the first half of last year.
National League pitchers who feel the urge to throw bean balls in the future may do so -- if their managers are willing to pay $200.

Accusing Mayor La Guardia of having "made himself the absolute czar of civilian defense in this town," Borough President James A. Burke of Queens took the Mayor to task yesterday for failing to call a single meeting of the city's war council since it was formed last June.

The announcement by Paul V. McNutt, administrator of the Office of Defense Health and Welfare Services and chairman of the War Manpower Commission, that a drive to increase production through improving industrial nutrition will be vigorously pressed, was hailed yesterday by the Grocery Manufacturers of America, co-sponsors of the national nutrition program.

THIS observer is pretty sore at Mr. Elmer Davis, the Director of the Office of War Information. He sent never a warning word to the public about that Naval Aviation five-man skeet team and, as a consequence, this innocent by-stander had his eye wiped in fine fashion when the flexible gunners in Navy flying suits won the national team championship at the recent Syracuse shooting.

In the lightest trading since July 1, but of such an indifferent nature that the session's proceedings were purely a matter "of record," prices on the stock market showed yesterday changes of trifling proportions. Wall Street pictured the war news -- fuller details on the Solomon Islands attack, the trend of the fighting on the Russian front and the strife in India -- as the main brake on active interest.
Your editorial "Wasting Rubber," Aug. 6, is right to the point, as it shows up the half-baked manner in which almost everything has been messed up by those responsible for the various functions.
Between 900 and 1,100 employes of the General Cable Corporation's plant, on West First Street, Bayonne, N.J., went on strike last midnight.

GOSHEN, N.Y., Aug. 10 (AP) -- Three days of Grand Circuit racing, featured by the $40,000 Hambletonian on Wednesday, get under way at Good Time Park tomorrow with 2-year-old trotters and pacers matching strides in the feature races.

PAWTUCKET, R.I., Aug. 10 (AP) -- Narragansett Park opened its forty-two-day Summer meeting to day with a throng estimated ,at more than 12,000 aiding the Treasury Department Day program by purchasing admission with war stamps and then buying additional stamps and bonds throughout the afternoon.

LONDON, Aug. 10 (AP) -- Giving point to General Spaatz's assertions today about impending American air action on this front -- assertions made soon after he had completed a flying inspection of United States airdromes in the British Isles -- was the announced arrival of additional contingents of American troops.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 10 -- The surgical dressings workroom of the Hampton Chapter of the American Red Cross opened here this morning in the Finchley Building in Main Street. Mrs. Charles Morgan and Mrs. Cecil Fairbank are co-chairmen of the program for the Hampton Chapter which also has workrooms in East Hampton, Westhampton, East Moriches, Bridgehampton, Mastic, Quogue and Center Moriches.
MOSCOW, Tuesday, Aug. 11 (AP) -- The Soviet midnight communique:

BOSTON, Aug. 10 (AP) -- New England firms received top orders in awards of contracts for nearly 3,000,000 pairs of black carbon rubber taps and 1,202,592 pairs of leather taps for service shoes announced today by the Boston Quartermaster Depot. Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company of Windsor, Vt., as awarded 347,465 pairs of the first type and the Tanners Cut Sole Company, Boston, 307,982 pairs of the second.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 -- Officials at the White House and the State Department withheld formal comment today on the uprisings in India on the independence issue.

CALCUTTA, India, Aug. 10 (U.P.) -- Authorities arrested two All-India Congress party leaders today in a quick move to prevent a paralyzing strike in the war-production factories of Calcutta by followers of Mohandas K. Gandhi.

CHICAGO, Aug. 10 -- Liquidation by holders of corn futures was stepped up to a more rapid tempo on the Board of Trade today as fears that a coming Department of Agriculture crop estimate would show a larger yield than expected. Stop loss orders were uncovered when the December and May deliveries went into new seasonal low ground.

Rolling up the best July production in history, the United States steel industry thus far in 1942 has turned out 49,719,071 net tons of ingots and steel for castings, 4.3 per cent ahead of 47,680,428 tons produced in the 1941 period, the previous best seven months, and within 2 per cent of production in the whole of 1917, the peak year in World War I, according to the American Iron and Steel Institute.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 -- Representative Holland accused the publishers of The New York Daily News, Washington Times-Herald, and The Chicago Tribune of committing "moral sabotage" and further told the House:

Bids on a substantial number of the 1,000,000 raincoats sought by the Army through the Quartermaster Depot of Philadelphia were reported placed yesterday by several firms in the garment industry and some raincoat manufacturers here. While the deadline for the bidding had been extended from Saturday to yesterday, the situation continued confused in several respects, and there was no widespread participation by the local needle industries.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 -- The Chicago Tribune, which has been accused of publishing confidential information about the battle of Midway, was attacked in the House of Representatives today and defended in the Senate.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 -- Asserting that the war production effort was "faltering badly" behind the President's goals, the House Defense Migration Committee, in a report presented today by John H. Tolan, chairman, severely criticized Donald M. Nelson, head of the War Production Board, for alleged transfer of authority over procurement and production to the armed services.

Four Democratic and two Republican contests for Congressional nominations hold the center of interest today as enrolled members of New York's three major parties choose candidates for local office and delegates to State and judicial conventions in primary elections.

MOSCOW, Tuesday, Aug. 11 -- The powerful German drive in the Caucasus has carried all the way to the region of Maikop, which produces 7 per cent of Russia's oil, the Soviet High Command acknowledged in a communique issued today.

Sol Lesser has closed a deal with United Artists to release his film, "Stage Door Canteen." The story deals with the canteens for service men of the United Nations which the American Theatre Wing War Service has opened in New York and elsewhere.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 -- In blunt, homespun fashion that must have recalled to many readers the style of a retired radio speaker who was their favorite, the Office of War Information has made its first public attempt to, as directed, "facilitate the development of an informed and intelligent understanding of the status and progress of the war effort."

NEWARK, N.J., Aug. 10 -- Anthony Cassale, 47 years old, a former Kearny police court recorder and former chairman of Kearny Draft Board 36, was released in $5,000 bail following his arrest today by FBI agents on a charge of violating the Selective Service Act.

The United States offensive in the Solomon Islands mainly is against Japanese-held Tulagi, which has a deep, hurricane-free anchorage almost vital in General Douglas MacArthur's scheme to reconquer the Southwest Pacific, it is noted by The Associated Press.

The German High Command announced yesterday that German motorized forces advancing rapidly through the foothills of the Caucasian Mountains had captured Pyatigorsk, about 150 miles southeast of Maikop and a few miles below the Rostov-Baku railway.

The name of 0wen D. Young, industrialist and spokesman for dairy farmers, was advanced again yesterday as a potential "dark horse" Democratic candidate for Governor this Fall despite the conflicting claims made by backers of Senator James M. Niead and Attorney General John J. Bennett Jr. that each had a majority of delegates to the nominating convention.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 10 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission cited Guaranty Underwriters, Inc., of Jacksonville, Fla., today for a hearing on the question of revocation of the corporation's registration as the result of alleged frauds perpetrated against customers.
LONDON, Aug. 10 -- The chief feature of today's stock market was falls in Kaffirs and Indian shares. Otherwise trading was dull.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 -- Official statements that the Navy needs 1,000 officers and 10,000 enlisted women in the WAVES do not mean that the present drive to enroll these numbers will fill the ranks of the Women's Reserve for the duration of the war, the Navy Department indicated.

David A. Savage, attorney for thirty-six of the sixty-five Welfare Department investigators dismissed by Mayor La Guardia last Saturday, said yesterday that he would start action in Supreme Court tomorrow or Thursday to regain the lost positions.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 -- Following is the text of the statement by Admiral Ernest J. King, Commander in Chief of the United States Fleet, on the landing of American forces in the Solomon Islands:

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 10 -- The veteran trainer, Sunny Jim Fitzsimmons, put over a double today with Ogden Phipps's Ship's Run in the Burnt Hills Purse and the Wheatley Stable's Eire in the mile test that was seventh on the program. Run over a sloppy track, the races were watched by 5,637 spectators who wagered $326,474 on the eight events and the daily double.

HARTFORD, Conn., Aug. 10 -- The joint Army-Navy "E" award was presented in East Hartford this afternoon to the Hamilton Standard Propeller Division of the United Aircraft Corporation. Simultaneously ceremonies took place at Hamilton's branch factory at Pawcatuck, Conn., which was connected with the microphones in East Hartford.

CHICAGO, Aug. 10 -- Hearings were begun here today by a Federal emergency board of three members in an effort to end disputes over wages and paid vacations for the non-operating personnel of about thirty short-line railroads.

We call it a blue Monday, or a blue Saturday, for that matter, when all the news in the paper is bad. Actually such days of unrelieved gloom are very rare. There is almost always a silver lining to be found if one will take the trouble to look for it.

The percentage of retail charge accounts frozen as of yesterday in accordance with the Federal Reserve credit regulations may prove smaller than the 22 per cent noted on July 10, when the regulations first went into effect, retail executives here said yesterday.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Brazil, Aug. 10 -- Although some quarters regarded Japan's attack on the Americans and on the British in the Far East as a gigantic act of national harakiri, the rapid advances of the Japanese military and naval forces southward through the Philippines, the Malay peninsula and the Netherland Indies have clearly indicated far-reaching and elaborate plans conceived by Tokyo's general staff for the military subjugation of the entire Orient.
Letters and pamphlets flowed from the office of the League of Women Voters, 461 Fourth Avenue, yesterday, in response to a flood of telephone inquiries about the primary elections today.

Hardly anything could please the Axis Powers more than the news from India. The Congress party outlawed, Gandhi, Nehru and other popular leaders under arrest, strikes and riots from Bombay and Karachi on the Arabian Sea to Calcutta, Cawnpore, Lucknow and Delhi, troops shooting down demonstrators -- the squeaking spokesmen of Berlin cannot get to the radio fast enough, and one hardly need listen to be sure what they will say.

It was open house in Franklin Simon's college shop yesterday afternoon. By way of celebrating the opening, the college board girls invited their friends in to view the display and clothes, and to sip a glass of milk or milk chocolate at the diminutive white bar set up in the middle of the shop.

Sales of New York and Brooklyn department stores showed a decrease of 12 per cent last week in comparison with the same week last year, according to the "flash report" issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.

VICHY, France, Aug. 10 -- The first 1,000 French war prisoners to be released from German prison camps in exchange for French workers who have gone to Germany will reach France tomorrow, it was announced here tonight.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 -- The Office of Price Administration today undertook the task of assembling a "stock list" of usable second-hand machinery offered for sale in the United States, together with a price list of the available items.
MOSCOW, Aug. 10 (AP) -- A Soviet Information Bureau communique:

WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 (AP) -- President Roosevelt sent to the Senate today the nominations of twenty-four brigadier generals for promotion to major generals and of eighty-one colonels for promotion to brigadier generals.
