Paul Porter, chairman of the Shipbuilding Stabilization Committee, operating under the War Production Board, announced yesterday, following a meeting of the committee at the Hotel New Yorker, that eighty additional shipyards working on war contracts would be invited to join the stabilization agreements now in force in the industry.
PORTLAND, Ore., Aug. 10 -- The Oregon Shipbuilding Corporation, which has built a Liberty ship in forty-six days, a national record, promised today to cut at least eleven days from that record.

The volume of business of members of the National Association of Merchandise Brokers, under their new form of operation, increased from 12 to 16 per cent during May, June and July over the same months last year, it was estimated yesterday by Julius Perlmutter, executive director of the association.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 -- American forces have landed in the Tulagi area of the Solomon Islands in the course of an engagement that has been in progress for about three days and is continuing, according to a Navy announcement issued today over the signature of Admiral Ernest J. King, Commander in Chief of the United States Fleet.

The criticism that I have to express in this letter is not intended for Elmer Davis. He has not yet had time to develop a formula for the presentation of the war news to the public. I myself have high hopes for his success in managing this job, for I know something of his ability, training and wide experience.

The cotton futures market yesterday prolonged the decline started Saturday following the government's unexpectedly high estimate of the probable crop yield. At one time prices on active months on the New York Cotton Exchange were as much as $1.10 a bale lower but price-fixing by the trade in late dealings won back part of the lost ground and quotations at the close were 10 to 14 points below Saturday's final prices.

WOODBRIDGE, N.J., Aug. 10 -- Thieves who got through a basement window from which the bars had been removed by workmen drilled out the combination lock in the night depository vault in the basement of the Woodbridge National Bank, 106 Main Street, last night and escaped with an unknown amount of cash and checks.

Charges of conspiracy, coercion, discrimination and misappropriation of funds against the president, treasurer, secretary and two trustees of the Gasoline Station and Parking Attendants Union of Greater New York and Vicinity, Local 917, A.F. of L., were filed yesterday in Supreme Court by Ralph Weeks, who identified himself as vice president of the organization.

BOSTON, Aug. 10 -- A battle between enemy submarines and destroyers and corvettes protecting a United States-bound convoy nine days out of a Russian port was described today by John Tattersall of Haverhill, able-bodied seaman.

A coupon-rationing plan for fuel oil in the Eastern States that contemplates a 25 per cent overall cut in consumption in the district, but would apportion oil to consumers in part on the basis of temperatures in the various communities, is being discussed in Washington by Secretary of the Interior Harold L. Ickes, Petroleum Coordinator, with oil company officials, it was learned in oil circles here yesterday.

MELBOURNE, Australia, Aug. 10 -- Prime Minister John Curtin, opening a Premiers' conference today, said that even if Australia came down to a stark subsistence level it would be the government's duty increasingly to divert to war purposes whatever there was in the nation's potential.

CHUNGKING, Aug. 9 (U.P.) -- Hsienning, Japanese concentration center thirty miles southwest of the great Yangtze River port of Hankow, was attacked this afternoon by fighter-bombers of the Twenty-third American Pursuit Squadron, operating from Hengyang, United States Hunan Province air base 240 miles to the south.
Two blockfronts were among the properties in the city reported yesterday as having changed hands.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 -- President Roosevelt nominated Leland B. Morris to be Minister to Iceland and nominated a large group of high-ranking officers in the Army, Marine Corps and Navy for promotion.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 -- Only members of the armed forces, civilians who are classed as "essential" and workers in war industries who actually need them will be able to buy bicycles after next Saturday as the result of a new order by the Office of Price Administration restricting the list of persons who are eligible for wheels.

BOMBAY, India, Aug. 10 -- Tear gas was dropped from a plane today on milling masses of Indian independence rioters, whose clashes with the police have taken eighteen lives and wounded 209 persons here in two days.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 (AP) -- Snub-nosed, low-slung landing boats, with twin machine guns jutting from their armored bows and from thirty to fifty fully armed United States marines loaded aboard, strike most effectively against resistance in landing attacks, Marine Corps officials here said today.

"Bull in a China-Shop" is a proverbial phrase for a person who does a lot of harm through carelessness, ignorance or blind anger. It comes, says one dictionarian, '"from a story of a runaway bull breaking into a china-shop and smashing its contents in his furious movements."

SOMEWHERE IN AUSTRALIA, Aug. 10 -- Last Thursday American correspondents and press association writers sent from Australia dispatches saying in effect that comparatively few American soldiers and only "a trickle" of airplanes had been sent to Australia from the United States.

The Bowery Savings Bank, largest mutual savings bank in the United States, is now insured by the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, it was announced yesterday by Leo T. Crowley, chairman of the corporation. With the inclusion of the Bowery, a total of seven mutual savings banks in this city now have their deposits insured by the FDIC.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 -- The War Department announced today the names of seventy-seven additional United States soldiers missing in action. On the list were nineteen officers and twenty-seven enlisted men missing in Alaska; five officers and twenty enlisted men -- missing at Midway, and six enlisted men missing in Hawaii.

CHICAGO, Aug. 10 (AP) -- Heavier weight hogs advanced 10 cents a hundredweight today, making up some of the ground lost late last week, while offerings scaling 240 pounds and less held steady. Trade was fairly active with a good demand from all outlets. Top price again hit $15 for the fourth consecutive day.

Fattening up at the expense of the Phils is one of the things the Dodgers do best. So it was with a great deal of relish that the Brooks tangled with the cellar occupants in last evening's twilight game at Ebbets Field. With Pete Reiser back in the line-up after a week's absence, the Dodgers found the Philadelphia diet to their liking and romped to a 6-0 triumph after three straight setbacks.

GRAND RAPIDS, Mich., Aug. 10 (AP) -- The printing and publishing industry was warned today that it must prepare "cheerfully to grub out its own salvation amid the shortages of labor and materials that appear all too close."

Malta, England's tough little island air fortress on sea routes to Africa fifty-eight miles south of Axis-held Sicily, "has been and still is" a hub of Allied destinies in the Mediterranean, British Air Vice Marshal Sir Hugh Pughe Lloyd said here yesterday.

"Priorities of 1942," which has earned the distinction of outdistancing other vaudeville bills in longevity here, will say good-bye to the Forty-sixth Street on Sept. 5. It has been residing at that house since March 12. On Sept. 7 the show will commence a fortnight's stand at the Forrest, Philadelphia.

NEWARK, N.J., Aug. 10 (AP) -- In the longest game of the International League this season the Bears beat Jersey City, 3 to 2, in the nineteenth inning today when Russ Derry slammed a home run into the right-field bleachers. It was the longest game ever played here, requiring 4 hours 21 minutes.

CHUNGKING, China, Aug. 10 (AP) -- Catching the Japanese completely off guard, both fighters and bombers of the United States Army Air Forces attacked the big invasion port of Haiphong, Indo-China, yesterday and got back to base without a loss, Lieut. Gen. Joseph W. Stilwell's headquarters announced today.
DETROIT, Aug. 10 -- Steps to mobilize 75,000 to 80,000 women of the Detroit area for work in war plants began today with delivery of the questionnaires for voluntary registration.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks of the Federal Reserve System in 101 leading cities shows the following principal changes for the week ended Aug. 5: A decrease of $532,000,000 in demand deposits adjusted, and increases of $338,000,000 in United States Government deposits and $112,000,000 in deposits credited to domestic banks.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Aug. 10 (U.P.) -- The newspaper Tidningens today quoted German press reports as saying that Nazi aerial reconnaissance over Britain had disclosed signs of Allied preparation to invade the European Continent.
MELBOURNE, Aug. 10 -- Newspaper comments on the allied counterattack on the Solomon Islands assumed a cautious tone today.

HARTFORD, Conn., Aug. 10 -- After first granting it on a defense motion this afternoon, Federal Judge J. Joseph Smith suspended an order to permit counsel for the Rev. Kurt E.B. Molzahn of Philadelphia, being tried for alleged espionage conspiracy, to question three prisoners who have pleaded guilty to the indictment -- G. Wilhelm Kunze, national leader of the German-American bunds; Dr. Wolfgang Ebell of El Paso, Texas, and Dr. Otto Willumeit of Chicago.

Manufacturers of upholstered furniture, many of whom have been scrambling for weeks to build up their stocks of springs, were growing alarmed yesterday over the prospect of having several months' supply left over after Nov. 1, when their use no longer will be permitted under L-135, issued Saturday by the War Production Board.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 (AP) -- Describing growing conditions as the best on record for this time of year, the Department of Agriculture reported today that the total volume of all crops this year was expected to be 21 per cent above the average output of the decade prior to adoption of Federal crop control programs.
The long sought after piccolo player for the WAAC band is almost within grasp at Army Recruiting Headquarters, 39 Whitehall Street.

Formal complaints from Army and Navy authorities of a huge increase in prostitution with a corresponding increase in venereal disease brought orders yesterday from Police Commissioner Valentine for a concentrated drive to curb the condition.

Following a one-day rest, the Giants left last night for Boston, where today they will open a three-game series with the Braves. A contest had been scheduled originally for yesterday but it was deferred some time ago to make a double-header tomorrow.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 (AP) -- The Senators won both ends of a double-header from Boston here tonight, shutting out the visitors for a 1-to-0 victory in the nightcap after winning a twilight game, 9 to 3.
May I make a strong plea to write off last Summer's aluminum drive and label it a dead issue once and for all?

LONDON, Aug. 10 -- Private Travis P. Hammone of Keltys, Texas, of the American Army, came before a United State general court- martial in a small English town today under the Ninety-second Article of War, accused of the rape of a 17-year-old-English shop assistant who is a voluntary Y.M.C.A. worker

Leaders of both right and left wing factions of the American Labor Party, engaged in an acrimonious struggle for control of the party's machinery, expressed confidence yesterday in the outcome of today's primary voting.

Supreme Court Justice Felix C. Benvenga yesterday dismissed suit brought by Richard Childs, as chairman of the Citizens Union to compel Park Commissioner Robert Moses and Public Works Commissioner Irving V.A. Huie to give up their positions as members of the City Planning Commission on the ground that they have no right to hold "dual jobs."

Edward R. Stettinius Jr., chairman of the Lease-lend Administration, arrived from Europe yesterday aboard a Pan-American Clipper. On leaving the plane at La Gaurdia Field, he declined to be interviewed on his trip to England for which he had left on July 15, but handed out a long type-written statement.

PINE CAMP, N.Y., Aug. 10 (AP) -- Future generals of the United States Army were buck privates today as 2,000 cadets from West Point took the art of war from the classroom into the field of practice in extensive manoeuvres.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 -- Public curiosity aroused by the published announcement that Rear Admiral Husband E. Kimmel, the Pacific Fleet commander when Pearl Harbor was attacked, is now holding a civilian job in New York has prompted an inquiry to the Navy Department as to whether he is receiving retirement pay from the Navy.

In concerted protest against Quisling regulations 96 per cent of Norwegian publishers have called a halt to issuing books. This is learned through a recent issue of The Times Literary Supplement, London, which reached here yesterday.
CAIRO, Egypt, Aug. 10 (U.P.) -- United States heavy bombers have attacked three ships in a daylight raid on the Axis supply port of Bengazi, it was announced today.

Since its establishment last December the Civil Air Patrol of the Office of Civilian Defense "has been responsible for the obliteration of many markers and some ground installations that might have aided enemy planes," James M. Landis, national OCD director, declared yesterday in a statement made public by regional headquarters.

BALTIMORE, Md., Aug. 10 -- The seventy-ton flying boat Mars, which the War Production Board has approved in a general way for production by Henry J. Kaiser, shipbuilder, has a supercharged cabin and air-conditioning equipment for high-altitude flight.

LONDON, Aug. 10 -- The American Red Cross Harvard Field Hospital Unit, after one year's service in Britain, has been taken over by the United States Army, it was announced here today. Many of its sixty-two Red Cross nurses have volunteered to stay on with the rank of second lieutenant, while others have scattered to Red Cross Clubs throughout the British Isles.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Brazil, Aug. 10 -- The Swedish liner Gripsholm, bearing more than 1,500 North and South American nationals evacuated from the Orient, arrived here today from Lourenco Marques, Portuguese East Africa, on her way to the United States.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 -- Fears that "as many as 1,000" war plants might be forced to cut production this month and next for lack of materials were voiced by the Labor Policy Committee of the War Production Board in a resolution adopted July 30.

Activities of British censors at Bermuda, which played a part last Friday at the trial in Federal court here of Werner von Clemm, were cited again yesterday when United States Attorney Mathias F. Correa introduced into evidence a copy the censors had made of a letter received by the diamond importer.
Eighty inspectors of the State Motor Vehicle Bureau began a five-day course of instructor training in war emergency rescue transport yesterday afternoon in the State Building, 80 Center Street.

Subway dimout tests to determine whether more light can be provided for passengers and still meet the Army's requirements were made last night by engineers for the Board of Transportation. Earlier in the day E.E. Dotting, superintendent of lighting for the board, had announced that the city hoped to work out some improvement.

SAM BYRD, a descendant of a "connection" of the famous William Byrd of Westover, played the role of Dude Lester in "Tobacco Road" for eleven hundred and fifty-one consecutive performances. Intelligence and compassion are not attributes of Erskine Caldwell characters, but that simply means that Sam Byrd had to have plenty of both qualities to simulate the poor white mentality which is diametrically opposed to his own.

An indictment of the colleges for failing to meet the needs of women and to prepare them for "certain inevitabilities" that they must face is made in a survey called "Women After College," published last week by the Columbia University Press.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 -- The Senate Finance Committee, by a vote of 11 to 4, rejected a Treasury proposal today whereby, recipients of earned income in eight community property States would have had to pay individual income taxes on the same basis as citizens of other States.

RIO DE JANEIR0, Brazil, Aug. 10 -- According to the propaganda fed the Japanese people by the military clique that has seized control of the Japanese Government, Japan is prepared to wage war for a hundred years and will not stop till the United States and Britain are crushed, till Japanese troops parade down Piccadilly and the Japanese Navy holds a victory review off New York.

Sir Walter Monckton, former director general of the British Ministry of Information, arrived at La Guardia Field yesterday aboard an American Export Line Flying Ace with fifteen other passengers from Europe.

WASHINGTON, April 11 -- Executives of three of the smaller steel companies told the Truman committee today that in the midst of demands for finished steel for war production they were being forced to operate at 67 to 78 per cent of normal capacity because of inability to obtain raw materials and alloys from larger companies.

The shortage of doctors in the ever-expanding Army Medical Corps is becoming so acute that married physicians were warned yesterday by officials at Selective Service headquarters here that their deferred 3-A draft classification already was "decidedly temporary and may not be continued for many more months."

A nation-wide war relief budget of $75,659,000 for ten major war relief organizations, with an unallocated reserve of $13,500,000 included, was recommended yesterday by the National Budget Committee for War Appeals. The total is $10,000,000 less than the original estimates made last month.

CHICAGO, Aug. 11 -- Mrs. Russell Mann's bid for a second straight women's Western amateur golf crown was in peril for 14 holes today, but the Omaha veteran found her game in time to escape elimination in the first round of match play.

The selection of Governor Lehman as temporary chairman of the Democratic State Convention to be held Aug. 19 and 20 at the Hotel St. George, Brooklyn, was announced yesterday by Frank V. Kelly, Brooklyn leader, who is chairman of the committee on temporary officers.

Aug. 15 has been mentioned in many diplomatic dispatches and reports as the date likely to be selected by Japan for striking at the Soviet Union in Siberia. The offensive that United States Army, Navy and Air Forces launched on the Japanese-held Solomon Islands may have been timed to hold back Tokyo with some sober reflection and to make General Hideki Tojo think twice before shouldering a new heavy task.

Bronx police reported yesterday that in the last two weeks they have had many frantic calls for the return of rationing books that were either stolen or lost. At the same time, Adolph J. Chesley, Bronx Federal Rationing Administrator, warned recipients of rationing books against general carelessness because of the difficulty encountered before lost or stolen books can be replaced.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 (U.P.) -- Red Cross officials said today that the Japanese Government had not guaranteed safe conduct for a ship to carry parcels to American prisoners of war in the Far East, and the prospects of receiving such a guarantee were "discouraging."

Mayor La Guardia replied last night to criticism of his handling of civilian defense made by Borough President James A. Burke of Queens by saying that Mr. Burke had been negligent in attending to his own defense duties.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 -- The American invasion attempt at Tulagi, Japanese base in the Solomon Islands, continued through the fourth day of fighting with no word as to conclusive results received at the Navy Department up to a late hour tonight.

Mrs. William C. Breed, chairman of the national amateur championship tennis matches to benefit the American Women's Voluntary Services, will give a tennis party this afternoon at the River Club for her committee and the assisting junior committee.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 (AP) -- An Office of Price Administration spokesman said today that fuel oil might be rationed in the East according to regional temperatures and the number of persons in a family.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 (AP) -- Under the demands of war production the average work week of American workers increased by one hour, from 45.7 to 46.7, during the year ended in June, the Works Progress Administration reported today.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 11 (AP) -Stockholders of the Standard Oil Company of New Jersey stand to receive $81,850,770 of gas utilities in a "new" company if a Standard Oil plan to escape the Holding Company Act goes through, it was disclosed today.

Peanut puppets made by the children of the Play Schools Association were given to the British War Relief Society shop, 6 East Fifty-seventh Street, yesterday, and were immediately placed on sale in the shop the proceeds to be sent to British children in bombed areas.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 -- President Roosevelt, in a message issued today through the Jewish Telegraphic Agency to the Jews of America as a prelude to Rosh ha-Shanah, the Jewish New Year. which will be observed Sept. 12, pledged that "there shall be no compromise in the struggle against hate, intolerance and bigotry."

BAYONNE, N.J., Aug. 11 -- An "independent" strike of about 1,000 employes of the General Cable Corporation plant, here, was started shortly after last midnight in protest against the refusal by the management or the War Labor Board to meet wage increase demands and to give vacations with pay.

A nineteen-year-old aircraftsman second class in the Royal Canadian Air Force was held at Police Headquarters on a charge of being a fugitive from justice from Toronto where, the police said, he was wanted for stealing a $1,000 diamond ring.

HOLLYWOOD, Aug. 11 (U.P.) -- Clark Gable, who abandoned his screen career when his wife, Carole Lombard, was killed in an airplane crash early this year, wound up his affairs today to join the army as a private. He received his physical examination yesterday and will be sworn in tomorrow.

The late Brig. Gen. William (Billy) Mitchell, foremost of the early exponents of air power, had been working shortly before his death in 1936 on what might have become a frank autobiography telling the whole story of his futile fight

WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 (AP) -- A Department of Agriculture survey showed today that while net incomes of farm families averaged 46 per cent higher in 1941 and in the first three months of 1942 than in the comparable period in 1935-36, living costs had increased approximately one-third.

A special continuous controlled-temperature dehydration process for beef, said to permit retention of much of the attractiveness and flavor of the natural product, has been developed by Swift Co., it was announced here yesterday by George Mitchell, New York district manager.
ALBANY, Aug. 11 (AP) -- The State has borrowed $395,000 to maintain its seventy parks until next July, being forced to the step by reduced revenue from tire and gasoline rationed vacationists.

NEWARK, N.J., Aug. 11 -- The State Board of Public Utility Commissioners, after a five-hour hearing here today, found that Glick Bengemann, Inc., of Camden, has carried horse-racing fans to and from the Camden State Race-track in Delaware township, in buses that had been licensed exclusively to serve war workers.

BAYONNE, N.J., Aug. 11 -- Several hundred residents of Bayonne added to their meager gasoline supplies tonight when construction workers accidentally sprung a leak in a gasoline pipe-line that runs from Jersey City to the Tidewater Associated Oil Company's storage plant at Constable Hook, Bayonne.

KEARNY, N.J., Aug. 11 -- The war cargo carrier African Star was launched at 9:38 A. 3K. today at the yard here of the Federal Shipbuilding and Drydock Company, the thirtieth cargo vessel built at the yard since the start of the merchant marine program of the United States laritime Commission three years ago.

DETROIT, Aug. 11 (U.P.) -- The Tigers lost their second regular in twenty-four hours today with announcement that Birdie Tebbetts, first-string catcher, has been ordered to report immediately for induction at his home town of Nashua, N.H.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 -- Representative Gearhart, Republican of California, intends to bring before the House Thursday a situation in connection with the quinine stockpile of the United Nations and the manufacture of synthetic substitutes here which is causing concern in some quarters.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 -- Secretary Ickes announced today that higher priorities just granted by the War Production Board for reclamation dams, power houses and generating equipment insure the addition of more than a million kilowatts of hydro power to the nation's war supply by July, 1944, at five of the Reclamation Bureau's multi-purpose irrigation projects in the West.

MOSCOW, Wednesday, Aug. 12 (AP) -German troops striking southeastward in the Caucasus were reported officially today to be only 200 miles from the rich Grozny wells after overrunning the devastated Maikop oil region in the west.

The Broadhurst Theatre has been reserved for "Count Me In," the musical comedy in which Charles Butterworth, Luella Gear, Mary Healy and June Preisser will be prominent. After a Boston tryout the attraction is expected to arrive here the week of Sept. 20.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 -- With plans going forward for solid-trainload movements of petroleum products from Southwestern fields to the Eastern seaboard, Senator Walsh of Massachusetts today urged the Office of the Petroleum Coordinator to relax regulations to permit individual home owners as well as dealers to build up re serve supplies off heating oil in preparation for Winter.

Magistrate Jenkin R. Hockert held an on-the-spot session of Flushing Court at the edge of a rain-water lake between Seventy-sixth and Seventy-seventh Avenues at 137th Street yesterday to consider the complaints of home owners in the neighborhood that the body of water was a menace to health and dangerous for children.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 -- Admiral Arthur J. Hepburn, retired former Commander-in-Chief of the United States Fleet, director of the Bureau of Public Relations since May, 1941, was appointed today to be chairman of an enlarged and reorganized general board of the Navy.
In your Aug. 8 editorial calling attention to the terrible number of deaths through accidents in this country you state that our tuberculosis death rate has been reduced "by 61 per cent since 1900."
Don't let any one tell S.L. Cavanaro of Riverhead, L.I., one of the East End's best anglers, that fishing is in the doldrums.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 11 -- Ted Schroeder of Glendale, Calif., and Seymour Greenberg of Chicago, finalists in the Eastern grass court tennis championship, will meet on the Casino turf Thursday morning in the play-off of the match that was rained out at the Westchester Country Club, Rye, last Sunday, but Greenberg is out of the running for the honors in the Newport invitation tournament.

MOSCOW, Aug. 11 (U.P.) -- Russia is convinced that her army will remain intact and that if it loses the North Caucasus it can stand indefinitely on the Volga River or, if necessary, in the Ural Mountains, Admiral William H. Standley, United States Ambassador, said today after a talk with Foreign Commissar Vyacheslaff Molotoff.

What may prove a better opportunity for production on war orders in the New York needle industries than that afforded by the recent Philadelphia Quartermaster Depot invitation on Army raincoats was seen yesterday in the arrival in this market of a sample WAAC overcoat on which the government is about to seek bids.

Cecil Hughson the Red Sox's tall Texan and currently the hottest pitcher in the American League, worked his way out of the tight spots and turned back the Yankees, 3 -- 2, in an eleven-inning thriller at the Stadium yesterday. The champions could not beat Tex, but there is consolation for them in the fact that no club has been able to do it in nearly two months.

Acting at the request of the government, the steel industry recently "created" in ten days a complete new series of alloy steels for special munitions purposes, it was announced by the American Iron and Steel Institute yesterday. In the past, new steels have been developed over periods of years, and, on rare occasions, of several months.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 11 -- Several parties were given today at the Old Mill Shop for the Blind in Water Mill, where Bridgehampton Day was held. Most of the guests arrived there on bicycles, a bicycle luncheon being a feature of the day.

MOSCOW, Wednesday, Aug. 12 -- A great column of German tanks, armored cars, truckloads of shock troops and self-propelled artillery has advanced from Armavir along the Caucasian foothills and has crossed the frontier of Circassia. At midnight the Russians announced fighting in the region of Cherkessk, chief town of this region, which is almost a third of the way from Armavir to Grozny, the most important oil and refining center of the North Caucasus.
Two Brooklyn Democratic district leaders appeared to have been defeated for re-election on the basis of incomplete returns compiled early this morning at Kings Democratic headquarters.

BUFFALO, Aug. 11 (AP) -- Warren (Buddy) Rosar, Yankee catcher who was fined $250 last month for leaving the club to take a Buffalo police civil service examination, was unsuccessful in his attempt to gain a position on the force.

HARTFORD, Conn., Aug. 11 -The Rev. Kurt E.B. Molzahn followed his wife to the witness stand in the Federal court this afternoon to defend himself against the government's charges of espionage conspiracy but he had been testifying only 35 minutes when court was adjourned until tomorrow forenoon.

Gripped by hysteria because his car had just run down a man on a motorcycle, Solomon Stein, a 50-year-old carpenter, leaped from the driver's seat yesterday afternoon, ran to the workshop in the cellar of his home at 1434 Coney Island Avenue, Brooklyn, and shot himself as his 14-year-old son tried to stop him.
A High Command communique broadcast from Berlin and recorded here by The Associated Press:
LONDON, Aug. 11 -- The stock markets were firmer today, but the turnover remained small.

Harold Comerford, 32 years old, of 435 West Twenty-fourth Street, was arrested yesterday in a polling place at 223 Avenue on a charge of voting illegally. Magistrate Joseph Glebocki in Essex Market Court paroled him in the custody of his attorney for a hearing on Sept. 4.
Representative Hamilton Fish Jr. scored a sweeping victory yesterday in the Republican primary election in the Twenty-sixth Congressional District.

More than 2,500 births occurred in New York City last week for the sixth time this year, Health Commissioner Ernest L. Stebbins reported yesterday. The birth rate last week rose to 17.3 per 1,000 population compared with 16.1 for the year so far.

Registrations of out-of-town buyers in the market for the week ended yesterday totaled 658, which compared with 580 in the preceding week and 925 in the similar period a year ago, according to the listings in THE NEW YORK TIMES. Yesterday's arrivals totaled 263 as against 306 for last Tuesday.

As part of their Summer war work, 100 New York City teachers have been assigned to the office of Major Edward Reikert of the War Identification Bureau to receive training as fingerprint technicians, it was announced yesterday.

Greater use of institutional advertising to develop customer preference for individual stores was foreseen here yesterday in anticipation of the trend toward "victory models" in a wider range of merchandise items. As the war economy develops and present stocks approach exhaustion, the likelihood is that goods available at retail will be pretty much the same.

The Chrysler Corporation ordered yesterday a dividend of 75 cents a share on the common stock payable on Sept. 14. In two previous quarters dividends of $1 each were paid. In 1941 the dividend rate was $1.50 a quarter. Earnings for the first half of this year showed a decline of 58 per cent in net.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 -- Certificates for Red Cross first-aid courses have been issued to more than 3,000,000 "war-conscious Americans" since Pearl Harbor, Harold F. Enlows, director of the organization's first-aid, water-safety and accident service stated to day.

Declaring that the East Coast States were hitting bedrock in their supplies of fuel oil and gasoline, Mayor La Guardia suggested yesterday that the Middle West share its supplies to alleviate the shortage.

Assisted by the heartening news of the invasion of the Japanese-held Solomon Islands, the stock market developed yesterday some stout resistance to the depressing dispatches from other war fronts. Accompanied by a moderate improvement in activity, fractional gains predominated throughout the list.

BEAR MOUNTAIN, N.Y., Aug. 11 -- A large influx of turkey vultures into the Bear Mountain-Harriman State Park area has been noted this Summer by staff workers of the Bear Mountain Trailside Museum. The birds, commonly but incorrectly known as buzzards, are common in the South and are now increasing the northern limits of their range.

GOSHEN, N.Y., Aug. 11 -- Final payments of $500 each were made today for eleven candidates for the $40,000 Hambletonian Stake, world's richest and most famous of light harness races, which will be trotted tomorrow over the mile kite-shaped track of Good Time Park.

LONDON, Wednesday, Aug. 12 -- Britain's Avro Lancaster bomber, which made its debut last April when a squadron led by J.D. Nettleton, V.C., was raiding Augsburg, Germany, came off the secret list yesterday.

Sales of war savings bonds in this State in July aggregated $168,072,722, an increase of 61.6 per cent over June, and were 18.67 per cent of the total nation-wide sales of these bonds in July, Richard C. Patterson Jr., State chairman of the New York War Savings Staff reported yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 -- Announcement of the establishment within the War Production Board of an Office of Technical Development, which will act as a clearing house for United Nations inventions and ideas for aiding the war effort, will be made within a few days by Donald M. Nelson, WPB Chairman, it was learned tonight.

Whatever else is to happen during our war effort, estimates on the yield of crops, given out by the Agricultural Department, show nothing but abundance. The growing season has been nearly perfect. Beginning with April, the Government's monthly estimates on Winter-sown wheat have been marked up 72,725,000 bushels and the total wheat yield, which last year had been twice exceeded, is now estimated as second only to the "billion-bushel crop" of 1915.

AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, Australia, Wednesday, Aug. 12 (U.P.) -- Today's communique said that Timor Island, the near-by Kei Islands and Rabaul, on New Britain, had been pounded by United Nations bombers.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 -- War spending by the United States reached a rate of $1,790 a second in July.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 -- The Office of Price Administration today defined the sort of "major capital improvement" which will allow a landlord to petition for an increase of rents even under rent control.

JACKSONVILLE, N.C., Aug. 11 (AP) -- Gangrene brought a grave threat today to Mrs. C.F. Thompson, 32-year-old Jacksonville woman, who calmly cut off her foot at the ankle with a six-inch fisherman's knife after it became entangled in the driving mechanism of a motor boat.

LONDON, Aug. 11 -- More prosecution witnesses were heard today in the general court-martial of Private Travis P. Hammond of Texas, a member of the United States Air Force accused under Section 92 of the Articles of War of criminally assaulting a 17-year-old English girl.

Arnold Genthe was a master photographer because he was a sincere artist. Even when he seemed to be idling at the camera he was toiling with infinite care to compose his picture and to catch from his subject the characteristic and revealing moment. Almost invariably the result was a portrait that John Sargent might have been proud of.

MILWAUKEE, Aug. 11 -- Max W. Babb, chairman, and Walter Geist, President of the Allis Chalmers Manufacturing Company, announced today that the company had arranged for a four-year bank credit of $40,000,000 with a group of banks, headed by the First National of Chicago.

COLUMBUS, Aug. 11 (AP) -- Representative Martin L. Sweeney, Democrat, who opposed pre-war foreign policies of the Administration, was defeated by Michael A. Feighan, ex-legislator, tonight in his bid for renomination.
Your editorial on the unpleasant situation in which radio stations and musicians find themselves under the dictatorship of Mr. Petrillo is most timely and effective.

Dr. Ernest L. Stebbins, Commissioner of Health, reported yesterday that requests for birth certificates, mostly from workers trying to get war jobs, totaled 34,657 in July, an increase of 655 per cent over the comparable period in prewar 1939.

Some of the complexities of camouflage are simplified in an exhibition called "Camouflage for Civilian Defense," which will be opened to the public today at the Museum of Modern Art, 11 West Fifty-third Street.

In 1938 seventy-four ships, averaging less than 900 tons apiece, entered and left Tulagi, main port of the Solomon Islands. They probably brought in such things as kerosene, soap, matches, metal tools and cotton cloth. They took away a small amount of copra and smaller quantities of sea shells.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 11 -- One of the large luncheons of the present racing season was given today at the Gideon Putnam by Mrs. Peter A.B. Widener and her cousin, Harry R. Neilson of Northeast Harbor, Me., and Philadelphia.

RIO DE JANIERO, Brazil, Aug. 11 -- The liner Gripsholm, carrying Americans returning from the Orient under diplomatic exchange, sailed for New York at 4:15 P.M. hours to permit the diplomats and some of the newspaper men to attend a luncheon as guests of the Foreign Office.

Three special offerings were made yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange with marked success. In eighty-eight minutes 1,600 shares of Norfolk Western, 3,000 shares of William Wrigley Jr. and 10,000 shares of Procter Gamble were moved. The last was over-subscribed more than twice.

The State of West Virginia awarded yesterday a new issue of $1,000,000 of road bonds to a syndicate comprising Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc. Blair Co., Inc., and George B. Gibbons Co., Inc. The bonds are dated April 1, 1942, and mature serially from Sept. 1, 1943 to 1967.

Candies that will not melt -- except in your mouth -- nestle in a flat blue box bestrewn with the pink-and-white blossoms of Summer. Each sweet, fastidiously tucked in a white-and-brown frilly cup, is designed to withstand the onslaughts of a "hot spell."

CLEVELAND, Aug. 11 (AP) -- Production of airplane parts was resumed tonight at the two plants of the Cleveland Graphite Bronze Company after a walkout by members of the Independent Mechanics Educational Society of America. M.J. O'Connell, Federal conciliator, recommended that a dispute over the dismissal of twenty-one employes be certified to the War Labor Board after a conference with union, company and Air Force representatives failed to produce a settlement.
A further decline in the tuberculosis death rate from forty-six per 100,000 in 1940 to forty-four last year was announced yesterday by the National Tuberculosis Association.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 -- A Navy Department communique:
The discovery of markers created by enemy agents in preparation for Nazi air raids on American industrial centers has brought once more the problem of blackout tests to the fore.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 (AP) -- The management-labor policy committee of the War Manpower Commission has adopted a strong resolution calling for an end to voluntary enlistment in the armed services, it was learned tonight.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Brazil, Aug. 10 -- According to Japanese war propaganda, Japan is engaged in a holy war to unify all races and nations into one universal household under the paternal rule of the Japanese Emperor in conformity to the principle of Hakko Ichiu, which allots to all nations their "proper place" and in the Japanese interpretation expels the "white barbarians" from the Far East.

CHICAGO, Aug. 11 -- Wheat had a sinking spell today which carried prices down around 1/2 cent a bushel. The selling was induced by a bearish construction placed on a Department of Agriculture crop estimate issued late yesterday and which showed a prospective yield of 955,000,000 bushels of wheat, or 51,000,000 more than a month previous.

After a Washington newspaper published an expose of what it characterized as "the great air marker hoax" the War Department at Washington admitted yesterday that a story released by the First Air Force at Mitchel Field, L.I., and published in Monday's newspapers "may be untrue."

CHICAGO, Aug. 11 -- Max Lanier turned in his eighth victory of the season today with a capable five-nit performance against the Cubs and the Cardinals defeated the Chicago team, 7 to 2, in the opener of a four-game series.
PINE CAMP, N.Y., Aug. 11 (AP) -- On the sandy plains and wooded slopes of this military reservation 2,000 cadets of the United States Military Academy were in action today.

Regulations designed to apply standards of health protection already obtaining in public elementary schools to the 1,000 parochial and private elementary schools in the city were adopted yesterday by the Board of Health, effective Oct. 1.

BOSTON, Aug. 11 -- Geared to its maximum strength with the return of Big Johnny Mize and a consequent realignment of its vital units, the Giants' production line finally got results for Van Lingle Mungo today at Braves Field.

The National Committee of a wellknown world organization, the I.L.O., has asked me to form a committee of employer, employe and public representatives to study post-war problems of one of America's largest industries. The object of this committee should be to advise on future policy and so prevent disorganization of business after the war.

Eighteen college costumes "most likely to succeed" on the campus this Autumn were shown last evening at the opening of the "College Knowledge Shop" at Saks- Thirty-fourth Street. Included in the group were all of this year's "musts" among the co-eds, such as the new "pedal-pusher" shorts, the youthful pinafore, the little boy knickers and the inevitable "date dress."
BOMBAY, Aug. 11 -- British Impenal troops joined police today in clashes with rioting mobs at Bombay, and more troops were called out at New Delhi as arson and sabotage got out of hand.

British Air Vice Marshal Sir Hugh Lloyd, for fourteen months Commander of the R.A.F. in the Mediterranean, said in this newspaper yesterday that the Maltese "are delighted when we sink Axis ships, although they know it will bring a boomerang in Axis bombs."

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 11 -- The Navy gave no answer today to the question whether it would bring charges against Tony Martin, the singer, and other Navy enlisted men and officers mentioned in specifications on which a naval court-martial yesterday presumably reached a verdict of guilty against Lieut. Comdr. Maurice N. Aroff.

All records for civilian and military employment were broken in June, when the total holding jobs reached 56,400,000, according to figures made public yesterday by the National Industrial Conference Board, private research organization.

AN innocent bystander might think that it was a cinch for a couple of coaches to get up a football team when they had 1,500 good players scattered around as a stock from which to draw. But when it's the All-Army team and those players are wearing soldier suits, it isn't so easy.

CHICAGO, Aug. 11 -- William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor, appealed to workers in all Allied countries today to keep a steady stream of materials and munitions flowing to the men in the front lines. He spoke before 400 delegates to the International Convention of the United Garment Workers of America at Michigan City, Ind.

For the first time in three days no new sinkings of merchant vessels in North American waters were announced by the Navy Department yesterday, but the governments of Brazil and Colombia revealed further depredations by Axis vessels in the South Atlantic.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 -- The War Labor Board today acted for the first time on a voluntary wage increase when it directed the General Electric Company and the Westinghouse Electric and Manufacturing Company to pay wage increases totaling $25,000,000 annually which the employers had refrained from making effective until it received governmental permission.

UNITED STATES ARMY AIR FORCE HEADQUARTERS, Hengyang, China, Aug. 11 (U.P.) -American fliers in China, striking out in support of the Allied offensive in the Southwest Pacific, have made destructive raids on five major Japanese bases scattered over a 500-mile area in the past twenty-four hours, it was revealed tonight.

Even a German-born Nazi could hardly match the stupid or cynical disregard of simple arithmetic which Pierre Laval showed yesterday when he went to Compiegne to "welcome home" a trainload of 1,000 released French prisoners. Before Hitler restored Laval to power in Vichy a trickle of such prisoners had been coming back.
MOSCOW, Aug. 11 (AP) -- A Soviet Information Bureau communique:

Supreme Court Justice J. Sidney Bernstein dismissed yesterday a stockholder's accounting action brought by Frederick W. Scholem against nine present and former directors of the Sperry Corporation for allegedly "grossly excessive and exorbitant compensation" paid to three officials of the corporation.
With few exceptions, members of Congress against whom the issue of isolationism was raised won renomination in yesterday's primary election, not only in New York State but also in Ohio and Idaho.
PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 11 (AP) -- Buck Newsom limited the Athletics to five hits tonight and the Senators registered a 3-to-1 triumph.

Prompt enactment of the Lanham bill, providing $600,000,000 for building additional housing for war workers is urged by twenty-eight officials of A.F. of L. and C.I.O. international unions and State bodies in a statement sent to Congress yesterday.

The "August for Compliance" drive now being conducted by leading retail organizations to insure fullest support for the OPA program was termed "good news" by Price Administrator Henderson in a communication to Lew Hahn, general manager of the National Retail Dry Goods Association.
VICHY, Aug. 11 -- France can raise 150,000 skilled workers to send to German factories, she can hope for the release of 50,000 of the 1,200,000 prisoners of war in German camps.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 -- The attitude of the War Production Board, now -- with its director, Donald M. Nelson -- under the heaviest fire of its career, seems to be to go ahead with its work and outride the storm on the following reasoning:

CHICAGO, Aug. 11 -- The OPA is working on a new basic system of pricing pork and, probably, beef products, Charles M. Elkington, associate price executive, OPA, told a belligerent meeting of small meat packers here today. The packers were here for the first of two sessions of protest against the effect of meat price ceilings on their business and to perfect the organization of the National Independent Meat Packers Association.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 -- Questions relating to the administration's wage policy, allegations that labor leaders were responsible for slow downs in war production, and assertions that "wildcat" strikes were increasing were directed at President Roosevelt at his press conference today and his general response was to request specific names, locations and incidents.

A much stricter interpretation of what constitutes "war use" can be expected as a result of the increasing shortage of vital materials, William E. Arnstein, chief of the Production Requirements Plan educational unit, declared yesterday.
MOSCOW, Wednesday, Aug. 12 (AP) -The Soviet midnight communique:
WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 -- The Senate Finance Committee, disregarding a plea by Dr. Francis E. ...

A new contract between thirteen members of the Publishers Association of New York City and the New York Newspaper Printing Pressmens Union, Local 2, providing for an increase of 50 cents a shift for the pressmen, went into effect yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 -- Commander Malcolm M. Hanson, a Naval Reserve officer who was chief radio man for Rear Admiral Byrd on the 1928-30 Antarctic expedition, has been killed in an airplane crash "somewhere in the North," the Navy stated today.

Nathan M. Ohrbach resigned as chairman of the tin can salvage committee yesterday in a letter to Clarence H. Low, chairman of the New York City Salvage Committee, in which he charged Mr. Low had interfered continually with his efforts to promote a campaign and characterized Mr. Low as "a man who knows only how to hamper, disorganize and discourage every salvage drive that has ever been attempted in New York City."

LONDON, Aug. 11 -- Jacques is tall, dark and raw-boned. His coal-black hair sweeps back from his forehead and his black mustache twitches when he is excited. Gabrielle, his wife, is small and plain, her face drawn like her body, and her fingers tightly and constantly interlocked.

CHUNGKING, China, Aug. 11 -- Though frankly apprehensive over the Indian situation, China is still a friend and ally of Britain while at the same time she has the warmest feelings for the Indians, declared Dr. T.F. Tsiang, Minister without Portfolio, as government spokesman today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 (AP) -The War Department announced today the names of eighty-six soldiers missing in action at sea. This brought the total of killed or missing men at sea thus far made public by the Army to 1,202.

" Keep warm, keep active, keep fit." This is the refrain that accompanies the college showings that are deluging New York. Yesterday morning it was Russeks Fifth Avenue's turn. Every item on the program pointed to the animated life that girls will live when they reach their campuses.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 -- Nearly 400,000 men and women have received certificates in home nursing in the last year, Red Cross National Headquarters stated today.

NEWARK, N.J., Aug. 11 -- Twenty per cent of the merchants in South Orange, N.J., have failed to comply with the price regulations of the Office of Price Administration through "ignorance or misunderstanding of the provisions of the Price Control Act," according to an announcement here today at the State headquarters of the OPA.

" The Pied Piper," Twentieth Century-Fox adaptation of the Nevil Shute novel, will open an engagement this morning at the Roxy. Monty Woolley, Roddy McDowall, Anne Baxter, Otto Preminger and J. Carrol Naish are featured in this topical drama.

AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, Australia, Aug. 11 -- United States landing forces kept their footholds in the Solomon Islands tonight, despite powerful Japanese counter-attacks, and the entire United Nations striking force was said by an official spokesman to be "outpunching" the Japanese.

Declaring that Max Fox "was mentally and physically ill" when he killed two other gamblers, one of them a former partner, in a Seventh Avenue card club, Saul S. Price, the slayer's attorney, demanded yesterday in the Felony Court that his client be released in bail pending grand jury action.

LONDON, Aug. 11 -- An important contribution to the controversy over who is to blame for the shortage of rubber afflicting the United Nations came today in the report of Sir John Hay to stockholders of the United Sua Betong Rubber Estates Limited.
TITUSVILLE, Fla., Aug. 11 (AP) -- Six soldiers were drowned today when an Army truck skidded and crashed through a bridge railing into ten feet of water in the Indian River.

CLEVELAND, Aug. 11 -- Paul (Dizzy) Trout hurled Detroit to a 3-to-2 triumph over Cleveland under the floodlights tonight after the Indians' Al Milnar had seen his bid for a no-hitter spoiled by Roger Cramer's single with two out in the ninth inning of a twilight contest that ended a scoreless fourteen-inning deadlock.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 -- The War Labor Board may have to abandon its "Little Steel" wage formula in the interest of solving the man-power problem presented by the migration of skilled copper, zinc and lead miners to munitions, aircraft, shipbuilding and other more highly paid war industries, it was reported today as preparations were made for convening a WLB panel to act on the situation on Aug. 19.

The report of the American Safety Razor Corporation for the quarter ended on June 30 shows net income of $156,455, after setting aside $440,735 for the Federal income tax calculated at 45 per cent, the possible Federal excess profits tax and special reserves.

MOUNT VERNON, N.Y., Aug. 11 -- A process of combining heavy fuel oil and finely pulverized coal to form a liquid fuel for use in the oil burners of industrial plants, steamships and large apartment buildings was demonstrated here today at the plant of the Town and Country Oil Corporation by Edward Moran, chief engineer of the concern.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 -- A alternative pricing method, designed to relieve the "squeeze" imposed upon many wholesalers and retailers by the general maximum price regulation, is being devised by the Office of Price Administration and will be promulgated formally in mid-September, according to an announcement from that office today.

CAZENOVIA, N.Y., Aug. 11 -- Finishing two games and winning both, Israel A. Horowitz of New York today regained the lead in the State championship tournament at the annual meeting of the New York State Chess Association in progress at the Cazenovia Junior College.

The theory on which Werner von Clemm will ask to be acquitted of charges of conspiracy to violate Federal restrictions on deals involving the property of Belgian and Netherland nationals took shape yesterday as the defendant began testifying at his trial in Federal court.

On these torrid midsummer days when the soaring temperature almost tempts one to carry a miniature cake of ice as fortification against the elements, there is always room for new ideas in the way of a cooling gesture. One that recommends itself as infinitely more practical than such extremes,

WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 -- The War Production Board, the National War Labor Board and the War Manpower Commission asked all employes and all employers in the tool and die industry in the Detroit area tonight to maintain status quo on wages and employment, pending an early conference of labor and management representatives on methods of employment and submission to the War Labor Board of the question of wages in this area.

The four-story, twenty-family apartment house at 12-16 Martense Street, Brooklyn, has been sold to Ida Griff and Regina Fergang by Jane T. Esposito as executrix of the estate of Jane E. Esposito. The building which is assessed for $60,000, land and improvements, was sold subject to mortgages totaling $51,700.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Aug. 11 -Ida Lupino will play the feminine lead in "Arctic Convoy," formerly "Half-A-Deck Harrigan," at Twentieth Century-Fox, the studio announced today. A leading man will be chosen later this month for the film, which Walter Morosco will produce from a screen story by Gene Fowler and his son, Gene Fowler Jr., dealing with the adventures of the skipper of a merchantman bound for Russia.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 -- The War Production Board, the National War Labor Board and the War Manpower Commission asked all employes and all employers in the tool and die industry in the Detroit area tonight to maintain status quo on wages and employment, pending an early conference of labor and management representatives on methods of employment and submission to the War Labor Board of the question of wages in this area.

The four-story, twenty-family apartment house at 12-16 Martense Street, Brooklyn, has been sold to Ida Griff and Regina Fergang by Jane T. Esposito as executrix of the estate of Jane E. Esposito. The building which is assessed for $60,000, land and improvements, was sold subject to mortgages totaling $51,700.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Aug. 11 -Ida Lupino will play the feminine lead in "Arctic Convoy," formerly "Half-A-Deck Harrigan," at Twentieth Century-Fox, the studio announced today. A leading man will be chosen later this month for the film, which Walter Morosco will produce from a screen story by Gene Fowler and his son, Gene Fowler Jr., dealing with the adventures of the skipper of a merchantman bound for Russia.
LONDON, Aug. 11 -- An illuminated manuscript of Chaucer's "Troilus and Criseyde," done on vellum for Henry V when he was Prince of Wales, brought 2,250 at today's sale at Sotheby's.
PITTSBURGH, Aug. 11 (AP) -- Hank Gornicki held the Reds to six hits today and the Pirates gained a 3-1 decision over the McKechnie clan.

OTTAWA, Ont., Aug. 11 (Canadian Press) -- The banana shortage has been worrying sufferers from celiaca and similar diseases who require large amounts of bananas in their diet, but today word came out of a new treatment that does not include the fruit.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 -- A Navy Department communique tonight stated that a series of heavy attacks by sea and air over the past week-end by a Pacific Fleet task force had caused extensive damage to Kiska, the American island in the Western Aleutians the Japanese captured and have developed as an invasion base.

CHUNGKING, China, Aug. 11 (AP) -- Chinese newspapers today expressed their support for the Indian Nationalists in editorials regretting the arrests of their leaders and appealing to the British to seek a peaceful settlement.

First half results of the Chrysler Corporation do not provide a measure of earnings which will accrue as the war program forges ahead. Owing to suspension of automobile production sales were about one-half the volume in the first half of 1941, when war production was only 5.5 per cent of total sales.

A.P. Herbert of Punch and Parliament has long waged "The Word War" in the former. In letters to The Times of London, which once indignantly accused him of "questionable levity," he has swatted the barbarous style of the bureaucrats; makers of what he calls "jungle English."

An audience of 19,743, the record for the season, packed the Lewisohn Stadium last night for the New York Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra's eleventh annual all-Gershwin program. Alexander Smallens was the conductor and the soloists were Oscar Levant, pianist, and Jane Froman, soprano.

The executors' final accounting in the estate of George F. Baker, banker and philanthropist, who died on May 30, 1937, disclosed a New York gross estate of $40,670,079, debts totaling $12,865,758 and a balance of $28,355,178.

NEWARK, N.J., Aug. 11 (AP) -- The Bears stretched their International League lead to eleven games today by beating the Jersey City Giants in both ends of a twilight-night double-header, 2 to 1 and 5 to1.
The bulk of the residential leases reported yesterday by brokers was on the East Side.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 -- Stiff increases in taxes on lower bracket incomes were urged and opposed today before the Senate Finance Committee.

Voting in yesterday's primaries in Westchester, Nassau and Suffolk Counties was the lightest in years, with most of the contests centered around the right and left wings of the American Labor party. There were no official tallies of the votes in Westchester or Suffolk pending meetings of the county election boards within the next few days.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 11 -- Leading from start to finish in what was one of the easiest victories ever scored in the history of the Kenner Stakes, which goes back to 1870, Mrs. Payne Whitney's Buckskin led yesterday by ten lengths at the end of a slow and heavy mile and three-sixteenths.

LONDON, Aug. 11 -- The wartime diet of the British people, which is a constant source of worry to Lord Woolton, the Food Minister, can and will be made more frugal without impairing the fighting effectiveness of the nation, he asserted today in a statement covering several aspects of the food situation.

As the Senate Finance Committee comes to the conclusion of its hearings on the tax bill it appears certain that the committee, like the House Ways and Means Committee, will turn down all three of the Treasury's pet proposals for eliminating "special privilege." These three are: the proposal to tax the interest of outstanding State and local securities; mandatory joint returns, and elimination of depletion allowances on natural resource industries.

Finding strength in the afternoon when price-fixing operations became intensive, the cotton futures market advanced yesterday 21 to 23 points, or $1.05 to $1.15 a bale, the session's top levels. The rise was helped along by a scarcity of contracts.

The President's call for old cannon and bum statues for war needs if answered thoroughly will serve another purpose rightly secondary at this time -- especially ridding us of the statues of the culturally naive Civil War period. And I have a hunch that the Chief chuckled when he thought that one up and remembered the metal monstrosities in Central Park!

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 11 -- Three Federal receivers and trustees who charge "mismanagement and waste" on the part of 113 present and former officers and directors of the Transit Investment Corporation, formerly the Mitten Bank Securities Corporation, filed suit in United States District Court today against the entire group to recover part of losses, estimated at more than $12,000,000.

The two-story garage building on a plot 100 by 98.9 feet at 446-52 West Twenty-ninth Street has been sold by the Emigrant Industrial Savings Bank to an investing client of Herbert Charles Co., Inc., brokers.

A Midsummer flower show, its first in more than ten years, will be held today and tomorrow by the Horticultural Society of New York at its headquarters at 598 Madison Avenue. The exhibition is part of the Victory Garden Harvest Show movement throughout the country and the proceeds will be turned over to war relief.

What stand would Mr. Petrillo have taken in the case of Henry Wadsworth Longfellow? It will be recalled that on one occasion the poet breathed a song into the air and later found it in the heart of a friend.

CHICAGO, Aug. 11 (AP) -- William D. Mitchell, New York lawyer and former Attorney General of the United States, arrived today to take charge of a grand jury investigation of the publication by three newspapers of "confidential information" about the Battle of Midway.
NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 12 -- Ted Schroeder of Glendale, Calif., and Harris Everett of Jacksonville, Fla., moved into the semi-final round of the Newport invitation tennis tournament at the Casino today.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 12 -- Bay area shipyards holding contracts for Navy work have begun weeding out loafers and sending their names to their draft boards for reclassification. One official said the Navy had requested that men discharged from naval work be reported to their draft boards after a full investigation to determine whether they had been loafing on the job.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 12 -- Expansion of the War Shipping Administration's open policies of war risk insurance to cover shipments of goods between United States' ports, was announced by WSA today. The expansion is embodied in a supplement to the agency's General Order No. 6 and is effective as of Aug. 1.
CHUNGKING, China, Aug. 12 -- Unconfirmed reports received here today said that Allied planes, presumably American, had bombed the large Japanese island of Formosa off the South China coast.

The North American Company, the nation's second largest utility holding concern, yesterday virtually divorced itself of affiliation with the Detroit Edison Company, a utility property in which North American has maintained a major investment position for thirty years.

The announcement by Price Administrator Leon Henderson that food wholesalers and retailers would be permitted to use an "alternative pricing method" under which "squeezes" will be relieved, was immediately reflected by a revival of activity in the markets yesterday.

NEWARK, N. J., Aug. 12 (AP) -- The league-leading Newark Bears registered a sweep of their five-game series with the Jersey City Giants today by capturing their second straight doubleheader by scores of 7 -- 2 and 3 -- 2. The twin triumph increased their lead in the international loop to thirteen games with only thirty-one remaining to be played.

HISTORICAL parallels are sometimes exact, sometimes suggestive, sometimes totally deceptive. But there is one thing a knowledge of history can do: it can keep you from fluctuating widely between moods of false hope and moods of equally false despair. If you know history, you don't expect too much of the human race, nor do you expect too little, either.

NEWARK, N.J., Aug. 12 -- Two employes of different war-production plants in this State were charged today by the Federal Bureau of Investigation here with having violated the Federal sabotage statute by damaging apparatus on which they worked.

i The German Propagand Minister, Dr. Joseph Goebbels, acknowl edged yesterday that "Germany for the time being is receiving bitter wounds" through Royal Air Force "spiteful attacks," according to a German broadcast recorded by Reuters.

VICHY, France, Aug. 12 -- French dissidents lobbed grenades into a group of sixty German aviators exercising at the Bouin Stadium near Paris last Wednesday, killing two and wounding eighteen, in the climax of a week of turbulence that included a frustrated scheme to blow up Chief of Government Pierre Laval's chateau at Chateldon, it can be revealed today.

MOSCOW, Thursday, Aug. 13 (AP) -- German troops have punched another hole in Russian positions astride the Rostov-Baku railroad in the Cherkessk area, but the Red Army is holding firmly on the approaches to Stalingrad, the Soviet High Command announced early today.
LOS ANGELES, Aug. 12 -- Clark Gable put aside Hollywood activities today to enlist in the Army as a buck private.

CLEVELAND, Aug. 12 (AP) -- Twice the Detroit Tigers trimmed Cleveland today, 4 to 2 and 2 to 0, in a double-header necessitated by last night's fourteen-inning scoreless tie, and the Tribe's losing streak grew to six games.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 12 -- An appeal, challenging the constitutionality of the "death sentence" provisions of the Public Utility Holding Company Act, has been taken before the Federal Court of Appeals in the District of Columbia from an order by the Securities and Exchange Commission directed on June 4 against the Middle West Corporation and two subsidiaries, it was learned here today.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 12 -- Wornout silk stockings may soon be added to the articles which housewives are being asked to save for salvage.

The Nazi flood has now spread so far across the Kuban steppes that it threatens to engulf not only Russia's oil supplies at Maikop and Grozny but the present base of her Black Sea Fleet. German tank columns are reported to be less than fifty miles from Novorossisk, to which port the Russian ships fled after the fall of Sevastopol.

Drastic clamping down on the exchange of trade information, even to the extent of prohibiting stockholders from looking over corporation books, was indicated here yesterday by Colonel Richard A. Magee, chief of the Army's committee for the protection of information.

Anthony Trollope's successful application of business principles to literary production has long invited the scorn or envy of lazier or less systematic hands in the novel shop. He kept regular hours, watched the watch, did his daily stint. He revered punctuality. Posterity has approved his work.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 12 -- The Navy Department reported today that all the naval districts had been "swamped" with letters from women requesting preliminary application blanks for officers' commissions in the Waves. To emphasize the surprising number of new applicants, the Navy also used the word "deluge" to describe the influx of letters to the offices of Naval Officer Procurement in twelve naval districts.

LONDON, Aug. 12 -- Bomber planes of the Royal Air Force made a "particularly successful" raid in large force last night on Mainz, at the junction of the Rhine and the Main Rivers, and left great fires in the German rail center among factories and chemical plants.

NOROTON, Conn., Aug. 12 -- Tommy Srafaci of Shore View walked off with the honors in the Metropolitan Golf Association's one-day tournament when he carded a one under par 35, 36 -- 71 over the Wee Burn Golf Club course today.

CAZENOVIA, .N.Y., Aug. 12 -- Israel A. Horowitz of New York made it five straight in the New York State Chess Association championship at the Cazenovia Junior College when he defeated Sven Almgren of Brooklyn in sixty-four moves today.

CHICAGO, Aug. 12 -- Representatives of some 600 small meat packing firms today telegraphed President Roosevelt a request for intervention in the meat price ceilings "squeeze," received a pledge of labor support for the aims of their organization and completed the formation of the National Independent Meat Packers Association.
A tract of land comprising sixtytwo acres in the Dix Hills section of Huntington, Suffolk County, L. I., has been sold by the Gould family to a client of the Upjohn Company, brokers.

In August, as usual, the necktie comes in for its annual denunciation as a required article of men's wear in Summer. But we all know what will happen: August will pass and September come in, and by then the necktie will have escaped again by, as it were, a tie vote.

FAYETTEVILLE, N.C., Aug. 12 -- The German drive into the Caucasus, which was nearing the region of the Grozny oil fields today, far overshadows in strategical importance our limited offensive in the Solomon Islands.

When the National Budget Committee for War Appeals announced a recommended twelve months' total of $75,659,000 yesterday it took pains to say, through its chairman, Gerard Swope, that there had been no "pretense of measuring, much less meeting, total needs."

Mayor La Guardia, who has pronounced views on the arts, has disapproved a statue symbolizing "Wings for Victory -- The Spirit of Aviation," which Artists for Victory, Inc., an organization of 10,000 American painters, sculptors and architects, had chosen in a contest and planned to erect on some conspicuous site in the city, possibly in front of the New York Public Library.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 12 -- Federal Grand Juries in New York, Brooklyn and Chicago will be asked to return treason indictments against as many as possible of twelve of the fourteen confederates of the Nazi saboteurs, Attorney General Biddle stated today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 12 -- The Office of Price Administration formalized a recent permission for adjustment of retail milk prices in metropolitan New York, in the course of an order granting similar relief to four other markets today. Markets affected by the order are, in addition to New York, Goodland, Kan.; Front Royal, Va.; Selma, Ala., and Ogden, Utah.

Chet Bedell has returned from one of those superlative fishing trips to Maine. Although he was unable to visit the Pine Tree State immediately after the ice had gone out of the lakes for the Spring fishing, he decided to try his luck despite the fact that he had been highly, skeptical of the results at this season of the year.

The Waac overcoat can "definitely be made by the women's coat industry" and a number of firms are expected to file bids on its production within a week or so with the Philadelphia Quartermaster Depot, it was reported yesterday following inspection of a sample garment by manufacturers and representatives of trade associations and the union at the offices of the National Coat and Suit Industry Recovery Board.

THERE is to be a Boxing show at Madison Square Garden tonight, and, after looking over the menu, the conclusion in this corner is that war economy is driving Uncle Mike Jacobs, the leading impresario of pugilism, to desperate extremities. Many of his principal crowd-pullers being in the Army, Navy, Marines and Coast Guard and not immediately subject to his orders, Uncle Mike is having a frightful time getting "name fighters" for his main bouts.

Dollars and diets -- how the first affects the second -- is a topic in the conversational limelight that interests all sorts and conditions of housekeepers. That the two can be reconciled, that one can be provided with an adequate diet on a remarkably few dollars, is a bromide bandied about in the classroom and kitchen.

BOSTON, Aug. 12 -- The peak five-game winning streak to which the Giants soared so majestically here yesterday came to an ignoble end today at Braves Field where Mel Ott's band nose-dived into a double defeat at the hands of the Braves.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 12 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission, finding that the voting trustees for Class A common stock of Peoples Light and Power Company now hold power to vote less than 10 per cent of its total voting securities, held them no longer to be a holding company.

LONDON, Aug. 12 -- "Any picture of widespread disorders" in India is "utterly distorted," said a statement tonight by the India Office. The British authorities were said to have the situation "completely in hand."

Expressing optimism over a gradual but well-defined shift away from hatlessness and hailing the trend created in the industry by the three designers comprising Millinery Fashion Inspirations, Walter A. Krafft, president of the Emporium World Millinery, Inc., one of the largest millinery syndicate operators, yesterday foresaw average sales gains of 10 per cent on Fall millinery.

A German broadcast, recorded by The Associated Press yesterday, said that since Tuesday night German and Italian air and submarine forces had been engaged in a new battle against a British "capital convoy," escorted in the Western Mediterranean by the bulk of the British Mediterranean fleet.

BOMBAY, Aug. 12 (U.P.) -- Six thousand workers walked out today at the Calcutta jute mills owned by the three millionaire Birla brothers, all of whom are backers of Mr. Gandhi and one of whom was his host in Bombay until his arrest last Sunday. The mills are reopening after a one-day closure.

Part of its Port Morris industrial property at 140th Street and the East River, the Bronx, has been sold by the Guardian Life Insurance Company of America to the H.O. Penn Realty Terminals, Inc., for general offices and the sale and distribution of construction and road machinery.

Of the total of 483,853 patients admitted to Mount Sinai Hospital in its ninety years of existence, more than 350,000 received free care, according to the eighty-ninth annual report of the hospital, a commemorative volume marking the ninetieth anniversary, published yesterday.

Military training for young men, to be continued even after the war is over, was advocated yesterday by Lieutenant Governor Charles Poletti, who addressed 1,000 City College students at a war bond rally held in the Great Hall of the college, 139th Street and Convent Avenue.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Aug. 12 -- "Starlight," a screen comedy by Jacques Thery, has been purchased by Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer as a vehicle for William Powell and Hedy Lamarr, the studio announced today. Harry Kurnitz is writing the scenario, and Powell will play an astronomer in the film, while Miss Lamarr will be seen as his wife, who dabbles in astrology.

The Borden Company announced yesterday that the five Borden awards, each consisting of a gold medal and $1,000, to foster research in milk and related fields, would again be made in 1943. Begun in 1936, the awards are administered by scientific organizations and have given recognition to significant developments accomplished by scientists associated with dairying and nutrition.

Listed for October inspection by Lee Shubert is a comedy entitled "Sweet Charity." The authors are two Hollywood writers, Irving Brecher and Manuel Seff, and their play has to do with a women's club in Connecticut. Before going to Hollywood Mr. Seff was employed by Mr. Shubert.

A German Transocean broadcast recorded by THE NEW YORK TIMES yesterday quoted the semi-official Deutsche Diplomatisch Politische Korrespondenz as saying, in comment on the United States' execution of six men as German saboteurs, that the persons executed were not convicted of accomplishing or even attempting any acts of sabotage.

Members of the traffic details of the New York Police Department, including motor-cycle, mounted and foot men, will soon be wearing white belts and shoulder straps that will be visible in blackouts and dimouts, Commissioner Valentine announced yesterday. Two thousand of the new belts and straps, similar to those used by policemen in England, have been ordered -- for delivery within the next four weeks.
MOSCOW, Aug. 12 (AP) -- A Soviet Information Bureau communique:

WASHINGTON, Aug. 12 -- To permit railroads, solvent but embarrassed by maturing obligations, to carry their war loads without disrupting and costly bankruptcy proceedings, the Senate was urged today to complete re-enactment promptly of expired relief legislation to which the House gave unanimous approval nearly two months ago.

A group of 150 refugee boys and girls, ranging in age from 6 to 12 years, were guests of the Roxy Theatre yesterday morning at the first showing of the motion picture, "The Pied Piper," which tells of the flight across France of a small band of war orphans. The youngsters of French, Polish, Czechoslovak and German nationality, later were guests at a luncheon later at the Hotel Astor.

The sinking of one Nazi submarine by a depth charge and the capture of another which had been disabled by airplanes were reported yesterday. Although reports of submarine sinkings have been withheld by the Navy, the report of the first case was published in Yank, Army newspaper.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 12 -- A plan for recapitalization of the California Oregon Power Company, involving contribution of its senior securities by its parent holding company, Standard Gas and Electric Company, was approved today by the Securities and Exchange Commission.

CHICAGO, Aug. 12 -- Mrs. Russell Mann of Omaha, Neb., the defending champion, fought off a head cold and the stiff challenge of Miss Georgia Tainter of Fargo, N.D., today to win her second-round match in the women's Western amateur golf tournament at Sunset Ridge.

LONDON, Aug. 12 -- British confirmation of the sinking of the 24-year-old aircraft carrier Eagle in the Mediterranean was accompanied by a German bulletin that said a battle was going on between strong German and Italian air and submarine forces and a large British convoy escorted by "the bulk of the British Mediterranean fleet."

With only a week remaining before the Democratic State Convention in Brooklyn, Terence J. McManus, chairman of the committee supporting Senator James M. Mead for the Democratic nomination for Governor, contended yesterday that there was a definite shift of up-State delegates from Attorney General John J.
