Bennett Jr., and predicted a break-up of Bennett-pledged delegates in Brooklyn sufficient to give Senator Mead the nomination.

What we are witnessing in India is just one more clash between right and expediency, but this war has produced no more piteous tragedy and none more dangerous. It really seems as if democracy were to be slain by the blunders and folly of those who feel themselves to be its most devoted defenders.

Acting swiftly to end the first strike directed against enforcement of the War Labor Board's wage stabilization formula, Federal officials indicated last night that the government would commandeer the Bayonne, N.J., plant of the General Cable Corporation unless 1,000 outlaw strikers there bowed to a WLB decision barring a blanket increase in pay and returned to work.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 12 -- Many additional tickets have been purchased for the lecture on "Victory Through Air Power," to be given by Major Alexander P. de Seversky, aviation expert and author, on Friday night in the auditorium of the Southampton High School under the auspices of the lecture committee of the Schola Cantorum of New York.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 12 -- It was Devil's Thumb again today. He gained his third successive stake victory at Saratoga, this time in the thirtieth running of the Sanford Memorial, which is best remembered as the event in which Man o' War met his only defeat.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 12 -- Senator Walsh, as chairman of the Naval Affairs Committee, has rejected the request of Secretary Knox for an immediate investigation by a special subcommittee into charges, made by another Senate committee, that officers of the Bureau of Ships were guilty of "negligence or willful misconduct" in the planning and production of barges to be used by American invading forces.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 12 -- Since politics has remained the major business activity of the elected officials here and many of those who are on the government payroll through their favor, the bad score run up in the primaries Tuesday against former isolationists and obstructionists in foreign policy drew a host of intensely interested analysts.

With a 26-pound cabbage vying with delicate, flame-colored gladioluses for attention, a midsummer flower show was opened yesterday by the Horticultural Society of New York as its contribution to the Victory Garden Harvest Show movement. The exhibition, the first such ever held by the society, will continue today from 9 A.M. to 5 P.M. at its headquarters, 598 Madison Avenue.

The stock market was a little more diversified yesterday, due to the activity in low-priced issues, and the moderate strength generated by this section offset the losses among some investment types. Although there were more stocks to show gains than losses, the best the closing could show was a firming line.

The National Noise Abatement Council presented to Mayor La Guardia at City Hall yesterday a plaque symbolizing the city's achievement in winning first place, among cities of 1,000,000 or more population, in the nation-wide campaign to improve health and war production power by reduction of unnecessary noise.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 12 -- American military forces in India have been ordered to "exercise scrupulous care to avoid the slightest participation in India's internal political problems," the State Department announced tonight.

AUCKLAND, New Zealand, Aug. 12 -- As the battle involving United Nations land, sea and air forces for jungle-covered Tulagi and neighboring Solomon Islands went into its fifth day, the feeling increased here that the outcome may be crucial for the United Nations' cause in the South and Southwest Pacific.

New York City's salvaging of tin cans compares unfavorably with the record of other large cities, although this city has been collecting cans longer than the others, Burton M. Parks, head of the tin salvage unit of the conservation division, War Production Board, in Washington, declared here yesterday.

LONDON, Aug. 12 -- The British people's health is standing up despite rationing and if available foods are utilized the British Isles have enough to get through without a threat to their health in the future, an American research man announced today.

NEWARK, N.J., Aug. 12 -- The Hudson Manhattan Railroad and the Pennsylvania Railroad have each designated experts to survey the operations of the H. M. and suggest improvements in its service, it was disclosed here today by the State Board of Public Utility Commissioners.

MINEOLA, L.I., Aug. 12 -- After they had conferred here this afternoon with Supreme Court Justice Meier Steinbrink in his chambers, it was announced that Helen Jepson, opera singer, and her former husband, George Possell of Seaford, L.I., had reaffirmed an oral agreement regarding the custody of their 9-year-old daughter, Sallie Patricia Possell, and Miss Jepson had withdrawn a writ of habeas corpus application under which she sought a determination of the child's status.

Renewed enforcement by Army officials of the regulation against soldiers carrying on civilian activities resulted yesterday in the denial of permission to Staff Sergeant Ezra Stone to continue in the leading role on the radio program known as "The Aldrich Family" over WEAF and the NBC Red Network.

Approval of a "tax-to-the-limit" war financing proposal, calling for levies to produce $37,000,000,000 a year, was announced last night by the executive committee of the National Association of Manufacturers.

For the fourth day in succession, no new sinkings in North American waters were reported yesterday by the Navy Department, but it announced the loss of a small Dutch merchant ship in the South Atlantic on July 24, 300 miles off the coast of South America.

The Marines, fighting their way deeper into the three key islands of the Solomon group, are performing one of the most difficult and hazardous feats in modern warfare. It requires no effort of the imagination to envision the high-hearted and obdurate courage of our shock troops as they slash in hand-to-hand combat through enemy territory.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 12 -- In the face of requests for resumption of work, issued by Dr. John R. Steelman, director of the Federal Conciliation Service, and William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor, retail food clerks today continued a strike over wages that has kept 112 Safeway Stores in the East Bay area closed more than a week.

The right wing trade union leaders of the American Labor party appeared certain last night to have retained control, at Tuesday's primary election, of the party machinery vested in its State committee, while control of the State convention remained in doubt.
LONDON, Aug. 12 -- Business on the stock markets today was not large, but industrial shares were a feature. In the gilt-edge section the 3 1/2 per cent War Loan sold at 105 7/8, and others gained.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 12 -- Rationing of some sort is inevitable this Fall and Winter if East Coast householders are to be assured of an equitable distribution of fuel oil, according to opinions expressed today by officials of fuel-oil distributing companies in the East.

LONDON, Aug. 12 (U.P.) -- The weekly Tribune, edited by Aneurin Bevan, Labor Member of Parliament, today criticized India Secretary L.S. Amery and the Viceroy of India, the Marquess of Linlithgow, and urged the party to appeal to the country for reversal of "the suicidal policy of the Government]."

When you liquefy something, it means reducing a solid to a completely liquid state. When you solidify something, it need not mean that you have changed a perfect liquid into a perfect solid. In common use it may mean changing something soft into something much harder; as when you solidify public support behind Bennett or when you solidify the opposition to Bennett.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 12 (AP) -- The Export-Import Bank announced tonight a loan of $6,000,000 to Mexico to help build the proposed Altos Hornos Steel plant at Monclova, State of Coahuila, Mexico.

SOMEWHERE IN AUSTRALIA, Aug. 12 -- In the Solomon Islands, objective of our South Pacific Fleet, the Japanese established three main air bases -- on Buka Island, at Kieta on Bougainville Island and at Lunga Bay on Guadalcanal Island. Near Lunga a United States reconnaissance pilot -- Lieutenant Robert L. Ramsey of Hollywood, Calif. -- recently encountered a new development in Japanese aircraft.

NEWARK, N.J., Aug. 12 -- Edward J. Bender, 24 years old, of 150 Lincoln Road, Westfield, N.J., a graduate of Princeton University in 1938 and a student for one year at the Columbia University Law School, is under parole in the custody of his father pending action of the Federal grand jury on a complaint charging refusal to report for Army induction on July 27.

Five days of revolt in India, conducted peaceably by orthodox members of the Congress party, violently by hotheads in a few important cities, appear not to have shaken the British power. London flatly announces:

WASHINGTON, Aug. 12 (AP) -- Treasury officials revealed today that a boom in the value of silver had forced them to discard a plan to make 5-cent pieces out of a 50-50 combination of silver and copper.

J.J. Singh, president of the India League of America and former member of the All India Congress Committee, proposed yesterday a political and military program for the settlement of the Indian problem.

Major Benjamin H. Namm, Brooklyn merchant, was suggested yesterday for the Republican nomination for Lieutenant Governor. Kings County Leader John R. Crews and New York County Chairman Thomas J. Curran conferred here with State Chairman Edwin F. Jaeckle, and were reported to have urged Major Namm's nomination, if he is available.

Crude oil production in the United States last week averaged 3,970,450 barrels daily, an increase of 587,400 over the 3,383,050 in the previous week, according to the American Petroleum Institute. Production was 68,050 barrels below the recommendation of 4,038,500 daily by the Office of Petroleum Coordinator for August.

ALBANY, Aug. 12 -- Governor Lehman has been asked by the State War Ballot Commission for aid in obtaining the names of soldiers in the armed forces who are eligible to vote in this State in the November election.

Larry French won a pitching duel from Rube Melton at Ebbets Field yesterday when the Phils' righthander walked Captain Dolph Camilli with the bases filled in the ninth, forcing Arky Vaughan across with the run that gave the Dodgers a 1-0 victory.

The five-story building on a plot 23.4 by 102.2 feet at 174 West Seventy-second Street has been l sold by the Bank for Savings to the 174 West Seventy-second Street Corporation. Sale was for cash above a purchase money mortgage of $70,000 for ten years.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Brazil, Aug. 12 -- A naval battle is believed near in the South Atlantic because a fast Allied cruiser, probably American, .is pursuing a German raider, sighted this morning about Lat. 20S., Long. 24:44W., 1000 miles east of Rio de Janeiro.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 12 -- A moratorium on obligations of Philippine companies held in the United States was announced today by the Treasury. It does not affect the obligations of the Philippine Government.

After twelve witnesses had testified yesterday as to the shooting Aug. 3 of Robert B. Greene and Morris Wolinsky, betting commissioners, in a card club at 846 Seventh Avenue, the grand jury handed up two first-degree murder indictments against Max Fox, former partner of Greene in the racket.

CHICAGO, Aug. 12 -- A program designed to further the consolidation into trainload lots of oil shipments to the East from the Middle West and to eliminate loss of time due to the practice of using small numbers of cars in these shipments was worked out today at a conference of oil and railroad men from Petroleum District 2, covering fifteen States, with officials of the Office of Defense Transportation and the Petroleum Coordinator's Bureau.
SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 12 -- Willing Spencer of Newport, R.I., has joined William Woodward for several days of racing.
AUGUSTA, Me., Aug. 12 -- J.C. Richdale of Boston, chairman of the New England Council on Liquid Fuel, told New England's six Governors today:

The feature boxing bout at Madison Square Garden tonight will show Bobby Ruffin, Astoria lightweight, in action against Bob Montgomery of Philadelphia. The battle is listed for ten rounds, and the winner will earn consideration as a challenger for the 135-pound crown, now held by Sammy Angott.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 12 -- As a result of the reduced cocoa supply, chocolate factories will soon be making radio detection equipment for the Army and Navy.

Three new films will open in midtown theatres this morning. At the Radio City Music Hall, "Bambi" will have its long-deferred premiere. The Walt Disney cartoon feature, in Technicolor, which has been five years in the making, is a picturization of the Felix Salten book. . . .

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 12 (AP) -- Two Brownie relief pitchers were necessary in the ninth inning today to quell a sudden outburst by the Chicago White Sox and assure Elden Auker of his thirteenth victory of the season as the Sox were defeated, 6 to 3.

The twenty-fifth season of outdoor concerts at the Lewisohn Stadium came to a close last night. True to tradition, it ended with "Auld Lang Syne," but because of the rain there were only seven violinists to play it and but 300 persons to join in the singing.

EAST HAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 12 -- When the Maidstone Club celebrates on Saturday the fiftieth anniversary of the formal opening of its first clubhouse, the original party will be duplicated as nearly as possible. There will be a tennis match at the Maidstone Tennis House in costumes of 1892 with Mrs. Leighton Stevens, Miss Jean Reid, Julian S. Myrick and John N. Cole as players.
A High Command communique broadcast from Berlin and recorded here by The Associated Press:

Werner von Clemm, head of the Pioneer Import Corporation, with which he is accused of having conspired to flout Federal rules on dealing with the occupied Low Countries, spent a second day on the witness stand in Federal Court yesterday.

GOSHEN, N.Y., Aug. 12 -- A 69-year-old driver, Ben White of Lexington, Ky., established a new record for the Hambletonian Stake by winning that classic of the light harness turf for the third time today.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 12 -- The War Labor Board took jurisdiction today over its largest dispute, involving 250,000 employes of subsidiaries of the United States Steel Corporation.

The Army, which is fast discovering that women French horn players are as hard to find as their sister piccoloists, announced with pride yesterday that "a healthy young lady" was seeking a French horn berth in the Waac band. If the applicant passes her physical examination, she will be the first of three such instrumentalists needed by the band.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 12 -- Enactment of a 10 per cent sales tax, and removal of all exemptions from the 5 per cent withholding tax already voted by the House were steps recommended to the Senate Finance Committee today by Ellsworth C. Alvord, a Washington attorney, in behalf of the Chamber of Commerce of the United States.
LONDON, Aug. 12 (AP) -- An Air Ministry communique:

TRENTON, Aug. 12 -- The Quartermaster General's department of New Jersey "failed in its duty" to check "scandalously high" food bills charged to the State's Executive cottage at Sea Girt last Summer, Governor Charles Edison was informed today by Adjt. Gen. James I. Bowers.

Advertising linage in newspapers of fifty-two major cities, measured by Media Records, advanced 0.7 per cent in July, compared with the 1941 month, reducing the loss for the first seven months to 7.4 per cent. All seven classifications continued to show losses for the year to date.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 12 -- Unconfirmed secret reports that Japanese Premier Hideki Tojo had been shot and slightly wounded on June 17 were made public today by Kilsoo Haan, head of the Sino-Korean People's League. He said the attempted assassin, Park Soowon, a Korean, had been killed by the police.

In your issue of Aug. 10 V.H. Garabedian suggests that highway signs and markers be painted on the roadway so that fifth columnists cannot so readily remove them, and also in order to conserve war material. This suggestion has several faults. Most important is that the removal of highway markers is the last thing the fifth column would have in mind.

AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, Australia, Aug. 12 (U.P.) -- United States Marines were reported battering their way into the interior of the three key islands of the Solomons today with the Japanese fighting a desperate delaying action while awaiting reinforcements.

The Japanese continued yesterday to claim a big victory in the Solomon Islands battle, but they were reticent on details and again there was no communique from the Imperial headquarters, The United Press reported on the basis of Tokyo broadcasts recorded in this country.

Four young women in blue and white uniforms marched yesterday up the hall of the nurses' home at the Montefiore Hospital for Chronic Diseases to receive their nurses' caps. This ceremony marked the eighty-sixth graduation of Red Cross nurse's aides at the hospital on Gun Hill Road, near Jerome Avenue, the Bronx.

The revised application form for individual export licenses just released by the Board of Economic Warfare is designed to tighten the controls on shipments to doubtful and undesirable consignees, exporters noted yesterday. On the form previously used, BEW 119, it was pointed out, traders were required to state only the name of the ultimate consignee, but on the new form the name of the ultimate consumer must be set forth.
CHICAGO, Aug. 12 (AP) -- The St. Louis Cardinals today took both ends of a double-header from the Chicago Cubs, 9 to 4 and 8 to 3, before a crowd of 14,127.

Unit furniture that builds upward with grace and efficiency is good news for homes with space problems. What once spread out horizontally now also climbs vertically, providing a new treatment of sectional groupings that is only one of the major features of sectional furniture now on display at Altman's.

Thirty-seven drawings have been submitted in the Fine Arts Federation's contest for an improved plan for the reconstruction of Battery Park, it was announced last night by Egerton Swartwout and John A. Thompson, the architects named as advisers in the competition.

Although the tropical worsted men's suit season normally draws to a close at this period of the year, retailers reported yesterday that trade is moving at a better pace than a year ago. Some believe that there is a note of anticipation in the buying, especially by men beyond military age, who are stocking up against the shortages of all-worsted goods next year.
OMAHA, Aug. 12 (AP) -- Foster May, a young radio announcer was paired today against a Republican organizer in the fight for the Nebraska Senate seat now held by George W. Norris.

Although the tropical worsted men's suit season normally draws to a close at this period of the year, retailers reported yesterday that trade is moving at a better pace than a year ago. Some believe that there is a note of anticipation in the buying, especially by men beyond military age, who are stocking up against the shortages of all-worsted goods next year.
OMAHA, Aug. 12 (AP) -- Foster May, a young radio announcer was paired today against a Republican organizer in the fight for the Nebraska Senate seat now held by George W. Norris.

The Eastman Kodak Company announced yesterday that net sales of the company and subsidiaries located in the Western Hemisphere for the first half of 1942 amounted to $97,539,272, an increase of 33 per cent over sales of $73,525,058 in the first six months of 1941.

Women now have the "universal job" of learning what it means to be citizens in a democracy, Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt told 1,500 Hunter College students yesterday. She stressed the importance of voting in primary elections and participating in the government as much as possible.
INDIANAPOLIS, Aug. 12 -- William Dudley Pelley, convicted of sedition in the Federal District Court last week, was sentenced today by Judge Robert C. Baltzell to serve fifteen years in prison.

The receivers for the Seaboard Air Line Railway invited holders of $22,000,000 of its receivers' certificates yesterday to tender them for purchase from the company's funds. The offer is the first of its kind to have been made under comparable circumstances.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 12 (AP) -- Richard J. Dearborn, who came to the government from the Texas company as a technical consultant in development of the synthetic rubber program, denied before a Senate committee today a charge that he had conspired to keep rubber production in the hands of a "German-American" patent pool.

In true Yankee fashion, reminiscent of the boom days of '27, Charley Keller stepped up to the plate in the ninth inning with the bases loaded, one out and the score tied and smashed a better-than-400-foot homer into the right-center-field bleachers at the Stadium yesterday.

The Omaha Housing Authority, Omaha, Neb., sold yesterday a total of $3,681,000 of bonds to refund a like amount issued on Oct. 1, 1940. Of this amount $3,128,000 went to a New York City banking group and $553,000 to the Federal Public Housing Authority.

LONDON, Aug. 12 (U.P.) -- Netherland sources asserted tonight that the German occupation authorities were holding 1,000 persons, including prominent teachers, scientists and doctors, as hostages under threat of execution unless saboteurs who wrecked a German troop train near Rotterdam were captured by Friday.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 12 -- Dr. T.V. Soong, Chinese Foreign Minister, said today that the Pacific War council members had been very much encouraged by the attack upon the Solomon Islands because it showed that the United Nations had moved from defensive operations to offensive action in the Pacific.

Woolen manufacturers were confident yesterday that the government's future wool goods buying policy, which has been confused for two weeks by conflicting reports from Washington and Philadelphia, will be announced soon, possibly early next week.

The theft of 4,450 gasoline ration books containing coupons for the purchase of more than 1,000,000 gallons of gasoline, was revealed here yesterday by Irving C. Rutter, chief enforcement attorney for Region II of the Office of Price Administration.

The German High Command announced yesterday that the battle of the big Don bend, west of Kalach, had ended with the destruction of the mass of the Sixty-second Soviet Army and said that 1,044,741 Russian soldiers had been captured since the beginning of fighting in the Spring, according to Berlin broadcasts recorded by The Associated Press.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 12 -- United States Marines have landed on three islands in the vicinity of Tulagi, in the Solomon Islands, and are consolidating their positions in the face of considerable enemy resistance, it was announced by the Navy today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 12 -- The proposal that liaison between countries after the war should not be merely that of Ambassador with Foreign Office but be effected by professional, commercial and cultural bodies serving the same purposes in different countries was made today by Jan Ciechanowski, Polish Ambassador.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 12 -- Far from battle-scarred France, where they first came together twenty-one years ago, the Unknown Soldier and Edward F. Younger were reunited today in the company of other honored American dead in Arlington National Cemetery.

CHICAGO, Aug. 12 -- Mill buying and strength in Minneapolis lifted wheat prices on the Board of Trade around 1/2 cent a bushel in the early trading today, but there was no follow up in the buying, and when the professional elements turned to the selling side they found support slow, and prices declined around 1 cent from the top.

The lively demand for apartments in Manhattan continued yesterday when brokers and renting agents added more names to tenant rosters of buildings in the East and West Side areas. Riverside Drive, West End Avenue and Central Park West were active centers in the rush for suites.
MOSCOW, Thursday, Aug. 13 (AP) -- A later Soviet Information Bureau communique:

BOMBAY, Aug. 12 (AP) -- The upheaval of riot and bloodshed that has marked Mohandas K. Gandhi's do-or-die independence movement showed signs of wearing itself out in its fifth day today. Gunfire, however, twice resounded through Bombay's streets, where violence has been at its height.

LONDON, Aug. 12 (AP) -- Indications that the Axis is starting a strong surface-raider and submarine campaign in the South Atlantic were reported by informed British naval sources today. The extension of Axis offensive operations into the South Atlantic was noted by naval sources as a further step in the battle of supply.

Requesting yesterday that all copies of James Aldridge's novel "Signed With Their Honour" be returned, Little, Brown gave some clue to why the novel about the British retreat in Greece and the battle of Crete written by a young Australian correspondent was suddenly postponed several weeks ago.

Mayor La Guardia submitted to the Board of Estimate yesterday, at a special meeting held in his office at City Hall, a resolution calling for the severance of 197 employes from the city payroll next Thursday because the funds were not available to pay the salaries to which they are entitled under the McCarthy Salary Increment Law.

PITTSBURGH, Aug. 12 (AP) -- Lefty Johnny Vander Meer was in rare form tonight, allowing only three hits in hurling the Reds to a 3 -- 0 victory over the Pirates and winning his thirteenth game of the year. Frank McCormick led the Reds' attack with four consecutive hits.

Objections to the probate of the will of Lawrence Myers, who died March 12, were filed yesterday in Surrogate's Court by his niece, Mrs. Emily Le Grand Myers. If Mrs. Myers is successful in her suit the legacies to six charitable institutions will be affected.

Sir Walter Turner Monckton, former director general of the British Ministry of Information and former Acting Minister of State in the Middle East, expressed yesterday the "strong belief that Turkey will not switch to the Axis."

Cloak manufacturers continued yesterday to inspect the sample Waac overcoat at the offices here of the National Coat and Suit Industry Recovery Board. Bids for 33,000 of the garments, including 3,000 officers' coats, are due by Aug. 21.

For weeks scores of statements by government officials and competent outside observers have been circulating through the press warning the American public that we, as a people, have not yet entered upon total war. And from Elmer Davis's Office of War Information comes the pronouncement that we are only "ankle deep" in production -- after nine months of fighting.

CLEVELAND, Aug. 13 -- With two men out and the bases full in the ninth, Oris Hockett came to bat today and smashed a double that drove in three runs, enabling the Indians to set back the Tigers, 3 to 2, and climb back in the victory column.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 13 -- The trustees of the Associated Gas and Electric Corporation were ordered today by the Securities and Exchange Commission to divest themselves of all interest in 116 subsidiaries scattered throughout the country from Maine to Arizona and including two in the Philippines.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 13 -- President Roosevelt vetoed today a measure which would allow commissioned officers of the Coast and Geodetic Survey to be deemed on active military service.

HAMILTON, N.Y., Aug. 13 -- Peace terms at the end of the present conflict must be dictated by the conservatives, not the radicals, if the world is to have a peace which will last longer than two decades, Dr. George Barton Cutten told Colgate students and faculty members today in a farewell address as president.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 13 (AP) -- The Dies Committee, it was learned today, will send to President Roosevelt this week a copy of a confidential letter sent from Germany to Nazi sympathizers in the United States, advising them that Walter Kappe had been appointed to head a fifth column front in this country and paving the way for his work.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 13 -- During the week ended Aug. 12 member bank reserve balances increased $107,000,000. Additions to member bank reserves arose from a decrease of $111,000,000 in Treasury deposits with Federal Reserve Banks and increases of $66,000,000 in Reserve Bank credit, $4,000,000 in Treasury currency and $3,000,000 in gold stock, offset in part by increases of $76,000,000 in money in circulation and $2,000,000 in Treasury cash.

Under our present income tax system taxpayers are constantly a year behind in their debt to the Government. This year they are paying taxes on last year's income and most of them are paying out of this year's income. As the tax burden increases, that constant overhanging tax debt becomes perilous.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 13 -- Sundodger and Baby Dumpling were the winners today in the Espino and Bedouin Purses, respectively, as 7,763 persons turned out for the races with the meeting just past the halfway mark.

Net earnings of the Mid-Continent Petroleum Corporation and its subsidiary companies, for the quarter ended on June 30, were $1,291,694, after Federal and State income taxes and other charges, or 70 cents each on 1,857,912 shares of common stock, it was announced yesterday.

Mrs. Guy Percy Trulock, president of the New York City Federation of Women's Clubs, was appointed yesterday chairman of the Tin Can Salvage Committee by Clarence H. Low, chairman of the New York City Salvage Committee.

Arnaldo Estrella, Rio de Janiero pianist, has won the first Columbia Concerts Award for young Brazilian pianists, it was announced yesterday. His prize will consist of a debut as soloist with the New York Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra in February, a Town Hall recital, appearances with orchestras in other parts of the country and his expenses to and from Brazil.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Aug. 13 -- "Five Graves to Cairo," a story by Charles Brackett and Billy Wilder about the war in the Egyptian desert, will replace "Bill of Goods" on the Paramount production schedule, the studio announced today.

Most of the 2,615 State prisoners released on parole in 1941 had not had much schooling, most of them also lacked the responsibility of marriage, and nearly half, when children, had suffered from "broken" homes, according to a study made public yesterday by Frederick A. Moran, chairman of the State Parole Board.
BERNE, Switzerland, Aug. 13 -- The "virtual destruction" of a United Nations convoy in the Mediterranean after two days of fighting is claimed in a series of Axis communiques issued late tonight.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 13 -- A tea and reception this afternoon marked the opening of an exhibition of portraits by Olive Bigelow (Mrs. Herbert C. Pell) at the Cushing Memorial Gallery of the art association. All proceeds from sales made during the two weeks of the exhibition will be donated to the Rhode Island Auxiliary of the Navy Relief Society.

CHICAGO, Aug. 13 -- Mill buying in relatively small amounts gave the wheat market a firm tone in the early trading on the Board of Trade today but there was no follow up in the demand and professional traders took the selling side later and caused a recession.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 13 -- Thomas Kennedy and Emil Rieve, labor members of the War Labor Board representing the Congress of Industrial Organizations, dissented today from the board's decision to review a wage increase voluntarily negotiated by employes of the Westinghouse Electric and Manufacturing Company.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 13 -- Senator Elbert D. Thomas, Democrat, of Utah today called on Americans to observe Chinese Air Force Day tomorrow as a tribute to "the bitter and heroic battle for Chinese skies" that this small and outnumbered force had fought against the Japanese invaders for five years.

SANTIAGO, Chile, Aug. 13 (AP) -- The Foreign Office announced tonight that President Juan Antonio Rios had been invited by President Roosevelt to visit the United States. Usually well-informed circles said he had decided to accept.

Bob Montgomery, Philadelphia lightweight, redeemed himself in the eyes of local boxing followers last night. He scored a decisive triumph over Bobby Ruffin of Astoria in the feature bout of ten rounds at Madison Square Garden, and in so doing erased the sorry performance he turned in several months ago when he was trounced by lightweight champion Sammy Angott in the same ring.

Final figures were not available last night, but officials of the New York Stock Exchange said its members had approved a constitutional amendment allowing the board of governors to set the unit of trading for any stock.

The Public Service Commission announced yesterday its approval of a plan proposed by the companies of the Long Island Lighting System for curtailing the supply of gas for house heating to new customers or for use in new equipment by existing customers.

"The Gay Sisters," Warners' screen version of Stephen Longstreet's novel, which opens at the Strand, will be this morning's lone film newcomer. Barbara Stanwyck, George Brent, Geraldine Fitzgerald and Nancy Coleman head the east of the drama.

In the last nine months this writer has visited every neutral country in Europe. In the north I saw Sweden "fed through a cage," and then Switzerland trapped in the center of the Nazi mass. In the south I saw Spain and Portugal.

CHICAGO, Aug. 13 (AP) -- The Cubs and Cardinals engaged in a long, drawn-out slugging match today, and when the smoke cleared the Chicago team had a 13-to-5 victory and Claude Passeau had won his sixteenth triumph of the season.
Fashion dictators and other such arbitrary persons to the contrary notwithstanding, it is still Summer. And you still have a sun tan.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 13 -- Commodity prices in primary markets were comparatively steady last week. The Bureau of Labor statistics index of 889 price series remained unchanged at 98.6 per cent of the 1926 level. Average prices for these commodities are now at exactly the same level as in the week of April 25, just before the General Maximum Price Regulation was issued.

YONKERS, N.Y., Aug. 13 -- Four of the twenty-five pro-amateur teams which played at the Hudson River Country Club today tied for first place in the Westchester County Golf Association best-ball event.

CAMDEN, N.J., Aug. 13 (AP) -- H.R. Dulany Jr.'s Visiting Nurse, one of the most consistent fillies of the Garden State Park session, added another victory today, taking the five-furlong Township Purse by three and a half lengths.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 13 (U.P.) -- Warplane production in the first six months of 1942 exceeded the entire 1941 output, Colonel John H. Jouett, president of the Aeronautical Chamber of Commerce of America, reported tonight.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 13 (AP) -- Secretary Stimson said today that Army policy for commissioning officers direct from civilian life was drawn carefully to grant such commissions strictly on the basis of merit, and to prevent favoritism.

A further decline in the volume of bankers' dollar acceptances outstanding in the United States was reported yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York in its monthly survey of the market. As of July 31, the volume was $156,302,000, a decrease of $6,547,000 on the month, and a drop of $53,597,000 from one year ago.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 13 -- Blame for shortages of raw materials plaguing the war drive in some areas was laid today by Senator Mead of New York to the alleged failure of the War and Navy Departments to cooperate on allocations.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 13 -- Sixty-one major groups of services, embracing most of those important to the cost of living, are affected by a revision of the Consumer Service Regulation No. 165 announced today by the Office of Price Administration.
The Navy seeks private pilots with as few as 125 flying hours for instructor or ferry duties, the Naval Aviation Cadet Selection Board, 120 Broadway, announced yesterday.

LONDON, Friday, Aug. 14 -- Soon after a strong force of big British bombers returned early yesterday from a destructive raid for the second consecutive night on Mainz in the Rhineland, United States Army Air Forces officials here announced that American fighter squadrons in the forty-eight hours to 9 A.M. yesterday carried out thirty-one offensive sorties against the Germans on this front.

A spurt of a point in United States Steel and a few other investment favorites in the final hour yesterday stirred the stock market to activity after four hours of narrow movements and listless trading. However, sales in the lower-priced issues were responsible for increasing the volume to the heaviest since Aug. 4.
LONDON, Aug. 13 -- The brighter tone which has been in evidence on the stock markets continued today with textiles and oils featured.

Purchases of government securities, now a weekly affair by the Open Market Committee of the Federal Reserve System on behalf of the twelve regional banks, amounted to $84,025,000 in the week ended Wednesday, according to figures released yesterday.

Though the Navy describes last week's surface attacks on the Japanese at Kiska Island as a heavy bombardment, the purpose of the raid was undoubtedly to obtain information as well as to inflict damage. The Aleutian fogs prevent satisfactory reconnaissance from the air, but our command ought now to have a fairly accurate idea of the strength and location of enemy batteries around the harbor.

New Yorkers should carry handkerchiefs, newspapers or other white objects in their hands when crossing streets in dimouts or blackouts, according to advice issued yesterday by the Greater New York Safety Council.

Twenty-seven passengers arrived from Europe last night on two flying boats, one a Flying Ace of the American Export Line with eighteen passengers, and the other a Pan-American Airways Clipper, with nine passengers.

LONDON, Aug. 13 -- While the immediate outlook is "somber" and the task ahead is "grim" as "the symphony of war rises to a crescendo," Minister of Production Oliver Lyttelton said today, the battle of the seas is not going so badly.

A record day of ship launchings will be celebrated by Portland, Me., and near-by communities on Sunday, when affiliated shipbuilding concerns will send eight seagoing vessels into deep water for the United Nations campaign against the Axis powers.

Although clothiers licensed to sell regulation Army uniforms under the Army Exchange Service Regulatory Plan will do from three to four times as much uniform business as in the past, their profits will be curtailed sharply, Henry Modell, president of the Modell Military Stores, declared yesterday.

HEADQUARTERS, SIXTH ARMY CORPS, Wadesboro, N.C., Aug. 13 -- The air-ground phase of the Sixth Corps manoeuvres, one of a series of Summer and Fall exercises intended to train and harden troops for overseas duty, ended today.

MANCHESTER, Mass., Aug. 13 (AP) -- Weather forced postponement today of the quarter-finals match between fourth-seeded Miss Louise Brough of Beverly Hills, Calif., and the unranked Miss Kay Winthrop of Hamilton, Mass., and doubles semi-finals in the eighteenth annual Essex County Club women's tennis tournament.

Max Rothman, 30 years old, for whom the police had been hunting two weeks as the alleged confederate of Frederick (Big Freddie) Bertolotti, the ex-convict operator of an East Side loan-shark racket, was arrested yesterday by Detective Thomas Kennedy of the East Fifty-first Street Station in his home, 41-12 Thirty-ninth Place, Queens.

Retail prices remained unchanged during July, the first month this has happened since September, 1940, according to the Fairchild retail price index, made public yesterday. The index remained at 113.1 in the month, only slightly above the March level, the base for the general maximum price regulation.

The can opener, scorned as a feminine gewgaw by Army mess sergeants who swear that a cleaver is the best implement for splitting a can, has come into its own in military camps and reservations in the interest of tin salvage.

Mildred Jordan's new novel is a change of pace for an author who started her literary career last Fall with a 550-page historical novel based on the life of the fabulous "Baron" Steigel, colonial glassmaker -- "One Red Rose Forever."

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Aug. 13 (AP) -- Little Ben Hogan -- whose size belies his mighty golf stature -- took the lead in the first round of the $5,000 Times-Union open tournament today by exploding a 64, six under par and four strokes better than his nearest opponent.

MONTCLAIR, N.J., Aug. 13 -- Three superior mudders were uncovered today at the Montclair Golf Club when ten of a starting field of twenty-five posted scores in the once-postponed qualifying round of the New Jersey State amateur golf championship.

Supreme Court Justice Bernard Botein ruled yesterday that Father Divine, Harlem cult leader, is in contempt of court for his failure to comply with a previous Supreme Court order directing him to pay $100 a week in satisfaction of a judgment.

The Schulte interests enlarged a midtown holding yesterday when the 1941 Corporation, controlled by David A. Schulte, bought the four-story store and loft building on a lot 20 by 75.5 feet at 103 West Forty-second Street. The parcel, which is assessed at $170,000, was bought for cash from the Dry Dock Savings Institution through Frank A. Cassidy, broker.

CHICAGO, Aug. 13 (AP) -- Rear Admiral Frederick C. Sherman, former commander of the aircraft carrier Lexington, and other naval officers conferred with a special prosecutor today as a Federal grand jury began investigating publication of alleged "confidential" naval information by The Chicago Tribune, The New York Daily News and The Washington Times Herald.

The decline in installment furniture sales more than doubled immediately following the tightening of credit regulations on May 6, Arthur Fertig Co., retail advisory service, reported yesterday. In April the decline compared with 1941 was 15.7, while in May the decrease was 32.3 per cent.

AUCKLAND, New Zealand, Aug. 13 -- The Marines have landed and the situation is well in hand. In brief, this seemed today to describe the state of affairs in the Tulagi area of the Solomon Islands. Since all communiques on the operations are being issued elsewhere, South Pacific headquarters continued to maintain silence and declined to confirm or deny reports that the success of the attack was virtually assured.

ATLANTA, Aug. 13 -- There were two reactions today to the appeal of Milwee Owens, editor of The Augusta Herald, to Governor Talmadge and Attorney General Arnall, candidates for Governor, urging them to purge the race issue from the political campaign.

Yesterday's statement of the twelve Reserve Banks showed holdings of United States Government securities to be the highest on record, having increased $81,025,000 during the past week. Note circulation was also the highest for the year, while ratio of reserve was at the lowest.

CHICAGO, Aug. 13 (AP) -- The reigning champions of the women's Western Golf Association -- Mrs. Russell Mann of Omaha, Neb., and Miss Betty Jameson of San Antonio, Texas -- rolled safely through the quarter-final round of the women's amateur meet today at Sunset Ridge and continued to head toward a possible meeting in Saturday's final.

Nylon, the wonder thread of coal, air and water -- a total stranger to women only two years ago before its appearance on the market in stockings -- has accomplished a new step in its fabulous career. Today, after having been used for stockings, lingerie fabrics, girdles and coats, nylon emerges from the chemical tube to be metamorphosized into hats, gloves, belts and bags.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 13 -- The White House issued the following statement in connection with the order to the Navy Department to take over the plant of the General Cable Company at Bayonne, N.J.:

ALBANY, Aug. 13 -- The State Board of Law Examiners, composed of John Kirkland Clark of New York, Philip J. Wickser of Buffalo and John T. DeGraff of Albany, today completed the rating of papers written by 690 applicants for admission to the bar.
LONDON, Aug. 13 (AP) -- Note circulation of the Bank of England increased slightly more than 1,000,000 in the week ended on Aug. 12 to 834,473,000, the statement disclosed today.

NEWARK, N.J., Aug. 13 -- A new motive for sabotage, the desire to impede a plant's war production with the object of prolonging the conflict and his $100 a week job, was ascribed by Federal authorities today to the technical foreman of a Jersey City plant who was arrested on a sabotage charge after officials of the plant had complained for the second time of his "eccentric" conduct in giving orders to subordinates.

Two inspectors of contractors' equipment at the Brooklyn Navy Yard arrested on charges of accepting bribes were reported in THE TIMES as having been trap drummers in jazz bands before their employment as inspectors.

While activity in the cotton market slowed down yesterday, there was sufficient trade support in the final minutes on the New York Cotton Exchange to convert the early small losses into equally slight gains. Active futures showed final net increases of 3 to 5 points.

LONDON, Aug. 13 (U.P.) -- The United Nations' forces have air superiority over land and sea in the Battle of the Solomons, where the Japanese Fleet has "lost control of Tulagi Harbor" under the blasting of American warships, the naval correspondent of The Yorkshire Post reported today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 13 -- Department-store sales for the week ended Aug. 8 were off 5 per cent from the comparable week last year, the Federal Reserve Board announced today. This compared with a 6 per cent decrease from 1941 for the previous week. Sales for the latest four-week period were off 1 per cent.

Prominent in the cast of "The Time, the Place and the Girl," a musical comedy of yesteryear, revised by John Neff, will be Joe E. Howard, who is perhaps best known as the author of that ballad called "I Wonder Who's Kissing Her Now."

WASHINGTON, Aug. 13 -- Weekly sugar allotments to consumers will probably be maintained at the present half-pound minimum through Oct. 1, 1943, the Office of Price Administration said today in a survey of the sugar rationing program since its inception.

A recommendation that the city allocate $100,000 to pay mandatory salary increments to 100 instructors in City, Brooklyn and Hunter College has been made to the Mayor by the executive committee of the Board of Higher Education, it was learned yesterday.

The five-story apartment house at 635 Jefferson Place, the Bronx, has been sold by the Hu-bel Realty Corporation, subject to a first mortgage of $58,050. The building is assessed at $70,000. Jacob Emil Leitner, Inc., were the brokers. The buyer was represented by Martin Fromer and the seller by Abraham L. Sobil.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 13 -- Charges that the pending grand jury investigation of The Chicago Tribune was part of "a smear campaign" were made in the House today by Representative Hoffman of Michigan, who called for an investigation of the motives of Secretary Knox in recommending it.
A communique broadcast from Rome and recorded here by The Associated Press:

It will be a misfortune if, while we are closely occupied watching the progress of fleets and armies abroad and the output of mills at home, we failed to learn at least one lesson from the experience through which our beloved homeland is passing. I refer to the part which American railroads are playing.

Motorized German infantry has swept across the Northeast Caucasian steppe below the Don and captured Elista, within 150 miles of the Caspian Sea, the German High Command announced yesterday, according to Berlin broadcasts recorded by The Associated Press.

CAZENOVIA, N.Y., Aug. 13 -- Defeating his sixth-round opponent, Ben Altman of Flushing, in a game lasting only seventeen moves, Milton Hanauer of New York headed the field in the annual tournament of the New York State Chess Association at Cazenovia Junior College today.

HARTFORD, Conn., Aug. 13 -- "Absolutely," was the reply of the Rev. Kurt E.B. Molzahn of Philadelphia, when asked this afternoon by one of the government lawyers prosecuting him for alleged espionage conspiracy if he despised Nazis.

MOSCOW, Friday, Aug. 14 -- The Germans' advance toward the Grozny oil region in the Caucasus was extended by about fifty miles yesterday, according to the midnight Soviet communique, which said the battlefield had spread to Mineralnye Vody, a junction, health resort and site of an important military airfield rather more than half way to the Caspian coast from the Black Sea.

LONDON, Aug. 13 -- A great air-naval battle in the Mediterranean, in which the British aircraft carrier Eagle has been sunk while engaged in escorting a big convoy to the island of Malta, apparently continued today.

NEWARK, N.J., Aug. 13 -- The production on war contracts at the Celanese Corporation's plant at 190 Ferry Street, here, was threatened today by a walkout of 250 employes on the three shifts in the concern's rolled celluloid department.

Unless it wished to see the whole war production program jeopardized by a series of outlaw strikes, the Government had no alternative but to accept the challenge of the outlaw strikers in the Bayonne plant of the General Cable Corporation and move promptly to a showdown.

Air raid wardens in supervisory or inspection services, City Patrol Corps members, American Women's Volunteer Service workers and other civilian defense volunteers are under certain conditions eligible for supplemental gasoline rations, Lee S. Buckingham, State OPA director, informed local rationing boards yesterday.

PAWTUCKET, R.I., Aug. 13 (AP) -- Mrs. Sam Orr's Us had enough at the finish today to withstand the closing challenge of Mrs. C.C. Winter's Night Editor in winning the North Attleboro purse, feature event at Narragansett Park.

MIDLAND, Texas, Aug. 13 (AP) -- Lou Zamperini, who as a California high school mile runner nearly provoked an international incident by tearing down a Nazi flag in front of Adolf Hitler's chancellery in Berlin during the 1936 Olympic Games, is ready to go back -- to tear down the chancellery.
BERNE, Switzerland, Aug. 13 -- That undernourishment is telling its tale in France, especially in the occupied zone, is confirmed by reports from Swiss citizens arriving from Paris and other regions.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 18 -- Isolationism as an issue took a prominent place in California's primary campaign today with a first-page announcement by The San Francisco Chronicle that it had decided against supporting Representative Thomas Rolph, Republican, of this city for renomination.
MOSCOW, Friday, Aug. 14 (AP) -- The Soviet midnight communique:

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 13 -- Adoption of the minimum capital requirements amendment to the by-laws of the National Association of Securities Dealers, Inc., would sound the death-knell for hundreds of small broker-dealer firms and lead to the disintegration of the association, it was predicted today in a hearing before the Securities and Exchange Commission.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., Aug. 13 -- Republican and independent groups that fought unsuccessfully against the renomination of Representative Hamilton Fish in Tuesday's Republican primaries will meet in New York tomorrow with Democratic leaders of the three counties comprising the Twenty-sixth Congressional District, it was disclosed today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 13 -- President Roosevelt issued an executive order directing the Secretary of the Navy to take over and operate the plant of the General Cable Company at Bayonne, N.J., where a strike has interferred with the production of war materials. His callers included the Argentine Ambassador, Mrs. Ogden Reid, Secretary Knox, Daniel J. Tobin and Thomas Wilson. Minister to Iraq.

EAST HAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 13 -- Two art exhibitions will complete the series for this season in the Guild Hall Galleries. On Tuesday afternoon, the fifth annual members' exhibition will open with a tea and preview in the Thomas Moran Gallery, and Mrs. Arthur Woolley-Hart will show her paintings in the Woodhouse Gallery.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 13 -- Charges that the Office of Price Administration was "seriously interfering" with present production and the future supply of combat planes for the armed forces, and was preparing to extend such interference to the output of ships, tanks, guns and munitions, were made in the House today by Representative Dow W. Harter, chairman of the special House committee investigating the aviation program.

SYRACUSE, Aug. 13 -- Attorney General John J. Bennett Jr. praised "the heart and mind and genius" of President Roosevelt in an address before the State convention of the American Legion at its opening session here today. He predicted that this "man of destiny" would lead America in winning freedom for all the peoples of the world.

All three of New York's major-league baseball teams were idle yesterday. The final game of the Yankees' series with the Red Sox at the Stadium was postponed, as was the twilight contest between the Dodgers and Braves at Ebbets Field. No game was scheduled for the Giants.
DETROIT, Aug. 13 (AP) -- Edward Rack, broad-shouldered printer from McKeesport, Pa., today won the Union Printcraft international golf title for the fifth straight year.

Werner von Clemm had warning of the crisis which changed Germany and Russia from treaty-bound friends into warring enemies three months before Germany's attack on the Soviet, he admitted on the witness stand in Federal court yesterday.

Seizure of the Bayonne, N.J., plant of the General Cable Corporation was ordered by President Roosevelt last night after 1,000 striking employes had rejected appeals from government and union representatives to end their defiance of a War Labor Board decision and return to work.
STOCKTON, Calif., Aug. 13 (AP) -- There's going to be only one change in the routine for 80-year-old Amos Alonzo Stagg this year.

Jacob Gould Schurman lived the legend dear to Canadians and Americans. He inherited nothing but poverty and health. His mind was trained and his experience widened in colleges at home and foreign universities. For twenty-eight years at Cornell he set his name as high as that of Goldwin Smith and Andrew White.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 13 -- Malta, battered British bastion in the Mediterranean, was named today by Air Vice Marshal Sir Hugh Pughe Lloyd as a probable jumping-off place for an eventual air invasion of Italy that would put Premier Mussolini and his followers "out of the war in no time."

No solution of the Indian question at this time is possible except on the basis of the proposals made to the leaders of the various Indian parties in behalf of the British Government by Sir Stafford Cripps, according to T.A. Raman, a Hindu journalist now visiting this country.

The city of Columbus, Ohio, announced yesterday it would sell on Sept. 1 through competitive sealed bidding a new issue of $280,000 of refunding bonds. The issue will be dated Sept. 16, 1942, and will mature serially on May 1 and Nov. 1, 1944 to 1955. Bidders are required to name the rate of interest.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 13 (AP) -- The Navy reported today that eighteen Marines who were killed in action aboard the aircraft carrier Lexington during the Coral Sea battle had been commended posthumously for setting "an example of courage and devotion to duty of the highest order."

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 13 (AP) -- Third Baseman Harlond Clift of the Browns smacked a homer and a double for four runs and scored another today in his team's 8-to-3 victory over the White Sox for a sweep of the three-game series.
The USO will receive soon a check for $72 from Clarence Low, chairman of the New York City Salvage Committee, but that is only one phase of the strange story of the 1,800 pounds of butter.

WITH UNITED STATES AIR FORCE, in Britain, Aug. 13 (AP) -- Erstwhile American football stars are digging ditches and some of the best civilian and Army aviation experts of the United States are converting centuries-old English estates into great air bases in a rush to send hundreds of bombers over Germany daily.

Councilman William M. McCarthy, Brooklyn Democrat and sponsor of the McCarthy Increment Law, criticized Mayor La Guardia yesterday for seeking to dismiss 197 city employes whose right to salary rises was recently upheld by the Court of Appeals.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 13 -- Allotment of $5,000,000 by the Federal Government to cover expenses of importing Mexican laborers to meet an "immediate and urgent" need in the harvest fields was urged today by the State Agricultural Advisory Committee.
CAIRO, Egypt, Aug. 13 -- A large formation of heavy bomber planes of the United States Army Air Forces swept in over the harbor of Pylos [Navarino], Greece, at dusk Tuesday.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 13 -- A question whether Associate Justice Murphy could legally be a member of the Supreme Court and an officer in the Army at the same time has been put to Chief Justice Stone and Secretary Stimson by. Representative Celler.

For the first time that the Office of Civilian Defense has taken part in recruiting activities for the armed forces, Director James M. Landis yesterday asked OCD regional heads to cooperate fully in an intensive campaign to enroll full-time personnel in the Coast Guard Temporary Reserve for beach patrol and coastal look-out duty.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 13 (U.P.) -- Two teams which played in "bowl games last New Year's Day -- Duke University and Alabama -- are included in the nine-game football schedule of the U.S. Navy Pre-Flight School at the University of Georgia, the Navy announced tonight.
LONDON, Aug. 13 (AP) -- An Air Ministry communique:

Disillusionment came yesterday to what is commonly regarded as one of the most "hardboiled" crews roaming the newsfronts of the city. It was dealt by three redheads, belonging to that part of our population ordinarily guaranteed to "take it" instead of give it.

LONDON, Aug. 13 (U.P.) -- Germans inflicted with "invasion jitters" are planning a wholesale execution of Netherland hostages for the wrecking of a troop train and have threatened to "annihilate all of Serbia" in an effort to stamp out Balkan guerrilla warfare, reports from the Continent said tonight.

How the nine members of the crew of a B-24 bomber and a reporter for Yank, the Army newspaper, hacked and paddled their way out of the Central American jungle in eight days after the big plane had been forced down in a storm on the way from a Caribbean port to "somewhere across the world" is told in the current issue of that newspaper.

At graduation exercises at the Naval Training School at Fort Schuyler, Throggs Neck, the Bronx, at 10:30 A.M. today, Uncle Sam's complement of naval officers will be increased by 334 men, according to an announcement yesterday from Third Naval District headquarters.

No difficulty is anticipated by Artists for Victory, Inc., in finding a suitable site on privately owned property for its patriotic statue, "Wings for Victory -- The Spirit of Aviation," which has been disapproved by Mayor La Guardia. Paul Manship, noted sculptor and a vice president of Artists for Victory, said yesterday that if the Mayor did not wish the statue erected on city property, it would be placed elsewhere.
MOSCOW, Aug. 13 (AP) -- A Soviet communique:

WASHINGTON, Aug. 13 -- J. Cheever Cowdin, chairman of the Committee on Government Finance of the National Association of Manufacturers, urged the Senate Finance Committee today to approve an 8 per cent "consumption" or retail sales tax to help finance the war and reduce the danger of inflation.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 13 (AP) -- General George C. Marshall, Chief of Staff, has rejected the suggestion of Senator Bankhead of Alabama that Northern Negro troops be stationed only in the North to avoid any possible racial difficulties, aides to the Senator disclosed today.

AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, Australia, Friday, Aug. 14 -- American Marines slashing through the jungles of the Solomon Islands from at least three beachheads were reported last night to be hurling the Japanese back while United States and other United Nations warships threw shells into enemy positions.

BOMBAY, Aug. 13 (U.P.) -- Police have killed five persons in a flare-up of independence rioting on India's industrial east coast, where mobs attacked a railway station and broke into a court room. Violence has subsided, however, in Bombay and New Delhi, storm centers of a five-day rebellion that has cost 74 lives.

A year ago today Franklin Roosevelt and Winston Churchill met off the coast of Newfoundland and signed the historic eight-point declaration that has come to be known as the Atlantic Charter. At that time neither the United States nor Japan was in the war.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 13 -- Henceforth American troops embarking for a land where a foreign language is spoken will be taught an elementary speaking knowledge of that language through a new and simplified method of instruction featuring the use of phonograph records, Secretary Stimson said today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 13 -- Leon Henderson, Price Administrator, asked Secretary Wickard today for permission to impose price ceilings on livestock to help end the meat shortage prevailing in some Eastern cities. OPA's idea is that a ceiling would discourage farmers who are declared to be holding animals off the market in the hope of higher prices.

Bank clearings in twenty-three cities in the United States amounted to $6,639,607,000 for the week ended on Wednesday, according to Dun Bradstreet, Inc. This was 15.5 per cent above the $5,746,495,000 recorded for the corresponding week last year, but was 3.4 per cent lower than last week's total of $6,875,059,000.

Mrs. John A. Davis will give a luncheon today in the Persian Room of the Plaza for the prospective attendants of her grandson, Ensign John A. Davis Banks, and Miss Joan Paige Flanagan, who will be married in the Church of the Heavenly Rest this afternoon.

WILMINGTON, Del., Aug. 13 -- A large group of college-trained women chemists recently have been added by the Hercules Powder Company to the research staff of its central experimental laboratories near this city.

"POLITICS, for me, means the fight against poverty." That one brief sentence contains the inner essence of the intense, evangelical, fighting political faith of Jennie Lee, a warmhearted, attractive Scotswoman who is convinced she knows how to solve the world's problems and would rather like a chance to do some of the actual solving herself.

GIBRALTAR, Aug. 13 -- I am a lucky man to be alive to write the story of the end of the British aircraft carrier Eagle. Clinging to a cork float with sailors, with waves capped with thick oily scum washing over us, I saw our ship sink with a thunderous, rumbling noise in the Western Mediterranean after she had been struck by four torpedoes.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 13 -- Secretary Ickes said today that fuel oil rationing for the East Coast area is not now under consideration by the Petroleum Coordinator's office.

Lieut. Gen. Drum's repudiation of the story given out at the public relations office of the First Air Force at Mitchel Field on Monday, that fifth columnists have been redesigning our terrain for the benefit of enemy flyers, is in one sense a relief. In another sense it is not.

Peter Franz Erich Donay, 35 years old, who formerly served in the Army and was stationed at Fort Jay, Governors Island, pleaded guilty yesterday in Federal Court, Brooklyn, to charges of conspiracy to act as an agent of a foreign government and of having transmitted to Germany information concerning the defense plans of the United States.

CHICAGO, Aug. 13 -- The first definite step toward reopening of peace negotiations between the American Federation of Labor and the Congress of Industrial Organizations was announced here today by William Green, A.F.L. president, following the closing session of the national executive council, over which Mr. Green has presided for twelve days.

MOSCOW, Friday, Aug. 14 (AP) -- German troops, in a swift fifty-mile advance in the Caucasus, have reached Mineralnye Vody, only 140 air-line miles from the rich Russian oil wells of Grozny, the Soviet High Command acknowledged early today as heavy fighting broke out on the long-dormant front northwest of Moscow.

PATERSON, N.J., Aug. 13 -- Milk, morals and machinery became hopelessly entangled here today and the result was that for fifteen minutes not a wheel turned in a part of Plant 2 of the Wright Aeronautical Corporation.

Mayor La Guardia conferred yesterday with other high city officials on a proposal to ask the Board of Estimate to authorize the expenditure of $10,955,780 for plans, sketches, preliminary studies and similar activities covering about half of the $628,000,000 post-war construction program outlined in the capital budget for 1942.

SOMEWHERE IN THE SOUTHWEST PACIFIC, Aug. 13 (U.P.) -- Sergeant Meyer Levin, the Brooklyn boy who as Captain Colin Kelly's bombardier bombed and sank the Japanese battleship Haruna, has done it again. He is almost certain he sank a big Japanese ship in the Coral Sea Battle.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Brazil, Aug. 10 -- A startling revelation of the Japanese war mind, as well as the ambitions prevalent not only in the military and ultra-nationalist cliques now dominating the Japanese Government but also among the intelligentsia, is contained in a booklet issued in Tokyo in February of this year by Professor Chikao Fujisawa, one of the leading exponents of Japan's political thought and philosophy.

Some of the plants entered in the Victory Garden Harvest Show conducted by the Horticultural Society of New York were sold yesterday for the benefit of the emergency fund for members of the armed forces.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 13 -- The question whether the administration was making sufficient use of German patents for the manufacture of atabrine and plasmochin, substitutes for quinine, to guarantee a large and cheap supply for war use, was raised in the House today by Representative Gearhart of California.

Messrs. Gilbert and Sullivan in their time seem to have understood perfectly the Japanese way of life. Mr. Tolischus, writing the other day about the supernatural sanctions behind Japanese imperialism, said: "Some of the more fanatical visionaries of the ultra-nationalist organizations led by Toyoma Nakano go farther.

CHUNGKING, China, Aug. 13 (AP) -- A communique from Lieut. Gen. Joseph W. Stilwell's United States Headquarters in China said today that American Sky Dragon bombers had carried out another attack Tuesday on the Japanese-held town of Yochow in the northeastern corner of Hunan Province.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 13 -- To prevent the use of Mexico by Axis agents as a place to dump dollar currency loot from Europe, the Mexican Government has restricted the importation and use of American currency in Mexico and the United States Government has taken confirmatory measures.
DO YOU KNOW THAT It takes only two hours' instruction to become a qualified fingerprint technician, and who knows what famous fingers you may be "printing" for the worthy cause of Civilian Defense?

WASHINGTON, Aug. 13 -- The House, with only twenty-eight of its 430 members present and under a gentleman's agreement to transact no controversial business during the unofficial recess, passed unanimously today the Rankin bill to authorize immediate payment of first allowances to dependents of enlisted men in the armed services under legislation enacted in June.

A national promotion for retailers of men's clothing and furnishings, to be sponsored by The American Weekly, is currently being announced in advertising in three trade papers. The campaign, designed to enable retailers to take advantage of the surplus buying power held by the "twelve men on the production front for every one on the fighting front, "will be announced also in The American Weekly.

LENOX, Mass., Aug. 13 (AP) -- Soviet Russia's Ambassador to the United States, Maxim Litvinoff, and his English-born wife, Mme. Ivy Litvinoff, will be in attendance tomorrow night at Tanglewood when Serge Koussevitzky conducts the student orchestra of the Berkshire Music Center in the first concert performance in America of Dimitri Shostakovich's Seventh symphony.

Alexander Marian Ziebowicz and his diary were in the custody of the Federal Bureau of Investigation yesterday, and from the contents of the diary Federal agents were fairly certain that the 20-year-old German would remain in durance for some time.
DETROIT, Aug. 13 (AP) -- John Duval Dodge, 43, son of the late automotive manufacturer. John F. Dodge, died tonight in Receiving Hospital.

James M. Landis, director of the Office of Civilian Defense, predicted yesterday an indefinite delay in the production of stirrup pumps for fighting fire bombs in case of air raids. He attributed this to military demands for the plastic, polyvinl-butyral, a substitute for rubber used in hose.
A communique broadcast from Berlin and recorded here by The Associated Press:

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 13 -- The board of managers of the Southampton Fresh Air Home for Crippled Children at a recent meeting held at Old Trees, the home of Mrs. Goodhue Livingston, president of the organization, announced that the annual rummage sale in behalf of the institution will take place on Sept. 10 in the auditorium of the parochial school in Hill Street.

The victory of various "isolationist" candidates in the primary elections on Tuesday is reported to have led to quiet discussion in New Deal quarters of a real "harmony" candidate for Governor on the Democratic ticket. It is based on the theory that under the present set-up the Republicans will elect Thomas E. Dewey as Governor unless all the Democratic organization and New Deal strength is mustered behind a single candidate.

By the fourth quarter it is expected that manufacturers who receive authorizations for material under the Production Requirements Plan should also be able to get the material, Norman E. Duehring of the training section, PRP branch of the War Production Board, declared here yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 13 -- Emergency freight rate revisions designed to facilitate the movement of coal by rail and water to New England points were announced today by the Office of Defense Transportation.

The Republican State executive committee picked its three principal legislative leaders yesterday for the key positions at the Republican State convention to be held in Saratoga Springs on Aug. 24 and 25. The committee discussed with delight the split in the Democratic party, and postponed consideration of lesser places on its State ticket until after the Democratic State convention has been held.

The largest Atlantic silver salmon reported taken from the Miramichi River so far this season was landed this week by Dr. J.A. Dunnington of New Canaan, Conn., according to a bulletin from Fredericton, N.B.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 13 -- Catch phrases, which offer the most convenient-means of stating a purpose that can be popularly understood, always carry with them the hazard of being twisted to suit the enemies of that purpose. Woodrow Wilson's "too proud to fight," which was sedulously misrepresented by his opponents on foreign policy, provides one illustration of this, and Mr. Baruch's long crusade to "take the profits out of war" provides another.

LONDON, Aug. 13 -- A United States Army general court-martial tonight acquitted Private Travis P. Hammond, a Texan serving with the air forces, of a charge of rape involving a 17-year-old English Y.M.C.A. worker.

As the season progresses, the list of vegetables regularly recommended each week-end by the Office of Price Administration grows gratifyingly more lengthy. Whereas city housekeepers were advised of the excellence of four or five varieties a month or so ago, they are now informed that a dozen kinds are good and abundantly available at pleasing prices.

While the August sales demand for fur garments in defense areas has been active, the moderate consumer response noted elsewhere has led trade observers to anticipate a strong later season business in October and November. This would reverse last year's trend, when August and September retail fur trade was extremely heavy, whereas volume was on the down-grade in October and November.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 13 -- Secretary Stimson gave orders today for a reduction of 75 per cent in the number of separate press agencies in the War Department and consolidation of the rest. There are about 100 such agencies in the department.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 13 -- A brief Navy communique issued today, announcing that "operations are continuing in the Solomon Islands area," indicated that the Marine shock troops who had landed on at least three of the islands were making progress, despite the bitter opposition of Japanese forces.

TRENTON, Aug. 13 -- Because of curtailment in the use of automobiles resulting from war restrictions, New Jersey motorists will be required to have their vehicles inspected only once a year instead of twice, it was announced today by State Motor Vehicle Commissioner Arthur W. Magee.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 13 (AP) -- The War Production Board reported today that Major Gen. Lewis B. Hershey, director of Seective Service, intended to have deferred from military service all persons engaged in copper mining "who are found by local boards to be essential to copper production."

Representative Hamilton Fish Jr. faced a new threat to his campaign for re-election in the Twenty-sixth Congressional District as leaders of the anti-Fish groups and the Democratic organization in the district met here yesterday and discussed plans to unite their forces behind the candidacy of former City Judge Ferdinand A. Hoyt of Beacon, Democratic opponent of the Representative.

LONDON, Aug. 14 -- Wing Commander Max Aitken, Lord Beaverbrook's son, revealed in a broadcast tonight that his Czech squadron had shot down a German "super-bomber" -- the Heinkel 177 -- believed able to carry a 1,000-pound bomb load from Brest to New York and make the return trip to France.

The five-story apartment building on a plot 25 by 100.1 feet at 364 West 117th Street, has been sold by Frederic D. Sasse, trustee, to an investing client of Saul Marshall Bernstein, attorneys. Keogh Keogh represented the seller.
CHICAGO, Aug. 14 (AP) -- The Cubs pounded three Pirate pitchers for eighteen hits today to run off with the opener of a five-game series, 7 to 1.

Backed by State Chairman James A. Farley, Attorney General John J. Bennett Jr., candidate for the Democratic nomination for Governor, seemed yesterday not only to have held his substantial lead in State Convention delegates but to have increased it.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 14 -- Employer members of the War Labor Board, for the first time since the board was created in January, publicly called upon a concern to abide by a decision of the board, saying that a refusal "is a refusal to obey the orders of the President of the United States, Commander in Chief in time of war."

Blasting Boston pitching for a total of forty-three bases, the Dodgers yesterday swept a twin bill at Ebbets Field, 10 -- 0 and 7 -- 3, to run their victory string to four straight and strengthen their grip on first place.

Hundreds of passengers on trains stalled in the BMT subway tunnel near the Fifth Avenue-Fifty-ninth Street station at 10:15 A.M. yesterday were thrown into a near-panic when a short-circuited third rail started a smoky fire on the right-of-way. Persons standing on the station platform also became panicky and made a rush for the exits.

While jubilant strikers returned to work at the Bayonne, N.J., plant of the General Cable Corporation acclaiming "Uncle Sam, our new boss," high government officials in Washington endeavored yesterday to dispel the notion that President Roosevelt's seizure of the plant represented a victory over the management for the 1,000 employes who walked out last Monday in defiance of a War Labor Board decision denying higher pay to them.

" Moscow Strikes Back," the Soviet documentary feature dealing with the Russian counter-offensive on the Moscow front last year, will have its premiere today at the Globe Theatre. The film, which is being distributed in this country by Artkino Pictures, Inc., has a commentary by Albert Maltz narrated by Edward G. Robinson.

The final drive of the Victory Fund Committees in this and other Federal Reserve districts to sell the government's "tap issue" 2 1/2 per cent bonds to non-banking investors before the Treasury formally closes the subscription books tonight will be made today in an effort to reach every likely subscriber and, in some instances, to ask for increases in subscriptions already made.

One hundred and ninety-eight Coast Guardsmen will be graduated as pharmacists' mates from Columbia University's College of Pharmacy at ceremonies at 3 P.M. today in the auditorium of the West Side Y.M.C.A., 5 West Sixty-third Street.

BOSTON, Aug. 14 (AP) -- The Commercial Bulletin will say tomorrow: "It has been a placid week in the wool trade. Only one or two houses have had a substantial business. Demand has favored very largely fine and half-blood territory wools, for which prices have approximated the ceilings very closely.

LENOX, Mass., Aug. 14 -- Tanglewood was on parade tonight for the great Russian War Relief benefit arranged by Dr. Serge Koussevitzky. The attendance was about 4,000, and it was estimated that net receipts would be between $12,000 and $15,000.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 14 -- Labor and public members of a War Labor Board panel recommended today that the General Motors Corporation increase wages for 225,000 employes 5 cents an hour. This proposal, with other financial changes suggested, would add at least $25,000,000 annually to the company's wage bill, it was unofficially estimated.

LONDON, Aug. 14 -- The body of Sir George Langton, 60-year-old justice of the High Court, was found this morning in an estuary of the River Parret, near Bridgewater, Somerset. He had been missing since Sunday.

Marist headquarters in Boston have received no word from Bishop Thomas J. Wade, S.M., American-born Vicar Apostolic of the Solomon Islanders, and his missionary co-workers, comprising forty-seven Marist priests and fifty-four Sisters of the Society of Mary, the Religious News Service reports.

MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, Aug. 14 -- A Free Italy movement, similar in organization and intent to General Charles de Gaulle's Fighting France, will be founded by the First Pan-American Conference of Free Italians, which was inaugurated in this capital tonight and which will continue sittings until Sunday morning.

CAZENOVIA, N.Y., Aug. 14 -- Successful in annexing his adjourned game with Edward Lasker from the sixth round, in which he held an advantage when hostilities ceased, Israel A. Horowitz of the Manhattan Chess Club today regained first place in the New York State Chess Association championship.

Protestant missionaries to Arabia and the Philippines and a former missioner to Japan will be heard here at morning church services tomorrow. Three Protestant Episcopal Bishops also will preach here. Roman Catholics will attend masses for the Feast of the Assumption of the Blessed Virgin Mary today.
