Richard Ernst Weber, 55 years old, formerly of 41-69 Forley Street, Elmhurst, L.I., pleaded guilty yesterday in the United States District Court in Brooklyn to an indictment charging him with conspiracy to transmit information about the defenses of the United States to Germany.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., Aug. 14 (AP) -- Yale University has awarded ten scholarships in the Graduate School to labor union leaders.

While Reformed and Orthodox Jewish leaders were at odds over whether Sabbath candles should be extinguished during a blackout, Magistrate Morris Rothenberg, in Bronx Magistrates Court, applied yesterday an ancient Hebrew maxim to solve the problem.

Yank, the United States Army's newspaper, has performed the equivalent of squeezing water out of a rock. It has persuaded many of the nation's leading band leaders to contribute many of their best swing arrangements without cost.

JERUSALEM, Aug. 14 -- The population of Palestine is just under 1,600,000 -- about the same as the State of Maryland in the United States. But even this tiny corner, comparatively speaking, may develop an acute man power problem unless effective measures are taken in time to regulate the distribution of employment in war industries.

LONDON, Aug. 14 -- The British Admiralty today broke its silence about the great naval and air battle that has been going on in the Mediterranean since Tuesday. The big news as far as this country was concerned was that part of the convoy for Malta got through. The Admiralty confirmed this hope tonight, dwelling upon the expectation of loss and damage inflicted upon the enemy.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 14 -- Putting on a show of versatility that fairly dazzled a gathering of 17,956 onlookers, the Yankees tonight battered the Athletics, 11 to 2, exploded fifteen hits and, not-withstanding all this taxing effort, found the time and energy to set a new all-time Major League record for double plays.

Several small issues of municipal bonds, one State issue and a sizeable amount of housing authority bonds were offered here this week for public subscription. They had an aggregate face value of $5,693,000 and the total was the largest in three weeks. It contrasted with an absence of financing last week, and it was above the total of $4,393,000 in bonds marketed in this week a year ago.

Right wing control of the State American Labor party machinery was increased rather than diminished by the vote in Tuesday's primary, tabulation of the ballots by official agencies indicated yesterday.

JERSEY CITY, N. J., Aug. 14 (AP) -- Jersey City snapped a five-game Syracuse winning streak today by taking the first game of a twilight-arc double-header, 3--0, but the Chiefs came back to notch the nightcap in eleven innings, 2--0, and earn an even break.

Only a terrestrial globe will reveal the scope of the campaign now developing in the South Seas. Though the battle seems to center in three small islands -- Guadalcanal, Florida and Tulagi, which are represented on a hemisphere map merely by dots -- actually the area involved in our attempt to take these islands, and Japan's attempt to resist that effort, is greater than that of the entire United States.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 14 -- The Senate Finance Committee may act on a number of Administration proposals when it meets again, but it already has closed the doors on two major recommendations which it was estimated would yield more than $400,000,000 in new revenue -- mandatory joint returns for married couples and taxation of income from outstanding State and municipal bonds.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 14 -- The Senate Finance Committee completed its public hearings today on the $6,271,000,000 tax bill passed by the House and took a recess until Aug. 24, when executive consideration of proposed amendments to the measure will begin.

Just so long as the contents of its coin purse jingle merrily, no one is going to fret because a woman's handbag has no other metal in its make-up. That is the consensus in the world of harrassed manufacturers contemplating the diminishing supply of base metals formerly used for frames, slide- fasteners and catches on the outsize carry-alls currently in favor with women who like to be in the mode.

CLEVELAND. Aug. 14 (AP) -- Attorneys for the Office of Price Administration said tonight that a suit filed here "only scratched the surface" in their nation-wide drive to break a "black market" in steel, the No. 1 war commodity.

Hugo Richard Steimle, national youth leader for the German- American Bund, pleaded guilty yesterday in Federal court to charges of conspiracy to hamper enforcement of the alien registration laws on which he and twenty-eight other bundists were indicted here on July 7. He thus became the fourth of the group to admit his guilt.

Mutual savings banks in New York State sold $32,224,000 of War Bonds in July, the Savings Banks Association of the State of New York reported yesterday, an increase of 72.8 per cent over June. Of this total, sales of series E bonds accounted for $24,538,000, or nearly one-third of the total series E bonds sold by all issuing agents in this State in July.

Permit me as a former resident of Paris during the occupation to take exception to a minor point in your editorial "Fashions in Paris." The clientele of the haute couture is not exclusively German. It is a mistake to suppose there are no wealthy French families left.

I just read in today's TIMES a "Dodger Fan's" letter conveying an unfortunate impression as to the sportsmanship and patriotism of those attending the Dodger-Giant Army Relief game. As a Yankee rooter, who was a relatively neutral observer at that contest, I should like to answer your Dodger fan and get a few things straight.

A proposal to let Mayor La Guardia decide the conflict between the Army-Navy relief fund double-header at the Yankee Stadium and the Giant-Dodger twin bill at Ebbets Field on Sunday, Aug. 23, was contained in a joint statement issued last night by President Larry MacPhail of the Brooklyn club on behalf of Horace C. Stoneham, head of the Giants, and himself.

Today marks the official opening of the hay-fever season. The ragweed pods are bursting with pollen, eager to ride the winds. Henceforth, until the merciful frosts seal the pollen sacs, three to five million Americans will have little comfort.

A writing contest for men in the Army was announced yesterday by Doubleday, Doran, 14 West Forty-ninth Street, who are putting up a $1,000 war bond as an outright prize for the best fiction or non-fiction manuscript submitted by either enlisted men or officers.
CAIRO, Egypt, Aug. 14 -- In the brief spell of cooler weather the British and German armies are attempting to make their positions on the El Alamein front too strong to be carried by assault.

Prices of cotton forged ahead again yesterday in the futures market. On the New York Cotton Exchange final quotations were at the day's best levels and 16 to 18 points above Thursday's closing prices. A scarcity of contracts and a continued moderate demand by mills and the trade accounted for the rise.

VICHY, France, Aug. 14 -- Two separate French protests of machine gunnings by British aviation involving fatalities, one on a French commercial airliner over the Mediterranean and the other on a large number of French fishing boats off the Brittany coast, were transmitted to Great Britain tonight.
A communique broadcast from Tokyo and recorded here by The Associated Press:
WASHINGTON, Aug. 14 (AP) -- The government has begun Federal court action against two Beaumont (Texas) police officers on charges of violating the civil rights of a negro soldier.

Treason trials in the United States have been neither numerous nor dramatic, as the law experts in Washington pointed out last week in connection with the German spy case. An apparent exception was noted in the matter of John Brown of Harper's Ferry.

In drawing up an effective wartime tax program it is essential that taxes be levied where the income exists and, especially, where it is expanding. This task would be greatly helped by reliable statistics of income. Yet the whole tax debate has been muddled by a series of studies of consumer income distribution, issued in recent years under Government sponsorship, which are open to charges of very serious distortion.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 14 -- Two facts stand out on the first anniversary of the Atlantic Charter. During the year since it was drafted the war on the whole has gone against the democratic powers and the turn that will roll back the tide of victorious aggression is not yet in sight.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 14 -- The House-approved McLaughlin Bill to permit railroads which are solvent but temporarily embarrassed to adjust impending maturities of securities without recourse to bankruptcy or reorganization proceedings was denounced today as "an intellectually dishonest measure" by Ralph Montgomery Arkush, spokesman for a committee claiming to represent $1,000,000 of 4 per cent first mortgage bonds of the Delaware Hudson Railroad due on next May 1.

A record-breaking total of 5,174,000 net tons of steel plates was produced in the first half of 1942 by the steel industry, exceeding by a wide margin the output of any other single class of steel products, the American Iron and Steel Institute announced yesterday.

AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, Australia, Saturday, Aug. 15 (AP) -- United Nations heavy bombers bent on checking Japanese reinforcements to the Solomons pounced yesterday on a small Japanese convoy off New Britain to the northwest, a communique from General Douglas MacArthur's headquarters announced today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 14 -- The resignations of three members of the Inter-American Commission of Women, all on its executive committee, were announced today by Miss Minerva Bernardino, vice chairman of the commission.

Carl Hubbell's seventh straight victory pointed the Giants back on the winning path yesterday at the Polo Grounds. The 39-year-old maestro of the screwball stopped Hans Lobert's Phils with four hits to triumph, 5 to 2.

Those who have been surf fishing on Eastern Long Island, especially east of Ditch Plains, have found that their luck compares favorably with other seasons. Although the number of surf anglers has dropped considerably, the results have been satisfactory for those who have been able to enjoy the sport.

NEENAH, Wis., Aug. 14 (AP) -- The first final event of the women's national A.A.U. swimming championships was marked by a stunning upset tonight, when 17-year-old Miss Suzanne Zimmerman of Portland, Ore., churned out a victory by inches in the 100-meter free style. Her time was 1:10.3.

BOMBAY, India, Saturday, Aug. 15 (AP) -- Eight demonstrators were wounded today when police fired into a crowd of demonstrators in Calcutta, ending a period of quiet in the All-India Congress party's campaign for independence for India.
ST. LOUIS, Aug. 14 (AP) -- Veteran Mort Cooper registered his fourteenth victory of the 1942 campaign tonight, limiting the Reds to two hits as the Cardinals went on to triumph by 4 to 0.

SOMEWHERE IN AUSTRALIA, Aug. 14 -- Before the Japanese occupied the Solomon Islands -- from which by all indications they are new being expelled by our fleet -- they did an efficient spying job there. Their method of operation was revealed today by a New Zealand sea captain who has sailed those waters for seventeen years.

Mainbocher, American-born Paris couturier, will add 11,000 new names to his world-renowned list of "best dressed women." That his revered label will stand behind every uniform of the Waves was announced here yesterday by Lieut. Comdr. Mildred H. McAfee, commanding officer of the Women's Naval Reserve Corps.

Officials of the city of San Antonio, Texas, issued yesterday a call for bids on a new issue of $33,950,000 of electric power and light and gas distributing system bonds dated Aug. 1, 1942, and due serially on July 1, 1944 to 1972. Bids will be opened on Aug. 24.

Donald Pendelton, chairman of the New York-New Jersey metropolitan milk industry war conservation committee, and Michael J. Cashal, international vice president of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, A.F. of L., expressed dissatisfaction yesterday with the recommendations of Hugh E. Sheridan, special representative of the National War Labor Board, in the dispute between the teamsters' union and the milk distributors.

HARTFORD, Aug. 14 -- Closely guarded by United States marshals, Gerhardt W. Kunze, national leader of the German-American Bund, walked into the court room today to contradict charges of espionage conspiracy against the Rev. Kurt Emil Bruno Molzahn of Philadelphia.

MOSCOW, Saturday, Aug. 15 (AP) German troops fighting toward Stalingrad in the Don River bend were reported officially early today to have pierced Russian positions south of Kletskaya, seventy-five miles northwest of Stalingrad.

To prevent the Board of Higher Education from dismissing staff members to save funds to pay to 100 instructors at City, Hunter and Brooklyn Colleges mandatory salary increments and back pay totaling $400,000, several of the teachers have indicated through their attorney, A. Mark Levien, that they would be willing to compromise.

MANCHESTER, Mass., Aug. 14 (AP) -- Miss Louise Brough of Beverly Hills, Calif., 19-year-old national junior champion, entered the singles semi-finals of the Essex County Club's eighteenth annual women's tennis tournament today with a 6- 4, 6-2 victory over unranked Miss Kay Winthrop of Hamilton, Mass.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 14 -- A new directive from the War Man Power Commission put in the hands of the Office of Defense Health and Welfare Services today authority to coordinate Federal programs to provide nursery schools for the children of mothers working in war industries.

Lieutenant William E. Milner of the Canadian Army arrived here yesterday to interview Canadian nationals registered with United States draft boards to explain to them how they could join the armed forces of their own country. He will be at the Hotel McAlpin throughout Tuesday and expects to confer with about 150 men who have written to Ottowa for advice.
MOSCOW, Saturday, Aug. 15 (AP) -- The Soviet midnight communique:

In last week's TIMES there appeared an article by Mr. Kieran entitled "Government Issue," wherein he commented on various athletic activities listed in a technical manual issued by the government for our troops' recreation. He didn't do justice to two games, lacrosse and touch football.

CHICAGO, Aug. 14 -- Professional traders were sellers of wheat futures in the early trading today on the Board of Trade in sympathy with a sharp decline in corn. Mills, however, were rather persistent buyers in small lots, and late in the session shorts attempted to cover and found little grain for sale.

CHICAGO, Aug. 14 (AP) -- The two reigning queens of the Women's Western Golf Association -- Mrs. Russell Mann of Omaha, Neb., and Miss Betty Jameson of San Antonio, Texas, won their semi- final matches in the Western Amateur at Sunset Ridge today and qualified for tomorrow's 36-hole championship match.

SARATOGA, N.Y., Aug. 14 (AP) -- The Jockey Club has changed its rules on weight allowances for apprentice jockeys, so that there will be three and seven pound allowances in future in addition to the more familiar five pounds for "bug boys."

American Export Airlines, the company which three months ago hired the first transatlantic airline stewardess, announced yesterday that seven stewardesses are now employed on the line. Chester H. Case, purchasing agent and superintendent of service, declared that the stewardesses, who average two round-trip flights a month, had proved especially valuable for war-time service, exhibiting a knack for putting passengers at ease and creating a congenial atmosphere.
SANTIAGO, Chile, Aug. 14 -- President Juan Antonio Rios accepted today the invitation extended by President Roosevelt yesterday for a visit to the United States in October.

The government's seizure of the strike-bound Bayonne, N.J., plant of the General Cable Corporation was characterized yesterday by the National Association of Manufacturers as an act of unfairness against an innocent management and a spur to further defiance of adverse War Labor board decisions by wildcat strikers.

The American sports public often has been guilty of a biased and improper judgment of contemporary performers. If a competitor happens to catch the fancy of the crowd he is lauded without reservation, his successes magnified, his failures excused and his rivals ignored.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 14 -- J.H. Kindelberger, a pioneer airplane designer and President of the North American Aircraft Corporation, said here today that at least five years would be required to put into production the 200-ton air transports advocated by Henry J. Kaiser.

ANKARA, Turkey, Aug. 13 (delayed) (U.P.) -- Military experts said tonight that it now was evident that Marshal Semyon Timoshenko had sacrificed the whole North Caucasus without attempting a single major stand, withdrawing the bulk of this army to the northeast behind Stalingrad.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 14 -- The organization of a central committee of national retail associations to meet the need for machinery to coordinate the field in the war economy was announced today by David R. Craig, president of the American Retail Federation.

SYRACUSE, Aug. 14 -A pledge that the full efforts of the American Legion of New York State would be devoted toward winning the war was made by Arthur G. Bouton immediately after his election as department commander at the closing session of the annual State convention of the Legion today.
DETROIT, Aug. 14 (AP) -- Brilliant four-hit hurling by young Hal White gave the Tigers a 7-to-1 victory over the White Sox today in the opener of a four-game series.

PRINCETON, N.J., Aug. 14 -- Owner Dan Topping and his new coach of the Football Dodgers were hosts today to football writers invited to watch a workout of the squad that John Bain Sutherland left when he became a lieutenant commander in the Navy.

Memberships in Lutheran churches in the United States and Canada had reached 5,052,000 at the latest tabulation, representing an increase of 61,000, or 1.22 per cent, for 1941 over 1940, according to statistics reported yesterday. The report said this was the first time the figure of 5,000,000 had been exceeded.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 14 -- The first anniversary of the Atlantic Charter finds the United States pressing forward under a definite program of war aims and post-war objectives.

David Lowe, assistant to William Saroyan in charge of production, and, in effect, director of the so-called Saroyan Theatre, which will present its first plays Monday night at the Belasco, is no longer acting in that capacity. He and Mr. Saroyan came to a parting of the ways Thursday -- four days before opening night. Last night Mr. Lowe was reluctant to discuss the matter, falling back on the cliche, "I have no comment."

WASHINGTON, Aug. 14 -- Priority assistance in obtaining additional quantities of all-wool worsted spun yarn for manufacture into carriage robes and garments for infants up to 3 years of age, will be given by the WPB, that agency's wool section announced today.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 14 -- The much-discussed policy of supplying Vichy French territory has been resumed, according to an announcement today by the Office of War Information.

SCHENECTADY, N.Y., Aug. 14 -- Thirty-six employes or sons of employes of General Electric Company will receive aid this year under the General Electric employes' education plan, the Gerard Swope Loan Fund for Union College and the Charles P. Steinmetz Memorial Scholarships, it was announced today by R.C. Muir, chairman of the G.E. education committee.

A PROPOS of the fact that a Navy skeet team suddenly sailed in from a secret base to beat the Army flexible gunners at the national skeet tournament at Syracuse last week, the following letter from Lieut. Col. Lawrence McC. Jones, graduate manager of athletics at West Point, is offered for perusal:
LONDON, Aug. 14 (AP) -- A British Admiralty communique:
AT SEA WITH THE INSHORE PATROL, Aug. 7 (Delayed) -- The convoy system and intensive air patrol are slowly but surely reducing ship sinkings in the Western Atlantic.

CHICAGO, Aug. 14 (AP) -- Hogs closed weak to 10 cents a hundred pounds lower today after establishing another twenty-two-year peak at $15.30. The early bulge was inspired primarily by smaller receipts than expected.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 14 -- The War Labor Board recommended today that employers of 61,000 textile workers in the North and in the South increase wages for all employes by 7.5 cents an hour and rejected a proposal that wages in the South be advanced 10 cents an hour to make up in part for the so-called North-South differential.

CHICAGO, Aug. 14 -- While furniture manufacturers pushed plans for a further conversion of their facilities to war products in this area, reports in well-informed trade circles suggested that retail sales of furniture have taken at least a moderate turn for the better.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 14 -- United States Marines are tightening their hold on positions in the Solomon Islands won from the Japanese in a week of fighting and supply vessels have been moving in under naval escort, the Navy Department reported in a communique tonight.

Retail trade here this week suffered from the combination of continued wet weather and comparison with high sales figures in the corresponding week of last year. Department-store volume was estimated as running about 11 to 12 per cent under 1941.

Lieut. Gen. Masaharu Homma, Japanese commander in the Philippines, has been assigned "to new duties elsewhere" and has been succeeded at Manila by Lieut. Gen. Shizuichi Tanaka, who at one time was military attache in Washington, the Tokyo War Office announced yesterday, according to a Japanese broadcast recorded by The United Press.

BOMBAY, India, Aug. 14 (U.P.) -- Indian rioters burned four railway stations between Madras and Calcutta and pulled down communication wires in the Central Provinces today in continued defiance of police bullets that have taken eighty-three lives in six days.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 14 -- Secretary Ickes, petroleum coordinator, authorized seven companies today to pool technical information involved in production of aviation gasoline and other war products, and urged that such pooling of information be accepted as a policy by the petroleum industry.

It is not likely that those of us who blow off steam by writing letters to newspapers will alter affairs of state by one jot or bend destiny to our will by one tittle. It may even be doubted whether, respecting some matters, we wield as much influence on the course of events as a locomotive whistle wields on a train's direction.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Aug. 14 (AP) -- Although lacking his first- round putting magic, Ben Hogan had enough other shots today for a sparking two-under par 68 -- good for a five-stroke lead at the halfway mark in the $5,000 Times- Union Open.

Salvage work on the capsized Lafayette, formerly the luxurious French liner Normandie, is proceeding so rapidly that the men in charge of the work say it is well ahead of the schedule set some months ago when operations began.

The approximate status of the municipal bond market is reflected in the following list of representative high-grade State, city and county bonds legal for savings banks in New York State, now offered by dealers:

To guard against the contingency of a sudden ending of contracts for munitions in the midst of all-out war production, the General Motors Corporation and its bankers have been carrying on discussions with the Federal Reserve System and the War and other government departments for a huge "stand-by" credit to be guaranteed by the appropriate Federal agencies, it was learned yesterday.
MOSCOW, Aug. 14 (AP) -- A Soviet communique:

Consolidated net income of the Creole Petroleum Corporation for the first six months of this year were estimated yesterday by C.H. Lieb, president, to be $2,200,000, or 32 cents each on the 6,974,356 capital shares outstanding. For the similar period of 1941 the company reported a net income of $4,895,000, or 70 cents a share.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 14 (AP) -- Predicting shortages of meats in some areas all through the war, the War Production Board's foods requirements committee is studying the problem of distributing available supplies equitably among all regions at all seasons.

ROCHESTER, Aug. 14 -- The State Federation of Labor, which puts its total membership at nearly 1,500,000, will support the man whom the Democratic party nominates for Governor, whether it be Attorney General Bennett or Senatory Mead, according to leaders of the federation who are arriving here for its annual convention.
SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 14 -- Shut Out, Mrs. Payne Whitney's 3-year-old champion, returns to competition here tomorrow in the historic Travers, oldest race renewed in the United States.

The German High Command said yesterday that the Russians were resisting fiercely in Caucasus Mountain passes guarding the way to the Black Sea coast, and reported that the Red Army was attacking heavily at Voronezh and northwest and southwest of Moscow.

An admission that he had served as a trustee, subject to check by the German Economic Ministry, in diamond deals which are involved in charges on which he is now on trial, was drawn yesterday from Werner von Clemm. The defendant spent his fourth day on the witness stand in Federal court, much of the time under cross examination by United States Attorney Mathias F. Correa.
HASTINGS, Mich., Saturday, Aug. 15 (AP) -- Nine men were killed when a two-motored Army transport plane crashed and burned last night on a farm north of Dowling.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 14 -- American housewives can contribute materially to the war effort by asking fewer truck delivery services and refusing to deal with stores which are not obeying present delivery curtailment regulations, Joseph B. Eastman, Director of the Office of Defense Transportation, said today.

NEWARK, N.J., Aug. 14 -- The walkout of 250 employes on the three shifts in the rolled celluloid department of the Celanese Corporation's war-production plant, here, is scheduled to end tomorrow morning as a result of the War Labor Board's taking jurisdiction of a contract dispute between the company and local 277, Textile Workers of America, C.I.O.
Among those leasing apartments yesterday through William A. White Sons was Harry Sosnik, music director, who took a suite in 383 Park Avenue, Brett, Wyckoff, Potter, Hamilton, Inc. acting as agent.
MONTCLAIR, N.J., Aug. 14 -- It took the New Jersey amateur golf championship a long time to get under way, but once it did, it went with a bang.

MOSCOW, Saturday, Aug. 15 -- The Russian High Command announced early today that enemy troops had driven through to the banks of the Don River in the region of Kletskaya, northwest of Stalingrad, and were being heavily engaged by the Red Army.

PEARL HARBOR, Aug. 14 (AP) -- The Japanese "have a toehold as a potential threat" in the Westernmost Aleutians, but the situation there "is not serious," a ranking United States naval officer who returned recently from that area, said here today.
A communique broadcast from Rome and recorded here by The Associated Press:

A wide search for an incendiary in Brooklyn was started early this morning by Fire Marshal Thomas P. Brophy and a squad of assistant marshals, detectives and plain-clothesmen after the suffocation of an elderly woman in one of a series of eight fires that occurred within forty-eight hours in the Stuyvesant and Bushwick areas.

New York City will have one-fifth of all the nation's unemployed workers by Fall unless there is an "immediate and aggressive mobilization" by the government of the war production facilities of small plants here, George A. Sloan, City Commissioner of Commerce, warned yesterday.

MONTPELIER, Vt., Aug. 14 (AP) -- Price Administrator Leon Henderson replied today to critics of Donald Nelson, War Production Board chief, asserting that "I don't know any one who knows American industry better" than Mr. Nelson.

WESTPORT, Conn., Aug. 14 -- Miss Vivien Kellems of Westport, an aspirant for the Republican nomination in the Fourth Connecticut Congressional District, is one of those who has taken with a grain of salf the announcement by Mrs. Clare Boothe Luce of Greenwich that she was not in the race for the post now held by Leroy D. Downs, a Democrat.

MADRID, Spain, Aug. 14 (AP) -- Reports from La Linea, Spain, said tonight that the British aircraft carriers Furious and Illustrious, a battleship of the Rodney type and five destroyers had entered Gibraltar harbor today from the Western Mediterranean.

LONDON, Aug. 14 -- Private Louis Stevens, 30 years old, of Brooklyn, was sentenced to six months at hard labor by a United States Army general court-martial today for accidentally killing Private Bernard Soffer while cleaning his service pistol.
A communique broadcast from Berlin and recorded here by The Associated Press:

WASHINGTON, Aug. 14 -- President Roosevelt sent to Prime Minister Churchill today a message commemorating the first anniversary of the Atlantic Charter. Realization of its principles, the President said, is the basis for "our hopes for a better future for the world."

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 14 -- Many members of the Summer Colony attended the lecture on "Victory Through Air Power" by Major Alexander P. de Seversky, aviation expert and author, tonight in the auditorium of the Southampton High School for the benefit of the surgical dressing unit of the American Hospital in Britain, now Base Hospital No. 1.

NEWARK, N.J., Aug, 14 -- Albert Bright, 52 years old, of Jersey City, formerly technical foreman in a Jersey City war plant, pleaded "definitely not guilty" today when arraigned before United States Commissioner Marvin Spaulding on a charge of sabotage based on allegations that he, with the object of prolonging the war and his $100-a-week job, had given orders that resulted in the slowing of the plant's production schedule.

Eighty-seven survivors from three Allied merchant vessels that had been sunk in the South Atlantic have landed at Recife, Brazil, The Associated Press reported yesterday from Brazil. The ships were a British freighter and British and Norwegian tankers. An Argentine vessel rescued the survivors.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 14 -- President Roosevelt sent to Prime Minister Churchill today a message commemorating the first anniversary of the Atlantic Charter. Realization of its principles, the President said, is the basis for "our hopes for a better future for the world."

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 14 -- Mr. and Mrs. Seth W. Morton entertained with a dinner tonight for George H. Bull and his house guests, Mr. and Mrs. Henry Delafield, Mr. and Mrs. Julius A. White, Mr. and Mrs. Henry Leroy Finch, Mr. and Mrs. Alexander Stoller, Mr. and Mrs. Edward Small Moore, Dallas Bache Pratt, Robert Gillham, William H. Lipscomb, Robert A. Fairbairn and Carter Bowie.
LONDON, Aug. 14 -- Led by industrial shares, among which the textiles and steels were prominent, the stock markets finished the week cheerfully.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 14 -- Rearrangement of ceiling prices on gasoline and fuel oil on the Atlantic Coast to make production of fuel oil more attractive to petroleum companies is under discussion in the Office of Price Administration and the Office of Petroleum Coordinator for War, according to reports.

NEWARK, N.J., Aug. 14 -- In an alleged attempt to wreak vengeance upon a contractor with whom he had quarreled, Michael E. Goldberg, 37 years old, of 340 Audubon Avenue, Englewood, N.J., a lumber broker, was under arrest today on charges that he falsely represented himself as a member of the Priorities Division of the War Production Board.

NEW DELHI, India, Aug. 13 (Delayed) (U.P.) -- United States Army Air Forces' bombers in India have blasted again at Myitkyina, major Japanese air base in the jungles of Northern Burma, and blown up two bridges on the 338-mile railway leading to it from Mandalay, their headquarters announced today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 14 -- Even greater conservation of material than was originally intended in the dress limitation order will probably be the eventual result of the slim lines now being sponsored by top designers of Fall clothes, it was predicted today by H. Stanley Marcus, former head of the War Production Board unit which drew up the now famous order L-85.

EAST CHARLESTON, Vt., Aug. 13 (AP) -- Mrs. Amy C. Ransome, long-time advocate of women's rights and vice chairman of the national Woman's Party, was killed yesterday when she fell downstairs in the home of a friend. She was about 70 years old.

The stock market carried over yesterday the last-hour spurt of the previous session, and, with enthusiasm spurred by the reports of successful naval and military operations in the Solomon Islands, prices were enhanced 1 to 2 points. A limited amount of profit-taking in the late afternoon produced some shading of values, but this minor back-down centered in a handful of issues.
During the days of peace being "set" in one's own particular and highly individualized way was a matter of pride.

In a voluntary settlement which establishes the principle that sales promotion or advertising display men are not outside salesmen exempt from the coverage of the Fair Labor Standards Act, the Philip Morris Company, Ltd., Inc., has paid $78,719 in back overtime compensation to 1,113 employes, Arthur J. White, regional director of the Wage-Hour Division of the United States Department of Labor, announced yesterday.

The volume of timber in board feet treated with preservatives in 1941 rose 20.22 per cent compared with that treated in 1940, according to a report prepared by R.K. Helphenstine Jr. of the U.S. Forest Service, in cooperation with the American Wood-Preservers Association, which was released yesterday.

If I had to, I suppose I could lick my weight in half a wildcat. But the other day I felt pretty strong, for once again I exercised my right to vote. The Constitution and the Bill of Rights guarantee us all life, liberty and the pursuit of happiness.

I have noted in today's paper that Under-Secretary of War Patterson stated that we are not doing so well on the war front, and he appealed to those in this country to exert more effort toward winning the war.

WASHINGTON. Aug. 14 -- Spurred by labor difficulties caused by shortages of raw materials, the War Manpower Commission is working on a plan to make it possible to draft, freeze or transfer labor in accordance with the demands of the situation.

CHICAGO, Aug. 14 -- Fear that the country will be confronted with widespread marriage difficulties after the war, unless more adequate provisions are made for recreation and social life in disrupted families, was expressed today by Mrs. Evelyn Millis Duvall, executive director of the Association for Family Living.

The report of the Columbia Gas and Electric Corporation and subsidiaries for the twelve months ended on June 30, issued yesterday by Edward Reynolds, president, shows a net income of $5,499,914, or $959,750 short of preferred dividend requirements for the period.

BOSTON, Aug. 14 -- Twelve hundred New England manufacturers were told today by Walter H. Wheeler Jr., regional director of the War Production Board, that there had been "too much emphasis on playing safe by getting and holding what we could in the way of materials," that the conversion phase of the war effort was about over, and that from now on the even distribution of materials would be of the utmost importance.

Determined to resist the granting of a permanent easement through State forest lands, although favoring a temporary right-of-way for a railroad to speed the shipment of iron and vanadium for war industry, conservation leaders are seeking the aid of New York members of Congress to bring about a shift in the War Production Board's attitude toward the proposed Adirondack railway spur, it was learned last night.
CHUNGKING, China, Aug. 14 -- A resolution appealing to President Roosevelt to send more planes to China was adopted today at a Chungking mass meeting celebrating Chinese Air Force Day.

For the second time in seven weeks, malodorous gas descended yesterday on the Clason Point section of the Bronx. The attack, which was described as much worse than the first, left residents limp with headaches or mild nausea. Metallic objects tarnished and plants wilted. The cause or source of the gas, which chemical analysis proved to be hydrogen sulphate, is still undetermined.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 14 -- A simple method designed to cut gasoline consumption of almost every type of automobile by as much as 40 per cent by shutting off the fuel and ignition supply and valve action of half the cylinders was demonstrated today by engineers of the Sun Oil Company.

A communique from Japanese Imperial Headquarters asserted yesterday that Japanese naval forces had sunk or damaged forty-one United Nations vessels and shot down fifty-eight planes thus far in the Solomon Islands battle, according to a Tokyo broadcast recorded by The United Press in New York.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 14 (AP) -- The Office of Defense Transportation reported today that the full police powers of New York State would be mobilized to enforce ODT's truck conservation orders, under an agreement reached between the New York State Council and the ODT.

A campaign in more than 350 newspapers in the East will be started immediately by 4,000 "blue coal" dealers to promote the conversion of oil burners to coal, Gordon C. Cooke, president of the Delaware, Lackawanna Western Coal Company, announced yesterday.
BALTIMORE, Aug. 14 (AP) -- Newark plastered a 9-0 defeat on Baltimore tonight, leaving the Oriooles stranded in a scoreless desert, the team having failed to score a run for five consecutive games.

When New York University initiated two Negro scholars in Phi Delta Kappa a few days ago, it set a precedent which should help strengthen our national unity. Several months back Phi Delta Kappa, one of the most important professional fraternities in the educational field, revoked its "white" clause, making it possible for educators to be admitted to membership on the basis of achievement and scholarship, rather than creed or color.

LONDON, Aug. 14 (U.P.) -- Scores and perhaps hundreds of Netherland intelectual and social leaders probably would be slaughtered by German firing squads at dawn tomorrow, a Netherland Government spokesman said tonight as the deadline arrived for the surrender of patriots who blew up a trainload of German "second front" troops near Rotterdam last Friday.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 (AP) -- Weighing present earnings against the rising cost of living, the National War Labor Board today announced it had disapproved the request of 32,000 aluminum workers for a wage increase of $1 a day. They are employes in ten plants of the Aluminum Company of America.

Certificates signifying completion of three months of intensive training as pharmacists' mates at Columbia University's College of Pharmacy were presented to 198 Coast Guardsmen yesterday afternoon in the gymnasium of the West Side Y.M.C.A., 5 West Sixty-third Street.

Byron H. Uhl, district director of immigration and naturalization on Ellis Island, will celebrate on Thursday his fiftieth anniversary as a government immigration man.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 -- One- armed men are being employed as welders in the production of munitions, men with but one leg are working as drill-press operators, persons with deformations as sheet- metal workers, midgets as aircraft riveters and deaf mutes as machinists -- all with credit to themselves and to the benefit of their country in time of war.
PITTSFIELD, Mass., Aug. 15 (AP) -- More than eighty Netherland aviators lined up today to receive from Queen Wilhelmina the highest honors ever bestowed by the Netherlands upon its heroes.

The seizure of five enemy aliens in Westchester County was announced yesterday by T.J. Donegan, acting agent in charge of the local office of the Federal Bureau of Investigation. The five, including one German and four Italians, were removed to Ellis Island to face internment boards.

LONDON, Sunday, Aug. 16 (U.P.) -- Strengthened fighter plane patrols and improved ship gunnery are forcing German aerial convoy raiders to operate hundreds of miles at sea with only occasional forays off the British coast, the Air Ministry announced today.

AT breakfast in a Kentucky inn an elderly judge was expressing admiration for the leadership of President Roosevelt and uneasiness over the pettiness of Congress during a period of great national peril. "Congress cannot get over the ad hominem point of view," he said gloomily.

The young Norsemen who are down here today from Camp Little Norway, in Canada, to play a soccer game with the Swedish Football Club would rouse a heartfelt "Skaal!" from any ancient Viking. The 119 metropolitan units of Bundles for America have been linked with the New York City Salvage Committee as depots for the collection of tin cans, Mrs. Wales Latham, president of Bundles for America, announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 -- There is now a definite possibility that Chile will join other Latin American republics and break off relations with the Axis within the next two months, it was learned tonight as the State Department made public the texts of President Roosevelt's invitation to President Juan Antonio Rios to make an official visit to the United States and the Chilean Chief Executive's quick acceptance.

ROCHESTER, Aug. 15 -- Moved by the growing unemployment in New York City arising from dislocations and displacements due to the war production program, leaders of the State Federation of Labor demanded today that the Federal Government devise "an intelligent program for distributing the available labor supply to avoid chaos."

LONDON, Aug. 15 -- Five prominent Netherlanders held as hostages, the first of a reported 1,600 who face death in the occupied country, were killed by a Nazi firing squad today.

SAN DIEGO, Calif., Aug. 15 -- The two-dollar bill, to which long standing superstition attached the stigma of unlucky, has come into its own. In fact, the demand so far exceeded the supply in San Diego that an urgent appeal for more was made to the Federal Reserve Bank at Los Angeles.

THE story of the underground church movement in Nazi Germany is told in a "fictionalized biography" entitled "Until That Day," to be published on Aug. 20 by Eagle Books. Inc., and to be distributed by Duell, Sloan Pearce.

SOMEWHERE IN AUSTRALIA, Aug. 15 -- The first real trial of the island-hopping method of fighting this war in the South Pacific is now under way at Tulagi and elsewhere in the Solomon Islands and should provide an answer to the question whether that method is the right one.

THE twenty-fifth anniversary season of the Goldman Band concerts will come to a close with tonight's program. The concert will take place in Central Park, conducted by Edwin Franko Goldman with Raymond Crisara as soloist.

IOWA CITY, Iowa, Aug. 15 -- That inter-faith ideals of the University of Iowa School of Religion are contributions to national unity in wartime and may become even more important in the post-war period is the belief of Director M. Willard Lampe as expressed in a report of the school's activities. Classes have been conducted for fifteen years.

Ickes, War Petroleum Coordinator, and Leon Henderson, OPA chief, which stated, however, that ways were still being sought to make such rationing unnecessary.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 -- Ninety-five organizations and individuals have registered since June 28 in compliance with the amended Foreign Agents Registration Act, according to an announcement today by Attorney General Biddle. The ninety-five registrants are acting as representatives of 415 foreign principals, he said.

HOLLYWOOD. THE Pacific Coast dimout order, issued by General De Witt to go into effect this Thursday, is causing concern among Hollywood producers because of the automatic prohibition it puts on outdoor night photography. Under ordinary circumstances, the solution would be to build sets on sound stages simulating outdoor conditions, and photograph night action indoors.

A photograph of a 1.50-francs stamp issued by Madagascar is inscribed "Mission de Hell Jehenne Passot" under portraits of three men in naval uniforms, and across the top is "Mayotte et Nossi-Be" with the dates 1841 and 1941. This item commemorates the beginning of French rule a century ago in Mayotte and Noissi-Be, island dependencies of Madagascar, and the "mission" that was carried out by Admiral de Hell in conjunction with Jehenne and Passot.

RUMSON, N.J., Aug. 15 -- A United Victory Day fair was given this afternoon and evening in Shrewsbury for the benefit of the American Red Cross. Mrs. L.S. Ylvisaker, chairman of the Shrewsbury unit, was in charge of the event, one of the largest of its kind held here in many years.

I rise to defend a favorite author from the false interpretation of his recently discovered letter to Miss Dorothea Sankey in which he "takes time by the forelock" to bespeak her for future marriage "although his affectionate and most excellent wife is still alive and in good health."

WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 -- Stocks of domestic and foreign crude petroleum on Aug. 8 totaled 246,975,000 barrels, according to the Bureau of Mines, United States Department of the Interior. This represented a decrease of 1,361,000 barrels in the week, comprising a decrease of 1,498,000 barrels in domestic stocks but an increase of 137,000 in foreign stocks.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 -- Representative Dies, chairman of the House Committee on Un-American Activities, sent to President Roosevelt today a list containing the names of about 17,000 persons who, he alleged, had been members of, or sympathetically affiliated with, German organizations that had supported the Nazi cause in the United States.

A serious shortage of teachers is beginning to be felt in this country, which may result in lowered educational standards and closed classrooms, Dr. Edward S. Evenden of Teachers College, Columbia University, warns in a far-reaching survey prepared for the American Council on Education, made public last week.

SOMEWHERE IN OKLAHOMA, Aug. 15 (AP) -- Senator Lee of Oklahoma said today America's expanding air power offered the only hope of escape from a war between the hemispheres "that would have possibilities of lasting for generations."

CAMDEN, N.J., Aug. 15 (AP) -- Thomas H. Heard's Boysy made it three victories in as many tries over the Garden State Park track when he came from behind today to score by three-parts of a length in the $5,000 added Valley Forge Handicap, six-furlong feature before a crowd of 16,500.

BAY CITY, Mich., Aug. 15 (AP) -- A recapitalization plan of the Industrial Brownhoist Corporation of Cleveland was rejected today by Federal Judge Arthur J. Tuttle in his decision on a suit brought by Daniel F. Comstock and Russell A. Johnson, stockholders.

COOPERSTOWN, N.Y., Aug. 15 -- Thirty-eight young girls of the Pathfinders Lodge presented this afternoon an original masque based on Millet's "The Sower," in the rustic setting of a pasture on the farm of Mrs. A.O. Choate near here.
ON BOARD A PC BOAT OFF THE ATLANTIC COAST, Aug. 7 (Delayed) -- She lay quiet and still, moored to the bollards of the Section Base pier, but even at rest the strong song of her blowers gave her life.

LONDON, Aug. 15 -- United States Marines already were landing in the Solomon Islands when they first were sighted by Japanese planes, Axis reports acknowledged today. The reports, which came in German dispatches from Tokyo that were broadcast by the Berlin radio, also said that the Marines now held positions at two places.

CHICAGO, Aug. 15 -- Liquidation of corn contracts by commission houses and professional traders was on today on the Board of Trade, and with stop-loss orders uncovered an deliveries sold at the lowest prices of the season, showing a drop of around 1 1/4 cents a bushel from yesterday's finish and 7 cents from the high point of the month. September touched 84 3/8 cents.

New York troops remember Father Duffy of the last war; and there was Chaplain James Caldwell of the Revolution, who was in the thick of the New Jersey battle of Springfield.

Although few buyers were in the wholesale markets last week, mail activity and requests for fill-ins increased, according to the market report prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by Kirby, Block Co. Reorders for certain classes of style merchandise were received in substantial quantity.

BAR HARBOR, Me., Aug. 15 -- With most of the attention of the Summer colony here directed toward the various wartime and philanthropic activities on Mount Desert Island, there is little formal entertaining, social events centering around the Sunday evening buffet suppers and Wednesday tombola luncheons at the Bar Harbor Club.

WALTON, N.Y., Aug. 15 (AP) -- To prove that modern Americans, like their pioneer ancestors, "are not soft," Arthur W. North, a 67-year-old explorer, has just completed an 1,100-mile canoe tour of New York's inland waterways.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 -- Colonel Caleb V. Haynes of Mount Airy, N.C., and Colonel Robert L. Scott Jr. of Macon, Ga., and twenty-one other officers and men of the Array Air Corps have won Silver Stars for their part in evacuating more than 5,000 refugees and wounded United Nations soldiers during the last three weeks of the Battle of Burma, it was announced today.

Wet weather retarded retail trade expansion here last week. Sales comparisons with a year ago were also adversely affected by the heavy rains during this period in 1941. Department store volume was estimated as ranging 11 to 12 per cent under last year, with a similar decrease for local specialty shops.

THE author of this book was once in Washington on two errands: first, to testify before a Congressional committee about the denial of civil rights to "union agitators" in Pineville, Ky.; second, to argue before another committee "against a bill to raise the tax on transfers of stock on the New York Stock Exchange."

NEWARK, N.J., Aug. 15 -- An estimated 75,000 persons, mostly "soldiers" on the home front, marched here today in a "Win the War Parade." Estimates of the number of spectators varied from 100,000 to 250,000.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 -- The Navy Department, in a communique giving additional information about the results of the recent American bombardment of Kiska, Japanese-held island in the Western Aleutians, disclosed tonight that a Japanese destroyer had been badly damaged.

ISTANBUL, Turkey, Aug. 15 -- Reports reaching foreign military intelligence sources here this evening said Serb guerrillas, operating from the new bases of General Draja Mikhailovitch's main forces in Western Bosnia and Hercegovina, early in the week launched a devastating series of raids against German, Italian and Croat garrisons in Southwestern Yugoslavia, inflicting losses estimated at upward of 2,000 and capturing large quantities of material and munitions.

NEWARK, N.J., Aug. 15 -- Seth Boyden Court, Newark's second largest housing project with 530 families and an estimated 1,000 children, was placed under quarantine today after three children of residents there were stricken with infantile paralysis.

THERE is a deep and sensitive awareness of the phenomena of nature in the writing of Ward Dorrance which lifts his work above the ordinary. One can visualize him as a naturalist as well as a writer of fiction. His novel, "The Sundowners," is essentially the story of a boy's life on a Missouri farm; the elements which shape that life are the daily and familiar miracles of wood and barnyard.
LOS ANGELES, Aug. 15 -- While combat pilots are winning battles on the fighting fronts, an army of civilian pilots is winning a battle no less important -- the battle of transportation.

MAMARONECK, N.Y., Aug. 15 -- In the eleventh special regatta of the season out on Long Island Sound, which was held by the Orienta Yacht Club, there was easy sailing this afternoon, with steady going for one-half of the session.
GREAT LAKERS, Ill., Aug. 15 -- The Ninth Naval District warned "well-meaning but misinformed" girls today that all sailors are not lonely.

Small prints will have an equal chance with large prints in the judging of the 1942 New York Salon of Photography, when prints of different sizes will be viewed from appropriate distances, according to the announcement of the Camera Club, which is the sponsor.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 -- A deep and profound anxiety characterizes all of the many conversations and conferences here in which the prospects of Russia in defending herself against the German war machine, now deep in the Caucasus, are discussed.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 -- Admiral A.J. Hepburn, former Director of Navy Public Relations, telegraphed today to Representative Clare E. Hoffman, Michigan Republican, denying charges by The Chicago Tribune that Secretary Knox had shown favoritism to The Chicago Daily News, his own newspaper, in the release of naval news.

PHILADELPHIA, Pa., Aug. 15 -- Joy Ann Blood, 3 years old, of Remsen, N.Y., arrived at the Municipal Airport at 7:20 this evening in a race against death. She was rushed immediately to the bronchoscopic clinic of Temple University Hospital for removal of an object in her lung, thought to be a peanut.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 15 -- The champion Shut Out, 130 pounds and all, took the seventy-third Travers Stakes today before 14,998 persons to continue along the victorious path which had whirled him through the Kentucky Derby, Belmont Stakes, Yankee Handicap and Arlington Classic.

Captain Johannes Jacobus Bijl commodore of the Holland-America Line, retired last week at the age of 62, after forty-four years of service. Peter van den Toorn, managing director of the company, who announced the retirement, said the captain "came ashore" with a perfect forty-four year record, having never had an accident.

LONDON, Aug. 15 (AP) -- The German High Command withdrew today its claim that the United States aircraft carrier Wasp had been damaged in the great Western Mediterranean convoy battle, but reported that the running fight was over, with six British warships and fifteen merchant ships sunk.

Against a background of increased buying activity resulting from the OPA announcement that an alternative pricing method was being devised for the food trades, industry leaders yesterday restated their belief that the plan would provide them adequate relief.

EAST HAMPTON, L.I., -- An ancient windmill in Eastern Long Island has just been moved for the third time in 129 years. Built at Southampton in 1813 to grind grain, it was moved in 1852 to Wainscott, a hamlet between Southampton and East Hampton, on the ocean side.

GRACE MOORE of the Opera has plans (they are more, than nebulous, she says) for a repertory theatre on Broadway for the presentation of operettas, old and new. As contemplated by herself and Russell Lewis and his associates they would be given at popular prices and Miss Moore and other topnotch singers would participate.

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 15 (AP) -- Morton Cooper, the Cardinals' speed-ball pitcher, is not superstitious, but Catcher Walker Cooper better get to the ball park early the next time his brother is scheduled to work.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Aug. 15 (AP) -- Injury and illness cost Colonel Bob Neyland's Eastern all-Army football squad two of its stars today.

CAZENOVIA, N.Y., Aug. 15 -- Israel A. Horowitz, Milton Hanauer and Dr. Edward Lasker, all of New York City, were still at the head of the field when play ceased today in the eighth and semi-final round of the New York State Chess Association title tournament at the Cazenovia Junior College.

PEOPLE of London have now lived more than 1,001 nights in the blackout. Fog, soot and the strictest regulations have seen to that.

Production of the Buna S type of rubber, the best and cheapest substitute so far found for the natural product in the manufacture of automobile tires, involves three distinct operations. THIS year's Egyptian tour of the Palestine Symphony Orchestra was led by Georg Singer, who made his first appearance in Cairo and Alexandria. ITHACA, N.Y., Aug. 15 -- Mobilization of all available sources of financial aid to students to help those taking accelerated programs of study has been completed at Cornell University, according to an announcement this week by President Edmund E. Day.

CAIRO, Egypt, Aug. 15 -- United States Army Air Force fighter pilots have been in action against the Germans for the first time in the Middle East, and during three days' operations have given a good account of themselves.

CHAMBERSBURG, Pa., Aug. 15 -- Wilson College students are contributing to the war directly and indirectly through Summer jobs and study, and in the process are acquiring additional motivation for maximum achievement in their college work during the coming academic year, Dean Margaret Criswell Disert declared here today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 -- Senator Byrd, demanding nation-wide rationing of gasoline, asserted today that it was "grossly unfair and destructive of public morale" to permit citizens in thirty-one States to obtain all the gasoline and fuel oil they needed and to ration those in seventeen States.

NEENAH, Wis., Aug. 15 -- Individual champions were successful in defense of their titles in three races in the women's national A.A.U. championships tonight and the Riviera Club of Indianapolis got off to a good start in defense of its team crown.
CHICAGO, Aug. 15 -- Occupation, fastest working 2-year-old on the American turf, raced to a neck victory in the $69,875 Washington Park Futurity today.

After two months of organizational work, 80 per cent of the counties and cities in New York State have emergency staffs of nurses able to care for possible civilian casualties resulting from enemy attack, Miss Margaret Arnstein, State nursing officer, reported yesterday to Major John J. THE Stadium concerts, at a time of need for their ministrations, have proved that they can take it! Thanks of the Treasury Department for the "fine job" retailers did in the sale of war bonds and stamps during the "Retailers for Victory Campaign" last month and the decision to continue similar efforts in the future were conveyed in a letter from Secretary Morgenthau to Major Benjamin H. Namm, chairman of the Retail Advisory Committee of the Treasury, made public yesterday.

PRINCETON, N.J., Aug. 15 -- The question in the minds of many political observers is whether the Republicans can duplicate this Fall their feat of 1918 when, in a period of war, they won control of Congress from the Democrats.

WESTERBURY, L.I., Aug. 15 -- Well handled in both heats by Paul Vineyard, T.L. Gustin's 4-year-old bay colt Saratoga took the Cherry Valley free-for-all pace at Roosevelt Raceway today, as the biggest crowd of the season, 7,900, sent a record handle of $133,172 through the betting machines.

TEANECK, N.J., Aug. 15 -- New York City policemen seem to have everything their own way in the eleventh annual international police pistol tournament here, where crack shots from thirty States and from Canada and Mexico are engaged in a three-day shoot at the Teaneck police range.

LONDON, Aug. 15 -- The Army plans to send many Negro Waacs to England to perform duties such as car driving and secretarial work and also to provide companionship for the thousands of Negro troops here, Lieut. Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, commander of American forces in the European theatre of operations, announced today.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Aug. 15 -- Ben Hogan eased his blister ing golfing pace today, but even a third-round 72, two over par, failed to reduce the Texan's five-stroke lead in the $5,000 Times-Union open tournament.

MARION, Mass., Aug. 15 -- Tabor Academy, whose original endowment of $300,000 came from the whaling ventures along the New England coast, is now intensifying more than ever the nautical training usually offered by it by having the largest Summer naval program in the history of the school.

PROFESSOR FRIERSON has done a piece of work for which not only the student but also the lay reader will be grateful He has gathered up all the loose threads which have gone into the making of the English novel from 1885 to 1940 and has created something resembling a pattern.

WHITE MOUNTAINS, N.H. -- Affairs for charity are predominating at resorts in the White Mountains. At the Mount Washington, Bretton Woods, the Mountain View House at Whitefield and Maplewood Club percentages from receipts from games played during the week are given to the USO.

College shops were particularly active last week in the three major test markets of New York, Chicago and Los Angeles, according to the survey prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by Meyer Both Reports. Main floors and basements were busy. Budget dresses were in demand and the call for coats, suits and furs expanded.

A spectacular and unusual flower show will be sponsored by the Flowerfield Bulb Farm of Flowerfield, L.I., on Aug. 22. It will include not only displays of dahliahs, gladioli, annuals, perennials, fruits and vegetables, but also exhibits of educational value.

Gayety with an accent on youth is the mood of the new informal fabrics appearing in the shops. Almost Springlike in their freshness, ginghams, new textured monk's cloth, denims and fruit and floral chintzes are now ready to give an engaging air to the one-room living quarters of the college girl or the defense worker.

A call for 100,000 volunteers to make a door-to-door educational campaign was issued yesterday by the New York City Salvage Committee as a preliminary to the institution of a householders' pledge system to step up the salvage of all kinds of critical materials.

WITH "End of Reckoning" Mrs. Covert adds a fourth to her group of Oklahoma novels. This one has its setting in the town of Paradise. The time runs from the early days, when the surrounding territory had just been thrown open for settlement and the town was only a clump of ramshackle tents and sheds, to the Nineteen Thirties, when Paradise was a rapidly growing city.
BOSTON, Aug. 15 -- The Red Sox hung two one-run defeats on Washington today, spoiling an upward surge by the Senators that had included twelve victories in their last sixteen starts.
