MacIntyre, newly appointed administrator of the production code section, said yesterday.

The Securities and Exchange Commission, forced to adopt a realistic viewpoint with respect to public-utility financing as a result of the war emergency and current high-tax schedules, appears to have discarded the now famous "frank doctrine" of conservative capital structures for utility enterprises.
Twenty survivors of attacks on two merchant ships by Japanese planes, a destroyer and a submarine have arrived at an East Coast port. The sinkings of the two ships had been announced previously.

Ray Robinson, Harlem welterweight who has won all thirty-four of his professional Lattles, will appear in the main bout of ten rounds at Madison Square Garden on Friday night. The New York boxer will tackle Rube Shank of Denver, a youngster who recently gained victories over such well-known 147-pound battlers as Henry Armstrong and Fritzie Zivic.

West Milford, N.J., which once had 2,500 inhabitants and now has 3,500 and a Summer population of more than 15,000, has lost its one doctor to the Army and has petitioned the Selective Service to exempt him. Since it is agreed that a single physician cannot care for more than 15,000 patients effectively, it follows that even in normal times West Milford was medically shorthanded.

With steel production in the United States having averaged 7,000,000 tons a month for more than a year, this country is producing every thirty days as much steel as Japan turns out in a whole year, according to the American Iron and Steel Institute.

LOS ANGELES, Calif., Aug. 15 -- Because of its geographical location near the key war industries of the Pacific Coast, the University of Southern California has geared its program to fit the increasing demands for technically trained experts.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 -- The Axis radios are doing their best to prolong and intensify the disorders in India. Over a dozen transmitters in Europe and East Asia they pour their venom into Indian ears.
MOSCOW, Aug. 15 (AP) -- A Soviet Information Bureau communique:

A FEW questions on literary subjects were among those submitted to the members of the B.B.C. Brains Trusts at its final meeting for the season. Was it right, they were asked, that critics should have the power of making or marring a new book?

HAMILTON, N.Y., Aug. 15 -- To insure a smooth transition when he assumes his duties as Colgate University's ninth president on Sept. 1, Everett Case, former assistant dean of the Harvard Graduate School of Business Administration, will spend half time on the campus for two weeks conferring with Dr. George Barton Cutten, the retiring president, administrative officers and school and department heads.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 -- Sugar ration stamp No. 8 will be good for five pounds of the commodity in the ten weeks Aug. 23 to Oct. 31, the Office of Price Administration stated today.

THE Victory Symphony Orchestra, which has been giving concerts in Army posts under the auspices of USO-Camp Show, was formed by G.S. Brooks, a New York biological chemist and amateur violinist. He organized it at his son's suggestion, for the young man found he missed symphonic music when he enlisted in the service.

SHARON SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 15 -- The Four Freedoms of the Atlantic Charter must be made "the inalienable rights of all peoples now held in bondage," Senator James M. Mead declared tonight in an address here at the annual Interfaith Conference of Christians and Jews.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., Aug. 15 (AP) -- Syracuse applied another coating of whitewash to an International League rival tonight by defeating the Jersey City Giants, 2 to 0, and dropping them into third place.

BOSTON, Aug. 15 -- In defiance of the emergency powers of the War Labor Board, officials of the S.A. Woods Machine Company of Boston questioned today the right of employer members of the board to order the company to include maintenance of membership and arbitration clauses in a union contract.
GLOUCESTER, Mass., Aug. 15 -- This fishing port will celebrate the 300th anniversary of its incorporation as a town with a program starting tomorrow and continuing for three days.

EAST POULTNEY, Vt., Aug. 15 -- Scenes of the boyhood days of Horace Greeley were re-enacted at the old meeting house here today when the East Poultney Historical Society observed Old Home Day and 200 persons heard speakers review the life of the editor, who learned the printers' trade in this hamlet, where he lived four years.

LONDON, Aug. 15 -- American soldiers on leave sitting around Red Cross Washington Club in Mayfair thought there was something familiar about the tall lean gentleman who walked in this morning. The visitor shook hands with the Americans and asked them to leave some London beer for the natives.

In 1917 and 1918 labor groups and Federal leaders were denouncing the practice of extending the then lawful fifty-four-hour work week for women and struggling to insure even minimum health standards in factories. A phenomenal change in the working conditions for women since that time is apparent today in plants throughout the nation.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 -- Tribute to the services given to the Inter-American Commission of Women by Senora Hena De Bayle of Nicaragua, Senora de Castro of El Salvador and Senora de Caceres of Honduras, who have resigned, was paid in a statement issued today on its behalf by Miss Minerva Bernardino, vice chairman.

CHICAGO, Aug. 15 -- Miss Betty Jameson became the undisputed champion woman golfer of 1942 today by winning the Women's Western Golf Association amateur championship to go with the Western open title she earned in June.

In time of war the democracies have one problem which never arises to trouble the dictatorships. That problem is the news. It is no problem for the dictatorships, because governments like those now ruling Germany, Japan and Italy are based on force and force alone.

MOSCOW, Sunday, Aug. 16 -- Apparently launching a full offensive against Stalingrad after securing strongholds in the North Caucasus, the Germans hurled masses of infantrymen, tanks and planes today against Russian positions on the Kletskaya and Kotelnikov fronts before the important Volga city.

I have probably seen and suffered from more B's than any other living man. Yet, I am not in accord with those who cry, "Away with the B's." To be specific, B pictures are those that cost $150,000 or less.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 -- Government power experts estimated today that rainfall had contributed about $100,000,000 to the country's war effort in the last few weeks.
PAWTUCKET, R.I., Aug. 15 (AP) -- The Valdina Farm's Rounders, carrying top weight of 116 pounds, led six other 3-year-olds and up today in the $5,000 added King Philip Handicap at Narragansett Park.
DETROIT, Aug. 15 -- The White Sox nicked Roy Henshaw, relief pitcher, for three safeties and two runs in the tenth inning to defeat the Tigers today, 4 to 2, and even the series at one game apiece.

ANYTHING can happen in the North African desert, that bleak land of sun and sand storms, mirages and mosquitos. The military record of the area approaches the fantastic. Rommel is trapped and cannot escape; Rommel captures Tobruk, the "invulnerable.

THE Messrs. Hal Wallis, Michael Curtiz and Casey Robinson -- producer, director and scenarist, respectively -- who will be responsible for the Warner film version of "This Is the Army," were in town last week to watch Uncle Sam's newly recruited thespians overwhelm the eager audience that nightly fills the Broadway Theatre to capacity.
PROVO, Utah, Aug. 15 -- Total war is thrusting major changes upon the colleges, and Brigham Young University is accepting the new responsibilities eagerly, according to President Franklin S. Harris.

COXEY RIDES AGAIN: An unprecedented Army and Navy salute for outstanding aid in the war effort was given last Sunday to the industrial city of Massillon, Ohio, a community of 30,000 people. Speeches, a parade and fireworks were part of the ceremony.

ROCKVILLE, Conn., Aug. 15 -- Articles of utilitarian value were intermingled with objects of art at a public auction held today in the fifty-room mansion of the late Miss J. Alice Maxwell, art collector and a member of a wealthy textile family.

MOSCOW, Aug. 15 -- German attacks on the defenders of Stalingrad's far approaches mainly have been beaten off, though the situation in some sectors of the thrust from the west gives reason for some concern.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 -- Byron Price, Director of Censorship, refused tonight to discuss the order issued by his office barring this week's issue of Life Magazine from leaving the country, but he said it was not the first time such an order had been issued.

LONDON, Aug. 15 -- A speedy renewal of negotiations between the government of India and Indian political leaders was urged today by two Members of Parliament. James Griffiths, member of the Labor party executive board, said the next step must be an invitation to representatives of all political parties in India "to come to a round table and hammer out a settlement of this vexed question."

KEARNY, N.J., Aug. 15 -- The Destroyer Waller was launched today at the Federal Shipbuilding and Drydock Company here. The Federal Company is the United States Steel Corporation subsidiary which Secretary of the Navy Frank Knox has credited with building destroyers at the rate of one every fifteen days.

GOSHEN, N.Y., Aug. 15 -- His Excellency, bay 4-year-old colt owned by William H. Strang of Brooklyn, owner of the Hambletonian winner, the Ambassador, today captured the Trotting Derby, closing feature of the Grand Circuit meeting at Good Time Park.

TO our novel-reading public, Louis Bromfield used pretty much to symbolize the literary Bohemian. He belonged to a post-war generation of writers who found it more congenial to live abroad than in their native United States. For thirteen years his villa, just north of Paris, was a favorite meeting place for diplomats and journalists, musicians and stage celebrities.

Officials of the Fifth Avenue Coach Company conferred yesterday with Mayor La Guardia on the pending negotiations between the company and the Transport Workers Union, C.I.O., for a new contract covering wages, hours and working conditions of the company's employes.

BACK in December, miraculously synchronizing, almost to a day, with the Japanese attack on Pearl Harbor, a camouflage exhibition was opened at the Advertising Club. Sponsored by the Civilian Camouflage Council, of which Greville Rickard is chairman, that show was set up under the supervision of James G. Boudreau, director of the art school at Pratt Institute.

A tea and dance recital will be held Thursday under the auspices of the Sharon-Salisbury (Conn.) committee of the British War Relief Society at Taconic, Salisbury. Dances by Ruth St. Denis will be featured.

Still showing resentment at the recent plan of some officers of the National Outboard Association to suspend racing sanctions and compilation of records for the duration of the war, the American Power Boat Association bigwigs have set in motion efforts to handle affairs for the pancake pilots in all sections of the country and especially in those areas where there are no government restrictions or fuel rationing.

THE fat little black engine which puffed across the prairies from Batesville to Buffalo Valley years ago was a sturdy veteran of Indian attacks. The Indians had fought the coming of the railroad which destroyed their hunting ground, and though now there was peace, the brash young braves muttered and grumbled as the buffalo herds scattered and good meat was hard to find.

BAYONNE, N.J., Aug. 15 -- Manufacture of wire and cable for the armed forces proceeded at "top speed" today at the General Cable Corporation plant, which the government took over after 1,000 employes had walked out in defiance of a War Labor Board decision denying higher pay.

FLORA, Miss., Aug. 15 (AP) -- The Army revealed today plans to create here the first complete ordnance regiment in American military history, a balanced organization of specialists equipped to repair anything a modern task force needs from a big tank to a precision control on a delicate rangefinder.

The American people are beginning to pay their debts at a rate which indicates that when the war ends the average person will have a comparatively small financial millstone around his neck. Charge and installment accounts, mortgages, personal loans and other obligations are being worked off rapidly.

Fordham University will open its scholastic year next week with the introduction of a revised program of studies, designed to give to every student an opportunity for maximum preparation before entering the armed forces.

Heralded by the Navy Recruiting Station of Boston as "voluntary ambassadors of good-will," Russell Moran, 15 years old, and his brother Edward, 13, who are on the last leg of a round trip between Boston and Washington, selling War Savings Stamps and stimulating recruiting for the Navy, arrived in New York yesterday with their bicycle-drawn sleeper.

The old-time country "harvest festivals" will be happily brought to mind again by the participation of New York City in the nationwide victory garden harvest shows. The New York exhibition, which will be held in Grand Central Palace on Sept. 21, 22 and 23, will be the largest of the thousands of shows in every State and community.

MONTICELLO, Ark., Aug. 15 (AP) -- War threatens to accomplish what constant defeat, jeers, depression and de-emphasis couldn't -- stop football's wandering minstrels, Arkansas A. and M.'s Bollweevils.
Bananas are getting more difficult to find in New York, but there are prospects of a small supply arriving during the latter part of this week.
BOMBAY, India, Aug. 15 (U.P.) -- Mahadev Hiralal Desai, Mohandas K. Gandhi's private secretary, under detention at Poona, died today of heart disease.

PRINCETON, N.J., Aug. 15 -- In his midsummer report to the trustees of Princeton University, made public today, Dr. Harold W. Dodds, president of the university, summarized Princeton's role to date in the war effort and gave Princeton's answer to the "Yale Plan" for compulsory enrollment of undergraduates in the armed forces.
LONDON, Aug. 15 -- Twenty hours apart lie two worlds -- one where they talk war, another where they live it. The transition is breathtaking.

THIS is the week-end that the season of outdoor Summer concerts comes to an end. The report is that the war did not materially alter the picture from other years. Lights were dimmer at concerts in coastal cities, but that was about all

Two long-promised series, one for Qu'aiti and one for Kathiri, which are protected states within Great Britain's Crown Colony at Aden, reached New York last week. Each group contains eleven values, all of which are inscribed "Aden," as these items from the Arabian desert circulate interchangeably with the postal paper of Aden.

DEMOCRACY found its most vivid poetic expression in the stormy years midway between the European revolutions of 1848 and our own Civil War. "Leaves of Grass," published by its author in 1855, became itself a center of violent controversy, which has by no means been resolved as yet.

A sharp rise in the proportion of men attending the Summer courses at Columbia University resulted from the adoption of intensified wartime studies, Edward J. Grant, registrar, reported yesterday in making public registration figures for the university's forty-third Summer session.
RICHMOND, Va., Aug. 15 -- Bill Terry, general manager of the Giants, who once wondered if Brooklyn was still in the National League, conceded today the Dodgers had a smart ball club.

OTTAWA, Aug. 15 -- For the first time since the price ceiling was instituted in Canada in October last year the cost of living has risen by more than one point during a single month and in consequence, beginning today, more than $1,000,000 a week will be paid out to Canadian workers in cost-of-living bonuses.

PERU, Mass., Aug. 15 -- An Army transport plane carrying nineteen officers and men crashed on Granite Rock, a huge bowlder on Peru Mountain, in the woods three miles south of this village at 9:30 o'clock tonight.

Reaffirming their determination not to accept Attorney general John J. Bennett Jr. as their candidate, leaders of the American Labor party at a conference yesterday selected City Controller Joseph D. McGoldrick, an independent Democrat, as the party's candidate for Governor in the event that Mr. Bennett is nominated by the Democratic State Convention.

Workrooms of the Friends of Children, which have turned out thousands of articles of clothing for the young war victims in Great Britain in the past two years, will reopen tomorrow after a two-week closing with new plans for directing all its efforts toward the relief of poor children in this country.

THE most fundamental of the useful arts is the one which is most often neglected these days in a girl's training. To far too many girls the kitchen is a place where they wander mystified, helpless, and very conscious of being in the way of a busy and superior cook.

PEEKSKILL, N.Y., Aug. 15 -- Training of 1,400 officers and enlisted men of the New York Guard here at Camp Smith was slowed little by the rainy days of this week. If the parade fields and wooded terrain were not available on parts of rainy days, the big recreation hall was.

LENOX, Mass., Aug. 15 -- Dr. Serge Koussevitzky will give a dinner tomorrow night at Curtis Hotel, Lenox, for a group of Boston Symphony Orchestra trustees, members of the faculty of Berkshire Music Center and a number of personal friends who are in Berkshire for final series of the Tanglewood concerts.

INSPECTOR SCHMIDT, familiarly known as Schmitty, discovers that air raid precautions sometimes complicate the problems of the police. Even a test blackout makes an excellent screen for murder and it also enables persons wanted by the police to elude them with little difficulty.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 14 (U.P.) -- Buyers of war savings bonds are holding on to them despite the sixty-day redemption privilege they carry.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 (U.P.) -- Albert S. Goss, master of the National Grange, said today that "the drift toward inflation" will not be halted until wages are frozen and adjustments are made in price control so that "all are treated alike."

In more than forty war plants, scattered throughout the nation from Seattle to Florida, work stopped for a brief period last week while Army and Navy officials awarded a new emblem for civilian service on the home front's production lines -- the joint Army-Navy "E" pennant.

The wilted New Yorker who lost his two weeks' vacation in the war has found Shangri-La. Friday evening he plants his bags on a railroad station an hour or two from New York and claims the territory in the name of all week-end vacationists.

SOME homely truths underlie this amusing account of the revival of a half-dead little town in Georgia, not far from Atlanta. Thessaly had been built during the first half of the nineteenth century, when Grecian ideas and Grecian architecture were especially popular, and many of its larger houses were fine examples of the period.

Consideration by the War Production Board of a retail and wholesale inventory reporting order, rather than an inventory limitation order, was urged at the week end by Lew Hahn, general manager of the National Retail Dry Goods Association, in a statement prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES.

Indicative of the lengths to which industry is going to cooperate with the government in price ceiling compliance is the work now beir done by Seeman Brothers, Inc., wholesale grocers, of 121 Hudson Street, where for the last few months fifteen trained statisticians have been working continuously to determine the company's ceiling levels.
MORSE code transmissions sent out from 6.05 megacycles in English at 8:30 P.M.E.W.T., are particularly interesting as they represent conquest over German radio jamming.

MASCOT: An order from the British Ministry of Health went out last week concerning Whisky -- a Scottie dog who, with his French master and mistress, recently escaped across the Channel to England. "Treat him as an honored guest of the British Government," the order said, and Whisky, while he waits for proper clearance papers, is to get the best that England has to offer.

CLEVELAND, Aug. 15 (AP) -- Brig. Gen. Leonard P. Ayres declared today that "railroad traffic, and not scarce materials, or fabricating capacity, or industrial manpower, will be the limiting factor which will restrict the expansion of our production of munitions."

PHILADELPHIA. Aug. 15 -- Connie Mack's Athletics seemed of a mind to do the Yankees some real mischief today when they slyly trumped one of Manager Joe McCarthy's aces in the opening clash of a double-header.

I should like to register a further protest against the proposal for omitting credit titles. To my mind the work of the various movie technicians is as important as that of the actors themselves, yet outside of the actual titles shown on the screen it is difficult to obtain most of the production credits on a film.
The Women's Metropolitan Golf Association will hold its annual husband-and-wife tournament at the Bonnie Briar Country Club on Tuesday.

NEW LONDON, Conn., Aug. 15 -- Fourteen college dinghy teams competed off the Coast Guard Academy today for the Danmark Trophy presented by Captain Knud L. Hansen of the training ship Danmark, now at the academy wharf. The races are held in cooperation with the Intercollegiate Yacht Racing Association.

ABOARD A CRUISER, with the British Mediterranean Fleet, Aug. 13 (Delayed) -- The guns of British warships, spouting sheets of white flame, poured ton after ton of high-explosive shells into Premier Mussolini's stronghold of Rhodes early today.

LONDON, Aug. 15 (U.P.) -- Besides the hostage killings in the Netherlands, the Germans were reported today to be exacting a heavy toll in other counties where outbreaks against the Nazi occupying forces continued.

Up to May, 1941, 50 per cent of the 2,000,000 young men drafted for service in the Army were rejected because of physical defects. The President was disturbed. On Oct. 10, last, he expressed the opinion that the conditions disclosed constitute "an indictment of America," suggested that an experiment be made with family doctors to rehabilitate 200,000 of the men, but added that something should be done along broader lines.

Negotiations are now going on here and in England among the Netherlands Government in exile, shipowners and representatives of the Netherlands Transport Workers Union to insure the post-war economic and social status of the Dutch merchant seamen.

England has promised self-government to India after the war and, unless India's behavior meantime is too outrageous, that promise will be kept. But what justifies the view that the masses of India are capable of self-government?
WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 (U.P.) -- President Roosevelt soon may use his wartime powers as Chief Executive to stabilize wages and prices and thus combat the rising cost of living, it was believed tonight.

VICHY, France, Aug. 15 (AP) -- The Paris press reported today that 4,000 Jews previously arrested in the unoccupied zone of France were deported yesterday "to regions where -- under good supervisions -- they will be able to do labor of use to the European collectivity."
About the only certainty for the stay-at-home these days is taxes, so it is difficult for the canine world to plan ahead with any assurance that arrangements made in advance can be carried through.

Despite a consumption report for July that was better than expected, cotton prices in the futures market yielded moderately in quiet trading yesterday. In the early dealings on the New York Cotton Exchange, prices were up a bit, but lost ground near the close with the result that final quotations showed net losses for the day of 7 points in all active positions.

THE nation waits anxiously these days for the definite report on rubber which President Roosevelt has ordered. That report may mean the end of automobile driving for pleasure for the duration, and thus drastically change the pattern of American life; but it is believed here that the man in the street will accept the sacrifice once the facts are laid before him.

AT 2:26 on the afternoon of Dec. 7, last, Americans received the biggest jolt ever given to the people of any nation at a given time. Wars broke out suddenly in times gone-by, but even in the most sudden, days and weeks passed between their inevitability and the moment when the shooting began.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 -- Everything the Army uses, from hot-water boilers to pots and pans, is being redesigned to reduce components of critical materials to a minimum, the War Department said today in announcing further estrictions upon the materials which can be used in its $7,500,000,000 construction program.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 -- A picture of the activities of American Army planes on fronts throughout the world, coupled with facts and figures on their records against the enemy, was given today by Lieut. Gen. Henry H. Arnold, commanding general of the United States Air Forces.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Brazil, Aug. 10 (Delayed) -- The principal and most effective slogans with which the military and ultra-nationalist cliques now dominating the Japanese Government plunged their country into war were "Asia for the Asiatics" and "Drive Out the White Barbarians."

NUTRITION RESEARCH -- The Nutrition Foundation, an organization sponsored by food-manufacturing concerns, has received new subscriptions amounting to $75,000 from six new members. The fund for research is thus brought to a total of $923,500. Nutrition Reviews, a monthly journal reporting progress in the science of nutrition, is to interpret the foundation's research results and to review pertinent current literature.

MOSCOW, Aug. 15 -- This week Moscow is preparing for a second war Winter. Scores of thousands of office workers, students and shopgirls are chopping timber in the country or helping to float it down to Moscow. Others are harvesting hundreds of thousands of tons of vegetables to be stored in the city's food depots for the cold months ahead.

CHUNGKING, China, Aug. 15 -- Describing conditions in Japanese-occupied Shanghai on the fifth anniversary of the outbreak of hostilities in Shanghai, Yuan Liang, former Mayor of Peiping, who recently escaped from Shanghai, said today that Japan's occupation of the International Settlement on Dec. 8 last year aimed, first to seize all British and American interests, and, second, to gain control of the most valuable base for waging economic war against China.

The men who sold about 3,700,000 new passenger cars to as many willing Americans last year now quiver with excitement like puppies, so to speak, if a customer materializes in the showroom. They go around looking behind fences and through telephone books for some one who has the desire and the permission to get a new automobile.

Buddy Moore of Harlem spotted Ben Moroz, Philadelphia, almost a hundred pounds in their six-round feature bout at the Queensboro Arena last night and won. Scaling 199 1/2 pounds as against 294 1/2 for Moroz, the New Yorker carried the action to his foe for the greater part, and punched often enough to the body to gain the award.

NEW indications of the inflation that is so widely discussed are observed in retail trade quarters. Volume is dragging along at decreases under a year ago and merchants are not hopeful of much change until they get to the period of comparison with last year when the hoarding booms subsided.

In looking back over the twelve months that have passed since President Roosevelt and Prime Minister Churchill drew up their declaration one seems to be gazing across a fragment of eternity much wider than a year. The very ship on which the two heads of state conferred now lies at the bottom of the China Sea.

BOSTON, Aug. 15 (U.P.) -- More than 1,100 gasoline rationing books -- sufficient to provide for an estimated 6,000,000 miles of automobile driving -- were stolen during the night by burglars who broke into the South Boston Rationing Board offices.

RICHMOND, Va., Aug. 15 -- New treads can be quickly "slipped on" worn smooth tire casings, according to a patent (No. 2,292,286) granted to Allison D. Owen of San Francisco, Calif., for a new process of retreading or capping tires.

The response of the Pennsylvania Railroad to an appeal by the government for railroads to produce machinery required by the war in their shops has been the undertaking of machining of marine engines and other mechanical operations adapted to appliances used in car and locomotive works.

Commander Giles Stedman, U.S. N.R., former master of the United States liner America, the largest merchant vessel under the American flag, has been promoted to the rank of captain, it was announced last week by the War Shipping Administration.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 15 -- Next Thursday will mark a six-month anniversary in the lives of Japanese of the Far West. It will be exactly a half year since Lieut. Gen. John L. De Witt, Western defense commander, received authority under Presidential order to exclude any person, American citizen or alien, from any part of the eight Western States on grounds of "military necessity."

An attitude of "show me" marked the reactions of motorists and mechanics here yesterday to the Sun Oil Company's plan to increase passenger car gasoline mileage one-third by "deadening" half the cylinders in engines of six or more cylinders.

MANCHESTER, Mass., Aug. 15 (AP) -- Two Californians -- top-seeded Miss Pauline Betz of Los Angeles and 15-year-old Miss Louise Brough of Beverly Hills -- reached the final today of the Essex Country Club's women's invitation tennis tournament.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 15 -- Miss Nuala O'Donnell was introduced to society this afternoon at a tea dance given by Mrs. Barclay K. Douglas, mother of the debutante, and her husband, Lieutenant Douglas, at the home of Mr. and Mrs. Harold W. Brooks.

There is one unalienable right which Thomas Jefferson failed to mention along with life, liberty and the pursuit of happiness. It is the unalienable right of every private citizen to plan the strategy of his country's wars and to teach the generals and the admirals their business.

The report of the Food Machinery Corporation for the quarter ended on June 30, issued by Paul L. Davies, president, for publication today, shows net earnings of $466,419 after estimated Federal income and excess profits taxes under the 1941 tax law and after setting up an additional reserve of $150,000 to provide for contingencies arising in the emergency.

DOUGLAS, Ariz., Aug. 15 (AP) -- A charge of assault with a deadly weapon was filed against Miss Margaret Herlihy, daughter of Lieut. Col. E.G. Herlihy, in connection with the shooting early today of her fiance, Captain D.D. Carr, 25, attached to the Anti- Tank Division at Fort Huachuca.

CHATTANAOOGA, Tenn., Aug. 15 (AP) -- Caught in a trap set by a city policeman they had seized a few hours earlier, one fugitive from the Federal authorities was killed and two others wounded in a brief gun battle, just before dawn, south of this city today.

BRIARCLIFF MANOR, N.Y., Aug. 15 -- A newly organized curriculum designed to meet the needs of young women seeking training for jobs in the war emergency and for those continuing their professional and academic studies has been instituted at Briarcliff Junior College, Mrs. Ordway Tead, recently appointed president of this two-year institution, announced in the 1942-43 catalogue, made public today.

Leland Olds, chairman of the Federal Power Commission, charged last night that if Attorney General John J. Bennett Jr. obtains the Democratic nomination for Governor at the party's State convention next week it would represent a victory for "forces out of harmony" with President Roosevelt and would be construed both here and abroad as a repudiation of the President's policies and leadership.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Aug. 15 -- One-third of the personnel engaged in Norwegian trade and commerce will forthwith be conscripted for work on German fortifications in Norway, Premier Vidkun Quisling's Social Minister, a man named Lippestad, announced today.

LONDON, Aug. 15 -- Average American girls such as you might meet almost anywhere make up the first contingent of American Army nurses to come to Europe. Few of the group now in Northern Ireland can tell you exactly why they joined the Army and asked for foreign service.
The railroads are working for the government one-half of the time in more ways than one, according to Railway Age.
NEXT in wartime importance to combat, with its planning strategy, and to the production and transportation of supplies for the fighting forces come news and propaganda.

SOUTH HADLEY, Mass., Aug. 15 -- French and Belgian scholars, who early this year founded Ecole Libre des Hautes Etudes in New York as an institution of advanced study, will come to the Mount Holyoke College campus for a Summer session organized for a informal symposium, starting Monday.

NEW DELHI, India, Aug. 15 (U.P.) -- Peace negotiations designed to end the week-long bloodshed and rioting of Mohandas K. Gandhi's civil disobedience campaign were reported under way in New Delhi tonight with one of Mr. Gandhi's stanchest supporters in attendance.

BOMBAY, India, Aug. 15 (AP) -- The situation in India remains critical. Indian bitterness is growing as a result of the clashes between the rioters and British troops and government police, and the Congress leaders who are not in jail already are believed to be preparing an organized non-violent campaign on the Gandhi formula to take up where violence leaves off.
CHICAGO, Aug. 15 (AP) -- The Cubs and the Pirates battled for almost six hours today as Chicago dropped a double-header, 8 to 5 and 8 to 7, the second game going eleven innings.

The German High Command reported yesterday that Axis forces driving ahead in the Caucasus had captured Georgievsk on the Rostov-Baku railway, but were fighting bitter defensive battles against Russian diversionary attacks northwest of Voronezh on the south-central front and in the Vyazma-Rzhev area 130 miles west of Moscow.

IT wasn't so long ago that Manager Joe Cronin of the rich Red Sox was chatting about the unusual number of nifty shortstops in the American League, including his own Johnny Pesky, of course. But if Joe goes over his preferred list now, he will find two missing. That would be Jack Wallaesa, late of the Athletics, and Bill Hitchcock, late of the Tigers.
Babe Young was poison to the Phils yesterday in their twin bill with the Giants at the Polo Grounds.

READING, Pa., Aug. 15 -- F. Clair Ross, Democratic candidate for Governor, declared tonight that "election corruption" was the paramount issue of the campaigns, because the Republican nomination was "bought" for his rival, Major Gen. Edward Martin.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 15 -- On one and the same day, Ted Schroeder of Glendale, Calif., won the Eastern grass court tennis championship and qualified for the final of the Newport invitation tournament this morning at the Casino.

An appeal for contributions to maintain the $15,000 to $20,000 yearly graduate scholarship fund for the School of Education at Fordham University "in behalf of Catholic education in the Archdiocese of New York," was made yesterday by the Rev. Joseph A. Murphy, Professor of Psychology and Religion at the college, at a solemn high mass in St. Patrick's Cathedral.

Motion-picture stars who will participate in a series of nationwide tours in behalf of the billion dollar War Bond and Stamp drive in September were announced yesterday by the film industry's War Activities Committee. The film players, traveling separately and in groups, will make ton-day tours, starting on Sept. 1.

JERUSALEM, Aug. 16 -- American Red Cross supplies that were en route to Greece but were diverted to Egypt when Greece was overrun by the Axis, have now been distributed to hundreds of Greek women, children and non-combatant men who are encamped somewhere in the Middle East awaiting transferment to permanent camps, it was stated today.

James A. Farley, Democratic State Chairman and chief sponsor of the candidacy of Attorney General John J. Bennett Jr. for the nomination for Governor, announced yesterday that he had called a conference of party leaders to be held at the Hotel Biltmore tomorrow evening, on the eve of the opening of the State convention.

HAVANA, Aug. 16 -- President Fulgencio Batista this afternoon announced the appointment of a new Cabinet, thus ending the crisis that has agitated the nation for the past three weeks. A majority of the Ministers retained their posts, only five new figures entering the Cabinet.

The new drama season opens tonight at 8:40 at the Belasco when "Across the Board on Tomorrow Morning" and "Talking to You," both written, produced and directed by William Saroyan, will be offered as the first presentations of the Saroyan Theatre.

PARIS, Ky. Aug. 16 IAI lfr.i Camden entered Kentucky political life in 1911 and was appointed to the Senate in ]914 by Governor James B. McCreary after the death of Senator W. 0. Bradley. A few months later he was elected to complete the unexpired term ending in 1917.

BAYONNE, N.J., Aug. 16 -Navy officials in charge of the General Cable Corporation plant here hope that their period of occupancy will be shortened as a result of their decision to withhold the 3-cents-an-hour night-shift bonus which the War Labor Board authorized before the workers went out on an outlaw strike last Monday.

LONDON, Aug. 16 (U.P.) -- Memorial services for the five prominent Netherland citizens, executed by the Germans in the occupied country yesterday from among hostages seized by the Nazis after the wrecking of a German troop train Aug. 7, were held here today.

Wholesale activity last week improved over that in the week preceding, but continued to run well behind last year's level, according to a summary of the week's activities prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by leading resident buyers.

PURCHASE, N.Y., Aug. 16 -Eighteen New York State guardsmen posing as "saboteurs" made simulated attacks today on "military objectives" at the 800-acre estate here of the late Whitelaw Reid, while 110 members of the Harrison township auxiliary police hid in thickets to await the enemy and save the objectives from damage.

Napoleon Bonaparte's descent has prodded some of his biographers into ingenious researches. It has been traced to Roman Caesars, to Byzantine emperors, to Majorca and one Bonpart, believed by a true believer to have been the Man in the Iron Mask. The family name, Buonaparte, obviously was born of the everlasting strife between Guelf and Ghibelline.

BOGOTA, Colombia, Aug. 16 -- The Foreign Relations Committee of Congress will meet tomorrow and it is expected to discuss the sinking by a German submarine of the Colombian schooner Roamar with the loss of twenty-three lives.
VICHY, France, Aug. 16 -- Publication of the monthly situation of the public debt has been resumed after a long interruption and permits the state of government finances to be followed more closely.
LONDON, Aug. 16 -- The decision of the British Government to draft women for fire watching brings the wives and mothers of this country a step farther into the front line of this war.

THERE came a letter with a clipping. This observer studied the clipping first. It was a clipping of a story dated "Stockholm, July 10," and contained an account of how "on a track rendered heavy by continuous rains, Arne Andersson of Goeteborg tonight equaled Gundar Haeggs world mile record of 4:06.2," with some added details of the performance.

Camouflage became a major military tactic in the first World War when the French formed a "section de camouflage" and the British organized their own camouflage service as a unit of the Royal Engineers. With the growing submarine peril in 1917 "dazzle painting" of war vessels and merchantmen was commonly applied, and in Washington a Dazzle Department was set up to deal with United States shipping.
The need for a purpose in life was emphasized in a sermon yesterday morning by the Rev. John Paul Jones, at Union Presbyterian Church, Ridge Boulevard and Eightieth Street, Brooklyn.

BERNE, Switzerland, Aug. 16 -Confirmation that Germany is demanding more French labor came in reports from both occupied and unoccupied France today. Hitherto it had been presumed that Berlin's requirements concerned exclusively skilled metallurgical workers.

One of the less imposing post-war problems about which we can begin to think now without overburdening our minds is what we shall do with the many executives who emerge from it. These are being produced in monumental numbers in the armed forces, and they are good ones, too.

This savage war has developed no horror to match Germany's cold-blooded slaughter of hostages. The Japanese follow the same practice, but at least have the shame to deny it. Without shame and without remorse the Nazis announce it to the world. Their long and futile campaign of vengeance on the innocent has now reached a climax in the announcement that the murder of Dutch hostages has begun with the shooting of five prominent Netherland citizens.

FORT DIX, N.J., Aug. 16 (AP) -Colonel Cassius M. Dowell, commanding officer of Fort Dix, today ordered the much-disputed tavern section of Pointville "off limits" for military personnel of the post after an early morning dispute in which one soldier was killed.

CALDWELL, N.J., Aug. 16 -The heaviest mosquito invasion since 1938 will hit the North Jersey counties of Essex, Morris, Passaic and Union early this week -on Tuesday, the experts predict -and will continue for about a month, George W. Eager, superintendent of the Essex County Mosquito Commission, warned today.

CAIRO, Egypt, Aug. 16 -- Much credit for the arrival of the recent Mediterranean convoy at Malta must go to Spitfire fighter formations operating from Malta. This fighter screen drove off many Axis bombers, forced others to jettison bombs and shot down at least thirteen enemy planes.
I am somewhat at a loss to understand the following passage in your otherwise informative Aug. 13 editorial on India:

BOMBAY, India, Aug. 16 (AP) -The president of the All-India Moslem League, Mohammed Ali Jinnah, declared today that if the British in seeking peace with the Hindu-dominated All-India Congress party sacrificed the Moslems' interests he would end his "cooperation."

WASHINGTON, Aug. 16 -- Startling red printed notices were scattered around the Federal District in Mexico last month calling the women of the capital to a mass meeting on civilian defense. One thousand strong, they gathered in the large hall of the Electrical Workers Union and heard thirty-five speakers from a platform decorated with posters of Mme. Chiang Kai-shek, Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt and women leaders from Latin countries.

VICHY, France, Aug. 16 -Among the prizes offered to encourage assistance to the government's efforts to collect nonferrous metals is the offer of a litre [about a quart] of wine to any one who turns in 200 grams [.44 of a pound] of copper.

Without something more than human wisdom and strength we cannot find our way out of the labyrinth of dire dilemmas that face us now, whatever way we turn, the Rev. Dr. Theodore C. Speers, pastor of the Central Presbyterian Church Park Avenue and Sixty-fourth Street, said in his sermon yesterday morning.

LONDON, Aug. 17 -- Units of the United States Army Air Forces have participated increasingly in the past twenty-four hours in the warfare over France and Britain and over the sea, it was officially announced today by American headquarters in the European theatre, as Brig. Gen. James H. Doolittle started upon duties here.

CHICAGO, Aug. 16 -- A further advance in hog prices last week to a new high since October, 1920, has resulted in a further squeeze of packers, especially the smaller ones, who find that they cannot cut hogs profitably at the present time due to the lack of a ceiling on them while retail cuts of meats, lard and other products cannot be sold above a level that prevailed some time ago.

A compendium titled "Advertising and Selling Practices under the General Maximum Price Regulation," listing what is permitted as well as what is forbidden under rulings of the Office of Price Administration, has been issued to members by the Association of National Advertisers, 330 West Forty-second Street.

Eleven players were named yesterday for the national junior Davis Cup squad, the 'teen-age stars hailing from all sections of the country, although the majority, six, are from the Pacific Coast. They are products of the nation-wide junior development work of the United States Lawn Tennis Association.

Conditions in Western Canada relative to the general increase in the duck population are reassuring to hunters. According to the latest survey completed by Ducks Unlimited, Canada, the early findings are again borne out that ducks were more numerous this year in Manitoba, Southern Saskatchewan and in parts of Alberta.

Despite a controversy with the Park Department and the frequent interruptions of rain, special exercises marking the dedication of a flagpole and plaque in memory of Mrs. Sara Delano Roosevelt, were held yesterday afternoon in the Sara Delano Roosevelt Park on the lower East Side.

EAST HAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 16 -- The second annual ladies' baseball game was played this afternoon at the Maidstone Club. The players included Mrs. Bruce Ryan, Mrs. J. Basil Maguire, Mrs. Thomas Yawkey, Mrs. Harold McCall, Mrs. Malcolm McAlpin, Mrs. John O'Keefe, Mrs. Jane Maxwell, Mrs. Thomas Clyde, Mrs. Russell Hopkinson, Mrs. Richard Woolworth, Mrs. Austin Pardue, Mrs. C. Edmunds Kimball and Mrs. Paul Harvey Deming Jr.

The Giants slipped more firmly into the third slot in the National League race yesterday as they downed the Phils at the Polo Grounds for their fourth straight victory -- and slipped is used advisedly in this case. The New Yorkers increased their margin over the fourth-place Reds, who slipped twice against the Cards, to three games.

The city's trophies of World War I, such as cannon, guns and tanks captured from the enemy, will be turned over to the Army in the near future, to be consigned to blast furnaces and converted into modern armament for use against the Axis, Mayor La Guardia announced yesterday.

NEW ORLEANS, Aug. 16 -- Better war news and prospects for another record breaking domestic consumption figure combined to lift sentiment in cotton futures late in the week after a carryover of selling orders from the large crop report of the previous week-end set prices off moderately at the start of the period.

INTERLOCHEN, Mich., Aug. 16 -- Besides having the Department of Justice on his trail for alleged violation of the Sherman Anti-Trust Act, James C. Petrillo, president of the American Federation of Musicians, is about to be stalked by Interlochen high school students, whose orchestra he put off the air.

The New York Board of Trade added its voice yesterday to those of the city administration and organized labor in demanding that the Federal Government act at once to end mass unemployment by awarding more war contracts to small plants here.
LONDON, Aug. 16 -- The following article was written by a correspondent of The Times of London who visited a United States airfield in the British Isles:
PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 16 -- The Yankees seemed to be having no trouble thrashing the Athletics today, but unforeseen developments almost deprived them of a victory.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 16 -- Edward R. Stettinius Jr., Lease-Lend Administrator, stressed in a statement today the controls which were being applied to lease-lend supplies and declared that the uses of all scarce raw materials were being rechecked to assure that the "most vital" of the combined war purposes were being served.

Forty-eight employes of the Bridgeport (Conn.) Brass Company will appear at the Stage Door Canteen at 10 P.M. Thursday in an hour's condensation of their own full-length musical show dealing with the Navy and called "Ready! Aim! Fire!"

The Rev. Frederic W. Golden-Howes, preaching yesterday at the Episcopal Church of the Incarnation, Madison Avenue and Thirty-fifth Street, declared that although the spiritual has been submerged, it has not been completely over-whelmed nor destroyed, beneath the merciless pressures of urges and needs governing this life.

The New York City Defensefs Recreation Committee, 99 Park Avenue (corner of Fortieth Street), through the generosity of the entertainment world offers a partial list of free amusement and recreational activities available today.

We would like to tip our very best bonnet to those ingenious gentlemen who devise the powders and potions and other paraphernalia to make us lovely. For no sooner have we absorbed the full significance of the priority problem, and begun to wonder uneasily where our next lipstick is coming from, then up they pop with a new solution.

"War Pages" are now making their appearance in new books. These are short personal statements on the war written by the author and placed, as a rule, somewhere in the front of the book. "War Pages" are the idea of the Writers War Board, of which Rex Stout is chairman.
Appeasement and not pre-Pearl Harbor isolationism is the issue in this campaign, Israel Amter, Communist candidate for Governor, declared yesterday in a speech broadcast from radio station WQXR.

"America needs men and women who are willing to live unselfishly, pursuing the noblest ideals," declared the Rev. Robert C. Carlson of the New York Avenue Methodist Church, Brooklyn, in a sermon yesterday morning at Trinity Baptist Church, 179 New York Avenue, Brooklyn, at a union service of the two churches.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 16 -- Mrs. Livingston Fairbank gave a musicale and tea this afternoon at Faircrest. During the afternoon Mrs. Fairbank sang a group of songs by Brahms, Hugo Wolfe, Eric Korngold and Gretchaninoff, and Mrs. Edward Fisher Brown, known professionally as Nathalie Boshko, played compositions for the violin by Tchaikovsky, Schubert, Sarasate and Ibert. Gerald Kendall was accompanist.
A High Command communique broadcast from Berlin and recorded here by The Associated Press:
CARACAS, Venezuela, Aug. 14 -Of all the Western Hemisphere peoples, the Venezuelans, who produce oil that helps keep Allied war machines running, are feeling the pinch of war most keenly.

The Boeing Flying Fortress is not a new plane, but it has proved itself in combat around the world to be one of the most effective fighting and bombing machines in existence. Our Army Air Corps knew it was good long before it was tried in war. They thought so well of it that they did not permit the Boeing Aircraft Company, its manufacturers, to sell it abroad.

CAIRO, Egypt, Aug. 16 (AP) -North African Axis supply ports were heavily pounded last night by the R.A.F. In other operations over the Mediterranean an Axis ship was reported hit and some power lighters attacked.

The period in which war production in New York State was expected to require the induction of women into factories on a wholesale scale is declared to be at hand. Officials of the United States Employment Service report that as conversion programs in up-State plants are nearing completion, women are being hired, often without any training, to keep up with the demand.

Tucked away in the berry of the wheat is a small section, so very tiny that it represents but a microscopic fraction of the whole kernel. There, in a sort of private cell, the seed hoards substances that are the sine qua non of its growth. This minute compartment, which is the source of the plant's vitality, has received an enormous amount of publicity of late.

LONDON, Monday, Aug. 17 (AP) -- Sharp gunfire was heard in the London area early today, although there was no air raid alarm. German air raiders were reported over a number of scattered areas in East Anglia and along the east coast, but at no place were they reported to have penetrated far inland.

LONDON, Aug. 16 -- The Economist's index of British commodity prices, based on 1927, as 100, was 110.9 on Aug. 4. This compares with 111.6 a fortnight before, 111.5 a month before, 106.4 a year before and 70.3 at the end of August, 1939.

MANCHESTER, Mass., Aug. 16 (AP) -- Nineteen-year-old Miss Louise Brough of Beverly Hills, Calif., girls' national tennis champion last year, continued her blistering tour of the East today, winning her fourth consecutive singles title with a 6-3, 1-6, 6-3 victory over top-seeded Miss Pauline Betz of Winter Park, Fla., in the final of the eighteenth annual Essex County Club invitation tournament.

HEWLETT, L.I., Aug. 16 -- J.W. Key of Seawane and Frank Simonson of Cherry Valley won the eighth annual Arthur Man Memorial member-guest invitation best-ball golf tournament at the Seawane Club today by beating W.D. Thomas of the home club and R.G. Narelle of North Hempstead, 4 and 2.

It seems to me that subscriptions to war bonds would be materially facilitated if Congress would act quickly and definitely on the income tax and sales tax. Many people may be holding back until they know how much cash they must lay aside or allow for these taxes, which cannot be paid in bonds or war savings stamps.

The answer to the cynics who complain that life is not worth living is the explanation that modern Americans have been badly educated, betrayed by our well paid pedagogues, the Rev. Dr. Bernard Iddings Bell, honorary canon of the Cathedral of St. John, Providence, R.I., declared in a sermon yesterday at Trinity Episcopal Church, Broadway and Wall Street.

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 16 (AP) -- The Cardinals slashed a game and a half from Brooklyn's National League lead today as they whipped the Reds, 10 to 5 and 6 to 3. St. Louis now trails the Dodgers by eight games.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 16 -- William Talbert of Cincinnati scored his biggest triumph on turf today when he carried off the Newport Challenge Trophy with a stunning victory over Ted Schroeder of Glendale, Calif., at the Casino.

BERNE, Switzerland, Monday, Aug. 17 -- The Red Army is reported to have launched two large-scale attacks on the southern front in Russia. One force is said to be pushing in a southerly direction from Voronezh, while the other is advancing to the northwest above Kotelnikov to engage the southern prong of the German drive toward Stalingrad.

ALBANY, Aug. 16 -- Results of the June dental licensing examination were made public today by the State Board of Dental Examiners. A total of 816 applied for the license, but only 411 were successful in the test.

Mental and physical examination of all men inducted into the armed forces should be centralized in one selection agency, it was urged yesterday in a report by a committee representing the New York City Committee on Mental Hygiene of the State Charities Aid Association and the Emergency Committee of Neuropsychiatric Societies of New York City.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 16 -- Declaring that Congress had now for the first time a "clear idea" of what government expenditures would be during the next few years, Senator Byrd said today that he hoped to persuade fellow members of the Senate Finance Committee to write an "adequate" tax bill which would remain unchanged for three or four years.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Aug. 16 -Warner Brothers' "Juke Girl," an Ann Sheridan film, which was released in the United States May 30, will not be shown to Latin-American audiences because of objections to its content made by the Motion Picture Society for the Americas, it was learned today.

DETROIT, Aug. 16 (AP) -- The Tigers came from behind in both ends of a double-header with the White Sox today, winning the opener, 3 to 2, in eleven innings, and taking the second, 7 to 3, with a four-run rally. The double victory gave the Tigers the series, three games to one.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 16 -- An intensive program for the training of dogs for use by the Army in its new "canine corps" was announced by the War Department today.

AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, Australia, Aug. 16 (AP) -- United States Marines, fighting in the Tulagi area and supported by naval units in the dangerous waters of Sealark Channel and Indispensable Strait, were tightening their grip in the Solomons tonight.
MOSCOW, Monday, Aug. 17 (AP) -- The Soviet Bureau of Information midnight communique:

LENOX, Mass., Aug. 16 -- With performances of Haydn's Eighty-eighth symphony and Shostakovich's Seventh this afternoon, and Bach's Magnificat and Beethoven's Ninth symphony last evening, the historic series of concerts given by the orchestra of the Berkshire Music Center at Tanglewood under the direction of Serge Koussevitzky came to an end.

Home owners who are heeding government advice to alleviate the Eastern fuel oil scarcity by converting their oil heating plants to coal burners were advised, in a statement issued yesterday by the National Better Business Bureau, to investigate the merits of the various advertised conversion devices before spending their money.

CHICAGO, Aug. 16 -- Persistent showers coupled with moderate temperatures have worked wonders with the corn crop, and while maturity is being delayed by lack of hot forcing weather, there has been considerable progress in this respect, and official reports indicate that with normal weather from now on there will be very little soft grain in Illinois or Iowa this season.

More scientists were called in yesterday by the city when the odor that has offended residents of the Clason Point section of the Bronx appeared again at 2 o'clock in the afternoon. After laboratory tests of trapped water from a landfill for Soundview Park in the section, they announced they had solved the mystery.

Appointment of Colby M. Chester, board chairman of General Foods, as general chairman of the 1943 Greater New York Red Cross War Fund campaign was announced yesterday by Lieut. Gen. James G. Harbord, chairman of the New York chapter, American Red Cross.

Under government orders, non-military flying -- except, of course, air transport operations -- must cease along the Atlantic coast from Maine to a corner of North Carolina. Civilian pilot training operators must close down or move to new bases west of a line that runs inland at depths varying from twenty to fifty miles from the coast.

At least 1,500 service men will be able, through the generosity of George E. Ruppert, to see Sunday's double-header between the Yankees and Senators for Army and Navy relief funds. The New York City Defense Recreation Committee yesterday was notified by President Ed Barrow of the Yankees that Mr. Ruppert had donated for service men this block of tickets, which he had purchased.
NEENAH, Wis., Aug. 16 -- The 1942 women's national A.A.U. swimming and diving championships closed tonight with six new champions crowned and one national record broken.

FRENCH LICK, Ind., Aug. 16 -A "million dollar war bond party," with Tom Taggart, proprietor of the French Lick Springs Hotel, as host, today turned in a bonanza of war bond purchases as Hoosier guests and those who sent their regrets bought nearly two and a quarter million dollars' worth of bonds.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 16 -- The food rationing division of the Office of Price Administration today announced a uniform means of providing allowable sugar inventories for retail and wholesale businesses which have opened since rationing went into effect on April 28.

AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, Australia, Monday, Aug. 17 -- United States Marines, consolidating and extending their gains in the offensive to throw the Japanese out of the Solomon Islands, now are receiving aerial support from planes based on at least one captured airdrome, it is believed here.

LOCKPORT, N.Y., Aug. 16 (AP) -- The United Automobile Workers, C.I.O., which is engaged in a wage controversy with the General Motors Corporation's Harrison Radiator Division, today scheduled a strike at the plant for Aug. 24, union officials announced.

The serious losses suffered by the British in the effort to get supplies to the battered island of Malta show that it is not unwillingness to take long chances that delays the opening of the Western front. To convoy supply ships through the Mediterranean from Gibraltar is so hazardous an enterprise that for nearly two years this route has been virtually abandoned in favor of the long voyage around the Cape of Good Hope.

Both in content and in manner of presentation, the report on the record of American Army planes in action, presented by Lieut. Gen. H.H. Arnold, is a highly satisfactory document. Although outnumbered in almost every aerial action, our planes have proved their superiority by destroying more of the enemy's craft than they have lost of their own.

A renewed outbreak of violence in Harlem brought extra details of police to the area last night after a Negro was stabbed to death, another badly knifed and a young white man and his sister assaulted on the roof of a Lenox Avenue tenement.

Running an interrupted race with the rain, the Dodgers yesterday contrived to get in one abbreviated game with the Braves at Ebbets Field, only to lose it, 2 -- 0, when Al Javery permitted only one hit in the seven innings, to hang up his fifth shut-out.
MOSCOW, Aug. 16 (AP) -- A Soviet Information Bureau communique:

Picturing totalitarianism as "the most dire threat ever to have menaced a civilization of free men," forty-three Catholics from Europe living in the United States and Canada declare in a manifesto on the world crisis, which will appear tomorrow in The Commonweal, that they believe the Russian people should be aided by the United Nations.

Only two new films are slated to open locally this week. These are the new Abbott and Costello comedy, "Pardon My Sarong," which will arrive on Wednesday at Loew's Criterion, and the twice-postponed "I Live on Danger," starring Chester Morris, which the Rialto promises to bring in on Saturday.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Aug. 16 -- The pistol won a technical victory over the bow and arrow at the first annual White Plains police revolver tournament this afternoon when rain washed the archers out of competition. Standing in mud and with water blurring their vision, the pistol experts fired despite the downpour.

Virtual abandonment of new capital projects, coupled with a general policy of strict economy, has enabled the city to accumulate, as of July 1, 1942, a free margin of $153,050,539 in borrowing power, Controller Joseph D. McGoldrick reported yesterday in a statement sent to the Board of Estimate, the City Council, the City Planning Commission and Budget Director Kenneth Dayton.

The Sperry Gyroscope Company, latest winner of the Army-Navy production award, yesterday exercised its American privilege of hiring a hall to tell the world that employers and employes alike were jointly proud of the job they were doing to help lick the Axis.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 16 (UP) -- A German victory over Russia would create a gigantic Nazi-controlled industrial machine whose inroads into world trade would lead to an economic isolation of the United States destined to force its ultimate "submission to totalitarian rule," the Foreign Policy Association warned tonight.
BALTIMORE, Aug. 16 (AP) -- The Baltimore Orioles broke loose from their scoreless spree today, winning the second game of a double-header with Newark, 3 -- 1, after dropping the opener, 4 -- 0.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 16 (AP) -- Fight promoter Joe Turner will try it again tomorrow night, looking for that charm which goes with the proverbial third time.

JERSEY CITY, Aug. 16 (AP) -- Jersey City defeated Syracuse, 1 to 0, today as Hugh East toppled Red Barrett in a brilliant pitchers' battle to give the Little Giants an even break in a series cut to four games.

Mayor Stanley W. Church of New Rochelle told the closing session of the convention of the Affiliated Young Democrats yesterday at the Hotel Piccadilly that all Democrats must support the candidate selected by the Democratic State Convention While he made a plea for the nomination of Senator James M. Mead, his words were taken to cover the increasing likelihood of the nomination of Attorney General John J. Bennett Jr.

BERNE, Switzerland, Aug. 16 -The extent of damage inflicted on the Rhineland city of Mainz by the recent Royal Air Force raids is gradually being revealed in German quarters and a dispatch from Frankfort estimates that the casualities confirmed so far exceed eighty.

After the high humidity had sent thousands to beaches and parks for relief, a heavy downpour of rain accompanied by thunder and lightning struck the city and metropolitan area shortly after 4 o'clock yesterday afternoon.

Surrogate James A. Foley, in a proceeding to determine the domicile of Mrs. Margaret P. Daly, widow of Marcus Daly, Montana copper mine operator, has held that Mrs. Daly never became a legal resident of New York and that the evidence showed that she never abandoned her domicile in Montana.

MONTCLAIR, N.J., Aug. 16 -Unless the Navy gets Charley Whitehead, which appears likely, officials of the New Jersey State Golf Association might just as well give him the championship trophy to hold in perpetuity.
CHICAGO, Aug. 16 (AP) -- The East defeated the West, 5 to 2, today in the Negro All-Star baseball game played before 48,000 persons, largest crowd of the season at Comiskey Park.

The leasing of apartments in the city is keeping up a brisk pace, according to lists of new tenancies disclosed by renting concerns over the week-end. Buildings on Fifth and Park Avenues attracted several new families in the activity on the East Side, while London Terrace and houses on West End Avenue, Riverside Drive and adjacent streets were centers of most of the leasing on the West Side.
CHICAGO, Aug. 16 (AP) -- Beaten twice by the Pirates yesterday, the Cubs today reversed the order and won both ends of a double-header, 5 to 1 and 4 to 1.

CHICAGO, Aug. 16 -- Hedging pressure against the movement of the new Northwestern oats crop was responsible last week for lower prices for that grain on the Board of Trade and futures lost 1 to 1 1/8 cents a bushel for the week, September finishing at 49 1/4 cents; December, 50 7/8 cents and May at 53 cents.

NEW LONDON, Conn., Aug. 16 -- After a two-day dinghy regatta off the Coast Guard Academy for the Danmark Trophy, the battle-royal for top honors among Harvard, Dartmouth and Yale ended late this afternoon with the Crimson winning the cup. Harvard had a total of 251 points for the two days. Dartmouth scored 242 and Yale 217.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Aug. 16 -- Ben Hogan, the Hershey, Pa., golf wizard, added the $5,000 Times-Union open tournament to his long list of triumphs today by carding a final-round 74, four over par, for a seventy-two-hole total of 278.
BOSTON, Aug. 16 (AP) -- The Red Sex won their fifth double-header at home from Washington today, 6 to 4 and 10 to 3, for a sweep of the four-game series.

TEANECK, N.J., Aug. 16 -- New York City police marksmen captured today first and second places in team competitions and several individual first places at the eleventh annual international police pistol tournament on the Teaneck police range in the finals of the three-day meet.

CAZENOVIA, N.Y., Aug. 16 -Competing for the first time in the annual championship tournament of the New York State Chess Association at the Cazenovia Junior College, Israel A. Horowitz of New York today emerged as victor with a score of 8 -- 1.

There was little movement on the Stock Exchange last week, but the previous week's decline was not repeated and values slowly recovered. Less influence seemed to be exerted, either by company earnings statements or by the continuing retreat of Russia's army.
The German High Command announced yesterday that Axis troops had broken the resistance of strong Soviet rear guards in the Caucasus and were advancing in continuous attacks.

Any fantastic visions of hordes of American women going barelegged through chill Winter days in the interest of conservation and priorities should be scotched by a quick glance at the Autumn fashions in hosiery. Stockings have by no means retired from the lists under the combined assault of priorities, limitation and leg make-up.

Three armed bandits and two girl companions -- sisters, 16 and 18 years old -- who were captured Saturday night after two hold-ups, were booked yesterday at the West Twentieth Street station, where it was said they admitted twenty other robberies in the last three weeks.

MANAGUA, Nicaragua, Aug. 16 -- The Standard Fruit Steamship Company has advised the government that it has acquired all concessions, rights and property of the Bragman's Bluff Lumber Company, Inc., of Delaware, operating banana plantations and a lumber industry at Puerto Cabezas, Nicaragua.

Though the country has been perplexed by conflicting statements on war production from various agencies which have a part in it, there is encouraging and increasing evidence of the kind of wholehearted cooperation and close teamwork among leaders on the factory firing line which is the best assurance of success.

CHUNGKING, China, Aug. 16 (AP) -- Japanese have launched a counter-attack at Linchwan and Huwan, twelve miles to the southeast, after receiving 3,000 reinforcements, and bitter fighting is raging in that part of Kiangsi Province, the Chinese High Command said today.

PITTSBURGH, Aug. 16 -- The major problem in the steel industry last week continued to be one of distribution, and there were signs that the War Production Board had further changes in store. With the WPB having complete control over the dividing up of finished steel products, ways and means were still being sought to break the jam in the high priority levels.

BY the grace of God, Ben Robertson and his kinfolk are Carolinians and all of his kissing kin are Carolinians. "There are about a thousand persons in our valley who are counted among our kin," he says, and one can well believe it after trying to keep up with him in his explanations of the genealogical labyrinth of his family connections, which includes Uncle Forrest's eleven girls and Cousin Caroline's ten boys.

LONDON, Aug. 16 -- Last week's developments in the war demonstrated again the toughness of the stock markets here in the face of conditions which approach a crisis. The British Minister of Production, forecasting that the struggle will rise in a crescendo for the next two months, called for buoyancy and vitality in meeting it.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 16 -- Two of Rusty Callow's University of Pennsylvania crews, representing the College Boat Club, won in the ninety-fifth annual Schuylkill Navy Day championship regatta on the Fairmount Park course today, but his Summer course varsity eight bowed to Fairmount's national titleholders by two and a half lengths.

MOSCOW, Monday, Aug. 17 -The Russian High Command announced today that the Caucasian oil city of Maikop [claimed by the Germans on Aug. 9] had fallen, but only after the Russians had applied their scorched-earth policy.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., Aug. 16 -- Many of the seventy-three competing craft in the Huguenot Yacht Club's regatta today carried spinnakers through a wet squall, and the remarkable fact was that none of them burst. Several went into the water as the boats jibed with them, but all remained intact.

VICHY, France, Aug. 16 -- Discussion continues in the press regarding the economic organization that will prevail after the war. Even the most ardent supporters of economic freedom are obliged to recognize that in any event it cannot be expected to return to it for a very long time.

Following the drop in the previous week on the government's unexpectedly large estimate of the coming crop, cotton prices turned firmer last week and made moderate net gains. At the close of the market on Saturday, active futures contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange showed for the week net advances of 16 to 23 points, against net declines of 26 to 28 points in the previous week.

Anibal Jara, Consul General of Chile, has leased the five-room dwelling at 10 Washington Mews and will occupy it as a Winter home with his bride, the former Ester Jurnet, it was disclosed yesterday by Henry Fippinger, Inc., the broker who arranged the lease.

Bishop Robert Nelson Spencer of the Protestant Episcopal Diocese of West Missouri, declared in a sermon yesterday morning at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine, that "false counsellors went very far toward damning a hole generation" in the twenty-year interval betwen the last World War and the present one.

Danger of encroachment on the Adirondack Park by corporate interests, beyond the demands of the war emergency, has not been removed by the latest action of the War Production Board. The matter involves the granting of a right of way to the Delaware Hudson Railroad to bring ore from a newly opened mine, the product of which is deemed important to war production.

AINEOLA, L. I., Aug. 16 -- The troubles of Miss Barbara Lucy Taylor with the Nassau County police are piling up. Scheduled to go on trial in the District Court here tomorrow on a charge of damaging a police booth, she was arrested again at 2:20 o'clock this morning on a charge of slapping and kicking a policeman in a row in Great Neck.

MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, Aug. 16 (AP) -- The Pan-American Free Italy conference today adopted a proposal by the Argentine delegation that the Free Italians (anti-Fascist Italians) of North and South America state their "absolute solidarity with the people of the United States, Britain, Russia, China and other United Nations."

New paid-for life insurance written in July by thirty-nine companies having 81 per cent of the life insurance outstanding in United States legal reserve companies, amounted to $620,728,000, according to the report of the Association of Life Insurance Presidents to the United States Department of Commerce.
CLEVELAND, Aug. 16 (AP) -- The Indians, suffering their worst batting slump of the season, scored only four runs today, but divided a double-header with the Browns.
LONDON, Aug. 16 -- Britain's supplies of manganese attracted chief attention this week in the British commodity trade because of the German advance in the Northern Caucasus and the rioting in India.

GARY, Ind., Aug. 16 -- President Roosevelt, in a message today to the American Federation of Teachers, declared that children must not be permitted to bear the cost of the war in neglect or loss of educational opportunity. He also called on the teachers to convey an understanding of the war issues and the hardships facing not only children but adults in every community.

SEATTLE, Wash., Aug. 16 (AP) -- Captain Delbert J. Kelley told today how American ingenuity and Irish luck had combined to effect delivery of a cargo of aviation gasoline at a United States Army airfield on a South Seas island.

It is interesting to note that a persistent building manager in the Bronx has uncovered sixty tons of scrap steel all by himself. He ought to get up a committee to hunt scrap steel on farms all over the country. The quantity which could be collected would amaze the steel companies.

CHICAGO, Aug. 16 -- Prices of wheat continue to hold within relatively narrow limits, but there has been a minor change in sentiment recently, and many of the professional operators are now talking much less bearishly than a short time ago as the anticipated pressure from the movement of the new Spring wheat crop has failed to develop.
SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 16 -- A small navy patrol blimp landed today in a street in a residential area of Daly City, a peninsula community five miles south of San Francisco.

MOSCOW, Aug. 16 -- Russia's army in the Caucasus has not been led into a trap and is not trying to fight a tank war without tanks. Although it has paid a fearful price for its realism in rich Kuban soil and flourishing farming communities, the cost is as nothing compared with the total destruction of the Soviet forces that might have taken place on the southern steppes.

ALBANY, Aug. 16 -- The employment of thousands of workers in the canning industry boosted New York State's employment figures by 1.6 per cent, from the middle of June to the middle of July, according to a report made public today by Industrial Commissioner Frieda S. Miller.

PARRIS ISLAND, S.C., Aug. 16 -- "Joe Blow" and his brother "Boots" -- 12,000 strong -- are upholding the proud traditions of the Marine Corps at this recruit depot at Parris Island and at the new and growing fleet marine force training base at New River, N.C.

MOSCOW, Aug. 16 -- Russia's army in the Caucasus has not been led into a trap and is not trying to fight a tank war without tanks. Although it has paid a fearful price for its realism in rich Kuban soil and flourishing farming communities, the cost is as nothing compared with the total destruction of the Soviet forces that might have taken place on the southern steppes.

ALBANY, Aug. 16 -- The employment of thousands of workers in the canning industry boosted New York State's employment figures by 1.6 per cent, from the middle of June to the middle of July, according to a report made public today by Industrial Commissioner Frieda S. Miller.

PARRIS ISLAND, S.C., Aug. 16 -- "Joe Blow" and his brother "Boots" -- 12,000 strong -- are upholding the proud traditions of the Marine Corps at this recruit depot at Parris Island and at the new and growing fleet marine force training base at New River, N.C.

CENTRAL ISLIP, L. I., Aug. 16 -- demonstration of the work that the emergency medical services of Islip Township would be called upon to perform in an air raid was presented to the accomI paniment of simulated raid condii tions before a throng of 3,000 perI sons in the stadium of Central Islip State Hospital this afternoon.

PORTLAND, Me., Aug. 16 -Three Maine shipyards sent eight new seagoing vessels into deep water today in a series of ceremonies marking a new peak of activity in the renascent Down East shipbuilding industry.

BOMBAY, India, Aug. 16 (London Times Dispatch) -- The All-India Moslem League working committee met this morning under the presidency of Mohammed Ali Jinnah to consider the situation arising from the arrest of Mohandas K. Gandhi and other All-India Congress party leaders.

ALBANY, Aug. 16 -- An interesting feature of the Schedule of Investments comprising Part 2 of State Controller Joseph V. O'Leary's annual report was disclosed today with the announcement that on July 1 the State owned $4,600,000 in United States Government bonds as against $800,000 a year ago.

GARDEN CITY, L.I., Aug. 16 -- The Long Island amateur golf team finished first with 85 points in the triangular match for the benefit of the United Service Organizations at Cherry Valley today. The professionals took second place with 70 1/2, while the women trailed with 24 1/2.

PERU, Mass., Aug. 16 -- A large Army transport plane carried seventeen men to flaming death last night when it crashed on isolated, 2,200-foot Garnet Peak on Peru Mountain in one of the most inaccessible spots in the Berkshires.

There is a mistaken theory that cats and dogs, especially cats, can take care of themselves in the country, and a good many people who spend the Summer or part of it at the seashore or in the mountains, and have pets to enliven their vacation, leave the pets behind when returning to the city.
