The Brooklyn city prison is denounced as "a dead storage warehouse for human beings," its administration and personnel are criticized, and a series of recommendations are made, primarily urging the erection of a new prison building after the war, in a final report by the office of Special Prosecutor John Harlan Amen on the functions in Kings County of the city's Department of Correction.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Aug. 16 -- The German home front is faced with ever-fresh restrictions aimed at concentrating every activity in the war effort. Last week a decree prohibited factories from obtaining new machinery unless the old machines could not be replaced by second-hand machines from other plants.

The hourly and weekly earnings of industrial workers went up again in June, surpassing all previous records, the National Industrial Conference Board reported yesterday. Both in terms of dollars and cents and in terms of the purchasing power of their pay envelopes, workers earned more than in any other month, the board said.

Charles Evans Hughes Jr., chairman of the War Committee of the Bar of New York, announced yesterday that letters were mailed Saturday to the city's 25,000 lawyers to compile a "war service roll-call." Each letter contained a questionnaire to be filled out by the recipient, setting forth his present war activities and asking the extent to which each is available for additional war work.

A definite program for rationing of hot water in apartment houses, as part of a general plan for conservation of fuel oil, coal and steam, will be adopted by the city within the next week or so, Mayor La Guardia announced yesterday in his weekly radio "Talk to the People" broadcast from his desk at City Hall.

Mayor La Guardia will officially open the "Win-the-War Show" at 10 o'clock this morning in Hearn's Auditorium, Fifth Avenue and Fourteenth Street. There will be no admission charge and the show will be open daily, except Sunday, through Aug. 29, from 10 A.M. to 6 P.M., and until 9 P.M. on Thursday.
On his first official day as head coach at Fordham, Earl Walsh, successor to Sleepy Jim Crowley, did what any other head football coach does. He started to worry.

BROOKVILLE, L.I., Aug. 17 -- Three annual horse shows, which for several years have been outstanding events on the North Shore, will be merged this year in a single benefit program, it was announced today by Mrs. James A. Hewlett, president of the combined feature.

CHICAGO, Aug. 17 (AP) -- J. Loy Maloney, managing editor of The Chicago Tribune, and Stanley Johnston, a war correspondent for the newspaper, were granted permission today to appear tomorrow before a Federal grand jury investigating publication of alleged confidential naval information.

Mixed reactions to Mayor La Guardia's plan to ration hot water in apartment houses were expressed by realty men yesterday. Generally those owning apartment buildings, or in charge of their management, were in favor of the suggestion.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 -- Secretary of the Navy Frank Knox today sharply rebuked wildcat strikers at the Bayonne, N.J., plant of the General Cable Corporation for their "ill-advised defiance" of a National War Labor Board decision which forced seizure of the plant by President Roosevelt last week.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 (AP) -- A strong sentiment within the Senate for the Beardsley Rural "pay-as-you-go" income tax proposal was reported tonight by Senator Clark of Missouri, chairman of a finance subcommittee which is exploring expert opinion on the withholding tax provisions of the new revenue bill.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Aug. 17 -- With the sinking of five more ships, Brazil's total of vessels lost soared today to nineteen, all torpedoed by Axis submarines in circumstances that are held to show great Axis animosity for Brazil. This view is based on the facts that Brazil is not at war with the Axis and in the past has allowed Italian and Japanese ships to enter her ports to provision and refuel.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 17 -- Century Note, full brother to Twenty Grand but long considered a disappointment by admirers of the champion of 1931 made a bid for favor when he captured the Schenectady Purse before 6,562 persons today. In a three-horse race the 5-year-old son of St. Germans and Bonus was the outsider and paid $9.90 for $2.

With one mighty thrust of his bat yesterday at the Polo Grounds, Babe Barna hammered the Giants into their fifth straight victory. At the same time, the reliable Ace Adams moved a step nearer that fifty-six-game pitching mark for which he is involuntarily shooting and the third-place Giants moved four games ahead of the Reds.

HARTFORD, Conn., Aug. 17 -- As the trial of the Rev. Kurt E.B. Molzahn, Philadelphia clergyman, on charges of espionage conspiracy drew to a close, a government rebuttal witness, Henry Pfau, who formerly belonged to the German-American Bund, testified today that it was generally known, a sort of whispering campaign, that Pastor Molzahn was a silent member of the bund."

The survey of the nation's most important "cost of living" food commodities now being undertaken by the Office of Price Administration "is in no sense a check upon compliance," but an attempt to gather information in order to prevent "undue hardships," William H. Schwartz, regional supervisor of the food survey for OPA, declared yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 (AP) -- A government official said today that the War Man Power Commission would ask the War and Navy Departments and the Maritime Commission to put inspectors in "cost-plus" war production plants to break what he called a growing practice of "labor hoarding."

CHICAGO, Aug. 17 -- Despite a record production of meats in the first half of the year, a 3,000,000,000-pound shortage looms, and consumers are facing meatless days and the possibility of rationing, Roy F. Hendrickson. Administrator of the Agricultural Marketing Association, told the National Association of Meat Dealers here today.

CHICAGO, Aug. 17 -- Liquidation continued in the corn market today, especially in the September delivery and all futures sold at a new seasonal low, with the near-by month declining 1 1/2 cents to 83 1/2 cents, the lowest at which it had been quoted on the Board of Trade since April 30.

Supplementing its recent ruling that food wholesalers need not inform their retail outlets in writing of the increases in their prices allowed under the amendment to the Maximum Price Regulation covering canned fruits and berries, the Office of Price Administration is now working on a standard form to simplify the notification procedure, it was learned in the food trade yesterday.

Supplementing recent indications that another Latin American republic was on the verge of a full break with the Axis, Pradenas Munoz, former Minister of Labor in Chile, declared here yesterday that an announcement "of tremendous importance to both the United States and Chile" would follow the visit of President Juan Antonio Rios to this country.

CLEVELAND, Aug. 17 (AP) -- The Browns clubbed two Cleveland pitchers for eleven hits, including Walter Judnich's two-run homer in the ninth, to triumph by 5 to 2 over the Indians tonight in the finale of their three-game series.
" Walter Johnson pitching, Babe Ruth batting."

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 17 -- Graduation exercises for the first class of volunteer nurses' aides of the Hampton Chapter of the American Red Cross will be held on Friday afternoon at the Parrish Art Museum. Seventeen young women will receive their caps, pins and certificates.

After conferring yesterday with ten of the sixty-seven Welfare Department investigators dismissed by Mayor La Guardia, Daniel Allen, secretary-treasurer of the State. County and Municipal Workers of America, said the employes would appeal to the City Council to adopt the Mayor's amendments to the McCarthy Salary Increment Law.

ALBANY, Aug. 17 -- Drafting men for the Navy will complicate Selective Service work, Major Gen. Lewis B. Hershey, national director, said here today but he indicated that there was no immediate prospect of taking men under 20 years. Man power is no problem, he said.

The report of the Middle West Corporation for the second quarter of this year, issued yesterday, shows a consolidated net income after expenses, taxes and other charges, of $464,574. This was equal to 14 cents a share on the corporation's 3,307,302 shares of capital stock outstanding and compares with an adjusted net of $657,201, or 20 cents a share, in the June quarter of last year.

LONDON, Aug. 17 -- When the hotel phone rang the bedchamber was dark. The blackout curtains were tightly drawn, and they shut out all light. I felt for the telephone, got the receiver to my ear and mumbled a sleepy "Hullo!"

Only one-third of the insurance companies accredited to the War Damage Corporation have filed thus far the data pertaining to the bombardment insurance placed with the Federal agency through the Federal Reserve Bank here, with only three days left in which this action must be taken, it was learned in insurance circles yesterday.

With the arrival of more than 700 new men at the end of August, the Navy Reserve Midshipmen School, at Columbia University and aboard the U.S.S. Prairie State, 135th Street and Hudson River, will become one of the largest naval training centers in the country, it was announced yesterday.

LONG BEACH, L.I., Aug. 17 -- Clipping eight strokes from par, Mal Galletta and Ralph Leaf of North Hills won the one-day amateur-pro golf tournament of the Long Island P.G.A. with a best-ball score of 33, 31 -- 64 over the Lido Golf Club course today.

Indicating that August retail promotions of women's apparel began to "click" in most sections of the country last week, mail reorders reaching the wholesale markets here yesterday were the heaviest of the season thus far.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 17 -- For no reason that one could see unless it was that events over which they had no control kept them in this sweltering town an extra twenty-four hours the Yankees piled into the Athletics with surprising vehemence today while 15,000 looked on helplessly.
CHEYENNE, Wlo., Aug. 17 (AP) -- A six-man race for the Republican Senatorial nomination is the chief feature in Wyoming's primary election tomorrow at the end of a listless campaign.

WASHINGTON, Aug. l7 -- President Roosevelt issued a statement saying that the shift of the Fair Employment Practice Committee to the War Manpower Commission would strengthen its stand against discrimination in employment; he had no engagements.

Proposals of the New York Department of Commerce for organization of a New York City Coordinating Corporation to get war work and then subcontract the jobs to plants now idle won the approval yesterday of the New York Board of Trade.

MOSCOW, Tuesday, Aug. 18 -- The Russians acknowledged today that German troops in the Caucasus had succeeded in crossing the Kuban River at two points near Krasnodar, but indicated that the Red Army was holding firm in the Kletskaya area of the

BUENOS AIRES, Aug. 17 -- News of the sinking of three Brazilian ships caused the deepest impression in Buenos Aires when vague rumors to that effect, which have been circulating all day, finally were confirmed from Rio de Janeiro.

Government charges that Werner von Clemm conspired to violate President Roosevelt's order tying up assets of Belgian and Netherland nationals were characterized as flimsy technicalities yesterday by Harold H. Corbin, the importer's defense attorney.

HARTFORD, Conn., Aug. 17 -- The Hartford Bridge Commission stated today that the last span of the new Charter Oak toll bridge over the Connecticut River between Hartford and East Hartford has been placed in position and that the bridge would be open to traffic about Labor Day.
LONDON, Aug. 17 -- The week commenced cheerfully on the London exchanges. Tobacco, cotton and textile shares were strong features.

BOSTON, Aug. 17 -- Seizure by the government of the S.A. Woods Machine Company's plant here appeared certain tonight when the company rejected a demand of the War Labor Board for compliance with its contract order by 2 P.M. tomorrow.

ALBANY, Aug. 17 -- Oliver A. Quayle, president of Quayle Son, engravers, died this morning in the Memorial Hospital a few hours after he had been struck by an automobile in Menands. He was 73 years old and the father of Oliver A. Quayle Jr., who is general manager of the Democratic National Committee.

A recent trade paper ad placed by N.W. Ayer Son, Inc., to call attention to the special wartime advantages of using newspapers has been reprinted by the bureau of advertising, American Newspaper Publishers Association, and distributed for publication in member papers.

CAIRO, Egypt, Aug. 17 (U.P.) -- British planes, waging a relentless offensive against Axis supply lines behind the Egyptian front, have bombed another force of enemy power lighters off the African coast and have blasted a transport column in the desert, the Middle East Command announced today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 -- Speculation as to whether the Office of Price Administration would act before the end of this month to establish ceilings on beef and pork at the producers' levels was general here tonight on the eve of a meeting of the Food Requirements Committee of the Department of Agriculture.

The newly renovated five-story building on a plot 20 by 80 feet at 11 1/2-13 West Twenty-sixth Street was sold by Dewey Carver to Jean and Marie Scieller through E. Dornbrook, broker. The seller recently purchased the building from the estate of James D. Black.
SYDNEY, Australia, Aug. 17 -- The Solomon Islands are the extremity of one prong of the triple Japanese drive toward Australia, the two others being Timor and a part of New Guinea.
LONDON, Aug. 17 -- The Honorable Gerald Lascelles, nephew of King George VI, has been working since last April in a munitions plant in the northeast of England, it was learned today.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Aug. 17 -- Half a million people will be evacuated from the Danzig-West Prussian areas eastward because they cannot meet the specifications of the "thoroughbred German," the Berliner Boersen Zeitung stated today.

ROCHESTER, Aug. 17 -- Attorney General John J. Bennett Jr. and Senator James M. Mead, rivals for the Democratic nomination for Governor, addressed the State Federation of Labor as it opened its convention today and received courteous and warm receptions as they pleaded for support.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 (AP) -- Represenative Ramspeck of Georgia has headed off a move to raise funds among Democrats and Republicans in Congress to help finance his re-election campaign.

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 17 (AP) -- The Cardinals, playing hound to the Dodgers' exceedingly fleet hare, chopped another half game off idle Brooklyn's lead today by downing the Reds, 5 to 2. The victory, provided in the seventh by Johnny Hopp's triple after Marty Marion had doubled with two away, left St. Louis seven and one-half games behind the Dodgers.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 -- Consent for a uniform plan of partial blind selling of feature films in blocks of thirteen will be refused to major motion picture producers, Thurman Arnold, Assistant Attorney General in charge of anti-trust proceedings, stated today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 -- A hope that Senator Norris of Nebraska would be a candidate for a sixth term this Fall was expressed in the Senate today by Senator Lucas of Illinois. Mr. Lucas said he was sure he expressed the feelings of millions of Americans.

The Senate Finance Committee has pushed its way with considerable energy and dispatch through a mass of testimony on the new tax bill. Having before it a specific measure, rather than mere general proposals, it has received more factual testimony than was presented to the House Ways and Means Committee.

TEHERAN, Iran, Aug. 17 -- With the Fascist armies grinding their way through the wheat fields and the outskirts of the oil districts of the North Caucasus, the world's eyes are turning toward that portion of the map between Iran's capital, Teheran, and the Caucasus range.

LONDON, Aug. 17 -- Dispatches and other reports tonight from all parts of Europe seemed to indicate increasing resentment of and opposition to Nazi oppression in occupied lands and further cruelties and pressure in occupied territories.

LONDON, Aug. 17 -- A joint declaration of the imminence of a combined United States and British air offensive against the Nazis was made here today by Major Gen. Carl A. Spaatz, commander of the United States Army Air Forces in the European theatre, and Air Marshal Richard H. Peck, assistant chief of staff, of the British Royal Air Force.

BROOKLINE, Mass., Aug. 17 -- After a two-year lapse, the Longwood Bowl invitation tennis tournament was revived today at the Longwood Cricket Club, which gave up the national doubles championship to the West Side Tennis Club for the Forest Hills organization's jubilee.

Lack of steel will probably result, in another thirty or sixty days, in a complete shutdown on production of steel and enamel cooking utensils for civilian use, manufacturers said yesterday. They discounted the effect of the most recent amendment to their limitation order which restricts output to 70 per cent of that in the base period, saying that there was not enough steel on hand to make half that amount.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., Aug. 17 -- The Independent Committee of the Twenty-sixth Congressional District, formed to oppose the re-nomination and re-election of Representative Hamilton Fish Jr., issued a statement today announcing that it was disbanding, and calling for unified support of Ferdinand Hoyt of Beacon, the Democratic, nominee opposing Mr. Fish.

NEWARK, N.J., Aug. 17 (AP) -- Drives for four runs in the third and six in the ninth gave the cellar dwelling Rochester Red Wings an 11-to-4 decision over the league leading Newark Bears today in the opener of a five-game series.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 -- A Navy Department communique:

DETROIT, Aug. 17 (AP) -- Production of armaments by the automotive industry has reached the rate of $5,000,000,000 a year, Alvan Macauley, chairman of the Automotive Council for War Production, said today, and "at peak, assuming materials are available, the industry will be operating on a $12,000,000,000 annual basis."
PITTSBURGH, Aug. 17 (AP) -- Philip Murray, C.I.O. president, announced today the signing and ratification of a union contract with the Bethlehem Steel Company, covering about 80,000 employes.

MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, Aug. 17 (U.P.) -- Leaders of the Free Italian movement, which closed a three-day conference here last night, said today that a Free Italian Legion would be organized and trained in the United States, using arms solicited from the United States Government and bought by donations from Free Italians throughout the American countries.
The semi-annual report of the Insurance Company of North America shows total admitted assets of $111,429,704 on June 30 last, compared with $116,693,395 a year earlier.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Aug. 17 -- How American farmers are increasing production of food and fiber for civilian use, for the armed forces and for our Allies was described in detail today to a group of visitors at the State Agricultural Experiment Station, Rutgers University.

CAZENOVIA, N.Y., Aug. 17 -- Siegfried Langer and Thomas Mahon, Brooklyn players who were in a triple tie for first place in the Class A event at the New York State Chess Association meeting here, finished their adjourned game this morning. Langer won in seventy-five moves to take the tournament honors.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 -- The War Production Board's Compliance Branch reported today that no such "black market" for steel products existed as recently alleged by Frank Higgins, Louisiana shipbuilder, but said that deliveries of steel made to Mr. Higgins by some warehouses appeared to have violated Office of Price Administration regulations.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., Aug. 17 -- The new Hudson County Board of Taxation, installed in office over the determined opposition of the Democratic organization of Mayor Frank Hague, scored another legal victory today.

LONDON, Aug. 17 -- A vest-pocket naval battle occurred in the Strait of Dover last night when patrols of light British coastal forces encountered five or six enemy R-boats. Shore batteries in Kent opened up to contribute their share of victory in another one of a series of engagements bearing many marks of old-fashioned and almost hand-to-hand sea warfare.

Loew's Criterion reported yesterday that it would hold its current attraction "Invisible Agent," for a third and final week, beginning Wednesday. The Abbott and Costello comedy, "Pardon My Sarong," scheduled for this Wednesday will be deferred until next week.

ON THE BURMA FRONT, Aug. 17 -- The Japanese have retired from many villages and vantage points occupied when the main British Army left the Irrawaddy and Chindwin valleys last May. Active British offensive patrols have now pushed back the fluid front well within Burma for most of its length, justifying the date line of this story.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 -- Six hundred thousand children, most of them in the northeastern States, have been receiving free lunches all Summer as they romped in city playgrounds or spent a happy vacation at a near-by camp, the Agricultural Marketing Administration stated today.

Although metropolitan anglers have often contended that giant tuna should be taken off our New Jersey coast, nevertheless the spotlight has turned once more to Ipswich Bay for one of the best rod and reel catches of the season.
The residence containing twelve rooms and four baths at 47 Avon Road, in Bronxville, has been purchased by R.D. Jenkins from the Corn Exchange Bank Trust Company of New York.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 -- Americans who have had trouble proving that they were actually born and where and when will have no further trouble if they happen to have been among the 24,000,000 men who signed draft registration cards in 1917 and 1918.

Mayor La Guardia in person opened it, the Civilian Defense Director and the Secretary of the Navy sent their official approval and a number of United Nations governments, war and defense bodies and private organizations entered displays.

Even the oldsters wished they were college girls yesterday afternoon so that they might jump into the campus togs that were displayed with plenty of imagination by B. Altman Co. in the Charleston Gardens. Huge tomes served as background.

CHICAGO, Aug. 17 (AP) -- Frank Stranahan of Toledo, Don Armstrong of Aurora, Ill., and Wilford Wehrle of Racine, Wis., traversed the Knollwood golf course today in 71's, two under par, to share medalist honors in the Chicago national amateur tournament.

EAST HAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 17 -- Dr. and Mrs. Shepard Krech will open their home, Briar Patch, on Wednesday afternoon, Aug. 26, for the annual bridge and tea to benefit St. Luke's Episcopal Church here. The committee planning the benefit includes Mrs. Nathaniel Adams Campbell, Mrs. George L. McAlpin, Miss Edna Nash, Mrs. Percy Schenck, Mrs. Louis E. Vanderbilt, Miss Marie Halsted, Mrs. Charles S. Shoemaker and Mrs. Krech.

A good many people will side with Mr. F. Martin of Palisades, N.Y., in refusing to take seriously that extraordinary letter of Anthony Trollope. It turned up recently at a London book auction. Writing to a Miss Dorothea Sankey, the famous novelist begs to take time by the forelock.
A German High Command communique broadcast from Berlin and recorded here by The Associated Press:

Borough President James J. Lyons of the Bronx led a safari into Clason Point yesterday to determine the source of the malodorous gas that has caused nausea and rebellion among the residents. Later, Mr. Lyons gleefully announced that Walter Doherty, a chemist, had apparently solved the riddle.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 -- Sales of independent retailers were at about the same level last month as in July of 1941, according to preliminary data released by the Census Bureau today.

Although the Tammany executive committee adopted a resolution endorsing Senator James M. Mead for the Democratic nomination for Governor and Terence J. McManus, Mead committee chairman, indignantly denied that there was any thought of Senator Mead's withdrawal, it appeared yesterday to be increasingly probable that Attorney General John J. Bennett Jr. would be nominated at the State convention tomorrow.

CHICAGO, Aug. 17 -- Henry J. Kaiser, the West Coast construction expert, said here today that he was going to prove to the War Production Board that cargo planes could be built now. He accented the word "now."

Singing telegrams and fixed-text holiday and social greetings are going into the discard for the duration of the war under revised tariff schedules filed yesterday with the Federal Communications Commission by the Western Union and Postal Telegraph Companies. The death sentence for these types of messages becomes effective September 18 unless the FCC disapproves.

Sales of New York and Brooklyn department stores showed a decline of 7 per cent last week under the corresponding week last year, according to the report issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. For the preceding week the bank had noted a drop of 13 per cent in sales.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 -- The petition of the Independent Protective Committee for holders of the first mortgage bonds of the Florida East Coast Railway Company and the trustees of the estate of Alfred I. du Pont for reopening of the Florida reorganization proceedings was denied today by the Interstate Commerce Commission, but modifications of the plan were approved.

Sinking by Axis submarines of five more Brazilian passenger and cargo ships, including one that was carrying soldiers, was announced yesterday by the Brazilian Government at Rio de Janeiro, as our Navy Department announced two other sinkings, of a Panaman and a United States merchant ship.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 -- Specific Manufacturers' ceiling prices for the fifth group of cotton textile products so treated under Maximum Price Regulation No. 118 were provided today by the Office of Price Administration. The agency announced approximately 700 additional top prices stated in dollars and cents.

DETROIT, Aug. 17 (AP) -- Detroit's Mayor and the leaders of unionized labor took issue today with an account of this city's performance in the war production effort published in the current issue of Life magazine.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Aug. 17 -- The police arrested today a naturalized 53-year-old Russian emigre and his 18-year-old son on charges of communicating with a foreign power by means of a clandestine radio. Their names were reported as Michael Katz, an artist, and his student son, Lennart

WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 -- The Federal Power Commission reported today that the principal public utility systems of the country had consumed 14,764,914,000 kilowatt-hours of electrical energy during June, a 12.1 per cent increase over consumption in June, 1941.

Apropos your remarks recently concerning what to do with the children when the parents are off on war work, the following extract from a letter recently received may be of interest. The writer, who has two married sons and three married daughters, all doing war work of some kind, writes:

LONDON, Aug. 17 -- The much-debated questions of whether United States heavy bombers -- Flying Fortresses and Liberators -- are best for day operations or for night raiding and whether they can be adapted to both jobs or are ill-suited for intensive combat work will be settled by the test of active service.

Cotton prices held to narrow range in the futures market yesterday and closing quotations on the New York Cotton Exchange were 1 point higher to 1 point lower than Saturday's final level. Early softness disappeared as trade and local buying increased, but hedge offerings and liquidation tended to retard the recovery.
PAWTUCKET, R.I., Aug. 17 (AP) -- S.W. Shapoff's Mixer scored by two and one-half lengths today in the $1,500 Seekonk claiming purse at Narragansett Park.

The first issue of equipment trust certificates to be sold by the Wabash Railroad since its reorganization -- the first conventional financing of the kind it has authorized in years -- was purchased yesterday by a group headed by Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc.

LONDON, Tuesday, Aug. 18 -- Comment in the British press today hails Prime Minister Churchill's Moscow visit as a sign that the United Nations are rounding out their grand strategy that was started when Mr. Churchill conferred with President Roosevelt.

In one of the great crises of the war Mr. Churchill has visited Moscow, as he had twice previously visited Washington, for the purpose of direct personal consultation with the leaders of an Allied Government. No one will mistake the significance of the fact that his journey was made in an American Liberator bomber piloted by two young fliers from Florida and California.

WILLIAMSBURG, Va., Aug. 17 (AP) -- Dr. John Edwin Pomfret, 43, dean of the Senior College of Arts and Sciences and the Graduate School of Vanderbilt University, was elected president of the College of William and Mary, by the Board of Visitors today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 -- After more than an hour's debate today the Senate put over until Thursday consideration of a bill extending to all service men and women within the continental United States, including Alaska, the privilege of absentee registration and voting in Congressional elections in November.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 -- A conflict over whether Congress or the War Production Board should set up an office for technical research and development to help the war effort, developed today with the introduction by Senator Kilgore of West Virginia of a bill for the creation of an "Office of Technological Mobilization."

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Aug. 17 -- Twentieth Century-Fox has shelved its recently purchased series of "Blue Chip Haggerty" stories by Ray Milholland at the request of the government because the yarns are "too explicit in illustrating methods of sabotage."

LONDON, Aug. 17 (AP) -- The war decisions that the United States, Britain and Russia have reached in the Moscow conference of Prime Minister Winston Churchill and Premier Joseph Stalin were regarded by observers tonight as answers to the Soviet cry for "deeds, not words" from their allies.

NEW DELHI, India, Tuesday, Aug. 18 (U.P.) -- Police bullets have killed two more persons and injured forty-two others as rioting and arson flared anew in the second week of India's civil disobedience campaign, it was disclosed today.
MOSCOW, Tuesday. Aug. 18 (AP) -- The Soviet Information Bureau's communique early today:

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 17 -- A standard form for reporting the financial condition of any firm or company probably will be adopted in the near future, it was announced today by Ganson Purcell, chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, following a second conference held by representatives of the SEC and of the securities trade, which lasted two hours.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 -- The United States Government was reported today to have advised both the British Government and representatives of Mohandas K. Gandhi that it was desirous of helping both sides reach an agreement on the issues so that India might make her full contribution of the United Nations.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 -- The reorganization of the War Department's public relations agencies, announced last week by Secretary Stimson, was revealed in detail in a directive made public today.

AT AN AMERICAN BOMBER BASE in Britain, Aug. 17 -- Led in person by the chief of the Bomber Command of the United States Army Air Forces in this theatre, Brig. Gen. Ira C. Eaker, big American Flying Fortresses raided Nazi-held territory in daylight today and unloaded their heavy bombs on the railroad yards at Rouen, France.

FORT DES MOINES, Iowa, Aug. 17 (AP) -- Colonel Don C. Faith, commandant of the Training School of the Women's Army Auxiliary Corps, today named a 41-year-old grandmother -- who also is a granddaughter -- for his personal secretary as the first 180 Waac graduates took up regular duties on the post.

Two men were stabbed on a northbound Lexington Avenue IRT express train yesterday afternoon when they attempted to restrain a Negro who allegedly molested a woman passenger. Two other men who said they were Treasury agents overcame the Negro and turned him over to the police at Eighty-sixth Street, the next train stop.

Railroads of the country have broken all efficiency and performance records since Jan. 1 of this year, Colonel A. Robert Ginsburgh, public relations officer of the War Department's service of supply, informed delegates to the biennial convention of the Brotherhood of Railway Signalmen at the convention's opening session in the Hotel Pennsylvania yesterday.

Being myself an East Indian and a former member of the Bombay Legislature, I know that all Indians want freedom. India's national consciousness is the greatest gain India has had from British rule. Differences of opinion on the type and time of freedom only deepen India's eagerness for it.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 -- The Senate adopted and sent to the White House today a bill permitting immediate payment by the Army and Navy of dependency allowances to families of men in the armed services. A restriction in previous legislation that such payments should not be made until Nov. 1 was removed.

Speculative interest broke out afresh yesterday in the railroad issues to lead the stock market into irregularly higher ground. With a lull in the war news, except for the revelation of the Churchill flight to Moscow, and with the tax question in suspense for the week, traders seized on the strong earnings statements of the carriers and expected favorable dividend actions in support of their activity in the rails.
LONDON, Aug. 17 (AP) -- An Admiralty communique:

My husband is 33 and will, in all likelihood, be called for military service. We are expecting a baby very soon. It isn't a pleasant prospect to look forward to maintaining a home and bringing up a child alone. But this is war.

Having quite a number of assorted plays on hand, Mr. Saroyan is dedicating two to the opening of a new theatrical season, "Across the Board on Tomorrow Morning" and "Talking to You." He has cast them with good-natured impulsiveness, directed them in a comradely spirit and he is producing them with his own money at the Belasco, where they were acted last evening.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 -- Official Washington welcomed today the news that Prime Minister Winston Churchill of Britain and Premier Joseph Stalin of Russia had conferred in Moscow and reached new accords on war problems that grow graver every day as the Nazi armies push forward into the Caucasus, endangering Russia's southern supply line.

Robert Houston Jr. of Tupelo, Miss., 19-year-old member of the 4-H Club and the Future Farmers of America, has been selected as the winner of Victory Son of Elsie, bull calf of Elsie, the "glamour cow," it was announced yesterday by the American Jersey Cattle Club, 324 West Twenty-third Street.

The city of Youngstown, Ohio, will open tenders on Sept. 5 on a new issue of $91,000 bridge and park bonds at a rate not exceeding 3 per cent. The bonds will be dated Aug. 15, 1942, and will be due on Oct. 1, 1944 to 1963.

GARY, Ind., Aug. 17 -- Asserting that the task of the teacher in the present world crisis was no less important than that of the soldier, defense worker or farmer, Dr. George S. Counts, president of the American Federation of Teachers, today outlined what he said were five responsibilities resting on the educator during the war and in the post-war era.

WESTPORT, Conn., Aug. 17 -- Vivien Kellems officially announced her candidacy today for the Republican nomination for the Fourth District Congressional seat from Connecticut in an address before 200 Westport and Fairfield County Republican women at a box luncheon on the lawn of her home here.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 (U.P.) -- Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt no longer will tell the readers of her daily newspaper column about weather conditions. She has received a "very stern letter" on the matter.

AUCKLAND, New Zealand, Aug. 15 (Delayed) -- It is reported here that the land fighting in the Tulagi area of the Solomon Islands continues to go well. The positions held by American Marines, which are believed to include the most important establishments on the islands involved in the battle, have been consolidated, it is thought.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 -- Forty-six industrial plants have been selected to receive the new joint Army-Navy Production Award in recognition of outstanding performance on war work, according to Robert P. Patterson, Under-Secretary of War, and James V. Forrestal, Under-Secretary of the Navy.

Long practice in learning how to avoid the payment of reparations has taught Germany some clever tricks in how to collect them. The device employed in France has now become familiar, but each new detail of its workings is noteworthy. The general scheme has been not to levy any "reparations" as such for the present, but merely to collect the "costs" of the army of occupation.

CLEVELAND, Aug. 17 -- Members of the armed forces have made about 3,500,000 applications for national service life insurance with a face value of more than $18,000,000,000, the United Spanish War Veterans were told today by Brig. Gen. Frank T. Hines, administrator of veterans' affairs.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 (U.P.) -- Theodore Wozniak, a part-time grocery clerk who was a key figure in the explosion which wrecked the shell-loading plant at Kingsland, N.J., during the first World War, was held today by the Justice Department for a hearing to determine whether he should be interned for the duration of the war.

An Associated Press dispatch from Bombay yesterday brought further evidence, if it were needed, that the chief obstacle to a settlement in India at this time is not British stubbornness but Moslem separatism. The dispatch in question quoted Mohammed Ali Jinnah, president of the All-India Moslem League, as saying that "if the British now seek peace with the Congress [Gandhi's party] we would consider that a betrayal of the Moslems."

SUPERIOR, Wis., Aug. 17 -- Coach Steve Owen reached deep into his bag of tricks today and for the first time had his football Giants working on modified T formations during the daily double workout. It was the first time the New Yorkers used the complicated attacking system made famous by the champion Chicago Bears.

PITTSBURGH, Aug. 17 -- Threat of a strike in seven aluminum plants vital to the war effort was raised tonight with the announcement by N.A. Zonarich, president of the Aluminum Workers of America, C.I.O., that his union had rejected the decision of the War Labor Board, refusing to grant a wage increase in plants of the Aluminum Company of America.

NEW ORLEANS, Aug. 17 -- Paratroops, air-borne units, tank divisions, hard-hitting infantrymen, mechanized cavalry and the motorized gunners of the modern army are being conditioned, trained, organized and welded into combat units in scores of Army training camps throughout the South.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 -- The National War Labor Board today set 2 o'clock tomorrow afternoon as the deadline for compliance by the S.A. Woods Machine Company of Boston with the board's order to accept membership maintenance and arbitration clauses in a contract with the C.I.O. United Electrical, Radio and Machine Workers of America.

IT'S amazing how certain sports have been accented by war. Football, for instance. In ordinary times football, after the big bowl games have been played to start the New Year right, is something to put away and forget. Nobody bothers about the game again until late August, when the coach puts the wind back in the football and early punts may be seen flying overhead.

The State executive committee of the American Labor party last night selected the Hotel Capitol, Eighth Avenue and Fifty-first Street, for the party's State convention on Saturday. A meeting of the full committee will be held on Friday night.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 -- President Roosevelt took cognizance today of a large number of complaints from Negro and other organizations against the transfer of the Fair Employment Practice Committee to the War Manpower Commission.

Princeton University receives a scholarship fund of $100,000 under the will of Mrs. Edith Thomson Mann, filed for probate yesterday in Surrogates Court. Mrs. Mann, who died on May 19, left the sum for the establishment of the George Williamson Mann '72 Scholarship Fund, in memory of her late husband, a mining engineer and graduate of Princeton.
ALBANY, Aug. 17 (AP) -- The war is hitting New York's educational system hardest in the little red school house, where the "real danger" of teacher shortage lies this year.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in 101 leading cities, the Federal Reserve System announced today, shows the following principal changes for the week ended Aug. 12: Increases of $56,000,000 in holdings of Treasury bills, $50,000,000 in holdings of United States Government bonds, $62,000,000 in balances with domestic banks and $388,000,000 in demand deposits-adjusted, and a decrease of $248,000,000 in United States Government deposits.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 17 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission gave approval today to a plan by the Missouri Edison Company to issue and sell privately to the Connecticut Mutual Life Insurance Company $550,000 of its 3 3/4 per cent first mortgage bonds to be dated Jan. 1, 1942 and due Jan. 1, 1967, at an approximate price of 101.52.

BOMBAY, India, Aug. 17 (AP) -- Bands of demonstrators pulled down telephone and telegraph wires and burned a street car in Calcutta today, but quiet prevailed for the fourth successive day in populous Bombay as the issue of Indian independence appeared no nearer solution than it did a week ago.

A GULF COAST PORT, Aug. 17 (AP) -- Survivors of a small British merchant ship, torpedoed in the Caribbean on July 21 with a loss of five lives, reported upon landing here today that a Spanish ship passed close by their lifeboats soon after the sinking but ignored their pleas for help.

" SOVIET ASIA,"* by R.A. Davies and Andrew J. Steiger, carries with it a subtitle: "Democracy's First Line of Defense." Forgetting, for the moment, the ambiguous and highly confusing use of the word "democracy" to cover a one-party nation, one can see the strategic logic that lies behind the description. For certainly the democracies of England and the United States are depending utterly on the resources and the distances of Soviet Asia.
Dean Charles M. McConn of Washington Square College, New York University, has rented a large suite in the Fifth Avenue Hotel, according to one of the residential leasing reports received yesterday.

MOSCOW, Aug. 17 -- Prime Minister Winston Churchill of Britain has visited Premier Joseph Stalin of the Soviet Union at the request of the Soviet leader and held with him a series of conversations concerned with the future conduct of the war, a Soviet communique revealed today.

Fuel oil rationing on the Eastern seaboard "appears to be quite likely," W. Walter Timmis, chief of the plumbing and heating branch of the War Production Board, declared yesterday at a meeting of heating engineers and representatives of trade associations of the heating industry sponsored by the American Society of Heating and Ventilating Engineers. The meeting was held at the Hotel Pennsylvania as part of War on Fuel Waste Week.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 -- Control over the water-borne movement of oil to the Atlantic seaboard was taken by the Office of Defense Transportation today.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 17 -- Rear Admiral William C. Watts, retired, former commandant of the Fourth Naval District, warned war workers today to be on guard against enemy agents and saboteurs in order to maintain undiminished production records.
MOSCOW, Aug. 17 (AP) -- A Soviet Information Bureau communique:

AKRON, Ohio, Aug. 17 -- "The nation's tribute to the spirit of patriotism and production effort" was the citation given by the War Department in conferring upon the Firestone Tire and Rubber Company's Akron plant the Army-Navy "E" Production Award at Washington today.

The full moon will go into eclipse in the shadow of the earth during the night of Aug. 25-26, for five hours and thirty-two minutes. Weather permitting, the spectacle will begin at 9:02 P.M., Eastern war time, when the rim of the moon enters the penumbra, the outer and lighter portion of the earth's shadow.
Allied Mills, Inc. and its subsidiaries reported yesterday for the fiscal year ending with June, net profit of $1,602,629 after provision of $3,107,618 for Federal income and excess profits taxes.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 -- The hourly earnings and the average weekly pay of workers in manufacturing industries continued to rise during June although the length of the work week remained almost the same as in May, Secretary of Labor Frances Perkins reported today.

" The New 1V[oon," a romantic musical comedy in two acts by Oscar Hammerste' 1 2d, Frank Mandel and Laurence Schwab, with music by Sigrnund Romberg, will open tonight at Carnegie Hall, the third in a series of revivals being produced there this Summer by Josepia S. Tushinsky and Hans Bartsch.

ALBANY, Aug. 17 (AP) -- Two of the largest awards ever made by New York's Court of Claims were included today in $151,260 damages allowed on eleven claims in an automobile accident for which the State was adjudged responsible.

In the cheerful cafeterias of the Westinghouse Electric and Manufacturing Company there is something new, nourishing and delicious. It is a special sort of luncheon, a Health-for-Victory lunch, that seems at first glance to be a dinner in miniature.
Why do the bureaucrats -- high, middle and low -- persist in lecturing the American people and telling them they are too complacent when such is decidedly not the case?

CAIRO, Egypt, Aug. 17 -- Lieutenant William O'Neill of Seminole, Okla., American Army fighter pilot, who swam part of the way home from an air raid, said today he was anxious to have another crack at the German Air Force.

BERNE, Switzerland, Aug. 17 -- Under the heading "Documentation," Saturday's Osservatore Romano, the Vatican organ, deplores the spread of atheism in Germany by contrasting without comment the wills left by two soldiers killed in this war.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 -- Shore positions in the Solomon Islands that were stormed and taken from the Japanese by United States Marines operating under the protecting guns of warships of the United States Navy "have since been developed and are now well established," the Navy Department announced this evening.

The launching of two warships at Bath and six freighters at South Portland on Sunday marks another chapter in the long and fine history of shipbuilding in Maine. On the Kennebec in 1608 the Virginia was launched, the first ship built by Englishmen on this continent. In 1622 a shipyard was set up on Richmond Island. In 1778 John Paul Jones's Ranger, built at Kittery, got the first foreign salute given to the American flag.

In the first place, wheels are scarce these days. Forward-looking youngsters are no longer dismantling their roller skates, but are oiling and shining them carefully to provide more or less rapid transportation when school opens in the Fall.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Aug. 17 -- Westchester and Putnam Counties had their first surprise daytime alert this afternoon, entailing mobilization of all emergency workers not employed or on vacation elsewhere. The test was to have lasted a full hour in the entire area, but General Thomas W. Darrah, Deputy State Director of Civilian Protection, surprised the surprisers by visiting Mount Kisco and terminating the test in that village after twenty-one minutes.
LONDON, Aug. 17 -- Prime Minister Winston Churchill went to Moscow via Cairo, according to a Cape Town report today, to synchronize United Nations strategy with Russian necessity.

To the delight of the neighborhood youngsters, "Jumbo and His Pals" had an unrehearsed circus performance yesterday on the corner of Broadway and 178th Street. The unhappy ringmaster was Captain Rudy Muller, whose circus van got two flat tires after crossing the George Washington Bridge.

BLOOMFIELD, N.J., Aug. 17 -- Ira S. Kahn of the Murray Hill Country Club, Summit, N.J., led the New Jersey contingent of 164 contestants in The World-Telegram's eleventh annual hole-in-one tournament when he placed one of his five tries 5 inches from the pin on the newly constructed 135-yard special hole at the Forest Hill Field Club today.

KARACHI, India, Aug. 17 (AP) -- American troops stationed in India were molested during recent disturbances connected with Mahatmas K. Gandhi's passive resistance campaign for independence, Brig. Gen. Francis M. Bradley, their commander, said today.

MOSCOW, Aug. 17 (AP) -- Winston Churchill, Joseph Stalin and United States and British field and staff commanders met for four days in MOSCOW last week and reached secret decisions for turning back the Germans on a tremendous battle-ground, the United Nations disclosed today.
SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 17 -- An all-day search of land and sea left the Navy without a clue to the fate of two officers who vanished from a patrol blimp before it crashed in a street at Daly City.

Out of eye-witness stories, documents and photographs, a book that is designed to be a history, a source book and "a taste of the hell-broth of destruction" has been made up at Putnam's. It is "The Black Book of Poland," 600 pages telling the grim story of how the "New Order" came to that country.

NEWARK, N.J., Aug. 17 -- Herbert Karl Friedrich Bahr, 29 years old, formerly of Buffalo and an honor student in high school and college, charged with having conspired to commit espionage by giving United States war information to the German Gestapo, went on trial here today before Federal Judge William F. Smith and a jury.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 (AP) -- Commending broadcasters for "doing a marvelous job for the war effort," James L. Fly, chairman of the Federal Communications Commission, expressed confidence today that the radio industry's stability would be maintained despite shortage of tubes and other materials.

The action yesterday by the New England Telephone and Telegraph Company in reducing its quarterly dividend from $1.50 a capital share to $1.25 served again to focus attention on the dividend meeting scheduled for today by the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, parent concern of the Bell System.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 -- A Fundamental labor policy that women should be paid at the same rate as men for equal work in war industries, recommended to the War Labor Board by a panel studying pay increases for General Motors employes, is hailed by the Women's Bureau of the Department of Labor as "a great victory."

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 18 (AP) -- The Securities and Exchange Commission dismissed today its proceedings against trustees of the Associated Gas and Electric Corporation and Gilbert Associates, Inc., a service company which has agreed to sever financial ties with the holding company system.

CHICAGO, Aug. 18 -- John A. Witherspoon, retiring president of the National Association of Life Underwriters, said today he was optimistic that the new Federal income tax laws would be favorable toward buyers of life insurance. The association is holding its fifty-third annual meeting in the Edgewater Beach Hotel.

The largest gift ever received by the Navy Relief Society was announced yesterday. It was $300,000, and the donor was Harold S. Vanderbilt, who received the money from the government following the taking over of his new 117-foot motor sailer Vagrant.

The Knitgoods Workers Union, Local 155, International Ladies' Garment Workers Union, announced yesterday that its negotiations for a new contract with the United Knitwear Manufacturers League, Inc. had reached a deadlock, and that the union membership had authorized the leaders "to take all measures necessary so that they receive enough to be able to meet the increased cost of living."

LONDON, Aug. 18 -- Norway's schools are to open tomorrow under a Quisling decree, but there is not room in the schools for the country's 400,000 children because most of the buildings have been converted into German barracks and hospitals for German wounded from the Eastern front.

Whatever may be the progress of wartime sacrifice in other sections of the economy, the corporation stockholder is certainly taking a stiff cut in income these days. The financial pages have lately carried the news of dividend reductions by Chrysler Corporation from $1 to 75 cents, Eastman Kodak from $1.50 to $1.25 and Goodyear Tire and Rubber from 37 1/2 cents to 25 cents a share.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 18 -- Mrs. Payne Whitney and her son John Hay Whitney divided honors today, when the main event was the memorial race for William Collins Whitney, who began the family racing dynasty. The $6,725 Whitney Stakes, run for the fifteenth time, saw Mrs. Payne Whitney's Greentree Stable run one, two, with Swing and Sway leading Corydon by five lengths.

CHICAGO, Aug. 18 -- Construction activity at the Gary site of what was to have been the nation's largest synthetic rubber plant came to a sudden halt today after announcement by the operator of the projected $90,000,000 plant that it had been deferred because supplies of raw material had been found elsewhere.

The risk that motorists who have not yet bought their Federal use tax stamps are running was dramatized in Brooklyn yesterday when summonses were handed to 284 drivers of automobiles not bearing stamps. These drivers, unless they appear at the Brooklyn Federal Building Friday morning, with their $5 tax stamps, face penalties of thirty days in jail, a fine of $25, or both.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 (U.P.) -- Attorney General Biddle and J.E. Murdock, chairman of the Board of Tax Appeals, warned the Senate Finance Committee today that a provision of the House tax bill exposes millions of new taxpayers to racketeers posing as tax experts.

Harry J. Fishbein, 44 years old, of 105 West Seventy-third Street, an internationally known contract bridge player, was arrested on a charge of maintaining a gambling place last night when he admitted that he was the proprietor of the Mayfair Bridge Club at 119 West Fifty-seventh Street.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 (AP) -- Scrap rubber collected in the recent country-wide drive is moving to central receiving depots and rubber-reclaiming plants at the rate of 4,000 tons a day, the War Production Board said today.

After four months of fruitless negotiations, officials of the Dutch officer and seamen unions yesterday morning notified the Netherlands Government that 500 members had voted Monday night to refuse to take their ships to sea until an agreement on present working conditions was reached and assurance was given on post-war economic status and social security.

LENOX, Mass., Aug. 18 -- Carr V. Van Anda, former managing editor of THE NEW YORK TIMES, has sold his Summer home, The Mount, with 155 acres, at Lenox, to Foxhollow School, Miss Aileen M. Farrell, proprietor. The Mount, which was developed in 1902 by the late Edith Wharton, novelist, adjoins the present Foxhollow School grounds and Miss Farrell will have a total of 365 acres with half a mile frontage on Laurel Lake.

Stocks climbed yesterday to their best levels in more than a month as a week of limited buying in the railroad issues on the Stock Exchange suddenly expanded and culminated in some aggressive bidding. Gains of 1 to 2 points were prominent through the list, while volume crossed the half-million-share mark, also for the first time in more than a month.

MOSCOW, Aug. 18 -- The big new German push in the Don bend to break through the strongly consolidated Russian defensive positions in the hills just west of the river, which was launched a few days ago, is failing to make appreciable headway though the defenders are outnumbered, according to reports available here today.

CHUNGKING, China, Aug. 18 (U.P.) -- Chinese troops have smashed Japanese attempts to gain complete control of the important Hangchow-Nanchang railway and are holding firmly to Hengfeng and Iyang, railway towns in Eastern Kiangsi Province, a military spokesman said today.

Jane Engel opened a new floor in her shop at Madison Avenue and Seventy-ninth Street yesterday with a press preview of 125 of her new Autumn costumes. Some of the suits, coats, furs and sportswear that will occupy the new quarters were included in the show, in addition to a collection of bright-colored L-85 costume suits and a group of "furlough" dinner gowns and evening dresses.

German military spokesmen said last night that the war in South Russia had entered a new phase, that of mountain hostilities, and that for the time being the trend of the Axis offensive would be obscured by official silence, according to Berlin broadcasts recorded by The United Press in New York.
LONDON, Aug. 18 (AP) -- An Admiralty communique:

The sudden outburst of submarine sinkings in the South Atlantic which has driven Brazil to the verge of war with the Axis and the decline of U-boat activity off our own east coast are two phases of a single campaign. German and Italian undersea boats have apparently been driven into less perilous waters, with the result that Brazilian shipping is now suffering the same destruction which we seemed helpless to stop even a month ago.

Preparations for the possibility of an enemy air raid were extended as far inland as Ohio for the first time last night as New Jersey and Pennsylvania joined in a two-State surprise blackout and air raid drill.

Responding to an appeal by Donald M. Nelson, chief of the War Production Board, that companies and individuals sell typewriters of defined specifications to meet the urgent needs of the government, the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company yesterday turned over to the WPB and the Treasury Department 410 business size typewriters.
Werner von Clemm, 44 years old, a United States citizen of German birth, was convicted in Federal court yesterday of conspiring with the German High Command. The jury was out ninety minutes.

AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, Australia Aug. 18 -- The successes thus far achieved in the Solomons battle are sufficient to raise again the question of a unified command in this theatre of war. That question first was raised when General Douglas MacArthur came out of the Philippines, and it was solved then by the geographical method.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Aug. 18 -- The presence of Norwegian General Steffans at the Moscow conference has attracted particular attention here, where the meeting as such was no surprise because of Axis propaganda since the beginning of this month giving advance publicity to the event.

LONDON, Aug. 18 -- The latest upheaval in Europe's population, as planned by the Nazis, is expected to be the shipment of half a million Poles out of Pomerania. Polish quarters here predict that the migration will begin in the Autumn and will coincide with an order forbidding the use of the Polish language in the Gau of Danzig and West Preussen.

The Aviation Corporation, manufacturer of military and naval aircraft, airplane engines, propellers and precision parts, announced yesterday in the semi-annual statement covering the six months ended on May 31 a consolidated net profit of $2,478,291 after all charges and estimated Federal taxes, which includes income from dividends and profit realized on the sale of securities.

CHICAGO, Aug. 18 (AP) -- The veteran Don Armstrong of Aurora, Ill., one of yesterday's co-medalists in the Chicago national amateur golf tournament, fell by the way today, but the other two medalists and defending champion Ray Billows of Poughkeepsie, N.Y., raced into third-round play.

PATERSON, N.J., Aug. 18 -- Army-Navy "E" pennants signifying excellence in war production work were awarded today to each of the five plants of the Wright Aeronautical Corporation in the Paterson area as employes of the company heard their achievements praised as "one of the truly great performances in the whole war production program."

JERSEY CITY, N.J. Aug. 18 (AP) -- Jersey City and Buffalo divided a twilight-arc double-header tonight, the Little Giants taking the opener, 2 -- 0, while the Bisons came back to notch the nightcap, 3 -- 1.

The end of Summer hove into sight yesterday for New York City's 1,000,000 school children and 35,000 teachers. At the direction of Dr. John E. Wade, Superintendent of Schools, posters were displayed at all the public school buildings announcing that the schools would reopen on Monday, Sept. 14.
The four-story walk-up apartment house on a plot 110 by 100 feet at 32-05 Eighty-first Street, Jackson Heights, L.I., was sold by Charles Walzer, operator, to an investor.

CHICAGO, Aug. 18 -- Liquidation was on again in corn today on the Board of Trade, continuing the movement that started about two weeks ago, and all deliveries sold at new low prices for the season, with September at 82 3/8 cents a bushel at one time, off 9 1/8 cents in about a month and the lowest level at which any future has sold in about nine months.
MOSCOW, Aug. 18 (AP) -- A Soviet Information Bureau communique:

Acknowledging that the collection of steel and iron scrap has failed thus far to keep pace with the gathering of such material by the individual householder, and especially by the farmer, the War Production Board reveals that a well-integrated and nation-wide program to perform this necessary function is now under way.

Among the apartment leases reported yesterday was one for twelve rooms in 10 Gracie Square signed by Rene Faure, director of the Grand Central School of Art, through Douglas Gibbons Co., agents, and Butler Baldwin, Inc., brokers.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 18 -- Taking the stand that he was "technically wrong but morally right," Dewey Mead, business agent for Painters' Local 1158 and a member of the San Francisco Board of Supervisors, sent thirty union painters to near-by Sausalito today to work on a Federal housing project on which members of San Rafael Painters' Local 83 had struck.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Aug. 18 -- A large collection of vocal phonograph records of leaders in letters, politics and the theatre has been given to Yale University by Robert Vincent of New York, a sound engineer formerly on the staff of the Radio Corporation of America.

BUENOS AIRES, Argentina, Aug. 18 -- The state of siege in Argentina, which forbids any discussion of international affairs, prevents the principal newspapers from commenting on the sinkings of Brazilian ships by submarines. Nevertheless the spokesmen for all political parties condemned such methods of war and predicted that unrestricted submarine warfare, even if it excluded Argentina, would create difficult problems for President Ramon S. Castillo.

GARY, Ind., Aug. 18 -- American education has been "too soft" and has not developed the mental discipline needed in military and naval leadership, in the opinion of Lieut. Col. Frederick E. Swanson, executive officer of internal security in the Illinois area, a speaker today at the convention of the American Federation of Teachers.

TRENTON, Aug. 18 -- Governor Charles Edison looked into the future today and said he saw a "possible solution" to completion of the inland waterway from Corpus Christi, Texas, to New York and to the Great Lakes via the Hudson River through the construction of a railroad across New Jersey to haul vessels overland from Bordentown, N.J., on the Delaware River, to Morgan, on Raritan Bay.

The Nova Scotia tuna season has been officially opened with the taking of a 496-pounder on rod and reel by a visiting angler, Dr. M.S. Bennett, who fished from Wedgeport Dr. Bennett required fifty-five minutes to land the fish and his party of four reported seven strikes in all.

The Fifty-fifth Street Playhouse, closed for several months, will be reopened on Aug. 28, according to Thomas V. Billings, owner of the house. He said the program policy on which the theatre will operate will be made known in a few days. . . . Orson Welles's "The Magnificent Ambersons" will be held over at the Capitol for a second week, beginning tomorrow.
The three-story brownstone rooming house containing fifteen rooms at 59 South Oxford Street, Brooklyn, was leased by E.L. Blackman to a client of the Bulkley Horton Company, brokers.

LONDON, Wednesday, Aug. 19 -- The Commandos raided the Dieppe area of occupied France early today, British Combined Operations Headquarters announced. A bulletin said that the operation was still in progress.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 -- The War Production Board received a recommendation from its food requirements committee today that the government allocate supplies of meats among butcher shops, stores and other retail outlets in a move to assure equitable distribution of limited supplies.

General Sir Harold R.L.G. Alexander, new British commander in chief in the Middle East, went over the top thirty times during the last war before he was wounded. He was promoted to major at the age of 25 and a year later to lieutenant colonel.

NEWARK, N.J., Aug. 18 (AP) -- The cellar-dwelling Red Wings held the league-leading Bears to an even break in a twilight double-header tonight. After losing the seven-inning opener, 7-0, the Wings came back with a 5-4 decision in the second tilt, limited to seven innings when the power in two light poles failed thirty-eight minutes before the 8:50 dimout deadline and could not be adjusted immediately.

Forty-six outmoded guns, a tank and some heavy ammunition which has been decorating public squares land parks throughout the city were designated yesterday by Park Commissioner Robert Moses for the city's metal salvage collection.

TUCKAHOE, N.Y., Aug. 18 -- One hundred and ninety-four Westchester contestants tried their luck on the picturesque downhill, tree-guarded 155-yard tenth hole at Leewood today as the eleventh annual World-Telegram hole-in-one tournament was brought to a close. The 1-foot 10-inch shot by Andrew A.H. Thompson, New York attorney, veteran of forty years in golf, was the best for the day.

HARTFORD, Conn., Aug. 18 -- Just before adjournment this afternoon of the espionage conspiracy trial of the Rev. Kurt E.B. Molzahn of Philadelphia, Joseph P. Cooney, assistant district attorney, told the Federal jury of eight men and four women that it was their duty in view of the evidence to convict the defendant.

WASHINGTOIN, Aug. 18 -- Representatives of the United States Steel Corporation and the United Steel Workers of America argued before the War Labor Board today the application of the board's "Little Steel" decision to the 250,000 employes of "Big Steel."

Though the latest Navy communique fails to bring the thirteen-day-old Battle of the Solomons completely up to date, it resolves all doubt that the first phase of the action has ended in a victory for our forces both on land and sea. The shore positions taken by our Marines in the early stages of the fighting "have since been developed and are now well established."

The vigorous discussion of the new tax bill is comprehensible and desirable, all the more because it aims at, and must achieve, two different ends: first, to cover as much as possible the tremendous Government expenditure without killing the goose that lays the golden eggs; second, to combat inflation.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 -- The cost of food to consumers continued to advance from mid-June to mid-July, with the price of foods not covered by the general price ceilings rising much faster than the average. Acting Commissioner Hinrichs of the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported today.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Aug. 18 -- In a new move to bring about the dissolution of Greek letter fraternities and sororities at the White Plains High School, members of the local board of education met secretly last night and approved a resolution barring students who join such organizations from all extra-curricular activities after Sept. 1.
A High Command communique broadcast from Rome and recorded here by The Associated Press:

CHICAGO, Aug. 18 (AP) -- Prices for hogs dropped today 10 to 15 cents a hundredweight. The top quotation fell from yesterday's $15.30, best in twenty-two years, to $15.15. Big packers took 3,500 head direct.

BOMBAY, India, Aug. 18 (AP) -- This tenth day since Mohandas K. Gandhi and his associates were arrested in advance of formally launching their civil disobedience campaign found India spotted with riotous outbreaks and closed stores, plus some evidence that violence was abating in some sections under strict military and police control.
LEESVILLE, La., Aug. 18 -- The days that will shake the world and will determine, not alone the duration of the war but the course of future history, are now entering their climatic phase.

Criticism of and protest against the acts of Government remain, even in wartime, the rights of a free people. Defiance of Government authority is something quite different, especially in matters connected with the war effort. The S.A. Woods Machine Company of Boston has every right to protest against the ruling of the National War Labor Board that it accept, contrary to its principles, membership maintenance and arbitration clauses in a union contract.

LONDON, Aug. 18 -- Industrial, oil and diamond shares were good features today in the stock markets, which were stimulated generally by the conference of Prime Minister Winston Churchill with Premier Joseph Stalin in Moscow.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 (AP) -- Failure to use alcohol manufactured from farm products, Representative H.P. Fulmer, chairman of the Agriculture Committee, declares "selfishness and greed on the part of certain monopolists."

MONTREAL, Aug. 18 (AP) -- Negotiations have collapsed for the transfer of Schoolboy Rowe, veteran pitcher, and First Baseman Babe Dahlgren from the Brooklyn Dodgers to their Montreal farm in the International League, Montreal officials said today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 -- Recommendations that the War Production Board develop a program for the allocation of meat supplies regionally and that the OPA formulate "as rapidly as possible," a procedure for rationing meats to consumers were made by the WPB's food requirements committee, called into special session here today to consider the problem.

LONDON, Aug. 18 (AP) -- Prime Minister Churchill had a long conversation with General Charles de Gaulle, leader of the Fighting French, in Cairo recently, the Fighting French Press Service announced today. It said the conversation was "most cordial and covered all subjects relative to French-British cooperation in the Middle East."

ELYRIA, Ohio, Aug. 18 (AP) -- Patrolman Howard Taft, 29-year-old policeman, and a Cleveland Negro were killed tonight in a gun battle which led to the discovery of the body of a white woman in the trunk compartment of the Negro's car.

The Working Committee of the Moslem League discussed yesterday a draft resolution authorizing its president, Mohamed Ali Jinnah, to find out from Mohandas K. Gandhi whether or not the All-India Congress party would join the Moslem League in forming a national war government, and would accede to the division of India into Hindu and Moslem States after the war, the British Broadcasting Corporation reported in a broadcast recorded by the Columbia Broadcasting System.

Charles Hunt, 57 years old, a Negro, was released in $2,500 bail by Magistrate Bromberger in Felony Court yesterday on charges of having stabbed two white men Monday afternoon in an uptown Lexington Avenue subway train after they had protested against his alleged insult to a white woman.

The Merchant Truckmen's Bureau of New York yesterday rejected as "preposterous" the demands of three locals of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters for a new contract which the trucking interests estimated would involve wage increases of 40 per cent.

PAWTUCKET, R.I., Aug. 18 (AP) -- The Circle S Stables' Wise Father won the $1,600 Cape Cod Purse at Narragansett Park today after surviving a claim of foul lodged against him by Jockey Ted Atkinson, rider of the Reynolds Brothers' Fly Ty.

CINCINNATI, Aug. 18 (AP) -- Johnny Lanning gave the stumbling Reds another push tonight as the Pirates took a 3-to-0 victory before one or the smallest night crowds of the season. The Reds are now five games behind the third-place Giants.

That prolific writer of the publishers' lists and of Hollywood, Stephen Longstreet, who also has doubled as Thomas Burton, is reported to have taken on a third writing name. Mr. Longstreet is perhaps best known for his novel "Decade," published by Random House in February, 1940.
A High Command, commuque broadcast from Berlin and recorded here by The Associated Press:

PRINCETON, N.J., Aug. 18 -- A comprehensive survey to determine what the British public thinks of Americans has just been completed by the British Institute of Public Opinion. The results, reported in The London News Chronicle and passed through British and American censorship, reveal that while the majority of Britishers with opinions have a pro-American attitude, slightly more than one-fourth do not look on Americans with favor or are critical of us.

KEARNY, N.J., Aug. 18 -- The Western Electric Employes Association announced on March 26 that it had called off an order to its members to strike at midnight the following day at the huge Western Electric plant here and at five branch plants after receiving word from Washington that Secretary of Labor Frances Perkins had certified the wage dispute between the independent union and the management to the War Labor Board.

The tentative draft of a platform to be submitted today to the Democratic State Convention at at the Hotel St. George in Brooklyn was completed last night by a special pre-convention committee headed by Lieut. Gov. Charles Poletti.

The six-story apartment building at 520 West 218th Street has been conveyed by the 520 West 218th Street Realty Corporation to Electra Estates, Inc., for cash above a mortgage of $230,000, in a deal negotiated by Isaac Portman, broker. Jerome L. Greene was attorney for the seller and Bernard Margolis represented the purchaser.

AKRON, Ohio, Aug. 18 -- With praise from Secretary Morgenthau, representatives of labor and management in the rubber and allied industries joined today to start the first joint war-bond campaign on a national scale.

SEATTLE, Aug. 18 -- Declaring that women who take their war jobs "lightly" will be "weeded out," H.O. West, executive vice president of the Boeing Aircraft Company plants here, indicated to fifteen women correspondents today that it might be necessary to segregate women from men workers.
MOSCOW, Wednesday, Aug. 19 (AP) -- The midnight communique:

MOSCOW, Aug. 18 (UP) -- The Communist party newspaper Pravda today summed up Soviet reaction to the British-American-Russian conferences here with the assertion that the talks "constitute a great political defeat for Hitlerite Germany."
WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 -- Regulation of residential rents in thirty-eight more defense areas was proclaimed today by the Office of Price Administration. Rents are frozen as of March 1, this year.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 -- A committee to discuss means of stopping the drafting of coal miners into the Army and their exodus to other industries has been appointed by Harold L. Ickes, in his capacity as coordinator of solid fuels.

A 17-year-old Negro, charged with attempting to "mug" two plainclothes policemen who permitted themselves to be "lured" into a darkened tenement hallway, was shot and seriously wounded at 74 West 118th Street early today, as the police drive on Harlem crime resulted in its second shooting within twenty-four hours.

CAIRO, Aug. 18 (U.P.) -- A. British Middle East command communiqu6 today said ground operations in the desert had been at a stand-still since Sunday night and that air activity over the battle area had been restricted. Three enemy fighters were sald to have been shot down over 1VEaita.

Forty associations switched their conventions to New York this year when it was found that there was shortage of hotel and transportation facilities in the cities where the meetings were originally scheduled to be held, the convention and visitors bureau of the Commerce and Industry Association of New York reported yesterday.

Calling upon the Truman Committee to investigate the reason why the Stanley Plan, which facilitates bringing prime and subcontractors together on war work, is being confined by the War Production Board to the Chicago area, the American Business Congress in a telegram to the committee yesterday declared that this week's Stanley directory on contract possibilities lists mostly Chicago contractors and only a few in Detroit, New York and Cleveland.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 -- As a result chiefly of the difficulty involved in renegotiating cost-plus-fixed-fee contracts which were substituted for the pre-war tender system to speed up war production, the Army, Navy and Maritime Commission now plan to replace these in turn by fixed-price contracts which might be described paradoxically as "negotiated bids."

Two motion picture companies that were victims of the extortions practiced by George E. Browne and Willie Bioff, convicted union officials, faced yesterday a novel damage suit arising out of the case. Members of a local affiliated with the international formerly dominated by Browne and Bioff filed suit in Supreme Court for more than $3,000,000 allegedly lost in wages as a result of acceptance by the two former union leaders of "bribes" from the companies.
ST. LOUIS, Aug. 18 (AP) -- The Cardinals jumped on Claude Passeau early tonight for a 5-to-0 victory over the Cubs.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 18 -- Plans were formulated at a meeting held this morning in the apartment of Countess Mercati at the Irving for an unusual entertainment entitled "An Auspicious Autumn Festival," to be given on the afternoons of Sept. 1 and 2 in the terraced gardens of Shelmar House, the home of Francis H. Markoe in Water Mill.

CHICAGO, Aug. 18 -- Government demands for meats may take as much as 50 per cent of the available supply of pork and more beef before the year is out, and hotels and restaurants will do well to consider new and more varied meat menus, George M. Lewis, marketing director of the American Meat Institute, told a convention of the International Stewards and Caterers Association today.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., Aug. 18 -- The fifteenth annual tournament for the metropolitan husband-and-wife golf championship was won at the Bonnie Briar Country Club today by Mr. and Mrs. Reinert M. (Ray) Torgerson of Lakeville, who tied their own record score with 38, 36 -- 74, three over regulation figures.

LONDON, Aug. 18 -- British submarine successes in the Mediterranean and off the coast of Norway, announced today by the Admiralty, included he torpedoing and damaging of two cruisers and the sinking of five supply ships, of which two at least were "big ones."

Now that subway riders must content themselves with a maximum of two foot-candles at seat-level and the Army has decided that the emission of light through car windows must not exceed one-quarter of a candle, we have become aware of the enormous strides made in illumination since we relegated gas to the kitchen stove.
