Even though the volume of business on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday was estimated to have been the smallest in several months, the market fluctuated moderately above the previous close and finished the day 7 to 11 points higher than Monday's final quotations.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 18 -- More than $4,000 in war bonds and stamps were purchased in a rally last night in Congress Park after the dedication by Mayor Addison Mallory of the city's Roll of Honor of 630 men in the armed forces.

The sinking of two British merchant vessels, one small and the other medium-sized by torpedoes from submarines off the northern coast of South America last month was announced by the Navy Department yesterday. Four persons were lost and 124 were saved.

BERNE, Switzerland, Aug. 18 -- The slight official or semi-official reaction in France to Prime Minister Churchill's visit to Moscow follows the line that might have been expected -- that it is a harbinger of disaster, like the British Premier's former trips overseas. This, of course, reflects the German view.

There are still a few confirmed pessimists who apparently believe that the sun will stop spinning about its accustomed orbit on the day when they catch a snag in their last pair of nylons. "Socks from bottles are all very well in the Summertime," they say, "but what will we do when Winter comes?"

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Aug. 18 -- Katharine Cornell will make her first screen appearance in "Stage Door Canteen," which Sol Lesser will produce for United Artists, the company announced today. Besides Miss Cornell, Katharine Hepburn, Kay Kyser and Edgar Bergen have agreed to appear in the picture, according to U.A.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Brazil, Aug. 18 -- Replying to demands for war against Germany and Italy, shouted by an angry crowd in front of his palace today, President Getulio Vargas promised that his government would "act energetically against the criminals."

The magic in the sinewy left arm of Carl Hubbell exerted another spell over the Braves at the Polo Grounds yesterday as the amazing screwball veteran spun off a gaudy six-hitter for his eighth victory in a row. Hub really makes it look easy and the Giants batted robustly behind him for a 10-2 triumph, their sixth in succession.

Your editorial "India's Revolt Hangs Fire" is wholly predicated upon the theory of racial equality. You say that British magnanimity can "end forever, in law and practice, all assumptions of racial inferiority."

The memorable run of "This Is the Army," Uncle Sam's successful venture into show business for the benefit of the Army's Emergency Relief Fund, will come to an end -- as far as New York is concerned -- at the Broadway Theatre on Saturday night, Sept. 26, the final extension of four weeks having just been ordered by the powers-that-be, it became known in Washington yesterday.

Rising to a new peak, merchandise inventories of New York City department stores at the end of July were 88 per cent above those of the corresponding period last year, according to the report issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. Sales of these stores showed an increase of 1 per cent for July over 1941 and of 9 per cent for January through July.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 -- To three Navy officers has been awarded the Distinguished Flying Cross by the Army for their part in the aerial rescue of Army fliers who were stranded late in June on the treacherous ice cap of interior Greenland.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 -- The General Electric Company, the Westinghouse Electric and Manufacturing Company and more than 100 public utilities companies were accused today by John W. Walker, Justice Department attorney, of operating together to retard the development of fluorescent lighting throughout the country because it requires only one-third to one-half the current required for incandescent lighting.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Aug. 18 -- Victory in the war and restoration of unity in organized labor must be the two chief objectives of the trade union movement in this country, George Meany, secretary-treasurer of the American Federation of Labor, told the convention of the State Federation of Labor today in an address in which he called for increased production for the armed forces and assailed the Communists as agitating for a second front.

The general death rate in New York City last week fell to 7.8 per 1,000 population, the lowest weekly rate this year so far, Health Commissioner Ernest L. Stebbins reported yesterday. The average for the year to date is 10 per 1,000 population.

Hats for milady's "unregimented hours" were presented yesterday morning at the Autumn showing of Henri Bendel, 10 West Fifty-seventh Street. In the absence of slightly gaudly colors and severe lines, the salon showed a determination to create becomingness and naturalness.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Aug. 15 (AP) -- Urging an accelerated fire prevention campaign, James J. Higgins told the State Firemen's Association convention today, "it is almost treason to have a fire at this time."

CHUNGKING, China, Aug. 18 (U.P.) -- P.S. Foo, Chinese Vice Minister of Foreign Affairs, predicted today that the "epoch-making" battle of the Solomons "will inevitably force Japan to revise her plans for continental aggression as they stood Aug. 7."

CHUNGKING, China, Aug. 18 -- "With the Japanese jackal howling by the side of India and Nazi paws already reaching into the Caucasus, both Britain and India should awaken to realities," the newspaper Ta Kung Pao said today.

The Board of Higher Education requested the presidents of City, Brooklyn and Hunter Colleges yesterday to submit possible savings in their budgetary appropriations for the present fiscal year to be used if the city does not allocate additional funds to pay 257 staff members $116,747 in mandatory salary increments as ordered by the Court of Appeals.

BROOKLINE, Mass., Aug. 18 -- Lieutenant Gardnar Mulloy from the Jacksonville naval flying base returned to the tennis courts on furlough today and played through two rounds of the invitation Longwood Bowl tournament at the Longwood Cricket Club.

The dress union is ready to agree under certain conditions to a cut in the amount of contributions by manufacturers to the New York Dress Institute, organized to promote the New York dress market, it was stated yesterday by Julius Hochman, general manager of the Dressmakers Joint Board of the International Ladies Garment Workers Union, at a meeting with leaders of the industry at the Hotel Astor.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Aug. 18 -- Thirty-three men, including the captain and pilot, were drowned when the 5,492-ton Swedish ore steamer C.F. Liljevalch was torpedoed at 3 o'clock this afternoon in Swedish territorial waters off Vaestervik by a submarine of unknown nationality.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Aug. 18 -- The I.G. Farbenindustrie, leading German chemical concern, will transfer the major part of its production from Frankfort on the Main to Norway, it was announced in Oslo tonight. The intensive Royal Air Force bombing of Western Germany and the prospect of even heavier bombardments are thought to have prompted this decision.

Sigmund Romberg's famous musical comedy, "The New Moon," was revived last night at Carnegie Hall. Nearly fourteen years ago (Sept. 19, 1928, at the Imperial, to be historically exact) it was wildly acclaimed and such songs as "Stout-hearted Men" and "Lover Come Back to Me" became immediate hits.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Aug. 18 (AP) -- Colonel Bob Neyland, head coach of the Eastern All-Army football squad, broke into smiles today as his charges put on a brilliant aerial scrimmage in which his Blues finally out-scored his Reds, four touchdowns to three.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 (AP) -- The Federal Reserve Board released today $400,000,000 of bank reserves in New York and Chicago for loans and investments.

CAMDEN, N.J., Aug. 18 (AP) -- Called on to meet a filly who hadn't been defeated in her last three efforts, Mrs. R. Feinberg's Charge proved equal to the occasion in the sixth race at Garden State Park today as he plowed through the "heavy" going to register by two and one-half lengths in the outstanding offering on a rather dull card.

BERNE, Switzerland, Aug. 18 (AP) -- The explosion of a time-bomb outside the Basilica de Begona at Bilbao, Spain, on Sunday was interpreted here tonight as an action designed to discourage, if not thwart, a monarchist plan to place the Infante Juan, 28-year-old son of the late King Alfonso, on the throne of Spain.

SOMEWHERE IN NORTHERN RUSSIA, Aug. 18 -- Four of us -- Captain Pavloff, Captain George Sullivan, Lieutenant Morton Wolfson and your corresponent -- were seated at a table in a little restaurant in the Far North. A band was playing.
BOSTON, Aug. 18 -- The Yankees went to great lengths today to convince the Red Sox that all further pursuit of their fading pennant hopes was in vain.

AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, Australia, Wednesday, Aug. 19 (AP) -- Strong units of American Vice Admiral Robert L. Ghormley's combined fleet, which so successfully shielded the Marines' occupation of positions in the Solomon Islands, were reported last night to be deployed in anticipation of a showdown naval fight with the Japanese for the sea lanes northeast of Australia.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 -- Stirred by an airplane manufacturer's plaint that many women in his plant were too frivolous, the women's division of the Labor Department replied today that the vast majority of women workers were doing their bit seriously and efficiently.

Twenty out of thirty-eight departments in Near York department stores showed increases in advertising linage in July compared with the 1941 month, according to an analysis of figures reported by Media Records. Total department store linage for the month, at 1,855,577, was up 7.9 per cent from the corresponding level of a year ago.

A pound of cheese, it is said, has double the energy value of a pound of well-aged beef and costs, perhaps, half as much. That is not to say that a chunk of cheddar is always preferable to a slice of steak; it merely means that should meatless days become a harsh reality there is help at hand.

BOSTON, Aug. 18 (AP) -- The New England Telephone and Telegraph Company voted today a dividend of $1.25 a share on its capital stock, marking the second dividend reduction this year from the long-established $1.75 quarterly rate. In the previous quarter the company paid $1.50 a share.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 -- Several alternative plans for assuring equitable distribution of available stocks of fuel oil on the East Coast this Fall and Winter, have been presented to the War Production Board and a subcommittee will be named by Donald M. Nelson to act upon one of them.

Warfare between the New York Stock Exchange and the large non-member houses came into the open yesterday. Dillon, Read Co. applied to the Exchange for permission to make a secondary distribution of 50,000 shares of capital stock of the Standard Oil Company of Indiana at the closing price on the Exchange, using members to aid in the distribution.

New York landlords and tenants alike appeared to be in a quandary yesterday over their status under the proposed hot-water rationing and fuel conservation program that Mayor La Guardia has announced will be adopted for apartment buildings within a few days.

CAIRO, Egypt, Aug. 18 (AP) -- United States medium bombers have gone into action in North Africa along with heavy bombers, it was disclosed today as fresh contingents of American troops arrived in this war theatre to reinforce growing United States forces.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 (AP) -- Eighty-nine Class I railroads had estimated operating revenues of $531,785,940 in July, an increase of 35.5 per cent over the $392,338,623 received in the same month last year, the Association of American Railroads reported today.

Secretary Stimson has gone at the problem of chaotic official war information in the most really effective spirit. He has acted like a destructive critic. In this respect he has apparently followed the lead of President Roosevelt in setting up the OWI.

LONDON, Aug. 18 -- The miners leaders warned the men today that the coal situation was "most alarming." The Union's executive committee said it had been informed by Government officials that coal production was below the level required for domestic needs and the war effort.
The American Machinist said yesterday that shortage of materials, principally steel, had resulted in a considerable decline in machine tool production this month.

The validity of two indictments in which twenty-nine German-American Bund leaders were accused last month of conspiring to injure this country was attacked yesterday in Federal court. Demurrers against both true bills were filed by Leo C. Fennelly, counsel to Gustav Elmer, national bund treasurer.

The contest for the Democratic nomination for Governor took a new turn last night at the conference of party leaders called by James A. Farley, State Chairman, in the Hotel Biltmore, when Governor Lehman read a letter from President Roosevelt, urging the supporters of the rival candidates, Attorney General John J. Bennett Jr. and Senator James M. Mead to settle their differences for the good of the party.

NEWARK, N.J., Aug. 18 -- There were seven cigars -- long, thin Havanas -- in the innocent-appearing cigar box Herbert Karl Friedrich Bahr had in the black leather gladstone bag that comprised his luggage when he reached Jersey City on the diplomatic exchange ship Drottningholm on June 30.

Total subscriptions to the government's "tap issue" of 2 1/2 per cent bonds, due from 1962 to 1967, offered only to non-banking investors, were $1,234,946,000, of which the New York Federal Reserve District accounted for $751,668,000, it was announced here last night by the Victory Fund Committee of the Second Federal Reserve District, of which Allan Sproul, president of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, is chairman.

Despite the recent heavy rains, New York City's up-State reservoirs are only 70 per cent filled, it was reported yesterday by Patrick Quilty, Commissioner of Water Supply, Gas and Electricity. Mr. Quilty said the rains came after several drought years had lowered the reservoirs.

CHICAGO, Aug. 18 (AP) -- A Federal grand jury investigating the publication of alleged confidential naval information approached the end of its task today after it heard testimony from J. Loy Maloney, managing editor of The Chicago Tribune, and Stanley Johnston, a war correspondent for the newspaper.

"What ails Nebraska?" asks a correspondent puzzled or disturbed by the result of the primary held there a week ago. There, as in Idaho, an as yet rather unfamiliar aspirant for political honors turned up. In Idaho a radio entertainer, campaigning on horseback, got the Democratic nomination for Senator.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 -- The National War Labor Board rejected unanimously today a proposed general wage increase of 10 cents an hour for 21,000 employes of the Western Electric Company at Kearny, N.J., but approved rises of 3 to 5 cents an hour, retroactive to June 1, for workers receiving less than the standard rate in ten wage classifications.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 -- The statement by Thurman Arnold, Assistant Attorney General, yesterday on partial blind selling of motion-picture films in blocks of thirteen brought an immediate reaction today from the Allied States Association of Motion Picture Exhibitors.

LONDON, Aug. 18 (AP) -- Late today members of the Third American Eagle Squadron made a series of small-scale sweeps that "kept the enemy busy" over a 180-mile strip of the Channel invasion coast from Havre, up the coast to Dieppe and Abbeville, and over to Ostend, Belgium, the Air Ministry announced.

ANCHORAGE, Alaska, Aug. 18 (UP) -- Attacks by United States Army bombers and the difficult terrain have compelled Japanese invaders in the Aleutians to convert their Zero fighters into seaplanes by equipping them with pontoons, returning bomber crews disclosed here today.
LOUISVILLE, Ky., Aug. 18 -- A walk-out by C.I.O. members slowed production today at the eleven plants here of the Reynolds Metals Company, which supplies fabricated aluminum parts for bombers.

HILAIRE BELLOC is 72 years old, the author of more than ninety volumes of poetry, nonsense verse, essays, biography and history, a fluent writer with a sense of style born in him, a pugnacious and indefatigable pamphleteer. Mr. Belloc has a quite understandable distaste for the modern world and all its works -- in fact, for everything since Martin Luther and John Calvin destroyed the religious unity of Western civilization.

There have been several items recently about an Act of Parliament under which American service men who commit offenses against the law of England shall be tried exclusively by American courts-martial instead of by the British courts.

There is "absolutely no cause for any marked meat shortage," Joseph Cohn, counsel and executive director of the Meat Trade Institute, declared yesterday, asserting that the current problem in Eastern cities is not that of a livestock shortage but of the distribution of meats.

Thousands of the Army's finest soldiers, undergoing conditioning in California's scorching deserts, depend almost entirely for their touch with civilian life upon the Desert Battalion, a unique corps of USO girls, who pay their own expenses and endure the heat to entertain the boys over the weekends.

The Presbyterian Wartime Service Commission will seek to raise $1,000,000 this Fall to meet the church's wartime obligations, the Rev. Dr. Stuart Nye Hutchison, moderator of the General Assembly of the church and chairman of the commission, announced yesterday.

LONDON, Aug. 18 -- Maintaining their air offensive, Royal Air Force fighters today raked the Germans from Havre, France, to Ostend, Belgium, following the British bomber raid last night on Osnabrueck, the Ruhr industrial rail center, where 50,000 incendiaries and tons of heavy bombs fired the city and destroyed installations for a second time in eight days.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 18 -- A State-wide blackout darkened Shibe Park for twenty-five minutes tonight to interrupt the arc-light game between the Dodgers and Phils, but, if you ask Lippy Leo Durocher, the lights never should have been turned on again.

MOSCOW, Wednesday, Aug. 19 -- The German Army, despite an asserted loss of 1,250,000 men since May 15, has reinforced a pincer drive on Stalingrad, pressed closer to the city from the northwest and regained its briefly lost initiative southwest of the Volga steel city, the Russians reported officially today.

Cosmetic manufacturers have organized for a scrap drive at the request of the War Production Board, it was announced yesterday at a meeting in the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria. A Cosmetic Salvage Committee of the Industrial Salvage Committee for Greater New York has been formed under the chairmanship of Herman L. Brooks, president of Coty, Inc.

BAYONNE, N.J., Aug. 18 -- The return of operation of the plant of the General Cable Company, taken over last Friday by the government following a "wildcat" strike, to the owners was indicated tonight in a statement by Rear Admiral Charles G. Bowen, who took over the plant by Executive Order of the President, and in a resolution adopted at a mass meeting of the workers here.

MEMPHIS, Aug. 18 -- Frank C. Walker, Postmaster General, in an address to delegates of the convention of the Knights of Columbus, called tonight for more vigorous prosecution of the war, on both the military and the production fronts.

Fire Commissioner Patrick Walsh yesterday granted the owners of multiple dwellings thirty days of grace in which to equip their buildings with air raid protective equipment, but warned householders against buying equipment that had not been approved by the Fire Department, Under the new arrangement, Sept. 18 will be the date on which all multiple dwellings must be equipped and registered with the Fire Department.

Stewart McDonald, chairman of the board and president of the Maryland Casualty Company, announced yesterday that the board of directors had just approved a proposed expansion of the company's capital structure by the addition of $12,500,000 in capital and surplus funds.

The time is past when the mere fact that Winston Churchill flew to Moscow to see Joseph Stalin is as significant as what happened at the meeting. Otherwise the drama of the encounter would overshadow its importance as a council of war.

The city of Honolulu, Hawaii, announced yesterday that it would be in the market on Sept. 22 with a new issue of $500,000 of refunding bonds. The issue will be dated as of April 15, 1942, and will mature serially from April 15, 1943, to 1952.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 (U.P.) -- Leo T. Crowley, alien property custodian, said today that his office had seized the following properties of foreign nationals:

BOSTON, Aug. 18 (AP) -- A statement that a general draft of married men under 40 years of age with dependents would come "in the not far distant future" was made today by Ted Luther, public relations director for the Selective Service Board.

Registrations of out-of-town buyers in the market for the week ended yesterday totaled 665, which compared with 658 in the preceding week and 856 in the similar period a year ago, according to the listings in THE NEW YORK TIMES. Yesterday's arrivals totaled 281, against 263 for last Tuesday.

Bartholomew Bransfield, 42 years old, of 40 Harrison Avenue, Port Richmond, S.I., a lineman employed by the Staten Island Edison Corporation, was rendered unconscious from shock and suffered fractures of both legs and burns of the hands yesterday when he touched a wire carrying 1,750 volts while he was at work atop a thirty-five foot pole in the B. freight yard at St. George.

One of the largest single pieces of municipal financing in recent weeks was announced yesterday by the city of New Orleans. On Sept. 15 the city will open bids on a new issue of $12,000,000 of refunding bonds. The issue will be dated Sept. 1, and will mature serially from Sept. 1, 1943 to 1950.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 19 -- The ability of American, Canadian, British and Fighting French forces to land and then conduct extensive operations on a broad front in the Dieppe area of the German-held Channel coast of France was generally interpreted in military circles in Washington tonight as a demonstration of the feasibility of establishing a second front in Europe.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 19 -- The War Production Board today restricted some less essential military uses of aluminum to insure adequate supplies for actual combat items. By consolidating two previous orders the board made several important changes in aluminum control.

During the war emergency conventions of trade and professional groups have assumed a position of increased importance as a medium by which government officials may come in direct contact with large numbers of persons in specialized fields, it was asserted yesterday by speakers at the twenty-ninth annual meeting of the International Association of Convention Bureaus at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.

A sharp increase in the showing of American films in England, amounting to 30 or 40 per cent over pre-war days, as well as a widespread demand by the English public for "escapist" themes in motion pictures, was reported yesterday by Joseph Seidelman, vice president of Universal Pictures.

LONDON, Aug. 19 -- The first American troops to receive a baptism of fire in Europe in this war were the men of the United States Ranger Battalion who fought in the Dieppe raid today. It was the first time that the name Rangers had appeared in a war communique anywhere. The organization, which is made up of volunteers, was created last December, a few days after Pearl Harbor.
